headline: And Now, a Moment With Todd English’s Mother

Mr. English, the chef, and his teenage son, Simon, were about to perform with a children’s music trio called Laughing Pizza. The matriarch of their family, Patrizia Arcuni-English, had come to watch.

headline: Qualified Immunity, Unqualified Doubt
text: The Supreme Court’s ruling Tuesday on the use of the material witness statute in combating terrorists was a victory for former Attorney General John Ashcroft and those who would shield Bush administration officials from accountability for their actions after Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Mortgage Company Settles Maternity Leave Case
text: A mortgage company has agreed to settle a federal complaint that accused it of discriminating against women on maternity leave. The company will set aside $750,000 to compensate any women who may have been affected, while paying at least one woman $15,000.

headline: How to File a Mortgage Bias Complaint
text: Last year, I wrote about how mortgage lenders were making it difficult for new parents to qualify for loans while they were home taking care of their babies. After the housing crisis, lenders began taking a closer look at these prospective borrowers whose income had temporarily fallen, even if they planned to return to work within a few weeks.

headline: Hooked on Meat
text: KAS, TURKEY — I sit on this peaceful peninsula marveling at how long it’s been since Odysseus sailed the eastern Mediterranean. Then I realize that those millennia are nothing compared with how long our species might take to adapt to the inexorable spread of the American diet.

headline: NATO Resumes Airstrikes After Qaddafi Vows to Fight On
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — After a 72-hour bombing lull to allow President Jacob Zuma of South Africa to fly into Tripoli on an unsuccessful peace mission for the African Union, NATO resumed its airstrikes on the Libyan capital after dusk on Tuesday. There was no immediate word from NATO or the Libyan government on the targets of the strikes.

headline: New York Sues Over a Drilling Rules Plan
text: A top New York State official filed a lawsuit against the federal government on Tuesday to force an assessment of the environmental risks posed by drilling for natural gas in the Delaware River Basin, arguing that a regulatory commission should not issue final rules governing the drilling until a study is completed.

headline: Officers’ Accuser Says She Was Devastated by Verdict

headline: Sales Tactics on Implants Raise Doubts

headline: U.S. Reduces Estimates of Homeless in Haiti Quake

headline: Does Chela Have Any Chance Against Murray?
text: While this year’s final eight in the women’s draw at the French is filled with unfamiliar faces, there is just one man left on the men’s side who hasn’t previously made it to the final of a major. Few view Juan Ignacio Chela, a 31-year-old Argentine journeyman, as a threat to win the title. According to Betfair, Chela’s odds of winning the French are more than five times slimmer than that of any of the other remaining players. He faces Andy Murray on Wednesday with a chance to advance to the final four and, as if he didn’t already have enough incentive to beat the 24-year-old Scot, Murray gave him some extra motivation during a postmatch interview on the Tennis Channel after finishing off Viktor Troicki on Tuesday.

headline: In Unusual Move, Apple Previews New Software Plans
text: Apple said on Tuesday that it would announce new versions of the software that powers its computers and cellphones, as well as a new Internet service that could connect these devices.

headline: Egypt’s Military Censors Critics as It Faces More Scrutiny
text: CAIRO — Even the mildest criticism of the Egyptian military was too much for Mahmoud Saad, a television host on the newly founded, independent Tahrir television network.

headline: Waiting for a School Miracle
text: TEN years ago, Congress adopted the No Child Left Behind legislation, mandating that all students must be proficient in reading or mathematics by 2014 or their school would be punished.

headline: Inseparable Teammates, as Opposite as Can Be
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — A few months ago, A. J. Burnett added another member to his family. It was all unexpected. The new addition is 24 years old, stands 6 feet 4 inches and hails from the Dominican Republic, and Burnett is still searching for how best to characterize their relationship: Is Ivan Nova more like his third son or his little brother?

headline: Overrated? Rodriguez and Chamberlain Can Laugh About It
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — A common practice of sporting publications is undertaking surveys that rate players, hoping to provoke a response. The latest version appears in this week’s Sports Illustrated, which asked 185 major leaguers to vote in the category of Most Overrated Player.

headline: The Caucasus: New Allies for Breakaway Region
text: The Black Sea region of Abkhazia, which considers itself independent but is claimed by Georgia and viewed as Georgian territory by most of the international community, won recognition Tuesday from a second South Pacific island, the Republic of Vanuatu. Earlier, Abkhazia was recognized by Nauru, which is the world’s smallest country and like Vanuatu is situated in the Pacific Ocean east of Australia. Abkhazia is also recognized by Russia — which fought a war with Georgia over it and another breakaway region — as well as Nicaragua and Venezuela. Tiny South Pacific island states have been a particular prize for Abkhazia, as they have been for decades for new nations seeking to bulk up on the number of countries offering recognition. The government of Vanuatu, which is in an economic slump, said in a statement that recognition was intended to “foster the development of friendly relations” and explore joint economic projects.

headline: Tracking Financial Crisis Cases
text: Very few cases related to the financial crisis have been brought against executives at large companies, and the ones that have been involved are almost entirely civil fraud, rather than criminal allegations. Here are the prominent cases so far. In many of them, the government negotiated a settlement with the defendants before it even filed a complaint, then announced both the case and settlement at the same time.

headline: The Bin Laden Decade
text: Visiting the Middle East last week, and then coming back to Washington, I am left with one overriding impression: Bin Laden really did a number on all of us.

text: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon, trying to create a formal strategy to deter cyberattacks on the United States, plans to issue a new strategy soon declaring that a computer attack from a foreign nation can be considered an act of war that may result in a military response.

text: The deadly tornadoes and widespread flooding that have left a trail of death and destruction throughout the South and the Midwest have also disrupted dozens of local economies just as the unsteady recovery seemed to be finding a foothold.

headline: Surgery Not Option for Carter’s Tumors
text: Gary Carter was diagnosed on Tuesday as having glioblastoma, an aggressive, fast-moving brain cancer that will be treated with radiation and chemotherapy, but not with surgery, according to a statement from the Preston Robert Tisch Brain Cancer Center at Duke University Medical Center, where biopsies of the cancer were tested.

headline: A Political Revival for Ralph Reed
text: LADY LAKE, Fla. — Ralph Reed turns 50 this month, but as he roused a crowd of retirees here with talk of restoring Christian values and bringing down President Obama, he still looked like the boy wonder who appeared on the cover of Time magazine in 1995, named “The Right Hand of God” for building the Christian Coalition into an electoral juggernaut.

headline: Bahrain’s Latest Promises
text: After months of brutalizing protesters, Bahrain’s government now says that it will lift a state of emergency beginning on Wednesday and soon begin a “comprehensive serious dialogue — without preconditions” on reforms. That is certainly what is needed. The monarchy has made similar promises before and not delivered.

headline: East Side Law Firms Go West, as Far as Eighth Ave.
text: Even before the law firm Wilk Auslander began looking for a new headquarters last summer, veteran lawyers were sharing offices or relegated to tiny cubicles at its offices on Third Avenue.

headline: Transit Hub in Maryland Gets a Second Chance
text: NEW CARROLLTON, Md. — Many people in the mid-Atlantic region probably know this small suburban town as a train stop on the way to or from Union Station in Washington. But with Amtrak and Maryland commuter train stops, a Washington Metrorail station, buses and major highways nearby, New Carrollton seems to have everything a far-sighted developer could want.

headline: Who Needs Health Care Reform?
text: It is no secret that health care has become increasingly unaffordable as the cost of medical treatments and insurance premiums keep rising. Two recent studies have documented just how severe the burden can be and underscored the urgent need for the health care reforms that Republicans are so determined to repeal.

headline: The Long, Hot Forecast
text: Heat can be deadly. A one-week heat wave in Chicago in July 1995 killed 739, more than double the death toll from the Great Chicago Fire of 1871. Give credit, then, to the city’s leaders for making long-term preparations for a warmer, stormier climate.

headline: Rutgers President Will Step Down in 2012 but Stay on Campus to Teach
text: Richard L. McCormick, a self-described “faculty brat” at Rutgers University who learned to swim at a campus pool on College Avenue in New Brunswick, N.J., and grew up to become the university president, announced on Tuesday that he would step down from that post at the end of next year to return to teaching — at Rutgers, of course — and writing.

headline: Wednesday: Garden Party
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — OOO, it’s a Liz Gorski puzzle. Lucky us. Just the thing to get us through the middle of our week. Don’t stress about it if you have trouble with the puzzle. It’s fairly easy, and that sort of stress is what causes those fine lines we all hate. Oh well. You can always slap on some OIL OF OLAY.

text: Jesse Bering, left, of Scientific American and Jessa Gamble, author of "The Siesta and the Midnight Sun," discuss our love-hate relationship with sleep.

headline: A Vision of an Oasis Beneath the Sprawl
text: MEXICO CITY — At rush hour, two architects and a biologist stand on a footbridge over the highway that runs east and west through the center of this concrete cityscape. They are eager and young (the oldest, Elías Cattan, is 32) but could just as well be blind old prophets, because all they seem to see in the grime and traffic is a magnificent past and future.

headline: Appliance Retailer Turns the Spotlight on Its Staff

headline: Slow Pace of Justice Creates Problems in Italy
text: It has taken six years, but Italy’s justice system has finally caught up with Antonio Fazio. Mr. Fazio, the former Bank of Italy governor, has been sentenced to four years in jail for his role in helping to rig a 2005 takeover battle. The conviction suggests Italy’s courts can hold the powerful to account. But the drawn-out process allows many to slip through the net.

text: Albert M. Sack, a prominent New York antiques dealer and the author of a guidebook to early American furniture that became the bible for a generation of weekend antiquers and a standard for professional collectors, died on Sunday in Durham, N.C. He was 96.

headline: Can Bill Simmons Win the Big One?
text: For Bill Simmons, the walk on Laker game days from his office at ESPN to the Staples Center — or “the Silicon Center,” as he once referred to it in a column — is an excruciating 250 yards, a nauseating gantlet of purple and yellow jerseys, T-shirts and banners that choke L.A. Live, the cheesy outdoor plaza that Kobe built. The games themselves are a special kind of sports abomination to him — more Hollywood scene than sports event, where no one gets drunk and yells at the officials, where the crowd could easily be mistaken for the audience at a Coldplay concert (his metaphor) and the loudest cheers are for Jack Nicholson.

headline: Eating Fat, Staying Lean
text: With the memory of Memorial Day cheeseburgers and bratwursts still lingering, many of us may be relieved to hear that a new study suggests that a meaty, high-fat, Atkins-style diet can do more than contribute to rapid weight loss. It may also be less unhealthy for the heart than many scientists had feared — provided you chase the sausage with a brisk walk.

Have you already found your calling in life? What issues and problems stir your interests and passions?

headline: Chastised, Toyota Tries to Loosen Grip on Product Development for U.S.
text: On May 23rd, Toyota received the recommendations of its North American Quality Advisory Panel, headed by Rodney Slater the former Transportation secretary. The panel recommended that Toyota’s Japan-based corporate leadership should empower its teams in outside markets, which would “improve its communications and speed in responding to quality and safety issues,” a reference to the automaker’s well-documented problems with sudden acceleration and floor mats.

headline: Rich Legacy of Andy Robustelli

headline: Sorting Out Maryland Racing’s Future

headline: Dark Times for Dark Girls
text: We had barely finished giving well-deserved honor, respect and praise to the “little colored girl born in Kosciusko, Miss.,” when a video was posted on the Internet last week offering a preview of an upcoming documentary to be released later this year titled “Dark Girls.” Produced by Bill Duke, D. Channsin Berry and Bradinn French, “Dark Girls” takes a compelling look at the impact of colorism: a state of prejudice, conscious and unconscious, that causes both black people and white people to label as more beautiful or desirable or intelligent individuals with lighter shades of skin, particularly when it comes to black women. Few among people of color are unfamiliar with the saying: “If you are light, you are all right. If you are brown, you can stick around. If you are black, get back.” A writer in The Washington Post aptly described the phenomenon a few years ago as “the crazy aunt in the attic of racism.”

headline: Tools That Can Help When There Is Too Much on Your Plate
text: We all feel a bit disorganized and even overwhelmed at times. You know the feeling — crucial tasks are slipping between the cracks, you’re not sure what needs to be done next, you’re missing deadlines, other people aren’t coming through with their pieces of the project. If you’re feeling that way more than occasionally, you may need help from project-management and other task-organizing tools. Just as financial-management services like Mint or QuickBooks can help you keep your house in order when it comes to money, project- and task-oriented tools can help you plan, manage and coordinate activities.

One way to summarize his argument is to say that slow-motion bank runs are already in progress in the European periphery, and that these countries’ banking systems are being sustained only by a process in which, say, Ireland’s central bank borrows from the Bundesbank and then lends the funds on to Irish private banks to replace the fleeing deposits. headline: Papaya Suzuki Goes on a Diet
text: I have come to believe that serious musicians in Japan are kept in an archipelago of secret prisons for the talented. Japanese TV is afflicted with a permanent plague of Justin Bieberish boy bands, lip-syncing and busting hip-hop-like moves. There are reasons for this, including a powerful talent agency called Johnny’s, media concentration and the buying power of teenage girls. Whenever I’m visiting Japan and catch sight of a boy band on a giant outdoor screen (which can happen several times a day), I jab an EpiPen into my thigh loaded with a dose of Papaya Suzuki.

headline: Soccer Leader Wins Vote, Immune to Scandal

headline: Stocks Drop Sharply on Disappointing Reports

headline: Vain Glorious | Looking Nice in Nice Is a 24-Hour Job
text: There are three places one must never wear makeup: to the beach, to the gym and to bed. Reader, I did all of these things over the course of a day during Cannes. But at least let me explain. I was staying at the Hotel Martinez, which, for those unaware, becomes so brimming with celebrities (from Vanessa Hudgens to Sarah Jessica Parker) during the film festival that every paparazzo in the world, and possibly the entire population of the South of France, hold vigil outside, cameras pointed at the door until they realize you are not, in fact, Clemence Poesy (thanks, though!). So when sharing an elevator with Jude Law, whether coming from the seventh floor gym or la plage across the street, is a real possibility, being caught barefaced is a bit daunting. As for my sleeping in makeup, blame Olivier Zahm and his Purple party at Le Baron, an early flight and the lack of the will to painstakingly remove the waterproof makeup I agreed to test for The Moment. (Plus, my bottle of the famous only-available-in-France eye makeup remover, Bioderma, was too large to carry on.)

headline: Venice Biennale: An Installation Art Contest
text: VENICE — After the first day spent looking at most, but not all, of the national pavilions in the Giardini, this year’s Biennale has started to shape up as a knock-down, drag-out contest among immersive, environmental installation artworks. The battle is especially pitched on the little hillock dominated by the pavilions of Britain (Mike Nelson), Germany (Christoph Schlingensief) and France (Christian Boltanski), although the fray has also been joined by Switzerland (Thomas Hirshhorn) and the Czech Republic. At that pavilion, a little-known artist named Dominik Lang, barely 30 years old, has mounted a strangely affecting time-capsule-like installation featuring a great deal of generic postwar figurative sculpture by his father, Jiri Lang (1927-1996), who stopped making art years before his son was born. It serves as a sobering reminder of the obscurity that awaits most of the art produced at any given point in time, as well as the ability of art objects, being objects, to wait out different phases of neglect.

headline: In Her Skin | Raquel Allegra
text: Summer is all about showing skin. But for those who aren’t into baring it all, one option is dipping into early fall offerings. Pared-down basics by the Los Angeles-based designer Raquel Allegra have long been favored by stars such as Halle Berry, Hanneli Mustaparta and Agyness Deyn. Although Allegra is best known for her supersoft cotton shredding technique, for her latest collection, which hits stores in July, she began thinking about leather. “I asked myself, What do I want to wear as a second skin?” The results include a dappled goatskin bouclé cardigan that is as pleasing to the touch as it is to the eye — and that still leaves enough to the imagination. There are also slimming thigh-high leather leggings that mold to one’s body, supple camel leather shirts and buttery black body-con dresses that look effortless and sensual, not overripe or overtly sexy. The collection, available July 31, ranges from $250 to $1,100 and can be purchased at barneys.com or netaporter.com.

headline: Detroit Auto Makers Topped Importers in Sales in May

headline: Firm Hired to Monitor Conditions for Workers on Louvre and Guggenheim Branches in Abu Dhabi
text: The government-run developer of Saadiyat Island in Abu Dhabi announced that it had hired PricewaterhouseCoopers to monitor conditions for foreign laborers building the new branches of the Louvre and Guggenheim museums there. A 2009 report by Human Rights Watch raised alarms about working conditions on the island, in particular the practice of workers having to pay hefty fees to recruiters in their home countries, putting them in debt before they even start to work.

headline: Wartime Architects: Creating Amid Chaos
text: MONTREAL — The history of architecture during World War II is barely talked about. We all know Albert Speer, the man who slavishly carried out Hitler’s megalomaniacal architectural fantasies; some know about Mies van der Rohe’s exile in Chicago. The rest seems to have quietly — and in some cases conveniently — faded from view.

headline: Meet the Baby Peregrines

headline: Flashbacks to 2006

On the flip side, the Mavericks are clearly overmatched, unworthy of LeBron James’s talcum powder and already booking a room for the pity party. Yes, it is a time-worn tradition to freak out after Game 1 of any playoff series, with orthopedists lining up to treat all of the sprained knee-jerk muscles, but this time it’s so egregious, perhaps surgeons should be on standby.

headline: A Bicycle Shop Struggles to Get a Loan

Mr. Kuhn’s father, after working as a salesman for Schwinn, bought the business from the founder’s wife in the 1940s. In the 1950s, Kopp’s earned a reputation for being one of the few bike shops in the United States to stock racing gear by renowned European makers, like Cinelli and Campagnolo.

headline: Reality TV Carries NBC in Tuesday Ratings
text: The return of “America’s Got Talent” catapulted NBC to No. 1 in the ratings on Tuesday as 15 million viewers watched the two-hour sixth-season premiere, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Up by more than 2.6 million over last year’s premiere (12.4 million), “America’s Got Talent” also lifted NBC’s ratings at 10 p.m., during which the network’s new reality competition “The Voice” attracted its largest audience to date, 14.4 million viewers. ABC finished second for the night, though reliable audience figures for its coverage of the N.B.A. finals were not immediately available. Preliminary overnight estimates were the highest for a Game 1 broadcast since 2004, slightly outperforming last year’s first game, which drew 14.1 million viewers. CBS was third with reruns of “NCIS” (11.1 million), “NCIS: Los Angeles” (9.9 million) and “The Good Wife” (6.2 million). Fox was fourth with a new episode of “Traffic Light” at 9:30 (2.2 million) after repeats of “Glee” and “Raising Hope.”

headline: Glenn Beck Starts New Publishing Venture

Its first title, “Michael Vey,” is a young-adult novel by Richard Paul Evans, a best-selling author, scheduled for release in August. The imprint will publish books, acquired by Kevin Balfe, the senior vice president of publishing for the imprint, in a wide range of genres, the companies said in a joint statement on Wednesday.

headline: Eurofile | The Paris Plage
text: At a recent Saint-Germain-des-Pres dinner party, the conversation turned to perfect destinations for a seaside weekend near Paris. A Los Angeles-based architect wondered aloud about Deauville, provoking a quorum of shaking heads, so our hostess set him straight. “Deauville, c’est trop bling-bling,” she told him. “Bling-bling?” “Flashy,” a fashion P.R. executive volunteered. Then someone suggested Cadaques, on Spain’s Costa Brava, which drew approving murmurs but was ultimately nixed because getting there requires a plane ride and a rental car. Belle Ile in Brittany got a heads up, too, but not for a weekend, since it’s too far away. Honfleur met with general approval, too, but it also requires a rental car. We all agreed that the perfect place would be only a train ride away.

And so, for many at a party for Hamptons magazine last Sunday at the new Southampton Social Club, it was a traditionally beautiful evening with a storied history.

headline: Hawk Cam | Pip’s Still There, Even if Out of Sight
text: The good news — great news, in fact — is that Pip the red-tailed hawk, who turned three weeks old last Friday, is getting more and more adventurous as he or she gears up to learn to fly (expect takeoff in mid-to-late-June). The bad news is that our Hawk Cam is seeing less and less of Pip — which means you are, too.

headline: TimesCast | June 1, 2011
text: Germany has a deadly E. coli outbreak; Representative Anthony Weiner now says he’s uncertain if that Twitter photo is of him; and how Lady Gaga’s new album sold more than a million copies in a week.

headline: The Morning Line: Preparing for the Belmont
text: Wednesday is very slow on the Triple Crown front. The main story involves the Kentucky Derby winner Animal Kingdom. Jay Privman in the Daily Racing Form reported that the trainer Graham Motion is sending his horse from his training center in Maryland to Belmont Park over the weekend. Barry Irwin, the president of the Team Valor International partnership that owns Animal Kingdom, said that Animal Kingdom “is slated to work a half-mile there on Monday.”

headline: Marc Jacobs Over the Years
text: Marc Jacobs has marched to his own baton, pivoting, when the mood took him, on a polished heel.

headline: The Survivor
text: CALL him a genius. Call him a junkie, an original, a shameless copycat, a winsome recluse, a brazen exhibitionist. Marc Jacobs has heard it all. And he has absorbed it all with a hard-won equanimity.

headline: Brian Butler’s Magick Act
text: For the Los Angeles artist Brian Butler, magic (or “magick,” as the case may be) is as modern as technology. Certain teachings may be ancient, he notes, but that doesn’t make them any less relevant. “In the modern world of computers, the same energies are still operating,” he says.

headline: Serra Sculpture Installed at Park in Qatar
text: The artist Richard Serra, whose massive steel sculptures have been exhibited at the Museum of Modern Art and elsewhere around the world, has installed his first public artwork in the Middle East, in a sculpture park under construction in Doha, Qatar, adjacent to the Museum of Islamic Art, designed by I.M. Pei.

headline: Dispute Grows as Egyptian Gas Is Still Not Flowing to Israel
text: JERUSALEM — More than a month after saboteurs blew up an Egyptian pipeline supplying natural gas to Israel, the line is repaired but gas is not flowing and foreign shareholders of the company suspect politics to be the reason. They are threatening legal action against Egypt.

headline: A Camera, a Card, a Connection
text: According to my Twitter followers, certain laws govern the consumer electronics industry. There’s @Slbrink’s Law: “The cheaper the printer, the more expensive the ink cartridge.” And @MichaeLVosburg’s law: “Any gadget’s ease of use is inversely proportional to the number of engineers who worked on it.” And @Invisible_Daddy’s law: “Any cool feature you try to show your spouse won’t work, discrediting your enthusiasm for your new purchase.”

headline: Phones Put a Bargaining Chip in the Car Buyer’s Hand
text: Car shoppers who thought that the Web would save them from wasting money were kidding themselves. As too many people have found, you can bring along boxes of printouts from car-advice sites, and slick or unscrupulous sellers will argue that the information is outdated or irrelevant.

headline: Analysis: Nadal Shows Why He Is the King of Clay
text: The reports of Rafael Nadal’s demise are exaggerated, as he showed in Wednesday’s straight-sets dismissal of Robin Soderling. With his level of play clearly rising, Nadal has swept into the semifinals at Roland Garros despite the negative buzz emanating from the press room and the locker room. Granted, Nadal has looked more vulnerable this spring than in any previous clay campaign, and, as the No. 1 player in the world, he knows that his every shot, and every utterance in news conferences, will be scrutinized, compared, assessed and commented upon.

headline: Israel to Participate in 2013 World Baseball Classic
text: Too bad Sandy Koufax is not pitching anymore.

headline: Russellandia!
text: For the Lives page this past Sunday, the novelist Karen Russell wrote about visiting the Cu Chi Tunnels in Vietnam. Here is a little roundup of further reading by and about her:

headline: Shareholders Approve Massey Sale to Alpha
text: Shareholders of Massey Energy voted on Wednesday to approve the coal miner’s $7.1 billion sale to Alpha Natural Resources, despite the protests of several shareholders that sued to temporarily halt the deal.

headline: Google Says Hackers in China Stole Gmail Passwords
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Google said Wednesday that hundreds of users of Gmail, its e-mail service, had been the targets of clandestine attacks apparently originating in China that were aimed at stealing their passwords and monitoring their e-mail.

headline: With These Rings
text: One was a former child star who grew up to be one of the most beautiful actresses in Hollywood. Another was a former child star who grew up to be one of the most beautiful actresses in Hollywood. The third is the spouse of the two-term governor of Indiana, who, until a few weeks ago, was considered by many as a leading candidate for the Republican Party’s presidential nomination. But what does Cheri Daniels have in common with Elizabeth Taylor and Natalie Wood? Like them, she divorced one husband to marry another, only later to remarry the first husband. That marital roundelay, though almost never discussed by the couple, was largely considered one reason Governor Daniels decided against a White House run. As he explained last month: “I find myself caught between two duties. I love my country. I love my family more.”

headline: Hochul Is Sworn In as House Member
text: Kathy Hochul, the Democrat who won a special election in upstate New York last week, was sworn in as the newest member of the House on Wednesday, giving her party a lift and reducing Republican dominance in the House by one.

headline: A Love-Struck Romeo Finds Inspiration at Last
text: Unlike its writer’s-blocked hero “Shakespeare’s Slave” suffers from a few too many ideas.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Sells Its Video Conferencing Business
text: Leo Apotheker, Hewlett-Packard’s chief executive, took a small step on Wednesday to refocus his slumping company by selling its video conferencing business.

headline: In Wake of Natural Disasters, Insurers Brace for Big Losses
text: The devastation from the natural disasters that have ripped through parts of the country this year has been starkly evident. Hundreds of people have died and thousands of houses have been shattered in a deadly string of tornadoes. Millions of acres of farms were inundated and businesses shut down by flooding along the Mississippi River.

headline: Battle For Libya | June 1, 2011
text: A bomb exploded Wednesday night in a parking lot outside a Benghazi hotel that has been a central meeting place for Libyan rebel leaders, diplomats and journalists. No deaths or injuries were reported.

headline: “What’s Going On” at 40
text: “What’s Going On,” Marvin Gaye’s groundbreaking 1971 album whose socially sensitive subject matter Motown boss Berry Gordy Jr. initially believed would ruin Gaye’s career, is 40 years old this year. And as we all know now, the album, contrary to Gordy’s fears, became a critical and commercial success. More important, its message has remained timely and relevant over virtually its entire four decades of existence.

headline: In Lady Gaga’s Album, Evidence of a New Order
text: A paradox of the new music industry: Albums sell less and less well every year, but as a marketing tool they are now more important than ever.

headline: Plan for China’s Water Crisis Spurs Concern
text: DANJIANGKOU, China — North China is dying.

headline: Slaking North China’s Thirst
text: The Chinese government’s solution to a chronic drought in the north is to divert water from the Yangtze River.

headline: Gold Mine Treasure: A New Worm
text: Single-cell organisms have been known to live deep in the earth, more than 9,000 feet below the surface.

headline: Graphic Content | Heavy Metal
text: Steven Heller, a former art director at The New York Times, is a co-chair of the MFA Design Department at the School of Visual Arts, a blogger, author, and a recent recipient of the National Design Award.

headline: Groupon and Expedia to Offer Travel Deals
text: The market for Web sites that offer flash sales and discounts for travel packages and hotel rooms has a new competitor. Today, Groupon and Expedia announced a new venture, Groupon Getaways, which will offer discounts for hotel rooms starting in late June.

headline: TimesCast | Sold This Way
text: A new online sales strategy helps make Lady Gaga's new album, "Born This Way," the fastest-selling album in six years.

headline: Taliban Aim to Derail Afghan Security Transfer
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Insurgents have stepped up attacks in parts of Afghanistan scheduled to be handed over to Afghan military control next month and have put a new emphasis on a campaign of assassinations aimed at important officials around the country, Afghan officials say.

headline: Brain Injuries Are Seen in New Scans of Veterans
text: A new study may help explain why some military personnel exposed to blasts have symptoms of brain injury even though their CT and M.R.I. scans look normal.

headline: Children Are Among Casualties of Syrian Military Raids After Demonstrations
text: CAIRO — Syrian military forces killed 42 people Wednesday, including a 10-year-old boy and 4-year-old girl, in raids on a string of towns around the central city of Homs as the government continued trying to crush a three-month-old popular uprising against President Bashar al-Assad, human rights activists said.

headline: ‘State of Wonder’
text: Chapter 1

headline: Will Perilous Trek to Amazon Reveal Heart of Darkness?
text: Dr. Marina Singh, the 42-year-old research scientist who is the heroine of “State of Wonder,” Ann Patchett’s most far-flung yet somehow least exotic book, is in her office at a large pharmaceutical company in Minnesota when the bad news arrives. Marina does unremarkable research on cholesterol. She is having an unremarkable affair with Mr. Fox, the company’s C.E.O. The bland, far-from-fantastic Mr. Fox arrives to tell her that her research partner, Dr. Anders Eckman, has died of a fever in a remote part of Brazil.

headline: Right Tools Unleash Creativity on an iPad
text: The iPad is great for activities like watching movies, surfing the Web, playing video games or reading digital magazines and newspapers. The rap against the iPad is that it is not as useful as a computer for creating.

headline: China Extends Hand and Fist to Protesters
text: HOHHOT, China — As riot police officers pounced on ethnic Mongolian protesters on Monday, hauling at least a dozen into waiting vehicles, a young college student took refuge at a nearby cafe, shivering with fear. He checked a metal teapot for imaginary listening devices and glanced repeatedly at the door while explaining how soldiers had prevented thousands of his fellow students at Hohhot Nationality University from joining the rally.

headline: Subtleties No Recording Could Catch
text: In the new-music world as elsewhere, scene makers and community builders come in a variety of shapes, sizes and inclinations. Important examples converged on Tuesday night when the Stone, the East Village performance space operated by the composer John Zorn, hosted the final evening of a two-week series produced by Innova, a hardy independent record label established in 1982 by the American Composers Forum in St. Paul. The program included two distinctive quartets that record for Innova: Zeitgeist, a mixed group from the Twin Cities, and the Prism Quartet, a saxophone ensemble based in New York and Philadelphia.

headline: China Sends Polluted Water North
text: After billions of dollars spent on the project, water sent north along the eastern line is polluted by industrial runoff and municipal waste.

headline: Oprah’s Network Goes to the Movies
text: Fifteen years ago Oprah Winfrey introduced a book club to her talk-show viewers and thus began providing the publishing industry with its own version of an entitlement program. As a subsidizer of literacy, she brought Tolstoy and Faulkner to those not necessarily in possession of the Penguin Classics while primarily shepherding forgettable middlebrow women’s fiction onto the shelves of those who might otherwise have been satisfied with People magazine. Three of her 10 selections in 1997 were children’s books by Bill Cosby, which should in itself sustain the question of her value as a national educator.

headline: First a Toast to the Past, Then the Frolics of a Bubbly Balanchine
text: Although you don’t need to know the ballets from one century to appreciate those from another, the connections are in some cases so profound that recognizing them deepens the whole experience. It was exciting on Tuesday night, amid American Ballet Theater’s week of performances of “Giselle” ( 1841) across the Lincoln Center plaza at the Metropolitan Opera House, to watch New York City Ballet dance George Balanchine’s “Donizetti Variations” (1960) at the David H. Koch Theater. Although “Donizetti” has no scenery and no narrative, it looks at first like an outtake from the older ballet’s celebration of the festival of the vine, with the jollification of decorous peasants.

headline: Just a Couple of Sports, Merrily Singing Along
text: If it is not their British accents, what accounts for the way British jazz and pop singers filter songs through a screen of hauteur? That slightly blasé affect tinged Claire Martin and Richard Rodney Bennett’s opening-night performance of their breezy Irving Berlin show, “A Couple of Swells,” at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel on Tuesday.

headline: TimesCast | Twitter Trouble
text: June 1, 2011 - Representative Anthony D. Weiner finds that his sharp voice on Twitter can cut two ways.

headline: Big Stars at 18, and Loving the Ride
text: LOS ANGELES — Sitting in a faux-leather booth at a waffle house here the other morning were two 18-year-olds. One was buttering her sourdough toast and giggling. The other was hacking into corned beef hash browns. A bored-looking waitress snapped her gum in the distance.

headline: Works That Make Technology an Ally
text: Le Poisson Rouge became a de facto laboratory for a scientist of sound on Tuesday evening when the International Contemporary Ensemble presented works by Nathan Davis  as part of its ICElab residency at that Greenwich Village space.

headline: Remembering a Champion Who Had Great Table Presence
text: One of the world’s greatest female bridge players, Edith Kemp Freilich, died on May 14 in Miami.

headline: Google Calendars on the iPad
text: How to sync an iPad 2 with online Google calendars, and a way to make Windows 7 reopen folders automatically when restarting a computer.

headline: On Location | Dream House in Mexico
text: The geometrically shaped three-story house on Isla Mujeres is made from pumice and tile and inspired by the modern, clean lines of a nearby boutique hotel.

headline: ‘Architecture in Uniform’
text: A new exhibition at the Canadian Center for Architecture in Montreal considers architects’ role in World War II.

headline: A Sliver of a Courtyard House in Paris
text: A designer’s 18th-century rental is only six-and-a-half-feet deep front to back.

headline: A Toehold in Paris
text: AS a designer, Kein Cross is pretty good at estimating space, and when he saw the 18th-century courtyard house in Paris in an ad, he knew it was small — maybe 9 or 10 feet deep.

headline: Case Stemming From Antiterrorism Registry Is Dropped
text: Immigration authorities announced on  Wednesday that they will drop their case against Mohammed G. Azam, a young Bangladeshi man who had been fighting deportation since 2003, when he registered with a special post-9/11 program for Muslims.

headline: A Gleaming Sculpture Facing the Caribbean
text: ISLA MUJERES, Mexico — For Richard and Karen Lock, all it took was a single trip to this small mellow island in the Caribbean Sea to know that they would someday build a home on its shores.

headline: Shopping for Patio Umbrellas With Christopher Myers
text: A designer of urban outdoor environments went shopping for both affordable and out-of-the-park patio umbrellas.

headline: Pull Up a Cupcake, and Then Eat One
text: The design of the newest Sprinkles Cupcakes shop, which opened recently on the Upper East Side, is an ode to the product. The cupcakes sold there, some of which are decorated with two-tone dots, inspired the large architectural dots that cascade down the facade (above). Inside, faux-leather hassocks are shaped like giant chocolate cupcakes frosted with colored dots. And the bands of color that run across the ceiling and down the wall are the company’s signature colors, used in its packaging.

headline: Reviving a Classic Swedish Textile Design
text: Fans of Swedish design may be familiar with Picknick, a pattern created by Marianne Westman in the 1950s for Rorstrand. A British company called New House Textiles, which has manufactured Swedish products for more than 30 years, has acquired the rights to Ms. Westman’s pattern and is putting it on products like cutting boards, tea towels, trays and coasters (pictured).

headline: Patio Umbrellas
text: WITH increasingly intense sun beating down on patios, decks and terraces, many people will soon be scrambling for shade on blistering summer days. “Shade is an essential element of any garden,” said Christopher Myers, the founder of Just Terraces, a New York design firm specializing in urban outdoor environments.

headline: Wallpaper With a Life of Its Own
text: Payton Cosell Turner still thinks about a wallpaper that hung in the home in Connecticut where her grandfather, the legendary sportscaster Howard Cosell, lived. “It was a fantastic frenetic laboratory print with beakers and test tubes flying everywhere,” she said.

headline: Using Gadgets to Zap Germs
text: TOILET SEATS get a bad rap, says Charles Gerba, an environmental microbiologist at the University of Arizona. Indeed, because of what goes on there, we tend to consider bathrooms — even the most respectable bathrooms — as generally less than sterile. That view, it turns out, is unfair.

headline: A Fire Lookout on Solitude (and Lots of Time to Read)
text: In addition to an incredible view and a few months of monklike solitude, one of the perks of Philip Connors’s job as a fire lookout in the New Mexico wilderness is a summer house.

headline: A Los Angeles Bungalow That Doubles as a Sustainability Lab
text: Kelly Coyne and Erik Knutzen keep bees, grow vegetables and make their own cleaning products at their 1,000-square-foot house in Silver Lake.

headline: Sales at John Derian, Broadway Panhandler and Others
text: Decoupage and other merchandise will be 30 to 80 percent off at the John Derian sample sale, through Sunday (decoupage crystal dome paperweights, originally $60, will be $25); 10 East Second Street (Bowery); (212) 677-3917.

headline: A Larger Home for Bright Chair
text: After nearly two decades in the New York Design Center, Bright Chair is moving to a larger showroom. “We’ve tried to create an environment that shows how our products can be used in a residence,” said Stan Gottlieb, the company’s president.

headline: Living Large, Off the Land
text: Los Angeles

headline: 1937 in 2011?
text: Gauti Eggertsson has a nice piece on the New York Fed blog about the great monetary/fiscal mistake of 1937, which sent the Great Depression into a second downward leg. As he notes, the underlying situation bore a significant resemblance to current events: unemployment still high (actually under 10 percent if measured by modern standards, so quite similar to now), but with rising prices thanks to commodity shocks.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,588 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Apple Issues Fix to Combat Malware
text: Apple issued a security update on Tuesday to address persistent attacks that are taking aim at Mac users with a fake antivirus program.

headline: For an Underground Arts Show, No Subway Service. Again.
text: In its brief, half-decade history, the Bushwick Open Studios festival has earned a reputation as an eclectic, unpredictable entrée into the underground Brooklyn arts scene, replete with cabarets, outré costumes, and free exhibitions from hundreds of local artists.

headline: Yankees Ride Sparkling Starters to a Sweep
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — It was the starters on the Oakland Athletics who were supposed to dominate this three-game series, a fledgling and talented bunch, none older than 25, all ranking among the American League’s top 11 in earned run average. The Yankees countered with three pitchers, all 34 or older, none ranking in the A.L.’s top 30 in E.R.A.

headline: Remedies for Cellphone-Cancer Concerns
text: Now that the World Health Organization’s International Agency for Research on Cancer has declared cellphones “possibly carcinogenic,” that is, apt to cause brain cancer, it’s worth reviewing ways to limit your exposure without resorting to a lead fedora.

headline: One Day, One Movie, 80,000 Filmmakers
text: LOS ANGELES — Where were you on Saturday, July 24, 2010? A large part of the movie world was in San Diego, attending (or plotting to escape) the third day of the giant Comic-Con International fan convention.

headline: Hidden App Lets You Find and Observe Burglars
text: Private eyes (clap), they’re watching you (clapclap)…

headline: Report Finds Inequities in Payments for Medicare
text: WASHINGTON — Medicare uses inaccurate, unreliable data to pay doctors and hospitals, the National Academy of Sciences said Wednesday.

headline: The Thriving (Online) Shelter Magazine Industry
text: SINCE Domino, the beloved shelter magazine, folded in early 2009, its staff members have gone on to lucrative consulting jobs, top editing posts, even television gigs, but none have advanced as swiftly as Michelle Adams. At Domino, Ms. Adams was a 24-year-old assistant answering phones and running around Manhattan in search of blankets in exactly the right shade of purple. Two years later, she’s the editor in chief of Lonny, a shelter magazine she co-founded. Already it has a cultlike following and has given rise to a mini-boomlet in online design publications.

headline: Americans Are Joining Flotilla to Protest Israeli Blockade
text: When an international flotilla sails for Gaza this month to challenge Israel’s naval blockade of the Palestinian territory, among the boats will be an American ship with 34 passengers, including the writer Alice Walker and an 86-year-old whose parents died in the Holocaust.

headline: The Next Wave of Shelter Magazines
text: The online start-ups Lonny, High Gloss, Rue and Matchbook are trying to fill the void left by their vanished print predecessors.

headline: Shanahan Replacing Campbell as N.H.L.’s Chief Disciplinarian
text: Colin Campbell will step down before next season after 13 years as the N.H.L.’s chief disciplinarian, Commissioner Gary Bettman said Wednesday.

headline: As Hurricane Season Begins, Heavy Storms Are Expected
text: The year began with birds falling out of the sky in Arkansas, followed by severe drought in some places and record-setting rainfall in others. This spring, a series of exceptionally destructive tornado swarms has wreaked deadly havoc across the South and Midwest, while a historic flood shoved its way down the Mississippi River.

headline: Walt Baranger on ham radio; making better videos; the tech term "vaulting;" news.
text: Ham radio in the Internet age? It's alive and well, says Walt Baranger of the News Technology department at the Times. He chats with Bettina Edelstein and J.D. Biersdorfer about what's going on in the world of amateur radio. J.D. also speaks with Steve Stockman, author of “How to Shoot Video That Doesn’t Suck,” about making better and more interesting home videos. And after his home network goes down, Pedro Rafael Rosado looks at the tech term "vaulting." The news roundup includes cellphones being seen as possibly carcinogenic; data breaches at Lockheed Martin and PBS; a forthcoming netbook/tablet hybrid with Intel processor called the Ultrabook; talk of a Facebook cloud music service; Apple getting set to talk about its next Mac OS X and iOS updates. J.D.'s tech tip: how to cut through desktop clutter on Windows 7 and Mac OS X.

headline: Second Appellate Panel Hears Arguments on Health Care Law
text: CINCINNATI — A panel of federal appellate judges seemed eager on Wednesday to rule on whether it is constitutional for the Obama health care law to require that uninsured Americans buy medical coverage. But the judges must first decide whether the plaintiffs still have legal standing to sue, after one disclosed that she recently bought health insurance from her employer.

headline: Running the Numbers on the Debt Ceiling Vote
text: Yesterday, the House of Representatives rejected an unconditional increase in the federal debt limit by a vote of 318 to 97, with all Republicans in opposition and Democrats splitting in favor 97-82.

headline: S.E.C. Enforcement Lawyer Joins Simpson Thacher
text: Cheryl Scarboro, the head of the Securities and Exchange Commission‘s foreign bribery unit, is leaving the agency to join the law firm Simpson Thacher & Bartlett.

headline: Advocates and Bankers Join to Fight Loan Rules
text: WASHINGTON — The weight of the mortgage crisis fell heavily on lower-income and minority communities, where first-time home buyers often fell victim to the predatory lending practices that resulted in an explosion of defaults and foreclosures.

headline: Shuttles, Turning Sedentary, Leave Pieces Behind for Science and Safety
text: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla. — NASA, it seems, is having trouble letting go.

headline: Bahrain Ends Martial Law but Renews Crackdown on Protests
text: Hours after Bahrain officially ended 11 weeks of martial law on Wednesday, security forces attacked peaceful protesters in more than 20 villages with rubber bullets, stun grenades, shotguns and tear gas, according to human rights observers in Bahrain.

headline: Crackdown on Dissent Continues in Bahrain, on the Streets and Online
text: After emergency rule was officially lifted in Bahrain on Wednesday, protesters who took to the streets in some places were dispersed with birdshot and teargas fired by the security forces, a rights activist told Agence France-Presse.

headline: Lexington Ave. and 77th St., 4:05 p.m.
text: A photograph of the No. 6 subway train station at 77th Street.

headline: Rosalyn S. Yalow, Nobel Medical Physicist, Dies at 89
text: Rosalyn S. Yalow, a medical physicist who persisted in entering a field largely reserved for men to become only the second woman to earn a Nobel Prize in Medicine, died on Monday in the Bronx, where she had lived most of her life. She was 89.

headline: Playing With Matches on the Debt
text: Just ignore Tuesday’s vote against raising the debt ceiling, House Republican leaders whispered to Wall Street. We didn’t really vote against it, members suggested; we just sent another of our endless symbolic messages, pretending to take the nation’s credit to the brink of collapse in order to extract the maximum concessions from President Obama.

headline: Many Civilians Have Been Killed in Disputed Region of Sudan
text: JUBA, Sudan — Officials from the disputed Abyei area of Sudan said Wednesday that 116 civilians, including many children, had been killed last month when the northern Sudanese army seized Abyei.

headline: A New York Staple, Korean Grocers Are Dwindling
text: Joo Han, the son of Korean immigrants, runs a Manhattan produce store that looks much as it did when his parents opened it a generation ago, working endless hours to forge a new life, banana by banana, milk carton by milk carton.

headline: Former Police Chief Is Sentenced for Cover-Up in Mexican’s Death
text: A former Pennsylvania police chief who was convicted of impeding a federal investigation into the beating death of a Mexican immigrant was sentenced to 13 months in prison on Wednesday, a lower-than-expected term in a case that had become a cause célèbre for Hispanics.

headline: Judging a Cancer Drug: Avastin’s Story
text: To the Editor:

headline: Remembering Humphrey
text: To the Editor:

headline: Defense Procurement
text: To the Editor:

headline: Creating New Jobs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Protests in Kurdistan
text: To the Editor:

headline: As Arizona Fire Rages, So Does Rumor on Its Origin
text: PORTAL, Ariz. — It is a dramatic tale: that illegal immigrants being pursued by the Border Patrol started one of the nation’s largest wildfires, which has burned up more than 70,000 acres of national forest along Arizona’s border with Mexico since it began almost four weeks ago. But the authorities say that despite the tale’s being repeated often by some residents of the rugged countryside here, they do not know for sure if it is true.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: The Energy Future
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Ham Radio and Videocams
text: Ham radio in the Internet age? It’s alive and well, says Walt Baranger of the News Technology department at the Times. On this week’s Bits: Tech Talk show, Mr. Baranger chats with Bettina Edelstein and J.D. Biersdorfer about what’s going on in the world of amateur radio.

headline: Governor Nominates Developer to Lead Thruway Authority
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has nominated a wealthy real estate developer to be chairman of the New York State Thruway Authority, which oversees the Thruway and the state’s 524-mile canal system.

headline: Christie Fields Criticism for State Helicopter Trip
text: Woe to the politician who claims to be fiscally responsible, in touch with regular folk, and turns out to have some pricey habits. Think Newt Gingrich and Tiffany, John Edwards and haircuts, Sarah Palin and clothes — and now, Chris Christie and helicopters.

headline: Buster Posey’s Injury Sharpens Debate on Collisions
text: ST. LOUIS

headline: I.P.O. Talk, Demos at Tech Confab
text: RANCHO PALOS VERDES, Calif. — The technology elite gathered for the annual AllThingsD conference here to discuss everything from the mood in Silicon Valley, to the latest technology gadgets and services. Here are a few highlights.

headline: Fertility Loves Company: Why Mauve Stingers Don’t Go Solo
text: By blooming in large numbers, mauve stingers were only doing what comes naturally: sticking together in order to reproduce more effectively.

headline: Dallas Hopes Nowitzki Can Play Through Pain
text: MIAMI — Dirk Nowitzki lofted shots that the rim swallowed whole during practice Wednesday. Nowitzki, one of the N.B.A.’s best shooters, will probably remain so Thursday in Game 2 of the finals against the Miami Heat — even with a torn tendon in the middle finger of his nonshooting left hand.

headline: Small but Innumerable, Jellyfish Storm a Beach
text: COCOA BEACH, Fla. — They swarmed the beach, taking control of prime holiday sand and surf like a group of marauding spring breakers. Then, just like that, they vanished, leaving behind the damage: spoiled vacations, red welts, heaps of annoyance, discarded containers of vinegar and Benadryl and a crew of exhausted lifeguards.

headline: Germans’ Deep Suspicions of Nuclear Power Reach a Political Tipping Point
text: BERLIN — Shortly after the earthquake and tsunami struck the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant in Japan in March, stores in faraway Germany began selling out of radiation-tracking Geiger counters. Sales of iodine pills to limit the absorption of radiation surged briskly, too, propelled by anxiety that people might find themselves engulfed in clouds of long-range radioactive fallout.

headline: NYT: Front Page for 06/02/2011
text: NYT: Front Page for 06/02/2011

headline: Tossing No. 1 Ranking in Bag, Donald Sets Out After Another Top-10 Finish
text: DUBLIN, Ohio — Among the things Jack Nicklaus values in golf, consistency ranks right up there with greens in regulation. So does normalcy, which the Memorial Tournament returned to this week with the presence of the world’s No. 1-ranked player.

headline: A Voice From the Past
text: Now that the Supreme Court has given California the choice of shrinking its prison population drastically or making sufficient room for the prisoners it has, attention has naturally turned to how the financially strapped state will respond. But that focus shouldn’t obscure the remarkable nature of what the court did last week when it upheld a lower court’s order requiring California to reduce its prison population to no more than 137.5 percent of capacity within two years to cure overcrowding so severe that it amounts to cruel and unusual punishment.

headline: At Least 4 Are Killed in Massachusetts Tornadoes
text: BOSTON — At least four people were killed when tornadoes touched down Wednesday in Springfield, Mass., and a number of nearby towns. The twisters flipped vehicles, collapsed buildings and stunned residents who are not used to such violent storms.

headline: Taking In the Start of Hamptons Season
text: The sky had parted, Memorial Day weekend had arrived and Nocturnalist was ready for the Hamptons. On Sunday night we chose our most Hamptonish outfit and borrowed a very Hamptonish convertible. Each year, the long weekend marks the moment when much of Manhattan’s night life heads east, and we were primed to tail it the length of the Long Island Expressway.

headline: Retroactive Reductions Sought in Crack Penalties
text: WASHINGTON — In a proposal that could allow as many as 5,500 federal inmates to apply for reduced prison terms, the Obama administration on Wednesday backed retroactively lightening some sentences for past crack cocaine convictions.

headline: When the Nile Runs Dry
text: Washington

headline: See No Wild Lands, Speak No Wild Lands
text: Writing about the environment does make one think about the costs and benefits of recycling. But let it be noted that, despite the temptation, this blog did not recycle the December headline that read “Bush Policy on Wilderness Is Reversed.”

headline: World Bank to Help Cities Control Climate Change
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The World Bank signed an agreement on Wednesday with mayors from 40 of the world’s biggest cities to work on technical and financial assistance for projects to minimize the effects of climate change.

headline: A Way Through the Debt Mess
text: THIS week House Republicans overwhelmingly rejected a plan to raise the nation’s debt ceiling without simultaneous cuts in taxes and spending, setting up a showdown with President Obama this summer over the budget.

headline: Pakistani Spy Agency Denies Role in Journalist’s Killing
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s premier intelligence agency, Inter-Services Intelligence, said allegations that its operatives were behind the abduction and killing of the journalist Syed Saleem Shahzad were baseless, and vowed Wednesday to help bring the perpetrators to justice.

headline: For Her, Nearly Every Day Is a Party Day
text: As a teenager, Kristy Shelberg, stoked by “Seinfeld” and “Friends” and subscriptions to Vogue and Elle, plotted her escape from Creve Coeur, Mo., for New York City and a job in fashion or photography. She graduated in 2010 with a B.A. in marketing from LIM College in Midtown Manhattan, became Kristy Whitwell when she married her hometown sweetheart in July, and was hired last August as the event and party coordinator at the Scholastic Store in SoHo. Ms. Whitwell, 24, lives on Roosevelt Island with her husband, David, a classical trombonist attending the Brooklyn College Conservatory of Music.

headline: The Cellphone Study
text: Cellphone users have every right to be befuddled. Just last year, a major study in 13 countries found no clear evidence that exposure to the radiation from cellphones causes brain cancer. Yet, this week, a panel convened by the same agency, the International Agency for Research on Cancer, declared that the radiation is “possibly carcinogenic” to humans. It made this pronouncement by press release before publishing a monograph that will lay out the basis for its concerns — and will give independent scientists their first chance to evaluate this new judgment.

headline: Syed Saleem Shahzad’s Courage
text: The Pakistani journalist Syed Saleem Shahzad knew he was a marked man. Mr. Shahzad, who covered national security and terrorism, had received repeated threats from Pakistan’s powerful spy agency. Yet he courageously kept doing his job — until somebody silenced him. His body, his face horribly beaten, was buried on Wednesday.

headline: For Mobster, a Life Term, Not His First, Offers Relief
text: On Wednesday afternoon, the federal Bureau of Prisons Web site suggested something of an uncertain future for Vincent J. Basciano, known in some circles as Vinnie Gorgeous for his stint as the proprietor of a Hello Gorgeous beauty salon in the Bronx: It listed his release date (“actual or projected”) as “unknown.”

headline: Lawmaker Denies Sending Suggestive Photo but Doesn’t Rule Out It’s of Him
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Anthony D. Weiner, trying to put to rest a bizarre episode that is overshadowing his role as liberal pugilist and threatening his dream of becoming New York’s mayor, emphatically denied on Wednesday that he had sent a suggestive photograph to a woman in Washington State but said he could not be sure that he is not the person in the image.

headline: When Tennessee Turned South
text: Two weeks after South Carolina declared its secession from the United States, Governor Isham G. Harris called Tennessee’s legislature into special session. Harris, a native son of Tennessee, was a popular-two term governor who had campaigned vigorously for John C. Breckinridge, the candidate of the Southern faction of the Democratic Party, during the presidential election of 1860.

headline: Quiet? In New York City?
text: The irony would not have been lost on John Lennon. Musicians at Strawberry Fields, a memorial to the murdered Beatle and one of eight quiet zones in New York City’s Central Park, have drawn more police attention lately. If some minstrel belts out “Imagine” or gets a crowd to sing along hoping to carry away a hatful of coins, this busker could face a fine ranging from $50 to $200.

headline: 3 Men Convicted of Killing Opponent of Chechnya’s Leader
text: MOSCOW — A jury in Vienna on Wednesday convicted three Chechen exiles in the murder of Umar S. Israilov, a bodyguard who had turned against his former employer, the Chechen leader Ramzan A. Kadyrov.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 1, 2011

headline: U.S. Says New Indiana Law Improperly Limits Medicaid
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration prohibited the State of Indiana on Wednesday from carrying out a new state law that cuts off money for Planned Parenthood clinics providing health care to low-income women on Medicaid.

headline: Brazil, After a Long Battle, Approves an Amazon Dam
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Brazil’s environmental agency gave final approval on Wednesday for a giant hydroelectric power plant in the Amazon rain forest that has been at the center of a protracted battle between the government and environmentalists over the fate of indigenous people.

headline: Employment Data May Be the Key to the President’s Job
text: WASHINGTON — No American president since Franklin Delano Roosevelt has won a second term in office when the unemployment rate on Election Day topped 7.2 percent.

headline: UBS Is Surviving in Spite of Itself
text: It feels as though Cary Kochman should turn out the lights in the American investment banking offices of UBS. Mr. Kochman, the global co-head of the UBS’s mergers and acquisitions unit, is leaving for Citigroup — the latest to join in a parade worthy of Macy’s on Thanksgiving. Yet even with the multiyear exodus, UBS has clung to clients. Crushing a big advisory franchise isn’t easy.

headline: The Many Sides of Shaq
text: Shaquille O’Neil was one of the most dominant centers in N.B.A. history, but at times his celebrity transcended the sport.

text: KOLKATA, India

headline: Nike Tries to Enter the Niche Sports It Has Missed

headline: Thursday: Big Stretch
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Some days you get the puzzle, some days the puzzle gets you. Today I got the puzzle, and although you can’t see it, I’m doing a happy dance.

headline: Quinn Offers Cuts as Alternative to Widespread Layoffs
text: The City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, proposed roughly $75 million in cuts to the Department of Education’s budget on Wednesday, in an attempt to help minimize the layoffs planned for thousands of teachers this summer, as outlined by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg last month.

headline: Gates Discusses Bolstering Asian Security
text: SINGAPORE — Faced with a future of significantly reduced military spending, the United States should pursue a program of “cost effective” cooperation with Asian allies to defend regional security and enhance American interests, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Thursday.

headline: Woman Is Fatally Hit by Subway Train
text: A young woman was killed when she fell onto the subway tracks and was struck by a train on the Upper East Side on Wednesday afternoon, possibly after fainting, law enforcement officials said.

headline: Shareholders Approve Massey Energy Sale to Alpha
text: Shareholders approved Alpha Natural Resources’ $7.1 billion purchase of Massey Energy on Wednesday, creating the nation’s largest metallurgical coal company, but one that still will have to overcome safety concerns after Massey’s Upper Big Branch mine disaster last year.

headline: Bronx Apartment Building Designed to Combat Obesity
text: A new apartment building in the Longwood section of the Bronx is the first in New York to be built with an eye to combating obesity with its design elements, city officials say.

headline: Bacteria Outbreak Casts Pall on Spanish Produce
text: MOTRIL, Spain — Early June is normally one of the busiest seasons here in Spain’s farming heartland, as an army of seasonal farmworkers harvests cucumbers and tomatoes in the 5,000 greenhouses that dot the surrounding countryside. But most of the greenhouses were deserted on Wednesday, as demand for Spanish vegetables collapsed after the regional authorities initially linked a deadly outbreak of E. coli in Germany to farms in Andalusia.

headline: In Iowa, Pawlenty’s Campaign Is Taking the Road Less Traveled
text: LE MARS, Iowa — There was no tour bus idling in the parking lot, no satellite trucks racing down the highway and no time for sightseeing excursions, unless you count driving by the soon-to-open museum here in a city that promotes itself as the Ice Cream Capital of the World.

headline: Philip Rose, ‘Raisin’ and ‘Purlie’ Producer, Dies at 89
text: Philip Rose, who as the producer of Broadway shows like “A Raisin in the Sun” and “Purlie Victorious” advanced the cause of black playwrights and actors and helped widen the scope of American theater to include stories of blacks and other minorities, died on Tuesday in Englewood, N.J. He was 89.

text: Mark Schmitt, left, of the Roosevelt Institute and Kevin D. Williamson of National Review debate the quality of American public schools.

text: A private equity firm, the Gores Group, is in talks to buy at least half of the Borders Group’s remaining stores out of bankruptcy, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Wednesday.

headline: Jonas Bevacqua, Co-Founder of LRG Clothing, Dies at 33
text: Jonas Bevacqua, a designer and entrepreneur who helped form the LRG brand, selling hip-hoppers and skateboarders clothing and other merchandise as expressions of “ridiculous swagger,” as the company puts it, was found dead on Tuesday in his home in Laguna Beach, Calif. He was 33.

headline: Mets Swinging for Fences That Remain Safely, Maddeningly, Out of Reach
text: Two boys, one with a glove, stood on the field behind home plate Wednesday and watched Mets left fielder Jason Bay hit a batting-practice pitch so hard that one of the boys was sure the ball would leave Citi Field.

headline: Cuomo Ends State’s Role in Checking Immigrants
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Wednesday that he was suspending New York’s participation in a federal immigration enforcement plan that has drawn fire from immigrant advocates, civil liberties lawyers and elected officials in the state and around the country.

headline: Backyard Bulgogi
text: In looking to create a menu for an early-season barbecue that would appeal to everyone — meat lovers, vegetarians, culinary thrill-seekers and whoever else might show up — I realized that such a menu already exists. It’s just that it isn’t what we think of as “American food.”

text: The day in sports from the Yankees’ game in Oakland to the N.H.L. finals in Vancouver.

headline: Canucks Score Once and Late, but It’s Enough to Beat Bruins
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — Last summer, the veteran free agent Raffi Torres did not know where or if he was going to continue his N.H.L. career.

headline: Pirates’ Infield Hits Add Up to More Than Collins Can Take
text: The punchless Mets finally hit a home run Wednesday night, ending a 10-game streak without one. But they were seven runs behind the Pittsburgh Pirates when Justin Turner walloped a ball into the left-field seats, and Manager Terry Collins was already fuming.

headline: Italy: Money Seized From Vatican Bank Is Released
text: Prosecutors in Rome ordered the release on Wednesday of 23 million Euros, or almost $33 million, seized from the Vatican Bank last year in a continuing money-laundering investigation. They said they released the money after the Vatican instituted new mechanisms to help it adhere to international anti-money laundering and antiterrorist financing standards. The changes included creating a financial watchdog to coordinate with international organizations — a new leaf for an organization known for its opaque finances. The Vatican on Wednesday said it “appreciated” the release of the funds. Prosecutors had preventively seized the funds last September and placed the bank’s top two financial officers under investigation on the grounds that they transferred the money without properly disclosing the sender or motive. The two officials remain under investigation but have not been charged with a crime. The Vatican has said the investigation is the result of a misunderstanding.

headline: Using Internet Outside? In Part of Brooklyn, Free Wireless Access Arrives
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg frequently proclaims New York as an ideal city to start a technology company, but until now not a single neighborhood offered free wireless access to the Internet.

headline: Surgeons Who Burn the Midnight Oil
text: A few years ago during a visit home, my mother interrupted me as I was recounting the details of a transplant operation I’d done a week earlier. For as long as I’ve been a doctor, my mother, who owns a small business, has queried me about my long work hours, usually punctuating her questions with sympathetic clucks and gentle exhortations to eat more of the Taiwanese food she has prepared.

headline: Word of the Day | submissive
text: submissive •\ˈsəb-ˈmi-siv\• adjective

headline: The Hague: Mladic Said to Be Cooperative
text: A war crimes tribunal official at The Hague said Wednesday that Ratko Mladic, who arrived there Tuesday, had been cooperative and appeared to have no cognitive difficulty. Mr. Mladic, the former Bosnian Serb military commander, had earlier claimed he was mentally and physically unfit for trial. John Hocking, the court official, also said that Mr. Mladic was not placed on suicide watch. Mr. Mladic is due to make his first court appearance in a brief hearing on Friday, when he will be asked to enter his plea on charges including violations of the laws of war, crimes against humanity and genocide, court officials said. Mr. Mladic, 69, was arrested last week in Serbia after more than 15 years on the run. He spent his first night at The Hague in a separate section of the prison, without mingling with other tribunal prisoners, who include former friends and enemies from the Balkan wars.

headline: Iraq: Blast at Policeman’s Wedding Kills 7
text: Explosives hidden in a plastic bag were detonated at the wedding of a policeman about 40 miles south of Baghdad on Wednesday, killing 7 people and wounding 15, according to a local security official. The policeman’s brother was among the dead, but few other details were immediately available. The blast occurred around 9:30 p.m. in the predominately Sunni village of Musayyib. The blast went off before a significant number of people had arrived at the wedding, according to the security official. It was unclear who was behind the attack. Policemen and soldiers are often the targets of insurgents.

headline: Education Department Increases Its Regulation of For-Profit Colleges
text: The Department of Education on Wednesday tightened its regulation of for-profit colleges and other vocational programs that get billions of dollars in federal aid but leave many students with crushing debt and credentials worth little on the job market.

headline: Improved Tax Collections Can’t Keep Pace With States’ Fiscal Needs, Survey Finds
text: Half the states plan to cut spending on higher education, and nearly a third plan cuts to elementary and high schools. Public assistance and transportation face cuts. Eighteen states have proposed slashing aid to struggling cities and local governments. Some states will raise taxes or fees. Others plan to lay off workers, or cut their salaries or benefits.

headline: Obama Urged to Act Quickly on Budget Agreement
text: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner said Wednesday that Congress and the White House should try to reach an agreement within the next month that would combine an increase in the federal debt limit with deep spending cuts, and he called on President Obama to play a larger role in negotiations.

headline: Jack Ma Wants a Smaller Yahoo
text: Jack Ma, chief executive of Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce company, likened negotiations to resolve a very public feud with his investors, Yahoo and SoftBank, to the United Nations.

headline: Finding Suppliers Who Meet Our Standards
text: In late 2008 I got a phone call from the owner of a company in Michigan that manufactures and distributes metal table legs in a variety of configurations. We usually make our own wood bases for our tables, but there are times when we want to provide a simpler, cheaper solution than we can make ourselves. Metal legs are much less expensive than a custom-made base, so we can fabricate a very nice top and sell it at a lower price point than if we build the whole table in house.

headline: Japan Prime Minister Survives No-Confidence Vote
text: TOKYO — Prime Minister Naoto Kan survived a bruising no-confidence vote in Parliament on Thursday, but only after promising to resign once his government made progress in overcoming the nuclear crisis and the devastating earthquake and tsunami that caused it.

headline: Opera and Ballet, With Roman Ruins as Striking Backdrop
text: For another summer, opera and ballet aficionados can look forward to performances at one of Rome’s most striking backdrops. Throughout July and August, Rome’s Opera House will stage evening concerts, operas and ballet performances in the Thermal Baths of Caracalla, one of the city’s most impressive archaeological sites.

headline: Over G.M.’s Objections, Dealers Sell “Used” Chevy Volts Without $7,500 Tax Credit
text: According to a recent report by Mark Modica, published by the nonprofit National Legal and Policy Center, some Chevrolet dealers are selling Volts to other dealers and claiming the maximum $7,500 green-vehicle federal tax credit for themselves.

headline: Chaos in Yemen Drives Economy to Edge of Ruin
text: WASHINGTON — Even as Yemen’s political crisis deepens, the country is on the brink of an economic collapse so dire it could take years to recover, and hobble efforts to rebuild its fragmented society.

headline: A Poppy Harvest in Helmand, Undeterred
text: KHAN NESHIN, Afghanistan — Late May marks the end of the annual poppy harvest in Khan Neshin, a remote and thinly populated district in southernmost Helmand Province. First cleared by United States Marines in 2009, the district was one of nine in the province to be included in this year’s counternarcotics eradication campaign.

headline: The Fire This Time
text: Friday night went suspiciously smoothly. The first night of the summer season flowed without incident, without anyone waiting, without a single disgruntled guest, staffer or friend. Spectacularly smooth. I was waiting for the first shoe to drop. Never happened. The hospitality flowed both ways, from staff to sun-drenched guests and back to the front of the house. Everyone was relieved to feel summery, even if or especially because we had skipped spring.

headline: Garment Center Murals Are Imperiled as District Disappears
text: Attention Jack Lubin fans: You’re running out of time for a parting glimpse of one of his giant mosaic murals, as another vestige of the Garment Center vanishes.

headline: A Slimmer Package, With Ingenuity to Spare

headline: For Politicians, Social Media Holds Promise and Peril

headline: At Akindale, Dignity in Retirement
text: Last week, as part of my travel with my book, I had the opportunity to visit Akindale Thoroughbred Rescue, a part of Akindale Farm, in Pawling, N.Y. Akindale Farm is owned by the estate of John Hettinger. I had heard of A.T.B.R. and its strong reputation among horse rescues. That, though, did not prepare me for my visit.

headline: Heat’s Big Shots Disguise Offensive Struggles
text: LeBron James and Dwyane Wade each had Game 1 performances worthy of awe, but Miami’s overall offense in the initial game of the N.B.A. finals was hardly deserving of any kind of blanket praise. The win-loss binary has a way of making winners infallible and losers hopeless, but it seems that perhaps too much stock has been placed in the consistency of Miami’s attack. Having two of the best players in the game does not guarantee offensive efficiency, and though the Heat hold a 1-0 lead in the series, its win did not come without asterisks.

headline: Parks to Parking Lots: All the City’s a Stage
text: “Don’t I have a nice theater?” Stephen Burdman asked as he stood in a green field in Central Park near West 103rd Street on a recent Saturday afternoon. During a rehearsal break he was pointing out sites used in past productions by his company, New York Classical Theater.

headline: Awesome Wrongness
text: About a year and a half ago, all the Very Serious People said that it was time for a pivot in economic policy. Recovery was underway, so no more efforts to stimulate demand; the big threat was the bond market vigilantes, so it was urgent to slash the deficit now now now.

headline: Li Prevails Over Sharapova to Reach Final
text: PARIS — Twenty-nine-year-old Li Na of China defeated Maria Sharapova of Russia, 6-4, 7-5, on Thursday afternoon to become the first Chinese player to reach the final of the French Open. The defeat denied Sharapova the chance, had she gained the final, to score a career grand slam with victories in all four major championships.

headline: After a Tornado, Shock: ‘This Doesn’t Happen in Massachusetts.’
