Mr. Schlegel and his fiancée grabbed the children and ran downstairs, trying to get to the cellar entrance outside their apartment building.

headline: Trichet Urges Creation of Euro Oversight Panel
text: FRANKFURT — Jean-Claude Trichet, the president of the European Central Bank, called on Thursday for the creation of a central finance ministry to oversee spending by countries that use the euro.

headline: Stress Tests for Europe’s Banks Take Longer Than Expected
text: LONDON — The stress testing of European banks is taking at least a month longer than initially expected because some banks submitted figures that were too optimistic or lacked detail, a person with direct knowledge of the process said on Thursday.

headline: Giuliani Peers Down Into the Presidential Pool …

text: BEIJING — As an act of subversion, the empty wall unveiled Wednesday afternoon inside the CCD 300 gallery was rather tame. The defiance apparently came in appending the name Ai Weiwei below the blank space.

headline: Jobless Claims Dip Lower, But Show Less Momentum

headline: Watching the Murder of an Innocent Man
text: The mob, desperate for vengeance, had found an unlikely guide to lead them into their dark work. Fifteen-year-old Siphiwe, short, round-faced and reliably smiling, declared, "I know where these criminals live."

headline: Life and Death in Diepsloot
text: The Times's Barry Bearak examines the culture of crime and xenophobia in a town in South Africa. Warning: This video contains graphic scenes.

headline: Vain Glorious | A New Book by François Nars
text: In his lush new how-to book, “Makeup Your Mind: Express Yourself,” the makeup artist François Nars uses real women as muses. Showcasing an incredible array of faces — there are all different ethnicities, ages and even a sprinkling of men — the dense tome contains “before” and “after” photos (shot by Nars himself) of each subject. A transparent overlay between the two shots shows you how and where to apply makeup, which is very effective. Seeing the outline of the shape you are trying to create helps you apply product in a more accurate, efficient way. Because you have a clear view of the “before” face, which is completely bare, you can see how a primer or a sheer glow or matte foundation changes skin quality, and how a simple application of makeup can bring a feature to life or downplay it. The book challenges you to take risks, and even the most seasoned makeup wearer will be enlightened. It brought me back to my teen years, when I delighted in playing with different, even extreme, looks. Building confidence and conveying a variety of moods through makeup, Nars inspires you to be playful, passionate, imaginative and, as he says, “have an open spirit, and believe in your own beauty.” Nars’s picks from his own line of cosmetics: the Multiple, All About Eve Eyeshadow Duo, EFA Night Infusion and the AquaGel Hydrator.

headline: Thursday Reading: Groupon and Expedia to Offer Travel Deals
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Progress Sells Stake in Shale Venture for $1.1 Billion
text: Progress Energy Resources of Canada announced on Thursday that it was selling a 50 percent stake in its North Montney venture in British Columbia to the Malaysian state oil company Petronas for nearly $1.1. billion, in the latest shale-related energy deal.

headline: Giorgio Tozzi, Esteemed Bass at the Met, Is Dead at 88

text: It’s the Art Biennale this week–time for me to experience the world’s most romantic city during rush hour.

headline: Rural Legislators’ Power Ebbs as Populations Shift

According to the most recent counts, there are more than three times as many cows (6.2 million) as people (1.8 million).

headline: BankUnited Buys a New York Bank
text: BankUnited, a Florida lender that was taken over by private equity firms during the financial crisis, has reached a deal to acquire Herald National Bank of New York for $71.4 million.

headline: Analysts Weigh In on Weiner’s Future
text: Enough with all the chatter about Representative Anthony D. Weiner and his Twitter account. What impact might what the tabloids have dubbed Weinergate have on his expected bid for mayor in 2013?

headline: Costs May Impede City’s Switch to Clean Boiler Fuel
text: This year New York City took a big step toward improving air quality by requiring that buildings phase out use of the most polluting grades of heating oil. But a report released on Wednesday by the Manhattan borough president’s office notes that the conversions could be slowed by challenges related to costs, especially from rent-controlled buildings with low operating incomes.

headline: Arrest in Sex Assault on Elderly Woman
text: Updated, 2:18 p.m. | A 32-year-old sex offender living in Brooklyn was arrested and charged with Monday’s sexual assault and robbery of an 85-year-old woman on the Upper East Side, the police said Thursday.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: Schiavone Returns to French Open Final
text: PARIS — Francesca Schiavone defeated Marion Bartoli, 6-3, 6-3, on Thursday afternoon to return to the final of the French Open.

headline: Abramson Named Executive Editor at The Times
text: Jill Abramson, a former investigative reporter who rose to prominence as a Washington correspondent and editor, will become the next executive editor of The New York Times, succeeding Bill Keller, who is stepping down to become a full-time writer for the paper.

headline: Retail Sales Rise, but Below Forecasts
text: The nation’s retailers posted higher sales last month, led by discount stores, but the increase fell short of analysts’ forecasts as consumers continued to face an uncertain economy.

headline: Arrests in Staten Island Gambling Operation
text: A police detective and two firefighters were among more than a dozen people arrested early Thursday on federal charges related to a gambling operation that held illegal card games at three locations across Staten Island, according to the indictment.

headline: Poetry Pairing | June 2, 2011
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

headline: Another Hundred (or So) People: ‘Company’ Cast Plans a Tonys Reunion
text: If you missed the New York Philharmonic‘s star-studded production of “Company” at Avery Fisher Hall in April, then you aren’t Woody Allen or Alec Baldwin (whom we’re pretty sure we spotted in the crowd on opening night), but you’re still entitled to see this A-list team reunite for the Tony Awards. Organizers for the Tonys said on Thursday that this “Company” cast will perform at the awards telecast on June 12. Neil Patrick Harris, who played the lonely bachelor Robert in that production, wasn’t hard to pin down, since he’s hosting the Tonys; he’ll be joined in this performance by Stephen Colbert, Jon Cryer, Christina Hendricks, Patti LuPone and Martha Plimpton, as well as Jill Paice, Anika Noni Rose, Jennifer Laura Thompson, Jim Walton, Chryssie Whitehead, Katie Finneran and Aaron Lazar. A statement from the Tony organizers did not indicate which number(s) the “Company” cast will perform (so can we put our thumb on the scale now for “Side by Side by Side/What Would We Do Without You?”). The Tonys will be held this year at the Beacon Theater and broadcast on CBS. An HD film version of the Philharmonic’s “Company” will also be shown in movie theaters starting June 15.

headline: Nutrition Plate Unveiled, Replacing Food Pyramid
text: The first lady, Michelle Obama, on Thursday relegated the government’s well-known food pyramid to the sands of history, unveiling a new, simpler image of a plate divided into basic food groups.

headline: Just One Look | Yves Saint Laurent Resort
text: Stefano Pilati took the idea of cruise to heart with a saucy collection anchored by, well, anchors, ropes and other nautical motifs. His point of departure? A similarly shipshape collection by Yves Saint Laurent from the early ’80s.

headline: Romney Makes His Run for President Official
text: 2:17 p.m. | Updated STRATHAM, N.H. — Declaring America to be broken, Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, on Thursday harshly criticized President Obama and pitched himself as the turnaround specialist the country needs as he formally began his second run for president.

headline: Arrest in Fatal Shooting of 14-Year-Old Brooklyn Boy
text: Updated, 12:43 a.m. | An 18-year-old was arrested Thursday for the fatal shooting of a 14-year-old boy in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, the police said. The victim, Tyrek O’Hara-Morris, was shot once in the head at the corner of Park Place and Troy Avenue, about five blocks from his home on St. Marks Avenue, around 8:35 p.m. Wednesday, the police said. Dequan Edwards, also of Crown Heights, was charged with murder. It appeared that Tyrek had been involved in a dispute before the shooting, the police said.

headline: HBO Documentary Tracks the Rise and Fall of Bobby Fischer
text: Bobby Fischer became a national hero when he defeated Boris Spassky in the 1972 World Chess Championship match but died in exile in 2008 after alienating many later in life with his anti-Semitism and reaction to 9/11. “Bobby Fischer Against the World,” a documentary having its premiere on HBO on Monday, surveys his journey from idol to pariah. Despite the drama of Mr. Fischer’s downfall, the filmmakers found the subject to be a tough sell until they got to HBO. “I must say that I didn’t realize how complex and fascinating he was,” said Sheila Nevins, head of documentaries for the cable channel. Read the full article here.

headline: New York’s June jazz festivals; The importance of Gil Scott-Heron; and the Song of the Week.
text: This week: Ben Ratliff and Nate Chinen size up New York’s three June jazz festivals; Larry Rohter on the importance of Gil Scott-Heron; and a Popcast song of the week from Ranburne, Alabama. Ben Ratliff is the host.

headline: Li Is First Chinese Woman in French Final
text: PARIS — Maria Sharapova was pin-drop quiet, which was both welcome and eerie for anyone who has listened to her shrieks and wails and “come onnns” echo through the chambers of Grand Slam tournaments all these years.

headline: In the Jobs Report, One Big Question
text: In each of the last two months, I’ve posed five big questions about the jobs report on the eve of its release. This month, there is only one big question: Has job growth slowed, as many economists now fear?

headline: 270 Migrants Are Missing After Accident Off Tunisia
text: PARIS — As many as 270 migrants fleeing Libya for Europe may have drowned after their vessel capsized off the coast of Tunisia, the authorities said Thursday.

headline: Another Blow for City Opera as Director of Artistic Planning Departs
text: The New York City Opera has suffered a staff departure at a critical time. Edward C. Yim, the director of artistic planning, is resigning to serve as a consultant at the New York Philharmonic. The financially strapped opera company announced two weeks ago that it was leaving its Lincoln Center home to save money, without saying where it was going or what operas it would perform for the season starting in October.

headline: Mid-Century Mutants
text: A look at some of the sets of “X-Men: First Class” with commentary from the production designer Chris Seagers.

text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Stalwarts in China’s Water Struggle
text: To report out my article on China’s ambitious and troubled plan to divert water from the south to try to satisfy the drinking needs of people in the dying north, I traveled to the Han River, a tributary of the Yangtze River that winds through the heart of the country. It is there, at a reservoir at Danjiangkou, that the middle channel of the water diversion project starts.

headline: Facebook Steps Up Attack on Man Who Claims Ownership
text: 4:59 p.m. | Updated  to add comment from Paul Ceglia’s lawyer.

headline: Bauer to Step Down as White House Counsel
text: The White House counsel, Robert F. Bauer, will return to private practice at the end of June and resume his role as lawyer for the Democratic Party and Mr. Obama’s re-election campaign, President Obama announced on Thursday. Mr. Bauer will replaced by the deputy presidential counsel, Kathryn Ruemmler.

headline: Raw Video of Massachusetts Tornadoes
text: Updated | 2:14 p.m. As my colleague Abby Goodnough reports, the first tornadoes to hit Massachusetts in three years killed four people and destroyed buildings in the city of Springfield on Wednesday.

headline: The Unbearable Cynicism of Being Mitt
text: Talking Points has a preview of Mitt Romney’s official I’m-running-for-president speech. He’s going to say that “We are only inches away from ceasing to be a free market economy,” and pledge to keep federal spending under 20 percent of GDP.

headline: Banks Where You Can Still Count Your Change
text: Change-counting machines seemed to be going by the wayside, leaving consumers with nowhere to put all those coins they pull out from under their couch cushions. (Yes, we increasingly use debit cards and even our phones to pay for things. But those nickels and dimes still seem to pile up.) Some banks, though, continue to see the kiosks as a way to please their customers and — because we are talking about banks, after all — maybe earn some fees.

headline: Guess Where This Is
text: It’s time again for our weekly contest: guess the location of the photograph above.

headline: Talks Show Progress on Deal for N.F.L.
text: ST. LOUIS — Commissioner Roger Goodell and a handful of the most influential N.F.L. owners concluded meetings with DeMaurice Smith, the head of the now-decertified players association, and a group of players Thursday afternoon in Chicago amid indications that for the first time since March, progress could be made on a deal that would end the labor strife that has brought the league to a halt.

headline: Venice Biennale: On the Pigeons
text: VENICE – When Henry James famously said “though there are some disagreeable things in Venice, there is nothing so disagreeable as the visitors,’’ he might have added pigeons to the list of annoyances.

headline: Despite Cutbacks, Night Court’s Small Dramas Go On
text: Camille Carter was surprised when Judge Leslie Purificacion looked down from the bench in small-claims court in Queens and said it would be October before the court might have time to get to her year-old case over her $1,136 damaged fender.

headline: Rubio Finally Signs With Timberwolves
text: The long-running drama of Ricky Rubio and the Minnesota Timberwolves was resolved Wednesday, with Rubio finally agreeing to join the team that drafted him fifth overall in 2009 next season or whenever the league reaches a new labor agreement.

headline: The O’Neal Smile
text: The retirement came the way everything else did in Shaquille O’Neal’s career, with a smile and a wink, another reminder that sports is supposed to be fun and athletes who embody that will be loved and cherished, no matter how many free throws they clank off the rim.

headline: Rihanna Video Depicting Violent Attack Is Criticized
text: Advocacy groups are condemning a new Rihanna video that depicts the singer exacting violent revenge on a man who sexually assaulted her. They have called on the television network BET to stop showing the video, saying it sends a dangerous message to real-life assault victims.

headline: Billion Price Update
text: Some readers have asked for a comparison between the official CPI and the Billion Price Project numbers, which are independently derived using online data.

headline: Popcast: Sizing Up New York’s Summer Jazz Festivals
text: June means jazz in New York and in this week’s Popcast, Ben Ratliff and Nate Chinen, the jazz critics for The Times, look ahead at the festivals that will fill clubs around the city this month with various strains of the music.

headline: A Banner Season for Whitewater Rafting
text: Rafting outfitters in the West expect higher water and a longer river-running season because of above-average snowpack and a cool, wet spring.

headline: Theater Talkback: Anything But Theater! (At Least for a Night or Two)
text: During the summer, ArtsBeat will invite guest contributors to the Theater Talkback column. Howard Sherman is the executive director of the American Theater Wing, which along with the Broadway League, puts on the Tony Awards every year.

headline: Under the Tent
text: An interactive look at the history of Cirque du Soleil.

headline: The Young Boss for a Day Has His Say
text: It was that time of year in the Police Department when a bright high school student is chosen as police commissioner for a day. So, on Wednesday, after a formal ceremony at Police Headquarters, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly stepped before the klieg lights and news reporters accompanied by this year’s recipient, Gabriel Gomez, as well as the teenager’s mother, sister and an aunt.

headline: Biggest Hypocrisy Money Can Buy
text: During the Final Four in Houston last April, Gene Smith, the Ohio State athletic director, talked about the pressures on a megaprogram like his to maintain a winning edge. It can be a beastly challenge, he said: paying more for coaches, spending more on the recruiting budget to land top-flight players. The difference between David and Goliath is money. Ohio State’s annual athletic budget is more than $100 million.

headline: Mets Blow Lead, and Lose Their Cowbell
text: Terry Collins wasn’t the only one who lost patience with the Mets on Wednesday. Perhaps the team’s most devoted fan — Eddie Boison, a k a Cowbell Man — threw up his arms in disgust after the Mets blew a two-run lead on the way to an ugly 9-3 loss to the Pirates.

headline: What’s In J.J. Abrams’s Mystery Box?
text: Spoiler alert: Hey J. J., if you’re checking this out — or if your minions at the Alliance of Twelve/SD-6 or the Impossible Missions Force or even Starfleet Command are intercepting communications for you — just pull down the curtains now, click off to somewhere else. Unless you want to find out what’s in that 39-year-old mystery box of yours.

headline: Chinese Life as Child’s Play
text: SOMETIMES the most telling things about a society can be found in the messages it broadcasts to children. That seems to be the gist of a curious 10-minute video on view at Lombard-Freid Projects in Chelsea. In it a Chinese-built truck made to look like Thomas the Tank Engine tootles around Beijing, delighting the children it encounters. But the truck is actually on a more prosaic mission: picking up rubble from one of the city’s many construction sites and unloading it in a dump near the Summer Palace.

headline: Fearless Ascent, as a God or a Jet
text: THE tiniest studio at New York City Ballet is a sad, windowless box that reeks of ballet dancer. Imagine the earthy bouquet of a teenager’s sneaker in August.

headline: Found Poem Favorite | World War II
text: Today’s poem, chosen from more than 650 submissions to our Found Poem Student Challenge, comes from John, who is 18 years old and lives in Prospect, Connecticut.

headline: Jose Reyes Rejoins Mets
text: After a dismal 9-3 loss Wednesday that led to Manager Terry Collins publicly lambasting his team, the Mets received a boost Thursday with the addition of shortstop Jose Reyes, who missed the previous three games because of the death of his grandmother Maria Trinidad Reyes.

headline: Small-Claims Court Cutbacks
text: Patience is a requirement at small-claims court in Jamaica, Queens. Cases are heard only one night a week.

headline: Blackstone Blamed for British Nursing Home Woes
text: 8:44 p.m. | Updated

headline: The Werewolf Within
text: I thoroughly enjoyed Alex Pappademas’s article (dare I say “tribute”?) in the magazine this week. Although “Teen Wolf” did well at the box office all those years ago, this current and rather astonishing flurry of attention and examination would certainly have been welcome on opening day. I believe that with any film, it is up to the filmmaker to put forth his or her story, and it is then up to the audience to ascribe motivations and meaning. Having said that, I thought you might be interested in a few of my intentions while directing the film. To me, this was never a film about a werewolf. It was about a normal kid fighting his way through puberty, girls, peer pressure, school, etc., who has a bomb dropped on him at the end of Act I. For me, the key scene in the film occurs when Scott, Michael J. Fox’s character, reveals the wolf for the first time in public, during a basketball game. In about 20 seconds, the reactions of the actors go from horror, fear and amazement to curiosity and acceptance.

headline: Does Twitter Make You Stupid?
text: As a high-school junior, I am deeply saddened by the attitude of despondency toward my generation expressed by Bill Keller in “The Twitter Trap.” There are some ill side effects of our prolonged exposure to the Internet, notably a shortened attention span and an unappeasable desire to be instantly gratified. But those are only the cons of being in constant communication with one another. Never before could a high-school student so brazenly reach out to a Harvard graduate student and ask for mentorship on his research paper. Never again will we think it odd for someone from the farthest corner of the globe to be exchanging witticisms on Twitter with a well-known celebrity.

headline: NBC Names Schiller as Chief Digital Officer
text: Vivian Schiller, who resigned as NPR’s chief executive in March in the midst of controversy, was named Thursday to the newly created position of chief digital officer at NBC News.

headline: Born That Way, and Proud of It
text: After a close call with franchise death (diagnosis: anemia), the X-Men film series has bounced back to life with its fifth installment, rescued with a straight injection of pop. Directed by Matthew Vaughn, “X-Men: First Class” reaches back to the early 1960s for an origin story of mutants, mad men and mods that takes some of its cues from James Bond and more than a few costumes from Austin Powers. Like “Mad Men,” this new “X-Men” indulges in period nostalgia as it gazes into the future, using the backdrop of the cold war (and its turtlenecks) to explore how the past informs the present (while also blowing stuff up).

headline: A New ‘Sweet Valley High’ Spinoff, Online
text: If the recent spinoff of the “Sweet Valley High” young-adult series wasn’t enough for nostalgic fans, there is another revival in the works. St. Martin’s Press said on Thursday that it would publish a follow-up to “Sweet Valley Confidential,” the novel by Francine Pascal that caught up with Elizabeth and Jessica Wakefield in their 20s and landed on the best-seller list in April.

headline: The Anti-James Twitter Crowd Gathers
text: It’s a simple and clear mantra: “Defeat. Pure. Evil.”

headline: House Panel Faults Administration Spill Response
text: Representative Darrell Issa, the California Republican who is chairman of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, charged Thursday that the Obama administration bungled the response to the Deep Water Horizon explosion and oil spill last year.

headline: Stumptown Expands With the Help of a Powerful Investor
text: It looks like a big year for Stumptown Coffee Roasters. The Portland, Ore., company, known for getting some of the finest coffee in the world and serving it with rock ‘n’ roll flair, plans to open two coffee bars in Brooklyn, add a bottling facility to its roaster in Red Hook for its cold-brewed coffee and, Duane Sorenson, Stumptown’s founder, says the company will try to open roasters in Chicago and San Francisco.

headline: Fox Dances to No. 1 Again
text: Fox topped the ratings on Wednesday night as 8.4 million viewers tuned in for another two-hour installment of “So You Think You Can Dance,” according to Nielsen’s estimates. Although down a bit compared to last week’s strong season-premiere ratings on Thursday (9.5 million), the Fox reality show still easily outperformed its repeat competition on CBS and ABC.

headline: 36 Hours in Stockholm
text: STOCKHOLMERS revel in the long days of summer when the sun rises as early as 3:30 a.m. and doesn’t set until after 10 p.m. Many locals escape to their country houses, but those who remain in the city spend as much time as possible outdoors — an easy feat since water and parkland make up almost two-thirds of Stockholm. Situated on the Baltic at the mouth of Lake Malaren, Stockholm is built on 14 islands connected by bridges. On sunny days, waterside bars and cafes are packed with people wolfing down summer favorites like herring (served in a variety of ways) and toast Skagen (shrimp in mayonnaise with lemon and dill served with rye bread). Everywhere, visitors will find establishments — new and venerable — celebrating Nordic design, cuisine and culture.

headline: 36 Hours in Stockholm
text: Visitors to Stockholm will find establishments — new and venerable — celebrating Nordic design, cuisine and culture.

headline: Queens College Graduates March Again, 70 Years Later
text: The nine college classmates adjusted their gowns and mortarboards and marched proudly out to the commencement ceremony on the quad of Queens College campus on Thursday morning.

headline: The Morning Line: From the Derby to the Belmont
text: Editor’s Note: This will be the final Morning Line from Bennett Liebman. The Rail would like to thank him for his contributions.

headline: Flipping to Grilled Cheese
text: This spring, I taught a course at the Columbia Business School called, “Consumer Tech: What Makes a Hit a Hit, and a Flop a Flop.” It was supposed to be half lectures, half guest speakers.

headline: Behind the Poster: ‘One Arm’
text: A boxer turned hustler with a missing arm seems like an unlikely subject for a play, considering that the pool of one-armed actors is probably small, even in New York. (How do you make an actor’s arm disappear on stage?) But that’s exactly what the New Group and the Tectonic Theater Project have collaborated on in “One Arm,” a show based on a 1948 short story and unproduced screenplay by Tennessee Williams. Adapted for the stage and directed by Moisés Kaufman (“The Laramie Project”), “One Arm” stars Claybourne Elder as Ollie, a young boxing champion who bitterly turns to hustling and a life of violence after he loses his limb in an accident.

headline: Peter Thiel Tells Why He Will Pay You to Drop Out of School
text: Peter Thiel, the technology entrepreneur and venture capitalist best known for being an early backer of Facebook, is giving $100,000 to 24 young adults to stop going to school and start focusing on building the tech companies of tomorrow. In an interview with CNBC, Mr. Thiel explains the motivations behind his pledge and talks about the more than 400 people who have applied for the initial round of grants.

headline: Spoleto Festival USA: Wading In
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — For a visitor about to plunge midstream into the Spoleto Festival USA here, its offshoot Piccolo Spoleto Festival offered a chance to toe the water on Wednesday evening: a 100th-birthday tribute to the composer Gian Carlo Menotti. It was Menotti who, in 1977, founded the Spoleto Festival, an outgrowth of his Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto, Italy.

headline: Poll of 9/11 Families Is Sought Over Unidentified Remains
text: A group of families of Sept. 11 victims is demanding that the Bloomberg administration help them poll the next of kin of people who died in the World Trade Center attacks about where they want unidentified remains of the dead to be kept.

headline: Renovation Reality: War Puts Five-Star Dreams on Hold
text: To this day, rusty flagpoles stand in the courtyards of Baghdad’s major hotels. They are reminders of a promising future that never materialized.

headline: Cao Fei's 'Shadow Life'
text: A clip from the artist's 2011 video that was inspired by a state broadcast of a Chinese Spring Festival Gala. (Video courtesy of the artist and Lombard Freid Projects.)

headline: Keeping Score: They Won a Lot of Games, and Soon a Title
text: The fact that these N.B.A. finals feature a noteworthy crop of stars seeking their first title is illuminated by a metric measuring players’ all-around contribution to team wins.

headline: Year-End Roundup | Language Arts, Journalism, Culture and Academic Skills
text: The school year is drawing to a close, and our lesson plans have already gone on summer vacation. So this week we’re looking back at the 2010-11 school year and collecting the year’s teaching materials by subject matter. Below are the lesson plans we ran this year in academic skills, language arts, journalism and culture as well as interdisciplinary topics.

headline: With More Single Fathers, a Changing Family Picture
text: Doing some comparative math in the weeks before Father’s Day, Matthew Weinshenker, an assistant professor of sociology at Fordham University, has calculated that the number of single-father families in the United States has jumped 27 percent in the past decade. Since 1990, it has nearly doubled — to 2.79 million from 1.5 million. That is still only 15 percent of all single parents, but the increase, Dr. Weinshenker says, shows that the picture of American families is changing.

headline: Shabazz
text: Shabazz photographs

headline: Jane Lynch, or Sue Sylvester, to Host Emmys
text: Either Jane Lynch or her snide alter ego, Sue Sylvester of “Glee,” will host this year’s Prime Time Emmy Awards, the Academy of Television Arts & Sciences said Thursday.

headline: Start-up Offers New Hires $10,000, and All the Accoutrements of Hipsterdom
text: Earlier this year, my colleague Claire Cain Miller and I reported on the fierce recruiting wars among tech companies as they competed to hire and retain talented software developers and engineers. We wrote about some of the perks that start-ups were offering to potential employees to convince them to join their companies, including free meals, haircuts and even iPads.

headline: Pauline Betz Addie, a Dominant Tennis Champion, Dies at 91
text: Pauline Betz Addie, a dominant American tennis champion who at the height of her amateur career was abruptly barred from the sport in 1947 because she had openly considered turning professional, died on Tuesday in Potomac, Md. She was 91.

headline: What if the U.S.D.A Subsidized Gardens?
text: Roger Doiron of Kitchen Gardeners International, a Maine-based nonprofit, has put together this nifty graphic that shows the planting layout of the White House vegetable garden – which is more an ideal than a typical garden, but not uncommon in its choice of plants – and then re-imagines how it would look if it were to reflect the crops that the federal government supports. The change is pretty stark. The data is culled from the Environmental Working Group’s fantastic farm subsidy database.

headline: How to Watch the Men’s Semifinals (and Not Travel to Paris)
text: The often confusing and confounding way that NBC covers the French Open men’s semifinals has a little more clarity this year thanks in part to the addition of an online component, nbcsports.com.

headline: Couple Sentenced to Prison in 18-Year Kidnapping Case
text: PLACERVILLE, Calif. — The couple who kidnapped Jaycee Lee Dugard in 1991 and held her captive for nearly two decades were sentenced to prison on Thursday, after listening to angry and emotionally wrought statements from the victim and her family.

headline: Ping-Pong in New York
text: From tiny novelty sets atop coffee tables to outdoor tables at Bryant and Tompkins Square Parks, ping-pong takes New York.

headline: The Little-White-Ball Obsession That Isn’t Golf
text: NOW that the glitterati, literati, digerati and hipsterati have been caught in the act of Ping-Pong, let’s be clear: There is Ping-Pong, and there is table tennis.  “Everybody I meet either knows somebody or they themselves were at one point a terrific Ping-Pong player,” said Marty Reisman, 81, the 1958 and 1960 United States Open table tennis champion. “Only a small group is cognizant of the extreme skill required to play the game.”

headline: Hawk Cam | Pip’s Progress
Summer TV
text: The upcoming summer television season includes shows new and old, including the final runs of “The Closer,” “Rescue Me” and “Entourage.”

headline: Neighborhood Joint | Fauna
text: At an Upper West Side pet shop, the owner hand-raises all of the birds he breeds and sells.

headline: A Menagerie Where Pets Do the Staring
text: EVERY afternoon except Tuesday, when this Upper West Side temple to alternative pets — jungle birds, desert reptiles and all things aquatic — is closed, Bob Myles and his Norfolk terrier, Bruno, pop through the front door and make a beeline for the spectacular glassed-in aviary at the back. There, Bruno plants himself on his haunches, nose to glass, and stares at the parrots in free flight on the other side. Mr. Myles, who lives in the neighborhood, is a regular at the shop, Fauna, but not a customer. “Bruno leads me here, and the people who run the store are very gracious about it,” he said. “They know we’re just here to look. The little green parrots are his favorites.”

text: Theater

headline: G.M.’s Bryan Nesbitt Pledges Design Differentiation for Chinese Market
text: General Motors recently announced that Bryan Nesbitt, currently the company’s exterior design lead across its North American brands, will be sent to Shanghai on Aug. 1 as vice president of General Motors international design.

headline: A Gay Couple’s Tax Predicament
text: Most of us pay income taxes because we know we have to. But what happens when you fail to pay an obscure tax that you never heard of — and that your employer should have told you about?

headline: Three Banks Grab Groupon I.P.O.
text: One of the most eagerly awaited initial public offerings of the year — that of Groupon — has finally landed.

headline: Venice Biennale: The ‘It’ Bag
text: It’s something of a tradition here that when the National pavilions dole out information on their artists, the papers and catalogs generally come with a handy tote bag.  Both a practical object and a free ad (they usually have an image of some sort and the name of the country on them) some are always more in demand than others.

headline: The Czar of All Media
text: Does Howard Stern still call himself “the king of all media”? If so, I think he has a rival for the throne these days: Bill Simmons, the subject of Jonathan Mahler’s profile in the magazine this Sunday. (Though I suspect Simmons might prefer the title of czar or grand poo-bah or godfather or maybe even pit boss.) Stern had — or has — what, radio? Some TV? Simmons will see you those media and raise you podcasts, books, magazine and online columns, documentaries, Twitter and now his own Web site, Grantland.

headline: The Lone Horseman of the Sportspocalypse
text: The countdown for Grantland.com is on.

headline: TimesCast | June 2, 2011
text: Mitt Romney formally starts his presidential campaign; fighting rages in Yemen, threatening to close the main airport; and economists predict slower job growth in May.

headline: The School Bully Is Sleepy
text: School bullies and children who are disruptive in class are twice as likely to show signs of sleep problems compared with well-behaved children, new research shows.

headline: Fox News and the Republican Field
text: Gabriel Sherman’s New York Magazine piece on Fox News in the age of Obama is filled with interesting material, but I’m not sure that its thesis about 2012 quite holds up:

headline: Moody’s Warns of Downgrade for U.S. Credit
text: WASHINGTON — Moody’s Investors Service warned Thursday that it might downgrade the United States government’s sterling credit rating if Congress did not increase the nation’s debt limit “in coming weeks,” putting a spur to the sputtering talks between party leaders and the White House on a plan to restore fiscal stability.

headline: Deals Move Apple Closer to Streaming Music
text: Apple has nearly completed its negotiations with the major music publishers over rights for a new cloud music service.

headline: Six Dead in Southern Arizona Shooting, Including Gunman’s Ex-Wife and Her Lawyer
text: PHOENIX — A man who was apparently upset over a contentious divorce killed his former wife, her lawyer and three others on Thursday morning in the border city of Yuma, Ariz., before killing himself, the authorities and friends of the victims said.

headline: The Enduring Legacy of Good Bureaucrats
text: A little break from the usual: there’s a fascinating paper on Vox by Becker and Woessmann on the lasting effect of the Habsburg empire. They point out that while the Habsburgs may not be your idea of sterling rulers, the empire was considerably better run than its neighbors, especially at the local level. And they also note that the empire’s boundaries ran through the middle of a number of modern countries.

headline: Burrows’s Bite, Unpunished, Joins Legion of Chomping Incidents
text: The N.H.L. announced on Thursday that no suspension was forthcoming against Vancouver’s Alexandre Burrows, who added a little color to Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals by biting the finger of Boston’s Patrice Bergeron. The incident ended in Bergeron showing his bloody finger to the referee and Burrows getting a double minor for roughing.

headline: An Unconventional Presentation of Shakespeare
text: Charles Isherwood on "Sleep No More", an unconventional theater piece inspired by Macbeth.

headline: Fête Accompli | ‘La Dolce Vita’ Is a Gucci Affair
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#650", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

headline: ‘Popular Crime’
text: I

headline: Crunch the Numbers; Solve a Famous Murder
text: Fans of Bill James — baseball fans, in other words — will have many of their expectations confounded by his new book. For starters, unlike his previous two dozen or so volumes, “Popular Crime” has nothing to do with the statistical analysis of baseball. The title doesn’t refer to certain general managers’ criminal neglect of the many advanced statistics that Mr. James has popularized over the years, which are best known by terms like O.P.S., P.S.N., W.A.R. and SecA. “Popular Crime” has nothing, in fact, to do with baseball. Its subject is our other national pastime: crime stories.

headline: Mets Show They Got Message, Rallying from 7-0 Deficit
text: The Mets acknowledged that Manager Terry Collins got his point across when he spit angry words at them after another disappointing loss. We need to play better, they said.

headline: Libya and Elsewhere — Pictures of the Day
text: Photographs from Libya, Somalia, Japan and Georgia.

headline: Hans Keilson, Novelist of Life in Nazi-Run Europe, Dies at 101
text: Hans Keilson, a German-born psychoanalyst who won literary fame at the very end of his long life when two of his long-forgotten works of fiction, set in Nazi-occupied Europe, were republished to great acclaim, died on Tuesday in Hilversum, the Netherlands. He was 101.

headline: Movie Listings for June 3-9
text: Movies

headline: Alone to Face the Fallout From a Son’s Horrific Crime
text: “Beautiful Boy” tiptoes into a minefield, where it loses its nerve and remains frozen in its tracks, too timid to find a way back. As you watch this earnest-to-a-fault, sensitively acted film about the parents of a campus killer reacting to their son’s shooting rampage and suicide, you may wonder why. Why make a fictional movie, however tasteful, about the aftermath of a horror apparently based on the 2007 Virginia Tech massacre, whose perpetrator killed 32 people and then himself? Why not a documentary?

headline: YouTube Enables Creative Commons Videos Sharing
text: YouTube is home to some of the more creative individuals online — people who create content, often splicing and dicing numerous videos together to create mesmerizing mashups. Now YouTube wants to help these people find videos online that are intended to be borrowed and re-edited without fear of violating copyrights.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings for June 3-9
text: Pop

headline: How to Be a Foul-Weather Friend
text: My husband and I have been good friends with another couple for several years. We’ve vacationed together and have dinner several times a month. Recently, the other husband confided in my husband about his marital infidelities. Now my husband is no longer interested in being friends with him. But his wife doesn’t understand why we’re not socializing with them. I want to remain friends with her. What should I say? Anonymous

headline: Venice Biennale: The Enormity of the Beast
text: And now the fun begins. I spent the second day of press previews for the Venice Biennale in the Arsenale, a narrow gauntlet of art compared to the Giardini, with its discreet national pavilions and semblance of order. Here “ILLUMInations,” as the Biennale exhibition is called — having started in the spacious galleries of the Giardini’s Central Pavilion — becomes a kind of extended scrum, spliced with additional national pavilions. The impossible enormity of the Biennale beast begins to sink in. With all the additional pavilions scattered about town and the independent exhibitions that are out there, too, Venice currently has more contemporary art on offer than any one person can see, even without the usual considerations of time, money and eye-strain.

headline: Toshiba’s Tablet Is for Laptop People
text: A new tablet by Toshiba, the Toshiba Thrive, will be available for pre-sale on June 13, and in stores by July 10, the company said Thursday.

headline: Groupon Chief to Make $575 in 2011
text: Andrew D. Mason, Groupon’s eccentric chief executive, is presiding over one of the hottest tech companies of the moment.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Libya, Somalia, Japan and Georgia.

headline: Pandora Increases Size of Its Planned I.P.O.
text: 6:15 p.m. | Updated

headline: Spendable Art That’s Not for Sale
text: It’s been a Warholian spring in New York: Warhol films at the Museum of Modern Art, Warhol paintings driving the May auctions, and a silver statue of Warhol in temporary residence at Union Square (Rob Pruitt’s “Andy Monument”). And now the winner of the Guggenheim’s Hugo Boss Prize has cashed his $100,000 check and pinned the money, in $1 bills, to the museum’s walls. Doesn’t that sound like something Warhol might have done?

headline: No Need to Settle for Summer Reruns
text: With the big-five television networks officially on reruns-and-reality cruise control, it’s time for everyone else to have some fun in the sun. Our list of highlights from the summer TV season includes shows new and old, serious and frivolous, as well as a round of goodbyes: the cable stalwarts “The Closer,” “Rescue Me” and “Entourage” will all be finishing their runs.

headline: ALONG THE YANGZI RIVER: ‘Regional Culture of the Bronze Age From Hunan’
text: China Institute Gallery

headline: SOL LEWITT: ‘Arcs and Lines’
text: Paula Cooper Gallery

headline: Reliving a Drug Dealer’s Halcyon Days
text: “Mr. Nice” is an affable throwback to those guilt-free days when hippie drug dealers radiated the glamorous aura of avant-garde heroes risking prison to spread the doctrine of liberation through cannabis. The title comes from the name Donald Nice, one of many aliases adopted by Howard Marks, a notorious Welsh drug dealer, now 65, who made millions traveling around the world wheeling and dealing.

headline: Q&A: Reopening Folders Automatically
text: Q.

headline: DAVID SHAPIRO: ‘Money Is No Object’
