headline: ‘ALCHEMY & INQUIRY’
text: Glyndor Gallery

headline: A Night for the Faithful: ‘Sister Act’ On Tap For Obama Re-Election Fundraiser
text: Tickets to the Broadway musical “Sister Act” usually top out at $200 for the best orchestra seats, but they’ll zoom to $10,000 for the June 23 performance — because the price includes a photo shoot with President Obama, whose re-election campaign has chosen the production for his first major Broadway fundraiser for the 2012 cycle. One of the musical’s lead producers, the actress Whoopi Goldberg, who starred in the original “Sister Act” movies, is a political supporter of Mr. Obama’s and will host the evening’s events at the Broadway Theater.

headline: TOM FAIRS: ‘Drawings’
text: KS Art

headline: Spare Times for June 3-9
text: Around Town

headline: Financial Repression
text: I’ve been getting questions about Carmen Reinhart’s new paper on financial repression (pdf) in the aftermath of large debt buildups, which asserts that said repression was a large part of the way the US and UK, in particular, dealt with their war debts.

headline: Soaring Nods to Industry, Camping on an Island for the Summer
text: Since the city bought it for a dollar in 2003, Governors Island has evolved from a spooky relic to a postcollegiate playground to a family-friendly weekend destination.

headline: Behold the Anonymous Downtrodden
text: Boris Mikhailov’s photographs of homeless people in Ukraine are not for the squeamish. They are hard to look at, hard to look away from and hard to forget. The 19 examples in “Case History” at the Museum of Modern Art portray people who are far from conventionally attractive in grungy rooms or in wintry outdoor sites, naked or pulling aside their clothes to expose parts of their bodies ordinarily hidden from view. An older woman bends over to reveal buttocks ravaged by a pimply red rash. A young nude woman with arms tightly wrapped around herself stands in an evidently freezing bathroom next to a filthy toilet.

headline: Behind the Cirque
text: A look at Cirque du Soleil and its reclusive impresario, Guy Laliberté.

headline: Coming of Age, and Then to Terms
text: “Submarine,” the debut feature directed by Richard Ayoade, a well-known English television comedian, is as smart and self-conscious as its protagonist, a 15-year-old Welsh schoolboy named Oliver Tate (Craig Roberts). This is only fitting, since the movie, in the manner of precursors like “Rushmore” and “Garden State,” is more or less the movie Oliver would make about himself.

headline: App Smart Extra: A Smartphone Magazine for Car Lovers
text: Car buyers can get real-time advice from a few good mobile apps, as today’s App Smart column points out.

headline: The Groupon I.P.O.: What Is Adjusted CSOI?
text: With its filing for an initial public offering, Groupon is shedding some light on its financials for the first time. But one question leaps out: What is the new metric the social-buying company calls “adjusted CSOI”?

headline: Changing of the Baton At St. Martin in the Fields
text: The words Academy of St. Martin in the Fields are indelibly linked with the name  Neville Marriner in the minds of classical music radio listeners from recent decades. Now the academy, the renowned London chamber orchestra, will have a new name officially associated with it: Joshua Bell, who has been named the music director. Mr. Bell, who first played with the oft-recorded Academy in 1986, will spend six weeks next season performing with it as a violin soloist and directing from the leader’s chair. His term starts in September and lasts for three years. Mr. Marriner, 87, founded the orchestra in 1958 and has the title of life president. Since 2000 Murray Perahia has been principal guest conductor.

headline: Marion’s Shot Isn’t Pretty, but It’s Pretty Successful
text: MIAMI — It begins with a dainty tuck, hands pulled back, as if to shield himself from danger, the ball nestled against his clavicle. Shawn Marion’s feet rise in front of him, and his body becomes a drafting compass, his waist as its hinge.

headline: Spare Times: For Children, for June 3-9
text: KIDSFILMFEST

headline: Streetscapes | Fifth Avenue and 77th Street
text: William A. Clark lavished millions on his 1911 mansion at Fifth Avenue and 77th Street. His daughter Huguette, who died last month, lived there until 1927.

headline: Resort: Castaways in Manhattan
text: On Thursday, the air swept clean of humidity, a few editors ducked into the shadows of 11 West 42nd Street and rode the elevator up to Michael Kors’s showroom. Waiters offered sparkling water and orange juice as perhaps 20 editors from various publications — Elle, W, Town & Country, In Style — stood in the blond-wood lobby checking their BlackBerrys or talking about when they were going to leave for the Hamptons or Fire Island for the weekend.

headline: Remembering When Dad Came Out
text: There is all manner of love crisscrossing through “Beginners,” connecting mothers and fathers, parents and children, sons and lovers, men and their dogs. The love feels heartfelt but it’s difficult loving other people (the dog has it easy), a hardship that’s evident in the happy-tearful faces, the tentative touches and searching glances that make this movie, or maybe all its yearning, so appealing. For the writer and director Mike Mills, who based this memory piece about a straight son and his dying gay father on his own life, love is a wonder even if its palpable reality largely remains elusive, a hoped-for gift locked in an adjacent room.

headline: Series of Deft Negotiations Involving Ill-Advised Attire
text: Christine Elmo is easy to look at. Yes, she’s attractive — petite with big eyes and a shock of dark hair — but I’m talking movement-wise. She eats up a stage in bounding leaps, and she’s terrifically precise, carving exact shapes in space that linger in the mind.

headline: Hacker Group Claims Responsibility for New Sony Break-In
text: A hacker group calling itself LulzSec claimed responsibility on Thursday for breaking into a Sony Web site and stealing personal information of about 52,000 customers.

headline: Jazz Listings for June 3-9
text: Jazz

headline: A Double Helix of Art and Science
text: ANTOINE LAVOISIER was a scientific revolutionary. Among other things, this father of modern chemistry, as he is known, named oxygen and showed that breathing is a form of combustion.

headline: Mercurial Dramas, Vertical and Horizontal
text: For all that he has been choreographing on both sides of the Atlantic for 15 years, Christopher Wheeldon is still young. Repertory on both sides of Lincoln Center Plaza has of late been enriched by three of his ballets. Last week American Ballet Theater presented the world premiere of his “Thirteen Diversions” at the Metropolitan Opera House; New York City Ballet recently revived his “Polyphonia” (2001) and offered his “Mercurial Manoeuvres” (2000) on Wednesday. He has made other fine works, but these three alone demonstrate why he has become so important to ballet worldwide.

headline: Above the Grand Canal, ‘Big Bambú’ Rises
text: VENICE — This jaded New Yorker wondered if it was really necessary to come all the way here to see “Big Bambú: You Can’t, You Don’t, and You Won’t Stop,” a hugely popular installation by the artist twins Mike and Doug Starn when it appeared on the roof of the Metropolitan Museum of Art last summer.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings for June 3-9
text: Classical

headline: Instrumentalists at an Exhibition
text: In the left panel of Simon Dinnerstein’s painting “The Fulbright Triptych” a woman sits with a child on her lap. In the right panel a man also sits in a neutral posture. All three stare blankly out at the viewer.

headline: 1. Make List; 2. Do Stuff
text: HERE is a partial list of the kinds of lists included in “Lists: To-dos, Illustrated Inventories, Collected Thoughts, and Other Artists’ Enumerations,” an exhibition beginning Friday at the Morgan Library & Museum: lists of bills to pay, things undone, failings in oneself and others; lists of people to call, stuff to buy, errands to be accomplished. There are also lots of lists of artworks, real and imaginary. That’s because all the material in the exhibition comes from the Archives of American Art at the Smithsonian Institution — mostly, as the curator of the exhibition, Liza Kirwin, remarked the other day, from drawers and folders marked “Miscellaneous.”

headline: Delights Alongside Dark Notes
text: As the San Francisco singer Wesla Whitfield sang a slow, ruminative “The Best Things in Life Are Free” at the Metropolitan Room on Wednesday evening, you had the impression of a wise, silver-haired aunt gently reminding a high-strung, hyperactive nephew of what really matters. It is “the flowers in spring” and “the robins that sing,” not the toys he flung around the room in a fit of temper.

headline: Dance Listings for June 3-9
text: Dance

headline: Jazz in June: Sorting Through the Abundance
text: AS usual, jazz pervades June in New York City. Besides better-than-normal bookings in the clubs, we’re looking at the first Blue Note Jazz Festival (monthlong), the second Undead Jazzfest (June 23 to 26) and the 16th Vision Festival (Sunday through June 11).

headline: Alia Creasey and Joshua Lilienstein
text: OF all the lines that Dr. Alia Creasey imagined might hook her into her dream relationship, this was not one: “My hearing is not so good.”

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for June 3-9
text: Art

headline: TimesCast | The Romney Factor
text: June 2, 2011 - Mitt Romney is officially running for president for a second time.

headline: Gil Scott-Heron’s Link to Soccer
text: Last Friday, the music world lost a seminal figure in Gil Scott-Heron.

headline: As Condos Fill, Retail Space Remains Vacant
text: RIVER LOFTS, a condominium at Laight and West Streets in TriBeCa, has attracted buyers like Gwyneth Paltrow and Chris Martin, who live in a spectacular all-white apartment. At the same time, the building’s exterior has required such extensive repairs that, for much of the four years since it opened, it has looked more like a construction site than a posh residence.

headline: Renovating City Hall, From Floor to Ceiling
text: High above the City Council chambers in City Hall on Thursday, Bertram Abdul spread a layer of plaster under the image of an eagle on the ceiling, finessing the edges to look like frosting on a cake.

headline: Showing the Grandchildren a Grand Time in the Big City
text: Grandparents figured large in this week’s correspondence, as Mr. Critic received missives from parents of parents from here and from afar. This led to ruminations on what it means to be a child visiting New York City, and what it means to be a child who lives and eats out in restaurants here, and why it matters. As always, you can send your own questions about dining out in restaurants in New York City to dinejournal@nytimes.com.

headline: So Successful, a New Ice Cream Shop Closes After 4 Days
text: If you thought the last thing brownstone Brooklyn needed was another purveyor of artisanal foods, you are officially wrong.

headline: 72 Hours at the Venice Biennale
text: Christoph Niemann, the genius who recently discovered the shocking truth about the E.P.A., has arrived in Venice for the Art Biennale. He’ll write about art, sure, but he’s mainly there to chronicle the sublimity and ridiculousness of the scene. (He’s also going to complain about the fact that he lost his luggage on the way there, and he’ll be justified in doing so.) Anyway, his first postcards are already up, and they’re fantastic. He’ll have many more coming over the next few days, so please keep checking back.

headline: Huguette Clark’s ‘Worthless’ Girlhood Home
text: SINCE Huguette Clark’s death last month, many eyes have zeroed in on her sumptuous suite of apartments at 907 Fifth Avenue, one of the most elegant buildings in New York.

headline: Play On
text: The work of the Chinese artist Cao Fei turns its attention to childhood.

headline: For Renters-to-Be, the High-Tech Lowdown
text: MILLIONS of New Yorkers are from outside the city, and many made the move as young adults. So hopeful transplants may believe that moving here and finding that first rental apartment will be a walk in the park.

headline: Artist’s Heroic Struggle to Make Heroic Paintings
text: William T. Trego, a Victorian painter who specialized in battlefield scenes, killed himself by taking poison during a June heat wave in 1909, when he was 50. He was broke and physically debilitated from a childhood ailment that was probably polio.

headline: IMHO
text: Humility has a bad reputation. The definition for humility and humbleness in my Random House dictionary includes: “having feelings of insignificance, inferiority, subservience…low in rank, importance, status, quality etc.” But recently I sat in on a panel at the Association for Psychological Science convention where the scholars had a much more appreciative view.

headline: The Work of Tod Seelie
text: The photographer Tod Seelie began taking snapshots of his friends. Now he brings his camera — and, with it, his audience — into some of the city’s most unusual and arresting happenings.

headline: A Place With the Family Seal of Approval
text: FOR more than five years, Julie Glickman lived in the ground-floor apartment of a Park Slope brownstone. The owners, family friends, lived upstairs. Ms. Glickman paid just $800 a month, and the rent never rose. The railroad-style apartment was charming, though dark. Ms. Glickman would have been happy staying there indefinitely, or at least “until my life expanded,” she said.

headline: Q & A
text: Two, and Only Two, Building Entry Keys

headline: Syrians to March for Young Martyrs
text: Syrians calling for President Bashar al-Assad to step down plan to march on Friday in memory of children who have been killed during the uprising, The Associated Press reports.

headline: Statements Skip Over REIT’s Woes
text: Late 2007 was among the worst times ever to invest in real estate, and those who did so have losses to show for it.

headline: The Peril of Social Media and the Jobless Rate's Effect on the President's Re-election Hopes
text: The peril of social media for N.Y. Congressman Anthony Weiner and the jobless rate's effect on the President's re-election hopes. Deputy news editor for blog development Megan Liberman, Washington correspondent Sheryl Gay Stolberg, and chief financial correspondent Floyd Norris join Sam Roberts in New York.

headline: City Ordered to Continue Housing Program’s Rent Payments
text: Updated, June 3 | An appellate court ruled on Thursday that the city must continue paying rent for thousands of families who moved out of city shelters through the Bloomberg administration’s Advantage housing subsidy program.

headline: On a Mediterranean Cruise Ship Steered by a Godardian Crew
text: Gertrude Stein once wrote that Ezra Pound, one of the sacred monsters of literary modernism, was “a village explainer, excellent if you were a village, if not, not.” Jean-Luc Godard’s place in late-20th-century French cinema is not unlike Pound’s in midcentury Anglophone poetry: endlessly influential and perpetually controversial, a longtime resident of the middle ground between sage and crank. But at this point in his career Mr. Godard is better described as a village mystifier. Which is excellent if you happen to inhabit the global village of easily accessible, disposable images. We villagers tend to like our movies comfortable and familiar, and this man’s job is to make them difficult and strange.

headline: New Ad Attacks Obama on Peace Proposal
text: Continuing Republican attacks against President Obama for the details of his Middle East peace proposal, a conservative  pro-Israel group has started running an advertisement describing Mr. Obama as having “sided with the Palestinians.”

headline: With Yoga and Fasting, Graft Fighters Shake India
text: NEW DELHI — For more than 40 years, reformers and other agitators have tried in vain to cleanse India of corruption. They have staged demonstrations, candlelight vigils and protest marches for naught. In Parliament, efforts to create an independent anticorruption agency began in 1968. It still does not exist.

headline: A Menagerie Where Pets Do the Staring
text: Every afternoon except Tuesday, when this Upper West Side temple to alternative pets — jungle birds, desert reptiles and all things aquatic — is closed, Bob Myles and his Norfolk terrier, Bruno, pop through the front door and make a beeline for the spectacular glassed-in aviary at the back. There, Bruno plants himself on his haunches, nose to glass, and stares at the parrots in free flight on the other side. Mr. Myles, who lives in the neighborhood, is a regular at the shop, Fauna, but not a customer. “Bruno leads me here, and the people who run the store are very gracious about it,” he said. “They know we’re just here to look. The little green parrots are his favorites.”

headline: The Power of Voices Lifted in Song
text: Theologians and clergy members of every religious stripe may debate the existence of God until the cows come home. But as demonstrated by “Rejoice and Shout,” Don McGlynn’s documentary history of African-American gospel music, reasonable arguments are nothing compared with the power of voices lifted in song to invoke the Holy Spirit. Your religion or lack of one doesn’t matter. At some point while watching the film, you may feel that music is God, or if not, a close approximation of divinity.

headline: A Bullish Fox Says Sales Are Up 10 Percent
text: The Fox network announced a rather quick end to its upfront advertising sales Thursday, with a healthy increase that signaled how avid the market is for commercials on network programs.

headline: T. J. Gottesdiener
text: Mr. Gottesdiener, 56, is a managing partner in the New York office of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, one of the world’s largest architectural firms, best known for its skyscrapers.

headline: Weiner Has Done Himself No Favors
text: “At the end of the day, however, fair or not, many of the questions and most of the talk — they’re being fueled by Congressman Weiner himself.” — Anderson Cooper on CNN

headline: Obama Campaign Revs Up Money Machine
text: With his field of potential Republican opponents still  taking shape, President Obama will seek to raise $60 million by the end of June for his re-election campaign and the Democratic Party.

headline: When Is a Child Ready for Kindergarten?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Friends, Football and Fun
text: Almost everyone who has ever been in a modern-art museum has had the experience of staring at some concoction — blobs of color, a mash-up of metals — and thinking the cliché: “But is it art?” Something similar might occur to viewers of “Turkey Bowl,” a quirky offering by Kyle Smith that does nothing more or less than show a touch-football game among friends. “It’s sort of interesting,” you might find yourself saying, “but is it a film?”

headline: Handling Combat Stress
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Politics of Doctors
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ms. Bloomberg’s Novel
text: To the Editor:

headline: Standards at CUNY
text: To the Editor:

headline: Special-Session Time, but to Whose Advantage?
text: Texas lawmakers are back for a special session that started the day after their 140-day regular session. That’s something like sprinting to the finish of a long race and having your coach yell, just as you break the tape, “One more lap.”

headline: An Environmental Horror Story
text: Thoroughly fed up but refusing to give in, the residents of the Coal River valley in West Virginia endure earsplitting explosions, raining boulders, toxic sludge and poisoned wells. Their tormentor is the union-busting, environmental-law-flouting Massey Energy Company and its use of the controversial mining strategy called mountaintop removal. Their solution is a grass-roots campaign to force the company to cease and desist, and Bill Haney’s furious documentary, “The Last Mountain,” is completely on board.

headline: A Welcome Mat for Builders
text: IN November 2007, a few months after Pat Meyersfield retired from the Great Neck school system, she and her husband, Sanford, drove through the North Fork visiting wineries, farm stands and model homes that in those days were popping up like clover in the midst of farm fields.

headline: The Suburban Side of Newark
text: NEWARK

headline: Legal Outsourcing Firms Creating Jobs for American Lawyers
text: Career prospects can look dim these days for young American lawyers.

headline: Analysis: Nadal vs. Murray, and a Matter of Aggressiveness
text: Andy Murray faces Rafael Nadal in Friday’s first French Open semifinal at Roland Garros. The two played a hugely entertaining match in early May in Monte Carlo, with Nadal prevailing in three sets. Murray is a shrewd tactician, a genius with the racket who can play with touch, power and variety. But he faces the top-seeded Nadal, who, as defending champion, appears to be playing better with each round.

headline: McIlroy Has Eyes on Bigger Issues Than Golf
text: DUBLIN, Ohio — It was a mundane question for the Memorial Tournament co-leader Rory McIlroy on Thursday — “What’s your plan leading up to the Open?” And it generated a response that shed much light on the values and social conscience of McIlroy, a 22-year-old from Northern Ireland.

headline: Coming Soon: A Town Within a City
text: YONKERS

headline: When the Seller Is the Lender
text: MORTGAGE underwriting is tight, and home sellers are anxious to unload properties into a stagnant market — it sounds as if it could be time to consider seller financing.

headline: Analysis: Schiavone Won by Playing Smart in the Wind
text: Francesca Schiavone played smart tennis in the wind to defeat Marion Bartoli in straight sets in a French Open semifinal Thursday at Roland Garros. Knowing that Bartoli thrives when she can control the middle of the court, where she drives double-fisted groundstrokes hard and flat into the corners, Schiavone used spin, height and placement to keep Bartoli off balance. The defending champion defended grittily, sliding on the clay to make Bartoli hit one more ball.

headline: Democrats Voice Support for Elizabeth Warren
text: A group of Democratic lawmakers urged President Obama on Thursday to appoint Elizabeth Warren to lead the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, a plea that further escalated the bitter partisan battle over the fledgling agency’s future.

headline: A Malibu Mystery, Washed in by the Tide
text: MALIBU, Calif. — Descending the steep cliffside steps to a slice of sand near Point Dume can feel like arriving on a deserted island. There are no cars as far as the eye can see, just a small tuck of shoreline accessible by foot — and only by those who are willing to follow a winding dirt path.

headline: The Dos and Don’ts of ‘I Do’
text: If there is a special hell for film critics, it probably has movies like “Love, Wedding, Marriage” on continuous rotation. A supposed romantic comedy with less romance — and significantly less comedy — than the instructions on a condom wrapper, this charmless clunker is the directing debut of the actor Dermot Mulroney. We can only hope that he isn’t planning to quit his day job.

headline: Captain Hannum Attends the Philippi Races
text: The sleepy hamlet of Philippi, nestled in the bucolic hills of western Virginia, awoke to bedlam on June 3, 1861. Early that morning, a federal force of about 3,000 in two columns converged on a camp of some 1,000 Confederates in what would be the first conventional engagement of the Civil War.

headline: A Direct Approach to Disaster Relief From Procter & Gamble
text: MANY companies have donated money and goods in the wake of the tornado that devastated Joplin, Mo., and left at least 138 people dead. But in addition to donating to disaster relief groups, Procter & Gamble, the consumer goods giant, is taking the unusual approach of providing disaster relief directly.

headline: Fighting Losing Battles Against Isolation
text: Fans of the guitarist-writer-actress Carrie Brownstein and her goofy television show, “Portlandia,” will need to adjust their expectations for “Some Days Are Better Than Others.” Starring Ms. Brownstein and another indie-music hero, James Mercer of the Shins, the film uses Portland and other Oregon locations (shot very prettily by Greg Schmitt) as a backdrop for neo-Depression anomie and darkly shaded melancholia.

headline: At 46, Bernard Hopkins Keeps Surviving, His Way
text: PHILADELPHIA — For his latest reinvention, Bernard Hopkins — street thug, convict, boxer, champion, retiree, champion again — wants to inspire aging athletes and spread the gospel of healthy living. Yes, that Bernard Hopkins. Once prisoner No. 44145.

headline: Banking and Bad Behavior
text: As expensive looking as any film about money ought to be, the Taiwanese historical melodrama “Empire of Silver” is rather an odd duck. (And not just because yes, that is indeed Jennifer Tilly in a supporting role.) Hovering somewhere between dryly factual base-touching and sails-to-the-wind dynastic extravagance, this weirdly engaging tale of banking and bad behavior makes 19th-century China look uncomfortably like 21st-century America.

headline: In Bay Area, Youngsters Are More Prone to Bicycle Accidents
text: For the Sorensen family of Alameda, the sound of knuckles rapping on the garage door was a familiar annoyance. It was their 13-year-old son, Brandon, who knocked on the door so frequently to put away his bicycle that his parents finally got him an access code to open the garage on his own.

headline: Companies May Face Rule to Shift Audit Firms
text: Publicly traded companies may be forced to change their audit firms after several years, the chief regulator of the industry said Thursday.

headline: The Mistake of 2010
text: Earlier this week, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York published a blog post about the “mistake of 1937,” the premature fiscal and monetary pullback that aborted an ongoing economic recovery and prolonged the Great Depression. As Gauti Eggertsson, the post’s author (with whom I have done research) points out, economic conditions today — with output growing, some prices rising, but unemployment still very high — bear a strong resemblance to those in 1936-37. So are modern policy makers going to make the same mistake?

headline: 25 More Cookbooks
text: ANCIENT GRAINS FOR MODERN MEALS. By Maria Speck. (Ten Speed Press, $29.99.) Mediterranean whole-grain recipes for barley, farro, kamut, polenta, wheat berries and more.

headline: Up Front: Sam Sifton
text: In the age of Google, it’s not that hard to find a photograph of Sam Sifton — but we’re not about to make his day job, as the restaurant critic of The New York Times, any more difficult by printing one here. (Besides, he tells us he’s taller now than in any extant picture, with much longer hair.)

headline: Additional Gardening Books
text: Inspired by Seattle Tilth, a community of “learning gardens,” Lisa Taylor’s YOUR FARM IN THE CITY: An Urban Dweller’s Guide to Growing Food and Raising Animals (Black Dog & Leventhal, paper, $18.95) includes helpful plant profiles and useful design ideas. For straightforward and lovely kitchen garden designs, along with helpful tips for companion plantings, consult Ellen Ecker Ogden’s COMPLETE KITCHEN GARDEN (Stewart, Tabori & Chang, paper, $24.95). Graham Kerr, of “Galloping Gourmet” fame, makes the most mouth-watering garden-to-table connection with simple, unpretentious recipes in GROWING AT THE SPEED OF LIFE: A Year in the Life of My First Kitchen Garden (Perigee, $27). And for those who neglected to sow beans in the spring, it’s not too late. With the guidance of the clear, concise instructions in Edward C. Smith’s VEGETABLE GARDENER’S CONTAINER BIBLE: How to Grow a Bounty of Food in Pots, Tubs and Other Containers (Storey, paper, $19.95), you can get a complete kitchen garden going. Just be prepared to do a lot of watering.

headline: Cookbooks
text: The lamb shakes rain from his wool, pea tendrils rise from the earth and a new yield of cookbooks arrives on bookstore shelves, ready for the fire. I worked with more than a dozen this spring, cooking like a summertime madman and considering sentences beautiful and lame. I read fantasy and prepared truth, imagined myself cooking in England and France, Mumbai and California, Italy, Spain, North Carolina, Georgia, Vancouver, Seoul. I made beautiful meals and terrible ones, found myself well instructed, poorly instructed, often coddled, sometimes lied to, perpetually amused.

headline: Gardening Books
text: The garden book jury has returned a verdict. You are either growing vegetables or you have become one. Attitude looms as large as artichokes. Unfortunately, the important book on how exactly to overhaul farms too big to fail has yet to be written — mainly because the standard wisdom is that they are, by definition, beyond hope of sustainability. But with over 300 million people in the United States, and with the global population approaching seven billion, most people will continue to depend for their meals on staggeringly large-scale agriculture. What’s to be done?

headline: Travel Books
text: Failed relationships, broken marriages and dead-end careers are among the catalysts that lead this season’s travel writers to hit the road. The escapees range from a middle-aged journalist seeking high-altitude transcendence in the Himalayas to a frustrated poetry scholar in search of beauty among the holy spots of Iran. And then there’s the global nomad torn between a longing for domestic tranquility and a masochistic impulse to throw himself into the world’s “messy heart.” This summer’s selection also includes authors driven by simple journalistic curiosity and academic inquiry, but it’s the more tortured souls whose journeys resonate the most.

headline: Fall of the Wild
text: GLEN ELLEN, Calif. — Dead at the age of 40, Jack London left behind more than 50 books produced by his fevered pen, a string of opinionated lovers and a Sonoma Valley ranch he described as heaven on earth.

headline: Antagonists Abound in the Initial Plot Line
text: Edmonton Oilers defenseman Ryan Whitney, at home in Boston, told a sports radio station Wednesday that the Vancouver Canucks were an easy team to hate.

headline: The Depravity Factor
text: By now you have probably heard about Hamza Ali al-Khateeb. He was the 13-year-old Syrian boy who tagged along at an antigovernment protest in the town of Saida on April 29. He was arrested that day, and the police returned his mutilated body to his family a month later. While in custody, he had apparently been burned, beaten, lacerated and given electroshocks. His jaw and kneecaps were shattered. He was shot in both arms. When his father saw the state of Hamza’s body, he passed out.

headline: Showdown on ‘Swipe Fees’ Likely Soon
text: The battle on Capitol Hill over capping “swipe fees,” the charges that banks collect from retailers when a customer makes a purchase with a debit card, could be approaching a final showdown.

headline: Hong Kong Looks to Regain Footing as I.P.O. Leader
text: HONG KONG — Is Hong Kong, the global leader for initial public offerings in 2009 and 2010, in danger of losing its coveted title this year?

headline: Japan’s Misguided Foreign Acquisitions
text: Japan Inc.’s latest mantra is that, with the domestic market shrinking, companies must hurry to make acquisitions abroad. But they should resist the temptation of international mergers and acquisitions adventurism. Creating more competitive enterprises through domestic consolidation would be better for the country in the long run — not to mention for shareholders, who are too often an afterthought in Japan.

headline: Living In | Ozone Park, Queens
text: The housing stock consists mainly of single- and two-family detached colonials on roomy lots; an architectural exception is Tudor Village.

headline: For Men, Shot at Final Is Just a Part of the Stakes
text: PARIS — The focus in men’s tennis has shifted at this Grand Slam tournament. For years, it has been on Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal, but this time — from practice courts to match day — the emphasis has been on the game’s third man turned essential man: Novak Djokovic.

headline: Syria Continues Attacks on Protesters While Calling for Dialogue
text: CAIRO — Syria’s military forces continued pressing to crush a three-month-old popular uprising on Thursday, shelling a string of southern and central towns even as Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton warned President Bashar al-Assad that his legitimacy had “nearly run out.”

headline: Chemicals in Farm Runoff Rattle States on the Mississippi
text: As the surging waters of the Mississippi pass downstream, they leave behind flooded towns and inundated lives and carry forward a brew of farm chemicals and waste that this year — given record flooding — is expected to result in the largest dead zone ever in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Battle For Libya | June 2, 2011
text: Libyan rebels went through military training in Benghazi before heading to the frontline.

headline: IPad Rivals Fail to Gain Traction, a Report Says
text: Technology companies who hoped to outdo the Apple iPad by offering alternate slate-like products are not seeing the demand they hoped for from consumers, according to an analyst’s report issued by JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Three Gorges Dam Is Said to Hurt Areas Downstream
text: CHONGQING, China — A Chinese official says the planners of the Three Gorges Dam failed to properly gauge its effects on lakes and other bodies of water downstream, according to a report on Thursday in Shanghai Daily, an English-language newspaper.

headline: Acquittal in D.W.I. Case That Was Test of Ticket-Fixing Issue
text: A personal-injury lawyer was found not guilty of drunken driving on Thursday in a trial in which jurors rejected the testimony of two police officers who admitted to fixing tickets in unrelated cases.

headline: Colonials, Tudors and, Soon, a Casino
text: A LOT has changed in Ozone Park, a neighborhood in southern Queens, since George Russo grew up there in the 1960s.

headline: N.H.L. Is Playing on Its Home Ice
text: There is nothing, absolutely nothing, like the sight of a red-coated Mountie to dress up the Stanley Cup finals, to make them official.

headline: Analysis: Djokovic Faces Federer, the Last Man to Beat Him
text: Novak Djokovic plays Roger Federer in a much-anticipated semifinal match Friday at Roland Garros. The last man to beat Djokovic was Federer, who handled the young Serb, 6-1, 6-4, in late November at the season-ending Masters.

headline: Heavy in School, Burdened for Life
text: MUCH of the debate about the nation’s obesity epidemic has focused, not surprisingly, on food: labeling requirements, taxes on sugary beverages and snacks, junk food advertisements aimed at children and the nutritional quality of school lunches.

headline: E-Mail Fraud Hides Behind Friendly Face
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Most people know to ignore the e-mail overture from a Nigerian prince offering riches in exchange for a bank account number. That is a scam, plain to the eye.

headline: Bloggingheads: Debating Divorce
text: Amanda Marcotte, left, of Pandagon and Michael Brendan Dougherty of The American Conservative debate America's culture of divorce.

headline: Hearts Beating Faster on High
text: THE morning after my date with Kenny, I could barely lift my arms to wash my hair. He had taken me to the High Line, where I spent an hour following his every command in front of total strangers.

headline: Iraq Arrests Seen as Effort to Squelch More Protests
text: BAGHDAD — Iraqi security forces arrested more than a dozen activists here over the past week in a sweep that rights groups called a pre-emptive strike to prevent a flickering reform movement from springing back to life.

headline: Insider Trial Opens With Focus on Expert Networks
text: Hiroko Masuike for The New York TimesOutside Federal District Court in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Collins Picks His Spots to Rant, but Doesn’t Hold Back
text: Terry Collins burst into the Mets’ clubhouse after a dreary loss and ripped into his players. He told them they needed to perform better and could not become deflated and give up when they fell behind in a game, as they just had. Minutes later, he repeated the message to reporters and said the team needed to go 9-2 over its next 11 games.

headline: Christie and G.O.P. Repay State for Helicopter Flights
text: DENVILLE, N.J. — Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey and the Republican Party reimbursed the state more than $3,300 on Thursday for his use of a police helicopter to travel to his son’s baseball games and to meet with political fund-raisers.

headline: Blagojevich, on Stand, Replies ‘Yes,’ He’s a Liar
text: CHICAGO — Prosecutors finally got the chance to question Rod R. Blagojevich, the ousted former governor of Illinois, in federal court here on Thursday in a combative cross-examination meant to show jurors that he was a liar.

headline: Best Sellers Weekly Graphic: E-No. 1
text: The titles that have held the top spot on the e-book best-seller lists since the The Times began publishing rankings of e-books in February.

text: A couple tore down a log cabin with little charm but lots of bats in favor of an airy home with porches overlooking woods and a stream.

headline: A Nimbler, More Energy-Efficient Marine Corps
text: Last year I wrote about how American troops sent into conflict zones were relying more on renewable energy and green products. In places like Afghanistan, fuel supply routes are extremely vulnerable to attacks, putting soldiers at risk when their cargo includes oil, diesel or kerosene-based fossil fuels.

headline: Incumbents Carve Out a New Congressional Map
text: During debate this week on Democrats’ remapping of Illinois congressional districts, criticized as heavily weighted against Republicans, Senate President John J. Cullerton hoisted a newspaper from 2001.

text: 9:21 p.m. | Updated

headline: House Tour: Milan, N.Y.
text: WHAT Three-bedroom house on five acres. A log cabin that had little charm and a lot of bats once stood where this house is now.

headline: A Heritage in Ruins
text: WITHIN a 40-minute drive of this city stands the 11th-century Bost Arch. A former gateway to Lashkar Gah, the capital of Helmand Province, the arch is today a national historic site; it even appears on the 100-afghani note. The arch withstood centuries of invasions, but today it’s a crumbling mess of inept supports and clumsy renovations.

headline: Dizzying Price for Seeking the Death Penalty
text: In the middle of February, 300 men and women of voting age answered a special summons for jury duty at the federal courthouse in Cadman Plaza in Brooklyn. They were ushered into a grand ceremonial courtroom to see if they might be candidates to serve as jurors in the case of the United States of America v. Vincent Basciano. His nom de mob is Vinny Gorgeous.

headline: House Sets Votes on Two Resolutions Critical of U.S. Role in Libyan Conflict
text: WASHINGTON — The House will vote Friday on two measures that are strongly critical of President Obama’s decision to maintain an American role in NATO operations in Libya, reflecting increasing disenchantment among elements of both parties about the United States’ involvement in the conflict.

headline: Groupon Plans I.P.O. With $30 Billion Valuation

headline: When States Punish Women
text: The Obama administration has rightly decided to reject a mean-spirited and dangerous Indiana law banning the use of Medicaid funds at Planned Parenthood clinics, which provide vital health services to low-income women.

headline: Chile: Inquiry Ordered in Poet’s Death
text: A Chilean judge has opened an investigation into the death of the country’s revered poet, Pablo Neruda, responding to allegations that he may have been poisoned just days after the 1973 coup, officials said Thursday. Mr. Neruda officially died of prostate cancer at 69 on Sept. 23, 1973, 12 days after the coup that toppled the government of his close friend, President Salvador Allende. But several witnesses, including Mr. Neruda’s longtime associate and driver, Manuel Araya, have raised questions about his death. Mr. Araya has said the poet was poisoned by agents of Chile’s dictator, Gen. Augusto Pinochet. The Pablo Neruda Foundation, which administers the poet’s estate, said there was no evidence to support Mr. Araya’s claim. Eduardo Contreras, a lawyer for the Communist Party, which requested the investigation, said that lawyers expect to request the exhumation of Mr. Neruda’s body.

headline: About That Precedent
text: It’s a rare day that a federal judge decides to revisit a decision the week after making it or that the Justice Department apologizes for failing to brief him on the crucial precedent. A re-do is clearly called for.

headline: A Toxic River Improves, but Still Has Far to Go
text: Thomas Simon remembers the day he found a carp in the Grand Calumet River in 1985, barely alive, bloody and with no fins. “It looked like someone had beaten it up,” said Mr. Simon, a biologist who studied the river for 26 years.

headline: Libya: Qatar Deports Dissident Woman
text: The Libyan woman whose mistreatment by the government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi made her a symbol of its brutality has been deported against her will from her temporary refuge in Qatar to the Libyan rebel stronghold of Benghazi. Eman al-Obeidi gained international attention in March when she told foreign journalists that she had been abducted and gang raped by Qaddafi militia. She was arrested, and later smuggled out of the country by a defecting soldier. She was in Qatar awaiting asylum elsewhere. A spokesman for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said she was deported Thursday by force and without explanation. A spokesman for the rebel authority in Benghazi said she was free to leave if she wanted.

headline: A Way to Pay for College, With Dividends
text: If you were a student looking for financing to pursue a degree in social science, would you accept an offer of $16,000, in exchange for paying 4.5 percent of your income for 10 years after you graduate?

headline: The High Cost of Cheap Meat
text: The point of factory farming is cheap meat, made possible by confining large numbers of animals in small spaces. Perhaps the greatest hidden cost is its potential effect on human health.

headline: Taking New Jersey for a Ride
text: Maybe Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey means it when he says that he isn’t running for president. No thinking presidential candidate — especially a Republican who wants to be known for ruthlessly cutting his state budget — would take a taxpayer-financed helicopter to his son’s baseball games. Nor would he use the State Police helicopter to rush to a meeting with Iowa business executives trying to recruit him to run for president.

headline: Russia: Charges in Reporter’s Killing
text: Russia’s investigative committee announced Thursday that it had enough evidence to prove that Rustam Makhmudov, a fugitive arrested in Chechnya on Tuesday, was hired to kill the journalist Anna Politkovskaya. He has been charged with her 2006 murder, and with kidnapping and extortion related to cases from the 1990s, prosecutors said. Murad Musayev, a lawyer who has represented Mr. Makhmudov’s family, said this week that Mr. Makhmudov had nothing to do with the crime and has long sought to turn himself in and cooperate with investigators.

headline: Yankees Say Rodriguez’s Cousin Has Not Violated Restrictions
text: Hardly anyone knew who Yuri Sucart was until February 2009, when Alex Rodriguez implicated an unnamed cousin as his steroid provider and that cousin was subsequently identified as Sucart.

headline: Fighting Litter in Brooklyn by Getting Rid of the Litter Baskets
text: New Yorkers angry about trash on their sidewalks tend to propose the obvious solutions: more litter baskets at more corners, more frequent collection, harsher fines for violators.

headline: A Siren Song on Casinos, With Emanuel in Tune
text: Eschewing Nobel Prize economists, I left analysis of the legislature’s approval of a kudzu-like growth of casino gambling to an actor-comedian who loves Chicago and works Las Vegas.

headline: In District, Puzzled by Weiner’s Uncertainty on Photo
text: Eran Ribak just does not understand how Representative Anthony D. Weiner could not recognize whether the man in the gray boxer briefs was him or not.

headline: U.S. Calls Antibiotics Wrong Step on E. Coli
text: There are few things more frightening in the world of food safety than becoming infected with the kind of toxic strain of E. coli that has sickened more than 1,500 people in Germany and beyond, but public health officials in the United States caution that the bacteria is not as scary as some reports suggest.

headline: As Missouri River Rises, Control Efforts Take Shape
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Adding to an already brutal season of flooding, another major waterway — this time, the Missouri River — is rising because of record rain and snow, meaning major flooding is likely from the headwaters in Montana to where it flows into the still-swollen Mississippi River.

text: June 2, 2011

headline: On the Maddeningly Inexact Relationship Between Unemployment and Re-Election
text: Make no mistake: the higher the unemployment rate in November 2012, the less likely President Obama is to win a second term.

headline: A Trader, an F.B.I. Witness, and Then a Suicide
text: In a Manhattan courtroom last week, federal prosecutors played for a jury a secretly recorded telephone conversation between two Wall Street traders exchanging stock tips.

headline: Friday: Do Stuff
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — This being Friday, we have no theme to talk about, so let’s focus on some individual entries and the reasons why I’m so entertained by them. Your mileage may vary, as always, but I thought this puzzle was a lot of fun.

headline: Court Lets City Restrict Church Use of Schools
text: New York City may again block religious groups from using school facilities outside of regular school hours for “religious worship services,” a federal appeals court in Manhattan ruled on Thursday.

headline: Romney, Opening Race, Presents Himself as the Candidate to Face Obama
text: STRATHAM, N.H. — Formally offering himself as a candidate for the presidency for a second time, Mitt Romney sought Thursday to look past the primary challenges of the next 12 months, portraying the choice for voters as one between himself and President Obama.

headline: As Mayor Holds Firm on Teacher Layoffs, Some See Reasons Beyond Money
text: Last month, in the days after Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled a budget calling for the elimination of 6,100 teaching jobs, most through layoffs, veterans of City Hall politics assumed his aggressive stance was about more than just closing the budget gap.

headline: Weekend Miser
text: It’s a perfect weekend for lovers of all things independent, with Rooftop Films bringing together indie bands, movies from the South by Southwest festival and a new documentary about the controversial makeover of the Atlantic Yards.

headline: U.S. to Sell Its Chrysler Stake to Fiat
text: DETROIT — The Treasury Department on Thursday said it reached a deal to sell its stake in Chrysler to Fiat for $500 million. The move would end the government’s involvement in Chrysler but still leave taxpayers about $1.3 billion short of recovering their full investment in the carmaker.

headline: Georgia: Suit Challenges Immigration Law
text: Several civil rights groups filed a class-action lawsuit on Thursday against a new Georgia law that authorizes the police to inquire about the immigration status of anyone they stop and in practice requires everyone in the state, including United States citizens, to carry documents verifying their status. The federal suit was brought by the American Civil Liberties Union and the Southern Poverty Law Center, among other organizations, against the law, which is scheduled to take effect July 1. One plaintiff, Paul Bridges, a Republican who is mayor of the small farming town of Uvalda, said he feared he could be criminally prosecuted for transporting residents who are illegal immigrants to the doctor or the grocery store.

headline: Wal-Mart to Test Small Store Format
text: GENTRY, Ark. — The neighborhood grocer could soon face some competition.

headline: Adolfas Mekas, Avant-Garde Filmmaker and Teacher, Is Dead at 85
text: Adolfas Mekas, a Lithuanian immigrant who became an influential avant-garde filmmaker and teacher and who, with his brother Jonas, founded Film Culture, the seminal journal for cinéastes, died on Tuesday in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. He was 85.

headline: A Soda Fountain Where Artifacts Tend to Drift in. (The Customers, Too.)
text: Wyoming’s symbol is the bucking cowboy, but the tumbling tumbleweed works, too, especially in thinking about the strange journey of the Chugwater Soda Fountain. Pieces of the place — the wood bar, the soda-making machinery, who knows, maybe even Wendell the Elk up there mounted on the wall — all drifted in and got lodged, as though caught by a windbreak in this wisp of a town of 244, about 45 miles north of Cheyenne.

headline: A G.O.P. Legislator Ardently Conservative, God-Fearing and Not a Team Player
text: He bowed his head, tightly shut his eyes and pressed his index finger to his lips, waiting and praying for the Texas Senate to approve one of his biggest priorities of his freshman legislative session: a measure that would apply criminal penalties to federal airport security agents who conduct intrusive pat downs.

headline: Clarice Taylor Dies at 93; TV’s Cosby Called her Mom
text: Clarice Taylor, an actress who was best known as the endearing, self-possessed grandmother on “The Cosby Show” and who also won an Obie Award for her Off Broadway portrayal of the vaudeville comedienne Moms Mabley, died on Monday at her home in Englewood, N.J. She was 93.

text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Solar-Power Incentives Get Results but Are Rare
text: Corky Hilliard mounted 19 solar panels atop her Austin home last month and expects to pay less than $4,500 — about a quarter of the initial cost estimate.

headline: A Quarterly Designed to Tweak All Senses
text: The actor James Franco crouched over a table, his neck bowed in deep concentration. Mr. Franco had come to a tiny 400-square-foot storefront in the Mission district to commemorate the passing of a friend. But this was no funeral. It was the latest installment of The Thing, a quarterly publication that Mr. Franco was guest editing.

headline: A Memorial Divides Survivors
text: At a recent dedication ceremony for a Peoples Temple memorial in Oakland, Kathy Barbour, a survivor of the 1978 massacre, knelt on the lawn of Evergreen Cemetery to look at photos of the victims of Jonestown.

text: For children in blighted neighborhoods, going to college can seem an impossible goal, especially when just making it through grade school is a challenge.

headline: Nowitzki Pulls Dallas Out of Hole to New Life
text: MIAMI — The Dallas Mavericks reached the N.B.A. finals as a team of finite ability, but infinite lives. As long as they relied on their only superstar, Dirk Nowitzki, with his steady confidence and sturdy jumper, no deficit was so steep that it could not be overcome — no matter how late in the game.

text: gauche •\ˈgosh\• adjective

headline: Pedestrian, 89, Is Killed in Upper Manhattan
text: An 89-year-old woman was killed in Upper Manhattan on Thursday when a pickup truck involved in a chain-reaction crash smashed into a crowd of pedestrians, the police said.

headline: Hand-to-Hand Combat
text: The Seaside Courts in Coney Island have some of the best handball action in the world, and some great betting action, too.

headline: Fighting in Gaza Continues
text: Israel continued its airstrikes against Hamas for a sixth day, killing a senior leader of the radical Islamic group and two of his wives and four children.

headline: A Geographer Pushes Climate Panel and Academia to Reach Out
text: Edward Carr, a geographer at the University of South Carolina, took umbrage last year when the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change urged him and more than 800 other authors contributing to the next batch of climate assessments by the group to “keep a distance from the media.” (That same mailing included a three-page brochure prepared by consultants that, among other things, advised the scientists not to use terms including uncertainty, risk and significant. “To avoid the risk of being misunderstood, avoid them,” the scientists were advised.)

headline: Woman, 89, Killed When Truck Hits Crowd in Harlem
text: An 89-year-old woman was killed on Thursday and three other pedestrians injured when a pickup truck hit a livery car and caromed onto the sidewalk at the corner of West 145th Street and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard in Harlem, the police said. The livery-car driver was also injured.

text: A look at the day in sports, from Lionel Messi in Argentina to the N.B.A. finals.

text: South Asian immigrants have brought their love of cricket to the city of Rome, where an amateur tournament is now in its third year.

headline: Bowlers and Batsmen Signal a Demographic Shift in an Eternal City
text: ROME — On a sunny recent Sunday in a playing field on the outskirts of the city, the sounds of cheering could be heard. “Come on, come on, come on!” someone shouted in Italian from the sidelines to a player scrambling on the slightly overgrown field. “Wake up!” another cried.

headline: News Quiz | June 3, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

text: Fighting rages on in Yemen.

headline: Rihanna Speaks Out About Violent ‘Man Down’ Video
text: Rihanna defended the video for her song “Man Down” on Thursday night during a telephone interview on the BET program “106 & Park,” saying that she did not intend to cause controversy but wanted to create “art with a message.”

headline: Test Yourself | History, June 3, 2011
text: Test your knowledge of history with today’s question about the history of China.

headline: Mladic Refuses to Enter Plea at War Crimes Tribunal
text: THE HAGUE — For years Ratko Mladic impressed friends and foes with his barking voice and commanding presence. But in the dock on Friday, he seemed much diminished — the swagger gone, his speech slurred, the feared warrior now an infirm and elderly man.

headline: A New York Times First: Female Executive Editor
