headline: How Do You Feel About Proms?
text: Does your school have a prom? Will you be going? If you’re going, what are you wearing, and about how much do you expect to spend? How do you feel about formal school dances in general? Why?

headline: China Faces ‘Very Grave’ Environmental Situation, Officials Say
text: BEIJING — China’s three decades of rapid economic growth have left it with a “very grave” environmental situation even as it tries to move away from a development-at-all-costs strategy, senior government officials said on Friday.

headline: Four Killed in Explosion at Chevron Refinery in Britain
text: LONDON — A storage tank exploded at a British oil refinery owned by Chevron, killing four workers and seriously injuring another, officials said Friday.

headline: Ending Myanmar Visit, McCain Urges Democratic Reform
text: BANGKOK — Ending a three-day visit to Myanmar, Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, warned the country’s leaders that “the winds of change” now blowing in the Middle East could spread if governments do not listen to the needs of their people.

headline: A Lively Look Back on ‘Back in the Days’
text: Not an ounce of energy has drained from “Back in the Days,” Jamel Shabazz‘s photo chronicle of the early days of hip-hop style, since it was published in 2001. Those who still remember its release might be amazed to learn that a decade has since gone by; reason enough for powerHouse Books to bring it out again, in an expanded edition, as “Back in the Days: Remix.” (Why not? They sold 35,000 copies the first time.)

headline: At Greenwich Concours, Hybrids of a Different Genus
text: The summer collector-car season is off to a clutch-dropping burnout of a start. At a Mecum auction in Indianapolis two weeks ago, $50 million in muscle cars changed hands. While there won’t be any Hemi ‘Cudas ripping up the pristine lawns at the Greenwich Concours d’Élégance this weekend, plenty of Chrysler Hemi power and other examples of Detroit V-8 muscle will be present, as the concours prominently features postwar European cars with American engines.

headline: The Virtues of Investing in Transportation
text: Laura D’Andrea Tyson is a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley, and served as chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Clinton. She currently serves on President Obama’s Council on Jobs and Competitiveness and its infrastructure subgroup.

headline: June 4-June 7: Top Matches
text: With the end of seasons in Europe, attention in some of the soccer world turns to North America (until the start of Copa América in Argentina), where the annual pilgrimage of top national and club teams begins with the World Cup champion Spain raising the curtain on two months of notable exhibitions.

headline: The Early Word: Warning
text: From Today’s Times:

headline: Despite Criticism, Berlin Art Festival Arrives
text: When Based in Berlin, an art festival running June 8 to July 24 at a handful of venues around the city, was first announced at the end of last year, it was dubbed a Leistungsschau — “an exhibit of achievement” — for young Berlin artists, complete with a citywide open call. The city had allotted about 1.4 million euros (about $2 million) to the exhibition.

headline: Tip of the Week: Seeing the Forest for the Windows
text: Need to find a certain open window on your desktop — but you cannot fully see it in the clutter of other open windows on the screen? Both Windows 7 and Mac OS X include features that help you focus quickly on the one window you need to find.

headline: A Turning Point for the East Village, 20 Years Later
text: When the city of New York built a band shell near the southern end of Tompkins Square Park in 1966, it was quickly embraced by people who began using it for concerts, rallies and poetry readings. Twenty-five years later, after police and protesters battled during a Memorial Day concert in the park, city officials closed it for renovations that lasted more than a year and included the destruction of the band shell.

headline: Reaching Your Limit as a Business Owner
text: I remember the day I reached my limit with the retail coffee and espresso business that my husband and I started in 2003. When we started our little food service venture, it was supposed to be a fun project that would eventually run itself and act as an additional source of income for our household. But after three years, two locations and countless hours, it became evident that our plan was easier said than done.

headline: Bodies Recovered After Migrants’ Boat Founders
text: PARIS — The Tunisian authorities have recovered the bodies of 150 refugees, mostly sub-Saharan Africans, who drowned after their boat foundered this week in the Mediterranean Sea, a United Nations official said Friday, but up to 120 refugees were still missing.

headline: Nadal Beats Murray to Reach Finals
text: PARIS — Rafael Nadal of Spain defeated Andy Murray of Great Britain, 6-4, 7-5, 6-4, to reach the final round of the French Open Friday, giving him a chance to win a sixth crown at Roland Garros.

headline: Good News, and Bad, About Community Services
text: Five years ago, the first edition of “The Maturing of America,” a report undertaken by the National Association of Area Agencies on Aging with groups representing local governments and city planners, found that most communities hadn’t begun to plan for the tidal shifts of the coming years. The proportion of people older than 65 is expected to swell from 13 percent of the nation’s population today to nearly 20 percent by 2030.

headline: The Woman With Creeping Paralysis
text: SYMPTOMSA 50-year-old woman came to the emergency room at St. Mary’s Hospital in Waterbury, Conn., with severe tooth pain. After several hours she was sent home with a painkiller and an antibiotic to treat a presumed dental abscess. The pills didn’t help. Two days later, the woman awoke in excruciating pain. It felt as if a knife were being plunged into her tooth, her jaw, her face. She called her son, but as soon as she began to tell him how terrible the pain was, he cut her off: “Ma, why are you talking like that?” Her words were slurred, as if she were having a hard time getting them out of her mouth. Hang up, he told her; then he called 911.

headline: Five-Ku: Short Poems on the Films of Brad Pitt
text: “Thelma and Louise”: Your abs alone deserved aStar on Walk of Fame. Moral of “Se7en”:When a psycho sends FedExNever sign for it.

headline: In Israel, a Soccer Game Reflects a Divide
text: It’s 10 minutes before game time, and the police lined up outside the entrances of Doha Stadium aren’t letting anyone in. If Bnei Sakhnin, the only Arab-Israeli team in Israel’s first division, loses today, the club will drop to the second division, an ignominious distinction, the equivalent of going from the major to minor leagues in baseball.

headline: How Football Players Got Trounced by ‘Glee’
text: You can’t blame NBC for thinking that it had a winner on its hands when “Friday Night Lights” had its premiere in 2006. The football drama translated the nostalgia and longing of small-town existence into moments of surprising sweetness and grace, while embracing dramatic improvisation and documentary-style camera work that placed this naturally humble tale at the stylistic forefront of TV. And it did this in the service of its central story, which, along with dissecting the harsh continual sorting of winner from loser in American life, thoughtfully explored 1) the little triumphs and defeats of high school; 2) the perils of striving for an egalitarian marriage; 3) the trials of young love; 4) the charms and flaws of a small town; 4) the charms and flaws of people who live in small towns; and 5) the uncertain futures of young people with big (and often delusional) dreams.

headline: A Theory of Conspiracy Theories
text: Dear Mr. Keller: Last night on the “PBS NewsHour,” they had a story about some Los Angeles Times reporters who uncovered corruption in a nearby, small city in California. The newspaper eventually received a Pulitzer Prize. That is what you can have if you will talk with me. Within one hour, I will convince you and your staff that Lee Oswald did not assassinate President Kennedy. Then, I will give you the evidence for the real killers, and how the cover up could be perpetrated. It is a great story, fully documented and supported with facts, many from the Warren Commission itself!!

headline: Barbara Sinatra’s Way
text: In your new book, “Lady Blue Eyes,” you describe one of your earliest visits to Frank Sinatra’s Palm Springs home, when you were still married to his neighbor, Zeppo Marx. You were keeping time for a charades game, and when you called time on Sinatra, he grabbed a clock from your hands and smashed it against a door. You never thought, Wow, getting involved with this man might be dangerous?  I never felt danger around him. He was always very much a gentleman, and he really cared about treating me well. He came from Hoboken, where the streets were very tough. I guess some of that came back when he was drinking.

headline: Lesson Lent
text: My daughter-in-law’s parents “forgot” to make payments on the $17,000 loan they took out for her college 14 years ago, when she was 19. Now they owe $40,000, and their tax refunds and Social Security are being garnished. Her parents are of limited means. My son is not, but he and my daughter-in-law believe that this is a problem of her parents’ own making (through mismanagement of money, gambling and not working as much as they could) and the debt is their responsibility. What do you think? J.G., BOCA RATON, FLA.

headline: Who, What and Where is Bon Iver?
text: Even by Kanye West standards, the Bowery Ballroom show last November was a spectacle. West had chosen the tiny club for a surprise concert, celebrating the release of “My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy,” and it didn’t take long for the scrum outside to get ugly. Having tickets, which went on sale that day and sold out instantly, didn’t guarantee entry. The line stretched around the corner, and for most people, that’s as far as they got. Even those who made it inside — rappers, models, record-company executives, Diddy, Spike Lee, ordinary fans with the good fortune to have shown up very early — had to endure an hours-long wait.

headline: Wednesday Night Is All Right for Loving
text: Love is blind. Of course it is. Still, there’s no reason to believe that there aren’t legitimate, data-driven ways to improve your dating life. So I recently joined up with Christian Rudder of OkCupid, a matchmaking site that takes a playful attitude toward the data it collects (like which camera takes the most successful profile photos). I asked Rudder if there was a way to determine which days of the week — and which times of day — are the best to meet someone at a bar. What he came up with is something called the “sexual availability index.”

headline: Whole-Life Premium
text: Lacy, the auto-insurance agent, transfers me.

headline: Bulb In, Bulb Out
text: Over the past few years, in conditions of strict secrecy, a multinational team of scientists has been making a mighty effort to change the light bulb. The prototype they’ve developed is four inches tall, with a familiar tapered shape, and unlighted, it resembles a neon yellow mushroom. Screw it in and switch it on, though, and it blazes with a voluptuous radiance. It represents what people within the lighting industry often call their holy grail, an invention that reproduces the soft luminance of the incandescent bulb — Thomas Edison’s century-old technology — but conforms to much higher standards of energy efficiency and durability. The prototype is supposed to last for more than 22 years, maybe as long as you own your house, so you won’t need to stock up at the supermarket. And that’s fortunate, because one day very soon, traditional incandescent bulbs won’t be available in stores anymore. They’re about to be effectively outlawed.

headline: In Defense of the Slow and the Boring
text: WHAT is boring? This question was inspired by a piece in the May 1 edition of The New York Times Magazine by Dan Kois that offered a cheerful conformist’s take on what in certain circles is sometimes termed slow cinema and that he simply finds boring, the equivalent of eating his “cultural vegetables.” Mr. Kois writes that he knows he’s supposed to embrace celebrated films that he variously describes as “slow-moving, meditative” and “stately, austere” and “deliberately paced.” But he can’t, won’t, doesn’t like or understand them. In this he empathizes with his 6-year-old daughter, Lyra, who, at a friend’s urging, tuned into “Phineas and Ferb,” a TV show that she doesn’t fully get but watches “aspirationally, as a sort of challenge to herself.”

headline: Defiant Showman Demands His ‘Wow’
text: MONTREAL — With a wolfish grin, mangled pinky and a bald head shaped like a bullet, Guy Laliberté, a co-founder and the owner of Cirque du Soleil, looks like a man with a plan for world domination. Appearances, in this case, do not deceive.

headline: E. Coli Source Remains a Mystery as Death Toll Rises
text: BERLIN — German health experts sought without immediate success on Friday to identify the source of a strain of E .coli spreading alarm through Europe, which international officials have described as a “super toxic” variant of the infection.

headline: Campaign Catch-Up: The Republican Candidates
text: The 2012 presidential campaign is picking up steam, and it can be hard to follow all of the candidates and potential candidates. So The Caucus has a roundup of what they’ve all been up to.

headline: Friday Reading: Why Obesity Can Affect Economic Success
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Sketching a New Home for the Buffalo
text: Got a flair for graphic design and a passion for buffalo? The Interior Department has an assignment for you.

headline: Hiring in U.S. Slowed in May With 54,000 Jobs Added
text: After several months of strong job growth, hiring in the United States slowed sharply in May, suggesting the economy may be running out of steam once again.

headline: Extra! Extra! Lindeberg Has Landed!
text: It’s big news when the Swedish import Johan Lindeberg, former C.E.O. of Diesel and creator of the popular J. Lindeberg label, celebrates a new project. His vowel-free clothing line, BLK DNM, a well-edited collection of downtown must-haves for men and women (available at us.blkdnm.com),  will soon have a temporary home at Pop 1 in SoHo, starting June 8.

headline: Suicide Bombers Attack a Mosque and a Hospital in Iraqi City
text: BAGHDAD — Violence erupted north of Baghdad on Friday as a suicide bomber attacked at a mosque, and then several hours later another suicide bomber attacked the hospital where the wounded were being treated.

headline: Yemeni President Wounded in Palace Attack
text: WASHINGTON — The embattled president of Yemen, Ali Abdullah Saleh, narrowly survived an attack on the presidential palace Friday morning when an explosion wounded him and a half-dozen other government officials in a brazen strike sure to intensify Yemen’s bloody civil conflict.

headline: Dr. Jack Kevorkian Dies at 83; A Doctor Who Helped End Lives
text: Dr. Jack Kevorkian, the medical pathologist who willfully helped dozens of terminally ill people end their lives, becoming the central figure in a national drama surrounding assisted suicide, died on Friday in Royal Oak., Mich. He was 83.

headline: Shares Drop on Weak Monthly Jobs Report
text: Stocks on Wall Street slumped on Friday after a disappointing monthly government jobs report showed that hiring in the United States slowed in May, sending both the Dow and the broader market down to their fifth consecutive weekly loss.

headline: Keep My Boldface Name Out of It
text: WAS that Lady Gaga touring a penthouse at the Soho Mews in what looked like a bra and panties? Yes, it was. But, a broker joked, the apartment had too many windows and so she didn’t buy there. Instead, it was Justin Timberlake who took the place.

headline: Big Deal | A Castle, in Yonkers, on the Market for $4.95 Million
text: Kohle Yohannan is a writer, but he is often at a loss for words when he tries to describe the house he recently decided to sell.

headline: An Early Celebration Leaves the Heat With a Game 2 Hangover
text: MIAMI — Eleven months later, LeBron James and Dwyane Wade are still being pilloried for their prancing. The two hyper-scrutinized Miami Heat stars cannot pump a fist, high a five or otherwise show elation without a quick backlash.

headline: What A Drag
text: From Goldman Sachs, an estimate of the federal budget impact on growth. The gray line shows the direct impact, the blue line includes the induced “multiplier” effects. Notice that this shows the rate of change, not the level effects. I explained the difference a while back.

headline: The American Way
text: From First Draft:

headline: Libyan Dissident Says She Was Beaten in Qatar During Forced Deportation
text: As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reported, on Thursday Qatar forcibly deported a Libyan woman whose mistreatment by the government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi made her a symbol of its brutality.

headline: Liquidity Preference and Loanable Funds, Still (Wonkish)
text: More than two years have passed since the big debate over the effect of budget deficits on interest rates in a liquidity trap. The original argument of the anti-stimulus types was that large-scale government borrowing would drive up interest rates even in the face of high unemployment, and that this would hurt the economy. At that time the argument was framed in terms of simple crowding out, not solvency. And I argued that the whole thing represented a failure to understand basic macroeconomics.

headline: We Want Your Travel Questions
text: Do you have a question about an upcoming trip? Looking for information on where to go? You’ve come to the right place. For our regular Q&A column, which appears both on this blog and in our print section, we want your questions about travel. Post them below, or e-mail them to travmail@nytimes.com. (A tip: be specific, but not too specific. And ask ahead of time — if you are hoping to travel next week, it’s probably too late.)

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: The Logic in Refusing to Block Massey’s Sale
text: Stuart Grant, one of the name partners of the law firm Grant & Eisenhofer, is mad.

headline: As Styles of Handball Clash, Two High-School Stars Are Disqualified
text: The finer points of street handball, unlike other youth sports, are not learned from camps and coaches and clinics, but from pickup games on hot concrete courts around the city. There is no professional league to aspire to; college scholarships are rare.

headline: Robert Redford, Mr. Nice Guy
text: We all like to count among our friends principled people who are serious about their chosen profession and dedicated to working toward the greater good. But do we want to read about them? That’s the uphill battle fought by Michael Feeney Callan in his meticulous, tiptoeingly respectful “Robert Redford: The Biography,” which covers in detail Redford’s four-decade acting career, his emergence as a director and his dedication to environmental causes. Redford is also, of course, the founder of the Sundance Institute, established in 1981 to help independent filmmakers polish their skills and bring their work to a wider audience; in 1985 he expanded the Sundance empire by taking over the United States Film and Video Festival, thereafter known as the Sundance Film Festival.

headline: How Obama Loses
text: I didn’t care much for Mitt Romney’s speech yesterday announcing his presidential bid. It struck me as vintage Romney, by which I mean it resembled a somewhat tin-eared consultant’s idea of the kind of political speech right-wing primary voters want to hear. (Okay, now the anti-European boilerplate: “The President seems to take his inspiration not from the small towns and villages of New Hampshire but from the capitals of Europe.” Now the hyperbole: “We are only inches away from ceasing to be a free market economy.”  Now the completely non-specific promises to cut spending: “I will cap federal spending at 20% or less of the GDP and finally, finally balance the budget.” Now the clunky one-liner: “You know, if you want to create jobs, it helps to have had a job.” Now wait for the applause …)

headline: SmartyPig Cuts Interest Rates Yet Again
text: It’s official: After cutting its interest rate for the third time in nearly nine months, SmartyPig’s rates are no longer the most attractive in the land of online savings accounts. The spectacled Pig is merely average.

headline: Assessing the Value of Owning Dividend-Paying Stocks
text: THE first security I was ever aware of was a dividend-paying stock, the AT&T shares that my grandfather, a retired postman, owned when I was little. Those shares along with some other dividend-paying stocks formed the foundation of his nest egg. By reinvesting his dividends, he was able to amass sizable savings for someone who probably never earned more than $20,000 a year.

headline: What Dick Van Dyke and Barbara Eden Wrought
text: In the snowy cathode days before cable TV, let alone niche channels like Nick at Nite or TV Land, misshapen UHF antennas and God-forsaken rabbit ears pulled in, if you were lucky, three networks and a handful of independent stations. The latter broadcast an era-and-mind-scrambling mixture of reruns — a daily delirium wherein “The Honeymooners” might rub shoulders with “The Avengers,” “The Rifleman” was just a shot away from “That Girl,” and a mad parade of castaways, cowboys, talking ­horses, detectives, bewitching witches, doctors, avuncular Martians, fugitives and flying nuns followed “Route 66” straight into “The Twilight Zone.”

headline: Edwards Charged With Election Finance Fraud
text: John Edwards, the former Democratic senator from North Carolina and nominee for vice president in 2004, was once one of his party’s most promising young stars. But on Friday he found himself in a stunning fall from grace — in a courtroom in North Carolina, being read his rights.

headline: A Daughter Remembers Cary Grant
text: When Jennifer Grant was born, in 1966, a 62-year-old Cary Grant retired from movies to concentrate on fatherhood. Following a divorce from Jennifer’s mother, Dyan Cannon, soon after, he began keeping an actual vault of photographs, audiotapes, Super 8 films and meticulously labeled aides-­mémoires of and for his only child. Jennifer Grant’s stream-of-consciousness hagiography offers glimpses of this material, along with a torrent of filial piety.

headline: Indictment Shows Six Counts Against Edwards
text: John Edwards, the former senator from North Carolina and presidential candidate, was indicted Friday morning by a grand jury in Raleigh on charges that he violated campaign finance law during his 2008 presidential campaign.

headline: Paramount Pictures, From the Peak
text: In 1967, when the lumbering old Hollywood studios were about to be shaken up by independent, visionary filmmakers, Peter Bart left his job as a New York Times reporter to become Paramount Pictures’ No. 2 production executive. “Infamous Players,” Bart’s breezy, anecdotal account of his eight years at the studio, casts him as the level-headed Sancho Panza to his pal, the production head Robert Evans, who comes across as a risk-taking, eventually cocaine-fueled Don Quixote. Together they led Paramount out of the dark ages of big-budget disasters like “Darling Lili” into the glorious, cutting-edge era of “The Godfather,” “Rosemary’s Baby” and “Chinatown.”

headline: The Commentariat Candidate
text: Jonathan Chait thinks Paul Ryan will run for president, and that he might well be the Republican nominee. Interesting point. On the surface, it seems crazy: Ryan’s budget plan is, after all, both spectacularly bad policy and spectacularly bad politics. But Ryan may have a secret weapon: despite everything, much of the punditocracy (myself obviously not included) still has a crush on him.

headline: Metropolitan Museum Raising Suggested Admission Fee
text: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, facing what it calls a “number of daunting, ongoing budgetary challenges,” has decided to raise its suggested admission fee to $25, from $20, where it has been set for the last five years. The change takes effect July 1.

headline: A Chronicler of the Art-Vandal Underground
text: In the windy darkness of a recent spring morning, 30 people of an arty, mostly Brooklynite persuasion gathered after midnight for an illicit get-together in a maintenance shed, high atop the Williamsburg Bridge. Billed as the “Third-Annual NYC Undercover, You-Might-Be-Arrested, Clandestine Errantry Trespassing Adventure Party,” the event attracted members of a distinct, risk-taking subset of the New York art world — heights-loving writers, courageous painters, a devil-may-care guitarist, a guy lugging bongos and the Williamsburg photographer, Tod Seelie — all of whom had been quietly invited to the late-night affair by its pseudonymous organizers, Agent Verde and Agent Rojo.

headline: Restaurant Critic Sam Sifton on New Cookbooks; An Overview of Books on Gardening; Best-Seller news
text: This week, Times restaurant critic Sam Sifton discusses new cookbooks coming out this season; Dominique Browning with an overview of books on gardening; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. The Book Review's Senior Editor, Alex Star is the host this week.

headline: Federer Beats Darkness and Djokovic to Reach Finals
text: PARIS -– Roger Federer defeated Novak Dokovic, 7-6, 6-3, 3-6, 7-6, to reach the finals of the French Open Friday and snap Djokovic’s winning streak of 43 consecutive matches dating to last year.

headline: Fears, and Opportunities, on the Road to Retirement
text: I’M not near retirement age — nor am I sure I ever will be — but I do feel as if I’m being inundated with conflicting messages about aging.

headline: Not Your Brother’s Circus: Cirque du Soleil Prepares for Return to New York
text: The first time I saw Cirque du Soleil was in Washington in the early 1990s and it was like no circus I had ever seen. There were no lumbering animals or clown cars. These performers were whimsical, the mood oddly dreamlike and, in between the death-defying acrobatics, there were moments of minor-key theatrical grace.I loved it.

headline: Donnie Walsh Is Leaving the Knicks
text: In a surprising twist, the Knicks announced late Friday morning that Donnie Walsh would be leaving his post as team president when his contract expires at the end of this month. The team characterized Walsh’s exit as by mutual agreement between him and the team’s principal owner, James L. Dolan.

headline: Child Safety Seats With a Racing Pedigree
text: You have to wonder why nobody thought of this before.

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘Storytelling’
text: Today’s poem, chosen from more than 650 submissions to our Found Poem Student Challenge, comes from Samantha, who is 16 and lives in Beacon Falls, Connecticut.

headline: Still Captivated by Bob Dylan
text: He arrived on the scene in the 1960s, nowhere near fully formed, but aware of his talent and ready to go to work. He may not have considered himself a member of the counterculture in those days, but he found his audience among its number. He was nimble and unsentimental. He did not hesitate to move on to other interests, other sounds, while many of his first admirers seemed stuck in place. Now in his seventh decade, Greil Marcus still writes with the almost foolish enthusiasm of a young person, and when he takes on Bob Dylan, who inspired him to become a writer, he is at his most alive.

headline: Cookbooks in Review
text: The New York Times Book Review‘s “Summer Reading” issue is out this week, and I did my part for the Diner’s Journal crowd with a round-up review of a dozen or so summer cookbook titles. Take a look at it, and then bring your thoughts back here to our burgeoning community of the food obsessed.

headline: Death of Israeli Tycoon Is Latest Twist in Scandal
text: JERUSALEM — Sammy Ofer, an 89-year-old Israeli shipping tycoon whose company is at the center of a storm over alleged dealings with Iran, died after an illness on Friday. It was the latest twist in a saga that has riveted Israelis and stirred furious speculation about possible links between wealth, power and Israeli intrigue.

headline: The Life and Times of Metallica and Queen
text: There is no such thing as a happy rock band. With the inexplicable exception of U2 — who have, to all appearances, somehow remained on good terms, from band practice in high school to sold-out stadiums in middle age — virtually every group of note either crashes and burns or struggles through hard times to reach a grudging business agreement that keeps them working.

headline: Taking a Baseball Bat to Your Child’s Cellphone
text: The latest viral parenting video show an irate father destroying his daughter’s cellphone after apparently finding some “sexts” sent by the teenage girl. First he pounds the phone with a baseball bat on the garage floor. Then he tosses it and swings, appearing to connect several times. Someone films the whole episode.

headline: The Mystical Heart of British Folk Music
text: Early on in “Electric Eden,” Rob Young’s awesomely researched, somewhat deranged history of “visionary music” from Britain, we read about the wanderings of an old-timey folk singer named Vashti Bunyan. She appears on a hedgerow-lined country road in 1967, a humble seeker who lived outdoors in a “camp in a clearing in some Kentish woods.” A page later we find out that the camp was actually right next to the suburban art school her boyfriend attended, and that the squatters had been hurried off posthaste by the local police.

headline: Brains of the World to Cogitate for Bragging Rights
text: All over the world this Saturday, know-it-alls will be furrowing their brows.

headline: Greek Talks Pave Way for Fresh Bailout Funds
text: ATHENS — Greece moved closer on Friday to receiving a second bailout after agreeing to new measures to bring down its debt.

headline: Jack Kevorkian and Me
text: Twenty-one years ago this week, I had just learned I was pregnant with my first child. I was absorbing that news when a family in Portland, Ore., held a press conference to announce that their wife and mother, Janet Adkins, had died in a rusty 1968 Volkswagen van rigged with a “suicide device” built by a man named Jack Kevorkian.

headline: The Girls Next Door
text: There’s not much going on in the small town of Orchard Park, N.Y.

headline: Game 2, Through Two Lenses
text: The way Game 2 of the N.B.A. finals ended became instant fodder for the perfect sports debate: did the Mavericks’ victory from 15 down with less than eight minutes to go against the Heat represent an epic comeback by Dallas or a monumental collapse by Miami? Was it heroism led by Dirk Nowitzki, or the Big Three coming unglued? Spirited revenge or self-immolation?

headline: A Former Spy Chief Questions the Judgment of Israeli Leaders
text: JERUSALEM — The man who ran Israel’s Mossad spy agency until January contends that Israel’s top leaders lack judgment and that the anticipated pressures of international isolation as the Palestinians campaign for statehood could lead to rash decisions — like an airstrike on Iran.

headline: Pikas Have Moved to Higher Ground
text: The pika, a small mammal that lives in talus slopes at high elevations in the mountains of the American West, has disappeared in the last decade at a rate five times faster than they disappeared during the 20th century, according to a study out this month.

headline: An Enthusiast’s Guide to the Tabloid Murder
text: Americans are generally not too kind when our cherished icons, literary or otherwise, indulge their interests in something other than what they are known for. No one really wanted Michael Jordan to play minor league baseball, or Stephen King to write about dragons, and I am certain no one wants to listen to Russell Crowe sing. Of course, there are exceptions. Paul Newman did make a mean balsamic vinaigrette.

headline: AT&T Races to Expand the Network
text: Much of the $18 billion AT&T will spend this year will be diverted into upgrades and expansions to meet the surging demands on the 3G network.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: TOP STORIES

headline: Prada Predicts $218 Million in First-Half Profit
text: Prada, the Italian fashion house, said Friday in a filing to the Hong Kong stock exchange that it expected to report at least 150.7 million euros, or $218 million, in profit for the six months ending July 31, and announced ambitious growth plans once its issue is completed.

headline: New State Bar Chief Focuses on Veterans’ Issues
text: Sometime in the past year, Vincent E. Doyle III was at a charity dinner with his wife to raise money for Iraq war veterans. The veterans needed money for things like modifying their homes.

headline: Considering the Lobster
text: It’s nearly impossible to put a live lobster into a pot of boiling water without asking yourself, “Does it feel pain?” In Richard J. King’s elegant little history of the world’s pre-eminent crustacean, he reveals that anguishing over this “final vestige of what it is like to butcher or kill our own food” isn’t restricted to our PETA-­sensitized age. Apparently, it’s been debated in the West since at least the early 19th century.

headline: Of Writers and Boxers
text: Today, championship boxing is lucky to win half a column in the sports pages. There was a time, though, when things were otherwise. In one of two introductions to “At the Fights,” George Kimball, who edited this anthology with John Schulian, recalls the 1910 fight between Jack Johnson and Jim Jeffries: “More than 600 writers of varying stripes augmented the ringside crowd of 20,000 spectators. . . . Western Union transmitted more than a million words of copy, a record that would stand until Lindbergh touched down . . . 17 years later.” And as indicated by the editors elsewhere in the book, when Jack Dempsey defended his title against Georges Carpentier, the coverage in The New York Times “consumed not just the sports section on July 3, 1921, but almost the entire paper.”

headline: Building the Perfect bike
text: Evangelizing cyclists will often pronounce, in a moment of populist zeal, something like: “It doesn’t matter what you ride, as long as you ride.” This is a rather oleaginous half-truth spread across a larger reality. It may not matter what you ride, but it matters deeply what I ride. People pick up on this. A Brooklyn bike shop owner recently described to me the almost apologetic air of patrons bringing him bicycles for repair, as if they feared the dusty specimens they had just freed from storage revealed some philistine streak, as if they knew some better bike would complete them.

headline: St. Derek Jeter
text: The Yankee shortstop Derek Jeter is widely revered as a dignified and respectful clutch hitter, a leader by example and an adroit spouter of clichés who has managed to remain scandal-free and child-friendly even during baseball’s steroids era. Ian O’Connor isn’t about to challenge that view, as he makes clear in the introduction to his new hagiography, “The Captain.” When O’Connor writes that he spent 18 months in search of the “tangible explanation for Jeter’s intangible grace” and “the passion behind his pinstripes,” he is more than foreshadowing that he did not unearth Montgomery Burns-like evil within this “biracial golden child.”

headline: The Glory of Joe DiMaggio and Hank Greenberg
text: Yale University Press, the pre-eminent academic publishing house, founded in 1908 by George Parmly Day, decided to roll out two books on baseball in the same month of 2011. Who wants to tell the Mayans their calendar is a year off?

headline: Silent Slugger
text: Here are just a few of the interesting things Stan Musial, the great slugger for the St. Louis Cardinals, didn’t do:

headline: Baseball Chronicle
text: UPPITY  My Untold Story About the Games People Play.  By Bill White with Gordon Dillow.  Illustrated. 303 pp. Grand Central. $26.99.

headline: Science and the Race for the South Pole
text: With the 100th anniversary of the conquest of the South Pole coming this December, books about Antarctica will be everywhere this year. One of the first out of the gate is “An Empire of Ice,” which looks at Antarctic exploration through the lens of science. Yes, many of the famous adventure tales are here, including the central one in which Roald Amundsen beats the less-prepared Robert Falcon Scott to the South Pole, and then Scott and his men perish on the way home. But to Edward J. Larson, a professor of history and law at Pepperdine University, the important thing about this story is not who arrived first at the pole, but who did the best field research along the way. And by this measure, Scott was the clear victor. “If the race to the South Pole eventually consumed Scott, it was never at the expense of science,” Larson contends.

headline: Memoirs of an Insatiable Traveler
text: Travel and sexual conquest have long been cast as male impulses, from Casanova’s far-flung affairs to the promiscuity of the modern adventure hero. “Men know they are sexual exiles,” Camille Paglia has written. “They wander the earth seeking satisfaction, craving and despising, never content. There is nothing in that anguished motion for women to envy.” But then Paglia hadn’t read “Wanderlust.”

headline: Extreme Travel of ’45
text: “Adventure” these days is merely an experience that allows for a modestly elevated number of variables — renting a car without a GPS unit, for instance, or visiting a friend in East Flatbush. Not that the world is denuded of excitement. It’s just that true adventure requires something that defies an itinerary: failure. Failure is the engine of adventure.

headline: Who Really Discovered America?
text: This slim work of historical investigation covers three subjects: a 14th-century voyage across the North Atlantic; a 16th-century publishing event; and a 21st-century quest. Andrea di Robilant is a distinguished scholar of Venetian history, and in “Irresistible North,” his third book, he strives to bind his tripartite material into a persuasive narrative unity.

headline: A Journey Down South America’s Spine
text: He may call himself an aging backpacker, but Michael Jacobs is hardly a rough-and-ready, revel-in-the-wilderness kind of guy. The first clue comes early in “Andes,” his rambling account of a journey from the northern reaches of South America’s great mountain range to its icy finish in Patagonia. The book is dedicated to his brother — and to “the bus drivers of the Andes.”

headline: Paul Theroux’s Travel Miscellany
text: Thoreau said he couldn’t preserve his health and spirits unless he spent four hours a day “sauntering.” Rousseau passed most of his last 15 years in walking. “Everything is finished for me on earth,” he declared, a touch melodramatically. “People can no longer do good or evil to me. . . . Here I am, tranquil at the bottom of the abyss, a poor unfortunate mortal, but unperturbed, like God himself.” Words­worth walked about 180,000 miles in his lifetime, in spite of being “not a well-made man,” according to Thomas De Quincey (who added that his friend’s legs were “serviceable”). When a visitor asked Wordsworth’s servant to show him his study, she answered: “Here is his library, but his study is out of doors.”

headline: Bahrain Grand Prix Approved Despite New Clashes
text: Updated | 2:49 p.m. Hours after Bahrain’s security forces again fired tear gas at protesters on Friday, the World Motor Sport Council unanimously approved a decision to hold the Bahrain Grand Prix in October. The race was to have been held in March, but was postponed as the country struggled to come to grips with mass demonstrations against the government.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Collected Cool
text: “Waiting for trade” is a common refrain from comic book fans. Rather than pick up the monthly issues of a comic book series, many fans haveopted to wait (sometimes patiently) for the collected edition of the title to arrive months later. It’s a risky proposition – if the monthly sales of a book sink, the chances of a collected edition may decrease dramatically. While softcover and hardcover editions have proved popular with fans, there’s been a growing number of deluxe, Absolute, Martini and Omnibus editions that have been catching fire.

headline: Girls of a Certain Age Challenge Hollywood
text: WHO wants to watch a tween girl on the big screen?

headline: UBS Hires Tech and Media Banker From Deutsche Bank
text: UBS said on Friday that it had hired Yusuf Nahmiyas as a managing director for its technology, media and telecommunications mergers team. Mr. Nahmiyas was most recently at Deutsche Bank and was previously at JPMorgan Chase. He is the Swiss bank’s latest hire amid a series of high-profile defections.

headline: DVD Extras From the Barbara Sinatra Interview
text: Kitty Kelley got scads of attention for her 1991 book, “Nancy Reagan: The Unauthorized Biography,” by alleging that Frank Sinatra and Nancy Reagan carried on an affair for years, even during Reagan’s years in the White House. In Kelley’s book, Old Blue Eyes and Old Adolfo Suits would supposedly disappear “for three-or four-hour ‘private luncheons'” in the family quarters. At the time, some disputed the claim in print.

headline: Picturing Mob Violence
text: A few months ago, Barry Bearak called. Barry lives in Johannesburg, where he and his wife, Celia Dugger, have been our bureau chiefs for southern Africa for the past three and a half years. He called to describe a video he had recently seen of a mob that was beating and killing a man. Barry’s response was immediate: he had seen something terrible, something terribly wrong, and he had to understand why it had happened. Barry won a Pulitzer in 2002 for his coverage of life in war-torn Afghanistan; in 2005, he recreated the day the tsunami wiped out much of Banda Aceh, Indonesia, telling the stories of six survivors. Suffice it to say that he works tirelessly to get the details that convey the truth of the matter, which he does in this most recent piece, a powerful, disturbing story, “Death by a Thousand Blows,” that appears in this Sunday’s magazine.

headline: Renewed Interest in Dividend-Paying Stocks
text: Paul Sullivan writes in his Wealth Matters column this week about a type of stock that had fallen into disfavor over the last couple of decades because it had none of the go-go appeal of a technology start-up — the dividend-paying kind. Paul speaks to several financial advisers who say they are now promoting dividend-paying stocks to people who still have money in cash or low-yielding bonds.

headline: Comparing Recessions and Recoveries: Job Changes
text: Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics. Chart by Amanda Cox. Horizontal axis shows months. Vertical axis shows the ratio of that month’s nonfarm payrolls to the nonfarm payrolls at the start of recession. Note: Because employment is a lagging indicator, the dates for these employment trends are not exactly synchronized with National Bureau of Economic Research’s official business cycle dates.

headline: Venice Biennale: Money Talks, Make That Sings
text: Let’s please dispense with the clichés about art and money and instead take a look at getting hold of cash in Venice. There is only one A.T.M. machine in the whole of the Giardini, the gardens at the tip of the city that is home to the national pavilions.  It’s in a space of its own at the back of the American pavilion.

headline: Just One Look | Michael Kors Resort
text: Michael Kors has been all over the map — in a manner of speaking. His resort collection was inspired by his first trip down under, where he was blown away by the urban beach culture. (“Women wear bathing suits as lingerie,” he exclaimed. “Divine!”) His homage includes a double-faced crepe “rashguard dress” and this three-piece power suit. Wish we worked in that  office.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $11,750,000
text: A co-op at Harperley Hall, a 1911 Arts and Crafts-style building at 41 Central Park West, was the biggest sale of the week, closing for $11.75 million, according to city property records.

headline: Chopin, Schubert and Dietrich (the Latter Nude)
text: AFTER “Blonde Venus” flopped in 1932, Paramount decided to break up the powerful creative alliance between the director Josef von Sternberg and the actress Marlene Dietrich, whom he had discovered in Germany and brought to Hollywood. While Sternberg, who was Jewish, entertained bizarre fantasies of returning to Germany to work for the state-controlled studio Ufa (he thought the Germans would treat him as the great artist he was), Dietrich was hustled directly into “The Song of Songs,” which has recently surfaced as half of a “Pre-Code Double Feature” available exclusively through the TCM Web site. (The other film is “This Is the Night.”)

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE LAST HERO: A Life of Henry Aaron,  by Howard Bryant (Anchor, $16.95.) Henry Aaron was his era’s greatest hitter; when he retired, in 1976, after a 23-year career, only Ty Cobb had more hits or scored more runs, and no one had more home runs. Bryant’s book is a rigorously researched and illuminating portrait of Aaron — he was the last Hall of Famer to play in the Negro Leagues — and his dogged pursuit of Babe Ruth’s career home run record.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE GREATER JOURNEY: Americans in Paris,  by David McCullough (Simon & Schuster, $37.50.) An exploration of the intellectual legacy that France settled on such 19th-century visitors as Mark Twain, Harriet Beecher Stowe, Samuel Morse and many others.

headline: Science Fiction Chronicle
text: ZOO CITY  By Lauren Beukes.  Angry Robot, paper, $7.99.

headline: Bleak Childhood, Dark Comedy
text: Why do good things happen to bad people? For some of us, this is one of life’s big questions, bigger perhaps than those all-stars: What makes Iago evil? How can a country justify firing both missiles and schoolteachers? The undeserved job promotion, the bequest without cause, the random assigning of accolades or attention: when unmerited rewards are doled out to others, some of us are capable of descending into decades of moping.

headline: After the Holocaust
text: For Silvana, the Polish Holocaust survivor at the center of Amanda Hodgkinson’s accomplished first novel, “22 Britannia Road,” maternal love is a heart-scorching, perilous emotion. During the war, threats to the life of Aurek, her young son, were everywhere: from the “filthy” skies, raked with thunder clouds and German planes, to the sunless, brambly depths of the Polish forests, where she and Aurek, like two figures in a fairy tale, hid out for years. They are rescued from a refugee camp by Janusz, the husband and father from whom they were separated at the beginning of the fighting. Janusz brings them to Ipswich, to the small house and garden that give the novel its title. There Silvana forces herself to believe that a normal life is possible: that she and Janusz will rediscover themselves as husband and wife, that Aurek will have a father — and that the secret still threatening her son’s security will stay buried.

headline: Inside the List
text: CON LAW: Beach-reading season may be in full swing, but that doesn’t mean there isn’t a whole lot of constitutional law being debated on the best-seller list. In “Where’s the Birth Certificate?,” at No. 14 in its second week on the hardcover nonfiction list, the veteran conspiracy theorist Jerome Corsi argues that Barack Obama’s supposed foreign birth runs afoul of Article 2, Section 1, which requires that the president be a “natural-born citizen.” (Didn’t Donald Trump ruin that story line a few weeks ago?) Meanwhile, in Steve Berry’s latest pretzel of a thriller, “The Jefferson Key” (No. 5 on the fiction list), the swashbuckling Justice Department operative Cotton Malone comes out of semiretirement to foil a presidential assassination rooted in a secret clause encoded in Article 1, Section 8.

headline: Bookshelf: Growing Up
text: LITTLE MIST  By Angela McAllister. Illustrated by Sarah Fox-Davies.  32 pp. Knopf. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 6)

headline: The Murder That Transfixed 1930s Paris
text: On Aug. 21, 1933, Violette Nozière, the 18-year-old only daughter of an engine driver and a housewife who lived in a claustrophobic two-room apartment in the working-class 12th ­Arrondissement of Paris, gave her parents drinks laced with a lethal dose of barbiturates. Her father died. Her mother, who drank only half her glass, fell into a deeply drugged sleep, but survived. When Violette was arrested — after a brief attempt at flight and a costly shopping spree paid for with her parents’ pilfered savings — she gave a full confession. She also explained, as motive for her crime, that her father had been raping her for the past six years.

headline: Teaching Aliens How to Lie
text: The innovative and protean British writer China Miéville’s declared ambition to write a novel in every genre offers an insight into his powers of invention. “I’m in this . . . business for the monsters,” he said in an interview a few years ago. “Unfortunately, you can’t really sell books of monsters to publishers. They insist on stories linking them.” To create the necessary narratives, Miéville repurposes genre formulas like a salvage artist, mixing a connoisseur’s respect for recovered materials with heretical joy in putting them to surprising uses.

headline: Richard North Patterson’s Al Qaeda Thriller
text: Nothing solidifies the reputation of a spy novelist so much as prescience. Graham Greene’s “Quiet American” appeared only a year after the French defeat at Dien Bien Phu, and before American advisers had been sent to Vietnam in large numbers. Four years before the Cuban missile crisis, with Fulgencio Batista still in power, Greene wrote another novel, this one about possible secret military installations in Cuba. As for Ian Fleming, his vision of nonstate terrorist groups seeking nuclear weapons remains the most frightening and relevant aspect of the James Bond series.

headline: The Mystery of a Sister’s Death
text: Two years ago, a British study suggested that men and women who grew up with sisters had happier lives and rosier outlooks than men and women who didn’t. The presence of even one sister in a household was enough to foster an atmosphere of emotional openness that helped family members communicate and tackle problems. No such benefit accrued to people who had only brothers. The study was small — only 571 subjects took part — but it was heartening to think that sisters, so often portrayed as fractious rivals, envious of one another’s attractions and covetous of one another’s friends and clothes, might actually serve as mortar binding the bricks of a family’s psyche.

headline: Lynne Tillman’s Innovative Stories
text: Despite the claim of the title, “Someday This Will Be Funny,” you wouldn’t want to reach for Lynne Tillman’s new book just for a good howl. In fact, that “someday” the title promises may never come. Tillman’s stories are too piercing, the obsessions of her characters too connected to their psychic wounds, for them to be considered exactly “funny.” In any case, it isn’t “someday” but rather “meantime” that counts for readers. And in the meantime, Tillman’s fictions tend to be (to steal a line from one of her stories) as “outrageously ineffable, obdurate and evasive” as the forms of desire they describe. Gorgeously at ease and technically virtuosic, the stories are ever on point — on point, that is, if the point of your reading has more to do with psychological nuance and bravura performances of language than with conventional story lines.

headline: Teens After Armageddon
text: How many times can the world come to an end? For Saba, the fatalistic 18-year-old heroine of “Blood Red Road,” quite a few. She lives long after Earth’s last major civilization, the Wreckers, went extinct. Her mother died nine years earlier, giving birth to Saba’s sister, Emmi. The lake beside her family’s shack is drying up, replaced by a wasteland of dust storms and heat.

headline: Figuring Out Dad
text: Twice in “The Absolute Value of Mike,” 14-year-old Mike is asked, “What’s your story?” The first time he equivocates, talking instead about the circumstances that surround him. The second time, he evades: “I — I don’t know.” Both are deceptions that come out of a humiliating sadness; because he does know his story. He is the kid whose father is a math and engineering genius, burdened with an un-smart son, one who is bound to disappoint and will probably end up on the street, because he is so much less than his father.

headline: Ghostbusters
text: It’s almost summer, so let’s get serious about those vacation reading lists. On second thought, let’s save the 600-page historical sagas and thickly plotted espionage thrillers for another day and kick back with something weird and wonderful — like a supernatural mystery.

headline: When New York City Went Dark
text: If you believe that books set in your neighborhood will somehow help your child love to read, then you would be lucky these days to be a parent in Brooklyn. Books for children by Brooklyn authors now match the similarly numberless books by Brooklyn-based authors for grown-ups.

headline: An Illustrated History of the Funny Papers
text: In 1906, the poet Ralph Bergengren, in the name of “common sense and Christianity,” denounced the Sunday comics supplement as “pandemonium, . . . the clamor of hooting mobs, the laughter of imbeciles, and the crash of explosives.”

headline: FIA Reinstates Bahrain Grand Prix
text: The Bahrain Grand Prix will go ahead this year, after the World Council of the International Automobile Federation voted to reinstate the race at a meeting in Barcelona today.

headline: FIA Reinstates Bahrain Grand Prix
text: The Bahrain Grand Prix will go ahead this year, after the World Council of the International Automobile Federation voted to reinstate the race at a meeting in Barcelona today.

headline: Olympic Gold, or the Stanley Cup?
text: The Sedins said it. Patrice Bergeron said it. Ryan Kesler said it.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Governors Island again plays host to the Veuve Clicquot Polo Classic on Sunday starting at 11 a.m. It is free for the public to attend the game, which starts at 2:30 p.m. Danny Meyer’s Union Square Hospitality Group will have a “Restaurant Row” selling food, and Veuve Clicquot will set up lounges selling flutes and bottles of Champagne.

headline: Mourning a Boy, Crowds in Syria Defy Crackdown
text: CAIRO — Syrians poured into the streets on Friday in some of the largest antigovernment protests yet despite the shutdown of much of Syria’s Internet network, which has been crucial to demonstrators’ ability to mobilize and a major source of information for those outside the country.

headline: City Opera to Lay Off 11 Workers
text: New York City Opera, as part of its resuscitation plan, will lay off 11 of its 48 administrative employees and eliminate four open positions, according to a company memorandum obtained on Friday. The layoffs are part of a reorganization approved at a May 19 board meeting when the company formally decided to leave its home, the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center. The memorandum did not identify the jobs and City Opera officials had no comment.

headline: Video: The Week in Politics
text: Megan Liberman and Jim Rutenberg discuss Mitt Romney‘s official announcement to run for president and how Sarah Palin‘s road trip to New Hampshire stole some of his thunder.

headline: Oilers’ Brule Saves Bono’s Day
text: Usually, it’s not advisable to pick up hitchhikers. It’s right up there with Mom’s stern warnings about not taking candy from strangers.

headline: History Repeats for a Correspondent in Tripoli
text: TRIPOLI, Libya – In March 2003, the Pentagon described its airborne onslaught on Baghdad at the outset of the campaign to topple Saddam Hussein as one intended to provoke “shock and awe.”

headline: Near Barcelona, Gems From Ancient Rome
text: WHAT draws travelers to the northeast of Spain? Cutting-edge food, of course. To Barcelona? Modernist architecture, perhaps. Along the coast, the beaches. And to Tarragona, a laid-back city about 60 miles south of Barcelona, the ancient ruins. On our first afternoon there, my husband and I headed from our hotel down the broad promenade of the Rambla Nova, the city’s main artery. We stopped at one of the outdoor cafes along the way, mixing with a crowd that seemed more local than tourist, and ordered gin-and-tonics.

headline: A Feminist Riot That Still Inspires
text: A quartet of teenage girls was onstage at the Knitting Factory, the Brooklyn club. Playing guitars and wearing mini-skirts, they did a tuneful pop cover of Ben Lee’s “I Wish I Was Him,” about the 1990s alt-rock heartthrob Evan Dando and given a flip by these long-haired 14- and 15-year-olds who called themselves Toy Sugar. Performing the song in 1994, Kathleen Hanna did that first, when, as the frontwoman for the punk band Bikini Kill and a founder of the feminist riot grrrl movement, she made it her business to overturn gender norms in a way that you could sing, or scream, along to.

headline: The Secrets of Tarragona
text: Much of this Spanish city’s richly layered history can be found within the Old City’s ancient walls.

headline: Caucus | The Week in Politics
text: Megan Liberman and Jim Rutenberg discuss Mitt Romney's official announcement to run for president and how Sarah Palin's road trip to New Hampshire stole some of his thunder.

headline: Making a Hipper Hybrid by Gilding the Prius
text: SCAN a roster of Toyota Prius buyers and you’ll find performers, policy makers and entrepreneurs. After being bowled over by the boldface names — Apple’s Steve Wozniak, Google’s Sergey Brin, earth-conscious artistes from Natalie Portman to Bill Maher — I wonder this: can’t these people afford a nicer car? Shouldn’t someone as cool as Mark Ruffalo (who cleverly called his Toyota “the Priss”) drive something that’s faster and sleeker than a garden gnome?

headline: St. Ann’s Warehouse Scrambles to Find New Home
text: St. Ann’s Warehouse, the Brooklyn theater whose versatile and cavernous playing space has become a magnet for New York and overseas acting troupes, is now confronting a likely fate that its leaders had worked years to avoid: homelessness.

headline: Riot Grrrl Revisited
text: The 1990s indie rock movement is being reexamined by academics and icons like Kathleen Hanna.

headline: Edwards Might Have Broken Distracted-Driving Law en Route to Court
text: As my colleague Katharine Seelye reports, John Edwards, the former Democratic senator from North Carolina and presidential candidate, was indicted Friday morning on charges that he violated campaign finance law and is scheduled to appear in a federal court in Winston-Salem, N.C., this afternoon.

headline: Walsh to Leave Knicks, Turnaround Unfinished
text: Donnie Walsh, who revived a flagging, dysfunctional Knicks franchise and repeatedly stated his intention to complete the turnaround, is instead stepping down as the team president in a dispute over his authority.

headline: Creole Choir of Cuba Brings Island’s Music to Brooklyn
text: For those who associate modern Cuban music with a Latin jazz sound, here comes the Creole Choir of Cuba to blow away those expectations with their first concert in this country.

headline: The Minimalist: Four-Spice Salmon
text: Mark Bittman is revisiting recipes from vintage Minimalist columns for a new series of videos.

headline: James Arness, Marshal on ‘Gunsmoke,’ Dies at 88
text: James Arness, who burnished the legend of America’s epic West as Marshal Matt Dillon, the laconic peacemaker of Dodge City on “Gunsmoke,” one of the longest-running dramatic series in television history, died on Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 88.

headline: A Revival In Manufacturing Seems to Be Fading
text: The strong revival of worldwide manufacturing seems to have slowed.

headline: June 5 — 11
text: Theater

headline: What’s In A Name?
text: A lot, or at least that’s what Republicans think. Greg Sargent reports that they’re demanding that a TV station stop running ads saying that the GOP wants to end Medicare; the claim is that this is a lie, because the new program the GOP wants to impose in place of Medicare is still Medicare.

headline: Dance for a Cause and Let the Votes Fall Where They May
text: And now, a public-service announcement about public-service announcements.

headline: Another Tale, or Two, Of That Operatic Figaro
text: FIRST “The Barber of Seville,” then “The Marriage of Figaro.” Then what? Whether we are speaking of the plays of Pierre-Augustin Caron de Beaumarchais or the operas they inspired, the Figaro triptych many have dreamed of — including Beaumarchais himself — remains an elusive goal. On Friday the Whitsun edition of the Salzburg Festival revives an opera that just might serve as the missing third panel: “I Due Figaro” (“The Two Figaros”), by Saverio Mercadante.

headline: Stravinsky’s Devil, Reignited
text: THE setting, dialogue and dance steps of Igor Stravinsky’s “Histoire du Soldat,” a music-theater piece from 1918, are as malleable as the Faust story on which the work is based. What doesn’t change is the music: a tart panoply of jazzy figures, dance forms and marches.

headline: Stay Away From Our Pay, Private Equity Tells Washington
text: The private equity industry has a knack for transforming losing companies into surprising success stories.

headline: Have Any Point Shoes In a Man’s Size 9?
text: CORY STEARNS sat on the floor of an American Ballet Theater studo holding a pair of satin point shoes as if he were trying to decide between two loaves of bread.

headline: Revealing Excessive 401(k) Fees
text: You may not realize this, but your 401(k) or other workplace retirement plan is not free.

headline: The American Phil Hill, Formula One Champion, Remembered at Monza
text: The career of the late Phil Hill, the American who won the Formula One world championship 50 years ago, will be celebrated this weekend at a series of vintage car races at the speedway in Monza, Italy.

headline: Garden of Big Sounds, Yielding Hybrid Crops
text: Ryoji Ikeda

headline: House Rebukes Obama for Continuing Libyan Mission Without Its Consent
text: WASHINGTON — The House of Representatives voted Friday to rebuke President Obama for continuing to maintain an American role in NATO operations in Libya without the express consent of Congress, and directed the administration to provide detailed information about the cost and objectives of the American role in the conflict.

headline: Shining a Light on Your 401(k) Costs
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I’m back on the topic of 401(k) plans and how to bolster returns by making them less costly.

headline: 3-D ‘Star Wars’ Theme Park Attraction
text: Among “Star Wars” fans, the most vivid depiction of the icy planet of Hoth, the lush jungles of Kashyyyk and the underwater Gungan world on Naboo exist on celluloid.

headline: Judge Advises N.F.L. and Players to Continue Efforts to End Dispute
text: ST. LOUIS — With the start of the 2011 regular season less than 100 days away, and recent negotiations providing hope for a settlement, the N.F.L. and its players faced off in a federal appeals court Friday to determine how much longer the lockout could last.

headline: Making It Easier to Navigate by Subway in Queens
text: In a godsend for G train riders — and proponents of clarity on the subway map — New York City Transit has introduced a free, sheltered transfer between the G and No. 7 trains at the newly christened Court Square subway complex in Long Island City, Queens.

headline: A Rant of His Own: V.S. Naipaul Takes on Women Writers
text: Paul Theroux has described his onetime mentor, the Nobel laureate V. S. Naipaul, as “a grouch, a skinflint, tantrum-prone, with race on the brain.” Mr. Theroux and Mr. Naipaul may have reconciled at a literary festival in Britain this week, but other critics are using new derogatory adjectives — like “arrogant” and “sexist” — to describe Mr. Naipaul after he declared that no female writer was his literary equal.

headline: In Cajun Country, in Search of the Boucherie
text: WE had come a long way for a hog killing, but the butcher had chosen that day of all days to have a meltdown. Nobody at La Grande Boucherie des Cajuns — an annual festival in St. Martinville, La., celebrating the Cajun tradition of boucherie, or the communal butchering of hogs — knew what had set him off. It might have been the thunderstorm that had hit town that morning, blowing tents from the festival grounds and drenching vendors. Or maybe it was the unseasonably cool air; a cold chopping block could make for unpleasant butchering. Whatever it was, he had packed up his apron and butchering tackle, locked the hog in the trailer, and sped off — presumably to the hog’s relief.

headline: A Low-Rise Shanghai Market
text: IN a corner of Shanghai’s old French Concession neighborhood, in the shadow of half-constructed high-rise apartment blocks, is something rather striking for a city going up at such a dizzying pace: a rooftop garden, complete with a resident rabbit and chicken.

headline: Mother and Sons, on the Same Track
text: MY sons have always loved trains. Most children do. I have vivid memories of mine as small boys crowding the window at the front of the car next to the conductor’s booth, crowing with glee at the powerful speed with which the world rushes past. For years, my older son had been fantasizing about taking a train all the way across the country. Suddenly this winter, the constellation of vacations lined up; one was on break from college, the other from law school. We stopped dreaming about the journey, and started planning it.

headline: Hotel Review: Singapore Moon Hotel
text: THE UPSHOT

headline: Letters: Leaving the Dog at Home
text: To the Editor: Regarding the Practical Traveler column, “Making the Skies Friendly for Pets” (May 22): My daughter and her fiancé flew here with Ben, an 11-pound Jack Russell-poodle mix and rescue dog, from New York last Christmas. Because the Delta check-in people didn’t know how to deal with the pet paperwork, they almost missed their flight. They also paid through the nose to put Ben in cargo, and had to buy a carrier with specific dimensions. Ben survived the flight in fine fettle; not so my daughter and her fiancé. They say never again.

headline: Enclave Embraces Brotherly Love
text: Mount Airy, a neighborhood of North Philadelphia, has recently attracted an influx of businesses that are embracing its diversity.

headline: Why We Travel: Readers Share Their Stories
text: WHAT follows are the final essays we will print from the “Why We Travel” submissions. On April 3, inspired by  an essay titled “Why We Travel” by Paul Theroux, we asked readers to write us with their answers to that question. Hundreds responded, and we have published 11.  There is a link to those essays here: travel.nytimes.com/why-essays.

headline: White Nights of St. Petersburg, Russia
text: THE motorized launch cruised toward the Hermitage, the former Winter Palace of the czars, passing underneath a low arched bridge that I feared would graze my scalp as we glided beneath it. Just ahead, a boisterous wedding party on the deck of a wooden cruiser filled the air with vodka-fueled shouts of “gorko!,” meaning bitterness, a traditional Russian encouragement to the bride and groom to kiss and thus provide the guests with the opposite of what was being proclaimed.

headline: White Nights in St. Petersburg
text: St. Petersburg, Russia, celebrates the arrival of summer, when the sun barely sets, with parties along the city’s rivers and canals.

headline: How to Add Flaxseed to Your Diet
text: Flaxseed is credited with a number of health benefits, including better digestive health, lower cholesterol and fewer hot flashes during menopause. But how do you add flaxseed to your diet?

headline: A Family’s Fellow Traveler, From Tropics to Tundra
text: ON a recent Saturday, Blaine Benson sifted through a folder of documents, the remains of a road trip taken 40 years ago. Among the ephemera were Pan Am airline tickets, ferry receipts, invoices for car repairs and a mileage log, handwritten on white notepad pages.

headline: Average Length of Unemployment at All-Time High
text: The average unemployed person in America has been looking for work for 39.7 weeks, or more than nine months. That is the longest average unemployment spell since the Labor Department started keeping track in 1948:

headline: Awareness: Top 5 Don’ts for Doctors in Primary Care
text: Antibiotics for sore throats and CT scans for minor head injuries in children are among the most wasteful practices in primary care medicine, a national physicians’ group said last week. Among the others are electrocardiograms performed routinely on healthy adults and widespread prescribing of brand-name statins to reduce L.D.L., or “bad” cholesterol.

headline: Screening: Saliva Test for Cytomegalovirus Proves Accurate
text: A new test offers a rapid, inexpensive and highly accurate method for screening newborns for cytomegalovirus, which can cause permanent hearing loss, researchers said on Wednesday.

headline: Food Groups? You Call Those Food Groups?
text: Don’t get us wrong. The new national Food Plate that the first lady unveiled on Thursday to replace the long-ridiculed food pyramid has its charms — nice proportions, easy-to-remember categories, potential to improve the health of Americans.

headline: Buyer Emerges for the Dallas Stars
text: The long search for a buyer of the ailing Dallas Stars may be nearing an end, solving another financial headache for the N.H.L. Tom Gaglardi, a businessman from Vancouver, British Columbia, is expected to pay roughly $250 million for the team and half of the lease to the American Airlines Arena, according to a person with direct knowledge of the deal.

headline: Obama Hails Auto Industry’s Turnaround in Visit to Chrysler Plant

headline: Why We Travel: Readers Share Their Stories

Several hundred responded, relating stories that took us from the mountains of Peru to the halls of Rome. Here are the final selections that illustrate the vast range of our readers’ experiences. Thanks to everyone who responded; it was a pleasure to read of your travels. The Editors

headline: More Than a Room of One’s Own
text: Women writers are “quite different,” said V.S. Naipaul in an interview at the Royal Geographic Society, picked up by The Guardian. “I read a piece of writing, and within a paragraph or two I know whether it is by a woman or not. I think [it is] unequal to me.” (To see if you have the master’s knack for sexing literature, go to what  New York magazine calls “Guess the Sex of the Authors on the V.S. Naipaul Test” on the Guardian’s Web site.) He goes on to explain that, in part, women fall short because they aren’t the boss at home. “She is not a complete master of a house, so that comes over in her writing too.” Maybe Virginia Woolf should have asked for more real estate.

headline: Liver Disease Keeps Uncle Mo Sidelined
text: Uncle Mo, the 2-year-old champion who was scratched the day before the Kentucky Derby, has been diagnosed with a liver disease called cholangiohepatitis.

headline: The Art World’s New Darlings
text: Adel Abidin and Ahmed Alsoudani, the young artists who represent Iraq at the 54th Venice Biennale, were sitting on the terrace of the Bauer Hotel here at dusk on Wednesday, studying their elaborately hand-written invitations to a private dinner given by François Pinault, the French billionaire. How would they cross the water to San Giorgio Maggiore Island?

headline: Money Woes Force Hiatus for Philharmonic Orchestra of the Americas
text: The fledgling Philharmonic Orchestra of the Americas, with few contributions on the horizon and facing rising costs, is suspending operations, its chairman said on Friday. The orchestra, based in New York, was founded in 2004 by Alondra de la Parra, a rising young Mexican conductor, and made a specialty of Latin American music. It toured in Mexico recently in honor of the country’s bicentennial and gave three or four concerts a year in New York. Ms. de la Parra and the orchestra also released a recording of Latin American works last year.

headline: ‘Liberal Bias’ Takes Toll On Hollywood Non-Partisan Group
text: LOS ANGELES — The dust-up around Ben Shapiro’s book, “Prime Time Propaganda: The True Hollywood Story of How the Left Took Over Your TV,” has taken a toll on a values-oriented Hollywood organization that prides itself on reaching across partisan lines. That is the Caucus for Producers, Writers and Directors, whose members include Tom Hanks, Dick Wolf, Garry Marshall and some of the more prominent creative types in television.

headline: A Photo Booth for Instagram Users
text: You can always tell the good parties from the bad ones based on the number of photos taken.

headline: The Return of the Blue-Collar Downturn
text: For much of 2010, the slumping economy was affecting white-collar, highly educated workers almost as much as it was affecting less educated and blue-collar workers. That’s no longer the case. In recent months, the economy has once again been easier on college graduates than it has on everyone else, much as it was during nearly all of 2008 and 2009.

headline: Music Pick of the Day: Gil Scott-Heron
text: Gil Scott-Heron died last week. A pioneering artist and progenitor of rap and hip-hop, Scott-Heron, who battled substance abuse for decades, experienced a resurgence in popularity last year after a new album reminded audiences of his thought-provoking lyrical prowess.

headline: Bringing Home the Wrong Race
text: IT was the morning after our first “I love you,” and I was filled with happiness on my way to breakfast with Seung Yong Chung. I couldn’t yet pronounce any of his three names better than many of you just did, but I called him “Sing,” like all his friends did.

headline: Viagra: The Thrill That Was
text: IT isn’t often that an article in AARP’s magazine gets the attention of People, the London tabloids, The Huffington Post and the celebrity blogosphere. But so it was last year when Michael Douglas, upon turning 65, sat down for an interview with the mass-circulation periodical for the over-50 set, and in the process uttered a word heard round the world: “Viagra.”

headline: Feelin’ Wisconsin
text: My favorite odd detail in Jon Caramanica’s profile of Bon Iver’s Justin Vernon in Sunday’s magazine — in an article stuffed with odd details — is Vernon’s description of the tattoo he has of the state of Wisconsin, with the six counties he knows best outlined. The specificity struck me with such force: the six counties? I mean, not to be parochial, but as far as homogeneous states go — well, let’s just say I had preconceptions about Wisconsin.

headline: Exhibition Shows Fierce Art Patronage of the Fierce Steins
text: If Gertrude Stein is remembered as the force behind the legendary Saturday soirées on the Rue de Fleurus in Paris — where artists, writers, collectors, dealers and curiosity seekers would gather in the early 20th century to see the most revolutionary art of the moment on the walls —that’s because she was the one retelling the story in her writings, while sidelining her brothers Leo and Michael, and Michael’s wife, Sarah. “The Steins Collect: Matisse, Picasso, and the Parisian Avant-Garde,” which opened at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art on May 21, presents the more complete story of the fiercely intellectual, risk-taking and competitive siblings who put these artists on the map through their visionary patronage.

headline: Checking It Twice
text: Whether you’re simply organized or mildy compulsive, a list can provide the structure for the everyday. However, when the to-do list is compiled by such artistic luminaries as Pablo Picasso, Alexander Calder and Franz Kline, it transcends its ostensible purpose and provides insights into the life and times of its maker. This is obvious from a new show — “To-dos, Ilustrated Inventories, Collected Thoughts, and Other Artists’ Enumerations,” curated by Liza Kirwin from the Smithsonian’s Archives of American Art — that opened today at the Morgan Library & Museum in Manhattan. For example, Pablo Picasso’s recommendations for inclusion in the 1913 Armory Show, the first international exhibition of modern art in the United States, astutely foresaw the historical importance of Marcel Duchamp, Fernand Leger and Juan Gris. Franz Kline’s shopping list for booze for his 1960 New Year’s party was evidence of his financial success (it was a hefty bill for the time) as well as his social nature. The artist Adolf Konrad illustrated his 1962 packing list: Khaki trench. Check. Six pairs of socks. Check. Sunglasses. Check. Two lemons. Check. Ah, the beauty of the artfully organized.

headline: This Sunday: A Meaningful Death
text: A couple of months ago, when we started putting credits and email addresses for the editors of feature stories on the magazine’s table of contents, Jack Shafer, media critic for Slate, felt inspired to not only mock the plan, but to impugn the editing profession generally. “Try complimenting an editor sometime about a good piece in his publication,” Jack wrote, “and you’re certain to get this eye-rolling response: ‘You shoulda seen it when it came in!'”

text: June 3 - China's Li Na hopes to be the first Asian to win a Grand Slam tennis tournament.

headline: Unemployment and the Economy; The Annuity Puzzle; Traders Who Know Better
text: This week: Jeff Sommer talks with Catherine Rampell on unemployment and the economy and Richard Thaler on the annuity puzzle. David Gillen chats with Andrew Martin on the pet boom; and Phyllis Korkki asks Jeff about frequent traders who know better.

headline: A Teenager Learns He’s a Breed Apart
text: Not too long into the initial hour of “Teen Wolf,” MTV’s cheeky new foray into supernaturalism, a mother hands her date-bound son the keys to the car and attempts a quick talk on safe sex. Incredulous at this display of mom corniness, he asks if she is joking. No, she isn’t, and she tells him, “I’m not going to end up on some reality television show with a pregnant 16-year-old.”

headline: N.B.A. Lifts ABC
text: ABC dominated Thursday night’s ratings with coverage of the National Basketball Association Finals, while reruns on CBS eked out a second-place finish, ahead of Fox. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 7.7 million viewers tuned in to “So You Think You Can Dance” in the 8 o’clock hour, a large enough audience to give Fox a modest lead in the time slot, ahead of CBS’s repeats of “The Big Bang Theory” (7.4 million) and “Rules of Engagement” (6.7 million). But at 9, Fox’s rerun of “Glee” (4.2 million) struggled opposite CBS’s “CSI” (8 million).
