Meanwhile preliminary overnight estimates for the ABC basketball broadcast were just slightly lower, compared with Game 1 on Wednesday night, which attracted 15.2 million viewers. NBC finished a distant fourth on the night with low-rated reruns of its comedy lineup. At 10, NBC’s premiere of “Love Bites” averaged 2.5 million viewers, lagging well behind CBS’s repeat of “The Mentalist” (8.8 million) in that hour.

headline: A Big Man Who Can Belt a Tune Isn’t Afraid to Show a Mellow Side, Too
text: Gregory Porter has most of what you want in a male jazz singer, and maybe a thing or two you didn’t know you wanted. A former outside linebacker (at San Diego State, on scholarship) and musical theater veteran (“It Ain’t Nothin’ but the Blues,” on Broadway), he brings to the stage an expressive physicality. His sturdy baritone and sure projection make him a natural belter, but he knows how to sidle up to a melody, working quietly with tension and release. He also knows how to write a song, and put together a show.

headline: Show Within a Show Gets Its Own Shot
text: There was no Ashton Kutcher to save “Sonny With a Chance.” When the Disney heiress apparent Demi Lovato went to rehab last fall to deal with “emotional and physical issues,” it left her several careers dangling, none more awkwardly than her role in the sitcom “Sonny,” which seemed destined to collapse without the peppy and wry Ms. Lovato at its center.

headline: Reviewing the Lexus CT 200h
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the Lexus CT 200h, a hybrid with more style and power, as well as a lot less baggage, than the car’s nominal forebear, the Toyota Prius hybrid sedan:

headline: A Couple of First Encounters, One Including Musicians
text: Though the brilliant German violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter has been artist in residence at the New York Philharmonic all season, she had never worked with Alan Gilbert until Thursday night. In fact, this was the first time these two artists in their 40s had ever collaborated, which was surprising, since they have long traveled the byways of the international orchestra world.

headline: The Agriculture Chief as Water Advocate
text: Most people do not realize the intense relationship between modern agriculture and water quality. In an article in Friday’s paper, I write about a dead zone in the Gulf of Mexico near the mouth of the Mississippi River and how it has been linked to runoff from farms, largely from chemicals used as fertilizers.

headline: A 40-Year Partnership That Is as Youthful as Ever
text: You know an ensemble is doing something right when it’s 40 years old and almost everything it plays is younger than itself.

headline: China Cheers Li’s Accomplishments
text: BEIJING — Millions of Chinese who have never swung a racket or seen a live tennis match will cheer on Li Na on Saturday as she plays in the French Open final and tries to become the first Asian player to win a major.

headline: Let a Few Good Ideas Loose, Then Repeat
text: There’s an impressive set awaiting audiences as they file into the Joyce Theater, where the Brian Brooks Moving Company opened the Gotham Dance Festival on Wednesday night. An arched opening at the back of the stage is strung with dozens of fine silvery cables that extend over the stage and the audience, creating a tunnel effect and the notion of a spider web in which we are caught along with the dancers.

headline: A Sharp Eye for Songs in the Key of Now
text: As Karrin Allyson breezed through Mose Allison’s “I Don’t Worry About a Thing,” at Birdland on Thursday evening, this jaunty blues shuffle with a twisted smile on its face sounded as fresh as if it had been tossed off just the other day.

headline: Tetris Expands Beyond Gaming, and Claims a New Record
text: When it began nearly 30 years ago, Tetris quickly became one of the most popular video games sold. Now, the Tetris Company, which owns the Tetris brand, says it plans to expand beyond videogames and soon hopes to introduce dozens of new Tetris-themed products. These will include Tetris branded T-shirts, Halloween costumes, tabletop games, chocolates, candy, waffles, furniture that nests together, and even Tetris soup.

headline: A Defender Is Undone by a Surfeit of Trumps
text: The Memorial Weekend Sectional was played at the Cavendish, Honors and Manhattan bridge clubs in New York last weekend. The diagramed deal from Saturday was unusual.

headline: A Stream of Postcards, Shot by Phone
text: Digital camera sales may be weak, but thanks to cellphones, picture-taking has never been more of an everyday thing. Now a wave of mobile applications is letting people tweak their cellphone snapshots and share them with friends and strangers.

headline: Selling J. R., Lock, Stock and Swagger
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. -- The smirking “Dallas” oil baron J. R. Ewing always knew how to make an entrance. And Larry Hagman, who brought that infamous TV villain to life, apparently still has the touch.

headline: Another Season of Change for Spoleto
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — As always, it seems, the Spoleto Festival USA here, in its 35th-anniversary season, finds itself in significant transition. Since Emmanuel Villaume’s departure as music director a year ago, Spoleto has been without one, so the signature festival concert at the Gaillard Municipal Auditorium on Wednesday evening was conducted by a transient, James Gaffigan, an obviously gifted young maestro who made a strong bid for future consideration.

headline: Serving Whimsy and Goofiness on a Dining Room Table
text: If you’re pressed to name some of Monica Bill Barnes’s inspirations, here are a quick three: the theatricality of the everyday, vaudevillian humor and storytelling through song. Such notes are played over and over in her work. What starts out as mildly amusing eventually falls prey tosomething ruinous: the cutesy-pie effect.

headline: Waves of Warmth In a Penguin Huddle
text: To stay warm in Antarctica’s bitterly cold conditions, emperor penguins are known to form tight huddles. Researchers now report that while in these huddles, the penguins move in a coordinated periodic wave. This allows every penguin a chance to move from the colder outer region of the huddle into the warmer inner region.

headline: Chic in Review | The Other Kate’s Wedding
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Apple Patents Way to Prevent Concert Piracy
text: A new Apple patent intended for mobile devices could help the music and film industries stop people from illegally recording a concert or a movie playing in a theater.

headline: Obama and Boehner Have Golf Date
text: President Obama and Speaker John A. Boehner are taking their budget negotiations to a place where a lot of deals get done in the business world: the golf course.

headline: Protein-Rich Diet Helps Gorillas Keep Lean
text: Gorillas don’t seem to be facing the obesity epidemic that humans in modern society are.

headline: U.S. Orders TransCanada to Shut Pipeline
text: After a series of spills, the United States Department of Transportation has ordered the TransCanada Corporation to suspend operation of its one-year-old Keystone 1 pipeline, which carries oil extracted from oil sands in the Canadian province of Alberta to the United States. The order was issued by the department’s Pipelines and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration.

headline: Despite Restrictions, Syrians Record New Protests
text: As my colleagues Liam Stack and Katherine Zoepf report, Syria’s government apparently tried to stifle the flow of information on the protest movement with a nationwide Internet shutdown Friday.

headline: Worth Reading: The Mouse Is Dead
text: MG Siegler at the Techcrunch blog lays out the evidence that the computer mouse is dead. He says Apple is leading the way, but his argument gains strength (despite a mixed metaphor) when he points out what Microsoft is doing with its next Windows release.

headline: The Week in Pictures for June 3
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include Fleet Week, a Skee-Ball tournament and a night at small-claims court.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 3
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Hawk Cam | The Newsletter
text: Updated, 11:46 p.m. | For those who can’t get enough of the Hawk Cam family, here is a quick guide to coming events and online resources. The world of hawk fandom is ever-expanding.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 3
text: More Photographs

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: This Week’s Business News in Photos
text: Elusive home ownership, climate change, rethinking packaging, protesting austerity in Greece and more.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Former SAC Capital Trader Aided Insider Inquiry
text: A former portfolio manager at the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors testified in federal court on Friday that he had provided investigators with the names of more than a dozen individuals when he confessed to insider trading.

headline: Wedding Etiquette
text: A Sense of Style and Generosity

headline: A Missing Bronx 12-Year-Old Is Back Home, but the Mystery Lingers
text: The bad news and frantic pleas for help often arrive with big, jarring smiles, and Denzel’s disappearance was no different. A 12-year-old boy goes to bed, and when his parents look in the next morning, the bed is empty, and soon “Missing” posters sprout all over the Bronx and Upper Manhattan, showing a smiling Denzel in his private-school vest and necktie before a cozy winter-on-the-farm background.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Cuomo and Legislative Leaders Strike Deal on New Ethics Rules
text: In the wake of scandals that have felled two New York governors and multiple state lawmakers, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and leaders of the Legislature announced an agreement on Friday to overhaul the state’s ethics laws as part of an effort to stem corruption and misconduct in Albany.

headline: An Impatient Davis Rejoins the Mets, But Only as a Temporary Spectator
text: Walking with only a slight limp and carrying his protective boot in his hand, Mets first baseman Ike Davis arrived in the clubhouse before the game with Atlanta on Friday, which could have been greeted as good news.

headline: Told to Keep Low Profile, Chinese Artist Takes a Stand
text: BEIJING — After 10 hours of questioning and 7 more locked up alone in an interrogation room, Wang Jun was shown the door of a police station on Thursday night and given some parting instructions: Keep your name off the Internet, move to another part of town and do not talk to anyone but yourself.

headline: Just Drive, She Said
text: Two Saudi activists get into a car ….

headline: Women’s Final Preview: Schiavone vs. Li
text: Saturday’s match between the defending champion Francesca Schiavone and China’s Li Na pits two tour veterans with contrasting styles against each other in a final that caps a wildly unpredictable — but very entertaining — French Open.

headline: Rebel Libya Finance Chief Hunts for Funds and Hope
text: BENGHAZI, Libya

headline: On the Street | City in Bloom
text: The nonchalant look prevails at the Union Square Greenmarket on Saturdays.

headline: Through the Lens of Jamel Shabazz
text: Jamel Shabazz is marking the 10th anniversary of the book of New York City photographs that put him on the map.

headline: Captive’s Own Account of 18 Years as a Hostage
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A normal morning violently interrupted. Day after day of fear, sexual assault and loneliness. A desperate striving for normalcy in depraved surroundings.

headline: The Partisan Wrangling Over Medicare
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ungainly Knicks Lose a Man of Elegance
text: Rest assured that if — and only if — Friday was the last day that Donnie Walsh served as the chief administrator of a professional basketball team, he went out in character, as a consummate professional. Not a coincidence, for anyone who was paying attention for the last three years.

headline: In Alabama, a Harsh Bill for Residents Here Illegally
text: Alabama has passed a sweeping bill to crack down on illegal immigrants that both supporters and opponents call the toughest of its kind in the country, going well beyond a law Arizona passed last year that caused a furor there.

headline: Israel and the Gaza Flotilla
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hanging Out With Cool Cats
text: The jazz flutist Dave Valentin has toured the world as a headliner, playing with everyone from Tito Puente to McCoy Tyner, but he always returns to the Bronx, where he was born 59 years ago. Home is a modest one-story bachelor pad in Harding Park, a hidden waterfront stretch of winding streets, close neighbors — and the occasional crowing rooster — better known as Little Puerto Rico. He won a Grammy in 2002 with Dave Samuels and the Caribbean Jazz Project, and this month he will release his latest album, “Pure Imagination,” in which he overdubs himself playing five flutes. Not surprisingly, Sundays usually include at least one practice session.

headline: Despite Protests, Grand Prix Schedules Race for Bahrain
text: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia — The organizers behind the Bahrain Grand Prix decided on Friday to schedule the auto race, delayed because of an antigovernment uprising, despite pleas from local and international human rights organizations to stay away.

headline: In Queens, New Mothers and Old Asian Custom
text: Katy Lu opened the front door of the two-story house near the Queens Botanical Garden. “Why don’t I show you the babies first?” she said in Mandarin Chinese, leading the way up a staircase and past a small kitchen where a rice cooker sat on a table.

headline: I Can’t Promise You A Rose Garden
text: But I can promise you a panel discussion on Charlie Rose, tonight. Me, Jared Bernstein, Ken Rogoff, David Walker.

headline: To Cushion Against Losses, Fed Considers Raising Capital Requirements for Banks
text: WASHINGTON — Determining which financial companies are so large that their failures could pose a risk to the nation’s financial system should be done using a “transparent and replicable” formula that makes it “clear to the financial firms, the markets and the public” what institutions are covered, a Federal Reserve governor said Friday.

headline: Al Qaeda Urges Attacks in West
text: In a new video, an American-born spokesman for Al Qaeda urged Muslims in the West to initiate attacks against Western and Jewish targets.

headline: Riding Hundreds of Miles, and Just Getting Started
text: A STEADY rain pelted the New Jersey back roads, and the sun had recently crested over Princeton and was just illuminating a small but hardy group of cyclists setting out on a 125-mile ride. In most cycling circles, the distance would be a major undertaking. For this group, it was a mere tuneup.

headline: What Do Economic Models Really Tell Us About Elections?
text: Yesterday’s column on the weak historical relationship between the unemployment rate and presidential performance generated a mostly favorable reaction. But I also got a few replies wondering how to reconcile these findings against the claims, made with some frequency by political scientists, that presidential elections can be forecast with pinpoint accuracy provided that you know the economic fundamentals.

headline: Views of New York, From Past to Present
text: THE New York of Leonard Lyons was a dream, the cultural critic John Leonard once wrote, “but in dreaming it he had dreamed his way out of the Jewish ghetto and the candy stand his mother ran on the corner of Rivington and Ridge Streets.” For exactly 40 years, from 1934 to 1974, he prodigiously churned out six columns a week brimming with anecdotal insights into celebrities (from Albert Einstein to Truman Capote) rather than headline-grabbing gossip.

headline: Setting Data-Roaming Rates
text: To the Editor:

headline: Why Some New York Fire Hydrants Are Yellow
text: There are yellow fire hydrants in parts of Queens, which the city inherited from the defunct Jamaica Water Supply Company.

headline: Technology and Love
text: To the Editor:

headline: From Federer’s Supporters, Cheers and I-Told-You-So’s
text: PARIS — Their son had ended Novak Djokovic’s lengthy winning streak and kept him, perhaps, from becoming the No. 1 player in the world. Roger Federer’s father, Robert, passed around beers. His mother, Lynette, talked happily about all the people who were wrong about her son’s career slide.

headline: City Critic: Be a Broadway Star!
text: To test a new board game called "Be a Broadway Star!", Neil Genzlinger challenged several real Broadway performers to a match.

headline: Korean Grocers in New York
text: To the Editor:

headline: Secret of Oprah’s Success
text: To the Editor:

headline: At a Policemen’s Gala, One Well-Protected Guest
text: The only thing that kept us from an apoplectic fit on Thursday night was our fear of the following headline: “Reporter Arrested at Policemen’s Gala.” And despite our Nocturnalist correspondent’s calm, cool demeanor, it seemed it almost happened.

headline: You’ve Got 2 Minutes to Cry. Go!
text: You’d think that with all the money theatrical producers lose, they’d be pretty good at crying. But the other night, Ken Davenport, who is such a producer, could not shed even one tear on demand.

headline: Podcast: Job Woes, Pet Boom and Annuity Puzzle
text: The economic recovery from the shock of the financial crisis has never been all that strong, but the Labor Department’s monthly report on jobs and unemployment painted a picture of an economy that may be struggling even to keep growing.

headline: At the Center of the Global E. Coli Scare, Hamburg Frets
text: HAMBURG, Germany — It is a worrisome time in this wealthy port city, known for its 19th-century churches and busy canals, where more than 100 people have fallen ill since the outbreak of a potentially lethal form of E. coli, putting 20 patients in intensive care, including five pregnant women.

headline: Ryancare Versus Obamacare
text: Some commenters have asked a good question, albeit in a belligerent tone: how does the Ryan plan differ from the Affordable Care Act? After all, in both plans people are supposed to buy coverage from private insurers, with a subsidy from the government.

headline: Even Strength Has Been the Bruins’ Big Advantage
text: If the Boston Bruins come back from their early deficit to win the Stanley Cup, they will probably do so by defying the hockey bromide that you cannot succeed without a good power play.

headline: Hacking of White House E-Mail Affected Diverse Departments
text: WASHINGTON — The computer phishing attack that Google says originated in China was directed, somewhat indiscriminately, at an unknown number of White House staff officials, setting off the Federal Bureau of Investigation inquiry that began this week, according to several administration officials.

headline: Leaving Her Mark With the Well Worn
text: Art can, at times, have a bit of an audience problem. On the one hand, it wants to speak to the largest population. On the other, it wants to participate in conversations that only a handful of people are knowledgeable about — philosophy, say, or politics, or art itself. Betsabeé Romero, an artist born in 1963, who was educated in Mexico and Paris and now lives in Mexico City, has hit upon a solution.

headline: Shouts of ‘Fore!’ and Budget Talks
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama and Speaker John A. Boehner are taking their budget negotiations to a place where a lot of deals get done in the business world: the golf course.

headline: When the Impresario Is Also a Performer
text: The celebrated guitarist and occasional impresario John Scofield has never let his penchant for the blues get in the way of a good free-form improvisation, and in “Shades of Jazz,” a three-show summer series he curates at the Katonah Museum of Art, he indulges these predilections as both performer and presenter.

headline: Summer Programs for Children Who Bring Their Muses
text: FOR Michaela Mahon, 15, of Syosset, a yearly summer routine of going to arts camp began back in 2003, when her mother, Joan, got a new job.

headline: Uncle Mo Found to Have Liver Disease
text: Uncle Mo, the 2-year-old champion who was scratched from the Kentucky Derby the day before the race, has a liver disease called cholangiohepatitis, his internists said in a statement. The ailment is a severe inflammation of the bile passages and the liver.

headline: Massey Energy’s Ex-Chief Rejects Finding in Blast
text: WASHINGTON — Two weeks after an independent government commission concluded that Massey Energy was to blame for the explosion that killed 29 coal miners last year, the company’s former chairman released a report on Thursday disputing the panel’s finding.

headline: Yes, Medicare Is Sustainable In Its Current Form
text: I keep seeing people say that Medicare in its current form is not sustainable, as if that were an established fact. It’s anything but.

headline: Dancing on a Cloud, Over Jersey City
text: JERSEY CITY

headline: Adapting a Show for Children With Autism
text: When Lisa E. Cooney, director of education for the Paper Mill Playhouse, called a meeting last November to discuss the particulars of “Stone Soup and Other Stories,” a children’s show to be presented June 11, there was crying at the conference table.

headline: A Remade Hole May Prove to Be the Undoing of Some
text: DUBLIN, Ohio — For the past two days, golfers have moved through the leafy corridor from the 15th green to the 16th tee at Muirfield Village Golf Club, walking slowly, almost warily, like patients headed to the orthodontist. Some glanced at the new pond, others stared at the narrow putting surface that was splayed out horizontally like a thin strip of green bacon amid three dollops of gleaming white sand bunkers.

headline: Vanuatu Recognizes Abkhazia. Or Maybe Not.
text: MOSCOW — Three days after Abkhazia announced that a fifth government — the tiny, impoverished Pacific island nation of Vanuatu — had agreed to formally recognize its sovereignty, an official from Vanuatu said the report was false, as a behind-the-scenes diplomatic competition went into overdrive.

headline: Arts and Ideas Festival Extends Reach Across Borders
text: NEW HAVEN

headline: A Neighborhood Changes; Its Ice Cream Girl Doesn’t
text: As Maria Campanella steers her truck through the streets of Bensonhurst, she blasts the speakers, blares the horn and rings the bells.

headline: When Teachers Talk Out of School
text: IN 1927, a schoolteacher in Secaucus, N.J., named Helen Clark lost her teaching license. The reason? Somebody had seen her smoking cigarettes after school hours. In communities across the United States, that was a ground for dismissal. So was card-playing, dancing and failure to attend church. Even after Prohibition ended, teachers could be dismissed for drinking or frequenting a place where liquor was served.

headline: Caffeine Jolt, With a Smile
text: On a steamy Saturday morning, I had to dodge toddlers and strollers to get in line at the Black Cow Coffee Company in Pleasantville, but the clientele was so cheerful, and Michael Grant, the shop’s co-owner, and his fellow baristas were so adept at fielding orders, that the wait was, well, a pleasant one.

headline: In a World of Tastes, No Easy Labels
text: ON my first visit to Myong Gourmet, my guests and I were greeted by a round of amuse bouches: smoked duck with pickled radish and, I believe, crème fraîche. The tastes blended wonderfully, but what was the orientation? French? Asian? New American? Next came a bowl of warm pita wedges matched with three spreads: edamame and tofu, some kind of pickled vegetable, and fruit and tofu. Again, delicious. And again, I felt a little unmoored.

headline: Spanish Players Deflect Questions on Rivalries
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Iker Casillas and Andres Iniesta slid their chairs up to the table — on the same side, literally and figuratively, for a change — and waited for the questions they knew were coming. They will play for Spain in an exhibition game against the United States at Gillette Stadium on Saturday, but on Friday many of the questions — predictably, inevitably — revolved around their two club teams: Casillas’s Real Madrid and Iniesta’s Barcelona.

headline: Why Khodorkovsky Matters
text: Over the past six months, I’ve written three columns about Mikhail Khodorkovsky, the former Russian oligarch who has been in prison since 2003, charged, tried, convicted — and recently reconvicted — on transparently bogus tax and embezzlement charges.

headline: A Renaissance on Main Street
text: IF you are looking for evidence that Riverhead is undergoing a renaissance, it can be found at 1 East Main Street. This 1929 building, home to offices and shops in the past, reopened in September after a renovation, with the Dark Horse restaurant on the first floor. (There are apartments upstairs.)

headline: Rieslings for Summer
text: Few summer whites offer charms to rival those of young rieslings, especially when the vineyard and cellar reflect German wine culture.

headline: Rubbermaid Cuts Its Full-Year Profit Forecast
text: Newell Rubbermaid, the maker of Sharpie pens and plastic storage containers, cut its full-year profit forecast Friday on slumping consumer spending, setting off a 12 percent decline in its share price. Profit, excluding costs for restructuring and other items, will be at least $1.60 a share, down from a projection of at least $1.67, the company said. Analysts surveyed by Bloomberg News had forecast a profit of $1.69 a share. More than two-thirds of Rubbermaid’s sales come from the United States, where persistent joblessness and surging prices for food and gas have forced shoppers to watch their wallets. The company lowered its growth forecast for sales, excluding foreign currency fluctuations, to 3 percent to 4 percent. That is down a point from a previous estimate April 29. Stock in Rubbermaid, which is based in Atlanta, fell $2, to $14.97 a share.

headline: Indelible Pizza
text: Wedged between Starbucks and Subway in a one-story red stone building, Stretch’s Pizza is easy to overlook. Taste one of its delicious pizzas, though, and the two-year-old pizzeria makes a much more lasting impression.

headline: Authentic Flavors and Parisian Charm
text: DISTANCING itself from a formal French restaurant right from the start — “Bohemian” is part of its subtitle — Café Lola in Fairfield has the eclectic charm of an authentic Parisian cafe, with two intimate dining rooms conducive to cozy conversation.

headline: Wal-Mart to Buy Back Billions More in Shares
text: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. — Wal-Mart said on Friday that it would buy back $15 billion more of its shares to try to improve returns for its shareholders.

headline: Chrysler Favors Stock Sale by U.A.W. Retiree Trust
text: TOLEDO, Ohio — Chrysler’s chief executive said Friday that a public stock offering remained the preferred method for a health care trust to sell its ownership stake in the Detroit automaker.

headline: False Choices
text: Friday’s jobs report was abysmal.

headline: Obama Lauds Bailout at Visit to Chrysler Plant
text: TOLEDO, Ohio — If the 2012 election is about the economy, as most people think, then President Obama’s visit on Friday to this struggling manufacturing city on the Ohio-Michigan border captured as well as any day could the complicated campaign he is likely to face — playing both offense and defense, taking credit and deflecting blame.

headline: U.S. Won’t Become Isolationist, Gates Tells Worried Asian Leaders
text: SINGAPORE — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates pledged Saturday that the United States would sustain its military presence and diplomatic involvement in Asia, as he sought to calm regional worries about the potential for a new isolationism brought on by fiscal difficulties at home.

headline: Do You Know the Duffin Man?
text: Spring was rather elusive this year, but Peter Lloyd, one of the owners of Brownie Points Bakery in downtown Summit, was undeterred: he had the walls of the shop painted sky blue, and decked out the windows and shelves with bird houses, daisies and tufts of artificial green grass.

headline: Italian, Inventive, and Keen on Vegetables
Before Bike-Share Effort Starts, Concerns Are Raised About How It Will Work
text: The Bloomberg administration is only months away from rolling out an ambitious bike-share program intended eventually to rival ones in London, Paris and Washington, yet the proposal has already been plagued by questions of its viability.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 3, 2011

headline: Ghosts of Guatemala’s Past
text: IN 1954, the American government committed one of the most reprehensible acts in its history when it authorized the C.I.A. to overthrow the democratically elected leader of Guatemala, President Jacobo Arbenz. It did so secretly but later rationalized the coup on the ground that the country was about to fall into communist hands.

headline: Connecticut House Debates Requiring Sick Pay
text: The Connecticut House of Representatives debated late into Friday night as members considered a bill that would make Connecticut the nation’s first state to mandate that some employers provide paid sick days to employees.

headline: Complex Case Ahead for Prosecutors
text: The criminal case against John Edwards on misuse of campaign funds will be a challenge for federal prosecutors, experts in campaign finance and corruption said.

headline: How a Democracy Works
text: President Obama, who has spent two and a half years not delivering on his promise to fix immigration, gave a speech in El Paso last month and cloaked his failure in tough statistics — this many new border agents, that much fencing, these thousands of deportations.

headline: Saturday: Scraps in the Sticks
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Not that it’s about me, but the first thing that struck me about today’s puzzle was the appalling number of adult beverages it would take to get me up on stage at a KARAOKE BAR. I’m not a shy person by any stretch, but for some reason the thought of getting up and singing by myself in front of other people terrifies me. The last Christmas party I attended for Bust Magazine (disclosure: I construct their X Games crossword puzzle) was held at a karaoke bar here in New York City, and although I had immense fun with my fellow Busties, you would not have been able to get me up on stage if you tried. NO SIREE BOB. I will gladly applaud and cheer wildly for others, though.

headline: President Assad’s Bloody Hands
text: Syrians have shown extraordinary courage, standing up to President Bashar al-Assad’s reign of terror. We wish we could say that about the international community. So long as Mr. Assad escapes strong condemnation and real punishment, he will keep turning his tanks and troops on his people.

headline: Give Me the Permits, or Else
text: It sounded like a simple bit of noncontroversial Senate routine: raising the salary of Interior Secretary Ken Salazar to the level of his cabinet peers. Then, with all the finesse of a shakedown artist, Senator David Vitter, Republican of Louisiana, declared that he will keep a legislative hold on the $19,600-a-year raise until Mr. Salazar has his department approve more deepwater drilling permits in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Baseball Awaiting Records on Colon’s Stem Cell Treatment
text: When it was disclosed that Bartolo Colon had received a novel stem cell treatment on his ailing elbow and shoulder, Major League Baseball said it would investigate, in part to ensure that Colon had not benefited from any banned substance as part of the medical procedure.

headline: What Do You See on Your Plate Today?
text: Let’s face it, if the food on your plate forms a pyramid, you’re probably eating too much. And yet the symbol meant to guide Americans’ eating choices has long been the food pyramid, one that has grown more abstract and harder to understand over the years even as the nutritional guidelines have improved. On Thursday, the secretary of agriculture, Tom Vilsack, and the first lady, Michelle Obama, abandoned the pyramid and unveiled its replacement: a dinner plate known as MyPlate.

headline: Settlements End Suits Over Raids By Officials
text: Two groups of plaintiffs have settled lawsuits against law enforcement agencies that raided several St. Paul buildings in advance of the 2008 Republican National Convention, searching for information about protests or unlawful activities. Items seized in the raids, according to court documents, included pamphlets titled “Wash Your Own Dishes” and “Activists’ Guide to Basic First Aid.”

headline: Rodriguez Affirms Defense of His Cousin’s Presence
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Alex Rodriguez’s cousin Yuri Sucart supplied him with steroids from 2001 to 2003 and was subsequently barred from having any contact with the Yankees or their facilities. Rodriguez was asked Friday what Sucart does for him now.

headline: Outbreak in Europe May Revive Stalled U.S. Effort to Tighten Rules on Food Safety
text: The deadly wave of food-borne illness in Europe, caused by a rare form of E. coli bacteria, could finally push the United States to take long-delayed steps to protect the food supply in this country from a similar group of toxic organisms.

headline: War of Ideas on U.S. Budget Overshadows Job Struggle
text: WASHINGTON — A run of disappointing economic data, punctuated by Friday’s employment numbers, is emboldening Congressional Republicans in their standoff with the White House over the best way for the government to encourage growth.

headline: Zimbabwe: Church Officials Detained
text: Four Anglican priests and 11 church wardens were arrested Wednesday for trying to prevent people allied with a supporter of President Robert Mugabe from taking over the home of the rector of St. Mary’s Church in Harare. The 15 were released on Thursday. The Mugabe supporter, Nolbert Kunonga, an excommunicated bishop, is seeking control of thousands of church properties across four countries. “We are angry we are not being protected by the police,” the new bishop of the Harare diocese, Chad Gandiya, said Friday.

headline: Libya: Rape Accuser Says She Was Beaten in Qatar
text: Eman al-Obeidy, a Libyan woman who became a symbol of resistance when she said she had been raped and beaten by Qaddafi militiamen, told CNN on Friday that she had been beaten again, this time by officers of the government of Qatar, who deported her Thursday to the rebel stronghold of Benghazi. The reason for her deportation was unclear, and Qatari officials could not be reached for comment.

headline: Mets’ Day Starts With Bad News, and Gets Worse With Latest Collapse
text: Another difficult day for the Mets began Friday afternoon when first baseman Ike Davis limped into the clubhouse and explained that his injured left ankle was still inexplicably sore. A few hours later, the Mets were making dubious history on the field with another late-inning collapse.

headline: As Catholic Schools Close in Major Cities, the Need Only Grows
text: Amid the grandeur and permanence of St. Patrick’s Cathedral, they marched down the aisle in pairs, the graduating seniors of Rice High School in Harlem. They were the 70th commencement class in the school’s history, the latest to bear the venerable epithet of being “Rice men.”

headline: Strong G.O.P. Field?
text: Matt Welch, left, of Reason and Rich Lowry of National Review debate the strength of the Republican presidential field.

headline: Using Legacy of Watergate, John Dean to Teach Ethics
text: It was a telling list.

headline: Florida: Rights Groups Challenge New Voting Law
text: The American Civil Liberties Union of Florida filed a suit in federal court on Friday to block a state law that makes it harder for voters to change addresses at the polls and for third-party voter registration groups to operate. The A.C.L.U., joined in the suit by Project Vote, says the law should not take effect anywhere until the Justice Department reviews it to ensure that it does not discriminate against members of minorities in five Florida counties that qualify for protection under the 1965 federal Voting Rights Act. The state law, signed by Gov. Rick Scott two weeks ago, took effect immediately, except in those five counties. “In six weeks, this ill law was conceived, drafted behind closed doors, jammed through the Legislature, signed by the governor and is being rushed to a speedy and illegal implementation,” said State Senator Arthenia L. Joyner, who also joined in the suit.

headline: Photo Replay: June 3
text: A look at the day in sports, from the Iranian women’s national soccer team to the New York Mets.

headline: Elmer G. Pratt, Jailed Panther Leader, Dies at 63
text: Elmer G. Pratt, a Black Panther leader who was imprisoned for 27 years for murder and whose marathon fight to prove he had been framed attracted support from civil rights groups and led to the overturning of his conviction, died on Thursday in a village in Tanzania, where he was living. He was 63.

headline: Stolen Data Is Tracked to Hacking at Lockheed
text: Lockheed Martin said Friday that it had proof that hackers breached its network two weeks ago partly by using data stolen from a vendor that supplies coded security tokens to tens of millions of computer users.

headline: Between Young and Old, a Political Collision
text: LAKEWOOD, Colo. — Economic wreckage in America’s older population is easy to find in the ashes of recession. And when combined with the politics of a presidential election next year and talk in Congress of cuts to the system of health and economic support for retirees, the result could be volatile.

headline: Where Prisoners Can Do Anything, Except Leave
text: PORLAMAR, Venezuela — On the outside, the San Antonio prison on Margarita Island looks like any other Venezuelan penitentiary. Soldiers in green fatigues stand at its gates. Sharpshooters squint from watchtowers. Guards cast menacing glances at visitors before searching them at the entrance.

headline: Venezuela's Prison Paradise
text: On the outside, the San Antonio prison on Margarita Island looks like any other Venezuelan penitentiary. But venture inside and you'll see how far the rabbit hole goes.

headline: Under Scrutiny, Official at State University Resigns
text: A top official at the State University of New York accused of giving a no-show job to the daughter of the former Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, has resigned amid mounting scrutiny of his conduct.

headline: Central Park Zoo Bear Is Euthanized at 25
text: New York City got a bit less fluffy this week.

headline: Battle For Libya | June 3, 2011
text: In LIbya, rebels continued their battle against the forces of Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Ray Bryant, Jazz Pianist, Dies at 79
text: Ray Bryant, a jazz pianist whose sensitivity and easy authority made him a busy accompanist and a successful solo artist, beginning in the mid-1950s, died on Thursday. He was 79.

headline: Corrections
text: EDITOR'S NOTE

headline: ‘Friday Night Lights’ Watch: The Lies They Tell
text: We are covering the final season of “Friday Night Lights” according to the NBC schedule. We ask readers who have already seen the season on DirecTV or on DVD to please refrain from giving away future plot points in the comments section. For analysis of previous episodes, click here.

headline: Sony Admits That Web Site Was Hacked
text: Sony Pictures Entertainment confirmed on Friday that hackers had broken into one or more of its Web sites and said it was taking steps to prevent a recurrence.

headline: Johanna Fiedler Dies at 65; Wrote of the Met Opera
text: Johanna Fiedler, a publicist who wrote tell-all books about the Metropolitan Opera and about growing up as the daughter of Arthur Fiedler, the conductor of the Boston Pops, died on May 27 at her home in Manhattan. She was 65.

headline: Why the Gold Cup Is More Important Than Beating Spain
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — One by one on Friday, United States Coach Bob Bradley and his players talked about what a privilege it is to play Spain. Special, Bradley called it. Exciting, said Clint Dempsey. A terrific opportunity, said Carlos Bocanegra.

headline: Despite Nova’s Solid Performance, Yankees Stumble Against Angels
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Ivan Nova had no time to react when Torii Hunter ripped a line drive directly at his head. So he threw up his glove for protection, the ball striking the heel, then his left hand, before rolling away. That play, which occurred in the fifth inning of the Yankees’ 3-2 loss to the Los Angeles Angels on Friday, was a microcosm of Nova’s night. He was adept at avoiding precarious situations, but unable to dodge them all.

headline: The Early Word: Rebuked
text: Today’s Times

headline: In Afghanistan, Gates Stresses U.S. Is Committed to the Fight
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Saturday that the United States should stick to its full counterinsurgency strategy in Afghanistan at least through this year, even as American forces begin a drawdown in July and some in Congress argue that the current mission is too expensive to continue.

headline: Li Beats Schiavone: French Open Women’s Final
text: Li Na, a 29-year-old from Wuhan, China, became the first man or woman from Asia to win a Grand Slam singles title on Saturday, beating defending champion Francesca Schiavone from Italy, 6-4, 7-6(0). Li, cool and calm as she won point after point in the second-set tiebreaker, fell onto her back when Schiavone’s last shot landed long.

headline: Pakistani Militant Chief Is Reported Dead
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — One of Pakistan’s most wanted militant commanders, Ilyas Kashmiri, was killed in an American drone strike in the tribal territory of South Waziristan, residents and a militant active in the area said Saturday. But Pakistani and American officials cautioned that they had not been able to confirm his death.

headline: The Lonely Crowd(ing Out)
text: A few commenters have suggested, in response to my post on the utter failure of the claim that budget deficits would drive up interest rates even in a liquidity trap, that things might look different if we looked at real rather than nominal rates.

headline: Hitting the Slow Lane Cross-Country on a Moped
text: About a year ago Mikael Tarkela heard some disturbing news about the 1976 Peugeot 103 moped that he had been storing in a warehouse in Bushwick, Brooklyn.

headline: A Farm Sale of Integrity
text: Carole-Terese Naser is the new general manager of Runnymede Farm in North Hampton, N.H. She fell in love with horse racing when Dancer’s Image won the Kentucky Derby in 1968.

headline: Fatal Fatalism
text: Our current economic discourse is pervaded by fatalism. Leave aside the people who insist that somehow Obama has destroyed capitalist incentives by passing Mitt Romney’s health care plan and threatening to raise tax rates to Clinton-era levels. Even among people who should be sensible, you hear many assertions that run something like this: historically, recovery from financial crisis is usually slow, so we have to accept a slow recovery this time around too. Actually, that’s more or less what Obama has been saying.

headline: Supporters of a Yoga Guru Assemble for an Anticorruption Protest in India
text: NEW DELHI — Led by a prominent yoga guru, thousands of protesters on Saturday staged a huge anticorruption protest in the heart of India’s capital, gathering beneath a vast outdoor tent for a yoga session, followed by a hunger strike orchestrated as a pressure tactic against the government.

headline: ‘Whale Wars’ Leader: ‘Arrest Me or Shut Up’
text: Amid scrambling to presentations at the World Science Festival and a United Nations screening of a remarkable new film, the “Journey of the Universe,” I slipped in 45 minutes to interview Paul Watson. He’s the founder of the anti-whaling Sea Shepherd Conservation Society and central character in the popular “Whale Wars” show on Animal Planet, which began its fourth season on Friday night and may have a new focus next year. Here’s part one of the interview:

headline: Italian Vogue Adds to Its Curvy Message
text: “Real Beauties” is the title of the June issue of Italian Vogue, which highlights women with more shape than the typical model. Steven Meisel shot the feature in a private home in Los Angeles.

headline: For Bosh, Trip Home Reflects a Road Back
text: MIAMI — Not everybody in Dallas rejoiced when Mavericks forward Dirk Nowitzki spun past the Miami Heat’s Chris Bosh for the winning layup Thursday night in the waning seconds of Game 2 of the N.B.A. finals.

headline: Afghans Want Sanctions Lifted on Taliban Figures
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — United Nations officials expect Afghanistan to make a serious effort to ask the Security Council to lift sanctions soon against more than 40 Taliban figures — more than a fourth of all those who are now on the organization’s blacklist of Al Qaeda and Taliban members.

headline: Variety: An Insane Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — I painted my entryway and living room recently, and the entryway to my house now sports a sunny, lovely Mediterranean yellow hue, which warms everyone who comes into my home and makes me very happy.

headline: NATO Begins Helicopter Attacks in Hopes of Ending the Stalemate With Qaddafi
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — In a move to intensify pressure on Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces, NATO introduced attack helicopters into its air campaign against Libyan forces for the first time on Saturday, military officials said.

headline: Li Na Dethrones Schiavone at French Open
text: PARIS — Which woman had the weight of China on her shoulders? It was easy to get confused on Saturday with Francesca Schiavone more on edge and off target than Li Na for much of the French Open final.

headline: Drug Can Reduce Risk of Breast Cancer, Study Says
text: CHICAGO — A drug now used to prevent recurrences of breast cancer can also reduce the risk of it occurring in the first place, providing a new option for women at high risk of getting the disease, researchers reported here on Saturday.

headline: As Web Returns, Syrians Post More Video of Friday’s Protests and Clashes
text: Updated | 4:03 p.m. On Saturday, after Syria’s government restored the Internet access it had cut off on Friday, in an attempt to disrupt the communications of protest organizers, Syrian activists were able to upload video of Friday’s demonstrations and clashes to the Web.

headline: As Labor Dispute Goes On, Some Are Looking Past Football
text: As the N.F.L. lockout wound through the legal system, Matt Kroul returned to the family farm in Iowa. There, amid soybeans and sweet corn and cattle, he works through football’s work stoppage. The bonus: his 86-year-old grandmother cooks lunch.

headline: In Connecticut, Paid Sick Leave for Service Workers Is Approved
text: After 11 hours of debate in Hartford, state legislators approved a bill on Saturday to make Connecticut the first state in the nation to mandate paid sick leave for hundreds of thousands of service workers.

headline: Syrian Tanks Move in on City as Thousands Mourn Protesters’ Deaths
text: CAIRO — Syrian tanks took up positions outside the city of Hama on Saturday, where tens of thousands of people took to the streets to mourn the deaths of at least 65 protesters gunned down by security forces there the day before.

headline: After Two-Year Break, a Special Grand Slam Rivalry Is Renewed
text: PARIS — No two men have met in a Grand Slam final as often as Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal, but there were times that it seemed it might not happen again.

headline: Lawrence Eagleburger, a Top Diplomat, Dies at 80
text: Lawrence S. Eagleburger, a troubleshooting diplomat and senior foreign policy adviser to presidents who served the country for more than 40 years, including 42 days as secretary of state at the close of President George Bush’s term, died on Saturday in Charlottesville, Va. He was 80.

headline: Laugh Lines
text: JON STEWART

headline: Obama Retools 2008 Machine for Tough Run
text: CHICAGO — Saddled with a faltering economic recovery, President Obama is rebuilding the campaign machinery that vaulted him into office, hoping it can overcome the challenges of persistently high unemployment and a fractured coalition of supporters.

headline: Fighting Words
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, a Republican who has won attention for preaching belt-tightening, faced criticism himself last week after he took a state helicopter to see his son play a high school baseball game and then flew to a meeting of political supporters. (Mr. Christie later paid $2,151 for the cost of flights he took to his son’s games; the State Republican Party reimbursed the state $1,232 for the flight to meet with supporters.)

headline: Bend Me, Shape Me: The Heavy-Metal Version
text: IT’S hard to beat the versatility of plastic on a production line. Melt and inject it into molds, let it cool and harden, and out comes an endless variety of parts at high rates of speed.

headline: Rays’ Test of Riches: Extra Draft Picks
text: The Tampa Bay Rays had to make a decision before last season. They could field a team with several potential free agents and try to win a championship, or they could trade those players for prospects. They chose the first path, won the American League East and let every free agent go.

headline: Considered: John Edwards
text: Courtrooms can be tricky places. For John Edwards, a skilled trial lawyer and a Democratic candidate for president in 2008, it was the place where he first found his fortune and fame.

headline: Prime Number
text: 85,000: The estimated maximum number of people killed in the Haitian earthquake last year, according to a new draft report prepared for the United States Agency for International Development. That figure is well below the death toll of 316,000 announced by Haiti’s government in January. An American official backed away from the new tally — by an outside research group that also found that other aspects of the disaster had been overstated — saying it was “beyond the scope of the commission and purely reflects the views of the author.”

headline: Prospect Heights, 4:40 A.M.
text: A four-alarm fire at the corner of St. Johns Place and Washington Avenue in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn in the early morning hours Saturday.

headline: Citing Medical Needs, Yemeni Leader Goes to Saudi Arabia
text: WASHINGTON — Yemen’s embattled president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, arrived in Saudi Arabia on Saturday for urgent medical treatment of wounds sustained in a bold attack on the presidential compound, Saudi officials said, abruptly shifting the political calculus that has allowed him to cling to power despite months of protest and violence.

headline: Power? Thanks, but I’d Rather Have Influence
text: This interview with  Bing Gordon, a partner with the venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Back Then: 1990
text: Dr. Jack Kevorkian, the central, controversial figure in the national debate over assisted suicide, died last week at age 83 in a hospital outside of Detroit. He first assisted in a suicide in 1990, connecting Janet Adkins, a 54-year-old woman suffering from Alzheimer’s disease, to a device of his own invention. The Times’s Lisa Belkin reported as follows:

headline: Edwards Case Casts Spotlight on a Long Reclusive Donor
text: Rachel Mellon, now 100 years old and long one of the richest women in America, has lived a life of maximum discretion and minimum exposure.

headline: Focusing on the Social, Minus the Media
text: THE scene unfolding at the Thai restaurant in Brooklyn was like that of any other casual dinner party. A small group of people sat around a wooden table, passing large dishes of spicy red curry and fried rice, drinking cold beers and swapping war stories about apartment hunting in New York.

headline: The Annuity Puzzle
text: IMAGINE a set of 65-year-old identical twins who plan to retire this summer after long careers. We’ll call them Dave and Ron. They have worked for different employers and have accumulated retirement benefits worth the same amount in dollars, but the benefits won’t be paid out the same way.

headline: Nets’ Dreams Under Construction
text: Like the Owen Wilson character in Woody Allen’s “Midnight in Paris,” Avery Johnson goes back in time by night whenever he flips on the N.B.A. finals and watches the team he almost won a championship with five years ago.

headline: Drug Makers’ Feared Enemy Switches Sides, as Their Lawyer
text: Michael K. Loucks was arguably the nation’s most influential prosecutor of health care fraud.

headline: Inciting a Revolution: The Investor Spring
text: THE Arab Spring gave Joseph W. O’Donnell an idea about, of all things, his investments.

headline: Sarah Palin and the Politics of Winging It
text: WASHINGTON — If a maybe-candidate for president does not issue an “official schedule” to the news media as she tours around in something that closely resembles a campaign bus, did the tour really happen?

headline: A Leaner, Fitter Berkman Regains His Form
text: ST. LOUIS — Lance Berkman played in a World Series with Andy Pettitte. Last fall, they were teammates again in the playoffs. They are each from Texas, earnest and friendly, married with four children, borderline Hall of Famers who pepper conversation with words like heck and golly.

headline: The Old Lance Berkman Is Back
text: ST. LOUIS – If the Yankees had somehow managed to win Games 6 and 7 of the American League Championship Series in Texas last fall, Lance Berkman would have been their first baseman in the World Series. (Mark Teixeira was out with an injury.) Seven months later, this still sounds bizarre to Berkman, who had always been a Houston Astro until a trade to New York in July.

headline: Should (Could) America and Pakistan’s Bond Be Broken?
text: WASHINGTON — America’s tormented relationship with Pakistan has long had the subtlety of a professional wrestling match. So when frayed relations turned openly hostile in recent weeks, it was hardly a surprise to see Pakistani officials flirt publicly with China, America’s biggest rival in Asia.

headline: The Guilt of Trading Too Much
text: FOR nearly all investors, frequent trading is a terrible proposition. Many people know they trade more than they should — but they just can’t stop.

headline: Fresh Tomatoes for Inner Cities
text: WE live in the midst of broken systems, or so it seems. From our education system to our financial and health care systems, we are confronted with all manner of interconnected problems. As if that isn’t enough, the system we rely on for our very sustenance — the one that delivers our food — is also in a state of disrepair.

headline: Side Effects? These Drugs Have a Few
text: Dr. Jon Duke of Indiana University was trying to figure out why his patient’s blood platelets were abnormal. Could it be a side effect of one of the dozen drugs the man was taking, a number that is not uncommon among elderly people?

headline: Between College and That First Job
text: Q. You’ve just graduated from college but couldn’t find a job or internship in advance — so you are moving back in with your parents. Can you take some time off before restarting your job search?

headline: Farming to Franchising
text: I  GREW up on a 100-acre farm in Michigan with almost every farm animal imaginable, including horses, peacocks, pigs, sheep and chickens. At age 6 or 7, I’d watch my father butcher the cows and I’d help pick the feathers off the chickens after they were slaughtered. I wouldn’t have the stomach for that today.

headline: Medicare Sustainability
text: Just a further data note. Canada has a system called Medicare; it’s actually quite a lot like US Medicare, but less open-ended and more serious about cost control. Here’s Canadian spending on health versus US spending, both as percentages of GDP:

headline: In Book Circles, a Taming of the Feud
text: When the Nobel laureate V. S. Naipaul shook hands with the novelist Paul Theroux at a book festival in the Welsh town of Hay-on-Wye last weekend, one of the longest-running feuds in the literary world came to a decorous and rather anticlimactic end.

headline: Confounding Jeter
text: Derek Jeter has faced 1,162 pitchers through Friday in his 17-year career. None have stymied him more than these seven pitchers.

headline: Under the Sea, Coral Reefs in Peril
text: A ghostly pallor is overtaking the world’s coral reefs.

headline: A Magnificent Seven of Pitchers Have Thwarted Jeter
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — The list of pitchers includes an up-and-coming starter and a down-and-out reliever, a begoggled right-hander and a nearsighted left-hander. One is from Canada and one plays there now. The final one played for nine teams, three of them twice, over 19 seasons.

headline: Preakness Winner to Race Derby Winner at Belmont
text: The rubber match between the Kentucky Derby winner Animal Kingdom and the Preakness Stakes champion Shackleford is, indeed, on for the 143rd renewal of the Belmont Stakes.

headline: Regret and Defense Amid Tressel Fallout
text: Ever since Jim Tressel resigned as Ohio State’s football coach on Monday, the fallout, the university’s president, E. Gordon Gee, said, has been “like a tsunami.” Gee acknowledged that the university had turned into a punching bag in the national news media. He also apologized for the way that he and the university handled parts of Tressel’s case.

headline: The ‘Murderabilia’ Market
text: THE Smith Corona typewriter went for $22,003. The hooded sweatshirt and sunglasses fetched $20,025. The 20 personal journals were a steal at $40,676.

headline: Saying No Thanks to a Thankless Role
text: The N.H.L. announced last week that its senior vice president for hockey operations, Colin Campbell, would no longer oversee player discipline beginning next season. Campbell, tired of the pressure that came with the job, suggested the change.

headline: The Curious Case of Nelson Obus
text: Nelson Obus is on no one’s list of Wall Street titans. He is just another guy who chased that golden dream: catch the morning train into Manhattan, run a small but prosperous hedge fund, catch the evening train out, back to a leafy island of suburban wealth.

headline: The Cubs’ Cincinnati Kid
text: Tony Campana would never be tall, destined to grow to only 5 feet 8 inches. But at 7, he could imitate his basketball hero in one way.

headline: Donovan Out for U.S.-Spain
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Landon Donovan will not play when the United States faces Spain in an exhibition game at Gillette Stadium on Saturday, U.S. Soccer announced via Twitter.

headline: Puzzling Golf Rule on Moving Ball Is Altered
text: DUBLIN, Ohio — One of golf’s more puzzling, and occasionally vilified, rules has been changed by the United States Golf Association and will soon be officially off the books.

headline: New Liberty Coach Establishes a Line of Defense
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — As the scrimmages against the Chinese national team and the Connecticut Sun progressed across five 10-minute periods Monday at the Madison Square Garden Training Center, John Whisenant never sat. He paced in front of the Liberty bench, evaluating and coaching all at once.

headline: The Death Sentence That Defined My Life
text: San Francisco

headline: Deaths on Dirt Revive Debate About Merits of Synthetic Tracks
text: LEXINGTON, Ky. — A sideways rain pounded the grounds of Keeneland racetrack ahead of the Lexington Stakes, a prep race for last month’s Kentucky Derby. Spectators found shelter under the clubhouse roof while the brave took a spot on the rail with an umbrella or a Daily Racing Form covering their heads.

headline: Robustelli’s Family Came First, and Giants Reaped the Benefits
text: If the Giants were to create a Mount Rushmore of their most important players, Andy Robustelli’s chiseled face would be at its right end, befitting his position on the defensive unit that popularized pro football in the New York metropolitan area half a century ago.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: With Michael Phelps
text: These days, even when Michael Phelps is not in a pool, he will be in a virtual pool. Michael Phelps: Push the Limit, developed by Blitz Games and published by 505 Games for use with the Kinect system for Microsoft’s Xbox 360, will be released on Tuesday. Phelps, 25, who has won 16 Olympic medals, including 14 gold, said it was “a cool feeling” to have his own game. JOE BRESCIA

headline: How the Debt Ballooned, and How to Deflate It
text: To the Editor:

headline: Battle For Libya | June 4, 2011
text: British Foreign Minister William Hague flew to Benghazi on Saturday to meet rebels fighting to oust Libyan leader Moamer Kadhafi after NATO deployed attack choppers for the first time.

headline: Paperback Business Best Sellers
Hardcover Business Best Sellers
Should a Medical Education Be Free?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Obesity and the Workplace
text: To the Editor:

headline: Coping With Alzheimer’s
text: To the Editor:

headline: Yalies in the Military
text: To the Editor:

headline: Video of Syrian Funerals and Demonstrations
text: As my colleague Liam Stack reports, thousands of people took to the streets in Syrian city of Hama on Saturday to mourn the deaths of at least 65 protesters who were killed in demonstrations there the day before. Razan Zeitouneh, a Damascus-based activist, said as many as 100,000 people came out in mourning.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: America’s Energy Options
text: Last week, under the headline “Invitation to a Dialogue: The Energy Future,” we introduced a feature in which we will occasionally invite readers to respond to a particularly provocative and interesting letter. We hope to spur a dialogue on issues of national or international importance. Here is the original letter, followed by a sampling of reader responses, and a rebuttal from the first writer.

headline: Sticker Shock
text: Lots of happy talk accompanied the Obama administration’s unveiling of new fuel economy stickers for cars and light trucks that will include annual fuel costs and information about emissions. The new stickers, mandatory starting with the 2013 models, are a big improvement on the simple miles-per-gallon estimates on the present label. If they were there right now, we suspect many car buyers would be experiencing a new sort of sticker shock.

headline: Overlooking Oversight
text: In late May, Congress extended three enhanced surveillance powers that were granted to the government after the 9/11 attacks — two in the Patriot Act and one from a related intelligence law. In doing so, lawmakers neatly managed to avoid any lapse in those powers. They failed miserably in their duty to carefully re-examine the provisions, trim back excesses, and add safeguards to protect civil liberties. In other words, they ignored the whole point of requiring that the provisions be periodically reviewed.

headline: Loan From Russia Props Up Belarus
text: MOSCOW — A Russian-controlled economic assistance fund agreed on Saturday to extend a $3 billion loan to Belarus, propping up the country’s teetering economy — and with it the authoritarian president, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko.

headline: John Edwards, A Cautionary Tale
text: Self-destruction in politics is painful to watch for voters whose hopes are stirred time and again by the high promises of a compelling candidate. The case of former Senator John Edwards is especially tawdry and disturbing. He was criminally indicted on Friday on charges of misusing hundreds of thousands of dollars in campaign donations to keep his mistress and their baby a secret while he pursued the White House in 2008 and protected “his public image as a devoted family man.”

headline: Drinking In the Draught of June
text: If we could bottle a few days to uncork later in the year — when the wind has got us by the neck and the curbs are full of taxi-slush — these would be the ones: early June, the days of peony and iris. Conifers still wear the green tips of new growth, and a few of the hardwoods, hickories especially, still show a last vestige of May. Otherwise, the trees have cast their pollen and fledged completely. Now come the deep, dark shadows of late summer.

headline: After Disputed Call, Schiavone Folds in Final
text: Francesca Schiavone was feeling it. She was back in the French Open final on Saturday as Li Na failed to capitalize on two big break opportunities.

headline: An Archbishop Burns While Rome Fiddles
text: THE archbishop of Dublin was beginning to sniffle.

headline: Israel Braces for Clashes During Border Protests
text: JERUSALEM — Israel on Saturday was bracing for possible clashes along its borders after Palestinian activists in the region called for protest marches on Sunday, three weeks after a similar wave of coordinated protests led to deadly clashes with Israeli troops.

headline: Advice for China
text: FROM: Ministry of State Security

headline: In Mountain View, 2 Contrasting Economic Worlds Intersect
text: At the Google campus on the outskirts of Mountain View, employees sip lattes under brightly colored umbrellas as others pass on company bicycles, laptops secured in the front baskets. This year the company will add substantially to its work force of more than 5,000 in that Silicon Valley city, and it has just leased nine acres to expand its campus.

headline: Should the Mets Retire Gary Carter’s No. 8?
text: In their 50-season history, the Mets have retired only one number for one of their players: Tom Seaver’s No. 41. Such restraint is admirable, perhaps, compared with the Yankees. But what about Gary Carter’s No. 8?

headline: Unelected Councils in India Run Villages With Stern Hand
text: SISANA, India — There are two laws in this dusty village less than 50 miles from India’s capital: the law of the land and the law of the village. And for local residents like Takdir Dahiya, the law of the village councils known as khap panchayats is the only one that matters.

headline: ‘City Family’ Has a Nice Ring, but It Looks a Lot Like a Machine
text: Elizabeth Lesly Stevens writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Our Fantasy Nation?
text: With Tea Party conservatives and many Republicans balking at raising the debt ceiling, let me offer them an example of a nation that lives up to their ideals.

headline: Development Guidelines Prompt Clash
text: Plans to build 12,000 homes in Redwood City are at the heart of an escalating spat between developers and environmentalists about proposed shoreline building guidelines to prepare the region for climate change.

headline: Choosing Words: How Careful Is Too Careful?
text: Re “The Other Torture Debate” (May 15):

headline: Little Kabul
text: The commercial area in Fremont known as Little Kabul is a cultural hub for the Bay Area’s sizable Afghan-American population. Signs in the Dari language dot the storefronts along this small stretch of Fremont Boulevard. At Maiwand Market, visitors line up every day for the traditional Afghan bread that is made fresh there. JONATHAN CURIEL

headline: As Iraqi Militants Flee, Families Are Targets of Blood Reckoning
text: KIRKUK, Iraq — Even his parents admit that Faras Awad was a killer. As an insurgent leader in this northern Iraqi city, he kidnapped women and executed civilians in the years after the American invasion. Then he vanished, to escape the law, his enemies and a $50,000 bounty on his head.

headline: The Next Outbreak
text: Buena Vista, Va.

headline: Too Late for Blagojevich, a Watergate Refugee Teaches Ethics to Lawyers
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Products for Pampered Pets
text: Makers of luxury goods for cats and dogs displayed their wares at the Global Pet Expo in Orlando.

headline: Plans for a Hospital Site Spark Tax Breaks Debate
text: Situated in the heart of busy, prosperous Lincoln Park, the three-way intersection of Halsted Street and Lincoln and Fullerton Avenues seems engineered for a traffic jam.

headline: ‘For the Dogs’ Has a Whole New Meaning
text: ORLANDO, Fla.

headline: A 60-Year Love Affair With Chicago, Caught on Film
text: Six decades of Chicago live inside the retirement-home apartment of the photographer Lee Balterman. Filed in cabinets, hung on walls and stacked precariously on most every available surface are thousands of Chicago moments captured on film.

headline: A Filibuster Creates an Overnight Celebrity
text: Texas Democrats never had much hope in this Legislature, where Republicans have a huge majority and an unshakeable drive to slash spending without raising taxes or dipping into the state’s giant savings account.

headline: Eden in Alberta
text: By some spiral of fate and capitulation, instead of a street in the East Village or a shabby lane in London, I stare out at a suburban patio, a generous and quiet garden in Edmonton, Alberta.

headline: Is Your Pet Eating Better Than You Are?
text: Despite a sluggish economy, the market for gourmet pet foods and other luxury pet products is booming, explains Business Day reporter Andrew Martin. As he writes:

headline: The Powers Never Veered From Their Set Course
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor at The Texas Tribune, writes a column for the Tribune.

headline: A Food System Under Strain
text: The Green Revolution that began in the 1940s raised global food output, but more innovation may be needed to feed a growing world population.

headline: Colleges Rewarded for Outcomes, but Which Ones?
text: During the regular session, Gov. Rick Perry’s top legislative priority for higher education was the implementation of a financing system that rewards universities for graduating more students, not just for getting students into classes. To reach its 2015 goals, Texas needs to increase the number of degrees awarded by 46,000 each year.

headline: Sunday: Cagey Answers
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — We last saw Yaakov Bendavid a little over a year ago (Across Lite, Solution, blog) when he flip-flopped on us. Today we welcome him back, and for what? So he can switch letters on us. We sit here, reading clue after clue, patiently filling in letter after letter — on a Sunday, mind you, our day off — and this is the thanks we get. I tell you, kids nowadays. …

headline: Lyle Lovett on Theaters With Magic
text: Last month, Texas politicians on both sides of the aisle found something they could agree on: House Concurrent Resolution 165, which named Lyle Lovett the 2011 Texas state musician. It’s an obvious honor to bestow upon the guy who wrote “That’s Right (You’re Not From Texas).” But as with the former honoree Willie Nelson and the Legislature’s 2012 selection, Billy Gibbons of ZZ Top, the consistency of Mr. Lovett’s four-decade career makes him one of the state’s most obvious — and instantly recognizable — good-will ambassadors.

headline: Amtrak, Protecting Us From Progressive Economists
text: And why does it think he’s Chinese?

headline: I Met My Future at the Mall
text: Providence, R.I.

headline: Not J.R.’s Kind of Town
text: Dallas

headline: Learning to Read on Zero Dollars a Day
text: Boise, Idaho

headline: A Real Economic Meltdown
text: Portland, Ore.

headline: Reader Comments on Sunday’s Column
text: My Sunday column perhaps contains a hint of bile: it reflects my distress at where the economic debate in this country is going, and at the rising levels of economic inequality. I’m afraid that efforts to address the budget mess — a serious challenge, but a medium- to long-term one — will aggravate the inequality and reduce opportunity in this country. In short, I worry that Republican or Tea Party budget policies will make America look more like…well, that’s the point of the column.

headline: Protecting the Food Supply
text: Wheat breeders in Mexico, worried about climate change, are trying to find drought-tolerant varieties.

headline: A Warming Planet Struggles to Feed Itself
text: CIUDAD OBREGÓN, Mexico — The dun wheat field spreading out at Ravi P. Singh’s feet offered a possible clue to human destiny. Baked by a desert sun and deliberately starved of water, the plants were parched and nearly dead.

headline: Damaging the Earth to Feed Its People
text: On a warming planet, humanity faces a great challenge in feeding itself at reasonable cost in the coming century, as I explain in Sunday’s paper. An issue I raise only in passing in the article is that agriculture itself is one of the earth’s greatest environmental threats.

headline: Questions on Climate Change and the Food Future
text: Justin Gillis is taking reader questions on the potential effects of  climate change on the global food supply and will respond this week on the Green blog.

headline: Back in Winnipeg, Bettman Strikes Different Chord
text: The contrast between what Gary Bettman said in 1995 and ’96, as the Winnipeg Jets prepared to leave Manitoba, and what he has said in the last few weeks, as the N.H.L. prepared to return there, shows how much he has learned about the sensitivities of hockey fans in the intervening years.

headline: Mets Knock Bay Down a Peg or Two
text: Jason Bay, the struggling slugger with the $66 million contract, was joined by Manager Terry Collins as he sat down to eat hours before the Mets played the Atlanta Braves on Saturday night at Citi Field. Collins had a quick piece of news that was not tough for Bay to digest: he was being demoted.

headline: Efforts to Ban Circumcision Gain Traction in California
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — When a group of activists proposed banning circumcision in San Francisco last fall, many people simply brushed them aside. Even in that liberal seaside city, it seemed implausible that thousands of people would support an effort to outlaw an ancient ritual that Jews and Muslims believe fulfills a commandment issued by God.

headline: A Grass-Roots Fight to Save a ‘Supertree’
text: NANJING, China — Tall as a 15-story building, with a mighty trunk, crooked branches and kingly canopy of leaves, the London plane tree, Platanus x acerifolia, is prized by horticulturists and city planners as a “supertree,” immune to urban grime and smog.

headline: A G.O.P. Hopeful Gathers Momentum as More Voters Like What They Hear
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Michele Bachmann was campaigning just north of here, the Sarah Palin tour was rumored to be arriving soon, and Mitt Romney was on his way to announce his entry into the presidential race.

headline: Showdowns for Young Stars Provide Glimpse of the Future
text: Two recent exhibition matches in St. Louis could help pave the way for an American to have a shot at the world title after the next championship match in 2012.

headline: D’Antoni a Question Mark as Walsh Moves On
text: Mike D’Antoni is comfortable with the transition game. It is a staple of his high-octane offense and an unfortunate reality of the coaching life. Momentum can shift quickly, unexpectedly.

headline: Sammy Ofer, Magnate and Israeli Power Broker, Dies at 89
text: JERUSALEM — Sammy Ofer, the Israeli international shipping magnate, philanthropist and art collector who headed a family ranked as the richest in Israel, and whose company is at the center of a storm over dealings with Iran, died at his home in Tel Aviv on Friday. He was 89.

headline: Signs of an Urban River’s Revival in Virginia
text: RICHMOND, Va. — Every urban river is a political canvas. What was, in hard industrial eras past, melds to what is and what might yet be.

headline: A Polarizing Figure in End-of-Life Debates
text: In reports of Dr. Jack Kevorkian’s death on Friday at the age of 83, the general rule of obituaries held: Do not speak ill of the dead.

headline: Edwin Honig, a Poet, Professor and Translator, Dies at 91
text: Edwin Honig, a poet, critic and translator known for his elegant English renditions of seminal works of Spanish and Portuguese literature, died on May 25 at his home in Providence, R.I. He was 91.

headline: With More Important Games to Come, U.S. Is Taught Low-Cost Lesson
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Bob Bradley and the United States national team never made any secret of the fact that Saturday’s exhibition game against Spain was not as important as the game they will play against Canada on Tuesday. That could be a good thing — it will make the loss easier to forget.

headline: Torrid Start, Frigid Finish as Stricker Holds Lead
text: DUBLIN, Ohio — Steve Stricker almost made himself look unbeatable on a blazing Saturday afternoon at Muirfield Village Golf Club, holing out from the fairway at the second hole for eagle, then ripping his approach from 238 yards to within 7 feet at the fifth and brushing that in for another eagle.

headline: Urgency Is Business as Usual for Heat
text: DALLAS — The Miami Heat again embraced its inner enigma amid a cross-examination of why the Dallas Mavericks now own home-court advantage, if not the psychological edge, in the N.B.A. finals.

headline: Leo Rangell, a Stalwart of Freudian Talk Therapy, Dies at 97
text: Dr. Leo Rangell, a leading psychoanalyst during the heyday of classical Freudian talk therapy in the 1960s and ’70s, and a relentless advocate for the slow approach to treating emotional distress even as antidepressants and managed care made short-term treatment the norm, died on May 28 in Los Angeles. He was 97.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 5
text: Following the revelation of May’s disappointing job numbers, the Sunday shows are almost single-mindedly focused on the economy this week. The White House is sending Austan Goolsbee, chairman of President Obama’s Council of Economic Advisers, to be its representative in the discussion on ABC’s “This Week” and CNN’s “State of the Union.”

headline: For the Jobless, Little U.S. Help on Foreclosure
text: The Obama administration’s main program to keep distressed homeowners from falling into foreclosure has been aimed at those who took out subprime loans or other risky mortgages during the heady days of the housing boom. But these days, the primary cause of foreclosures is unemployment.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: Hughes Takes Baby Steps
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — On a sun-splashed June afternoon in Southern California, it felt like early March in Florida for Phil Hughes.
