His second spring training continued Saturday, when he threw 22 pitches to hitters from the mound at Angel Stadium, where he moved ever closer to an eventual return. Hughes remains at least a month away, according to Manager Joe Girardi, but his progress has allowed him to start looking ahead.

headline: Photo Replay: June 4
text: A look back at the day in sports, from the triathlon championships in Madrid to the French Open.

headline: Green Men to Invade Boston
text: The Vancouver Canucks’ superfans, the Green Men, are on their way to Boston for Games 3 and 4 of the Stanley Cup finals.

headline: Bay Is Dropped in Order, and Gee Keeps Rising for the Mets
text: Jason Bay, the struggling slugger with the $66 million contract, sat down to eat hours before the Mets played the Atlanta Braves on Saturday night and was joined by Manager Terry Collins. Collins had a quick piece of news that was not tough to digest: Bay was being dropped in the batting order.

headline: Quiz: Locked-Out Players Become Jacks of New Trades
text: With their time off, some lesser-known N.F.L. players have been making a living at other pursuits.

headline: Rafa vs. Roger: One for the Ages
text: Rafael Nadal looks to win his sixth French Open Sunday as he faces his longtime friend and rival Roger Federer in the finals of the French Open. Nadal has beaten Federer four times here at Roland Garros, in the semifinals in ’05, and in consecutive finals in ’06, ’07, and ’08. Federer won here two years ago, defeating the only man to ever beat Nadal at Roland Garros, Robin Soderling, in the final. Federer advanced to the final with his upset win on Friday over Novak Djokovic, in a stirring match that will be remembered for its high level of play.

headline: Lauren & Alex
text: Lauren Blasch and Alex Carabelli met during their freshman year at Boston University. In this homemade video, they describe how their friendship turned into love.

headline: Jane & Nathaniel
text: In this homemade video, Jane Borden & Nathaniel Stogdill tell how they met like people did 20 years ago, by running into each other at a coffee shop.

headline: Lillian & Adam
text: In this homemade video, New Yorkers Lillian Baharestani and Adam Archer reflect upon how they met in San Francisco.

headline: Morgan & Ross
text: Morgan Brooks and Ross Thompson's parents have known each other for 25 years but they connected in 2004 when Morgan went to Ross' birthday party. They share their story in this homemade video.

headline: Burrows Strikes In Overtime To Put Canucks In Command
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — Alexandre Burrows, who escaped suspension in the wake of a biting incident in Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals, scored two goals, including the winner 11 seconds into overtime, and gave the Vancouver Canucks a 3-2 victory here on Saturday night and a 2-0 series lead over the Boston Bruins.

headline: Alaina & Hale
text: In this homemade video, Alaina Stahl and Hale Simon recount how they started falling in love after Thanksgiving with Hale's family.

headline: Keila & Daniel
text: In this video produced by Joel Witmer, Keila Lopez and Daniel Harrington describe how they found happiness together online.

headline: Larry & Jeremy
text: Larry Slater says he moved to Alabama to settle down and coincidentally he met Jeremy Erdreich four days later.

headline: Jennifer & Cory
text: Twelve years after meeting and nine years of dating, Jennifer Atanasoska and Cory Davis share their story in this homemade video.

headline: Stacey & David
text: In this homemade video, David Abeles says he took the role of Santa Claus in the Radio City Christmas Spectacular because traveling with 32 Rockettes was alluring. He ended up falling for Stacey Sund.

headline: C. C. Sabathia Makes Himself at Home on the Road
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — It was understood during the 2008 off-season that C. C. Sabathia preferred to pitch for a team on the West Coast. It is where he grew up, where he felt comfortable and where he has pitched so well over the last week for the team that signed him: the Yankees. Sabathia worked the first eight and two-thirds innings Saturday night against the Los Angeles Angels before giving way to Mariano Rivera, who needed one pitch to secure the final out of a 3-2 victory at Angel Stadium.

headline: Israeli Troops Advance Into Gaza
text: Israeli ground troops and tanks cut swaths through the Gaza Strip, bisecting the coastal territory and surrounding its biggest city as the new phase of an offensive against Hamas gained momentum.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S. vs. Spain
text: The game was ugly. And the player ratings are, too.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 4, 2011

headline: Discovering Science on Governors Island
text: Children identified plant species, built robots and gazed at the sun as part of a World Science Festival event on Governors Island.

headline: Malhotra Returns From Injury and Helps Buoy Team to Win
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — An eye became the focus of the Stanley Cup finals on Saturday, after a set of teeth and a finger were a distraction on Wednesday.

headline: Remembering Hall of Famer John Henry Johnson
text: John Henry Johnson, one of the best all-around backs in N.F.L. history, died Friday at age 81. He may not be as famous as some other Hall of Famers, but he left his mark, both on his teammates, and especially on those who played against him. Andy Barall writes about pro football history for the Fifth Down.

headline: At the Scoop, a Summer of Culture in London
text: A sunken, 1,000-seat, open-air amphitheater on the South Bank of the Thames with stunning views of Tower Bridge and the Tower of London is the setting for the annual Scoop at More London festival, running this year through the summer with a program of theater, music and film — all  free.

headline: Five Tips for Rainy Day Photography
text: Not many of us will risk our lives racing into the path of a tornado to photograph the funnel, like cameraman Jim Reed, but many of us will risk our cameras in the rain trying to get a shot of a kids’ soccer game or an impressive cloud formation.

headline: Google’s New Chromebook Explained
text: Update Sunday, June 5 7:52 p.m.: Clarified that, while Chromebooks do have a hard drive, that drive is used by the OS, not for a user’s data storage. Also changed wording to indicate that data is not in Google’s possession, necessarily, but whichever cloud-based service a user is using.

headline: French Open: Rafael Nadal Beats Roger Federer
text: Rafael Nadal won his sixth French Open, tying Bjorn Borg’s record, with a 7-5, 7-6(3), 5-7, 6-1 victory over Roger Federer, his primary rival and the winner of 16 Grand Slam tournaments.

headline: After Raid, Indian Guru’s Protest Stirs a Firestorm
text: NEW DELHI — A sobbing but defiant Swami Ramdev vowed Sunday not to be intimidated by a police crackdown that dispersed thousands of followers massed for a hunger strike to protest corruption. He blamed the governing Congress Party for turning a peaceful protest into chaos.

headline: Protesters in Yemen Rejoice as Leader Goes to Saudi Arabia
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Thousands of antigovernment protesters celebrated in the streets of Yemen’s capital on Sunday, setting off fireworks and slaughtering cows to mark the departure of President Ali Abdullah Saleh for medical treatment, despite new uncertainty about when — and even whether — he would agree to a lasting transfer of power.

headline: Israeli Soldiers Shoot at Protesters on Syrian Border
text: JERUSALEM — Israeli forces fired at pro-Palestinian protesters on the Syrian frontier on Sunday as they tried to breach the border for the second time in three weeks, reflecting a new mode of popular struggle and deadly confrontation fueled by turmoil in the Arab world and the vacuum of stalled peace talks.

headline: Stage Version of ‘Once’ Will Start Downtown
text: Rather than open on Broadway in the fall as producers originally hoped, the musical adaptation of the 2006 Dublin-set indie film “Once” will receive a downtown production at New York Theater Workshop in November, with Broadway a possibility after that, according to executives involved with the show.

headline: Women’s Preview: U.S. vs. Mexico
text: HARRISON, N.J. — As the United States women’s national team prepares to play Mexico on Sunday in its final domestic World Cup tune-up match, some of the players on the other side of the field will probably look familiar.

headline: Fireworks in Yemen’s ‘Change Square’
text: As my colleague Robert Worth reports, on Sunday Yemenis crowded into an area of the capital, Sana, they have renamed “Change Square” to celebrate the departure of President Ali Abdullah Saleh, who went to Saudi Arabia on Saturday for urgent medical treatment.

headline: Drugs Show Promise Slowing Advanced Melanoma
text: CHICAGO — Two new drugs have been found to prolong the lives of people with advanced melanoma, representing what researchers say is notable progress against the deadly skin cancer after decades of futility.

headline: Farming in a Challenging Climate
text: The deep, almost inherent, adaptability and resilience of the world’s farmers makes them well suited to deal with a changing climate. But they are also dealing with limits to usable land and water, rising populations and the near-insatiable appetites of the world’s fast-expanding middle class.

headline: Iran Protests Hijab Ban
text: As if FIFA did not have enough problems, now comes word that Iranian soccer officials plan to lodge a protest against a FIFA official who prohibited Iran’s women’s national team from taking the field in an Olympic qualifying match because the players were wearing the traditional Muslim head cover, the hijab.

headline: Canadian Health Care in Perspective
text: Yesterday I pointed out that Canadian Medicare looks much more sustainable than our system. But how good is their system, eh? Well, the Commonwealth Fund does regular surveys of health system performance on a variety of indicators; the latest is here (pdf). The summary table:

headline: Business Expansion and the Political Climate
text: So I didn’t have much time to take down the Chamber of Commerce guy on This Week today. But if you look at the National Federation of Independent Business survey (pdf), you’ll see a lot of businesses complaining about the political climate — hey, a lot of them watch Fox — but very few actually saying that this climate is deterring expansion:

headline: Inquiring Minds on Governors Island
text: Is Kentucky bluegrass really blue? What is a weed? Why do plants need to shoot their seeds?

headline: 2 Are Killed in Sixth NATO Copter Crash Since Late April in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two NATO service members died Sunday when their helicopter crashed in eastern Afghanistan. It was the latest in a string of crashes in recent weeks that were being investigated.

headline: Steeper Pullout Is Raised as Option for Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s national security team is contemplating troop reductions in Afghanistan that would be steeper than those discussed even a few weeks ago, with some officials arguing that such a change is justified by the rising cost of the war and the death of Osama bin Laden, which they called new “strategic considerations.”

headline: Prospect of 2nd Greek Bailout Worries Economists
text: VENICE — As European leaders move toward a second bailout for Greece, some economists are warning that a new rescue would merely kick the country’s problems further down the road and might not avert a default that could strain Europe’s monetary union.

headline: First Place for ‘X-Men: First Class’
text: One of the year’s best-reviewed wide-release movies, “X-Men: First Class,” took in a solid $56 million at the North American box office over the weekend — easily enough for No. 1 and to help reboot a sagging franchise. Facing audience and critical rebellion over the last two “X-Men” installments, Tom Rothman, co-chairman of 20th Century Fox, took creative risks with “First Class” that appeared to pay off, including casting a cadre of untested young actors and approving a screenplay that includes Russian, French, German and Spanish dialogue — highly unusual for a summer blockbuster. In partial release overseas, the film took in an additional $64 million. “The Hangover Part II,” the raunchy buddy comedy from Warner Brothers, was second with an estimated $32.4 million for a two-week total of $187 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing statistics. “Kung Fu Panda 2” (DreamWorks Animation via Paramount) was third with about $24.3 million, sending its two-week total past $100 million. “Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides” showed continued life in fourth place, taking in about $18 million for a three-week total of $190.3 million. The crude comedy “Bridesmaids” (Universal) was fifth with about $12 million for a four-week total of $107.3 million.

headline: Nadal Equals Borg’s Record With Sixth French Open Title
text: PARIS — Bjorn Borg could not make it to Roland Garros on Sunday, which turned out to be a missed opportunity. It would have made for just the right photograph: Borg handing over the Coupe des Mousquetaires to his successor in the soft evening light in Paris.

headline: Every Home’s a Castle, Cinderella
text: Last week came the unhappy news that the housing market had plunged in March, with analysts telling us that the downward spiral would proceed indefinitely. Faith in the market has been further tarnished, and we’re told that renting appeals. As one housing-industry expert explained: “There was a time when owning a home was a symbol you had made it. Now it’s O.K. not to own.”

headline: Weighing In on Synthetic Tracks
text: Since their arrival on the horse racing landscape, synthetic tracks have been the subject of fierce debate.

headline: American Wins Boys’ French Open Title
text: PARIS — Unseeded Bjorn Fratangelo of the United States defeated Dominic Thiem of Austria, 3-6, 6-3, 8-6, on Sunday to win the French Open boys’ singles championship.

headline: No BELL Prize
text: Via Edward Hugh, I see that the BELLs — Bulgaria, Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania — are now being lauded as great success stories for having maintained their euro peg and avoided default.

headline: Health Care Zombies
text: I actually first encountered the term “zombie lies” with regard to Canadian health care, where false beliefs — like the one about hordes of Canadians heading to America for care, which is completely untrue — just keep coming back, no matter how many times they’re killed by evidence.

headline: In Golf, Justin Timberlake Sees Metaphors for Life
text: Justin Timberlake does not moonwalk, or dance at all, after making a birdie putt on the golf course.

headline: Teeing Off With Justin Timberlake
text: On Par columnist Bill Pennington hits a Brooklyn golf course with entertainer Justin Timberlake.

headline: Will Victory Spur Athletic Reform in China?
text: BEIJING — Li Na’s victory in the French Open on Saturday thrilled China, but some observers wondered whether the country’s sports machine would allow many other athletes to follow her unorthodox career path.

headline: Old Patina Encircles Fresh Art in Venice
text: VENICE — “Illuminations,” the title of the main exhibition at the 54th Venice Biennale here, is meant to evoke the notion of artists as a source of enlightenment. But that does not necessarily mean new, cutting-edge artists. Much of this Biennale is more subdued and less experimental than in years past, more of a nostalgic meditation on life and art than a revelatory peek into the future.

headline: Palin Says She Didn’t Err on Paul Revere
text: Sarah Palin defended her historical account of Paul Revere’s famous midnight ride of 1775 on Sunday, telling an interviewer “I know my American history.”

headline: Wade Finds Himself in Familiar Surroundings
text: DALLAS — Dwyane Wade has strolled these corridors many times in the last five years, but never with the resonance he felt upon returning to the American Airlines Center this weekend.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Albertina Sisulu, Who Helped Lead Apartheid Fight, Dies at 92
text: JOHANNESBURG — Albertina Sisulu, considered by many to be the mother of South Africa’s liberation struggle, a woman who was hounded and jailed by the apartheid government but who lived to see her children assume leadership roles in a democratic nation, died here on Thursday. She was 92.

headline: In Search of the True Self
text: Mark Pierpont used to be an important figure in the evangelical Christian effort to help “cure” gay people of their homosexual desires. He started out just printing up tracts and handing them out in gay bars, but his ministry grew over time, and eventually he was traveling the world and speaking to crowds that sometimes numbered in the thousands. There was just one problem. Mark Pierpont himself was gay. He continued to feel sexual desires toward other men and was constantly engaged in an effort to suppress them. In the documentary film “Protagonist,” Pierpont movingly describes his inner conflict, saying that he sometimes felt an almost physical revulsion at his own desires and would then think: “Good. I hate this.  I hate sin, just like God hates sin.”

headline: At the Bienniale
text: The 54th Venice Biennale, on view until November, includes a diverse array of exhibitions, from 89 countries, scattered across the city.

headline: In Pandora’s Valuation, a Few Sour Notes
text: Pandora Media is distinctly Web 2.0. Its Music Genome Project tailors Internet radio stations to individual tastes. Pandora is using that digital DNA to capitalize on investor demand for hot technology plays, with an initial public offering that could value the company at $1.4 billion. But investors should be going in with their eyes, and not just their ears, wide open. Pandora’s business model is pretty old school.

headline: If You Celebrate Nihilism, Is It Somethingism?
text: Hunter Hunt-Hendrix, the frontman and dogma director of Liturgy, the Brooklyn black-metal band, has a lot to say about the genre. He says it with his boyish mien, reminiscent of Shannon Hoon: soft, long hair; baby face; ever-present faint smile. He says it with his vocals, which are notionally the growls that predominate the music, though he delivers them gently, like a cat lapping up water. Mostly what he’s saying to purists is: Kiss off.

headline: Monday: Jug Band Instrument
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — There doesn’t seem to be a special occasion for this puzzle, but it’s a fine tribute nonetheless. Gary Whitehead offers us a shout out to WEST POINT, the military academy that has been churning out Army officers since 1802.

headline: In Philadelphia, an Operatic Portrait of a Stepmother for the Ages
text: PHILADELPHIA — Unsettling news from the financially struggling Philadelphia Orchestra, whose recent announcement of shortened seasons, a smaller ensemble and a populist programming agenda sent tremors of shock and dismay throughout the classical-music world, paints a bleak prognosis for progressive artistic initiatives here. But look at what’s going on in the city this month, and a different picture emerges.

headline: A Mistress of Voltaire, Set to Video
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — At a gathering like the Spoleto Festival USA here, the profusion of events large and small often yields revealing juxtapositions, not necessarily intended. Two unrelated programs last week showed the good and the bad of combining classical music with video projections, a recourse hailed in some quarters as an ideal way to attract new listeners in a visually oriented age if not the very salvation of the field.

headline: Cuban Visitors Share Sounds and Moves of Their Roots
text: Music follows history’s paths. One leads to the Creole Choir of Cuba, which is known there as Grupo Vocal Desandann, the Choir of Descendants. The choir made its exhilarating United States debut on Saturday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music as part of the ¡Sí Cuba! Festival. Desandann is a 10-member voice-and-percussion choir from the Cuban city of Camagüey, although only four men and five women performed Saturday because of the seemingly inevitable visa problems. The choir is made up of Cuban descendants of Haitians who were twice displaced: first from Africa to Haiti by the slave trade, then from Haiti to Cuba in waves dating back to Haiti’s 1790 revolution. Their families held on to the Haitian Creole language and to songs remembered through generations.

headline: Dreams of a Dying Courtesan
text: At a certain point in “Lady of the Camellias” — and that point is pretty much the beginning — the audience member driven to despair by the inanity before her is reduced to trivial entertainments like counting the number of times Armand Duval, the ballet’s petulant leading man, casts himself to the ground in a fit of something or other.

headline: An Affair, a Murder, a Sensation
text: Before it became one of the most familiar premises for hard-boiled fiction and film noir, the tale of the wife who coaxed her lover into getting rid of her annoying husband and cashing in on his life insurance was an actual news event. As he writes in an essay called “Whence Novels Come” (posted on the Web site of Santa Clara University, where he teaches) Ron Hansen found this out only accidentally. But he has made it the basis for “A Wild Surge of Guilty Passion,” a novel that separates the mawkish tabloid murder case from its later, tougher incarnations.

headline: Experimental Sounds, Soothed by the Waves
text: Looking at a concert program on Friday and seeing that the opening work was by Charles Wuorinen, I was expecting the thorny, dense style — fascinating but difficult to penetrate—that is his trademark.

headline: When a Nobel Prize Isn’t Enough
text: Lexington, Mass.

headline: More ‘Jersey Shore’
text: Maybe MTV has figured out a way to keep “Jersey Shore” on the air for eternity. (Cue the rapture predictions once more.) With production of Season 4 of this hit reality show about to be shown, the network said it had ordered a fifth season, to begin production this month in New Jersey. The cast members (including Snooki, below) evidently won’t have much time for a vacation between their on-camera vacations. On Friday MTV said that Season 4, based in Italy, would have its premiere on Aug. 4. “Jersey Shore” is, by far, the most popular series in MTV’s history.

headline: Broader Conflict Is Feared as Fighting Breaks Out on the Border
text: JUBA, Sudan — Fighting broke out in a heavily militarized part of Sudan on Sunday, United Nations and Sudanese officials said, escalating tensions between the northern and southern areas of the country a month before it is to be officially divided.

headline: Upright Citizens Brigade Joins SiriusXM Radio
text: The Upright Citizens Brigade Theater will start a weekly hourlong live radio show on SiriusXM Radio, that satellite radio company announced. “Live From UCB Theater” will record a different show each week at its theaters in New York and Los Angeles, showcasing the comedy troupe’s usual mix of improv, sketch comedy and stand-up. The first episode will run at 11 p.m. on Saturday on the radio service’s Raw Dog Comedy Channel. The partnership increases the potential audience for Upright Citizens Brigade performances from 245, the maximum number of seats sold at its two theaters combined, to 20.6 million, the reported number of SiriusXM subscribers. “This is just one step in our secret evil plan to take over the world! Oops,” Amy Poehler, a founding member of the group, said in a statement. The initial shows will include “Totally J/K,” hosted by Joe Mande and Noah Garfinkel; “Waiting for Obama: A Night at the Hall of Presidents”; and “The Roast of Justin Bieber.” “We were always told we had a face for radio,” Ms. Poehler said. “We just never knew it would be satellite.”

headline: A Galaxy of Ballet Stars Spinning in a Flickering Universe
text: High among the highlights of American Ballet Theater’s annual eight-week spring season are its world-class guest ballerinas. This year the company is graced by Alina Cojocaru, from the Royal Ballet in London; Natalia Osipova, from the Bolshoi in Moscow; Polina Semionova, from the Berlin State Opera Ballet; and Diana Vishneva from the Mariinsky of St. Petersburg. Nowhere else in the world will you find the like.

headline: A Troubling Trend for the Heat
text: DALLAS — Miami has established a fairly reliable winning formula, and it does not involve shooting dozens of 3-pointers. So the first two games of this series provided an anomaly and a concern. The Heat took 54 3-pointers in Games 1 and 2, and just 50 free throws.

headline: Taking the Customer From Check-In to the Checkout Line
text: BUSINESSES and advertisers are using retail check-in services on mobile phones and daily deal Web sites to stay in constant contact with their customers these days. Now a new feature from Meebo is trying to bridge the gap between check-ins at brick-and-mortar locations and online deals by allowing users to check into Web sites.

headline: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include consumer credit for April (Tuesday); Federal Reserve beige book (Wednesday); trade deficit for April, weekly jobless claims and wholesale trade inventories for April (Thursday); and import prices for May (Friday).

headline: Syrian Army Kills 38 In North, Reports Say
text: CAIRO — Syrian military forces were reported to have killed 38 people in the northern province of Idlib on Saturday and Sunday, demonstrators and rights activists said, as security forces appeared to redeploy from other towns to join the latest front in the harsh crackdown on a three-month-old popular uprising against the government of President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Keeping Count, Getting a Clue
text: The Memorial Weekend Sectional Flight A/X Swiss Teams was played at the Cavendish Club in Manhattan eight days ago. It was won by Jeanne Rahmey, Win Allegaert and Rizo and Jack Alhale of New York. They finished 6 victory points ahead of Susan Schnelwar, Jesus Arias, Bill Begert and Doug Heron of New York.

headline: With Pitching and Power, Yankees Pass a Road Test
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — The way their schedule falls, the Yankees’ reward for playing nine games on the West Coast against the three best rotations in the American League is an unforgiving homestand. Going to New York are the rival Boston Red Sox, who have rebounded from a miserable start, then Cleveland and Texas, who lead their divisions. But so do the Yankees, who did more than just survive what could have been a ruthless trip.

headline: For Couric, ABC’s Pitch Proved Best
text: On Feb. 8, executives from NBC, including Steve Burke, the new chief executive, and Steve Capus, the president of news, made their way to the St. Regis Hotel in Manhattan, prepared to make a pitch to bring their one-time news star, Katie Couric, back into the network fold.

headline: Cellphone Fears, Twitter Tears
text: When it comes to cultural shifts and personal regimes, I’m with Dr. Spock: Trust yourself. If you give some new practice a real try and you like it, keep doing it. If it seems weird, it probably is.

headline: Data Grows, and So Do Storage Sites
text: SAN FRANCISCO — When people had only one or two computers, file sharing wasn’t a big worry.

text: For a few hours on Sunday, Governors Island became something of a Hamptons satellite, dotted with people in Nantucket reds, linen suits, Lilly Pulitzer pinks and sunhats that seemed as wide as a city block.

headline: Lowering the Bar in Olympic Bidding
text: NBC’s Olympic reign could end Tuesday in a hotel in Lausanne, Switzerland, when it faces ESPN and Fox in an auction for the rights to the 2014 Winter Games in Sochi, Russia, and 2016 Summer Games in Rio de Janeiro.

headline: Projects Use Phone Data to Track Public Services
text: When New Yorkers head underground, they cannot always be sure of what awaits them. The city’s subway system can be mysterious, with daily delays resulting from minor emergencies, track work and other events in the tunnels that riders know they will never truly understand.

headline: Deadly E. Coli Outbreak Linked to German Sprouts
text: BERLIN — Local German officials said Sunday that they had evidence that tainted domestic sprouts had caused the deadly E. coli outbreak that has afflicted Germany and unnerved fresh-produce markets throughout Europe, and they shut down the farm in the northern part of the country where the sprouts were grown.

text: Refugees from the contested Sudanese border town of Abyei have found themselves cramped together at a makeshift camp in the town of Turalei.

headline: No Radios by the Fountain, Please! Or Cellos!
text: The crisp new signs began going up in some of the most popular spots in Central Park near the end of May. In large white letters on green backgrounds they announce that the areas have been designated Quiet Zones, and that musical instruments and amplified sound are not permitted. Some of the signs cite the authority of the Central Park Conservancy, the private organization that manages the park. Others also bear the name of the city’s Department of Parks and Recreation.

headline: Brinkmanship in Sudan as a Deadline Nears
text: AGOK, Sudan — In the past few weeks, President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan, who has been accused of orchestrating a genocide in Darfur, seems to be steering his country back toward war.

headline: Online Video Start-Ups Seek to Carve Out a Place Beside YouTube
text: CHICAGO — For many Internet users, YouTube is synonymous with online video. But Mike Michaud and several friends who live in suburban Chicago are trying to change that.

headline: U.S. Women Top Mexico on the Way to Germany
text: HARRISON, N.J. — For more than 90 minutes Sunday, the United States women’s national team swung unproductive crosses into the middle of Mexico’s penalty area or tried to barge its way within whispering distance of goalkeeper Ceci Santiago.

headline: Mets Leave Bay Out of Lineup
text: A night after Manager Terry Collins dropped the struggling Jason Bay to sixth in the Mets’ order, Bay’s name was not on the lineup card for Sunday night’s series finale against the Atlanta Braves.

text: LOS ANGELES — Many young companies are trying to seize on the intersection of social media, personalization and celebrity, but StarGreetz.com has something most do not: a pack of prominent Hollywood backers.

headline: Cuomo Health Adviser Absolved in Ethics Inquiry
text: A health care consultant with close ties to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo did not violate state lobbying regulations when he contacted state officials on behalf of a Queens hospital seeking more Medicaid financing, a confidential investigation by the state ethics commission has determined.

headline: Showdown Puts Sizzle Back in the Belmont
text: The Kentucky Derby champion Animal Kingdom arrived at Belmont Park on Sunday, ensuring that the 143rd Belmont Stakes will not lack in star power or drama. With the Preakness Stakes champion Shackleford already on the grounds, next Saturday’s race will be viewed through the prism of a championship showdown.

headline: Bruins Failing to Be Strong to the Finish
text: BOSTON — The Vancouver Canucks won the first two games of the Stanley Cup finals at home by the narrowest margin possible, but each time, they prevailed by being the more energetic team in the final minutes.

headline: John Henry Johnson Dies at 81; Inspired Fear on the Field
text: John Henry Johnson, a brawny but agile runner and a powerful blocker who starred for the San Francisco 49ers, the Detroit Lions and the Pittsburgh Steelers in a Hall of Fame career spanning 13 professional football seasons, died Friday in Tracy, Calif. He was 81.

text: LOS ANGELES — Doing well is difficult. So is doing good.

headline: Burress Will Soon Be Free to Redefine Himself
text: Plaxico Burress will be released from the Oneida Correctional Facility in Rome, N.Y., on Monday. Television trucks and cameras, which began gathering at the facility last week, will be on hand to record the moment, which comes three years and four months after Burress made a game-winning touchdown catch for the Giants in Super Bowl XLII.

headline: Bank Shares Take a Beating, and It May Not Be Over Yet
text: Michael Scanlon is tempted by bank stocks, truly he is.

headline: Maverick Hopes for Title to Leave Permanent Mark

headline: Helping Teachers Help Themselves
text: ROCKVILLE, Md. — The Montgomery County Public Schools system here has a highly regarded program for evaluating teachers, providing them extra support if they are performing poorly and getting rid of those who do not improve.

headline: Program for Special-Needs Pupils Is Jeopardized
text: Like thousands of other Chicago parents every year, Jennifer Meade-Magruder is not sure which public school her child will attend in the fall. This year, the prospects are even more unsettling because the preschools that could serve her special-needs son, Joshua, face smaller budgets that could force them to close.

headline: Despite His Season-Long Slump, the Braves’ Uggla Isn’t Being Written Off

headline: For Bay, a Day Off From the Quest to Find His Swing
text: The gloom that hovers over Jason Bay extended even to a victory by his favorite hockey team Saturday night. Bay, the Mets’ left fielder, had just gone hitless for the fourth game in a row, but a treat awaited him when he flipped on the television at home. His Vancouver Canucks were about to start the overtime period of Game 2 of the Stanley Cup finals against the Boston Bruins.

headline: In Hasidic Village, Attempted Murder Arrest Is Linked to Schism

headline: Vouchercare Is Not Medicare
text: What’s in a name? A lot, the National Republican Congressional Committee obviously believes. Last week, the committee sent a letter demanding that a TV station stop running an ad declaring that the House Republican budget plan would “end Medicare.” This, the letter insisted, was a false claim: the plan would simply install a “new, sustainable version of Medicare.”

headline: Beltran Pulled From Game
text: 9:39 p.m. | Updated

headline: Stricker Survives a Barrage of Birdies by His Competitors to Win the Memorial
text: DUBLIN, Ohio — Steve Stricker’s challengers came out swinging in Sunday’s final round of the Memorial Tournament, firing at flags, pouring in birdie putts and eliciting Augusta-like roars from the galleries that swarmed Muirfield Village Golf Club from early in the morning until nearly 8:30 at night.

headline: Dr. Kevorkian’s Victims
text: The case for assisted suicide seems to depend on human sympathy — on the impulse toward mercy, the desire to ease what seems like pointless pain and suffering. Why shouldn’t the terminally ill meet death on their own terms, rather than at the end of prolonged agonies? Why shouldn’t the dying depart this earth with dignity, instead of enduring the inexorable stripping away of their physical and mental faculties?

headline: A Force Behind Lady Gaga Inc.
text: Troy Carter, Lady Gaga’s manager, helped start Backplane, a way to connect fans, whether of music or sports teams.

headline: ‘We Shall See What Stuff You Are Made’
text: Years later, as he recalled the difficulty of writing about the Civil War, Herman Melville wondered how best “to speak of the hurricane unchained.” He wasn’t alone: many prominent Northern writers wrestled with the same problem, from the aftermath of Fort Sumter to the end of the fighting. Indeed, of all the effects the war would have on American culture, few were as profound as the impact on literature.

headline: They Want to Make Voting Harder?
text: One of the most promising recent trends in expanding political participation has been allowing people to vote in the weeks before Election Day, either in person or by mail. Early voting, which enables people to skip long lines and vote at more convenient times, has been increasingly popular over the last 15 years. It skyrocketed to a third of the vote in 2008, rising particularly in the South and among black voters supporting Barack Obama.

headline: No Time to Let Up on the Fight
text: The battle to slow the global AIDS epidemic has made astonishing progress over the past decade, especially in countries whose survival as functioning societies had once seemed threatened. The question is whether the momentum can be maintained at a time when donations are falling, the need for treatment is rising, and research suggests that with sufficient resources the epidemic could be stopped in its tracks.

headline: Stopping Fraud at Trade Schools
text: New York State needs to do a better job of regulating the for-profit trade school industry, which is increasingly known for deceptive practices and saddling students with debt while providing them little in return.

headline: We Call That a Big Tent
text: If you drew up the specs for a commerce secretary, John Bryson would seem to fit the bill. Mr. Bryson, president Obama’s nominee, brings a distinguished career as a businessman, public servant and environmentalist. This is just the résumé for someone whose department is tasked with expanding exports, managing the census, monitoring the atmosphere and protecting America’s ocean waters.

headline: Happy Sweating and Singing
text: No matter what Michelle Obama keeps telling us about our dangerous diets, there are times when a person craves nothing so much as a long swig of soda pop. Especially now that summer’s upon us, don’t you feel the need for something cool and sweet and fizzy, bursting with delicious empty calories?

headline: Fantastical Adventures of a Missing Son
text: The stage is wreathed in wonders for the Signature Theater Company’s stately production of “The Illusion,” the final offering in its season devoted to the works of Tony Kushner. Adapted by Mr. Kushner from “L’Illusion Comique,” a mongrel oddity of a work from the 17th-century French playwright Pierre Corneille, this “Illusion” trafficks in a special, baroque brand of magic in which flowers bloom out of nowhere, a half-buried piano plays itself, and spectral circles of seemingly airborne lanterns glow wanly, with the threat of sudden darkness always lurking.

headline: Demi Moore to Host Report for CNN on Human Trafficking
text: For months, CNN has been campaigning against modern-day slavery on its newscasts and Web sites. For the next stage, it’s bringing in star power.

headline: Nintendo Is Hit by Hackers, but Breach Is Deemed Minor
text: TOKYO — Nintendo, the manufacturer of the Wii and 3DS game systems, said Sunday that it had been the target of a recent hacker attack, the latest in a flurry of intrusions into corporate Web sites.

headline: Stranded Whales Now Far From Alone
text: KEY LARGO, Fla. — With labored breath and diminished strength, three remaining pilot whales from a pod of 23 that stranded itself off the lower keys have fought to stay alive in a bayside pen here at the rustic Marine Mammal Conservancy center.

headline: The High Line Isn’t Just a Sight to See; It’s Also an Economic Dynamo
text: A decade ago, so many moneyed interests were united against saving the elevated freight tracks that cut through the West Side of Manhattan that the idea appeared to be doomed. Owners of land and buildings throughout Chelsea wanted the decaying High Line viaduct razed, and the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani supported their feelings.

headline: Dr. Irwin D. Mandel, Expert on Dental Chemistry, Dies at 89
text: Millions of dental patients who have successfully avoided unpleasant drill-and-fill procedures owe much to Dr. Irwin D. Mandel — an expert on dental chemistry jocularly known among colleagues as a leader of “the Salivation Army.”

headline: Josephine Hart, Author of Best-Selling ‘Damage,’ Dies
text: Josephine Hart, an Irish-born novelist whose best-selling tale of erotic obsession, “Damage,” inspired the 1992 feature film of that name starring Jeremy Irons and Juliette Binoche, died on Thursday in London. Ms. Hart had long been circumspect about her age but was believed to have been in her late 60s.

headline: Social Democrats Claim Victory in Portugal
text: LISBON — Portugal’s Social Democrats unseated the governing Socialists with a resounding parliamentary election victory on Sunday, giving the next government a strong mandate to enact a tough austerity program in return for 78 billion euros, or about $114 billion, international bailout.

headline: Deal to Sell Goldman Unit Said to Be Near
text: Goldman Sachs’s brief and disappointing time in the mortgage servicing business could draw to a close early this week.

headline: Fitness Training to Get Your Game in Better Shape
text: Golf fitness is a hot topic because so many professional golfers have bought into the concept that fitter means farther and straighter ball flights. And there is little doubt that overall fitness is good for your overall game.

headline: Texas Still Has Its Rustlers, and Men in White Hats Chasing Them
text: GROESBECK, Tex. — Whoever was stealing cattle had to have some cowboy in him, the theory went. You could tell by the seamless way he could lure more than a dozen animals at a time out of their pens, onto his trailer and into the endless Texas night, like some Pied Piper of bovines.

headline: Witness to Abuse
text: Frustrated by the state's failure to respond to her reports that residents were being abused, a worker at O.D. Heck, surreptitiously recorded a conversation with top agency officials.

headline: Golf’s Journey to the East
text: A little more than three weeks ago, K. J. Choi of South Korea won the Players Championship. Five days after Choi hoisted the crystal trophy that comes with that near-major victory, Titleist and Foot Joy — two of the biggest brand names in the golf industry — were sold to a group led by the sporting-goods maker Fila Korea.

text: Jonathan Carey did not die for lack of money.

headline: Ex-Officer Set to Win Narrow Victory in Peru

Muammar el-Qaddafi — already in its fourth month, and the third month of NATO airstrikes — to drive him from power.

headline: What Limits Should There Be on Teachers Writing Publicly About Students?
text: Should teachers be suspended or fired for writing about their students on Facebook, or in other public forums, in a way that mocks, demeans or disparages them — or does this impinge on teachers’ rights to freedom of speech? What limits, if any, should there be on what teachers write publicly about their students, whether via social media, on blogs, in a memoir, or anywhere else? Why?

headline: Lent Influential Ears, the Arts Salute Education

Bringing together the worlds of art and politics, the invitation-only benefit, “Lincoln’s Legacy and a New Era of Hope,” celebrated President Abraham Lincoln’s hope for a world of tolerance and acceptance — with a call for influential guests to do their part to make it a reality.

text: “A photograph of a roomful of servers wouldn’t really be interesting,” Mike Osborne said. Printing presses, on the other hand — now there is something to marvel at.

headline: U.S. Drone Strikes Are Reported to Kill at Least 18 in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — American drone aircraft attacked at least three sites in the tribal region of South Waziristan on Monday, killing at least 18 people, according to Pakistani officials.

headline: The Early Word: Drawdown
text: In Today’s Times:

headline: Justin Tuck Wants to See Burress Back With Giants
text: One benefit from the N.F.L. lockout is that players can devote more time to their charities. Justin Tuck, the Giants defensive end, hosted his Third Annual Celebrity Billiards Tournament at Slate nightclub in Manhattan on Thursday. The event benefits Tuck’s Rush for Literacy, a program for New York students. When he’s not working for his charity, Tuck said, “I’m watching ESPN for at least four hours a day.”

headline: Prague’s Museums, Open at Night and Free
text: These days, few things in life are free, making Prague’s annual Museum Night a rare and alluring treat. Offering a unique opportunity for cultural hobnobbing in the evening hours, many of the city’s museums and galleries will be staying open late on June 11, and admission will be free from 7 p.m. to 1 a.m.

headline: Vermont’s Move Toward Single-Payer Health Insurance
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

headline: Sentence of the Month: May
text: The time has come, once again, to decide the winner of our past four winners — the Sentence of the Month for May. Here are the candidates:

headline: Amazon’s and Google’s Cloud Services Compared
text: On Monday, Apple chief executive Steve Jobs is expected to announce a new product that allows iPhone owners to stream music from their personal iTunes collections to their phones.

headline: Q&A: Printing Properly in IE 9
text: Q.

headline: Complaint Box | A Report Card Ritual, Destroyed
text: Sometime soon, for the fourth time this school year, my children’s grades will appear here at home — via e-mail, the postal service or maybe one day soon, cellphone app.

headline: This Week in Small Business: Is the Sky Falling?
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

headline: U.S. Braces for Withdrawal Along Iraqi Road
text: BAGHDAD — Even as the American military winds down its eight-year war in Iraq, commanders are bracing for what they fear could be the most dangerous remaining mission: getting the last troops out safely.

headline: H.P. Tests Mobile Technology in Fight Against Malaria
text: For years Hewlett-Packard has been equated with computers and printers. The company is looking to be a player in a new era of mobile health monitoring.

headline: Daimler and Rolls Gain Majority of Engine Maker
text: Daimler and Rolls Royce said on Monday that they jointly held nearly 60 percent of Tognum shares, calling it a milestone in the takeover of the German engine maker whose shareholders they have wooed for weeks.

headline: Reverend Malthus and the Future of Food
text: My article in Sunday’s paper about the world’s food supply offered portents of a more difficult human future.

headline: Who Made That Oreo Emboss?
text: There are many imitations, but there is only one Oreo. Thankfully, distinguishing it from the rest is easy, due to the signature pattern that’s printed on each chocolate wafer. Seen above is a nonedible representation by the artist Andrew Lewicki, titled, “Oreo Manhole Cover.” Although the sculpture is 28 inches in diameter, cast in iron and lacks a cream filling, Lewicki’s diligent rendering of the pattern makes the likeness instantly recognizable.

headline: Fix a Ticket, Alienate a Bronx Jury
text: Bronx juries are to the New York police what third terms are to New York mayors: sources of bedevilment. There is nothing new in this, but lately it has acquired a fresh twist. The reason is a tendency of some officers — probably more than a few — to fix tickets as a, ahem, “professional courtesy” to an assortment of friends, relatives and some others found in the ranks of the overprivileged.

headline: Bankrate Sets Price Range for I.P.O.
text: Bankrate, an online personal finance publisher, on Monday set the price range for its initial public offering at $14 to $16 a share.

headline: Face Time | Nonie Creme
text: Tina Turnbow is a professional makeup artist, who is known for lending her celebrity clients editorial polish.

headline: Eurazeo Buys 45% Stake in Italian Fashion Brand
text: Moncler, the Italian luxury clothes and accessories maker, said on Monday that the French investment house Eurazeo had agreed to buy a 45 percent stake in the company for 418 million euros.

headline: Monday Reading: Boutique Hotels Offer Loyalty Programs, Too
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: The Morning Skate: Top Draft Prospects, Higgins Helps Canucks, Plus/Minus
text: The N.H.L. scouting combine was held in Toronto over the last four days. One hundred of the top-rated players eligible for this year’s draft participated in physical testing under the watch of doctors and trainers and in meetings with the hockey operations staffs of the league’s 30 teams. James Mirtle of The Globe and Mail visited the combine and got Matthew Nieto, a forward from Boston University, to sum up the feelings of a lot of players.

headline: Strauss-Kahn Pleads Not Guilty
text: Updated 10:55 a.m. | Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former managing director of the International Monetary Fund, pleaded not guilty on Monday to charges that he sexually assaulted a hotel housekeeper.

headline: Axis of Hip-Hop, Onstage and Online
text: “The song that best encapsulates the push and pull of hip-hop in 2011 is ‘I’m on One,’ the recent DJ Khaled-organized collaboration of Drake, Lil Wayne and Rick Ross,” Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The Times wrote after seeing those three perform that joint effort at Hot 97’s Summer Jam, three-and-a-half hours of hip-hop at the New Meadowlands Stadium on Sunday. “ ‘I’m on One’ was the high point of the most vibrant Summer Jam lineup in recent memory, and the one that reinforced the fact that hip-hop’s current power centers couldn’t be further away from hip-hop’s birthplace.” Read more from Mr. Caramanica on the concert, which started as a “dogged, if not quite thrilling reminder of the limitations of New York hip-hop,” but picked up by the time Drake, Lil Wayne and Mr. Ross shared the stage.

headline: ‘Culture Warrior’ Rick Santorum Jumps In
text: 12:02 p.m. | Updated Former Senator Rick Santorum made it official on Monday, announcing first to ABC News and then to a crowd at the courthouse in Somerset, Pa., that he would join the field seeking the Republican nomination for president.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: A Force Behind Lady Gaga Inc. | Lady Gaga’s manager, Troy Carter, is a driving force behind the star’s digital strategy. Now, he has helped create a start-up Web network, Backplane, and Lady Gaga is heavily invested.

headline: Day of Days
text: Is it just me, or is there a remarkable absence of D-Day related stories in today’s news? Maybe editors are too busy saving Ryan’s privatization.

headline: Inside the Financial Wreckage of ‘Lucky Guy’
text: New York theatrical flops consuming $2 million to $3 million usually occur on Broadway, where plays cost that much and musicals are easily twice as expensive. Such debacles are rarer Off Broadway, but the lead producer and investors in the Nashville-themed musical “Lucky Guy” lost at least that much money when the show closed on May 29, 10 days after opening night, according to two theater producers with knowledge of the musical’s capitalization.

headline: Goldman Sells Mortgage Servicing Unit to Ocwen
text: Goldman Sachs has agreed to sell its Litton Loan Servicing unit to the Ocwen Financial Corporation for about $263.7 million, ending its ties to an industry steeped in controversy.

headline: The Hot and Sweaty Side of Summer Reading
text: In New York we’ve already had a taste of summer, never mind the calendar date: the heat, the humidity, the subways sticky and bound to get stickier. In fact, nothing quite screams summer like the wall of hot air that greets passengers as they step off trains and into the sweltering warren that is New York City underground. So we at the Book Review were delighted when our art director, Nicholas Blechman, unveiled the subway-themed cover art for Sunday’s Summer Reading issue, designed by the Toronto-based illustrator Frank Viva.

headline: Animal Kingdom Turns in Effortless Workout
text: The Kentucky Derby winner Animal Kingdom took to the Belmont track like a veteran Monday morning, turning in an effortless half-mile workout with his regular rider, John Velazquez, aboard. Animal Kingdom appeared to get stronger got a hold of the racetrack surface known as Big Sandy. He covered the first quarter-mile in 24.18 seconds, a half-mile in 47.76 seconds and galloped out a strong five-eighths of a mile in 1:00.60.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: Lazard Hires Ex-Cleary Gottlieb Managing Partner
text: Lazard said on Monday that it has hired Mark A. Walker, a former managing partner of the law firm Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton, as a senior adviser to the investment bank’s government advisory team.

headline: Yemen’s Leader Is Said to Plan Return ‘in Days’
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Diplomatic maneuvering intensified on Monday to push President Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen to accept a peaceful transition from power while he recuperates in a Saudi military hospital from burns and other injuries sustained during an attack on his palace mosque.

headline: Everything Is Political
text: Peter Diamond has a depressing op-ed in today’s Times, withdrawing himself for contention as a member of the Fed board in the face of Republican opposition.

headline: Peter O’Toole Has a Few Words for Directors
text: Even if you are inclined to believe that Peter O’Toole is The Man, it is possible that you may have missed one of his most capital-M Manliest performances in Richard Rush’s 1980 black comedy, “The Stunt Man.” In that movie, Mr. O’Toole plays Eli Cross, a megalomaniacal but magnetically charismatic film director, who recruits a wanted criminal (played by Steve Railsback) to replace a stunt performer who was killed in an accident on his latest project, and then generally proceeds to mess with the minds of his new hire and his film’s leading lady (Barbara Hershey).

headline: Power Shifts, Played Out Onstage
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The song that best encapsulates the push and pull of hip-hop in 2011 is “I’m on One,” the recent collaboration of Drake, Lil Wayne and Rick Ross, organized by DJ Khaled. On the one hand, it’s all bombast, just like any other Khaled number, but unlike the typical megalomania of those songs, Drake’s trademark egotistical melancholy drives this one, and it spills over to everyone’s verses. Winning is everything, winning is fun, and winning takes its toll.

headline: E. Coli Not Found in Initial Testing of Sprouts
text: BERLIN — A day after German agricultural officials identified locally grown sprouts as a possible cause of the E.coli outbreak that has killed 22 people and sickened more than 2,200, the officials said Monday that initial tests had failed to show conclusively that the bacteria originated with the sprouts.

headline: JPMorgan Hires Former United Airlines Chief
text: Glenn F. Tilton, a former chief executive of United Airlines, has been named chairman of JPMorgan Chase‘s Midwest business, succeeding William M. Daley, who left the bank this year to become White House chief of staff. Mr. Tilton, 63, will also be a member of the bank’s executive committee.

headline: The Monster Raving Loony Party
text: Via Steve Benen, I see that Haley Barbour has the explanation for higher gas prices. It’s not demand from China and instability in the Middle East; it’s a deliberate conspiracy on the part of the Obama administration (pdf):

headline: Antiwar Republican Is No Longer Party’s Pariah
text: GREENVILLE, N.C. — On matters like abortion, military spending and religion, Representative Walter B. Jones seems thoroughly in tune with this conservative, staunchly Republican district in eastern North Carolina, home to the Marine Corps’ Camp Lejeune and thousands of military retirees.

headline: Stoking Excitement, Arenas Pump Up the Volume
text: DALLAS — It was only the pregame show. As the ear-splitting cacophony rocked American Airlines Center before a recent Dallas Mavericks playoff game, the team executive Martin Woodall whooped gleefully over the din: “My clothes are shaking!” His words were discernible only to a lip reader; their sound stood no chance.

headline: Coming Home
text: The men and women of First Battalion, 87th Infantry, return home from Afghanistan to joy, loneliness and new risks.

headline: Worthwhile Canadian Initiative
text: Aaron Carroll has a post debunking various myths about Canadian health care. Go read.

headline: AAA: Teenagers Face Heightened Crash Risk During Summer
text: Prom and graduation season has arrived, and with it heightened worries among parents about the driving of their teengers. A new report by AAA suggests that such concerns at this time of year are not unfounded.

headline: What Future for the Tired Bruins?
text: BOSTON — The Stanley Cup finals are back on Causeway Street for the first time in two decades, but if the Bruins don’t fix a couple of things, they won’t be here long. It’s like Robert Mitchum said at the old Boston Garden in the 1973 film “The Friends of Eddie Coyle” …

headline: Stumptown’s New Investor Met With Other Top Coffee Companies
text: When the news broke last week that a private equity firm had taken a stake in Stumptown Coffee Roasters, one of the nation’s top boutique roasters, officials from both companies indicated they were just building a few cafes and roasting plants.

headline: Web Site Posts Image Said to Be of Bare-Chested Weiner
text: Updated, 1:58 p.m. | A conservative blog published a series of embarrassing photographs and e-mails on Monday that it claimed had been sent by Representative Anthony D. Weiner to an unidentified woman over the last few weeks.

headline: Five-Figure Rentals? In City, the Demand Is Growing
text: A divorced businesswoman wants to try on a new lifestyle. An actor in town needs a plush pad for a year. An investor prefers to keep his cash on hand for, well, investing.

headline: Frustration Grows as Nominee for the Fed Withdraws
text: WASHINGTON — The decision by a noted economist Monday to end a 14-month wait for a seat on the Federal Reserve Board of Governors is renewing concerns among some Democrats about the fighting spirit of the Obama administration.

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘Together: we arch, twine, dangle’
text: Today’s poem, chosen from more than 650 submissions to our Found Poem Student Challenge, comes from Samantha, who is 17 years old and lives in Hartland, Wisconsin.

headline: Iowa Town Is Largely Emptied in Fear of Rising Missouri River
text: More than half the people in a small Iowa town fled on Monday as the Army Corps of Engineers worked to build an emergency levee to hold back the rising Missouri River, officials said.

headline: Everyone’s a Critic
text: Several works from the deluge of contemporary art at the Biennale stuck with a critic from The Times. Add your own impressions in six words.

headline: Venice  Biennale: Everyone’s a Critic
text: Take a look, see what you think and add your own mini-review to the mix.

headline: Nadal’s Best
text: It was not a classic French Open final, the kind fans will be talking about forever, or even two weeks from now. And when Rafael Nadal’s career is finally over, and he needs an ocean liner to carry around all his Grand Slam trophies, it will probably be but a blip. His sixth French Open title? How many games did Roger Federer manage in that one? Oh yeah, Federer won a whole set. Got it.

headline: DealBook Portraits: Laurence D. Fink
text: Laurence D. Fink is chairman of BlackRock, and one of the highest-paid executives on Wall Street. He recounts the path that led him to the top of the largest asset management firm in the world.

headline: Syria, Claiming Heavy Toll in Town, Hints at Retaliation
text: CAIRO — The Syrian government said “armed gangs” had slaughtered at least 120 police officers, security personnel and civilians in a town near its border with Turkey on Monday, an account that, if true, suggests a violent shift in the uprising against Syria’s hard-line leadership.

headline: The Claim: Cranberry Juice Can Cure Ulcers.

headline: Q. Who Finished 112th in the Battle of the Brains?

headline: So Much More Than Plasma and Poison
text: BALTIMORE — Until I met Doug Allen, the wiry, ponytailed senior aquarist who guided me through the extremely popular jellyfish exhibit at the National Aquarium, my personal experience with jellyfish consisted mainly of using them as yet another excuse not to go swimming: “Hey, I could get stung by a jellyfish!” Isn’t that what happened to 1,800 people off the coast of Florida last week? So when Mr. Allen suddenly stopped, clambered a ladder to the top of one of the tanks and called down, “You want to try holding a moon jelly?” my first impulse was to knock a few schoolchildren out of the way as I bolted for the door. My second impulse ...

headline: The Twins Connection
text: My 4-year-old twin sons usually fall asleep within minutes of each other in toddler beds that are separated by no more than eight inches, but in the hope of settling Leo down early the other night, we opted to do bedtime one at a time.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Earnhardt Cannot Overcome Keselowski at Kansas
text: With 10 laps remaining at the STP 400 in Kansas City, Kan., Dale Earnhardt Jr.’s No. 88 car was showing a measure of aggression not seen since its qualifying laps at Daytona in February. Earnhardt overtook Denny Hamlin for third place, and with a full tank of gas, was charging for greater glory that was not to be.

headline: Libya Stokes Its Machine Generating Propaganda
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — The nightly propaganda tour to NATO bombing sites around the Libyan capital — the main component of every foreign reporter’s routine in a city controlled by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi — led to a rustic backyard in the predawn hours of Monday where a family with several small, frightened children, said to have been dining outside late into the night, had supposedly endured a narrow escape from a NATO missile.

headline: In Vietnam, a State Company Plays Loose With Lenders
text: Vinashin GroupA ship built by the Vietnam Shipbuilding Industry Group.

headline: Economists Lower G.D.P. Forecasts for 2nd Quarter
text: Quarter after quarter and month after month, the United States has been subjected to increasingly disappointing economic numbers. And this quarter is no different.

headline: In Update on Sperm, Data Show No Decline
text: It is one of the most fraught topics in environmental health. Are men becoming less fertile, with declining sperm counts and diminishing sperm quality? If they are, then sperm might be an early warning sign of environmental dangers. And the prime suspects have been substances like plastics and pesticides that can have weak estrogenlike effects on cells.

headline: Live Blogging Apple’s iCloud Announcement
text: SAN FRANCISCO — At Monday’s Apple Worldwide Developers Conference at San Francisco’s Moscone Center, Apple’s chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, announced upgrades to both the Macintosh and iOS operating systems and unveiled iCloud, a cloud-computing service that will store music, photos and documents remotely, as well as eliminate the need to sync devices to a PC.

headline: The Rent Is High, and So Is the Demand
text: This week, the Appraisal takes a look at the five-figure rental — a surprisingly in-demand abode these days, and not just for the Dominique Strauss-Kahns of the world, looking to spend their house arrests in splendor.

headline: A Prom Where 'No One is Judged'
text: At the 7th annual Anti-Prom, organized by the New York Public Library, chokers, chains and Mohawk haircuts were the norm — not corsages, tuxedos or rented limos.

headline: New Deals With Old-Style Risk
text: Risk-taking is back in mergers and acquisitions.

headline: When Television Feeds the Urge to Trade
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

text: Do or Dine Menu

headline: Nicole Scherzinger Takes Cheryl Cole’s Spot as ‘X Factor’ Judge
text: “The X Factor” will go forward in the United States without the British singer and model Cheryl Cole, one of the judges that Simon Cowell had recruited for the talent competition.

headline: Military Small Arms & Libya: Security Puzzles, and Profiteers
text: In their fight to overthrow the government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the rebels in Libya have resorted to many forms of scrounging to arm themselves, step by step, for a war they did not foresee.

headline: The Rentier Regime
text: Bob Kuttner has a very good column (pdf) in The American Prospect about “debt politics.” Let me elaborate a bit.

headline: Oil Drilling Off Cuba Raises Specter of What-If
text: Florida voters have long opposed offshore oil drilling along their coasts, and given that Florida is a swing state in presidential elections, they have gotten their way. But it looks as if drilling is coming to nearby Cuban waters as early as the fall when the Spanish oil company Repsol is due to drill an exploratory well.

headline: The Falcon Autistic Solar Team
text: Royce from the Falcon Autistic Solar Team of Independence High School discusses the need for alternative energy.

headline: Law on End-of-Life Care Rankles Doctors
text: I shouldn’t be surprised when doctors object to laws telling them how to practice medicine, as does New York State’s new Palliative Care Information Act — not surprised, but in this instance, distressed.

headline: Pistons’ Turnover Continues
text: What do Larry Brown, John Kuester, Rick Carlisle, Doug Collins, Ron Rothstein, Flip Saunders, Don Chaney, Alvin Gentry, Michael Curry and George Irvine have in common?

headline: Book by French Resistance Hero to Be Published in U.S.
text: A book by the French Resistance hero Stéphane Hessel that has sold more than 3 million copies in Europe since its publication in October will be published in the United States this fall. Twelve, an imprint of the Hachette Book Group, said on Monday that it would release “Time for Outrage,” which has been translated from the French by Marion Duvert, in September.

headline: Five-Cylinder 2012 Volvo S60 Is Recalled for Fuel Pump Issue
text: Volvo is recalling almost 7,600 of its 2012 S60 sedans powered by 5-cylinder engines because of a possible stalling problem, the automaker told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Ronzoni Borrows From Sports for New Pasta Campaign
text: Advertising by Ronzoni, the pasta company, has come a long way from its decades-old slogan, “Ronzoni sono buoni, Ronzoni is so good,” familiar to Americans of a certain age.

headline: Hawk Cam | Fans of a Feather
text: About 30 denizens of the Hawk Cam’s sprawling chat room got together on Sunday in Washington Square Park to put faces to screen names and say hello in person (through binoculars) to Pip, Violet and Bobby, who obliged, variously, with flyovers and wing-flapping. The Chatroom regular IreneLF filed this report:

headline: Video: Republican Hopefuls and the Economy
text: John Harwood and Jeff Zeleny discuss how recent bad news on the economy is playing for the Republican presidential field.

headline: Just One Look | Jason Wu Resort Collection
text: Jason Wu’s resort collection, inspired by a recent trip he took to Old San Juan, P.R., is best described as old world meets new wave — as in this silk-taffeta dress, which combines a pretty Art Deco floral print with sporty wet suit details. The surf gear wasn’t just for show: this is the first season Wu is doing swimwear.

headline: China Rejects Google’s Hacking Charge
text: BEIJING — China’s official Communist Party newspaper issued a caustic response on Monday to Google’s charge that Chinese hackers had taken aim at influential users of its Gmail service, calling the accusations “political gaming” aimed at fomenting new discord between the Beijing and Washington governments.

headline: ABC Signs Katie Couric to a Multiyear Deal
text: ABC made it official Monday, formally announcing what has been expected for weeks: it has signed Katie Couric to a multiyear contract to host a new daytime talk show that ABC will syndicate.

headline: Caucus | Republicans and the Economy
text: John Harwood and Jeff Zeleny discuss how the issue of the economy is playing for the 2012 Republican presidential field.

headline: A Prom for Students Who Don’t Want One
text: Dijon James, 17, and Jo Doodle, 17, showed up for their prom on Friday night looking as if they had just come from a skate park.

headline: Library for the Performing Arts Plans Coward Exhibition
text: Noël Coward once said, “The only thing that really saddens me over my demise is that I shall not be here to read the nonsense that will be written about me and my works and my motives.” The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center promises to display both sense and nonsense about the composer, director and playwright at a new exhibition devoted to Coward that is scheduled for next spring.

headline: Suicide and Abortion
text: From Will Saletan’s piece on the death of Jack Kevorkian (whose career is the subject of my column today):

headline: WNET to Oversee New Jersey Public Television
text: 4:57 p.m. | Updated New York’s WNET will take over the television operations of the New Jersey Network for five years under a deal announced on Monday by Gov. Chris Christie.

headline: The Complexity of Jellyfish
text: Researchers have found that there is far more complexity and nuance to a jellyfish than meets the eye.

headline: A Proto-Jeep Stakes Out Tame Terrain
text: GREENWICH, Conn. — On Friday, President Obama visited the Jeep factory in Toledo, Ohio, where Wranglers are built. Jeep is celebrating the 70th anniversary of the creation of the first Jeep, which involved the Willys-Overland company.

headline: DealBook Portraits: Laurence D. Fink
text: Laurence D. Fink has come along way since his days working in his family’s shoe store in California.

headline: Already Sick? You May Be Able To Afford New Government Health Premiums
text: If you have had trouble getting health insurance because you were already sick, the federal government is trying to make it easier for you to get coverage.

headline: Under Stricter Rules, Dredges Return to Hudson
text: General Electric began the second phase of its cleanup of the Hudson River on Monday under tightened federal requirements, including a limit on how much contamination could be sealed on the riverbed rather than removed.

headline: Flies in the Dark
text: Q. Where do flies go at night? In summer in Australia, flies are everywhere in the daytime but seem to disappear at night.

headline: What Would Justice for John Edwards Mean?
text: Like a lot of you, I imagine, I’ve been trying to decide how I feel about the case against John Edwards — not as a legal matter, which I’ll leave to lawyers, but more as a larger matter of justice.

headline: Hundreds of Livery Drivers Protest Medallion Plan
text: If you found it hard to get a livery cab on Monday morning, there was a good reason: Nearly 2,000 drivers skipped work to rally outside City Hall against a city proposal to create a separate class of taxis that would pick up street hails outside of most of Manhattan.

headline: Israel Disputes Toll of Border Clashes, Saying Syria Has an Ulterior Motive
text: JERUSALEM — Israeli military officials on Monday disputed the casualty figures announced by Syria a day earlier, after Israeli forces fired on protesters who had tried to breach the Syrian frontier border with the Israeli-held Golan Heights. The discrepancy in numbers underlined the messages being conveyed by each side.

headline: Women Atop Their Fields Dissect the Scientific Life
text: Elena Aprile, Joy Hirsch, Mary-Claire King and Tal Rabin are members of a rare breed — women scientists at the top of their fields.

headline: Which Apps Are Threatened by Apple’s Upgrades?
text: How do you know if you’ve created a really great, useful iPhone app? Apple tries to put you out of business.

headline: Wednesday Night Is All Right for Loving
text: In his latest Acts of Mild Subversion column, Nate Silver teamed up with the matchmaking site OKCupid to figure out which night of the week is best for finding love — well, the ephemeral kind of love at least. Read more.

headline: The Airport Indulgence: Bending Your Diet Rules
text: I LOVE flying. Good weather, bad weather, middle seat or aisle seat, I really don’t care. Nothing bothers me. I’m even one of those lucky people who can fall asleep during a flight and stay asleep.

headline: Korean Food’s Mild Sidekick: Lettuce
text: In my enthusiasm for the terrific side dishes (known in Korea as banchan) that accompanied beef bulgogi in Sunday’s Eat column — stir-fried spinach with crumbled tofu, Korean-style potato salad, grilled-scallion salad, fried hijiki and (the mother of all Korean sides) kimchi — I didn’t have room to mention what may be the most indispensable element of the meal: lettuce leaves.

headline: Fill-In | Verbs Used to Describe a Soccer Game
text: Today’s special fill-in honors lively sports reporting by showing how many vivid ways there are to describe a ball being moved down a field. Can you fill in the 18 missing verbs?

headline: Apple Unveils ‘Cloud’ Music and Storage Service
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Declaring that the personal computer was no longer the central hub of people’s digital lives, Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, on Monday unveiled the company’s new online storage and syncing service for music, photos, files and software.

headline: Architect Acquires Majority Share of Gwathmey Siegel
text: Ever since Charles Gwathmey died in 2009 people in the architecture world have wondered what would become of his partner, Robert Siegel, and the firm they founded in 1968, Gwathmey Siegel & Associates Architects. Now the answer is clear: the architect Gene Kaufman has acquired a majority share and the firm will become Gwathmey Siegel Kaufman & Associates.

headline: Glinting Sun and Gleaming Chrome at Greenwich Concours d’Élégance
text: GREENWICH, Conn. — While the cars are always beautiful at the Greenwich Concours d’Élégance, the weather often is not. Previous shows have been held in stifling 90-degree humidity or after heavy rains that rendered Roger Sherman Baldwin Park, where the show takes place, into the world’s most rarefied mud pit.

headline: Sentence of the Week: Open-Flesh-Wound Edition
text: Now that we’ve officially crowned Shamblanderson’s Sentence of the Month for May, it’s time to pick our next Sentence of the Week. Here are the candidates:

headline: Drugs: Steep Vaccine Price Reductions Could Help in Reaching More Children
text: Several makers of children’s vaccines announced Monday that they would lower prices in the world’s poorest countries, a move that could save donors billions of dollars and help bring the vaccines to more children (above, a polio vaccination in Congo).

headline: Weiner Says He Sent Photos and Lied, but Won’t Resign
text: At a news conference in Midtown Monday afternoon, Representative Anthony D. Weiner tearfully confessed to sending a photo of himself in his underwear to a woman via Twitter and then lying about it.

headline: Building a Better Breadstick
text: I often get requests from readers for healthy snacks, and whole-grain breadsticks fit the bill. Commercially made varieties, however, are rarely healthy -- little more than insipid junk food, just crispy and salty enough to keep you reaching for more. Fortunately, breadsticks are easy and fun to make on your own.

headline: TimesCast | June 6, 2011

headline: Double-Teaming Dirk Nowitzki

headline: After 90 Years, a Dictionary of an Ancient World

headline: Artifacts | Happiness on Wheels

headline: A Hot-Water Bath for Thawing Meats
text: EVEN in kitchens where fresh is king, the freezer remains a handy tool. There’s no easier way to deal with a bounty of meat from a big-box store or a butchering class or a C.S.A. share, or the haul from a fishing trip, or the unpredictable sighting of partridge and other rare birds in the Chinese market. In my house, the freezer is essential for drawing out the enjoyment of the prime mail-order meats that my mother sends for my birthday, and that arrive rock-hard under a block of dry ice.

headline: At 170, a Venerable Ballet Returns to Its (Quicker) Roots
text: SEATTLE — “Giselle,” the two-act Romantic ballet about (among much else) love beyond death, will be 170 on June 28. Because Peter Boal’s new production for Pacific Northwest Ballet is based on research by the dance historians Doug Fullington and Marian Smith, and in particular on three detailed production records from between 1842 and 1903, I went expecting to see features I had never encountered in the many productions I have watched over the last 36 years. I was not disappointed.

headline: Under the Milky Way, in Suspended Reality
text: La MaMa Moves! Dance Festival, now in its sixth year, is frustratingly exhaustive, the kind of event that is overrun with too many mixed bills. But on Friday night there was an exception: Lance Gries, a former member of the Trisha Brown Dance Company, presented a new solo, his first show in New York in 10 years. “Etudes for an Astronaut,” described in program notes as “one man’s search for his place in the universe,” was already in motion as the audience entered La MaMa’s intimate club space. In head-to-toe black and flip-flops Mr. Gries repeated a movement sequence that gave his body — through deceptively simple means of sitting, standing, leaning and rolling — a sense of melting and hardening. In “Etudes” he is searching for balance between inner space (as in the mind) and outer space (the world).

headline: Roussillon, Into the Sunlight
text: IT’S not easy being an afterthought, yet that’s exactly what has happened to the tail of the fused French compound region commonly referred to in wine books as Languedoc-Roussillon.

headline: Piercing the Fog Around Cellphones and Cancer

headline: Fooling Them All With a Big Name
text: It sounds like the plot of a movie: “Catch Me if You Can,” the 2002 high-spirited Steven Spielberg thriller about a serial impostor named Frank Abagnale Jr., who managed to pass himself off as an airline pilot, a doctor and a lawyer, while making millions of dollars forging checks. Or maybe something darker, like Alfred Hitchcock’s 1943 classic, “Shadow of a Doubt,” about a man wanted for murder who hides out with his sister’s family in a quiet California community where he charms the unsuspecting townsfolk.
