headline: ABC Is a Winner With the N.B.A.
text: Game 3 of the National Basketball Association finals topped the ratings on Sunday night, lifting ABC far ahead of its network rivals, which broadcast mostly repeats in prime time. Final audience figures were not available on Monday for ABC’s live basketball coverage of the Miami Heat’s victory over the Dallas Mavericks, but Nielsen’s preliminary overnight estimates were higher for Sunday’s broadcast than for either of the first two games in the series, which attracted 15.5 million and 15.2 million viewers last week. CBS ranked second on the night, garnering its best ratings at 7 p.m. for “60 Minutes” (9.4 million). CBS broadcast a repeat of “Undercover Boss” at 9 (4.6 million) between reruns of “CSI: Miami” at 8 (5.7 million) and at 10 (6.1 million). NBC was third with “Dateline” at 7 (3.7 million) followed by “Minute to Win It” at 8 (2.9 million) and a rerun of last week’s installment of “America’s Got Talent” from 9 to 11 (5.2 million). Fox finished fourth with repeats of its animated sitcoms.

headline: New York City Ballet Adjusts Its Ticket Pricing
text: The Metropolitan Museum of Art is not the only cultural institution around playing with its prices (raising its suggested admission fee to $25 from $20 as of July 1). New York City Ballet has also adjusted its prices for subscription tickets in Lincoln Center’s David H. Koch Theater for its 2011-12 season in an effort to increase ticket revenue by 5 to 10 percent, the company’s spokesman, Robert Daniels, said in a telephone interview. City Ballet, whose dancers include, at left, Robert Fairchild and Teresa Reichlen, is not simply raising prices. Instead, it is offering a wider range of prices within each section, with some seats becoming more affordable and others more expensive. For example, seats in the orchestra, which in the 2010-11 season have ranged from $85 to $100, will now be $26 to $119. (Orchestra seats for American Ballet Theater performances at the Metropolitan Opera House run $30 to $102.) Seats in the third ring, formerly $50 or $60, will now range from $26 to $103. “New audiences especially want to come in, want to sample the company at a lower ticket price,” Mr. Daniels said, “so we wanted some of those ticket prices to be available in the orchestra level, where they didn’t used to be.”

headline: Three Gems of the Here and Now
text: George Balanchine’s “Jewels,” choreographed in 1967, is an anthology of ballet history, a densely packed guide to the evolution of classical dance over the last 150 years. Or it’s simply a marvelously entertaining compilation of three linked yet unrelated ballets — “Emeralds,” “Rubies” and “Diamonds” — to wonderful music by Fauré, Stravinsky and Tchaikovsky.

headline: A ‘Despairing Optimist’ Considered Anew
text: 8:06 p.m. | Updated When I was in college in the 1970’s, I became a devotee of René Dubos — a scientist and essayist who combined extraordinary achievements in microbiology, most notably his methodical discovery of the first practical antibiotic, with a passion for forging a sustainable human relationship with the environment. The honor comes at a fortuitous time. Later this month, “Fred Hayman: The Story of Rodeo Drive, Hollywood Glamour and the Showman Who Sold It All” will be available in stores. headline: The 10-Word Question That Could Cost Obama the Election
text: The year 1980 was one in which economic forecasting models were in agreement that the economy had slumped too significantly to allow President Jimmy Carter to win re-election. Unemployment was at 7.5 percent and inflation was at 9.7 percent. Per-capita GDP and disposable income growth, adjusted for inflation, had been negative over the course of Mr. Carter’s term. The economy was officially in recession for much of the election year.

headline: Radiation’s Unknowns Weigh on Japan
text: As officials in Japan agonize over what constitutes a safe radiation dose for people who live near the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear reactors, the state of the science has been a daunting problem. Studies on the effects of exposure are based mostly on large doses delivered quickly by atomic bombs, while radiation from the Fukushima disaster would more likely result in small doses delivered over many years.

headline: Paying for Their Crimes, Again

headline: ‘I Don’t Know What I Was Thinking’

Portraying a young woman sliding into insanity in Jenny Worton’s stage adaptation of Ingmar Bergman’s 1961 film, which opened on Monday night at the New York Theater Workshop, Ms. Mulligan creates the illusion of someone who has no idea that she’s being observed.

headline: Russia: Parole Denied for Ex-Tycoon; Paperwork Cited
text: A Moscow court on Monday refused a parole request by Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the jailed former oil tycoon, citing a lack of proper paperwork. Having served half of his 13-year sentence for tax evasion, fraud and other crimes, Mr. Khodorkovsky is eligible for parole under Russian law. He and his business partner, Platon Lebedev, who is serving time for similar charges, filed parole requests last week. The requests were returned because the court received “insufficient accompanying documents,” a court spokeswoman told the Interfax news agency, without elaborating. Mr. Khodorkovsky was jailed in 2003 after clashing with Vladimir V. Putin, then the president and now the prime minister.

headline: Immigration Program Is Rejected by Third State
text: Gov. Deval Patrick of Massachusetts has decided the state will not participate in a fingerprint-sharing program that is central to the Obama administration’s immigration enforcement strategy, dealing a new political blow to a program that has met rising resistance nationwide.

headline: An Artist Who Gained Fame From a Work’s Disappearance
text: Judy Taylor, a painter of bucolic nature and domestic scenes, has found herself cast in the spotlight after Paul LePage, Maine’s Republican governor, ordered that her 2008 mural depicting the state’s labor history be removed from the waiting room of Maine’s Department of Labor building. (He said the mural favored labor interests at the expense of business interests.) A federal lawsuit has been filed to return the mural to the building. The state plans to file an appeal seeking to dismiss the case by June 17. Ms. Taylor has not joined the lawsuit, saying she wants to avoid alienating anyone by becoming personally involved. Ms. Taylor discusses.

headline: Canada: Extradition Ordered of Suspect in Paris Synagogue Bombing
text: A judge in Ottawa approved the extradition of a suspect in the 1980 bombing of a Paris synagogue that killed four people. But Justice Robert Maranger, of the Ontario Superior Court also noted that the French murder case against Hassan Diab, a Canadian citizen born in Lebanon, was weak and that “the prospects of conviction in the context of a fair trial seem unlikely.” The case rests heavily on handwriting analysis of a hotel registry card. Mr. Diab, a former sociology teacher, says he is innocent. He has 30 days to appeal.

headline: Georgia: Officials Cite Russian Hand in NATO Bomb Plot
text: A man who said he had been paid by Russia to detonate a bomb near a NATO office in the capital, Tbilisi, has been arrested, officials said Monday. The man, Badri Bagiashvili, said a Russian border guard had promised him $2,000 for the job, the Interior Ministry said. The police said he had been detained carrying the bomb into the city. Officials say they have evidence of Russian involvement in 12 bombing plots. After the arrest last week of a man and a woman on charges of plotting to bomb a provincial market, a deputy Russian foreign minister suggested Georgian officials were making the allegations against Russia to deflect attention from internal unrest.

headline: Bruins Answer Hit With Goal After Goal
text: BOSTON — The Bruins, backed into a corner while one of their best players was being driven by ambulance to a hospital after taking a vicious predatory hit, came out slashing and snarling and baring their teeth. They scored four goals in the second period and added four more in the third en route to an 8-1 thrashing of the Vancouver Canucks in Game 3 of the Stanley Cup finals Monday at TD Garden.

headline: 17-Year-Old Is Arrested in Thefts of Laptops From Public Schools

Seventy-seven laptops were stolen from one school alone, Public School 73 in the Bronx, in two separate burglaries in late May. All told, more than 100 computers were taken from about a half-dozen schools.

And like all New Yorkers, I am drawn to anything that helps me to understand what it means to live in this city. This paragraph deserved to be saved, reread and questioned by other New Yorkers.

headline: How Can We Forgive You If You Won’t Go Away?
text: At a lunchtime conversation yesterday, just before Anthony Weiner used a tearstained press conference to confess to being both a serial Twitterer of tasteless amateur photography and an exceptionally ineffective liar, a colleague of mine made the case for forgiveness in such cases. His point, at least as I understood it, was that most politicians are raging narcissists of one stripe or another, walking a tightrope between flagrant egotism and true pathology. But public figures who pass through the fire of a major scandal-driven humiliation have a rare chance to come to terms with that narcissism’s catastrophic consequences, and as a result many of them probably come out of these kind of self-inflicted disasters as better people — and perhaps, by implication, better public servants — than your typical Joe Q. Politician.

headline: High Notes | New Art on the High Line
text: Section 2 of the High Line, which opens to the public tomorrow, passes just beyond Frank Gehry’s IAC building and Jean Nouvel’s 100 11th Avenue Residences one block to the west. With the installation of Sarah Sze’s “Still Life with Landscape (Model for a Habitat),” some of the more modest denizens of the neighborhood will have a piece of starchitecture to call their own. The sculpture, a dynamic steel and wood complex of bird, ladybug and butterfly condos, sits between 20th and 21st Streets, and serves as a sort of gateway onto the High Line microclimate known as the Chelsea Thicket. Among its noteworthy amenities are feeding trays that will be regularly restocked with seeds and nectar, and miniature troughs designed to catch rainwater. But as with any luxury real estate development — even one with a boldfaced name attached to it — its occupancy rate is not a guarantee. “It’s really an experiment,” says Lauren Ross, the curator and director of arts programs at Friends of the High Line, adding that Sze consulted various urban birding groups but received conflicting predictions. “It functions first and foremost as sculpture. We are not sure how wildlife will respond to it.”

headline: After Report of Disappearance, Questions About Syrian-American Blogger

text: Spc. Michael Gannon guides us through a mission on Qurghan Tapa Hill by sharing the video he captured on a helmet camera.

headline: Weiner Was Not the Topic. Really.
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg called a news conference on Tuesday to unveil an effort to improve safety in apartment buildings. But the reporters in attendance seemed more interested in another question: Should Representative Anthony D. Weiner resign?

headline: Can the Yield Gap Be Closed — Sustainably?
text: In my article on Sunday about the future of the food system, I briefly mentioned the potential for improved agricultural output in Africa. The situation there is a prime example of a larger problem that concerns the world’s agronomists: the yield gap.

headline: We’re Here All Week, Folks…
text: If you’re not on Twitter, you’re missing all kinds of hilarity. I have no big point to make with today’s blog post — I just wanted to share some of the witty responses to a Tweet I sent out last week.

headline: Mog, Streaming Music Service, Syncs Up With Car Audio Manufacturers
text: Later this week at the Telematics Detroit show, companies will highlight their efforts to put Web-served music into automobiles, with the hope of supplanting satellite and traditional radio. To that end, Mog, a subscription-based music service, announced several new partnerships on Tuesday.

headline: Companies Offer Free Versions of Identity Theft Services
text: The recent spate of computer hacking and security breaches has heightened interest in credit and identity-theft monitoring services. Two companies, TrustedID and Debix, have started offering free versions of their surveillance systems.

headline: Germany Is Criticized Even as E. Coli Outbreak Slows
text: PARIS — The German government came under increased criticism on Tuesday at home and abroad, accused of mismanaging the crisis surrounding an E. coli outbreak that has killed more than 20 people.

headline: Pawlenty Promises High Growth, Low Taxes and Tight Spending
text: Tim Pawlenty, the former governor of Minnesota, called on Tuesday for across-the-board federal spending reductions and large tax cuts for businesses and individuals, saying that such policies would drive rapid economic growth, create jobs and reduce the federal debt.

headline: Yao Still Hopes for N.B.A. Comeback
text: The clock is ticking for Yao Ming. His contract with the Houston Rockets expires June 30, and he’s still trying to recover from a serious left foot/ankle injury and surgery in January that cost him all but five games of the 2010-11 season.

headline: British Tabloid Apologizes to Actress for Hacking
text: LONDON — The News of the World formally apologized to the actress Sienna Miller on Tuesday for systematically, and illegally, intercepting her cellphone messages in the mid-2000s and using the information to publish articles about her private life.

headline: Deutsche Borse Sweetens NYSE Bid
text: NYSE Euronext and Deutsche Börse announced on Tuesday that they would pay shareholders a special dividend in an effort to secure support for their merger deal.

headline: Introducing the Motherlode Book Club
text: My shelves are filled with parenting books. A good percentage of them are there because parenting is now my beat — new ones arrive in the mail every day and they are now piled everywhere. But my collection began long before Motherlode. Even before I was pregnant I figured that if I gathered enough of these volumes I would find the answers. Part of me still believes this, and an archaeologist could easily see what I was looking for over time by excavating down through the piles. “What to Expect When You’re Expecting,” “Your Baby and Child,” “Operating Instructions,” “Siblings Without Rivalry,” “The iConnected Parent,” “Parenting Your Adult Child.”

headline: Pondering Defensive Changes for the U.S.; UPDATED with Lineup
text: Now that Sunil Gulati has confirmed that Bob Bradley isn’t going anywhere — not that he ever was — what should Bradley do with his lineup as the United States opens the Gold Cup?

text: Times photographers were a presence at Aqueduct, Belmont, Yonkers and Roosevelt from the 1950s through the 1970s.

headline: In Nintendo’s Successor to Wii, a Hand-Held Screen
text: LOS ANGELES — Nintendo of Japan unveiled the prototype of its next home video game console, the successor to the Wii, here on Tuesday at the annual E3 convention.

text: Designers, tastemakers and celebrities gathered at Lincoln Center on Monday night for the 2011 Council of Fashion Designers of America Awards.

headline: Mexico City Art Museum for World’s Richest Man
text: The richest man in the world now has a gleaming museum to house his extensive art collection.

headline: Labor Demand Gets Softer
text: Last week brought dismal news from the labor market as the government reported feeble job creation in May.

headline: NBC Wins U.S. Television Rights to Four More Olympics
text: Since 2000, no network has carried the Olympics but NBC. But when NBC Universal was bought by Comcast this year, there was doubt that it had the passion for the Olympics that led the network’s former parent, General Electric, to pay billions of dollars to stock NBC with the Summer Games and the Winter Games.

headline: Arsonists Damage and Deface Mosque in West Bank Village
text: JERUSALEM — Arsonists damaged a mosque in a West Bank village early Tuesday and sprayed Hebrew messages on the walls, leading to suspicions that Jewish settler extremists were responsible.

headline: Group Seeks Inquiry into Claim of Kazakh Donations
text: The Justice Department should investigate whether the Kazakhstan Embassy in Washington tried to illegally funnel money to members of Congress as part of its lobbying efforts, a government watchdog group has said in a letter to Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.

headline: Republicans Challenge Democrats on Weiner Donations
text: The scandal engulfing Representative Anthony D. Weiner is already threatening to taint other Democrats in Congress.

headline: Born Free: A Response
text: I am glad that my article, “Are There Natural Human Rights?” prompted nearly 300 responses.  Though a few playfully sang the tune of Molière and Aristophanes concerning the utility of philosophers in the public square, most took the claims made in the article seriously and offered comments, suggestions and critiques. I would like to briefly respond to four groups of comments: (a) questions about God, (b) the role of science, (c) Confucius, and (d) operative rights.

headline: G.M. Still Hopeful of Fully Paying Back the Government
text: DETROIT — The chief executive of General Motors said on Tuesday that he hoped the federal government would be able to sell its stake in the automaker soon, and expressed concern about the country’s economic recovery.

headline: Wheelies: The Beetle Bucks Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: G-8 Energy Ministers Pledge Support for Stricter Nuclear Safety Tests
text: PARIS — International energy ministers and officials of nuclear agencies pledged support Tuesday for a global push to improve safety tests at nuclear power plants.

headline: On a Broadway Stage and Under the Gaze of a Star
text: It wasn’t the golden statuettes, the crystal chandeliers or the velvet seats that made Jasmine Hernandez nervous as she took the stage of the Majestic Theater on Broadway Monday morning with other students from Public School 111 in Manhattan. It was the company.

headline: The S.E.C.’s Advice to Defense Lawyers
text: Note to defense counsel: Do not tap your clients under the table if they say something you don’t like.

headline: Oklahoma’s Boren Leaving Congress
text: Representative Dan Boren of Oklahoma, one of the most conservative Democrats in Congress, will not seek re-election next year, party officials said Tuesday.

headline: Introducing the Motherlode Book Club
text: Over at Motherlode, The Times’s parenting blog, Lisa Belkin is introducing a monthly book club. She writes:

headline: International Paper’s Gambit in Its Pursuit of Temple-Inland
text: International Paper’s bid for Temple-Inland appears at first blush to be a rerun of the epic lost war fought by Air Products and Chemicals for Airgas. But on deeper examination, it has some fundamental differences.

headline: Obama and Merkel Tell Qaddafi to Go
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Tuesday ramped up his calls for the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, to step down, as NATO warplanes repeatedly dropped bombs on Tripoli in an intensifying campaign.

headline: Suskind Plans Book on Financial Crisis
text: Ron Suskind, the author and Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist, will offer a new account of the financial crisis and its aftermath in “Confidence Men,” a book to be released by HarperCollins in September, the publisher said on Tuesday. “This is a book that shows how the financial collapse did virtually nothing to change the culture of Wall Street,” Tim Duggan, a vice president and executive editor of Harper, said in an e-mail.

headline: Naples: Must-Sees and See-What-Happens
Thiel: Tech Bubble? What Tech Bubble?
text: There has been lots of chatter about a technology bubble in Silicon Valley. LinkedIn’s initial public offering, Groupon’s upcoming I.P.O. and bloated start-up investments and valuations are bringing back painful memories of the dot-com bubble’s burst roughly a decade ago.

headline: Syrian Leader’s Brother Seen as Enforcer of Crackdown
text: As reports mount of defections in the Syrian military and the government staggers from the killing of soldiers and police officers in a northern city this week, President Bashar al-Assad may turn increasingly to his brother, Maher, whose elite units in a demoralized army could prove decisive to his government’s survival, activists and analysts say.

headline: The KAWS Effect
text: In the back of Brian Donnelly’s studio in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, behind three wheeled, wooden work tables and neatly organized racks containing bottles of brightly colored acrylic paint, past an array of painted canvases in different shapes and sizes, hides a four-foot-tall sculpture of Mickey Mouse. Mickey has seen better days, apparently. He’s gray. And his eyes are x-ed out, as if he just drank from a bottle labeled “Poison.” Donnelly, 36, who is better known by his alias, KAWS, is getting ready to haul a 16-foot-tall version of this mouse, titled “Companion (Passing Through),” from the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum in Ridgefield, Conn., to the Standard hotel in New York. A graffiti artist, illustrator, toymaker, sculptor and painter, Donnelly first collaborated with the hotel earlier this year, with a series of blue, red and green light bulbs that sold out in a matter of days. For all of his visibility in the worlds of fashion and art, Donnelly remains an unassuming, self-proclaimed “blusher” from New Jersey. T caught up with him on the eve of the unveiling at The Standard to talk about art, life and why his large “companion” looks so darned shy.

headline: Ali at Budokan
text: My in-house Japanese-culture consultant turned to me Sunday night and said, “Do you remember when Muhammad Ali fought the Japanese wrestler in the 1970s?” I assumed this was a gross misinterpretation of something. Maybe a cartoon she saw once. But no. On June 26, 1976, Ali met Antonio Inoki, a professional wrestler, in the ring in Tokyo (at Budokan!). Inoki, for reasons best known to him, which is not to rule out terror given his prominent chin, spent most of the match on his back, trying to kick Ali. It ended in a draw.

headline: Flim-Flammed
text: I’ve been getting requests that I respond to my colleague David Brooks’s column today. Actually, I’ll just outsource it. Read Ezra Klein, Jonathan Chait, and Jonathan Cohn. The bottom line is, sorry, the evidence is indeed dispositive: decentralized, “consumer-based” health care is worse, and far more expensive, than universal systems run by the government.

headline: Blue Shield of California Vows to Cap Profits
text: Blue Shield of California, a not-for-profit health insurer based in San Francisco, is promising to limit its profits and give the bulk of any excess income it makes back to policyholders who are buying coverage.

headline: Ma! He’s Looking At Me Funny! Watch
text: Oh, my: apparently the new line on the right is that the economy is weakening because Obama, that nasty man, said bad things about Paul Ryan.

headline: The Keystone XL as Environmental Cudgel
text: As I noted in Tuesday’s article about Canada’s contingency plans should the Keystone XL pipeline be vetoed, the project has become a surrogate for the American debate on Canada’s oil sands development. Because the pipeline spans the international border, the State Department must give its approval before construction begins.

headline: Getty Acquires Vast Archive of Post-War Art Documents
text: Harald Szeemann, who died in 2005, was not only one of the most prominent contemporary art curators of the late 20th century; he was also a somewhat obsessive documentarian of the curatorial process and of his relationships with artists, including Joseph Beuys, Bruce Nauman, Richard Serra and Cy Twombly. The Getty Research Institute in Los Angeles announced on Tuesday that it has acquired Mr. Szeemann’s substantial archive, consisting of more than 1,000 boxes of correspondence, research files, drawings, and ephemera, as well as some 28,000 books and 36,000 photographs.

headline: My (Tenuous) Connection to the Belmont Stakes
text: I’ve always felt that if I had a racehorse and it won the Belmont Stakes, I’d have myself a pretty nice horse. I’m sure others feel the same way. I’d venture that the owners of the 142 winners of the Belmont Stakes have felt the same way too. Funny how horse people think alike.

headline: City to Crack Down on Illegally Divided Apartments
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council, reacting to a spate of recent deaths involving fires in illegally subdivided apartments, announced a program on Tuesday to crack down on the practice.

headline: Fill-In | D-Day Invasion
text: Today’s special fill-in is based on a descriptive passage from a historical Times article about the World War II invasion of the beaches at Normandy. Can you fill in the 20 missing words?

headline: Social Media Gets Its Due, New York-Style
text: If a lot of people were checking in to Gracie Mansion on Foursquare on Monday night, there was a good reason.

headline: Justified Boom or Overheated Bubble?
text: Alan Patricof, a partner at the venture capital firm Greycroft Partners, talks with CNBC about the fervor for social networking companies like LinkedIn.

headline: Woods Says He’ll Miss U.S. Open, and Doubts Grow About His Health
text: When Tiger Woods announced Tuesday that he would skip next week’s United States Open at Congressional Country Club because of a “mild” sprain to his medial collateral ligament and a “mild” strain of his Achilles’ tendon, the news came as no surprise and raised more questions than it answered about the extent of the damage to his left leg.

headline: Yangtze Rains Bring Drought Relief, and Floods
text: NANJING, China — Heavy rains since last Friday have brought some relief from the worst drought in the Yangtze River region in 50 years, but also caused flooding in at least two southern provinces, state news organizations reported Tuesday.

headline: Pawlenty Wants To Abolish the Army

text: As Justin Gillis reported this week in The Times, some experts suggest that the world is in need of a new agricultural revolution.

headline: The Unimog, Mercedes’ Resident Poison Dart Frog, Celebrates 60 Years
text: Mercedes-Benz marked the 60th anniversary of its rugged Unimog vehicle with a concept shown Monday at its plant in Wörth, Germany.

headline: Walsh Had Mark Jackson Pegged as a Future Coach
text: DALLAS — Donnie Walsh figured it was only a matter of time and place. Someone would do what he didn’t do and make Mark Jackson a head coach in the N.B.A.

headline: Number of Rare E. Coli Cases in U.S. Rose Last Year
text: Federal officials said on Tuesday that a national monitoring system for food-borne illness detected an increasing number of sicknesses last year from a group of rare E. coli bacteria related to the little-known and highly toxic strain that has been ravaging Germany.

headline: A Candid, and Prophetic, Interview With Weiner
text: On a sunny morning about three weeks ago, I found myself sitting across a table from Representative Anthony D. Weiner at Coffee Shop, in Union Square, chatting about Twitter.

headline: The High Line’s Beery Locavorism
text: New York state farm to New York City table? Ho-hum. But New York state farm to New York City brewery? Hasn’t happened in at least a century. And indeed, a high degree of difficulty marked the creation of what is believed to be the first modern commercial beer brewed in the city from local wheat. (The Tundra Brewery in Stamford, N.Y., is now selling a beer made from New York state grains at Manhattan Greenmarkets.) Here, then, is the unexpectedly complicated recipe for a seemingly simple new summer brew:

text: Photographs from Libya, Yemen, Afghanistan and Washington.

headline: Reviewing Imperial No. Nine
Imperial No. Nine
text: CONSISTENCY matters in restaurants. Customers may appreciate a new filling in a favorite ravioli or pie, may enjoy the new pinot noir served at the bar. But mostly what they want is the same dish they had last time. Often it is why they returned.

headline: Fed Wants Priority Put On Deficit
text: WASHINGTON — The leaders of the Federal Reserve are talking like people ready to sit down and let others take the lead in addressing the nation’s economic problems.

headline: Slow Furniture

text: Representative Anthony D. Weiner's constituents speak out; a look at how politicians express shame; and Glenn Beck takes his show online, for a fee.

headline: Three Sisters, a Deluded Dad and Some Wretched Rock
text: Momma Rose may not be the most lovable character in musical theater, but at least she has a sense of humor and a steamer trunk full of galvanizing songs to perform. That’s a lot more than can be said for Austin Wiggin (Peter Friedman), the tyrannical father determined to exorcise his own demons by making stars of his kids in “The Shaggs: Philosophy of the World,” a glum “Gypsy” for the hippie era that opened on Tuesday night at Playwrights Horizons in a co-production with New York Theater Workshop.

headline: Are Serious Errors Lurking in Your Credit Report?
text: How accurate is the all-important data in your credit report? It depends on whom you ask.

headline: Facebook Changes Privacy Settings to Enable Facial Recognition
text: Facebook is pushing the privacy line once again, according to a new report from a security and antivirus company.

headline: Just One Look | Narciso Rodriguez Resort Collection
text: As a rule, Narciso Rodriguez cuts a pretty strict silhouette. But for resort, it seems he took a deep breath, and then actually exhaled. He stuck to a clean, graphic, mostly black and white palette, but the best looks — like this top and slouchy pants — were as inviting as a favorite pair of pajamas.

headline: Tony Picks From a Drama Book Shop Employee
text: In the week leading up to the Tony Awards on June 12, ArtsBeat is asking several New Yorkers who are not Tony voters to pick their favorite shows, actors and designers in the New York Times’s interactive Tonys ballot.

text: How can the electric system take intermittent energy sources like wind and sun and integrate them with conventional fuels for electricity, like natural gas?

headline: City Principals Demand Return of January Regents Exams
text: Warning of a “real and devastating impact on our students,” more than 110 New York City high school principals are urging state officials to reverse course and reinstate the Regents exams that are usually given in January.

text: Every day on NYTimes.com you can solve a new sudoku puzzle that matches your level of expertise. Select easy, medium or difficult. For information on how to play, please see below.

headline: For City Opera, Spare Show May Signal Future
text: If New York City Opera were a thriving company with stable finances, a clear vision and a home base, the gratifying program it presented on Monday night at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem would have come across simply as a successful effort at community outreach.

headline: Would Gucci’s Owner Look Good in Prada?
text: PARIS — A spate of big-name deals in the luxury sector — Bulgari, Jimmy Choo, Jean Paul Gaultier — has left everyone wondering what’s next.

headline: The Lowdown | Yimmy’s Yayo
text: If there is such a thing as cult celebrity in the blogosphere, then the man behind Yimmy’s Yayo embodies it. Any post on his sexy, well-curated blog could trigger a virtual avalanche of traffic, and his following spreads from Sydney (where he’s based), to Berlin, New York and pretty much anywhere there’s Internet access.

headline: The Ironman Triathlon Comes to New York
text: Bringing the nation’s biggest triathlon to the nation’s biggest city turned out to be an organizational feat comparable to the Ironman itself. When it was officially announced Tuesday that the Ironman U.S. Championship would be contested in New York and New Jersey in August 2012, it capped seven years of planning with the knowledge that the 140.6-mile course could not involve closing any New York City streets.

headline: Grassley Grants More Time for S.E.C. Response
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission is seeking more time to respond to a Congressional request regarding how the agency handled referrals about suspicious trading activity at the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors.

headline: Leaving a Warming Arctic
text: Kate Stafford, an oceanographer at the Applied Physics Laboratory at the University of Washington, writes from Alaska, where she is participating in a visual census of bowhead whales.

headline: A Heckuva Book Pitch. That’s Putting It Mildly.
text: Last October, just before the deal-making frenzy of the Frankfurt Book Fair, the indie publisher Johnny Temple received an e-mailed book proposal that he was tempted to brush off.

headline: Living a Drug Life in a World of Snow
text: The title of Joonas Neuvonen’s “Reindeerspotting: Escape From Santaland” makes explicit the film’s premise: to take the kind of intimacy and immediacy Danny Boyle achieved in his fictional story of Glasgow heroin addicts, “Trainspotting,” and apply it to a documentary about Mr. Neuvonen’s fellow drug users in northern Finland.

headline: That Look, That Weiner-Spitzer-Clinton Look
text: The names may change, but the face remains essentially the same.

headline: Mourning, Bach and a 9/11 Theme
text: Among the many fascinating details that have punctuated the pianist Simone Dinnerstein’s long and winding road to success, one in particular resonated during a brief recital she gave on Monday evening at St. Paul’s Chapel in downtown Manhattan. On learning that she was expecting a baby in 2001, Ms. Dinnerstein decided to master Bach’s “Goldberg” Variations as an accompaniment to her pregnancy. Seven months into both personal journeys, she was at home in Brooklyn on the morning of the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline: Judge Won’t Reconsider Decision on Corporate Donations
text: A federal judge on Tuesday denied a request by prosecutors to reconsider his ruling last month striking down a ban on direct contributions from corporations to political candidates, setting into motion what could be a pivotal court battle over one of the biggest legal and political issues of the day.

headline: Taking on the Risks of a Mixed Lineup
text: Sampler programs — bits and pieces from different artists — are a gamble for both presenters and audiences. Perhaps everyone will show the same kind of work? Perhaps all the lighting will be dim and the costumes brown? Perhaps the styles will be so widely disparate or obscure as to leave watchers with furrowed brows?

headline: How Does a Choreographer Create Art? Day by Ho-Hum Day
text: The movies like to present portraits of artists who create great works all at once, driven to some sort of divine (perhaps substance-enhanced) frenzy in the dark hours of the night. But anybody who has ever really engineered something, be it a table or a painting or a dinner party, on some level understands that this isn’t the way it happens for most of us — even those residing in that dubious category, “genius.” In her fine 2003 essay “Dailiness,” in an anthology, “Choreographic Encounters,” the choreographer Susan Rethorst muses on the day-by-day practice of dance making.

headline: Glenn Beck's New Venture
text: On Tuesday, Glenn Beck revealed he's taking his show online, shunning the traditional TV format, and will charge viewers a monthly fee to watch it.

headline: Who Are The Rentiers?
text: Following up on my rentier post and the eurocentric followup, a question: who are we talking about? That is, who stands to gain from deflation, and lose if inflation is, say, 4 percent over a period of 10 years? Is it little old ladies living on fixed incomes, and salt of the earth workers who have scrimped and saved?

headline: TimesCast | Expressing Shame
text: When Representative Anthony D. Weiner of New York held a news conference on Monday and admitted to lying, Dan Hill, an expert in the role of emotion in consumer behavior, was watching.

headline: Enjoying the Quiet Pleasures of a Meeting of Minds
text: Vinicius Cantuária and Bill Frisell sat facing the audience, but angled toward each other, throughout their calmly transfixing show at the Highline Ballroom on Monday night. Each cradled a guitar — nylon-string acoustic for Mr. Cantuária, electric for Mr. Frisell — and both often had slight smiles on their faces, the sort of expression you might wear while hearing an old friend tell a fondly half-remembered tale. The setting was sparse, but the performance, part of the Blue Note Jazz Festival, conveyed a sense of fullness.

headline: Cirque du Soleil's Wheel of Death
text: A scene from Cirque du Soleil's new show "Zarkana." (Video courtesy of the company.)

headline: Video: Glenn Beck Soon Available Online, For a Price
text: Related: Glenn Beck to Charge Fee for Online Show

headline: Beethoven Elegant and Beethoven Frenetic
text: Listening to a pianist perform the manic and psychotically complex Fugue from Beethoven’s “Hammerklavier” Sonata (Op. 106) can inspire the same sense of anticipation as watching a gymnast execute a series of gravity-defying maneuvers. Will he or she land safely?

headline: TimesCast | Weiner's Constituents
text: Representative Anthony D. Weiner's New York constituents speak out.

headline: In the Labyrinth of Medical Research
text: There is great ambition in Matthew Maguire’s drama “Wax Wings,” at the Wild Project, not least in its inquiry into scientific issues. The play, presented by the Creation Production Company, of which Mr. Maguire is co-artistic director, offers copious information about the dengue mosquito, the form of pneumonia known as SARS (severe acute respiratory syndrome) and the pressures that researchers endure from their backers. It also addresses conflicts between faith and rationality; the drive to reproduce and the impulse to resist it; and the relative merits of expediency and caution in a crisis. The debates, unfortunately, don’t end there.

headline: A Superhero’s Day (and a Damsel’s) Never Ends
text: Friday’s show had been over for a couple of hours, but Reeve Carney and Jennifer Damiano were still working hard for “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” at Joe Allen’s, the Broadway watering hole. The two young stars were downing fries and sandwiches when a table of tipsy fans came by, one of them calling himself an investor in this $70 million musical.

headline: My Top 10 Business Travel Tips
text: Over the past decade, I have gone from being an aggressive domestic traveler to being an aggressive global traveler, constantly visiting our various foreign locations and opening up new operations. I travel so much that I can relate to George Clooney’s character in the movie “Up In the Air.” (Last year, I traveled more than half a million miles!)

headline: Pawlenty Talks Tough on Obama
text: Tim Pawlenty hails from Minnesota, where folks are Midwest nice. But you wouldn’t know that from listening to him recently.

headline: No Poker Faces at Star-Struck Fashion Awards
text: IT was 30 minutes past midnight — after all of the Council of Fashion Designers of America Awards had had been handed out at Lincoln Center, well after Lady Gaga had removed what little there was left to remove of her outfit, and just after she joined Patti LaBelle in a performance of “Over the Rainbow” at a nightclub in the Standard hotel — when the opportunity arose to ask the question that had been on everyone’s lips.

headline: Despite Worries, Serving at the Top Carries Little Risk
text: Harry Campbell

headline: How to Shop a Flea
text: Alex Bell and Shira Entis know their fleas, from Elephant’s Trunk in Connecticut to Portobello Market in London. Which you would expect from the girls who started the awesome line of handbags and totes called Fleabags.

headline: Ernesto Bazan
text: Fidel

headline: A Gold Rush, Deep in a City’s Sewers
text: BAGHDAD — Deep below the workshops in Baghdad’s cramped, run-down jewelry district, unemployed men spend their days scouring the city’s sewer system for the one thing they say can bring them money: flakes of gold.

headline: Emerging Nations Warm to Lagarde for I.M.F. Role
text: PARIS — As the race for a new leader at the International Monetary Fund moves toward a pivotal deadline this week, the global charm offensive by the French finance minister, Christine Lagarde, appears to be paying off.

headline: Disunion Q. and A. on Facebook
text: Join Jamie Malanowski, Disunion lead writer and author of the e-book “And the War Came,” tomorrow at noon, E.D.T., for a discussion about the Civil War on the Disunion Facebook page. To learn more about Jamie and the book, visit the website of his publisher, Byliner.

headline: The Trick an Animal Cannot Learn: How to Be Wild Again
text: There’s no denying the “aww” appeal of a man and an elephant walking down a street, hand in trunk. That is one truth in “One Lucky Elephant,” a sweet, heart- and trunk-tugging, modestly sized documentary — except for its 10,000-pound title subject — about a circus man and the wild animal he foolishly bought, helped to train, loved like a (captive) daughter and finally, tearfully, tried to do right by, mostly by letting her go.

headline: Nurses Rally for Health Care Funding
text: Hundreds of members of the nation’s largest nurses’ union demonstrated outside the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and on Capitol Hill on Tuesday.

headline: ABC Rules Again on Monday Night
text: “The Bachelorette” had the highest ratings in prime time on Monday, extending ABC’s winning streak to 13 weeks as the most-watched network on the night. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 8 million viewers tuned in to ABC from 8 to 10 p.m. for Week 3 of this reality dating series, easily outperforming Fox’s second-season premiere of “MasterChef” in the 8 p.m. hour (4.3 million). But the news was not all positive for ABC as its new 10 p.m. series, “Extreme Makeover: Weight Loss Edition” (5.7 million), lagged behind its time-slot competitors, “Law & Order: Los Angeles” on NBC (6.2 million) and a rerun of “Hawaii Five-0” on CBS (6.5 million). For the night CBS ranked second, broadcasting repeats of its sitcom lineup from 8 to 10. NBC was third with reruns of “Minute to Win It” at 8 (3.9 million) and “Law & Order: Criminal Intent” at 9 (4.5 million). Fox finished in fourth place, garnering 3.4 million at 9 for a repeat of “House.”

headline: CW Becomes 2nd Network to Finish ‘Upfront’ Sales
text: CW, home of series like “Gossip Girl” and “The Vampire Diaries,” has become the second broadcast television network to complete its upfront advertising sales before the beginning of the 2011-12 season.

headline: Public Opinion on the Wars? New Polls Offer Conflicting Evidence

headline: The Job Market: Germany vs. the U.S.
text: My column this week — comparing the German and American economies — mentions a couple of job-market statistics that I wanted to show in more detail. The first shows how the German and American unemployment rates have slipped since the financial crisis began, in 2007:

headline: Girardi and Yankees’ Pick Go Back a Long Way
text: Joe Girardi says he got to know Dante Bichette in 1993, when both joined the Colorado Rockies, an expansion team. The Rockies lost 95 games and were outscored by more than 200 runs, and Girardi and Bichette were about as opposite as two players could get.

headline: Ettore Messina Prepares for Life in the N.B.A.
text: Ettore Messina, one of Europe’s most celebrated coaches, appears close to joining Mike Brown on the staff of the Los Angeles Lakers. It’s not the first time that N.B.A. teams have courted Messina — he has turned down offers from Sacramento, Toronto and New Jersey. But this time he appears ready to make the jump.

headline: A Break for the Philharmonic’s Summer Concerts
text: The New York Philharmonic is taking a break from its normal early-summer concerts in New York City parks, adding performances in September instead. The orchestra will perform with the tenor Andrea Bocelli on Sept. 15 on Central Park’s Great Lawn, a special event outside its usual parks series. Two days later at Avery Fisher Hall, it will play William Walton’s music from the movie “Henry V,” narrated by Christopher Plummer, and music from Shakespeare’s time. The concert had originally been planned for the spring but was moved because of a conflict with Mr. Plummer’s schedule, said the orchestra’s spokesman, Eric Latzky.

headline: ‘Million Dollar Quartet’ to Close, Then Move
text: The producers of the Broadway musical “Million Dollar Quartet” announced on Tuesday that the show will transfer Off Broadway to New World Stages after it plays its final performance at the Nederlander Theater on Sunday. No opening date for the Off Broadway production was announced.

headline: Sony Unveils the PlayStation Vita, a New Portable Gaming Device
text: Here are some first reactions to Sony’s $250 PlayStation Vita (PSVita), the former NGP, unveiled Monday at E3 in Los Angeles, and in stores later this year. On first glance, PS Vita (the short name) looks like a wide-body version PSP, with a bright (OLED), large (5-inch) touch screen.

headline: In Greenwich Village, the Signs They Are A-Changin’
text: When a preservationist in Greenwich Village learned last week that Panchito’s Mexican Restaurant had painted over the faded lettering reading “Fat Black Pussycat Theatre” above its entrance, he was outraged by what he viewed as the destruction of a link to a musical milestone.

headline: U.S. Endorses Secretary General’s Re-election
text: The White House on Tuesday endorsed Ban Ki-moon for a second term as secretary general of the United Nations, helping assure his re-election. “Under Ban’s leadership, the United Nations has played a critical role in responding to crises and challenges across the globe,” the White House said. Mr. Ban, a former foreign minister for South Korea, has led the United Nations through recent crises involving Libya and Ivory Coast. He has served since December 2006.

headline: Beltran’s Back in the Lineup
text: Two days after fouling a ball off his right leg and leaving the game in the second inning, Carlos Beltran was back in the lineup Tuesday night as the Mets opened a three-game series in Milwaukee against the Brewers.

headline: In Santa Monica, Circumcision Opponent Abandons Efforts
text: LOS ANGELES — The primary backer of an effort to get a ban on circumcision on the ballot in Santa Monica is abandoning her push, saying the proposed legislation had been misrepresented as an effort to impinge on religious freedom. A similar measure in San Francisco is scheduled for a fall vote.

headline: Sudan: Foreigners Evacuated in Border City
text: Fighting continued on Tuesday between northern troops and soldiers aligned with the southern Sudanese in Kadugli, the capital of Southern Kordofan State, forcing about 400 foreigners to be evacuated, the United Nations said. At least six people were killed in the last two days, the United Nations said, adding that about 3,000 people had taken shelter at a nearby hospital on Monday night. Southern Kordofan is on the border between northern and southern Sudan, which is to declare its independence next month.

headline: The Resort Collections: Acid Reign
text: My notes from Diane Von Furstenberg’s resort show on Monday, scribbled on the back of a press folder (my, we’re getting fancy!), include the words surf shorts, side-zip minis, anoraks, silver kitten heels, lemon/lime/neon, and squiggly prints that vaguely suggested an African origin. The sporty collection thrived on big pops of bright color, with more tech appeal than sex appeal. You can probably coordinate your iPad case.

text: DALLAS — As they crossed paths, at long last, on the N.B.A.’s grandest stage, Mike Bibby and Peja Stojakovic exchanged a meaningful glance, a knowing smile, a quiet acknowledgment of their mutually delayed gratification.

headline: For a Longtime Forger, Adding One Last Touch
text: LAFAYETTE, La. — This is expected to be a formality, one of the lawyers said, a simple affirmation of what has already been put on paper. The courtroom was mostly empty but for a few lawyers and federal agents and a handful of journalists and onlookers who had followed the case with cultish fascination.

headline: E. Coli: Don’t Blame the Sprouts!
text: One hundred thousand E. coli can dance on the head of a pin; it may only take 50 to make you sick enough to die. Benign E. coli are everywhere, even in your own pink gut right now, and all E. coli can live on (or in) things as different as sprouts, burgers and water. But if you were able to trace back far enough, their reservoir is most likely the gut of mammal: a goat, a sheep, a deer, even a majestic elk or a dog. They’re most often associated with cows.

headline: Ethics Case for Weiner? Maybe One of Psychiatry
text: The matter of Anthony D. Weiner, unclothed congressman, is being lodged by Democratic Party elders with the House ethics committee, a holding room where it will remain until either it, or he, goes away.

headline: Based on an Old Family Recipe
text: A COUPLE of years ago, Jason Wang graduated from Washington University in St. Louis with a bachelor’s degree in business. At the moment, he is dishing out spicy hand-cut rice noodles in a narrow storefront in the East Village, and seems pretty thrilled about his career path.

headline: The Earth Is Full
text: You really do have to wonder whether a few years from now we’ll look back at the first decade of the 21st century — when food prices spiked, energy prices soared, world population surged, tornados plowed through cities, floods and droughts set records, populations were displaced and governments were threatened by the confluence of it all — and ask ourselves: What were we thinking? How did we not panic when the evidence was so obvious that we’d crossed some growth/climate/natural resource/population redlines all at once?

headline: Chinatown's New Generation
text: Wilson Tang is a second-generation American who is taking over ownership of the legendary Nom Wah Tea Parlor in Chinatown.

headline: A New Voice of America for the Age of Twitter
text: WASHINGTON — When Walter Isaacson championed Voice of America’s decision to shut down its shortwave radio broadcasts to China — and shift those funds to the Internet, cellphones and other forms of digital media — he viewed it as the sensible updating of a propaganda playbook dating from the cold war.

headline: After 40 Years, the Complete Pentagon Papers
text: It may be a first in the annals of government secrecy: Declassifying documents to mark the anniversary of their leak to the press. But that is what will happen Monday, when the federal government plans to finally release the secret government study of the Vietnam War known as the Pentagon Papers 40 years after it was first published by The New York Times.

headline: 2 Hoteliers Form Partnerships to Enhance Luxury Image
text: TWO of the world’s largest hotel companies are reaching out to other industries to establish partnerships that they hope will help their luxury brands continue their recovery.

headline: In Cuts, Fears for Program That Assists Rape Victims
text: With recent sexual-assault cases in the headlines, several City Council members and victims’ advocates said Tuesday that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s cost-cutting would devastate a program that treats sexual-assault victims at public hospitals and gathers evidence to be used in prosecutions.

headline: Zabb Elee
text: IS a puzzlement: a Thai restaurant that does not serve pad Thai. There’s also no roster of coconutty curries, no clear demarcation between appetizers and entrees and just one small section of “Bangkok rice and noodles.” The bulk of the menu, evidently, hails from beyond the country’s capital.

text: Add Massachusetts to the groundswell of states and localities opposing President Obama’s misconceived and failing immigration dragnet.

text: PARIS — A woman identifying herself as the Syrian ambassador to France announced her resignation by telephone on French television Tuesday evening, in what would be the first such defection from the government of President Bashar al-Assad in months of unrest.

text: MADISON, Wis. — The gears of government tend to grind slowly. But in Wisconsin lately they are racing at turbocharged speed.

headline: As Ethics Measure Emerges, So Do Questions About Its Teeth
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s office unveiled legislation to improve ethics enforcement on Tuesday, revealing details that raised questions about whether the reforms would be weaker than expected.

headline: Two Yankees and Two Milestones, but Mixed Emotions
text: Until his contentious contract negotiations last off-season, Derek Jeter was as bulletproof as a star athlete could be. The new deal was an obvious overpay by the Yankees — $17 million per year — and it has fed the kind of scrutiny Jeter has never faced before.

headline: The Gas Is Greener
text: IN April, Gov. Jerry Brown made headlines by signing into law an ambitious mandate that requires California to obtain one-third of its electricity from renewable energy sources like sunlight and wind by 2020. Twenty-nine states and the District of Columbia now have renewable electricity mandates. President Obama and several members of Congress have supported one at the federal level. Polls routinely show strong support among voters for renewable energy projects — as long as they don’t cost too much.

headline: The Cup Finals Are Leaving a Nasty Mark
text: BOSTON — The image remained seared into Stanley Cup memory the day after Vancouver’s Aaron Rome flattened Boston’s Nathan Horton with a thunderous shoulder five minutes into the Bruins’ 8-1 victory Monday night: Horton lying motionless on the ice, his eyes staring blankly at the TD Garden ceiling, his arm upright, frozen frighteningly in position as the Bruins’ medical staff rushed out to care for him while Rome headed to the dressing room with a five-minute interference major and a game misconduct.

headline: Pawlenty Calls for Greater Tax and Spending Cuts Than G.O.P. Rivals
text: WASHINGTON — Former Gov. Tim Pawlenty called on Tuesday for more than $2 trillion in tax cuts for individuals and businesses over the next decade and two to three times as much in federal spending reductions and loophole closings, saying that such policies would drive rapid economic growth.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Farm Talk

headline: For Dad, Candy Made From Beer
text: Father’s Day is not gleefully anticipated by chocolatiers, except, perhaps, by a company called Beercandy. The owner, Steve Casselman, a brewer in Santa Clara, Calif., began experimenting with beer-based candy more than 10 years ago with lollipops. More recently, he’s used beer to flavor the caramel fillings for chocolate-covered candies, which he’s been selling online since fall. Beer’s bitter edge is a nice balance for the caramel and chocolate. The India pale ale caramel is covered with white chocolate; the lager caramel, with milk chocolate. The robust stout is dipped in dark chocolate, and the raspberry flavor of the lambic comes through its dark chocolate shell. His latest treat is beer-flavored taffy. He also sells Hop Drops, made by Bob Bero under the name B-Hoppy, which are flavored with the oil of American Cascade hops for a citric flavor. (Hop Drops and taffy are at right.)

headline: Little Espresso Bars Might Be Big Business
text: A COFFEE fanatic in a vintage Pink Floyd T-shirt pulling shots of single-origin espresso from El Salvador on the latest-generation machine might not seem like a blue-chip investment.

headline: Off the Menu

headline: Smoky Salmon for the Pantry
text: In 1978, Bruce Gore founded Triad Fisheries, a Seattle company whose boats became known for salmon gutted and flash-frozen on board. Now, it has hot-smoked Coho salmon in six-ounce jars that don’t need refrigeration until opened. The smoky pieces are perfect for quick canapés, sandwiches and garnishes.

headline: Fresh Eggs So Local, They’re at Your House
text: Imagine fresh eggs from your own backyard. Jason Stroud, an antiques restorer in Red Hook, Brooklyn, knows that pleasure well. And he has started sharing it, helping urban homesteaders set up backyard coops with the appropriate kinds of chickens. He has been so busy since he started building and selling the coops a couple of months ago that he is phasing out his antiques business.

headline: In Weiner’s District, Supporters Still Are Easy to Find
text: Representative Anthony D. Weiner, who is embroiled in a scandal over sexually explicit exchanges with women, announced on Monday that he would leave his political fate to the voters in his district, saying that, “My constituents have to make a determination.”

headline: Democratic Rule Remakes Connecticut’s Legislature
text: HARTFORD — In a year when conservative politics have dominated even traditionally Democratic states like New Jersey and New York, Connecticut is closing out its most activist, liberal legislative session in memory.

text: MOUNT PROSPECT, Ill. — Like many people approaching their 50th birthday, the Randhurst Mall is having a little work done.

headline: Push for A’s at Private Schools Is Keeping Costly Tutors Busy
text: Siddharth Iyer spent eight Mays cramming for finals, first at Stuyvesant High School and then at Columbia University.

headline: California Insurer Says It Will Cap Earnings
text: Blue Shield of California, a large nonprofit health insurer that has come under sharp criticism in recent months for its double-digit rate increases, said on Tuesday that it planned to cap its earning and refund the bulk of any excess income to its policyholders.

headline: Weiner Faces Calls to Resign and Tries to Make Amends
text: Representative Anthony D. Weiner of New York, reeling from revelations of salacious online behavior that threaten his political career, moved rapidly on Tuesday to make amends as Republicans called for his resignation and leading members of his own Democratic Party distanced themselves from him.

headline: Fleeing to Foreign Shores
text: Reva Medical, a maker of medical devices in San Diego, wanted to go public last year to raise money to satisfy impatient venture capitalists and finance research for its heart stents.

headline: Citi Field Welcomes Soccer
text: For the first time in weeks, fans occupied nearly every seat at Citi Field on Tuesday night. Only this time vuvuzelas, not “Take Me Out to the Ballgame,” resonated throughout the ballpark, and yellow, not blue, was the dominant color in the stands.

headline: The Switzerland of America
text: East Tennessee, wrote a pamphleteer shortly after the end of the Civil War, had long been considered the Switzerland of America. “Its towering mountains locking up deep, rich and verdant valleys and coves, its succession of ridges and valleys, its magnificent forests, its roaring streams, the general fertility of the soil, the glory of the climate, the salubrity of the atmosphere, the sublimity, beauty and picturesqueness of the scenery, the freshness and voluptuous abundance of the country, all conspire to make it one of the most desirable spots in America.”

headline: Keeping Protectionism at Bay
text: The world’s big trading nations have done a fairly good job over the last two years of resisting protectionism even as their economies stalled or shrank. But their patience with open markets seems to be wearing thin.

headline: Ambitious Goals for Ford
text: Ford Motor’s punchy global ambitions are not as worrying as they look. The Motor City automaker expects to sell eight million vehicles a year by the middle of the decade, according to the plan unveiled on Tuesday by Alan R. Mulally, the chief executive. That is 50 percent higher than Ford’s showing in 2010 and more bullish than the one-third sales pickup he sees for the industry.

headline: Calling for ‘Achievable’ Target, Christie Plans Cut in State’s Renewable Energy Goals
text: Gov. Chris Christie said Tuesday that he planned to scale back New Jersey’s goals for renewable energy as he looked for an “achievable” approach to generating electricity in the state.

headline: Hovnanian’s Revenue Falls 20%, a Worse Loss Than Expected
text: Hovnanian Enterprises, the home builder, reported a wider quarterly loss on Tuesday as revenue fell 20 percent amid slumping demand for new houses.

headline: The Fair Rewards of Invention
text: Before the Bayh-Dole Act was passed in 1980, the billions of federal dollars spent on scientific research rarely benefited the public through commercial applications. Fewer than 5 percent of government patents were licensed to industry. To push patents into practical use, the law set up a scheme for awarding the rights to institutions, like universities, that have incentive to bring inventions to market.

headline: An Unexpected Trend Toward Office Sublets
text: Six months ago, when the law firm Venable began a search for a permanent home in New York, it did not end up moving far. Venable, based in Baltimore, had been subletting 52,000 square feet at 1270 Avenue of the Americas. With the agreement about to expire, it decided to stay on and sign a direct lease with its landlord, Tishman Speyer, for the same space.

headline: Search for Bodies Resumes on Long Island, Aided by Aerial Images
text: BABYLON, N.Y. — It was 84 degrees on Tuesday, with an abundance of sun and a healthy breeze — the kind of day that Oliver Kurzyp and Adam Janowski could not let pass without a trip to the beach.

headline: Andrew Gold and the ’70s Sound
text: At one time, I thought I owned every album Andrew Gold played on between 1974 and 1980, nearly all of them recorded and produced in southern California. I was wrong. I never owned the albums he recorded with Barbi Benton, Hugh Hefner’s girlfriend in the early 1970s, even though she went to high school with me. I wasn’t intentionally collecting Gold, who died last week at age 59. He just happened to back up, produce or appear with nearly everyone I was listening to at the time.

headline: Rector at Muslim University in Russia Is Shot to Death
text: MOSCOW — Gunmen on Tuesday killed the rector of a Muslim university in southern Russia who had been leading a government-sponsored effort to counter violence in the region by reviving the local traditions of Sufi Islam that he said were less likely to inspire suicide bombers.

headline: Countering Video Game Rivals, Nintendo Introduces a Touch-Screen Wii
text: LOS ANGELES — Nintendo on Tuesday announced a new version of its Wii video game console, in a move to counter increased competition from higher-resolution consoles from Microsoft and Sony, as well as multifunction devices like the Apple iPad.

headline: O.A.S. Promises to Tackle Drug Trafficking and Crime
text: SAN SALVADOR — Goaded by what they say are extraordinary levels of violence, the Central American nations and their allies are moving closer to a transnational strategy to attack drug trafficking and organized crime.

headline: Monster Trucks on the Road, From Gangs in Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY — Rhino trucks, narco tanks, Mad Mex-inismos? No one can agree on what to call the armored monster vehicles that Mexican criminal groups have been welding together in recent months, but this much is clear — they are building more of them.

text: The nation’s biggest banks and large technology companies like SAP rushed Tuesday to accept RSA Security’s offer to replace their ubiquitous SecurID tokens as many computer security experts voiced frustration with the company.

headline: Top Aide to Brazilian Leader Steps Down Amid a Scandal
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — A top cabinet official in the government of President Dilma Rousseff resigned Tuesday amid reports that he had enriched himself while a federal lawmaker, deepening the first political crisis for Ms. Rousseff since she took office in January.

headline: Fighters Shoot Protesters at a Palestinian Camp in Syria
text: Gunmen from a pro-Syrian Palestinian organization shot and killed as many as 14 people during a protest at a Palestinian refugee camp near Damascus on Monday, WAFA, the official Palestinian news agency, reported on Tuesday.

headline: Senate May Alter Law for Widows From Rig Blast
text: Jason Anderson’s death was both tragic and especially unlucky. Tragic, like the death of any man who leaves a widow and two young children. Unlucky because his life’s end, with 10 other men in the explosion of the Deepwater Horizon oil rig last year, constituted death on the high seas, which under maritime law limits the recovery available to his widow in court.

text: The Anthony Weiner story has claimed another victim: Jon Stewart, the host of “The Daily Show.” Or part of him, at least.

headline: North Carolina: Second Guilty Plea in Terror Case
text: The 22-year-old son of a North Carolina man who pleaded guilty in February to supporting Islamist terrorism pleaded guilty himself on Tuesday, Justice Department officials announced. Zakariya Boyd, the son of Daniel Patrick Boyd, admitted to one count of conspiracy to provide material support to terrorists in a federal court in New Bern. He faces up to 15 years in prison. Mr. Boyd was charged in 2009 along with seven defendants including his father with providing money, training and other resources to further violent jihadist activity overseas. Five of the other six defendants are in custody and are facing trial in September; the sixth is overseas and not in custody.

headline: Mets’ Top Pick Wants to Put Wyoming on the Baseball Map
text: Brandon Nimmo is well aware of the skeptics, those who wonder if a Wyoming kid can consistently perform at a high level against elite competition.

headline: Soccer Makes Its Debut at Citi Field, With More to Come
text: Citi Field’s inaugural soccer game Tuesday night between Ecuador and Greece drew a boisterous crowd of 39,656, most of whom were cheering for Ecuador, and provided a festive atmosphere at a stadium that has been home to its share of bad news this spring.

headline: Yankees Are Doomed by Two Early Exits
text: Only four outs after Yankees Manager Joe Girardi gingerly escorted an injured and grimacing Mark Teixeira from the batter’s box and down the dugout steps, he was striding across the infield to take the baseball from his ineffective starting pitcher, Freddy Garcia.

headline: Covidien May Seek Sale of Drug Unit

headline: Lilian Jackson Braun, ‘Cat Who’ Writer, Dies at 97

headline: Back in Milwaukee, Capuano Wins With Assist From Reyes
text: MILWAUKEE — For seven arduous years, the left-hander Chris Capuano was on the Milwaukee Brewers. He earned an All-Star berth one season, then was forced to deal with an embarrassing string of losses and a career-threatening injury.

headline: In Texas, Mass Grave Report Leads to Drama but No Bodies
text: HARDIN, Tex. — The police in East Texas were led on a fruitless search on Tuesday evening when a woman, claiming to be a psychic, called in a sensational tip, saying she knew of a mass grave where dozens of dismembered bodies were buried.

headline: After Appealing Suspension, Papelbon Earns 200th Save
text: Jonathan Papelbon became the fastest to reach 200 saves Tuesday night when he sealed the Boston Red Sox’ 6-4 win over the Yankees at Yankee Stadium. His milestone came hours after he learned he would be suspended for three games and fined an undisclosed amount for bumping an umpire Saturday.

headline: Nowitzki Shakes Fever and Rallies Mavericks

headline: As Heat Lose Series Lead, Hints of a James Slump

headline: Evercore to Buy Lexicon in European Push
text: Evercore Partners, the boutique investment bank founded by Roger Altman, agreed on Tuesday to buy a British rival, Lexicon Partners, for £86 million ($141 million) to expand in Europe.

headline: Another Cuba, a Different Fidel
text: Ernesto Bazan’s images of the Cuban countryside are remnants of a tropical dream — suffused with tenderness, color and a hint of mystery. You can almost touch the damp earth, where a freshly slaughtered pig lays near a puddle of blood, or smell the hand-rolled puros whose smoke hangs in the air like a milky veil.

Robert Darnton’s review in the June 9 issue of The New York Review of Books was the most entertaining. headline: Iran Says It Will Speed Up Uranium Enrichment
text: Iran declared Wednesday that it planned this year to triple production of its most concentrated form of nuclear fuel, expanding its manufacturing efforts to a mountainous, once secret nuclear site buried deep underground. Atomic experts worry that the production of more concentrated fuel could bring Iran closer to the ability to rapidly make weapons-grade uranium for a bomb.

headline: Melissa Leo, Hayden Panettiere Among Those Eyeing Broadway Roles in ‘Picnic’
text: The producers developing a Broadway revival of William Inge’s Pulitzer Prize-winning play “Picnic,” about young love and growing older in small-town Kansas, held a private reading on Monday to assess the artistry and star power of potential cast members, according to theater executives familiar with the lineup. Among those reading were the Academy Award-winning actress Melissa Leo (“The Fighter”) as the widow, Flo; Hayden Panettiere (TV’s “Heroes”) as her well-behaved daughter Madge; Laura Innes (“ER”) as her neighbor Rosemary; and Seth Numrich (“War Horse”) as the college student Alan, the role that was Paul Newman’s Broadway debut in 1953.

headline: From a Special-Ed Class, Solar Evangelists
text: Kevin Crosby, a special-education teacher at Independence High School in Bakersfield, Calif., hit on the idea early in the school year. Why not try to get about six of the teen-agers in his class focused on a solar energy project — something that would allow them to build and operate small solar-powered machines?

headline: Drone Strikes Kill 20 in Pakistan, Reports Say
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — At least 20 suspected militants were killed in Pakistan’s northwestern tribal region Wednesday in what were described as a pair of American drone strikes, local news media reported.

headline: R.O.T.C. Returns to Yale and a Soldier Applauds
text: Yale gave R.O.T.C. the door in 1969-70, while my father was an undergraduate. It was a big deal, and I was certainly too young to know anything about their decision. But I think it was probably made for good and positive reasons. During the social and political upheaval of the late ’60s, the horrors of the Holocaust and World War II were not that distant, and concerns about how those terrors might be playing out across the battlefields of Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia were on the minds of many Ivy League administrators at that time.

headline: Split by Infighting, OPEC Keeps a Cap on Oil

That left existing quotas in place, despite rising world prices and pressure from major oil-consuming countries to increase output.

headline: Economic Winner in 2010: North Dakota

headline: Summer at the Book Review: What We’re Reading
text: People often ask editors at the Book Review whether we find the energy to read for pleasure in between all the reading we do for work. The answer: yes! As we assembled our Summer Reading issue, we thought it was a good time to see what some of us were looking forward to reading as the warmest months approach (besides the galleys piling up on our desks, that is). From whale tales to political writing to rubber duckies and Parisian escapes, one editor’s “pleasure” isn’t necessarily going to be another’s — but who’s to say that Shakespeare, Heidegger and Leo Strauss aren’t good enough for the beach?

headline: You Blow My Mind. Hey, Mickey!
text: Something you learn rearing kids in this young millennium is that the word “Disney” works as a verb. As in, “Do you Disney?” Or, “Are we Disneying this year?” Technically a person could use the terms in speaking about the original Disneyland, in California, but this would be an anomalous usage. One goes to Disneyland and has a great time there, probably — I’ve never been — but one Disneys at the Walt Disney World Resort in Florida. There’s an implication of surrender to something enormous.

headline: Hulkamania Really Is Coming For You: Hulk Hogan Plans Live Tour
text: Listen up, Hulkamaniacs: Are you an aspiring young actor or journeyman performer looking for advice, inspiration and insider anecdotes from a seasoned show-business veteran? Would you be interested in attending an hour-and-a-half lecture by Terry Gene Bollea, a seasoned actor, musician and athlete? Not sure? How about a 90-minute, no-holds-barred stage production starring Hulk Hogan, the pointing, preening, all-American professional wrestler? Whichever sounds more appealing, you’ll have your chance to pose questions to and receive wisdom from Mr. Hogan, the body-slamming alter ego of Mr. Bollea, on a tour that the wrestler is planning for next year and which his agency is envisioning as a Hulk-ified version of “Inside the Actors Studio” (with perhaps more Atomic Leg Drops than James Lipton’s incarnation). The Agency Group said on Wednesday that it had signed up Mr. Hogan for the production, called “In Conversation: Outside the Ring with Hulk Hogan,” which will start with a few dates in the fall before commencing a worldwide tour next year.

headline: How to Avoid Credit Card Problems Abroad
text: LIKE many Americans who have tried to use their credit cards in Europe, Elliot E. Porter, a historian from San Francisco, has encountered his share of payment headaches. Perhaps the most aggravating occurred a few months ago at Amsterdam Centraal Station, where he learned only after waiting in line to purchase train tickets that none of his credit cards, which include a MasterCard, Visa and American Express, would be accepted. The problem? They rely on magnetic-strip technology rather than embedded microprocessor chips, which are becoming increasingly common outside the United States.

headline: Qaeda No. 2 Delivers Video Eulogy to Bin Laden

headline: ‘Super 8’ Gets Super-Secret Twitter Rollout

Abrams and produced by Steven Spielberg. Imax theaters and top-performing multiplexes –- some 325 locations across the country –- will host afternoon sneak-peek screenings of that movie and customers will be urged to Tweet about it afterward using #super8secret. (These screenings will be available to anyone who buys a ticket, however; you do not need to use Twitter to attend.)

headline: In India, Dynamism Wrestles With Dysfunction

Mercedes-Benzes and BMWs shimmer in automobile showrooms. Apartment towers are sprouting like concrete weeds, and a futuristic commercial hub called Cyber City houses many of the world’s most respected corporations.

headline: Rosie Perez’s Prom Night
text: It’s hard to believe, but the Oscar-nominated actress Rosie Perez (“Do the Right Thing,” “Pineapple Express”) wasn’t always the sassy, silver-tongued woman we’ve come to recognize. “I had such a bad speech impediment as a result of the emotional trauma I was going through in my life,” Perez says. “I couldn’t even say my name correctly. I would say, “Wosie Pewez.” But when Perez’s fifth grade teacher, Mr. Mackey, asked her to sing one of her favorite Jackson 5 songs, she discovered the impediment disappeared. “It changed me,” she says.
