headline: In Switzerland, Minimalism and Industrialism
text: WETTINGEN, Switzerland — Seen from the street, Ratibor and Nada Hadzimanovic’s home, a boxy three-floor structure with a beige plaster exterior, a half basement peeping above ground, and a pitched terra cotta tile roof, isn’t much of a looker. Neither is its location in Wettingen, a small town dotted with vineyards and farmland about 15 miles northwest of Zurich. Opposite the house are a plumbing and heating outfit, and a nondescript pink-and-gray apartment complex.

headline: Homeless Veterans Sue Over Neglected Campus
text: LOS ANGELES — It is a 387-acre campus of green fields and low-lying buildings in a prosperous neighborhood, donated to the federal government more than 100 years ago for use as a Pacific Coast home for wounded veterans. But over the last 20 years, as Los Angeles has become inundated with homeless veterans, advocates for the homeless say the campus has become a symbol of a system gone wrong: as veterans sleep on the streets, many of its buildings lie abandoned and one-third of the land has been leased for commercial use.

headline: A Cause With Every Party
text: IT was a sunny, warm Memorial Day weekend in Fire Island Pines, and Josh Wood sat in his seaside garden, laptop open and phone to his ear. A fountain burbled in the ornamental pond. The roses were in bloom. Led Zeppelin played over outdoor speakers.

headline: How Apple Can Make Money From Higher-Quality Songs
text: Whenever Apple introduces a new mobile device, I go through an anxious ritual: trying to decide how much memory I need in the device.

headline: You Can Also Lead a Horse to Nirvana
text: LAST Sunday evening, Buck Brannaman strolled the High Line, two stories above the streets of Manhattan and hundreds of miles from his native habitat, the ranch country where he runs clinics in enlightened horsemanship. The documentary “Buck,” which won a Sundance audience award this year and will open on Friday in New York and Los Angeles, details his shaman-like skills around horses and the people who ride them.

headline: Banks Defeated in Senate Vote on Debit Card Fees
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate refused Wednesday to delay new rules that would sharply cut the fees that banks can charge retailers to process debit card transactions.

headline: Activist or Terrorist, Rendered in Red, White and Green
text: WHEN Daniel McGowan moved in with his sister after college, he was so passionate about recycling that he took all the labels off her canned food. The problem was, he didn’t wait for her to open the cans. “I didn’t know if I had soup, or what kind of soup; I don’t know if there’s peas, or corn,” Lisa McGowan said in an interview. “He said, ‘I never thought of that.’ ”

headline: Shaping Energy Menus Through 2030
text: 4:42 p.m. | Updated I’m in Waterloo, Ontario, for the final two days of a summit aiming to clarify how science and technology can meaningfully improve the world’s energy menu by 2030. There’s a layered discussion underway, hosted by the Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics, involving both established analysts and researchers and younger scholars and students.

headline: New Questions Rise in Cause and Trajectory of Germany E. Coli Outbreak
text: BERLIN — As Germany’s tally of deaths increased in what has become one of the world’s most lethal infections of E. coli, new elements of confusion surfaced Wednesday with conflicting signals about whether the outbreak is abating and what caused it.

headline: A Fight Over Anne Frank’s Fallen Tree
text: AMSTERDAM — From the window in the attic of her family’s hiding place in Amsterdam, Anne Frank could see the crown of an old chestnut tree growing in a neighbor’s garden. For two years, it was her only contact with nature.

headline: How Dimon Played on Wall Street
text: In an exchange with Ben S. Bernanke of the Federal Reserve, Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, questioned whether regulation was too harsh. CNBC discusses whether this is the broad industry view.

headline: Good Boy! A Trainer’s Tony Treat
text: BROADWAY bears a distinct resemblance to a wildlife preserve these days, with its war horses and Bengal tigers jockeying for Tony Awards Sunday night (and flying spiders biding their time until next season). What better year, then, to give a special Tony to the animal trainer William Berloni, who found Little Orphan Annie her first Sandy and has since put hundreds of critters through their paces?

headline: Steeds to Spiders
text: A look at some of the hoofed and fanged creatures on Broadway this season.

headline: Video: Weiner’s Fate
text: Megan Liberman and Michael Barbaro discuss what’s ahead for Representative Anthony D. Weiner as he tries to weather the scandal from his salacious online behavior.

headline: Welcome to the Recovery
text: For unrelated reasons (textbook!) I just reread Tim Geithner’s unfortunate August 2010 op-ed Welcome to the Recovery. Even at the time, it seemed tone-deaf to both the economic and the political realities; now, of course, it looks much worse.

headline: Frank Moss of the MIT media lab; Joshua Brustein on Web photo rights; news.
text: J.D. Biersdorfer chats with Frank Moss, former director of the MIT Media Lab and author of the new book "The Sorcerers and Their Apprentices," which looks at the lab's approach to creating innovative technologies. Ever wonder who controls the images you post online? Bettina Edelstein speaks with the producer of the Times technology section, Joshua Brustein, about the murky world of photo rights on the Web. Alan Yacavone of the News Technology desk stops by to talk about Apple's planned new rollouts — the Lion version of OS X; iOs 5's new features for Apple mobile devices; and the forthcoming iCloud, with untethered syncing across devices. Other news includes reaction to the proposed AT&T and T-Mobile merger; lots of new stuff for gamers via 3E; a software update for BlackBerry PlayBooks; and a new report that says the iPad still rules in the tablet market. J.D.'s tech tip: using smart playlists to explore your own music collection in iTunes.

headline: Who Is Monzon?
text: The staff at Sagamore Farm, once owned by Alfred G. Vanderbilt and being restored by the Under Armour founder Kevin Plank, sent us these videos of Monzon’s final work before the Belmont Stakes on Saturday.

headline: Tony Picks, Courtesy of Michael Musto
text: In the week leading up to the Tony Awards on June 12, ArtsBeat is asking several celebrity theatergoers who are not Tony voters to pick their favorite shows, actors and designers in the New York Times’s interactive Tonys ballot.

headline: The Stories Behind the Work
text: Eric Wilson visited the photographer Arthur Elgort in his SoHo studio, where the two spoke about some of the most memorable photographs Mr. Elgort has taken over his 42-year career.

headline: A Visit With Arthur Elgort
text: One of the more poignant moments during the fashion awards on Monday night happened when the Council of Fashion Designers of America honored the photographer Arthur Elgort, who has been creating images for Condé Nast magazines for over 42 years. Mr. Elgort suffered a stroke last year, but he has recovered considerably and is back at work.

headline: Fill-In | The Science of Hamburgers
text: Today’s special fill-in is based on a passage from a Science Times article about attempts to use technology and science to make tastier burgers. Can you fill in the 18 missing words?

headline: For Mets, Collegiality Is Part of Closing
text: Before a recent game at Minute Maid Park in Houston, Jason Isringhausen and Francisco Rodriguez walked out of the clubhouse together toward the field. In the hallway, Isringhausen held open a door to allow his teammate to pass through first.

headline: Lock Up Your Safes
text: Having a nice strong safe with sturdy locks is not much help if someone can just wheel the whole thing out the door of your apartment. Such a brazen act of criminality was performed, and captured on video, in a building in Elmhurst, Queens, recently.

headline: The New Bohemians: Casting Announced for ‘Rent’ Revival
text: The names Idina Menzel, Anthony Rapp, Taye Diggs, Wilson Jermaine Heredia, Jesse L. Martin, Adam Pascal, and Daphne Rubin-Vega didn’t mean much in the theater world until they became stars in the 1996 musical “Rent,” a Pulitzer Prize-winning hit Off Broadway that quickly transferred to Broadway and won the Tony Award for best musical.

headline: Envelope, Please, for the Great Parking Facilities of 2011
text: There is no shortage of field guides to the greatest driving roads in the United States, where switchbacks, curves and corkscrews test the mettle of wannabe Earnhardts. High-riding trail raiders can reference a wealth of catalogs and online forums for remote routes guaranteed to crack teeth and shred oil pans.

headline: Remembering Waitz, a Champion and Companion
text: Jack Waitz keeps learning about his wife, Grete Waitz, since she died April 19 at the age of 57. People tell him about their one meeting, stories that glow with kindness and generosity.

headline: Before the Mosquitoes Come
text: Natalie Boelman, an ecosystem ecologist at the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory at Columbia University, writes from the North Slope of Alaska, where she is studying the effects of climate change on the interactions among plants, insects and migratory songbirds.

headline: U.S. Is Falling Behind in the Business of ‘Green’
text: LEICESTER, England — The Mark Group started hunting for a new untapped market when it realized that its core business — insulating old homes using innovative technology — would drop off in coming years. Based in this rust-belt city, the company had grown rapidly over the last decade largely because of generous and mandatory government subsidies for energy conservation that impelled the British to treat their homes.

headline: S.E.C. Stops Would-Be Buyers of Pabst Beer
text: An effort to buy the maker of the oft-ironically enjoyed Pabst Blue Ribbon beer has fizzed out, after the Securities and Exchange Commission became involved.

headline: In 2nd Week, Lady Gaga’s Sales Plummet, but She’s Still No. 1
text: In Week 2 Lady Gaga’s album sales have come down to earth. But she’s still No. 1.

headline: Mark Teixeira Returns to Yankees’ Lineup
text: The day after a fastball by Jon Lester drilled him in the knee with such force that he left the game, Mark Teixeira was in the Yankees’ lineup, batting third and playing first against the Red Sox.

headline: Téa Obreht Wins Orange Prize for Fiction
text: Téa Obreht won the Orange Prize for Fiction on Wednesday for her debut novel, “The Tiger’s Wife,” making her at 25 the youngest person to win the award. The winner, chosen by a panel of five judges, was announced in London. The award is given annually for the best novel written in English by a woman and comes with a prize of about $49,000.

headline: The Bruins Keep Their Lucky Jacket in Horton’s Stall
text: BOSTON — A powerful talismanic artifact has been hanging in Nathan Horton’s stall in the Boston dressing room for several days: a 1980s vintage shiny black and yellow Bruins jacket. What first seemed to be a joke now has become a symbol of the Bruins’ feelings for themselves as a team and for Horton in particular.

headline: F.D.A. Issues Safety Alert on Zocor
text: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday announced new safety restrictions on high-dose simvastatin, also known as Zocor, a cholesterol-lowering drug taken by an estimated 2.1 million Americans.

headline: Euro Zone | Summer in Stockholm
text: If Northern Europe were pressed to name its cultural capital, it very well might be Stockholm. Built on 14 islands, the Swedish city buzzes with a robust dining scene, high-end design, smart new hotels and dozens of museums. And in the summer, Stockholm hosts a clutch of food and music festivals, among them a jazz festival, June 17-19, and the Culture Festival, Aug. 16-21, when the city’s plazas and parks fill up with spectators for some 500 musical acts, readings and comedy shows.

headline: The Resort Shows: Artists and Rebels
text: Reed Krakoff used the term “warm minimalism” to describe the changes — actually, improvements — offered in his resort line. Mr. Krakoff, trying to establish a look with his still-new signature label, makes progress with a more feminine-looking bunch of clothes that plays on rounded edges, easy volumes and intense colors offset by fleshy beige tones. Those colors — ultraviolet blue and green, coral and cinnamon — are his strength. They’re sharp and specific, with a modern art reference that he likes. See a green panel on a sleeveless wrap dress in an abstract blue python print, and you think, as intended, Rothko. It’s not all highfalutin: Mr. Krakoff also showed a well-done blazer in beige lightweight wool with a double lapel, a nice way to suggest layering. He paired the jacket with soft red trousers. Also strong were a leather shift, pounded thin like a cutlet, and an electric blue python skirt with pleating at one side.

headline: Hour by Hour, a Measure of Economic Stress
text: Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, highlighted a relatively obscure measure of economic health, “aggregate hours of production workers,” to make the important point that our economy is not very healthy at all.

headline: A Partnership Forged by a Mutual Love of Music
text: David Parker and Jeffrey Kazin are not romantically involved — but there are all kinds of love affairs. “Misters and Sisters,” which had a short run at Joe’s Pub last week, is Mr. Parker’s latest piece on that postage-stamp stage, and it’s an ode to the relationship between the two men, who have worked together for 21 years.

headline: F.A.O. Sees Stubbornly High Food Prices
text: The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations is out with a new report this week on the world food outlook. The general picture is consistent with the themes I outlined in my recent piece on the food supply.

headline: McDonald’s to Serve Sustainable Fish in Europe
text: PARIS — McDonald’s, the world’s biggest fast-food company, said Wednesday that it had reached a deal under which a nonprofit organization would certify as sustainable the catch used for each of the 100 million fish sandwiches the chain sells in Europe every year.

headline: Recovering From the Red Flood
text: Eight months ago, a containment reservoir in western Hungary collapsed, releasing a million cubic meters of highly corrosive red mud that covered more than 2,500 acres.

headline: TimesCast | June 8, 2011
text: Syrian refugees cross into Turkey to escape escalating violence; Saudi Arabia's rulers use money to buy stability; and the Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof on continuing repression in Bahrain.

headline: Live Tweeting a Home Birth
text: Speaking of Twitter, this is another, er, unusual, use of the new tool. The British photographer Mary Wycherley gave birth at home Monday morning, and she and her husband, Martin Carr, live tweeted the event to thousands. It all happened during morning rush hour in England, and a cheer reportedly went up on at least one commuter train when the couple announced their daughter, Sailor Carr, arrived.

headline: The Problem With Obama’s Re-Election Pitch
text: As you might have seen, my colleagues Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg did a nice job of previewing President Obama’s re-election campaign in a front page article on Sunday. One line in particular jumped out at me: “With their hopes dashed of substantial improvement in unemployment anytime soon, aides indicated that the theme was likely to be less ‘morning in America’ and more ‘don’t change horses in midstream.’”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Yemen, India and Washington.

headline: Yankees Put Chamberlain on D.L. With Elbow Injury
text: On Tuesday, Manager Joe Girardi watched Mark Teixeira writhe in such pain after being struck by a pitch that he thought Teixeira broke his right kneecap. On Wednesday, Teixeira seemed one of the healthier players in the Yankees’ clubhouse.

headline: Does This Swimsuit Make Me Look Fat?
text: IN its Platonic ideal, a bathing suit removes you momentarily from yourself, and perhaps unleashes heretofore dormant aspects of your personality. Wriggle into a great-looking suit that’s black and snug and tailored, and suddenly you’re ready for an underwater cocktail party; rock a pair of floral Hawaiian board shorts and suddenly you’re convinced that the only way to spell “dude” is with two o’s.

headline: Nice Jacket, but It Can’t Do My Taxes
text: CLOTHES, much like everything else in modern life, are into multitasking.

headline: 2,500 Firefighters Struggle to Restrain Arizona Blaze
text: SPRINGERVILLE, Ariz. — The massive wildfire that continued its surge Wednesday through eastern Arizona was sending burning embers miles downwind, igniting dozens of smaller fires that required the urgent attention of firefighters and raising the prospect of the fire greatly extending its 11-day run, the authorities said.

headline: Zen Farm
text: Zen Farm

headline: The Latest From Steve Jobs: iSpaceship
text: It’s well known that Steven P. Jobs, the chief executive of Apple, has had a hand in the design of just about everything Apple makes, including the Macs, MacBooks, iMacs, iPods, iTunes, iPhones, iPads and, now, the iCloud.

headline: ‘India’
text: 1: ACCELERATED HISTORY

headline: An Intimate Biography of Millions
text: The critic Dwight Macdonald liked to lower the boom on academic books, especially biographies, that he called “lumbering dinosaurs with brains the size of a teacup.” Patrick French’s recent biography of V. S. Naipaul, “The World Is What It Is” (2008), was the opposite kind of book. It moved with feline grace and instinctual wit. It mapped its subject’s plus-size talent and ego like an MRI scan.

headline: Toys for the Father Who’s Not Too Grown Up
text: AS a father of 19 years, I can say with some degree of authority that some Father’s Day gifts have been better than others. There was that year I was blindfolded and led to the garage to find a large box containing an unassembled lawn mower. It was a nice gift, but it made me feel that I should mow the lawn.

headline: Tunisia Postpones Election, Possibly Aiding New Parties
text: CAIRO — The interim Tunisian government on Wednesday postponed the first election since the ouster in January of the former dictator Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, citing technical problems for the delay but also inevitably reshuffling Tunisian political dynamics.

headline: Smartphone Games Worth Downloading
text: Seth Schiesel discusses six video games designed for cellphones.

headline: Revenge as a Dish Served in Mason Jars
text: A bad breakup inspires an odyssey into the realms of exotic spiritualism — or at least highly decorative forms of revenge — in Tanya Saracho’s play “Enfrascada,” the first production in the Clubbed Thumb theater company’s annual Summerworks festival at Here Arts Center. The first significant salvo in what has become an exhausting gantlet of June-to-September festivals in New York, the Summerworks series has previously presented early work by talented writers including Sarah Ruhl, Gina Gionfriddo and Adam Bock.

headline: With Smartphone Games, Downtime Becomes a Pastime
text: All right, fess up, people. Have you never played a game on your cellphone? Really? I’m here to let you know you can come out of the closet now.

headline: Reader Q. and A.: In India, Dynamism Wrestles With Dysfunction
text: India, with one-sixth of all humanity, is expected to become the world’s fastest-growing economy as soon as next year thanks to aggressive, free-wheeling businesses that in many cases are becoming the behemoths that state-run goliaths are in China.

headline: Susan Stroman Signs On to Direct Stage Musical of Tim Burton’s ‘Big Fish’
text: Susan Stroman, the Tony Award-winning director and choreographer (“The Producers”) who was nominated for both jobs on “The Scottsboro Boys” in this Sunday’s Tonys competition, has her next Broadway project: A musical adaptation of the film and novel “Big Fish,” aiming to open in spring 2012, the producers announced on Wednesday.

headline: Winning Games for Tablets
text: Some tablet games that Seth Schiesel found most enjoyable.

headline: Games on Tablets: Lean Back, Commence Tapping
text: Tablets are just great for gaming. Everything that modern cellphones bring to games — touch screens, tilt sensitivity and of course constant Internet access — the tablets do better. The screens are finer and larger and the games are more immersive. And you can use a tablet in ways and places that rarely work for even the smallest netbooks.

headline: Just One Look | Reed Krakoff Resort Collection
text: Reed Krakoff is one to wear his knowledge of art on his sleeve. His resort collection took its cues — and also perhaps its often vibrant hues — from the likes of Mark Rothko, Helen Frankenthaler and Josef Albers.

headline: Booth for Two, Dialogue Optional
text: People with intimacy issues — which is to say most respectably neurotic New Yorkers — may need to steel themselves before a visit to “Theater for One,” in which a single actor and a single audience member are sequestered in a plush red booth in Times Square for a one-on-one performance. The experience will last no longer than a few minutes but is likely to settle somewhere in your soul for a lot longer than most of the splashy jamborees in the neighboring theaters do.

headline: Last Days, Perhaps, for Group That Sued for Poor School Districts
text: After a series of setbacks, the Campaign for Fiscal Equity, the advocacy organization whose victory in a historic lawsuit brought billions of additional dollars to poor school districts in New York State, has run out of money to sustain itself, the organization said.

headline: Affordable iPad Cases, or Not So
text: WHICH would you rather have: three iPads or an iPad case?

headline: The Defense Was Accurate; The Bidding Was Less So
text: When the Eastern States Regional was canceled for lack of a suitable location in New York, the one event that survived in the replacement, the Memorial Weekend Sectional, was the Reisinger Knockout Teams.

headline: The Green, Green Sod of Home
text: Ever since the 1994 World Cup in the United States, when organizers for the New York/New Jersey site came up with an innovative tray system at to lay grass over an artificial turf field at Giants Stadium, the idea of plopping the real stuff on top of the fake stuff as a short-term solution has gained — forgive me — traction.

headline: Using the Right Lens for the Right Photograph
text: A SWISS Army Knife is a terrific tool that is useful for a lot of tasks, but don’t try to tile a kitchen with one. Some jobs require specialized tools. And so it is with camera lenses.

headline: Cuomo Urges Broad Limits to N.Y. Public Pensions
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, joining a parade of officials from across the country who are seeking to rein in spending by limiting public employees’ pensions, proposed Wednesday to broadly limit retirement benefits for new city and state workers in New York.

headline: Campsite Discounts for Great Outdoors Month
text: Are you itching to pitch a tent beneath the stars?

headline: Weiner’s Wife Is Pregnant
text: Their marriage has become the subject of intense speculation and scrutiny amid an embarrassing online sex scandal.

headline: Club Mixes Old, New and Blue
text: From the outside the club appears to be just another shuttered and somewhat grotty East Village storefront, and the interior, with its scarred wooden floor and graffiti-daubed walls, isn’t any more impressive. Instead, it’s what happens onstage that has made Nublu’s reputation as an incubator of musical talent, with some of the most adventurous and varied offerings in the city.

headline: Update Your Car With GPS, Radar and Other Gadgets
text: TYING a big red bow around a new sports car is one way to give someone the latest in-car technologies, but for most of us that’s just a marketer’s fantasy. Fortunately, there are plenty of high-tech baubles that can be added to your own car to improve safety, convenience or both. And you don’t have to take out a new loan to get them (or give them).

headline: Despite Drop, ‘America’s Got Talent’ Still Draws a Crowd
text: Opposite Game 4 of the National Basketball Association Finals on ABC, “America’s Got Talent” saw a drop in its ratings compared to its premiere a week ago the NBC reality show still outperformed all other programming on the night excluding basketball. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 12.7 million viewers tuned in to “America’s Got Talent” at 8 p.m., down from 15.3 million who watched the two-hour premiere last week.

headline: Footnote
text: The producers of the Broadway musical “Million Dollar Quartet” announced on Tuesday that the show would transfer Off Broadway to New World Stages after it plays its final performance at the Nederlander Theater on Sunday. No opening date for the Off Broadway production was announced.

headline: Trolling Heaven and Earth for Sounds
text: As cultures blend, as art forms meld with one another and with science and other disciplines, all is convergence, and the cellist Yo-Yo Ma is somehow at the center.

headline: Debit Card Fees to Fall, but Will Consumers Benefit?
text: After weeks of back-and-forth debate and heavy lobbying by banks and retailers, the Senate voted Wednesday against delaying a cap on the swipe fees that stores must pay for the processing of debit card purchases.

headline: On Limits and Leaps
text: Tom Friedman’s column today focused on Paul Gilding’s new book, “The Great Disruption: Why the Climate Crisis Will Bring on the End of Shopping and the Birth of a New World.” The column and the cited comments from Gilding gave the impression of planetary overload, but a critical clause from Gilding was easy to miss and is worth highlighting here (my italics):

headline: Who Made California’s License Plate?
text: California has been having a lot of problems lately, but despite the budget, gas prices and the fear of earthquakes, the Golden State can still conjure romantic notions of endless summer: surfing in the Pacific, camping in Redwood, taking the archetypal road trip down a coastal highway. Driving is a large part of California’s culture, and typographically speaking, the bold red script on the state’s license plate seemingly embraces the happily casual and free-spirited notions commonly associated with the West Coast.

headline: 24 Hours in New York Sports
text: Mike Tanier's mission: to cover six major New York sports events in a span of 24 hours.

headline: Suspicion and Disunity Impede Central America’s Effort to Fight Drug Violence
text: SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador — The nations of Central America agree on one thing: They cannot by themselves combat the drug and organized crime violence that is making the region among the world’s unsafest.

headline: The Balanchine Way, Imprinted
text: On Tuesday night at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater five teenage girls from the School of American Ballet, dancing to Tchaikovsky, each extended a leg toward the audience above hip height. Then, keeping the legs high in that position, they all began to fall forward off balance toward the audience. They didn’t actually fall, of course, but, before they brought the legs down, they had transferred much of their weight in its direction. It was easy for the audience to feel the suspense involved in the moment of extension and then the audacity involved in that transfer of weight: those girls were aiming those legs straight at us.

headline: Paul McCartney to Perform at Yankee Stadium
text: Sorry, Queens, but you’ve had plenty of opportunities to feature the Cute Beatle, now it’s time to let the Bronx host him for an evening: Paul McCartney will play his first concert ever at Yankee Stadium on July 15, Live Nation Entertainment said on Wednesday. Mr. McCartney, the pop musician whose work in Wings is perennially overshadowed by his time with another popular British rock outfit, has some familiarity with New York ballparks, having served as the inaugural performer at Citi Field as in 2009, and as a surprise guest when Billy Joel closed down Shea Stadium in 2008; Mr. McCartney also played at Shea Stadium in 1965 as part of that beloved band whose name momentarily escapes us. (No, not the Rolling Stones, the other guys.) A statement from Live Nation said Mr. McCartney’s performance at Yankee Stadium “can safely be predicted to feature some nearly three hours of the world’s best loved and most known music, with hits, deep cuts and surprises spanning his unrivaled career,” including the 2008 album “Electric Arguments” that he released under the name the Fireman. With a top ticket price of $279.50 for this show, Mr. McCartney will hopefully throw in “Band on the Run” or “Let It Be,” too.

headline: Chinese Truck Driver Sentenced to Death Over Homicide
text: BEIJING — An ethnic Han truck driver who killed an ethnic Mongolian herder with his truck last month, sparking Inner Mongolia’s largest protests in 20 years, was sentenced to death on Wednesday by a court in Xilinhot, the area of Inner Mongolia where the incident occurred.

headline: Houston to Manage Knicks’ New Development League Team
text: The Knicks announced an affiliation partnership with the Erie (Pa.) Bayhawks of the N.B.A. Development League on Wednesday, with Allan Houston to serve as the team’s general manager as well as continuing his role as assistant general manger of the Knicks.

headline: Weiner’s Seat Could Be Scrambled in Redistricting
text: There is much speculation about whether Representative Anthony D. Weiner will remain in Congress or resign his seat. But there is a politically expedient solution for Democrats if they want to show him the door: Neuter his district in the redistricting process, which will require New York to lose 2 of its 29 seats in the House of Representatives.

headline: Night at the Caravanserai
text: Yo-Yo Ma led Silk Road Ensemble in a cultural blend of music and dance to open the season Tuesday night at Central Park’s Summerstage.

headline: Headphones That Fit Different Needs, and Ears
text: IN this day of cloud computing and virtualization, it’s important to remember that satisfying feeling of holding a well-built, overengineered object in your hands; to be in touch, literally, with a thing’s “thingness.”

headline: That Chloë Sevigny Look
text: Chloë Sevigny’s resort collection for Opening Ceremony, shown yesterday evening at the St. Patrick Youth Center in SoHo, exuded a nostalgic, teenage spirit — and even included pieces made in collaboration with the storied skate brand Vision Street Wear. “It’s hard to encapsulate my inspiration because there are so many different looks, but I think it’s just like, sexy girl you see walking down the street in a cool outfit,” Sevigny said. “A lot of eyelet, a lot of leather, playing with the hard and the soft, the good and bad inside of us all.” The hairstylist Thomas Dunkin, who used Sebastian Potion 9 for a “soft, natural, ’80s skater girl vibe,” spared the models’ hair from heat tools (good thing, as the center was not air-conditioned). The makeup artist Lottie Stannard applied M.A.C. Coffee Eyeliner “haphazardly” — topped off with loads of black mascara — and M.A.C. Blush Cream in Laid Back. “I’m really into a blush on the eyelid and on the high of the cheek,” Sevigny said. “The singer of Cocteau Twins used to do that — really pink eyelids. It added a little romance to the hard kind of street-edge clothes.”

headline: Hearing the Voice of the Horse Whisperer
text: Leslie Knauf is a writer, editor, marketer and horsewoman in upstate New York who has been attending the races at Saratoga for 50 years. She began riding horses at 9 and owned several thoroughbreds over the years that she rode for pleasure. She’s confident they taught her far more than she ever could teach them.

headline: A Preview of the 2011 Tony Awards
text: Charles Isherwood with a preview of the 2011 Tony awards.

headline: Artists Decorate Palazzos, and Vice Versa
text: VENICE — When it comes to dense, out-of-control concentrations of contemporary art, there is nothing like the Venice Biennale. With its big central exhibition, its ever-rising number of national pavilions and the scores of collateral shows organized in museums, galleries and palazzos all over the city, the Biennale never stops. It is a cornucopia of recent artistic endeavor, endlessly amplified by Venice itself, which remains one of the most culturally layered, artful and art-filled places on earth.

headline: 24 Hours in Sports: A Yankees Game, Five Other Events, One Reporter
text: Can one reporter cover six major New York area sporting events in 24 hours and not lose his mind?

headline: Shopping Snapshots for June 9
text: Openings by Kiehl’s and Bonpoint, and a sample sale at Opening Ceremony.

headline: Art & Design Books
text: Images from new art and design books, reviewed by Steven Heller.

headline: Visuals
text: Before the personal computer, one way to pick out graphic designers in a crowd was from the pieces of colored adhesive film, like Cello-tak or Rubylith, stuck to their clothes. Most of the designers I knew back then yearned to rid themselves of messy cutting and pasting. So in 1984, when the Macintosh was introduced and became a design tool, they enthusiastically embraced desktop-computer design. Today, though, many designers are proud to engage in dirty handwork. Young and old designers alike are employing revered methods of making art and design by hand, especially in silk-screen print-making. Having clothes stained with ink and paint is now a status symbol.

headline: A Cornucopia of Contemporary Art
text: When it comes to dense, out-of-control concentrations of contemporary art, there is nothing like the Venice Biennale. The 54th edition will run through Nov. 27.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Frozen, and Actors Are Relieved
text: It’s a major moment in the life of any new Broadway show, but it’s hard to imagine another production savoring the moment as much as “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark.”

headline: ‘On the Media’: Comics Edition
text: Remember that great episode of NPR’s “On the Media” about the Goldilocks number? Brooke Gladstone ruthlessly disassembled a claim by the NBC reporter Chris Hansen, on a “To Catch a Predator” episode of “Dateline,” that at any given moment, 50,000 child predators are online, skeevily perving out on your child.

headline: Comics Roundup
text: Images from six new comics collections and graphic novels, reviewed by Douglas Wolk.

headline: Comics
text: Gilbert Hernandez is one of the great craftsmen of modern comics, the writer and artist of elegant, fiery, carefully controlled graphic novels like “Palomar” and “Luba.” Over the past few years, though, he’s been doing his best to break away from (or at least expand on) that highbrow reputation with a series of short, pungent thrillers whose conceit is that they’re adapted from B movies starring one of his recurring characters: the tragic, top-heavy bombshell Fritz Martinez.

headline: Tom McNeal’s Southern California Home
text: The writer’s house is the architectural equivalent of a carefully crafted novel: well constructed, inviting, with a few surprise twists.

headline: An Imagination With Built-Ins
text: FALLBROOK, Calif.

headline: Poll: Most Say Palin Shouldn’t Run for President
text: As Sarah Palin continues to ponder a run for the 2012 Republican presidential nomination, a new poll finds that most Americans, including a majority of Republicans and half of Tea Party supporters, do not think she should run.

headline: Bernanke-san Watch
text: An interesting juxtaposition: Bill Gross defending his bet on rising rates, which isn’t looking too good right now:

headline: Decorating the Farm
text: At a farm outside Pittsburgh, iron chairs wear mink coats, candelabras sprout from picnic tables and crystals hang from the trees.

headline: The King of the Trash Finder’s Ball
text: A trash picker’s life can be an ignoble, even solitary one. It is rare that one woman says to another, “Lunch, and then a bit of Dumpster diving?” And many people remain shy about acknowledging that the source of that beautiful antique dining table was the town dump.

headline: Flash Sales Reach the Design World
text: There’s a new player in the world of online flash sales: Fab.com, a site with a focus on modern design that goes live today. The first week’s offerings include the Plumen light bulb, posters by Milton Glaser and items from Kid Robot, FontanaArte, Iittala and Eva Zeisel. (The Syrup collection by Objeti, pictured, will go on sale later in the month.)

headline: Moths and Mice: It’s You or Them
text: FIFTEEN years ago the crawl space of my previous home became the site of a turf war between skunks and rats. When the stench subsided, huge flies sprang from the rat carcasses and into the house.

headline: Ann Gish, Now Making Her Bed in New York
text: Ann Gish’s first New York store opens in the Flatiron district today, in a 4,000-square-foot space on 20th Street.

headline: Colonial Revival Décor on Display
text: A Head by a Nose, the designers James Boyd and Ann Reath’s take on Colonial American wallpaper, pictured, features the silhouettes of well-known people like Charles de Gaulle, Nefertiti and Alfred Hitchcock. The wallcovering, created in 2009, is part of “The American Style: Colonial Revival and the Modern Metropolis,” an exhibition that opens on Tuesday at the Museum of the City of New York.

headline: A New Bar, With a Nod to Whitman
text: The Vault at Pfaff’s, a new subterranean lounge in NoHo, is named after Charles Pfaff, the proprietor of a popular bohemian gathering place in the area 150 years ago. “Walt Whitman was said to be drinking and hanging out there,” said the interior designer Mark Zeff, who mined inspiration from the past for his design of the space. “He alluded to the place in one of his pieces.”

headline: Ice Cube Trays
text: VISIT any of the “proper” cocktail bars in New York and it is clear that the ice in one’s drink has become almost as important as the drink itself. The once humble cube of frozen water is now mentioned in terms usually associated with the other “ice” (cut, clarity and size) and is made into balls, cylindrical columns and squares of all sizes, sometimes even hand-carved.

headline: Sales at Holly Hunt, Christofle and Others
text: Christofle is offering 15 percent off all current collections of flatware, hollowware and jewelry, through Saturday (the Vertigo Champagne Cooler, pictured, usually $780, is $663); 680 Madison Avenue (62nd Street), (212) 308-9390, christofle.com.

headline: The Decorated Shed
text: BULGER, Pa.

headline: Shopping for Ice Cube Trays With Eben Freeman
text: The director of bar operations and innovation for Altamarea Group searched for trays for making good-looking ice at home.

headline: Two Rebel Figures, One Traditional Painting
text: ROME — One story holds that it was only when they co-signed the canvas they had just painted together on a fall day in 1966 that Franco Angeli discovered the identity of his fellow artist: Jack Kerouac.

headline: Obama Hails Auburn Football Team
text: Football players from Auburn University‘s N.C.A.A. championship team met President Obama at the White House on Wednesday afternoon.

headline: TimesCast | Inside Saudi Arabia
text: June 8, 2011 - A look at why the Arab spring has not sparked a mass movement inside Saudi Arabia.

headline: Battle for Libya | June 8, 2011
text: The Libyan government gave a guided tour of the areas they said were hit by NATO airstrikes on Tuesday.

headline: Eisman to Leave FrontPoint Partners
text: Steve Eisman, the colorful hedge fund manager who made a fortune betting against the subprime mortgage market, is leaving FrontPoint Partners, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: Homes for $770,000
text: A contemporary in Charlotte, N.C., a row house in Alexandria, Va. and a pueblo-style house in Santa Fe, N.M.

headline: What You Get for ... $770,000
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C.

headline: Surfer Died of Heart Attack and Drugs
text: Andy Irons, a three-time world surfing champion from Hawaii, who died at 32 in a hotel room last November, succumbed to a combination of a heart attack and drugs in his system, according to an autopsy report.

headline: Fed Says Economy Is Growing, but at Uneven Pace
text: Economic activity in the United States continued to grow in April and May, but higher food and energy prices, severe weather conditions and supply disruptions caused by the earthquake and tsunami in Japan put pressure on consumers, according to a survey by the Federal Reserve released on Wednesday.

headline: New Questions as Sony Is Hacked Again
text: Thursday, June 9 | Updated Added comment from Sony.

headline: Economy Sends Japanese to Fukushima for Jobs
text: IWAKI-YUMOTO, Japan — Just after 6 a.m. in this still sleepy hot spring town, bleary-eyed workers emerged from their inns, ready to board buses to return to their daily battle to contain the crisis at the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant.

headline: UFC Looking to Buy Part of G4 Channel
text: Comcast is in talks to sell a controlling interest in the G4 cable channel to the Ultimate Fighting Championship.

headline: Strine Nominated for Top Job at Delaware Chancery Court
text: Gov. Jack Markell of Delaware nominated Leo E. Strine Jr., a veteran judge of Delaware’s Court of Chancery, to become its chancellor on Wednesday.

headline: Fervor for Tech I.P.O.’s Doesn’t Reach Other Sectors
text: Joe Raedle/Getty ImagesSpirit Airlines cut the size of its offering by 35 percent.

headline: Former Mexican Mayor is Charged with Weapons Violations
text: MEXICO CITY — Jorge Hank Rhon is a billionaire betting magnate who keeps a private zoo of exotic animals. A former mayor of Tijuana from a powerful political family, Mr. Hank Rhon has been the subject of rumors, never proved, about links to organized crime for almost a quarter century.

headline: Fountain Called ‘Jewel’ of a Connecticut Waterfront Becomes a Health Concern
text: NEW LONDON, Conn. — It was envisioned as a striking centerpiece of this city’s revitalized waterfront, an eight-foot-high blackened sculpture of an upright whale’s tail from which water gushes in a gentle waterfall that allows children to frolic underneath.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Treasured Pissarro Print Turns Into Costly Headache
text: Sharyl Davis thought she was in luck 25 years ago when she bought a charming market scene by the Impressionist Camille Pissarro from a San Antonio art gallery for $8,500. But since 2003, when she took the print to Sotheby’s to sell, her luck has been running the other way.

headline: When the Latin and Jazz Converge
text: Perhaps you’ve heard that Latin jazz has been in a state of uproar recently. Since the announced elimination in April of its category from the Grammy Awards, some of the genre’s most prominent artists have united in protest, charging the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, which administers the Grammys, with a cultural affront. (Some 30 other categories also got the ax, but the Native American, Cajun and Hawaiian constituencies have been relatively quiet.)

headline: For Paddy O’Prado, a Time to Heal
text: Liz O’Connell is a professional horsewoman who just finished foaling season and is looking for new adventures. She is a member of the New York State Task Force on Retired Race Horses and spends too much time rehoming off-the-track thoroughbreds.

headline: AIDS Prevention
text: To the Editor:

headline: Evoking ’50s Glamour, Through Teasing Taunts
text: Ah, Paree! As the statuesque French chanteuse Yanna Avis sang Cole Porter’s great ode to the City of Light, “You Don’t Know Paree,” on a recent evening, a composite view of the city as imagined by Balzac, Zola and of course, Porter himself, flickered in my imagination. “Until you’ve lived a lot, and loved a lot, and lost a lot, you don’t know Paree,” go lyrics that Ms. Avis, a soigné international beauty, sang with a wry understanding.

headline: New Move to Condemn Syria in U.N.
text: UNITED NATIONS — Britain and France circulated a revised draft resolution at the United Nations Security Council on Wednesday that would condemn the Syrian government for using force against its own civilians, but would scrupulously avoid a call for military action or any sanctions against the Syrian government.

headline: More Trade and More Aid
text: A FEUD over trade has erupted in Washington, and American workers are caught in the middle. Congressional Republicans (and some Democrats) are threatening to hold up approval of free-trade agreements with South Korea, Colombia and Panama if President Obama keeps insisting on renewing expanded benefits under Trade Adjustment Assistance, the main aid program for American workers harmed by foreign trade.

headline: Ending Tape-Delayed Games
text: The pledge offered by NBC on Tuesday was that in 2014 it will carry the Olympics live.

headline: Scatological Mockery of Chinese Official Brings Swift Penalty
text: BEIJING — Apparently dismayed by the considerable political power of Bo Xilai, the fast-rising Communist Party leader in the south-central Chinese city of Chongqing, Fang Hong went online in April to express his views about Mr. Bo’s regard for the rule of law — comparing it, in a stanza of crude verse, to excrement.

headline: Genaro Hernandez, Twice a World Champion, Dies at 45
text: Genaro Hernandez, a prizefighter nicknamed Chicanito — roughly translated as Little Mexican — who was twice the world super featherweight champion, died Tuesday at his home in Mission Viejo, Calif. He was 45.

headline: Pfizer Suspends Sales of Chicken Drug With Arsenic
text: WASHINGTON — Farmers have for decades fed chickens an arsenic-containing drug that promotes growth, but after a government study found trace amounts of this poisonous carcinogen in chickens, its maker will suspend its sales.

headline: Order Sushi Like a Native, and Know What You’re Eating
text: Want to take someone down a notch? Take them to a sushi bar and ask them to order. Even sushi fans face a moment of uncertainty when a server who is clearly fluent in Japanese addresses the table. Novices have it even worse.

headline: Low Cost and Hi-Fi: Building a Player
text: Back when my music was on vinyl or CD, I had a stereo in the living room where my music-loving friends would gather to listen, chat and argue. But now that I, like most of the world, buy digital downloads, my music resides on my main computer. So when my friends come by, we end up awkwardly crowded around the computer in my office, clicking on songs. This is not gracious entertaining.

headline: Year After a Drowning, New York Schools Chief Tightens Rules for Field Trips
text: A year after a 12-year-old girl from a Harlem public school drowned on a class trip to a Long Island beach, the New York City schools chancellor, Dennis M. Walcott, signed an emergency order on Wednesday toughening regulations for field trips and strengthening guidelines for swimming outings.

headline: Nicholas D. Kristof and Bahrain
text: The Op-Ed Columnist Nicholas D. Kristof focuses on Bahrain's repression of the democracy movement.

headline: For Edwards’s Adult Daughter, a Recurring Role: Family Glue
text: In a display of loyalty that surprised many outsiders, Cate Edwards walked into a North Carolina federal courthouse last week with her father, John Edwards, the former senator and presidential candidate who had cheated on her mother and shattered his career and their family.

headline: Collins Remains Reyes’s Big Booster
text: MILWAUKEE — With every game Jose Reyes plays, and every hit and run he records, he solidifies his case for a whopping contract in free agency, if not a most valuable player award.

headline: Release My Friend!
text: Dear King Hamad of Bahrain,

headline: Golfer Includes a Dose of Rock in His Approach
text: CLEVELAND — There were two Hunter Mahans on display at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame this week. The first one sat on an auditorium stage talking to a rapt group of children from the local First Tee youth development program. He wore his work clothes: Under Armour golf togs and shoes, and trademark white-framed Sundog shades balanced on a flat-brimmed Ping cap.

headline: In Saudi Arabia, Royal Funds Buy Peace for Now
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — As one nation after another has battled uprisings across the Arab world, the one major country spared is also its richest — Saudi Arabia, where a fresh infusion of money has so far bought order.

headline: Sex Assaults Underreported, Inquiry Into V.A. Concludes
text: WASHINGTON — Veterans Affairs facilities that provide mental health treatment failed to properly report many sexual assaults from 2007 to 2010, according to an investigation by the Government Accountability Office.

headline: Bank Said No? Hedge Funds Fill a Void in Lending
text: Hedge fund managers have been called plenty of names.

headline: Yemen’s Opposition Aims to Strip President of Power
text: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — Yemeni opposition leaders and protesters intensified their demands on Wednesday for the creation of a presidential council that would take power from the country’s president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, who is recovering in Saudi Arabia from wounds sustained in an attack on his palace mosque last week.

headline: For Stars, Fans and Paparazzi, Court’s the Spot
text: The scene outside the courthouse in Lower Manhattan on Wednesday was familiar, as a central figure, surrounded by a flock of photographers, lumbered toward the building’s entrance.

headline: Whispers Return for James as He Falters at the Finish
text: DALLAS — The question provoked a smile, and the smile provoked the click-click-clicking of about two dozen camera shutters, flashes popping in every corner of LeBron James’s peripheral vision. He chuckled softly.

headline: Judges Weigh Limits of Health Law’s Powers
text: ATLANTA — In perhaps the weightiest of the dozens of challenges to the Obama health care law, a panel of appellate judges grappled Wednesday with the essential quandary of the case: if the federal government can require Americans to buy medical insurance, what constitutional limit would prevent it from mandating all manner of purchases and activities?

headline: The First Computer Musician
text: If the difference between 1911 and 2011 is electricity and computation, then Max Mathews is one of the five most important musicians of the 20th Century. – Miller Puckette

headline: A Russian A.T.M. With an Ear for the Truth
text: MOSCOW — Russia’s biggest retail bank is testing a machine that the old K.G.B. might have loved, an A.T.M. with a built-in lie detector intended to prevent consumer credit fraud.

headline: U.S. Is Intensifying a Secret Campaign of Yemen Airstrikes
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has intensified the American covert war in Yemen, exploiting a growing power vacuum in the country to strike at militant suspects with armed drones and fighter jets, according to American officials.

headline: ‘To Have a Revolver’
text: Elizabeth City County, Va., June 9, 1861

headline: A Conversation About Scandal Turns a Tad Scandalous
text: Former Mayor Edward I. Koch asked Nocturnalist a question so salty that had we been less concerned about keeping our job, we might have exacted Zsa Zsa Gabor-style retribution on his cheek.

headline: Gang of Six, Minus One, Finds Cuts
text: A bipartisan group of senators working on a proposal to rein in the national debt has identified more than $4.7 trillion in deficit reductions over a decade, more than the separate proposals put forth by President Obama or House Republicans. The two leaders of the so-called Gang of Six said the savings could grow to $6 trillion if the economy improved.

headline: Partnership to Further Global Quest by N.Y.U.
text: New York University, well on its way to becoming the first truly global university, is starting a new partnership with the University of the People, a unusual nonprofit online school offering free classes to students around the world.

headline: Victory Cures All That Ails Nowitzki and the Mavericks
text: DALLAS — Dirk Nowitzki’s sniffles and fever were essentially gone Wednesday, after a long shower, soup, tea, some food and a good night’s sleep — rest made easier by the Dallas Mavericks’ 86-83 victory over the Miami Heat.

headline: When Culture, Power and Sex Collide
text: How cultural attitudes toward sex, in France or anywhere else, can distort our perceptions of sexual violence.

headline: My Bad: A Political Medley
text: After a week of sometimes indignant public denials and insistence that he was the victim of an Internet hacker, a weeping and stammering ... [Representative Anthony D. Weiner] acknowledged at a news conference that he had sent the photo of himself in his underwear to ... a college student in Seattle.

headline: House Democrats Step Up Calls for Weiner to Quit
text: WASHINGTON — House Democratic leaders began an orchestrated effort on Wednesday to force Representative Anthony D. Weiner of New York to resign his seat, saying his sexually explicit Internet messages and subsequent lies about them were making him, and the party, the subject of ridicule.

headline: Talk Builds on Challengers and a District Vulnerable to Elimination
text: Representative Anthony D. Weiner said he had no plans to resign from Congress, but many others are now hoping to show him the door.

headline: Syrians Flee Violence
text: June 8, 2011 - Syrian refugees are escaping across the Turkish border to run from escalating violence.

headline: Comcast Said to Be in Talks Over G4 Cable Channel
text: Comcast is in talks to sell a controlling interest in the G4 cable channel to the Ultimate Fighting Championship.

headline: Syrians Flee to Turkey, Telling of Gunmen Attacking Protesters
text: GUVECCI, Turkey — Since violent clashes broke out in a northern Syrian town close to this border last weekend at least 140 Syrians have fled into Turkey, some bearing tales of black-clad gunmen opening fire on protesters without warning. Many other Syrians, camped out in scrubby fields within sight of the Turkish border, are ready to follow them at the first sign that security forces are pursuing them, those who have crossed say.

headline: Judge to Determine if RICO Act Can Be Used by Madoff Trustee
text: Judge Jed S. Rakoff of United States District Court in New York has agreed to decide whether the trustee liquidating Bernard L. Madoff’s firm could use United States racketeering law to sue UniCredit of Italy with other banks for $59 billion.

headline: Too Radical a Debt Plan From Greece
text: LONDON — In March, just as it was becoming clear that Greece might have to ask Europe for more money to prop up its failing economy, Prime Minister George A. Papandreou seriously considered a radical plan intended to resolve his country’s debt crisis once and for all.

headline: Internet Piracy and How to Stop It
text: Online piracy is a huge business. A recent study found that Web sites offering pirated digital content or counterfeit goods, like illicit movie downloads or bootleg software, record 53 billion hits per year. That robs the industries that create and sell intellectual products of hundreds of billions of dollars.

headline: I.R.S. Ends Exemptions For 275,000 Nonprofits
text: The I.R.S. announced on Wednesday that it had revoked the tax exemptions of 275,000 nonprofit organizations after they did not meet legal requirements to file annual tax forms.

headline: BP Is Resuming Oil Exploration, Chief Says
text: LONDON — BP said Wednesday that it would focus on oil exploration outside Russia, in the wake of its collapsed deal with the Russian oil company Rosneft.

headline: Hot Enough to Exasperate, Since It’s Technically Spring
text: From the moment George Zoulis woke up on Wednesday, sweat sticking between him and his bedspread, he knew he was in for a long day.

headline: Aide’s Quitting Casts Doubt on Brazil’s New President
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The resignation of the top adviser to President Dilma Rousseff under scandal-clouded circumstances has called into question the strength of her government and her own political judgment just six months after she took over.

headline: Sifting Syrian Fact From Syrian Fiction
text: Updated | Thursday | 8:10 a.m. This post has been revised, below, to add more details about the mystery surrounding the author of a widely read blog, A Gay Girl in Damascus.

headline: A Star Search, With Bing’s Help
text: A NEW reality competition series that will search for someone to join the cast of the hit show “Glee” is teaming up with a brand that, appropriately enough, helps with searches.

headline: After a Misstep, Smooth Going on the Ice
text: Wade Corbett, a certified rink rat, likes his water frozen and his skate blades sharp. As director of the skating school at Sky Rink at Chelsea Piers, Mr. Corbett, 64, coordinates lesson programs for aspiring skaters from “age 3 until death,” his way of saying that, with the proper instruction, anyone can learn to skate. He laced up his first skates at 25 at the original Sky Rink in Midtown. He lives on the Upper West Side with his “significant others,” two cats.

headline: General Counsel of News Corp. Resigns in Wake of Settlement
text: The general counsel for News Corporation, Lawrence A. Jacobs, is leaving “to pursue new opportunities,” the company said Wednesday.

headline: Housing for the Wounded
text: The federal government should not have to be sued into giving veterans with mental illnesses and brain injuries the care they need so they don’t end up living in the street. But it has come to that.

headline: Thursday: Do as Dürer Did
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Solvers frequently comment on a constructor’s use of the “rare” letters seen in crossword puzzles, particularly J, Q, X and Z. In fact, this usage has even been given a nickname. A puzzle with a plethora of these letters is described as “Scrabbly.” I have to confess that I enjoy a Scrabbly puzzle as much as the next person, although I am in the camp that believes that you shouldn’t endanger a perfectly good theme or sector just to get those letters into the grid.

headline: Shadowing the Reclusive Painter of Light
text: Trackers of the artist Edward Hopper tirelessly pursue the true settings of his city tableaux, so tinged with Gotham loneliness. Was the night-shrouded “Drug Store” modeled from the Waverly Place shop in Greenwich Village currently occupied by a corner bookstore? The artist offered them little help. “What I wanted to do was to paint sunlight on the side of a house,” was his typically terse clue about his work.

headline: Special Parking Rules
text: In New York City, because of Shavuot, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended on Thursday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Mortgage Market Must Be Balanced
text: Regulators and financiers could be focused on the wrong mortgage market. They are right that healthy American home lending hinges on the private sector’s ability to finance all or most of it, rather than relying on government-run Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac or their equivalents. But architects of the postcrisis home loan market may be assuming it needs to be larger than it really does. It could be scarcely half as big as the current $10.5 trillion and therefore much easier to finance.

headline: Citizens United’s Outrageous Offspring
text: Judge James Cacheris gave the impression last week that he was considering putting right what he got wrong when he ruled in May that corporations are free to make direct donations to federal candidates. That first judgment directly contravened last year’s Citizens United case and the Supreme Court’s earlier decision in Federal Election Commission v. Beaumont, which upholds a ban on corporate donations to candidates.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: June 8, 2011

headline: Egypt and Hamas Reach Accord on Rafah Crossing
text: After days of acrimony between Hamas and Egypt over limitations on who could pass through the Rafah border crossing between Gaza and Egypt, Hamas said Egypt had agreed to allow 550 people a day to leave Gaza and to lengthen the operating hours of the crossing. The crossing was shut for much of the past four years after Israel, with Egyptian cooperation, closed it to pressure Hamas, which rules Gaza. Hamas said differences remained, chiefly concerning blacklists of Gazans who were forbidden to travel during Hosni Mubarak’s rule.

headline: Iraq: 4 From Movement Are Released From Jail
text: Four young leaders of Iraq’s struggling government-reform movement were released from jail after being held for 12 days without formal charges. At a news conference on Wednesday, a day after their release, the men said they had been interrogated by officers who asked questions about possible ties between the protest movement and Al Qaeda or the outlawed Baath Party. Ultimately, security officials accused the men of carrying fake identification cards — a charge all of them denied. It is unclear whether officials will attempt to formally prosecute them. Human rights activists have called the detentions an attempt to sap the strength of the youth-led reform movement.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,597 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: J. Hilburn Raises Money for Bespoke Men’s Clothes Online
text: Bespoke clothing has been a luxury for the rich. But a men’s e-commerce start-up, J. Hilburn, wants to use the Internet to make custom-made suits and shirts more affordable.

headline: You Left Out the Part About ...
text: Last weekend, like seemingly half the country, I took my son to see “X-Men: First Class,” the latest, and best, big-screen incarnation of the popular comic book franchise.

headline: Tony Awards May Bring Out Pickets, Along With Stars
text: Will a big rat greetAl Pacino,Frances McDormand,Daniel Radcliffe and other celebrities on the red carpet Sunday evening at the Tony Awards, newly located on the Upper West Side? It’s possible.

headline: Bloggingheads: Sex and Power
text: Michelle Goldberg, left, of The Daily Beast and Rebecca Traister of Salon.com debate Anthony Weiner and political sex scandals.

headline: In Reckless Fashion, Rapid Online Pursuits of Political Admirers
text: Gennette Cordova said she did not even think the photo was real.

headline: Red Sox Are Rude Guests Once Again
text: Anyone who believes that civility is dead has not been watching the Yankees. They are polite, hospitable, generous even. Recently, they have made a habit of receiving guests from out of town and treating them like long-lost friends, giving them the run of the plate.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Creating Innovative Technologies
text: On this week’s Bits: Tech Talk podcast, J.D. Biersdorfer chats with Frank Moss, former director of the M.I.T. Media Lab, about his new book “The Sorcerers and Their Apprentices,” which looks at the lab’s approach to creating innovative technologies. They also discuss some of the projects that were going on during his five years leading the Media Lab.

headline: Photo Replay: June 8
text: A look back at the day in sports, from handball championships in Germany to sailing in England.

headline: California Raids Net Dozens Suspected of Being Gang Members
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The authorities in California announced Wednesday the arrest of more than 100 people suspected of being gang members in the largely agricultural Central Valley, the latest sweep by law enforcement to stem what they call a growing — and international — menace in the nation’s most populous state.

headline: Economy’s Woes Shift the Focus of Budget Talks
text: WASHINGTON — Recent signs that the economic recovery is flagging have introduced a new tension into the bipartisan budget negotiations, giving rise to calls especially from liberals to limit the size of immediate spending cuts or even to provide an additional fiscal stimulus.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Horton Hit Fresh, Bruins Tie Finals
text: BOSTON — If the Bruins or the TD Garden crowd needed any inspiration for Game 4 of the Stanley Cup finals, they had to look no further  than ol’ No. 4, Bobby Orr, waving a Bruins flag with Nathan Horton’s No. 18 stitched on it before the opening face-off.

headline: Brewers Batter Bullpen to Take Down Mets
text: MILWAUKEE — During the course of a lashing rainstorm outside Miller Park on Wednesday, water came pouring through a crack in the roof and cascaded down on dozens of fans behind home plate. The brief deluge was not the first in the stadium’s history, nor was it the only seepage on this night.

headline: Police Rarely Turn to Psychics, Texas Report Aside
text: “Oh my God, now we’re all going to get a black eye,” was Jacki Mari’s first thought when she heard that a false tip from a psychic had led law enforcement officers on a fruitless search for a mass grave in East Texas on Tuesday night.

headline: A Federal Study Finds That Local Reporting Has Waned
text: An explosion of online news sources in recent years has not produced a corresponding increase in reporting, particularly quality local reporting, a federal study of the media has found.

headline: The World, Grain by Grain
text: A look at some of the samples of sand in Rob Holman’s international collection.

headline: Word of the Day | berserk
text: berserk •\bə(r)-ˈsərk, ˌbər-, -ˈzərk; ˈbər-ˌ\• adjective

headline: New Effort to Protect Immigrants From Tricks
text: Immigration officials are teaming up with federal and state prosecutors, the Federal Trade Commission, lawyers’ groups and immigrant advocate organizations in a new nationwide effort to combat an epidemic of schemes by people posing as immigration lawyers.

headline: Message of Survival Won Denver Race for Mayor
text: DENVER — Lots of politicians, when stumped on the stump, resort to talking about their own lives and the results are often about as exciting as your average greeting card.

headline: Putting Antics Aside, Ortiz Homers Again
text: David Ortiz strolled to the plate in the first inning awash in a lusty chorus of boos. He was perceived to have slighted the Yankees on Tuesday night — a bat-tossing incident that brewed overnight in the caldron that is the Yankees-Red Sox rivalry — and their fans craved retribution.

headline: Obama Tries to Focus on Economic Fears
text: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — President Obama, battling the public’s loss of confidence in his handling of the economy, came to a community college here on Wednesday to talk up a $2 billion program aimed at tailoring classes to match the needs of manufacturing companies.

headline: Keith Irvine, Interior Designer, Dies at 82
text: Keith Irvine, an interior designer who brought a sense of wit and unpredictability to the English country-house style that won the allegiance of clients like Jacqueline Onassis, Rex and Lady Harrison, and Pat and William F. Buckley Jr., died on May 31 in Carmel, N.Y. He was 82.

headline: Legendary Entertainment Prepares Push Into Chinese Market
text: LOS ANGELES — One of Hollywood’s top film financiers and producers is making a big push into China.

headline: A Distinctive Voice on Instagram
text: The Instagram photo-sharing app for iPhones, around only seven months, has already given rise to remarkably creative picture streams. It’s no surprise, given his reputation as an innovator, that Richard Koci Hernandez‘s pictures are among the more notable.

headline: The Banking Emperor Has No Clothes

headline: How Do You Feel About Your Last Name?
text: The spotlight on Representative Anthony D. Weiner prompted a man named Eric Weiner to write for the Op-Ed page on his experiences with and his relationship to his surname. Do you like your last name? Do you share it with anyone famous – or infamous? What does it mean to you?

headline: Citi Says Credit Card Customers’ Data Was Hacked
text: 12:49 p.m. | Updated Citigroup acknowledged on Thursday that unidentified hackers had breached its security and gained access to the data of hundreds of thousands of its credit card customers in North America.

headline: S.U.V.’s, Longtime Targets of Auto Safety Analysts, Get High Marks From I.I.H.S.
text: Drivers of today’s sport utility vehicles are among the least likely to be killed in a crash, according to the most recent analysis of driver death rates conducted by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. The full report appears in the organization’s latest status report, released Thursday.

headline: Prague’s Historic Golden Lane Reopens
text: Last May, the most picturesque part of Prague Castle, Golden Lane, closed for one year, because of  broken pipes that were flooding its pretty cottages. On June 1, the street reopened, and some of its historic buildings are housing new, artistic offerings.

headline: The Early Word: Number Crunching
text: In The Times:

headline: Fearing Assault, More Syrians Flee Into Turkey
text: KARBEYAZ, Turkey — Security forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria converged in the country’s restive northwest on Thursday as hundreds of residents fled across the border into Turkey, heightening fears of a budding refugee crisis and a widening crackdown on dissent.

headline: Jim Northrup and the 1968 Tigers’ Two-Sport Stars
text: Jim Northrup, who died Wednesday at age 71, was a starting outfielder on a Detroit Tigers team that was unusually long on two-sport athletes. And those 1968 Tigers were also good enough to win the World Series.

headline: Elizabeth Taylor on ‘Someone’ Similarly Named

Someone had a new fiancé, a strapping construction worker named Larry Fortensky. Someone was friends with Michael Jackson, and someone released a perfume called Passion.”

headline: What I’ve Learned From Blogging
text: It’s been 13 months since I started writing about my business, and I’ve posted 60 times since then. I’ve been asked by many people how I got involved with “You’re the Boss.” The short answer: good timing and luck.

headline: Better Than Honour Joins Racing’s Royalty
text: Liz O’Connell is a professional horsewoman who just finished foaling season and is looking for new adventures. She is a member of the New York State Task Force on Retired Race Horses and spends too much time rehoming off-the-track thoroughbreds.

headline: Nokia’s Top Technology Officer Departs, Maybe for Good
text: The Finnish cellphone maker Nokia said on Thursday that its chief technology officer had taken a leave of absence and would be temporarily replaced by the head of the company’s research center.

headline: European Central Bank Holds Rate Steady but Hints at a July Increase
text: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank left its benchmark interest rate unchanged on Thursday but signaled that markets should expect an increase next month, despite the euro area’s uneven economic recovery.

text: Weak investor demand has led Samsonite to lower expectations for its initial public offering, to $1.3 billion from $1.5 billion.

headline: Listen to the New Bon Iver Record
text: Jon Caramanica’s profile of Justin Vernon, the frontman of Bon Iver, appeared in last Sunday’s magazine. Bon Iver’s new record, “Bon Iver, Bon Iver,” isn’t available until June 21, but you can hear it now in the player below. How do you think it compares to “For Emma, Forever Ago“? A natural transition? A complete break from the past? Can you detect any Kanye influence? Can the hipster dread of the Phil Collins effect be overcome? Your thoughts are welcome.

headline: New Recruits for Team Dad
text: Any ideas I had about trying to handle my father’s move alone evaporated with a conversation about a flashlight.

headline: China Appears to Be Moving to Halt Grass-Roots Candidates
text: BEIJING — The Chinese authorities appear to be restricting attempts by a handful of citizens to run in local legislative elections as self-proclaimed independent candidates, stating that such candidacies are illegal and that no one can run for office without first clearing a series of procedural hurdles.

headline: The Tony Nominee Nina Arianda Performs
text: The New York Times presents the third of four videos of first-time Tony nominees. The actress Nina Arianda performs an excerpt of the Broadway revival of the 1946 comedy "Born Yesterday."

headline: An Ethics Bill at Last (Fingers Crossed)
text: The Department of Men Behaving Badly has been awfully busy this week, what with Anthony D. Weiner perhaps slouching toward career perdition, Dominique Strauss-Kahn pleading not guilty to sexual assault allegations, and the rapper Ja Rule heading to prison on a weapons charge.

headline: Even Before Layoffs, Schools Lost 135 Arts Teachers
text: Supporters of arts in the schools complain that art, music, theater and dance are among the first subjects to suffer when budgets are tight. A new survey of New York City schools shows that this may, indeed, be the case.

headline: Repole Stays Positive, Despite Trying Triple Crown Season
text: Joe DePaolo is the chief NYRA correspondent for Horseracingnation.com and a freelance radio producer.

headline: Thursday Reading: What to Do When Your Therapist Yawns
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Live Blog: The Panetta Confirmation Hearing
text: Leon E. Panetta, the director of the C.I.A. — and President Obama’s choice to lead the Department of Defense — appears on Capitol Hill Thursday for his confirmation hearing before the Senate Armed Services Committee. A master of Congressional relationships and all but a lock for confirmation, Mr. Panetta will still face some tough questions about administration policy in Afghanistan and Iraq, spending plans for the Pentagon and the fighting in the Middle East and North Africa, especially in Libya.

headline: Center Stage at Edinburgh Fringe: Two New Works From the National Theater of Scotland
text: New work from the National Theater of Scotland, John Malkovich in the role of director and Simon Callow appearing in drag are just a few highlights coming this summer to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, the enormous arts festival that annually takes over the Scottish capital. Festival organizers announced on Thursday that the festival, the biggest to date, would comprise a record 2,542 events in 258 sites (up from 2,453 shows last year). More than 600 productions will be offered for no charge during the festival, which runs Aug. 5-29. The revamped Web site www.edfringe.com will be available later Thursday and tickets go on sale Friday morning.

headline: Calvin Klein Resort: Silver Linings
text: Francisco Costa’s modest resort collection for Calvin Klein flowed easily from his fall line, with a fluid fit, an abundance of long-sleeved looks, and not too many surprises until the very end of the show. One difference is length; on Wednesday, in the Calvin Klein showroom, Mr. Costa’s hemlines were below the knee.

headline: U.S. Hit a Record for Exports in April
text: The American trade deficit shrank unexpectedly in April after the United States sold $175.6 billion in goods and services overseas, the most exports on record, the government reported on Thursday.

headline: Without Even a Song, Willie Nelson Pot Charge Goes Poof
text: There will be no “Blue Eyes Crying in the Rain” at a West Texas courthouse where Willie Nelson was to face misdemeanor drug charges, but Mr. Nelson’s red eyes won’t be crying in the rain either, as a prosecutor there has said the singer can make his plea and pay his fine by mail, Reuters reported.

headline: An Interview With Sebastião Salgado
text: The Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, where these pictures were taken, is a pretty remote place. How did you get there, and how did you get around once you were there?

headline: Just One Look | Marc Jacobs Resort Collection
text: Marc Jacobs has always had a knack for play clothes. His resort collection, with its luxed-up variations on tees and sweatshirts and its seemingly sun-bleached wallpaper prints (here’s a head-to-toe floral that even a wallflower could get into), didn’t scream fantasy holiday — it quietly beckoned, Wouldn’t it be great to steal a few days off?

headline: The Economics of Men Behaving Badly
text: Maureen Dowd, among others, observed in Tuesday’s paper that many of the recent examples of men behaving badly were perpetrated by men married to powerful, independently successful wives, on whom some of the cheaters were financially dependent. And with so much political power and celebrity of their own at stake, there was even more reason to avoid boneheaded decisions like texting crotch-shots to strangers or impregnating the housekeeper.

headline: Poetry Pairing | June 9, 2011
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes.Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

headline: Zealous Advocacy vs. Obstructive Conduct
text: Robert Khuzami, director of the enforcement division at the Securities and Exchange Commission, highlighted questionable behavior by defense lawyers in a recent speech to the UJA-Federation of New York.

headline: Fusion-io I.P.O. Surges
text: 4:22 p.m. | Updated Shares of Fusion-io ended up more than 18 percent on their New York Stock Exchange debut on Thursday, the latest technology offering to be met with strong investor demand.

headline: Apple Will Reject D.U.I. Checkpoint Apps
text: After Apple announced its latest software at its annual Worldwide Developers Conference on Monday, the company also updated its guidelines for new applications that are submitted to the iTunes app store.

headline: Sadrist Verse: Pen and Sword Meet in Poetry Contest
text: BAGHDAD — Foes of the United States military in Iraq have deployed armed militias, explosives and mass demonstrations to battle the American presence. Their latest salvo, though, was one delivered in verse: a poetry contest.

headline: Microsoft Loses Final Appeal in $290 Million Patent Case
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday unanimously upheld a $290 million award against Microsoft in a patent dispute. The case was brought by a Canadian software company, i4i Limited Partnership, which said a version of Microsoft Word had infringed its patented method for editing documents.

headline: The Bin Ladens’ American Confidante
text: Jean Sasson wrote a book with a wife and son of Osama’s, and yes, she has stories.

headline: What We’re Reading
