headline: News of the World, One Click Away
text: How are things in Glocca Morra? Check Newspaper Map, a Google Map that has been annotated with sites from more than 10,000 worldwide news outlets. One click will take you to a news site, and you can choose which language you would like to read it in, thanks to Google’s translation services. The site is the work of Great Name, a Web-development squad from Gothenburg, Sweden (home of both Metro and Götesborgs Posten).

headline: RSA Gets a Security Chief
text: RSA, the computer security unit of EMC that was hacked, has named Edward Schwartz as chief security officer, promoting him from the same role at NetWitness, a firm it recently acquired.

headline: Taiwan Approves A.I.G.’s Sale of Nan Shan Life
text: Taiwan’s financial regulator said on Thursday that it would support the sale of American International Group‘s local unit, Nan Shan Life Insurance, for $2.2 billion to a consortium led by Ruen Chen Investment Holding.

headline: Drones Transform How America Fights Its Wars
text: The Pentagon now has about 7,000 aerial drones in its inventory, compared with fewer than 50 a decade ago.

headline: The Five-Hanky Bro-ness of Bon Iver; Framing Riot Grrl for the History Books; New Releases
text: This week: Melena Ryzik on framing Riot Grrl for the history books; Jon Caramanica on the five-hanky bro-ness of Bon Iver; and new CDs from Ronnie Dunn; Corea, Clarke + White; and Ford and Lopatin. Ben Ratliff is your host.

headline: Apple Gives Publishers a Sales Break
text: In the tug of war between Apple and publishers over digital media, the balance of power shifted a bit this week to the side of the publishers.

headline: White House Creates Advisory Group for Rural Issues
text: President Obama is creating an advisory council aimed at boosting the economy and quality of life in rural America, White House officials said on Thursday.

headline: Rare Protest Reported in the Syrian Capital
text: Syrian activists claimed that there was a rare, small protest in the Syrian capital, Damascus, on Wednesday. As my colleagues Sebnem Arsu and Katherine Zoepf report, activists pointed to video posted on YouTube that appeared to show protesters on a street in the well-to-do district of Sha’alan, an area with fashionable stores and food stalls.

headline: Heady Advice From a Hard-Living Heavy Metal Frontman
text: OXFORD, England — He had to leave high school early (there was an unfortunate incident involving some macaroni and cheese) and never went to college at all. So it felt a bit strange, the rock star Corey Taylor admitted, to be addressing the hyper-educated students at the Oxford Union here on Wednesday night.

headline: Democrats Take Aim at House Republicans on Medicare
text: Perhaps in an attempt to change the subject from the tweeting albatross that Representative Anthony D. Weiner has been to their party this week, Democrats are once again singling out Republicans on the Medicare issue this week in automated calls across the country.

headline: Gates Vows ‘No Rush to the Exits’ in Afghanistan
text: BRUSSELS — As the Obama administration moves toward a decision on how rapidly to withdraw its extra combat forces from Afghanistan, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates assured the NATO alliance on Thursday that “there will be no rush to the exits.”

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘A Lost American Place’

headline: Hey, Guys, Let’s Make a Monster Flick
text: There is something odd about watching a movie called “Super 8” digitally projected onto an Imax screen with 12,000 watts of gut-rumbling Dolby sound. J. J. Abrams, the writer and director and presiding pop-culture guru-geek, is surely aware of the incongruity. You might even say that it’s the subject of the movie, which makes much of the technological gap between the present day and 1979, when this story of kids and monsters takes place.

headline: Peer-to-Peer Car Sharing Gains Traction in Oregon
text: Oregon soon could become the second state to allow peer-to-peer car sharing. Legislation establishing standards for personal vehicle sharing programs was approved this week by the House of Representatives and the Senate. HB 3149 paves the way for residents to rent their cars directly to other people through vehicle sharing programs like Getaround or the Google-backed RelayRides. California passed a similar law last year.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Bank Said No? Hedge Funds Fill a Void in Lending | With traditional lenders still avoiding risky borrowers in the wake of the financial crisis, hedge funds and other opportunistic investors are filling the void. They are going after midsize businesses that cannot easily raise money in the bond markets like their bigger brethren.

headline: Tim Pawlenty’s Supply-Side Time Warp
text: Earlier this week, Ramesh Ponnuru had an excellent column on the Republican Party’s struggle to come up with an economic agenda that doesn’t just feel like “half-remembered bits of Reaganism.” Here’s how it ended:

headline: Lives Cut Short by Depression
text: There is something about a first friend that is irreplaceable. No matter how disparately your lives travel, the first friend you ever had occupies a special place in your heart. I was lucky that Michael was considerate enough to be born four months before me, waiting next door, ready to join me in elaborate childhood games of hide-and-seek, multilevel couch forts and family camping trips in the Catskills.

headline: Arizona Wildfire Threatens Electrical Grid
text: PINETOP, Ariz. — The gusty winds that have been fueling a vast wildfire in eastern Arizona slowed somewhat on Thursday, allowing firefighters to make some headway against the blaze, which has already turned much of the lush green pine forest here to black soot and sent thousands of residents fleeing for their lives.

headline: Into the Wild
text: Sebastião Salgado’s stunning portfolio in this Sunday’s magazine represent several months spent photographing in Alaska. In an online-only interview with John Bowe, Salgado explains what it took to get these pictures. The right shot required not just waiting for the caribou to show up but having the right equipment at hand:

headline: The Story Under Mrs. Landman’s Umbrella
text: When we left Eva Landman, she was holding the umbrella — a clever and improbable umbrella — with a clouded back story.

headline: 'Weird Al' and the Gaga Saga
text: "Weird Al" Yankovic navigates copyright law and fair-use rules with his new single, a parody of Lady Gaga's "Born This Way."

headline: Colleges Now Offering Education in Disaster
text: NEW PALTZ, N.Y. — Carlene Pinto watched from her middle-school classroom in Brooklyn as the plane pierced the second tower; then she trudged the three miles home as paperwork and dust rained from the sky. Rebecca Rodriguez felt helpless as a teenager watching Hurricane Katrina unfold on television. And Lindsay Yates still shudders at the recollection of Hurricane Fran, which killed two dozen people in her native North Carolina when she was a second grader.

headline: Americans Still Split on Global Warming, Poll Shows
text: Judging from an annual survey by researchers at Yale and George Mason universities, the American public is roughly as fractured in its attitudes toward climate change today as it was last year.

headline: Helmsley’s Millionaire Maltese, Trouble, Dies at 12
text: Trouble, the fluffy white lap companion of the widely vilified hotel and real estate tycoon Leona Helmsley — and a dog that managed to be both the world’s richest and most hated Maltese — died in December, a vice president of the Helmsley trust has confirmed.

headline: Popcast: Riot Grrrl Redux
text: This week’s Popcast looks at women who riot and men who weep.

headline: Filling Classes With Learning, Not Fears
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban insurgents are attacking fewer schools, easing the way for boys and girls to attend in larger numbers, even in largely insecure areas of the country, Afghan education officials say.

headline: Disappearing Acts
text: In both the N.H.L. and N.B.A. championship series, it has become all about the meltdown, and no, we’re not talking about the Slushie the two hockey teams were playing on in TD Garden Wednesday night. (Here’s an idea, N.H.L., don’t stretch a winter sports season so long it ends in summer ... )

text: Dan Kois may indeed be “suffering from a kind of culture fatigue,” as he wrote in his April 29 essay about the merits of eating ones cultural vegetables, but the debate his riff sparked has endured online.

text: There are a few requests for advice idling in my inbox. This afternoon, I will run one of the more philosophical ones (so check back in), and this morning, we will deal with the practical.

She called the collection “Body Forms,” emphasizing the group of “bold and direct body-molded must-haves” — like this knee-skimming scuba dress — at its core.

headline: Message to Einhorn: It’s Time to Pay Reyes

It is now time for the prospective part owner of the Mets to demonstrate a third talent: channeling his inner Nelson Doubleday and bludgeoning his new business chums into doing the right thing.

headline: Trove of Palin E-Mails Draws Press to Alaska
text: JUNEAU, Alaska — Sarah Palin is long gone from this capital, what with the new ranch in Arizona and the is-she-running-or-not bus blitz of American heritage landmarks Outside, as Alaskans like to call the lower 48 states.

headline: Panetta Demurs on Troop Drawdown in Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON — Leon E. Panetta, President Obama’s nominee to be secretary of defense, deflected persistent questions on Thursday about one of the most pressing issues at the Pentagon, the scope of the American troop withdrawals from Afghanistan next month.

text: Pip the Hawk Cam hawk in the nest above Washington Square Park, 12:31 p.m. Heat index: 102 degrees. Hawks really do pant when it’s hot.

headline: Dunn Struggling to Fill a Void for the White Sox

headline: Help Us Review the Sarah Palin E-Mail Records
text: On Friday, the State of Alaska will release more than 24,000 of Sarah Palin’s e-mails covering much of her tenure as governor of Alaska. Times reporters will be in Juneau, the state capital, to begin the process of reviewing the e-mails, which we will be posting on NYtimes.com starting on Friday afternoon.

headline: Have German Wages Really Risen?
text: Matthias Rumpf of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development wrote me the following response to my column on the Germany economy:

headline: What the Hippest Preschooler on the Block Will Be Reading
text: For parents who spent their 20s mooning over “A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius” and intend for their children to read “What Is the What” as soon as they’re globally-sensitive teenagers, there is now an interim means — a baby step? — into Dave Eggers’s literary world.

headline: Animal Kingdom: Anatomy of a Derby Winner
text: Steeplechase Times has been with Animal Kingdom during his rise to the top of the 3-year-old class. Joe Clancy filed this report on Thursday:

headline: Bow Makers Unite Behind a Precious Tree
text: As the earth’s forests and other natural resources face growing peril, humans are affected in many unexpected ways. In recent years, musicians have found themselves organizing to save the pernambuco, a medium-size tropical tree native to Brazil and known for its unique red wood. Discovered by French bow makers 250 years ago, it provides the primary — indeed only — wood for making high-end bows for professional musicians. (The tree is also known as the pau-brasil.)

headline: Buried in Anonymity, and Ignominy, Too
text: EL DORADO HILLS, Calif. — Wedged between a strawberry patch and an encroaching swath of suburbia, the men and women who lie in the Mormon Island Relocation Cemetery are a long-dead, little-noted lot: a Mr. Outen, for example, who died in December 1862, or Elizabeth, the wife of James, who died in April some two decades later.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Afghanistan, Turkey and Britain.

headline: A Congressional ‘Sexting’ Warning
text: At a moment when Representative Anthony D. Weiner is mired in scandal because of sexually explicit text messages, the research arm of Congress has circulated a report on some of the downsides of text messaging, including a primer on “sexting.”

headline: Small U.S. Farms Find Profit in Tourism
text: SANTA MARGARITA, Calif. — For all the talk about sustainable agriculture, most small farms are not self-sustaining in a very basic sense: they can’t make ends meet financially without relying on income from jobs off the farm.

headline: The Value of a One-Man Press
text: The Miami Heat’s halfcourt offense may lack in consistency, but the capacity for dominance never subsides. Even at his worst (which he very nearly approximated in Game 4), LeBron James is still LeBron James; defenses must account for his presence and his passing at all times, and be wary of his explosive scoring potential.

headline: ABC Completes Upfront Sales
text: The sale of commercial time by the big English-language broadcast television networks, in what is known as the upfront market, is moving along as a third network, ABC, finishes its business.

headline: Video of the Fight Against an Arizona Wildfire
text: As my colleague Marc Lacey reports, an enormous wildfire is tearing across eastern Arizona, forcing thousands of people from their homes. Despite the work of 2,500 firefighters from across the country, this 12-day-old fire has spread across more than 600 square miles and was still zero percent contained Thursday morning.

headline: Ex-N.S.A. Aide Gains Plea Deal in Leak Case; Setback to U.S.
text: WASHINGTON — A former spy agency employee agreed late Thursday to plead guilty to a minor charge in a highly publicized leak prosecution, undercutting the Obama administration’s unusual campaign to prosecute government officials who disclose classified information to the press.

headline: Just One Look | Calvin Klein Resort Collection
text: Minimalism never takes a holiday at Calvin Klein, not even when Resort rolls around. Francisco Costa remained cool and collected as ever, sticking to a palette of mostly white, black and midnight blue and a modest, knee-skimming silhouette. But a side-effect of all that modesty is that small details like the slit in the front of an ivory shift or, in the case of this look, a deeply cut racer back, become quite unexpectedly erotic.

headline: More From the Bin Ladens’ American Confidante
text: This week I’ve practically rescued an entire second column from the cutting-room floor of my Talk interview with Jean Sasson, who told the weird and fascinating life stories of Osama bin Laden’s son and wife in her 2009 book, “Growing Up Bin Laden.” Here we learn a family insider’s take on Bin Laden’s “Real Housewives of Tora Bora”-like drama, and what she imagines he was thinking in his last moments of life.

headline: Parents Who Wish They Weren’t
text: From the practical to the philosophical…

headline: Europeans Act to Stem Drought Damage
text: PARIS — Suffering from a record-shattering drought, European nations started preparing emergency plans this week to conserve water and provide millions of euros in aid to farmers, including the deployment of soldiers to deliver hay for cattle grazing on sun-baked soil.

headline: S.E.C. Issues Warning About Reverse-Merger Stocks
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission on Thursday issued a warning about the risks of investing in so-called reverse-merger companies, private businesses that merge with already public shell companies to gain a market listing.

headline: Used-Car Prices Continue Rise, Blurring Value Case for Consumers
text: “Would you buy a used car from that guy?” was the old refrain. Now, that guy is desperate to buy your car.

headline: 36 Hours in Bologna
text: Market stalls, specialty shops and osterias offer compelling reasons to linger.

headline: 36 Hours in Bologna
text: VIBRANT, independent and home to one of Europe’s oldest universities, Bologna is a dynamic counterpoint to more popular, touristy cities like Rome and Florence. About 50 miles north of Florence, the city is as famous for its cuisine as it is for its fiery left-leaning politics. Market stalls brimming with asparagus and fava beans, specialty shops selling cured meats, and osterias serving fresh pasta with the city’s signature ragù (known as Bolognese in the rest of the world) offer compelling reasons to linger. And then there are architectural masterpieces like the church of Santo Stefano and the iconic Due Torri (Two Towers). Grittier than in most of its northern counterparts, Bologna’s politics — the last mayor, Flavio Delbono, resigned when it was alleged that he was using public money on his mistress, and now residents are waiting to see if the new mayor, Virginio Merola, will make good on his promise to spruce up the city center — somehow only adds to the excitement of a visit here.

headline: Just How Much Is a Tony Worth?
text: Every year, Broadway producers with musicals struggling to fill theaters to capacity every night place their financial hopes on the Tony awards. But just how valuable is winning a prestigious Tony? And how much does the publicity — and the broadcast television showcase for the musical numbers on CBS — help the runners-up? FiveThirtyEight, a blog devoted to helping readers of The New York Times cut through the clutter of this data-rich world, decided to find out.

headline: Videos Show Defectors From Syrian Army, Activists Say
text: Two videos uploaded to a Syrian activist YouTube channel on Tuesday purport to show defectors from Syria’s security forces. The videos’ veracity cannot be independently confirmed because of government-imposed restrictions on reporting inside Syria. Neither video makes clear when the videos were recorded.

headline: ‘Otherworldly’
text: More images from the exhibition at the Museum of Arts and Design.

headline: New Disney Stores Will Put Focus on Babies
text: The Walt Disney Company will open two stand-alone stores dedicated to all things baby as it seeks to become a bigger player in that robust consumer products market.

headline: House Tour: Copake, N.Y.
text: An 1890s Greek Revival house in Copake, N.Y., in Columbia County, is available for rent at $13,500 for the month of July.

headline: An M.I.T. Plan for Natural Gas With Planet in Mind
text: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology has released “The Future of Natural Gas,” the latest in its valuable series of reports examining global energy choices. The report lays out a path for exploiting this abundant and relatively clean source of energy in ways that could limit environmental concerns and give the biggest near-term boost to efforts to trim emissions of carbon dioxide.

headline: House Tour: Copake, N.Y.
text: WHAT A four-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bathroom house with 2,800 square feet.

headline: Storming the Box Office in His Jammies
text: WEST HOLLYWOOD

headline: Uncommon Threads | Sophia 203
text: With their refined silk embroidery and unironic butterfly and heart shapes, Sophia 203 belts, necklaces and flower-child headbands feel very Yves Saint Laurent by way of Williamsburg. Sophia Edstrand, the designer behind the label, is from Sweden but her C.V. has a very French accent: she studied fashion design in Paris, worked as a salesgirl at Colette — “It was supposed to be for pocket money while I was a student, but I spent it all on shoes,” she says gleefully — then did a 10-year stint as the creative assistant to the Parisian jeweler Marie-Hélène de Taillac. Edstrand now splits her time between Paris and Jaipur, India, where she moved six years ago and where her one-year-old line is produced by traditional craftsmen. “The embroidery that’s done here is unbelievable,” Edstrand says. “When I showed one of my pieces to Manish Arora” — the New Delhi designer who’s known as the John Galliano of India — “he couldn’t believe it. And people here are not afraid of color.” Neither is Edstrand, who named the line for her favorite Pantone shade, a bright fuchsia. Lampshades, children’s wear and bridal pieces are coming up next, and Edstrand is happy to undertake custom orders. She claims she had no thoughts of YSL when she was designing her pieces but is happy to report that Stefano Pilati has already bought one of her heart belts. “I’m inspired by happiness and lightness,” she says. “That’s really where the collection is coming from.”

headline: $1 Billion Is Pledged to Support Libya Rebels
text: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates — The nations intervening in Libya pledged as much as $1 billion in support for the opposition there on Thursday as senior officials continued to predict that the collapse of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s government could be imminent.

headline: How a Confession About Cultural Vegetables Turned into a Film-Critic Food Fight
text: On May 1 — almost seven weeks ago, or several eons in Internet time — the magazine published a Riff by Dan Kois titled “Reaching For Culture That Remains Stubbornly Above My Grasp.” The shorter online headline is “Eating Your Cultural Vegetables.” The tonal distinction between these two headlines may be crucial, for reasons explored below.

headline: Gingrich’s Senior Campaign Staff Resigns
text: Newt Gingrich’s campaign manager and a half-dozen senior advisers resigned on Thursday, two aides said, dealing a significant setback to his bid for the Republican presidential nomination and severely complicating his hopes for a political comeback.

headline: Can Cyberattacks Be Stopped?
text: Citigroup’s discovery of a security breach that occurred last month, affecting 200,000 credit card accounts in North America, underscores corporate vulnerability to Internet attacks. In this video interview, CNBC asks a cybersecurity expert if a tipping point has been reached in the battle to keep secure networks safe.

headline: I.B.M. Researchers Create High-Speed Graphene Circuits
text: I.B.M. researchers said Thursday that they had designed high-speed circuits from graphene, an ultra-thin material that has a host of promising applications, from high-bandwidth communication to a new generation of low-cost smartphone and television displays.

headline: Salzburg Easter Festival Finds an Orchestra
text: The Dresden Staatskapelle will replace the Berlin Philharmonic as the resident orchestra of the Salzburg Easter Festival starting in 2013, officials have announced. The Berliners wanted to increase their performances at the Easter festival but were rebuffed for lack of money, so they announced a plan to move to Baden-Baden’s festival hall after next year.

headline: Answers About Abuse in State-Run Homes
text: On Monday, The New York Times published a second article in a series examining the treatment of the developmentally disabled in New York State. In his investigation, Danny Hakim of The Times reviewed thousands of state records and court documents and interviewed current and former employees at nine state-run institutions that house the developmentally disabled. He found that supervisors at these institutions have tolerated physical and psychological abuse, knowingly hired unqualified workers, ignored complaints by whistle-blowers and failed to investigate credibly cases of abuse and neglect.

headline: The Fabulous Bharara Boys
text: There are a bunch of brothers and sisters who have reached the pinnacles of their respective fields. Standouts include the late Bruce Wasserstein, the star investment banker, and his late sister, Wendy Wasserstein, the renowned playwright. There is Maryanne Trump Barry, a federal judge in New Jersey, and her brother, The Donald. And most famously these days, we have the Emanuels: Rahm, the mayor of Chicago; Ari, the Hollywood super agent; and Zeke, a health care expert.

headline: A Look Back at the Space Shuttle
text: Two weeks ago, “CBS Sunday Morning” aired my story about the end of the Space Shuttle program. It was a story dear to my heart, one I’d hoped to do for years. It took me three trips to Kennedy Space Center to finally film the liftoff (because the final liftoff of the shuttle Endeavour kept being delayed).

headline: Coney Island, 5:23 A.M.
text: Photo: dawn still life with haze-shrouded cruise ship and lifeguard awaiting arrival of bathing hordes.

headline: The Living Is Easy; The Women Are Missing
text: IF you’re a woman who roared, snorted or sniggered at “Bridesmaids,” if you like watching other women on screen, you should see it again. Because that hit comedy written by Kristen Wiig and Annie Mumolo and directed by Paul Feig, turns out to be one of the few occasions this summer when you can enjoy a movie about and with women released by a major studio. From now through August, American films will again be almost all male, almost all the time (the occasional decorative gal pal notwithstanding) as this year’s boys of summer — the Green Lantern and Captain America, Conan the Barbarian and Conan O’Brien — invade the multiplex, seizing media-entertainment minds and your dollars.

headline: To Rand Paul, Legal Immigration Is Also a Concern
text: It’s common to hear a senator express concerns about illegal immigration these days, but Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, is also concerned about legal immigration.

headline: Fox’s ‘Terra Nova’ Steeped in Mystery
text: There’s a rhythm, slightly irritating to television critics, to the rollout of the new fall shows on the major television networks. After the upfront presentations in May, DVDs are mailed or online screeners are posted with warnings that the shows in question are works in progress, and that credits and effects — or even actors and entire plot lines — may change. Later in the summer the final screeners are provided (meaning that the conscientious or curious critic could end up watching every new pilot twice).

headline: Goldman Fined $10 Million for Tips Sent to Big Clients
text: Stock research has long been considered a big money loser on Wall Street. It costs millions to produce and most investors are unwilling to pay hard cash for it. But in 2006 Goldman Sachs came up with a plan to leverage its equity research, funneling short-term stock tips to its biggest trading clients.

headline: Ford C-Max to Spawn a Prius-Fighting Family
text: At its corporate headquarters in Dearborn, Mich., the Ford Motor Company announced Thursday that it would introduce its C-Max small crossover vehicle in 2012 as the foundation of a dedicated line of parallel hybrid and plug-in hybrid vehicles. The strategy closely resembles that of the Toyota Prius, the hybrid sedan that soon will be offered also as a plug-in hybrid, as well as in a wagon body style and potentially a compact hatchback.

headline: Sarah Fox and Calvin Ford
text: IN July 2009, a few weeks after her fiancé called off their engagement, Sarah Fox sent word in an e-mail to her high school sweetheart, Calvin Ford.

headline: Morgan Stanley’s Bet on LinkedIn
text: Morgan Stanley may have been one of the lead underwriters for LinkedIn‘s initial public offering, but the firm didn’t get its shares at a bargain price.

headline: CBS on Top, Again, as Upfront Market Ends
text: As the big English-language broadcast networks wrap up their advertising sales before the start of the 2011-12 season, in what is known as the upfront market, CBS is again taking the lead in total volume.

headline: Small Boat, Big Mission: An Arctic Whale Survey
text: “Just when you think the sun is finally going to set, it starts coming back up again!” Chris Debicki, sleep-deprived but enthusiastic, said over a crackling cellphone connection from Ilulissat, a fishing village on Greenland’s western coast. Sled dogs may outnumber people there.

text: Growing numbers of Syrian refugees cross into Turkey; Arizona’s wildfire threatens blackouts for thousands of homes; and world leaders meet to discuss how to finance Libya's opposition.

headline: What a Repeal of the Gay Marriage Ban Means
text: As gay couples know all too well, there’s a long list of federal benefits, both financial and legal, that are available only to straight couples. Social Security spousal survivor benefits. Less expensive health care options. The ability to file one set of tax returns. And the list goes on.

headline: Neighborhood Joint | Springs General Store
text: The Springs General Store in East Hampton, N.Y., predates the arrival of the glittering hordes to the Long Island resort.

headline: Year Round, a Haven for All
text: AT the Springs General Store, a pine-shingled, two-story building that started life in 1847 as the area’s post office and general store, the small-town atmosphere of East Hampton, from the days before the glittering hordes, is miraculously preserved.

headline: Actors Wade Into the Fracking Debate
text: Environmental groups seeking to mobilize opposition to the gas industry’s plan to drill extensively in the Marcellus Shale in upstate New York have pulled out the big guns: celebrities, of course.

headline: Updates From Paris and Texas
text: I ran a guest post just before Memorial Day from Liane Kupferberg Carter, who was about to leave for a weeklong vacation with her husband to celebrate their 30th wedding anniversary. It would be the first time the couple had left their adult son, and in the comments, a number of you asked if she could come back and let you know how things went.

headline: Now Starring in Chicago, a Prime Rauschenberg
text: To bolster its holdings of contemporary classics the Art Institute of Chicago has bought “Short Circuit” by Robert Rauschenberg. The work is a seminal example of his “Combine” paintings, a term he coined to describe works that incorporate castoff objects like rubber tires, flatware or furniture. It is the last acquisition by James Cuno, the director of the Art Institute, who is leaving Chicago this summer to become the president and chief executive of the J. Paul Getty Trust in Los Angeles.

headline: Chamberlain Faces Season-Ending Surgery
text: Joba Chamberlain had just finished a second round of testing on his right elbow Thursday when he walked into the office of Chris Ahmad, the Yankees’ team physician. Ahmad could not bring himself to look at Chamberlain. Ahmad’s head was down, and right then, as Chamberlain settled into a seat, he knew.

headline: An Extra Week for ‘Lysistrata Jones’
text: The Off Broadway production of “Lysistrata Jones,” the musical marriage of ancient Greece and high school basketball, has extended performances for one week, its producer said on Thursday, after opening to strong reviews from theater critics. The show, with a book by Douglas Carter Beane (“Sister Act”) and music and lyrics by Lewis Flinn, will now end its limited engagement on June 24.

headline: California Wildfires
text: More than a dozen wildfires continued to rage in Southern California, driven by shifting, gusting winds that make them all but impossible to stop.

headline: Mrs. Landman’s Umbrella: Transparent at Last
text: When we left Eva Landman last September — she was featured in a Lens post about some of the more unusual studio portraits taken for this newspaper in the 1920s and ’30s — the mysterious provenance of her storm-shield umbrella was left unsettled. That wasn’t a good enough for a software patent lawyer in San Francisco, who helped our colleagues at Lens get to the bottom of the story.

text: For one magic day, horse racing will dominate the sports news in New York.

headline: Belmont Awaits Its Annual Return to Glory
text: IF the last couple of years are any indication, about 50,000 fans will show up at Belmont Park on Saturday to watch the running of the 143rd Belmont Stakes, the premier race on the New York State calendar.

headline: Keep a Straight Face
text: I am 10 years away from being a “woman of a certain age.” But the bags under my eyes and my slack jaw line make me feel bad. So I’ve decided on some plastic surgery. I will share the fact with my close friends. But should I tell people at work and in the neighborhood, the people I see casually around town? (By the way, I’m not vain — really.)

headline: Ruling Favors a 10-Inch Citizen of France
text: PARIS — France was punished on Thursday for not taking proper care of its hamsters.

headline: The Radiance, Then the Ashes
text: WHEN I met Peter, six years after my divorce, I wasn’t in the market for marriage. In contrast, Peter’s faith in matrimony was untarnished, even after losing his first wife, who had died the previous year from breast cancer.

headline: ‘Trollhunter’
text: We’re all vampire-savvy now, able to discuss the finer points of sun exposure, threshold etiquette and werewolf bites. But do you know what to do when a troll lumbers into view? Will you have a strobe handy so you can turn it into stone, or — if you’re Christian — some troll scent to rub on yourself so that it can’t sniff you out?

headline: U.N. Nuclear Watchdog Presses Case Against Syria
text: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations nuclear watchdog voted Thursday to report Syria to the Security Council, citing Syria’s construction of a covert nuclear reactor and its failure to cooperate with investigators, diplomats said.

headline: Jennifer Sousa and Paul Sousa
text: PAUL and Jennifer Sousa are chasing down clean living the way they used to chase down drugs. They want immediate gratification.

headline: State Pays Adirondacks Farmer After Losing Suit
text: The state’s legal pursuit of an upstate farmer, Salim B. Lewis, ended in lopsided defeat on Thursday after the Adirondack Park Agency agreed to pay $72,000 in legal fees to Mr. Lewis.

headline: Theater Talkback: Women on the Verge of Disappearing From the Stage
text: Brian Bedford’s performance as the august Lady Augusta Bracknell in “The Importance of Being Earnest” was a glittering adornment to a season rich in superlative acting, most theater watchers would surely agree. But I can also imagine that Mr. Bedford’s undertaking might have caused just a little bit of consternation in certain circles – namely among actresses who might regard a man assuming such a choice woman’s role as an ungentlemanly bit of poaching.

headline: For Zayat, All Focus Is on the Belmont
text: Bruno De Julio has been a workout analyst and thoroughbred owner for the past 20 years. He is the author of “Bruno on Workouts: Exposing the Mystery” and can be found daily at Racing With Bruno and Grade One Racing.“I was totally frozen; my kids couldn’t get a pulse out of me during the Derby,” Ahmed Zayat said of watching his horse Nehro in the Kentucky Derby. “Nehro was on the lead and had gone by Shackleford, and I said to myself, ‘Oh no, a bridesmaid’ again!'” Animal Kingdom was winding up and taking dead aim at the leaders on his way to victory. (Zayat had finished second in the 2009 Kentucky Derby with Pioneerof the Nile.)

headline: ‘Queen of the Sun: What Are the Bees Telling Us?’
text: Answering its own question, Taggart Siegel’s revelatory documentary “Queen of the Sun: What Are the Bees Telling Us?” would like us to know that its fuzzy subjects are starving, sick and stressed out. Examining the alarming phenomenon known as colony collapse disorder, Mr. Siegel buzzes around the globe and deep into the hive; what he finds is an insect done in by human insult.

headline: 40th New York Mini Is Dedicated to Waitz
text: Joan Benoit Samuelson recalls lining up for the 1980 L’Eggs Mini Marathon in New York, a women-only 10-kilometer race then in its early years in Central Park, and being too intimidated to speak with Grete Waitz.

headline: Artsbeat: June 9, 2011
text: Patrick Healy on the upcoming Tony Awards, and Dave Itzkoff on the "Weird Al" Lady Gaga controversy.

headline: ‘Viva Riva!’
text: Repackaging the revenge thriller in parakeet colors and distinctive African beats, the Congolese writer and director Djo Tunda Wa Munga gives “Viva Riva!” a playful sensuality that goes a long way toward disguising formula.

headline: Surrealist Partners in Painting, but Don’t Call Them a Team
text: KATONAH, N.Y. — “Double Solitaire: The Surreal Worlds of Kay Sage and Yves Tanguy,” at the Katonah Museum of Art, takes a fascinating look at the married life and work of this Surrealist It couple. Their union was remarkably equitable, even by modern standards, though it may also have been artistically suffocating.

headline: The White House Believes in the Confidence Fairy
text: Ryan Avent brings grim news from a White House forum on the economy:

headline: Lots of Talk on Bahrain but No Answers
text: MONTREAL — Sometimes you get the feeling that there is a united front in Formula One among team directors, drivers, stakeholders and others when it comes to thorny issues. Today in the heat of the paddock in Montreal, in near tropical weather conditions of 28 degrees Celsius and 57 percent humidity, the hot topic of Formula One’s Bahrain about-face was discussed at length. But nothing much was said.

headline: Lots of Talk on Bahrain but No Answers
text: MONTREAL — Sometimes you get the feeling that there is a united front in Formula One among team directors, drivers, stakeholders and others when it comes to thorny issues. Today in the heat of the paddock in Montreal, in near tropical weather conditions of 28 degrees Celsius and 57 percent humidity, the hot topic of Formula One’s Bahrain about-face was discussed at length. But nothing much was said.

headline: Captured: A New York Minute, or One in Havana
text: In a photograph by Elliott Erwitt, “New York City, 1949,” we behold, from behind, Augustus Saint-Gaudens’s bronze sculpture of a nude Diana. Drawing her bow, she seems to be aiming at the silhouetted figure of a man far away down a long hallway. In this, like so many of Mr. Erwitt’s images, the light humor thinly veils poetic profundity. A modern cipher of a man is about to get his comeuppance from a mythical divinity: Diana, the virginal huntress, the sight of whom makes men fall prey to the hounds of their own lust. As the sex scandals reported almost daily in the news media attest, many powerful men have suffered, metaphorically, the fate of that unlucky voyeur Actaeon.

headline: From Africa, Nature as Victim and Muse
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.

headline: What’s Always Been Missing in Food Trucks: Alcohol
text: The Pera Turkish Taco Truck, stationed daily at the tourist office and gift shop that was once Tavern on the Green, has won what is apparently the first liquor license granted to a New York City food truck.

headline: TimesCast | Arizona Fire
text: June 9, 2011 - Arizona's wildfire threatens blackouts for hundreds of thousands of homes.

headline: Avaya Files for an I.P.O.
text: Avaya Holdings, a telecommunications equipment maker, filed on Thursday for an initial public offering, becoming the latest company owned by a private equity firm to again seek a stock listing.

headline: A Guessing Game Over 11 Secret Words
text: What were the 11 words? It was an irresistible mystery.

headline: Reality vs. Reality: NBC Tops Fox
text: In the ratings battle of reality shows on Wednesday, NBC’s “America’s Got Talent” outperformed Fox’s “So You Think You Can Dance” by a wide margin, lifting the network to No. 1 on the night. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 12.3 million viewers tuned in for the two-hour installment of “America’s Got Talent” from 9 to 11 p.m., while “So You Think You Can Dance” drew 7.1 million from 8 to 10. NBC’s “Minute to Win It” garnered a meager 4.7 million at 8, but NBC still averaged more viewers over all for the night than second- place Fox. CBS was third with repeats of “Undercover Boss” (4.4 million), “Criminal Minds” (5.7 million) and “Blue Bloods” (6.2 million). ABC finished fourth, earning 4.4 million for back-to-back reruns of “The Middle” in the 8 p.m. hour, followed by repeats of “Modern Family” at 9 and 9:30, which also drew 4.4 million. At 10, an ABC “20/20” special exploring the allure of reality television lagged well behind in its time slot, attracting just 3.6 million viewers.

headline: TimesCast | Financing Libya's Opposition
text: June 9, 2011 - At a meeting in Dubai, foreign nations discussed how to fund Libya's opposition.

text: Anticipating a crackdown, growing numbers of Syrian refugees cross into Turkey.

headline: ‘Reversion’
text: Opens on Friday in Brooklyn.

headline: MTV Cancels the Controversial Series ‘Skins’
text: MTV belatedly acknowledged on Thursday that it had decided to cancel “Skins,” a scripted series that came under criticism for its risqué depictions of underage actors.

headline: Dollar Debasement
text: Just a reminder: when people start talking about the plunging dollar, dollar debasement, whatever, the actual numbers look like this:

headline: Just One Look | Louis Vuitton Resort Collection
text: Even though it is rather obvious that Marc Jacobs doesn’t design all of the 947 collections he turns out annually, he has always been gracious when it comes to giving credit where credit is due. And credit for this year’s Louis Vuitton Resort collection goes not only to his studio design director, Julie De Libran, but to his longtime friend Sofia Coppola, who continues to play the role of muse at large. The clothes were largely inspired by 1960s and ’70s French cinema, but a few looks, like this kicky, pleated dress with its matching Vespa helmet, would look at home on Coppola herself, as she tools around Paris’s Sixth Arrondissement.

headline: Weekend Miser
text: The fourth annual Bike Parade takes off from Socrates Sculpture Park in Queens on Saturday, with cycle-centered festivities throughout the day. Children can get ready to roll in Hallets Cove Playground (Vernon Boulevard and 30th Avenue) from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. at a bike swap organized by Recycle-a-Bicycle. The city Transportation Department will provide helmet fittings and giveaways, and Bike New York will talk safety. At noon the Free Style Arts Association, a group commissioned by communities to build interest in the arts, helps host a bike-decorating workshop that continues until the parade leaves the park at 3. The celebration ends with a reception in Queensbridge Park. (Free; Long Island City; 718-956-1819, Ext. 12, socratessculpturepark.org.)

headline: UCB Pays $34 Million and Pleads Guilty in Epilepsy Drug Fraud Case
text: The drug maker UCB has agreed to pay more than $34 million and pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor for illegal promotion of Keppra, an epilepsy drug, for headaches and pain, according to a court filing unsealed on Thursday in Washington.

headline: Budget Talks Heat Up as Deadline Nears
text: With time growing shorter, lawmakers and White House officials involved in budget talks tied to the debt limit said on Thursday that they would meet at least three times next week to try to close in on an agreement.

headline: A Painter’s Menagerie of Birds and Beasts Comes Back to Life
text: The painter Robert Winthrop Chanler enjoyed spending his inheritance from his Astor ancestors in the 1910s and ’20s by giving parties and maintaining a zoo and a plant conservatory at his Manhattan town house near Gramercy Park.

headline: Kenneth Arrow Was Here
text: Some readers ask why my argument that relatively centralized systems work better for health care than the “free market” isn’t an argument for government ownership of everything.

headline: Knocking, Twitching, Buzzing, Rasping
text: In most rock songs the landmarks are standard ones: the beat, the riffs, the lyric. Radian, an Austrian instrumental trio that played Union Pool in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on Wednesday night as part of a rare United States tour, sets most of those aside. Its music features sounds that are more often treated as glitches. Instead of melodies there are buzzes, thuds, creaks, high-pitched electronic hums or crackles of static. Silence too. There’s no predicting when an element that had been consistent will suddenly disappear. Radian replaces landmarks with potholes. It makes for a bumpy, mesmerizing ride.

headline: Dance Listings for June 10-16
text: Dance

headline: Go West, Wide-Eyed Easterners
text: The setting of a Pullman sleeping car departing Grand Central in spring 1914, bound for the Pacific Coast, evokes thoughts of adventurous pre-Depression train travel, when crossing the country was as much an endurance test as a glamorous jaunt. It suggests East Coast sophisticates leaving behind their cosmopolitan yet insular world to enter a landscape that opened their horizons in ways both physical and figurative.

headline: A Collection of Classics With a Cuban Touch
text: The Ballet Nacional de Cuba’s short season, which opened at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday, also concludes the ¡Si Cuba! Festival, which has brought all things Cuban to the city for several weeks now.

headline: Somalia Extends Government; Premier Fired
text: JOHANNESBURG — After months of feuding, Somalia’s bickering leaders on Thursday agreed on a compromise that extends the transitional government for one more year but, at the same time, led to the dismissal of the popular prime minister.

headline: Newt
text: But she turned ME into a cocktail-quaffing sheep.

headline: Ford Cancels Minivan Plan for Hybrids and Plug-Ins
text: STERLING HEIGHTS, Mich. — The Ford Motor Company has canceled plans to re-enter the minivan market in the United States. Instead, Ford said on Thursday that it would introduce a smaller, five-passenger hatchback version of the minivan that it was going to build and offer it only as either a hybrid or plug-in hybrid.

headline: Signature Theater to Open New Home With a Celebration of Fugard
text: Signature Theater Company has chosen the celebrated South African playwright Athol Fugard as the focus of its first year in its new 74,000-square-foot home, known as Signature Center, which will open in February 2012, the theater’s leadership announced on Thursday.

headline: You Can Feel Her Pain (Just Don’t Ask Questions)
text: The tantalizing thing about “Finding Sarah,” the Duchess of York’s six-part voyage of self-discovery beginning Sunday on OWN, is that not even Oprah Winfrey can pin her down.

headline: A Comrade by Accident, a Seeker by Design
text: “You don’t say much,” says the man who flirtatiously sidles up to Joy, the young heroine of Lisa See’s latest novel. He has a smile that’s “warm and embracing.” He leaves Joy “dumb with wonder and astonishment.” And he has a question for Joy’s father: “How many more pretty daughters have you left across China?” Perhaps the question is impertinent, but this is a man who can say whatever he wants to: Joy is fielding a come-on from Chairman Mao.

headline: Dogonomics
text: If this doesn’t convince Congress that there’s an unemployment crisis, I don’t know what will.

headline: An Inopportune Sex Scandal; the Republican Field of Candidates Gels; Addressing the Economy During the Elections
text: An inopportune time for a Democratic sex scandal while the Republican field of presidential hopefuls starts to gel. Chief correspondent for The Caucus at NYTimes.com Michael Shear, White House correspondent Jackie Calmes, Deputy news editor for blog development Megan Liberman, lead writer of the 538 Blog Nate Silver and national political correspondent Jeff Zeleny join Sam Roberts in New York. join Sam Roberts in New York.

headline: With NBC’s Finish, the ‘Big Five’ Complete Upfront Sales
text: NBC on Thursday afternoon became the fifth of the five big English-language broadcast television networks to complete the sale of commercial time ahead of the 2011-12 season in what is known as the upfront market.

headline: Questions Amid the Wreckage of Gingrich’s Campaign
text: It doesn’t require any deep thinking to determine that when virtually all of your most senior advisers suddenly decide to quit your campaign — as happened to Newt Gingrich on Thursday afternoon — your bid for the presidency isn’t off to the best start. Although Mr. Gingrich is insisting — at least for the time being — that he’ll remain in the race, betting markets now give him just a 1-in-200 chance of winning the Republican nomination.

headline: Lady Liberty Extends Her Family Tree
text: PARIS — For the last century or so, people wanting their own Statue of Liberty settled for a knockoff, like the version that looks down from a hotel rooftop in Pristina, Kosovo, or the copy in the bar of a bowling alley in Warrington, England. Now those with a preference for authenticity (and the means to indulge it) can buy the closest thing possible — a bronze cast made from the plaster sculpture that Frédéric-Auguste Bartholdi used to create the famous monument.

headline: Book of Tonys: Anything Goes?
text: WITH 14 nominations, will “The Book of Mormon” sweep the Tony Awards on Sunday night or come close to the record of 12 wins by another megahit musical, “The Producers”? Can Americans beat the British in a passel of play and acting categories? Can anything sink the U.S.S. Sutton Foster? And will it be gags or grudging respect on the CBS broadcast for ineligible-but-not-inconsequential “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark”?

headline: Maqbool Fida Husain, India’s Most Famous Painter, Dies at 95
text: Maqbool Fida Husain, an artist whose modernist reinterpretations of mythic and religious subjects made him India’s most famous painter and, in recent years, a target of right-wing Hindu groups, died on Thursday in London. He was 95.

headline: ‘Just Like Us’
text: Stand-up comedians have been straying into documentary film territory for some time now, with both Chris Rock and Bill Maher finding the form useful for airing pet peeves. The latest to cross that border is Ahmed Ahmed, the Egyptian-American comic whose “Just Like Us” is a laudable if lightweight argument for broader minds and thicker skins.

headline: Field Testers of Mini E Bonded With Cars, Study Finds
text: Given the brief amount of time that contemporary electric vehicles have been on the road, broad studies reflecting E.V. drivers’ user experiences are rare. But the coming findings of a yearlong survey by the University of California, Davis Plug-in Hybrid and Electric Vehicle Research Center reveals that drivers of a particular E.V., the Mini E, are an overwhelmingly contented lot.

headline: ‘Judy Moody and the Not Bummer Summer’
text: Take the animated adolescent flourishes of “Scott Pilgrim vs. the World” and apply them to a hyperactive child’s imagination, and you have an idea of the texture of “Judy Moody and the Not Bummer Summer,” John Schultz’s rambunctiously exuberant film featuring Megan McDonald’s popular children’s book character.

headline: SALVATORE SCARPITTA: ‘Trajectory’
text: Marianne Boesky

headline: CHRIS KRAUS: ‘Films’
text: Real Fine Arts

headline: ‘ALWAYS THE YOUNG STRANGERS’
text: Higher Pictures

headline: AMELIE VON WULFFEN: ‘This Is How It Happened’
text: Greene Naftali

headline: 167th Street, The Bronx, 2:57 P.M.
text: Photo: wet dog.

headline: Three Friends, Each on a Journey
text: The scent of perfumed suds hangs heavily over “Bride Flight,” a 130-minute fictionalized quasi-epic inspired by an actual contest known as the Last Great Air Race. The winner of the roughly 12,000-mile flight from London to Christchurch, New Zealand, in October 1953 touched down 41 minutes ahead of its closest rival. The movie incorporates vintage newsreel footage of the plane leaving London on a bumpy journey nicknamed the Bride Flight because many of the passengers were Dutch brides-to-be fleeing a country devastated by World War II.

headline: Winter and Davidson Are Doubly Honored
text: A decade ago, the Missouri School of Journalism and the National Press Photographers Association parted ways, ending what had been the jointly administered Pictures of the Year contest. Sometimes, however, they still see eye to eye.

headline: Five People Shot on Boardwalk in Brighton Beach
text: 11:30 p.m. | Updated For the latest updates, read the news article from Friday’s paper.

headline: A Rural Struggle for Subsistence, Rooted in Dignity
text: The title of Uruphong Raksasad’s “Agrarian Utopia” evokes the romance of rural toil, and also the political ideal, present in various Western back-to-the-land movements, of life lived close to the soil. And the film’s bucolic rhythms and stunning vistas of the Thai countryside give it a sometimes-idyllic quality. One of its subjects, whose long hair, plaid shirts and pointy beard give him the aspect of a hippie philosopher, espouses what sound like variations of locavore and organic-farming ideas.

headline: Shimmying Into Shape
text: As 1920s New Orleans jazz played recently in an East Village studio, a buxom dancer began a sultry dance. She wore black fishnets, a leotard and cherry-dotted bloomers. She had on sparkly lipstick, a boa and high heels — all in vivid red — as she led nearly a dozen women in a bumping-and-grinding class called “Flirting With Burlesque.”

headline: Activision Takes Different Approach to Mobile Gaming
text: You would be hard pressed to find anyone in the gaming world who won’t agree that Activision is the hottest game developer in the world. The company has surpassed its own video game sales records several times over. Earlier this year Activision made over $650 million in just five days from the sale of its latest hit, Call of Duty: Black Ops.

headline: Tony Awards Preview
text: Patrick Healy talks about what to expect in the upcoming Tony Awards show.

headline: Yes, No, Yes. Vanuatu Clarifies Position on Abkhazia
text: MOSCOW — The south Pacific nation of Vanuatu, which has engaged in an on-again-off-again relationship with the separatist government in Abkhazia, released a video early Friday seeking to clear up the confusion. In a brief statement, Foreign Minister Alfred Carlot said that Vanuatu has, in fact, recognized Abkhazia as a sovereign nation.

headline: Limón’s Spiritual Heights and Depths
text: José Limón’s “Missa Brevis” had its premiere 53 years ago, and it can take a bit of time and concentration to sink into its religion-infused depths today, especially for the agnostically inclined. (I cannot speak for the atheists out there.) It is worth the effort, however, at least it was on Wednesday evening at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater, when the Limón Dance Company performed the work with intensity and palpable joy.

headline: Trouble Ahead: Director Falls for Leading Lady
text: Voltaire’s observation “Illusion is the first of all pleasures” is the tag line of Monte Hellman’s grandiloquent neo-noir, “Road to Nowhere.” The dangerous temptation to embrace impossible dreams is also addressed in Tom Russell’s title song, a gloomy stylistic mash-up of Dylan, Springsteen and Cash. “Row, row, row your little dreamboat violently back upstream,” Mr. Russell sings in the sepulchral tone of a dour country prophet warning of inevitable doom.

headline: A Date With Bill Clinton, for a Donation
text: If you could meet any historical figure, who would it be and why? If it’s former President Bill Clinton, you might just get your chance.

headline: A Kind of Orthodoxy Built on Improvisation
text: The Vision Festival, a hand-sewn New York institution now in its 16th year, presents avant-garde jazz as a form of religion, complete with saints and sacraments, a clergy and a congregation. The sheer range of music gathered under its umbrella — detailed compositions as well as top-to-bottom improvisations, in all manner of instrumental lineups — suggests a house policy of ecumenicalism. On some nights, though, the festival organizes itself around a single artist, yielding fully to his doctrine. (It’s usually a he.)

headline: A New Church Organ, With Vocal Celebration
text: “You must really love music to have come out tonight,” Dennis Keene, the artistic director of Voices of Ascension, said on Wednesday evening, greeting the audience after a day of temperatures in the high 90s with little relief yet in evidence.

headline: Shortage Forces VW to Cancel Back-Up Cameras
text: Volkswagen will be unable to offer rearview cameras in several models due to ongoing parts shortages caused by the March 11 earthquake and tsunami in Japan. Autoblog broke the story after citing a blog post by a Volkswagen dealer on Thursday, and The Times confirmed the news with Volkswagen of America.

headline: ISABELLA KIRKLAND: ‘Nova’
text: Feature Inc.

headline: Q. and A. With Alex Brown
text: Alex Brown, a regular contributor to The Rail, answered questions about his book, “Greatness and Goodness: Barbaro and His Legacy.”

headline: Alone in the Wilderness and the Spotlight
text: The Frick Collection has long since mastered the art historical meet and greet. Last spring Rembrandt, seen in a late self-portrait, received fans in the Frick’s skylighted Oval Room.

headline: 2 Pairs of Sharp Elbows On White Tablecloths
text: In contrast to Roger Corman’s 1967 freakout, “The Trip,” no hallucinogens are harmed in the Michael Winterbottom comedy of the same title, a British road movie laced with lacerating laughs and starring Steve Coogan and Rob Brydon. Mr. Coogan does, in fact, smoke a joint, lighting up in the same house where Coleridge wrote “Dejection: An Ode” and indulged in opium, the soporific that enslaved him in “humiliation and debasement.” Mr. Coogan has made a career partly by riffing on narcissism and he’s in fine self-loving form, as is Mr. Brydon. For one man, the humiliation of choice here is fame (with a debasement chaser), while for the other it’s his incessant vocal mugging. Both give you a contact high.

headline: Wi-Fi Set to Expand to 19 More City Parks
text: Free Wi-Fi service will be made available in 19 more city parks, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced on Thursday in East Harlem, which would more than double the number of parks with Wi-Fi.

headline: The Implications of Assisted Suicide
text: Ezra Klein writes that he didn’t find the arguments in my Jack Kevorkian column persuasive, but I think our views aren’t actually all that far apart. Here’s his critique:

headline: Richard Bove Does an About-Face on Goldman
text: Richard X. Bove, one of the most bearish stock analysts covering Goldman Sachs, has had an about-face on the firm’s role in the credit crisis.

headline: The Pleasures and Perils of Creative Translation
text: The first modern French novel I read — the one that introduced terms like “avant-garde” and “surrealism” to my tongue — was “Les Enfants Terribles,” by Jean Cocteau. I thrilled to the extravagant antics of Paul and Elisabeth, brother and sister, soon to be sleeping partners, in “the Room” they share with teenage friends. Life in Cocteau’s Paris is “the Game,” with its own rules or no rules, a state peculiar to the spirit on the threshold between infancy and adolescence. All lovers of this slim novel seek to unlock the secret door leading from their own room to the Room on the Rue Montmartre. When I open it now, it is my cleareyed 20-year-old self in Scotland who begins to read, as much as the weathered, bespectacled “me” of almost four decades on.

headline: Up Front: Lydia Davis
text: On our cover this week, Lydia Davis reviews John Ashbery’s new translation of Rimbaud’s “Illuminations.”

headline: Rimbaud’s Wise Music
text: Some associations with the name Rimbaud are very familiar: the highly romantic photograph taken a few months after he first settled in Paris, already at 17 the dedicatedly bohemian artist, with his pale blue eyes, distant gaze, thatch of hair, carelessly rumpled clothes; the startling, much interpreted declaration Je est un autre (“I is someone else”); the fact that he produced a masterly, innovative and influential body of poetry while still in his teens; that he stopped writing around age 21 and never went back to it, engaging thereafter in various sometimes mysterious commercial and mystical enterprises in exotic locations, including a period of gun-­running in Africa (and, oddly, an attempt to enlist in the United States Navy).

headline: The Four-Story Jigsaw Puzzle
text: Q. In his family history, my father, William H. Zinsser, writes that his cousin August Zinsser moved his mansion, brick by brick, from West 58th Street and 10th Avenue to 14 West 68th Street. Can you find a picture of the old house in its previous location?

headline: Mavericks Win Game 5, 112-103
text: LeBron James went missing again in the fourth quarter, and the Mavericks were too much team to handle for the Big Three in Game 5 of the N.B.A. finals on Thursday.

headline: Battle for Libya | June 9, 2011
text: A fire was seen at the Rixos Hotel, where foreign journalists are staying in Libya’s capital, Tripoli.

headline: Google in Talks to Buy Admeld for $400 Million
text: Google is in discussions to buy Admeld, a display advertising company, for around $400 million, according to three people briefed on the negotiations.

headline: A Peephole Perspective on Tiny Worlds
text: TWO years ago David Revere McFadden, chief curator of the Museum of Arts and Design in New York, found himself thinking a lot about dioramas. He was installing a show that included work by Thomas Demand, known for slightly creepy photographs of rooms that look realistic but are actually fabricated with colored paper. “How reality is defined is one of those questions that has plagued human beings since the beginning of culture,” Mr. McFadden said. “I suddenly thought maybe there are other artists out there working in the same vein but on a smaller scale.”

headline: Vancouver’s Circumspect Superstars
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — On the ice, Henrik and Daniel Sedin, the twin forwards for the Vancouver Canucks, can rack up points as few others can. But outside of Canada and their native Sweden, not many people recognize them.

headline: The Night the Music Died. Really.
text: Chamber music concerts rarely elicit reactions more raucous than polite applause, but last Sunday, an artistic melee more appropriate for a Metallica show broke out at The Royce Gallery in San Francisco after a heckler interrupted a viola performance.

headline: Picking Up the City’s Garbage Is a Sweet Deal, and a Monopoly
text: Garbage is, obviously, a dirty business. But for Recology, the outfit that has had a monopoly on handling San Francisco’s detritus for the past 80 years, it is one sweet gig. And one the company would very much like to keep.

headline: A ‘Real’ Statue of Liberty
text: A French art dealer will seek to sell bronze casts of the Statue of Liberty.

headline: ‘One Arm’
text: Photos from the new stage production of a Tennessee Williams screenplay.

headline: Georgia Threatens To Abandon Russia Talks
text: MOSCOW — Georgia said Thursday that it might withdraw from regular talks with Russia after uncovering what it said were Russian plots to plant bombs in Georgian territory. The talks, which are held in Geneva, have been the two countries’ main line of communication since their war in 2008.

headline: Providing Warmth, Year Round
text: At the Springs General Store, a pine-shingled, two-story building that started life in 1847 as the area’s post office and general store, the small-town atmosphere of East Hampton, from the days before the glittering hordes, is miraculously preserved.

text: To the Editor:

headline: At the Nexus of Abuse and Execution
text: SAN ANTONIO — St. Clare’s is a small church with a tight-knit congregation in this impoverished south side neighborhood, a place where neighbors come for a respite from the gritty streets.

headline: Blagojevich Jury to Begin Deliberating in Retrial
text: CHICAGO — The fate of Rod R. Blagojevich, Illinois’s beleaguered former governor, who is accused of, among other things, trying to sell an appointment to the Senate seat that once belonged to President Obama, was in the hands of the jury on Thursday.

headline: Nine Killed in Attack on Afghan Wedding Party
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Armed men attacked a wedding party in eastern Afghanistan Thursday, killing nine people including the groom and his father, local officials said. Five others were wounded.

headline: Alabama: Tough Immigration Measure Becomes Law
text: Gov. Robert Bentley signed a tough immigration law on Thursday, and several civil rights groups said they would sue to stop it from taking effect. The law, which goes beyond an immigration enforcement bill Arizona adopted last year, requires public schools to determine the immigration status of all students starting in kindergarten and makes it a crime to knowingly give a ride in a vehicle to an illegal immigrant. It requires police officers to inquire about the status of anyone they stop if they suspect the person might be an illegal immigrant. Calling the law extreme, the Southern Poverty Law Center, the National Immigration Law Center and the American Civil Liberties Union said they were preparing a lawsuit.

headline: The Wowing of a Practical Person
text: AFTER her graduation from dental school a decade ago, Maryann Riordan had two major goals: the first was to buy a dental practice; the second to buy an apartment.

headline: How Tyrants Endure
text: WHY do certain dictators survive while others fall? Throughout history, downtrodden citizens have tried to throw off the yoke of their oppressors, but revolutions, like those sweeping through the Arab world, are rare.

headline: Peter M. Lehrer
text: Mr. Lehrer, 69, is the chairman of Lehrer LLC, a construction consulting firm, and a board member of the National September 11 Memorial and Museum at the World Trade Center. He was a founder of Lehrer McGovern, the construction manager for the Statue of Liberty restoration. Bovis Ltd. bought a 50 percent stake in that company, creating Lehrer McGovern Bovis, and eventually acquired the rest.

headline: College Fights Subpoena of Interviews Tied to I.R.A.
text: Boston College filed a motion this week to quash a federal subpoena seeking access to confidential interviews of paramilitary fighters for the Provisional Irish Republican Army.

headline: Exurb With Suburban Trimmings
text: WITH cul-de-sacs a hop, skip and short drive from major corporations, the town of Brookfield is in many ways a classic bedroom community. By that measure it has the look and feel of its Fairfield County neighbors.

headline: The Reluctant Mormon
text: Politicians are trained from the time they mouth their first public lie to be reflexively certain about everything. So it was startling and certainly encouraging to hear Jon Huntsman sound less than convinced the other day about the God of his Mormon upbringing.

headline: Sgt. Barney Longs for Home — and a Fight
text: Barely six weeks into their enlistment, the volunteers of the First Vermont Infantry had become bored with army life. Tedious daily drills and inspections had proved monotonous. Sunday services provided welcome relief from the exceedingly dull routine.

headline: Director of National Counterterrorism Center Is Resigning
text: WASHINGTON — Michael E. Leiter, the head of the nation’s main counterterrorism center, is resigning after nearly four years in a job that has increasingly focused on detecting and thwarting smaller and more diverse terrorist plots.

headline: A Gallery to Call Home
text: FOR years now, it has been the practice among some condominium developers to incorporate artwork into the design of their buildings’ public spaces, as an inducement to sophisticated buyers.

headline: A Diplomat, He Isn’t: Prince Philip’s Tongue Remains Sharp as Ever
text: LONDON — In a rare move by a man who appears to despise few activities more than speaking to the news media, Prince Philip recently agreed to cooperate in the making of a television documentary about his life. Although “cooperate” might be too strong a word.

headline: More Luxury-Home Owners Opt for Short Sales
text: Glen Cove

headline: Politicians Behaving Well
text: One reason many politicians behave badly these days is that we spend less time thinking about what it means to behave well. This was less of a problem in past centuries when leaders, teachers and clergy held detailed debates over what it meant to have good character.

headline: 55-and-Up Complexes Shift Gears
text: WILLIAM COONS Jr. didn’t sell a single house last year at Windermere Village, his development in Ellington, so the four sales since the start of 2011 strike him as impressive. His new sales strategy is clearly paying off.

headline: Changes in Refinancing
text: REFINANCING your mortgage now is different from the last time you did it.

text: No Tally Released in Co-op Board Vote

headline: Leonard B. Stern, Creator of Mad Libs, Dies at 88
text: Leonard B. Stern, an Emmy-winning writer, producer and director for television whose frantic search for an adjective one day led him and a colleague to create Mad Libs, the game that asks players to fill in blanks with designated parts of speech to yield comically ________[adj.] stories, died on Tuesday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 88.

headline: Nothing Soft About This European
text: DALLAS — The suggestion that Dirk Nowitzki had overcome injury and illness to keep the Mavericks afloat in the N.B.A. finals did not impress Miami’s Dwyane Wade.

headline: Tracy Reese Celebrates Five Years in the Meatpacking District
text: 11:20 a.m. | Updated

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: After Nuclear Crisis, Japan’s Biggest Utility Faces Insolvency Risk
text: TOKYO — Far away from the battle to contain the nuclear crisis at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, investors are increasingly edgy about a related issue: the fate of Tokyo Electric Power, the stricken plant’s operator.

headline: A Pest in Bruins Black and Gold Gets Mad, and Gets Even
text: The Canucks do not possess the good-luck charms the Bruins have as they try to right themselves for Game 5 of the Stanley Cup finals Friday in Vancouver, British Columbia.

headline: In Connecticut, Pondering the Loss of a Big Employer
text: STAMFORD, Conn. — Dino Sakakini, owner of a restaurant here called Layla’s Falafel, surveyed the dinner crowd on Wednesday night and sighed. Many of his patrons were still wearing security badges from the nearby headquarters of UBS, the Swiss banking giant, and Mr. Sakakini was contemplating what might happen to his business if, as now seems quite likely, UBS moves its sprawling trading floor to Manhattan.

headline: Rule by Rentiers
text: The latest economic data have dashed any hope of a quick end to America’s job drought, which has already gone on so long that the average unemployed American has been out of work for almost 40 weeks. Yet there is no political will to do anything about the situation. Far from being ready to spend more on job creation, both parties agree that it’s time to slash spending — destroying jobs in the process — with the only difference being one of degree.

headline: Yankees Consider the End of an Aura
text: In the lobby of the Cleveland Indians’ executive offices is a framed photograph of pitcher Fausto Carmona, covered in Lake Erie midges in the 2007 playoff game that changed everything for Joba Chamberlain. Carmona is focused, undisturbed by the swarm. The same conditions unraveled the Yankees’ Chamberlain.

headline: Pakistan Orders an Inquiry After Troops Kill a Teenager
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — President Asif Ali Zardari of Pakistan ordered an investigation on Thursday into the shooting death of an apparently unarmed teenager by paramilitary troops in the southern port city of Karachi. The shooting, which was captured on video and broadcast on national television, has led to protests and has been condemned by political parties and human rights groups.

headline: Aceves Displays a Versatility The Yankees Wish They Had
text: With Joba Chamberlain apparently needing season-ending Tommy John surgery and other Yankee relievers already out of action, the team’s bullpen is a shell of what it was supposed to be. Making matters worse, one possible remedy has instead become a valuable component of the Boston Red Sox pitching staff.

headline: Oakland Mayor and Gang Policy Mix Uneasily
text: An Alameda County judge is expected to decide this month whether to restrict the movements of people suspected of being gang members in the violent Fruitvale neighborhood of Oakland.

headline: It’s a Scandal, Sure, but Hardly a Reason to Undermine the Will of Voters
text: It takes one kind of brazenness for a man to send lewd pictures of himself to women he knows only through a few on-line chats.

headline: Gov. Cuomo and Public Pensions
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo campaigned for office vowing to reduce the ruinous growth in New York State’s public pensions, and on Wednesday he offered a strong set of proposals that would also rein in New York City’s skyrocketing costs. Although unions howled, such sacrifice is essential to preserve the state’s and the city’s most essential services. It is also fair that New York’s public workers — long cosseted by Albany — share more of the burden.

headline: Ally Is Said to Delay Its I.P.O.
text: Ally Financial, the former financing arm of General Motors, plans to delay its $5 billion initial public offering because of unfavorable market conditions, people briefed on the matter said Thursday.

headline: Out of Prison, Into a Vicious Circle of Debt
text: On Tuesday, I wrote about the Clapham Set, a Boston program that works with recently released prisoners.   It asks judges to waive their court fees if the prisoners complete an academic course and work with a coach who helps them get jobs and services they need to turn their lives around.

headline: Could It Happen Here?
text: The deadly outbreak of food-borne illnesses in Germany may seem a distant threat, especially since that strain of E. coli bacteria has never caused an outbreak here. Don’t get complacent.

headline: New Yorkers Try to Beat the Heat
text: As temperatures rose to a high of 97 Thursday, city dwellers took to the beaches, fountains and shady areas for relief.

headline: Budgeting for Insecurity
text: House Republicans talk tough on terrorism. So we can find no explanation — other than irresponsibility — for their vote to slash financing for eight antiterrorist programs. Unless the Senate repairs the damage, New York City and other high-risk localities will find it far harder to protect mass transit, ports and other potential targets.

headline: Prize Horses Slower, and Maybe That’s Good
text: Animal Kingdom, a horse who had never even competed on dirt, won the Kentucky Derby on the first Saturday in May and stamped himself the leader of his 3-year-old class. His time for the mile-and-a-quarter race, though, was an ordinary 2 minutes 2.04 seconds. Two weeks later, Shackleford, who finished fourth in the Derby, held off Animal Kingdom to win the shorter Preakness Stakes in 1:56.47, the slowest winning time in that race since 1993.

headline: Egypt’s Economy Slows to a Crawl; Revolt Is Tested
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s economy, whose inequities and lack of opportunities helped topple a government, has now ground to a virtual halt, further wounded by the revolution itself.

headline: What They Think in Massachusetts
text: Discount most of what you hear from Republican critics about the alleged failures of health care reform in Massachusetts, the template for the national reform law. The people who should know best — residents of Massachusetts — have just given their state’s reform law, which was enacted in 2006, a strong vote of confidence.

headline: Heightened Security for a Former Detainee
text: In the end, Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani did not avoid being sent to the so-called Supermax prison in Florence, Colo., after all.

headline: Muddy Waters Research Is a Thorn to Some Chinese Companies
text: SHANGHAI — Carson C. Block makes even Wall Street cringe.

headline: Cultivating a Prince to Coax an Ally to Change
text: WASHINGTON — As the Arab Spring grinds into summer, President Obama has turned on repressive Arab governments in different ways and at different speeds. He broke quickly with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya and more reluctantly with Hosni Mubarak of Egypt. He slapped sanctions on Bashar al-Assad of Syria and has encouraged a Saudi-led effort to ease Ali Abdullah Saleh out of Yemen.

headline: Bonnaroo: Returning to a Festival Much Changed
text: MANCHESTER, Tenn. — I haven’t been to Bonnaroo in a while — since the second festival, in 2003. The tenth edition starts Thursday, and runs through Sunday. Looking at this year’s schedule, I remembered that one of the festival’s organizers, Ashley Capps, told me eight years ago that he wanted to book Eminem. It sounded a little like a back then joke. Eminem is playing here this year, though, headlining on Saturday night.

headline: Five Mexico Players Suspended for Failed Drug Tests
text: Five players from Mexico’s Gold Cup team were suspended from the tournament Thursday after they tested positive for a banned substance, a serious blow to the team’s hopes to win the tournament. The five players included two starters, goalkeeper Guillermo Ochoa and defender Francisco Rodriguez, and three reserves: defender Edgar Duenas and midfielder Christian Bermudez and Antonio Naelson, who is known as Sinha.

headline: In Visit to Puerto Rico, Obama Has Eye on Mainland
text: SAN JUAN, P. R. — When President Obama arrives here on Tuesday — becoming the first American leader to visit officially since John F. Kennedy in 1961 — his feet will be planted firmly in San Juan’s historic district but his words will be aimed mostly at Puerto Ricans in Florida, New York and Pennsylvania.

headline: Romney to Skip Iowa Straw Poll
text: Mitt Romney will not participate in the Iowa Straw Poll in August, his campaign announced Thursday evening, a departure from four years ago when he invested millions of dollars and criticized fellow Republicans who skipped the event that is a traditional test of organizing in the state.

headline: His Second Chance May Be Fighter’s Last
text: Gabriel Bracero built an impressive professional boxing record: five victories and no losses.

headline: Training at Gleason’s Gym
text: Gabriel Bracero trains at boxing cathedral Gleason’s Gym.

headline: Governor Seeks Sharp Tuition Increase in Five-Year Plan for SUNY
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, suggesting that what he sees as rock-bottom tuition rates could be holding back the ambitions of the state’s public universities, introduced legislation on Thursday that would sharply increase what students pay to attend the State University of New York.

headline: Stretches of the Country Face Record-Setting Heat
text: It was so hot in St. Paul that a once-giant snow pile, the remnant of a long, harsh and suddenly vanquished winter, succumbed this week in 103-degree heat.

headline: A Competitor’s Drive
text: Damian Lopez Alfonso has one reason for wanting prosthetic arms: to be able to ride an unmodified bicycle and compete in officially sanctioned international events.

headline: Lottery Numbers
