headline: Gingrich’s Future in Question After Aides Quit en Masse
text: WASHINGTON — Newt Gingrich’s presidential campaign imploded on Thursday as his top advisers banded together and resigned, setting off a further exodus of aides and supporters and battering his hopes of a political comeback.

headline: In Harlem Buildings, Reminders of Easy Money and the Financial Crisis
text: At Riverton Houses, a middle- and working-class apartment complex in Harlem, residents noticed a few changes after new owners came in. Lobbies were renovated. New elevators were installed. A decorative fence went up around the entire property.

headline: Troubled Audit Opinions
text: On one side is an assessment of a company with a clean audit opinion from the Toronto office of Ernst & Young, and with bonds rated just below investment grade by Standard & Poor’s and Moody’s. It has raised billions in capital markets.

headline: Wade Putting on Show on Defensive End, Too
text: DALLAS — When a player scores as brilliantly, as creatively and as often as Dwyane Wade does, his defense tends to get overlooked. Wade has made that nearly impossible in the finals.

headline: Big Banks Penalized for Performance in Mortgage Modification Program
text: As the nation’s housing market continues to teeter, the Treasury Department on Thursday penalized three of the nation’s largest banks for subpar performance in administrating a government-sponsored program to modify mortgage loans for distressed homeowners.

headline: Split Verdicts for Man Accused of Terrorism
text: CHICAGO — A federal jury on Thursday found a Chicago businessman guilty of supporting plans to attack a Danish newspaper that published cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad, but acquitted him of the more serious charge of helping to plot the 2008 terrorist attacks in Mumbai, India.

headline: Old-Time Torture Tests Resurface on YouTube, and Tablets Take a Licking
text: THE advertising tradition of subjecting products to torture tests dates back to at least the 1950s, when the crooner Vaughn Monroe starred in commercials where both an RCA Victor radio and an unnamed competing brand were dropped from the top of a ladder, and only the RCA Victor radio remained in one piece.

headline: New ‘Ring’ Straddles Two Visions
text: “The Ring of the Nibelung,” Richard Wagner’s monumental, four-part opera cycle chronicling the battle between gods, heroes and monsters over an all-powerful, magical ring wrought out of a mystical hoard of gold, is opera’s answer to extreme sports.

headline: The Cultural Calculation: Museum Fees
text: The Metropolitan Museum of Art announced last week that it planned to raise its admission price to $25 from $20. Though the price is only recommended (you can pay a penny and get in, as the museum hates to see newspapers write, and as newspapers love to keep writing), the announcement has occasioned an outpouring of sentiment on the Web and elsewhere about the cost of museumgoing. Do sizable admission prices, even suggested ones, discourage lower-income visitorship? (Of course.) Should museums that receive taxpayer money charge for admission? (A lot of people say no, even though many museums receive relatively little in the way of public subsidies.) Do museums have a kind of moral obligation, like libraries, to be free? (Museum directors are divided on the subject. Some, like Philippe de Montebello, the former director of the Met, point out that almost all cultural goods come with a price. “Philosophically, what is it about a work of art that makes it mandatory that it should be available for nothing?” he has asked.)

headline: Friday: Elaborate Spectacles
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Uncle! I crashed and burned on this one, with the notable exception of LEAVE IT TO BEAVER and JOSIE and the Pussycats. Maybe that says something about me, but I don’t apologize for my pop culture preferences to anyone.

headline: Hustler on the Streets, Missing Both a Limb and a Capacity to Feel
text: Two decades before Joe Buck peddled his flesh in Times Square — as the dim, hunky hero of the 1965 James Leo Herlihy novel (and 1969 movie) “Midnight Cowboy” — Ollie Olsen was feeling the pangs of alienation that come from being a male hustler of great beauty and small intellect. Conceived by Tennessee Williams, who specialized in angels in exile, Ollie first appeared in a 1944 short story. But he is only now making his New York debut, on the stage of the Acorn Theater on West 42nd Street.

headline: Water Policy in Legislature Rode on One Word
text: With the Big Dry upon us, the longstanding fight over the water percolating under the surface in Texas’ 9 major and 20 minor aquifers was bound to get contentious before the end of the 82nd legislative session. And it did, at least for a while, because of a single word.

headline: A Competitor’s Drive

headline: The Long Hard Ride of Damian Lopez Alfonso
text: WITH only the tips of his elbows touching his bicycle’s upturned handlebars, Damian Lopez Alfonso pedaled along the Hudson River bike path on a cool March day. His balancing act elicited stares from disbelieving pedestrians and curious double-takes from fellow cyclists.

headline: Damian's Ride
text: Damian Lopez Alfonso survived a brutal childhood accident in Cuba that left him without forearms. Two decades later, he is a world class cyclist training to compete in the Paralympics.

headline: Probation, Not Prison, for Scalpers
text: Three men who ran a multimillion-dollar ticket-scalping business by evading the online security safeguards of companies like Ticketmaster and Major League Baseball were sentenced on Thursday at a federal court in Newark to probation and community service, avoiding as much as five years of prison time.

text: Citigroup’s revelation that hackers stole personal information from more than 200,000 credit card holders makes it one of the largest direct attacks on a major bank.

headline: With Bay Benched, Niese Comes Through

headline: Gunfire on Boardwalk Kills One and Injures 4

headline: Companies Spend on Equipment, Not Workers

headline: Prices Fall for Some Gas-Rich Shale Land
text: The gas-rich land of the Marcellus shale has offered some of the hottest wildcat real estate in recent years. But if Exxon Mobil’s recent $1.7 billion acquisition is any indication, the days of eye-watering prices are over. The oil titan is paying barely half the price such acres were fetching last year, as the frenzy has shifted to Texas. Cheaper real estate may even make gas assets look appealing again.

headline: In Court, a Victim Gives Voice to Sex Abuse
text: He had never met the young girl, recognizing her only through a 15-minute video he had downloaded that showed her being sexually abused by a man. Her circumstances were not familiar to him; he knew her only as “Vicky,” the self-titled subject of a series of videos popular in child-pornography circles.

headline: A Bank Regulatory Logjam May Be Easing
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration, moving to fill vacancies at several financial regulatory agencies, is considering nominating Thomas J. Curry to head the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, which oversees most of the nation’s large banks, according to several people with knowledge of the deliberations.

headline: Behind the Scenes, Plans for Insurance Exchange
text: Gov. Rick Perry has made no secret of his disdain for federal health reform or for one of its key tenets, a Travelocity-like state insurance marketplace in which consumers could choose from public and private health plans.

headline: Sun and Sand Attract Crowds, and Also Trouble
text: A sun-kissed army of teenagers and 20-somethings preen in flip-flops and strut their way down the jam-packed path at North Avenue Beach on a hot Saturday afternoon. There’s music blasting and plenty of boozing, volleyball and eye candy for almost every taste. This isn’t just a beach. It’s a single’s bar with sand.

headline: Edgar Tekere, Leader in Fight for Zimbabwe Independence, Dies at 74
text: JOHANNESBURG — Edgar Z. Tekere, who was imprisoned for a decade with Robert Mugabe during the struggle to end white minority rule in Rhodesia, and later unsuccessfully challenged Mr. Mugabe’s political domination of what had become an independent Zimbabwe, died on June 7 in the eastern city of Mutare, Zimbabwe. He was 74.

headline: Under the Dome in Bucktown, Restoration Goes On
text: For drivers stuck in traffic on the Kennedy Expressway, the restoration of the dome atop St. Mary of the Angels Church in Bucktown is providing a divine distraction this summer, as workers scale the scaffolding and then descend gracefully under a blue banner that proclaims “SavetheDome.net,” the century-old church’s new Web site.

headline: John H. Sinfelt, Who Helped Introduce Unleaded Gas, Dies at 80
text: John H. Sinfelt, a chemical engineer whose research for an oil company helped lead to the introduction of unleaded gasoline and significant reductions in air pollution, died on May 28 in Morristown, N.J. He was 80.

text: John R. Alison, an ace fighter pilot in World War II who helped organize and lead a broad American air campaign that enabled British forces to bog down the Japanese in the jungles of Burma, died Monday at his home in Washington. He was 98.

headline: After Jeter Reaches 3,000 Hits, Who’s Likely Next?
text: With Derek Jeter’s membership in the 3,000-hit club imminent (he needed 11 hits entering Thursday’s games), the baseball world can soon turn its attention to the players who could follow him on the path to 3,000. At first blush, the most logical place to look would be at the active players on the career hits leader board, which has Ivan Rodriguez (2,835 through Wednesday) and Omar Vizquel (2,821) right behind Jeter.

text: DALLAS — LeBron James glanced repeatedly at the final box score as he spoke into the microphone. He broke down the numbers, strangely making little eye contact with his questioners, perhaps hoping the bottom line might somehow change.

headline: Bonnaroo: Getting a Feel for the Early Crowd
text: MANCHESTER, Tenn. — June 9 (into June 10): The crowd math seems all wacky on the first night at Bonnaroo. Thursday when the campers are still arriving, the two biggest of the five music stages are dark and the 80,000-plus community is taking shape, figuring out the map of the remarkably shapeless campus on the gigungous field; it’s sort of the night before the first night, but it’s on nonetheless. People are ready for whatever. They’ll take whatever.

That is when she isn’t isn’t taking on a wildfire, hurricane, volcano or oil spill as the nation’s leading expert in disaster airspace coordination.

headline: Hitchens on the Art of the Feud

Naipaul, Rick Moody has thrown a friendly pie at Dale Peck and Twitter has supplanted the White Horse Tavern (or “The Dick Cavett Show”) as the best place to throw a bookish punch.

headline: Clip: 'Trollhunter'
text: A scene from "Trollhunter," about a group of student filmmakers who find trolls in the Norwegian countryside.

headline: Design Miami/Basel | Hella Jongerius, in Print and in Porcelain
text: You would expect to see the British publisher Phaidon Press at the Frankfurt book fair, not among the galleries at Design Miami/Basel. Nonetheless, the publisher has reserved a booth at the Swiss event next week, where it will display “Colored Vases (Series 3),” a collection of 300 unique vases by the Dutch design superstar Hella Jongerius, to accompany her monograph, “Hella Jongerius: Misfit.”

headline: The Guardians of Racing’s Slow Death
text: When injections of furosemide and doses of aminocaproic acid to control exercise-induced pulmonary hemorrhage are given to starters in the 143rd Belmont Stakes Saturday, it might be the last time an American Triple Crown race will ever be run on legal performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Challenge the Leader
text: Until recently, I worked for a small nonprofit that, among other things, runs an international leadership program for high school students. While working for its president, I had access to his contact list, which included many sex-for-hire people. (Mostly transvestites.) What people do on their own time is their business, but I feel that the parents of these students would want to know this about a man who will be escorting their children overseas for a week. I know I would. Do you agree? A. K.,NEW JERSEY

headline: A Mind of Their Own
text: Susan Dominus’s article on the Hogan twins, Krista and Tatiana, and their family was sensitive and insightful. Throughout, Dominus suggests the under-explored relationship among philosophy, spirituality and science. She does so without ever losing sight of these extraordinary little girls in all of their humanity. Most especially, the author is content with leaving questions unanswered. She acknowledges that there is much we don’t know. The girls provide the opportunity to revel in the questions, the mystery, that motivate great scientific discovery and artistic innovation.

headline: Going for Broken
text: The glorious ruins of the Erie Canal.

headline: Entering Darkness
text: Last month I went to a particularly cavelike theater (the basement walls, outside the bathrooms, were covered with synthetic stone) to see “Cave of Forgotten Dreams,” Werner Herzog’s 3-D documentary about cave paintings. The film is a rapturous tour of the Chauvet cave in southern France, a dramatic pocket of rock that was discovered, in 1994, to contain the oldest known paintings in the history of the world: portraits, up to 32,000 years old, of bison, mammoths, reindeer, lions, bears and woolly rhinoceroses — the improbable megafauna of southern France during the last ice age.

headline: The Getaway Car
text: For a long time now, I’ve been looking forward to this year with apprehension: 2011 is when my daughter, Julia, now 18, will undertake that very American rite of passage and “go away to college” — a phrase whose operative word is “away.” We live in Seattle, and in the Pacific Northwest, “collegeland,” as my daughter calls it, is centered in New England and New York, where most of her immediate friends will be going in September.

headline: Sticker Shock and Awe
text: Saturday night, Las Vegas. In this mecca of extreme retail, shops remain open as late as midnight, like fancy bodegas, because even a craving for Balenciaga ballet flats should have the option of satisfying itself on demand. While overall consumer spending still hasn’t recovered from the recession, there are signs that luxury spending may be on the rise. High-end retailers (Tiffany & Company, Hermès, Saks Inc.) have reported first-quarter gains. In America, analysts note, the wealthiest 2 percent of the population has been doing most of the buying. Where does this leave Las Vegas, purveyor of luxury for the masses?

headline: Scout, Ski, Fly and Shoot
text: A brief history of adventure and travel in America.

headline: The Perfumed Cuban
text: In three days, I saw, heard and ate things that you see, hear and eat only on a 3,280-mile Greyhound trip across the United States. I also smelled unusual things. Battle Mountain, a town in Nevada that The Washington Post once called “the armpit of America” didn’t actually reek of rancid sweat. It smelled like clean desert air and the sweetness of boredom. If I close my eyes, I can smell the burritos they sell at 4 a.m. in Wendover, Utah, near the base where the pilots who dropped the atomic bombs were trained. They smelled like melted plastic. After this trip across 11 states, I’m also familiar with the odor of the toilets at the station in Des Moines and the candied peanuts they sell outside the Port Authority in Manhattan, my final destination.

headline: Going for Broken
text: We paddled canoe-style; I sat in the middle and Marie at the stern. The water was clean and cold and deserted. We circled an island. Dead branches washed up in piles along the banks, making intricate symmetrical reflections in the nearly still water. Nathaniel Hawthorne described a ride on the Erie Canal in 1835 as “so tiresome.” From our small, slow rowboat, I found it mesmerizing.

headline: Is Iowa Still Relevant for Republicans?
text: Iowa’s Republican presidential contest just can’t seem to catch a break.

headline: French Court Delays Ruling on Lagarde Investigation
text: PARIS — A French court moved on Friday to postpone a decision on an investigation of Finance Minister Christine Lagarde over abuse of power charges. This cleared an immediate hurdle to her candidacy to lead the International Monetary Fund, but left possible future legal proceedings hanging over her bid.

headline: Morning Take-Out

headline: Beleaguered Greek Government Presents Austerity Steps to Parliament
text: ATHENS — Greece provided details on Friday of a four-year economic plan designed to extract the country from its deepening debt hole, including new taxes as well as additional cuts to public spending and a winnowing of the civil service.

headline: The Decline of Pimco Macro
text: I first talked to the Pimco people in, I think, 1991, when I was asked (and paid) to talk to them about economic issues; don’t remember the subject. It was a striking experience, sartorially: I showed up in Newport Beach in my gray business suit, and they were all in casual shirts and slacks, some (as I remember it) with fashionable stubble.

headline: Struggling College Graduates
text: Sally Cameron has an Ivy League graduate degree, and yet found herself tending bar. Mel Rodenstein earned a master’s degree in international affairs but was working in a “mindless” clerk’s job, eating rice and beans to save money.

headline: Following Up, Part 1: Battlefield Refuse, Social Media and Qaddafi’s Cluster Bombs
text: Researchers who try to document and track the weapons used in conflicts today sometimes find the unusual or unexpected. This has been the case several times during the war in Libya. After the uprising turned violent in February, weapons from Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s arsenals flowed onto the battlefield and formed a grab bag of killing tools — a mix of mostly formerly Eastern bloc weapon systems and munitions spiced with, among other things, American armored vehicles and self-propelled artillery, French and British mortar rounds, NATO-standard rifle and machine-gun cartridges, Belgian rifles, Chinese Type 84 scatterable land mines and Spanish cluster munitions.

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘It’s Late at Night’
text: Today’s poem, chosen from more than 650 submissions to our Found Poem Student Challenge, was written by Lakenya, who is 15 years old and from Milwaukee.

headline: What’s Up, Doc? New Looney Tunes, With an Assist From Mel Blanc
text: That’s not quite all for the motion-picture career of the Looney Tunes, or for Mel Blanc, the versatile voice artist and comedian who helped bring to life the animated antics of Daffy Duck and Tweety Bird. Those speech-impeded cartoon characters, along with Sylvester the Cat, Elmer Fudd, Wile E. Coyote and the Road Runner are set to return in a new series of 3-D computer generated shorts that will use some vocals previously recorded by Blanc, and which will begin appearing with Warner Brothers movies in the fall, the studio’s animation division said.

headline: Pensionscare

headline: Add Audacity To Understatement, And Stir In Patience
text: TEARS gathered in the creases of Nikolaj Hübbe’s eyes, but he wasn’t crying. Do you really suppose he’s changed that much in the three years since he left New York for Copenhagen? He was shaking from laughter, and his laughter was directed at himself.

headline: Hail the Amateur, Loved by the Crowd
text: THE crowd is taking over. Tasks that have traditionally been performed by highly skilled professionals are increasingly being outsourced to the masses, often with surprising results. And it’s not only production that is being crowd sourced. Judgments about the quality of that production, traditionally determined by experts, are also being turned over to the crowd. Champions of crowd sourcing claim that tapping the talents of the many, even the amateur or untrained many, can often meet or surpass the efforts of the expert few.

headline: Friday Reading: It’s a Seller’s Market For Used Cars
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Snowmelt in the Rockies Just Isn’t the Same
text: The summary of the new United States Geological Survey paper in Science Magazine was blunt. “Over the past millennium, late-20th-century snowpack reductions are almost unprecedented in magnitude across the northern Rocky Mountains,” it said.

headline: Dispute Between Vietnam and China Escalates Over Competing Claims in South China Sea
text: BEIJING — Vietnam said on Friday that it would conduct live-fire naval exercises off its coast next week, a step that escalated a long-running dispute with China over territory in the South China Sea that both nations claim.

headline: A Reunion of Sorts: Two Pieces of Unpublished Austen Novel Are Both in New York
text: Beginning on Saturday the two manuscript parts of the unfinished and unpublished Jane Austen novel known as “The Watsons” will not be reunited, exactly, but will be closer they’ve been in almost 100 years — just 35 blocks or so from each other. The first part of the manuscript, some 12 pages, was sold during World War I to benefit the Red Cross, and now belongs to the Morgan Library & Museum. The rest, 68 pages which had been in private hands in England until recently, is going on display for a week at Sotheby’s before being shipped back to London, where it will be auctioned off in mid-July.

headline: Unforgivable Behavior, Except When It’s Not
text: “Lying publicly about something like this is unforgivable and he should resign.” — Tim Kaine, former chairman, Democratic National Committee, on Representative Anthony D. Weiner.

headline: Golly Gee, By Jove!
text: Just one of my periodic reminders: quite a few otherwise reasonable comments have to be rejected because they contain obscenities. I know that’s the way all of us !@#$%^& talk these days, but this is a Times blog.

headline: G.M. Recalls Nearly 47,500 Cadillac SRX Crossovers to Repair Faulty Curtain Air Bag
text: General Motors is recalling about 47,500 of its 2011 Cadillac SRX crossovers in the United States because an air-curtain air bag may not deploy in a crash, the automaker told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. The action is part of a North American recall that affects roughly 50,500 vehicles.

headline: Afghan Leader Seeks Pakistani Help in Talks
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan arrived in Islamabad on Friday for a two-day visit, which was being viewed as an effort to ensure Pakistani help in the peace talks he has initiated with the Taliban.

headline: India’s Way: Jim Yardley Responds to Readers on Development in Gurgaon
text: I want to thank everyone for all the thoughtful comments about the Gurgaon story. India is one of the most fascinating assignments in the world, if occasionally a vexing one, given its complexities and contradictions. In the India’s Way series, we hope to examine how India works — and doesn’t work. We want to look at how it has grown, examine the unique ways Indians are trying to move their country forward and also explore the challenges ahead.

headline: Assisted Living or a Nursing Home?
text: Like so many adult children, Catherine Hawes confronted The Promise. You may have experienced this fraught conversation, too: Your elderly parent grasps your hand and pleads, “Promise me you’ll never put me in a nursing home.”

headline: Just One Look | 3.1 Phillip Lim Resort Collection
text: Phillip Lim’s Resort collection is based in utility rather than fantasy, designed for what he describes as “the artificial nature we create for ourselves in our urban environments.”

headline: The View From Behind the Betting Windows
text: Elizabeth Minkel started taking bets at Saratoga in 2003. She still moonlights as a parimutuel clerk, but she spends most of her time working as a production editor and books blogger for The New Yorker.

text: Dallas

headline: Stocks Plunge Amid Fears That Global Economy Is Slowing
text: Investors anxious about the outlook for global economic growth sent stocks sharply downward on Friday as the Dow closed below 12,000 for the first time since March.

headline: Fountain Is Reopening, but Not to Splash In
text: The new Whale Tail Fountain in the heart of New London, Conn., will reopen in the next few days, but it will now be used as a true fountain, and children will no longer be allowed to splash around in its gently gushing waterfall.

headline: Security Checks on Boaters Disrupt Idyllic Life on the Hudson
text: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. — For Bill O’Brien, summer had meant the bliss of the Hudson River ever since he went out fishing for stripers as a boy. But last year, after he was stopped once too often by law enforcement patrol boats with armed officers, he decided he had had it. He sold his 22-foot jet boat, convinced that a once-restful afternoon on the Hudson was just becoming too stressful to enjoy.

headline: Your Own Facts
text: “Just Google it!” has become a common cyber-snobbish response to questions that seem too trivial to merit a human conversation. But is it really an answer? Now that more and more Internet sites are tailoring their services to the idiosyncrasies of individual users, queries for “climate change,” “stem cells” and even “pizza” may yield different outcomes for different people. This may be an era when we are increasingly entitled to our own facts — but should we also be entitled to our own search results?

headline: Negative Online Data Can Be Challenged, at a Price
text: THE Web is like an elephant — it never forgets, and if let loose it can cause a lot of trouble.

headline: Fill-In | June Events in History

headline: Spain Approves Measure to Free Up Labor Market
text: MADRID — The Spanish government approved Friday measures intended to reduce chronically high unemployment by introducing more flexibility in labor relations, despite failing to get support from employers and unions for the changes.

headline: Paul Watson Recalls Civil War’s Whale Wars
text: .Here’s a short second segment of the interview I conducted last week with Paul Watson, the leader of the Sea Shepherd campaign that cut short Japan’s Southern Ocean whale hunt this year. (Part one is here.) He describes a book he is writing about the first real whale war, one that long predated his effort and the “Whale Wars” television series.

headline: Some Heart Disease Screens May Be Unnecessary
text: HEART disease remains the No. 1 cause of death in the United States, killing more than 800,000 people each year, and accounting for one in three of all deaths. It is no wonder, then, that screening for heart disease is a routine part of just about every physical exam given in this country.

headline: As Ally Delays Offering, How Have G.M. and A.I.G. Done?

headline: Exploring the World of Travel Options
text: Whether you are trying to find the best time to travel to a favorite spot or have no destination in mind, a little-known travel tool, Kayak Explore, can help you find the best flight deals to hundreds of cities across the globe.

headline: Joe Drape’s Belmont Stakes Picks
text: The New York Racing Association oddsmaker Eric Donovan set the morning line odds, and Joe Drape lists the selections in order of preference for Saturday’s 143rd running of the Belmont Stakes.

headline: Jerusalem Outings Go Beyond the Biblical
text: CASBAH-LIKE alleys lined with stone houses wound upward toward hills cloaked in pine and cypress trees. Hand-painted signs beckoned visitors to the shops and studios of jewelers, potters and other artisans. Just past a popular brunch spot with a packed terrace, Christian pilgrims from Russia, Poland and the United States gathered around a spring where Mary and Elizabeth, the mother of John the Baptist, were said to have met.

headline: Storm Claims a Venerable Catalpa Tree
text: Thursday night’s storm, in addition to forcing the cancellation of the Black-Eyed Peas concert in Central Park, uprooted and knocked down Dave Thom’s catalpa tree. It had stood in front of Mr. Thom’s house on West 217th Street in Inwood since at least 1934, where it appears, manicured into a delightful umbrella shape, in the city tax photo below.

headline: After 30-Year Hiatus, the Return of the IndyCar Doubleheader
text: On Saturday night, Texas Motor Speedway will host the Firestone Twin 275s, the first IndyCar doubleheader since June 28, 1981, when Rick Mears swept two 125-mile races at Atlanta. Saturday’s two 114-lap, 275-kilometer (171 miles) races replace the Firestone 550, which traditionally is held at the Fort Worth track at this time of year.

headline: Giant Rat Will Miss Tonys’ Red Carpet After Deal Is Reached With Stagehands
text: The Broadway stagehands’ union will not have a picket line by the red carpet at the Tony Awards on Sunday evening, after reaching an agreement on Friday morning with the managers of the awards festivities to allow union workers to stage the carpet, according to representatives of both sides. The union and the Tony ceremony managers had been in a public standoff over the last 36 hours, with the clock ticking to set up the red carpet.

headline: In Germany, ‘Watch Out for Communion!’
text: During the swine-flu crisis of 2009, I was living in Germany. I remember bicycling to work down Friedrichstrasse, one of Berlin’s main arteries, passing all the newsstands lined up outside convenience stores. The headlines of Bild, Germany’s best-read and most hysterical tabloid, were printed in such large type that I could take in the day’s news as I biked by. Often I would see one rather ugly word: SCHWEINEGRIPPE!!!

headline: Call It a Night, or Wait Out the Rain?
text: As Ben Shpigel reported in “Fans at Stadium Who Waited Had Plenty of Time to Dry Off,” the Yankees expected C.C. Sabathia to throw his first pitch at Yankee Stadium on Thursday night two hours before he eventually did, at 10:32 p.m.

headline: Out and About in Jerusalem
text: An artists’ colony, an Arab-Israeli town, a hike in the forest and some great food.

headline: Monetary Calvinball
text: I was trying to come up with a way to describe Raghuram Rajan’s latest on why interest rates should go up despite high unemployment and quiescent inflation — but Mike Konczal saved me the trouble.. As Mike says, it’s Calvinball — making up new rules on the fly to justify whatever you, for some reason, want. And today’s column was about that reason.

text: In a long article on Sunday and a string of posts on the Green blog this week, The Times has given readers a large body of reporting and analysis on the global food situation, including the risk to the food supply from climate change. I would like to end that run of coverage by pointing concerned readers toward the best thinking out there that tries to answer this question:

headline: Joe Lieberman’s Plan to Make Health Care Worse and More Expensive
text: So Joe Lieberman is proposing that we raise the Medicare eligibility age. That’s a truly cruel idea; as it happens, I know several people who are hanging on, postponing needed medical care, hoping that they can make it to 65 before something terrible happens. And if I know such people in my fairly sheltered social circles, just imagine how widespread such stories must be.

headline: For Gay Aspiring Politicians, a Workshop on Campaign Strategies
text: PITTSBURGH — As a gay person running for the City Council in Houston, which already has a lesbian mayor, Josh Verde figured he would have no trouble talking to voters about his sexuality. Then he came here, to a boot camp for openly gay candidates, and promptly flubbed his lines.

headline: Did J.F.K. Lose Berlin?
text: On Aug. 13, 1961, Robert H. Lochner drove to the eastern sector of Berlin. A radio director in the city’s American sector, Lochner used a hidden tape recorder to capture stories of families who were suddenly trapped in the East by the decision to build the Berlin Wall. Thousands had been fleeing each week, threatening the Communist state’s viability. Now Lochner watched as an elderly woman timorously walked up to one of the transport policemen and inquired when the next train was due for West Berlin. He never forgot the officer’s contemptuous response: “That is all over. You are all sitting in a mousetrap now.”

headline: Baking a Better Breadstick
text: On the popular television show “Glee,” the ultimate prize for a great performance is a trip to a restaurant called Breadstix. And in the real world, breadsticks are a main attraction at restaurants like the Olive Garden, and even pizza delivery services have gotten on the breadstick bandwagon.

headline: U.S. Weighs Cancer Risk of Styrene and Formaldehyde
text: WASHINGTON — Government scientists are expected today to declare styrene a likely human carcinogen, a move that manufacturers have long feared. Styrene is used to make those ubiquitous white foam coffee cups and food containers and is widely used in building materials.

headline: Russian Officer Jailed for Chechen Murder Is Killed
text: MOSCOW — A former Russian tank commander who was paroled early after being jailed for the murder of a young Chechen woman was shot to death in central Moscow on Friday in what the police said was probably a contract killing.

text: Last Updated | 6:58 p.m. As my colleagues Sebnem Arsu and Liam Stack report, even as the Syrian military moved to take control of a strategically important town near the Turkish border on Friday, protesters took to the streets in other parts of the country.

text: Analyst Brad Hintz has a solution for Morgan Stanley’s flailing stock price: Send the company to the chop shop.

headline: The Unhappiness Project
text: It’s hard to think of a less privileged creation than the second novel. When we admire a writer’s debut, it’s like falling in love across a crowded room; we are seduced by a part that we have mistaken for the whole. And when the follow-up reveals, as it must, a more complex picture than we at first believed we saw, our feelings are mixed. And so Dean Bakopoulos’s second novel, “My American Unhappiness,” is already at a disadvantage; if you liked his first one, you can be certain only that this one won’t be the same.

headline: A Critic’s Take on the Mortgage Modification Program
text: The Treasury Department announced penalties on Thursday against three of the nation’s largest banks for what it said was poor performance in the government’s main foreclosure prevention program.

headline: Good When He Needed to Be Great
text: The N.B.A. finals have become the LeBron James microscope, all powers of examination trained almost solely on him. Dirk Nowitzki as heroic leader? Dwyane Wade playing through pain and proving himself the Biggest of the Three? Jason Terry backing up his big talk with a crucial shot? In a real basketball world, those are all valid developments, but in James’s basketball world, they are reduced to background noise.

headline: Belmont Awaits Its Annual Return to Glory
text: If the last couple of years are any indication, about 50,000 fans will show up at Belmont Park on Saturday to watch the running of the 143rd Belmont Stakes, the premier race on the New York State calendar.

headline: The Golden Age of the Secretary
text: In 1977, the group Women Office Workers held a contest for secretaries, inviting them to name the “most ridiculous personal errand” they’d ever run. As Lynn Peril tells it in “Swimming in the Steno Pool,” her light, wry history of the secretarial profession, the winner was a woman whose boss asked her to take pictures of him before, while and after he shaved off his moustache. The runner-up’s task was to pick up her boss’s wife and newborn baby from the hospital.

headline: It’s Hot, and These First Graders Are Bothered
text: Beware the fury of a first grader scorched.

headline: Saudi Arabia, Defying OPEC, Will Raise Its Oil Output
text: In the wake of an unruly OPEC meeting, Saudi Arabia has decided to go it alone and raise production substantially in the coming weeks to meet rising global demand.

headline: Ellen Willis’s Pioneering Rock Criticism
text: Woodstock was a rip-off. Creedence Clearwater Revival eclipsed the Rolling Stones. Bob Dylan struggled with identity. Janis Joplin “was not so much a victim as a casualty.” As the first pop critic for The New Yorker, Ellen Willis wrote deeply original commentary on the music that defined a generation. She wrote about landmark figures and events in prescient, unpredictable ways. She wasn’t so much cranky — others pioneered that rock-crit stereotype — as she was rhapsodic, a fan who could be vociferously vexed by self-indulgent albums and overpriced shows. So vexed, eventually, that in the 1980s she turned her formidable analytical and literary skills to matters of (to Willis at least) greater weight: feminism, global politics, freedom.

headline: Strahan Joins Same-Sex Marriage Campaign
text: Michael Strahan, the former Giants defensive end, has joined the quest to legalize same-sex marriage in New York.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: The Big Apple Barbecue Block Party will have 16 pit masters from across the country at Madison Square Park (Madison Avenue between 23rd and 26th Streets) once again this Saturday and Sunday from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Plates of food are $8. There will be live music and cooking demonstrations throughout the two-day event. One note: go early, since some vendors often run out of food. On Friday, a preview party at the Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street (between Park and Lexington Avenues), from 6 to 8 p.m., includes food, drinks and films. Tickets for that party are $100 online. If you’d rather watch the pit masters setting up and smoking meats between 7 and 9 p.m., Blue Smoke will serve some food and drinks during a V.I.P. party that costs $250 per person but includes a FastPass for two allowing access to an express lane (those passes are sold out otherwise) and $100 for food and drinks. Proceeds from the event benefit the Madison Square Park Conservancy.

headline: ‘You Look Great’ and Other Lies
text: MY friend sat down and ordered a stiff drink. I didn’t think of her as the stiff-drink kind. An hour later, after our spouses drifted off into conversation, she leaned over the table. “I need your help,” she said. “My sister has a brain tumor. I don’t know what to do.”

headline: The Constitution After 9/11
text: At 11 o’clock on the morning of Sept. 11, 2001, David K. Shipler experienced what he describes, immodestly if not inaccurately, as “a moment of extreme clarity.” While most of us remained glued to our television sets in a post-traumatic daze, Shipler evidently sought nobler ground. His thoughts turned to the first 10 amendments of our nation’s Constitution. “There go our civil liberties,” he recalls thinking.

headline: A Novel as Big as America
text: Near the end of his vast new historical novel, “A Moment in the Sun,” John Sayles describes a street performer who “built an elaborate house of tiles on his little table, balancing one upon the other till the structure was almost up to his chin.” Spectators bet against “the master architect” and his precarious creation, but he keeps adding tiles and winning wagers. This performer is, of course, a stand-in for Sayles himself, who has also built an elaborate house of tiles and managed, against all odds, to keep it standing. The book opens in 1897, the year of the Klondike gold rush, and closes in 1903, the year after the Philippine-American War ended, and in between it takes the measure of America on the brink of the 20th century.

headline: Notes From the Underground | Macao Madness
text: The word on the street is that no one ever leaves Macao Trading Co. sober. The restaurant cum lounge is a haven for all manner of cool kids and gourmet-food chasers, and the management loves to get the customers sauced and smiling. As a no-holds-barred celebration of this mentality, the lounge, in collaboration with a performer who goes by the name Calamity Chang, hosts an annual Drunken Dragon Festival, where for five hours a completely free open bar and passed hors d’oeuvres menu attract a cast of hundreds costumed in either 1940s colonial or Chinese attire. At the most recent incarnation of the event, several burlesque performers took over the main room, which was packed with revelers and covered in a blanket of confetti. And yes, the snake is real. A smaller version of the madness, Drunken Dragon Nights, is held weekly, downstairs at Macao, and features live burlesque performances. Go to macaonyc.com.

headline: Lessons From Jane Austen
text: In 1990, William Deresiewicz was on his way to gaining a Ph.D. in English literature at Columbia University. Describing that time in the opening pages of his sharp, endearingly self-effacing new book, “A Jane Austen Education,” Deresiewicz explains that he faced one crucial obstacle. He loathed not just Jane Austen but the entire gang of 19th-century British novelists: Hardy, Dickens, Eliot . . . the lot.

headline: The Idea of Germany, From Tacitus to Hitler
text: Why is there a Germany? Part of the answer goes back to a battle fought in A.D. 9 in the treacherous marshes and dense thickets of Teutoburg Forest, near modern Osnabrück. As described by the Roman historian Tacitus, three Roman legions led by Quinctilius Varus had crossed the Rhine from Gaul, intent on incorporating the vast area known as Germania into the empire. They were ambushed and annihilated by German tribes under the command of a warrior named Arminius. It was one of the worst military disasters the Romans ever suffered. Some years ago, archaeologists discovered the site of the battle; the debris field was a mile wide and 15 miles long. Caesar Augustus, it is said, roamed the hallways of his palace, crying, “Quinctilius Varus, give me back my legions!” Henceforth, the Romans pretty much wrote off the area east of the Rhine and north of the Alps. The line of demarcation survives to this day as a cultural divide — beer versus wine, butter versus oil, Germanic versus Romance.

headline: A Memoir of Self-Destruction and Therapy
text: Emma Forrest’s memoir, “Your Voice in My Head,” is part of a literary tradition that began long before Susanna Kaysen’s girlhood was interrupted or Elizabeth Wurtzel got her first Prozac prescription. Indeed, on her book’s first page Forrest invokes the patron saint of mentally ill beauties with bad taste in men, as she describes how, at 13, she began making regular pilgrimages after school to the Tate in London, to visit Millais’s portrait of the drowned Ophelia. “I believe that she infected me,” she writes. “I was afraid . . . that I saw in her my own destiny.”

headline: Sleeping With the Gestapo
text: William E. Dodd was an academic historian, living a quiet life in Chicago, when Franklin D. Roosevelt appointed him United States ambassador to Germany. It was 1933, Hitler had recently been appointed chancellor, the world was about to change.

headline: Beach Retreat, Baggage Included
text: Ah, family. Isn’t it satisfying to leave your own briefly behind to drop in on another — and see how thoroughly they bungle it all up? This is the pleasure of “Maine,” J. Courtney Sullivan’s second novel, which delves into the secrets and simmering emotions of one dysfunctional family over the course of a single summer month.

text: Senator Charles E. Grassley chastised the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday for failing to detail how it handled nearly 20 referrals of suspicious trading at a major hedge fund, the latest salvo in an escalating face-off between the Iowa Republican and the commission.

headline: Crosses That Bear the Past
text: IF you are suffering from a surfeit of repressed emotions, why not pay a visit to Midtown Manhattan? The steaming summer heat gives you the perfect excuse to blow your cool with all the unprintable expletives your heart desires.

headline: Caucus | The Gingrich Campaign Implodes
text: June 10, 2011 - Michael D. Shear on what's left of the Newt Gingrich campaign. Also, Jim Rutenberg previews the release of thousands of pages of Sarah Palin's old emails.

headline: ‘Appropriated Landscapes’ in Ulm
text: Ulm, a small German city on the Danube, entered the contemporary photography scene with last year’s opening of the Walther Collection, a small museum founded by Artur Walther, a native of Ulm and former Wall Street banker. Mr. Walther’s collection of about 1,100 works from the late 19th to the early 21st centuries is noteworthy for its Chinese and African photographs.

headline: On the Erie Canal
text: Dana Spiotta joins Sebastião Salgado and J. J. Sullivan in this week’s issue. In her review of Spiotta’s novel “Eat the Document,” about two radicals on the lam, Michiko Kakutani credited her with erecting “an elliptical narrative filled with musical leitmotifs and searing, strobe-lighted images of contemporary life — a narrative that immerses us, headfirst, in the chaos and incongruities of the American scene while goading us into a melancholy contemplation of the country’s penchant for discarding the past.”

headline: A Father With Regrets
text: Friday, Steph asked to hear from parents who regretted having children. Most of you assured her that parents rarely regret the children they have, but sprinkled amid the many comments were a few that were starkly sad. Most of those were from mothers, and they were about the added price women seem to pay — in sleep, income, ambition, time, status — when they have children.

headline: Still Cute, but Now Sunny as Well
text: TESTED 2012 Fiat 500C

headline: Far Beyond the Clothes
text: Elegance seemed to go viral in the photographs of George Hoyningen-Huene. A Russian émigré in Paris in the 1920s, and a baron at that, Huene produced an exquisite quality of longing — or was it remoteness? — in the pages of French Vogue, where he was chief photographer in the most glamorous of 20th-century decades. You might say that Huene (pronounced HEW-neh) sealed the deal between modern-thinking couturiers and photographers, seducing us with light and classical forms. Afterward, nothing seemed the same. In her review of a 2001 exhibition that brought together Huene and his great friend Horst, the critic Vicki Goldberg noted “the two H’s influenced almost everyone else.”

headline: Erik Larson’s new best-seller; Emily Gould on “Your Voice in My Head,” the new memoir by Emma Forrest
text: This week: Dorothy Gallagher on Erik Larson’s new best-seller, “In the Garden of Beasts”; Emily Gould discusses “Your Voice in My Head,” the new memoir by Emma Forrest; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: Paperback Row
text: A GREAT UNRECORDED HISTORY: A New Life of E. M. Forster,  by Wendy Moffat (Picador, $20.) Between 1905 and 1924, E. M. Forster (1879-1970) published five novels, including “Howards End” and “A Passage to India.” Moffat’s perceptive biography explores the 46 years of relative silence that followed, drawing a picture of a sensitive, influential novelist whose homosexuality explained much, but certainly not all, of his mystery.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: SISTER,  by Rosamund Lupton (Crown, $24.) In Lupton’s novel, which is both tear-jerking and spine-tingling, a free-spirited sister’s death — perhaps it was murder — forces a highly conventional woman to examine the truth of their relationship.

headline: Inside the List
text: TIME TRAVELER: David Eagleman, who hits the hardcover nonfiction list this week at No. 14 with “Incognito: The Secret Lives of the Brain,” is the kind of guy who really does make being a neuroscientist look like fun. His experiments tend to involve things like dropping people off amusement park thrill rides (to measure the way time seems to slow down during near-death experiences) and hanging out in the studio with Brian Eno and the drummer from Coldplay (to see how professional timekeepers stay precisely on the beat). He wears hip ankle boots and designer jeans while dashing between TED talks and his lab at Baylor. In his spare time, Eagleman has even written an acclaimed collection of speculative short stories, “Sum: Forty Tales From the Afterlives,” that will be staged as a full opera in London next year. He’s also getting some traction with his efforts to start a new quasi-religious movement called Possibilianism, which aims to move beyond the dueling certitudes of traditional religion and atheism to explore radical what-ifs about the universe and human consciousness. One story in “Sum,” for example, considers the possibility that life on earth may be just a brief, pleasurable vacation from our true existence as gigantic beings doing the heavy lifting of holding up the cosmos. (“If you are thinking of dying,” Alexander McCall Smith wrote in the Book Review in 2009, “this book may not exactly increase your peace of mind.”)

headline: Cleaning Up an Online Reputation
text: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, takes note of the women who received Representative Anthony Weiner’s texts to make the point that their names will be forever linked to his in any online search. Yes, this is a high-profile example, but Paul says that all sorts of people can be negatively branded on the Web, even if they did nothing wrong.

text: Michael D. Shear on the next steps for the Newt Gingrich campaign. Also, Jim Rutenberg previews the release of thousands of pages of Sarah Palin’s old e-mails.

text: “Paying for It,” the memoir about prostitution by the cartoonist Chester Brown, has had to share the hardcover list with a lot of superheroes. But this week it is joined by “Life With Mr. Dangerous,” by the cartoonist Paul Hornschemeier, the fictional, slice-of-life story of Amy Breis. It is No. 6 on the list this week.

headline: Perpendicular to Brunch
text: ON a recent Sunday, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, was bustling at midday. You couldn’t move on the main drag of Bedford Avenue, between the people milling, the sidewalk vendors selling, and the groups jockeying for position in the sport of brunch. Day-trippers from Manhattan were headed for Smorgasburg, the food extension of the Brooklyn Flea; a line had formed outside Blue Bottle Coffee over on Berry Street; and the sign-up sheet at Egg, the little breakfast place on North Fifth Street, was oversubscribed.

headline: At Video Game Convention, a Crowded Field of Winners
text: LOS ANGELES — For anyone involved with the video game industry, surviving the E3 convention is an annual rite of passage. Many of the tens of thousands of developers, journalists and PR people here find themselves attending up to 16 hours of meetings each day for four or even five days straight, giving the whole thing the feeling of summer camp meets the Bataan Death March. In a good way. After all, we’re talking about video games.

headline: Croatia Given Conditional Approval to Join E.U. in 2013
text: LONDON — After six arduous years of talks on its bid for European Union membership, Croatia was told Friday that it should be able to join in 2013, but that its efforts to combat corruption and reform its judiciary will be monitored in the meantime in case they slip.

headline: Behind the Curtain at Your 401(k) Plan
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I explain who really pays for 401(k) plans. (That would be you.) And I also explain who truly understands how the money flows. (That would be pretty much no one.)

headline: The Week in Pictures for June 10
text: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Turkey, Iraq, Yemen and Somalia.

headline: Search for the New ‘Funny Girl’ Goes Online
text: It was never going to be easy to find the actress who could step into Barbra Streisand’s shoes and star in a new Broadway-bound production of “Funny Girl,” the 1964 musical comedy that propelled Ms. Streisand’s career. But the man searching to fill the role of Fanny Brice — Bartlett Sher, the Tony Award-winning director of “South Pacific” — has newly reckoned with how challenging it will be.

headline: Revealing Hidden Costs of Your 401(k)
text: Your 401(k), 403(b) or other similar plan isn’t free. In fact, it’s probably pretty expensive, costing you tens of thousands of dollars in lost retirement money over the course of your career.

headline: Airlines, Now Flush, Fear a Downturn
text: So far this year, the airlines have been able to repeatedly raise ticket prices while still filling their planes. It has been a lucrative formula.

headline: Nearly 600 Arrested in Asian Swindling Ring
text: BEIJING — Taiwanese police officials said on Friday that they and other Asian authorities had smashed a large multinational swindling operation, arresting nearly 600 people in six Asian nations in a variety of telephone and Internet schemes that bilked tens of thousands of people out of their money.

headline: Business Cards Go Paperless, or Almost
text: MOST people know the scenario: It’s been days, maybe weeks, since the big convention, and you are finally sifting through the hodgepodge of business cards you’ve stuffed in a bag, jacket or desk drawer.

headline: The Venice Biennale, by Design
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#556", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

headline: ‘I Do,’ and a Vintage Pony to Bind Them
text: In Sunday’s Vows section, Micheline Maynard writes about the wedding of Calvin Robert Ford, the great, great grandson of Henry Ford, to Sarah Jane Fox.

headline: Case Dismissed, but Jewelry Stays in Government Hands
text: Artur Hiaeve got just what he wanted this week.

headline: Twitter’s Secret Handshake
text: CHARLIE SHEEN’S meltdown took many forms: a cocaine-fueled rampage in a New York hotel room, an erratic radio rant, a vulgar one-man comedy tour. But his biggest contribution to current culture may have been more subtle. With a simple Twitter phrase, #winning, known in the parlance of social media as a hashtag, Mr. Sheen underscored one of the newest ways technology has changed how we communicate.

headline: Thousands Flee in Sudan as North-South Clashes Grow, U.N. Says
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The northern Sudanese military is on a “house-to-house” hunt for opposition forces in the embattled city of Kadugli, near Sudan’s disputed internal border, as intensifying clashes are forcing tens of thousands of people to flee, United Nations officials said on Friday.

headline: Expanding the Cultural Realm in Singapore
text: ON a balmy Saturday evening last summer in the Dhoby Ghaut neighborhood of Singapore,  a few hundred people — residents and in-the-know tourists — stood or sat in rows of plastic chairs taking swigs of Tiger Beer retrieved from an ice-filled inflatable kid’s pool.

headline: Restaurant Report: Two One Two Bar and Grill in Mumbai
text: Over the last few years, the Mumbai dining scene has been bombarded with hip openings competing for attention from a group of increasingly well-heeled residents. While the ambience at these restaurants might be buzzing, the food doesn’t necessarily impress. The upscale Italian boîte Two One Two Bar and Grill, which opened just over a year ago, is different: although the glamour set has already descended here, the draw is decidedly on the menu.

headline: Hotel Review: The Redbury in Los Angeles
text: THE UPSHOT

headline: Revitalizing An Auckland Neighborhood
text: The reopening of a long-defunct train station has transformed Britomart, a three-block-square piece of downtown Auckland, New Zealand’s most populous city.

headline: Seattle, a Tasting Menu
text: OUR waitress was in a panic, and no wonder. She couldn’t pinpoint the cradle of our clams.

headline: Hollywood Comeback Trail
text: A COMEBACK has been underway in Hollywood — that famous glamour-meets-grit area of Los Angeles — for over a decade now. But over the last few years, the revitalization has moved eastward along Hollywood Boulevard or, as movie fans know it, the star-paved Walk of Fame. Most of the recent renewal has been concentrated around Hollywood and Vine, perhaps the city’s most famous intersection. While souvenir shops and tattoo parlors are still part of the area’s kitschy charm, they now share sidewalk space with high-class hotels, refined bars and restaurants and even a new Trader Joe’s outlet.

headline: It’s Back to Nature at Rustic Spas in Quebec
text: A SOFT summer rain stippled the surface of the lake. As I toweled off my racer-back Speedo after a chilly swim, I spotted a muskrat busy building a nest beneath the willows. As campsites go, this clearing 30 miles northeast of Quebec City in the foothills of the Laurentian Mountains offered tranquillity. Except it wasn’t a backcountry destination — it was a spa with a wild streak.

headline: Fork by Northwest
text: To eat in and around Seattle, isn’t merely to eat well. It is to experience an exhilarating sense of place.

headline: Letters: Off-Season Summer
text: To the Editor: Re “Traveling Off-Season, in Summer” (Practical Traveler, May 29): If you go to Greece and avoid Athens and the popular islands, there are a lot of other lovely places to visit on the mainland that will remind people of what the islands were like 30 years ago. The less popular islands are also great. Small hotels can be very affordable and quite nice. You could easily spend $100 or less a day for off-the-beaten-path but still nice lodgings. Spend a little more and it would be even nicer, with hardly any company. Joseph Coates

headline: Reggae via Senegal, and a Tough Utopia
text: Aaron Goldberg and Guillermo Klein

headline: Aiming for the Fences With Our Belmont Picks
text: The Rail’s contributors welcome TWO guest pickers, Joe Torre and Mark Shapiro, for this year’s Belmont Stakes. Torre managed the Yankees from 1996-2007 and is now the executive vice president of baseball operations for Major League Baseball. Shapiro was the general manager for the Indians from 2001-2010 and is now the team’s president. Torre has long been involved with horse racing, owning the 2010 Derby contender Homeboykris, who finished 16th. Maybe that’s a good sign for the Indians (34-26), who open a four-game series tonight against the Yankees (33-27) at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Italian Neorealism in Softer Hues
text: ROBERTO ROSSELLINI’S reputation continues to rise — his large body of work on film and video seems to have inspired a whole branch of academic film studies — while the standing of Vittorio De Sica, the director most responsible with Rossellini for the worldwide propagation of neorealist filmmaking in the late 1940s, appears to be descending just as rapidly.

headline: Three for the (Short) Road
text: The Think City, Smart Fortwo ED and Mitsubishi i-MiEV hope to carve out a niche for the electric commuter car.

headline: No Charges Are Brought in Kahlo Case
text: In a setback for the guardians of Frida Kahlo’s work, the Mexican attorney general’s office has declined to bring charges against two art dealers who say they have an enormous collection of paintings, keepsakes and letters that belonged to the artist. The Mexican trust that owns the copyright to Kahlo’s work says that the works are fakes and last year asked prosecutors to investigate.

headline: Answers About Abuse in State-Run Institutions, Part 2
text: On Monday, The New York Times published a second article in a series examining the treatment of the developmentally disabled in New York State. In his investigation, Danny Hakim of The Times reviewed thousands of state records and court documents and interviewed current and former employees at nine state-run institutions that house the developmentally disabled.

headline: Just One Look | Helmut Lang Resort
text: It should surprise no one that Helmut Lang’s resort collection was dominated by macabre hues of gray and black. The asymmetrical lines of this silk dress follow the natural curvature of the body; it takes its inspiration from Jan Kempenaers’s photographs of the Yugoslavian monuments known as Spomeniks. How silk can be modeled after concrete is as much a triumph of drapery as it is of ideological sculpture.

headline: Ailey Dance Camp Coming to Newark
text: AileyCamp, a full-scholarship summer day camp with classes in dance technique for urban students, will come to Newark this summer. The announcement was made by officials at Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, the Newark public schools and the New Jersey Performing Arts Center. The six-week program will be held at the Newark Arts High School, from July 5 to Aug. 12 for 100 middle-school students ages 11-14 from Newark schools.

headline: A Spider by Any Other Name
text: Last week, while I was combing through the transcripts of Miki Meek’s interviews with American soldiers stationed in Afghanistan for this week’s What They Were Thinking, I became intrigued by repeated references to the source of their good humor in the photo: a camel spider that was loose amid their belongings.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $12,000,000
text: A four-bedroom four-and-a-half-bathroom condominium in the Park Millennium on West 67th Street that closed for $12 million was the highest sale of the week, according to Streeteasy.com and brokers with knowledge of the final sale price.

headline: Move Over, Estée Lauder

headline: $23 Million Payout to I.R.S. in Hollywood Plea Deal
text: LOS ANGELES — As the criminal case against the former Hollywood tax lawyer Matthew Krane heads to a conclusion — Mr. Krane is to be sentenced after pleading guilty to tax evasion and making a false statement on a passport application — the Treasury Department can breathe a little easier about the deficit.

headline: Quit Your Day Job? Winner of Lark Playwriting Fellowship Will Do Just That
text: On many if not most weekdays, A. Rey Pamatmat follows the same routine: Wake at 5 a.m., then two hours of ashtanga yoga followed by two hours of playwriting, before heading from Jackson Heights, Queens, to the East Village and his day job as a database manager at the Public Theater. He usually hits the sack at 10 p.m. — a lifestyle with which he has no complaints, he said, other than one: He has craved more time for writing.

headline: Boys Will Be Boys? Not in These Families
text: A 3 ½-year-old named Harry was playing at home in Los Angeles recently when his father walked in with a Target shopping bag. Inside was a special gift for the little boy: a sparkly princess Barbie doll.

headline: Navigating Gender in Pre-K
text: A little boy wants to… play with Barbies, wear a dress to school, use pink nail polish.

headline: CT&T Executive Denies Reports of Company’s Poor Health
text: “Don’t believe what you read,” Joseph J. White, the chief operating officer of CT&T E.V. Sales and Marketing, said Friday in response to recent news reports alleging that the electric vehicle company’s South Korean parent was unable to deliver vehicles, was reneging on announced plans for ambitious North American sales and manufacturing, and was on the verge of financial collapse.

headline: More Clashes in Somalia; Minister Is Killed
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Protests and violence racked this capital city on Friday, incited by the announcement the day before that the country’s popular prime minister had resigned.

headline: Government Says 2 Common Materials Pose Risk of Cancer
text: WASHINGTON — The government issued warnings on Friday about two materials used daily by millions of Americans, saying that one causes cancer and the other might.

headline: New Leader at Labor Council Had Earlier Quit in Protest
text: The New York City Central Labor Council, the main federation for the city’s more than one million union members, is well on its way to electing a new president: he is a former aide at the labor council who quit in protest last year because of concerns about excessive spending by the council’s previous president, Jack Ahern.

headline: Ristretto | On the Rocks
text: I became hooked on cold-brew coffee after working a construction job in New Orleans more than 10 years ago. It was strictly a regional thing then, everywhere in the Big Easy and nearly impossible to find elsewhere — you could find cold-brew concentrate in the supermarket, but most of the people I knew were given mayo jars full of the dark, dense liquid by an aunt or a grandmother. In the following years, I became a proselytizer for cold-brew coffee, gaining converts for a steep-and-strain method that seemed counterintuitive until you tried it.

headline: First-Base Umpires Must Keep Eyes, and Ears, Open
text: A common exercise at umpire clinics is to blindfold students and have them call close plays at first base. It’s not a frivolous thing. The idea is to teach the students to use their ears as an umpiring tool, to listen for the separate sounds of the foot on the bag and the ball in the glove — “a thud and a pop,” as the veteran major league umpire Mike Winters described them.

headline: Woman Found Dead at Bonnaroo
text: MANCHESTER, Tenn. — A woman has been found dead at the Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival, as the Associated Press reported, and was confirmed by the festival’s organizers. The Coffee County Sheriff’s office confirmed the death of a 32-year-old women from the Pittsburgh area this morning, and according to Sheriff Stephen M. Graves, the woman was found dead at her camp site by friends at 11 p.m. on Thursday, the opening night of the four-day festival. The state medical examiner will perform an autopsy to determine the cause of death, according to the A.P. report. Her name has been withheld pending notification of her family.

headline: Jorge Semprún, Who Blurred Line Between Novel and Memoir, Is Dead at 87
text: Jorge Semprún, a Spanish writer whose novelistic memoirs (or memoirish novels) drew on his experiences as a French Resistance fighter, concentration camp survivor, Communist organizer and Communist dissident, and who wrote distinguished screenplays for Alain Resnais, Costa-Gavras, Joseph Losey and other directors, died on Tuesday at his home in Paris. He was 87.

headline: Why I Don’t Believe in the American People

headline: TimesCast | June 10, 2011
text: Syrian forces sweep into the town of Jisr al-Shoughour; social media acts as a key conduit of information from inside Syria; and Defense Secretary Robert Gates issues a sharp warning to NATO.

headline: Shiite Militia Claims Responsibility for Attack in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD — A Shiite militia with ties to Iran claimed responsibility on Friday for an attack five days ago that killed five American soldiers, in what was the deadliest day for the United States here since 2009.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Turkey, Iraq and Somalia.

headline: The Case of the Mystery Study
text: Oh, wow. From Greg Sargent:

headline: ‘My American Unhappiness’
text: 1: Zeke Pappas is off to the Rotary Club luncheon.

headline: Reforming the financial system, the power of a German banker, and where does the housing crisis go next.
text: This week: Jeff Sommer with Louise Story on delaying financial regulatory reform, David Gillen and Liz Alderman on a powerful European banker, and Robert Shiller on the cause and future of the housing crisis.

headline: Blunt U.S. Warning Reveals Deep Strains in NATO
text: BRUSSELS — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates sharply criticized NATO nations on Friday for what he said were shortages of military spending and political will, warning of “a dim if not dismal future” and “irrelevance” for the alliance unless more member nations contributed weapons, money and personnel.

headline: Tony Picks From a Young Playwright
text: In the week leading up to the Tony Awards on June 12, ArtsBeat is asking several New Yorkers who are not Tony voters to pick their favorite shows, actors and designers in The New York Times’s interactive Tonys ballot.

headline: Mexican Cops: These Are Their Stories
text: MEXICO CITY

headline: Just How Much Is a Tony Worth?
text: A Tony award brings prestige, respect and glamour to the winning Broadway production. But who cares about those things? Let’s talk money. Does winning a Tony put people in the seats? Over at ArtsBeat, FiveThirtyEight contributor Brian J. McCabe unpacks the data. Read more.

headline: A Voice Actor Shows His Face and Hits the Road
text: JON BENJAMIN knows that you may well be unimpressed by his face. After all, you’ve probably never seen it, though his distinctive voice is familiar to viewers of the two animated series on which he currently plays the title roles, FX’s “Archer” and Fox’s “Bob’s Burgers.” That rich, deep, deeply annoyed baritone seems at odds with the impish, bearded actor sipping soup in a downtown restaurant on a recent rainy afternoon. After fans meet him, he said, they often complain online that his looks didn’t live up to their fantasies. “To read people’s disappointment is really great,” he said, laughing. “ ‘His voice is so wonderful!’ But then they meet me, and it’s awful.”

headline: Playing Up the Music in That Musical
text: SHORTLY before midnight on a rainy Thursday, Bono was headed to work, bearing plastic bags of takeout food from Esca up to a Manhattan studio on a nearly deserted West 48th Street. “Rise Above 1,” the first single from the cast album of “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” was due for release in less than a week; it wasn’t finished. Nor were the rest of the songs for the album, which arrives on Tuesday. That’s also the official opening night of the musical, with its songs by Bono and the Edge from U2. Its long, torturous run of Broadway previews has been — as a self-conscious new song lyric puts it — “a $65 million circus tragedy.” In separate interviews Bono and the Edge described the experience the same way: “humbling.”

headline: Man vs. Machine
text: In the epic battle of man versus machine, machines have a growing price advantage.

headline: The Statue of Liberty Is Being Cloned in France
text: She’s proudly welcomed our poor and huddled masses from her post in New York Harbor since 1886, and, as every child knows, the Statue of Liberty was a gift to us from the people of France.

headline: ‘It’s Always Personal’
text: Chapter 1: The Moment of Truth

headline: Peas and Mussels, Fresh Off the Farm, a Fine Summery Pair
text: FARMED mussels have many excellent attributes. They are environmentally friendly, inexpensive and ridiculously easy to clean (they come preshaven, with no hairy beards to yank off).

headline: App Smart Extra: Sushi-Making Apps
text: This week’s App Smart column helps sushi lovers navigate the confusing territory of the sushi menu, with photos, descriptions and other useful crutches.

headline: ‘Out of the Vinyl Deeps’
text: Dylan From Cheetah, 1967

headline: Reviving West Bengal
text: New leaders in the Indian state of West Bengal face challenges to draw industry to Kolkata, formerly the nation’s de facto business capital.

headline: Now Lobbying for a Poor Indian State
text: KOLKATA, India — Amit Mitra was recently telling visitors why he had just left his cushy job as corporate India’s top lobbyist to brave the tumultuous politics of his home state, West Bengal, by becoming its finance minister. A colleague barged into his office.

headline: ‘Optical Delusions’
text: “Otherworldly: Optical Delusions and Small Realities,” an exhibition focusing on dioramas of various sorts, is at Museum of Arts and Design in Manhattan.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘In the Garden of Beasts’
text: In Sunday’s Book Review, the writer Dorothy Gallagher reviews Erik Larson’s new best-seller, “In the Garden of Beasts: Love, Terror, and an American Family in Hitler’s Berlin.” Gallagher writes that the book, which recounts the experiences of the ambassador William E. Dodd and his daughter, Martha, “has all the pleasures of a political thriller: innocents abroad, the gathering storm.” Also this week, Emily Gould reviews “Your Voice in My Head,” a memoir by the British journalist Emma Forrest, about overcoming self-destructive behavior with the help of a gifted therapist.
