headline: Just One Look | Diane Von Furstenberg Resort Collection
text: Diane Von Furstenberg called her resort collection “Wrapsody Rap,” a term clearly defined by the first look down the runway — a wrap romper in a dynamic print that the designer describes as both hip-hop and heartfelt.

headline: Chamberlain to Have Surgery on Elbow
text: It’s official: Joba Chamberlain will have Tommy John surgery.

headline: Best Sellers Weekly Graphic: One Big List
text: How the best sellers would rank if fiction and nonfiction titles were combined on a single list.

headline: Macro Readings, Self-Referential Edition
text: Largely for my own purposes, some links to stuff I’ve written over the past three years bearing on macroeconomic policy. Read all of them, and you’ll have a good sense of where I’m coming from.

headline: Elizabeth & Sarah
text: On a rainy day in Boston Common Park, Elizabeth got down on one knee to propose to Sarah with a chocolate engagement ring. Sarah agreed and proposed right back. This homemade video tells their story.

headline: This Week’s Business News in Photos
text: The booming business in pet goods, Apple’s new iCloud music service and more.

headline: Multitasker Reverses the Aging Process
text: Well before just about every choreographer on the planet declared their allegiance to multidisciplinary work, Meredith Monk was creating pieces that defied characterization in their use of song, speech, movement, film and images.

headline: Bonnaroo: Mountaintop Removal, Bluegrass Triplets and Other Things in the Air
text: MANCHESTER, Tenn. — Some topics in the air today at Bonnaroo, other than the syrupy heat and the death of a woman at a campsite here this morning: mountaintop removal, courtesy of the cellist-singer-environmental activist Ben Sollee; and the metal-bluegrass-jazz connection.

headline: A Choreographer’s 2 Sides, Cut From the Same Cloth
text: To celebrate her company’s 25 years, the choreographer Susan Marshall has taken over two spaces at the Baryshnikov Arts Center to show, essentially, two sides of her artistic self. But on Thursday evening, watching “Frame Dances,” a gallery-friendly piece performed at the Howard Gilman Performance Space, back-to-back with “Adamantine,” a proscenium work for the Jerome Robbins Theater, was to see remnants of the same fabric. The material is respectable and deliberate, yet it’s stretched a little thin.

headline: Al Hubbard Joins Pawlenty Team
text: Tim Pawlenty, the Republican presidential candidate and former governor of Minnesota, has taken on board another influential Republican, Al Hubbard.

headline: Look of the Moment | Sarah Jessica Parker
text: The Look: White hot — it might be scorching outside, but the LWD (little white dress) sizzles when paired with a Côte D’Azur tan.

headline: Once It Was a ‘Miracle’; Soon It’ll Be an Artifact
text: STATESVILLE, N.C. — With blankets and children and umbrellas to ward off the Southern sun, hundreds gathered at overpasses and grassy wide spots on the shoulder along Interstate 77 on Friday morning.

headline: Bahrain Organizers Give Up, and Paddock Notes
text: MONTREAL — Along with the weekend of the Monaco Grand Prix and Indianapolis 500, this weekend is one of the biggest, busiest of the year in auto racing. It’s not only the Canadian Grand Prix here on the hot Ile Notre Dame in Montreal. It’s also the 24 Hours of Le Mans endurance race in France, where many of the greatest drivers will team up, starting Saturday at 3 p.m.

headline: Bahrain Organizers Give Up, and Paddock Notes
text: MONTREAL — Along with the weekend of the Monaco Grand Prix and Indianapolis 500, this weekend is one of the biggest, busiest of the year in auto racing. It’s not only the Canadian Grand Prix here on the hot Ile Notre Dame in Montreal. It’s also the 24 Hours of Le Mans endurance race in France, where many of the greatest drivers will team up, starting Saturday at 3 p.m.

headline: Taco Bell Promotes a Worry-Free Summer
text: Taco Bell is offering a new twist on its summertime advertising, giving it more of a campaign look and feel with a big idea that echoes an age-old thought about eating, drinking and being merry while one still can.

headline: Reviewing the Think City, Smart Fortwo ED and Mitsubishi i-MiEV
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Bradley Berman reviews three new entries in the electric vehicle market, all of modest footprint and all eager to be embraced by American commuters.

headline: On Eve of Le Mans, American Wins GT Academy
text: While the world’s attention was trained on the data security perils of networked video gaming, one enthusiast was riding his Sony PlayStation skills into the seat of a professional racecar.

headline: Baking, Minus the Oven
text: When my husband and I moved into our beautiful Santa Cruz rental we made a major sacrifice. We gave up our baking privileges, as our new place did not have an oven.

headline: She Can Be Tender, but She May Be a Killer, Too
text: A woman is wandering alone in the forest. She stumbles on the corpse of her lover. It gradually becomes possible, even probable, that she — jealous and angry — is the one who killed him.

headline: Dancing Danes (No Holy Water)
text: WASHINGTON — Because the three-act ballet “A Folk Tale” (1854) is governed by the idea of changelings, it has haunting aspects of pathos, nostalgia and perplexity that render it unlike any other ballet. Hilda, a human, and Birthe, a troll, have been swapped as babies.

headline: Cost of Imports Rises, Despite Dip in Fuel Costs
text: Prices of goods imported into the United States unexpectedly rose in May as increasing costs for consumer goods like autos and clothing overshadowed the first drop in fuel expenses in eight months.

headline: Chic in Review | Another Decision From LeBron
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: On the Street | Jet Set
text: Visitors may wonder who died, so many New Yorkers are dressed head to toe in black.

headline: Spotify Steps Closer to U.S. With Universal Deal
text: Spotify, a popular European digital music service, has made a big step toward finally opening in the United States, after two years of negotiations with the major record companies and many promises that its debut was right around the corner.

headline: Looking Back on Love and Loss, With an Eye on More to Come
text: “Here’s to life/And dreamers and their dreams,” sighed Barbara Cook, spinning out the word “dreams” so that it lingered like the glow on the horizon after a spectacular sunset.

headline: This Sunday: What’s Not in the Magazine
text: If you’re doing your job as a magazine editor, there’s a lot of wonderful stuff readers never get to see — because there isn’t room. This applies especially to photography. The editing process can break your heart. For a single feature, we’ll sometimes look at hundreds of pictures, leaving many great ones on the cutting-room floor. So for this editor’s note on an issue filled with spectacular pictures, I asked the photography department to pick a few images they loved that did not make the print edition of our “Voyages in America” special issue. If you click on the headline, it’ll take you to the story.

headline: Playing Like Children, but Much Is at Stake
text: Kate Weare creates terrifically satisfying dance phrases. And her fine company of four (Adrian Clark, Douglas Gillespie, Leslie Kraus and herself) brings these steps to full, luscious life.

headline: College Football's Undeniable Scandal
text: William C. Rhoden says that cheating is to the N.C.A.A. what steroids is for Major League Baseball.

headline: When Sleep Opens the Door to the Dark Side
text: Clearly, the romance at the forefront of “Any Night” has a very dark side. It’s easy to spot the clues in the script, by its stars Daniel Arnold and Medina Hahn: the small indiscretions that anticipate bigger ones, the mysterious family tragedies with questionable veracity, the warnings of death. It all points in one direction: meet cute, leave bloody.

headline: It’s a Crime That Men Are So Lazy
text: Most crime shows open with a murder — a brutal park slashing or a nighttime break-in by a serial killer in a ski mask. “The Protector,” a new series on Lifetime that begins on Sunday, offers an even more chilling tableau of horror: a woman, late for work, trying to hurry two children through breakfast before they miss their school bus.

headline: Video: Rhoden on the N.C.A.A.’s Undeniable Scandal
text: William C. Rhoden says cheating is to the N.C.A.A. what steroids is to Major League Baseball.

headline: Reads & Reactions
text: In this edition: the Brookings Institution responds, and elections — special, primary and presidential.

headline: Reality Check
text: Sometimes, after gorging for days on fast food and Snickers, one is in need of a palate cleanser. Or, say, after a hysterical fit, a bracing splash of water to the face. Or, more to the point, after a frenzied media binge in which enormous human and financial resources were poured into the production of story after story on a virtual sex scandal of questionable importance, a thoughtful pause is needed.

headline: 24 Hours in Sports: Journey Begins at Red Bull Arena
text: Can one reporter cover six major New York sporting events within a period of 24 hours and not lose his mind? We will find out this weekend as Mike Tanier documents his experience with live blogging, photos and tweets throughout the day and into the night. After tonight’s Red Bulls game, Tanier will attend five more area events starting Saturday morning and document his experience live. Follow him on the Bats blog and on Twitter (@FO_MTanier) using the hashtag #6sports.

headline: The Week in Pictures for June 10
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include an “anti-prom” at the New York Public Library, the death of a polar bear at the Central Park Zoo, and Representative Anthony D. Weiner’s admission to having relationships with several women on the Internet.

headline: Echoes of Rodney King in Karachi and Miami
text: A Pakistani television journalist who recorded the killing of an apparently unarmed teenager by a government security officer in Karachi on Wednesday has gone into hiding after receiving death threats.

headline: Battle for Libya | June 10, 2011
text: Libyan rebel fighters fought Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces near Misurata as others mourned their fallen comrades.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 10
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 10
text: More Photographs

headline: Help! Consumerism-Mocking Artists Just Ate My Store!
text: It reads like an old joke now, muses Hercules Dimitratos, shaking his head.

headline: Glossary of Abbreviations
text: Following are abbreviations and acronyms found in the trove of Governor Palin’s e-mails released on Friday.

headline: Mets’ Buffalo Pipeline Again Provides a Boost as Gee Remains Undefeated
text: PITTSBURGH — Dillon Gee made only two starts for the Class AAA Buffalo Bisons this year, one on April 7 and the other five days later. Playing with Gee in those games were five men who also served as his teammates Friday night with the Mets.

headline: Friends With Entanglements, Hoping for Benefits
text: There’s a certain nervous energy people often have when they’re with those they desire, especially when the relationship is not entirely secure. It’s a sort of performance energy, a directed one, and it isn’t all that different from the charge emanating from many a stage actor.

headline: Rare Infection Strikes Victims of a Tornado in Missouri
text: Several people who were injured when a tornado devastated Joplin, Mo., last month have become sickened by an uncommon, deadly fungal infection and at least three have died, although public health officials said Friday that a link between the infection and the deaths was not certain.

headline: Concern About Stockpiles Pushes Corn to Record
text: Corn hit a record near $8 a bushel on Friday, on signs that global inventories would drop as bad weather slashes acreage in the United States, the world’s top producer, and demand rises for livestock feed and ethanol. Worldwide stockpiles will be 111.89 million metric tons before the 2012 harvest in the Northern Hemisphere, the Agriculture Department said Friday. That was down from 129.14 million forecast in May. Prices have more than doubled in the last year.

headline: Judge Says Case Against Goldman Trader Will Proceed
text: Fabrice Tourre, the Goldman Sachs trader accused of misleading investors, failed in his bid for a dismissal of a lawsuit by the Securities and Exchange Commission. While Judge Barbara Jones of United States District Court in Manhattan did narrow some of the claims in her decision on Friday, she said the S.E.C. had met its burden that Mr. Tourre had violated a law meant to prevent fraudulent sales of securities. The S.E.C. initially sued Mr. Tourre in April 2010, saying he had defrauded investors by not disclosing that the Paulson & Company hedge fund had helped pick the underlying securities for a collateralized debt obligation and planned to bet against them. Goldman and the S.E.C. agreed to a related $550 million settlement.

headline: Rainbow Flag Goes Up; Letters Flow In
text: RICHMOND, Va. — The Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond ran a rainbow flag up its flagpole last week and has been hearing about it ever since.

headline: Federal Reserve Will Require More Banks to Submit Capital Plans
text: The Federal Reserve on Friday said it would expand a capital planning program to the 35 largest United States banks to ensure they had an adequate buffer in an economic crisis.

headline: Nowitzki’s Uncanny Play Rattles the Heat
text: DALLAS — In the space of eight days, Dirk Nowitzki mangled a finger, fought off a fever, rebranded fourth quarters in his own name and pushed the N.B.A.’s slickest, starriest team to the edge of a psychological crisis.

headline: Clinton Dismisses Rumors of World Bank Job, However Plausible They Sound
text: WASHINGTON — Rumors about Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton’s next job pop up regularly in Washington, but she and her aides knocked down a report this week that she was in talks to become president of the World Bank with more vehemence than with previous rumors, including that she was in line for defense secretary or might elbow Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. off the Democratic ticket in 2012.

headline: Brian Lenihan, Ireland’s Finance Minister, Dies at 52
text: LONDON — Brian Lenihan, who as Ireland’s finance minister led the nation’s effort to fend off bankruptcy during the worldwide economic collapse, died on Friday at his home in Dublin. He was 52.

headline: Podcast: Dodd-Frank, Housing and Europe’s Power Banker
text: It’s been a year since Congress enacted the Dodd-Frank financial regulation law. That might seem plenty of time to get the new rules in good working order. But as it turns out, many haven’t even been written yet, and lobbying is under way to derail at least some of them.

headline: A Successful Diplomat Tries His Hand at Politics
text: KONYA, Turkey

headline: Growlers at the Grocer’s
text: DeCicco Family Markets have been a valuable Westchester source for groceries, deli fare and more since the first one opened in Pelham in 1984. But three of the company’s seven stores offer something that truly sets them apart: a commitment to beer.

headline: President to Nominate Vice Chairman of F.D.I.C. to Lead It
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Friday that he would nominate Martin J. Gruenberg to run the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the agency that guarantees bank deposits and cleans up failed banks.

headline: A Journey Through Nuevo Latino Flavors
text: EXPRESS interest in the tropical-hued painting that dominates the dining room at Ramiro’s 954, in Mahopac, and you may be invited upstairs to a small art gallery, part of the restaurant’s formal second-floor dining area. But the primary draw here is the food, and I preferred staying in the more casual ground-floor space with the full bar and lounge, a rustic fountain and, not least, a view into this restaurant’s well-orchestrated open kitchen.

headline: Using Tutors to Give Students an Edge
text: To the Editor:

headline: Indiana’s Law to Limit Abortions
text: To the Editor:

headline: Warning Labels on Drugs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hamburgers Roll
text: Cars stretched down the shoulder of Deer Park Avenue in North Babylon on a recent afternoon, waiting for one of 22 carhop stalls at Sonic, the first Long Island outpost of a national fast-food chain, where 1950s-style carhops on skates delivered food to cars in the stalls. Some customers sat and ate in their open hatchbacks, legs dangling.

headline: Asian Fusion? Mission Accomplished
text: MANY restaurants on Long Island claim to serve fusion cuisine, but Asian Bistro Next Door in Woodbury delivers on the promise with dishes like a perfectly cooked, crisp-skinned salmon atop a mélange of wild mushrooms, accompanied by a miso-truffle cream sauce. Then there is the minced chicken flatbread, which includes Thai basil, a soy reduction and Spanish Manchego cheese. Perhaps the ultimate marriage of East and West is the miso Caesar salad, with white miso and white anchovy fillets in the dressing.

headline: At West Virginia, Innuendo and a Football Coach’s Exit
text: MORGANTOWN, W.Va. — On a lazy weekday afternoon, storm clouds gathered as the future of the West Virginia football coach Bill Stewart became hazier. Inside Mario’s Fishbowl Bar and Grill, a hangout popular with the campus crowd, the beer was cold and the conversation, like the signature chicken wings, had a kick to it.

headline: Sea Lions Make a Party, Don’t You Think?
text: Kristin Davis is an elephant hunter.

headline: Doing Business in Russia
text: To the Editor:

headline: Antibiotics in Farm Animals
text: To the Editor:

headline: Top-Rated Toppings
text: The entire product line of  the Purple Pear by Tina consists of six dessert sauces — small but mighty, if you go by the accolades.

headline: An Elegant Spinoff With Italian Flair
text: LA PERGOLA looks like a typical neighborhood Italian restaurant — the kind you are likely to find in a residential section of East Haven. But like its polished marble floors, much of the food is unusually well crafted.

headline: Indian Fare for Those on the Go
text: Hurry Chutney, a 40-table Indian restaurant that opened last July in Somerville, is not the kind of place that invites lingering. Its name and its strip-mall location suggest as much.

headline: Flavors of Middle East, and Its Hospitality, Too
text: WHEN the Four Seasons Kebab House in Montclair opened last fall, a generous $9.95 lunch special earned it a steady clientele. Now that spring has blinked by, a wider audience is discovering how lovely it can be to linger in the restaurant’s cozy courtyard of an evening, lulled by a gurgling fountain, sated by a meal as heavy or healthy as you desire, and doted upon by an owner so friendly you halfway expect him to tell you not to bother paying the bill.

headline: Ronald’s Exit Interview
text: McDonald’s Corp. is standing by its clown. The 48-year-old, red-haired mascot has come under fire from health-care professionals and consumer groups who, in recent days, have asked the fast-food chain to retire Ronald McDonald.

headline: A Summer Firepot, a ‘Safe’ Label, and Two Life-Altering Explosions
text: They said it was like napalm: it exploded in a flash, stuck to skin and clothing, and refused to stop burning.

headline: For Some in Congress, an Unexpected Thank-You Note
text: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has written to members of Congress thanking them for criticizing President Obama last week over his involvement in the NATO-led military campaign in Libya.

headline: Celebrating Hopper, a Favorite Son
text: Nyack, N.Y.

headline: Folk Heroes’ Kin Keep Legacy but Carve Own Path
text: WHEN Tao Seeger took the stage at the Tarrytown Music Hall in April at a benefit for the Hudson River Sloop Clearwater environmental organization, he quipped that he hoped his grandfather wouldn’t come after him with an ax. He then began a free-form banjo performance whose electronic effects owed more to Jimi Hendrix than to the folk-singing legend Pete Seeger.

headline: The Park Is Elevated. Its Crime Rate Is Anything But.
text: The images on Christine C. Quinn’s television a few years ago would seem to have been a worst nightmare for everyone — including her — involved in a highly anticipated new attraction for tourists and locals.

headline: Death by Nostalgia
text: THE modern historic preservation movement started in New York City in the early 1960s, when a band of locals pushed the issue into popular awareness with their unsuccessful effort to block the destruction of the old Pennsylvania Station.

headline: ‘Rhapsody’ and More: Gershwins’ Nice Work
Truck Dealers Win $2 Billion in Ford Suit
text: DETROIT — The Ford Motor Company must pay $2 billion in a class-action lawsuit accusing it of overcharging commercial truck dealerships over an 11-year period, an Ohio judge ruled on Friday.

headline: Live, From Sag Harbor, Darrell Hammond in ‘Tru’
text: The voice, first heard from a pitch-dark stage, sounds feminine and oddly tinny. But when the lights come up at the Bay Street Theater in Sag Harbor, the speaker is a man. It’s Darrell Hammond, the expert impersonator from “Saturday Night Live,” delivering a precise embodiment of Truman Capote in “Tru,” Jay Presson Allen’s 1989 one-man play about the flamboyant author remembered as much for his distinctive drawl and mannerisms as for his elegant prose and wit.

headline: Blocking Elizabeth Warren
text: It’s official: Elizabeth Warren will return to the torture chamber known as the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform on July 14. Earlier this week, Darrell Issa, the California Republican who is chairman of the committee, tweeted the news. Apparently, Democrats aren’t the only ones who use Twitter to harass women.

headline: Paying Tribute to ‘Subversive’ Album
text: IN a musician’s life, few moments reveal themselves to be genuinely subversive. But when the clarinetist Evan Ziporyn first heard Brian Eno’s “Music for Airports” in 1978, he knew such a moment was at hand.

headline: In E-Mails, a Glimpse From Inside Palin’s Rise
text: JUNEAU, Alaska — Few could have been more surprised than Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska when Senator John McCain picked her as his running mate in 2008.

headline: Music Festival Celebrates Spirits of Norfolk’s Past
text: LAST summer, when the renowned clarinetist Richard Stoltzman visited the Norfolk Chamber Music Festival, he was given lodging in the Sibelius Room. Occupied by the fabled Finnish composer Jean Sibelius nearly a century ago, the room, nestled in a stately mansion on the festival grounds, was an enviable accommodation, save for the warning with which Mr. Stoltzman said it came: “Beware of the ghosts.”

headline: What’s to Be Done With 15 Feet of Snow in June? Utah Knows
text: LITTLE COTTONWOOD CANYON, Utah — At the base of a slope that at this time of year usually tests the skills of mountain bikers, roughly 60 skiers and snowboarders, hoping to get first tracks on the mountain, waited for the 8 a.m. opening of the tram at Snowbird resort.

headline: Art for the Masses, and by the Masses
text: Not all the art is for sale at Art All Night, an annual celebration in Trenton to be held next weekend at the Roebling Wire Works factory building and a park adjacent to it. And not all the artists are professionals; far from it.

headline: A Man in Love, Despite His Best Efforts
text: The thing to keep in mind about “The Misanthrope” is that in 17th-century France, you could apparently be arrested for insulting a man’s sonnet. Even though it was in the privacy of your girlfriend’s living room. And even though he specifically asked for your opinion and begged you to be brutally honest.

headline: Bruins’ Thomas Is Stopping Canucks’ Shots, and Doling Out a Few
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — The Boston Bruins charged back into these Stanley Cup finals behind an offense that exploded for 12 goals in two victories, a defense that rendered Vancouver’s offense invisible and a raucous home crowd.

headline: Report Blasts Management Style of Nuclear Regulatory Commission Chairman
text: WASHINGTON — Gregory B. Jaczko, the chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and the subject of a harsh new investigative report from his own agency, finds himself in the cross-fire of a 30-year political battle over disposal of radioactive waste from the nation’s nuclear power plants and weapons program.

headline: Big Kindergarten Wait List Limits City’s Pre-K Slots
text: There were more applications for children to enter prekindergarten classes in New York City this year than last, but a smaller proportion of them ended up getting in: 68 percent, down from 72 percent.

headline: The World This Week
text: A week of sex scandals and a rare appearance by Steve Jobs of Apple Inc.

headline: The Poster Plant of Health Food Can Pack Disease Risks
text: Sprouts are a fixture of salad bars and the epitome of health food to many people. But the reality can be very different.

headline: Talking Truth to NATO
text: Defense Secretary Robert Gates spoke bluntly to America’s NATO allies on Friday. They needed to hear it.

headline: U.S. Sending Training Agents to Afghanistan to Stem Infiltration of Local Forces
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Concerned over the growing pattern of Afghan soldiers and police officers attacking their coalition counterparts, the American military is sending 80 counterintelligence agents to Afghanistan to help stem the threat of Taliban infiltration in the Afghan National Security Forces, military officials said Friday.

headline: Picturing Big Bethel
text: On June 10, 1861, Confederate and Union forces met in what was arguably the first land battle of the Civil War. And while the Battle of Bethel is relatively forgotten, little more than a footnote in Civil War history and dwarfed by later engagements that were far more ambitious, costly and consequential, it is significant for leaving us one of the earliest and most detailed battlefield maps of the conflict.

headline: Subprime Education
text: The Obama administration is right to tighten rules for for-profit colleges, which have come under scrutiny for deceptive practices and burying students in unreasonable debt. But the Department of Education is limited in its regulatory authority. It is up to Congress to rein in abuses by toughening the laws that govern this industry.

headline: At Triple Crown Race Known for Its Distance, Familiarity Can Go a Long Way
text: Dale Romans is ready to go home. He likes New York just fine, but he has been here for nearly two weeks, far from his old Kentucky home, getting his Preakness champion, Shackleford, ready for the 143rd running of the Belmont Stakes on Saturday.

headline: TimesCast | Syrian Unrest
text: Syrian forces swept into the village of Jisr al-Shoughour, near the border with Turkey, and residents reported that military helicopters were firing at moving objects.

headline: Viewership of N.B.A. Finals Stays Steady at About 16 Million
text: The Dallas-Miami series is proving just about as popular as last year’s Boston-Lakers finals. The average viewership through the first five games on ABC is 16.08 million, down slightly from 16.15 million last year. Game 5, which was won by Dallas on Thursday, generated 18.3 million viewers, down from last year’s 18.7 million. ¶ Cappie Pondexter scored 21 points, including the winning jumper with 8.1 seconds left, to give the Liberty an 81-80 road victory over the Indiana Fever. Plenette Pierson added 13 points for the Liberty (2-0), which won after squandering an 18-point lead in the second half. (AP)

headline: TimesCast | Secretary Gates Warns NATO
text: Defense Secretary Robert Gates issues a sharp warning to NATO in his final address.

headline: Critics Fume Over Intensity of News Coverage for Palin’s Messages
text: News organizations mobilized teams of reporters and even recruited online volunteers to scan more than 24,000 pages of e-mails from Sarah Palin that were released on Friday, prompting some critics to accuse the news media of overkill at best and vigilantism at worst.

headline: TimesCast | Sifting Fact From Fiction
text: New videos of Syrian security forces have surfaced online that contradict official government accounts.

headline: At Picnic for Black Mormons, No Sign of Church’s Biased Past
text: COTTONWOOD HEIGHTS, Utah — On Christmas Day in 1964, the day before Darius A. Gray was to be baptized as a Mormon, he learned that the church would not allow a black man, like him, to be in the priesthood.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,450 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,599 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Opposition Is Split on How to Reshape Yemen
text: SANA, Yemen — The protesters, arrayed in the tens of thousands under a blazing sun, pumped their fists in unison as they stood on the hot tarmac on Friday and chanted triumphantly, “The people, at last, have defeated the regime!”

headline: A Slaughterhouse in Brooklyn, and Misery Next Door
text: For decades now, the pattern has been the same: New York City factories fall prey to the hunger for offbeat places to live, and once-gritty industrial neighborhoods like SoHo, TriBeCa, Dumbo and the meatpacking district are transformed into enviable residential enclaves.

headline: Massachusetts: Six Seals Are Found Shot to Death
text: Six gray seals have been found shot to death in recent weeks on Cape Cod beaches. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is investigating, but it is unclear whether the seals were shot at sea or on land. Five were shot in the head, said Todd Nickerson, a special agent for the agency. A sixth was discovered on Friday and was still being analyzed, the International Fund for Animal Welfare said. All were discovered on beaches between Dennis and Chatham. New England’s seal population has been growing, and some fishermen have complained that the animals damage their nets and eat too many fish. Under the Marine Mammal Protection Act, anyone who hurts or kills seals can face up to $100,000 in fines and a year in prison.

headline: N.A.A.C.P. on Defensive as Suit on Charter Schools Splits Group’s Supporters
text: In some ways, it seems like a natural cause for the N.A.A.C.P.: students — many of them poor, most of them black — treated as second-class citizens when the public schools they attended had to share buildings with charter schools. A lawsuit filed last month by the N.A.A.C.P. and the United Federation of Teachers described children having to eat lunch so early it might as well be breakfast, and getting less exercise because gym hours were evenly divided between the schools despite big differences in their enrollment sizes.

headline: Cuomo Seeks Tougher Laws for Texting While Driving
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, joining officials in other states who have sought steep penalties for phone-wielding motorists, said on Friday he would introduce legislation to crack down on drivers who text, post on Twitter or otherwise distract themselves with handheld electronics while at the wheel.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: Minnesota: F.B.I. Identifies Suicide Bomber
text: Federal authorities have identified a Minnesota man as one of the suicide bombers in an attack in Mogadishu, Somalia, on May 30. The man, Farah Mohamed Beledi, 27, was identified using his fingerprints, the F.B.I. said. Last summer, Mr. Beledi was charged with terrorism offenses in Minneapolis for joining the Shabab militant group in Somalia. The attack at a peacekeeping base in Mogadishu killed three people. The F.B.I. is seeking to identify a second suicide bomber in the attack.

headline: Saturday: Attempt to Enter Dead Space
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I’d like to personally thank Gary Cee for restoring my faith in myself as a solver. Not only was today’s puzzle much easier for me than yesterday’s Patrick Berry grid — quite a statement for a Saturday puzzle to begin with — but Mr. Cee was kind enough to include a snippet from the Rudyard Kipling poem Gunga Din that made me feel like I was a better, um, person for having attempted it.

headline: Zimbabwe’s Mugabe Faces Pro-Democracy Push From Powerful Neighbor, South Africa
text: JOHANNESBURG — As heads of state from across southern Africa meet here Saturday to wrestle yet again with Zimbabwe’s intractable crisis, the country’s 87-year-old strongman, Robert Mugabe, is facing a new reality: a strong and very public pro-democracy line from the region’s most powerful country, South Africa.

headline: Drug Bust
text: Friday marks the 40th anniversary of one of the biggest, most expensive, most destructive social policy experiments in American history: The war on drugs.

headline: Computer Studies Made Cool, on Film and Now on Campus
text: NEW HAVEN — When Keila Fong arrived at Yale, she had never given much thought to computer science. But then last year everyone on campus started talking about the film “The Social Network,” and she began to imagine herself building something and starting a business that maybe, just maybe, could become the next Facebook.

headline: Well, It’s a Start
text: The New York State comptroller, Thomas DiNapoli, has proposed an excellent way to clean up the costly and tainted campaigns for his powerful job. He has submitted a bill that creates the state’s first voluntary public campaign financing system, which would apply only to his office. To clean up Albany’s muck, the state needs a much broader system. But this is a start.

headline: Bonnaroo: Days 1 and 2
text: The Bonnaroo festival in Manchester, Tenn., which draws 80,000 rock fans for four days, kicked off on Thursday.

headline: Remember Microsoft?
text: Steven Ballmer is going through a rough patch. Not only did the influential hedge fund manager David Einhorn call for him to step down from the top job at Microsoft, “to give someone else a chance,” Microsoft stock jumped right after he said it.

headline: A Family Mourns as Bathers Return to a Beach
text: Beachgoers in bathing suits and the patter of residents speaking Russian: Brighton Beach on a hazy Friday in June.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Weiner Confirms He Sent Private Messages to Girl, 17
text: Representative Anthony D. Weiner said on Friday that he exchanged at least five private messages on Twitter this spring with a 17-year-old Delaware girl who became an admirer of his after hearing him speak during a high school trip to Washington.

headline: Scenes From Bonnaroo, Days 1 and 2
text: More Photographs

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Photo Replay: June 10
text: A look at the day in sports, from Rafael Nadal’s defeat to a glimpse of the Stanley Cup finals.

headline: Redistricting by Citizens Has Test in California
text: LOS ANGELES — Republicans and Democrats are battling across the country for advantage this year in drawing new Congressional and legislative districts in every state, based on new census data. California set out to do it differently, with an independent citizens commission, approved by voter initiative, designed to be insulated from the push-and-pull of partisan politics, a development that unsettled many elected officials here.

headline: Lawyers for Guantánamo Detainees Allowed to See Leaked Files
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has eased restrictions preventing lawyers representing prisoners at the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, from reading the classified files about their clients that were leaked to WikiLeaks and then made widely available on the Internet.

headline: With Passion, Yankees Show Indians They’ve Had Enough
text: It all may have come a few days too late. But after a three-game sweep at the hands of the Boston Red Sox, the Yankees on Friday night finally displayed the sort of intensity and emotion — and generally strong play — that they had so lacked in an otherwise feckless week.

headline: The First Shall Be Last: Recovering From a Financial Crisis
text: Tables rank European countries on economic growth, government budget surpluses or deficits and outstanding national debt.

headline: Luongo and Canucks Turn the Tide
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — After four games and another two periods on Friday night, the hometown Canucks and the Boston Bruins entered the final period here deadlocked, two wins against two wins, 0-0 in Game 5. With two goaltenders near perfect and two offenses far from it, the final 20 minutes promised to shift these Stanley Cup finals in one direction.

headline: Ethnic Protests in China Have Lengthy Roots
text: DAMAO BANNER, China — The Mongol nomads who have ranged across these blustery grasslands for millenniums have long had a tempestuous relationship with their Han Chinese neighbors to the south. Genghis Khan’s horseback conquerors overran Beijing in 1215, and Qing dynasty armies returned the favor four centuries later.

headline: Bloggingheads: Being a Black Academic
text: John McWhorter, left, of The New Republic and Glenn Loury of Brown University discuss the position of the black public intellectual.

headline: ‘Friday Night Lights’ Watch: Hubris and Tension Reign at East Dillon
text: We are covering the final season of “Friday Night Lights” according to the NBC schedule. We ask readers who have already seen the season on DirecTV or on DVD to please refrain from giving away future plot points in the comments section. For analysis of previous episodes, click here.

headline: Patrick Leigh Fermor, Travel Writer, Dies at 96
text: Patrick Leigh Fermor, the British writer whose erudite, high-spirited accounts of his adventures in prewar Europe, southern Greece and the Caribbean are widely regarded as classics of travel literature, died on Friday at his home in Worcestershire, England. He was 96.

headline: With Abstentions, Iowa Questions Political Role
text: WASHINGTON — For decades, Iowa has served as the official kickoff for the presidential campaign, providing the first real test for candidates hoping to win their way to the White House.

headline: Norman Redlich, Ex-Dean of N.Y.U. Law School, Dies at 85
text: Norman Redlich, a quiet luminary of the New York legal community who pioneered the pro bono defense of indigent death row inmates and who, as a staff member of the Warren Commission, helped develop the so-called single-bullet theory to explain how President John F. Kennedy was killed by a lone gunman, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 85.

headline: As Ex-Aides Speak Out, Gingrich Continues Bid
text: Newt Gingrich vowed on Friday to campaign for the 2012 Republican presidential nomination on his own terms, saying he would do “whatever it takes” to remain in the race despite the exodus a day earlier of nearly his entire senior staff.

headline: Chamberlain Looks Ahead to Recovery After Surgery
text: What seemed inevitable is now official. Joba Chamberlain will have season-ending Tommy John surgery next Thursday, with the procedure to be performed by Dr. James Andrews, the renowned orthopedic surgeon, in Pensacola, Fla.

headline: Toxic Coal Ash Spill in Tennessee
text: A coal ash pond ruptured and sent a billion gallons of toxic sludge across 300 acres of East Tennessee.

headline: Bonnaroo: My Morning Jacket, on Main Stage for First Time
text: MANCHESTER, Tenn. — Live, with its simple song forms blown up to cathedral dimensions, the Kentucky band My Morning Jacket can suggest so many different sources that at least in print it looks ridiculous: Pink Floyd (in all eras), Lynyrd Skynyrd, the Rolling Stones, the Grateful Dead, Television, Prince, the early Paul McCartney solo records and Bob Dylan’s “Nashville Skyline,” which more than any other source seems to have given Jim James, the band’s singer, his voice. That voice is soft and big and throaty; tonight at Bonnaroo, in a two-hour set that just ended (I write this at 10:15 on Friday night), he stuck his tongue halfway out on the loudest and highest falsetto notes.

headline: One Festival Under Lil Wayne
text: “This is what I came here for, right here,” said a college boy next to me. It was a little after 2 a.m., and Lil Wayne had just cued the beginning of “I’m Single,” his narcotic, spectral slow jam from last year. The fan rapped every word loudly, twice as loud as Lil Wayne did, but with the exact inflections. Dozens of college boys around him were doing the same thing. They all looked different, but had the same purpose.

headline: The Weekend Word: Relevance
text: Today’s Times

headline: Small-Business Regulation Bill Gets (and Loses) a Vote
text: Senator Olympia Snowe of Maine, the top Republican on the Senate Small Business Committee, finally got the vote she sought for legislation that would make sweeping changes to federal rule making by requiring more deference to small-business interests. She lost, largely on party lines.

headline: Rise and Shine, Little Raccoon
text: Awakening from a hot day’s nap. Wednesday, Riverside Park. Click to enlarge.

headline: Deutsche Bank’s Chief Casts Long Shadow in Europe
text: FRANKFURT

headline: Dancing With the Stars, Belmont Style
text: Molly Jo Rosen has been involved with thoroughbred racing from coast to coast: from Churchill Downs to TVG to Smarty Jones’s personal assistant to managing a major New York racing operation. She now runs Community Communications at GradeOneRacing, finds future superstars at 2yoSales.com, and serves her blend of pony punditry on her blog, Focused Filly.

headline: Thoughts on Voodoo
text: With Tim Pawlenty — who was supposed to be a sensible Republican — going all-in for high voodoo, I thought it’s worth pointing out that at the moment there’s a pretty good case that there is a kind of Laffer curve in which more is less and less is more. Namely, there’s a good case that fiscal stimulus right now would actually improve the long-run fiscal situation, while fiscal austerity makes it worse.

headline: Afghan Civilian Deaths Set a Monthly Record, U.N. Says
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The United Nations announced Saturday that May was the deadliest month for Afghan civilians since it began keeping count in 2007 — most likely a reflection of intense fighting, as militants seek to show they can stand up to the surge in American forces and try to undermine the government of President Hamid Karzai as it prepares to start taking over security.

headline: Can Ticketmaster’s Builder Now Unseat It?
text: FREDRIC D. ROSEN has winked through Steely Dan, blinked through Neil Diamond and nodded through the Rolling Stones.

headline: News Outlets Pounce on Palin E-Mails
text: News organizations that pored over nearly 25,000 pages of e-mail correspondence relating to Sarah Palin on Friday focused on her selection as Senator John McCain’s running mate in 2008, her relationship with the media and her style of governing.

headline: Woods Is Out, but Always on the Mind
text: In the absence of Tiger Woods, the United States Open has seldom been more open than it will be, starting Thursday, at Congressional Country Club outside Washington.

headline: Cause of the Yips Is Debated, but the Effect Isn’t
text: Among the many embarrassments golf can dole out, missing a short putt may be the worst. The stroke starts with a twitch of the hands and a flip of the wrist, and then the ball lips out of the cup or skitters wide of the hole. And sometimes, with recreational golfers, the ball does not move at all because they have bounced the putter over it.

headline: A Coveted Souvenir (Hair No Extra Charge)
text: In a bucket-list moment, Julie June Stewart woke up at 4 a.m. and bought a ticket to the 2008 Belmont. She hasn’t stopped going to the races since. That is when she isn’t taking on a wildfire, hurricane, volcano or oil spill as the nation’s leading expert in disaster airspace coordination.

headline: Protests Challenge Japan’s Use of Nuclear Power
text: TOKYO — Beating drums and waving flowers, protesters in Tokyo and other major cities rallied against the use of nuclear power on Saturday, three months after a devastating tsunami set off a nuclear crisis.

headline: I.M.F. Reports Cyberattack Led to ‘Very Major Breach’
text: WASHINGTON — The International Monetary Fund, still struggling to find a new leader after the arrest of its managing director last month in New York, was hit recently by what computer experts describe as a large and sophisticated cyberattack whose dimensions are still unknown.

headline: For James, Once Again, a Star Turn as Houdini
text: LeBron James is the N.B.A.’s Harry Houdini, with a touch of wrestling’s Gorgeous George.

headline: Taking Your Feelings to Work
text: WHEN I graduated from college in 1977, the world was still neatly divided into two spheres: work and everything else. Work was supposed to be a hyperrational realm of logic, filled with timetables, organizational charts and returns on investment. It was only outside of work that emotions — so dangerously ill-defined and unpredictable — were supposed to emerge.

headline: A Few (Middle) Seats Still Available
text: A pie chart that categorized the source of complaints to the Haggler would leave a glutton’s slice for the airlines. Tales of doomed luggage, missed connections and fare disputes are legion, as are service reps and gate agents who say that they would love to help, if only they could.

headline: The Power of the Pets
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Class of 2011
text: Word usage in 40 speeches given at graduations this year.

headline: Variety: Spiral With a Reason For Being
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — A reader asked me the other day about different methods for solving, and today’s Spiral puzzle by Will Shortz made me wonder: Do you start from the inside, working out, or do you start from the exterior of the spiral? Do you fall into the “a little of both” camp, as the instructions suggest? How about blindfolded, just to set yourself an extra challenge?

headline: The Annuity Question
text: To the Editor:

headline: As Arizona Fire Rages, Officials Seek Its Cause
text: SPRINGERVILLE, Ariz. — There is no yellow police tape ringing the huge wildfire raging along Arizona’s eastern flank, but the torched forest is a crime scene nonetheless.

headline: Azerbaijan and Armenia Meet to End Land Dispute
text: MOSCOW — The foreign ministers of Azerbaijan, Armenia and Russia met behind closed doors here on Saturday, as international mediators ratcheted up the pressure for a breakthrough in the long conflict over the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh.

headline: Agassi’s Post-Tennis Career Is Anything but Restful
text: PARIS — Andre Agassi has retired from tennis, but is hardly retired from the work force. At 41, he has announced his goal, in conjunction with a Los Angeles-based investment firm, to finance the construction of as many as 75 charter schools in the United States in the next several years.

headline: Car Bombings and Shooting of Family Kill 11 in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — Twin car bombs ripped through a crowded neighborhood of restaurants and peanut vendors in the northern Iraqi city of Mosul on Saturday, and unidentified gunmen killed a teacher and his family in the central part of the country. At least 11 people were killed in the attacks.

headline: Best Sellers Weekly Graphic: Hurricanes, Serial Killers, Murder and Nazis
text: Erik Larson, the author of “The Devil in the White City,” has had four books on the hardcover nonfiction list.

headline: Best Sellers Weekly Graphic: Back in the Top Spot
text: Charlaine Harris’s “Dead Reckoning” is one of five books over the past year to spend three or more weeks at No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list.

headline: The Worry Meter May Overlook Some Warning Signs
text: WHILE market risks appear to be climbing — stocks have lost ground for six consecutive weeks as the economy seems to have hit another soft patch — most traditional gauges of volatility show no noticeable jump in market anxiety.

headline: Residents Flee as Syrian Forces Bombard Town
text: CAIRO — Syrian security forces bombarded the restive northern town of Jisr al-Shoughour for a second day Saturday with withering tank and helicopter fire as frightened people struggled to escape, residents reported.

headline: Somalis Kill Mastermind of 2 U.S. Embassy Bombings
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Fazul Abdullah Mohammed, Al Qaeda’s leader in East Africa and the mastermind of the American Embassy bombings in Kenya and Tanzania, was killed in a late-night shootout at a security checkpoint in Mogadishu, Somalia’s capital, Somali and American officials said Saturday.

headline: The Sickness Beneath the Slump
text: THE origins of the current economic crisis can be traced to a particular kind of social epidemic: a speculative bubble that generated pervasive optimism and complacency. That epidemic has run its course. But we are now living with the malaise it caused.

headline: Got an M.B.A.? Great, but I Prefer Uncommon Sense
text: This interview with Byron Lewis Sr., the chairman and chief executive of the UniWorld Group, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Out of Cuba, With a Suitcase
text: MY family emigrated from Cuba when I was almost 7, after the failed Bay of Pigs mission. We had a nice life in Cuba. My father worked for the Coca-Cola Company, and we’d spend weekends at our beach house. But my parents didn’t support Fidel Castro and wanted safe passage out of the country at that point.

headline: Two New Web Sites Aim to Connect Travelers
text: Two new Web sites aim to make traveling a more social event. Both sites — triptrotting.com and igottaguide.com — combine travel with elements of social media, connecting members based on common interests.

headline: Preview: U.S. vs. Panama
text: The United States could clinch a top-two spot in Group C with a victory over Panama in the Concacaf Gold Cup at Raymond James Stadium in Tampa, Fla., Saturday night (8 p.m., Eastern, FSC/TeleFutura) and a Canada tie against Guadeloupe in the opening game of the doubleheader.

headline: When Two-Thirds Isn’t Enough
text: IT’S one of the great anomalies of our ownership society: shareholders own companies, but executives can easily slap them down. The hired help, in other words, holds the cards.

headline: Guard That Password (and Make Sure It’s Encrypted)
text: FOR a pretty strong password, think 10. If your password contains 10 characters, you should be able to sleep well at night — perhaps for 19.24 years.

headline: Laugh Lines
text: JAY LENO

headline: Fighting Words
text: Sean Penn, the actor, and Ozzie Guillen, the manager of the Chicago White Sox and a native of Venezuela, have been feuding over the actor’s support of President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela.

headline: Eritrea Detains Four Antipiracy Contractors
text: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa — Eritrea, a secretive and often testy nation in the Horn of Africa, has accused four British security contractors who are working for an antipiracy company of espionage, sabotage, terrorism and “acts of invasion.”

headline: You Bring an Idea, and They’ll Do the Rest
text: BETSY RAVREBY KAUFMAN is a lot of things — a freelance television producer, a former anchor, a wife and mother, a resident of Houston. One thing she is not, she insists, is an inventor.

headline: No Middle Ground in Reliever’s Commitment to Helping
text: When the San Francisco Giants needed a player to speak to the crowd before their game with the Los Angeles Dodgers on April 11, the choice was obvious. It would not be a star, but a journeyman left-handed middle reliever. It had to be Jeremy Affeldt.

headline: A Guide to Palin E-Mail Notes
text: When The Times began posting nearly 25,000 pages of e-mail correspondence relating to Sarah Palin on Friday, we asked readers poring over them to highlight noteworthy and interesting messages. Our thanks to the hundreds of you that have done so since then. Here is a listing of the notes that we’ve made, based on Times research and your suggestions:

headline: In Race or Behind the Scenes, Women Cement Their Gains in the Industry
text: This Triple Crown season has been rife with story lines, many involving women. Rosie Napravnik posted the highest finish by a female jockey in the Kentucky Derby — ninth with Pants On Fire. Kathy Ritvo, recovering from a heart transplant, trained Mucho Macho Man for all three legs of this grueling series.

headline: Suburban Hip Is Where It’s At
text: No one knows how things will end in the busted love affair between Manhattan and the wandering bankers of UBS. Fifteen years ago, the Swiss bank jilted Manhattan for the fresh face and roomy digs of Stamford, Conn. Now, it appears some aspiring masters of the universe are balking at working outside New York City and UBS is pondering coming back home, like the ending of a weepy Meg Ryan romance.

headline: Husband Retraces Grete Waitz’s Swift Footsteps
text: Jack Waitz said he probably should not have eaten so much before Saturday’s race. But he could not help it. Delis had been a tradition for him and his wife, Grete, on their visits from Norway.

headline: Weiner Agrees to Get Treatment as Calls for Resignation Intensify
text: Defying forceful demands for his resignation, Representative Anthony D. Weiner of New York said on Saturday that he was entering a psychological treatment center and seeking a leave of absence from the House to deal with a pattern of reckless online behavior with women.

headline: Days of a Dynasty Are Only a Memory for a Distinct Race
text: So much can happen in a mile and a half. And it can happen fast. It’s enough to humble owners and trainers and jockeys, knowing that the Belmont Stakes can be lost right after the clang of the bell at the opening of the gate.

headline: The Mets’ Bat Whisperer
text: PITTSBURGH — Whenever he receives a new box of bats, Carlos Beltran takes each bat out, holds it to his ear and raps it, gently but convincingly, with the base of his hand, his head cocked, one eye shut, concentrating like a virtuoso tuning his violin.

headline: Carmona Says He Didn’t Mean to Hit Teixeira
text: The Yankees were convinced that the Cleveland right-hander Fausto Carmona intentionally hit Mark Teixeira in the second inning of Friday night’s game, an 11-7 Yankees victory. Carmona left Yankee Stadium without speaking to the news media, and on Saturday morning he offered his account of the pitch that sparked a benches-clearing incident and a shouting match between the managers.

headline: No Guide to Survive a Political Scandal
text: There is no more wince-inducing time for a Washington politician than the moment that a sex scandal bursts into public view. But Representative Anthony D. Weiner’s fate notwithstanding, the truth is that they are not always politically fatal.

headline: When It Comes to Scandal, Girls Won’t Be Boys
text: WASHINGTON — There was a collective rolling of the eyes and a distinct sense of “Here we go again” among the women of the House of Representatives last week when yet another male politician, Representative Anthony D. Weiner, confessed his “terrible mistakes” and declared himself “deeply sorry for the pain” he had caused in sexual escapades so adolescent as to almost seem laughable.

headline: Technology and the Political Sex Scandal
text: In 1791, while serving as secretary of the Treasury, Alexander Hamilton began an affair with Maria Reynolds, being blackmailed by her husband for several years to allow it to continue. When a muckraker exposed the affair and the cover-up, Hamilton turned to the communications technology of the day to defend himself, publishing a pamphlet in which he argued that he had never abused any public resources.

headline: Blaming Sprouts Again
text: European officials have finally identified bean sprouts as the likely culprit in a deadly outbreak of E. coli poisoning, the latest in a series of outbreaks traced back to tainted sprouts.

headline: Something Has Been Missing in October
text: Baseball fans had reason to be envious of the N.B.A. and the N.H.L. last week. Each sport’s championship series stood at 2-2 after four games. The World Series has not been tied 2-2 since 2003, when the Yankees played the Florida Marlins.

headline: An Airlift, Family by Family, Bolsters Cuba’s Economy
text: HAVANA — Alejandrina Hernández packed only light clothes and a makeup bag when she flew here from Miami this spring. As always, she kept her baggage to a minimum.

headline: Clemente’s 3,000th Hit Was Muted Milestone in Ambivalent City
text: When Derek Jeter reaches 3,000 career hits, he will achieve more than a milestone. At that moment, Jeter will match the career hit total of Roberto Clemente, the Hall of Famer who stands forever as the greeter to the club.

headline: Bayler Teal Was South Carolina’s Talisman
text: When South Carolina won the 2010 N.C.A.A. Division I baseball championship, the university’s first men’s title in more than 100 years of athletic competition, Coach Ray Tanner thanked three people, posthumously.

headline: McEnroe-Borg 1980: A Great Match Endures
text: Bjorn Borg was conspicuously absent from last weekend’s French Open final when Rafael Nadal defeated Roger Federer and tied Borg’s record six singles titles in Paris. But Borg is conspicuously present in a new HBO documentary he shares with his longtime rival John McEnroe.

headline: Another Vettel Pole, and Another Thought on Schumacher
text: MONTREAL — Sebastian Vettel scored pole position in his Red Bull in Montreal today, but since he has done that at most of the races this year, I’d rather talk about other things.

headline: Another Vettel Pole, and Another Thought on Schumacher
text: MONTREAL — Sebastian Vettel scored pole position in his Red Bull in Montreal today, but since he has done that at most of the races this year, I’d rather talk about other things.

headline: Dying to Tell the Story
text: Islamabad, Pakistan

headline: E. Coli Fallout: My Salad, My Health
text: The Greek salad I ordered at a business lunch in the Netherlands near the German border two weeks ago was served up with a dilemma. “Are you sure you want to eat that? — look at the cucumbers,” my Dutch dining companion pointed out, ominously.

headline: The Quiet Corner of the Mideast (Surprise)
text: WASHINGTON — In the Arab democracy movement, there is a dog that has not yet barked. And whether or not it does — and how loudly — is causing a lot of heartburn among American policy makers.

headline: New Curb, No Ban, On Hits to the Head
text: Last week the N.H.L.’s general managers fired the latest salvo in the rear-guard action they have fought over the last season and a half.

headline: From a Twitter Photo to Treatment
text: FRIDAY, MAY 27: A sexually suggestive photograph is sent to a young woman from the Twitter account of Representative Anthony D. Weiner. It is quickly deleted.

headline: After a Stroll, Luongo Is Immovable
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — In this hockey-mad city and throughout Canada, fans have been perplexed by the uneven performance of Roberto Luongo, the Canucks’ veteran goalie and Vezina Trophy nominee. His games in the Stanley Cup finals have been endlessly scrutinized, dissected and discussed. After two miserable showings in Boston last week, he entered Game 5 against the Bruins on Friday under the microscope once again.

headline: The Mayor’s Go-To Man on the Council
text: After giving his victory speech and plunging into the audience to shake hands with supporters, Rahm Emanuel climbed back onto the stage at his election-night party in February. Chicago’s next mayor then noticed someone he had to return to floor level to greet.

headline: Qaddafi Forces Shell Rebels Near Misurata
text: CAIRO — Forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi intensified their shelling of rebel positions near the city of Misurata, a rebel spokesman said Saturday, and news reports suggested that other pro-Qaddafi troops were on the move around the formerly rebel-held city of Zawiya, just west of Tripoli.

headline: Mr. Daley’s New Chapter, Starting in the Loop
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: In Tampa, With Panama Up Next
text: Sorry it has been so long since my last entry, I’ve been a little busy with traveling and what not. So I’ll try to get everyone up to speed.

headline: Newt Loves Callista
text: WASHINGTON

headline: It May Look Like a Scone, but It’s Job Training
text: When Lonnie Griffin was released from prison in December, he had a goal: to find a job. But with a criminal record and no work experience, Mr. Griffin, 23 and the father of two, had two strikes against him, in a tough job market. So his job counselor recommended the 12-week job-training course at Blue Sky Bakery, a Lincoln Park cafe known for its delectable scones — and for creating first jobs for young people who need them most.

headline: Video Shows Efforts to Contain Arizona Blaze
text: As my colleague Marc Lacey reports, an enormous wildfire that has ripped through 408,000 acres in Arizona continued to burn on Saturday. Officials were bracing for high winds, projected to pick up in the afternoon, that would test the containment efforts after a two-day reprieve from harsh weather.

headline: Revolving Door Is Not an Open-and-Shut Case
text: Does this look right? Mark Jackson is an ABC analyst for the N.B.A. finals and the coach of the Golden State Warriors. Can one man do that? Should he? Shouldn’t there be a panel of wise men to decide this?

headline: The Uncertainty Tax
text: If you want to understand why the unemployment rate has been stubbornly lodged around 9 percent, a good place to start is with the eye-popping mortgage statistics released last week by the economic analysis firm CoreLogic: 38 percent of homeowners with second mortgages are underwater. They borrowed against the value of their homes, and they now owe more than their houses are worth. The total number of underwater homeowners in America, with first and second mortgages, is a stunning 22.7 percent. In Nevada alone, 63 percent of all mortgaged properties are worth less than the owners paid; in Arizona 50 percent, Florida 46 percent, Michigan 36 percent and California 31 percent.

headline: Handicapping the Obama-Boehner ‘Golf Summit’
text: MIAMI — On the first tee, President Lyndon B. Johnson often warned his golfing partners, “One lesson you’d better learn if you want to be in politics is you never get out on a golf course and beat the president.”

headline: Work Cut Out for Him, a Schools Chief Dives In
text: With three meetings already under his belt by 10 a.m. on the Monday of his second full week on the job, Jean-Claude Brizard, chief executive of Chicago Public Schools, rode in his city-issued Ford Crown Victoria to visit Northside College Prep High School.

headline: Agglomeration Wins
text: Not about the usual: this article in the Times, Regretting Move, Bank May Return to Manhattan is up my old alley — the stuff I got the Swedish thingie for. And it should make Ed Glaeser happy. Together with Jess Gaspar, Ed wrote a paper 15 years ago arguing that contrary to what many people were saying, the Internet and all that wouldn’t undermine the agglomeration forces that support places like Manhattan; if anything, agglomeration would increase. Actually, I wrote about that back in my “looking backward from the year 2096” piece, written about the same time.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: When Food Kills
text: The deaths of 31 people in Europe from a little-known strain of E. coli have raised alarms worldwide, but we shouldn’t be surprised. Our food often betrays us.

headline: 30 Seconds With David Feherty
text: A new personality is entering the talk-show fray, long before Katie Couric. David Feherty’s half-interview, half-improv weekly show, “Feherty,” will make its debut at 9 p.m. Eastern on June 21 on the Golf Channel and run for 12 weeks. Feherty, 52, a native of Northern Ireland, became a professional golfer at 17, won five tournaments in Europe and three in South Africa, and represented Europe at the 1991 Ryder Cup. He joined CBS Sports full time as a golf commentator in 1997. As a host, Feherty will be a cross between Oprah Winfrey and Johnny Carson: at once confessional and a chameleon who inhabits characters like Dr. Phyll and Hamish McGregor, who was a central figure in Feherty’s 2002 novel, “A Nasty Bit of Rough.” Feherty has been an open book over the years about his clinical depression and addictions to alcohol and painkillers.

headline: Ideologies That Fail Upwards
text: CBPP reminds us that the Bush tax cuts totally failed to deliver, even before the financial collapse:

headline: Lobbyists Play Outsize Role as Political Fund-Raisers in San Francisco
text: In late March, Supervisor Ross Mirkarimi of San Francisco met with lobbyists from Zynga, the online gaming giant, and agreed to introduce a bill to eliminate the city’s unusual tax on corporate stock options.

headline: Urban Forager | A Lovely Mushroom, if Not Too Tasty
text: A few weekends ago, while rushing through Central Park toward a breakfast date, I spied a giant cluster of scaly brown mushrooms that resembled a bird’s plumage, partially hidden under some weeds. Closer inspection revealed a cacophony of fungi spread out across an old tree stump — one mushroom growing singly like a shelf, others in trumpet-shaped clusters, and a few as large as pancakes. Each had that lovely speckled pattern fanning out across the cap.

headline: Pay Dispute Splits Bay’s Shippers and Bar Pilots
text: The nearly 60 bar pilots who navigate commercial ships through San Francisco Bay might be earning an average of $530,000 a year each by 2015.

headline: The Economy and D.C.: Renewed Weakness
text: The recent deluge of weak economic data has led to a guessing game among analysts. Is the weakness temporary? Or is there more bad news to come?

headline: Palin’s E-Mails Undercut Simplistic Views of Her, Both Positive and Negative
text: JUNEAU, Alaska — In the three years since Sarah Palin stormed the national political stage, her brief tenure as governor of Alaska has often been reduced to caricature. Critics cast her as petty, preoccupied and disengaged. Supporters say she was a maverick reformer, a salt-of-the-earth true believer who bucked the establishment elite.

headline: Injury Shuts Down Colon’s Revival and Puts Damper on a Victory
text: A sense of inevitability has surrounded Bartolo Colon from the moment he signed with the Yankees: no matter how well he pitched or how long he defied logic and expectations, his 38-year-old body would eventually betray him.

headline: From I.R.S. to Gay Couples, Headaches and Expenses
text: Scott James writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Viola Renews Tie to Mets
text: As the new pitching coach for the Brooklyn Cyclones, the Mets’ rookie-level team in the New York-Penn League, Frank Viola will have few pupils who were born in the 1980s, when he starred for the Minnesota Twins. But his pitchers will discover who he is.

headline: The Economy and D.C.: Republicans’ Tax-cutting Fantasia
text: High unemployment numbers may be good for Republicans in the next election, which makes it disturbing that Republican leaders have blocked any discussion of stimulus policies that might succeed in putting people back to work.

headline: After Rest, Girardi’s Ire Over Pitch Is Tempered
text: The Yankees were convinced that the Cleveland right-hander Fausto Carmona intentionally hit Mark Teixeira in the second inning of Friday night’s game, an 11-7 Yankees victory. Carmona left Yankee Stadium without speaking to members of the news media, and on Saturday morning he offered his account of the pitch that sparked a benches-clearing incident and a shouting match between the managers.

headline: For Republicans, Redistricting Offers Few Gains
text: WASHINGTON — On paper, the sweeping gains Republicans enjoyed last year in statehouses across the country gave the party a profound advantage in the nascent and increasingly contentious power struggle to create new Congressional districts.

headline: Making Food Safe
text: My Sunday column looks at food safety and, in particular, the way the agribusiness lobby has blocked some basic reforms — not least the banning of routine feeding of antibiotics to health livestock, for growth promotion. That’s just unconscionable, given the risks of developing antibiotic resistance.

headline: Ruler on Ice Wins 143rd Belmont Stakes
text: Ruler on Ice, ridden by Jose Valdivia Jr., shocked in the Belmont Stakes on Saturday, holding off Stay Thirsty by three-quarters of a length on a sloppy track. Brilliant Speed finished third.

headline: Stuck in the Muddle
text: Making sense of the Armed Career Criminal Act’s “residual clause” has become an almost annual rite for the Supreme Court. Sykes v. United States, decided last week, is the court’s fourth attempt in five years. The continuing confusion is obvious in the sharp, separate dissents from Antonin Scalia and Elena Kagan.

headline: Bushrod Ball Fields
text: Generations of professional athletes have gotten their start at Bushrod Ball Fields, part of Bushrod Park, an unassuming neighborhood park on 59th Street between Telegraph and Shattuck Avenues in North Oakland. AARON GLANTZ

headline: Texas Governor Draws Criticism on Prayer Event
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — When Gov. Rick Perry invited fellow governors to join him on Aug. 6 for “a day of prayer and fasting on behalf of our troubled nation,” some speculated that he was trying to raise his national visibility for a possible presidential run.

headline: ‘The Waste Land’ by App
text: It’s always hard to say what a dead poet would have liked, especially a poet as particular, not to say critically sniffy, in his likes and dislikes as T. S. Eliot. But the guarantee of electronic posterity should be hard for even him to resist. Eliot’s own publishing house — Faber & Faber, where he worked for many years — has just rereleased what may be his greatest poem, “The Waste Land,” in the form of an iPad app produced by Touch Press.

headline: A Lightning Rod on U.T. Board, Regent Is Not Deterred
text: On Feb. 12, Gene Powell, the chairman of the University of Texas System Board of Regents, sent a note to Francisco G. Cigarroa, chancellor of the U.T. System, about the newest regents appointed by Gov. Rick Perry. The new members “all have extensive experience in higher education and all of them are hard core conservatives. And none of them are shy. We will see no ‘break in’ period from these individuals,” he wrote.

headline: In Saudi Arabia, Comedy Cautiously Pushes Limits
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — You know you are attending a Saudi Arabian comedy night when the sprawling performance tent is pitched 50 miles out into the desert to avoid the morals police and, astonishingly, the ushers are women, even if they remain shrouded by the standard-issue black garments.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: The Way America Eats
text: Last week, under the headline “Invitation to a Dialogue: The Way America Eats,” we continued a new feature in which we invite readers to respond to an interesting letter, in hopes of spurring a dialogue. text: Senator Steve Ogden, Republican of Bryan, is the latest lawmaker to say it: A $4 billion reduction in state financing does not have to mean teachers lose their jobs.

headline: On the Road to Austin: Food, Shopping and Sights
text: Ben Edgerton, a former advertising executive based in Austin, grew up spending weekends at Contigo, his family’s ranch in Jim Wells County, an hour west of Corpus Christi. The area, known for thriving brush country, has long attracted doves, deer, feral hogs and, at the top of the food chain, hunters.

headline: Where Words Can Never Do Justice
text: LAST week’s coverage of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict brought out passionate reader complaints, on both sides of the issue — as usual.

headline: Sunday: Pullet
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — If you talk to enough people about crossword puzzle solving, you eventually see that there is a pervasive misconception that the Sunday New York Times crossword is the mother brain buster of the week, the puzzle that is for the truly suicidal. Most people know that the puzzles increase in relative difficulty throughout the week, so they naturally assume that the puzzle on the last day of the week must be the hardest. Then there’s the sheer size of it. Not only does Will Shortz want us to break our brains, they reason, he wants us to suffer. This might be the puzzle we have to leave to our children in our wills.

headline: Missouri’s War Within the War
text: On June 11, 1861, at St. Louis’s sumptuous Planters’ House, two Army officers met with Missouri’s governor and former governor, the latter now commanding the state militia, in the governor’s suite. The meeting, called to discuss Missouri’s role in the unfolding Civil War, was anything but cordial. For the first half hour, the governors, Claiborne Fox Jackson and Sterling Price, insisted their state, though still a part of the Union, remain neutral, and that, in exchange for disbanding the state militia, the federalized German home guard be disbanded as well.

headline: Your 4-Year-Old Can’t Do That
text: THE art market has made a remarkable recovery from the depths of the financial crisis, and so perhaps it is not surprising that in this time of optimism a 4-year-old girl would be the latest sensation. An exhibition of work by the wonderkid painter Aelita Andre opened on June 4 at the Agora Gallery in Manhattan for a three-week run.

headline: Separation of Church and School
text: FROM our apartment you can see the front door of our children’s public school. It’s a bright red double door made of solid wood and framed in brown-red brick. Last summer I spent a lot of time looking at that door with anticipation and excitement. We had just moved to the Upper East Side of Manhattan from California, and had chosen the neighborhood for its school.

headline: Mets Move Hot-Hitting Tejada to No. 2 in the Order

Instead, he chose Ruben Tejada, the 21-year-old infielder who went into the game hitting .329.

headline: On a Somber Mission to Restore the Missing Face of a Mountain
text: FRANCONIA, N.H. — There is no replacing the Old Man of the Mountain, the beloved natural landmark that tumbled from its craggy perch at Franconia Notch State Park in 2003, sending this state into deepest grief.

headline: Before Reality TV, Life in an Actual Bubble
text: The desert vista here is stunning, with saguaro cactuses and rugged hills as far as the eye can see, if only someone would spray some Windex on the glass.
