headline: C.I.A. Director Warns Pakistan on Collusion With Militants
text: WASHINGTON — Leon E. Panetta, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, confronted Pakistani intelligence officials face to face with what the United States believes is evidence of collusion between Pakistani security officials and militants staging attacks in Afghanistan, an American counterterrorism official said Saturday.

headline: In a War of Words, Makers of Plastic Bags Go to Court
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The plastic bag industry, increasingly on the defensive as municipal bag bans proliferate, has gone on the attack against ChicoBag, a competitor that bills itself as an eco-friendly alternative. A federal lawsuit in South Carolina accuses ChicoBag of illegal trash-talking about plastic bag waste.

headline: South Carolina Prevails, Putting UConn Under Familiar N.C.A.A. Pressure
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Connecticut sent Matt Barnes, its ace and newly selected first-round draft pick of the Boston Red Sox, to face the defending national champion South Carolina on Saturday in the Columbia Super Regional of the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Joke Aimed at Nowitzki Shifts Focus to Wade
text: MIAMI — LeBron James has been dissected like a frog in biology class, his guts put under a microscope for examination throughout the N.B.A. finals. On the eve of the Heat’s must-win game at home Sunday against the Dallas Mavericks, the focus shifted to his teammate Dwyane Wade, whose gall now has come under scrutiny.

headline: The Electoral Effect of Sex Scandals
text: One point frequently raised in the coverage of Representative Anthony D. Weiner is that David Vitter, the Lousiana Senator who in 2007 acknowledged that he was a longtime client of a Washington-based prostitution service, did not resign his seat. In fact, Mr. Vitter won re-election with 56.6 percent of the vote last November.

headline: At Adidas Grand Prix, Gay Loses Men’s 100 Meters in a Photo Finish
text: With the temperature a nudge above 60 and a relentless rain dampening the afternoon, the conditions were not ideal for sprinters Saturday at the Adidas Grand Prix meet at Icahn Stadium on Randalls Island.

headline: First in Mud at Belmont: Long Shot Ruler on Ice
text: Why in a Triple Crown season dominated by fresh faces and improbable long shots would the 143rd running of the Belmont Stakes be any different? Why wouldn’t the racing gods give horseplayers and horse lovers alike one more bank-busting bomber in the winner’s circle of the mile-and-a-half Test of the Champion and introduce another unlikely set of Triple Crown first-timers?

headline: Yes, We Want to Cut the Budget. Just Not That Part.
text: WASHINGTON — As hard as it may be for lawmakers and the White House to reach an agreement to raise the federal debt ceiling in the coming weeks, striking a budget bargain is just the beginning of the real work.

headline: Rooftop Seating, for Everyone
text: Some hotels have exclusive rooftop bars, open only to guests and V.I.P.’s, but at Above 6 at the 6 Columbus hotel, across 58th Street from the Time Warner Center, the approach is more democratic. The bar, a casual aerie perched high above Columbus Circle, welcomes hotel guests and the general public on a first-come-first-served basis — patrons need only ask at Blue Ribbon Sushi in the lobby to be let up in the elevator to the roof. Open for just two months, the spot, which does not serve food but supplies wasabi peas free upon request, is already popular with neighborhood residents, office workers and diners waiting for a table downstairs when the restaurant bar is full. On Wednesday, the crowd included two friends from the television business chatting with each other and the patrons at the adjacent table.

headline: In the Park and Then the Wig
text: Jessica Walter famously, and creepily, stalked Clint Eastwood in the 1971 film “Play Misty for Me” and portrayed the over-the-top alcoholic matriarch Lucille Bluth on the TV series “Arrested Development.” Now she is appearing on Broadway as the haughty, overbearing Mrs. Evangeline Harcourt in the Tony-nominated revival of the Cole Porter musical “Anything Goes.” Most Sundays revolve around the matinee; today, though, there is none because of the Tony Awards.  Ms. Walter, 70, lives in an Upper West Side brownstone with her husband, the actor Ron Leibman, and their black Lab, Reggie; they also own a house in Pound Ridge, N.Y., where they plan to make an early getaway this weekend.  ROBIN FINN

headline: A Killer’s on the Loose? Oh, It’s Just an Actor
text: If you see something, you might want to pause a moment before you say something.

headline: Food, Phone, Opinion. A New App Is Born.
text: WHEN the pork ribs at Má Pêche restaurant in Midtown arrive luxuriously bathed in a glaze of Thai basil and lemongrass caramel, members of the Porcine Lunch Club gasp before diving in. It is a “wow” moment to write home about — in the modern, 140-character sense — except that sticky fingers tend to smudge a mobile phone screen.

headline: Hands That Punch Also Gently Guide
text: AT 5-foot-7 and 220 pounds, Sonya Lamonakis has a stinging left hook. She is the Women’s International Boxing Association’s third-ranked heavyweight, and has all but assured herself a chance to fight for the world title after beating the 300-pound GiGi Jackson in a six-round bout in April.

headline: Afghan Taliban Cede Ground in the South, but Fears Linger

headline: Gus Tyler, Firebrand of Labor Movement, Dies at 99
text: Gus Tyler could recite word for word the first firebrand speech he gave more than 80 years ago on a soapbox on the Lower East Side. That long-ago youth tingled with the revolutionary promise he saw on the teeming streets of New York, in the new Soviet Union, in the great books he devoured, in the endless nocturnal debates.

headline: Clara Luper, a Leader of Civil Rights Sit-Ins, Dies at 88
text: Her name does not resonate like that of Rosa Parks, and she did not garner the kind of national attention that a group of black students did when they took seats at a Woolworth’s lunch counter in Greensboro, N.C., in February 1960. But Clara Luper was a seminal figure in the sit-ins of the civil rights movement.

headline: Bonnaroo: Dust and Ice
text: MANCHESTER, Tenn. — Day 3 of Bonnaroo: dust, dust and ice. Thousands of bags of ice, trucked all over the enormous site, used as soon as the bags got opened. People sunburned and zombified, spilling around most of the stages, even the film tent, even the comedy tent. The drowning feeling set in today.

headline: 24 Hours in Sports: One Reporter’s Quest
A Scholar of the Sweet Science
text: Sonya Lamonakis, who teaches at an elementary school in Harlem, will likely fight for the female world heavyweight boxing title later this year.

headline: Nearing .500, Mets Again Fail to Reach Mark
text: PITTSBURGH — Within a game of .500, the Mets took the field at PNC Park on Saturday night looking to reach equilibrium for the first time in three weeks. A resurgent R. A. Dickey was on the mound, and the team was boasting a winning record in the month of June, so they had every reason to feel worthy of getting their heads above water again.

headline: Mourning Slain Women, Families Hold Vigil on Long Island
text: Storm clouds swirled above and the wind proved too strong for their candles, but that did not stop a group of grieving families from holding a vigil on Long Island on Saturday for women who worked as prostitutes and are believed to be the victims of a serial killer. The remains of some of them have turned up in recent months on a desolate stretch of the beach in Suffolk County, near where the vigil was held.

headline: Education Secretary May Agree to Waivers on ‘No Child’ Law Requirements
text: Unless Congress acts by this fall to overhaul No Child Left Behind, the main federal law on public education, Secretary of Education Arne Duncan signaled that he would use his executive authority to free states from the law’s centerpiece requirement that all students be proficient in reading and math by 2014.

headline: A Syrian Funeral
text: Mourners gather around the coffin of Rafaat Deab, allegedly shot and killed by the Syrian military in the town of Serminia, during his funeral procession along the Syrian-Turkish border.

text: Before Saturday’s game against Panama, the United States national team had never lost a group stage match in the Concacaf Gold Cup.

headline: Disqualified by Evidence on a Phone
text: A German master was disqualified from his country’s championship tournament this month, done in by his cellphone.

headline: Bonnaroo: Day 3
text: MANCHESTER, Tenn. — “We’re Buffalo Springfield,” said Neil Young, by way of introduction on Saturday night. “We’re from the past.” They sure are. Some of the band’s reunion set at Bonnaroo, after a string of California concerts and more planned for the fall, felt older-guy casual: retirement rock. Richie Furay sings very much like what he has become, which is a church pastor. Stephen Stills sings like a bumpy road. And the bassist Rick Rosas and drummer Joe Vitale played comfortable older-guy grooves, slower than the songs in your head from their very short history.

headline: Riverside Berlin Club Offers Food, Views and Plenty of Parking
text: Summer in Berlin brings with it a sudden proliferation of sandy beach bars, lounges and all-night clubs perched along the banks of the Spree River. The  Ressort, now in its second year, is one such seasonal locale, though with an address more unusual than most. The restaurant and club is situated at the far corner of a vast parking lot behind the Hamburger Bahnhof Contemporary Art Museum, and its relative isolation turns out to be a welcome reprise from the city’s hectic summer vibe.

headline: A Free Site Helps Find Stolen Cameras
text: A clever experiment may make it possible for you to recover a stolen camera, find people using your photos without permission and help police catch child pornographers.

headline: Photos Released as Giffords Prepares to Leave Hospital
text: PHOENIX — Photographs of Representative Gabrielle Giffords were posted on her Facebook page Sunday, the first clear public images of her since she began rehabilitation from a bullet wound to the brain in January.

headline: Amid Pomp and Circumstance, Words for Life and a Few Laughs
text: Having spent much of the last nine months chronicling this year’s college application process, with an occasional word of advice sprinkled in, I want to pause to mark the end of that season — and, as a reminder of the ultimate prize, point readers of The Choice to The Times’s compilation of 2011 college commencement speeches.

headline: For Favorites at the Belmont, an Eighth of a Mile Too Much
text: It’s just such a deflating feeling, and you hate to feel like that because a horse did win the Belmont Stakes, and ran hard to win. But still, Animal Kingdom was taken out of the race right from the beginning, and Shackleford ran out of steam. Both horses looked weak in the final eighth of a mile, and from that point on it was not pretty.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 12
text: The 2012 presidential election saw some new twists this week as Newt Gingrich’s senior advisers resigned and Mitt Romney announced  plans to skip the Iowa straw poll. Keeping up the conversation, the Sunday shows will focus on the race as well as the economy.

headline: It’s the Health Care Costs, Stupid
text: I’ve already written about Joe Lieberman’s very bad, no good idea of raising the Medicare eligibility age. Austin Frakt and Aaron Carroll show that it’s even worse than I thought: Americans near 65 who don’t have good health insurance delay needed treatment, causing a bulge in Medicare costs when they hit the magic age, and the same phenomenon would get even worse, so this might not even save money.

headline: Syrian Troops Retake Control of Rebellious Town in North
text: CAIRO — Syria’s most trusted forces retook control of a rebellious northern Syrian town on Sunday, responding with tanks and helicopter gunships and crushing an alliance of mutinous soldiers and armed civilians, while prompting thousands of frightened residents to flee into Turkey or camp out in open fields on the border.

headline: Battery Power Gives Deliverymen a Boost, at a Cost
text: It’s almost impossible to walk a block or two in Manhattan and not spy a Chinese-food deliveryman on a bicycle.

headline: Clinton Honors Embassy Bombing Victims
text: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania — Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton on Sunday honored those killed in the bombings in 1998 of the American Embassies here and in Kenya, a day after the authorities confirmed the death of the feared operative from Al Qaeda who masterminded the attacks.

headline: Israeli Economist Enters Race to Lead I.M.F.
text: With probably the most impressive résumé and the least chance of succeeding, Stanley Fischer, the governor of the Bank of Israel, has added his name to the list of candidates for managing director of the International Monetary Fund.

headline: Free To Lose
text: Matt Yglesias is having fun with a study from the Mercatus Center (pdf) purporting to rank states by their levels of freedom. I was disappointed to discover that New Jersey is only the second most tyrannical regime, behind New York.

headline: U.N. Pulls Staff from Sudanese City
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The United Nations has begun pulling nonessential staff members from the restive Sudanese state of Southern Kordofan, even as it sends more peacekeepers there to protect civilians, officials said Sunday.

headline: Discretionary Truthiness Update
text: Politifact has now updated its work on the claim, universal on the right — and repeated often by Paul Ryan — that discretionary non-defense spending is up 80 percent under Obama.

headline: Chinese Street Vendor Dispute Expands into Violent Melee
text: BEIJING — Authorities in a town near the southern metropolis of Guangzhou arrested 25 people after a dispute between street vendors and security guards grew into a confrontation with bottle-and-brick throwing onlookers, state news agencies reported Sunday.

headline: Miami’s Abandonment of the Full Pick-and-Roll Read
text: The Miami Heat has rightfully been roasted for an inability to muster more than 3 points over the final 3 minutes 23 seconds of Game 5, but the volume of that criticism has drowned out a dissonant fact about the Heat’s fourth-quarter performance. Before Miami’s collapse in clutch time, the Heat had spent half of the fourth quarter working its offense and scoring efficiently, and managed to turn a 5-point deficit into a 3-point lead.

headline: More Photos and More Calls for Weiner to Resign

text: NHE web data (pdf), Table 13. I deflated both sides by the consumer price index.

headline: With 18 Hits, the Yankees Are Humming Again
text: There was no meeting, no pep talk, no nothing after the Yankees were embarrassed by Boston last week. “Report at 4 o’clock the next day, that was it,” Curtis Granderson said. Every series has its own pace, its own rhythm. And at Yankee Stadium the thump-thump-thump of the Red Sox has given way to the off-key stylings of the Cleveland Indians.

headline: Q. and A. With the Puppeteers of ‘War Horse’

headline: Red Chain Reactions Against the Sky
text: The first performances of Trisha Brown’s “Roof Piece” took place on rooftops from 53 Wooster Street to 381 Lafayette Street in Manhattan, and even though I wasn’t there, a remarkable photograph from 1971 has always made me feel otherwise. In Babette Mangolte’s black-and-white image a dancer stands in the foreground. Leaning forward, one knee bent with her hands pressing into her lower back, she faces an industrial landscape where water towers and a panorama of rooftops dot a hazy horizon. She stares at it, and it stares back: a frontier of open space, freedom and possibility.

headline: A Little Lipstick Soothes Poverty’s Rawness
text: A small film with a gigantic heart, “The Lips” casts a spell far greater than its modest narrative. Shadowing three government social workers (perfectly embodied by Victoria Raposo, Eva Bianco and Adela Sanchez) on a trip deep into the impoverished Argentine countryside, this affecting merger of fact and fiction unfolds so naturally that the line between becomes immaterial.

headline: Mets’ Capuano Throws Zeroes and Support Arrives Late
text: PITTSBURGH — On Friday night, as Jose Reyes waited on deck for his turn at bat, a Pirates fan began to taunt him, trying in vain to highlight some perceived flaws in Reyes’s game. The heckler shouted that Reyes, who is in the final year of his contract, would never get a payday similar to the seven-year, $142 million deal that the Boston Red Sox gave Carl Crawford last winter and pointed out that Reyes does not hit home runs.

headline: Schick Uses Scent to Give Men’s Razor a Competitive Edge
text: IN 2005, Bic introduced what it said was the first disposable women’s razor with a scented handle, and competitors Gillette and Schick followed suit, selling women’s razors with scents like lavender, citrus and tropical. Right under the noses of razor marketers, meanwhile, was half of the population, but the prevailing wisdom was that men would reject scented razors as unmanly.

headline: Los Angeles Rap, New and Vintage, Straight Out of Brooklyn
text: Among the lights-and-action, spectacle-filled arenas and the jazz-soundtracked barbecue restaurants and the dizzying, echolocation-requiring nightclubs and the remote ramshackle warehouse spaces, occasionally New York City manages to cough up a truly weird experience, as it did Friday night.

headline: The Game of Twitter
text: For a Generation Xer born 34 years before Google, Anthony Weiner seemed to have a younger man’s knack for Internet culture. In merely 20 months using Twitter, the virtual social club that now has more than 200 million participants, Weiner managed to interest some 77,000 people in subscribing to his dispatches, jokes and provocations on topics ranging from hockey to finance to Israel’s borders.

headline: Three Bands, Floating Their Music on a Cool Breeze
text: Saturday night’s free concert at Central Park Summerstage amounted to three and a half hours of intelligent groove, informed by jazz but rarely beholden to it, with improvisation as a binding but nonidiomatic force. With three bands on the bill — Medeski Martin & Wood, Josh Roseman and the King Froopy All-Stars, and Jim Black’s AlasNoAxis — there were innumerable on-the-fly decisions about timbre and color, rhythm and counterrhythm. Each set was impressive in its own way, but there was continuity among them.

headline: Restarting Comics’ Clock Is Issue No. 1
text: Audacious. That is the best way to describe the recent DC Comics announcement that it was renumbering its entire DC Universe line of comics: by September 52 series will have begun anew, each with an issue No. 1.

headline: Philosophy as an Art of Dying
text: It happens rarely, but when it does it causes a commotion of great proportions; it attracts the attention of all, becomes a popular topic for discussion and debate in marketplaces and taverns. It drives people to take sides, quarrel and fight, which for things philosophical is quite remarkable. It happened to Socrates, Hypatia, Thomas More, Giordano Bruno, Jan Patocka, and a few others. Due to an irrevocable death sentence, imminent mob execution or torture to death, these philosophers found themselves in the most paradoxical of situations: lovers of logic and rational argumentation, silenced by brute force; professional makers of discourses, banned from using the word; masters of debate and contradiction, able to argue no more. What was left of these philosophers then? Just their silence, their sheer physical presence. The only means of expression left to them, their own bodies — and dying bodies at that.

headline: Publisher Brings Digital Shopping to Its Magazines
text: The photos and quizzes in Hearst’s online magazines are about to get a digital upgrade.

headline: A Fairy-Tale Anniversary
text: There is no better way for a performing ensemble to commemorate an anniversary than with a piece made to order. That is what the enterprising Riverside Symphony, celebrating its 30th anniversary, did on Friday night at Alice Tully Hall before a sizable audience of loyal supporters.

text: Scenes from a performance by the Trisha Brown Dance Company.

headline: With a Harvest of Prospects, UConn Baseball Makes Its Mark
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — The moment George Springer had waited and worked and prepared a lifetime for came and went last Monday without celebration. There were no embraces or back slaps from his family or Connecticut teammates, no party and no Champagne.

headline: Casey Anthony Coverage Gives HLN an Identity

headline: Peasants Having Fun Down on the Old Soviet Farm
text: To call Alexei Ratmansky, some of whose works have their obvious flaws, the most fascinating choreographer alive is unfair to such illustrious and older choreographers as Paul Taylor, Twyla Tharp, Mark Morris and Matthew Bourne, each of whom has made several more provably enduring masterpieces. Yet it’s tempting to do so.

headline: Erdogan’s Party Wins Third Term in Turkish Elections
text: ISTANBUL — The conservative party of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan won a clear victory in parliamentary elections on Sunday with a strong showing that critics worry might be used to further consolidate its power after nearly a decade of rule and to circumscribe civil liberties and its political opposition.

headline: Monday: How Much You Really Earned
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Right. Let’s all get it out of our systems now: Will Shortz likes to play table tennis. This puzzle is about table tennis. Ergo (from the Latin, meaning “I know some Latin and I like to show it off”), this constructor must have been published because he appealed to Mr. Shortz’s love of the pastime. Makes sense, right?

headline: Wartime Songs Keep Luster From Long Ago and Far Away
text: “Someone Talked!” the World War II propaganda poster screams. A terrified young soldier, drowning, points his finger in accusation toward the viewer, with the implication that his friend’s or neighbor’s gossip about his ship’s location was overheard by a German spy.

headline: ‘Super 8’ Surprises Viewers and the Box Office
text: A mix of science fiction suspense, coming-of-age drama and Spielbergian wonder proved to be a winning formula, giving “Super 8”  a better-than-expected opening weekend gross of $37 million and the No. 1 spot at the North American box office. The film, directed by J. J. Abrams, is one of the few summer releases that does not benefit from being a sequel or having a built-in fan base. In an effort to offset this handicap and spread some quick word of mouth Paramount Pictures held early screenings on Thursday and urged customers to tweet about the film. Private screenings were also held on Wednesday night for Twitter users with large numbers of followers. “X-Men: First Class” from 20th Century Fox held steady at second place with $25 million, dropping 55 percent from last weekend’s total, an above-average second-week showing for a summer blockbuster. That franchise reboot has accumulated a North American total of $98.9 million, according to Box Office Mojo, which tracks sales data. “The Hangover Part II” (Warner Brothers) was third with $18.5 million, proving the continued appeal of the misadventures of the Wolf Pack. In fourth place, “Kung Fu Panda 2” (DreamWorks Animation, via Paramount) piled on another $16.6 million. At fifth place with $10.8 million, “Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides” (Walt Disney Studios) crossed the $200 million mark in North America. So far at this summer’s box office, ticket sales are up 13.5 percent compared with this stage in the season last year, but are still down 9 percent for the year so far.

headline: Judy Garland’s Career in 2 Retrospectives
text: The Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Paley Center for Media are teaming up to present one of the most complete Judy Garland retrospectives in recent memory. The film society’s All Singin’, All Dancin’, All Judy! will feature 31 titles from Garland’s career, including “A Star Is Born” and a sing-along screening of “The Wizard of Oz” (above). There will also be a presentation of short films and rarities hosted by John Fricke, a Garland historian and author of the forthcoming “Judy: A Legendary Film Career” (Running Press, 2011). The retrospective will run from July 26 to Aug. 9 at the Walter Reade Theater; the Paley Center’s “Judy Garland: The Television Years,” a comprehensive collection of highlights and performances from “The Judy Garland Show, “The Ed Sullivan Show” and “Tonight,” will run from July 20 to Aug. 18.

headline: Looking for Truth in All That Lying
text: “Tangled Webs” is James B. Stewart’s engrossing re-examination of a quartet of celebrated federal investigations, all of which culminated in convictions for lying: the insider-trading probe that ultimately ensnared the homemaking diva Martha Stewart; the complex inquiry to determine who leaked to reporters the identity of the former C.I.A. covert operative Valerie Plame Wilson, which led to the perjury conviction of the ex-vice-presidential chief of staff  I. Lewis Libby; the long-running San Francisco grand jury probe into steroid use by athletes that implicated the sprinter Marion Jones and (after the book was finished) the home-run king Barry Bonds; and the Securities and Exchange Commission inquiries in which the reigning king of swindlers, Bernard L. Madoff, managed to gull overworked young investigators and keep his Ponzi scheme alive, prior to his ultimate undoing in 2008.

headline: An Eccentric Sendoff for a Festival’s Leader
text: DURHAM, N.C. — “Modern dance is an ongoing revolution,” Charles L. Reinhart said in 1987. At that point Mr. Reinhart had run the American Dance Festival for almost 20 years; on Thursday night the festival celebrated his 43-year reign and final season as director with an opening-night gala at the Durham Performing Arts Center here. Mr. Reinhart was honored with an appropriately eccentric lineup of pieces, punctuated by brief tributes to his influence on the dance world.

headline: The Online Looking Glass
text: In every time and place, people have associated new technologies with moral decline. “Men think that it is essential that the Nation have commerce,” Henry David Thoreau griped in 1854, “and export ice, and talk through a telegraph, and ride thirty miles an hour ... but whether we should live like baboons or like men, is a little uncertain.” Similar anxieties have greeted most subsequent inventions, from the automobile to the iPhone: We’re always teetering on the brink of baboondom, always one technological leap away from forfeiting our humanity.

text: In the not-so-wilds of Connecticut, the sightings have come with some regularity for years: Immense, muscled cats, with tails nearly as long as their torsos, emerging out of the forest, appearing first as a flash in the corner of the eye, and then suddenly, shockingly, in front of a motorist’s car.

headline: Woman Sexually Assaulted in Inwood Hill Park, Police Say
text: A woman was sexually assaulted while walking through Inwood Hill Park late last week, the police said on Sunday. The attack has left many women uneasy about using the park late in the day.

headline: To Curb Malpractice Costs, Judges Jump In Early
text: In Justice Douglas E. McKeon’s fluorescent-lighted chambers in the Bronx, a new way of handling medical malpractice suits was on full, and sometimes gruesome, display. Around a polished wood table, lawyers haggled over the price for a lost nose ($300,000) and the missing tip of a finger ($50,000).

headline: ‘Book of Mormon’ and ‘War Horse’ Win Top Tonys
text: “The Book of Mormon,” a smash-hit Broadway musical made out of the unlikeliest of elements — unwavering faith, jokes about AIDS and lyrics so profane that many of its songs could not be televised — emerged as the runaway winner at the Tony Awards on Sunday. Created by Trey Parker and Matt Stone of “South Park” fame, along with the composer Robert Lopez, “Mormon” earned nine Tonys, including best musical and three more for Mr. Parker, making this Broadway newcomer as honored in one evening as Joshua Logan, the director and a writer and producer of the classic musical “South Pacific.”

headline: Two States Ask if Paperwork in Mortgage Bundling Was Complete
text: Opening a new line of inquiry into the problems that have beset the mortgage loan process, two state attorneys general are investigating Wall Street’s bundling of these loans into securities to determine whether they were properly documented and valid.

headline: Mavericks Defeat Heat for First Title
text: MIAMI — The thumping, bumping, smoke-filled revelry that began 49 weeks ago, sweeping up South Beach in championship fever and transforming the Miami Heat into the most polarizing force in sports, ended in stunned silence Sunday night, in the same place where it all began.

headline: Libyan Leaders Defiant as Battle Rages at Oil City
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — With loyalist forces clashing for a second day with rebels around a strategic oil city less than 30 miles west of here, the government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi on Sunday told the “ugly, evil forces of NATO” to accept that the rebel cause was doomed and that the Libyan leader would not be driven from power by rebel attacks or NATO airstrikes.

headline: About That Tonys Rap
text: Neil Patrick Harris, the host of this year’s 65th annual Tony Awards, closed the ceremony with a rap composed by Lin-Manuel Miranda. In case you missed it, here is the transcript.

headline: In Nuclear Crisis, Crippling Mistrust
text: TOKYO — On the evening of March 12, the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant’s oldest reactor had suffered a hydrogen explosion and risked a complete meltdown. Prime Minister Naoto Kan asked aides to weigh the risks of injecting seawater into the reactor to cool it down.

headline: F.B.I. Agents Get Leeway to Push Privacy Bounds
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Bureau of Investigation is giving significant new powers to its roughly 14,000 agents, allowing them more leeway to search databases, go through household trash or use surveillance teams to scrutinize the lives of people who have attracted their attention.

headline: Word of the Day | monumental
text: monumental •\ˌmän-yə-ˈmen-təl\• adjective

headline: Dreaming of Center Stage, but the Gift Shop Is Already a Second Step
text: CENTRAL CITY, Colo. — Selling hardware in small-town Minnesota might not be the traditional route to an operatic career. And selling mugs and T-shirts in an opera house gift shop is also at least several steps removed from Laura Pancoast’s dream of life on the stage — and of tragic death each night as a doomed, love-besotted soprano.

headline: 2011 Tony Awards
text: Photos of the winning actors and shows.

headline: ‘Gay Girl in Damascus’ Blog a Hoax, American Says
text: Six days after a post on a well-known blog called “A Gay Girl in Damascus” triggered panic among its readers by suggesting that the author, who claimed to be a Syrian-American lesbian caught up in the protest movement, had been arrested, a new entry appeared on Sunday that described the entire online diary as a work of fiction by an American man.

headline: Tales of the Search for a Summer Job
text: Steve Jobs likes to tell how his own career in computers was shaped by a lucky summer job. Fascinated by electronics and already brash at age 13, he looked up Bill Hewlett, of Hewlett Packard, in the Palo Alto telephone book and called him. They talked shop, and the boy ended up putting in screws on an HP assembly line. His first day, he later said, was “bliss.”

headline: Turning to a City Program After an Earlier Search Proved Fruitless
text: BOSTON — Every time Jocelyn Herrera Lazo stepped into a store, she tried to apply for a summer job.

headline: NYT: Front Page for 06/13/2011
text: NYT: Front Page for 06/13/2011

headline: Summer Jobs of the Rich and Famous
text: The Chefs

headline: Pressure Grows Over Job Search as the School Year Winds Down
text: LOS ANGELES — Crystal Casciano had tickets to the Los Angeles Sparks WNBA game. But to get there, she needed money to fill her car’s gas tank.

headline: To Get His Job, He Just Worked Until Somebody Noticed
text: ATLANTA — Some teenagers search for jobs by asking their parents’ friends. Others submit résumé after résumé online. And then there is Cameron Stephens’s approach: work until they pay you.

headline: Convicted Militant Seeks Retrial in ’95 Case
text: More than 15 years after El-Sayyid A. Nosair was convicted of seditious conspiracy and of murdering Rabbi Meir Kahane, a dispute has erupted over a claim by Mr. Nosair that prosecutors improperly blocked his trial lawyers from gaining access to a witness who he says would have supported his claim of innocence, court papers show.

headline: Corrections
text: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Messages on news coverage can be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left toll-free at 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). Comments on editorials may be e-mailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.

headline: Tales of the Search for a Summer Job
text: Only one in four youths ages 16 to 19 is expected to find work this summer. Four teenagers share their stories.

headline: Mavericks Take Championship
text: With brilliant shooting from Jason Terry and a lethal final push from Dirk Nowitzki, the Mavericks claimed a 105-95 victory over the Heat and their first N.B.A. championship.

headline: News Quiz | June 13, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Bonnaroo: The Final Night
text: MANCHESTER, Tenn. — During the lengthy sound-checking before Superjam, one of the last gigs at Bonnaroo this year, a production assistant brought an enormous stack of towels to the stage. They were hardly used. Dr. John set up on Hammond organ along with Dan Auerbach and some of the members of the Black Keys’ new expanded touring band, as well as the drummer Patrick Hallahan of My Morning Jacket, two singers, and, in time, the Preservation Hall Jazz Band, which has strangely enough acted as a kind of binding glue for this festival.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, June 13, 2011
text: Test your math skills with today’s question, created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the article “Analysts Wary of LinkedIn’s Stock Surge.”

headline: Coming Right Back
text: Jeffrey Henson Scales, 57, a photographer and a photo editor at The New York Times, learned in 2008 that he had prostate cancer. Soon after his return from treatment in Toronto, Mr. Scales began taking pictures again — largely in Morningside Park and Times Square — at the urging of his wife, Meg Henson Scales, herself a photographer and writer. Running from Jan. 9 to Dec. 25, 2009, the pictures compose the exhibition “That Year of Living,” presented by the organization Light Work. It is on display until July 10 at the Robert B. Menschel Media Center in Syracuse.

headline: Gay Girl in Damascus Blogger Admits to Writing Fiction Disguised as Fact
text: Six days after a post on the blog A Gay Girl in Damascus triggered panic among its readers by suggesting that the blog’s author, who claimed to be a Syrian-American lesbian caught up in the protest movement, had been detained in the Syrian capital, a new entry appeared on Sunday that described the entire online diary as a work of fiction by an American man.

headline: Horizon Buys Power Rental Firm APR Energy
text: Horizon Acquisitions said Monday that it had bought APR Energy, the temporary power supplier backed by Madeleine Albright and George Soros, in a deal worth $855 million.

headline: Gingrich Attacks Obama in Return to Campaign Trail
text: LOS ANGELES — In his first campaign address since his top aides quit en masse last week, the Republican presidential hopeful Newt Gingrich delivered a blistering critique of the Obama administration’s Middle East policy on Sunday, hoping to revive his floundering campaign by shifting the focus to the kind of issue-based discussion he has viewed as his strength in this presidential campaign.

headline: The Early Word: New Edition
text: Today’s Times

headline: Everything You Need to Know About the New iTunes
text: Last week, at the opening of its annual developers’ conference, Apple announced iCloud — its new online storage and syncing service for music, photos, files and software. Although not all of its features are available immediately, one part — “iTunes in the Cloud Beta” — is, if you’ve updated to iTunes 10.3.1. Here is a primer about what you need to know, right now, about it.

headline: How to Cut Child Poverty in Half
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

headline: At Fair, the Flavors of London Suburbia
text: For the casual visitor, London’s squashed suburbia, with its tightly packed terraced houses and the occasional pub for visual relief, isn’t the most appealing aspect of the city. But amid London’s sprawl sit villages that were once outside the city. Among them is Highgate, a desirable neighborhood of Georgian town houses, independent cafes, antique shops and celebrity homes, perched atop a hill.

headline: The ‘Internet in a Suitcase’
text: WHO is leading a global effort to deploy “shadow” Internet and mobile phone systems? WHO are the groups using–and eager to use–such systems?WHO wants to silence the groups?

headline: Where Do You Find New Music?
text: In an  Op-Ed piece about college radio, former D.J. Freddie O’Connell writes about Vanderbilt University’s campus radio station, which, its license having been sold to the local public radio station, has gone off the air. Do the colleges and universities near where you live have radio stations? Do you listen to them? Do you listen to music on the radio in general? Why or why not?

headline: Congressional Week Ahead: Budget Agreement
text: The House and Senate will both be in session this week for the first time in June with a focus on trying to make progress in the negotiations toward a budget agreement.

headline: Saab Signs Up Another Chinese Investor
text: PARIS — In the latest twist on its road to recovery, Saab Automobile announced a deal Monday with two Chinese companies that will take stakes in the Swedish automaker and make and sell its cars in the world’s most populous country.

headline: This Week in Small Business: Repeal the Tanning Tax!
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

headline: Complaint Box | Going Up Standing Still
text: There are many platforms in the city’s rail system so deeply underground that climbing the stairs to the surface is daunting for the best of us. (Think Main Street, Flushing; the No. 7 at Grand Central Terminal; the Long Island Rail Road to 34th Street.) I occasionally braved the stairs, but after I hurt my knee I began to take escalators routinely — and quickly became aware of their express lanes.

headline: VF Corporation to Buy Timberland
text: The VF Corporation agreed on Monday to buy the Timberland Company, the boot maker, for about $2 billion in cash, paying a big premium in an effort to bolster its outdoor clothing offerings.

headline: Maple Makes Hostile Bid for Toronto Exchange Owner
text: The Maple Group on Monday moved forward in its hostile play for TMX Group with a $3.8 billion bid, besting a $3.6 billion offer by the London Stock Exchange.

headline: Ad Spending Increases Again, Report Finds
text: Advertising spending is continuing to recover from the recession and financial crisis, according to a report released Monday morning, although the rate of growth is slowing.

headline: Wendy’s Sells Arby’s to Private Equity Group
text: 10:35 a.m. | Updated

headline: Saving Electricity on a Philadelphia Subway Line
text: Subway trains need a lot of electricity to get going, turning electricity into kinetic energy, the energy of movement. When they pull into a station, many of them can do the opposite: generate electricity from their momentum. They turn their motors into generators to slow the train, producing current.

headline: Monday Reading: How to Avoid Credit Card Problems Abroad
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: The Rail’s Final Scoreboard, Year 4
text: How The Rail’s contributors did with their predictions this Triple Crown season (using a simple 3-2-1 point breakdown for win-place-show). Jim Squires, who scored in every race, led the final standings. (Our guest pickers struck out this season.)

headline: Best Political Quotes of the Weekend
text: Miss the best of the political chatter over the weekend? Don’t worry. The Caucus has gathered the quotes and clips you need to see.

headline: In Reversal, 3 Democratic Senators Will Back Gay Marriage
text: Updated, 3:45 p.m. | ALBANY — Three wavering Democratic lawmakers in the State Senate on Monday announced that they now support the legalization of same-sex marriage in New York, marking a potential turning point for the long-debated measure.

headline: High-Speed Trains in China to Run Slower, Ministry Says
text: BEIJING — China’s troubled Railway Ministry on Monday lowered the top operating speed for its flagship Beijing-to-Shanghai bullet train, which is set to open later this month, scaling down what was supposed to be a pinnacle of a transformed rail system that has become one of the country’s proudest and most ambitious domestic initiatives.

headline: The $2.6 Million Buffett Power Lunch
text: Lunch in New York just got a little more expensive.

headline: Honeywell to Buy EMS Technologies
text: Honeywell International said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire EMS Technologies, a maker of systems for mobile networks and satellites, for $506 million in cash.

headline: Wanderlust | A Buenos Aires Duo
text: At Fueguia, a new scent lab and shop in Buenos Aires’s Palermo Viejo neighborhood, Julian Bedel creates candles, room scents and perfumes from 100 different notes and a large helping of imagination. For a candle named after the fanciful writer Jorge Luis Borges, Bedel turned to the Asian champaca flower. “Borges would have dreams of tigers moving through fields of champaca,” he explains. Pulpería, named for a traditional gaucho’s pub, has notes of cedar, musk and pepper; Pampa Húmeda smells of the Argentine countryside; and the store’s namesake, Fueguier, is redolent of Patagonia (the name of the scent comes from the indigenous people Darwin encountered while on an expedition to the region). There are 23 soy-based candles in all, set in red, blue and clear glass and packed in hand-carved oak boxes. Customers can also create their own fragrances from ingredients like red mandarin, bergamot and Cis-3 Hexenol, which smells like grass.

headline: Aetna to Buy Genworth Unit
text: Aetna announced on Monday it would pay $290 million to acquire a Genworth unit focused on supplemental Medicare coverage.

headline: Live Blog: Riding the New East River Ferry, All Day
text: Ah, for a day out on the sea. Or, well, out on the East River.

headline: A Bang-Up Night for Broadway, Even if the Wrong Play Won
text: On behalf of men who wear hats — real hats, that is, not baseball caps, and certainly not caps with visors facing backward — I want to express some dismay that the Tony Award for best play did not go on Sunday night to the only show on Broadway with “hat” on the marquee. You know which play this is, the one with a troublesome word in the title, something about a guy with unresolved oedipal issues.

headline: Raising Keynes
text: I’m off to England for a couple of weeks; a shortish bike trip, then a conference, then some more touristing. Posting will be rare, columns will be on hold.

headline: When ‘Hero’ Rings Hollow
text: It is not uncommon for politicians, media figures and the general public to claim – without question – that those serving in the armed forces are heroes. Military service is unique, and the challenges faced by service members are unlike those of other professions. Violent death is a real possibility while wearing a service uniform. But does this make everyone who served a hero?

headline: Macro Readings Update
text: As I mentioned in an earlier post, I often have the sense that many of this readers of this blog are, in effect, entering in the middle of a conversation, not aware of the steps by which I got to the latest argument. This is especially true on issues of macroeconomics. So I thought it might be useful to maintain, for some time, a list of links to earlier posts that lay out some basic ideas I use repeatedly. Here they are as a blog post; in the near future they’ll become a standing feature on the right side of this page.

headline: Are You a Kind Boss? Or Kind of a Boss?
text: I’ve been writing for this blog for about two years now. It’s been interesting to learn how readers view the boss. Many people who comment are the boss, some want to be the boss, and others just have an opinion about the boss.

headline: Shares Eke Out Increase After 6 Weeks of Losses
text: Stocks rose on Monday after six weeks of losses, as an increase in takeovers and the cheapest valuations in almost a year helped offset concerns about a slowdown in the economic recovery.

headline: For His Tonys Speech, Rylance Turns to a Favorite Source
text: 12:00 p.m. | Updated

headline: On Strawberries and Riverfront Revivals
text: I had the pleasure of joining Pete Seeger, the Grammy-winning Rivertown Kids and some friends in some music on Sunday at the annual Beacon Sloop Club Strawberry Festival, which is held in a park on the Hudson River that was once a landfill. I was invited to speak on the remarkable ability of landscapes to recover ecological vigor and aesthetic appeal even after extraordinary degradation. There’s a bit more on what I said below.

headline: A Toast to Horse Racing, With a Classic Twist
text: Case Clay is President of Three Chimneys Farm, one of the premier Thoroughbred Farms in North America. He is a graduate of DePauw University, with a background in marketing and finance.

headline: TellApart Raises Money to Help Online Retailers Advertise
text: Offline retailers have many ways to identify their most promising customers. They can talk to people who come in to their stores and handle certain items, and are clearly in the mood to shop because they’re carrying shopping bags. Also, they can mail catalogs and coupons to shoppers who buy the most.

headline: James Can Learn From Nowitzki
text: Dirk Nowitzki had just turned 28 — or one and a half years older than LeBron James is now — when the Dallas Mavericks lost the 2006 N.B.A. finals to Dwyane Wade and a Miami team they couldn’t put away after leading by 2 games and 13 points with six minutes left in the fourth quarter of Game 3.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: The Cave Fish of Madagascar
text: John S. Sparks, curator of ichthyology at the American Museum of Natural History, writes from Madagascar, where he is studying cave fish.

headline: Bove: I Am Not Full of Hot Air
text: Richard X. Bove has a message: He is not full of hot air.

headline: Holding the Trophy, but Not His Tongue
text: MIAMI — For years, N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern had collected fines from Mark Cuban, the Dallas Mavericks’ owner. On Sunday night, the 2011 N.B.A. finals served up one last irresistible subplot when Stern was called upon to present Cuban with the Larry O’Brien championship trophy.

headline: Graham Packaging Discloses Higher Offer
text: 2:12 p.m. | Updated

headline: To London, in Discounted Style
text: It may not be a way to beat high summer airfares, but British Airways’ sale on business class tickets to London offers attractive savings. Sale tickets start at $1,055 each way, for flights leaving from all of British Airways’ gateways in the United States and Canada.

headline: Zvi Goffer Found Guilty in Insider Trading Case
text: Zvi Goffer, a trader nicknamed Octopussy because his arms reached into so many sources of information, was found guilty of insider trading Monday, the latest victory for the government in a sweeping crackdown on insider trading at hedge funds.

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ’90 Ways to Wake From Drowning’
text: This is the last of the 10 poems we’ve chosen as “favorites” from 650 submissions to our Found Poem Student Challenge. You can find the other nine here.

headline: Distributors of ‘Human Centipede’ Sequel Protest British Ban
text: Fighting for the rights of British filmgoers to see horror movies about hostages stitched together in deeply uncomfortable ways, the distributors of the “Human Centipede” sequel have protested a recent decision by Britain’s film board that will prevent the movie from being shown there and criticized the board for giving away some crucial plot details.

headline: Best Free Agent Forwards, Luongo vs. Thomas, Plus-Minus and the Next Chara?
text: Remember the summer day in 2003 when Teemu Selanne and Paul Kariya, very much in the primes of their respective careers, signed with the Colorado Avalanche? The unrestricted free agent class of 2011 won’t make anyone forget it.

text: Rudy Giuliani, 2008:

headline: Without Fossil Fuel, Two Teams Prepare for Nürburgring 24 Hours
text: While most racers competing at the ADAC Nürburgring 24 Hours this month will burn high-octane racing gasoline or conventional diesel, two entrants will run on fuel that may have been used to fry wiener schnitzel.

headline: Fuller and Blackwell Create Joint Venture for Established Artists
text: The creator of “American Idol” and the record executive behind Bob Marley and U2 have started a joint venture to develop media and branding deals for superstar musicians who no longer have recording contracts.

headline: When Nature Destroys in Slow Motion
text: KEENE VALLEY, N.Y. — On May 6, the iris garden alongside Jim and Charity Marlatts’ house on a mountain two hours north of Albany was cleaved by a small crack only two inches wide. It was the start of a natural catastrophe, one that is still unfolding at an excruciatingly slow pace.

headline: Numberplay: Let’s Play 1-2 Nim
text: Katherine Cook and Dan Finkel bring us Nim — a classic game of strategy and logic.

headline: Republican Debate Prep: What to Watch For in New Hampshire
text: 2:13 p.m. | Updated The first Republican presidential debate of the 2012 campaign, held in South Carolina several weeks ago, produced precious little drama, in part because some of the major candidates chose not to participate.

headline: Asked & Answered | Marianne Goebl
text: Last year, when Ambra Medda, the co-founder and former director of the annual design fairs Design Miami and Design Miami/ Basel, unexpectedly announced her resignation, tongues were wagging in the international world of collectible design: Who could replace her?

headline: With 1.2 Billion People, India Seeks a Good Hangman
text: MEERUT, India — India has 1.2 billion people, among them bankers, gurus, rag pickers, billionaires, snake charmers, software engineers, lentil farmers, rickshaw drivers, Maoist rebels, Bollywood movie stars and Vedic scholars, to name a few. Humanity runneth over. Except in one profession: India is searching for a hangman.

headline: Carole King to Tell Her Story in Memoir
text: Carole King, the longtime singer-songwriter, has written her first memoir, her publisher, Grand Central Publishing, said on Monday. The memoir, “A Natural Woman,” is scheduled for release in April 2012.

headline: 19-Year-Old Is Arrested in Boardwalk Shooting
text: A 19-year-old-man has been arrested in connection with a shooting last week on the crowded Boardwalk in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, in which a 16-year-old girl was killed and four others were wounded, the authorities said on Monday.

headline: Clinton Presses Africans to Abandon Authoritarian Rulers, Singling Out Qaddafi
text: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton bluntly warned African leaders on Monday that authoritarian governments ruled by aging despots were “no longer acceptable,” saying that those who refused democratic reforms would find themselves “on the wrong side of history.”

headline: El Tri Scores 4, Looks for More
text: The most popular and most successful soccer team in the United States will be returning to the New York metropolitan area and expects to draw another capacity crowd to a stadium in the New Jersey Meadowlands.

headline: Justices Turning More Frequently to Dictionary, and Not Just for Big Words
text: WASHINGTON — In a decision last week in a patent case, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. puzzled out the meaning of a federal law by consulting the usual legal materials — and five dictionaries.

headline: Living With Mistakes
text: Some of the blogs I follow—Marginal Revolution, Ezra Klein—have given ample attention to Tim Harford’s new book, “Adapt: Why Success Always Starts with Failure.” So I solipsistically assumed that everybody must be aware of it. But then I happened to glance at this book’s Amazon ranking, which as I write is down on the wrong side of 1,500. This is an outrage, people! For the good of the world, a bigger slice of humanity should be aware of its contents.

headline: Aging Left-Hander Will Play Two at Yankee Stadium
text: Paul McCartney has added a second date at Yankee Stadium, “by overwhelming popular demand,” according to an announcement on Monday morning. The second concert will be Saturday, July 16, the day after the first show, and tickets went on sale through Ticketmaster.com at 11:40 a.m., Eastern time. As for the first concert, prices range from $34 to $279.50, plus fees.

headline: Using Google Searches to Track Housing Prices
text: The Bank of England has started to use Google search data to help it spot trends in Britain’s housing and labor markets.

headline: The Claim: A Sunscreen Chemical Can Have Toxic Side Effects
text: THE FACTS

headline: The Job to End All Others
text: I was in the middle of a business meeting when my 17-year-old son called the office and told the receptionist it was urgent.

headline: Michelle Obama Pushes for Better Treatment of Military in Hollywood
text: LOS ANGELES—First Lady Michelle Obama will have her work cut out for her when she turns up here today for a talk with members of the Hollywood guilds about getting more positive attention for military service members and their families into popular entertainment.

headline: Should Women Be Doctors?
text: Yes, it’s a purposefully provocative headline, but it goes to the core of the debate over life/work balance.

headline: Germany Officially Recognizes Libyan Rebel Government
text: BERLIN — Germany, which declined to participate in the NATO air campaign against Libya, on Monday recognized the opposition National Transitional Council as the legitimate representative of Libya, Foreign Minister Guido Westerwelle said during a visit to the rebel capital of Benghazi.

headline: ‘Scottsboro Boys’ Sets Record for Tonys Futility
text: “The Scottsboro Boys,” the final collaboration between the composer John Kander and the lyricist Fred Ebb, seemed to have a shot at redemption for its short-lived, six-week Broadway run when it was nominated for 12 Tony Awards in May, the second-highest tally after the much-lauded “Book of Mormon.” Instead, “The Scottsboro Boys” set a record at Sunday night’s ceremonies by becoming the most nominated show to receive no Tony Awards, the American Theater Wing confirmed.

headline: Disparities: Health Risks Seen for Single Mothers
text: Middle-aged women who were single when they had their first child are in worse health than similar women who were married when first giving birth, suggesting that the stress of being a single parent has long-term health consequences, a new study has found.

headline: Social Media Join Toolkit for Hunters of Disease
text: On a chilly February night in Los Angeles, attendees at the DomainFest Global Conference crushed together in a tent at the Playboy Mansion for cocktails and dancing. Two days later, Nico Zeifang, a 28-year-old Internet entrepreneur from Germany, woke up with chest pains, chills and a soaring fever. Four colleagues shared his symptoms, Mr. Zeifang soon learned.

headline: Report Says Clarence Clemons Had a Stroke
text: Clarence Clemons, the saxophonist who has played for nearly 40 years with Bruce Springsteen and the E-Street Band, has had a serious stroke, according to a Springsteen fan Web site with close connections to the band and tweets by associates of Mr. Clemons. The site, Backstreets.com, said that Mr. Clemons, 69, had undergone two brain surgeries at a hospital near his home in Florida after the stroke, which was described as “massive,” but is “responsive and in stable condition.”

headline: Risks: Better Odds for Surviving Complex Surgery
text: The odds that a Medicare patient will die after undergoing one of eight high-risk operations have fallen sharply, an analysis of medical records has found.

headline: Marching Through Life With Parkinson’s
text: Dr. Karen Jaffe, an obstetrician-gynecologist in Cleveland, was only 48 when she learned she had Parkinson’s disease. Four years later, she continues to maintain a full-time medical and surgical practice, even performing ritual circumcisions.

headline: Famous Last Words: No More Stocks Ever!
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

headline: Just One Look | Balenciaga Resort Collection
text: In his resort collection for Balenciaga, Nicolas Ghesquière turned the volume way up. Key pieces included a blouse with serious wingspan and a dramatically undulating “umbrella” skirt. Even the heel of the shoe had a provocative bulge. Resounding through the collection was a new print for the season that mixed a hand-painted brick motif adapted from the Balenciaga archive with a roughly drawn houndstooth pattern. Executed in scorching fuchsia, the cacophony was rather brilliant.

headline: Perelman Offers to Buy Out M&F Worldwide
text: Ronald O. Perelman‘s holding company, MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings, on Monday offered to buy out the rest of M&F Worldwide that it did not already own.

headline: The Getaway Car
text: As Jonathan Raban and his daughter, Julia, drove the distance that will separate them once she’s away at college, the landscape around them became a reflection of how unnatural, earth-shattering, wrong this natural separation feels. Raban knows, as Richard Bernstein wrote in The Times in 1999 when reviewing his book “Passage to Juneau,” that “Wildness is not friendly, but … neither is human life.”

headline: Sentence of the Week, Heat-Wave Edition
text: It was almost too hot last week to track down and tweet good sentences, but somehow (i.e., by wiping myself down continuously with hand towels) I managed. Here’s what I came up with:

headline: Her $16,000 Town House, Now Available for Just $1.879 Million More
text: When Mildred Furiya moved to a 19th-century town house on State Street in Brooklyn from a cramped walkup in Greenwich Village in 1967, a boarding house known for prostitution stood across a barren street, groups of unemployed men hung out on the corner and the Brooklyn House of Detention was a defining presence a block away. Standing in the garden — which functioned as a garbage dump for the apartment building next door — her husband, George, was almost hit in the head by a plaster Madonna statue someone had thrown from a window.

headline: Bruins’ Tim Thomas Aims to Stay Steady

Who’s scoring, who’s in a drought, who’s able to draw those key penalties to jump-start an important power play usually consumes the attention of the critics and fans.

headline: The Importance of Being Audited

headline: A Low-Impact Stove for Rwanda
text: Last year, Eric Reynolds, the co-founder of the outdoor sports gear company Marmot, contacted me with an aggressive business plan for rolling out fuel-efficient, low-pollution cookstoves across Rwanda. Having seen dozens of entrepreneurial projects in Rwanda start with a big bang and then founder for lack of momentum and commitment, I initially brushed off his enthusiasm. I gently explained that he would have to move to Rwanda if he was to get anything done, and he explained that this was exactly his plan.

headline: Patterns: Prenatal Vitamins May Ward Off Autism

headline: Farm-Fresh Favas

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry

The employees of Apex that are joining Big Fuel include its founders, Ben Luntz and Josh Scheiner. Jennifer Barron joined the New York office of Prophet as a senior partner. She had been senior vice president for strategy and market insights at Fidelity Investments, Boston.

Though pleasing to the eye, such landscapes are sorely lacking in automotive context.

headline: Making Hiring Cheaper
text: On Friday, I wrote about how equipment and software prices are getting rapidly cheaper while the cost of labor has been getting more expensive, making capital a more attractive investment to companies than people. Tax incentives that encourage earlier capital investment may be helping, too.

headline: Tony Telecast Sees Dip in Viewers
text: The 65th Annual Tony Awards may have been a big success for “The Book of Mormon” on Sunday night, but in ratings they were not for CBS. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 6.9 million viewers tuned in to the awards show on CBS, down slightly from last year’s broadcast (7 million) as well as the 2009 show (7.4 million), the last time Neil Patrick Harris performed host duties. But this year’s show did fare a bit better among viewers 18 to 49 compared with last year, improving by one-tenth of a ratings point in that demographic.

headline: Google Agrees to Acquire Admeld
text: Google said Monday that it had agreed to buy Admeld, a display advertising start-up.

headline: Finding Purpose on a Trip to Vietnam
text: I ABSOLUTELY love flying. It’s the only time during the week I feel unencumbered. But that’s slowly changing as more flights offer Internet access. People wind up finding me and I feel the need to respond — well, most of the time.

headline: Governor Gregoire of Washington to Retire
text: SEATTLE – Gov. Christine Gregoire of Washington, a two-term Democrat who has steered the state through a period of painful budget cuts, said Monday that she would not seek a third term.

headline: Drawing Dance: Scenes From the Merce Cunningham Legacy Tour
text: The Brooklyn-based artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting their two-year Legacy Tour through a series of drawings and paintings. After 58 years, the company is scheduled to disband on New Year’s Day 2012.

headline: A Graduation That May Carry Unnecessary Risk
text: Right before I moved from Boston to New York City, I went to see one of my patients graduate from high school. I was in an elegiac mood — leaving the city, saying goodbye to friends — and I teared up as I watched her from the balcony. It felt right that her time as my pediatric patient was ending not with my moving away, but with her marching proudly into the future.

headline: A Perfect Doctor, but Behind the Times
text: For millions of us he was the perfect physician, even if he never existed.

headline: Agency Cuts Greece’s Debt Rating Again
text: LONDON — Standard & Poor’s, the credit ratings agency, lowered its grade on Greek debt to CCC on Monday in the latest sign that the market believes that Greece will be forced to default on its debt. The three-notch downgrade makes Greece’s debt the lowest-rated in the world by S.& P., a spokesman for the agency said.

headline: As Local Militias Expand in Northern Afghanistan, Tales of Abuse Follow
text: KABUL – Arbakai militias are a growing feature of life in northern Afghanistan, and many of them are actually former Taliban insurgents who have declared for the government side. So if they levy taxes on local villagers and beat up people they do not get along with, at least they’re not fighting on the side of the enemy, right?

headline: Italian Voters Come Out to Overturn Laws and Deliver a Rebuke to Berlusconi
text: ROME — Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi suffered a stinging political defeat on Monday when voters overturned laws passed by his government that would have restarted Italy’s nuclear energy program, privatized the water supply and granted him immunity from prosecution.

headline: $4.3 Billion Pledged at Vaccine Fund-Raiser
text: Public and private donors have pledged $4.3 billion toward vaccinating children against a variety of diseases, according to the GAVI Alliance, which held its first fund-raising conference for vaccines in London on Monday.

headline: Supreme Court Ruling in Janus Case Limits Shareholder Suits

text: Update | July 29: The contest has now ended. To see our four winners, one each week of July, please visit this page. Thank you to all who participated!

headline: Sizing Up the Deal for Timberland
text: After the Timberland Company’s agreed $2 billion sale to the VF Corporation, other buyers may be hungry for more outdoor and footwear company deals. It is not clear, however, that the strategic logic for the merger can translate well for other businesses in the sector. DealBook’s Adrienne Carter and Michael J. de la Merced analyze the deal.

headline: Documentaries Supposed to Make Money, Court Told
text: LOS ANGELES — Bad enough that documentarians have a hard time getting an audience for their wares. Now the United States Tax Court is raising alarms throughout the documentary world by questioning whether documentary-making can generally be considered for-profit activity.

headline: Does James Need His Own P.R. Firm?
text: Since making The Decision to head to Miami last summer, LeBron James has come under fire whenever he has taken a misstep or failed to succeed. He is critiqued in the news media and made the butt of jokes on Twitter. Sometimes you want to feel bad for him. Then he does something that sweeps the sympathy right out of you, and makes you wonder what kind of advice he’s getting — if any at all.

headline: Seeking New Energy to (Re)Focus the Nation
text: Focus the Nation, a youth-oriented nonprofit group aiming to propel a transition toward non-polluting energy choices, is preparing for Recharge!, an August retreat on Mount Hood in Oregon at which members of what I call Generation E will chart new ways to forge progress. The group is offering expenses-paid trips to the week-long meeting for five young leaders in each of four areas the group defines as “technicians, innovators, politicos and storytellers.”

headline: Making Waves
text: The change of season calls not only for lighter fabrics and abbreviated hems but for a reconsideration of one’s grooming practices too. Whether it’s a sunscreen with enough SPF to withstand the summer’s harsh rays or a simple update of hairstyle, a change to your regimen can be as refreshing as a new pair of shorts. Modeled on the season’s It boys — who themselves reflect the wide spectrum of male beauty today — these tips and trends will help you embrace the transition effortlessly. Rick Perry’s call for a “day of prayer and fasting on behalf of our troubled nation,” which has been criticized for being exclusively Christian, is open to people of any faith — “who will feel the love, grace and warmth of Jesus Christ in that assembly hall,” the event’s chief spokesman explained on Monday in a statement that provoked new charges that the event is intended to convert non-Christians.

headline: Type Matters
text: For all of the magazine’s themed issues, the art department strives to develop a look and feel that is specific to the issue’s topic, yet still feels like The Times Magazine. This often involves rolling out a new font. This past Sunday’s Voyages issue was about travel in America. The destinations in the articles weren’t exotic but, rather, familiar places made interesting by the experiences and observations of the writers. With the design, we wanted to develop a visual language that subtly evoked Americana and also felt unique and personal, like the articles themselves. We looked at a variety of travel-related materials: everything from postcards to airline identities to airport-way-finding systems.

Here is Sullivan last week, mounting a quasi-defense of Weiner’s behavior by placing it in the context of the online world’s come-ons and confusions:

headline: National Design That’s Hidden in Plain Sight
text: One sign of a powerful style is its invisibility. It is so familiar it is scarcely noticed. It is so natural, how could things be otherwise? We don’t really pay attention to the style itself. Instead we notice contrasts, variations, violations.

headline: Imagining a Secret Life for Diana
text: Staging one’s own death or disappearance, or switching identities with someone else: it’s not just a premise of witness protection (and witness protection comedies like “Bird on a Wire”), but it’s also the catalyst of classic works like Antonioni’s landmark film “The Passenger” and Anthony Minghella’s Hitchcockian thriller “The Talented Mr. Ripley.” Not to mention a fantasy of anyone who has ever imagined ditching all the emotional baggage and obligations accumulated over the years and starting over, tabula rasa.

headline: A Video Tour of Progress at Ground Zero
text: When Christopher O. Ward took over as executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in 2008, the reconstruction effort at ground zero was in disarray. So he and his team promptly tore up the plans and started over. “We came to realize that the most important part of this project is the plaza,” Mr. Ward said, referring to the green space and cobblestones that will surround the buildings’ footprints. “It had to be done by the 10-year anniversary.”

Muammar el-Qaddafi, a man who has been known to want to pitch a tent for his comfort in Manhattan’s Central Park, along with a host of other behaviors unusual in a national leader.
