headline: A ‘Napoli’ Changed, Yet Unchanging
text: WASHINGTON — Ballet is an art so laden with tradition that today’s foremost practitioners all seem at most six degrees of separation from the leading lights of the Romantic period. This is nowhere more true than with the Royal Danish Ballet. The set for Act III of August Bournonville’s “Napoli” (1842) features a bridge from which little children watch the cornucopia of choreography. Some of the leading figures in the ballet world — Peter Martins, the ballet master in chief of New York City Ballet, and Nikolaj Hübbe, the artistic director of the Royal Danish Ballet — once stood on that bridge.

headline: New Music
text: BARRY MANILOW

headline: Just One Look | Missoni
text: This resort collection from Missoni is meant to evoke beach escapades and the mementos gathered along the way. A viscose-blended ocean blue knit dress and matching cardigan use gathered fabric paillettes, cowrie shells and mother-of-pearl to hint at the ebb and flow of the Mediterranean landscape. The collection also includes scalloped-detailed polo shirts, lobster orange platforms and long breezy chiffon dresses.

headline: Tracy Morgan Plans Meetings to Make Amends for Antigay Comments
text: Following the widespread uproar over a recent standup routine that was condemned for several anti-gay remarks, Tracy Morgan said he will meet with gay youths in New York and return to Tennessee, where he performed the show, to apologize to people who were offended by his act.

headline: Madison Avenue Turns a Keen Eye Toward Mothers
text: An organization that seeks to improve the quality of information about how consumers consume media is releasing its most comprehensive data to date.

headline: A Television Family Tree That Bears Surprising Fruit
text: Midway through the first hour of “The Nine Lives of Chloe King,” television’s latest capitulation to the vigorous appetite for fantastical 10th graders, the title character sits down to some cake with her mother and delivers a selective briefing of the day’s events. For Chloe, it’s been an intense 24 hours. Spurred on by an unfamiliar sense of confidence and daring on the eve of her 16th birthday, she kisses a boy for the first time, thus inadvertently endangering his life, an event followed by a swift and weaponless takedown of a random attacker on the streets of San Francisco. We are near “Twilight” country, and the ominous fog is nearly as dense.

headline: Superstars Never Guessed the Size of ‘Spider-Man’ Challenges
text: In their fullest comments yet about the creative clashes this winter inside “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” Bono and the Edge, of U2 — first-time Broadway composers — said they originally embraced Julie Taymor’s script and characters for the show but were wholly ill-prepared for putting her ambitious ideas onstage. They ultimately lost faith in her and quietly maneuvered to overhaul “Spider-Man,” before finally shocking Ms. Taymor, their longtime collaborator, with her ouster in March.

headline: Religion and Family at Odds (With Blacks Playing Jews)
text: If I. D. Berkovitch’s play “Under the Cross” feels like a theatrical missive from another time and place, that’s because it is. It hails from the vanished province of Yiddishland and considers the problem of how to be a Jew in a world hostile to the very idea.

headline: It Was a Hot Time in Tennessee at the Snob-Free Bonnaroo Fest
text: MANCHESTER, Tenn. — The 10th Bonnaroo Music & Arts Festival ended on Sunday, and more than 85,000 people returned to civilian life, their ears ringing with too much music. Because it is a brand with a mysterious grip on hale young-adult Americans with mystical tendencies, because it broke little aesthetic ground and because it’s a milestone year, let’s do consumer service first.

headline: 150 Chemicals Are No Longer Incognito
text: This month the Environmental Protection Agency made public the names of 150 chemicals that were investigated in health and safety studies but whose identities were withheld as confidential business information.

headline: A New Anchor, but the Same Ratings, on CBS
text: CBS introduced Scott Pelley as the new anchor of its evening news with no fanfare last week, and the result was no new fans.

headline: Glass’s Players Warm Up for a Festival in August
text: Followers of the composer Philip Glass could scarcely miss a turn in recent decades from the hypnotic extended works that earned him the Minimalist label toward the traditional forms and trappings of the classical music mainstream. Interviewing Mr. Glass onstage in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Saturday night, Richard Guérin, the associate director of Mr. Glass’s record label, Orange Mountain Music, noted the development.

headline: Now Arriving | Orla Kiely
text: On this side of the Atlantic, Orla Kiely is best known for her instantly recognizable leaf-print bags, which hang on strollers from Brooklyn to Santa Monica. But the Irish-born, London-based designer makes much more than just mummy-friendly diaper bags. She also has home décor and ready-to-wear lines, both of which feature cheerful graphics and mod silhouettes. And while it’s taken a while, London hipsters have finally lit upon her her clothing designs, which make references to the Chelsea girl charm of Mary Quant, Julie Christie and Jean Shrimpton. Thanks to bright young fans like Alexa Chung and Keira Knightley, Kiely is enjoying some well-deserved celebrity on her home turf. It helps, of course, that she has a bevy of cool girls working for her. Venetia Scott, the Marc Jacobs stylist-turned-photographer, shoots her ad campaigns, and Leith Clark, the Canadian editor of the British indie fashion magazine Lula, styles them. Her first American store is set to open in SoHo in September. In anticipation, Kiely’s hosting an event at the Ace Hotel tomorrow night. Chung will D.J. and Mercedes Heinwein’s short film about the fall collection, which was inspired by Tippi Hedren’s wardrobe in “The Birds,” will be screened. Describing her recent success, which she’s hoping to replicate in the United States, Kiely is as well mannered and ladylike as her neat blouses and primly tailored coats. “Oh, gosh, I’ve really just been enjoying it,” she says. “I hope Americans like the clothes, too.”

headline: Obama Suggests That Weiner Step Down
text: President Obama said on Monday that if he were in Representative Anthony D. Weiner’s position, “I would resign,” according to NBC, which conducted an extensive interview with him.

headline: An Afternoon of Aggressive Hair and Forlorn Boots
text: The Gotham Dance Festival wrapped up over the weekend with its second summer sampler matinee, and it was as mixed up as mixed bills can be.

headline: Laura Ziskin, Producer of ‘Spider-Man’ and ‘Pretty Woman,’ Dies at 61
text: LOS ANGELES — Laura Ziskin, a prominent Hollywood producer who ventured into the largely male world of special-effects movies to become a shaping force behind the blockbuster “Spider-Man” franchise, died on Sunday at her home in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 61.

headline: Major Art Gift to Stanford
text: In an economically rough period when many university art museums seem to be in a position of retreat, Stanford University plans to announce on Tuesday that it will soon be a major West Coast presence in postwar art. The university is accepting a donation of works from one of the most important private collections of Abstract Expressionism. The group of 121 paintings and sculptures, owned by Harry W. and Mary Margaret Anderson, had long been expected to make its way to the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, which has been the beneficiary of the Andersons for many years. But the couple, known as Hunk and Moo, said in a statement that “we have always been closely associated with colleges and universities, and in making this gift to Stanford we anticipate the students, the public and the entire art community will have the opportunity to fully engage the collection.” The collection, which the Andersons began building in the 1960s, includes one of the last major Jackson Pollock drip paintings still in private hands, “Lucifer,” from 1947, when Pollock was making his transition from a more traditional style to his signature volcanic canvases. Several years ago dealers familiar with the painting said that the Andersons had turned down as much as $100 million for it. The collection also includes significant works by Franz Kline, Robert Motherwell, Mark Rothko, David Smith, Helen Frankenthaler, Sam Francis and Philip Guston. Stanford said that by 2014 it expected to complete construction of a building to house the collection, which includes 86 artists in all, in styles including Abstract Expressionism and reflecting movements like Light and Space and Color Field painting.

headline: The Turnesa Legacy
text: A half century later, the Turnesa name is back in the U.S. Open golf tournament.

headline: Wisconsin: Republicans May Not Wait for Court to Rule on Union Limits
text: Republican lawmakers say that if the State Supreme Court does not rule by Tuesday on collective bargaining limits they passed this spring, they will simply pass the limits again. The law, which sharply curtails bargaining rights for public workers, has not taken effect because of legal challenges. A judge ruled last month that Republican legislators violated open-meetings requirements when they passed it, but state officials have appealed that decision. Lawmakers may now attach the limits to the state’s new budget bill, which is to be considered this week, Speaker Jeff Fitzgerald, Republican of Horicon, said Monday.

headline: Washington: Governor Won’t Run in ’12
text: Gov. Christine Gregoire, a two-term Democrat who has steered her state through a period of painful budget cuts, said Monday that she would not seek a third term. Her decision was not unexpected, and it clears the way for what some political observers expect to be an extremely close race in 2012. Rob McKenna, a Republican who is the state’s attorney general, announced his long-anticipated candidacy last week. Representative Jay Inslee, a Democrat whose district includes parts of the politically crucial Seattle region, has signaled for months that he would run if Ms. Gregoire did not. The state, like many others, has been forced to make major spending cuts, including to schools and social programs, and the question is whether frustration with the its direction will be enough to overcome Democratic control.

headline: Missouri: 2 Levees Are Breached
text: As the Missouri River continued to rise to record levels, two protective levees ruptured Monday, sending floodwaters pouring over fields and toward small communities in Missouri and Iowa. The breaches had been expected in both Hamburg, Iowa, and Big Lake, Mo. Despite the construction of secondary levees to hold back the water, evacuations were under way because of concerns that those hastily built barriers might also fail. The dam-controlled river, which has caused flooding from Montana to Missouri because of record rain and snow, is expected to remain at flood levels for the next two months.

headline: 2 Underwhelming Choices for TMX
text: Pity the TMX Group’s shareholders. The owners of the Toronto stock exchange face an unenviable choice of suitor. Neither the London Stock Exchange nor the Maple Group, which went hostile with its counteroffer of 3.7 billion Canadian dollars ($3.8 billion) on Monday, has made a compelling bid for the bourse.

headline: Scientists Measure the Accuracy of a Racism Claim
text: Scientists have often been accused of letting their ideology influence their results, and one of the most famous cases is that of Morton’s skulls — the global collection amassed by the 19th-century physical anthropologist Samuel George Morton.

headline: Yemen’s Opposition Meets With Government Officials
text: SANA, Yemen — Leaders of the political opposition met on Monday with Yemen’s vice president, Abed Rabbo Mansour al-Hadi, and two other senior governing party officials here in the first known meeting between the two sides since the beginning of the year.

headline: E.P.A. Plans Delay of Rule on Emissions
text: WASHINGTON — Facing intense opposition from Congressional Republicans and industry over a broad range of new air-quality regulations, the Environmental Protection Agency said Monday that it was delaying by two months the release of a proposed rule on greenhouse gas emissions from power plants and other major pollution sources.

text: MEURSAULT, France

text: Physicists from Harvard Medical School have created the world’s first living laser, using a cell.

headline: In 5-4 Vote, Supreme Court Limits Securities Fraud Suits
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday ruled that a mutual fund’s investment adviser may not be sued for securities fraud over misstatements in fund prospectuses.

headline: The Diving Bell and the Underwater Spider
text: Of the tens of thousands of spider species, only Argyroneta aquatica spends its lifetime underwater — even though, like its terrestrial counterparts, it requires oxygen to survive.

headline: The Punches, Verbal as Much as Physical, Keep Coming
text: BOSTON — The N.H.L. does not keep track of such things, but if there were records in the Stanley Cup finals for taunting, petulance and sniping through the news media, and even in the streets, the Canucks-Bruins series might hold several of them, even before Game 6 was played Monday.

headline: Tickets for a Potential Milestone Grow Hotter
text: It has been a matter of when, not if, Derek Jeter will reach the 3,000-hit milestone. And as he approaches the mark, predicting when he will reach 3,000 is becoming easier.

headline: In Hedging Iowa Bets, Is Romney Going for Silver?
text: On Thursday, amid the media frenzy surrounding Anthony Weiner and Newt Gingrich, Mitt Romney’s campaign announced that their candidate would not compete in the Ames, Iowa straw poll — despite the fact that Mr. Romney won the straw poll in 2007 and that he currently leads in surveys of the Iowa caucuses.

text: The Boston Bruins will live to play another day.

text: To the Editor:

headline: A Fast Life and Success That Starts in the Pouch
text: We found them in a corner of our garage: a half-dozen baby opossums, peeping like birds, squirming over one another and scratching the wall. They were cute and ghastly in an “Addams Family” sort of way, their long snouts tapered like wine stoppers, their black eyes bulging up from their pale fur like peppercorns from a bed of rice, and their tiny teeth as sharp and plentiful as a piranha’s.

headline: Live Blogging the G.O.P. Debate in New Hampshire
text: Seven Republican candidates for president are set to take the stage in Manchester, N.H., for a debate Monday evening that will include questions asked by moderators, posed by live panels of voters, and submitted via Twitter and Facebook.

headline: Tracing of Rice Genomes Reveals Cross-Breeding
text: Last month, a study in The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences claimed to end a longstanding dispute about the two major subspecies of rice, indica and japonica. Researchers studied select gene regions of the species and suggested that both had a single point of origin, in the Yangtze Valley of China.

headline: Hot Posada May Be Cooled by Schedule
text: There is never a bad time to start hitting, butJorge Posada certainly could have planned his recent hot streak better.

headline: Afterward, a Blend of Defiance, Disdain and Diplomacy
text: MIAMI — It was after midnight when LeBron James and Dwyane Wade — friends, teammates, co-captains, coequals in defeat — took the stage one final time. The partnership was intact, though diminished by failure.

text: Q.

headline: Adoptions by Gay Couples Rise, Despite Barriers
text: Growing numbers of gay couples across the country are adopting, according to census data, despite an uneven legal landscape that can leave their children without the rights and protections extended to children of heterosexual parents.

headline: Rescuing the Real Uncle Tom
text: THE novelist Harriet Beecher Stowe, born 200 years ago today, was an unlikely fomenter of wars. Diminutive and dreamy-eyed, she was a harried housewife with six children, who suffered from various obscure illnesses worsened by her persistent hypochondria.

headline: Soreness Knocks Santana Off the Mound
text: PITTSBURGH — Johan Santana, who is recovering from surgery last September to repair his left shoulder, stopped pitching off a mound a week and a half ago because of soreness in the joint.

headline: In a ‘Perfect Storm,’ One Case of Equine Herpes Becomes Many
text: FORT LUPTON, Colo. — The death of Chief, a highly trained performance horse found here last month in his stall, unable to stand, the victim of a raging neurological infection, was certainly a major emotional and financial loss for his owners.

headline: Opportunity in Somalia After Killing of Qaeda Militant
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Once again, the Transitional Federal Government of Somalia has been handed a golden opportunity.

headline: Obama Offers Training Plan Designed for High-Tech Jobs
text: DURHAM, N.C. — Confronting the challenge of running for re-election while the unemployment rate remains stubbornly high, President Obama convened a session of his new jobs council on Monday, offering a proposal to train 10,000 American engineering students a year in a program focused on filling high-tech jobs.

headline: Battling Obesity in Louisville
text: The city of Louisville, Ky., where more than six in 10 people are considered seriously overweight, is trying to encourage residents to make healthier choices.

headline: Disposing of an Old TV on the Cheap
text: When I finally had to let go of my old tube TV — a 200-pound, 36-inch Sony Wega — there was the problem of how to let it go. Finding someone to haul off an oversized, outdated television wasn’t easy. But I did eventually find an inexpensive and simple answer to my problem that may be available to anyone in a sizable city.

headline: Supreme Court Upholds Nevada’s Law on Conflict of Interest
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday unanimously rejected a First Amendment challenge to a Nevada law that barred officials there from voting on matters in which they had a conflict of interest. Such legislative recusal laws are common, and a decision striking them down or even subjecting them to strict First Amendment scrutiny would have reshaped politics across the nation.

headline: Healthier Mother Pushes for Healthier City
text: LOUISVILLE — Four years ago, Keishanna Hughes, then a young mother of four on welfare, wandered into a meeting where residents of Louisville’s historic Smoketown neighborhood were talking about the toll obesity was having on their community and what might be done to tackle the problem.

headline: A City Tries to Slim Down
text: LOUISVILLE — This city’s Broadway displays its own array of neon signs — two dozen fast-food restaurants, as diverse as McDonald’s and the local Indi’s — beckoning along a 2.8-mile corridor bookended by low-income neighborhoods on the front lines of a multimillion-dollar battle against obesity.

headline: A Music Festival to Make Your Head Spin
text: Manchester, Tenn.

headline: An Effort to Foster Tolerance in Religion
text: CHICAGO — For a guy who is only 35 and lives in a walk-up apartment, Eboo Patel has already racked up some impressive accomplishments.

headline: The Triumph of the Humanities
text: Our house in the western Catskills overlooks the Pepacton Reservoir, a 20-mile ribbon of water between Margaretville and Downsville. Maps on the Internet, depending on their scale and detail, will show you where the reservoir is in relation to nearby towns and roads. What they won’t show you, although every resident of the area knows about them, are the four towns — Arena, Shavertown, Union Grove and Pepacton — that were flooded in the middle ‘50s so that the reservoir could be constructed. (Today, after more than 50 years, resentment against New York City remains strong.)

headline: Moving Into Social Web, Menlo Ventures Adds Partner
text: Peter DaSilva for The New York Times Shervin Pishevar is joining Menlo Ventures to help the firm improve its stature among young entrepreneurs.

headline: Now Banks Take a Turn at Coupons
text: Bank statements give customers monthly tallies on what they have saved and what they have spent. Now those same statements may give suggestions on where customers should spend their money, too.

headline: Two Views on Bank Rules: Salvation and Jobkillers
text: Jamie Dimon is frustrated.

headline: Mixed-Race Students Wonder How Many Boxes to Check
text: Multiracial students confess to spending sleepless nights worrying about how best to answer the race question on college applications. Some say they wonder whether their answers will be perceived as gamesmanship or a reflection of reality.

headline: Boeing Labor Battle Is Poised to Go Before Judge
text: Barring a last-minute settlement, lawyers for the National Labor Relations Board will begin arguing before a Seattle judge on Tuesday that Boeing broke the law by building a new, nonunion production line in South Carolina instead of expanding its unionized operations in Washington State.

headline: Palestinian Unity Effort Shows Cracks as Factions Disagree Over Choosing Leader
text: JERUSALEM — Fatah and Hamas so far disagree on who should lead a unity government, a possible sign of discord before talks scheduled to start in Cairo on Tuesday, prompting Palestinian officials and analysts to question the durability of the recent reconciliation agreement.

headline: Getting Away With It
text: Not long ago, I came into possession of the names of the investors in the now-defunct Galleon Group, the hedge fund firm that was run by Raj Rajaratnam, who last month was convicted of insider trading.

headline: Comcast to Offer Customers Skype Video Calls on Their TVs
text: In the cable television industry’s latest extension into home communication, Comcast and Skype announced on Monday that some Comcast customers would soon be able to video chat on their TV sets from the comfort of their living rooms.

headline: White? Black? Hispanic? Why Not All of the Above?
text: In an article just posted on The Times’s Web site and slated for publication in Tuesday’s newspaper, my colleague Susan Saulny and I examine the increasing number of college applicants who identify themselves as multiracial.

headline: Jordan: Protesters Clash With Police During King’s Visit to Tribal Town
text: Youths clashed with riot police officers during a visit by King Abdullah II to Tafileh, a long-neglected tribal area 125 miles south of the capital, in a rare outburst of anger surrounding a royal event. About 30 riot police officers were hurt and five police cars were burned. Youths in Tafileh had been protesting against corruption and had wanted to meet the king, left, a request that was denied. A government spokesman said the clashes occurred as people rushed to salute the king. In a nod to protesters the king pledged Sunday that in the future the government would be elected, rather than appointed, but he set no timetable for the change.

headline: Airports Say They Too Need to Raise Fees
text: AIR travel and fees seem to be inextricably linked these days.

headline: On College Forms, a Question of Race, or Races, Can Perplex
text: HOUSTON — At the beginning of the college application season last fall, Natasha Scott, a high school senior of mixed racial heritage in Beltsville, Md., vented about a personal dilemma on College Confidential, the go-to electronic bulletin board for anonymous conversation about admissions.

headline: Venturi Remembers When He Was Hot Stuff
text: BETHESDA, Md. — Ken Venturi returned on Monday to Congressional Country Club, where 47 years earlier he won the United States Open while suffering from dehydration and heat exhaustion. The temperature at Congressional on Monday was a balmy 75, or about 25 degrees lower than when Venturi trudged through 36 holes on the final day of the 1964 United States Open to win by four strokes.

headline: Pundit Under Protest
text: I’ll be writing a lot about the presidential election over the next 16 months, but at the outset I would just like to remark that I’m opining on this whole campaign under protest. I’m registering a protest because for someone of my Hamiltonian/National Greatness perspective, the two parties contesting this election are unusually pathetic. Their programs are unusually unimaginative. Their policies are unusually incommensurate to the problem at hand.

headline: Progress Claimed in Reporting Abuse at Group Homes
text: ALBANY — Roughly 40 percent of the allegations of physical abuse of the developmentally disabled at group homes and institutions in New York in recent months were not reported to law enforcement authorities, a senior state official said on Monday.

headline: Police Arrest 19-Year-Old in Shootings at Boardwalk
text: A 19-year-old man was arrested in connection with the shootings last week on the Brighton Beach Boardwalk that left a girl dead and four men wounded, the authorities said Monday.

headline: Thieves Found Citigroup Site an Easy Entry
text: Think of it as a mansion with a high-tech security system — but the front door wasn’t locked tight.

headline: Medication Is Cited in Horse Racing’s Decline in U.S.
text: The American thoroughbred industry has acknowledged recently that it is in trouble, and on Monday, its counterparts from around the world told it why: it races too often, allows race-day medications that prop up inferior horses and is paying the price for these flaws with plummeting sales at breeding auctions.

headline: Pakistan: Suicide Bomber Attacks Bank, Leaving Two Dead and Puzzle Over Motive
text: A security guard was killed and three people were injured Monday afternoon when a suicide bomber detonated his explosives at a bank in Islamabad, police officials said. It was not clear why the bomber attacked a branch of a local bank, and there was no immediate claim of responsibility. The police speculated that the bomber might have been trying to create panic or mistakenly thought the bank was foreign owned.

headline: A Finishing Hole With Real Stopping Power
text: BETHESDA, Md. — Face-lifts can often prompt a quick intake of breath, not so much a gasp, which would be rude, but more a small sip of surprise, covering any reaction, good, bad or undecided.

headline: Nearly a Year After Dodd-Frank
text: Without strong leaders at the top of the nation’s financial regulatory agencies, the Dodd-Frank financial reform doesn’t have a chance. Whether it is protecting consumers against abusive lending, reforming the mortgage market or reining in too-big-to-fail banks, all require tough and experienced regulators.

headline: The Fine Line Between Championship and Comeuppance
text: Miami

headline: They Need to Stand Up for Equality
text: The New York State Senate is just two votes away from approving same-sex marriage. At least four senators — all Republicans — still won’t say where they stand. They need to declare their support. There is no excuse for their silence, except for appeasing a conservative political base that clearly does not represent the interests or the values of this state.

headline: Reading Turkey’s Vote
text: Turkey’s voters gave Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s Justice and Development Party roughly half the popular vote and a solid new parliamentary majority. But the party fell short in Sunday’s vote of the two-thirds majority it needs to push through a new Constitution on its own. That is good news for Turkey’s democracy.

headline: Unhappy Flag Day
text: Hartford, Conn., June 14, 1861

headline: A Clear View of the Troubled Oceans
text: The scale and toll of industrial fishing is far less familiar than even the scale and toll of industrial farming. Groups like Seafood Watch at the Monterey Bay Aquarium put out sustainable seafood lists for diners and shoppers, good reminders that fisheries are in decline. But even they do not convey how bad things have become.

headline: Fact Checking the Republican Debate
text: As they debated the economic downturn and health care, the Republican candidates who faced off Monday night in New Hampshire sometimes let spin run ahead of the facts.

headline: Unions Weigh New Plan to Avert Teacher Layoffs
text: Leaders of New York City’s most powerful municipal labor unions are discussing a plan to save 4,100 teaching jobs by giving the Bloomberg administration hundreds of millions of dollars from a health care reserve fund established 25 years ago.

headline: Her Call for Weiner to Resign Puts a Diminished Pelosi Back in the Limelight
text: WASHINGTON — Less than a year ago, Representative Nancy Pelosi was one of the most powerful figures in Washington, an agenda-setting House speaker able to impose her will on a notoriously fractious Democratic caucus.

headline: Cuomo Pick Played Role in Calamity
text: Jean Saint-Jean and his wife own a modest brick home in Canarsie, Brooklyn, 10 miles and an incalculable economic distance from Manhattan, where fiscal cleverness is daily transmuted into riches.

headline: S.E.C. Seeks to Halt Sales of Stocks of 2 Chinese Companies
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission moved to halt new share offerings in two companies after their independent auditors resigned.

headline: Albany Money Flows to Clients of Firms Employing Legislators
text: ALBANY — Over the past five years, New York State has awarded more than $7.4 billion in contracts to clients of law firms that employ state legislators, according to a review of court filings and other records.

headline: Tuesday: Place Getting a Lot of Buzz
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Don’t let this get back to Doug Peterson and Angela Olson Halsted, but I think they could use a little cheering up. They just haven’t been themselves lately, and their puzzle — Ms. Halsted’s debut in The New York Times — is clearly a cry for help. It’s a very good puzzle, but they just seem a little, well, depressed. I hope it’s nothing we said.

headline: City Will Have 50% Increase in Summer School Students
text: The number of New York City elementary and middle school students who scored so low on the state math and English exams that they will be required to attend summer classes has grown by nearly 50 percent since last year, the city’s Education Department said on Monday.

headline: Once Again, .500 Slips From Mets’ Grasp
text: PITTSBURGH — The final step to reaching the podium of mediocrity has been fleeting for the Mets. For the third time in less than a week, the Mets sought to reach the elusive .500 mark, only to be thrust backward.

headline: Owners and Players Weigh a Future Without Divisions
text: The N.B.A. season is over, with the potential of a lengthy lockout up next. The N.F.L. is deep into its own lockout, with no sign of a quick resolution. Baseball also has no labor contract for next season, but there is no threat of a work stoppage.

headline: Syrian Unrest Stirs New Fear of Deeper Sectarian Divide
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian government’s retaking of a town this weekend that had teetered beyond its control is sharpening sectarian tensions along one of the country’s most explosive fault lines: relations between the Sunni Muslim majority and the minority Alawite sect to which the family of President Bashar al-Assad belongs, residents and officials say.

headline: Once Against Gay Marriage, 4 Senators Say They Will Back It
text: ALBANY — Four lawmakers who two years ago voted against legalizing same-sex marriage reversed course on Monday, saying their constituents’ thinking on the socially divisive issue had evolved, in a move that significantly improved the odds that New York will become the largest state in the nation to allow gays and lesbians to wed.

headline: Mobilizing the Playground Movement
text: On Wednesday more than 500 volunteers will gather at the Imagine Southeast Public Charter School, in Congress Heights, one of Washington’s poorest neighborhoods, to help construct the 2,000th playground led by KaBOOM!, an organization that has turned community playground building into the modern-day equivalent of barn raising. Among those assembling slides and swing sets alongside residents and Americorps volunteers will be Michelle Obama and Secretary of Education Arne Duncan who will be highlighting the importance of play and the administration’s Let’s Move initiative, which aims to attack the problem of childhood obesity.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Bloggingheads: Approving Gay Marriage
text: Robert Jones, left, of Public Religion Research Institute and Michael Brendan Dougherty of The American Conservative discuss public support of gay marriage.

headline: East River Ferry Service, With 7 Stops, Starts Run
text: The blue-and-white ferry nudged up to the dock at East 34th Street on Monday morning and deposited its cargo: about 70 commuters, their business suits unmoved by the wind, happy to have made it from Brooklyn to Manhattan in less time than it can take to catch an L train at rush hour.

headline: Restrictions on Exports Ignite Protests in Belarus
text: MOSCOW — Call it the mac-and-cheese rebellion.

headline: Kaymer Finds National Pride in N.B.A.
text: BETHESDA, Md. — Germany’s Martin Kaymer, who won the 2010 P.G.A. Championship, noticed how his countryman Dirk Nowitzki reacted as the Dallas Mavericks were about to claim the N.B.A. championship on Sunday night.

headline: Republicans in Debate Unite to Attack Obama
text: GOFFSTOWN, N.H. — Opening a new phase in a race to define the direction of their party, the leading Republican presidential candidates gathered Monday night for the first time to begin drawing distinctions among themselves in a vibrant competition to be seen as sufficiently conservative for primary voters, but electable enough to defeat President Obama.

headline: Turkey Scrambles to Accommodate Syrian Refugees
text: HATAY, Turkey — There was a growing urgency for tents and supplies as heavy rains fell on this border region where thousands sought refuge as the Turkish authorities rushed to open three more camps for those who fled a Syrian government crackdown that bombarded villages and burned fields to put down an armed uprising.

headline: Bachmann Announces Presidential Candidacy
text: Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota used her first question during Monday’s Republican presidential debate in New Hampshire to announce that she had formally filed paperwork to make a run for the White House.

headline: Carl Gardner, Singer With Coasters Pop Group, Dies at 83
text: Carl Gardner, the spunky tenor who was the lead singer of the original Coasters, whose mixture of rhythm-and-blues, doo-wop and sitcom humor created 1950s hits like “Yakety Yak,” “Charlie Brown” and “Searchin,’ ” died on Sunday in Port. St. Lucie, Fla. He was 83.

headline: Gunnar Fischer, Cinematographer for Bergman, Dies at 100
text: Gunnar Fischer, a cinematographer whose use of stark lighting and sharp focus lent mood and psychological depth to a dozen of Ingmar Bergman’s early films, including “The Seventh Seal” and “Wild Strawberries,” died on Saturday in Stockholm. He was 100.

headline: Calf Strain Slows Jeter’s Pursuit of 3,000 Hits
text: It was already a challenge for Derek Jeter to notch the seven hits he needed for 3,000 in the last four games of this homestand, but his quest is bound to take a little longer now.

headline: Manchester United Gets a Little Younger
text: After Barcelona beat Manchester United to win the Champions League final last month, five of the Catalans raced across the Wembley turf towards Paul Scholes to ask for his shirt as a keepsake. This was not a mere souvenir, but a salute to a player to whom Barça could relate: a youth team product who grew into a European champion.

headline: Battle for Libya | June 13, 2011
text: Libyan rebel fighters clash with pro-Qaddafi forces near Misurata and Dafniya.

headline: Calf Strain Likely to Delay Jeter’s Run to 3,000
text: Derek Jeter has a Grade 1 strain of his right calf, the Yankees announced after Monday’s 1-0 loss to Cleveland. The team said it would determine his status on Tuesday.

headline: Bruins Extend a Bruising Series to the Limit
text: BOSTON — The Bruins clobbered the Canucks, 5-2, Monday night to extend the Stanley Cup finals to Game 7 in Vancouver on Wednesday. Did anyone expect anything different? Hardly.

headline: In Lebanon, New Cabinet Is Influenced by Hezbollah
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Lebanon’s new prime minister, Najib Mikati, announced on Monday a long-delayed government dominated by members and allies of the Shiite militant group Hezbollah, a move likely to alarm Western powers.

headline: Corrections
text: BUSINESS DAY

headline: Study Finds Rebound in Entertainment and Media Spending
text: Entertainment and media spending in the United States rebounded in 2010, according to a widely followed annual report, for its first gain since 2007.

headline: Word of the Day | pediatrician
text: pediatrician •\ˌpe-de-ə-ˈtri-shən\• noun

headline: Whimsical Works of Art, Found Sticking to the Sidewalk
text: MUSWELL HILL, England — When first exposed to the art of Ben Wilson, or to Mr. Wilson in the act of creating it, people tend to respond with some degree of puzzlement.

headline: Woods’s Caddie Takes a Side Job
text: BETHESDA, Md. — Going by the initial reaction to the news that Steve Williams will caddy for the Australian star Adam Scott at the United States Open this week, one would have been excused for concluding that the Tiger Woods-Williams partnership, which began in February 1999, was on the rocks.

headline: Game 6 Viewership Up 31 Percent
text: The decisive game of the N.B.A. finals on Sunday generated an average of 23.5 million viewers on ABC, up 31 percent from the 17.9 million who watched the comparable game last year when the Los Angeles Lakers beat Boston.

headline: NYT: Front Page for 06/14/2011
text: NYT: Front Page for 06/14/2011

headline: Debate Swings Door Open for Perry, Closed for Palin
text: Most people have better things to do than to watch a presidential debate eight months in advance of the Iowa caucuses. So when considering a debate like the one that took place among Republican candidates in New Hampshire tonight, it’s important to be mindful of the following:

headline: China Steps Up Campaign to Fight Inflation
text: HONG KONG — China stepped up its campaign to combat rising inflation and restrain the sizzling pace of economic growth Tuesday by further restricting lending at the nation’s banks after government data showed inflation remained persistently high in May.

headline: Loving Parents, Unhappy Children
text: Lori Gottlieb is training to be a therapist. All the books she read in graduate school taught her that behind every patient, there is a problem parent — one who is not supportive or loving or empathetic enough. Then, as she puts it in a piece in The Atlantic hitting newsstands next week, “I started seeing patients.” And one after the next they came to say they were depressed, and unmoored, and anxious, and that “they had little to quibble with about Mom or Dad.”

headline: Strike at Air Canada Disrupts Travel
text: OTTAWA — Air travelers in Canada faced disruptions after Air Canada’s customer service and ticket agents went on strike early Tuesday morning.

headline: Digital Flirting — Easy to Do and to Get Caught
text: Representative Anthony D. Weiner may have taken it to an extreme. But the online flirtations and provocative photos that got him into so much trouble are far from unusual among adults these days, experts say.

headline: I.M.F. Names Lagarde and Carstens as Contenders for Top Post
text: The long-shot bid by Stanley Fischer, the governor of the Bank of Israel, to become managing director of the International Monetary Fund appeared to be over after the international lender’s executive board said late Monday that it would consider only two other candidates.

headline: Avis Budget to Buy Avis Europe for $1 Billion
text: Avis Budget Group said Tuesday that it would buy Avis Europe for $1 billion, in a sign that the car rental company may be moving on from its long campaign to take over Dollar Thrifty.

headline: Test Yourself | English, June 14, 2011
text: Test your editing skills with today’s question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues, from the article “Study Questions Treatment Used in Heart Disease.”

headline: In Praise of Roughhousing
text: Go ahead. Throw your children around. It’s good for them, say Anthony T. DeBenedet and Lawrence J. Cohen, the authors of “The Art of Roughhousing: Good Old-Fashioned Horseplay and Why Every Kid Needs It.” You can trust them, because they are doctors. Well, DeBenedet is an M.D., while Cohen has a Ph.D. And in the days before Father’s Day they chatted with me by e-mail about exactly how “rough” the horseplay should get.

headline: News Quiz | June 14, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Mavericks Throw Cold Water on the Heat
text: WHO led the Dallas Mavericks to victory over the Miami Heat?

headline: Chasing Stigma in Indonesia
text: How does one capture stigma?

headline: Are You Working This Summer?
text: Only 25 percent of people ages 16-19 are expected to find work this summer — a lower percentage than in years past. How are you spending your summer? Have you tried to find work? Do you have a job or internship? Are you earning money?

headline: Nokia Settles 2-Year Fight With Apple on Patents
text: BERLIN — Nokia said on Tuesday that it had settled a two-year-old patent fight with Apple over smartphone technology through a licensing agreement that will commit Apple to make a one-time payment to the company and to pay regular royalties in the future.

headline: Fantasy Focus: Batted-Ball Types
text: Back in December, Carlos Gonzalez was hailed by many as a top-five pick during early industry mock drafts. As the winter rolled along, he seemed to fall between third over all and 12th in a vast majority of mixed-league drafts. As a 24-year-old in hitter-friendly Coors Field, Gonzalez was a five-category star in the making on the heels of hitting .336 with 34 homers, 117 runs batted in, 111 runs scored and 26 steals.

headline: Can We Afford the Military Budget?
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul.

headline: The Early Word: Making Introductions
text: Today’s Times

headline: Madrid Festival Offers Diversity of Genres
text: From June 23 to Aug. 28, Madrid turns into an open-air festival of music, dance, film and theater, when the Veranos de la Villa festival takes over the city. Packed with variety, it offers 170 performances, including concerts by everyone from Kool and the Gang to Wynton Marsalis and the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra. Also performing will be the jazz vocalist Cassandra Wilson and the flamenco guitarist Tomatito.

headline: Q&A: Taking the iPad to Europe
text: Q.

headline: The Comment That Changed My Business
text: Last week I wrote about what I’ve learned from blogging — including the useful feedback it has brought. Of all the comments I’ve received, one stands out because I followed the advice and it has made a large difference in our shop. It came from John, and it was left on a post called “I Know I’m Doing This Wrong.” Here’s John’s comment:

headline: When the Meatpacking District Lived Up to Its Name
text: Down the block from the photo-snapping tourists and the chic-looking locals — and the just-extended High Line park — Richard K. Lieberman was having a Proustian moment. Think meat, not madeleines.

headline: The Two Republican Debates
text: If you were being kind to the Republican contenders on the debate stage last night, you would say that a debate featuring 60 second answers and 30 second responses, with no room to elaborate and little or no interaction between the candidates, is hardly a format in which any politician is likely to particularly shine. Throw in CNN’s “this or that” gimmick, which asked the candidates to choose between Conan and Leno, American Idol and Dancing With the Stars, and other oh-so-creative binaries, and the night was a good reminder why most sane Americans ignore the early primary debates entirely.

headline: No Brawl for Republican Candidates — Yet
text: The opportunities were there.

headline: Reason Seen More as Weapon Than Path to Truth
text: For centuries thinkers have assumed that the uniquely human capacity for reasoning has existed to let people reach beyond mere perception and reflex in the search for truth. Rationality allowed a solitary thinker to blaze a path to philosophical, moral and scientific enlightenment.

headline: Iraqi Militants Kill 7 at Provincial Offices
text: BAGHDAD — A team of six gunmen and suicide bombers dressed in police uniforms attacked a provincial council’s offices in northeastern Iraq on Tuesday, the latest in a string of brazen assaults against police and government buildings aimed at puncturing the country’s uneasy security.

headline: Ericsson to Acquire Telcordia for $1.15 Billion
text: 2:12 p.m. | Updated Ericsson of Sweden said Tuesday that it would buy Telcordia, one of the architects of the U.S. telephone system, for $1.15 billion.

headline: Bright Passages
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Bright Passages
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Nudging Narcissus Toward the Door
text: There are plenty of lessons to be learned from the Anthony D. Weiner horror show, one of them being the peril of extreme narcissism, which has come to define our X-rated congressman.

headline: What to Do When Financial Institutions Fail
text: This morning I’m off to Washington to give the House Financial Services Subcommittee on Financial Institutions my thoughts on Dodd-Frank’s Orderly Liquidation Authority. DealBook readers may be able to guess what I’m going to say, and I’ve posted my written submission at Credit Slips.

headline: California Redoes Its Greenhouse Gas Analysis
text: Nothing focuses the mind like being told by a thesis adviser (or a judge) that your analysis is inadequate and that your degree (or your carefully constructed policy for reducing greenhouse gas emissions) will be on hold until you provide a better one.

headline: World’s First Production Bentley and Steve McQueen’s Brough to Vie for Checkbooks
text: Gooding & Company of Santa Monica, Calif., announced Tuesday that it would sell a 1921 3-liter Bentley, which it claimed to be the first Bentley ever to be delivered to a customer, at its Pebble Beach auction this coming August.

headline: An Effort to Clarify the Climate Conversation
text: A group of Australian scientists has begun a new online effort to communicate the body of science pointing to a rising human influence on the climate system.

headline: Just One Look | Acne
text: For his first resort show in New York, Acne’s Jonny Johansson described his look as a young downtown “jeans girl” who collides with romantic historic fashion. That collision is anything but metaphorical. “For me,” Johansson says, “it’s like a film clip of a girl trapped in this world of volume but slimming it down and containing it.” These billowing trousers under a simple top and a tight denim mini are mash-up worthy of a fashion hermaphrodite.

headline: Rhyme Schemes: See the Creation of the Tony Awards’ Closing Rap
text: No matter who the fellows in this video might say they are, that’s Lin-Manuel Miranda and Thomas Kail at work on Sunday night, hurriedly trying to compose the rap number performed by Neil Patrick Harris at the end of the Tony Awards telecast. Watch for cameos from the newly minted Tony winner Nikki M. James and from Mr. Harris, who in his first run-through of the hot-off-the-presses number makes it look every bit as effortless as when he recited it for real.

headline: Just One Look | The Row
text: If there is one thing Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen of the Row want you to take away from their resort collection, it is that they’re in the business of luxury. Just take this nautical mink coat and sheath dress (and supercute sailor striped socks). The collection is inspired by the gilded age in Europe. Embroidered floral tops and dresses, crisp checked Prince of Wales separates and jewels designed with Ileana Makri are reminiscent of the Belle Epoque. And in case you had a shred of doubt about how luxe they want to go, consider their handbags: classic totes, satchels and bags glow in rich tones of bright purple and neon green. Not to mention, a fox and mink snow white backpack.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Two Views on Bank Rules: Salvation and Jobkillers  |  Remarks by Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan Chase’s chief, criticizing efforts to regulate banking highlight a contentious issue that is short on black and white arithmetic.

headline: Graham Packaging Endorses Offer From Rank
text: The Graham Packaging Company, which is controlled by the Blackstone Group, said on Tuesday that its board had decided to endorse a $1.6 billion takeover offer from a unit of the Rank Group of New Zealand, snubbing an earlier deal with Silgan Holdings.

headline: Second Death at Bonnaroo Festival Is Reported
text: A man attending the Bonnaroo Music & Arts Festival in Manchester, Tenn., over the weekend died on Sunday, officials told The Associated Press. Stephen M. Graves, the sheriff of Coffee County, said that Christopher William Yoder, 24, of Raleigh, N.C., had died of hyperthermia after he was airlifted from the festival to a hospital in Chattanooga. The sheriff told The A.P. that he was awaiting the results of toxicology tests. The organizers of the festival said in a statement, “The safety of our patrons is our No. 1 concern, and we are deeply saddened by this.”

headline: Tuesday Reading: Decorative Firepot Maker Stops Sales After Accidents
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Inconclusive Agent Orange Study Is Conclusive Enough for Vet Groups
text: It has been nearly a month since the Institute of Medicine released its report on Agent Orange exposure and so-called Blue Water Navy veterans from Vietnam, yet the Department of Veterans Affairs says it is still reviewing the document. That’s not surprising, for the report is chock-full of nonconclusions, unknowns and uncertainties.

headline: Markets Rise Sharply on Retail Sales and Other Economic Data
text: Stocks on Wall Street surged Tuesday after the United States government released new statistics on the economy, including a retail sales report that traders viewed as positive.

headline: Regulator: Wall Street Not Too Big to Fail
text: 3:22 p.m. | Updated

headline: F.D.A. Unveils New Rules About Sunscreen Claims
text: WASHINGTON — After 33 years of consideration, the Food and Drug Administration took steps on Tuesday to sort out the confusing world of sunscreens, with new rules that specify which lotions provide the best protection against the sun and ending claims that they are truly waterproof.

headline: Three Moves the U.S. Should Make Against Guadeloupe
text: This was supposed to be the easy one.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Un Chien Andalou’
text: In this week’s Critics’ Pick, A. O. Scott looks at a slice of surreal life in Luis Buñuel and Salvador Dalí’s 1928 short film “Un Chien Andalou.” The film, which catalogs a variety of random, sometimes shocking scenes, was part of the Surrealism art movement, one that rebelled against order and coherence. Mr. Scott says that even now, 80 years later, the movie “still seethes with creative, revolting imagery.” Mr. Scott praises Mr. Buñuel’s filmmaking, saying that he was “among the first to discover that the language of cinema could proceed beyond the boundaries of sense and produce powerful and strange effects and emotions.” Have you seen “Un Chien Andalou?” Please share your thoughts in the comments area below.

headline: The Caucus Click: Mitt Romney in Derry, N.H.
text: The morning after the first major Republican debate, Mitt Romney visits Derry.

headline: Social Web Browser RockMelt Teams Up With Facebook
text: For the Facebook- and Twitter-obsessed, the RockMelt Web browser, introduced last year by veterans of Netscape, offers plenty of goodies: a button to share any Web page or link; a rail showing what’s happening on their favorite social sites; another rail showing the activities of their friends and making it easy to chat with them; and plenty of other nifty social features.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: Lockout Could Cost Former Lineman Care at Dementia Facility
text: SUGAR LAND, Tex. — The potential casualties of the N.F.L.’s work stoppage include players, owners and, eventually, parking-lot attendants and many others whose work is tied to the sport. The lockout’s first victim, however, could be a former merchant seaman from Brooklyn who once worked on the Apollo lunar module but today lies inert in Room 12 at the Silverado dementia-care facility here.

headline: In Manhattan, District Attorney Sees DNA as Tool to Solve Cold Cases
text: With the casual flick of a spent cigarette, Lerio Guerrero unwittingly demonstrated recent advances in DNA testing and a heretofore unspoken peril of smoking.

headline: New American Express Prepaid Card Is Light on Fees
text: Many prepaid cards are known for charging fees at every turn — fees to activate the card, fees to make a purchase, even fees to call customer service.

headline: A.M.D. Releases Chips With New Graphics Abilities
text: The slogan “Intel Inside” is true for four out of five personal computers sold today, and the Intel brand remains one of the most recognizable in the world. Advanced Micro Devices has been playing second fiddle year after year. But times have changed, and A.M.D. could find itself perfectly positioned to benefit.

headline: Century-Old Immigration Debate Has Familiar Sound
text: Until recently, Morris Claman’s legacy to New York has been the few surviving manhole and coal chute covers in Manhattan and Brooklyn that bear the logo of his stove parts and repair business on Orchard Street as well, of course, as his descendants. But it turns out that he had left something else behind: his anger over an immigration debate that is still being echoed today.

headline: For Franciscan Twins, Simple Lives Had Depth
text: ST. BONAVENTURE, N.Y. — They were like paired birds of Franciscan brown. If Brother Julian was gardening in front of the friary, Brother Adrian weeded in the back. If Adrian was driving the van, Julian sat by his side. Preparing the altar for chapel, chopping wood for kindling, exulting in ice cream at the Twist & Shake, the identical Riester twins were together, always.

headline: The Costs of an Urban Diet
text: The city of Louisville, where six of 10 residents are overweight, has tried to deploy every municipal agency to put its citizens on a regimen of diet and exercise. Like other cities across the country, Louisville is receiving federal and private money to build bike paths and racks, sponsor community gardens and other healthy alternatives — all aimed at efforts to influence and change the habits of its residents.

headline: Royal Ballet Names New Artistic Director
text: The speculation has been incessant, but on Tuesday morning the Royal Ballet in London put an end to the chatter about who will take over once its current artistic director, Monica Mason, steps down in July next year. It will be Kevin O’Hare, a former principal dancer with the Birmingham Royal Ballet who has been steadily making his way up the Royal Ballet’s hierarchy since his retirement from the stage in 2000. He joined as company manager in 2004 and became administrative director in 2009.

headline: U.S. Students Remain Poor at History, Tests Show
text: American students are less proficient in their nation’s history than in any other subject, according to results of a nationwide test released on Tuesday, with most fourth graders unable to say why Abraham Lincoln was an important figure and few high school seniors able to identify China as the North Korean ally that fought American troops during the Korean War.

headline: Fill-In | 2011 Commencement Speeches
text: Can you fill in the 30 missing words from graduation speech excerpts?

headline: Twins United in Faith and Purpose
text: Two weeks ago, the Riester twins died on the same day in a Florida hospital; they were 92. Both Franciscan monks, Brother Julian died in the morning and Brother Adrian died in the evening — after being told of Julian’s death. Few who knew them were surprised, as it would be hard to imagine one’s surviving without the other.

headline: Just One Look | Ohne Titel
text: Everything that’s come to be associated with Ohne Titel — asymmetry and body consciousness — is present and accounted for in Alexa Adams and Flora Gill’s saucy designs for resort. But this season, the designers added the luxury of volume in a collection inspired by “L’Orient des Femmes,” an exhibition of Syrian clothes at the Quai Branly museum in Paris.

headline: Dear Gmail Labs
text: Update: It turns out the feature desired exists in a free plug-in called Boomerang. Read this new post to learn more about it.

headline: After Metal Music’s Deafening Roar, Hüsker Dü’s Guitarist Pauses to Reflect
text: Among the many reasons to like “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart” is this: its theme song, “Dog on Fire,” was written by the former Hüsker Dü guitarist and singer Bob Mould.

headline: Another Bad Sign for Hiring
text: Small businesses have ratcheted down their plans for hiring, according to a report from the National Federation of Independent Business.
