headline: Romney Smiles, for Now
text: DERRY, N.H. – Mitt Romney walked away emboldened – and untouched – from his first Republican presidential debate, but he said Tuesday that his rivals were not likely to treat him so gently as the campaign intensifies, and he conceded that the criticism over his health care plan was not likely to go  away.

headline: Chancellor Leaving Troubled Wisconsin for the Presidency of Amherst College
text: Carolyn A. Martin, the chancellor of the University of Wisconsin-Madison, a flagship public research university with 42,000 students, is resigning to become president of Amherst College, a prestigious liberal arts college with 1,750 students.

headline: Huntsman Will Announce at Liberty Park
text: 2:58 p.m. | Updated Jon M. Huntsman Jr., the former governor of Utah, will officially declare his intention to unseat his former boss from the White House next Tuesday in the shadow of the Statue of Liberty, where Ronald Reagan opened his fall campaign for the presidency in 1980.

headline: Anish Kapoor Cancels China Plans to Protest Ai Weiwei Detention
text: The Britain-based sculptor Anish Kapoor has decided to cancel plans to show his work at the National Museum of China in Beijing, a protest against the Chinese government’s detention of Ai Weiwei, the artist, architect and social critic who has been in custody in an undisclosed site for two months.

headline: Graduation Rate Rises, but College Readiness Lags
text: The high school graduation rate in New York City improved slightly last year, but the vast majority of those graduates were not prepared for college, state officials announced on Tuesday.

headline: Mini-Reagan
text: So, based on what I’ve seen so far, my verdict on the UK economy is … OK, I haven’t seen anything except a monstrous traffic jam on the M25.

headline: Apple Stores Chief to Take the Helm at J.C. Penney
text: J. C. Penney has poached the head of Apple’s retail stores to head the department store chain, betting that a deity of the digerati can revive its sales in the same way he found success in brick-and-mortar stores for Apple.

headline: Fleeing Syrians Take Refuge Along Border With Turkey
text: KHIRBIT EL JOUS, Syria — Hundreds of Syrians displaced by a ferocious crackdown on the uprising here fled to the Turkish border by tractor, truck and foot on Tuesday, some huddling in muddy olive groves without shelter and food, residents said.

headline: The Power of Minus
text: David Altig points out that given the recent decline in gasoline prices, we’re likely to see a negative headline inflation number by June. What will the inflationistas say?

headline: Local Colors
text: Montauk, N.Y., may be the last hold out against the looming tide of Hamptonization, but its stuck-in-time fisherman’s-village feeling is fading fast. Which might explain the appeal of a new collection of T-shirts by Local Knit, featuring the logos from Montauk institutions like Duryea’s Lobster Deck, the Montauket and Paulie’s Tackle. Montaukers are snapping them up, as are weekenders. (Curbed’s Lockhart Steele is a fan and ordered a Herb’s Market shirt in beach plum with the slogan “You Can’t Beat Herb’s Meat.”) Amagansett and East Hampton — two towns ripe for nostalgia — will get their own logo tees next.

headline: Canucks Goalie Goes Flat
text: It’s hard to put Vancouver goalie Roberto Luongo in the same villain category as LeBron James. He did not embarrass franchises when he left — the Islanders and the Panthers did that all on their own, thank you — or predict that multiple championships would flock to him. He has no self-reverential tattoos and his entourage consists of equipment guys who hang up his goalie pads. And it’s hard to gin up much dislike for a hockey player in the United States, where Luongo’s name recognition hovers somewhere around the Dodgers’ backup shortstop.

headline: Dear Gmail Labs, Part II – The Rise of Boomerang
text: I just learned (first from a friend, then from the many comments people posted on my previous post) that what I’ve been looking for from Gmail (reposting of received messages at a future date) actually exists in the form of Boomerang—a free Gmail plug-in that does exactly what I described. I just installed it and it works perfectly—messages can reappear in my inbox (marked as unread, starred and/or at the top of my inbox) at a date or time I set.

headline: Danielle Chiesi’s Lawyers Seek Leniency, Blaming a Love Affair
text: Danielle S. Chiesi, the former beauty queen turned convicted Wall Street trader, deserves a light prison sentence because her crimes were the result of a tortured love affair with her boss, her lawyers said.

headline: In Montreal, Glitz, Glamor and Sponsorship News
text: The Canadian Grand Prix was  a wild race — one of the greatest we have seen in a long while. It also had a lot of big name stars visiting, and I heard lots of talk of new sponsors coming into the series; two of whom have been confirmed.

headline: In Montreal, Glitz, Glamor and Sponsorship News
text: The Canadian Grand Prix was  a wild race — one of the greatest we have seen in a long while. It also had a lot of big name stars visiting, and I heard lots of talk of new sponsors coming into the series; two of whom have been confirmed.

headline: More ‘Spider-Man’ Drama: Ousted Taymor to Attend Opening Night
text: Julie Taymor is planning to attend Tuesday’s opening night of the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” her spokeswoman said, returning to the Foxwoods Theater three months after the producers ousted her as director as part of their remake of the $70 million show into a more family-friendly entertainment. Her decision to go comes after several cast members and friends called her recently to encourage her to attend, including the star, Reeve Carney, who said in a recent interview that “Julie deserves to be at our opening as much as anyone.”

headline: Why We Don’t Usually Look for Experience When We Hire
text: TerraCycle’s staff has grown quickly. In 2008, we had about 35 employees, all in the United States. We now have about 100, including 70 or so in the United States and 30 abroad, managing operations in 14 foreign countries. Given our anticipated growth, I expect we will have 125 employees around the world by the end of 2012.

headline: Q&A: Brewery Tours in the Midwest and West
text: Q.

headline: Nick Curtin Leaves Compose
text: Nick Curtin, the young chef at Compose, the tiny TriBeCa restaurant with a $120 set menu that opened in December, will leave at the end of this month to pursue another venture yet to be determined. A replacement has not been announced.

headline: Violent Crime on the Rise in Athens
text: A sharp increase in violent crime is stirring unrest among a public already demoralized by unending economic hardship.

headline: Cuban Ready to Foot Mavericks Parade Tab
text: Mark Cuban has paid for many things during his 11 years as the owner of the Dallas Mavericks.

headline: Warm Welcome for Obama in Puerto Rico
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. — When even the press plane is greeted by festive dancers and Bacardi miniatures, chances are the president himself is in for a big welcome.

headline: Mario Draghi Holds E.C.B. Line Against Restructuring for Greece
text: BRUSSELS — With European governments divided over how to shape a new bailout for Greece, Mario Draghi, who is likely to become the next president of the European Central Bank, warned Tuesday against forcing private investors to take part.

headline: Not All Restaurants Show Their ABC’s, Health Department Finds
text: Bring out those B’s. Come forward with the C’s. And the A’s? Well, why wouldn’t you?

headline: From African Village to Center of Ordeal
text: This article is by  Anne Barnard,  Adam Nossiter and  Kirk Semple.

headline: Ex-Mayor Of Tijuana Investigated In Killing
text: MEXICO CITY — The former mayor of Tijuana was released from jail Tuesday after a federal judge threw out weapons charges against him, but state prosecutors immediately detained him in an investigation into the shooting death of his son’s girlfriend.

headline: Photo Replay: June 14
text: The day in sports included Serena Williams’s re-entry into women’s tennis and the first day of the horse racing meeting in Ascot, England.

headline: Just One Look | Stella McCartney
text: Only Stella McCartney could pull off hand-painted Hawaiian shirts, make them look new and turn them into a must-have. The designer’s resort collection proved to be a tropical fusion of hippie-inspired deck chair stripe tunics and skirts, like this three quarter length one, along with preppy seersucker and houndstooth separates. Accessories were similarly a contrast of classic shapes and fabrications, like a python print box with Lucite fluorescent pink piping. An orange kitten-heel sandal completed it all.

headline: 25 Charged With Having Images of Child Sexual Abuse
text: Updated, 4:35 p.m. | The Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., announced Tuesday afternoon that his office had filed charges against 25 people accused of possessing images or videos showing the sexual abuse of children.

headline: Just One Look | Vera Wang Resort
text: Vera Wang does prints! “Resort 2012 is all about strong brights, counterbalanced by gentle geometrics and dots,” Wang says. This season the house mixes its classic shapes and style (utility vests and jackets, sporty draped skirts and voluminous blouses) with subtle yet popping prints like this red spotted cutout dress and sporty cropped pants.

headline: A Star Faces Barriers to Deutsche Bank’s Top Job
text: LONDON — Hanging on the wall of Anshu Jain’s office, where he runs Deutsche Bank’s worldwide investment banking operations, is a picture of Mr. Jain’s former boss and mentor, Edson V. Mitchell.

headline: In Apulia, Vacationing Like an Italian
U.N. Charts High Jobless Rate in Gaza, Despite Israel’s Easing of Blockade
text: JERUSALEM — A  report  issued Tuesday shows unemployment in Gaza standing at 45.2 percent for the second half of 2010, one of the highest rates in the world, even though Israel eased its blockade of the Palestinian coastal strip in that period.

headline: Small Space, Big Flavor: First, Start the Beans
text: WE all have to eat, and we all want dinner. More often than not, I want dinner at home. To me, it’s the best place to be. I like to cook, I’m fairly confident I’ll produce something good, I know it’s going to be a lot less expensive than a restaurant meal, and with a few good friends around the table and a bottle of wine, it’s bound to be convivial.

headline: Introducing City Kitchen, a New Cooking Column
text: Today, we’re introducing a new column about home cooking written by David Tanis. Called City Kitchen, it will run weekly in the Dining section of The New York Times, and online.

headline: CBS Sees Better News in Pelley’s Ratings
text: CBS News took issue Tuesday with early comparisons between ratings for its old anchor, Katie Couric, and its new anchor, Scott Pelley, saying that Mr. Pelley should get credit for improving the ratings for the newscast in his first week when compared to Ms. Couric’s results during the same week last year.

headline: Critic of James Has a Happy Ending for His Book
text: From Section 104 of American Airlines Arena in Miami on Sunday night, Scott Raab witnessed a personal and literary miracle: the Heat lost the N.B.A. finals to the Dallas Mavericks. Raab called LeBron James the Whore of Akron last September during his reporting for a coming memoir that mixes his passion for the Cleveland teams he loves with his loathing of James for bolting the Cavaliers for the Heat.

headline: Just One Look | Céline Resort
text: Wild patterned pants dominated the fall runways, and, judging by Céline’s resort collection, which included leopard, jailhouse stripes and neon pink trousers, they’re not going anywhere. Other highlights: this mix of a floral brocade jacket and bustier atop classic separates (and, ironically, a logo tee from the pioneers of the no logo “it” item). The collection offered a taste of Phoebe Philo’s past hits (leather patchwork coats and bags reminiscent of pre-fall) and a glimpse of the future (neon yellow, pink, orange and color-blocked renditions of the design house’s classic bags like the luggage tote).

headline: Daily DealBook: Pandora's I.P.O.
text: Ahead of Pandora's initial public offering, investors are exuberant about the tech sector. Can the tech sector live up to investor expectations, or is this a repeat of the dotcom boom of 1999?

headline: Cuomo Supports DNA Collection Legislation
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Tuesday threw his support behind a proposed law that would allow law enforcement authorities to take DNA samples from anyone convicted of a felony or misdemeanor.

headline: China Navy Reaches Far, Unsettling the Region
text: QINGDAO, China — The photographs of Chinese warships speeding between Japanese islands in the Pacific for drills circulated quickly last week, raising what Japan’s defense minister called “serious concern.”

headline: Cameron Revises Overhaul Plan for British Health Care
text: LONDON — After enduring months of criticism over his bold proposal to drastically overhaul Britain’s publicly financed National Health Service, Prime Minister David Cameron on Tuesday released a new, watered-down version of the plan designed to be more palatable to interest groups and to Parliament.

headline: India’s Self-Made Man
text: In January we published an article by Anand Giridharadas called “The Caste Buster,” about Ravindra Misal, an Indian striver from the town of Umred who pulled himself out of the laboring class of “daily wage earners” and opened a finishing school for others like himself. That article, which also ran in our sister publication, The International Herald Tribune (under the title “India’s Future in a Self-Made Man”), has now been honored with the award for excellence in feature writing from the Society of Publishers in Asia. Smart decision, because it’s really a remarkable, unexpected story. It was adapted from Anand’s book, “India Calling: An Intimate Portrait of a Nation’s Remaking,” and presents a subtle picture of a new Indian ethos, best described by Anand this way:

headline: Political Volleys Over Nuclear Waste
text: House Republicans and some Democrats argued at a hearing on Tuesday that the chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission had introduced politics into the government’s consideration of a nuclear waste dump at Yucca Mountain. Others said this was hardly possible because the original choice of the site, in the Nevada desert, was nothing but politics to begin with.

headline: Daily DealBook: Pandora’s Pending I.P.O.
text: The technology sector is seeing a flood of public offerings, with the latest, Pandora, set for Wednesday.Will the industry live up to investor expectations, or is this a repeat of the dot-com boom of 1999? DealBook’s Adrienne Carter and Evelyn M. Rusli discuss the deal of the day.

headline: Bachmann Used Debate to Widen Her Appeal
text: The key question for Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota before the Republican debate on Monday night was whether she could appeal to voters beyond the Tea Party wing that she helped to create, while avoiding the gaffes that have sometimes emerged from her strident, passionate persona.

headline: Saratoga Dreaming
text: Jeff Deitz is a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst in Connecticut and New York. He teaches at the Beth Israel Medical Center. He learned to read the Daily Racing Form at Pimlico Race Course in Maryland.

headline: Hawk Cam  | Pip Has Something to Tell You
text: Pip at 1:40 p.m. Tuesday. Note dramatic progress since last scream shot, taken May 27.

headline: M&T Bank Offers Access to FICO Credit Score for a Fee
text: M&T Bank is now offering its online-banking customers access to their credit score for a monthly fee.

headline: Wildfire Is Now the Largest in Arizona’s History
text: PHOENIX — The massive Wallow Fire that is raging through eastern Arizona and neighboring New Mexico has burned so much additional acreage that it has become the largest fire in Arizona’s history, officials said Tuesday.

headline: Who's Watching Whom?
text: Untangling the web of financial institutions and their regulatory agencies.

headline: As India’s Growth Slows, Leaders Face Political Headwinds
text: NEW DELHI — India’s central government, convulsed by a series of corruption scandals, is under increasing pressure to deal with the potentially conflicting challenges of rising inflation and slowing growth.

headline: Samuel L. Jackson Gives Voice to ‘Go the ____ to Sleep’
text: From “Pulp Fiction” to bedtime stories? Samuel L. Jackson, the actor probably best known for his performance as Jules, the menacing assassin of “Pulp Fiction,” has recorded the audiobook of “Go the ____ to Sleep,” the parody children’s book that reached No. 1 on the New York Times best-seller list.

headline: Russian Rights Activist Cleared of Defamation
text: MOSCOW — A Moscow court on Tuesday cleared a prominent human rights campaigner of defamation charges, ruling that he had committed no crime when he accused Ramzan A. Kadyrov, the leader of Russia’s tumultuous region of Chechnya, of complicity in the murder of his colleague.

headline: The Times and the Common Core Standards: Reading Strategies for ‘Informational Text’
text: Update | Sept. 2012: We’ll be exploring the new Common Core State Standards, and how teaching with The Times can address them, through a series of blog posts. You can find them all here, in the lesson plan category “Common Core.”

headline: Ristretto | Nordic Invasion
text: A handful of the world’s small-batch roasters have outsized reputations, tiny operations that are less like coffee companies than coffee workshops. They might look and feel like neighborhood stores – places where you run into a friend while standing in line for a Saturday morning cappuccino – but because they function at such a high level of craft and quality, they lead the entire industry. A few of them have a near-mythic status that falls between Red’s Eats and Le Corbusier’s Notre Dame du Haut, a refined and aesthetic experience that’s worth the detour because what you’ll find there tastes so good.

headline: Hundreds of Restaurants Don’t Display Their Health Rating
text: City Room reports that the health department found that over 700 restaurants had not displayed their letter-grade health rating, including 23 that had received A’s.

headline: Museum for African Art Delays Opening Again
text: The Museum for African Art is postponing the opening of its new home on Fifth Avenue and 110th Street by a year, to late 2012, to give it more time to raise money, the museum said on Tuesday. It has so far raised $86.3 million toward its $95 million goal and is delaying the final stage of construction until it has reached $92.5 million.

headline: Google Finds Ways to Search Faster and Without Typing
text: How fast is fast when talking about search? Google thinks it can be even faster — and easier — and one way is by eliminating typing altogether, at least in some cases.

headline: In Shift, Interior Dept. May Allow Tribes to Build Casinos Far From Reservations
text: Rescinding a Bush-era rule, the Interior Department said Tuesday that it would consider allowing Indian tribes to build casinos far from their reservations, raising the possibility that new gambling resorts could be built close to New York and elsewhere around the country.

headline: India Aims $1 Billion at Sacred but Filthy Ganges
text: NEW DELHI — Indian officials signed an agreement with the World Bank on Tuesday to use a $1 billion loan to finance the first major new effort in more than 20 years to cleanse the revered Ganges, one of the world’s dirtiest rivers.

headline: TimesCast | June 14, 2011
text: Syrian refugees speak out against the government crackdown; Republicans face off in a televised debate; and a look at the early life of Dominique Strauss-Kahn’s accuser.

headline: Boston Festival a Paradise for Early-Music Fans
text: BOSTON — The Boston Early Music Festival and Exhibition, held biannually since 1981, takes over churches, libraries and concert halls, and turns the city into an early-music fan’s idea of paradise for a week. The performances include operas, symphonic concerts, chamber music and recitals produced by the festival. They also include a huge slate of fringe events, concerts presented by musicians and ensembles from around the country who flock to Boston in hopes of being heard by an audience of enthusiasts as well as managers and concert presenters who are in town for the festival’s starrier offerings. This year’s festival, the 16th, opened on Sunday and runs through next Sunday.

headline: After Years Without Change, Cracks Appear in I.P.O. Process
text: The last few decades have wrought a revolution in finance. One thing, though, remains stubbornly the same. It is the control that investment banks wield over initial public offerings.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Syria, Kenya, Libya and Puerto Rico.

headline: Repetitions Build Drama With Rhythm and Gesture
text: DURHAM, N.C. — Rosas is the name of Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker’s company, which she started in Brussels in 1983. The title of its inaugural work, “Rosas Danst Rosas,” suggested a kind of manifesto: this is what we are; this is what we do.

headline: Just One Look | Altuzarra Resort
text: For his first resort collection, Joseph Altuzarra thought a lot about travel and staying in hotels. “Everything is a wrinkle-free fabric, very pack-and-go,” he says. The clothes look effortless and feel surprisingly feminine, including the baby blue lightweight poplin smock dresses or tunics paired over pants (which call to mind a very chic housemaid at one of the hotel’s Altuzarra is channeling). There are also updated versions of his fall 2011 parka in white organza (“I’m still on that utility kick,” he says) over crisp eyelet dresses. When you’re ready to step out of the lobby and hit the street, there are flirty ruffled dresses like this one.

headline: Charting the Rich Kidz
text: The Rich Kidz are a young rap group from Atlanta known for sing-songy tracks like 2009’s “Partna Dem” and a few merry mixtapes. The artist Andrew Kuo charts their latest, “Straight Like That 2.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Syria, Kenya, Libya and Puerto Rico.

headline: After El Bulli
text: When the most influential restaurant in the world closes, who will step up to take the lead?

headline: Armstrong Encounter Draws Scrutiny by F.B.I.
text: The F.B.I. has requested surveillance video from a Colorado restaurant to glean more information about a recent confrontation there between Lance Armstrong and his former teammate Tyler Hamilton, according to a restaurant co-owner.

headline: Same-Sex Marriage Within One Vote of Passage in Albany
text: ALBANY — New York is within a single vote of legalizing gay marriage after a second Republican state senator said on Tuesday that he would support the measure should it come to the floor this week.

headline: Just One Look | Givenchy Resort
text: At his Givenchy resort presentation, the designer Riccardo Tisci was clear: “The collection is still 1950s mixed with surfing, but everything is about cropping and pieces missing.” Dangling dorm-style key chains, neon visors and rope heels (inspired by Birkenstocks) accompanied bird-of-paradise prints and a computerized update of last season’s panther print in the form of pencil skirts paired with cutout stretch-knit sweatshirts. “My obsession is daytime to evening,” Tisci says. As proof he showed a very French couture frilled bustier evening dress with a cropped sweater thrown over. “I’m obsessed with sweatshirts and T-shirts — that’s how I live my life.”

headline: Reviewing Masa
Masa
text: IS it worth it?

headline: Ackman Scores Big With Penney’s Latest Hire
text: William A. Ackman is a very happy investor today.

headline: Just One Look | Lanvin Resort
text: Alber Elbaz opened Lanvin’s resort collection with a poster-board slide show of everything that’s been inspiring him of late — island vacations, island women, Elizabeth Taylor, the royal wedding uniforms, Madame Grès — and most important, he added, “the idea of women wearing clothes over and over again.” He said he tried to nail down a decade that would envelop this. “I thought maybe the 1920s, then the 1980s, but nothing came.” What did emerge was glammed-up versions of island life: draped Grecian dresses, ruched secretary skirts and this silk fringe dress with stacked jewels. However, when it came to unveiling Lanvin’s new children’s line — little versions of the house’s favorite looks — the present was just precious.

headline: Are Happy Countries All Alike?
text: Happiness is….

headline: Syria’s Ruling Alawite Sect
text: As my colleague Anthony Shadid reports, the uprising in Syria “is sharpening sectarian tensions along one of the country’s most explosive fault lines: relations between the Sunni Muslim majority and the minority Alawite sect to which the family of President Bashar al-Assad belongs.”

headline: A Fresh Taste of a Hot, Dry Summer in Burgundy
text: The 2008 vintage of white Burgundy is that rare vintage that possesses both supercharged acidity and plenty of rich flavors. I love it and wrote about it in my column. But what about the 2009 vintage, which is now in the stores alongside the 2008s?

headline: In ‘Cars 2,’ Villains Are Expected to Bring the It Factor
text: 6:51 p.m. |Update

headline: Nocturnal Voyages Through Many Eras and Textures
text: Strains of Bartok, Britten, Radiohead and Pink Floyd echoed through the musically omnivorous soundscape that unfolded in the first of two sets at Le Poisson Rouge on Sunday evening, blurring genres and centuries into one enigmatic, continuous sequence.

headline: Just One Look | Bally Resort
text: Bally’s resort collection shows us how to do vacation, luxe Alpine style. A poplin and crepe de chine dress, like this one, is the go-to uniform for relaxing in St. Moritz. The collection has other sportif classics, like utility windbreakers and chic, cotton dresses. The line’s recently introduced Moritz accessories line features perforated leather handbags and sporty perforated nappa leather handbags and slate blue sandals.

headline: Lenny’s Sandwich Shops to Pay $5.1 Million for Wage Violations
text: The New York State Department of Labor has reached a $5.1 million settlement, its largest ever, with the chain Lenny’s: The Ultimate Sandwich for minimum-wage and overtime violations, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Tuesday.

headline: When Everything Moves but the Subject
text: Easiest thing in the world, taking a picture of a building. Right? It doesn’t blink. It doesn’t turn its back. It doesn’t duck out of sight. It just stands there, frozen. (O.K., leave the Milwaukee Art Museum out of this.)

headline: Into the Crocodile Cave
text: John S. Sparks, curator of ichthyology at the American Museum of Natural History, writes from Madagascar, where he is studying cave fishes.

headline: Just One Look | Nina Ricci Resort
text: Pretty, airy dressing is what Nina Ricci does best. And this resort season is no exception. The Ricci woman finds her classic summer look in pretty-in-pink ruffled suits, tight belted sheaths with horizontal ruching, floaty chiffon minis, belle époque gowns and this strawberry confection with marabou, which will make you look absolutely yummy.

headline: Madewell, but Remade How Well?
text: FOR about five years, the brand Madewell has been rattling like rusty ironworks around the edges of my consciousness, producing vague and somewhat conflicting associations, like “flannel shirt,” “rain boots” and “Alexa Chung.”

headline: Maison Premiere
text: 298 Bedford Avenue (Grand Street), Williamsburg, Brooklyn; (347) 335-0446, maisonpremiere.com.

headline: TimesCast | Surviving Inside Syria
text: June 14, 2011 - Sebnem Arsu crosses into northern Syria and speaks to desperate refugees fleeing Jisr al-Shoughour.

headline: Inside Maison Premiere
Life With a Gay Ex-Husband. It Happens.
text: Not so long ago there was nothing funny about a wife discovering that her husband is gay.

headline: Just One Look | Burberry Prorsum
text: Burberry Prorsum delivered a resort collection intentionally rooted in tradition but updated with color and pattern. There are electric yellow trench coats and orange leather ones. There are classic necessities like dusty rose bell-bottoms and high-waisted pencil skirts in turquoise leather. Prints that resemble African fabric make for chic little shirtwaist dresses. And beading around ankle and around the trim of a classic Burberry plaid hits the swoon button.

headline: ABC’s Rose Bouquet From ‘The Bachelorette’
text: ABC’s latest two-hour installment of “The Bachelorette” delivered Monday night’s largest audience as 7.8 million viewers tuned in to that reality show from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. The solid ratings were high enough to lift ABC to the top spot in prime time as the night’s most watched network even though a repeat of CBS’s “Hawaii Five-0” (7.4 million) outperformed ABC’s “Extreme Makeover: Weight Loss Edition” (5.9 million) in the 10 p.m. hour. CBS ranked second over all with reruns of its sitcom lineup from 8 to 10, including “Two and a Half Men” (6 million) and “Mike & Molly” (6.3 million) in the 9 p.m. hour. NBC ranked third, averaging 5.3 million viewers for its coverage of Game 6 of the National Hockey League’s Stanley Cup Finals while Fox was fourth with a new episode of “MasterChef” at 9 (4.9 million).

headline: When What’s Left of a Man Is Found in His Collections
text: W. David Hancock’s “Race of the Ark Tattoo” caused a small sensation downtown about a dozen years ago, partly because of its intriguing conceit. Inside a flea market a man spun stories about his foster father, who had died, by randomly picking up the man’s belongings and musing on them. It was a little bit of a gimmick but it worked.

headline: Debate Coverage Brings CNN a Ratings Win
text: CNN pushed to the top of cable news ratings Monday night with its coverage of the debate in New Hampshire among Republican candidates for president.

headline: TimesCast | From Guinea to New York
text: June 14, 2011 - Metro reporter Kirk Semple looks at the life long journey of Dominique Strauss-Kahn's accuser, from a childhood in Guinea to a job in a New York hotel.

headline: Pandora Prices Its I.P.O. at $16 a Share
text: The online music service Pandora may not be profitable, but that hasn’t discouraged investors clamoring for a piece of it.

headline: Filling the Void Left by El Bulli
text: When the most influential restaurant in the world closes, who will step up to take the lead?

headline: Just One Look | Vionnet Resort
text: Visits to India, Africa and Japan informed Vionnet’s 2012 resort collection. Color-blocked tunics and dresses in vivid combinations like purple and gold, and orange and white, were reminiscent of 1960s Courrèges as well as of origami. And Vionnet’s reputation as a house famous for cut came through loud and clear: there were fluid, sensationally draped evening gowns; even a simple blue shirtdress had crisscross drapery on the bodice. Oh, and the jewelry. So chic.

headline: Government Will Try to End Strike at Air Canada
text: OTTAWA — The Canadian labor minister introduced a motion on Tuesday that could legislate an end to a strike by Air Canada’s airport customer service agents if a negotiated settlement proves impossible.

headline: Ushering In Golden Age for Fans of Film
text: Nostalgia is frequently the default setting for movie lovers, who, even as they direct their eyes toward the screen, look back dreamily at a lost Arcadian time when the popcorn was crunchier and the films more substantial. New Yorkers are burdened with a similar feeling, the sense that back then — then being a vague moment sometime before now, when La Guardia was mayor and the Dodgers were in Brooklyn and men wore hats and action painters hung out at CBGB and the Dutch had not yet landed — was when things were really happening.

headline: After El Bulli, Spain Looks Forward
text: EL BULLI, currently the most influential restaurant in the world, will serve its last dinner on July 30. The next morning, Spain’s chefs will wake up to a radically changed universe.

headline: From a Season Aloft, High Hopes Linger
text: Have certain Balanchine steps and certain Balanchine roles ever been better danced than they were in the six-week season by New York City Ballet that ended on Sunday? The question makes the mind fly like an arrow to the tall, naturally grand, pale-blond Teresa Reichlen, the most compellingly unknowable and pure dancer that company has had since the departure of Kyra Nichols four years ago.

headline: Chefs Assess El Bulli’s Legacy
text: I wrote an article that explores the effect of El Bulli’s imminent closing on Spanish cuisine, but its chef, Ferran Adrià, has influenced cooking all over the world, especially in haute cuisine. I asked some American chefs (and one restaurateur) to assess the legacy of Mr. Adrià and his cocina de vanguardia — the term he and others prefer over “molecular gastronomy.”

headline: A Facebook App for the iPad (Just Not From Facebook)
text: Facebook has had a mobile app for some time, but iPad users have had to go without a native iPad app.

headline: The Knife Rack Goes High-End
text: FOR years, a few privileged cooks have joined a waiting list to spend thousands of dollars for the carbon steel knives Bob Kramer makes by hand at his forge in Olympia, Wash. Two weeks ago the cookware chain Sur la Table began selling a signature line made to his specifications by Zwilling J. A. Henckels. Though the knives are priced as high as $349.95 for a 10-inch chef’s knife, cooks quickly bought hundreds of them, with the chain selling about 20 percent of its inventory in 10 days, said Jacob Maurer, the vice president for merchandising for Sur la Table.

headline: Resort Looks from Céline and Nina Ricci
text: There were so many resort presentations happening at Milk Studios on Monday that the building, which bumps up against the High Line park, began to feel like a department store. First floor: Marc by Marc Jacobs. Second floor: Céline, Nina Ricci, Erin Fetherston. Farther up were Lanvin, Givenchy and Pedro Lourenço.

headline: Facebook Hires Former White House Press Secretary Joe Lockhart
text: Facebook has hired Joe Lockhart, the White House press secretary during President Clinton’s second term, to be its vice president of communications.

headline: The Cook Who Couldn’t Taste
text: ON a bright May morning at the Union Square Greenmarket, Molly Birnbaum came across a potted clump of rosemary. She squeezed a leaf of it between her fingertips, brought the invisible smear of scent to her nostrils and inhaled.

headline: Postcards From the Resort
text: Oh my, aren’t designers taking the term “resort” a bit literally this season? I thought we were calling it pre-spring now.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Drink for Charity

headline: New on Smith Street, Croissants and Cured Fish
text: Breakfast and lunch at Seersucker in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, have been discontinued. Why? Because Robert Newton and Kerry Diamond, the owners, have turned a century-old pharmacy a few doors away into Smith Canteen, a cafe. They left the wood shelves and trim, tin ceiling and tile floors and added counters and tables. The coffee and espresso dispensed from a marble bar is from Counter Culture, and the iced coffee is dynamite. Pastries, like whole-wheat croissants with spinach filling, start the day. By lunch, there are sandwiches like duck confit banh mi, salads and items like a sweet pea quiche. Many use Greenmarket ingredients.

headline: Bamboo Pickles, With Grandma’s Help
text: Carla Squires grew up making bamboo pickles with her grandmother Johnsie Walsh, who had a stand of bamboo behind her house in Wilkes County, N.C. “I was the only grandchild who did it,” she said. Then, about four years ago, she took courses in food science at North Carolina State University and began making the pickles in a commercial kitchen.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Juicers for a Cocktail Splash
text: For that quick splash of citrus juice, be it orange, grapefruit, lemon or lime, this new four-in-one juicer (above, left) designed by Quentin de Coster in the Netherlands for the Royal Delft Group, is the answer. It has two reamers, one for smaller fruit, one for larger, and sits securely on top of a glass or cocktail shaker. An internal channel directs the juice, not the seeds, into the glass. It is dishwasher-safe, but not suggested for use on stemware or delicate glassware because of the pressure needed for juicing.

headline: Fedora
text: RECENTLY OPENED

headline: Boehner Warns Obama on Libya Operations
text: House Speaker John Boehner on Tuesday warned President Obama that his administration would be in violation of the War Powers Resolution unless he seeks authorization from Congress for America’s military involvement in the NATO operations in Libya or the United States withdraws from those operations.

headline: Bishops Won’t Focus on Abuse Policies
text: Despite recent cases in which Roman Catholic bishops failed to report or suspend priests accused of child sexual abuse, the bishops head into a meeting in Seattle on Wednesday proposing no significant revisions to the abuse prevention policies they passed in 2002 at the height of the scandal.

headline: Battle for Libya | June 14, 2011
text: Libyan rebels held a funeral for a comrade killed in clashes with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces, and NATO dropped leaflets warning of helicopter airstrikes.

headline: Russia Seizes Animal Parts
text: MOSCOW — The 26 elk lips were just the tip of the pile. The items the Russian customs agents reported seizing Tuesday were exotic even by the standards of Russia’s border with China, where wildlife smuggling is rampant: 1,041 bear paws, lynx fur, unspecified claw parts and five tusks from the extinct woolly mammoth.

headline: Slump Still in Effect, Bay Returns to Bench
text: ATLANTA — For the fourth time in nine games, Jason Bay was left out of the Mets’ starting lineup Tuesday night, with the possibility of more time on the bench to come.

headline: In Visit to Puerto Rico, Obama Offers (and Seeks Out) Support
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. — President Obama came to this United States commonwealth on Tuesday and promised to stand by Puerto Rico no matter what residents decide about its future — statehood, independence or a continuation of the status quo.

headline: One Voice or Many for the Taliban, but Pegged to a Single Name
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Will the real Zabiullah Mujahid, mouthpiece of the Taliban movement in Afghanistan, please stand up?

headline: Suddenly, Jeter’s Not Fine
text: “I’m fine,” Derek Jeter usually says when he is hit in the ribs or the hand by a pitched ball, or is suffering from a bug. Managers and teammates smile when he says he’s fine.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,604 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Inside BAMcinemaFest
text: Images from some of the films playing at BAMcinemaFest, a Brooklyn festival that celebrates independent cinema.

headline: The Work-Family Balance for Doctors
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Taste for Pad Thai, Then Criminal Court
text: The case could have been filed as an Upper West Side edition of “Clue”: the mezzo-soprano, in the frozen-food section of Trader Joe’s, with the open palm of her manicured left hand.

headline: A Call for Lower-Key Debate on Debt Limit
text: Many of the nation’s top economic and political power brokers gathered on Tuesday for a conference aimed at a more sober conversation regarding the federal budget.

headline: Philippe Petit: ‘Wireless!’
text: The famous tightrope walker has a new one-man show showcasing his other identities: juggler, magician, pickpocket, bullfighter, lock picker, motivational author.

headline: Street-Level High-Wire Man
text: “I am a madman!” Philippe Petit announced, and who’s to disagree?

headline: Charter Schools in Texas
text: To the Editor:

headline: Is Obesity in Youth a Deterrent to Future Success?
text: To the Editor:

headline: California Judge Upholds a Ruling on Gay Marriage
text: LOS ANGELES — A federal judge on Tuesday upheld the ruling that struck down California’s ban on same-sex marriage, asserting that the judge’s 10-year relationship with another man did not disqualify him from deciding the case.

headline: The Humanist in the Foxhole
text: Stockbridge, Mass.

headline: Indictments Over 2009 Quake Cause Quite a Furor
text: MILAN — Seven members of an Italian commission that assesses major risks like earthquakes have been indicted on manslaughter charges here for not adequately informing residents of the potential danger posed by the seismic activity that shook the Abruzzo region for months before the fatal earthquake that killed 309 people on April 6, 2009.

headline: Effort to End Tax Credit for Ethanol Fails in Senate
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate beat back a challenge to ethanol fuel subsidies on Tuesday in a demonstration of how the drive to cut the federal deficit can run headlong into a favored interest on Capitol Hill.

headline: The True Cost of Tomatoes
text: Mass-produced tomatoes have become redder, more tender and slightly more flavorful than the crunchy orange “cello-wrapped” specimens of a couple of decades ago, but the lives of the workers who grow and pick them haven’t improved much since Edward R. Murrow’s revealing and deservedly famous Harvest of Shame report of 1960, which contained the infamous quote, “We used to own our slaves; now we just rent them.”

headline: Candidates Show G.O.P. Less United on Goals of War
text: DERRY, N.H. — The hawkish consensus on national security that has dominated Republican foreign policy for the last decade is giving way to a more nuanced view, with some presidential candidates expressing a desire to withdraw from Afghanistan as quickly as possible and suggesting that the United States has overreached in Libya.

headline: Obama in Old San Juan
text: San Juan, P.R.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Standards for Politicians
text: To the Editor:

headline: A California Bankruptcy Court Rejects U.S. Law Barring Same-Sex Marriage
text: A bankruptcy court in California has declared that the 1996 law barring federal recognition of same-sex marriage is unconstitutional, increasing pressure against the law.

headline: The G.O.P. Debate
text: Monday’s Republican presidential debate in New Hampshire — full of historical error, economic obfuscation, avoidance of hard truths and even outright bigotry — was a feast for connoisseurs of political dysfunction. Desperate to avoid being outflanked on the right, the seven candidates tried so hard to outdo each other in finding fault with President Obama that they seemed to forget that they are competing for the same party nomination. By evening’s end, they had melted into an indistinguishable mass of privatizing, tax-cutting opponents of Shariah law.

headline: Wisconsin Court Reinstates Law on Union Rights
text: The Wisconsin Supreme Court cleared the way on Tuesday for significant cuts to collective bargaining rights for public workers in the state, undoing a lower court’s decision that Wisconsin’s controversial law had been passed improperly.

headline: Arnold Palmer’s Grandson Makes the Open on His Own
text: BETHESDA, Md. — Sam Saunders, one of the qualifiers at the United States Open, was quietly practicing his putting Tuesday at Congressional Country Club when a fan tried to summon his attention.

headline: Garmin Acquires a Rival Car Navigation Company
text: Selling car navigation devices is increasingly challenging these days because, after all, people can use their mobile phones to get directions free of charge.

headline: Somalia: Prime Minister Refuses to Quit
text: The future of Somalia’s transitional government became even more uncertain on Tuesday after the prime minister, Mohamed Abdullahi Mohamed, announced that he was refusing to resign, defying an agreement last week between Somalia’s president and Parliament speaker that included a reshuffling of the cabinet. Mr. Mohamed is popular among many Somalis and soldiers, and riots erupted last week when the president and the Parliament speaker said that Mr. Mohamed would be replaced. The president and speaker had bickered over whether to hold elections in August and agreed to a deal to extend Somalia’s weak transitional government for another year and to make changes in the cabinet. Mr. Mohamed says he will step down only if the full Parliament orders him to do so.

headline: A Call to Shift Policy on Marijuana
text: Night court in Manhattan, Monday, 7:30 p.m.

headline: Jeter Goes on Disabled List, Delaying Push to 3,000 Hits
text: Derek Jeter has paused his pursuit of history, landing on the 15-day disabled list Tuesday with a strained right calf, six hits short of 3,000 hits for his career.

headline: Fatah and Hamas Leaders to Meet
text: Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian Authority president and Fatah party chief, and Khaled Meshal, the Damascus-based leader of the militant group Hamas, will meet in Cairo next week to try to finalize the makeup of a Palestinian unity government after lower-level talks ended Tuesday without a consensus, according to the official Palestinian news agency Wafa. Fatah, which dominates in the West Bank, and Hamas, which controls Gaza, signed a reconciliation agreement in early May. Fatah has nominated Salam Fayyad, the current prime minister of the Palestinian Authority government, to lead a unity government of independent technocrats. Hamas has rejected Mr. Fayyad as a candidate.

headline: Banks Turn to Schumer on Patents
text: WASHINGTON — For years and much to their frustration, big banks have paid hundreds of millions of dollars to a tiny Texas company to use a patented system for processing digital copies of checks, making Claudio Ballard, the inventor of the system, a wealthy man and the bank industry’s biggest patent foe.

headline: Account Executive Is Antiquated. Consider Yourself a Catalyst.
text: A LEADING public relations agency is reorganizing its operations in another example of how the marketing communications industry is scrambling to adapt to the significant changes in consumer behavior, most notably the public’s fast and fierce embrace of digital and social media.

headline: In East Village, Harbingers of Spring Are Missing
text: For years, warm weather in the East Village has been heralded by an influx of young, tattooed visitors carrying backpacks and bedrolls and wearing clothes so stiffened with grit that they have come to be known in the neighborhood as crusties.

headline: Canada: Drug Raids in Mohawk Areas
text: About 500 police officers conducted a series of drug raids at Mohawk communities in the Montreal area on Tuesday and detained about 50 people. The police said they were investigating a drug trafficking ring that dealt primarily in marijuana. Some of the raids were at reserves, which are comparable to reservations in the United States.

headline: So No One’s Responsible?
text: With Justice Clarence Thomas writing for a 5-to-4 majority, the Supreme Court has made it much harder for private lawsuits to succeed against mutual fund malefactors, even when they have admitted to lying and cheating.

headline: France: Guardian Suggested for Heiress
text: A specially appointed medical panel is recommending that Liliane Bettencourt, the elderly L’Oréal heiress, be protected by a guardian because of her deteriorating health, according to the newspaper Le Monde. The panel’s members did not examine Mrs. Bettencourt, 88, the newspaper said, but based their opinion on her medical records. Her lawyer, Pascal Wilhelm, declined to comment Tuesday “due to the current situation.”  Mrs. Bettencourt’s daughter, Françoise Bettencourt-Meyers, has asked for court-appointed guardianship; France’s highest appeals court will review the request to determine whether it can be imposed without Mrs. Bettencourt’s support.

headline: Two Golfers Revisit a Memorable Masters
text: BETHESDA, Md. — Charl Schwartzel and Rory McIlroy completed their practice rounds Tuesday about 20 minutes apart — Schwartzel finishing first, followed by McIlroy. Two months ago, in the final round of the Masters, the order was much the same.

headline: Albany’s Duty to Stop Domestic Violence
text: There are just a few days left in the New York State legislative term, and there is a lot of important business left to do. We want to draw particular attention to two bills that would help protect victims of domestic violence. Both need to pass before lawmakers go home.

headline: David C. Baldus, 75, Dies; Studied Race and the Law
text: David C. Baldus, whose pioneering research on race and the death penalty came within a vote of persuading the Supreme Court to make fundamental changes in the capital justice system, died on Monday at his home in Iowa City. He was 75.

headline: Gay Marriage Bill Is One Vote Shy of Clearing State Senate
text: ALBANY — New York was on the cusp of legalizing same-sex marriage on Tuesday, after a second Republican state senator came forward to support the measure, leaving it a single vote shy of passage.

headline: Bias and the Beholder
text: Stephen Jay Gould, a prominent evolutionary biologist, gained broad public attention for exposing how scientists’ biases can skew their research. In one celebrated case, he charged that a famous study of human skulls in the mid-19th century had been manipulated, probably unconsciously, to support racist notions.

headline: Dr. James J. Rahal, 77, Virus Expert, Dies
text: Dr. James J. Rahal, an infectious-disease specialist who raised early alarms about the rise of drug-resistant bacteria in hospitals, and who emerged as a leading expert in the treatment of West Nile virus after the Queens community where he worked became the epicenter of a deadly outbreak in 1999, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 77.

headline: For Rubio, a Senate First
text: As far as Senate rituals go, Marco Rubio is old school, honoring the longtime Senate tradition of biding one’s time before joining the more seasoned politicians in speaking out on the floor; learning the rules before getting in the game.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Cutting the Deficit, Adding Jobs
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Transfers Delay Release of Detainees, Report Finds
text: Despite assurances that they would curb the practice of transferring detained immigrants to distant detention centers around the country, federal immigration officials continue to move hundreds of thousands of people a year, impeding the detainees’ access to lawyers and extending their time in custody, a human rights organization said in a report released on Tuesday.

headline: Vancouver Is Hoping to Avoid Replay of 1994
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — The intersection of Granville and Robson Streets, the center of what is referred to here as the party zone, was a somber place Monday night. With about 30 police officers looking on, dejected fans in blue and green floated through downtown Vancouver’s entertainment district unsure of where to go and what to do.

headline: Justice Goes Global
text: You probably missed the recent special issue of China Newsweek, so let me bring you up to date. Who do you think was on the cover — named the “most influential foreign figure” of the year in China? Barack Obama? No. Bill Gates? No. Warren Buffett? No. O.K., I’ll give you a hint: He’s a rock star in Asia, and people in China, Japan and South Korea scalp tickets to hear him. Give up?

headline: A Slowdown for Small Businesses
text: In the latest sign that the economic recovery may have lost whatever modest oomph it had, more small businesses say that they are planning to shrink their payrolls than say they want to expand them.

headline: Justice Department Accused of ‘Reckless Technique’
text: WASHINGTON — In a report issued Tuesday by two powerful Republicans in Congress, the Justice Department was accused of conducting an operation that allowed nearly 1,000 guns to flow illegally into Mexico, including two that were eventually found at the scene of the murder of an American Border Patrol agent.

headline: Perry Speaks, but Avoids  Big Question
text: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas came to Manhattan on Tuesday night to address local Republicans, and in the process stoked speculation about his ongoing presidential deliberations.

headline: A Hole in One Helps, but Mental Discipline Is Critical at Majors
text: BETHESDA, Md. — The only thing more difficult than winning one of golf’s four major championships is winning them all.

headline: Shuttle’s End Leaves NASA a Pension Bill
text: The nation’s space agency plans to spend about half a billion dollars next year to replenish the pension fund of the contractor that has supplied thousands of workers to the space shuttle program.

headline: With a Game 7 to Go, Omens Take the Stage
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — One final game will decide who will lift the Stanley Cup, one game to decide the winner of one of the oddest, most contentious, culturally fascinating and entertaining finals in N.H.L. history.

headline: College-Readiness Low Among State Graduates, Data Show
text: Heightening concerns about the value of many of its high school diplomas, the New York State Education Department released new data on Tuesday showing that only 37 percent of students who entered high school in 2006 left four years later adequately prepared for college, with even smaller percentages of minority graduates and those in the largest cities meeting that standard.

headline: At Chase, Top Ranks Get a Big Shake-Up
text: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, removed the head of the bank’s consumer banking business and reshuffled several other top executives in the biggest shake-up of his management team since the financial crisis.

headline: State Lawmakers Argue Over Rent Laws as Deadline Looms
text: ALBANY — Rent regulations that limit how much landlords can charge for more than one million apartments in New York City and its suburbs are set to expire at the end of Wednesday, and lawmakers on Tuesday were still debating whether to simply renew them or to make changes sought by tenant advocates.

headline: Thriving Corporate Park Spurs Growth in Bronx
text: In 2001, when Joseph Simone, the president of the family-owned Simone Development Companies in New Rochelle, N.Y., bid $3.7 million at a state auction for a weedy 18.5-acre site in the Bronx, home to an abandoned residential treatment center, skeptics wondered what such a normally astute businessman could possibly be thinking.

headline: Wednesday: Having Four Sharps
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Confession: Sometimes I have to look really, really hard to spot the words in “words-hidden-inside-other-words” themes. Today’s puzzle, however, very kindly supplies the answers following the theme entries, and those answers also help to flesh out the theme itself.

headline: 1 Radioactive Bite, 8 Legs and 183 Previews
text: There is something to be said for those dangerous flying objects — excuse me, I mean actors — that keep whizzing around the Foxwoods Theater, where the mega-expensive musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” has entered the latest chapter of its fraught and anxious existence. After all, if you’re worried that somebody might fall on top of you from a great height, the odds are that you won’t nod off.

headline: ‘Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark’
text: Photos of the Broadway musical at the Foxwoods Theater.

headline: Squeezing Costs, Builders Take New Look at Prefab
text: PHILADELPHIA — A package arrived on a shabby north Philadelphia block in January 2010, wrapped in Tyvek and measuring 55 feet long and 16 feet wide. Inside was a kitchenette, a bathroom and two bedrooms. The only thing missing was the toilet bowl lid. Just six weeks — and 88 similar packages — later, the Modules at Templetown, a four-story student-housing complex of 80,000 square feet near Temple University here, had completely risen from its concrete foundation.

headline: City Comptroller Is Asked to Curb Comments on Fraud Case
text: Seeking to prevent additional unauthorized disclosures about the continuing criminal inquiry into the city’s troubled automated payroll project, the United States attorney in Manhattan has urged John C. Liu, the city comptroller, to make no more public statements about the case without first consulting investigators.

headline: Camel’s Nose Under the Wheel?
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Wal-Mart Workers Try the Nonunion Route
text: After numerous failed attempts to unionize Wal-Mart stores, the nation’s main union for retail workers has decided to try a different approach: it has helped create a new, nonunion group of Wal-Mart employees that intends to press for better pay, benefits and most of all, more respect at work.

headline: Corrections
text: NEW YORK

headline: Apple’s Hype Envelops Penney
text: Apple’s reality distortion field has enveloped J. C. Penney. The department store chain poached Ron Johnson, the man behind Apple’s stores, to be its eventual chief executive. The hiring helped lift J. C. Penney’s market value by nearly a fifth, or $1.2 billion, before edging back a bit at the end of trading on Tuesday. It is true that Mr. Johnson also spent 15 years at the retailer Target, but Apple’s halo looks too wide.

headline: Defense Cites Unforeseen Factors in Deutsche Bank Fire
text: Summarizing their theories of what caused the deaths of two firefighters battling a blaze in the former Deutsche Bank building in Lower Manhattan, two defense lawyers on Tuesday echoed what they said 10 weeks earlier during opening statements — that an artificially created smoke chamber, not a missing standpipe, was to blame.

headline: Pakistan Arrests C.I.A. Informants in Bin Laden Raid
text: WASHINGTON — Pakistan’s top military spy agency has arrested some of the Pakistani informants who fed information to the Central Intelligence Agency in the months leading up to the raid that led to the death of Osama bin Laden, according to American officials.

headline: A Green Solution, or the Dark Side to Cleaner Coal?
text: LIANYUNGANG, CHINA — The six massive silos standing beside this industrial port in northeastern China hold seemingly contradictory promises: They could help improve the quality of China’s polluted air, but they might also contribute to faster global warming.

headline: Braves Wet Down the Infield, but They Can’t Slow Reyes
text: ATLANTA — Ever since the Atlanta Braves moved into the National League East in 1994, and Bobby Cox started managing against his rival Bobby Valentine later that decade, the Braves and the Mets have engaged in fierce competition and creative gamesmanship.

headline: To Be Good Citizens, Report Says, Companies Should Just Focus on Bottom Line
text: A new paper by an advisory firm that works with major corporations argues that companies would achieve more social good by simply focusing on the bottom line rather than social responsibility programs, double- and triple-bottom-line accounting and hybrid structures that have nonprofit and for-profit arms.

headline: Relic of Saint Disappears From Its Case Inside Church
text: LONG BEACH, Calif. — When missing something, devout Catholics often turn to St. Anthony of Padua, the patron saint of lost objects. Now, parishioners here are turning to him to pray for the return of his own relic.

headline: Southern Baptists Elect Black Pastor
text: The Southern Baptist Convention elected a popular black pastor as first vice president on Tuesday, a decision described by church leaders as historic and a prelude to his likely elevation to the presidency of the nation’s largest Protestant denomination next year.

headline: Extent of the Wallow Fire
text: Raging through eastern Arizona and neighboring New Mexico, the Wallow Fire has become the largest in Arizona’s history.

headline: C.I.A. Building Base for Strikes in Yemen
text: WASHINGTON — The Central Intelligence Agency is building a secret air base in the Middle East to serve as a launching pad for strikes in Yemen using armed drones, an American official said Tuesday.

headline: Yankees’ Bats Fill Void With Whacks
text: For more than eight years before Tuesday, Derek Jeter was active for every Yankees game. He collected 1,603 hits between trips to the disabled list, and the Yankees can only hope this one turns out as well for them as the last.

headline: T-Mobile USA Offers a Daily Deals App
text: Even phone companies are getting in on the daily deals craze.

headline: Coltrane’s Final Home Is Put on List of Endangered Historic Sites
text: The final residence of John Coltrane, a ranch-style home in Dix Hills, N.Y., where he composed his masterpiece “A Love Supreme,” is now among the 11 most endangered historic places in the country, the National Trust for Historic Preservation is to announce on Wednesday.

headline: When Warming Up for Exercise, Less May Be More
text: Few aspects of sports are as wrapped in myth as the warm-up. Most of us dutifully warm up in some way before we work out or compete, but according to a new study, “little is known about how an athlete should warm up.” In fact, as that study and other recent research make clear, the more scientists study warm-ups, the less they seem to understand about the practice.

headline: Aston Villa’s Coaching Conundrum
text: It was revealed last week that Sheriff Woody from “Toy Story” is a fan of Aston Villa, or at least the man who supplies his voice is. Tom Hanks isn’t the only big name follower of Villa; the recently married Duke of Cambridge and the British Prime Minister David Cameron are staunch supporters. The team from England’s second city has no trouble attracting big names to its stands; however, it’s finding things slightly trickier when it comes to finding a man to actually run the team.

headline: Conviction of Officer Is Reversed
text: An appeals court on Tuesday overturned the manslaughter conviction of a former New York City police officer, ruling he was justified when he fatally shot a drunken driver while he was off duty four years ago.

headline: As ‘Spider-Man’ Opens, Its Former Director Shows Up. And a Former President.
text: A night on Broadway that was elusive for so long — the opening of “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” — came at last on Tuesday and included a reunion that once seemed truly improbable: Julie Taymor, the musical’s director of record, on stage for the curtain call hugging onetime collaborator Bono and the producers who ousted her.

headline: Vancouver Is Doing It the Hard Way
text: The Vancouver Canucks are averaging 1.33 goals a game in the Stanley Cup finals, a meager total that has not prevented them from winning three of the first six contests. In Cup history, only 14 teams in the finals have had a worse scoring rate than Vancouver’s and only one of those clubs — the 1945 Maple Leafs — ended up as the champion.

headline: NYT: Front Page for 06/15/2011
text: NYT: Front Page for 06/15/2011

headline: Lead Poisoning in China: The Hidden Scourge
text: MENGXI VILLAGE, China — On a chilly evening early last month, a mob of more than 200 people gathered in this tiny eastern China village at the entrance to the Zhejiang Haijiu Battery Factory, a maker of lead-acid batteries for motorcycles and electric bikes. They shouldered through an outer brick wall, swept into the factory office and, in an outpouring of pure fury, smashed the cabinets, desks and computers inside.

headline: Word of the Day | irreconcilable
text: irreconcilable •\i-ˌre-kən-ˈsi-lə-bəl, -ˈre-kən-ˌ, ˌi(r)-\• adjective

headline: Test Yourself | Math, June 15, 2011
text: Test your math skills with today’s question, created by Kari Kokka at Math for America from the article “Li Na Dethrones Schiavone at French Open.”

headline: News Quiz | June 15, 2011

headline: I Ruined The Economy And All I Got Were These Lousy Tax Cuts
text: That’s the title of a report by David Dayen. Key takeaway:

headline: Doubletalk Express
text: Rick Perlstein sends me to Sam Husseini asking Paul Ryan why, if he’s so concerned with government spending on health care, he doesn’t support single-payer. Ryan’s response is pure gobbledygook: he never answers the question, cites irrelevant facts (Medicare costs are rising! But what about private insurance, which is rising even faster?), and in general stonewalls and runs out the clock.

headline: After Earnings Lead to Share Drop, Glencore Denies ENRC Bid
text: Glencore said Wednesday that it was not actively considering a takeover of the Kazakh mining company ENRC, triggering a clause in the British takeover code that prohibits the Swiss commodities trader from bidding for ENRC for six months.

headline: Checking the Boxes
text: WHO are grappling with the issues raised by new college application forms that provide more options for indicating one’s ethnic and racial identity?

headline: Silent Sentinels Along a Vast Frontier
text: In American English, “frontier” calls to mind opportunity, myth and adventure. But “frontera,” in Spanish, has a different sense. It is the limit, the edge and the border.

headline: The Big Banks Fight On
text: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: What Is Your Best Subject?
text: A nationwide test revealed that American students’ weakest subject is history, and they performed best in economics. What subjects are you most proficient in? Why do you think that is the case? Are your favorite subjects also the ones in which do you best? Do you perform best in classes in which you have the best teachers? Or which coincide with your abilities?

headline: Canucks’ General Manager Opens a Can of Worms Over Raymond Injury
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — Add one more controversy to this Stanley Cup final series filled with shattering hits on the ice and bitter accusations off it. Fittingly, it came on the eve of Game 7.

text: Involved a fender bender? There’s an app for that.

text: Hong Kong’s creative community is small but growing, and it’s easier to participate in than ever.

headline: Myanmar Government Troops Battle Rebels Near China Border
text: BANGKOK — Fighting spread on Wednesday in the volatile northern reaches of Myanmar between a large rebel army and government troops, a rebel spokesman said, the latest flare-up in a simmering conflict between ethnic groups and Myanmar’s central government.

headline: Crash Tests Suggest Jeep Fire Risk, Safety Group Says
text: MILLIONS of Jeep Grand Cherokees from the 1993 through 2004 model years are particularly susceptible to fires when struck from behind and should be recalled, an auto safety group says. The Center for Auto Safety based its conclusion on a review of three independently conducted crash tests, including one performed last month.

headline: Did Wells Fargo Answer Your Lending Questions?
text: Two weeks ago, in tandem with our conversation with two Wells Fargo small-business lending officers, Marc Bernstein and Doug Case, we invited You’re The Boss readers to submit questions for the executives. Today, we present their responses.

headline: Strike Deadline Nears for Macy’s Workers
text: The lines outside Macy’s flagship store on 34th Street in Manhattan often tend to consist of shoppers, or perhaps onlookers gawking at the Thanksgiving Day Parade floats.

headline: At Impasse, Greek Leader Vows to Reset Cabinet
text: ATHENS — Prime Minister George Papandreou of Greece said on Wednesday that he would reshuffle his cabinet and request a vote of confidence in Parliament after talks with the opposition about a unity government foundered.

headline: How People’s Opera Orchestrated Its Peril
text: AT first glance New York City Opera would appear to have been blessed with a full chorus of advantages.

headline: Britain Backs Higher Capital Rules for Banks
text: LONDON – Britain’s government is supporting a proposal that would require banks to hold more capital and partly shield retail operations from investment banking.

headline: The Alphabetized War on Food-Borne Pathogens
text: When terrorists strike in other cities, no matter how far away, New Yorkers shudder. It’s reasonable for them to wonder if they may be next. So train bombings in, say, London or Madrid, lead automatically to more vigorous police patrols in our own subways.

headline: Dish Network Bids $1.37 Billion for TerreStar
text: Charles W. Ergen‘s Dish Network has bid $1.375 billion in cash and the assumption of liabilities for TerreStar Networks, according to a bankruptcy filing on Wednesday.

headline: Most Mail Delivery in Canada Halts After Strikes
text: OTTAWA — For the second day in a row, Canada’s labor minister took steps toward legislating an end to major work stoppage on Wednesday.

headline: Markets Falter as Worry Rises in Greek Crisis
text: Greece’s financial and political crisis, compounded by new fears about the pace of the United States economic recovery, sent financial markets reeling on Wednesday.

headline: The Uneasy Media-Military Relationship
text: In 2008 my battalion was tasked with a mission to clear one of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia’s last bastions in one of Iraq’s most troubled regions. Two weeks before the mission, my battalion commander sternly ordered that every soldier was to keep it secret from family, friends and Facebook.

headline: Wednesday Reading: F.D.A. Sets Rules For Sunscreens
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Heading to Edinburgh, but First Some Exposure in New York
text: A drama about St. Francis of Assisi, a tragicomic performance about struggles in the life of a comedian, and several lighthearted works are among more than a dozen shows that will make up “East to Edinburgh,” a festival of New York productions bound for the Edinburgh Festival Fringe this summer.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S. vs. Guadeloupe
text: The United States national team needed a result against Guadeloupe to advance to the quarterfinals of the Concacaf Gold Cup, and they got one — a 1-0 victory over the tiny Caribbean archipelago.

headline: America’s Favorite Talking Hothead
text: Keith Olbermann likes looking into a camera. The return of its gaze animates him and reminds him that he has a million friends on the other side of it. But he doesn’t picture those people. He talks directly to the camera. “I’ve never been convinced the cameras are plugged into anything,” he said.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Pandora Prices Its I.P.O. at $16 a Share  |  The online music service Pandora may not be profitable, but that hasn’t discouraged investors clamoring for a piece of it.

headline: Another Oscar Shakeup: Number of Best Picture Nominees Will Vary
text: LOS ANGELES — Delivering yet another jolt to an Oscar system that has been shaken by changing rules and shifting dates, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences says that it will now shift to a variable system under which the number of best picture nominees can range from 5 to 10 in any year.
