text: With the New Hampshire debate behind them, the Republican candidates for president begin the summer political season with several challenges facing them.

headline: After Royal Wedding, Kicking Back in New York
text: Any party planner or diplomatic official would agree that hosting visits from the pope and the president and hosting a royal wedding within the past nine month warrants a vacation.

headline: The Governors’ Advantage in Presidential Races Is Bigger Than You Thought
text: It’s reasonably well known that governors have a more successful record than senators when it comes to winning presidential nominations. Throughout American history, about twice as many governors as senators have been chosen to be standard bearers by the major parties, even though at any given moment there are only half as many sitting governors as sitting senators.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: A Targeted Payroll-Tax Cut
text: 11:34 a.m. | Updated with today’s report on inflation.

headline: Murder? Madness? Cherchez la Femme
text: As the last hot weeks of the summer of 1933 settled over the working-class edges of Paris, a tall 18-year-old murderess, robed in a dark dress purchased hours before at an opulent department store, surveyed her family’s two-room apartment in the crowded Rue de Madagascar. The poison that she had fed her parents had by that time left her father dead and her mother unconscious. The girl stepped around their bodies as she searched the apartment for money, then opened the gas valve in the kitchen. After waiting for the gas to fill the air, she walked quietly out of the apartment to her neighbor’s door. “Help!” she called. “I think my parents have committed suicide!”

headline: Expanding the Internet; finding free music, books and movies; news.
text: The Internet is vast but it's also running out of addresses. Bettina Edelstein speaks with Times contributor Verne Kopytoff about IPv6, a successor to the IPv4 protocol that allows many more addresses to be created — around 340 undecillion. Who doesn't love free? J.D. Biersdorfer and Pedro Rafael Rosado chat about ways to find free books, music and movies on the Web. The news roundup includes a suit against Apple over the name iCloud; Apple changing In-App subscription policy; new console from Nintendo called the Wii U; and a report of defections from Facebook. J.D.'s tech tip, about quick answers from search engines for trigonometric functions, among other things.

headline: C.F.T.C. Faces More Budget Woes
text: Gary Gensler is fighting for funding — again.

headline: Researcher Responds to Arguments Over His Theory of Arguing
text: An article posted on Tuesday about an academic theory proposing a new evolutionary explanation for the development of human reasoning has generated a lively debate among readers. One of the theory’s co-authors, Hugo Mercier, a researcher at the University of Pennsylvania, read through the first 200 or so online comments and wrote this brief response from London, where he is attending a conference.

headline: May Consumer Inflation Rose at a Slower Rate
text: Consumer prices crept up last month at the slowest pace so far this year, tempered by a decline in energy prices, according to government figures released on Wednesday, while a regional report for New York suggested a decline in manufacturing activity and optimism.

headline: Texan Defends Proposed Ban on ‘Intrusive’ Airport Searches
text: The Texas House of Representatives approved a bill last month banning “intrusive” airport screening, but the legislation stalled in the State Senate after Washington threatened to consider halting flights to Texas if screeners were prevented from doing their jobs properly. The bill would have banned any pat-down that “touches the anus, sexual organ, buttocks or breast of another person including through the clothing, or touches the other person in a manner that would be offensive to a reasonable person.” The measure might be reintroduced in the current special session, where its backers say it might have enough votes this time to pass the Senate. Its sponsor, Representative David Simpson, a Republican from Longview, discusses.

headline: Great Deals on Europe’s Seas
text: PRICED out of Europe this summer? Consider a cruise.

headline: Cable Channel ‘Spots’ New Stars
text: A special on the E! cable channel on Wednesday night is devoted to the actors who are watched by the public a half-minute at a time.

headline: SoundCloud, an Audio-Sharing Site, Hits 5 Million Users
text: In the past, musicians who wanted to share their tracks online might have used MySpace Music. But SoundCloud, a popular audio-sharing service, is steadily gaining traction as a way for musicians to post their songs and for fans to discover them.

headline: Medicaid Managed Care Plans
text: As more states turn to health plans to deliver Medicaid services, a Commonwealth Fund report published on Wednesday analyzes the cost and quality among plans with publicly traded stock.

headline: Would Solar Lull Snuff Climate Action?
text: [5:14 p.m. | Updated I’ve just posted a detailed new critique of the predicted sunspot lull by one of the country’s leading solar scientists.]According to news reports (and a news release) from a meeting of solar scientists in New Mexico, three separate lines of analysis point to decent prospects for a sustained downturn in solar activity, with important potential implications for Earth’s climate, and for climate policy.

headline: U.N. Officials Warn of a Growing ‘Panic’ in Central Sudan as Violence Spreads
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — United Nations officials warned on Wednesday of “a growing sense of panic” in the volatile Kordofan area of central Sudan, with 60,000 people displaced, aid convoys blocked, ethnic clashes erupting and dozens dead — possibly including several United Nations workers. President Obama urged the Sudanese government to cease “its military actions immediately.”

headline: Missing Dad
text: This will be a tough Father’s Day for Josh Tyson — his first without his father. That is hard enough when the memories are mostly good ones. But when the memories are muddled, and there is a lingering feeling of what might have been, the day can take on a meaning not found in any Hallmark card.

headline: The Stockholm Syndrome Theory of Long Novels
text: More than a month ago, Dan Kois wrote a Riff on force-feeding yourself highbrow cinema. And while this essay is still reverberating loudly online, Kois also wrote a review last week for NPR of “The Pleasures of Reading in an Age of Distraction,” by Alan Jacobs, dealing with the literary equivalent of “cultural vegetables” and the much-bemoaned American affliction: reading with A.D.D.

headline: Copa Libertadores Finals: Peñarol vs. Santos
text: It has been a long, long time since the Estadio Centenario in Montevideo, Uruguay, the site of the first World Cup final in 1930, has hosted a match of such significance (and that would probably be the 1995 Copa América final won by the hosts against Brazil).

headline: With Wife Home, Focus on Weiner’s Next Steps
text: Top Democrats in the House were bracing Wednesday morning for a decision from Representative Anthony D. Weiner, who has been under growing pressure to resign after revelations of his lewd online exchanges with women.

headline: Lewis Hamilton Jumps Border and Swaps Cars With Tony Stewart
text: As far as diversions go, this one was impeccably timed.

headline: Guid Mornin: Fasten Your Seatbelts, and Ha a Guid Journay, Hae a Guid Rin*
text: Portland Timbers Coach John Spencer is the flight attendant from Scotland in a new, hilarious commercial for Alaska Airlines, the lead sponsor for the Major League Soccer expansion team.

headline: A Dose of Confusion
text: If the label on one bottle of prescription drugs says, “Take one tablet twice daily,” and the label on another says, “Take one tablet every 12 hours,” would you realize that you could take both medications at the same time?

headline: Northern Ireland Has an Outsize Presence in Golf
text: Rory McIlroy and Graeme McDowell entered the world’s top-10 rankings with a sonic boom, and now they are heading into the U.S. Open that starts Thursday with McDowell sitting seventh, one spot ahead of McIlroy. It’s been a stratospheric rise in the sport for Northern Ireland, which leads to the question: How is it that a country of roughly 1.6 million people is flying so high?

headline: New Recruit in Homework Revolt: The Principal
text: GALLOWAY, N.J. — After Donna Cushlanis’s son kept bursting into tears midway through his second-grade math problems, which one night took over an hour, she told him not to do all of his homework.

headline: Citi Hires Senior Capital Markets Banker
text: Citigroup has hired Elinor Hoover from Morgan Stanley as a vice chairwoman for capital markets and origination in the Americas, the firm announced in an internal memorandum on Wednesday. A 20-year veteran of Morgan Stanley, Ms. Hoover will start at Citi on Sept. 6. She will report to John Chirico and Richard Zogheb, the co-heads of Citi’s capital markets business.

headline: Rebels Seize Buildings in Southern Yemen
text: SANA, Yemen — Militants made a serious incursion early Wednesday into a provincial capital in Yemen’s southeast, warning government officials to leave or face retaliation. The attack was the latest case of armed groups’ taking advantage of the security vacuum created by the country’s prolonged political crisis.

headline: South African Is Acquitted in Case Linked to Diamonds
text: JOHANNESBURG — Jeremy Ractliffe, a South African businessman left holding a bag of mysterious diamonds given to him by the supermodel Naomi Campbell, was found not guilty here on Wednesday of charges that he violated laws against possessing uncut gems.

headline: For His Children’s Book, Weird Al Gets a Weird App
text: Weird Al Yankovic continues to find his way into the hearts and minds of America’s youth, and this time there’s nothing that Lady Gaga can do to stand in his way. On Wednesday, HarperCollins Children’s Books said an application would be released for Apple iPad, iPhone and iPod Touch devices based on Mr. Yankovic’s best-selling children’s book, “When I Grow Up.” The original book, written by Mr. Yankovic (who, in a rare career move, did not declare himself to be “Weird” on its cover) and illustrated by Wes Hargis, follows an 8-year-old boy named Billy as he considers grown-up career options, such as becoming a doctor, firefighter, giraffe milker or snail trainer. The “When I Grow Up” app, which is developed by the Web design company Bean Creative, offers interactive games and features based on the book, including the option to have Mr. Yankovic read it to you, and opportunities to practice some of Billy’s more fanciful future occupations, such as shaving a tarantula or massaging a gorilla. Mr. Yankovic said in a statement that when he was a child, “I dreamed of one day helping to produce a cross-platform app that would be sold in the iTunes Store.” He added: “I was a very prescient kid.”

headline: This Agency Makes It Easy to Buy, Buy, Buy
text: Advertising agencies are always trying to persuade consumers to go shopping. Now, one agency is going to eliminate the middleman, as it were, by bringing the retailers onto its premises and inviting shoppers to come by.

headline: From Tom Donohue, Pointed Jocularity on the Debt Limit
text: Tom Donohue, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, told an Atlanta audience on Monday that he was confident Congress would raise the debt ceiling. Then he delivered a warning to members of Congress who have threatened to block any increase in the amount of money the government is allowed to borrow.

headline: SunPower Investors Back Total Takeover
text: A majority of SunPower’s investors have backed the $1.3 billion takeover by Total, a wealthy partner, that will allow it to roll out its technology around the world.

headline: How Dimon Shook Up His Management Team
text: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, has a reputation as a ruthless boss. But in his deftly orchestrated management shake-up on Tuesday, he showed he could also be compassionate.

headline: Thomas Most Valuable Already?
text: It seems to be the perfect combination for the Boston Bruins: larger-than-life Zdeno Chara patrolling up front, smashing people into the boards, while goalie Tim Thomas holds down the fort.

headline: One Game for the Cup
text: It’s fitting that the Stanley Cup finals will slam to a close Wednesday night in a Game 7 between two teams that have found new and inventive ways to bludgeon each other. The Boston Bruins and Vancouver Canucks’ grudge match has been the perfect bookend to a season in which the N.H.L.’s biggest star spent time in darkened rooms and players were being carted off the ice at an alarming pace.

headline: China Takes a New Interest in Energy Efficiency
text: SHANGHAI — The Chinese government is considering plans to subsidize the use of energy-efficient materials and renewable energy technologies in new buildings and is encouraging provincial and municipal governments to impose stricter efficiency standards than the national minimums, Chinese officials said Wednesday.

headline: Connecting With Clients Through the Power of Tech
text: In Lynn Milos’s previous business endeavors as a caterer and private chef, customer service was old school and face to face — the longstanding marketplace advantage enjoyed by small businesses over big businesses.

headline: The Race to Lead Carlyle’s I.P.O. Heats Up
text: On Wednesday, many of the top banks on Wall Street put on a show.

headline: College Students Don’t View Debt as Burden
text: Debt has become a way of life for American college students. The average student loan debt among graduating college seniors was more than $23,000 in 2008, according to FinAid.org. In addition, the student lender Sallie Mae says the average graduating senior with at least one credit card had $4,138 in debt on the card.

headline: Wear Resort Now | Drop-Waist Dresses
text: Though designers like Preen favored a nipped waistline, others did away with fitted construction and are preferring a more relaxed, neo-1920s silhouette this resort season. It all started with Chanel’s beachy drop-waist dress done in polished tweed, which proved that refined does not necessarily mean restricted. Louis Vuitton presented sporty, Gatsby-era dresses in white, while Thakoon played with patterns, clashing ikat with bold stripes, and Missoni melded the ’20s and ’60s with drop-waist dresses presented in psychedelic knits. Whether it’s a day dress, minidress or housedress, torsos are getting the attention this time around. Check out Rag & Bone’s striped mesh dress ($395) or Issa’s easy white cotton-voile dress ($460). For summer evenings, try Temperley London’s black lace and cotton dress ($1,325) and Anna Sui’s embellished tulle and lace dress ($1,065). They are all available at netaporter.com. The only thing you’re missing is a straw hat.

headline: BMW Reveals M5 Ahead of Frankfurt Auto Show
text: Dressed in baby-blue clear coat and spinning a new twin-turbo engine generating more than 550 horsepower, the 2012 BMW M5 sedan was revealed online Wednesday.

headline: The Korean Paul Potts
text: For several hours, I thought this clip was a hoax: either the Koreans were making fun of us, or someone had hijacked an actual “Korea’s Got Talent” episode with an imported vocal track and mock subtitles.

headline: Cracking the Q.R. Code
text: Vanda Asapahu was living in Bangkok working in public health with the United Nations until two years ago. That’s when her parents back in Los Angeles told her they were planning to retire from the Thai restaurant they had been running for six years and asked her to come home to take over the business with her brother.

headline: As Number of Medicaid Patients Goes Up, Their Benefits Are About to Drop
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration injected billions of dollars into Medicaid, the nation’s low-income health program, as the recession deepened two years ago. The money runs out at the end of this month, and benefits are being cut for millions of people, even though unemployment has increased.

headline: Behind the Small-Business Funk
text: If you are a reader of economics blogs, you should probably add Jared Bernstein to your mix if you haven’t yet done so. A former Obama administration adviser, he now works at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities and appears on CNBC, among other places. He made a smart point earlier today about the recent drop in small-business confidence:

headline: B. Smith, a Renaissance Woman, Comes Home
text: BEFORE B. Smith found success as a fashion model, restaurateur, television host and cookbook author, she was a struggling lounge singer and actress. “I worked all the small clubs throughout Manhattan and the Catskills,” she said. “Anywhere that would have me.”

headline: U.S. Reactors Unprepared for Total Power Loss, Report Suggests
text: Nuclear safety rules in the United States do not adequately weigh the risk of a single event that would knock out electricity from the grid and from emergency generators, as a quake and tsunami recently did in Japan, officials of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Wednesday.

headline: A Deeper Look at an Energy Analysis Raises Big Questions
text: [June 16, 12:45 a.m. | Updated  A lead author, Dan Kammen, has defended the report below, and the co-chairman of the climate panel working group dealing with climate policy, as well as Greenpeace representatives, have added comments, as well.]

headline: Australia Hints at Prisoner Swap with China in Rio Tinto Case
text: SHANGHAI — The Australian government said Wednesday that it was considering approval of a prisoner transfer treaty that could eventually allow Stern Hu, a former executive at the British-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto, to leave China and serve out the rest of his 10-year prison term in Australia.

headline: The Great Growth Disappointment
text: Second verse, same as the first: The quarter when the economy was supposed to stage its comeback is looking just as bad as its disappointing predecessor.

headline: Now How Much Will You Pay?
text: AT some point during the last five years, it occurred to Michael Bastian that $540 was a lot to charge for a pair of khaki cut-off shorts, even if some men were willing to pay.

headline: Democrats Complain About Republican Edits
text: When Representative Gerald E. Connolly, Democrat of Virginia, tried to send a taxpayer-paid newsletter to his constituents this month, the Republican majority had a few edits first.

headline: One Size Fits One, Redux (Wonkish)
text: The San Franciso Fed has a new letter (pdf) analyzing the dilemmas of eurozone monetary policy in terms of a Taylor rule. But it has a methodological problem that I think skews the results; doing it right would, I’d argue, look much less favorable for the ECB.

headline: Accused Pad Thai Slapper Found Not Guilty
text: The legal protection of self-defense, it seems, has been extended to noodle-related strife.

headline: How Not to Tell the Dalai Lama a Joke
text: During a television interview with the Dalai Lama last week, Karl Stefanovic, the host of a morning news show in Australia, told the revered leader of Tibetan Buddhists, “I have a joke for you, that my son told me, that he said you would laugh at, even though it’s about you.” What happened next, as the joke was haltingly translated, proved Mr. Stefanovic’s son quite wrong.

headline: Video: Will Rick Perry Run?
text: Megan Liberman and Jeff Zeleny discuss the possible presidential campaign of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas. Also, a conversation with a reporter who has covered Mr. Perry for years.

headline: Memories of a Father’s Rage
text: Corbyn Hightower also remembers her father, and her memories are also mixed. We talk often about anger from a parent’s point of view here on Motherlode. In a guest post today, Ms. Hightower crawls back into how it felt to be the child who feared her father’s loss of control.

headline: Fragmented Memories | Morocco
text: For the fourth issue of the The Rig Out (out in two weeks), the photographer Antony Crook — a co-founder of the magazine — says he chose Ouarzazate, Morocco, as the backdrop for an editorial that explores abstract fragmented memories. “We were looking for the feeling of hostility and isolation,” he explains. This companion video offers a sneak peak into the story, styled by another co-founder, Glenn Kitson, and featuring utilitarian clothing by Woolrich Woolen Mills, Clarks Originals and Stone Island.

headline: Caucus | Rick Perry's Possible Run
text: June 15, 2011 - Megan Liberman and Jeff Zeleny on the possible presidential campaign of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas. Also, a conversation with a reporter who has covered Mr. Perry for years.

headline: From Tonys to Billboard Chart: Good Week for ‘Book of Mormon’
text: Adele returned to the top of the Billboard album chart this week, supplanting Lady Gaga after two weeks. But the biggest news is what’s at No. 3: the cast recording of the Broadway show “The Book of Mormon.” According to Billboard it is the highest-charting Broadway album since 1969, when “Hair” was No. 1 for 13 weeks.

headline: Most Serious Charges Are Rejected in Terror Case
text: Two men who were accused of plotting to blow up the largest synagogue in Manhattan, and kill as many Jews as possible in the process, were formally indicted on Wednesday, but not on the most serious criminal charges sought by the Manhattan district attorney’s office.

headline: N.Y. Senate Republicans Undecided on a Gay Marriage Vote
text: ALBANY — Senate Republican leaders said on Wednesday that they had not decided whether to take a vote on legalizing same-sex marriage, as advocates were in a full-court press to gain the one vote needed to pass the measure before Monday, the scheduled end of this year’s legislative session.

headline: United Rentals Founder’s Next Bet: Transportation
text: Bradley S. Jacobs has already made a lot of money by building up companies in the waste disposal and rentals business. Now he has set his sights on transportation.

headline: Shinnecock to Host 2018 U.S. Open
text: BETHESDA, Md. -– The United States Golf Association announced Wednesday that Shinnecock Hills would host the 2018 United States Open, the fifth time the event has come to the Long Island club. The tournament was first held there in 1896.

headline: A Solar Scientist Rebuts a Cool Sunspot Prediction
text: June 16, 12:36 p.m. | Updated Douglas Biesecker, a scientist at the Space Weather Prediction Center of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and the leader of an international effort to chart and forecast trends in sunspots, has offered a detailed new critique of three lines of analysis predicting a long and deep lull in sunspot activity, with substantial potential impacts on Earth’s climate (and climate policy).

headline: Culled Geese Are Bound for Tables, Not Dump
text: This year, at least, the city’s slaughtered geese will not go to waste: They will go to feed hungry Pennsylvanians.

headline: Video: Huntsman Teases Campaign Announcement
text: 6 Days from Jon Huntsman Jr. on Vimeo.

headline: Just One Look | Emilio Pucci Resort
text: Peter Dundas had the temerity — and good taste — to take Pucci’s heritage print and update it, substituting a sun bleached, watercolor Ikat for the familiar 60’s pattern. There are other innovations in this rich, Euro-looking collection, including skinny mod suits, and hippie sundresses, with a fabulous use of zebra accents on belts, bags and blazers.

headline: At Some Hotels, Helping You Fill the Tank
text: With the cost of gas on the rise again, some hotels this summer are doing their part to help ease the crunch for guests.

headline: Viewers Shun Reruns for NBC Reality
text: On a night of mostly reruns, new episodes of “America’s Got Talent” and “The Voice” lifted NBC to No. 1 in the ratings on Tuesday. According to Nielsen’s estimates “America’s Got Talent” delivered the night’s largest audience with 12.3 million viewers at 8 p.m. although “The Voice,” which drew 12.1 million from 9 to 11, attracted higher ratings in the demographic of viewers 18 to 49.

headline: In ‘Bloombergville,’ Budget Protesters Sleep In
text: So it may not be quite on the scale of the so-called Walkerville sit-in in Wisconsin, or the protests in Tahrir Square in Cairo. Nor will it remind anyone of the anti-apartheid shantytowns on college campuses in the 1980s, or even, on a much less serious note, the legions of Duke students who regularly camp out in a makeshift tent city, known as Krzyzewskiville, before college basketball games.

headline: Fit for Life’s Challenges
text: ON a Tuesday night in April, Jillian Michaels, the fitness guru, sat down on a table at the Borders store in Columbus Circle and kicked off shiny beige Christian Louboutin pumps, revealing a blue pedicure. She was faced by a snaking line of hundreds, mostly women and teenage girls (but also a few potbellied men) clutching her sixth book, “Unlimited: How to Build an Exceptional Life.” Periodically, a giddy squeal would erupt from the crowd.

headline: Picture Books About the Backyard
text: It is sheer speculation to imagine that John Berendt, the best-selling author of “Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil,” has writer’s block (his last book was 2005’s “City of Falling Angels”), but if he does, what greater serendipity than to have a family of birds alight and make their home on his New York City balcony? If nothing else, it’s perfect fodder for Berendt’s first children’s book.

headline: Art Critic Meets a Tough Crowd
text: The words and images on these pages come from an online experiment in participatory art criticism. Part of my assignment to review the Venice Biennale involved a new interactive project called “Everyone’s a Critic.”

headline: A Bank and the ‘Taste’ of a Tournament
text: 3:54 p.m. | Updated For its fourth annual promotion in New York centered on its sponsorship of the Wimbledon tennis championships, HSBC will offer consumers a “taste” of the tournament — literally as well as figuratively.

headline: Shopping Snapshots for June 16
text: J. W. Hulme of St. Paul now offers Apple accessories like iPhone and iPad cases, nautically striped rompers and other items.

headline: Misdirection in Goldman Sachs’s Housing Short
text: Goldman Sachs appears to be trying to clear its name.

headline: Scouting Report
text: LIMITED EDITIONS

headline: White House Defends Continuing U.S. Role in Libya Operation
text: WASHINGTON — The White House, pushing hard against criticism in Congress over the deepening air war in Libya, asserted Wednesday that President Obama had the authority to continue the military campaign without Congressional approval because American involvement fell short of full-blown hostilities.

headline: Untangling the Reviews For ‘Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark’
text: After shredding Julie Taymor’s version of the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” in February, the nation’s theater critics weighed in late Tuesday night with reviews of the new, 2.0 version of the musical that, for the most part, described “Spider-Man” as improved but nowhere near good enough to justify its record-setting $70 million budget.

headline: Lautenberg Criticizes Obama on Guns
text: Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, has written a letter to President Obama rebuking him for not pressing Congress to create some restrictions on guns and gun ownership.

headline: Powder Surge: It’s a Guy Thing
text: MICHAEL LEVY was returning to his desk from the restroom one morning when a female co-worker asked what he had spilled on himself.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: ROUGHING IT Think of acid-washed colored jeans... on your nails; or a tiny segment of a Gustav Klimt painting ... on your nails. That will give you a sense of what Sally Hansen’s new Crackle Overcoat line, which includes eight styles like Cherry Smash and Ink Splatter ($5.95), delivers. OPI also offers many options to get the crackle look, including a collection inspired by the movie “Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides,” featuring names like Mermaid’s Tears and “Silver Shatter,” and one called “Shatter” with basic colors like red and black ($8.50).

headline: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Greece, Afghanistan and Germany.

headline: Just One Look | Rochas Resort
text: Marco Zanini had one word in mind when designing Rochas’ collection: naiveté. That translates into adorable silhouettes of enfant-like qualities: drop-waist dresses in the palest pastels and flouncy chiffon, multi-layered skirts paired with middle-school sweaters. The White Rock nymph could look dashing in this golden brocade dress and matching trousers.

headline: At Friars Club, Exotic Dancer Roasts a Congressman
text: The Friars Club in Midtown Manhattan — famous for its provocative celebrity roasts — was the unlikely, if fitting, backdrop for the latest development in the tragicomedy that has become Representative Anthony D. Weiner‘s political life.

headline: Grassley Says 65 SAC Referrals Came to S.E.C.
text: For the last several weeks, Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, has pummeled the Securities and Exchange Commission with letters asking the agency to explain its response to 19 instances of suspicious trading at a major hedge fund.

headline: Photo Replay: June 15
text: The day in sports included the final day of practice before the United States Open golf tournament and the Stanley Cup final in Vancouver.

headline: Civilians Flee Another Northern Syria Town, Fearing a Military Assault
text: GUVECCI, Turkey — Hundreds fled a town in northern Syria on Wednesday that appeared to be the next target of a military seeking to crush a three-month uprising against President Bashar al-Assad, activists said, joining thousands already displaced in a growing crisis that has embarrassed the Syrian government.

headline: More on Women and Medicine
text: The conversation continues in response to Dr. Karen Sibert’s op-ed piece wondering whether women should be doctors if they also want flexibility in their working lives.

headline: Cambridge, Mass., Equalizes Cost of Health Insurance for Gay Workers
text: The city of Cambridge, Mass., may be the first municipality to equalize the cost of health benefits for its gay employees, following the lead of many corporations.

headline: Using Twitter as Your Database
text: For the 2010 election, we built a continuously updated election guide that let readers explore data related to each of the 509 congressional and gubernatorial races.

headline: Olbermann, Then and Now
text: In this Sunday’s magazine, David Carr catches up with Keith Olbermann just before he begins work on his new/old show for Al Gore’s Current network. In November of last year, Deborah Solomon got him just before he and MSNBC parted company. At the time, Solomon asked Olbermann, “What do you say to critics who find you smug?” He replied:  “I don’t know. I don’t have a good working definition of ‘smug.’”

headline: States Want More in Pension Contributions
text: First came the pay freezes and unpaid furloughs. Then came the higher contributions for health insurance. Now, in the most definitive sign yet that the era of generous compensation for public-sector employees is ending, workers in more than half the states face the prospect of paying more of their salary toward their pensions.

headline: Johnson & Johnson to End Line of Drug-Coated Heart Stents
text: Johnson & Johnson announced on Wednesday that it would stop manufacturing drug-coated heart stents by the end of the year, abandoning an intensely competitive $4 billion market after a series of setbacks for the company and rising concerns about the use of stents in some patients.

headline: ‘Follies’ Is Coming to Broadway This Summer
text: Those unhappily married couples of Stephen Sondheim’s legendary musical “Follies,” who long for their younger, happier days revolving around New York theater, will have another shot at Broadway this summer. The Washington revival of “Follies” at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts will transfer north to the Marquis Theater for a limited run that is expected to begin performances in August, the president of the Kennedy Center said in an interview on Wednesday.

headline: A Laptop, Its Head in the Cloud
text: You can say all kinds of nice things about Google’s Chromebook laptop concept. You can say it’s ahead of its time. Or that it’s thinking way, way outside the box. Or that, as failures go, at least this one swung for the fences.

headline: Southern Baptists Approve Steps Aimed at Diversity
text: With the election of a black pastor to a senior position this week and a new action plan to increase ethnic diversity in its leadership, the Southern Baptist Convention has taken its most concrete steps yet to overcome a history of racial exclusion and to broaden its appeal in a changing American population.

headline: Sony Makes Music Service Available on Android
text: In February, Sony introduced a digital music service called Music Unlimited Powered by Qriocity that allowed users to stream millions of songs to Sony’s home entertainment machines, like Internet-connected televisions, Blu-ray players and the PlayStation3. But it lacked one major feature: mobile access.

headline: I.P.O. Fever Calms Down for Pandora
text: 8:31 p.m. | Updated

headline: Prospect Park Geese Will Be Sent to Food Banks in Pennsylvania
text: City Room reports  that geese being slaughtered this year in Brooklyn’s Prospect Park to protect air traffic will be sent to food banks in Pennsylvania. Geese slaughtered last year were sent to a landfill.

headline: Daniel Sedin Predicts Canucks Victory. Well, Maybe Not
text: The Canucks’ Daniel Sedin pulled off one of the funnier backtrackings in recent Stanley Cup annals. In Tuesday’s Vancouver Sun he was quoted as saying, “We’re going to win Game 7” against the Boston Bruins. But on Wednesday morning he softened that sentiment to a grand extent.

headline: More Winners From the Pandora I.P.O.
text: Pandora Media’s initial public offering generated more than a handful of winners on Tuesday — including the New York Stock Exchange and Morgan Stanley.

headline: Video Targeting California Democrat Is Criticized
text: LOS ANGELES— A YouTube video invoking brutal gang imagery and incendiary language as part of a political attack on Janice Hahn, a Democratic candidate for Congress in a special election here, has come under fire from Republicans and Democrats here, throwing a cloud over an election that has drawn some attention across the country.

headline: TimesCast | June 15, 2011
text: Same-sex marriage stalemate in New York; Pandora opens to high stock expectations; and the columnist Thomas L. Friedman on President Bashar al-Assad's political future in Syria.

headline: Can Pandora Prove Its Worth?
text: Pandora Media, the online music service, made its market debut as investors embraced the latest Internet company to go public. DealBook spoke to Joseph Kennedy, chief executive of the company.

headline: Netflix Helps People Cut Cable Cord, Report Says
text: It has now been a couple of years since I cut my cable and began exclusively watching Internet video on my home television. I still feel that it was one of the wiser decisions I’ve made with technology, saving me hundreds of dollars a year and countless headaches dealing with a cable company.

headline: Can Pandora Prove Its Worth?
text: Pandora Media, the online music service, made its market debut as investors embraced the latest Internet company to go public. DealBook’s Evelyn M. Rusli spoke to Joseph Kennedy, chief executive of the company.

headline: On Bluefin Tuna in Restaurants
text: Over on the Twitter machine, a small electrical storm has been raging over the mention of bluefin tuna in my Wednesday review of the restaurant Masa.

headline: Weak Economic Data Belies British Optimism
text: LONDON — It is the job of the chancellor of the Exchequer to project an air of optimism, no matter how bad the data on the British economy has become. And at a glittering dinner Wednesday night in the city of London, George Osborne did his utmost.

headline: Instrument Makers Take Their Turn at Boston Festival
text: BOSTON — The exhibition, the trade-show part of the Boston Early Music Festival and Exhibition, opened at 10 a.m. on Wednesday, and though not all the booths were fully set up, a full complement of recorder, gamba, lute and violin makers were on hand, as were music publishers, universities and plenty of shoppers making sometimes joyful, sometimes ill-tuned noises trying out the available wares.

headline: Swiss Commodities Trader Expands Into Ethanol in Africa
text: GENEVA — Jean Claude Gandur, a Swiss commodities trader, made a fortune during the 1990s buying oil concessions in Africa that others did not want or could not hold.

headline: New Push on Sustainable Agriculture
text: This week the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations threw its weight behind a new push for sustainable agriculture in developing countries. While declaring that “we have no option but to further intensify crop production” to feed a growing and increasingly affluent world population, the F.A.O. nonetheless urged a broader application of techniques that, while raising yields, have also been shown to reduce inputs of water, energy and fertilizer, compared to more conventional farming approaches.

headline: Just One Look | Rag & Bone Resort
text: There was denim dyed in indigo, pink and green as well as prints galore at Rag & Bone’s resort show. There was also a fabulous tank and skirt that looked like an exact replica of the paint drippings spattered all over the design studio’s floor. (A hallowed space, as it turns out; the artist Matthew Barney once bunked here.) The studio now houses this season’s striped tees, silk dresses (that fasten around the shoulders with utility straps) and fur trimmed parkas. That’s right, for these designers, resort is all about giving their girls what they really need in chilly November New York.

headline: Gay Marriage in New York State
text: Nicholas Confessore, a reporter for The New York Times, on the political debate behind the same-sex marriage legislation that is nearing a vote in New York State.

headline: Nazar Mohammad

headline: Niyaz Mohammad

headline: Torialy, son of Abdul Anan
text: Meet Torialy, a counterterrorism officer with the Afghan National Police who is working with American soldiers to put down the Taliban in northern Afghanistan.

headline: To Be Safe, Politicians Keep Golf at a Distance
text: WASHINGTON — Less than 20 miles from the Capitol’s steps, through the buttoned-down section of the city and down a tree-lined parkway, sits a country club founded 87 years ago to give politicians and businessmen a place to loosen up and schmooze.

headline: Guides for the Casual Movie Buff and Dedicated Cinephile
text: Of the more than 500,000 apps on the major mobile platforms, I’m aware of fewer than 10 with an average user rating of five stars — not counting apps that have been reviewed only by the developer’s closest friends.

headline: Sgt. Brian Keith
text: As Sgt. Brian Keith nears the end of his yearlong deployment to Afghanistan, he reflects on what he is looking forward to at home.

headline: New Rules to Set Field for Chasing Top Oscar

headline: The Presumption Against Suicide
text: Last week, I posed a hypothetical to Kevin Drum, who had written in support of assisted suicide and dismissed the suggestion that it constitutes a kind of murder, asking what he would think if he had a wheelchair-bound friend who was physically healthy but despairing, and a doctor prescribed that friend a lethal dose to put an end to his despair. He responded by taking the hypothetical in a more personal direction:

headline: Smorgasbord of Mythology and Mayhem
text: BOSTON — The theme of this year’s Boston Early Music Festival and Exhibition is “Metamorphoses: Change and Transformation,” and the temptation is to look for changes and transformations within the historically informed performance movement itself.

headline: City Plans $10 Million in Cuts to School Cleaning
text: Already a friendly haven for dried chewing gum and food wrappers, the city’s public schools may soon become even grimier.

headline: Summertime Idyll in the Rockaways
text: Over the last few summers, this sandy and pockmarked peninsula has become an unlikely hangout for young, artsy types who make their home in Brooklyn and Lower Manhattan.

headline: Taking the A Train to Summer
text: WHEN the sun glares down on the city, New Yorkers of means flee for the beach. Matt Kaye, a bar manager and D.J. who lives in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, was such a refugee.

headline: Starting With Perkiness, Then Leaping Beyond It
text: What’s the difference between a Disney princess and a prostitute? Not much if you are Lea Salonga, the Filipino diva who joked last week about having played both types, as she opened her new cabaret show, “New York in June,” at the Café Carlyle.

headline: Just One Look | Giambattista Valli
text: For Giambattista Valli, leopard is a neutral. It’s always been thus. But for resort, his favorite print gets a sophisticated twist when mixed with pattern (like this Aztec looking weave) and jewel tones (like lime, fuschia and purple). The maestro does interesting things with photographed macramé, and his short, empire-waisted coats with cocoon sleeves are divine relics of the sixties.

headline: In Glasgow, an Architectural Gem in the West End
text: A six-bedroom Victorian town house in the West End of Glasgow is on the market for $1.4 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... Glasgow, Scotland
text: A six-bedroom Victorian town house in the West End of Glasgow

headline: A Benefit Bares It All
text: THE host committee included names like Courtney Love and Heidi Klum, the honorees were James Franco and Michael Kors, and the headline act was Liza Minnelli. So why was it that the good people behind an amfAR benefit at the Museum of Modern Art on Tuesday night still felt the need to spice up their party with a bunch of freshly depilated hunks wearing only boxer briefs?

headline: Scene City: The AmfAR Benefit
text: The benefit was filled with a celebrity cast, and many, many near-naked male models.

headline: From the Venice Cup Trials, Subterfuge and a Big Swing
text: The 96-board match that chose the U.S.A.-1 Venice Cup world championship team last week in Detroit was won by Sylvia Moss, Judi Radin and Migry Zur Campanile of New York and JoAnna Stansby of Dublin, Calif. They combined well for a game swing on the diagramed deal, Board 74.

headline: Women Rule a Marathon of New One-Act Plays
text: Intriguing women populate Series B of the Ensemble Studio Theater’s 2011 one-act play marathon. Their backgrounds may be diverse, but the shared depth and detail of their personal histories makes their stories spill beyond the frames of the short works in which they appear.

headline: Just One Look | Alexander Wang Resort
text: Alexander Wang is today’s sports authority. With the debut of his first swimwear collection – eight athletic cutout and scuba style suits – his resort line focuses on swimming, cycling and running. Super roomy jackets were inspired by cycling uniforms. There were hints of basketball in the intarsia-knit jersey-style tops, and the perforated pants were all about the track. And speaking of running, it’s worth hoofing downtown for those red, blue and yellow colored kicks.

headline: Hitsville U.S.A.: Detroit Rolls in Without Cars
text: For baby boomers there’s no more surefire party starter than Motown songs. That made “Motown Meets NYC” an easy concept for Summerstage’s annual fund-raising gala. Rain on Tuesday night moved the concert indoors, from Central Park to Roseland, where the New York Pops orchestra backed 1960s Motown stalwarts — Martha Reeves, minus the Vandellas, and Dennis Edwards from the Temptations — and other singers for songs from the Motown canon and beyond.

headline: Homes for $590,000
text: A duplex condo in downtown Atlanta; a 1932 house in Fort Worth, and an brick 1872 farmhouse in Chanhassen, Minn.

headline: A Danish Modern Twist Updates Classical Ballet
text: See Naples and then die? In the passage of his memoirs that describes his visit to Naples and his subsequent composition of his three-act ballet “Napoli” (1842), the Danish choreographer August Bournonville quotes the old motto. Since the highlight of “Napoli” is the stream of uninterrupted dancing in its third act, this is often performed by itself and is the exuberant conclusion of the quadruple bill with which the Royal Danish Ballet opens its weeklong engagement at the David H. Koch Theater. Unfortunately the three ballets that precede it are each in different ways so depressing that the evening seems to say “Die, die, die, and then see ‘Napoli.’ ”

headline: What You Get for ... $590,000
text: ATLANTA

headline: Faces on Film Add Humanity to the News
text: If there is one hard lesson we’ve learned since 9/11, it is the degree to which fear lurking just below the placid surface of everyday existence can poison the social climate. Fear of terrorism, fear of disease, fear of the Other, of the Unknown, is easy to instill and hard to dislodge. Instead of surrendering blindly to paranoia, one way of combating it is to confront the very things that scare us the most.

headline: Giffords Is Released From the Hospital
text: TUCSON, Ariz. — More than five months after being shot point-blank in the head, Representative Gabrielle Giffords was released Wednesday from a Houston rehabilitation hospital where she had been relearning how to walk and talk, hospital officials said.

headline: For Starters
text: Think graphics, think floral. Just don’t think too hard.

headline: Restaurant Shirts Gain Admission
text: THOUGH Robert Graham shirts are sold nationally in hundreds of stores, the label does not yet engender the kind of instant recognition that makes marketing people salivate.

headline: Thousands Protest Austerity Measures
text: Thousands joined a nationwide strike in Greece as Parliament prepared to debate a second round of sharp cuts to government spending.

headline: Even in Custody, Bahrain Activists Use Twitter to Protest
text: Three women who were arrested in Bahrain on Wednesday as they tried to stage a sit-in at a United Nations office turned to Twitter to explain and document their protest, continuing to file updates even after they were taken into custody.

headline: The Tom and Jerry Problem
text: If the 2012 election were held in the newsrooms of America and pitted Sarah Palin against Barack Obama, I doubt Palin would get 10 percent of the vote. However tempting the newsworthy havoc of a Palin presidency, I’m pretty sure most journalists would recoil in horror from the idea.

headline: Dracula Lurks in Your Set-Top Box
text: Imagine pulling into your parking space and just hopping out, leaving the car idling all day while you’re at the office.

headline: White House Report on U.S. Actions in Libya

headline: A Lifetime of Roles, Sometimes Two at a Time
text: PERFORMING two of Shakespeare’s “problem plays” in repertory during the wilting summer nights, contending all the while with low-flying helicopters and errant raccoons, can be challenging.

headline: Stage Scenes: John Cullum
text: Photos of some of the actor’s past performances.

headline: Newly Released Books
text: The ties in this month’s new books — between sisters, first loves and family members, real and improvised — don’t break. In some cases, however, the characters might have liked a little more give.

headline: Everything You Ever Wanted to Know About Immokalee, Fla.
text: Fifty years after Edward R. Murrow concluded his tenure at CBS with “Harvest of Shame,” an arresting expose of migrant field workers in rural Florida, CBS News correspondent Byron Pitts returned to Florida’s tomato, bean and sugarcane fields for an update. In Harvest of Shame: 50 Years Later, Mr. Pitts found that, while wages have improved, the work — when it could be found — is just as backbreaking as it was in 1960. Juan Lopez, a 62-year-old tomato picker in Immokalee, said he gets up before dawn hoping to find work; in 2009 he said he earned “$7,800 for a full year of work.”

headline: In Sydney, Finding Room to Grow
text: A couple combined their building with an adjacent one to create a modern spin on the Victorian-era town house.

headline: Their Space Solution Is Found Next Door
text: SYDNEY, Australia

headline: Summer Fashions
text: Looks for $100 or less.

headline: Easy Summer Looks With Prices to Match
text: JACQUELYN ORTIZ scours her favorite cheap-and-chic fashion outposts once or twice a week to stock up on a season’s worth of flowing dresses, tank tops, sandals and tees. “In the summertime I do a lot more shopping,” said Ms. Ortiz, who works at an advertising agency in New York.

headline: Talking Heady
text: David Carr, who wrote the magazine’s profile of Keith Olbermann, doesn’t just report stories. Sometimes he’s the one the camera is trained on.  As The Daily Beast, Underwire and Slate report — yes, sometimes new media do speak the truth — Carr is the “breakout star” of Andrew Rossi’s new documentary, “Page One: A Year Inside the New York Times.” Asked about his role in the film, Carr told The Daily Beast: “My daughter, when she saw [the film], she said, ‘You look like a thug.” . . . I don’t like how mean I am in the movie.”

headline: Hacking Group Says It Brought Down C.I.A. Site
text: 7:05 p.m. | Updated  Adding background on denial of service attacks, update on availability of C.I.A. site.

headline: A Tool to Help Secure Your Browser
text: Web browsers are top targets for hackers. They’re abused in more than 90 percent of attacks meant to hit random Internet users (versus more targeted strikes), according to Kaspersky Labs. And more than half of those attacks exploit flaws in browser software and seek to install dangerous malware on computers.

headline: Royal Danish Ballet at the Koch Theater
text: Royal Danish Ballet is performing a weeklong engagement at the David H. Koch Theater.

headline: This Time, Rangers’ Wilson Doesn’t Mind Short Porch
text: Four Texas pitchers were taking batting practice around 2:30 p.m. Wednesday, but only one of them was taking his left-handed hacks in a Dirk Nowitzki T-shirt: C.J. Wilson. The free spirit of the bunch, Wilson deposited a few balls into the second deck in right field – which, as he playfully mentioned to a reporter, is different from the upper deck.

headline: Just One Look | Gucci Resort
text: In a well executed version of Gucci minimalism, Frida Giannini relied on gold to add a lustrous note to simple basics, like this shining pleated skirt. The collection was up to the minute in current trends, from color blocking (red, white and purple sheath dresses) to funky pattern-on-pattern suits. Other standouts: her python skirt, lamé top and a black jumper with a medallion broach on the shoulder, all accented in gold, what else?

headline: Finding Frames That Fit
text: The Times's Simone Oliver and Stephanie Rosenbloom get refreshing tips for selecting sunglasses.

headline: Shopping for Alarm Clocks With Jonas Damon
text: The New York industrial designer shopped for interesting alarm clocks.

headline: Jean Prouvé’s Designs Reinterpreted
text: Many design purists consider Jean Prouvé one of the most important designers of the 20th century. The idea, then, that anyone would think to alter his classic furnishings amounts to sacrilege. Yet that’s exactly what the Dutch clothing company G-Star Raw has done, with the blessing of Prouvé’s manufacturer, Vitra.

headline: Pop! Goes the Chandelier
text: The designer Lindsey Adelman is best known for her bubbles, the hand-blown spherical glass shades she uses to build a wide range of light fixtures.

headline: Sales at Frette, ABC Carpet & Home, Canvas and Safavieh
text: Upholstered chairs, sofas and sectionals are up to 44 percent off at the Safavieh Home Furnishings seating sale, through July 5 (the Chester sofa, originally about $5,600, is $3,134; the Easton chair, regularly $1,065, is about $600; the Tufted sofa, originally $5,725, is $3,206); 902 Broadway (20th Street); (877) 919-1010 or safaviehhome.com.

headline: Take an Old Master to Your Next Picnic
text: This summer, you might be surprised by the faces staring back from the picnic blanket.

headline: Traditional Meets Quirky in a Campana Brothers Cafe
text: The cafe at the century-old Municipal Theater of São Paulo reopened to the public this week, with furnishings by the Brazilian designers Humberto and Fernando Campana, as part of a two-year-long renovation of the entire theater.

headline: Todd Oldham
text: Todd Oldham has been many things in his 49 years: fashion designer, television personality, interior designer, product designer, film director, photographer and writer, just to name a few. “I’ve had the greatest privilege of having a lot of adventures,” he said. “But I’ve been moving away from doing things where success is hinged on my face being stuck on things. It’s a happy transition.”

headline: Lost in Time and Words, a Child Begins Anew
text: TO this day it is hard for me to speak about possessing any real sense of a home, at least during my childhood and adolescence. Or, to put this idea more precisely: whatever sense of a secure home life, of belonging, that I once felt as a boy was whisked out from under my feet at a tender age.

headline: Alarm Clocks
text: FOR more than a decade, the New York industrial designer Jonas Damon has been giving some serious thought to alarm clocks.

headline: Bringing in the Big Fans
text: SOMEWHERE in modern America, there are people who do not like air-conditioning. But they are awfully hard to find. After studying home energy use for decades as the principal research scientist at the Florida Solar Energy Center, Danny Parker puts the number of air-conditioning heretics at “1 to 2 percent of the population.”

headline: A Father, a Daughter, a Collaborative Garden
text: The garden behind John Fry’s house in Westchester is inhabited by a dozen or more creatures created by his daughter, Leslie Fry, a sculptor.

headline: Sowing Enchantment
text: KATONAH, N.Y.

headline: A Murder in Diepsloot
text: As horrified and shaken as I am by Barry Bearak’s article “Watching the Murder of an Innocent Man,” I am also grateful for it. We are too often inured to what we do not ourselves confront, and we need to be shaken from our complacency. Some of the comments take the familiar tack of dehumanizing the “other,” of casting the murder of this man as an act committed by “savages.” Well, as others have noted, we all have the potential to be savages, all of us.

headline: The Hunt for the Right Shades
text: I thought about buying a pair of round sunglasses this summer. I pictured myself wearing sphere-shaped tortoiseshell shades with bright red lipstick for the entire summer, until I changed my look again for fall. But something has held me back from running to the nearest optical boutique with debit card in hand. Fear, rooted in vanity, had me questioning whether round frames are the look for me.

headline: First
text: In “Let Me Take Off My Tinfoil Hat for a Moment,” Bill Keller muses on conspiracy theories and discusses “why otherwise smart people fall for crackpot conspiracy theories.” I read the article to see if Keller would include in his examples how in reporting the events leading to the Iraq war, “otherwise smart people” at The Times fell for the malicious crackpot conspiracy theory of the Bush-Cheney administration that Iraq possessed weapons of mass destruction that threatened the United States. But alas, no. Millions of people here and abroad, though, saw through this particularly wacky notion, the consequences of which, in deaths, displacements and destruction, are far worse than the consequences of some poor guy believing he has the key to the J.F.K. assassination.

headline: Piercing Cats Is Cruelty, Judges Rule
text: Piercing kittens to give them a “goth” appearance is cruel, a panel of Pennsylvania judges has ruled.

headline: Restoring Life to Mountain Retreat Where Mao Napped
text: MOGANSHAN, China — The first to build and occupy European-style stone villas atop this bamboo-cloaked mountain were the foreign missionaries. Then came Big-Ear Du and other Shanghai gangsters looking for a getaway (or maybe hideaway). Later still, the big guns rolled in: Chiang Kai-shek and Mao Zedong.

text: New York racing officials suspended jockey Rajiv Maragh for seven days on Wednesday for careless riding in the Belmont Stakes, saying he compromised the Kentucky Derby winner Animal Kingdom’s chance to win the third leg of the Triple Crown.

headline: Atlanta’s Wet Infield Has the Mets’ Attention
text: ATLANTA — In response to a request by the Mets, the umpiring crew for Wednesday night’s game at Turner Field was notified by Major League Baseball to keep an eye on the condition of the infield, which was so boggy and wet Tuesday night that Jose Reyes slipped three times on it and fell twice.

headline: In France, Sauciness Extends Well Beyond Food
text: One thing has to be made clear right from the start: To the French, seduction is about compliments, smiles and mutual pleasure, not locking someone in a hotel room and trying to force her to have oral sex.

headline: Bruins Win the Stanley Cup
text: The Cup is coming back to Boston.

headline: Social Media Help Keep the Door Open to Sustained Dissent Inside Saudi Arabia
text: AL KHOBAR, Saudi Arabia — When Manal al-Sharif posted a video of herself breaking the law by driving her own black S.U.V. around this hot, flat city and called for a collective protest on Friday, the government responded harshly: she was jailed for nine days.

headline: Inside the Timothy Leary Archives
text: Selections from Leary’s papers, which have been acquired by the New York Public Library.

headline: Judge Is Asked to Throw Out Bonds’s Obstruction Conviction or to Retry the Case
text: The lawyers for Barry Bonds have asked a federal judge to throw out Bonds’s obstruction of justice conviction or to retry that charge, arguing that Bonds was unjustly convicted of “unauthorized rambling” during his grand jury testimony in 2003.

headline: Swisher Finds Himself in Strange Spot
text: With Derek Jeter on the disabled list with a strained right calf, Joe Girardi has been forced to shuffle the Yankees’ lineup. He moved Nick Swisher to the leadoff spot Wednesday night for the first time since 2008, when he played for the Chicago White Sox.

headline: After the Scandal, More of the Same at the I.M.F.
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Exit Near, Gates Speaks Bluntly of U.S. Allies
text: WASHINGTON—Robert M. Gates has 15 days left as secretary of defense — just ask him — and has become ever more unleashed from the constraints of the job.

headline: Around Tornado Deaths, a Nagging Tale of Shelter Denied
text: CORDOVA, Ala. — Everybody in town heard about it.

headline: In Berlin, Moved by Music, Place and Memory
text: “Our view of reality is conditioned by our position in space and time — not by our personalities as we like to think. Thus every interpretation of reality is based upon a unique position. Two paces east or west and the whole picture is changed.” — Lawrence Durrell, “Balthazaar”

headline: Activists by Invitation
text: No one loves an activist judge. We know this because members of the Senate Judiciary Committee are forever denouncing “judicial activism” and warning of its hidden dangers. Last summer, when Sen. Orrin Hatch, Republican of Utah, became the first member of the committee to oppose Elena Kagan’s Supreme Court nomination, he explained that the nominee had “endorsed, and praised those who endorse, an activist judicial philosophy.”

headline: News Office in Jordan Is Damaged in an Attack
text: JERUSALEM — The offices of the French news agency in the Jordanian capital, Amman, were attacked on Wednesday by about 10 men who broke windows and destroyed furniture, a day after several hundred people demonstrated against the bureau, accusing it of harming the kingdom through its dispatches.

headline: Our Lefty Military
text: As we search for paths out of America’s economic crisis, many suggest business as a paradigm for cutting costs. According to my back-of-the-envelope math, top C.E.O.’s earn as much as $1 a second around the clock, partly by cutting medical benefits for employees. So they must be paragons of efficiency, right?

headline: California Lawmakers Close Budget Gap
text: LOS ANGELES — The Democratic-controlled Legislature passed a stopgap state budget on Wednesday to close California’s $10 billion deficit.

headline: A Case for Reform at Japan Tobacco
text: The Children’s Investment Fund was humiliated when it brandished the sword of shareholder activism at Japan’s corporate shogunates in 2008. Now the London hedge fund is back with what appears to be an even more foolhardy campaign — to prod the Japanese finance minister to shake up Japan Tobacco. But this time around the embattled government may have enough to gain to push for corporate reform.

headline: Watching the Detectives
text: Los Angeles

headline: Children on Medicaid Shown to Wait Longer for Care
text: Children with Medicaid are far more likely than those with private insurance to be turned away by medical specialists or be made to wait more than a month for an appointment, even for serious medical problems, a new study finds.

headline: Ahmadinejad’s Fall, America’s Loss
text: Washington

headline: Still Writing, Regulators Delay Rules
text: Regulators overseeing financial reform are delaying many of the planned changes in the immense market for complex securities known as derivatives because they are running drastically behind schedule in writing their new rules.

headline: The Smokies Light Show
text: Thousands of tourists are drawn every year to the Great Smoky Mountains National Park to witness the mating ritual of a species of fireflies that blink in beautiful synchrony.

headline: Plane Crashes Into Hudson River
text: A US Airways plane that took off from La Guardia Airport landed in the Hudson River, but all the passengers and crew appeared to be safe.

headline: Czechs, Disliking Role, Pull Out of U.S. Missile Defense Project
text: BERLIN — The Czech Republic announced Wednesday that it was withdrawing from plans to participate in the United States missile defense program out of frustration at its diminished role in the system, which was conceived as a deterrent against a potential threat from Iran.

headline: Fireflies, Following Their Leader, Become a Tourist Beacon
text: ELKMONT, Tenn. — Lynn Faust remembers the old days of firefly season here.

headline: Nice Work if You Can Get It
text: New York’s legislators plan to go home for the rest of the year on Monday, even though they have not finished what the public pays them to do. If they were students, they would earn F’s for diligence. Here are crucial measures still on the Legislature’s to-do list:

headline: Stoudemire Offers Wisdom to James
text: Amar’e Stoudemire gave LeBron James some public relations advice on Wednesday.

headline: Blue, Gray and Everything in Between
text: While the colors blue and gray are almost iconically associated with the opposing ground forces of the Civil War, early in the conflict many regiments reporting for duty on either side were much more colorfully attired. Some rebel troops wore blue, some northern troops wore gray, units on both sides sported every shade of red, green, black, white or even tartan, and uniform patterns were almost completely non-standardized.

headline: After Delay, Iranians Launch a Satellite
text: Iran said it launched a satellite into orbit on Wednesday that Western aerospace experts said could be used for limited military reconnaissance and also to monitor crops and track damage from earthquakes, flooding and other natural disasters.

headline: Scientists See More Deadly Weather, but Dispute the Cause
text: WASHINGTON — The United States experienced some of the most extreme weather events in its history this spring, including deadly outbreaks of tornadoes, near-record flooding, drought and wildfires.

headline: Tigers’ Ace Is Also a Drawing Card
text: DETROIT — In the sixth full season of his major league career, Justin Verlander is the Detroit Tigers’ biggest drawing card, providing a reason for fans to climb into their cars and drive hundreds of miles from across the state and other parts of the Midwest to watch him on the mound.

headline: Can Justice Be Bought?
text: Two years ago, the Supreme Court tried to bolster public trust in the nation’s justice system by disqualifying a state judge in West Virginia from a case that involved a coal company executive who had spent more than $3 million to help get the judge elected.

headline: A Place to Laugh, Cry, Hide, Complain ... and Verify a Scorecard
text: BETHESDA, Md. — It is called the scoring tent, and there may be no other space like it in sports. Although it occasionally is a hut, trailer or clubhouse room instead, the scoring tent is always the way station just steps from the 18th green where all golfers report directly after a round at the United States Open or other golf championship.

headline: Cuomo Gives Lawmakers Ultimatum on Rent Laws
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Wednesday that he would not let lawmakers leave the capital at the scheduled end of the legislative session early next week unless they had come to an agreement on how to extend the state’s rent regulation laws.

headline: Unaffordable Roaming
text: In a plugged-in, hyperglobalized world, one might expect that our communications networks would allow us to roam widely, cellphones and tablets connected to the matrix, no matter the location. But when it comes to telecommunications pricing, globalization stopped at the border.

headline: When Sporting Cultures Collide
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia

headline: Untold Stories of How Everyone Got Here
text: Border-guarding Minutemen and immigrant-pummeling politicians should get a grip on this country’s history at the Ellis Island Immigration Museum in New York Harbor. Exhibits are planned to tell the full story of the teeming masses, including African slaves, displaced Indians, modern globetrotters and Know-Nothing nativists.

headline: Labor Talks Offer Signs of Optimism for the N.F.L.
text: Earlier this month, as the prospect of a shortened N.F.L. season loomed, so did the pessimism about the state of labor negotiations as owners and players awaited a critical court ruling in their fight over how to divide billions of dollars.

headline: Bloggingheads: Debt Ceiling Showdown
text: Daniel Drezner, left, of ForeignPolicy.com and Megan McArdle of The Atlantic discuss the fight over raising the debt ceiling.

headline: Concern for Money, Not Safety, Was Behind Deutsche Fire, Prosecutor Says
text: The deaths in 2007 of two firefighters during a blaze at the former Deutsche Bank building in Lower Manhattan were caused by the actions of contractors working inside the building, a prosecutor repeatedly told jurors on Wednesday.

headline: Nuclear Plant Safety Rules Inadequate, Group Says
text: ROCKVILLE, Md. — Nuclear safety rules in the United States do not adequately weigh the risk that a single event would knock out electricity from both the grid and from emergency generators, as an earthquake and tsunami recently did at a nuclear plant in Japan, officials of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Wednesday.

headline: Nuclear Plant, Left for Dead, Shows a Pulse
text: HOLLYWOOD, Ala. — Spider webs line the 50-story cooling towers, parts have been amputated for the scrap value of their nickel or copper, and the control room still has analog dials at Bellefonte 1, a half-built nuclear plant here that was shelved 23 years ago.

headline: In a Harlem Basement, Beneath the Stars
text: After our Tonys romp, where we spent Sunday night nestled on a staircase with Joel Grey, in a phenomenally expensive hotel suite with a Bono and a Broderick — the air scented with scads of Diptyque candles so costly we estimate that each intake of our breath was worth at least $7, we have a confession: Nocturnalist was on a bit of a high.

headline: Human Rights Watch Film Festival
text: Images of some of the films appearing in the festival, which runs June 16-30.

headline: Where Others Have Gone Without Success, J.C. Penney Goes Again
text: Trying to redefine itself, Sears Holdings introduced a flurry of concepts when its new chairman, Edward S. Lampert, took over.

headline: Ex-Spy Alleges Bush White House Sought to Discredit Critic
text: WASHINGTON — A former senior C.I.A. official says that officials in the Bush White House sought damaging personal information on a prominent American critic of the Iraq war in order to discredit him.

headline: Learning to Navigate in the City’s Rough Waters
text: Kevin J. Walsh is three years into the 12-year training program — five years as an apprentice and seven as a deputy pilot — required of a full branch pilot, licensed by the state and federal government to board vessels offshore and navigate them into port through the devilish traffic and currents of New York Harbor. In essence, a pilot takes over for the captain of the ship, whether it’s a vacation cruise liner or a tanker with hazardous cargo. Mr. Walsh, 28, a 2005 graduate of the United States Merchant Marine Academy in Kings Point, N.Y., is one of 14 apprentices with Sandy Hook Pilots on Staten Island. He lives in Point Pleasant, N.J., with his wife, Jacquline, a hairstylist, and their 19-month-old daughter, Willa.

headline: For Police in the Bronx, a Ticket-Fixing Investigation Stirs Up Fear and Anger
text: A new policy intended to combat ticket-fixing in the Bronx requires that police officers hand their summonses to desk sergeants. But some officers are apparently taking the requirement a step further: they wait to watch the sergeant electronically scan those tickets, and even resist orders to return to patrol until they have seen the entire transaction.

headline: Labor Coalition Is Divided Over Financial Rescue Plan
text: Members of New York City’s powerful municipal labor coalition met on Wednesday to discuss a financial rescue package that could prevent thousands of teachers from losing their jobs.

headline: Thursday: Let Off Some Steam
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Earlier this week, we saw the debut of a young new constructor named Alex Vratsanos, who graduated from high school on the same day his puzzle was published. Today, just to make us all feel even older, we get to do a puzzle by someone who has mastered the art of crossword construction, but cannot drive himself to the store to pick up the newspaper in which it appears.

headline: Drug Is Harder to Abuse, but Users Persevere
text: BROCKTON, Mass. — Michael Capece had been snorting OxyContin for five years when a new version of the drug, intended to deter such abuse, hit the market last summer. The reformulated pills are harder to crush, turning instead into a gummy substance that cannot be easily snorted, injected or chewed.

headline: Top Agency Officials Knew of Disputed Gun Program
text: WASHINGTON — Knowledge of Operation Fast and Furious, a controversial border security strategy that allowed guns to be shipped illegally into Mexico in an effort to track them to drug cartels, went to the top of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, according to evidence released on Wednesday at a House Oversight Committee hearing.

headline: At Congressional, a Few Players Dare to Talk About Fun
text: BETHESDA, Md. — Four competitors rocking out on the eve of the 111th United States Open in a new music video may, or may not, rival the impact of the Chicago Bears’ “Super Bowl Shuffle” from Super Bowl XX, but the slickly produced spoof has lightened the atmosphere of a traditionally staid week.

headline: In Case You Missed It, the 2014 World Cup Just Started
text: Less than a year after Spain lifted the World Cup trophy in South Africa, and nearly three years to the day before the next one begins in Brazil, the 2014 tournament quietly began on Wednesday with the first qualifier.

headline: Rep. Giffords Released From Houston Rehabilitation Center
text: TUCSON — More than five months after being shot point blank in the head, Representative Gabrielle Giffords was released Wednesday from a Houston rehabilitation hospital where she had been relearning how to walk and talk, hospital officials said.

headline: Journeyman’s Long Trail Takes Him to Bronx
text: In need of a starting pitcher on Thursday afternoon, the Yankees will turn to a former outfielder with 3,810 at-bats over a 15-year minor league career and only four innings of work pitching in the majors, all in 2008.

headline: Pakistan’s Chief of Army Fights to Keep His Job
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s army chief, the most powerful man in the country, is fighting to save his position in the face of seething anger from top generals and junior officers since the American raid that killed Osama bin Laden, according to Pakistani officials and people who have met the chief in recent weeks.

headline: American Retailers Try Again in Europe
text: PARIS — On a recent Sunday afternoon, the Champs-Élysées was packed with people enjoying this city’s most famous boulevard — window shopping, sipping wine at sidewalk cafes and strolling toward the river with ice cream cones.

headline: At Empire State Building, a Feud Over a Virtual Tour of New York
text: It is pretty much compulsory on any tourist’s to-do list. You ascend to the 86th-floor Observatory of the Empire State Building and soak in the big city in all its dizzying splendor, and probably get dizzy yourself.

headline: Coughlin Takes In a Ballgame
text: Giants Coach Tom Coughlin said the N.F.L. lockout had left him feeling disoriented because of the absence of practices and routine preparations typically associated with the run-up to the season. But he got close to players on Wednesday night.

headline: Separate Bills Focus on Two Pieces of Immigration Puzzle
text: WASHINGTON — For many lawmakers in Congress, the immigration issue has become too hot to touch, especially with presidential campaigns starting up and voters, burdened with persistent unemployment, in a volatile mood. But competing bills introduced this week, one by Republicans and another by Democrats, show small but consequential steps on immigration that leaders on both sides think they might accomplish in coming months, before electoral politics overwhelm the debate.

headline: Wisconsin: Law Curbing Unions Is Back in Court
text: Several unions filed a federal lawsuit on Wednesday to block a law that limits collective bargaining rights for public workers in the state. A day earlier, the Wisconsin Supreme Court reinstated the law, overruling a lower court’s decision to halt it because it had been passed improperly. The unions, which represent teachers and state and city workers, say provisions of the law violate the Constitution by singling out only some public workers and not others.

headline: Massachusetts: Ex-Speaker Guilty of Taking Kickbacks
text: The former speaker of the State House was convicted Wednesday of conspiracy, extortion and fraud for helping award a lucrative state contract to a software company in exchange for kickbacks. The former speaker, Salvatore F. DiMasi, 65, of Boston, was convicted on seven of nine counts and faces up to 20 years in prison. Prosecutors said that Mr. DiMasi lobbied Gov. Deval Patrick and other state officials to steer $17.5 million in contracts toward the company, Cognos. Mr. DiMasi received $65,000 over two years and worked with two co-conspirators, the authorities said. Sentencing is scheduled for Aug. 18.

headline: Supporter of Leak Suspect Is Called Before Grand Jury
text: A supporter of Pfc. Bradley E. Manning, who is accused of leaking hundreds of thousands of documents to WikiLeaks, was called before a federal grand jury in Alexandria, Va., on Wednesday, but he said he declined to answer any questions. The supporter, David M. House, a freelance computer scientist, said he invoked his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination, because he believes the Justice Department is “creating a climate of fear around WikiLeaks and the Bradley Manning support network.” The grand jury inquiry is separate from the military prosecution of Private Manning and is believed to be exploring whether the WikiLeaks founder, Julian Assange, or others in the group violated the law by acquiring and publishing military and State Department documents.

headline: Kathryn T. Windham, a Storyteller of the South, Dies at 93
text: Kathryn Tucker Windham, who wove a tapestry of Southern folklore, bucolic scenes, reminiscences, cherished recipes and ghost stories through books and commentaries on public radio, died Sunday at her home in Selma, Ala. She was 93.

headline: Yanks Roll, Proudest of a Run That Didn’t Score
text: There is no way of knowing how the remainder of the sixth inning — and Wednesday’s game — would have unfolded if the throw home from Curtis Granderson had taken an unfriendly bounce, or if Francisco Cervelli had not swung out his left leg to block the plate, protecting it like a moat.

headline: The Art of the Mannequin
text: With retailers scrambling for an edge, the generic mannequin is being pushed aside by alternatives that entice shoppers with striking sculptural details and lifelike bodies.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Stores Demand Mannequins With Personality (Heads Optional)
text: “One size fits all” no longer applies to mannequins.

headline: NYT: Front Page for 06/16/2011
text: NYT: Front Page for 06/16/2011

headline: G.O.P. Senators Are Stalled in Talks on Marriage Bill
text: ALBANY — Anguished Senate Republicans held a four-hour meeting on Wednesday at which they were unable to decide even whether they would bring same-sex marriage to a vote, stalling a last-minute drive by supporters of the legislation.

headline: Battle for Libya | June 15, 2011
text: Libyan rebels gathered for a ceremony in honor of air force officers killed during the fight against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in Benghazi.

headline: Alan Haberman, Who Ushered In the Bar Code, Dies at 81
text: On a summer morning in 1974, a man in Ohio bought a package of chewing gum and the whole world changed.
