text: NATIONAL

headline: Woolite Commercial
text: The commercial that is the centerpiece of Woolite's campaign, making its debut on Thursday on the brand’s Facebook page, was directed by Rob Zombie.

headline: Laundry Soaps Try a Hint of Horror and Some Tough-Guy Talk
text: A LOW-INTEREST category in consumer marketing is getting interesting.

headline: Boston Wins Game 7 on Road for First Cup Since ’72
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — For nearly four decades, the Boston Bruins fought a losing battle with futility and sorrow. Five times they had reached the Stanley Cup finals and had not raised the silver chalice in triumph. On Wednesday night, after 39 years, the Bruins became N.H.L. champions.

headline: Setbacks for Samsonite and Prada I.P.O.’s in Hong Kong
text: HONG KONG — Two of the most prominent initial public offerings in Asia this year were dealt setbacks on Thursday, as renewed worries about the debt crisis in Greece and the waning growth momentum in China sent stocks sharply lower.

headline: A Billionaire’s Eye for Art Shapes Her Singular Museum
text: BENTONVILLE, Ark. — The era of the world-class museum built by a single philanthropist in the tradition of Isabella Stewart Gardner, John Pierpont Morgan Jr. and Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney may seem to have passed, but Alice L. Walton is bringing it back.

headline: Mapping Sun’s Potential to Power New York
text: Two-thirds of New York City’s rooftops are suitable for solar panels and could jointly generate enough energy to meet half the city’s demand for electricity at peak periods, according to a new, highly detailed interactive map to be made public on Thursday.

headline: ‘Orfeo ed Euridice’
text: Photos from the Metropolitan Opera’s revival of the Mark Morris production.

text: acuity •\ə-ˈkyü-ə-te, a-\• noun

headline: Dioxin Traces Found Near U.S. Base in South Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Trace amounts of dioxin have been found in water samples taken near an American Army base in South Korea, according to a joint investigation into possible chemical dumping that analysts said could have repercussions for the alliance between South Korea and the United States.

headline: Global Agenda_Tantawy
text: Tantawy

headline: Trouble in Vancouver’s Streets After Defeat
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — In one of the worst episodes of rioting Canada has seen in decades, hockey fans angry over losing the Stanley Cup clashed with police officers, set vehicles ablaze, smashed windows and looted and burned stores throughout the downtown area here on Wednesday night.

headline: Citi Says Many More Customers Had Data Stolen by Hackers
text: The Citigroup credit card data breach exposed the private financial data of more than 360,000 customer accounts, about 80 percent more than it reported last week, according to a statement the bank released late Wednesday night.

headline: Pena Provides Yankees With Unexpected Power
text: Exactly 166 at-bats after he hit his first career home run, Ramiro Pena hit his second homer Wednesday night in the Yankees’ 12-4 demolition of the Texas Rangers at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Mets Thriving in Waterlogged Atlanta
text: ATLANTA — For the second game in a row, water was the issue at Turner Field. On Tuesday night, there was too much of it on the infield dirt, and on Wednesday night, there was too much falling from the sky to enable the rookie Dillon Gee to gain a victory that he seemed destined to earn.

headline: Test Yourself | English, June 16, 2011
text: Test your editing skills with today’s question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues, from the article “Texas Still Has Its Rustlers, and Men in White Hats Chasing Them.”

headline: Indonesia Sentences a Radical Cleric to 15 Years
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — A leading radical Islamic cleric the United States had pressed Indonesia to prosecute for the past decade was convicted Thursday after a four-month trial on terrorism charges. The cleric, Abu Bakar Bashir, 72, was sentenced to 15 years in prison for supporting a jihad training camp.

headline: I.E.A. Says World Will Increasingly Turn to Americas for Oil
text: HOUSTON — Over the next few years, world consumers are going to become more dependent on North and South America to satisfy their growing thirst for crude oil, according to a forecast to be released Thursday by the International Energy Agency.

headline: News Quiz | June 16, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: New Rules for Sunscreens
text: WHO is “thrilled” about the Food and Drug Administration’s new rules for sunscreens?

headline: Modern Agonies in Ancient Mexican Villages
text: Journalists from the United States often stop at the Mexican border when they’re covering immigration issues, almost as if the crisis starts and stops on this side.

headline: Do You Have Too Much Homework?
text: Some schools and school districts are taking a hard look at how much homework is assigned and how valuable it is for student learning. How much homework do you have, on average, each night? Is it a burden for you? Does it mostly help you learn the material and skills you are being taught? Does some of it seem like “busy work”?

text: In Today’s Times:

headline: Prague Festival Promises Classical and Jazz
text: Prague Proms, a monthlong tribute to jazz and classical music – with a splash of Hollywood — officially kicks off the summer festival season on June 21.

headline: Q&A: Choosing Your Own Priorities in Gmail
text: Q.

headline: Qaeda Selection of Its Chief Is Said to Reflect Its Flaws
text: WASHINGTON — American counterterrorism officials all but welcomed the announcement on Thursday that Ayman al-Zawahri would succeed Osama bin Laden as leader of Al Qaeda, arguing that his deep flaws are likely to weaken the core of the terrorist network.

headline: Uncertainty Over Greece Weighs on Markets
text: Financial markets remained unsettled on Thursday amid concerns about political stability in Greece and the fate of a second Greek bailout, sending investors into less risky assets.

headline: Five Things I Wish I Had Known Before the Fire
text: The question I now hear most often is: Do you have insurance? More experienced folks ask: Do you have business-interruption insurance? That is, recoupment of operating expenditures or lost revenues, maybe even payroll during this unplanned hiatus. The answer is that I am not quite sure; nothing about insurance is sure — not the amount or the timing or the results of investigations or who is suing whom. Every claim is contested; every cost is subrogated. You never know how good your insurance is until you try to cash in your chips.

headline: Alibaba Group to Split Up E-Commerce Site
text: 9:10 p.m. | Updated

headline: Pawlenty Bets That His Debate Performance Fades
text: Tim Pawlenty‘s performance in Monday night’s debate was roundly panned after the former Minnesota governor appeared overly reluctant to press earlier attacks against his Republican rival, Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts.

headline: A Stork Rises From Its Ashes
text: They were all back again, back at the Stork Club, the legendary celebrity beehive that endures as an icon of cafe society in Manhattan from the 1930s through the 1950s.

headline: Itochu to Buy Stake in Colombia Mine Project
text: The Itochu Corporation, the Japanese conglomerate and trading firm, said Thursday that it would pay $1.5 billion for a 20 percent stake in a Colombian coal project run by the Drummond Company, the coal mining company based in Birmingham, Ala.

headline: Energy Transfer to Buy Southern Union for $4.2 Billion
text: 9:18 p.m. | Updated

headline: Greek Turmoil Raises Fears of Instability Around Europe
text: ATHENS — The instability rocking Greece this week is the latest manifestation of a troubling new phase in the global financial crisis: political turmoil is sweeping through Europe, toppling governments and threatening to undermine efforts to rescue the financial system and, ultimately, the euro zone itself.

headline: Who Will Step Up to Meet Oil Demand?
text: For those of you who use gasoline or diesel to get to work in the morning, you may have a problem, in case you haven’t noticed prices at the pump lately.

headline: Thursday Reading: Hotels Offer Free Gas Cards
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Gay Marriage: Fourth and Goal at the One
text: Originally, this column on same-sex marriage was going to begin with a quotation from Dorothy L. Sayers, a British crime writer, poet and essayist in the first half of the 20th century. But events in Albany on Wednesday got in the way. So we’ll rely instead on one of those sports metaphors that abound in politics. This is from football.

headline: HomeAway Valued at $2 Billion
text: Amid a flurry of technology offerings, HomeAway on Thursday said it could raise as much as $250 million, valuing the vacation home rental site at roughly $2 billion.

headline: Bloomberg Headed to Albany to Push Gay Marriage Bill
text: In a rare unannounced visit, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York City will travel to Albany Thursday morning to try to persuade Republican state senators to legalize same-sex marriage before they are scheduled to adjourn for the year, according to a person briefed on the plan.

headline: Vain Glorious | Grooming Gifts for Dad
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#950", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

headline: Demag Backs $1.4 Billion Offer From Terex
text: Demag Cranes of Germany said Thursday that it would accept an improved offer from the Terex Corporation, the Connecticut-based equipment manufacturer, in a deal that values the company at about 963 million euros ($1.4 billion).

headline: Boeing Raises Forecast for Sales by 8.5%
text: Boeing on Thursday raised its long-range forecast for commercial aircraft demand, citing expectations that annual increases in passenger and cargo traffic, particularly in Asia, would continue to outpace average global economic growth over the next two decades.

headline: Robin Williams’s Personal Legend of Zelda
text: The jury’s still out on what long-term effects Gwyneth Paltrow and Chris Martin have wrought on their daughter by naming her Apple, but at least Robin Williams has earned himself a little geek cred – and the above Nintendo commercial – by naming his daughter Zelda. Mr. Williams, who with his feral beard is currently starring in the Broadway play “Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo,” arrived at that appellation not as a tribute to the Lost Generation figure Zelda Fitzgerald, but in recognition of the lost princess Zelda, who is repeatedly rescued by the hero Link in the Legend of Zelda video game series. If our folks named us after a video game character, we might beat them over the head with the Ocarina of Time, but to show there’s no hard feelings, the real-life Zelda Williams appears in the commercial with her dad.

headline: Weiner Resigns in Chaotic Final Scene
text: Representative Anthony D. Weiner, a once-promising politician whose Brooklyn roots and scrappy style made him a leading candidate to be the next mayor of New York, resigned his seat on Thursday, ending a three-week scandal over his lewd online behavior that startled his constituents and alienated many of his colleagues.

headline: Top Spanish Banker Faces Inquiry on Tax Charges
text: MADRID — Spain’s already fragile banking sector was shocked Thursday by the news that Emilio Botín, the country’s most influential banker and chairman of Banco Santander, and 11 of his relatives were the subjects of an investigation into tax evasion stretching back to accounts that ostensibly were opened during the dark days of the Spanish Civil War.

headline: Cosmos Copa Links Present to Past
text: Twenty-seven years have passed since a professional team wore the Cosmos uniforms. And while decades have passed since Werner Roth captained, Pelé bid his farewell, and Vladislav Bogicevic (known, of course, as Bogie) fed Giorgio Chinaglia for a goal, there is an effort to revive the Cosmos at a grassroots, community-based level.

headline: Colon Investigation Gathering Dust
text: When Major League Baseball learned that Yankees pitcher Bartolo Colon had undergone a special stem-cell procedure in the Dominican Republic to help his injured shoulder and elbow, it said it would conduct an investigation to make sure he did not receive any banned substances as part of the treatment. Right away, the two main doctors in the case, Colon’s lawyers, his agent and Colon himself — expressed a commitment to transparency and to making the medical records from the procedure available. But 37 days later, those documents have yet to be delivered to baseball from the Dominican hospital where Colon was treated. And there seems to be no sense of when that may happen.

headline: Clans and Tribes Forge New Yemen Unity
text: SANA, Yemen — After more than four months of insurrection, this tormented country may seem to be more divided than ever, with rival rallies still seizing the capital every week and fierce gun battles raging in the north and south.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: I.P.O. Fever Calms Down for Pandora  |  Sobriety has returned to the market for new Internet companies — at least for one day.

headline: Celebrating a City’s Solar Muscle
text: Given that New York City has been falling behind some of its municipal counterparts in new solar power installations, renewable energy advocates are happy to hear that its rooftops can hold more than water tanks and lounge chairs.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Adding Addresses to the Internet
text: The Internet is vast, but it’s also running out of addresses. On this week’s Bits: Tech Talk show, Bettina Edelstein speaks with Verne Kopytoff, a contributor to The Times’s  technology section, about IPv6, a protocol that allows many more addresses to be created — around 340 undecillion (the number one followed by 36 zeros), actually. The current system, known as IPv4, allows for some 4.3 billion addresses.

headline: McIlroy Moves to the Front, Again
text: BETHESDA, Md. — These bravura opening-round performances in major championships are becoming second nature for Rory McIlroy, the 22-year-old sensation from Holywood, Northern Ireland. At one with his golf game like a virtuoso musician with his instrument, McIlroy was brilliant on a gray Thursday at the United States Open, shooting a flawless round of 65 that was the best of the day by three strokes and the worst he could have shot.

headline: ‘Desert Cities’ Coming to Broadway, But Lavin Chooses Off Broadway Role Instead
text: The Tony Award-winning actress Linda Lavin will play the matriarch of the latest dysfunctional family from playwright Nicky Silver (“Three Changes,” “Pterodactyls”) in the Off Broadway world premiere of “The Lyons” at the Vineyard Theater this fall, the theater company announced on Thursday.

headline: Weiner to Resign This Afternoon
text: The Times’s Raymond Hernandez reports that Representative Anthony D. Weiner has told friends that he plans to resign his seat after coming under growing pressure from his Democratic colleagues to leave the House.

headline: Euro Zone | Barcelona Update
text: Barcelona’s tourist season technically shifts into high gear in July and August. But in June, the Catalonian capital in Spain is equally drenched in sun, with a full roster of outdoor cultural events (and fewer tourists clamoring around Guadi’s Sagrada Família). A couple of highlights include Barcelona Bike Week, which runs until June 19 and offers free bike rentals and tours at the Plaza Carles Pi I Sunyer, and the Grec Festival, from June 17 to July 31 at the open-air Teatre Grec, which showcases classical and contemporary theater, dance, jazz, flamenco, even circus acts.

headline: New York Police Investigating Confession in Robbery of Tupac Shakur
text: The New York Police Department said it is investigating the account of a man who said that he was involved in a 1994 shooting and robbery of the rapper Tupac Shakur, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Wall Street Frets Over New Rules
text: Wall Street is stepping up its attacks on new financial regulation, warning Congress on Thursday that a wave of restrictions threatens to weaken big banks and the broader United States economy.

headline: For Children on Medicaid, the Doctor Is Out
text: Children with Medicaid, the nation’s heath insurance program for those with low incomes, are more likely to be turned away by medical specialists compared to those with private insurance, a new study finds. As health reporter Denise Grady explains:

headline: Poetry Pairing | June 16, 2011
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

headline: The Fine Art of Casting Hits on Broadway
text: AN early step in creating a Broadway production — and one of the most critical — is the casting process. Directors and producers hire the actors, but it is usually the show’s casting director who first finds them to audition and consider: Hollywood celebrities, theater veterans, performers who might act better than they sing (or sing better than they act), onetime understudies who have grown into star material.

headline: Bachmann Said to Have Deal For Memoir
text: Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota has made a deal to publish her memoir, selling a book to Sentinel, a conservative imprint at Penguin Group USA, two people familiar with the negotiations said on Thursday.

headline: Managing a Brand He Made Himself
text: SHORTLY before 10 p.m. on the final night of Best of the Best, a reggae and hip-hop concert held over the Memorial Day weekend in Veterans Park in Miami, DJ Nuffy, the master of ceremonies, began to introduce the dancehall reggae artist Vybz Kartel. But Vybz Kartel wasn’t actually in the park, in Miami, or even in the United States. He was more than 500 miles away at Jamaica Jamaica, a fancy nightclub just outside Ocho Rios, because he has been denied a United States visa.

headline: A Rabbi Speaks About Faith on the Job
text: They see the worst moments of humanity, often in the midst of lives unraveling. Death. Despair. Lives torn by drugs. Police officers show up when a civilian is shot or stabbed. They might guard a body at a suicide, awaiting the arrival of workers from the medical examiner’s office, or they might transport a cache of guns whose illicit sales have plagued a neighborhood’s youth.

headline: The Memory of Bush
text: As the economy continues to struggle, Jay Cost compares Barack Obama to Jimmy Carter, and Walter Russell Mead compares him to Herbert Hoover. But HotAir’s Allahpundit, parsing the numbers from the latest Wall Street Journal poll, suggests why neither of those shoes quite fit. Neither Carter nor Hoover could credibly pin the country’s economic problems on their predecessor, but the country still assigns George W. Bush much more of the blame for our ongoing malaise than it assigns to Obama.

headline: Help for an Abused Family
text: In a guest post yesterday, Corbyn Hanson Hightower wrote a resonant, distressing essay from the point of view of the helpless child she was, cowering from the raging father she feared. It was hard to read, but softened, at least a tiny bit, by the fact that her threat was past.

headline: Among Democrats, Relief as Weiner Bows Out
text: 3:46 p.m. | Updated Democratic leaders wished Representative Anthony D. Weiner well after he announced his resignation on Thursday, as the party looked forward to an end to weeks of scandal.

headline: It’s Not Easy Being ... You Know
text: It’s shocking how little $150 million buys you in Hollywood these days. That galactic sum is the estimated production price tag swinging from “Green Lantern,” the chintzy-looking movie featuring the emerald-hued superhero who’s been riding high and low on and off the comic-book circuit since 1940. But there’s no keeping a masked avenger down, especially a contender in cross-marketing promotion. Do you want Green Lantern tie-in Doritos or Reese’s with your tie-in Lipton Brisk green-tea beverage? (After the sugar rush subsides, settle in with the newly published “Green Lantern and Philosophy: No Evil Shall Escape This Book.”)

headline: Build-Your-Own Passes for City Attractions
text: Go Select, a customizable attraction pass for both the budget-minded and the discriminating, was recently started by Smart Destinations, a Boston company.Travelers build passes online by selecting two or more attractions, and can save up to 36 percent compared with the cost of individual tickets.

headline: Get a Sneak Peek at Revamped ‘Carrie’ Musical
text: For anyone who simply cannot wait see the revamped musical “Carrie” until its Off Broadway run next year, a sneak peek will be available at the Lucille Lortel Theater on Aug. 1, the musical’s producers announced on Thursday. The creators of the legendary, short-lived Broadway production of “Carrie” — the book writer Lawrence D. Cohen, the composer Michael Gore and the lyricist Dean Pitchford — have been overhauling the 1988 musical with the director Stafford Arima (“Altar Boyz”), and they will discuss the creative process for a paying audience, with tickets ranging between $39 and $99. The evening will include songs from the coming production — about half the music is new — performed by its cast members, including Molly Ranson, who will play Carrie, and the Tony Award nominee Marin Mazzie as her mother, Margaret White. MCC Theater is producing the musical, which is scheduled to begin preview performances on Jan. 31.

headline: Driving the Toyota Prius V: a Prius With Costco Capacity
text: According to Toyota, its Prius accounts for 52 percent of the United States hybrid market and outsells all its competitors combined. It’s no surprise, then, that the company would want to give the car some siblings.

headline: Romney: ‘I’m Also Unemployed’
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Mitt Romney sat at the head of the table at a coffee shop here on Thursday, listening to a group of unemployed Floridians explain the challenges of looking for work. When they finished, he weighed in with a predicament of his own.

headline: Bloomberg Visits, but No Breakthrough on Gay Marriage Vote
text: ALBANY — Senate Republicans emerged from a brief session with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Thursday morning and said they had still not decided whether to allow a vote on same-sex marriage.

headline: On Bloomsday, Joyce Fans Say Yes, Yes to Twitter
text: “—Warily walking went Bloom, unconquered hero. Jingle a tinkle jaunted. Not yet. At four. What is he doing at the Ormond? Let’s hear the time.” The words may not be exactly Joycean, but they’re pretty close for 140 characters. At approximately 10:45 a.m. Eastern time this entry was the latest added to @11ysses twitter account. It’s part of the marathon project, known as “Ulysses Meets Twitter 2011,” conceived by “Stephen from Baltimore,” which invited readers of “Ulysses” to retell the great, lengthy work through tweets from start to finish within the 24-hour period that the novel’s odyssey through Dublin (on June 16, 1904) takes place.

headline: Go to Sleep! Please?
text: Although Adam Mansbach’s Go the F@#k to Sleep, a foul-mouthed exhortation of a children’s bedtime story, has been at the top of best-seller lists for weeks, yesterday marked its actual publication date, and sales, already mind-boggling, can only go up. What makes the story so compelling is not just Mansbach’s quick shot of shock, but the language of the book as it goes on, evoking perfectly the desperation and deep sense of generalized failure that parents feel when they are both sleep-deprived and, in fact, failing at the presumably straightforward task of bending a small child’s will to their wishes.

headline: The Tricky U.S. Reactor Tally
text: At the entrance to the unfinished Bellefonte nuclear plant in Hollywood, Ala., are morale-building posters for Tennessee Valley Authority employees. In bold type, they proclaim “106.”

headline: Bruins’ Recchi Retires on a Winning Note

headline: Theater Talkback: What Oscar Can Learn From Tony About How to Put on a Show

By 8:03, all the muscles involved in sustaining that expression had started to atrophy. Good heavens. Could this really be happening to an inveterate Tony loather? All the snark was draining out of me, as if from a punctured boil.

headline: Nissan Leaf Telematics May Leak Driver Data to Third Parties
text: By design, in-car telematics systems are a two-way street. Only after collecting data about a driver’s coordinates can they offer the location of the nearest gas station or a recommendation for a nearby pizzeria. But as the owner of a Nissan Leaf recently discovered, once a service possesses a motorist’s data, it is unclear how it might be used.

headline: Beer on the Go | Portland, Ore.
text: The Portland, Ore., metro area boasts more craft breweries than any other city in the world. One of the smallest is Captured By Porches, a literal “mom and pop” operation based in the nearby suburb of St. Helens. The mom and pop in question are Suzanne Moodhe and Dylan Goldsmith, for whom a home brewing hobby has become a sustainable family business with seasonal offerings, reusable packaging and a one-of-a-kind home: the Captured By Porches Mobile Public Haus, a bar on wheels that takes advantage of Portland’s spirit of mobile culinary adventure and loose alcohol regulations.

headline: How Much Is Too Much Homework?
text: Homework used to be something that your children did, no questions asked. At my New Jersey elementary school in the mid-1970s, I received packet after packet of mind-numbing addition and subtraction problems. It never occurred to me, or my parents, to question that homework.

headline: No Strike at Macy’s
text: There will be no picket lines on 34th Street, no marching in Herald Square. Tourists who feared their jaunts to New York might be ruined by a strike at Macy’s need worry no longer: the department store and its employees reached a tentative agreement on a new contract early Thursday.

Weiner that began 20 days ago when he unwittingly cc’d the world a lewd photo came to an end in a most old-fashioned way: He announced his resignation Thursday afternoon in a brief speech at the same senior center in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, where he had announced his candidacy for City Council in 1991 at age 26.

headline: Wear Resort Now | Spain
text: New York may be miles from Madrid, but what’s popping up on the resort runways shows that Spain isn’t far from designers’ thoughts. Oscar de la Renta took his inspiration quite literally with flamenco hats trimmed in pompoms and bolero embroidery on jackets. A flamenco influence was also evident in Chloë Sevigny’s collection for Opening Ceremony with layers of ruffles on crisp white shirts and at the hems of long, flouncy skirts. Yves Saint Laurent featured dresses in dramatic reds and blacks, evoking images of a matador’s costume, while Richard Nicoll’s rose slip dress was a romantic and wearable take on the trend. If you want to make like Shala Monroque at the Whitney Art Party and incorporate a little salsa into your wardrobe now, it’s not that hard: fresh ruffled cotton blouses and skirts, vintage embroidered anything or a simple black ribbon around your collar does the trick.

headline: 36 Hours in Newport, R.I.

headline: 36 Hours in Newport, R.I.
text: WITH its summer cottages the size of palaces and its century-old status as a yachting capital, Newport is the quintessential playground of American aristocracy. Still, this harbor town is more than model ships and mansions. The waterfront — with views of wide, tentacled Narragansett Bay — is still Newport’s soul, and the estates along Bellevue Avenue haven’t lost their Gilded Age glamour. But in a town that seems, on the surface, so untouched by time, there’s an undercurrent of youthful rebelliousness. Ambitious upstart restaurants, a boisterous night life and a beachy surf culture belie Newport’s staid reputation.

headline: Libya Campaign Reveals the Doves — on the Left and Right
text: And you thought the only thing that Democratic Representative Dennis Kucinich and House Speaker John Boehner shared were their humble origins in Ohio. Not so. President Obama’s decision to bring American firepower to the NATO campaign in Libya has brought the two men together. Both men say that Mr. Obama’s decision to launch airstrikes in Libya is a violation of the War Powers Act, which requires presidents to seek permission from Congress to go to war.

headline: Behind the Surge in Energy Deals
text: As the deal-making steadily returns from the depths of the financial crisis and the recession, energy companies are leading the way. Oil, natural gas, and utility players are rapidly consolidating. On Thursday, Energy Transfer Equity bid $4.2 billion for Southern Union Company, a deal that will create one of the largest natural gas pipeline operators. DealBook’s Andrew Ross Sorkin and Adrienne Carter talk about what’s fueling the strong activity.

headline: Farewell, Morticia. Greetings, Titania.
text: Bebe Neuwirth is going from the queen of freaks to queen of the fairies. Ms. Neuwirth, who plays Morticia in the Broadway musical “The Addams Family” through June 26, will portray Titania next spring in Classic Stage Company’s production of Shakespeare’s “A Midsummer Night’s Dream,” the theater announced on Thursday. The production, directed by Tony Speciale, is to run from March 28 through May 6 at Classic Stage’s Off Broadway theater in the East Village.

headline: Crunch Talks Aim at Deal to Defuse Crisis in Greece

headline: Living the Good Lie
text: Denis Flanigan isn’t hiding anything. A 42-year-old psychotherapist in Houston, he has a straightforward manner that meshes nicely with his no-nonsense buzz cut and neatly clipped goatee. Unlike many mental-health professionals, Flanigan puts personal items on display in his office, including a photo of his partner, who is attractive, and male. For his patients’ amusement he has on hand an S-and-M Barbie as well as a Tickle Me Freud doll. (“It’s so, so . . . wrong,” Flanigan told me, in a tone that signaled he believed it was exactly right.) Flanigan’s no-secrets policy extends to his Web site, where he writes that he “has frequently been asked to speak on the gay and lesbian experience and mental health, transgender concerns and body-modification issues.” A member of the American Psychological Association, Flanigan has also served as Mr. Prime Choice Texas, winning a contest “designed for men 40 years or older who represent the masculine aesthetic embraced by the leather/Levi/uniform/fetish community.” In his own words, he identifies as a “militant homosexual.”

headline: My Ex-Gay Friend
text: One Saturday afternoon last winter, I drove north on Route 85 through the rolling rangeland of southeastern Wyoming. I was headed to a small town north of Cheyenne to see an old friend and colleague named Michael Glatze. We worked together 12 years ago at XY, a San Francisco-based national magazine for young gay men, back when we were young gay men ourselves.

headline: Now Slammin’ | Iceage in Brooklyn
text: Scandinavian music is not all sleepy-sounding blondes and whistling guys in striped T-shirts. Four teenagers from Copenhagen have seen to that, with a muscular punk that shows Denmark’s darkest side. Iceage’s first album, “New Brigade” (What’s Your Rupture Records), is a 12-song, 24-minute onslaught that takes early-’80s influences like Killing Joke and Wire to another dimension. Their first United States show, on June 17, might not be as bloody as those pictured on their MySpace page, but it’ll definitely be a scrum as critics and fans shove their way in.

headline: If It’s About Atrocity, Does That Make It Good?
text: On the fourth floor of the New Museum of Contemporary Art the elevator doors open to reveal an old photograph blown up to mural scale, covering a wall about four feet away. It shows concentration camp prisoners in regimental order, guarded by German soldiers. In the background looms the familiar gateway of Auschwitz. From the elevator, you step onto a boardwalk of rough wooden planks. To the left, exposed aluminum studs give the impression that you are being herded into a camp yourself.

headline: ‘House of Blue Leaves’ To Close Early
text: The Broadway revival of John Guare’s “House of Blue Leaves” will close on Saturday, June 25, two weeks earlier than it was originally scheduled to end its run, the show’s producers announced on Thursday.

headline: Why Republicans Should Keep Expectations Modest for Winning Weiner’s Seat
text: I’m on a brief vacation through early next week, so a more prolonged analysis of the upcoming special election in New York’s Ninth Congressional District — made necessary by Representative Anthony D. Weiner’s resignation on Thursday — will have to wait. But there are a couple of pieces of data to bring to bear.

headline: What You Need to Stay Charged While Traveling
text: A friend of mine refuses to let his gadgets run down. At the slightest movement of the battery bar he goes into a panic, hunting down an outlet like a terrier sniffing out a fox den. His obsession, while unbecoming, is common and staying charged on the road is often a difficult — but not impossible — proposition.

headline: Stars of Venice Shine in Basel
text: BASEL, Switzerland — The German artist Hans-Peter Feldmann said that the sheer size of his $100,000 Hugo Boss Prize inspired him to paper a gallery at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York last month with 100,000 $1 bills.

headline: Rep. Anthony Weiner Resigns; Congress Debating the U.S. Role in Libya; the Republican Presidential Candidates; Censorship and the Franking Privilege
text: Rep. Anthony Weiner resigns; Congress debating the U.S. Role in Libya; the Republican presidential candidates; censorship and the Franking Privilege. Chief correspondent for The Caucus at NYTimes.com Michael Shear joins Sam Roberts in New York.

headline: Need a Kidney? A Skull? Just Bring Cash
text: Whereas black markets trade in illegal goods like guns and drugs, the “red market,” the journalist Scott Carney says in his revealing if somewhat scattershot new book, trades in human flesh — in kidneys and other organs, in human corneas, blood, bones and eggs. Many of the real-life examples he cites in this chilling volume cannot help but remind the reader of a horror movie, or of Kazuo Ishiguro’s devastating dystopian novel “Never Let Me Go” (2005), in which we learn that a group of children are clones who have been raised to “donate” replacement body parts.

headline: Just One Look | Versace Resort
text: Without falter, this year’s resort collections want you to have fun in the sun. Versace didn’t disappoint. Tropical touches included short asymmetrical dresses with a palm-tree print and pumps in a beach towel stripe. And there was no shortage of sex appeal either, like grommets on stark black trim and the exposed zipper on this va-va-va voom bustier.

headline: A Hyperactive Fly on a Newsroom Wall
text: "Page One: Inside The New York Times" is a documentary about this newspaper and the people who put it out. All of these people know far more than I do about The Times and are better positioned to judge the movie. But what might strike nonjournalists as an advantage looks to journalists like a disadvantage, in fact a disqualification. It’s a “conflict of interest.” I, by contrast, know almost nothing about how The New York Times works.

headline: Struggle for the Soul of Islam
text: In a 2007 documentary collaboration with PBS, The New York Times interviewed Abu Bakar Bashir, who was sentenced to 15 years in jail on Thursday in Jakarta.

headline: For Love and Watson, a Visit With the President
text: BETHESDA, Md. — For Davis Love III, meeting the president does not come once in a lifetime; it comes with each new administration.

headline: TimesCast | June 16, 2011
text: Representative Anthony D. Weiner bows to pressure and resigns; Greece struggles over economic austerity measures; and a growing community of protesters in Yemen's capital.

headline: Billy the Kid, Toshiko Takaezu, Mural, Vietnam War Zippos
text: Billy the Kid posed for only one portrait — at least that scholars can agree on.

headline: Just One Look | Tory Burch Resort
text: Tory Burch’s penchant for patterns landed her in bohemian Santa Fe, circa 1972. Shades of lobster, turquoise and desert sand colored the collection’s landscape of silk blouses, cardigans and disco striped denim. Also speaking in a regional accent were her raffia braided platforms, woven bags and this updated rendition of a Navajo poncho.

headline: Credit Cards That Offer Savings at the Pump
text: From our colleagues at Bucks:

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for June 17-23
text: Art

headline: Petition Seeks Better Pay for Musicans at Jazz Festivals
text: 4:37 p.m. | Updated The Undead Jazzfest, now in its second year, will employ dozens of jazz musicians next week, in more than 50 sets, from Thursday through Sunday, in New York. But the terms of that employment have drawn criticism, according to a petition posted online.

headline: Pandora Shares Crushed in Second Day of Trading
text: A bad buzz surrounded Pandora Media’s shares on Thursday, as the online radio company’s stock price plummeted 24 percent, below its initial public offering price.

headline: Buyers in East Hills Enticed by Its Park
text: East Hills

headline: But Where Will My Cars Sleep?
text: ANGIE RIBOWSKY and her husband, Ian, love almost everything about their four-bedroom center-hall colonial in Scarsdale. Built in 1927, it has the charm of a prewar house, along with an updated kitchen, lots of nooks and crannies, and ample room for a family of four.

headline: A Home Invasion by the Antarcticans
text: It would seem that “Mr. Popper’s Penguins,” a summer family stopgap between the “Kung Fu Panda” and “Cars” sequels, missed the movie-penguin craze by about five years, though perhaps it will prompt a penguin revival. In any case, the film, directed with bounce and snap by Mark Waters, stands as a comeback of sorts for Jim Carrey, who mugs and prances and does funny voices and manages not to be upstaged by a half-dozen flightless birds. The birds — real gentoo penguins with computer-enhanced abilities — honk, defecate and waddle around Manhattan while Mr. Carrey’s Popper, at first vexed and then beguiled by the creatures, tries to deal with them, his job, his children and the state of his soul.

headline: Hitting the Streets for the Fun of It
text: FEED ME OIL. Doodle Jump. Angry Birds. With so many addictive mobile-device games competing for attention it may seem counterintuitive to expand an annual festival devoted to urban gaming — meaning playing games, often outside with other humans! — but the organizers of the annual Come Out and Play Festival seem confident that sometimes old ways can be very enjoyable ways.

headline: Movie Listings for June 17-23
text: Movies

headline: Even a Media Circus Needs a Clown
text: Representative Anthony D. Weiner came to Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, to resign from Congress, and Benjy Bronk came to steal Mr. Weiner’s glory, if it could be called that. Fortunately for Mr. Bronk, no one was checking press credentials at the door.

headline: Bad Credit, but Good Vibes
text: BARUCH HERZFELD, a landlord in Brooklyn, sometimes finds himself unsure about a potential tenant. Because his buildings are in neighborhoods like Bushwick and Bedford-Stuyvesant, which are frequented by artistic and creative workers, a number of his applicants have questionable credit or spotty incomes.

headline: Redesign of World Financial Center Includes Huge Food Market, and Restaurants
text: O.K., it won’t exactly be a Disney food theme park, but it could bring some new culinary drama to Lower Manhattan. Specifically: a 25,000-square-foot marketplace abundant with fresh produce, meat, cheese, bread and coffee, not to mention wines. Adjacent will be six new restaurants plus 15 casual-dining outlets in a 30,000-square-foot space with 600 seats overlooking the Hudson River.

headline: A Site for Figuring Out the Cheapest Time to Make a Purchase
text: Online shoppers are accustomed to comparing prices across the Web, but they may not realize that e-commerce sites also change their prices many times over the course of a week.

headline: LEO VILLAREAL: ‘Volume’
text: Gering & López Gallery

headline: A Palette of Wine, Blood and Sex
text: A critic recently strolled through a drizzle to a theater on a remote stretch of West 52nd Street, the home of Intar, the Latin company. Accessible via a dilapidated elevator, the room was a mere 59-seater. Translucent tarpaulins served as curtains.

headline: Life in Freedom Square
text: Five months into Yemen’s revolution, a look at the growing community of protestors in Sana’s main square.

headline: Spare Times for June 17-23
text: Around Town

headline: JEAN-PIERRE GAUTHIER: Recent Work
text: Jack Shainman Gallery

headline: WILLEM DE KOONING: ‘The Figure: Movement and Gesture’
text: Pace Gallery

headline: TYSON REEDER
text: Daniel Reich Gallery

headline: BILL RICE: ‘Paintings and Works on Paper’
text: Steven Harvey Fine Art Projects

headline: Big Deal | Soon After Buying, Developer to Sell Fifth Avenue Co-op
text: William Lie Zeckendorf, a developer of 15 Central Park West who made a $30 million profit on the sale of his penthouse in the building late last year, has already listed the new apartment he bought in December, at 927 Fifth Avenue, according to brokers familiar with his decision.

headline: ROE ETHRIDGE: ‘Le Luxe’
text: Andrew Kreps Gallery

headline: One Man Who Knows the Way of the Horse
text: When the soulful cowboy philosopher Buck Brannaman talks, people — and horses — listen. The aw-shucks star and one of the two-legged attractions in the documentary “Buck,” Mr. Brannaman is a former trick rope performer who, after a childhood of pain, became something of a shaman and an inspiration for the novel and movie “The Horse Whisperer.” He doesn’t just talk to the animals; he also transforms snorting, bucking horses into companions who follow his lead without a tether and even join him in a graceful meadow duet.

headline: Reviled Tycoon, Assad’s Cousin, Resigns in Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria’s most powerful businessman, a confidant and cousin of President Bashar al-Assad, announced on Thursday that he was quitting business and moving to charity work, Syrian television said. The move, if true, would suggest that Mr. Assad was so concerned about the continuing protests that he would sacrifice a relative to public anger.

headline: Spare Times: For Children, for June 17-23
text: ‘CURIOUS GEORGE’

headline: TimesCast | Turmoil in Greece
text: Greek Prime minister George Papandreou struggles to avert a financial crisis.

headline: A Big-Time Dose of Downsizing
text: DOWNSIZING was both necessary and welcome for Jeff Kwong and Bob Moriarty when they moved to New York from Denver. Their four-story 3,000-square-foot Denver house had three bedrooms, four bathrooms and three fireplaces. It was far too large for two men and a dog.

headline: Artists Whose Vitality Flows From the Streets
text: Because of a long renovation of El Museo del Barrio’s Fifth Avenue building, four years have passed since the museum’s last “bi-annual” survey of new Latino, Caribbean and Latin American art. As if to make up for lost time, the new edition is the biggest so far. It includes work by 75 artists spread over seven shows in four boroughs, with the main event at El Museo itself.

headline: Bloomsday Machines
text: In the spirit of Bloomsday — which honors the James Joyce novel “Ulysses,” which takes place entirely on June 16 — here’s a not-entirely random roundup of how various media are marking the occasion.

headline: The Best of Vincent Moon
text: The director Vincent Moon comments on a few of his favorite music videos from the dozens and dozens he has made in the past decade.

headline: Close Up, Mercury Is Looking Less Boring
text: For years, many planetary scientists did not express much curiosity about Mercury, which looked gray and cratered — a slightly larger version of the Moon.

headline: A Look at How Many Calories $1 Will Buy
text: Lapham’s Quarterly has put together a graphic showing how many calories a dollar will buy in various forms, including lettuce, canned tuna, a bottle of Coca-Cola and a McDouble sandwich at McDonald’s. It’s a good illustration of one of the problems with the American diet: unhealthy food is often a lot cheaper than healthy food.

headline: Gardner Takes Star Turn With Winning Hit in 12th
text: The Yankees won a game on Thursday in the 12th inning on a broken-bat single by Brett Gardner, who spent the first eight innings on the bench. The winning pitcher, Cory Wade, joined the team on Wednesday after not appearing in a big-league game for 23 months.

headline: It’s Might Versus Right Versus Space Monster
text: And a pediatrician and a history professor will lead them.

headline: A ‘Ring’ Made of California Gold
text: SAN FRANCISCO — When the three Rhinemaidens appear at the opening of the San Francisco Opera’s production of Wagner’s “Rheingold,” they look like wholesome young women in gingham dresses right out of a John Ford western. Alberich the dwarf intrudes on the scene, a grimy forty-niner in sturdy boots and overalls, panning for gold and looking desperate.

headline: A True-to-Life Setting for Voices From the Dead
text: THERE was nearly a full moon over Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn on Monday night, when the cast of the cemetery’s latest theatrical performance gathered for a full run-through.

headline: Broadway’s Next Stanley Kowalski: Blair Underwood
text: Women generally make up two-thirds of the audiences for Broadway shows, and they are more likely than men to buy the tickets for a night at the theater. The television actor Blair Underwood (“The Event,” “L.A. Law”) is known to be popular with the ladies. “Plus he is a great actor,” the theater producer Stephen C. Byrd said on Thursday. “One plus one plus one. And even better news is, this role is a great fit for him.”

headline: The Songs Of Prince, Faithfully Reimagined
text: Meshell Ndegeocello outlined a catalog of social and natural disasters at one point in her sold-out show at the Highline Ballroom on Wednesday night. “You turn on the telly and every other story/Is tellin’ you somebody died,” she sang in her deep-shadow vocal register, a notch or two above a murmur. The tune was “Sign o’ the Times,” by Prince, rearranged for upright bass, pinging keyboards and hazy rhythm. The overhaul affected everything but melody and lyrics, amplifying the bitterness in the song.

headline: ESPN’s Bill Simmons
text: Those of us who remember Bill Simmons from his Boston Sports Guy days can’t possibly love him as much now as we did then. Back then, he really was one of us — just another fan — and his fatalistic tone was perfect for the awful Boston sports scene of the late ’90s and very early 2000s. Jonathan Mahler would have done well to mention that the unprecedented success of Boston sports franchises over the last decade did a lot to boost Simmons’s profile, particularly in the mid-2000s; I wonder whether a Cleveland Sports Guy or a Buffalo Sports Guy would have had the same success. In fact, I wonder whether a Cleveland Sports Guy, just as witty and clever as Simmons, has been writing for a tiny audience for years and is seething about living in a town that has arguably the most depressing sports scene in America.

headline: Moving On Simply by Moving Out
text: During four weeks this spring at Danspace Project, the choreographer Melinda Ring has redefined the organization’s Platform series by paying homage to a single and singular dance artist: Susan Rethorst. This weekend, “Susan Rethorst: Retro(intro)spective,” programmed by Ms. Ring, concludes the series with two new works — “208 East Broadway Part 3: Over and Out,” which was shown for the first time on Tuesday evening and “208 East Broadway Part 4: Sold,” a performance installation that will be presented on Saturday afternoon.

headline: Wheelies: The Normalcy Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: A Piano Tour of Schoenberg’s Career
text: “My only intention is to have no intentions,” Schoenberg wrote in 1909, the year he composed his landmark Three Piano Pieces (Op. 11), “no formal, architectural or other artistic intentions (except perhaps of capturing the mood of a poem), no aesthetic intentions.”

headline: In Mahler’s Chamber, a Radical Departure
text: How often do you encounter a program of chamber music named for Mahler? Only one Mahler chamber work has survived in the literature; or rather, part of a work. What we call the Piano Quartet in A minor — written around 1876, when Mahler was 16 — was intended as the first movement of a larger piece, otherwise represented by only 24 bars of a scherzo.

headline: Anthony Weiner Resigns
text: At last, there was a dignified moment in the decline and fall of Anthony Weiner.

headline: Norah O’Donnell Leaves NBC for CBS
text: CBS announced Thursday that it had hired Norah O’Donnell, the long-time Washington-based correspondent for NBC News, as its new chief White House correspondent.

headline: Pawlenty Goes After Romney
text: 9:39 p.m. | Updated Four days after declining to criticize Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, during a Republican presidential debate, Tim Pawlenty acknowledged his flub in a Twitter message on Thursday.

headline: Andrea Catsimatidis and Christopher Cox
text: RICHARD NIXON could never have scripted it — that it would take a Democrat to help his avowedly Republican oldest grandson fall head over heels in love. Yet that is what fate had in store in April 2008 for Christopher Nixon Cox, then 29 and working for Senator John McCain’s presidential campaign.

headline: The Caveat to Early Preference Polls
text: As polls measuring voters’ preferences in the 2012 presidential election abound, one finding is important to note at this early stage in the campaign to help put them into context: the large majority of voters, including Republican voters, are simply not yet tuned in.

headline: Merciless Congressional Takes Toll on Former Champions
text: BETHESDA, Md. — Ernie Els, the 1997 United States Open champion, and Jim Furyk, who won in 2003, were having pretty good outing Thursday at Congressional Country Club until a few measly holes ruined everything.

headline: A Plea From South Kordofan State, Sudan
text: This week, Sudanese airstrikes near Kadugli and Kauda in Southern Kordofan have made access for reporters to the contested area all but impossible. The following email is from a South Sudanese humanitarian worker who is trapped in a United Nations Mission in the Sudan (UNMIS) camp, which is apparently surrounded by Sudanese forces. It seems to be consistent with other reports that have trickled in throughout the last few days.

headline: The Unsung Queen of the Colonial Revival
text: THE Museum of the City of New York’s new exhibition, “The American Style: Colonial Revival and the Modern Metropolis,” covers the energetic movement in the late 19th and early 20th centuries to restore the homespun virtues of the 18th.

headline: Lawmakers Seek Assurances on Bank Regulations
text: Financial regulators sought to reassure lawmakers that they could coordinate with global officials and still maintain industry competitiveness as they rewrote Wall Street oversight rules.

headline: Making the Switch to Rentals
text: ELIZABETH

headline: Reunited by Kia, and Ready for Adventure
text: Kia Motors America is getting the old gang together again.

headline: Paying Off Your Mortgage Early
text: JUST because you own a home doesn’t mean you have to keep carrying a mortgage — about a third of American homeowners don’t, according to the Federal Reserve.

headline: Dominique Strauss-Kahn Voluntary Disclosure Form
text: A summary of evidence to be used against Dominique Strauss-Kahn provides insight into the early hours of his arrest.

headline: Q & A
text: Security Concerns Over Broken Buzzer

headline: Stephen M. Ross
text: Mr. Ross, 71, is the chairman, chief executive and founder of the Related Companies in New York, which is best known for the Time Warner Center. Among the company’s latest projects is the development of the 26-acre Hudson Yards.

headline: Court Papers Detail Strauss-Kahn’s Statements After Arrest
text: About 15 minutes after police detectives from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey pulled Dominique Strauss-Kahn off a Paris-bound flight, he told them he had diplomatic immunity, according to a document filed by prosecutors on Thursday.

headline: Truth Behind Watergate Uncertain, Even With Technology
text: A high-tech attempt to plug the mysterious 18 ½-minute gap in the Watergate tapes turned up a tantalizing clue, the National Archives and Records Administration said Thursday, but ultimately proved inconclusive in solving the scandal’s most intriguing questions: What did President Richard M. Nixon know, and when did he know it?

headline: Take Mugwort and Call Us in a Week
text: Dragon’s blood incense, musky and sweet, burns from an altar. The rich smoke wafts across an 18th-century Bible and through shimmering peacock feathers, mingling in midair with hundreds of allies: roasted dandelion root, Irish moss flakes, horny goat weed, astragalus.

headline: Ecoexistence Project
text: A Palestinian and an Israeli engineer crossed borders and barriers to work together on establishing a sustainable future for their joint environment.

headline: Use Twitter? Always Remember These Three Things
text: Congressman Anthony Weiner’s resignation on Thursday was triggered by a Twitter mistake last month that he admitted making.

headline: Pakistani Journalists Threatened After Filming Police Shootings
text: As Pakistani officials investigate two cases of extrajudicial killings caught on video, both cameramen report that they have been threatened for having recorded the incidents.

headline: Alternative Worlds Where Even McMansions Are Tiny
text: In the age of the flat screen, a show about the diorama sounds charmingly naïve. The word itself conjures benign images of hobbyists with tweezers and sixth graders with shoeboxes.

headline: Weekend Miser
text: Grill? Check. Flip-flops? Check. Vernon Reid, founder of Living Colour? Check.

headline: Allergic to Homework and Possibly Smitten
text: Someday every overprivileged, misunderstood high school boy who has ever come of age in New York will have his own movie, and one good thing about “The Art of Getting By” is that it brings that day, the day we can move on to other matters, a little closer. Another good thing about the movie, written and directed by Gavin Wiesen, is Emma Roberts, who plays the protagonist’s beguiling and elusive soul mate. She did similar duty in “It’s Kind of a Funny Story” — also rising above its above-averageness — which makes you wonder when she will get a coming-of-age story for herself.

headline: Long Dead, Yet Somehow Vaguely Alive
text: PHILADELPHIA — After a while, you get used to the trappings of death: the vacant, hollow stares; prongs of teeth protruding from desiccated gums; the shriveled flesh pulled like dried leather over jutting joints. And there’s a dreadful uniformity in those signs, whether you look at the remains of a 500-year-old dog that was found in 1953 in a peat bog in Germany or at an 800-year-old embalmed child from Peru who had been interred in a crunched and compact crouch.

headline: Intruders at the Window, and Then a Nightmare
text: The money shot in the Spanish horror thriller "Kidnapped" lasts only a split second, but you are not likely to forget it. What looks like a hunk of chopped meat with wet marbles stuck into it is actually a bashed-in face.

headline: Up Front: Stacey D’Erasmo
text: Before Stacey D’Erasmo’s first novel, “Tea,” came out in 2000, she worked for seven years in the late 1980s and early 1990s as a senior editor at The Village Voice Literary Supplement in downtown New York.

headline: Loud Music, Clean Living
text: The ambition of “Ten Thousand Saints,” Eleanor Henderson’s debut novel about a group of unambitious lost souls, is beautiful. In nearly 400 pages, Henderson does not hold back once: she writes the hell out of every moment, every scene, every perspective, every fleeting impression, every impulse and desire and bit of emotional detritus. She is never ironic or underwhelmed; her preferred mode is fierce, devoted and elegiac.

headline: Wrapped Up
text: Images from the new “Mummies of the World” exhibition at the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia.

headline: Battle for Libya | June 16, 2011
text: Libyan government minders took foreign journalists to the scene of a bombing hours after a NATO strike in Tripoli.

headline: Derby Champion Has Leg Injury After Belmont
text: The Kentucky Derby winner Animal Kingdom, who was bumped and nearly unseated his jockey in the opening strides of the Belmont Stakes, has a minor injury to his left hind leg.

headline: House Tour: Southampton, N.Y.
text: An interior designer finds a Hamptons getaway that doesn’t need to be rebuilt. And it’s next to a horse farm.;

headline: House Tour: Southampton, N.Y.
text: WHAT Four-bedroom house.

headline: Life in the Big House: The Danish Experience
text: For a mild-mannered movie critic the Danish prison drama “R,” set in a maximum-security penitentiary, raises inescapable personal questions: Could I survive in such a brutal environment, and if so, how? I should add that “R” is far from the most harrowing prison film ever made. And life inside Horsens State Prison, the Danish institution, now closed, where the movie was filmed with a cast that includes former inmates and guards, isn’t as hellish as the situation behind bars is portrayed in American movies, some of which are so gory they qualify as prison porn. But it is awful enough.

headline: Long Memory or Short, Boston Fans Savor Success
text: BOSTON — To Brittany Shepard, life without a Boston sports championship every year or two is like the days before text messages and Twitter: a bygone era she simply cannot fathom.

headline: Banished in California, Dance Event Edges East
text: LAS VEGAS — The Electric Daisy Carnival drew nearly 160,000 people to the Los Angeles Coliseum last year for a two-day outdoor extravaganza of electronic music and dazzling visual displays.

headline: Caution Needed in Changing Share Disclosure Rule
text: A new plan to ease a disclosure rule that has been burdensome for private companies like Facebook gets it only half right. Tweaking, rather than gutting, the current requirements would be a better way to balance companies accessing capital with investor protection.

headline: Young Lords and Ladies of the Dance
text: Girls may do it in wigs, and boys may do it in secret, but Irish dancing — if the documentary “Jig” is any indication — is nothing if not exhibitionist. Tracking eight international aspirants on their pogoing path to the 2010 Irish Dancing World Championships in Glasgow, this programmatic entry in the tykes-and-trophies genre has too much on its plate and not nearly enough on its mind.

headline: Plenty of Seats, but Only One Behind the Wheel
text: My stepfather has asked me to accompany him and my mother to the airport two hours away, and then drive their car back. He insists on driving to the airport because he is “a nervous passenger.” But I don’t feel safe when he drives. He goes too fast and has had accidents in the past. I’ve explained my concerns to my mother, but she won’t get involved. How can I ask him to slow down and be more careful? He’s thin-skinned, and I don’t want him to blow his stack. But I’m not risking my life just to keep him happy.

headline: Meatless Mondays Catch On, Even With Carnivores
text: ASPEN, Colo. — Friction between the health-and-eco-minded hippies who came here for a Rocky Mountain High in the 1970s and the superwealthy second-homers who followed from the intersection of Hollywood and Hedge Fund is an old story here at 8,000 feet.

headline: In Brooklyn, Pushing Back Against a Redevelopment Plan
text: “Battle for Brooklyn,” a documentary about the unending mess that is the Atlantic Yards project, is unabashedly slanted and as a result will probably be dismissed by those it portrays unflatteringly. That’s unfortunate, because this film should be discouraging and dismaying for people on all sides of the project, for what it says about oversize expectations and missed opportunities.

headline: Partisan Politics, Public Frustration
text: To the Editor:

headline: Does Suspect Need Miranda Warning? It May Depend on Age, Justices Rule
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court issued four decisions in criminal cases on Thursday, including one ruling that a suspect’s age must be taken into consideration in deciding whether to issue Miranda warnings.

headline: Seeking a Balance: Part-Time Doctor and Mom
text: To the Editor:

headline: Trade Schools in New York
text: To the Editor:

headline: How China Behaves
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Sound of (Experimental) Music
text: How’s this for pedagogy? “I teach so that you won’t be able to write music.” That’s Schoenberg quoted by his student John Cage in Jacqueline Caux’s film “The Colors of the Prism, the Mechanics of Time.” As for Cage, what interests him most, he says in an archival interview (in French), are the “ugliest things,” because in the end we realize that they’re not ugly at all, “but life itself.”

headline: Day After in Vancouver: Dissecting a Failed Run
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — The first question on the minds of Vancouver Canucks fans Thursday morning was: what went so terribly wrong in the Stanley Cup finals?

headline: My Dinner With Prince Philip
text: To the Editor:

headline: Republicans Urge Cuomo to Alter Same-Sex Marriage Bill
text: ALBANY — Several Republican senators in New York are urging Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to consider changing his proposed same-sex marriage bill to better protect religious institutions, addressing a concern that has emerged as one of the bill’s chief obstacles as the legislative session comes to an end.

headline: Venus Williams Loses
text: Venus Williams lost to Daniela Hantuchova, 6-2, 5-7, 6-2, in the quarterfinals of the Eastbourne tournament in England. She was playing her first event in five months since retiring with hip and abdominal injuries during the Australian Open. Williams said she was headed to Wimbledon with plenty of confidence as she targets a sixth title. “I played a lot of matches here, spent a lot of time on the court,” Williams said. “It’s not the best luck today, but I feel good about my preparation.” (AP)

headline: Sleazy Charm, Bloody Ends
text: The past few years have offered impressive European accounts of celebrated career criminals. There was Olivier Assayas’s sprawling “Carlos,” the story of Ilich Ramírez Sánchez, the international killer called Carlos the Jackal, and Jean-François Richet’s “Mesrine: Public Enemy No. 1” and “Mesrine: Killer Instinct,” about the French gangster Jacques Mesrine. Matteo Garrone’s dispassionate, corrosive “Gomorrah” recounted the enterprises of the Camorra, the Neapolitan Mafia.

headline: Gates Stresses the Importance of Ties With Pakistan
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates and the nation’s top military officer said on Thursday that it was critical for the United States to maintain ties with Pakistan despite growing anti-Americanism in the Pakistani military and the worst relationship between the two countries in years.

headline: Delivering a Lawyer Within 15 Minutes (Soda Extra)
text: The wheels of justice tend to be slow, but arrests can happen with lightning speed — and what happens next can be crucial. In searches, seizure and interrogation, things can go badly wrong.

headline: The Best Unknown Park in America
text: CHINLE, Ariz. — On the floor of Canyon de Chelly, what pops up in three dimensions of desert light are the remains of 900-year-old stone apartments, the graveyard of peach trees cut down by Kit Carson’s Indian killers, and sandstone walls that drew the cameras of Edward Curtis and Ansel Adams.

headline: France: C.E.O. of Nuclear Company to Be Replaced
text: One of the most prominent female executives in France was pushed out of her job on Thursday when the French government said it would replace Anne Lauvergeon as chief executive of Areva, one of the world’s largest nuclear power companies. Areva, which she created in 2001 in a merger of other nuclear companies, is majority-owned by the state. Ms. Lauvergeon, 51, will be succeeded by Luc Oursel, also 51, who had headed Areva’s nuclear reactor business before becoming chief operating officer. Her departure at the end of the month caps a struggle with Henri Proglio — a favorite of President Nicolas Sarkozy — who runs the state electric utility, an important Areva customer.

headline: Umenyiora Says Giants Broke Contract Pledge

headline: RIM Profit Falls Below Estimates

text: The Bloomberg administration says that by arresting more than 350,000 people for having small amounts of marijuana since 2002, the police have helped drive down serious crime — and that the consequences for the people locked up have been minimal.

headline: Same-Sex Marriage Opponents Frustrated in N.Y. Lobbying
text: ALBANY — The Rev. Duane R. Motley, a Baptist minister, stood in a marble hallway in the Capitol on Thursday, frustrated. Behind the closed door, all of the Senate Republicans were meeting with one of the state’s most prominent supporters of same-sex marriage, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. But Mr. Motley, a leading opponent of same-sex marriage, could not get the same audience.

headline: Epistemology and the End of the World

headline: How’s the Weather?
text: LATELY, the Sun has been behaving a bit strangely. In 2008 and 2009, it showed the least surface activity in nearly a century. Solar flare activity stopped cold and weeks and months went by without any sunspots, or areas of intense magnetism. Quiet spells are normal for the Sun, but researchers alive today had never seen anything like that two-year hibernation.

headline: A Schizophrenic, a Slain Worker, Troubling Questions
text: BOSTON — Last November, Yvette Chappell found herself increasingly anxious that her 27-year-old son, Deshawn James Chappell, was spiraling downward into deep psychosis. He was exhibiting intense paranoia and calling late at night to complain about deafening voices in his head.

headline: Those Manly Men of Yore

Weiner of New York, who announced Thursday that he would resign, just over a week after admitting he’d sent sexually explicit photographs and messages to women over the Internet.

headline: At Bronx High School, Field Is 20 Yards Short of Being a Home
text: For decades it has been an inconvenience bordering on embarrassment. Herbert H. Lehman High School, with an enrollment of more than 4,000 students in the Bronx, has never played a home football game simply because its field, at 80 yards, is too short for regulation contests.

text: In the landmark Miranda case, the Supreme Court ruled that the Constitution’s guarantee against self-incrimination required that police warn criminal suspects about their right to remain silent and to have a lawyer present when they are taken into custody for questioning.

headline: East Tennessee’s Unruly Unionists
text: When the East Tennessee Convention reconvened on June 17 in Greeneville, a small town near the North Carolina border, the Union-minded delegates assembled on what was technically Confederate soil — though nothing in their defiant tone acknowledged the fact.

headline: China: Media Coverage of a Study Embarrasses Party
text: A media storm over corrupt officials is embarrassing China’s Communist Party as it prepares to celebrate its 90th birthday on July 1. The news coverage has focused on a study circulating on the Internet claiming that corrupt officials have fled the country with more than $100 billion since the mid-1990s, mainly to the United States. It is unclear who wrote the 71-page study, which is marked “internal material” but has no author, letterhead or other identifying features. It was reported to have been posted on the Web site of the People’s Bank of China. It remains online, but not on the bank’s Web site.

headline: Wuerffel Found to Have Disorder
text: The last time Danny Wuerffel was in Birmingham, Ala., it was 2002 and he considered his trip serious business. Dr. James Andrews, the noted orthopedic surgeon, was examining Wuerffel’s shoulder, which he had injured while playing quarterback for the Washington Redskins.

headline: Public Gardens Turn on the Charm
text: IF you are still bummed by the endless 2011 winter and sunless spring, here’s a way to put your blues away: Get out into a public garden. They weathered many tough months too, but they’ve recovered, are full of color and ready to charm. In mid-May I toured Western and Central Connecticut, visiting gardens of varying size, style and spirit. Here are five favorites.

headline: Pretty in Petals
text: Four public gardens in Western Connecticut offer something for everybody.

headline: The Rewards of Renewal
text: In “Self-Renewal,” a landmark book on how societies innovate, John W. Gardner wrote that the task for every new generation was not to “stand a dreary watch over the ancient values” but to face the “bracing truth that it is their task to re-create those values continuously in their own behavior, facing the dilemmas and catastrophes of their own time.” Society, he added, was not “like a machine that is created at some point in time and then maintained with a minimum of effort; a society is being continuously re-created, for good or ill, by its members. This will strike some as a burdensome responsibility, but it will summon others to greatness.”

headline: Concern for Vast Social Services Database on the City’s Neediest
text: New York City has spent the past 18 months developing a database on four million residents, most of them the city’s neediest, which officials say will enhance social services but which advocates for the poor say could put their privacy at risk.

headline: Who Is James Johnson?
text: Most political scandals involve people who are not really enmeshed in the Washington establishment — people like Representative Anthony Weiner or Representative William Jefferson. Most scandals involve spectacularly bad behavior — like posting pictures of your private parts on the Web or hiding $90,000 in cash in your freezer.

headline: Young Chicagoans With Varied Opinions
text: About a mile from President Obama’s 2012 re-election headquarters, a crowd of young Republicans was swelling at an Irish bar. If Republicans in Democrat-ruled cities like Chicago sometimes sound lonely and gloomy, particularly with a hometown Democrat in the White House, they were anything but that now.

headline: Many Choices in the G.O.P. Field
text: The Republicans who bellied up to the bar at a trendy restaurant here Wednesday for an evening of drinks and politics agreed on neither the beverages they sipped nor the presidential candidates they backed. But as the servers took order after order, and as the drinks fueled spirited conversations on the fledgling presidential campaign, one thing was clear: nobody felt as though they lacked choices.

headline: A Sneaky Attack on Clean Water Rules
text: Congress often kills or delays federal regulations it doesn’t like by simply denying agencies the money they need to carry them out. This spares Congress from actually debating the regulation on its merits.

headline: Libya and the War Powers Act

However, Mr. Obama cannot evade his responsibility, under the War Powers Act, to seek Congressional approval to continue the operation.

headline: City Reduces Chronic Absenteeism in Public Schools
text: At Public School 309 in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, students wear necklaces with colorful pendants, each marking a month in which they did not miss a day of school. At P.S. 75 in the South Bronx, a row of young adults welcomes students each morning as they walk in the door. Some 40,000 city children got daily automated wake-up calls from Magic Johnson and other celebrities to remind them to show up for class, and City Hall offered prizes like baseball tickets and gift certificates.

headline: Friday: Hunter With Rough Hair
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Ah, Fridays. Based on the mail I get, I would have to say that reactions to the late week puzzles vary widely. There are those of you who avoid the trickier grids like the plague, only venturing into the early week puzzles for fear of defeat at the hands of those evil themeless constructors. There are also quite a few of you who only do the late week puzzles because they are the only ones that pose a real challenge to you. Still some of you, who shall remain nameless, do only the Saturday grid blindfolded, using only every third down clue, mentally translating everything into Latin while reciting the whole of Shakespeare’s works backward. Whatever works for you, is my philosophy.

headline: Wall Street Braces for New Layoffs as Profits Wane

headline: Fun (Actually in the Water!) on the Trinity River

On a Thursday night in early June, several hundred people, mostly young adults, stripped to their swimsuits and floated atop inner tubes on the Trinity River clutching soda and beer cans while listening to Josh Weathers & the True Endeavors playing on a stage on the west bank above a sign that read “Trinity River Vision.”

headline: Memory Implant Gives Rats Sharper Recollection
text: Scientists have designed a brain implant that restored lost memory function and strengthened recall of new information in laboratory rats — a crucial first step in the development of so-called neuroprosthetic devices to repair deficits from dementia, stroke and other brain injuries in humans.

headline: Information Officer Is Leaving
text: Vivek Kundra, the White House’s first chief information officer, will leave in August after two and a half years in the post. Mr. Kundra is leaving to become a joint fellow at Harvard University’s John F. Kennedy School of Government and the Berkman Center for Internet and Society, said Jacob J. Lew, the White House budget director, in a blog post Thursday. A successor to Mr. Kundra was not immediately named. The announcement comes as the administration is preparing to spend roughly $80 billion this year on technology, financing that includes upgrading thousands of federal data programs and worker e-mail.

headline: Greece Replaces Finance Minister
text: ATHENS — After a week of social and political turmoil, and under mounting pressure to push through new austerity measures, Prime Minister George Papandreou named a new finance minster on Friday as part of a broad cabinet reshuffle aimed at restoring confidence among Greeks and foreign creditors.

text: The story so far: McKinsey released the alleged results of a study showing that large numbers of firms will drop health insurance coverage once the Affordable Care Act goes fully into effect. text: A quick, belated note on the IMF’s decision to ban Stan Fischer from contending because he’s over 65: how cheesy.
