text: Tony Hayward and Nathaniel Rothschild’s acquisition vehicle Vallares said Friday that it had raised 1.35 billion pounds ($2.18 billion) as it seeks out oil and gas companies and assets.

headline: What Are Your Favorite Summer Hangouts?
text: In New York City, an area in Queens called the Rockaways has emerged as a favorite destination for the young and hip. And every June, people flock to Great Smoky Mountains National Park in Tennessee to experience the annual natural “light show” put on by fireflies. Where do you like to go in the summer, for both fun and special moments?

headline: The Early Word: Heckled Out
text: From Today’s Times:

headline: At Petersen Automotive Museum, a Salute to the Scoot
text: The image of scooters often includes the cool (think Gregory Peck and Audrey Hepburn in “Roman Holiday”) and the quirky (almost everyone else), and now the entire spectrum is on display in Los Angeles.

headline: Making Choices ‘as if the Future Matters’
text: Diane Coyle is a British economist who blogs at The Enlightened Economist and is an active Twitter user. Her previous book, “The Soulful Science,” examined the revival of economics as a field relevant to the rest of us, and her latest book is called “The Economics of Enough.”

headline: Paris Show Spotlights Caillebotte Brothers
text: Gustave and Martial Caillebotte, wealthy men about town, shared lodgings on the Boulevard Haussmann in the fashionable, newly-built Eighth Arrondissement of fin-de-siècle Paris. From there, Martial, an enthusiastic amateur photographer, and his brother, a dilettante painter of exceptional talent, observed and chronicled the daily life of the belle époque.

headline: Syrian Town Is Strained by Flood of Refugees
text: AIN al-BEIDA, Syria — Final exams were canceled in this farming village, but the concrete schoolhouse is full. The students have been replaced by anxious families seeking shelter from a violent crackdown on antigovernment protesters that has spread in recent weeks here to the rural northwestern corner of Syria.

headline: Tip of the Week: Using Search Engines for Higher Math
text: The ability of search engines to calculate basic arithmetic right in the search box is well known, but some can handle higher math as well. Both Bing and Google can perform trigonometric functions like sine, cosine and tanget when the sin, cos and tan operators are typed into the search box. For example, typing “sin 45 degrees” and hitting the Enter key brings a result of 0.707107 — with no digging around for a calculator. Microsoft has a full list of mathematical operations that work with Bing here; a similar list for Google is here.

headline: A Postcard From 1912 Returns to Brooklyn
Father’s Day and the Vacation Dilemma
text: A widely quoted recent study done by American Express says that only 46 percent of business owners are planning to take a vacation this year — down from 67 percent in 2006. Given the economy, gas prices and rising airfares, this probably will surprise few business owners. For entrepreneurs, the decision of whether to take a vacation can be complicated and gut-wrenching.

headline: Mobile Shopping Set to Spike, Says Forrester
text: 6:40 p.m. | Updated  to reflect that the graphic above refers to billions of dollars, not millions.

headline: The Very Quiet Revolution
text: At the end of Lebanon’s 15-year civil war, in 1990, Beirut’s downtown was an apocalyptic scene of rubble and weeds, inhabited by squatters in skeletal buildings and bored soldiers moving among sewage-filled craters. The rare splash of color came from the blue advertisements for a billboard company that read: “What do our boards have in common with the C.I.A.? They’re both all over the place.” In the two decades since then, Beirut has become a monument to globalism, home to Louis Vuitton, Chanel and the priciest hotels, the power of capitalism concealing but never really healing the war’s scars. Among the chrome-and-glass buildings downtown stands a grand statue of Riyadh al-Solh, a founder of modern Lebanon, looking like a fat and happy pasha. And beneath that statue, in a patch of bare sand he calls the Square of Change, sits a lonely man named Tony Daoud.

headline: Storyseller
text: Amanda Hocking, the star of self-publishing, was sitting in the front seat of her Ford Escape earlier this spring when she spotted a messenger delivering flowers to her home in Austin, Minn. She watched her best friend and roommate, Eric Goldman, get the door.

headline: The Video Explorer
text: About five years ago, a prodigious young French filmmaker named Vincent Moon reinvented the music video. Filming in an intimate cinéma vérité style in odd locations, mostly around Paris, Moon created dozens and dozens of raw, enigmatic clips that stripped away everything but the performer and the song. He put musicians in awkward situations, and the results were magnetic. He set up the band Phoenix, already fairly famous at that point, as buskers in a sea of tourists outside the Eiffel Tower; the National sat crammed elbow to elbow around a picnic table in the South of France; Yo La Tengo played a Troggs cover amid squealing schoolchildren in Montmartre. But it was the clip of Arcade Fire — 10 of them, strings, horns, xylophone, guitar — packed into an elevator and singing, with the rip of magazine pages for percussion, that came to represent Moon’s innovative new oeuvre. A combination cool-hunter and documentarian, Moon proved it’s possible to reinvent an old, tired format (the music video) using the very thing (the Internet) that supposedly killed it.

headline: How My Mom Discovered Crack
text: It was 1985. I was 12 and standing next to my mother in a police station in Greenwich Village. She was a pretty red-haired gal in her late 30s, but the three police officers she was talking to weren’t looking at her. They were looking at the bag of crack vials she had in her hands, confused about what they were. I wasn’t confused. We had a lot of crack vials in our apartment at that point. Hundreds of them. My brothers and I played with them in Washington Square Park. We carried them around in our pockets the way other kids carried marbles.

headline: Lights Out
text: To put Andrew Rice’s “Bulb In, Bulb Out” in perspective: More than 100 years ago, Robert Louis Stevenson’s “Plea for Gas Lamps” grieved the passing of the evening lamplighter and ranted against the horror of electric light. “The word ‘electricity’ now sounds the note of danger. . . . A new sort of urban star now shines out nightly, horrible, unearthly, obnoxious to the human eye; a lamp for a nightmare! Such a light as this should shine only on murders and public crime or along the corridors of lunatic asylums, a horror to heighten horror. To look at it only once is to fall in love with gas, which gives a warm domestic radiance.” Technologies past are always “warmer” than the harsh, cold, high-tech future, even in the 19th century.

headline: Doctor’s Order
text: I have a chronic medical condition, which is being treated with injections every other week. The drug has a potentially deadly side effect that can occur without warning, after years of symptom-free doses and days after an injection. The treatment for this side effect is epinephrine, which I carry with me as a precaution. My doctor recently announced that after each injection, I must wait 30 minutes before leaving the clinic. There is no reason I would be able to use an Epi-pen after 30 minutes but not before, but he says, “These are new guidelines from the manufacturer, and I won’t allow you to be dosed unless you agree to comply with them, here and now.” Is this a textbook example of coercion? Thinking that term might be hyperbole, I looked up various definitions, many of which apply. P. C., NORWELL, MASS.

headline: Grumpus Maximus
text: I think about your HBO show, “Lucky Louie,” which lasted just one season, and I think, I’ve seen your penis.  That’s exactly right. It wasout there.

headline: ‘Underneath Every Hoarder Is a Normal Person Waiting to Be Dug Out’
text: In 1947, Erich Fromm, a humanist, psychoanalyst and philosopher, developed a theory of character that divided people into five “orientations,” mostly determined by their relationship to stuff. He characterized four of these — the receptive, exploitive, hoarding and marketing orientations — as part of the “having” mode, which is focused on consuming, obtaining and possessing. (The fifth orientation was “productive,” which focuses on experience and human connection.) Fromm specifically linked the hoarding orientation to the Protestant work ethic and the American merchant middle class and argued that this orientation is characterized by, among other things, being “constipated and squinty.”

headline: Washington Fallout From Weiner’s Resignation
text: The Twitter scandal that engulfed Representative Anthony D. Weiner played out its final scene on Thursday in New York, amid lurid catcalls, screaming tabloid headlines and expressions of contrition by the fallen lawmaker.

headline: Merkel Changes Stance on Aid to Greece
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany retreated Friday from demands that private financial institutions be pressured to participate in efforts to rescue the Greek economy, a compromise that seemed to offer some breathing space in Europe’s efforts to confront its potentially ruinous debt crisis.

headline: Leonard Green and CVC Bid for BJ’s Wholesale
text: Leonard Green & Partners and CVC Capital Partners have teamed up with to buy BJ’s Wholesale Club, which announced earlier this year that it was exploring a sale.

headline: T Exclusive Video | Louis Vuitton
text: In this video, Marc Jacobs gives us a behind-the-scenes look at the Louis Vuitton fall/winter 2012 campaign.

headline: Bullwinkle, Rejoice
text: The federal government has reinstated endangered species protection for the Virginia northern flying squirrel, also known as the West Virginia northern flying squirrel, also known as the inspiration for Rocket J. Squirrel, the airborne mammalian superhero and nemesis of Boris Badenov and Natasha Fatale.

headline: What You’re Reading This Summer: The Results of Our Survey
text: Update: June 7, 2012: We’re asking people to talk about #summerreading on Twitter today, and blogging about it. We also have a summer-long reading contest going that starts June 15. Join in!

headline: Beecher’s — Cheesemaking on Display in Manhattan
text: Beecher’s Handmade Cheese, which has been making and selling cheeses in the Pike Place Market in Seattle for the last seven years, will open a cheese-making factory, retail store and restaurant in the Flatiron district on June 24. They’ve taken over 8,000 square feet of space on three levels in a landmark building, where a gleaming steel 8,000 gallon milk tank stands at attention and cheesemakers are at work over troughs of curds and whey in a huge room enclosed in glass. Above it is a mezzanine with tables for 25 where customers can take the sandwiches, salads, panini, soups, and other items sold on the main floor.

headline: Offering Complete, Rothschild Company to Seek Energy Deals
text: 8:34 p.m. | Updated

headline: Hopes for Greek Bailout Help Most Shares Gain
text: Stock prices stabilized on Friday and the euro was higher as increased hopes for a Greek bailout gave major indexes their first weekly gain since April.

headline: Friday Reading: Criminal Lawyers On Call for $4.95 A Month
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: City School Funds Were Spent Elsewhere, Lawmakers Say
text: Did the city withdraw more than $200 million in financing for public schools after the state gave it that amount of money to help avert some of the threatened school budget cuts and teacher layoffs?

headline: Wall Street's Summer of Discontent
text: The biggest names on Wall Street - Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, Bank of America - are preparing for a round of cost cutting and layoffs. DealBook takes a look at why finance is cutting back.

headline: Graham Packaging Clinches $4.5 Billion Sale
text: Silgan Holdings and Graham Packaging have terminated their $4.1 billion deal, clearing the way for Reynolds Group Holdings to acquire Graham.

headline: Why Wall Street Is Cutting Back
text: The biggest names on Wall Street — Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, Bank of America — are preparing for a round of cost-cutting and layoffs. Goldman Sachs alone is planning to cut $1 billion from its noncompensation expenses over the next 12 months, roughly 10 percent of the total. DealBook’s Susanne Craig and Adrienne Carter discuss why Wall Street is cutting back and what it means for earnings and stock prices.

headline: Woody Allen Gets His Biggest Roll-Out
text: Woody is going wide. Sony Pictures Classics said Thursday that it planned to increase the number of theaters showing Woody Allen’s new time-traveling comedy “Midnight in Paris,” to 1,038 screens, the widest release of any of Mr. Allen’s films. “Midnight in Paris,” which has been well-received by critics, has earned more than $16 million in the United States and more than $18.3 million overseas, where in recent years Mr. Allen has found a much bigger audience than he enjoys at home. (His last critically successful film, “Vicky Christina Barcelona,” earned $23.2 million in the United States and $73.2 million internationally, according to boxofficemojo.com.)

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Wall Street Braces for New Layoffs as Profits Wane  |  Wall Street plans to get smaller this summer. Faced with weak markets and uncertainty over regulations, many of the biggest firms are preparing for deep cuts in jobs and other costs.

headline: Weiner Is Gone, but His Staff Will Hold the Fort
text: When Representative Anthony D. Weiner announced his resignation from Congress on Thursday at a center for the elderly in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, where he had started his first campaign for City Council 20 years earlier, his Washington office sat locked and shuttered.

headline: Wear Resort Now | Scuba Suits
text: Resort’s must-have swimwear makes us lustful for no-fuss, color-blocked geometric maillots right now — even though we know we’re supposed to wait for winter holiday. In fact, resort was swimming in surf wear. Michael Kors, Chanel and Jason Wu, to name a few, showed scuba-styled, wet-suit-inspired pieces, while Burberry Prorsum, Zero Maria Cornejo, Preen and Juan Carlos Obando took advantage of neoprene accents and neon colors. And how we adored Lisa Marie Fernandez’s front-zipper dive-suit bikini, which left us panting for flippers. But wait! We can dip our toes in right now (see below).

headline: McIlroy Runs Away With the Lead
text: BETHESDA, Md. — Through 35 holes of the 111th United States Open, Rory McIlroy was in a zone of his own, scorching Congressional Country Club with birdies — almost at will — and strutting as close to perfection as any golfer has during this annual survival test.

headline: Early Music Festival: Quicksilver at Night
text: BOSTON — Talk about musicians who work hard for the love of it: at 11:30 on Wednesday night, Quicksilver, a period-instrument sextet, took the stage at Emmanuel Church to play a program of vigorous, texturally rich sonatas from the dawn of the Baroque era. The lateness of the hour was not so unusual: the Boston Early Music Festival, which presented the concert, has always offered late- night performances, and the concept has taken root elsewhere too (at Lincoln Center, for example, which has offered refreshing late performances, particularly after Mostly Mozart concerts, in recent years).

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: China: Maritime Patrols on the Rise
text: China is increasing its maritime surveillance force to 15,000 people by 2020, up from 9,000 now, according to a report on Friday in China Daily, an English-language newspaper. By 2015, the aviation branch of the force, which is officially civilian in nature and operates under the State Ocean Administration, will have 16 aircraft; the sea patrol fleet will have 350 vessels by then, and 520 by 2020, the report said.

headline: High-Horsepower Porsche 911s Recalled for Premature Wear of Wheel Hubs
text: Porsche is recalling about 1,700 of its most powerful 911s from 2010-11 because wheel hubs may wear prematurely, resulting in a compromised wheel-retention system that could lead to a crash, the automaker told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: He’s Created a Monster: Alan Ball Talks ‘True Blood’
text: As anticipation grows for the June 26 season premiere of “True Blood” on HBO, an article in this weekend’s Arts & Leisure section looks at Anna Paquin, her trajectory on the show and what Season 4 holds in store for Sookie Stackhouse. Of course, Ms. Paquin would have no lines to speak, and never know when to bare her neck or shed her clothes if not for Alan Ball, the “True Blood” creator and producer, who adapted the series from Charlaine Harris‘s best-selling “Southern Vampire Mysteries” novels.

headline: No Season for Loners: People (and Penguins) Stick Together in Films
text: LOS ANGELES — “The films of a nation reflect its mentality in a more direct way than other artistic media.”

headline: Jean Paul Gaultier — Sidewalk to Catwalk
text: The designer’s first retrospective, in Montreal, is a definitive look at his creations.

headline: Filtering of Tainted Water Begins at Japanese Plant
text: TOKYO — The Tokyo Electric Power Company, the utility trying to contain the crisis at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, took a significant step forward on Friday when it began operating a huge filtration system that it hopes will ease the amount of contaminated water produced at its damaged reactors.

headline: Arizona Town Cashes In on a Rock Song
text: WINSLOW, Ariz. — Repeat the lyric, “Well, I’m a standin’ on a corner in Winslow, Arizona,” and watch the glint of recognition in people’s eyes.

headline: On Location, in a Cryptic Sort of Way
text: The film crew began setting up around 6 p.m. Thursday in front of the Apple Store on Broadway and West 67th Street. By nightfall, cameras were rolling and the star hopped out of a black sport utility vehicle to shoot the scene.

headline: From Jackie Robinson to Dead Silence
text: There is no Latin American Jackie Robinson, no single Hispanic ballplayer who lifted his people onto his back and crashed through baseball’s racist barricades. But there always has to be a first, and many of the game’s historians point to two Cubans, Rafael Almeida and Armando Marsans, who made their debut with the Cincinnati Reds a century ago. Of course, baseball was still segregated then. The Reds took great pains to highlight the irreproachable ethnicities of their newest employees: yes, they were Cuban, but they were purebred Spaniards, without so much as a trace of African blood.

headline: Fathers More Active, and More Absent
text: It’s the time of year when everyone seems to be taking the measure of Dad.

headline: The Situation at Pitti
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#405", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

headline: On the Hunt For a Better 401(k) Plan
text: It generally isn’t easy to make improvements to your 401(k) plan.

headline: How Hitler Could Have Won
text: How did the Wehrmacht, the best fighting force, lose World War II? The reader seeking the answer to this question, posed by Andrew Roberts in his splendid history, will be treated to a brilliantly clear and accessible account of the war in all of its theaters: Asian, African and European. Roberts’s descriptions of soldiers and officers are masterly and humane, and his battlefield set pieces are as gripping as any I have ever read. He has visited many of the battlefields, and has an unusually good eye for detail as well as a painterly skill at physical description. (His nearly perfect sense of terrain and geography is marred only by his regrettable conflation of Russia with the Soviet Union, which leads to confusion about battlefield locations, German war aims and Soviet casualties.) He is just as much at home at sea as on land; from Midway to El Alamein his prose is unerringly precise and stirringly vivid. It is hard to imagine a better-told military history of World War II.

headline: Partners in Wind Power Bridge a Mideast Divide
text: When I first sought out Muhammad Salem, he was awaiting the birth of his fourth child, a girl, at Al-Makassed hospital in East Jerusalem. The baby’s name would go through several iterations in the course of the night. First it was Luna. Then Natalie. Eventually the family would settle on Dina.

headline: How You Solved Your 401(k) Problem
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I tell the tale of Alan Wenker, who spent 10 years hunting for a better 401(k) for his fellow workers and himself.

headline: Sometimes a Vegetable Is Just a Vegetable
text: ON May 1 The New York Times Magazine published an article, “Reaching for Culture That Remains Stubbornly Above My Grasp,” in which Dan Kois wrote about watching certain critically regarded movies, like Andrei Tarkovsky’s “Solaris,” that he likened to eating his “cultural vegetables.” In the June 5 Arts & Leisure section the chief film critics of The Times, Manohla Dargis and A. O. Scott, defended such films, adding to a vigorous, sometimes fractious discussion about so-called boring and slow films that is still continuing, lighting up the blogosphere and beyond, and inspiring hundreds of readers’ comments. They invited Mr. Kois to join them in the still-simmering conversation.

headline: The Central Park Jogger Case Revisited
text: In the wake of the 1989 rape and near-fatal beating of a 28-year-old white woman named Trisha Meili (known to many as the Central Park jogger), and after the arrests, confessions and eventual convictions of one Latino and four African-­American teenagers for the crime, the media relentlessly asked: How did this happen? In her slim but ambitious book, “The Central Park Five: A Chronicle of a City Wilding,” Sarah Burns tackles this same question, but with a changed referent. “This,” rather than signifying a horrific gang rape in New York City’s bucolic backyard, here signifies a preventable miscarriage of justice that put five Harlem teenagers behind bars for a crime they didn’t commit. Each of the boys — Antron McCray, Kevin Richardson, Yusef Salaam, Korey Wise and Raymond Santana Jr. — served between 7 and 13 years. Their convictions were vacated in 2002 by the New York State Supreme Court, after a confession and DNA analysis linked a serial rapist, Matias Reyes, to the crime.

headline: Bob or Bun? A Ballerina’s Tough Choice
text: EVERYONE has bad hair days, but just consider the plight of the ballerina: her locks are teased, sprayed and shellacked into submission. For dancers split ends or an unruly cowlick are first-world problems. What about receding hairlines caused by scraping the hair, day in and day out, into a bun?

headline: Reporting Under Fire: a Survey of a Century of War Correspondents
text: MANCHESTER, England — Within a few hundred yards of each other in Old Trafford lie the Manchester United Football Club and the Imperial War Museum North. One is a monument to the global sport that unites continents and peoples, the other a monument to the study of forces that divide and despoil them.

headline: Nasdaq Said to Seek Stake in London Clearinghouse
text: Nasdaq OMX wants to take a minority stake in LCH.Clearnet, the London-based swaps clearinghouse, as the exchange operator heads into another stand-off with its rival, NYSE Euronext.

headline: Financial Advice Gleaned From a Day in the Hot Seat
text: WHEN I started writing this column almost three years ago, one of my goals was to figure out what the wealthiest Americans knew and pass along those lessons to middle- and upper-middle-class readers.

headline: Eleanor Henderson, Author of “Ten Thousand Saints”; Asti Hustvedt, Author of “Medical Muses”
text: This week: Eleanor Henderson discusses her debut novel, “Ten Thousand Saints,” and the straight-edge music scene; Asti Hustvedt on her book, “Medical Muses: Hysteria in Nineteenth Century Paris”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: Taming a Mountain Road With Horses and Cars
text: PINKHAM NOTCH, N.H

headline: A Course That Tests Reflexes and Vertigo
text: IN 1899 it took F. O. and Flora Stanley about two hours and 10 minutes to reach the top of Mount Washington in their Stanley Locomobile. That did not include the time it took to stop, find and add water, which is a good thing to have if you depend on steam power.

headline: American Star Shines in Hall of Mirrors
text: PARIS — In a back room at the Palace of Versailles, Marie-Antoinette’s secret lover was informing her that their love affair had come to a dramatic conclusion.

headline: Bin Laden Indictments Dismissed
text: Six weeks after Osama bin Laden’s death, a federal judge in Manhattan on Friday formally dismissed a series of indictments that had remained pending against the former Qaeda leader. They were originally brought more than a decade ago.

headline: The Politics of Food Aid
text: One of the world's biggest charities said that the American food aid system may hurt the people it aims to help.

headline: The Fairy Tale Continues: A Musical About Susan Boyle
text: She rose to fame in a YouTube second in 2009, her autobiography came out last year, and now the swift mythologizing of the cultural phenomenon known as SuBo seems to be gaining even more speed, Agence France-Presse reported. On Friday plans were announced for a new stage musical of the life of Susan Boyle, the best-selling singer discovered as a contestant on “Britain’s Got Talent,” who has since sold more than 10 million copies of her recordings.

headline: As if You Don’t Have Enough to Read
text: Inspired by The Guardian’s recent list of the 100 greatest nonfiction books, we here at the magazine decided to create our own list. Dispensing with all pretense to rigor — it’s a list, silly! — we simply asked each member of the staff to pick their five favorites. The complete list is after the jump. But here a few details:

headline: The Gift Apartment From Mom and Dad
text: FOR some parents, an engraved pen set just won’t cut it as a graduation present. It seems so insubstantial, so unoriginal. Anyway, the kid will just lose it. So how about a New York apartment?

headline: Paradoxical Storytelling for Children
text: A tiger lies on the parquet floor of a deserted room, telling lies to a newly awakened stone statue: Long ago, the tiger says, he had a family, but he was shot and stuffed with straw, and glass baubles were sewn where his eyes had been. Later, however, he says he was made in a factory out of artificial fibers. Which story is true?

headline: A Beachcomber’s Guide to Growing Up
text: Sometimes things don’t happen exactly the way you want them to happen. In this gentle tale of growing up, 9-year-old Alice Rice learns that even though she’s growing older, life is seldom about achieving perfection. She senses this in the very first paragraph of the story, by Kevin Henkes, a Newbery Honor winner and Caldecott medalist, as her family crosses the bridge that connects the Florida mainland to the island they visit every winter. Alice, who ordinarily enjoys being suspended between two worlds, suddenly feels strange. “Her breath caught high in her chest and she became light-headed. It seemed as though there wasn’t enough air in the car.”

headline: Violent Clashes as Thousands Protest in Cities Across Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Thousands of protesters poured into the streets in the suburbs of Damascus, Syria, and in three of the country’s five largest cities on Friday, in a weekly show of defiance that came days before President Bashar al-Assad was expected to address Syrians for the first time in two months. Activists said at least 19 people were killed and dozens wounded.

headline: Saudi Women Defy Driving Ban
text: Updated | 3:15 p.m. Although random acts of women driving were reported in major cities across Saudi Arabia on Friday, the protest against the longstanding ban appears to have been smaller than initially anticipated after the Saudi government imprisoned a main organizer for nine days last month.

headline: Shorts Sale
text: If you can buy just one pair of shorts this summer, try slim-fitting chinos in either khaki or navy. When you’re ready to branch out, consider a more adventurous print, like these from Sunny Sports. You’d be surprised how well batik, ikat, baja and nautical stripes integrate into your exist- ing warm-weather staples.

headline: Little Frogs, Big Family
text: Poky puppies may take the prize in the charm category in Picture Book Land, but the natural spring in a young frog’s step has its own special appeal for newly mobile toddlers. With growing confidence in their ability to go where they please, 2- and 3-year-olds begin their first, tentative experiments in independent exploration, suddenly deciding one day to check out the far side of the playground, for example — though typically not before first making sure that Mom or Dad is keeping a weather eye on their adventure.

headline: Fresh From Europe, a Japan-Built Wagon
text: AS the world has grown smaller, Americans have acquired tastes that were once foreign. Soccer, si. Sushi, yum. The Euro-style sport wagon? Forget it.

headline: Bookshelf: Farm
text: HOGWASH!  By Karma Wilson. Illustrated by Jim McMullan.  40 pp. Little, Brown. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 6)

headline: Graphic Book Best Sellers: Wonder Woman and Zombies
text: At No. 1 on the hardcover list this week is “Wonder Woman: Odyssey,” in which the superheroine wakes up to find that someone has altered her past. She sets out – in a new costume – to find out what went wrong. This is the first half of the journey, written by J. Michael Straczynski and illustrated by Don Kramer. About halfway through the story, Mr. Straczynski departed to work on a sequel to “Superman: Earth One,” an interpretation of the Man of Steel’s origin for today’s audience. The first installment of that story hit No. 1 in our hardcover list in November. Phil Hester, who took over the Wonder Woman story, has two installments in “Odyssey” that were helped along by the original writer’s notes. Of course, they’ll likely be more tinkering with the Amazing Amazon’s origin in September when DC Comics restarts the majority of its superhero series with new number ones.

headline: An Unvarnished Critique of Your Finances
text: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, writes about the experience of having his financial life examined by eight wealthy men, all members of an investment club called Tiger 21.

headline: Archbishop Calls Gay Marriage Bill an ‘Ominous Threat’
text: ALBANY — Timothy M. Dolan, the Roman Catholic archbishop of New York, who has been a low-key presence during the debate over same-sex marriage in the state, called in to a capital radio talk show Friday morning to warn that the proposed legislation posed an “ominous threat” to society.

headline: All Those Online Videos, Still Chasing an Audience
text: DRUMBEAT would be too strong a word. But in recent months there’s been a steady patter of news indicating a fresh urgency in the world of original Web series: projects involving high-profile filmmakers, additional rounds of financing, redesigned and expanded video-sharing sites.

headline: Because It’s There
text: For 150 years, the road up Mount Washington in New Hampshire has challenged man, beast and machine.

headline: Montreal Toasts Gaultier
text: “The crowd is ecstatic!” shouted the fashion historian Valerie Steele. She was referring to the more than 2,000 fans at Tuesday’s preview opening of “The Fashion World of Jean Paul Gaultier: From the Sidewalk to the Catwalk,” the designer’s first major solo exhibition, at the Montreal’s Musée des Beaux-Arts. (It opens to the public today.) The guests had lined up for hours in front of the museum to catch a glimpse of the show and, with luck, of the man insiders call “fashion’s enfant terrible.” That proved nearly impossible; every room was packed, with visitors struggling to reach a bar or a faraway friend.

headline: Sax and Cicadas – An Interspecies Jam
text: [April 27, 1:45 p.m. | Update | “Bug Music,” David Rothenberg’s book and CD on insect sounds and human communication and music is out and getting much deserved attention.]

headline: The I.P.Nos
text: The one-day pops usually associated with initial public offerings are looking more like one-day fizzles.

headline: Best Sellers Weekly Graphic: American Historian
text: David McCullough first appeared on the hardcover nonfiction list in 1977. This week, his “Greater Journey” sits atop the list for the second week in a row.

headline: Paperback Row
text: HALF A LIFE: A Memoir,  by Darin Strauss (Random House, $13.) At 18, Strauss was behind the wheel when his Oldsmobile struck and killed a fellow high school student in suburban Long Island. In his subtle yet wrenching book, Strauss, the author of “Chang and Eng” (2000), explores memory, guilt and coming-of-age after a life-altering event.

headline: Ann Patchett’s Amazon Wonder Drug Novel
text: Ann Patchett’s most characteristic subject is the hell turned unlikely paradise, a kind of reverse “Lord of the Flies” in which a group of strangers, shipwrecked into a disaster beyond their imagining, manage nonetheless to create a peaceable habitat where love and decency prevail. Patchett’s best-­selling 2001 novel, “Bel Canto,” opened with a botched terrorist operation in a South American country, after which an American opera diva, a Japanese industrialist, a French ambassador, various Russian businessmen and their Marxist-Leninist guerrilla captors turned their long captivity into a peculiar sort of idyll. “State of Wonder,” Patchett’s eighth book and sixth novel, is no less multinational in its cast of characters, or high-stakes in its plot.

headline: Young Love in Little Russia
text: Magic and magical thinking are the means by which the innocent can acquire power. This accounts for the appeal not only of the Harry Potter books but of adult-minded novels like Michael Chabon’s “Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay.” Now Haley Tanner’s first novel, “Vaclav & Lena,” takes the figure of the young magician and mixes it with a second magical device, the mutual love of a young boy and girl.

headline: Inside the List
text: WOMAN IN BLACK: When Ann Coulter last appeared on the hardcover nonfiction list in 2009, with “Guilty: Liberal ‘Victims’ and Their Assault on America,” some commentators asked whether the conservative attack dog had lost a bit of her sales bite. “Guilty” spent six weeks on the list — an enviable showing by most standards, but a decline from the mark set by “Godless” (12 weeks), “Treason” (13 weeks) and “Slander” (15 weeks).

headline: When Women Lost the Vote
text: I wonder how today’s advice columnists might handle a query John Dunton received in 1691. A London printer and bookseller, Dunton was the great-granddaddy of all agony aunts and uncles. He had offered to answer questions from readers of his periodical, The Athenian Mercury. Someone asked him what a man should do if his mother and his sweetheart were in equal peril at the same time. Which one should he save? Dunton suggested that “we esteem it more generous, were it possible, to die himself than lose either.” Gallant Mr. Dunton appears nearly halfway through Mary Beth Norton’s suggestive if idiosyncratic new book, “Separated by Their Sex.” He is a villain in the story, since Norton assigns him the role of defining women as suited to the soft glories of home life and men as strivers in the public world. His chivalry was part of a larger effort to keep the “fair sex” away from political power. Or so it seems.

headline: David Mamet’s Right-Wing Conversion
text: This is an extraordinarily irritating book, written by one of those people who smugly believe that, having lost their faith, they must ipso facto have found their reason. In order to be persuaded by it, you would have to be open to propositions like this:

headline: The Pseudoscience of Hysteria
text: Readers who can’t identify Jean-Martin Charcot as the name of the French neurologist whose 19th-century experiments with hypnosis influenced Sigmund Freud’s theory of neurosis may yet recognize the work he conducted at the Saltpêtrière Hospital in Paris. Photographs and illustrations of Charcot’s patients, all women suffering hysteria, remain in currency today, 140 years after they were made, if more as curiosities than as clinically valuable documents. Once seen, these images — of, for example, a woman wearing little more than a tangle of bed sheets, her eyes rolled up into her head in either “ecstasy” or “delirium,” or fixed on the invisible object of her “amorous supplication” — are not easily forgotten, let alone dismissed. Poses classified as “passionate attitudes,” they have the disquieting aspect of pornography masquerading as intellectual inquiry.

headline: Story of a Jazz Age Murder
text: Even by the standards of a time when some dozen major New York area newspapers competed for scoops and sensations, the 1927 murder trial of Ruth Snyder and her lover, Judd Gray, was a huge story. The pair, who murdered Snyder’s husband, embodied the sort of colorful contradictions that reporters love — and that novelists are hard-pressed to better.

headline: I’m O.K., You’re a Psychopath
text: Do psychopaths enjoy reading books about psychopaths? In his engagingly irreverent new best seller, The Psychopath Test: A Journey Through the Madness Industry (Riverhead, $25.95), the journalist Jon Ronson notes that only about one in 100 people are psychopaths (there is a higher proportion in prisons and corporate boardrooms), but he wonders if this population will be overrepresented among readers of his book. After all, people do enjoy learning about themselves, and psychopaths in particular have an enhanced sense of their own importance. And they might like what Ronson has to say. He approvingly quotes experts who argue that psychopaths make “the world go around.” Despite their small numbers, they cause such chaos that they remold society — though not necessarily for the better.

headline: Malcolm X: Criminal, Minister, Humanist, Martyr
text: “His aura was too bright,” the poet Maya Angelou said of her first meeting with Malcolm X. “His masculine force affected me physically. A hot desert storm eddied around him and rushed to me, making my skin contract, and my pores slam shut.” Malcolm X had that same sort of bone-deep, visceral impact on America. He got under everyone’s skin — either in the sense that he seeped into your pores and transformed you the way the great love of your life does, or in the sense that he annoyed or scared the living hell out of you. There is no middle ground with Malcolm. If you hate him or distrust him, you should consider giving him another try: officers assigned to monitor the wiretaps on his phones sometimes ended up being flipped, because close listening led them to believe that his programs and philosophies were sensible and righteous and that law enforcement agencies should not have been working against him at all. And while Malcolm’s ideas changed America, his life journey has captivated us even more. He went from a petty criminal and drug user to a long-term prisoner to an influential minister to a separatist political activist to a humanist to a martyr. Throughout his life he continually grew upward, unafraid to challenge or refute what he believed, giving hope that any of us can rise above even our deepest convictions to become better people.

headline: Escaping Hitler, Cracking Up in L.A.
text: The not unimportant but somewhat undervalued writer Heinrich Mann (1871-1950) and his second wife, Nelly Kroeger-Mann, 27 years younger and socially several rungs lower, had suspenseful lives during the great emigration — or cultural diaspora — of the Hitler years, and years of exile thereafter. This could make for a wonderful book if the author exercised sufficient self-control rather than showing off in various ways, and kept the work reasonably concise. Unfortunately, ­Evelyn Juers’s “House of Exile” is not, or not quite, that book.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: ILLUMINATIONS,  by Arthur Rimbaud. Translated by John Ashbery (Norton, $24.95.) Besides his early absorption of Rimbaud’s poetry, Ashbery brings to this resourceful translation a long and deep familiarity with French life, language and culture.

headline: What Physics Owes the Counterculture
text: “What the Bleep Do We Know!?,” a spaced-out concoction of quasi physics and neuroscience that appeared several years ago, promised moviegoers that they could hop between parallel universes and leap back and forth in time — if only they cast off their mental filters and experienced reality full blast. Interviews of scientists were crosscut with those of self-proclaimed mystics, and swooping in to explain the physics was Dr. Quantum, a cartoon superhero who joyfully demonstrated concepts like wave-particle duality, extra dimensions and quantum entanglement. Wiggling his eyebrows, the good doctor ominously asked, “Are we far enough down the rabbit hole yet?” All that was missing was Grace Slick wailing in the background with Jorma Kaukonen on ­guitar.

headline: Life of a Psychohistorian
text: For many years, Robert Jay Lifton has been recognized as a leading “psychohistorian,” or as he prefers to define his vocation, a “historically minded psychiatrist.” Psychohistory is the field of inquiry that explores the psychological motives of individuals and groups of historical actors, as well as the psychological impact of historical events. Lifton is perhaps best known as the author of “Death in Life: Survivors of Hiroshima,” published in 1967, which received a National Book Award. In that book, he described how the hibakusha, those residents of Hiroshima who survived the atomic bomb on Aug. 6, 1945, lived with deep and shameful feelings of being “inwardly poisoned” by their experience, as well as an embittered “sense of special knowledge” that set them apart from those who had not witnessed the horrors of the attack.

headline: Final Curtain
text: Back in the golden age of British detective fiction, the New Zealand author and theater producer Ngaio Marsh set the bar for backstage mysteries with “Enter a Murderer” (1935), distinguished by its realistic theatrical settings and strong dramatic themes. Dame Ngaio still rules, but Peter Lovesey carries on in her honorable tradition with STAGESTRUCK (Soho Crime, $25), a brilliantly conceived and smartly executed mystery set in the hallowed Theater Royal of Bath.

headline: In Panama, a Respite for People and Pelicans
text: I WOKE with the sun and the roosters. The clouds on the horizon hung over the Panama mainland — just 12 miles away, across the wide-mouthed Bay of Panama — in dusty, caramel-colored bands. It was Fat Tuesday on Taboga Island. The night before, sulfurous firecrackers mixed with the sea air as an elaborately dressed Carnival Queen was carried through town to the rolling drums of a marching band. But now San Pedro, a brightly painted tangle of houses woven with footpaths, was still and quiet. At the beach, small waves came ashore like a series of tiny sighs. The only action was in the sky, where brown pelicans made their morning commute, traveling in uneven V-shaped constellations as they hunted fish from above.

headline: Old Cars Still Stars at Beverly Hills Auction
text: Hollywood filmmakers have been treating cars as disposable props for more than a century. Cars, like everything else in a movie, serve the story, and if that means they must be destroyed in the process, so be it. Even the cars that survive filming are treated poorly; they often pile up on studio back lots after their moments of cinematic glory and sit until they’re weathered down to scrap.

headline: Letters: Crowd-Free Colorado
text: To the Editor: Regarding the Practical Traveler column, “Bargain Summer Trips Free From Crowds” (May 29): Winter Park and the Grand Valley offer fabulous golfing on three stunning mountain courses. Dwight Eisenhower thought this valley, the headwaters of the Colorado River, to be the best fly-fishing in the country. Many agree. The southern entrance to Rocky Mountain National park is a few miles away. If you want an authentic Colorado experience for a family, rent a pontoon boat on Grand Lake then take the kids to the rodeo. You can ride at Devil’s Thumb Ranch or the Y.M.C.A. of the Rockies; all are within a few miles of the resort. There are several top-notch restaurants where you can enjoy creative food in a casual environment. Leave your mink coat at home.

headline: Back to Provence
text: THE difference, for the traveler, between a first and repeated visit is crucial. To “go back” is not “to go.” Yet old, familiar places retain a kind of magic, and all the more so when the memories are shared. For our 40th wedding anniversary year, my wife, Elena, and I returned to the place where our marriage began: the South of France. We planned to visit old haunts, the area we’d once called home. Then, we had had all the time in the world; now we could spend a week. Too, there’s a difference between 20-somethings living on a shoestring and tourists “of a certain age” who stay in fine hotels.

headline: Restaurant Report: ING, in Chicago
text: In Chicago’s Fulton Market meatpacking district, the hot restaurant of the moment is Next, where the chef Grant Achatz will change the entire concept behind the menu every three months. Instead of reservations, the owners are selling nonrefundable tickets to dinner, offered, in order, to potential diners who have signed up online. Those who tire of waiting for notification might consider heading just two doors down to iNG, the latest project from Homaro Cantu, Chicago’s other cutting-edge chef.

headline: Blood, Sand, Sherry: Hemingway’s Madrid
text: IN the Legazpi neighborhood of Madrid, a vast complex of early 20th-century buildings of ornate stone and brick sits near the banks of the Manzanares River. For most of the 20th century, the Matadero Madrid, as the compound is known, was the city’s main slaughterhouse; its robust stench lingered far beyond the high stone walls surrounding it and deep into the working-class neighborhood nearby.

headline: California Houses as Celebrities in Themselves
text: PERHAPS the most clichéd Los Angeles tourist activity is the curbside ogling of celebrity homes. But take away the famous residents, and Los Angeles is still the ultimate showplace of American dream houses. With legions of architects and Hollywood set designers equally adept at building a Southern plantation or a medieval Transylvanian castle, it’s no wonder that some streets are lined with English Tudors and Mexican haciendas that somehow look more authentic than anything you’d find in Chichester or Chihuahua.

Hamilton and Anthony James Hamilton of Avenbury, England. The Rev. Otto H. Hentz, a Jesuit priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Augustine in Larchmont.

text: In this video produced by G.K. Haigwood & Meredith Greene Megaw, Heather Purcell and Robert Leja describe meeting through their cycling team in Colorado.

headline: Critics of Drug Industry Attack New Innovations
text: A two-day conference at Georgetown University by some leading critics of the pharmaceutical industry is attacking some of the very innovations that industry says would improve care and reduce costs.

headline: Meghan & Thomas
text: In this homemade video, Meghan Conklin and Thomas McCabe describe how they met in 2000 at a conservationist organization in Washington, DC.

headline: Good Pawlenty? Bad Pawlenty? So Far It’s Been Both
text: The presidential campaign of Tim Pawlenty appears uncertain about just which Tim Pawlenty story they want to showcase right now.

text: In this homemade video, Kristina Carroll and Ty Barnes describe meeting at a mutual friend's barbeque in 2008 in San Francisco.

headline: U.S. Pledges to Raise Deportation Threshold
text: Moving to repair an immigration enforcement program that has drawn rising opposition from governors and police chiefs, senior immigration officials on Friday announced steps they said would focus the program more closely on deporting immigrants convicted of serious crimes.

headline: Ethanol Industry Is Unruffled by Senate Vote Against Tax Breaks
text: The Senate dealt the ethanol industry a rare defeat on Thursday when it voted 73-27 to end the annual $6 billion tax break given to blenders of ethanol, along with a tariff on foreign ethanol intended to protect the domestic industry from Brazilian sugar ethanol imports. The vote was on an amendment to a bill with a very uncertain future, but it did suggest that Congress will be looking at ethanol when it takes an ax to federal spending to get the budget deficit and national debt under control later this summer.

headline: #trendingNYC: The Week on Twitter
text: New Yorkers went to bed on Sunday and woke up on Monday buzzing — and posting — about the Tonys (also  #tonyawards), where a strong slate of nominees, a much-talked about and much-nominated “The Book of Mormon” and a disarming host — that would be Neil Patrick Harris or @ActuallyNPH, as he is known on Twitter — restored the theater awards to a place of unlikely hipness.

headline: Wear Resort Now | Full Body Prints
text: Come November, when resort hits the stores, you’ll see lots of head-to-toe pattern worn in one of two ways: You can either belt a matching top and bottom, à la Marc Jacobs, to look like a pseudo-jumpsuit, or you can wear your patterns all mixed up, à la Thakoon. Either way, this is one trend that can be activated right now with a pair of printed mini shorts, like the cotton ones from Etoile Isabel Marant ($225; go to net-a-porter.com), and an equally busy tank top from your closet. Just remember to stick to the same palette. Or, you could revive that printed onesie you were hoping never to wear again. Courage, girl.

headline: Turn On The TV: ‘Law & Order’ Episode Inspired by ‘Spider-Man’ Airs on Sunday
text: It’s been two days without any “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” headlines but fear not: “Law & Order” is here to fill the gap, ripping the outlines of a script from the much-reported travails of that $70-million superhero musical, which opened on Tuesday.

headline: Exercise and Olives, Part 2
text: The Dalmatian ham with Pag (a salty sheep cheese) that my parents and I ordered recently on the Croatian island of Mljet came with loads of olives. Fourteen, by my count. My mother, who likes olives, took four. My father, whose hatred of olives I’ve inherited, took none. Since I had challenged myself to eat every olive I could this summer in an effort to appreciate what so many of my friends love in them, that left me with 10.

headline: Becoming a Father
text: You don’t become a parent until you have a child. No class can really prepare you, and no conversation can truly make you ready. That said, having a child is just the start. What you think you know the moment they are born will change by the hour.

headline: Another Voice at the Table: Your Plates
text: IF it’s sparkling dinner-table conversation the happy couple is after, maybe they should let the dishes and glasses do the talking, too. These conversation pieces lend an edge to a setting that gold rims and floral motifs could never match. Some dinnerware and glassware come printed with standard sayings; others may be custom-ordered with whatever image, witticism or wise words fit your style. All will elicit a smile (or a smirk).

headline: Oaktree Capital Files to Go Public
text: The Oaktree Capital Group filed for an initial public offering on Friday, the latest alternative asset manager looking to tap into the stock market.

headline: Sony PlayStation Phone: It Lives!
text: The folks at Sony Ericsson have engaged in the sort of experimentation that got Victor Frankenstein in trouble. They have combined a phone and a PlayStation-style keypad to create a gaming phone. Here you may imagine an evil laugh and crash of thunder if you wish.

headline: Open Arms for Yankees, but Bats Can’t Deliver
text: CHICAGO — It had been eight years since the Yankees visited Wrigley Field, so for their return Friday, the City of Broad Shoulders opened its arms wide for them. The weather obliged, producing an idyllic June afternoon. A block party outside peddled New York-style hotdogs. And the Chicago Cubs cooperated by offering up a starting pitcher, Doug Davis, who had yet to win any of his six starts this season.

headline: Company Led by Potential Astros Buyer Was Fined for Violations
text: As Major League Baseball investigates Jim Crane’s $680 million deal to buy the Houston Astros, it will be easy for its officials to find the public information about federal crimes committed by two executives of his former company, Eagle Global Logistics, a freight-forwarding company based in Houston.

headline: Bob Lutz, Car Guy, on the Make in Manhattan
text: Robert A. Lutz, the former General Motors vice chairman, made whistle stops around New York this week to promote his new book, “Car Guys vs. Bean Counters: The Battle for the Soul of American Business.” He appeared Monday night at the Russian Tea Room in midtown on a program for the Hudson Union Society and spent the rest of the week doing radio and television appearances.

headline: Gravlax, Party Food Without a Party
text: GRAVLAX is party food, the kind of thing I used to whip up for large, boisterous cocktail parties in my energetic pre-child days. The recipe started with an entire side of salmon and ended three days later when I carefully carved the fish, one rosy, gossamer sliver at a time.

headline: An Actor, Inventor, Accountant, and Now, a 9/11 Victim
text: Jerry J. Borg was a bit-part actor and a small-time inventor, but his day job was as an accountant for New York State. On Sept. 11, 2001, he was working in an office a block or two from the World Trade Center.

headline: A Good Appetite: Gravlax on the Grill
text: Most gravlax is served cured and cold, as with my version with fennel and tarragon. But recently, my friend Jeff Joseph told me about his innovative gravlax recipe, which requires a grill.

headline: The Minimalist: Cold Pea Soup
text: This Minimalist recipe comes from July 2001, an age of relative innocence (and youth!), or so it seems to me now. The column was on weeknight entertaining, made possible by a menu of make-ahead dishes, including white bean and garlic dip, green salad with fresh mild herbs and hazelnut oil, puréed fresh pea soup, salmon with cherry tomatoes en papillote, and coeur à la crème (that creamy French concoction that’s often chilled in heart-shaped molds and served with fresh fruit). Of these, only the salmon and dessert strike me as dated — the former because salmon no longer seems nearly as good and guilt-free as it did a decade ago, and the latter because these days I rarely indulge in desserts that are 80 percent full-fat dairy and 20 percent sugar, as coeur à la crème is.

headline: Lessons From I.B.M.; Consensus On Health Care; Financial History That Rhymes.
text: This week: Jeff Sommer with Steve Lohr on lessons from I.B.M., David Gillen and Geraldine Fabrikant on Graff Diamonds, and Greg Mankiw on the health care consensus. And Sommer discusses financial history that rhymes.

headline: A Surprise on Fox
text: The judges of “So You Think You Can Dance” made a surprise move on Thursday’s results episode and opted not to eliminate any of the remaining contestants. But ratings for that Fox reality show were modest, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The network finished in third place, garnering 6.3 million viewers for “So You Think You Can Dance” at 8 p.m. and 3.4 million at 9 for a rerun of “Glee.” CBS led with repeats of “CSI” (7.3 million) and “The Mentalist” (8.1 million) from 9 to 11 after reruns of “The Big Bang Theory” (6.7 million) and “Rules of Engagement” (5.6 million) at 8 and 8:30. ABC was third, averaging 5.8 million for “Wipeout” reruns from 8 to 10, but 3.5 million viewers at 10 for a repeat of “Rookie Blue.” NBC lagged in fourth, drawing 2.3 million in the 10 p.m. hour for “Love Bites.”

headline: Bail Set for Billionaire Accused of Corruption With Mubarak
text: MADRID — Spanish judges set bail of more than $38 million on Friday for a billionaire and friend of former President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt.

headline: ‘Vaclav & Lena’
text: “Here, I practice, and you practice. Ahem. AH-em. I am Vaclav the Magnificent, with birthday on the sixth of May, the famous day for the generations to celebrate and rejoice, a day in the future years eclipsing Christmas and Hanukkah and Ram - adan and all pagan festivals, born in a land far, far, far, far, far, far, far distance from here, a land of ancient and magnificent secrets, a land of enchanted knowledge passed down from the ages and from the ancients, a land of illusion (Russia!), born there in Russia and reappearing here, in America, in New York, in Brooklyn (which is a Borough), near Coney Island, which is a famous place of magic in the great land of opportunity (which is, of course, America), where anyone can become anything, where a hobo today is tomorrow a businessman in a three-pieces-suit, and a businessman yesterday is later this afternoon a hobo, Vaclav the Magnificent, who shall, without no doubt, be ask to perform his mighty feats of enchantment for dukes and presidents and czars and ayatollahs, uniting them all in awestruck and dumbstrucks, and thus, one day in the future years, be heralding a new era (which is a piece of time) of peace on earth. Ladies and gentlemans, I give you, I present to you, I warn you in advance of his arrival, so that you may close your eyes or put your hands on your face if you are afraid, Vaclav the Magnificent, Boy- Magician.”

headline: Japan Strains to Fix a Reactor Damaged Before Quake
text: TSURUGA, Japan — Three hundred miles southwest of Fukushima, at a nuclear reactor perched on the slopes of this rustic peninsula, engineers are engaged in another precarious struggle.

headline: When We Were Young and Gay, Under the Disco Ball
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The intoxicating abundance of Armistead Maupin’s beloved “Tales of the City” novels is one of their signal pleasures. Reading these intertwined stories of men and women searching for sex, love and themselves in the heady, indulgent atmosphere of San Francisco in the 1970s is like dipping into an inexhaustible bag of M&Ms, with no risk of sugar overload. The stories — of ardent friendships and surprising liaisons, startling family secrets and scandalous crimes — keep piling up and tumbling together, and somehow too much is never enough.

headline: Design for the Road in ‘Cars 2’
text: Pixar’s film takes the race-car Lightning McQueen and his tow-truck pal, Mater, to great world cities.

headline: ‘The Central Park Five’
text: The day it happened, Wednesday, April 19, 1989, Raymond Santana, Jr., walked over to the Taft Houses in East Harlem to visit a friend. Raymond, whose family had moved to New York from Puerto Rico before he was born, lived with his father and grandmother in an apartment building on 119th Street, a few blocks north of the project, but he often hung out in the courtyard of the Taft Houses, where some of his friends lived. At fourteen, he was of average size — about five six and 130 pounds — with curly hair and small features. He was well liked at school, where his good sense of humor made him popular with girls. Even though there were always kids playing sports around the neighborhood, especially basketball and football in local school yards and the decrepit project courtyards, Raymond was more interested in drawing. He took art classes and spent a lot of his free time sketching.

headline: Bahrain and the British Libel Loophole
text: Bahrain has announced that it intends to sue The Independent, the British newspaper, for libel, after the Middle East correspondent Robert Fisk took the Bahraini royals to task on June 14 for starting “an utterly fraudulent trial of 48 surgeons, doctors, paramedics and nurses, accusing them of trying to topple the tin-pot monarchy of this Sunni minority emirate.”

headline: How Many Households Are Like Yours?
text: Explore different types of American households and see how they have changed over time.

headline: Global Auto Racing and Spy Chasing
text: FOR the sequel to its 2006 film, “Cars,” Pixar Animation Studios once again takes to the streets to bring vehicles to life. But the roads this time are filled with considerably more adventure, excitement and peril. Think of shaken, not stirred. The plot of “Cars 2,” opening Friday, bears more resemblance to an entry in the James Bond franchise than it does to the original film.

headline: Palestinians Record West Bank Protests With Cameras Supplied by Israelis
text: While journalists have found themselves scouring the Internet in search of video from protests across the Middle East recently, one protest movement, by small groups of villagers opposed to Israel’s security barrier in the West Bank, has gotten far less attention.

headline: A Dual Portrait of American Fatherhood
text: Fathers today are far more involved with their children than their counterparts four decades ago, but more fathers today also live apart from their kids, according to a new analysis of dads in the United States.

headline: Reviewing the 2011 Acura TSX Sport Wagon
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the 2011 Acura TSX Sport Wagon, a car that clearly benchmarks the luxurious, autobahn-tuned family haulers produced by European brands.

headline: ‘Klinghoffer’ Returns, to Be Debated Anew
text: ST. LOUIS — Has the time come at last for “The Death of Klinghoffer,” the second opera created by the composer John Adams with the librettist Alice Goodman and the director Peter Sellars? The work, which recasts the 1985 hijacking of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro along the lines of a Bach Passion, has been a lightning rod for controversy and protest since its premiere in 1991. That its Palestinian terrorists are humanized and sympathetic, while its Jews can be read as slight and self-pitying, has outraged many listeners.

headline: The Week in Privacy (Just Between Us)
text: Do you believe in the theory of the insidious plot to flood the minds and bodies of the American public with ever-more-mesmerizing and shinier technological gadgets and distractions so that those who already mostly control the world can for their own benefit further monitor and control the behaviors of the powerless masses, and that said powerless masses will be too busy operating or figuring out how to operate their new personal devices to even know what happened?

text: The very first thing you do in Duke Nukem Forever is relieve yourself.

headline: The Insanity of War Is Not Ancient Myth
text: Ellen McLaughlin wants you to know that while you are reading your paper or computer screen, American soldiers in Iraq are on duty, very busy being soldiers. When you have dinner, they will still be there. And when you go back to work after the weekend. And she wants you to know that they have good reasons to exhibit some form of insanity.

headline: An Opening Bid Helps Declarer Place the Cards
text: The 96-board match that chose the U.S.A.-2 Venice Cup world championship team last week in Detroit was won by Geeske Joel of Palo Alto, Calif.; Tobi Sokolow of Austin, Tex.; Jill Levin of Henderson, Nev.; Jill Meyers of Santa Monica, Calif.; Debbie Rosenberg of New Rochelle, N.Y.; and Janice Seamon-Molson of Hollywood, Fla.

text: “Cat” is a mummy. Ptolemaic Era. Tucked in a limestone sarcophagus.

text: Like countries, companies rise and fall, and some of them rise again.

headline: Meditating in Silence as the Fire Draws Near
text: PHOENIX — Those living in the path of a huge wildfire typically express all sorts of emotions, but in one remote community in southeastern Arizona, the reaction has been muted.

headline: Three Men Are Indicted Under Drug Kingpin Law
text: Three men who the authorities say played key roles in a major cocaine trafficking ring that has been operating in East Harlem for about a quarter-century have become the first to be indicted in Manhattan under New York State’s two-year-old law known as the kingpin statute, the district attorney announced Friday.

headline: Justice Department to Review Google’s Admeld Deal
text: The Justice Department will review Google’s proposed $400 million acquisition of the display advertising company Admeld, according to a person briefed on the investigation.

headline: U.S.G.A. Takes McIlroy’s Score in Stride
text: BETHESDA, Md. — The United States Golf Association takes a certain amount of pride in making the golf course conditions demanding and difficult during the United States Open, but the association’s executive director, Mike Davis, was not upset that Rory McIlroy had posted a two-round score of 11-under par.

headline: This Sunday: Even More Appealing Than Washboard Abs
text: One of the advantages The Times Magazine has over its competitors is that our print edition comes tucked into the newspaper, and we are therefore liberated from playing celebrity musical chairs with our cover. However, this also means we miss out on the opportunity of watching our magazine fly off the newsstand (to the extent that ever happens with any magazine anymore). We never get that rock-solid indication of a cover’s popularity. Instead, we have to rely on anecdotal feedback in the form of reader mail, Twitter feeds and Web sites like Coverjunkie (which we love, by the way; thank you for your support).

headline: World Bank Is Withholding $70 Million as Afghans Try to Resolve a Scandal
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A World Bank-managed trust fund is withholding $70 million in incentive money from the Afghanistan government after it failed to reach an agreement with the International Monetary Fund over the Kabul Bank scandal by a key deadline that quietly passed last week.

headline: Bachmann Accuses Obama of Secret Medicare Plan
text: NEW ORLEANS — Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota, the latest candidate to join the Republican presidential campaign, suggested Friday that President Obama secretly wanted Medicare to go bankrupt so retirees would be forced to enroll in the new national health care law.

headline: How a Breeder Reactor Works
text: How a fast-breeder nuclear reactor works.

headline: On Staten Island, Mixed Views on Gay Marriage
text: State Senator Andrew Lanza, who holds a crucial vote on the same-sex marriage bill being considered in Albany, represents a Staten Island constituency with a higher percentage of Republicans than is found in New York City’s other boroughs.

headline: Falcone’s LightSquared Reaches Wireless Deal With Sprint
text: 8:46 p.m. | Updated

headline: A Normal Teenager, Who’s Playing in the Open
text: BETHESDA, Md. — A quick glance at Beau Hossler staring down the fairway for his second shot Friday at the United States Open revealed hints that he was unlike the typical player here.

headline: Senate Inquiry Promised in Case of War Critic
text: Senator Dianne Feinstein, a California Democrat and chairwoman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, said Friday that the panel would investigate accusations that the White House of President George W. Bush sought to have federal intelligence officials collect damaging personal information on a prominent critic of the Iraq war in order to discredit him. In a brief statement, Mrs. Feinstein said, “Depending on what we find, we may take further action.” She was responding to an article in The New York Times on Thursday in which a former senior C.I.A. official said the Bush White House sought to direct intelligence officials to collect sensitive information on the critic, Juan Cole, a University of Michigan professor and Middle East expert. The Central Intelligence Agency has denied the accusations and said agency officials never provided any derogatory information to the White House about Mr. Cole.

headline: Towers With Babel’s Diversity, but a Much Happier History
text: This being June, weddings and proms are colliding at Terrace on the Park banquet hall in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, and doing so with a particularly Queensian flair.

headline: Turkey: Aid Ship Won’t Join Flotilla
text: Technical problems will keep a Turkish humanitarian aid ship that was the target of a fatal raid by the Israeli military last year from joining a flotilla that is set to leave for Gaza next week, the pro-Palestinian charity that owns the boat announced on Friday. The charity, the Humanitarian Relief Foundation, said the decision was not the result of political pressure from the government. Nine people were killed in the raid on the ship, the Mavi Marmara, straining ties between Turkey and Israel. The new flotilla is expected to challenge Israel’s blockade of the Gaza Strip this month. Israeli military officials warned Thursday that they would use force if necessary to prevent boats from breaking the blockade.

headline: Short Trial May Decide if Dodgers Are Sold
text: The Dodgers’ ownership situation, and perhaps the team’s future, gained some clarity Friday in a divorce settlement reached by Frank and Jamie McCourt. The judge overseeing the divorce scheduled a one-day trial on Aug. 4 to determine if the team will remain solely Frank McCourt’s or will be sold as a community property asset.

headline: China: Maritime Force Is Beefed Up
text: China is bulking up its maritime surveillance operations, according to a report on Friday in China Daily, the official English-language newspaper. The force will grow to 15,000 people from 9,000 by 2020, the report said. By 2015, the aviation branch of the force, which is officially civilian, will have 16 aircraft, and by 2020, its sea patrol fleet will have 520 vessels.

headline: California: Woman Arrested in Relic’s Disappearance
text: The parishioners of St. Anthony’s Catholic Church in Long Beach may well think their prayers have been answered. Police officials say they recovered a nearly 800-year-old relic of St. Anthony — the patron saint of lost objects — from the home of Maria Solis, who they say stole it from the church on Monday. Rico Fernandez, a spokesman for the Long Beach Police Department, said officers used surveillance video from a nearby business to identify Ms. Solis, 41, who was arrested on burglary charges. Mr. Fernandez said that the relic appeared to be undamaged and was promptly returned to the church on Thursday, but that officers were still questioning Ms. Solis. The relic had been on rare display for Mass last Sunday, and church officials realized early Monday that it had disappeared from its glass case.

headline: Walk This Way: The Punk Tour
text: Enough already with the jazz. It’s all over the city this month, what with the Blue Note Jazz Festival, the Undead Jazzfest and the Vision Festival: flitty, formless music that makes me want to bang my head against some bathroom porcelain. I had to go see Jake Szufnarowski and John Joseph to restore my heavy-punk-metal-thrashing-garage-acid-hard-rock soul.

headline: Bill Haast, a Man Charmed by Snakes, Dies at 100
text: Bill Haast figured he had handled more than three million poisonous snakes over the years, and he had the hands to prove it.

headline: Wild Man Fischer, Outsider Musician, Dies at 66
text: Wild Man Fischer, a mentally ill street musician who became a darling of the pop music industry in the 1960s and as a result enjoyed four decades of strange, intermittent and often ill-fitting celebrity, died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 66.

headline: Mayors See End to Wars as Fix for Struggling Cities
text: BALTIMORE — While states are seeing their tax collections begin to rise again, much to the relief of budget-battered officials, the nation’s cities are having a far rougher time, with many losing state and federal aid just as the burst housing bubble is belatedly driving down property taxes.

headline: United States: Federal Court Drops Charges Against Bin Laden
text: A federal judge in Manhattan formally dismissed charges against Osama bin Laden on Friday that were originally brought more than a decade ago. A first indictment, for conspiracy to attack United States defense installations, was filed in 1998 when the authorities were considering a plan to capture and try him in New York. Later indictments charged him in the 1998 bombings of two American Embassies in East Africa. Judge Lewis A. Kaplan ordered the dismissals at the request of federal prosecutors in Manhattan, who filed papers citing proof of Bin Laden’s death. Charges remain open against other Qaeda figures, including Ayman al-Zawahri, who has succeeded Bin Laden as the group’s leader.

headline: A Black Cultural Tradition and Its Unlikely Keepers
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — After the shish kebab and blueberry pie, as dusk calmed the Lowcountry heat, the dinner guests gathered around Park Dougherty’s table prepared to sing. They clapped hands in one rhythm, beat their feet against the floorboards in another, and lifted their voices into a song that had been passed down to them through generations and in defiance of a rigid racial divide.

headline: Morocco King Proposes Limited Steps to Democracy
text: In a major effort to try to respond to calls for more democracy and accountability, King Mohammed VI of Morocco announced proposed constitutional changes on Friday night that would reduce his own nearly absolute powers and name a prime minister from the largest party elected to Parliament as head of the executive branch.

headline: After Talks With G.O.P., Cuomo Expects Passage of Gay Marriage Bill
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Friday that he expected same-sex marriage legislation to be approved before the end of the legislative session next week, and indicated that to win passage of the measure he is prepared to yield to Republican concerns for greater protections of religious groups.

headline: Waiting (and Waiting) in the Wings
text: You forget it can happen.

headline: The Influence of Syria
text: Op-Ed columnist Thomas L. Friedman discusses what a democratic Syria could mean to the Middle East.

headline: After Snips to Budget, a Thicket Looms
text: WASHINGTON — Those taking part in the bipartisan budget talks being led by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. have characterized them as civil, constructive and productive. What the discussions have not been to date is decisive.

headline: 2 Big Banks Exit Reverse Mortgage Business
text: The nation’s two biggest providers of reverse mortgages are no longer offering the loans, as the economics of the business have come under pressure.

headline: 2 Top Lawyers Lost to Obama in Libya War Policy Debate
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama rejected the views of top lawyers at the Pentagon and the Justice Department when he decided that he had the legal authority to continue American military participation in the air war in Libya without Congressional authorization, according to officials familiar with internal administration deliberations.

headline: Backpack Scare Prompts Road Closings
text: Federal authorities closed roads around the Pentagon on Friday morning after a man carrying a backpack and acting suspiciously was found overnight in Arlington National Cemetery. The man, identified as Yonathan Melaku, 22, a Marine Corps reservist from Alexandria, Va., ran from federal parks police officers and was arrested, officials said. Investigators initially said his backpack contained “suspicious materials,” though they later determined nothing was explosive, said Chris Allen, a spokesman with the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The authorities searched his car, found in a wooded area near the Pentagon, but did not find anything suspicious, Mr. Allen said.

headline: Highest Praise for McIlroy Comes From Inside the Ropes
text: BETHESDA, Md. — Standing in the 16th fairway, 244 yards from the hole, Phil Mickelson lashed a shot on Friday that bounced on the front of the green, rolled forward and checked up 45 feet from the cup. It left him a long eagle putt, but he had avoided a dangerous bunker, found a narrow opening and seemingly put some pressure on his young playing partner, Rory McIlroy.

headline: Deploying New Tools to Stop the Hackers
text: Trying to secure a computer network is much like trying to secure a building — the challenge is trying to screen out real threats without impeding the normal traffic that needs to go in and out.

headline: Costly Guard Dogs
text: To the Editor:

headline: When Snoopy Landed on the Moon
text: IN March 1969, Charles M. Schulz created six sequential “Peanuts” cartoon strips following the pensive beagle Snoopy on a journey to the moon and back. They not only reflected America’s anticipation of Apollo 11 — the first manned lunar landing, which would take place in July of that year — but also drew on the relationship between NASA and the “Peanuts” gang. That connection is the subject of “To the Moon: Snoopy Soars With NASA,” now on view at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center.

headline: In Fine Society, Infidelity and Its Consequences
text: One woman, a country-house guest, is relaxing in high heels, a tasteful dress and pearls. A couple of young people with British accents saunter in, wearing tennis whites, rackets in hand. The room is filled with uncomfortable furniture, and there is an equestrian portrait over the mantel.

text: Minh Uong/ The New York Times

headline: ‘Goon Squad’ Writer Prepares a Visit
text: As soon as Karen Sirabian, the director of the Master of Arts in writing program at Manhattanville College, finished reading “A Visit From the Goon Squad,” she decided to invite its author, Jennifer Egan, to participate in the college’s annual Summer Writers’ Week.
