headline: The Banking Miracle
text: The president of the American Bankers Association was railing against excessive regulation in a speech at the Waldorf Astoria. The banking reform bill, he complained, “would destroy a substantial part of our bond-distributing machinery.” He added, “Can anyone expect that a step of this kind will improve the quality of our long-term investments?”

headline: Inside the Studio of a Pop Art Icon
text: Bridgehampton, N.Y.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: U.S. Pressing Its Crackdown Against Leaks
text: WASHINGTON — Stephen J. Kim, an arms expert who immigrated from South Korea as a child, spent a decade briefing top government officials on the dangers posed by North Korea. Then last August he was charged with violating the Espionage Act — not by aiding some foreign adversary, but by revealing classified information to a Fox News reporter.

headline: Arab Spring, Kurdish Summer
text: Istanbul

headline: Celebrating Progress While Recoiling From It
text: One of the ways modern art confused critics and audiences in the early 20th century was with its images of machines, bridges and factories. Were the artists celebrating industry or condemning it? Were they on the side of progress or recoiling from its advances?

headline: Jim Rodnunsky, Cablecam Creator, Dies at 54
text: Jim Rodnunsky, whose film work above the Canadian ski slopes resulted in the Cablecam, a rope-mounted, remote-control camera system that provides overhead and rapid-moving shots for televised sporting events and films, died on June 10 at his home in Granada Hills, Calif. He was 54.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: How to End the N.F.L. Deadlock
text: Philadelphia

headline: Little League and Dim Sum
text: John C. Liu, 44, New York City’s feisty and ambitious comptroller and the first Asian-American to win a major elective office in the city, has at times been at odds with the Bloomberg administration. But on Sundays, Mr. Liu says, auditing, fraud-busting and the mayor are the last things on his mind. It’s a time for Little League and maybe a dim sum outing in Flushing, Queens, where Mr. Liu, a former actuary, arrived from Taiwan at age 5. He still lives there with his wife, Jenny, 43, a director at the New York Power Authority, and their son, Joey, 10.

headline: L.I.R.R. Train Sets and a Brooklyn Park
Sky’s the Limit: Yogis Head Outdoors
text: ONE night early this month, hundreds of yogis accustomed to grounding to the earth figuratively did so literally, on the green expanse of lawn near Pier 63 along the Hudson River. Schuyler Grant of the Kula Yoga Project, a founder of the event, Wanderlust Yoga in the City, made in situ additions to the yoga canon, suggesting, “Reach your heart to the water,” and encouraging participants to try handstands on the forgiving grass.

headline: In Libya, More Novice Soldiers in Defense of Qaddafi
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Refat, 26, was happily working in the information technology department of a British retailer here until just a few months ago when he was called to military service by the government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Wine Bar in a Vintage Setting
text: After five years of planning and an investment of more than a million dollars, Thomas DeChiaro, a businessman and longtime area resident, has succeeded in preserving the abandoned century-old St. George’s church, with its lovely Norman-style architecture, while bringing a sophisticated wine bar to commercial Route 6 in Mohegan Lake.

headline: A Waterfront Party, and a Restaurant
text: WE saw him coming: a middle-aged man in tomato-red pants poised on the prow of a boat that swanned up the Byram River and moored alongside Bartaco, a waterfront taqueria with a penchant for lowercase letters and a club vibe that is attracting patrons in droves. Part of a deeply tanned foursome, he was soon holding court on the restaurant’s crowded outdoor deck, administering margaritas to his guests from an icy carafe.

headline: Collins Not a Fan of Interleague Play
text: If Mets Manager Terry Collins had his way, his club would not play the Los Angeles Angels this weekend. Or any American League teams other than the Yankees.

headline: Frozen Dead Guy Festival for Sale (the Man Himself Stays on Ice)
text: NEDERLAND, Colo. — As a business opportunity, Nederland’s frozen dead guy is pretty hot right now. Well, technically, of course, he’s still frozen, packed in dry ice in a shed outside town, as he has been for going on 20 years.

headline: Refreshing Sparklers
text: Sparkling Pointe, in Southold, Long Island’s only producer specializing exclusively in sparkling wine, kept its portfolio entirely brut — dry — starting with its first vintage in 2004. Then last month it added a fifth bubbly, the nonvintage Cuvée Carnaval ($27), providing an option for consumers who like sweetness.

headline: Upscale American Menu, and an Open Kitchen
text: WITH its prominent bar up front, wooden booths and pressed-tin ceiling, Left Coast Kitchen and Cocktails in Merrick looks like a pub. Don’t expect nachos and wings, though. This is more like a gastropub, with an inventive, upscale menu.

headline: Syria’s Nightmare
text: With thousands of Syrians being slaughtered, jailed or forced to flee their country, President Obama and other leaders need to find better ways to punish and isolate President Bashar al-Assad and his cronies.

headline: Saturday: Creatures With Electrocytes
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — This one went all over the place for me, as most Saturdays are wont to do, but I did enjoy the ride. Joon Pahk has already hit for the cycle — he’s had at least one crossword published on each day of the week — but he seems to hang out primarily in the late-week end of the constructing spectrum.

headline: Eye-Popping Pies, and More
text: Flour Garden Bakery makes a range of modestly priced breads, but you will have to look hard to find them. It’s not that the loaves are hidden away; it’s that nearly everything else is so vibrantly appealing they might be easily overlooked.

headline: Grandma’s Here, in Name and Spirit
text: THE space at 51 Bank Street in New Milford has seen restaurants like Arrivederci and Cucina 51 come and go. But the current occupant, Lucia Ristorante, may be here to stay, judging by the full house, the moderate prices and, most persuasive of all, the freshly made dishes that emerge from a highly competent kitchen.

headline: The Treaty and the Law
text: Humberto Leal García Jr., a Mexican citizen who faces execution in Texas next month, has petitioned Gov. Rick Perry for a six-month reprieve. He is asking for a stay under a vital international law, the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations, which requires that foreign nationals who are arrested be told of their right to have their embassy notified of that arrest and to ask for help.

headline: Fake Identities Were Used on Twitter in Effort to Get Information on Weiner
text: At least three months before the revelation that former Representative Anthony D. Weiner was sending lewd messages and photos to women online, a small group of self-described conservatives was monitoring his exchanges with women on Twitter. Now there is evidence that one or more people created two false identities on Twitter in order to collect information to use against him.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Organic Blueberries Don’t Come Easily
text: NEW EGYPT, N.J.

headline: A Book at the Beach
text: Beach season is upon us, which means that lists of summer beach reading have begun to appear. They include books that are fat and credential-building, books that are fat and breezy, and books that Bertie Wooster would be reading if he were going to the South of France. The lists lead to an important question. Can you actually read at the beach? Or do you merely hold a book before your face as a blind for better beach-watching?

headline: Debt Limit Endgame
text: The White House has said not to expect any back-nine breakthroughs on the debt limit when President Obama and the House speaker, John Boehner, get together for a game of golf on Saturday.

headline: Corrections
text: NEW YORK

headline: Remembrances of My Father
text: Occasionally, without warning, the drunken wreckage of my father would wash up on our doorstep, late at night, stammering, laughing, reeking of booze.

headline: For Want of a Word, Arizona’s Jobless Lose Checks
text: One word, just one little word.

headline: Freed by a Journalism Professor and His Students
text: Reporting by David Protess and his students, both before and after his time at the Medill Innocence Project, has had a part in freeing more than 10 wrongly convicted men from prison — five of them from death row.

headline: A Watchdog Professor, Now Defending Himself
text: For the last two years, David Protess, a renowned journalist and professor who spent three decades fighting to prove the innocence of others, has been locked in a battle to do the same for himself. It hasn’t gone as well.

headline: In a Scattered Protest, Saudi Women Take the Wheel
text: CAIRO — Several dozen women drove in defiance of the law in major cities of Saudi Arabia on Friday, according to reports on social media and by an informal network of activists in the country. There appeared to be few confrontations reported with either the traffic or morals police, and at least half a dozen women who were stopped were escorted home and admonished not to drive again, said activists reached by telephone.

headline: Medicare Claims Show Overuse for CT Scanning
text: Long after questions were first raised about the overuse of powerful CT scans, hundreds of hospitals across the country needlessly exposed patients to radiation by scanning their chests twice on the same day, according to federal records and interviews with researchers.

headline: Progress in Labor Negotiations, but Lockout Still Looms in N.B.A.
text: The shape of the N.B.A.’s future and the prospect of a labor war that could radically alter it may be decided early next week in a Manhattan hotel conference room.

headline: 17 Years Later, Still Searching for the Driver of a White Box Truck
text: Human nature won out, for good or bad, that day in 1994, and all the eyes on the Brooklyn corner turned down to the fallen mother and her little girl in white sandals beside her. People wanted to help, and so no one looked up, northbound on Fort Hamilton Parkway, at the vanishing white truck.

headline: A View of a Chess Genius
text: The photographer Harry Benson befriended the eccentric American chess champion Bobby Fischer in 1971. A book with Mr. Benson’s photographs of Mr. Fischer is being released this month.

headline: A Yoga Fund-Raiser Brings Out an Appetite
text: Juice cleanses, yogis and gurus were the hot topics at a fund-raiser on Wednesday for Bent on Learning, a nonprofit that takes yoga to public schools. The atmosphere was so healthy that we wondered if the carbohydrates we had had for lunch would set off some sort of detector at the door.

headline: Bloggingheads: Perry’s Prayerfest
text: Sarah Posner, left, of Religion Dispatches and Mollie Ziegler Hemingway of GetReligion.org discuss Gov. Rick Perry's upcoming prayer rally.

headline: Mets’ Resilience Falls Flat for a Night
text: The wildly vacillating weather in New York on Friday — periods of warm sun and clear skies interspersed with thunderous, gloomy downpours — could serve as a metaphor for the Mets’ fortunes this season.

headline: U2 Guitarist’s House Plan Rejected by California Board
text: LOS ANGELES — Turning that Malibu dream house into reality is never easy, even when you are a world famous rock star.

headline: ‘Barefoot Bandit’ Pleads Guilty to 2-Year Theft Spree
text: SEATTLE — Colton Harris-Moore, the teenage fugitive who became known as the Barefoot Bandit during his two-year crime spree, pleaded guilty here on Friday to seven federal charges, including stealing airplanes, a boat and firearms and transporting them across state and sometimes national boundaries. He faces up to six and a half years in prison.

headline: Win a Trip 2011: First Impressions in Morocco
text: Saumya Dave, a student, and Noreen Connolly, a teacher, are the 2011 “Win-A-Trip” winners and are currently traveling with Nick through parts of North and West Africa. Saumya’s first post is from Morocco.

headline: The World This Week
text: A look back at Greek contagion fears and the continuing political deadlock in Belgium.

headline: Computer Failure Delays United Flights Nationwide
text: Passengers were stranded at airports across the country Friday night after a failure in United Airlines’ computer system, the airline said.

headline: Workers Reject Union at Target Store
text: The nation’s main union for retail workers lost a unionization vote on Friday at a Target store in Valley Stream, N.Y., in what was an effort to make it the first of Target’s 1,750 stores in the United States to be unionized.

headline: Lashing Out, Karzai Says U.S. Is Talking to the Taliban
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan said publicly for the first time on Saturday that the United States and the NATO-led coalition have been actively negotiating with the Taliban, an assertion he made in a speech that he also used to fire a broadside against his coalition allies.

headline: U.S. vs. Jamaica: Roster Musings
text: The United States had hoped to cruise through the group stage of the Concacaf Gold Cup and arrive in the quarterfinals bursting with confidence. Ideally, key players could have rested during the group stage, and reserves could have been given a chance to play once or twice.

headline: Tepco Halts Filtering of Tainted Water at Japanese Plant
text: TOKYO — The Tokyo Electric Power Company said Saturday that the filtration system it had struggled to put into operation at the damaged Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant had broken down after just five hours, a disappointing setback in its efforts to cool the reactors.

headline: The King of Really Big Diamonds Heads to China
text: ON this big night out, Gisele Bündchen, darling of the cameras, is decked out in diamond earrings from Van Cleef & Arpels. The cover girl Shalom Harlow wears rocks from Harry Winston. And Madonna, that proto-Gaga, is bejeweled in Cartier.

headline: Losing Vote at a Target in New York, Union Vows to Try Again
text: Even as the nation’s main union for retail workers acknowledged that it lost a unionization vote on Friday at a Target store in Valley Stream, N.Y., it demanded a new election and accused the company of illegally intimidating workers.

headline: A Gentler Atmosphere at Yankee Stadium
text: The tarp concealing the diamond was peeled slowly away Tuesday night, and despite a persistent drizzle, thousands of fans who had sought cover in the concourses of Yankee Stadium were soon trickling to their seats, wiping them dry with thin napkins. When the public-address announcer indicated the night’s game would go on as planned, albeit 40 minutes late, a cheer rang out.

headline: Making Metal Bats Play Like Wood

headline: Mavs’ Founder Has Title to Hang His Hat On
text: Thirty-one years ago, Don Carter knew about a lot of things. He was a “bidnessman” in the lexicon of Texas entrepreneurs, one who got rich through home furnishings, wore a Stetson like a crown and piloted his own plane to and from his own holdings. What did Carter know about basketball or the N.B.A.?

headline: Red Bulls Get Help to Start a Long Trip
text: LITTLE FALLS, N.J. — Red Bulls Coach Hans Backe spoke with his inimitable candor when he was asked how he felt about Dwayne De Rosario’s return to the club after Canada was eliminated on Tuesday from the Concacaf Gold Cup.

headline: Laugh Lines

headline: Out of Fashion
text: The black beret is out. Ten years after it became standard gear in the United States Army, it has been replaced by the patrol cap as the default head gear for soldiers wearing combat uniforms, CNN reports. Soldiers had complained that the wool beret was hot, hard to adjust and took two hands to put on. Soldiers who were already wearing berets, and who will continue to wear them — like Special Forces, airborne troops and Army Rangers — were not happy either. They thought that having every soldier wear a beret diminished the work they had done to earn theirs. The decision by Gen. Martin Dempsey, the Army chief of staff, reverses a policy laid down by a predecessor, Gen. Eric Shinseki. The patrol cap looks like a baseball cap, but with a flat, not rounded, top. Soldiers wearing their dress uniforms will still wear berets, but by reducing the number they will need from two to one, the Army will save $6.5 million.

headline: Prime Number: 2
text: The annual cost, in millions of dollars, of insuring $10 million in Greek sovereign debt for five years as of Thursday. Greece’s financial and political crisis, compounded by new fears about the pace of the economic recovery in the United States, sent financial markets reeling last week. The worry is that in the worst case, a Greek debt default would lead to damaging losses for European banks and replay the global panic of 2008. Markets calmed a bit after Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany retreated from her demand that private financial institutions be pressured to help rescue the Greek economy. But the potential for trouble in Europe remained.

headline: Fighting Words
text: Some school districts are lowering the homework load, to try to lower the pressure on students. But the competition for college admission, not to mention the stress of testing, remains.

headline: 30 Seconds With Penny Toler, a W.N.B.A Pioneer
text: On June 21, 1997, the Liberty and the Los Angeles Sparks took the court at the Great Western Forum in Inglewood , Calif., for the first game in the W.N.B.A. There were 14,284 fans in the stands to see the Liberty win, 67-57. Penny Toler, who had played professionally overseas for eight years, was the Sparks’ starting point guard, and she scored the first points in the league’s history. The W.N.B.A., in its 15th season, is recognizing the anniversary of the game Tuesday night with a matchup between the Liberty and the Sparks at Staples Center in Los Angeles. Toler, 45, will be there for the anniversary. She is in her 12th season as the Sparks’ general manager and has built two championship teams.

headline: Athlete-Fan Dialogue Becomes Shouting Match
text: Just exactly what did LeBron James have in mind with his stream-of-consciousness rant last week?

headline: Under a Full Moon, a Search for Horseshoe Crabs
Serena Williams Is Facing Her Toughest Comeback
text: Serena Williams has actually played more grass-court tennis than usual this year as she prepares for another Wimbledon. But Williams, who lost in the second round in Eastbourne last week, is still short on matches as she returns to the All England Club after nearly a year away from her sport and the Grand Slam tournaments that define it.

headline: McIlroy Continues His Mastery
text: BETHESDA, Md. — When the moment came on the back nine Saturday for Rory McIlroy to put some walk to all the talk, to take a few more steps down the narrow path to United States Open history, he delivered the way golfers who win majors do.

headline: In Libya, Delusion Makes a Last Stand
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — The chess match last week between Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and a visitor from the remote steppe of southern Russia who had traveled to Tripoli to promote chess in Libyan schools was a case of the oddest of couples, at the oddest of times. With NATO bombs and missiles pounding the Libyan capital and Colonel Qaddafi venting on Libya’s airwaves only days before that he would choose “death before surrender," it captured something quintessential about the Libyan leader and the oddball qualities he has displayed in decades of repressive one-man rule.

headline: Men’s Players to Watch at Wimbledon
text: Three men’s players to keep an eye on at this year’s Wimbledon.

headline: Welcoming the Wild Ideas of the Week
text: This interview with  Amy Gutmann, president of the University of Pennsylvania, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Women’s Players to Watch at Wimbledon
text: Three women’s players to watch at this year’s Wimbledon.

headline: Paychecks as Big as Tajikistan
text: WHEN does big become excessive? If the question involves executive pay, the answer is “often.”

headline: Manhattan Meets Nascar as Chef Becomes a Racer
text: Six years ago, Tim George Jr. was working for a Manhattan restaurant that was catering a function at a sports-car race at Lime Rock Park in Connecticut. As George recalls, the head chef harshly criticized him, in Italian, for altering a recipe. So George, then 24, took a break to watch sleek Ferraris conquer the racetrack.

headline: Lessons in Longevity, From I.B.M.
text: AS it turned 100 last week, I.B.M. was looking remarkably spry. Consumer technologies get all the attention these days, but the company has quietly thrived by selling to corporations and governments. Profits are strong, its portfolio of products and services looks robust, and its shares are near a record high. I.B.M.’s stock-market value passed Google’s earlier this year. Not bad for a corporate centenarian.

headline: The America’s Cup, Translated for Television
text: THE yacht-club crowd may turn out to cheer at regattas, but sailboat racing hasn’t been a big hit with mainstream television audiences — perhaps because they have trouble following what’s happening on the waves.

headline: Hoffman Glimpses Rivera Warming Up
text: The Yankees always seem to have history in reserve. A strained right calf has stalled Derek Jeter’s pursuit of 3,000 hits, but Mariano Rivera is actively chasing the career saves record. Trevor Hoffman, the longtime closer for the San Diego Padres, has 601 saves, 26 more than Rivera through Friday.

headline: Seriously, Some Consensus About Health Care
text: WE are entering the season of polarization. With various Republicans vying to replace Barack Obama, the president eager to keep his job, and both the House and the Senate up for grabs, candidates from both sides of the aisle will spend the next year and a half stressing their differences.

headline: Funny, but I’ve Heard This Market Song Before
text: “SOUND familiar?” the e-mail asked. It came from Birinyi Associates, a research firm, and contained a list of financial headlines from several news organizations, including this one.

headline: One Musical Succeeds. One Struggles. Discuss.
text: Both had powerhouse teams. So what made the difference between the boffo success of “The Book of Mormon” and the brutal trials of “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark”?

text: Insurance adjusters take to the field in Joplin, Missouri to help the storm victims reclaim their lives.

text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — First, a very happy Father’s Day to all who are fathers, grandfathers, caring uncles, etc. I hope you are all having a relaxing, puzzle-filled day.

text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: The Big Switch, One Step at a Time
text: PITY the company that is looking for a whiz at HTML5, the up-and-coming Web language. Or the business seeking people to develop mobile applications or a social media strategy. There aren’t enough of these types to go around, and positions remain vacant despite the urgent need.

headline: Denialism, Here and There
text: OK, starting to clue back in, although not arriving in Cambridge until tomorrow.

headline: Hip, Hip — if Not Hooray — for a Standstill Nation
text: WASHINGTON — Early in June, President Obama and House Republicans met at the White House to bridge differences. Republicans complained that Mr. Obama was demagoguing their Medicare plan. The president said he knew a little about demagoguery as the “job-killing, death-panel, probably-wasn’t-born-here president.” Seventy-five minutes later, they parted no closer to agreement.

headline: Seeking Cures, Then and Now
text: MY mother gave my sister, Suzy, and me our first lessons in stewardship. On Saturday afternoons, she would drive us to volunteer somewhere. We might go to a homeless shelter, or to the Red Cross or to an ill neighbor’s house to do laundry. One day we complained and she pulled off onto the side of the road and gave us her stewardship talk. She told us that it was up to us to fix what was wrong in this country.

headline: Cup Upset Was Strange, Not Inexplicable
text: The Stanley Cup finals that ended Wednesday were among the strangest ever, apart from what happened in the streets of Vancouver afterward.

headline: United Flights Resume After Five-Hour Computer Failure
text: United Airlines said on Saturday morning that its planes were flying again after a computer system crashed on Friday night and left travelers on dozens of canceled flights stranded at airports around the country.

headline: ‘Hopey-Changey’ Alive
text: Refudiate this: Sarah Palin’s undeniable impact on the English language. Exhibit A, of course, is the idiom she lent wildfire currency to only last year, by asking at a Tea Party convention on Feb. 6, “How’s that hopey-changey stuff working out for ya?” Witness the meme’s broad cultural reach ever since and — perhaps unfortunate in some cases — its seemingly limitless versatility.

headline: Gourmet Mushy Peas
text: What has happened to English food?

headline: On Golf Courses, the Fairway as a Runway
text: BETHESDA, Md. — In the weeks before the United States Open, Davis Love III received a package from his clothing sponsor, Ralph Lauren, and was startled by one particular item inside: linen pants the hue of Pepto-Bismol. He was told to pair them with a blue-and-white-striped shirt on the first day of play.

headline: Gunfight Shatters Calm Spell in Kabul
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Three insurgents wearing military uniforms and vests filled with explosives attacked a police station in a busy downtown market on Saturday, killing nine people in a gun battle that lasted more than an hour, the authorities said.

headline: Europeans Doubt Greece’s Ability to Stick to Budget
text: ATHENS — In the year since Greece received its first financial bailout, many things have changed. The country has reduced its budget deficit by 5 percent of gross domestic product. Workers have been hit by wage freezes and pension cuts, prompting a growing popular outcry. The state has revealed for the first time how many people it employs, and tax collectors can now cross-reference swimming pool ownership with declared income to help determine wealth and cut down on rampant tax dodging.

headline: One Musical Succeeds. One Struggles. Discuss.
text: Why has “The Book of Mormon” emerged as the hit musical of the year on Broadway, while another artistically ambitious show a few blocks away, “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” has struggled?

headline: Looking Back, Gates Says He’s Grown Wary of ‘Wars of Choice’
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates, as he prepared to depart the government for the second time, said in an interview on Friday that the human costs of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan had made him far more wary about unleashing the might of the American armed forces.

headline: ‘You Might Remember This’
text: In 2007 I posted an animated portrait of my son Buster’s first years called “You Won’t Remember This.” “You Won’t Remember This Either,” covering the toddler years but featuring my younger son, Oscar, followed in 2009. This new film continues the series and features Buster from ages six to 10. While these films portray childhood, the perspective is parental. If Buster had made this film it would be all baseball, and the actual point of view, looking up at grownups twice his size, would surely feature more chins and nostrils. The angle might seem a small thing, but it can alter the feeling in subtle ways. Looking at children, our perspective is angled down and as they look up, we see eyes, those big ones, looking up like lasers. And, like every portrait, these films are double portraits, simultaneously reflecting the sensibility of who made them as well as who they picture.

headline: Alexi Ogando: A Rule 5 Tale
text: The minor league phase of the Rule 5 draft is generally the final item on the agenda at baseball’s annual winter meetings. It is such an afterthought that most executives scatter before it begins, gathering their bags to check out of the hotel after days of strategy sessions.

headline: Savoring the Small Victories With My Two Little Girls
text: When my younger daughter, Sylvia, was about 10, she was on one of those alleged super-duper basketball teams. She was in a tough tournament game at a dank gym one Sunday, and after the game, I put my arm around her with a twisted grin.

headline: Amid Texas Drought, High-Stakes Battle Over Water
text: On the cliffs surrounding Lake Buchanan in Central Texas, a white ring extends some 13 feet above the shoreline, marking where the water reaches when the lake is full. At nearby Lake Travis, staircases that once led to the water’s edge now end well above it.

headline: A New Twist to Wives’ Playbook for Sex Scandals
text: It has been almost two decades since Hillary Rodham Clinton declared that she was not “some little woman standing by my man like Tammy Wynette.” It was a striking moment: she was saying that she was not reflexively standing by her man, as previous generations had, but she was standing by him nevertheless.

headline: Obama’s Social Media Outposts Join the Campaign
text: 2:18 p.m. | Updated Reaching out once again to the young technically savvy voters who helped him get elected, President Obama has officially moved his Facebook page and his Twitter account, @BarackObama, into campaign mode.

headline: The Week in Review, in Review
text: A tour of the section’s covers from 1935 to the present.

headline: Coming Next Sunday: The Latest Evolution of the Review
text: WHEN readers opened their New York Times on Sunday, Jan. 27, 1935, they discovered the debut of The News of the Week in Review. Snaking along seven columns of a very gray first page were short items, a few paragraphs each, of unsigned, backstage perspective on the events of the previous week.

headline: Jagr Eyes N.H.L. Return
text: Jaromir Jagr’s exit from the N.H.L. was strange and largely unexplained when he left the Rangers in 2008 and signed a contract with Avangard Omsk of the Russian Kontinental Hockey League. But now it seems that was not his final exit after all.

headline: Friendship of Justice and Magnate Puts Focus on Ethics
text: PIN POINT, Ga. — Clarence Thomas was here promoting his memoir a few years ago when he bumped into Algernon Varn, whose grandfather once ran a seafood cannery that employed Justice Thomas’s mother as a crab picker.

headline: Conservative Bloggers Cheer Palin Film
text: MINNEAPOLIS — A documentary portraying mainstream Republican leaders as villains and Sarah Palin as an inspirational heroine for the Tea Party received an enthusiastic reception from grass-roots conservatives at the film’s first public screening here on Friday night.

headline: In Arizona, Sponsor of Immigration Law Now Faces a Recall
text: MESA, Ariz. — It has been a rough year for Russell Pearce, the president of the Arizona Senate, as he has sought to solidify his state’s reputation as the nation’s incubator for hard-edged conservative policies.

headline: Bay Area Underground Market Draws Authorities’ Notice
text: For the past two years, the San Francisco Underground Market has served up bacon-laced chocolates, sea salt and chili truffles, and other haute fringe food.

headline: In Praise of Not Knowing
text: WHEN I was 17, I took a record of John Cage’s piano pieces out of the library. The pieces were interesting, but what really arrested my attention was the B-side of the album — a work called “The Dreamer That Remains,” by a composer I’d never heard of named Harry Partch. This was music from another planet: unearthly yowling strings, metallic twangs, rippling liquid percussion. I couldn’t even identify the instruments.

headline: Chemical Suicides, Popular in Japan, Are Increasing in the U.S.
text: In Japan it is known as detergent suicide, a near-instant death achieved by mixing common household chemicals into a poisonous cloud of gas.

headline: Jack Kerouac Tailgates T.S. Eliot Into the App Store
text: Gasps went up last week when a digital edition of T.S. Eliot’s 1922 poem “The Waste Land” knocked Marvel Comics out of the top spot on the list of top-grossing book apps for the iPad.

headline: Young Russians Work to Spread Message of a Soviet-Era Dissident
text: MOSCOW — Andrei Sakharov was one of the best-known dissidents of the Communist era — a celebrated physicist persecuted for crusading for human rights and against Soviet brutality. He won the Nobel Peace Prize, and came to personify the struggle to create democracy here.

text: As a rule, Florida doesn’t stand still. It evolves and absorbs and builds and levels and then builds again. Few things remain untouchable traditions, but Alabama Jacks, a watering hole in the Keys, is one of them.

headline: Vatican Calls Meeting and Plans Database in Effort to Stop Sexual Abuse
text: ROME — Bishops and the leaders of religious orders around the world have been invited to a symposium at Rome’s Jesuit University in February about how to prevent and respond to abuse of children by clergy members.

headline: What to Do With Lemons
text: While President Obama and Secretary of State Hillary Clinton have gotten a lot of things right on foreign policy, they’ve made quite a mess in Israeli-Palestinian relations, where they’ve alienated all sides and generated zero progress. They’ve been inconsistent — demanding a settlements freeze then backing down — unimaginative and politically wimpy. Then again, the actors they’ve had to work with were both lemons — a Palestinian government that was too divided to make any big decisions and an elusive right-wing Israeli government that was strong enough to make big decisions but had no will to do so.

headline: Is Omar Hassan al-Bashir Up to Genocide Again?

text: The Obama administration has long been bumbling along in the footsteps of its predecessor when it comes to sacrificing Americans’ basic rights and liberties under the false flag of fighting terrorism. Now the Obama team seems ready to lurch even farther down that dismal road than George W. Bush did.

headline: Reyes Pledges His Loyalty To His Agent, Not Boras

Reyes, who can become a free agent after the season, spoke before a game against the Los Angeles Angels at Citi Field, saying several times that he was happy with his current agent, Peter E. Greenberg.

headline: Signs of Life Spotted in the Senate
text: Sitting in a defensive crouch for months at a time can get a little uncomfortable, and several Senate Democrats are finally starting to rouse themselves. In the last weeks, there have been some tiny but tantalizing hints that at least a few senators want to offer an alternative to the Republican cost-cutting frenzy and talk about ways to cut sensibly and help put people back to work.

headline: Qaeda Woes Fuel Talk of Speeding Afghan Pullback
text: WASHINGTON — As the Obama administration nears a crucial decision on how rapidly to withdraw combat forces from Afghanistan, high-ranking officials say that Al Qaeda’s original network in the region has been crippled, providing a rationale for an accelerated reduction of troops.

headline: The Court Disses Fathers
text: Children born outside the country to an unmarried American parent are considered American citizens at birth if the parent lived in the United States before the child was born. For a mother, the required period of residence is one year. For a father, it is 10 years, five of them after he turns 14. Fathers must also prove parenthood and pledge to support the child.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 19
text: Set to leave his post at the end of June, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates will appear on CNN’s “State of the Union” and “Fox News Sunday” this week. In addition to reflecting on his career in public service, Mr. Gates will discuss the war in Afghanistan, the conflicts in Libya and Syria and the strained relationship between the United States and Pakistan, which he called critical in his final press conference on Thursday.

headline: After Home Schooling, Pomp and Traditional Circumstances
text: MIAMI — The 26 young men and women, seated in alphabetical order, were nearly silent as they waited for their high school graduation to start. No giggles. No buzz. No camaraderie. And no wonder: they had met just once before, at the rehearsal two weeks earlier where they got their caps and gowns.

headline: The Other Major Anderson
text: Robert Anderson and Joseph Reid Anderson had more in common than a surname. Though not kin, both men were Southerners by birth and educated in the North, at West Point. The two even dined together in early 1861 at Fort Sumter, where Robert Anderson led the Union forces under siege. But when Robert Anderson and his men came under fire a few weeks later, the first shell was launched from a mortar manufactured by Joseph Anderson, the man who came to be known as the “Ironmaker of the Confederacy.”

headline: Sunday: Say What?!
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Well, it was bound to happen. You spend the last 20 years creating puzzles, editing puzzles, talking about puzzles, just surrounding yourself with puzzles and sooner or later something’s got to give. We wouldn’t blame a man for cracking under those circumstances, would we? Frankly, goes the quiet buzz around the water cooler, we’re surprised he lasted this long. It was really just a matter of time.

headline: Readers Weigh In on my Morocco Column
text: My Sunday column argues that Morocco’s king has actually handled Arab spring rather better than other leaders in the region — while adding that this is an exceptionally low bar. If Morocco can continue to liberalize, and turn into a British-style constitutional monarchy, it could be a leader for the region. You agree? Read the column and post your thoughts.

headline: Local Intelligence: Audium
text: An unassuming building on Bush Street in San Francisco shelters Audium, billed as a theater of sculptured sound. Stan Shaff began the sound experiment more than 50 years ago. In a room that looks like a set piece from the original “Star Trek,” audience members in total darkness are immersed in what Mr. Shaff calls “sound choreography”: a cornucopia of sounds, from running water to galloping horses to electronic music.

headline: Difficult to Place, Students May Be Relocated Again

text: WASHINGTON — From across the fairway, the four looked as chummy as, well, a bunch of middle-age men on a golf course can look.

headline: Activists Using Video to Bear Witness in Syria
text: KHIRBET AL-JOUZ, Syria — Jamil Saeb stared intently into the bluish light of his laptop screen, feverishly editing video as antigovernment chants rose up the hillside from the makeshift refugee camp on the valley floor below.

headline: Joseph Miller, Who Sold Horse Tack to the Well-Heeled, Dies at 93
text: Joseph Miller, who built his father’s humble harness shop in Manhattan into one of the nation’s largest suppliers of fashionable saddlery, riding apparel and other equestrian equipment, died on June 12 at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.

headline: Mietek Pemper, 91, Camp Inmate Who Compiled Schindler’s List
text: Mietek Pemper was doing his job as a secretary taking dictation. One day his boss, Amon Goeth, glanced out the window and saw that a worker did not have a full load of stones in his wheelbarrow. Mr. Goeth walked outside and shot the man to death, then returned to his desk and said, “Where were we in the text?”

headline: NATO Says It Mistakenly Hit Libyan Rebels Again

Rick Perry of Texas, the latest Republican to muse openly about exploring a Republican presidential candidacy, drew booming applause here on Saturday for not only assailing President Obama but also lecturing some members of his own party on the importance of socially conservative principles.

headline: Yankees’ Martin Takes a Hit, Gets the Out and Points the Way to a Win
text: CHICAGO — Russell Martin has endured dozens upon dozens of collisions at the plate, and not once can he remember ever dropping the ball. Not even one time in the minor leagues, when a stray forearm socked him in the side of the head. He sustained a concussion, but the runner was out.

headline: Clarence Clemons, Springsteen’s Soulful Sideman, Dies at 69
text: Clarence Clemons, the saxophonist in Bruce Springsteen’s E Street Band, whose jovial onstage manner, soul-rooted style and brotherly relationship with Mr. Springsteen made him one of rock’s most beloved sidemen, died on Saturday at a hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 69.

headline: Well Behind the Leader, an Exciting Tournament Takes Shape

headline: Taymor Calls New ‘Spider-Man’ Much Simpler
text: LOS ANGELES – In her first public comments about “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” since the opening of the $70 million Broadway musical, the director Julie Taymor on Saturday described the new show as “much simpler” than the version she created before being fired in March. Speaking to a conference of theater leaders here, she also tacitly criticized her former producers for drawing ideas from audience focus groups.

text: Rory McIlroy continued his dominance on Saturday, setting a 54-hole record for the United States Open and extending his lead to eight strokes.

headline: Cotton Candy and Giggles Coat the Raunch
text: Katy Perry shrewdly polled her sold-out audience — at least 85 percent female, young and eager to scream — at Nassau Coliseum on Friday night. She asked who had just graduated from college, high school and junior high, and junior high won, decisively. That may be why Ms. Perry made her concert all bright colors, candy-shaped scenery and wide-eyed, kewpie-doll smiles. It was camouflage to keep parents from worrying.

headline: Plane Crash in Westchester County Kills 4
text: Four people were killed on Saturday afternoon when a small plane crashed on its approach to an airport runway in Westchester County, the authorities said.

headline: Reyes Discusses His Future Before Displaying His Value to Mets

headline: Lottery Numbers

text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Almost 79,000 fans were in attendance at New Meadowlands Stadium on Saturday for a quarterfinal doubleheader in the Concacaf Gold Cup. And for almost 44 minutes of the nightcap, the pro-Mexico crowd was on pins and needles as Guatemala looked poised to upset its neighbor.

headline: In Unrelated Cases, 2 Small Children Found Dead in Bronx
text: Two small children died in the Bronx over the weekend, and the police were investigating whether relatives or family friends had caused their deaths.

headline: In the Family: Dinner Night
text: Carol Einhorn's son, Griffin, was conceived with a sperm donation from her best friend, George Russell, who is gay. He and his partner get together with Ms. Einhorn for family dinners on Sundays.

headline: U.S. Ambassador Responds to Karzai’s Criticisms
text: HERAT, Afghanistan — The departing American ambassador to Afghanistan, Karl W. Eikenberry, lashed out at President Hamid Karzai on Sunday in a carefully calculated and candid rebuke of the Afghan leader’s increasingly inflammatory criticism of the coalition forces.

headline: The Obstinacy of Error, Interest Rates Edition
text: Brad DeLong reposts something he wrote two years ago about interest rates; it was, I think, at least in part a followup to my slightly earlier post on liquidity preference and loanable funds. Brad and I both believe that the story of interest rates in this crisis is both remarkable and under-appreciated.

headline: Kicking the Eurocan
text: The reaction of European leaders and institutions to the Greek crisis is a sight to behold. Essentially, it boils down to the fact that default would be very inconvenient, both as a practical matter and in terms of prestige. Therefore default must not be considered a possibility, even though it has long been obvious that non-default is not an option.

headline: Music Festival Takes to Prague’s Islands
text: The islands of Prague will be pulsating with music and pounding with dancing feet during United Islands, a free international music festival that is held on islands in the Vltava River from June 23 to 25.

headline: Get Me to the Game on Time
text: Landon Donovan and Clint Dempsey, the heart of the United States national team attack, were scheduled to rejoin the team in Washington late Saturday after leaving the team in midweek to attend their sisters’ weddings.

headline: Baby Makes Four, and Complications
text: AT the apartment in Brooklyn where George Russell spends four nights each week, he checked the clock: 7:09 p.m. Wasn’t it 7:05 about 20 minutes ago?

headline: Three Grown-Ups and a Baby
text: We only come to intimately know a handful of families in a lifetime. There’s the one we were raised in, and the ones we form on our own. That’s not a large sample size, which often leaves us wondering if the way we do things is “normal.” When we get glimpses here and there of how other families work, we crane our necks toward those for hints of what happens behind doors that aren’t ours.

headline: Rating Sebastian Vettel
text: An Autosport journalist, Edd Straw, has done an interesting analysis of Sebastian Vettel, the Red Bull driver, comparing him with the  great drivers of the past. The 23-year-old German has gotten a lot of attention lately, winning five of seven races this year as well as several races last season.

headline: Early Music Festival: Weighing the Costs
text: BOSTON — You would hardly know it, given the number of performances the Boston Early Music Festival and its related fringe festival have fielded this year, but this successful, 30-year-old celebration of early music has been fighting the effects of the economic downturn just as other arts organizations have. Financial support from foundations, corporations and individual donors has not quite recovered. But Kathleen Fay, the festival’s executive director, said that the situation has improved greatly since the last festival, in 2009.

headline: Let’s Talk About Redistricting
text: The following is an edited transcript of an interview with David Wasserman, the House editor of The Cook Political Report. Mr. Wasserman is Cook’s resident redistricting expert and the author of “Better Know a District,” the The Cook Political Report’s 2012 redistricting outlook. (Readers might also want to check out Cook’s redistricting scorecard for background).

headline: Now Streaming | Calvin Klein
text: The Spring/Summer 2012 men’s collection from Calvin Klein at Milan Fashion Week.

headline: Deal on Lifeline to Avert Greek Bankruptcy Is Postponed
text: LUXEMBOURG — Europe’s finance ministers unexpectedly put off approval early Monday of the next installment of aid to debt-laden Greece, delaying the decision until July and demanding that the Greek Parliament first approve spending cuts and financial reforms that include a large-scale privatization program.

headline: Five Books
text: I talked to Sophie Roell at The Browser about five books that influenced me as an economist; interview here.

headline: Keynes and the Moderns
text: Draft for my talk (pdf) at the Keynes conference tomorrow. Regular readers will recognize most of the ideas and a fair bit of the text; this is an opportunity to put various thoughts together.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Bottega Veneta
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#263", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

headline: NATO Admits Missile Hit a Civilian Home in Tripoli
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — NATO acknowledged Sunday that an errant missile had destroyed a civilian home in the Libyan capital in the early morning, saying it may have killed civilians. It was the alliance’s first such admission in the three-month-long campaign of airstrikes against the military forces of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: How Do You Engage Your Customers?
text: At TerraCycle, consumers can interact with our business in two crucial ways. First, they can send us garbage (postage paid), and for each piece of waste they collect, we typically give 2 cents to the charity or school of their choice. Today, more than 21 million people in the United States are actively involved in our collection programs, and there’s another 2 million participating outside of the United States. The second way to interact with TerraCycle is for consumers to buy the products that are made from the waste we’ve collected. These products are typically available at major big-box stores, including Wal-Mart and Target.

headline: ‘Green Lantern’ Fizzles at the Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES — An all-hands-on-deck effort by Warner Brothers to turn “Green Lantern” into a box office superpower fizzled over the weekend.

headline: Struggling to Stoke Economic Growth in Greece
text: ATHENS — A few months after Greece was seized by its debt crisis, Prime Minister George A. Papandreou had a grand idea to revive growth: sun-drenched islands would be dotted with solar panels and wind turbines to transform the country into a “green economy,” attracting badly needed investments and creating hundreds of thousands of new jobs.

headline: Divided on Premier, Palestinians Cancel Meeting
text: GAZA — In a blow to Palestinian unity efforts, a meeting in Cairo planned for this week so that the leaders of the two main factions could announce a new government has been called off for lack of agreement on a prime minister, Palestinian officials said Sunday.

headline: Our Man in Milan
text: Joe Jonas has 2,132,660 Twitter followers, a new solo album, a growing fan club among the fashion cognoscenti and a posse of devoted teen faithful who wait, like pilgrims at Lourdes or extras in Sofia Coppola’s “Somewhere,” every day outside the Principe di Savoia hotel for a glimpse of this pop divinity.

headline: English Food Followup
text: In re my text-free post on gourmet mushy peas: as several commenters pointed out, I had some fun with the subject of English food way back when.

headline: Karlovic Communicates in Brief but Bold Strokes
text: Although he is the tallest person to play Grand Slam tennis, Ivo Karlovic is attracting more attention at the moment for short messages. But then Karlovic has long been a man of surprising contrasts.

headline: Rackets Provide Window Into Tennis’s Top Three Men
text: WIMBLEDON, England — The top three men’s players in the world tennis rankings — Rafael Nadal, Novak Djokovic and Roger Federer — each possesses a distinct style and, more surprisingly, a distinct racket.

headline: Somali Prime Minister Resigns as Part of a Political Deal
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Mohamed Abdullahi Mohamed, the American-educated  prime minister of Somalia, resigned Sunday after weeks of pressure to abide by a deal between two other top officials that extends Somalia’s wobbly transitional government for another year.

headline: At New Network, Olbermann Sets Sights on MSNBC
text: Starting on Monday, there will be new competition for progressive attention spans on television.

headline: U.S. Lineup vs. Jamaica
text: The biggest news on Sunday was that Landon Donovan, to many people the face of the U.S. national team and the career leader in goals and assists, has been benched by Coach Bob Bradley for the Concacaf Gold Cup quarterfinal against Jamaica in Washington.

headline: For 2012 Hopeful, Envoy Job in China Was a Useful Detour
text: As guests including Barbra Streisand and Yo Yo Ma mingled in three resplendent rooms in the White House in January to honor President Hu Jintao of China, David Axelrod, President Obama’s senior strategist, needed to take care of some political housekeeping.

headline: McIlroy Cruises to U.S. Open Victory
text: BETHESDA, Md. — During the first three days of the 111th United States Open, Rory McIlroy moved through the cheering galleries with a boyish smile and the occasional laugh, a young man playing near-flawless golf and enjoying the walk on the lush grounds of Congressional Country Club.

headline: Gates Acknowledges Talks with Taliban
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates acknowledged on Sunday that the United States had begun preliminary talks with members of the Taliban as part of an effort to end the war in Afghanistan.

headline: An Explosion in Universe of Web Names
text: PARIS — One of the biggest changes in the history of the Internet could be set into motion Monday. Whether that is a good thing or a bad thing remains open to fierce debate.

headline: Boeing to Decide This Year Whether to Revamp or Replace 737 Jet
text: PARIS — Boeing will decide this year whether to revamp its popular 737 jet with more fuel-efficient engines or to develop a new single-aisle jet, an executive of the company said on Sunday.

headline: Williams Returns to Wimbledon With Title to Defend and Ground to Make Up
text: LONDON — According to Serena Williams, her fearsome serve has not yet made the trip across the Atlantic Ocean, but she was definitely here Sunday: reflecting, joking and even yanking off her sneakers at one point to show a small group of American reporters the scars on her feet that symbolized her year of living dangerously.

headline: Some Early Stumbles by Niese Leave the Mets With Few Opportunities to Recover
text: After a sputtering beginning to the season, Jon Niese seemed to finally be finding his footing on the rubber, winning five of his last six decisions for the Mets before his start Sunday at Citi Field.

headline: Grieving, From Asbury Park
text: Fans of Bruce Springsteen gathered at the Stone Pony in Asbury Park, N.J., to mourn the loss of Clarence Clemons.

headline: Debate Swirls Around Research Showing Lung Problems for Returned Troops
text: As a teenager in northern New York, Gary Durham ran cross-country and hiked the Adirondack’s high peaks. In Army basic training, he did two-mile runs in under 13 minutes. But after a yearlong deployment to Iraq with the 101st Airborne Division in 2003, he says he started gasping for air while just mowing the lawn.

headline: Players Ratings: U.S. vs. Jamaica
text: Time for a change.

headline: The Big Man, Much More Than Springsteen’s Sideman
text: It was never just about the saxophone. In more than three decades wielding his tenor sax with Bruce Springsteen’s E Street Band, from its beginning in 1972 to his death at 69 on Saturday, Clarence Clemons was as much a symbol as a sideman.

headline: PNC Is Said to Be Near $3.45 Billion Deal for R.B.C. Unit
text: 6:01 p.m. | Updated The PNC Financial Services Group is near a deal to buy the Royal Bank of Canada’s American consumer banking operations for about $3.45 billion in cash and stock, people briefed on the matter said on Sunday.

headline: Internet Geeks and Freaks
text: A four-word anthem played on Twitter the other day, and I fell silent in awe: “SOCIAL MEDIA IS DISCO.”

headline: The Failure of Rational Choice Philosophy
text: According to Hegel, history is idea-driven. According to almost everyone else, this is foolish. What can “idea driven” even mean when measured against the passion and anguish of a place like Libya?

headline: Bargains on Flash Sale Sites Serve a Long-Range View
text: FLASH sale Web sites, a thriving e-commerce trend to promote limited-time sales, started as a way for brands to unload excess inventory in a controlled, high-end place. But now they have become something else: a way to advertise and find new customers, many of whom visit the sites of the brands and buy full-price merchandise soon after the sales.

headline: Two Women Love One Man, Worthy of Neither
text: Lee Martin, a 2006 Pulitzer Prize finalist for “The Bright Forever,” about a 9-year-old girl’s disappearance in rural 1970s Indiana, specializes in tautly written, unsettling novels that reveal the evil secrets lying just beneath the seemingly banal surfaces of American small towns. “Quakertown,” his first novel, took place in the titular African-American community in 1920s Denton, Tex.; the fictional Mount Gilead, Ill., was the setting for 2008’s “River of Heaven.”

headline: Beer. Nachos. Arena. Ballet?
text: LONDON — The idea was to bring the ballet to the masses, so it was perhaps inevitable that the masses would bring nachos, beer and hot dogs to the ballet.

headline: Monday: Employee-Abetted Crime
text: Administrivial Upcoming Tournament Alert!: If you plan to be in the New York City area in August, sign yourself up for the most fun you can have with a sharpened #2 pencil, Lollapuzzoola 4. Hosted by Brian Cimmet and Patrick Blindauer (who is not at all bitter that Brian beat him out as ACPT Division E Winner in 2009, I don’t care what Brian says), Lollapuzzoola is tons of fun and gaggles of crossword challenges in a single day for the low, low cost of $25.00. Kick in $5.00 more and they will convince you that you will be getting pizza at the end. Clicky here to read more about it and sign up.

headline: Taymor Tries to Reclaim a Reputation
text: LOS ANGELES — Breaking her silence about “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” the Broadway musical from which she was fired in March, Julie Taymor tacitly criticized her former producers on Saturday afternoon for relying on audience focus groups and said that the rise of Twitter and blogs for instant theater criticism was damaging to shows.

headline: Elena Bonner, Widow of Sakharov, Dies at 88
text: Elena G. Bonner, the Soviet dissident and human-rights campaigner who endured banishment and exile along with her husband, the dissident nuclear physicist Andrei D. Sakharov, died Saturday in Boston. She was 88.

headline: Al Jazeera at Home on a Former PBS Outlet
text: Even as Al Jazeera English continues its battle for broader cable distribution in the United States, it is reaping a growing audience in Los Angeles on a broadcast channel.

headline: Giggles and Cotton Candy Camouflaging the Raunch
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Katy Perry shrewdly polled her sold-out audience — at least 85 percent female, young and eager to scream — at Nassau Coliseum on Friday night. She asked who had just graduated from college, high school and junior high, and junior high won, decisively. That may be why Ms. Perry made her concert all bright colors, candy-shaped scenery and wide-eyed, kewpie-doll smiles. It was camouflage to keep parents from worrying.

headline: An Obsessive Killer Is Revealed in a Stylish Whodunit
text: Early on in “The Killing,” the American adaptation of a Danish thriller that has had a talked-about run on AMC, an unusually creepy funeral director guides a pair of bereaved parents through the retail dimensions of his mortuary. Mitch and Stan Larsen have lost their 17-year-old daughter, Rosie, to a deranged act of violence and stare achingly into the bottom of an expensive coffin they cannot afford. Trailing the couple as though they were shopping for hatchbacks, the undertaker offers that the object of their attention is “a beautiful choice for a young girl.” He goes on to instruct the Larsens on how their child should look for her interment, discreetly relishing the thought of her corpse in a pretty dress.

headline: Afghanistan Veteran, Afghan Sounds
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — Though the experienced arts administrator Thomas W. Morris is the official artistic director of the Ojai Music Festival, much of the artistic planning for this innovative annual four-day event is turned over each June to a rotating music director, who organizes the programs. This summer that artist was the soprano Dawn Upshaw, and not surprisingly she devised diverse and adventurous offerings.

headline: An Orphan, a Libertine and the Walking Dead
text: ST. LOUIS — The Opera Theater of St. Louis is a small, hardy institution not averse to risk. Its choice of John Adams’s “Death of Klinghoffer,” which opened triumphantly on Wednesday, was only the latest proof. Founded in 1976 and modeled after the Santa Fe Opera, another seasonal company, the theater earned its renown by championing opera in English, including standard works sung in translation, and by offering premieres and unusual, important revivals among its steady supply of user-friendly chestnuts.

headline: Captive to Politics and Radical Poetry
text: After a pair of critically lauded independent documentaries, “Street Life” and “Ghost Town,” Zhao Dayong turns to fiction in his new feature, “The High Life.” His subjects are the same — the rootlessness and avarice that afflict contemporary China, and the agonies of self-expression in a country that limits speech and effaces identity. His storytelling skills, however, are not at the same level in this awkward mash-up of what feel like two completely different movies.

headline: Great Time for a Perfect Read
text: The 60-board match that chose the U.S.A.-2 d’Orsi Senior Bowl Cup world championship team this month in Detroit was won by Gaylor Kasle of Boca Raton, Fla.; Larry Kozlove of Louisville, Ky.; Peter Boyd of Darnestown, Md.; Steve Robinson of Arlington, Va.; Neil Chambers of Schenectady, N.Y.; and John Schermer of Seattle.

headline: A Booed Winehouse Cancels Shows
text: Only weeks since checking out of an alcohol rehabilitation program, the British pop star Amy Winehouse, right, canceled part of her European tour after strange behavior during a performance on Saturday night in Belgrade, Serbia. During the concert, which one Serbian newspaper called “the worst in the history of Belgrade,” Ms. Winehouse was booed as she mumbled and stumbled her way through her performance, The Associated Press reported. A spokesman for Ms. Winehouse said that she would return to London after agreeing with management that “she cannot perform to the best of her ability.”

headline: New Group Lineup Features Rabe Play
text: The world premiere of a play by David Rabe is among the New Group’s productions for the 2011-12 season, the theater company announced. “An Early History of Fire,” a coming-of-age story set in the 1960s and directed by Jo Bonney, heralds Mr. Rabe’s return to original theater production after an eight-year absence. The Off Broadway New Group company previously collaborated with Mr. Rabe on a revival of his 1984 play, “Hurlyburly.” Other coming productions include “Russian Transport” by Erika Sheffer and “Burning” by Thomas Bradshaw (“The Bereaved”). Both plays will be directed by the company’s artistic director, Scott Elliott (“Marie and Bruce”).

headline: Love Does in Fact Die
text: The London production of “Love Never Dies,” the sequel to “Phantom of the Opera,” will close on Aug. 27 after running for a little more than a year, BBC News reported. Andrew Lloyd Webber’s troubled musical received poor opening reviews, underwent numerous rewrites and was ultimately met with a tepid reception at the box office. Although it was nominated this year for seven Olivier awards, including best new musical, it won none. The Sydney Morning Herald recently reported that Mr. Lloyd Webber would prefer to bring the better received Australian version to Broadway in the future, instead of the West End version.

headline: Genetic Basis for Crime: A New Look
text: It was less than 20 years ago that the National Institutes of Health abruptly withdrew funds for a conference on genetics and crime after outraged complaints that the idea smacked of eugenics. The president of the Association of Black Psychologists at the time declared that such research was in itself  “a blatant form of stereotyping and racism.”

headline: A Daily Deal Site Aimed Squarely at Gay Men
text: Like millions of people, Mario Correa wakes up every morning to an in-box full of offers and deals. But most of the time, he just isn’t interested. As he puts it, he doesn’t “want to learn to knit, go on a Segway ride, get my varicose veins removed or take a mommy-and-me yoga class.”

headline: A Wild Man-Child by Way of the Bolshoi Tears Up the Met Stage
text: The Bolshoi Ballet star Ivan Vasiliev, still in his early 20s, is just what you want a Russian male dancer to be: powerful, ardent, engaging and a bit on the wild side. Even without matinee-idol looks, he has loads of physical charm. His smile is happy, his dark brown hair is none too tidy, there’s a mischievous glint in his eyes, and he’s virile without having completely shaken off his boyishness. Vast though the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House is, he makes it look much too small for comfort when he tears around it. His jumps are out of all proportion to his medium height.

headline: In Milan: Rigor at Bottega Veneta; Wit at Prada
text: Rigor and humor, two qualities you don’t see much of in Milan, were the marquee features in two assured presentations bracketing a day that didn’t lack for stimulus, what with 11 scheduled fashion shows by major labels and dozens of presentations in showrooms across the city.

headline: Newcomers’ Arrival Scares Up Tales of the Mayan Apocalypse
text: XUL, Mexico — In Mayan, the name of this speck of a village means “the end.” A long time ago, it was just the end of the road. Those who tell tall tales, though, say the strangers who settled here four years ago have come to await the end of the world.

headline: War Crimes Charges Weighed as Crisis Continues in Syria
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration, seeking new ways to force the Syrian leadership to halt its violent crackdown on domestic dissent, is examining whether war crimes charges can be brought against President Bashar al-Assad, senior administration officials said.

headline: Union Square, 3:52 p.m.
text: Demonstrators demanding the legalization of same-sex marriage rallied in Union Square on Sunday.

headline: U.N. Reports Steady Rise of Refugees
text: PARIS — The United Nations refugee agency said Monday that as of last year, 43.7 million people around the globe had been forcibly displaced from their homes by conflict or persecution, the highest number in 15 years. Eighty percent of refugees were being sheltered in the world’s poorest countries, and the agency warned that they could not continue to shoulder the burden alone.

headline: Shop Talk for Prosecutors in Sex Crimes Cases
text: LOS ANGELES — What do sex crimes investigators do when they’re not investigating sex crimes? Among other things, they watch movies about sex crimes investigators.

headline: Risks of Reversing the Afghanistan Surge
text: WASHINGTON — In the 18 months since President Obama ordered a surge of 30,000 troops into Afghanistan, he has scaled back, time and again, Washington’s goals in a country that the British, the Soviets and ultimately the Americans tried, and failed, to change.

headline: Claims of Wartime Rapes Unsettle and Divide Libyans
text: The prosecutor of the International Criminal Court said this month that evidence was emerging that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi had authorized his soldiers to rape Libyan women, an assertion that seemed to support months of rumors about a brutal, continuing campaign.

headline: The Onion Is Seeking a Pulitzer, Any Pulitzer
text: Despite a professed designation as “America’s Finest News Source,” The Onion has never actually won the highest honor in American journalism: the Pulitzer Prize.

headline: Scrutiny of German Leader Builds as Debt Crisis Rattles Europe
text: BERLIN — When the euro became the common currency for many Europeans less than 10 years ago, it was feted by supporters as a grand opportunity, turning a historic page toward integration. Now, with the euro-zone debt crisis threatening to spread from Greece, the single currency represents an equally epochal challenge to shield the broader European project from derailment.

headline: MSG Vault: Rangers-Canadiens
text: A clip provided my MSG that shows footage from a 1953 game between the Rangers and Canadiens.

headline: A Brutal Hockey Fight in 1953 Finds New Life
text: In one swift and brutal sequence during a game in 1953 at Madison Square Garden, the Montreal Canadiens’ Bernard Geoffrion turned his stick into a weapon against Ron Murphy, a left wing for the Rangers.

headline: For Giffords, a Brief Taste of Her Old Life in Tucson
text: TUCSON — She went past her old haunts and her old hiking trails in a driving tour of this city she loves.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Soldiers and Militants Clash in Yemen, Leaving 21 Dead
text: SANA, Yemen — Yemeni security forces continued to battle Islamic militants in southern Yemen, leaving at least 21 dead over the weekend, according to a military official and a local doctor.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Burberry’s Well-Heeled Slacker
text: Heritage is played. The hype surrounding venerable brands had its moment and that moment is passed. The mere fact of putative antiquity is not enough to justify continuing consumer interest in established labels or designers who scour the back pages for mannerisms passed off as ideas.

headline: Blaming Incumbent for the Economy, a Political Tradition
text: WASHINGTON — A recent Republican Party news release aboutPresident Obama, Democrats and the economy declared simply: “They own it.”

headline: Federer Is a Favorite Again
text: WIMBLEDON, England — If you walked through the gates at the All England Club on Saturday for the first time this year and passed the still-vacant Centre Court, your peripheral vision would have picked up familiar movement on another patch of green.

headline: Afghanistan’s Last Locavores
text: Arlington, Va.

headline: Investors Provide Millions to Risky Start-Ups
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — What if you threw a $41 million party and nobody came? A start-up company called Color knows how that feels.

headline: House May Vote This Week on Money for Libya Strikes
text: WASHINGTON — The House appears likely to vote this week on a measure that would limit financing for the American military efforts in Libya, using the chamber’s appropriations power to push back against the White House, which did not seek Congressional authorization for the mission.

headline: Rand and Rubio
text: On domestic policy, the Republican candidates in last week’s primary debate seemed to speak with one voice: Cut taxes, cut spending, repeal Obamacare, declare victory.

headline: The Long Arm of the Law
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Nunez Fills In for Jeter With Hits, Errors, Hope
text: CHICAGO — In about 10 days, Derek Jeter is expected to return from the disabled list, at which point Eduardo Nunez will again assume his role of dutiful understudy. This, he knows, is not some Wally Pipp situation. “We’ll go back to the same way,” Nunez said with a laugh.

headline: Ugly Details in Selling Newspapers
text: Any look behind the curtain of Wall Street is not going to be pretty. But there is not pretty and then there is plain ugly.

headline: Get Radical: Raise Social Security
text: Chicago

headline: How Greek Debt Could Hurt U.S.
text: Europe is still embroiled in Greece’s sovereign debt crisis. It has been more than a year in the making, allowing many American financial firms time to slash even their indirect exposure. But money market funds are still sitting on $360 billion worth of European bank short-term debt. That leaves open a trans-Atlantic channel for Greek turmoil to play havoc with United States markets.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Suspicions Rise as Pakistan Bomb Labs Empty Before Raids
text: WASHINGTON — For the second time this month, bomb-making factories in Pakistan were evacuated shortly after American intelligence officials notified Pakistani security forces of their existence, fueling suspicions that such intelligence is being shared with insurgents.

headline: At High School in Queens, R.O.T.C.’s Enduring Influence
text: In 1994, when retired First Sgt. Richard Gogarty arrived at Francis Lewis High School in Queens to start an Army Junior R.O.T.C. program, only two staff members, one of them a custodian, would talk to him. The sergeant sat by himself in the teachers’ cafeteria, hoping someone would say something, even if it was just “please pass the salt.”

headline: A Military Education
text: An overcrowded, immigrant-dominated public high school in Queens is the unexpected home of one of the largest Junior ROTC programs in the nation, and it produces impressive results.

headline: Defend Muslims, Defend America
text: Chicago

headline: A Hallowed and Imperfect Ballpark
text: Chicago

headline: A.E.P. Protests Too Much
text: American Electric Power, one of the nation’s largest utilities, warned last week that new air quality rules could force it to “prematurely” shut down about two dozen big coal-fired units and fire hundreds of workers. This is a deceptive and particularly cynical claim. The utility is making a business decision that has little to do with the rules.

headline: A Goal Met Before Age 50, and No Training Wheels!
text: On a recent Sunday morning, Bruce Mauro let his girlfriend and two daughters assume he was heading out for his usual routine of playing the organ at church. Instead, he was taking care of some unfinished childhood business: he was learning to ride a bike.

headline: The Rookie Dream Must Be Lived to Be Understood
text: This Thursday, a new class of college players will enter the brave, new uncertain world of professional basketball as the N.B.A. holds its draft in Newark.

headline: In Death, a Young Author Is Born
text: New York, June 20, 1861

headline: Within the Industry, an Urge to Cash Out
text: SAN FRANCISCO — While Silicon Valley and Wall Street debate whether a new technology bubble is in the making, some early Facebook employees are not taking any chances. They’re leaving the company to cash out on millions of dollars in stock options while Facebook’s valuation continues to soar.

headline: Crashing the Party in Silicon Valley
text: Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times The partners at Felix Investments, from left, are John Bivona, Frank Mazzola and Emilio DiSanluciano. Felix has been buying shares in Facebook, Twitter and others.

headline: Mother Charged in Death of 5-Year-Old Boy in Bronx
text: A Bronx woman was arrested on Sunday in the death of her 5-year-old son, who was struck in the abdomen with such force that he suffered internal injuries, the police said.

headline: Renewing the I.M.F.
text: Watching the clumsy and clubby way the International Monetary Fund has been choosing a new managing director, you would not guess that its credibility as an impartial arbiter of global economic policies is at stake. It is.

headline: As Survivors Dwindle, Tulsa Confronts Past
text: TULSA, Okla. — With their guns firing, a mob of white men charged across the train tracks that cut a racial border through this city. A 4-year-old boy named Wess Young fled into the darkness with his mother and sister in search of safety, returning the next day to discover that their once-thriving black community had burned to the ground.

headline: Too Little, Too Late
text: With many local governments and states insisting they want out, the Obama administration says it is working to improve Secure Communities, its troubled data-sharing program that pushes local police to the front lines of immigration enforcement.

headline: Reading, Writing and Rodeo
text: Rodeo riders can earn college scholarships and professional prize money.

headline: A Welcome Silence
text: Last week, the wind pulled apart a sugar maple on the edge of the pasture. It left a long, tapering wound on the side of the standing trunk, and a huge, forking branch on the ground. Late one afternoon, I began disassembling it with a chainsaw. I loaded my tools — saw, sharpener, logging chain, gas — in the tractor bucket and put on my hearing protectors — orange plastic earmuffs — for the drive. Before I started the saw, I switched to a helmet with a face guard and built-in orange plastic earmuffs.

headline: Astride Rodeo’s Professional and Amateur Worlds
text: CASPER, Wyo. — JR Vezain leads a double life that many young athletes might envy. A top contender to be the Professional Rodeo Cowboy Association’s rookie of the year, he also recently completed his freshman year as a full-time college student on an athletic scholarship.

headline: Small Group Rode LinkedIn to Big Payday
text: For Reid Hoffman, the chairman of LinkedIn, it took less than 30 minutes to earn himself an extra $200 million.

headline: James P. Hosty, Investigated Oswald, Dies at 86
text: Special Agent James P. Hosty had a few dozen cases in his portfolio in October 1963 when his supervisor in the Dallas office of the F.B.I. handed him another. It was the well-thumbed file on a suspected communist agitator and possible spy named Lee Harvey Oswald.

headline: For a Couple, Strauss-Kahn Is a Case for Silence
text: Marc A. Agnifilo was at his weekend home in upstate New York near the Berkshires, watching his three children after dinner on a Saturday evening when his cellphone rang.

headline: Two Teenagers Shot With Rifle in Brooklyn
text: When a group of teenagers began to kick parked cars and rip open bags of garbage on a quiet street in Marine Park, Brooklyn, on Saturday night, a few residents ventured onto their front lawns and yelled at the group to leave. Others stayed indoors and watched from windows.

text: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction.
