headline: Bloomberg, Bypassing City Council, Asks Legislature to Allow Street Hails of Livery Cabs
text: With time ticking down on the legislative session in Albany, the Bloomberg administration made a new proposal on Sunday to accomplish one of its most highly publicized goals of the year: providing New Yorkers the right to legally hail a livery cab outside crowded parts of Manhattan.

headline: Companies Push for Tax Break on Foreign Cash
text: Some of the nation’s largest corporations have amassed vast profits outside the country and are pressing Congress and the Obama administration for a tax break to bring the money home.

headline: Nominees at Standstill as G.O.P. Flexes Its Muscle
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans are blocking a wide range of presidential nominees as a means of reshaping and restraining the Obama administration’s economic policies on prominent issues like housing, finance, foreign trade and offshore drilling.

headline: Frederick Chiluba, Infamous Zambia Leader, Dies at 68
text: Frederick Chiluba, the first democratically elected president of Zambia, a man whose image as a defender of civil liberties was later tarnished by his efforts to suppress political opposition and accusations that he used millions of dollars of public money on his wardrobe and other extravagances, died Saturday in Lusaka. He was 68.

headline: Few Taliban Leaders Take Afghan Offer to Switch Sides
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — Toor Jan, who used to kill Americans and Canadians here, does not want much from the Afghan government. A home. A job. And, yes, eight security guards.

headline: Inside the Accountants' Playbook
text: Background on four strategies that American companies use to reduce their taxes.

headline: For Coach and His Stars, a Win-Win Situation
text: Washington

headline: When Golden Couple Melts Down, Puddles Ensue
text: Now that Joely Richardson has returned to the New York theater, I have just one question: Can we keep her? Seen Off Broadway a decade ago as the older woman in Macaulay Culkin’s life in “Madame Melville,” Ms. Richardson has since become best known for her work on television (“Nip/Tuck,” “The Tudors”).

headline: Notes on ‘Game of Thrones’
text: By now, the idea that television serials like “The Sopranos” or “The Wire” are the great popular novels of our time feels like a cliché rather than an insight. But HBO’s adaptation of George R. R. Martin’s fantasy saga is one of the few high-profile attempts to take the cliche and try to literalize it, by faithfully translating a big fat teeming novel into a 10-episode television season. With exceptions like “True Blood,” which is based on Charlaine Harris’s vampire novels (though how closely I’m not sure, as a non-fan of the show and books  alike), few of the major cable dramas have been adaptations of existing stories. From Al Swearengen to Walter White to Stringer Bell, the great characters of television’s dramatic golden age have sprung from the imaginations of TV writers, rather than the printed page.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Ban on Hearing Aids Is Forcing Out Veteran New York City Police Officers
text: The New York Police Department’s policy regarding a job candidate’s hearing ability is straightforward enough: Applicants who fail a basic hearing test will not be hired as officers.

headline: Robber Kills 4 in L.I. Pharmacy; One Victim Is a 17-Year-Old Girl
text: Four people were shot and killed at a pharmacy in Medford, N.Y., on Sunday morning in what appeared to be an attempted robbery, the Suffolk County police said. One of the victims was a senior at a local high school who was to graduate this week.

headline: Father Stays on Sideline, Quietly Proud
text: BETHESDA, Md. — Teetering on his tiptoes, behind fans eight deep from the course, Gerry McIlroy stood along the sixth fairway of the United States Open on Sunday and could not see a thing.

headline: Charitable Giving Rose Last Year for First Time Since 2007

headline: A Fresh Young Star Easily Wins the Open, and the Fans’ Affection
text: BETHESDA, Md. — Golf’s next great prospect is every mother’s son, a self-effacing and unaffected 22-year-old from Northern Ireland, who bounced down the fairways to win his first major championship Sunday with a smile, a shrug and an incomparable swing.

text: NATO and the Afghan government are trying to bring Taliban fighters in from the cold, but the program is hampered by lack of infrastructure in key provinces, and doubts about who the defectors are.

text: NATO acknowledged Sunday that an errant missile had destroyed a civilian home in the Libyan capital in the early morning, saying it may have killed civilians.

headline: War Evolves With Drones, Some Tiny as Bugs
text: WRIGHT-PATTERSON AIR FORCE BASE, Ohio — Two miles from the cow pasture where the Wright Brothers learned to fly the first airplanes, military researchers are at work on another revolution in the air: shrinking unmanned drones, the kind that fire missiles into Pakistan and spy on insurgents in Afghanistan, to the size of insects and birds.

headline: From Blimps to Bugs: The Miniaturization of Drone Technnology
text: Aerial drones are transforming the way America fights and thinks about its wars. While the Cessna-sized Predator drones have become a brand name, military researchers are now at work shrinking these devices to the size of insects and birds.

headline: The Changing Shapes of Air Power
text: Drones are playing an increasingly important role in the American military. Only 10 years ago, the Pentagon had about 50 drones; now there are 7,000 drones in its inventory, ranging in size from large blimps to tiny Hummingbirds. Here are 10 drones currently on the battlefield or on the drawing board.

headline: Imagining the Future of Military Gadgetry
text: Micro air vehicles may seem like the stuff of science fiction, but, as our colleagues Elisabeth Bumiller and Thom Shanker report, they are a very real part of a drone explosion that is transforming the way America fights its wars. So as these “spy flies” — once found only in “Get Smart” and James Bond movies — are now being developed for espionage and the battlefield, The New York Times asked three spy novelists to speculate on the future of spy drones and military gadgetry.

headline: Japanese ‘K’ Computer Is Ranked Most Powerful
text: SAN FRANCISCO — In the rankings of the world’s most powerful supercomputers, a Japanese machine has earned the top spot with a performance that essentially laps the competition.

headline: Many Cities Face a Long Wait for Jobs to Return
text: Two years into a fitful recovery, unemployed Americans are getting painfully accustomed to the notion that it will take years to bring back the jobs eviscerated by the financial crisis.

headline: Charlotte R. Bloomberg, Mayor’s Mother, Is Dead at 102
text: Charlotte R. Bloomberg, the mother of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and a constant source of encouragement and wisdom for him, died on Sunday at her home in Medford, Mass., according to a statement from Mr. Bloomberg’s office. She was 102 years old.

headline: College Board Finds Minority Men Continue to Lag Academically
text: The College Board is releasing two reports today on the crisis facing young black and Latino men, who, the reports find, continue to be measurably less educated than minority women and white men.

headline: Swisher Makes Cubs Pay for Their Strategic Move
text: CHICAGO — More people crammed Wrigley Field to watch the Cubs play the Yankees this weekend than for any other three-game series in the venerable ballpark’s 97-year-history, a figure that does not include all the patrons filling aluminum bleachers beyond the outfield walls. Those fans sitting high atop Sheffield Avenue on Sunday night very well could have thought a ball was zooming in their direction in the eighth inning.

headline: Iranian Company Charged With Tricking U.S. Banks
text: An Iranian government-owned shipping line that the United States believes is integral to Iran’s efforts to obtain banned technology for its nuclear and missile programs has illegally funneled tens of millions of dollars in financial transactions through the American banking system over the past three years, evading sanctions by cloaking itself in corporate alter egos and falsifying records, according to an indictment that the Manhattan district attorney plans to unveil on Monday.

text: TOKYO — Japan and the United States will probably agree to delay the relocation of an American air base on Okinawa, Japan’s defense minister said, a decision that could encourage calls to rethink the stalled relocation plan.

headline: Profiling Jon Huntsman
text: Matt Bai on writing about Jon Huntsman. It was a process that began with meeting the candidate for the first time during a trip to New Hampshire and ends with a profile in this week's Magazine.

headline: Huntsman Steps Into the Republican Vacuum
text: ‘I’m not sure there’s any way to be prepared for something like this,” Jon Huntsman told me last month. He was reflecting on his debut a few days earlier as a prospective presidential candidate: a gorgeous Thursday evening in New Hampshire when his chartered plane touched down at a little airport and a waiting Suburban whisked him off to Jesse’s, a hillside steakhouse a few miles from the Dartmouth campus. As the recently departed ambassador to China and a former governor of Utah, Huntsman has some experience with polite, state-run media and small cliques of capital reporters. When he stepped out of the car, he had in mind that sort of familiar scene.

headline: What Makes a Graduation Ceremony Memorable?
text: Preschoolers, kindergartners, eighth graders, those who have finished courses of study in high schools, colleges, universities, military academies, trade schools, myriad professional training programs–they all don the graduation garb, walk across countless stages, hear words of encouragement and say “goodbye,” especially around this time of year. What do you remember most about graduation or other rite of passage ceremonies you’ve participated in or attended as a guest? What is the reason for such ceremonies?

headline: Devastation Pictured in the Details
text: Andrew Burton, 24, grew up in Australia and Oregon. He graduated from Syracuse University in 2010. He has interned with The Syracuse Post-Standard, Bloomberg News, The Oregonian and Getty Images, and now works as a freelance photographer and multimedia journalist for various organizations, including The New York Times. He covered the aftermath of the earthquake and tsunami in Japan. This conversation with Kerri MacDonald, for the Turning Point series, is condensed.

headline: Not Wrong, Again
text: I’ve written recently about what should be a well-known fact: Medicare spending has risen less than premiums on private health insurance. This shouldn’t be a controversial proposition; it comes straight from the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services health expenditure data. You can argue about why it’s happening and whether it’s sustainable, but the fact shouldn’t be up for dispute.

headline: Our Lost Decade Relationship
text: Clive Crook argues that we’re flirting with the possibility of a lost decade. I disagree — the flirting took place three years ago. The lost decade question now isn’t whether our flirtation with a lost decade will turn into something serious; it’s whether the torrid affair we’re now having with the potential for a lost decade can somehow be broken up.

headline: Top 10 Defensive Ends in N.F.L.
text: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely -– but not strictly -– by film study of all 32 teams from the 2010 season. Stats weren’t acknowledged, but players with poor numbers generally don’t make top 10 lists anyway. Vague enough for you? Criteria for top-10 lists tend to be. That’s why most of you will have no trouble finding some disagreement with what you’re about to read.

headline: Historic London Garden Gets a Makeover
text: The renovation of the gardens surrounding Chiswick House in west London, which took two years and cost £12.1 million (about $20 million) was completed last year and the gardens are now fully open to the public for the summer season. First developed in 1729, these 65 acres are considered the birthplace of the English Landscape Movement — not to mention the inspiration for New York’s Central Park.

headline: Congressional Week Ahead: Budget Talks Heat Up
text: Congressional budget talks with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. enter a critical phase this week with four meetings planned as the Fourth of July recess looms.

headline: A Mayor’s Recollections of Motherly Advice
text: As the sun set over a Staten Island community meeting last month, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg sped through questions about budget cuts, wind power and, inevitably, ferry service. But when a woman thanked him for helping save a popular local Boy Scouts camp, he slipped into unscripted territory.

headline: Complaint Box | I Don’t Have Kids. Deal With It.
text: I’m sick and tired of people who are parents thinking that those of us who have decided not to have children, for whatever reasons, regularly eat babies for breakfast. Many of us actually like kids, but we thought long and hard about the task of raising a child, and we decided against it.

headline: F.D.A. Confronts Challenge of Monitoring Imports
text: WASHINGTON — In her first two years as Food and Drug Administration commissioner, Dr. Margaret A. Hamburg has repeatedly expressed alarm about waves of imported food and drugs overwhelming her organization’s ability to monitor them. But she had not provided a strategy to deal comprehensively with this problem — until now.

headline: Best Political Quotes of the Weekend
text: Was your weekend too busy for paying attention to politics? No worries. The Caucus has compiled some of the best political quotes for you.

headline: Top 10 Fantasy Quarterbacks
text: Michael Vick tops our top 10 quarterbacks for the 2011 fantasy football season.

headline: Broadway Revival of ‘Born Yesterday’ to Close
text: It’s here today, gone tomorrow for “Born Yesterday” as that Broadway play will close on Sunday, its press representatives said on Monday. This latest production of Garson Kanin‘s comedy about a brutish tycoon, his girlfriend and the tutor entrusted with her education drew praise for the performance of its star Nina Arianda, who plays the dopey girlfriend, Billie. (Jim Belushi plays the tycoon and Robert Sean Leonard plays the tutor.) Ms. Arianda was compared favorably to Judy Holliday, who portrayed Billie in the original Broadway production and the George Cukor film version of “Born Yesterday,” and she was nominated for a Tony Award for leading actress in a play. The revival, directed by Doug Hughes (“Doubt”), also received a Tony nomination for costume design but did not win in either category. The production, which opened on April 24 at the Cort Theater, will have played 28 previews and 73 performances when it closes, its press representatives said.

headline: Woodford on Monetary and Fiscal Policy
text: One question I’ve been asked a lot is why I spent 2009 campaigning for fiscal expansion rather than monetary expansion. Well, at the Keynes conference this morning Mike Woodford gave an overview of policy options when you’re up against the zero lower bound that in some ways expressed better than I’ve managed to what I was thinking at the time.

headline: U.S. Ambassador’s Riposte to Karzai
text: As my colleagues Ray Rivera and Ginger Thompson reported on Sunday, the departing American ambassador to Afghanistan, Karl Eikenberry, took exception to critical remarks made a day earlier by President Hamid Karzai about the presence of foreign troops in an address on Afghan television.

headline: Poll Finds a Shift Toward More Libertarian Views
text: Libertarianism has been touted as the wave of America’s political future for many years, generally with more enthusiasm than evidence. But there are some tangible signs that Americans’ attitudes are in fact moving in that direction.

headline: How Old Is Jack McKeon?
text: 1:55 p.m. | Updated The Miami Herald has reported that Jack McKeon will return to the Marlins dugout Monday night as interim manager.

text: What: The latest jewelry fad

headline: Monday Reading: Bargains on European Cruises
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: Ain’t It Strange: Patti Smith on Her ‘Law & Order’ Experience
text: Maybe the most surprising detail about Sunday’s episode of “Law & Order: Criminal Intent” – based, don’tcha know, on the real-life circus that is Broadway’s “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” – was the number of times this procedural drama was able to work the word “dramaturge” into its dialogue. Or maybe it was the guest appearance by Patti Smith, the recording artist, poet and memoirist, as a Columbia University professor of mythology, who helps with the investigation of murder at a Broadway musical based on the story of Icarus.

headline: What’s It All About, Gucci?
text: Imagining Michael Caine is a cottage industry in fashion. We are talking about the early Michael Caine, the little-known British actor who became an international star in “Alfie,” a 1966 film that The New York Times critic of the era said “bubbles with humor and ripe modern wit” and that only those who now qualify for Social Security benefits are likely to have seen in its first run.

headline: Riske Takes Zvonareva to Three Sets
text: WIMBLEDON, England — After a disastrous first set, Alison Riske of the United States, playing one of the best matches of her career, steered herself into a third set against Vera Zvonareva of Russia, the second seed, in the 125th Wimbledon championship.

headline: Faulty Wiper Motor Prompts Recall of Mazda 3 and Mazdaspeed 3 Models
text: A problem with the windshield-wiper motor has prompted Mazda to recall about 409,000 of its 2008-9 Mazda 3 and Mazdaspeed 3 models worldwide, including about 103,000 in the United States.

headline: HopStop to Offer More Than Directions
text: When HopStop was founded in 2005, the idea that a user could type two addresses into a Web site and get reliable directions about how to travel between them on public transportation was a pretty unique idea. How times have changed. Today there are over 40 mobile apps focused on New York City’s transportation system alone, and Google gives directions for drivers, walkers and bus and subway riders through its Web site and its mobile app, which comes installed on many smartphones.

headline: Fish Sweeps Granollers in Three Close Sets
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Even though he had just won a tie breaker to claim the first set, Mardy Fish of the United States looked worried as he pulled a towel over his shoulder and changed ends during his first-round match against Marcel Granollers of Spain.

headline: Justices Rule for Wal-Mart in Class-Action Bias Case
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday threw out an enormous employment discrimination class-action suit against Wal-Mart that had sought billions of dollars on behalf of as many as 1.5 million female workers.

headline: Big Banks Lose Ruling on Research
text: A federal appeals court ruled on Monday that investment banks could not stop a financial Web site from immediately publishing the research recommendations of their stock analysts, delivering a blow to Wall Street and a win for the investing public.

headline: Chicago’s Baseball Rivalry Rivals New York’s
text: On the 2008 campaign trail, the usually diplomatic Barack Obama broke down Chicago baseball in three and a half sentences.

headline: Nadal Cruises Into the Second Round
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Rafael Nadal of Spain vaulted out of his chair and ran for the backcourt with a clenched fist and an eager expression as the Centre Court crowd murmured. He had trailed by 4-2 in an unexpected lapse during an opening-round match at the All England Club.

headline: Should Every Business Invest in Social Media?
text: I was taking the shuttle bus from an off-site airport parking lot this week when I noticed a large poster on the window of the bus. “Like Us on Facebook! Tweet Us on Twitter! Watch Us on YouTube!” it beseeched travelers. Really? Will someone please tell these people that they’re running a parking lot? Not that the video on their YouTube channel showing a natural gas fueling demonstration wasn’t compelling.

headline: Summing Up a Father’s First Year
text: As the creator of Six-Word Memoirs, Smith Magazine founder Larry Smith has encouraged people to process many of life’s most interesting moments in six-word sound bites.

headline: Jon Huntsman: The Unfrozen Caveman Candidate?
text: My article in next Sunday’s magazine on Jon Huntsman, the soon-to-be-official Republican presidential candidate, went live on the Web this morning. If you’re the kind of person, though, who preferred the “Wuthering Heights” Cliffs Notes to the all-night reading experience before the exam, then you can also watch my short video recap here, expertly edited by The Times’s Ben Werschkul. Everything you always wanted to know about Jon Huntsman, and considerably less.

headline: Scorecard | Burberry Prorsum Wins!
text: Status Update: It’s Scorecard season, again. From the panoply of rockabilly chic on the opening day of Milan fashion week, it was evident even without the newsfeed at Dolce & Gabbana that designers were in the mood for some nostalgic Bandcamp surfing. Apologies to Raf Simons, who proved himself a master of postmodernist sartorial play in his collection for Jil Sander, but critical consensus was Christopher Bailey’s flip-flop luxe look at Burberry Prorsum might go over better with the accidental billionaire generation.

headline: ‘Hobbit’ Cast Adds Evangeline Lilly, Dame Edna and Sherlock Holmes
text: If your natural inclination is to spell the word “color” using the letter u, there’s a good chance you have just been cast in Peter Jackson’s ever-expanding film adaptation of “The Hobbit.” In a Facebook post published over the weekend, Mr. Jackson announced that his two-movie version of that J. R. R. Tolkien fantasy novel would feature Evangeline Lilly, a “Lost” alumna; Barry Humphries, the comedian best known for his garish alter ego, Dame Edna Everage; and Benedict Cumberbatch, who plays the title character on the television series “Sherlock.”

headline: McQueen’s ‘Voodoo Rock ‘n’ Roll’
text: (Three hours later and in a warehouse across the city, Sarah Burton, the Alexander McQueen designer, gave a gleeful laugh when told of the Kray brothers reference. Previewing her show, the first for the label since she designed the wedding dress for Catherine Middleton, she pointed out that it, too, draws on the English 1960s, that inexhaustible mine of style. “It’s rock ‘n’ roll, with stripes and checks, a very McQueen shoulder and fuller trousers,” Ms. Burton said, adding that the special jet embroidered pieces, a distinctive McQueen touch, were “also rock ‘n’ roll, but voodoo rock ‘n’ roll.”)

headline: Battle Waged Over Real Estate Gossip on the Web
text: A Web site, now defunct, that claimed to expose “the underbelly of the Manhattan real estate market” by reporting on bad broker behavior, abusive landlords and run-down apartments quickly became a forum for bitter accusations against landlords, brokers, real estate industry co-workers and even roommates.

headline: Curtain Down Heads Up: Advice for Broadway Producers and Casting Directors
text: Readers had a lot to say about two recent theater-related articles, one that explored the line between success and struggle on Broadway and another that took a close look at the challenging work of Broadway casting directors.

headline: British Store Sells Old New York ‘Don’t Walk’ Signs. Only £975.
text: Consider the “Don’t Walk” sign, that lost classic of the New York streetscape. It is a yin-yang traffic signal, a functional poem — “Don’t Walk/Walk” — inside an iconic yellow box. It is to Martin Scorsese’s midcentury Manhattan what the gas lamp is to Edith Wharton’s gilded age.

headline: Is It Too Late for the Damba?
text: Tuesday, June 14

headline: The Lights Are On Again at Monte’s in Gowanus
text: It’s been 105 years since Angelo and Angelina Monte opened the Brooklyn landmark once called Monte’s Venetian Room, known for its murals of Venice, and its Rat Pack clientele. Now, after having been closed for more than two years, new owners, Tina Esposito and her husband, Dominick Castelvetre, have refurbished the restaurant, but without the murals. “They were gone when we took over,” Ms. Esposito said. But except for a new marble top, they’ve left the bar room alone, just cleaning and brightening it.The menu is less focused on traditional “parmigiana” dishes, offering more authentically regional Italian fare. The chef, Salvatore Zapparata, is a native of Sicily.

headline: Announcing Historic Headlines
text: As promised, we’ll be experimenting with new features this summer, and this is our first: a collaboration with Finding Dulcinea to highlight, and add to, our popular On This Day feature.

text: We’re trying something new this week by collaborating with findingDulcinea to bring you a new Historic Headline each day. Read more about it here, and let us know what you think!

headline: Harbin Electric to Be Sold for $750 Million
text: Harbin Electric has signed an agreement to be sold to its chief executive, Tianfu Yang, for $24 a share, the latest chapter in the continuing story of Chinese companies listed in the United States.

headline: Spin Magazine Fires Publisher and Editor
text: Spin, the alternative-music magazine founded in 1985, has fired its editor and publisher, part of a larger transformation that will expand the publication’s presence online.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Franchitti and Power Deadlocked Atop IndyCar Leader Board
text: The horse race began in earnest on June 11 at the Texas Motor Speedway, when Dario Franchitti won the first Firestone Twin 275 but surrendered the second race to Will Power, who at the time was the overall IndyCar series leader. At the Milwaukee Mile last weekend, Franchitti’s equalizing performance left no doubt that IndyCar had a genuine, ratings-boosting rivalry on its hands.

headline: The Comparisons Have Begun
text: Perhaps you missed it over the weekend amid the constant burbling of golf’s talking heads, who were beside themselves over their newfound savior, Rory McIlroy (what they were really saying: “We’re relevant again! People love this kid. They might actually watch us!”), but we believe there was an official announcement at Congressional Country Club on Sunday: Ladies and gentlemen, start your Tiger Woods comparisons!

headline: Expert Network Consultant Is Convicted in Insider Trading Case
text: 8:37 p.m. | Updated During the insider trading trial of the expert network consultant Winifred Jiau, the government’s central witness referred to her as “the Poohster.” And as is the case in the adventures of Winnie the Pooh, it was a sweet tooth that brought her down.

headline: Sentence of the Week, Noah’s Ark Edition
text: This week, for some reason, the sentences came in pairs: two each from Haruki Murakami, Helen DeWitt and James Joyce. Even the people who are only quoted once — John Jeremiah Sullivan and Bonzi Wells — have a hint of doubleness: Wells repeats the words “million dollar”; Sullivan talks about a “double hallucination.”

headline: Hope and Dread in Tech I.P.O.s

headline: Asparagus With an Italian Twist
text: Some weeks all I want to cook is Italian food, and so it was this week as I availed myself of the last of the season’s asparagus. Italians have a way with this vegetable, both the pencil-thin stalks that grow wild in the countryside and the thicker cultivated varieties.

headline: Beatles Tribute ‘Rain’ Will Dry Up on Broadway
text: And in the end, “Rain: A Tribute to the Beatles on Broadway,” a production that recreates the music of the Fab Four, will play its final performance at the Brooks Atkinson Theater on Sept. 4, its press representatives said on Monday. Rather than splitting into separate tribute shows for Wings and the Plastic Ono Band, “Rain” will embark on a national tour through 2012. (Productions in Singapore and Johannesburg are scheduled for this summer as well.) The Broadway production, which opened at the Neil Simon Theater in October, will have played 8 previews and 341 regular performances when it closes.

headline: Documentaries Delve Into the Sushi Economy
text: In the greater Paris region, where I live and work, there are more than 1,600 sushi restaurants. They are springing up faster than can be counted in Eastern Europe, India and China, not to mention Los Angeles and New York.

headline: New York State Capitol, 11:03 A.M.
text: Protesters urged the State Senate not to legalize same-sex marriage.

headline: McHale Upsets Makarova
text: WIMBLEDON, England –- Unseeded Christina McHale of the United States upset 28th-seeded Ekaterina Makarova of Russia Monday in a three-set battle, 2-6, 6-1, 8-6, to make the second round of the 125th Wimbledon Championships.

headline: Elder Care Specialists: A Missed Opportunity
text: File under: Another Smart Idea That’s Not Happening (Yet).

headline: N.Y.U. Teaching Assistants’ Unionization Hopes Get a Boost
text: Many graduate teaching assistants at New York University and a dozen other private universities are spoiling to unionize, but they have been frustrated by a 2004 ruling from the National Labor Relations Board saying they cannot unionize because they are students, not employees.

headline: City Payroll Project Was Riddled With Fraud, U.S. Says
text: Nearly all of the $600 million that New York City has paid to the main contractor for its troubled automated payroll project has been tainted by fraud, prosecutors said Monday in announcing a new indictment that charged two technology executives and their company in what a United States attorney called a “massive and elaborate scheme.”

headline: Hope and Dread in Tech I.P.O.’s
text: There are signs that a new technology bubble is inflating, focused on a narrow sector of social media companies. DealBook’s Evelyn M. Rusli talks to Nelson D. Schwartz about whether the valuation fears are valid.

headline: In Shot After Shot, a Challenge to Woods
text: Bethesda, Md.

headline: Salad Matrix Bonus Recipe
text: You can add almost anything edible to greens and call it salad, but there are at least a few terrific combinations that have stood the test of time. Eagle-eyed readers will notice that I’ve paid tribute to a couple of them in Sunday’s Eat column for the magazine.

headline: Investing Should Be Dull
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

headline: Pujols to Miss 4-6 Weeks With Fractured Wrist
text: Albert Pujols’s roller-coaster season continued on Sunday when the all-world slugger injured his left wrist and shoulder in a collision at first base with the Royals’ Wilson Betemit, casting a shadow over the Cardinals’ 5-4 win.

headline: China’s Boom Is Beginning to Show Cracks, Analysts Say
text: SHANGHAI — New economic analyses of China provide further indication that the nation’s supercharged economy is beginning to slow, and warn that soaring inflation, rising labor costs and mounting local government debt threaten to weaken growth even more.

headline: Summertime, and the Viewing Is Easy?
text: For television programmers, the lazy, hazy, crazy days of summer are not so lazy anymore. Broadcast networks as well as cable channels now fill their summertime schedules with new episodes of shows during what was for many years a no-viewer’s land of reruns.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: CNN’s Ed Henry to Join Fox News
text: 5:00 p.m. | Updated Ed Henry, CNN’s senior White House correspondent, is leaving that job for the top White House position at the network’s principal rival, the Fox News Channel.

headline: Nearly 1,200 Vehicles Toast Louis Chevrolet in Switzerland
text: The annual owner’s rally for Chevrolet enthusiasts held in La Chaux-de-Fonds, Switzerland, the town of Louis Chevrolet’s birth, used to attract a few dozen vehicles in a good year. On Sunday, to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the brand, close to 1,200 Chevrolets descended on the town.

headline: Asia Society Plans Exhibition of Ai Weiwei New York Photos
text: Long before he was a star of the international art world and a target of the Chinese government, the artist Ai Weiwei was at the center of an obscure group of Chinese cultural emigrés in the East Village, a community that he documented in some 10,000 photographs in the decade that he lived there, from 1983 to 1993. Now, while Mr. Ai remains under detention in China, without formal charges, the Asia Society is preparing to open an exhibition of 227 of his New York photographs. They show not only important East Village events like Wigstock and local characters like Allen Ginsberg, but also humble gatherings in Mr. Ai’s Third Street apartment featuring people like the artist Xu Bing, the filmmaker Chen Kaige and the composer Tan Dun, all now major Chinese cultural figures who were then toiling in immigrant obscurity.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Tim Blett, senior partner and senior vice president at Doner, Southfield, Mich., who had been the head of the agency’s office in Newport Beach, Calif., is stepping down and selling his interest in Doner back to the agency. Three executives at the office are assuming his duties: Brian Born, senior vice president and creative director; Henni Sanft, senior vice president and director for planning and research; and Peter Watkins, senior vice president for brand leadership. Mr. Blett’s departure leaves two remaining partners at Doner: David DeMuth, president and co-chief executive, and Rob Strasberg, co-chief executive and chief creative officer.

headline: Milan Top 5 | Burberry Prorsum
text: There was an air of the exotic in Christopher Bailey’s great Burberry Prorsum collection. Brightly colored tribal prints covered jackets and camp shirts, while coats sprouted woven raffia collars and trim. Lace-ups with jute and ethnic-inspired fabric insets and woven totes perfect for an open air market completed this global nomad’s look.

headline: Lidstrom Chooses One More Year With Wings
text: The Detroit Red Wings have received the news they were hoping for, that their captain and All-Star defenseman Nicklas Lidstrom will be returning for a 20th season.

headline: Bronx Man Is Charged in Death of 3-Year-Old Girl
text: The police arrested a 26-year-old Bronx man, Edgar Algarin, on murder and manslaughter charges on Monday after a 3-year old girl in his care was discovered dead on Saturday.

headline: Portable Pools Pose Drowning Risk
text: Wading pools and larger portable pools have grown in popularity, but they also pose a serious safety risk to young children and lack the security features of larger in-ground backyard pools, new research shows.

headline: Caucus | Focus on Afghanistan and Libya
text: John Harwood and Mark Landler discuss two crucial foreign policy debates in the weeks ahead. Also, Matt Bai reflects on his piece about Jon Huntsman, the likely presidential candidate.

headline: ‘Dr. Oz’ Show Wins Daytime Emmy
text: The medical talk show “Dr. Oz” was a first-time winner at the Daytime Emmy Awards, which were telecast by CBS on Sunday night.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Missoni
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#458", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

headline: The ‘Killing’ Finale: Clearer Than You Thought
text: The first season of AMC’s much-talked about series “The Killing” ended on Sunday night with what many viewers and most critics believe was an entirely ambiguous (and frustrating) conclusion. Call me crazy — and legions of readers and a couple of good friends already have — but I do not share that view.

headline: Treatment May Help Ease Effect of Cancer
text: Top plastic surgeons from around the country met in Manhattan last month to observe an experimental surgery that may cure lymphedema, a serious complication of breast cancer treatment.

headline: Video: Foreign Policy Debates; Covering Jon Huntsman
text: John Harwood and Mark Landler discuss two crucial foreign policy debates — on the United States’ role in Afghanistan and Libya — that may culminate in the weeks ahead. Also, Matt Bai reflects on profiling the presidential candidate Jon M. Huntsman Jr.

headline: Sensing the Wonder of Science, in Flight
text: I HAVE a bachelor’s degree in physics and a master’s in social science. I do a lot of cultural anthropology and I find airports fascinating.

headline: Assad’s Image Pelted With Shoes After Speech
text: As my colleague Anthony Shadid reports, Syrian President Bashar al-Assad’s address on Monday, in which he promised reform but said that the state had to use force against “saboteurs,” was met with disappointment and anger by his opponents.

headline: Milk as Menace
text: Q. Some singers swear that drinking milk creates phlegm. True? And do dairy products make a cough worse?

headline: When Running Up Mileage, 10 Percent Isn’t the Cap
text: My friend Martin Strauss of Ann Arbor, Mich., was running 60 miles a week when he suffered a stress fracture that put him on crutches for three months. Now that he’s better, he wants to play it safe to avoid another injury. But what’s the best way to do that? How quickly can he ramp up the miles?

headline: Monday Morning Skate: Top Free Agent Defensemen, Bruins’ Second-Round Success, Draft Preview
text: The free agency signing period begins July 1 and many teams will be shopping for impact defenders. None are of the available ones are of the franchise-altering variety, but they could help teams in their pursuit of the Stanley Cup.

headline: Stereotyping Patients, and Their Ailments
text: When Mr. S. was doing time at Rikers Island in the early 1990s, he was given a standard battery of tests for the medical ailments that run rampant behind bars — AIDS, hepatitis, tuberculosis. He received the unwelcome news that he was H.I.V. positive, though his T-cell count was still in the normal range.

headline: Five Tips to Avoid Travel Photo Clichés
text: In three decades as a photographer for Smithsonian Magazine, Michael Freeman has been asked to shoot some of the world’s most picturesque locales. But they are also some of the world’s most photographed, which presents a challenge. When photographers have had nearly 100 years to perfect the shot of, say, the Taj Mahal, how do you improve on shots so classic they have become cliché?

headline: Russian Oil Tycoon Sent to Prison Again, Near Finland
text: MOSCOW — Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former Russian oil company owner and convicted felon who has already served one prison sentence in Siberia, was sentenced this month to serve his second term in a penal colony in a northern region bordering Finland.

headline: New Hurdle Is Placed for Loan to Greece
text: ATHENS — Pressure rose on Greece on Monday after a surprise decision by euro zone finance ministers to delay a loan payment until the troubled Greek government secures a confidence vote from Parliament.

headline: In Tiny Worm, Unlocking Secrets of the Brain
text: In an eighth-floor laboratory overlooking the East River, Cornelia I. Bargmann watches two colleagues manipulate a microscopic roundworm. They have trapped it in a tiny groove on a clear plastic chip, with just its nose sticking into a channel. Pheromones — signaling chemicals produced by other worms — are being pumped through the channel, and the researchers have genetically engineered two neurons in the worm’s head to glow bright green if a neuron responds.

headline: EMI Puts Itself Up for Sale. Again.
text: EMI, the music company that was seized by Citigroup in February after a disastrous four-year ownership by the private equity firm Terra Firma, is going up for sale again.

headline: General Says Shorten Army Combat Tours to 9 Months
text: WASHINGTON – To fight the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, the Army has sent its troops on 12-month deployments to the combat zones, sometimes with not even a full year back home before being ordered off to fight again. Some soldiers even served 15-month stints.

headline: Obama Starts Tweeting for Himself
text: Over the weekend, President Obama did something his Internet fans have long dreamed of: He sent a Father’s Day message in his own words via the @BarackObama Twitter account. The 122-character tweet was also posted to the Barack Obama page on Facebook.

headline: Thorny Night in the Rose City
text: The Red Bulls’ 3-3 tie late Sunday night (New York time) in their first visit to Portland, Ore., for a game in Major League Soccer had a little bit of everything as the club reclaimed the top spot in the Eastern Conference with its eighth draw of the season.

headline: Only Connect
text: The tiny roundworm known as C. elegans is an excellent subject for studying neural networks.

headline: Compensating Stanford’s Investors
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission froze the assets of R. Allen Stanford’s financial empire almost two years ago. But authorities are still figuring out whether investors can get compensated for some of their losses

headline: Defying Father Time: A McKeon-Inspired Highlight Reel
text: It looks like Jack McKeon can’t get enough.

headline: Little Girls, Everywhere: Portraits From the ‘Annie’ Open Casting Call
text: Residents of several Upper East Side blocks awoke one recent Sunday morning not to the peals of church bells or birdsong, but to Katie Schults, of Glen Ridge, N.J., belting out “Tomorrow,” from the musical “Annie,” as if her 14-year-old life depended on it.

headline: Perceptions: Cancer Drugs Get on a Faster Track in U.S.
text: New cancer drugs are approved in just six months on average in the United States, half the time it takes for the same drugs to be approved in Europe, a new report finds.

headline: Asia’s Heavy Use of Asbestos Is Expected to Cause Rise in Deaths in Coming Decades
text: Deaths from asbestos-related diseases will surge in Asia over the next 20 years, a recent study has warned.

headline: Broadway’s Prince Revisits Material That Earned Him the Title
text: Harold Prince, who has won more Tony Awards than anyone in history — 21 — for producing and directing some of the greatest musicals of the 20th century, is planning a return to Broadway in the fall of 2012 with a new show that celebrates and re-examines some of the material from his theater career. Dancap Productions announced on Monday that the new musical, “Prince of Broadway,” is in development for a production to begin in Toronto in the summer of 2012 to be followed by a Broadway run.

headline: Recomposing Life’s Details From Scraps
text: PHILADELPHIA — For decades, Frank Bender has stared at human skulls, handled them, even boiled scraps of flesh off them. He has done this to shape clay busts in the hope of giving names to rotting corpses and skeletons found in woods or alleys or abandoned houses.

headline: Fantasy First Take: Quarterbacks
text: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for the 2011 season. Follow them on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy) for more news and analysis.

headline: The March of Progress, According to I.B.M.
text: With a first print run of more than 500,000 copies, it qualifies as a truly big book in the publishing world, even if you’ve probably never heard of it.

headline: A Bookshop Opens for a One-Month Stand in Washington Hts.
text: “This did not look like this two hours ago,”  Veronica Liu said as she surveyed the crowd at Word Up, Washington Heights’ newest, possibly even first, pop-up bookstore. It was 8 p.m. on Friday. At 6 p.m. — Word Up’s stated opening time — Heights residents and newly recruited volunteers were still moving boxes into the former pharmacy storefront on Broadway and 176th Street, where the community bookstore is in residency until mid-July.

headline: Just One Look | Chloé Resort Collection
text: Clare Waight Keller will make her debut at Chloé for spring 2012. But in the meantime, the design team is sticking to the DNA of the brand. Resort has that 1970s vibe: secretary scarf blouses, superwide trousers, trapeze dresses and this breezy, romperlike top and skirt ensemble.

headline: Asparagus Rolled in Herb Crêpes
text: A simple and elegant way to serve asparagus, this dish makes a great main course for a vegetarian dinner party. It can be assembled ahead of time and baked just before serving.

headline: Explaining Sperm Donation to a Preschooler
text: Two of the most talked-about stories in The New York Times on Father’s Day were about sperm donors.

headline: With Sales Strong, Audi Designs a $14.3 Million Party Hall for Frankfurt Auto Show
text: 12:32 p.m. |Update

headline: Drawing Dance: Merce in Moscow
text: The Brooklyn-based artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting their two-year Legacy Tour through a series of drawings and paintings. After 58 years, the company is scheduled to disband on New Year’s Day 2012.

headline: Managing Risk in Booming ‘Global Bazaar’ of Food and Drugs
text: The Food and Drug Administration, racing to keep up with explosively growing global flows of food, drugs and other products it tracks, has released a report outlining how it plans to minimize threats to public health and welfare.

headline: Friendlier Court Replaces Wimbledon ‘Graveyard’
text: WIMBLEDON, England — For the record, the first stroke hit during a match on Wimbledon’s new Court 3 was a missed first serve by Katie O’Brien at 12:01 p.m. Monday.

headline: App Smart Extra: Picking Age-Appropriate Movies
text: In my current App Smart column, I describe some of the difficulties I had with movie-related apps that failed to provide quick information on the content of children’s movies. If the developers of the best movie apps have children – or any concerns about their children’s exposure to profanity, violence or sexual situations – it didn’t show.

headline: N.Y. Legislature Tightens Rules on Water Withdrawals
text: New York State is poised to take a new step to protect its water: a just-approved bill awaiting Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s signature would impose new restrictions on withdrawals of large volumes of water from lakes, rivers and streams.

headline: TimesCast | June 20, 2011
text: The Supreme Court throws out a lawsuit against Wal-Mart; Syria's President says other political parties can now exist, but critics are skeptical; and questions over the death of a Libyan guard.

headline: U.S. Bank and Chase Add to E.M.V. Chip Cards for Travelers
text: U.S. Bank is joining the small-but-growing ranks of American financial institutions offering credit cards with tiny, secure microprocessing chips that are widely used overseas. But U.S. Bank’s card, aiming for maximum flexibility, uses technology that lets the card work with three different payment systems.

headline: Pregnancy: Weight-Loss Surgery May Affect Fertility
text: Weight loss surgery may have helped restore fertility in a handful of extremely obese women who were unable to have children because of a hormonal imbalance caused by polycystic ovarian syndrome, according to a report presented at a recent medical conference.

headline: Justices Rebuff States on Utilities’ Gas Emissions
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday unanimously rejected a lawsuit that had sought to force major electric utilities to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions without waiting for federal regulators to act.

headline: With Clock Ticking, No Agreements to Report in Albany
text: The order of the day in Albany? Let’s not make a deal.

headline: Explaining Sunscreen and the New Rules
text: Attention, sun lovers (and yes, that includes all who think they are adequately protected against the sun’s damaging rays): Nearly four years after announcing its intention to improve the labeling of sunscreens, the Food and Drug Administration has finally issued new rules that should help reduce the confusion that currently prevails when consumers confront the aisle-long array of products in most pharmacies.

headline: A Feat of Engineering That Doubles as a Home
text: I live in a nice clapboard house and work in a gleaming steel-and-glass skyscraper, but after reading “Avian Architecture: How Birds Design, Engineer and Build,” I feel cheated. I’ll never get to enjoy the comforts of the nest of a long-tailed tit.

headline: Historical Health Advertisements
text: A selection of posters from the art exhibit “Health for Sale: Posters from the William H. Helfand Collection” at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

headline: Photo Replay: June 20
text: The day in sports included rain at Wimbledon, Bruins goalie Tim Thomas shaving his beard for charity, and celebrations for Rory McIlroy in Holywood, Northern Ireland.

headline: Spoonfuls of Medicine, Marketed for Centuries
text: Everyone knows you can’t buy health, but that has never stopped anyone from trying to sell it to you. As a small, gorgeous and fiercely funny exhibition of posters at the Philadelphia Museum of Art makes clear, the marketing of this particular noncommodity is an enduring art in every sense of the word.

headline: Lincoln Center Chairwoman Plays Dual Role in China
text: This spring Katherine G. Farley, the chairwoman of Lincoln Center, has been involved in developing two projects in China: a consulting deal in which Lincoln Center will help the government build a performing arts center in Tianjin and a construction project in which her company, Tishman Speyer, is building offices and residential projects next door.

headline: Taxi Drivers Rally Against the Mayor’s Livery Cab Bill
text: The fate of the Bloomberg administration’s plan to enable livery drivers to pick up street hails outside Manhattan was unclear on Monday, as versions of the bill were being weighed in Assembly and Senate committees in Albany. Meanwhile, a crowd of drivers of yellow taxis gathered at City Hall to denounce the plan.

headline: The Land of Dik Diks and Pangolins
text: Kay E. HoleKamp, a zoologist at Michigan State University, writes from the Masai Mara National Reserve in Kenya, where she is studying the behavior of spotted hyenas.

headline: Hazards: A Pacemaker Is Found to Carry Risk
text: A special type of pacemaker fails to help almost half of the heart patients who get it, and now researchers believe they know why.

headline: Hackers Declare War on Government Agencies
text: The Internet may be about to get a little more chaotic than usual. Over the weekend, a group of hackers declared that they are initiating cyber warfare with governments and security companies around the world.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Russia and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Russia, Syria, China and New Jersey.

headline: Really? The Claim: Pets Can Raise a Child’s Risk of Developing Allergies
text: THE FACTS

headline: Once Rare, Infection by Tick Bites Spreads
text: A potentially devastating infection caused by tick bites has gained a foothold in the Lower Hudson Valley and in coastal areas of the Northeast, government researchers have found.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Syria, China, Pakistan and Nepal.

headline: In Opposition to Teacher Layoffs, de Blasio (and Wife) Take the Lead
text: The battle against Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s proposed budget cuts have spurred offensives from many corners. There has been rally after rally attended by thousands of labor loyalists. There have been spontaneous expressions of discontent staged by parents outside schools across the city. And there’s Bloombergville, the sleep-in protest organized by students and social workers near City Hall.

headline: The Day After: Dissecting McIlroy
text: Glory, glory, The Belfast Telegraph writes about Rory McIlroy’s record-breaking victory at the United States Open on Sunday, adding that his “genius” at Congressional Country Club in Bethesda, Md., “has us all gasping.” Of course, the local coverage notes some ambivalence: his eight-stroke victory proves nice guys finish first, but will the news media and the golf world try to make him out to be some kind of saint?

headline: Director or No, Wall Street’s Newest Cop Is Ready for Duty
text: Michael Houghton for The New York Times Richard Cordray runs the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau’s enforcement division.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Gucci
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#666", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

headline: Tall Tales From Gifted Storytellers
text: “Cruelty, like every other vice, requires no motive outside of itself; it only requires opportunity.” This George Eliot quotation is the cynical and telling epigraph to Adam Ross’s noirish, self-consciously constructed stories — a collection that underscores the same dark view of human relationships that animated his debut novel, “Mr. Peanut” (2010), which focused on a man’s morbid fantasies of killing his wife.

headline: ‘Ladies and Gentlemen’
text: Middleman

headline: Numberplay: Bubble Magic
text: Frank Morgan played five delightful roles in the classic movie “The Wizard of Oz,” including that of the wizard himself. This film had a lot of bubble magic in it. The good witch’s favored mode of transport was a floating bubble, Emerald City was enclosed in a bubble, and horses changed color like soap bubbles. Two weeks ago, at the Math Encounter talk I recently wrote about, I was treated to some real bubble magic, by another Frank Morgan.

headline: Keeping Score on How You Take Your Medicine
text: Most people are well aware that companies compile credit scores on just about everyone. Now, one company is planning to rate how likely people are to take prescribed medication.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Rome, Open City'
text: A. O. Scott looks back at Roberto Rossellini's film about the struggle against oppression.

headline: Letter Highlights Divisions Among Republicans on Libya
text: Underscoring the increasing divisions within the Republican Party over the United States’ involvement in Libya, 37 conservative former government officials and foreign policy experts wrote an open letter to Congress on Monday urging members not to cut funding for military involvement in the NATO-led operations in that nation.

headline: A Pair of Siegfrieds Complete the ‘Ring’
text: SAN FRANCISCO — One of the toughest challenges for an opera company presenting Wagner’s four-part “Ring” cycle, even beyond the complexities and costs of mounting a production, is finding a tenor who can sing Siegfried.

headline: Are Moms and Dads Interchangeable?
text: The ongoing discussion about “Torn: True Stories of Kids, Career & the Conflict of Modern Motherhood” and the announcement of the creation of the Fathers Forum both led readers to ask versions of the same question in the comments: Can we assume mothers to be different from fathers? If they are not, then what institutional, social and historical obstacles are to blame for reinforcing unequal roles and expectations? And if they are, then how? And what do those differences mean institutionally, socially and historically?

headline: The Passions and Travails of a Jazzy Everywoman
text: JILL SCOTT

headline: Photos of the Moment | Alexander McQueen
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#705", 592, 395, true, chameleonData);

headline: Excerpt: '101 Ways to Leave a Game Show'
text: The new ABC game show uses stunts to eliminate contestants.

headline: Libyan Media Minders Nervous After Guard Death
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Reports that a guard at the hotel housing foreign journalists here had been fatally shot sent a tremor of anxiety through the Qaddafi government’s media operation on Monday.

headline: Hoping to Survive This Round. Literally.
text: SIMI VALLEY, Calif. — On the rim of a rock quarry in the blistering June heat, three people are huddled in spacesuits with metallic jet packs on their backs, worrying aloud about which jet pack is about to be turned on. Five camera operators are sprawled around them, capturing every groan and sigh and exhortation to God.

headline: The Complete Pentagon Papers
text: Forty years after the New York Times published the leaked Pentagon Papers, the National Archives has released them in their entirety.

headline: Young and Old, With No Particular Place to Go
text: Death steals quietly into a Greenwich Village apartment, like morning sunlight gradually suffusing a darkened room, in “4000 Miles,” a funny, moving new play by Amy Herzog that opened on Monday night at the Duke on 42nd Street. Beneath the plain-wrap surface of this drama about a grandmother and grandson sharing a few weeks of casual cohabitation lies a quiet meditation on mortality. But it’s hardly a downer: Ms. Herzog’s altogether wonderful drama also illuminates how companionship can make life meaningful, moment by moment, in death’s discomforting shadow.

headline: Keyboard Speaks Louder Than a Microphone
text: On Sunday evening Shea Stadium, a performance space in Bushwick, Brooklyn, had the feel of a dorm party in its dwindling hours. Young people sat on lumpy couches, barely talking to one another, lost in their own reveries. Onstage a series of performers came and went, though at any given time there were as many people smoking and chatting on the balcony as were loosely gathered near the stage to watch.

headline: For Artists, Growing Up Is Still Hard to Do
text: A coming-of-age tale about struggling artists in the big city, “Next Thing You Know” is a sort of “Rent” for the Organization Kid generation.

headline: A Festival Brings the Obscure to the Fore, With a Global Touch
text: BOSTON — You might expect an early-music festival to celebrate the settled canon, with programs devoted to, say, Josquin and Dufay Masses, Bach’s “Brandenburg” Concertos, Mozart’s Requiem and other repertory high-water marks, in interpretations that reflect the latest notions of period style.

headline: For One Fan of McIlroy, a Major Payoff
text: This weekend 22-year-old Rory McIlroy cruised to a United States Open title, becoming the youngest Open champion since Bobby Jones in 1923. The incredible performance -– he finished 16-under par, eight shots ahead of the runner-up, Jason Day -– included 12 records. And it also sparked comparisons to Tiger Woods as the sport seeks a young superstar for a future that may not feature the dominant Woods the world grew accustomed to.

headline: Viewers Still Drool for Frosting Fantasies
text: By any logical standard, say the collapse of Holland’s tulip bubble in 1637 or Mrs. Fields filing for bankruptcy in 2008, cupcake mania should surely by now be waning.

headline: Thaw in a Player’s Dispute With the U.S.T.A.
text: WIMBLEDON, England -– Two unseeded Americans who traveled thousands of miles from home faced off on opposite sides of the net at the All England Club on Monday. The match was anti-climactic compared to a controversy involving the losing player, Donald Young, 21, of Atlanta.

headline: Working With Whimsy Fit for the Philharmonic
text: Among the many novel ideas implemented at the New York Philharmonic since Alan Gilbert took the reins as its music director in 2009, one has come to loom larger than all the rest. “Le Grand Macabre,” a musically unorthodox, wickedly funny absurdist opera by Gyorgy Ligeti, represented a substantial risk when the Philharmonic mounted a series of performances of it at Avery Fisher Hall in May 2010, imaginatively and resourcefully staged by Doug Fitch, a designer and director with whom Mr. Gilbert had worked in opera houses.

headline: TimesCast | Syria's Opposition
text: June 20, 2011 - Syrian President Bashar al-Assad says he will allow political parties other than his own to exist.

headline: Weiner Resigns — Officially

headline: A Vision Glimpsed Through the Window, and Its Consequences
text: See what’s outside! Last weekend you could go from the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s exhibition “Rooms With a View: The Open Window in the 19th Century” to two theatrical depictions of (sometimes open) windows in the 19th century: Tom Stoppard’s play “Arcadia” and August Bournonville’s ballet “La Sylphide.” The recent revival of “Arcadia” at the Ethel Barrymore Theater closed on Sunday; from Friday to Sunday the Royal Danish Ballet gave four performances of “La Sylphide” at the David H. Koch Theater.

headline: House Speakers Gather to Honor Henry Clay
text: One current and three former speakers of the House are scheduled to gather together Friday in Lexington, Ky., to pay tribute to another member of their illustrious fraternity – Henry Clay.
