headline: TimesCast | Inside the Rixos Hotel
text: June 20, 2011 - A Libyan guard is killed, or killed himself, at the hotel housing foreign journalists in Tripoli, Libya.

headline: Empathy and Cruelty (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: House Republicans’ Solution to Recess Appointments? No Recess
text: The freshman class of House Republicans has offered to sacrifice vacations to keep Congress perpetually in session for the next 18 months, which would prevent President Obama from appointing officials while Congress is not in session.

headline: Baseball Commissioner Rejects Dodgers’ TV Deal
text: Bud Selig, Major League Baseball’s commissioner, rejected a proposed cable television deal by the Los Angeles Dodgers on Monday. That scrambled the team’s financial future and voided a divorce agreement reached Friday by Frank McCourt, the Dodgers’ owner, and his wife, Jamie, who wants the team to be declared half hers.

headline: Pizza From Scratch
text: Melissa Clark proves that making pizza at home is easier than you may think.

headline: Planners Want to ‘Enliven’ Fourth Avenue in Brooklyn
text: The City Planning Department on Monday proposed a commercial rezoning of upper Fourth Avenue in Brooklyn, the famously unscenic stretch of flats-fixed joints and auto body shops that has lately sprouted a collection of blocky apartment buildings.

headline: Open Continues International Players’ Domination
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — For all the well-deserved hoopla attending the transcendent United States Open performance by Rory McIlroy, a 22-year-old from Northern Ireland, his record-setting victory at Congressional Country Club on Sunday did not come without some cautionary notes for the game.

headline: Pizzeria-Quality Pies at Home
text: There is nothing like pizza fresh out of a brick oven. That thin-yet-chewy crust blistered to perfection was one of those things I thought was utterly impossible to reproduce at home — until I met Andrew Feinberg.

headline: Mr. Peanut Gets Back in the Peanut Butter Business
text: Take cover, Peter Pan. Be choiceful, all you choosy moms who choose Jif. A dapper legume who had bowed out of the peanut butter market some decades ago is returning.

headline: A Cumin, Ginger and Sweet Pea Kind of Day
text: WE all want to believe in the myth of one-stop shopping, but the truth is, you won’t find everything you want at a regular supermarket. More to the point, life would be a lot duller if you could.

headline: Milan Top 5 | Prada
text: An ingenious AstroTurf green with a grid of electric blue foam cube seats set the perfect scene for Prada’s “Summertime” show. Whimsical cartoon-printed ’50s-style camp shirts and floral pants and golf bags made it clear that Miuccia Prada was serious about her leisure time. Though tough to choose, my favorite look was a mismatched tattersall sports jacket and trouser worn with a ghillied golf shoe. Country club clothes with a sense of humor.

headline: What’s Your Favorite Food-Hunting Ground?
text: In this week’s City Kitchen, we’ll take a spin through Curry Hill to pick up some fragrant Indian staples for the pantry, along with a cauliflower, for a one-pan vegetable dish that delivers pungent, citrus-laden herbs and spices.

headline: Man Turns to Crime for Prison Health Care
text: As if conjured up by a presidential speechwriter to star in an anecdote about America’s dysfunctional health insurance system, James Verone, an unemployed 59-year-old with a bad back, a sore foot and an undiagnosed growth on his chest, limped into a bank in Gastonia, N.C., this month and handed the teller a note, explaining that this was an unarmed robbery, but she’d better turn over $1 and call the cops. That, he figured, would be enough to get himself arrested and sent to prison for a few years, where he could take advantage of the free medical care.

headline: Hawk Cam | One Reader’s Family Portrait
text: Not much news today from the 12th floor of Bobst Library at New York University, where Pip the hawk is expected to take flight any day now. But in the increasingly wide world of Hawk Cam spinoffs there’s this: a family portrait of Bobby, Violet and Pip sporting the school colors, courtesy of chatroom regular Cheryl Ann Kingston’s new Pip at NYU blog.

headline: Ex-Tunisian President Found Guilty, in Absentia
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — A Tunisian court sentenced the country’s ousted president, Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, and his wife, Leila Trabelsi, to 35 years in prison and a fine of roughly $66 million after a trial in absentia for embezzlement and misuse of public funds, state news media said Monday night.

headline: A Tech Entrepreneur’s Plan for Grilled-Cheese Sandwiches
text: Jonathan Kaplan, who created the Flip video camera and sold it to Cisco Systems for $590 million, surprised a lot of people when he announced that his next start-up, the Melt, would make grilled-cheese sandwiches.

headline: Q&A: Deauthorizing iTunes From Afar
text: Q.

headline: Decide.com: The Farecast for Electronics
text: Here are some rather startling facts, but ones that explain a lot about why buying electronics can be anxiety-producing. Last year, on average, six new laptop models and one new TV model came out each day; a new camera came out every other day.

headline: Charles Isherwood on the revamped musical "Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark".
text: Charles Isherwood on the revamped musical "Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark".

headline: How Much Homework Is Just Right?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Yanks’ Newcomer Is Ready for Second Time Around
text: CINCINNATI — On the eve of his second career start, Brian Gordon said he felt less anxiety than he did last Thursday, when he transformed from Lehigh Valley IronPig to New York Yankee. But not much.

headline: Protests Aside, Yemen’s Leader Has His Followers
text: SANA, Yemen — Out of the ancient, ornate mud brick buildings and across the narrow alleyways where barefoot children play, a chant emerges frequently in the old walled city here in the capital. Seemingly at random, someone will raise his voice to announce: “The people want Ali Abdullah Saleh!”

headline: Protecting a Home, but Contemplating a New Future
text: A family protected its home from the rising flood waters in the Mississippi Delta, but its farming legacy is not as secure.

headline: Levees Save a Farmhouse, but Farming Is Still a Risk
text: YAZOO CITY, Miss. — Sitting on a boat, in a driveway on dry ground in the middle of a flood, a man can get to thinking about his place in the world.

headline: Venus Williams Has Little Trouble in First Round, but Expects Some in Next Round
text: WIMBLEDON, England — The scream is still difficult to forget. It came in the second round of this year’s Australian Open as Venus Williams stretched high for a backhand against Sandra Zahlavova, and it signaled a brutal shift in her fortunes.

headline: Despite Rejection, SABMiller to Pursue Foster’s
text: Tim Wimborne/Reuters Foster’s, the biggest Australian brewer, said SABMiller’s offer “significantly” undervalued the company.

headline: Different Ways of Reading ‘Uncle Tom’s Cabin’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Belarus: European Union Imposes New Sanctions
text: The European Union on Monday imposed additional sanctions on Belarus in response to the government’s crackdown on opposition groups and independent media. Officials condemned the imprisonment of about two dozen opposition figures for participating in an antigovernment protest last December. The sanctions apply to three major companies linked to the government, a prominent arms exporter, a judge and two prosecutors, a union spokeswoman said.

headline: Witnesses to Sunrise Over the Strip
text: The economic news in the morning newspaper was grim this past weekend: another uptick in the unemployment rate for Las Vegas, to 12.4 percent from 12 percent. Room occupancy rates on the Strip are stagnant. There were tables to be had at some of the fancier restaurants around, and empty spots at craps tables at the Cosmopolitan, the hot new casino, during what should have been a prime hour.

headline: With Xbox’s New In-Game Advertising, Engagement Is the Goal
text: Users of Microsoft’s popular Xbox Kinect gaming console will soon be able to use voice and motion commands to interact with advertisements while they are playing their favorite game or watching a video.

headline: France: Ex-Minister Held in Sexual Abuse Inquiry
text: The French police took a former government minister into custody on Monday for questioning about accusations of sexual assault by at least two women employees. The former minister, Georges Tron, resigned May 29 over allegations that he persuaded women who worked in the town hall where he was mayor into letting him massage their feet, which turned into groping. The women came forward, inspired, they said, by the New York hotel chambermaid who has accused Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former director of the International Monetary Fund, of attempted rape. Mr. Tron was reportedly confronted by three women during the questioning, Agence France-Presse reported. He has not been charged in the case.

headline: Rules to Stop Overfishing
text: To the Editor:

headline: Wanted: Hygienist (and Her Gangster Pal)
text: BOSTON — Catherine Greig, a former dental hygienist, is thin and blond with “well-kept teeth” — or at least she was before she went on the lam. Now the F.B.I. is hoping the public will provide more help finding her so it can solve a case that has stumped the agency and fixated Boston for years.

headline: Is Voting Speech?
text: At the first tenure meeting I ever attended, a candidate for promotion was approved by a single vote, and it turned out that one of my colleagues in the majority had gotten mixed up and believed he was voting for someone else. (It was a very large department.) The decision stood because, it was said, a vote is a vote and the motivations behind it, including having been motivated by a mistake, were not to the procedural point. Voting was, by definition, a one-time affair, and if misgivings or second thoughts or the fact of confusion were enough to warrant a revote (“I now know who she is; let’s do it again”), there is logically no place to stop and the department’s business could never get definitively done.

headline: Still Chewing on Cigars and Champing at the Bit
text: MILWAUKEE

headline: Anger and Mystery on Cape Cod in Wake of the Killing of Six Gray Seals
text: HARWICH, Mass. — Summer’s arrival, usually cause for celebration on Cape Cod, has been dampened this year by a grim question: Who is killing the gray seals?

headline: FIFA Power Broker Is Out After Years of Whispers
text: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad — Jack Warner commands headlines nearly every day in this Caribbean nation, known simply by his first name in his highly visible if conflicting roles as energetic public servant and now disgraced soccer power broker.

headline: Court Issues Split Ruling on Poor’s Right to Counsel
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday gave a complicated answer to the simple question of whether poor people facing jail time for failing to pay child support are entitled to court-appointed lawyers.

headline: Flooding Brings Worries Over Two Nuclear Plants
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — As record floodwaters along the Missouri River drench homes and businesses, concerns have grown about keeping a couple of notable structures dry: two riverside nuclear power plants in Nebraska.

headline: Mayors Call for a Quicker End to Wars So Money Can Be Used for Needs at Home
text: The resolution that the United States Conference of Mayors passed on Monday calling on President Obama and Congress to “speed up the ending” of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan was not nearly as strong as the one it passed 40 years ago, calling on President Richard M. Nixon to withdraw all American troops from Vietnam within six months.

headline: Joining the Crowd and Standing Apart
text: Carlyle will soon join the crowd — but try to stand apart from it. The private equity firm is preparing to join its rivals Apollo, Blackstone and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts as a publicly listed company. Carlyle’s unique structure could be its best hope of arguing the tough case that profits from investing, or carried interest, as it is known in the industry, should be worth more than investors currently think.

headline: Bonus Cuts, Pay Raises, Then Layoffs
text: It’s hardly surprising that Wall Street is bracing for layoffs. The European debt crisis is rocking the markets. New regulations are crimping bank profit centers. And smaller bonuses are sending other compensation costs soaring.

headline: In New Jersey, ‘Shared Sacrifice’ for Public Workers, Not the Rich
text: Trenton

headline: Did My Brother Invent E-Mail With Tom Van Vleck? (Part Two)
text: This is part two of a five-part series. Parts 1 | 3

headline: N.B.A. Draft, Even in a Down Year, Offers Hope to the Depleted Cavaliers
text: For a franchise that lost 63 games and stopped playing in mid-April, the Cleveland Cavaliers have had a rather glorious spring, full of charmed Ping-Pong balls and perverse satisfaction.

headline: Bloomberg TV Pushes for a Wider Audience
text: BLOOMBERG has begun a major marketing effort for its television operation in a bid to persuade business executives to see the company as more than just a maker of the terminals that are popular on trading floors.

headline: Vote of Confidence Is Only the First Step for Greece
text: If the Greek government can win a crucial vote of confidence Tuesday night, paving the way to passing austerity measures into law this month, it will also win an immediate infusion of cash that will tide it — and the rest of Europe — over for now.

headline: Health Law in a Swirl of Forecasts
text: The debate over the effects of the federal health care law on employer-provided insurance has been intensifying in recent weeks, with controversial polls and consultants contradicting one another about whether employees will benefit or lose coverage by 2014.

headline: Anti-Muslim Politics
text: Jeff Sharlet, left, of Dartmouth College and Amy Sullivan of Time discuss anti-Muslim sentiment in American politics.

headline: Wal-Mart Case Is a Blow for Big Cases and Their Lawyers
text: With the dismissal of a sex-discrimination lawsuit brought on behalf of 1.5 million women who have worked at Wal-Mart, the Supreme Court on Monday significantly tightened the rules for how a large group of individuals can join together to sue a company for alleged harm done to them.

headline: Legislature Still at Odds Over Cuomo’s Top Issues
text: ALBANY — The annual legislative session sputtered into overtime on Monday night with no visible progress on critical elements of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s ambitious first-year agenda, while legislative leaders battled behind the scenes on a host of contentious issues.

headline: Germany Debates New Life for a Behemoth of the Nazi Era
text: PRORA, Germany — Three years before the outbreak of World War II, Adolf Hitler’s lieutenants ordered the construction of what was portrayed as a remarkable perquisite for the toiling masses of the Third Reich — a vacation complex along the Baltic coast with 10,000 sea-view rooms in eight identical six-story blocks of steel-reinforced concrete, each one the length of five football fields.

headline: In New Jersey, Bill Advances on Public Workers’ Benefits
text: TRENTON — A central piece of Gov. Chris Christie’s agenda moved to the brink of becoming law on Monday, when a bill requiring government workers to pay much more for benefits, while limiting their bargaining rights, passed two crucial tests.

headline: Cal Is Facing Elimination, a Situation It Knows Well
text: OMAHA — Two days into the College World Series, California-Berkeley already finds itself in the losers’ bracket, one loss from elimination.

headline: Plight of the Expat Spouse
text: Overseas assignments are more brisk after the recession, but accompanying spouses and partners still struggle to find work abroad, too.

headline: When the F.B.I. Picks Through Americans’ Trash
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Little Clarity in the Fuzzy World of Airline Fees
text: FOR several weeks, I’ve been looking hard at the questions about airline fees.

headline: Support Is Mutual for Senator and Utah Industry
text: SALT LAKE CITY — A drive along mountain-lined Interstate 15 here shows why Senator Orrin G. Hatch is considered a hero in this region nicknamed the Silicon Valley of the nutritional supplement industry.

headline: Orrin Hatch: An Industry Champion
text: Senator Orrin G. Hatch repeatedly defended the dietary supplement industry, which has a major presence in his home state of Utah, from new regulations.

headline: Rebel Leader From Libya Is Expected to Visit China
text: BEIJING — The chairman of the Libyan opposition’s executive board, Mahmoud Jibril, will visit Beijing for talks on Tuesday and Wednesday, the Chinese Foreign Ministry announced on Monday, in the latest sign that China is hedging its bet on the survival of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s government in Tripoli.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Legal Acrobatics, Illegal War
text: New Haven

headline: Warner Resigns, Cutting Short Ethics Inquiry
text: Jack Warner, who for nearly three decades was a powerful but polarizing figure in regional and international soccer, resigned his positions as the vice president of FIFA and as the president of Concacaf on Monday. In response, FIFA closed an ethics inquiry that had accused him of bribery and said “the presumption of innocence is maintained.” Read the article here, and come back to comment.

headline: In Iran, a Brotherhood of Doctors and Patients
text: Few doctors anywhere in the world have done their country a greater service than the Iranian brothers Arash and Kamiar Alaei.  Kamiar, who is 37, is currently living in Albany, N.Y., where he is working on a doctorate in public health.   Arash, who is 42, is a resident of Tehran’s notorious Evin prison — where until recently, Kamiar lived as well.

headline: Moving Beyond Its Feisty Roots, Hudson River Park Group Focuses on Fund-Raising
text: The nature lovers and community activists who founded Friends of Hudson River Park in 1999 never shied from a fight; years earlier, they even helped kill Westway, the superhighway planned to run down the West Side of Manhattan.

headline: Scores of U.S. Strikes in Libya Followed Handoff to NATO
text: WASHINGTON — Since the United States handed control of the air war in Libya to NATO in early April, American warplanes have struck at Libyan air defenses about 60 times, and remotely operated drones have fired missiles at Libyan forces about 30 times, according to military officials.

headline: Smart Power Setback
text: So far, few politicians have embraced my plan for a Marshall Plan Tax. The idea is that every time a think-tanker, op-ed writer or retired senator calls for a new Marshall Plan or a moonshot-type initiative to solve a social problem, they would have to pay a tax of $50. Within a few months, we’d have enough money to pay for an actual new Marshall Plan.

headline: Banking’s Moment of Truth
text: Capital matters. Let me put that another way. The current fight over additional capital requirements for the banking industry, eye-glazing though it is, also happens to be the most important reform moment since the financial crisis broke out three years ago. More important than the wrangling over Dodd-Frank. More important than the ongoing effort to regulate derivatives. More important even than the jousting over the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

headline: Uranium Mine Moratorium Extended at Grand Canyon
text: The federal government on Monday extended for six months a moratorium on new uranium mining claims in a million-acre buffer zone around the Grand Canyon as it awaits the conclusions of a study of potential environmental harm to the region.

headline: Tuesday: Limo-Riding Sorts
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Stop me if you’ve heard this one before. A young woman walks into her high school class (she’s too young to walk into a bar, so I changed it), sits down at her desk and pulls out a crossword puzzle. Despite her teacher’s bid to maintain her attention, she’s more interested in doing that puzzle.

headline: Wal-Mart Wins. Workers Lose.
text: Wal-Mart Stores asked the Supreme Court to make a million or more of the company’s current and former female employees fend for themselves in individual lawsuits instead of seeking billions of dollars for discrimination in a class-action lawsuit. Wal-Mart got what it wanted from the court — unanimous dismissal of the suit as the plaintiffs presented it — and more from the five conservative justices, who went further in restricting class actions in general.

headline: Man Shot in Brooklyn Shop; Police Kill Gunman
text: A pair of police officers shot and killed a gunman on Monday minutes after he walked into a Brooklyn auto shop and opened fire on a man in an apparent feud, the police said.

headline: Chilean Court Blocks Plan for Patagonia Dam Project
text: A Chilean appeals court on Monday suspended a plan to build five dams and hydroelectric plants in the country’s Patagonia region.

headline: The Sun Is the Best Optometrist
text: WHY is nearsightedness so common in the modern world? In the early 1970s, 25 percent of Americans were nearsighted; three decades later, the rate had risen to 42 percent, and similar increases have occurred around the world.

headline: Police Suspect That Drugs Were Goal of Killer on L.I.
text: The Suffolk County police commissioner said on Monday that investigators seeking the killer of four people at a Medford pharmacy would plead for help from pharmacists and doctors who might have recently “come into contact with a person expressing an urgent need for painkillers.”

headline: Politically Tied Lawyers Win Jobs Handling Foreclosures in the City
text: In 2009, a judge in Manhattan had a lucrative appointment to hand out: oversight of a diamond district building that was drifting into foreclosure.

headline: Despite Setback, Plaintiffs to Pursue Wal-Mart Cases
text: Wal-Mart has spent 10 years fighting claims that it discriminated against female employees, and by many accounts, it has improved its hiring and promotion policies for women during those years.

headline: Murder Rate and Fear Rise in Puerto Rico
text: LOÍZA, P.R. — As people strolled past the Alambique liquor store here recently, the puddle of blood and the bullet-shattered storefront behind it scarcely merited a glance. Yet another young man had been shot. Yet another tally would be added to the record books.

headline: Obama to Announce Plans for Afghan Surge Pullout
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama plans to announce his decision on the scale and pace of troop withdrawals from Afghanistan in a speech from the White House at 8 p.m. Eastern time Wednesday evening.

headline: Potential on Display, Nova Dismantles Powerful Reds
text: CINCINNATI — The Cincinnati Reds are the highest-scoring team in the National League, and they play in a ballpark that yields home runs by the bushel. One of their left-handed sluggers, Joey Votto, is the reigning most valuable player. Another, Jay Bruce, is among the league leaders in homers.

headline: Upending Anonymity, These Days the Web Unmasks Everyone
text: Not too long ago, theorists fretted that the Internet was a place where anonymity thrived.

headline: Doing Right by the Poorest Countries
text: Ten years ago in Doha, Qatar, the world’s leading trading nations began the so-called development round of trade negotiations, billed as an effort to open markets in rich countries to the exports of the world’s poorest nations to help them rise out of destitution.

headline: Hypocrisy, Locked and Loaded
text: If Congressional Republicans are really intent on getting to the bottom of an ill-conceived sting operation along the border by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, they should call President Felipe Calderón of Mexico as an expert witness.

headline: Elena Georgievna Bonner, a True Human Rights Activist for 40 Years
text: On Jan. 22, 1980, shortly after I arrived in Moscow as a reporter, but before I met him, Andrei Sakharov was arrested and flown to internal exile in Gorky, a city closed to foreigners (now called Nizhny Novgorod). The operation was a stunning show of the Soviet state’s paranoia about a mild man who did nothing more than publicly criticize its human-rights violations. All the traffic around Sakharov’s apartment on Chkalova Street was halted and phones in the neighborhood turned off as if armed dissidents were out there ready to defend him.

headline: Immigrants Sue Over Loss of Green Cards
text: A class-action lawsuit was filed against the State Department in federal court in Washington by immigrants from more than 20 countries who say officials mishandled the annual lottery of permanent resident visas. After notifying more than 20,000 foreigners this year that they had won the permanent visas, known as green cards, the State Department canceled them, saying a computer glitch had tainted the process. The immigrants, who are all living legally in the United States, had waited years for the green cards and were bitterly disappointed to have them granted and then taken away.

headline: As Secession Nears, Sudan Steps Up Drive to Stop Rebels
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The Sudanese Army and its allied militias have gone on an unsparing rampage to crush rebel fighters in the Nuba Mountains of central Sudan, bombing thatch-roofed villages, executing elders, burning churches and pitching another region of the country into crisis, according to United Nations officials and villagers who have escaped.

headline: TimesCast | Ruling for Wal-Mart
text: June 20, 2011 - The Supreme Court throws out a class-action discrimination lawsuit against Wal-Mart, saying 1.5 million women could not unite their collective cases.

headline: Sudan to Pull Troops From Abyei and Allow Peacekeepers
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The Sudanese government has agreed to pull its troops out of the flashpoint Abyei area and allow Ethiopian peacekeepers to come in, the result of a deal signed Monday that could ease tensions along Sudan’s disputed north-south border.

headline: Ethnic Killings by Army Reported in Sudanese Mountains
text: PARIENG, Sudan — Underneath the wisp of shade he now calls home, Hamed El Bardi is a leader of a lost community. With more than 100 of his fellow Nubans huddled in the backyard of a county office in this southern Sudanese village, Mr. El Bardi tabulates newcomers and tries to figure out what to do next.

headline: California: Beating Suspect Jailed for Parole Violation
text: The suspect in the beating of a Giants fan at Dodger Stadium on opening day was sent back to prison on Monday because of a parole violation. The parole board ordered Giovanni Ramirez, 31, suspected of being a gang member, to spend 10 months behind bars after the Los Angeles police found weapons in the home where he was living when he was arrested in the beating case on May 22. The parole revocation comes as the police have struggled to put together a case against Mr. Ramirez, who has been in custody since his arrest and remains the primary suspect but has not been charged. The parole board declined earlier this month to hold Mr. Ramirez on charges related to the beating for lack of evidence.

headline: Nokia Unveils a New Smartphone, but Not a Product of Its Microsoft Deal
text: ESPOO, Finland — Late last year, the Apple iPhone became the best-selling device at Finland’s leading mobile operator, a highly embarrassing situation for Nokia, the struggling mobile phone maker that has long been Finland’s corporate standard-bearer.

headline: Battle for Libya | June 20, 2011
text: The Qaddafi government made new charges that a NATO airstrike had killed civilians, including children, when it hit an estate belonging to Khoweildi al-Hamidi, a former military officer.

headline: The Mouth That Roared Begins a New ‘Countdown’
text: Keith Olbermann returned to cable television on Monday mad as hell and pointedly madder than other self-described liberal anchors on his former channel, MSNBC.

headline: A. Whitney Ellsworth, First Publisher of New York Review, Dies at 75
text: A. Whitney Ellsworth, who helped get The New York Review of Books up and running as its first publisher, a position he held for nearly 25 years, died Saturday at his home in Salisbury, Conn. He was 75.

headline: Knicks See Brooks and Four Others Again
text: Marshon Brooks, a high-scoring guard from Providence who could fill the Knicks’ need for another shooter, had a second workout with the team on Monday, along with four other prospects who returned for a second look.

headline: Ryan Dunn, Daredevil Comedian, Dies at 34
text: Ryan Dunn, a star of the “Jackass” television show and movies, which feature perilous stunts and gags that often run afoul of good taste, died early Monday when his car went off a road and crashed in woods in West Goshen Township, Pa. He was 34.

headline: Recalls of Imported Foods Are Flawed, a Government Audit Reports
text: Government food officials are often sloppy and inattentive in their efforts to ensure that contaminated foods from abroad are withdrawn promptly and completely from the nation’s food supply, according to government investigators.

text: exert •\ig-ˈzərt\• verb

text: NYT: Front Page for 06/21/2011

headline: Brian Haw, 62, Dies; Camped in Front of Parliament to Protest War
text: Brian Haw, who day after day and night after night for nearly a decade maintained a vigil outside Parliament in London to protest the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, becoming an annoyance to some politicians and a stopping point for tour guides, died on Saturday. He was 62.

headline: News Quiz | June 21, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Test Yourself | English, June 21, 2011
text: Test your editing skills with today’s question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues, from the article “Brain Calisthenics for Abstract Ideas.”

headline: What’s the Best Advice You’ve Gotten?
text: When his mother died on Sunday at age 102, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg recalled some of his favorite bits of advice she had given him. What’s the best advice someone has given you? Who did it come from — a parent or other family member, a graduation speaker, a teacher, a coach, a friend?

headline: Attack in Iraq Kills Dozens Near House of Governor
text: BAGHDAD — Suicide bombers detonated two car bombs on Tuesday outside the governor’s compound in a city in southern Iraq, killing at least 27 people, many of them police officers, and wounding dozens of others, local officials said.

headline: At Hong Kong Hotel, the Highest Bar in Asia
text: Hong Kong has taken the lead in the two-city race to build the world’s highest bar in Asia.

headline: Top 10 Defensive Tackles in N.F.L.
text: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely -– but not strictly -– by film study of all 32 teams from the 2010 season. Stats weren’t acknowledged, but players with poor numbers generally don’t make top 10 lists anyway. Vague enough for you? Criteria for top 10 lists tend to be. That’s why most of you will have no trouble finding some disagreement with what you’re about to read.

headline: Are Taxes High or Low? A Further Look
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and servedon the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul.

headline: The Early Word: Resolute
text: Political news from today’s Times and around the Web, plus a look at what’s happening in Washington.

headline: In New Hampshire, a Race to the Clouds
text: When a rally race up the Mount Washington Auto Road returns this weekend after a 10-year hiatus, Nicholas Cota does not intend to follow in his father’s skid marks.

headline: My Job and My Hobby
text: How can this game make us feel so terrible one moment, and so wonderful the next?

headline: Keynes Talk, Non-pdf Version
text: The talk — or rather the paper that more or less tracks the talk — is up in an easy-read version at Vox.

headline: McKinsey Pulls Back the Curtain
text: McKinsey has now released some (not all) of the details from its mystery study. True to form, the company now claims that a study touted as evidence that companies “will” drop coverage was “not predictive.” Uh-huh.

headline: The FOO Theory of Investment
text: It is now a firm article of faith, not just on the hard right, but among many Serious People, that business investment is depressed because of FOO — Fear of Obama.

headline: Japan Plans to Unlink Nuclear Agency From Government
text: TOKYO — Responding to criticism that lax oversight played a role in the Fukushima nuclear accident, Japan’s government may make its nuclear regulatory agency more independent as early as next year.

headline: How I Learned to Love Bartering
text: The last couple of years have been tough on those of us who make our living selling small businesses. At my firm, 2008 was great, 2009 was bad and 2010 was abysmal.

headline: For Obama, the Politics of War Are Tricky
text: The politics of war are always tricky.

headline: European Leaders Propose a Sweeter Deal for Greece
text: BRUSSELS — Seeking to sweeten the medicine for Greek politicians who must decide next week whether to embrace a strict austerity plan, the president of the European Commission, José Manuel Barroso, on Tuesday proposed early payment to Athens of about 1 billion euros in money from the European Union.

headline: Live Free And Die
text: During the Bush years, every time a new estimate of life expectancy came out I would get letters saying “Hah! You say things are terrible, so how come life expectancy is rising, huh?” This was, of course, stupid: medicine continues to progress, the long-term decline in smoking has reduced lung cancer, etc.. Life expectancy is rising just about everywhere in the world; sharing in that trend is no big achievement.

headline: U.S. Releases Graphic Images to Deter Smokers
text: Federal health officials released on Tuesday their final selection of nine graphic warning labels to cover the top half of cigarette packages beginning next year, over the opposition of tobacco manufacturers.

headline: It Danced Once, but More Often It Crashes
text: MOSCOW — In April an amateur video of a distressed Tupolev Tu-154 jet flying low over the city circulated on the Internet and the craft became known as the Dancing Airplane, as it appeared to waltz in the air — because of equipment failure, officials said. The plane, which the pilots astonishingly managed to land safely, was being flown to a repair shop and was not carrying passengers.

headline: Eva Gabrielsson: The Girl Who Cast a Viking Spell
text: Eva Gabrielsson, who found herself pursued by fame and controversy as the longtime companion of Stieg Larsson, the posthumously best-selling author of the Millennium trilogy of Swedish crime thrillers, has published a book of her own. In Linda Coverdale’s English translation, the book, which first came out in French in January and is now available in the United States from Seven Stories Press, has the direct, plainspoken title “ ‘There Are Things I Want You to Know’ About Stieg Larsson and Me.” (The quotation is a reference to a letter that Larsson wrote to Ms. Gabrielsson in the 1970s, when he was in his 20s, and about to leave for Africa.)

headline: Amy Winehouse Cancels European Tour
text: Fulfilling the expectations of everyone who predicted that her European tour would be short-lived, Amy Winehouse’s European tour was short-lived. On Tuesday the troubled pop singer canceled the remaining dates of a planned 12-stop concert series after a Saturday performance in Belgrade, Serbia, in which she was seen meandering around the stage and struggling to remember her own songs, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Two Swings and Two Misses for Sports Programs on Comedy Central

But “Sports Show With Norm Macdonald” isn’t it: Comedy Central said that it would not pick up a second season of the satirical series, which poked fun at the world of professional athletics, and that it was also not renewing another humorous sports-themed show, “Onion SportsDome.”

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Rome, Open City’
text: In this week’s Critic’s Pick, A. O. Scott looks back at Roberto Rossellini‘s 1945 drama “Rome, Open City.” The film was one of the first examples of Italian neorealist filmmaking, which used a documentary-style aesthetic and several nonprofessional actors to tell its story of a group of people struggling to survive in Rome during the Nazi occupation. Mr. Scott appreciates how the love its characters express toward one another creates a compelling way to resist the oppression surrounding them.

headline: A Rebel From Libya Is Greeted in Beijing

headline: Handwriting Experts Weigh In on Weiner’s Signature (and Psyche)

headline: Who Made That Big Brown Bag?
text: I can’t walk down the street anymore without seeing someone with a canvas tote. They have become the default choice for the environmentally conscious and have also provided fertile ground for graphic designers, illustrators and other creatives. I think I have at least 10 of them but only one of which I actually purchased. They just keep appearing either as gifts or freebies, which makes me wonder how earth-friendly they actually are if enough people have similar tote-bag-to-person ratios to my own. A couple years ago, Dimitri Siegel wrote an article on the Design Observer blog about this phenomenon and noted, “Just as the remarkable efficiency of the plastic bag ended up making it a menace to the environment, graphic design’s ability to generate options and choices may turn a sustainable idea into an environmental calamity.” It seems that sustainable design is not limited to just the materials that are used but also to the endurance of the design itself.

headline: Managing Never Gets Old
text: In honor of Jack McKeon, we invite you to feel young today. Most of us don’t usually do this, no matter how young we are, because the feeling is so easily wiped out by a backache or a nasty bout of allergies or that jerk who cut you off in traffic. But on Monday, the 80-year-old baseball manager climbed into a Marlins uniform, cracked some jokes, benched his shortstop, and watched the Marlins lose. It is quite a task, signing up to stay awake through every Marlins game. Heck, most 40-year-olds couldn’t do that.

headline: Asked & Answered | Catherine Ringer
text: Imagine a lissome Parisienne in short skirt and high heels, lit Gauloise dangling from pursed red lips as she steps out of some smoky Left Bank boîte. Now imagine what she sounds like, and you have Catherine Ringer (pronounced Rahn-ZHAY). Forceful but suave, more Garbo than Gaga, Ringer, 53, was the lead singer of Les Rita Mitsouko, the high-energy, genre-bending pop duo that ruled the airwaves in France for much of the 1980s and ’90s.

headline: Oceans at Dire Risk, Team of Scientists Warns
text: The state of the oceans is declining far more rapidly than most pessimists had expected, an international team of experts has concluded, increasing the risk that many marine species — including those that make coral reefs — could be extinct within a generation.

headline: Troops Engaged in Libya Campaign Are Receiving ‘Imminent Danger Pay’
text: WASHINGTON – United States troops participating in the NATO-led campaign in Libya are receiving “imminent danger pay.” Does that make it harder to argue that the American military component of the mission does not rise to the level of “hostilities,” as the Obama administration contends?

headline: A Mother’s Right to Drive
text: It seems fitting that the Rosa Parks of the fight to drive in Saudi Arabia was a single mother trying to get home to her 5-year-old son. In America, after all, the car is all but synonymous with parenting. And as Saudi women continue to risk jail for getting behind the wheel, I find myself thinking of all the complaining I have done about carpool arranging, and activity shuttling, and babysitter dropping and grocery hauling. It has me looking at my all too messy, somewhat rattly wagon with new affection — and more than a little anger that all these have become a political act for some women.

headline: The White House’s Rooftop Solar Challenge
text: As you know by now, I sometimes differ with my friend Bill McKibben on pathways to energy progress. But I think he’s made a valid point in criticizing President Obama for not living up to the pledge his administration made last fall to install solar hot water and photovoltaic systems on the White House by the start of summer (that would be today).

headline: Where Park Visitors Answer a Call to Battle
text: FISHERS, Ind. — The drama unfolding here on the outskirts of Indianapolis involves a dashing, Kentucky-born guerrilla fighter, ruthless in plunder and genteel in manners. There’s a pioneer fur trader, too, a man who negotiated with the Lenape Indians to move them out of central Indiana and lost his Lenape Indian wife and children in the bargain. And let’s not forget the 20th-century philanthropist who envisioned a living museum that would reflect the history of his state; his gift of that museum to a nearby college that had other priorities led to 21st-century courtroom battles and, ultimately, to the museum’s recent independence. Now teams of “interpreters” and “facilitators” and costumed Indianians lure more than 220,000 visitors a year to this endearingly strange place.

headline: Those Perplexing WPIX Subway Ads, Explained
text: They’re standing in a dark room strewn with papers. Something bad must have just happened. A square-jawed man holds a broken television in one hand, the other fixed on his hip in a tough-guy pose, as if he’s daring you to try to steal his static. Nearby, a middle-aged fellow slumps in an armchair, tie askew, his hand supporting his weary chin. His feet are resting on — is that an encyclopedia set? Why is he so exhausted? Why is he identified only as “Mr. G.”? What’s going on here?

headline: Times’s Outstanding Playwright Award Goes to Kristoffer Diaz
text: Kristoffer Diaz is the winner of the 2011 New York Times Outstanding Playwright Award for “The Elaborate Entrance of Chad Deity,” his satire of professional wrestling and the ethnic stereotypes and political imagery of that industry, The Times has announced. The award, created in 2009, recognizes an American playwright whose work recently received its professional debut in New York; “Chad Deity” was produced Off Broadway in 2010 by Second Stage Theater, drawing mostly positive reviews. (The play was also a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize in drama that year.) Previous recipients of the Times playwright award, which comes with a cash prize of $5,000, were Tarell Alvin McCraney for “The Brothers Size” and Dan LeFranc for “Sixty Miles to Silver Lake.”

headline: ABC Rolls On

headline: Jeremy Kost Is Ready for His Close-Up
text: Before Jeremy Kost became a Polaroid-snapping phenom, he was working a day job as a manager for an Internet company in Washington. “I started taking pictures at the big parties I was throwing with Ed Bailey and John Guggenmos, but I eventually felt I had outgrown that city,” says Kost. He had already flirted with New York nightlife during business trips, and in 2006 he quit his Web job, moved to New York and began taking party photos full time. The result has been an oeuvre of Warholian portraits showing off his favorite nocturnal denizens. His first hardbound monograph, “It’s Always Darkest Before Dawn” (PowerHouse, $50), contains his typical club pictures, but blown up and and methodically assembled to show graphic detail. The book features a selection of cropped photographs and Polaroid collages (the result of a collaboration with Sam Shahid, a former creative director of Calvin Klein).
