headline: Obama T-Shirts: All The Rage in Rural Niger
text: While visiting a village in Southern Niger, Nick, along with “Win a Trip 2011″ winners Saumya Dave and Noreen Connolly, noticed an entire gaggle of boys sporting t-shirts that either said “Obama” or pictured him. Click here to see the video by Thomas Nybo, who is also traveling with the group.

headline: Poll Affirms Grim Views of U.S. in Pakistan
text: Most Pakistanis disapprove of the American raid that killed Osama bin Laden and think it will have harmful effects on relations between Pakistan and the United States, according to a recent survey conducted by the Pew Research Center. But overwhelmingly negative attitudes toward the United States did not change from the month before the raid to two weeks after, remaining at the worst levels measured in eight years.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Russia and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Russia, Syria, China and New Jersey.

headline: Walgreens Faces Off With a Benefit Manager
text: Walgreens, the nation’s largest drug store chain, said on Tuesday that negotiations with Express Scripts, a pharmacy benefit manager, had broken down. As a result, the chain said it was not planning on continuing to offer its retail pharmacies in the Express Script’s network in 2012.

headline: Revenue Still Down, Gannett Lays Off 700 Employees
text: Gannett confirmed on Tuesday what many newspaper publishers and employees across the country have feared since the recession officially ended two years ago: that the lagging economic recovery will force more downsizing.

headline: TimesCast | June 21, 2011
text: In Greece, a confidence vote could avert financial collapse; the Republican presidential candidate Michele Bachmann’s years as a foster mother; and the evolution of tobacco warnings.

headline: 3 Essential Steps to Facebook Privacy
text: With most of the civilized world (or so it seems) now on Facebook, some users have been unpleasantly surprised to find out who contacts them out of the blue, or who lets them know they saw that photo from a party in May (“Wasn’t that the day you called in sick?”) That’s because by default, Facebook is promiscuous about who it allows to search for your personal information and for photos in which you have been tagged by name.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Russia and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Russia, Syria, China and New Jersey.

headline: ‘Pins and Needles’
text: A 1930s revue is getting new life at a theater in Brooklyn.

headline: Milan Top 5 | Tom Ford
text: Tom Ford’s always-dapper Dans slinked around the showroom on Via Borgonuovo in a quiet palette of sharply cut linen suits. Still shapely, the tonal single-breasted suits with a subtler notched lapel were punched up by graphic polka dot dress shirt and tie combinations in varying scales that looked especially chic. The dash of a new airier pochette finished off these ensembles that will look right at home in L.A.’s Deco-dent Sunset Tower.

headline: Baghdatis Holds Off Blake for Victory
text: WIMBLEDON, England -– James Blake of the United States walked with his head down, deep in thought, or, perhaps, in early despair. His serve had been broken in the first game of the match by Marcos Baghdatis of Cyprus.

headline: West Village, 10:19 A.M.
text: Students participating in Socapa, a summer arts camp for kids across the country, mill around between scenes of a film project they’re working on outside the New School.

headline: Broadway Bares 2011
text: Scenes from the annual fundraiser for Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS.

headline: Isner Wins Again in Rematch That Is 9 Hours Shorter
text: WIMBLEDON, England — For all their discernible differences, Nicolas Mahut and John Isner are like two sides of the same piece of paper. When they met again Tuesday in the first round of Wimbledon, they might as well have been clutching pens in their hands instead of rackets.

headline: What Happens When Is Closing After Saturday
text: What Happens When, John Fraser’s experimental restaurant – he doesn’t use the term pop-up because it was to be open for nine months, from late January into October – will close after dinner on Saturday.

headline: Reporting From a Crime Scene That Is Down the Block
text: The gunshots echoed on the Lower East Side streets just after 12:30 a.m. Tuesday, rousing people from their sleep and sending many to their windows to take a look outside. A few minutes later, a notification came across a pager service that reporters use. “Male shot,” the blunt message read, giving the address 85 Pitt Street.

headline: Just One Look | Proenza Schouler Resort Collection
text: “Our girl wears a Baja, not a bikini,” Lazaro Hernandez said yesterday as he and Jack McCollough gave a tour of their newly expanded showroom. Indeed, the resort vibe at Proenza Schouler is at once hippie and hip, with one wedge sandal planted in San Francisco in the late ’60s and the other firmly planted in New York City 2011. The only true flashback came in the form of hefty, handmade necklaces designed for the boys by the jewelry artists Alex & Lee.

headline: Harrison Defeats Dodig to Reach Second Round
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Ryan Harrison of the United States was displeased, to say the least.

headline: Heading Back Down South
text: St. Albans, Queens, once a magnet for successful blacks, is now losing residents to the American South, from which earlier generations fled.

headline: Hamm Joining espnW for Women’s World Cup
text: Perhaps Mia Hamm’s only regret about attending the Women’s World Cup in Germany on assignment is that her 4-year-old twin girls are not quite ready “to sit through a whole game.”

headline: Exploring Moral Consequences, the Obvious and the Unintended
text: With most great games, you see ’em coming. Not that many teams have the creative and technical chops to create superlative interactive entertainment, the kind that gleefully whisks you to a faraway place you want to spend dozens of hours exploring. And so the leaders in various niches are usually well known.

headline: Why Study Hyenas?
text: Kay E. HoleKamp, a zoologist at Michigan State University, writes from the Masai Mara National Reserve in Kenya, where she is studying the behavior of spotted hyenas.

headline: Desmond’s
text: THE greatest restaurant fish in the world may be Dover sole, an exquisite flounder of eastern Atlantic heritage that takes its name from the English port from which its best hunters once sailed. Diners love the fillets for their mild, sweet flavor and for the way the edges crisp in the heat. Add a film of clarified butter as a kind of force multiplier and you have a dish of intense simplicity.

headline: Cholesterol Drugs Linked With Diabetes Risk
text: Cholesterol-lowering drugs called statins, which have been shown to lower a person’s risk for heart attack, can also slightly increase a patient’s risk for developing diabetes, particularly at higher doses, new research shows.

headline: Reviewing Desmond’s
N.Y. Missed Deadline on Indian Point Decision, Operator Says
text: New York State missed a deadline for ruling on an application for a water quality certificate for the Indian Point nuclear plant, the plant’s owner, Entergy, said on Tuesday in a notification to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. The filing raised the possibility that state officials may have lost a tool for blocking a license renewal for the plant’s nuclear reactors.

headline: Reyes Postpones Contract Talks as Athletics Drop Mets
text: Jose Reyes’s seemingly inexorable march toward free agency passed the latest stage in the process when his agent told the Mets on Monday that Reyes would not engage in contract negotiations until after this season.

headline: Talk Frames Performance of Recent Works
text: “I wrote it when I was 100 years old” is something few people besides Elliott Carter can say.  Now 102, Mr. Carter, ever lively and lucid, was at the Miller Theater on Saturday evening to speak about his Concertino for Bass Clarinet and Chamber Orchestra, which received its American premiere with the Orchestra of the League of Composers, conducted by Louis Karchin.

headline: Milan Top 5 | Calvin Klein
text: Italo Zucchelli’s über-athletic Calvin Klein show was as strong as the muscled guys strutting down the runway. In a style reminiscent of 1980s-era GQ fitness portfolios, the buff guys sported tight layered tanks with voluminous nylon and leather pants, perforated windbreakers and airtex sport jackets that were Bruce Weber ready. The baggy basketball-style shorts worn with a trim sport jacket over a tank took the medal.

headline: A Bold Statement on Time
text: Look Ma, no hands!

headline: Taking the Cello a Ways Down a Country Road
text: As a cellist Erik Friedlander has confronted his share of conventions: surrounding technique, repertory and proper usage. He mastered those a while ago, and departed from them. In his work with avant-garde composer-improvisers (John Zorn) and the indie-rock intelligentsia (John Darnielle) he often engages his instrument with an ear tilted toward possibilities. The same is even truer in his own work, especially within the last five years.

headline: Symmetry and Geometry, in Mirror Image
text: The titles of dances often seem to have nothing to do with their content. But the name of Beth Gill’s new work, which began a two-week run at the Chocolate Factory over the weekend, is “Electric Midwife,” and despite its non sequitur oddness, the title has a curious resonance after you’ve watched Ms. Gill’s highly formal, minimalist female sextet play itself out over 45 minutes.

headline: A Night in White Satin
text: ‘‘To me, it represented a new beginning; we were opening up to the world,’’ said Miss Fashionetta 2011, LaKeySha Bosley, 18. ‘‘And when we got back up, we were women.’’

headline: City Hall Protest
text: With a budget due by the end of next week, a crowd rallied at City Hall to protest proposed cuts in jobs and services across the city.

headline: TimesCast | Testing Confidence in Athens
text: June 21, 2011 - Greece awaits a parliamentary vote that could save it from financial collapse.

headline: Cut, Baste, Stitch, Sing!
text: The big voice and dramatic flair that served Wanda Imasuen well as a community organizer are turning out to translate nicely to another stage: musical comedy.

headline: Polls Show More Americans Favor Withdrawal From Afghanistan
text: President Obama‘s announcement that he plans to speak on Wednesday on removing troops from Afghanistan comes amid polls that find an increasing number of Americans supporting a withdrawal.

headline: Israel to Allow Building Cargo to Enter Gaza
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli military said Tuesday that it had agreed to allow a United Nations agency to bring building materials for 1,200 new housing units and 18 new schools into Gaza, one of the largest construction projects in the Palestinian coastal strip in years.

headline: Brooklyn Museum Cancels Graffiti Show
text: The Brooklyn Museum has canceled plans to show “Art in the Streets,” the popular but controversial graffiti exhibition originated by the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art. In both a terse press release and an e-mail that, according to L.A. Weekly was sent to an artist in the show, the Brooklyn Museum’s director, Arnold Lehman, blamed tight finances for the cancellation. In the email quoted by L.A. Weekly, Mr. Lehman said: “With no major funding in place, we cannot move ahead.”

headline: Wear Resort Now | Suiting
text: From Stella McCartney’s lemon-drop blazer and candy-striped trousers to Jason Wu’s daytime-meets-nighttime navy suit with black piping, it’s evident from the resort shows that designers are suiting up in an anticipatory nod to fall. Translation? The cropped suit, nipped and trimmed from the leg to the sleeve, never looked so cool. Wear a facsimile now, before the weather turns brutal.

headline: It’s a Convention of Superheroes, Taking Over a Stage and a Nearby Van
text: “Our Greatest Year,” Robert Attenweiler’s tender and knowing inquiry into just why sports fans are so messed up, takes its time listening to what its characters say (or don’t say) and why. As such, it is an oasis of psychological complexity among the bells and whistles of the Comic Book Theater Festival, which is currently stuffing the Brick Theater with no end of chintzy superhero outfits.

headline: McCain and Manchin Clash on Afghanistan
text: Senator Joe Manchin, a freshman Democrat from West Virginia, got a taste Tuesday of what it is like to find oneself at odds with Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona.

headline: Victorian Goddesses, a Real Wife and a Sour Marriage
text: Most people who have read about the great Victorian art critic John Ruskin remember two things about him: that he was sued by Whistler and had to pay a farthing in damages, and that he was unable to consummate his marriage to Effie Gray because, knowing the female body only from paintings and classical statuary, he was appalled by the sight of her pubic hair.

headline: Violence Continues in Syria, Activists Say
text: While Syria’s state media lavished attention on rallies in support of President Bashar al-Assad on Tuesday, opposition activists posted video online showing what they described as evidence that security forces are continuing to use violence to suppress dissent.

headline: The End of AfPak
text: Remember how after 9/11, Osama bin Laden’s attacks on us could be linked to almost anything, from shopping habits to the rediscovery of Western values to carbon-pricing schemes?  Something similar appears to be happening with Bin Laden’s death. Jihadism sure isn’t what it used to be. After 10 years, it seems, the time has come to go home. Troops are and will be coming back to the United States from Iraq and Afghanistan. The military budget will be cut. The outgoing secretary of defense feels able to openly mock NATO because, presumably, he thinks he can afford to — because it doesn’t matter all that much. The global war on terror is being downgraded from Armageddon to something more out of Leviticus: a tricked-out police action, just as John Kerry, in this magazine, always said it should be. On Sunday, Helene Cooper and Mark Landler reported that “American success in the counterterrorism campaign would seem to bolster arguments for a swift withdrawal from Afghanistan.” By Tuesday morning, they were reporting that President Obama would announce his withdrawal plans on Wednesday. Meanwhile, a Harris poll revealed that 51 percent of Americans and 54 percent of Britons believed “the death of Bin Laden meant it was time to bring troops from their countries home.”

headline: A Resurgence in Art Buying Over the Web
text: Roland Sledge, a 65-year-old lawyer for an oil and gas company in Houston, is no art world habitué. He began collecting prints and works on paper a little more than a decade ago, focusing on Abstract Expressionism, and has done some business with small New York galleries, “though I mostly just stumbled into things that I liked,” he said in a broad Texas accent.

headline: F.B.I. Seizes Web Servers, Knocking Sites Offline
text: 6:16 p.m. | Updated  Adding that the F.B.I. did not comment.

headline: At Protest Over Planned Cuts, Promises of More Protests to Come
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s plan to close 20 fire companies and lay off thousands of teachers has already prompted a steady drumbeat of protests across the city. But that may just be the beginning.

headline: Unions and Ailing City Opera Meet About Next Season
text: The troubled New York City Opera let some details about its next season dribble out on Tuesday during a meeting with its unions, which confronted the company’s leader, George Steel, with symbolic votes of no confidence in his leadership.

headline: Shakira Makes a Star Turn at an Israeli Conference
text: JERUSALEM — When Israel’s octogenarian president, Shimon Peres, opened his Israeli Presidential Conference here on Tuesday, he chose an unlikely partner to stand by his side: Shakira, the Colombian pop star who is partly of Lebanese descent, performed last month in Beirut and was once (wrongly) accused in an Internet rumor of saying she would rather have pigs listen to her music than Israelis.

headline: Design Miami/Basel Wrap-Up
text: Last week professionals, collectors and amateurs of all things art flocked to Basel for the 42nd edition of Art Basel, the “world’s top contemporary art fair.” While the main fair was received with mixed reviews (too crowded, confusing layout, not enough outstanding pieces), an entirely different tune was sung over at Hall 5 of Basel’s venerable Messegelände, where only a day earlier Design Miami opened the doors to its annual sister fair, Design Miami/Basel, a satellite fair specializing in collectible design. There was a noticeable excitement in the air as this was the first Design Miami/Basel under the new directorship of Marianne Goebl. Her debut did not disappoint: a record 43 exhibitors showing everything from 20th-century classics to contemporary designers, intelligent design collaborations with corporate sponsors (take note, Art Basel V.I.P. lounge), a great bookstore (courtesy of doyoureadme?! from Berlin) and a well-curated series of talks (full disclosure: I moderated one of them). Design Miami/Basel may keep flourishing thanks to the cross-pollinating effect from the neighboring art fair(s), but judging by the increasingly educated and design-passionate public, it seems that the fair could very well stand on its own if it had to.

headline: Angela Bassett Will Star Opposite Samuel L. Jackson in ‘The Mountaintop’
text: Angela Bassett’s only experience working with Samuel L. Jackson was in the early 1980s when she was an understudy, and he a star, in a Negro Ensemble Company production of “Colored People’s Time,” a play of vignettes set between the Civil War and the Montgomery bus boycott. This fall the two actors will reunite on Broadway — as co-stars — for another play inspired by history, Katori Hall’s drama “The Mountaintop,” about Dr. Martin Luther King on the night before his assassination.

headline: Beating Death of Schoolgirl Shocks French
text: PARIS — A 14-year-old boy fatally beat a 13-year-old girl at her school in rural southern France this week, in what appears to be an unusual revenge crime that has shocked the local community and drawn wide attention.

headline: Let’s Keep Talking About Redistricting
text: This is Part 2 of an interview with David Wasserman, the House editor of The Cook Political Report. Mr. Wasserman is Cook’s resident redistricting expert and the author of “Better Know a District,” The Cook Political Report’s 2012 redistricting outlook. (Readers might also want to check out Cook’s redistricting scorecard for background).

headline: The First Dad …
text: shows the First Mom how it’s done!Awwww …

headline: Three-Ingredient Summer Cocktails
text: The Times asked some of the country’s top bartenders to suggest streamlined coolers built for easy summer drinking.

headline: Guadalajara Sour
text: Adapted from Michael Bowers, Modern Hotel and Bar, Boise, Idaho

headline: Absinthe Frappé
text: Adapted from Lydia Reissmueller, Central, Portland, Ore.

headline: TimesCast | Foster Mother and Politician
text: June 21, 2011 - A first look at a story in Wednesday's Times on the Republican presidential candidate Michele Bachmann's years as a foster mother.

headline: Summer Cocktails Made Simpler
text: SO, what’ll it be tonight? How about a Smoke Signal made with bacon-infused rye, chipotle syrup, cold-brewed coffee ice and porter? Or the Grillo Canción, an exotic and possibly deranged member of the Collins family that fuses pisco, cumin syrup, citrus and celery bitters? Or maybe a Knot Twist would hit the spot: a two-ounce riot of malty genever, smoky Scotch, smokier mezcal, absinthe, maraschino and bitters, stirred into accord and set before you like a dare?

headline: Chevrolet Looks to Consumers for Super Bowl Ad
text: The Chevrolet division of General Motors is turning again to creative types outside its agency roster to come up with the kind of commercial that is meant to be at the apex of advertising achievement: a Super Bowl spot.

headline: Pawlenty to Begin Airing Ads in Iowa
text: Tim Pawlenty will become the first Republican candidate of the 2012 presidential race to begin airing television commercials, aides said, with his ads set to begin Wednesday in Iowa.

headline: Soaring From Poverty All the Way to Ecstasy
text: It is undoubtedly useful to sort music by nationality, period, genre and style, but the actual experience of listening to music can often leave such categories in shambles. If I said, for example, that “Passione,” John Turturro’s galvanic tribute to the songs and singers of Naples, Italy, was a documentary about soul music, that might be confusing, since that term commonly refers to 1960s African-American music.

headline: Clinton Adds Her Voice in Support of Saudi Women
text: WASHINGTON – Hillary Rodham Clinton’s advocacy for women’s rights – as First Lady, Senator and now Secretary of State – is well known. And yet she found herself facing criticism for not being outspoken enough on one issue: Saudi Arabia’s ban on women driving.

headline: The Caucus Click: Jon Huntsman in Exeter, N.H.
text: Jon M. Huntsman Jr., the former governor of Utah, returning from Exter, N.H. on his campaign plane, with 5-year-old daughter Asha.

headline: Crimes Against Property, as Protests
text: Do crimes against property in which no one is killed or injured constitute acts of terrorism? That is one of two nagging questions that run through Marshall Curry and Sam Cullman’s thoughtful documentary, “If a Tree Falls: A Story of the Earth Liberation Front.” The other has to do with the efficacy of traditional forms of peaceful protest.

headline: Romney Sets Fall Debate Schedule
text: Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, will participate in a half-dozen presidential debates this fall, his campaign announced Tuesday.

headline: Rangers to Play in Winter Classic
text: The Rangers will play in the next N.H.L. Winter Classic, traveling to Philadelphia to play the Flyers in the league’s annual outdoor game on Jan 2.

headline: Albany Reaches Deal on Tax Cap and Rent Rules
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders struck a tentative deal on Tuesday paving the way for a vote on issues that affect millions of New Yorkers — renewing regulation of rent-regulated apartments, capping property taxes for homeowners and raising tuition at state universities — but reached no agreement on whether to take a vote on legalizing same-sex marriage.

headline: Oversight Group Did Not Refer Housing Complaints
text: The federal agency overseeing Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the taxpayer-owned mortgage finance giants, failed to refer to criminal investigators and other authorities almost 100 complaints about possible foreclosure abuse and mortgage fraud at the companies over a recent two-year period, according to a report issued late Tuesday by the inspector general of the Federal Housing Finance Agency.

headline: Hulu Weighs Sale After Unsolicited Bid
text: Hulu has established itself as a top hub for streaming television shows and movies online.

headline: Valentino: A White Resort
text: The Valentino designers Maria Grazia Chiuri and Pier Paolo Piccioli winged it into New York this week to show their pre-spring collection here for the first time, and you could tell they were excited. The duo went running in Central Park on Tuesday morning and still were in the Valentino showroom overlooking Bryant Park by 9 a.m., looking as fresh as their designs.

headline: Pisco Makes the Trip North
text: PISCO, the clear grape spirit of South America, is emerging from the mist of history and bringing rich freshness to cocktails. In New York and other cities, liquor stores and bars that carried no pisco a few years ago have several now and are adding more, making it the fastest-growing spirit in the country.

headline: For Upper West Siders, an End to H & H’s Steaming Hot Bagels
text: H & H Bagels, the Upper West Side’s most celebrated destination for what is quite possibly the Upper West Side’s most iconic food, is closing its Upper West Side store, employees said Tuesday.

headline: Ex-Partners Fight to Break Up the BLT Empire
text: “YOU are the front line,” Jimmy Haber said intently. “You are the heart and soul of our restaurant.”

headline: In City Parks, Fancier Noshing
text: YEARNING to soar above its tired, rote roster of hot dogs and pretzels, the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation put out a call five months ago for the food vendors of New York “to propose your most inventive, exciting food idea,” adding, “whatever the idea, we want to see it.”

headline: California Legislators to Lose Pay Over Budget
text: LOS ANGELES — California lawmakers will lose at least a week’s pay and living expenses because the state budget they passed last week was not balanced, the state controller said Tuesday.

headline: Two Senators Assail Health Care Law
text: Two Republican senators, Ron Johnson of Wisconsin and John Barrasso of Wyoming, said Tuesday that evidence of the failure of the new health care law could be found in the number of employers that have been granted exemptions.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Touring Old New York

headline: Toronto-Dominion’s Chief Continues a Run at the Border
text: TORONTO — While the Royal Bank of Canada has long enjoyed a profitable and comfortable reign as this country’s largest bank, the United States proved tough to conquer.

headline: More Preschoolers Test as Gifted, Even as Diversity Imbalance Persists
text: The number of gifted preschoolers in New York City is on the rise, but they mostly live in the city’s middle-class and wealthier districts.

headline: Yanks’ Gardner Finds His Comfort Zone
text: CINCINNATI — In three games batting first for the Yankees since Derek Jeter strained his calf, Brett Gardner has reached base in 9 of 15 plate appearances, and scored five times. In 50 games since April 28, Gardner has hit .357 with a .440 on-base percentage, ideal numbers for a leadoff hitter.

headline: As 3-D Falls From Favor, Director of ‘Transformers’ Tries to Promote It
text: LOS ANGELES — Michael Bay, the king of the summer movie spectacle, is not afraid of getting in the audience’s face. But on the eve of the release of his “Transformers: Dark of the Moon,” he is on a charm offensive with reporters, bloggers and even theater owners.

headline: Eating on the Rockaway Beach Boardwalk
text: IT took imagination to envision the utilitarian concession stands on the Rockaway Beach Boardwalk as a food destination.

headline: Arepas and Cappuccino at Rockaway Beach
The Deficit, Real vs. Imagined
text: Republicans say they won’t raise taxes. Democrats are reluctant to cut Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid. So discretionary spending — the roughly 35 percent of government that includes other social programs and the military — will have to be a big part of any deal in coming weeks to raise the debt ceiling.

headline: Roots of Bachmann’s Ambition Began at Home
text: STILLWATER, Minn. — Nearly two decades ago, a stay-at-home mother and onetime federal tax lawyer named Michele Bachmann felt a spiritual calling to open her clapboard home here to troubled teenage girls.

headline: Bloggingheads: Will Syria Crack?
text: Joshua Landis, left, of the University of Oklahoma and Ausama Monajed, a Syrian activist, debate the future of the Syrian regime.

headline: Trying to Get Back in the Game
text: WASHINGTON — Several dozen of the nation’s top corporate lawyers convened at a conference here last week to discuss the future of securities litigation.

headline: U.S. Mission Exposes Divisions in Congress and Within G.O.P.
text: WASHINGTON — It is a familiar pattern in a government of checks and balances: members of Congress almost instinctively criticize the foreign adventures of a president from the opposite party.

headline: Pairings: Edible Cocktail
text: The classic rum drinks, most of them made with spirits that are aged briefly, if at all, are well-suited for summer sipping. They are beautiful at bolstering fresh fruit combinations, made with citrus, mango and melon, without intruding notes of woody intensity. Good cachaças perform similar magic. A thoroughly non-classic use for agricultural rum or cachaça is the edible cocktail that El Bulli was recently serving as a first course. Sticks of sugar cane are marinated in mojito and caipirinha baths and stuck into a bowl of crushed ice. Diners would pick them up and chew the cane to get the cocktail’s essence. Once I was home, I tried it with sticks of pineapple core and a mixture that suggested both drinks. My guests were happy, so I checked it with Ferran Adrià, who gave his enthusiastic approval in an e-mail: “Fantástica tu idea!!! We’re going to try it!”

headline: Savoring Rum, Fresh From the Cane
text: ALLOW me to set the scene in the tasting room: about 20 goblets arranged neatly before each of four seats. The colors of the liquids within were enticing enough, ranging from clear to beige, golden, amber and even burnt umber, if I recall my Crayola 64-pack properly. Ah, but the aromas!

headline: Italy: Berlusconi Wins Confidence Vote
text: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi won a confidence vote on an economic bill in the lower house on Tuesday, his first political success after his center-right coalition suffered defeats in local elections in May and in referendums last week. He also addressed the Senate on Tuesday, saying Italy’s economic future depended on the longevity of his coalition, whose mandate expires in 2013. Rejecting opposition calls for his resignation, he said a government crisis “would be madness” when Italy needed to focus on growth.

headline: New Syrups for Ice Cream or Cocktails
text: The alchemists in Brooklyn have been concocting syrups. And we don’t mean Fox’s U-bet. They tend to have cocktails, not milkshakes, in mind, though ice cream and fruit benefit from a quick drizzle.

headline: Summer’s Pink Wine in Williamsburg
text: At Le Comptoir, a bistro that opened last year and finally got its wine license in December, an owner, Adrien Angelvy, a native of St.-Tropez, knows his rosés well. He has assembled a growing list, 10 so far, mostly from France, and poured by the glass or the bottle. There are even a couple of magnums and a towering slender jeroboam (six bottles) of Château d’Esclans from Provence. For a cocktail, Whispering Berry: Crush 10 raspberries with 3 tablespoons lemon juice and 2 of agave nectar, add 4 tablespoons St-Germain elderflower liqueur, 1 cup rosé, ice; stir and strain into two wineglasses. Add ice and a few raspberries.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: A New Cheesemonger for the Flatiron District
text: Beecher’s Handmade Cheese, which has been making and selling cheeses in the Pike Place Market in Seattle for the last seven years, will open a cheese factory, a retail store and a restaurant in New York on Friday.

headline: No Food Safety in These Numbers
text: I’m eager to cover some curious and less depressing topics here — did you know Asian multi-millionaires are cornering the market on first-growth Bordeaux? — and equally eager to stop throwing mind-numbing numbers around. But as long as those pesky Republicans keep attacking the food supply for low-income people and food safety for all of us, and as long as most Democrats put up toothless defenses instead of actually trying to make things better, I gotta pay attention. If we needed further evidence that the party of “family values” only values wealthy families, we have it now; when these guys say “women and children first,” they mean “first to throw overboard.”

headline: China: Military Ties With India Resume
text: China and India have restarted military-to-military relations, nearly a year after India froze exchanges because of a visa dispute related to territorial claims, according to a report on Tuesday in the newspaper China Daily. An eight-member Indian military delegation arrived in Beijing on Sunday for a six-day visit. The head of the delegation is the head of a counterinsurgency unit deployed in the Indian-controlled part of Kashmir.

headline: Indian Company Under Scrutiny Over U.S. Visas
text: A giant Indian outsourcing company with thousands of employees in the United States is facing an expanding federal investigation prompted by claims from an American whistle-blower that it misused short-term visitors’ visas to bring in low-cost workers from India.

headline: N.F.L. Set to Proceed Toward Deal With Players
text: ROSEMONT, Ill. — N.F.L. owners and players will resume negotiations toward a new labor agreement near Boston on Wednesday after little significant dissension among owners emerged during a nearly six-hour meeting here in which they were briefed on the broad outlines of a potential deal.

headline: Mexican Police Arrest Leader of Crime Gang
text: MEXICO CITY — Six months after killing the leader of La Familia Michoacana, one of the country’s most ruthless criminal gangs, Mexican police officials said Tuesday that they had arrested his successor, hoping to deliver a blow to the group and bolster public support for the war on organized crime.

headline: Group Blends Music and Food in a Town That Reveres Both
text: This town likes to brag about a couple of things. One is an abundance of music, as manifested by statues of guitars set along the main drag and live bands playing every night of the week.

headline: In G.O.P. Presidential Race, a Focus on Cash Over Votes
text: TAMPA, Fla. — With their first major fund-raising deadline nine days away, the Republican presidential candidates are in a cutthroat, coast-to-coast scramble to sign up top party donors to gain a financial edge — and, just as crucial, to block them from helping a rival campaign.

headline: Sides Remain Far Apart in N.B.A. Labor Talks
text: Another bargaining session ended without an agreement Tuesday, despite provocative moves on both sides of the table and the pressure of a rapidly approaching deadline.

headline: Celebration, and Mourning, on a Day With Lingering Sunlight
text: Elise Emerson sat in the darkest nook of the darkest cafe she could find on the Upper West Side, trying to study and, as she put it, not to “get pessimistic.”

headline: In New York, Dieter Zetsche Delivers a China-Centric Prospectus for Mercedes-Benz
text: A condominium at the Plaza Hotel Residences recently sold for $48 million to a Russian music producer. The sale, reportedly the richest condo deal in the city’s history, set a suitably optimistic — and internationalist — backdrop for Dr. Dieter Zetsche, the Daimler chairman and head of Mercedes-Benz, to outline the luxury marque’s product strategy for a roomful of journalists who gathered at the Manhattan landmark on Tuesday morning.

headline: The President, Congress and War Powers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Did My Brother Invent E-Mail With Tom Van Vleck? (Part Three)
text: This is part three of a five-part series. Parts 1 | 2

headline: With Safety in Mind, N.H.L. Bolsters Rule on Hits to Head
text: The N.H.L. board of governors on Tuesday broadened Rule 48, which governs hits to the head, in an effort to reduce the number of concussions and other serious injuries.

headline: Adoptions by Gay Couples
text: To the Editor:

headline: Huntsman Enters Race With Promise of Civility
text: JERSEY CITY — Jon M. Huntsman Jr., the former governor of Utah, officially announced he was running for president on Tuesday, telling supporters and reporters gathered at a park facing the Statue of Liberty that he would be a better leader than President Obama, for whom he served as the ambassador to China until recently.

headline: Banana Republic Reaches Back to the ’60s for That ‘Mad Men’ Look
text: LAST year, fans of “Mad Men” could buy versions of Barbie and Ken dressed in outfits inspired by the television series. This year, they will be able to dress that way themselves.

headline: Cost of Wars a Rising Issue as Obama Weighs Troop Levels
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will talk about troop numbers in Afghanistan when he makes a prime-time speech from the White House on Wednesday night. But behind his words will be an acute awareness of what $1.3 trillion in spending on two wars in the past decade has meant at home: a ballooning budget deficit and a soaring national debt at a time when the economy is still struggling to get back on its feet.

headline: Jefferies’s Shadow on Wall Street
text: The latest results from the Jefferies Group should have its larger investment banking rivals on Wall Street quaking about their own performance. The company’s shareholders were unimpressed with quarterly numbers Tuesday that revealed a 17 percent jump in noncompensation expenses since February. Its stock tumbled more than 3 percent before regaining ground. But investors in other banks should worry more about the 30 percent fixed-income revenue decline at Jefferies since the previous quarter.

headline: All Charges Are Dropped in an Attack in Brooklyn
text: The scene, on a Friday afternoon in April, seemed a chaotic clash of old and new Brooklyn: A celebrated pizza chef and a mob henchman, acquaintances from the neighborhood, were slashing each other on Smith Street.

headline: For New Life, Blacks in City Head to South
text: In Deborah Brown’s family lore, the American South was a place of whites-only water fountains and lynchings under cover of darkness. It was a place black people like her mother had fled.

headline: Learning Empathy by Looking Beyond Disabilities
text: RIDGEWOOD, N.J. — Students at Ridgewood High School were shown photos of young people with genetic disorders — muscular dystrophy, albinism, port-wine stains — and told not to look away.

headline: Expanded Boundaries Likely to Make More Eligible for 9/11 Compensation
text: The special master in charge of a fund for people suffering lingering health effects from the Sept. 11 attack proposed on Tuesday to greatly expand the area of Lower Manhattan it covers, potentially increasing the number of residents, workers, students and passers-by who would be eligible for federal compensation.

headline: Contending the Police Went Beyond What a Cab’s Sticker Allows
text: Just as the taxi pulled to the curb in front of Terrence Battle’s home, flashing lights came on. Three officers in street clothes approached, and one asked the driver if everything was O.K. It was, the driver said. “The other officers were shining lights in the car,” Mr. Battle said. “They told me to get out of the car.”

headline: Fed’s 3-Year Rescue Plan Falling Short of Promise
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve hoped that its three-year-old economic rescue campaign would reach a climax at the end of June. It hoped that consumers and businesses by now would be spending more and more, and the central bank could start doing less and less.

headline: Divorce, Fine-Dining Style
text: Breaking up is hard to do, and some of the most regrettable food fights have involved the flameout of restaurant partnerships.

headline: For Soldiers, Death Sees No Gender Lines
text: MEHTARLAM, Afghanistan — When Specialist Devin Snyder, a 20-year-old from the Southern Tier of New York State, was killed by a bomb planted on a highway near this town in eastern Laghman Province on June 4, she became the 28th female American soldier to die in Afghanistan.

headline: Citing Finances, Brooklyn Museum Cancels Plans for Graffiti Art Exhibit
text: The Brooklyn Museum has canceled plans to mount a controversial exhibition of graffiti art, citing financial constraints. The show, “Art in the Streets,” is currently at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, where it has drawn large crowds but has also attracted criticism for prompting an increase in graffiti in the surrounding neighborhood.

headline: After 3,000, Even Dirt Will Sell
text: Derek Jeter’s 3,000th hit will be a cause for celebration, marketing and — not least of all — digging up dirt.

headline: Defendants in Drug Case at Columbia Reject Pleas
text: Four of the five Columbia University students charged in December with dealing drugs from fraternity houses rejected plea offers on Tuesday that would have spared them jail time. The fifth student indicted in the ring, Harrison David, who was the prosecution’s main target, turned down a deal that would have included one year in prison.

headline: Miranda and Juveniles
text: To the Editor:

headline: On Day 7, Speculation About Blagojevich Jury Grows
text: CHICAGO — Summer arrived, another day passed, and the jury in the case of Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois, went right on deliberating behind closed doors. As Tuesday came and went — it was Day 7 of deliberations over charges that Mr. Blagojevich tried to sell a United States Senate seat to the highest bidder — eyebrows were inevitably rising around Chicago.

headline: Reviving a Nuclear Plant
text: To the Editor:

headline: Both Sides Square Off at Hearing on Charter School Suit
text: The debate began an hour before Justice Paul G. Feinman of the State Supreme Court opened a hearing on Tuesday on the lawsuit by the United Federation of Teachers against the New York City Department of Education.

headline: The Republicans' June Fund-Raising Sprint
text: Some Republican presidential candidates scheduled fund-raisers outside the early-deciding states of Iowa and New Hampshire.

headline: Senate Republicans Ponder Marriage Vote as Clock Ticks
text: ALBANY — With the legislative clock ticking down to its final hours, the Republicans who control the State Senate still have not decided whether to allow a vote on same-sex marriage.

headline: In Data, ‘A’ Schools Leave Many Not Ready for CUNY
text: Some of the New York City high schools that received the highest grades under the Education Department’s school assessment system are graduating students who are not ready for college, newly released data show.

headline: 100-to-0 Vote Puts Panetta in Top Post
text: WASHINGTON — Leon E. Panetta was confirmed unanimously by the Senate on Tuesday as the new secretary of defense, placing him in charge of the final stage of the withdrawal in Iraq and the Obama administration’s military policy in Afghanistan.

headline: Walsh Has One Last Chance to Reshape Knicks
text: On June 28, 2005, Donnie Walsh had the 17th pick in the N.B.A. draft — and zero confidence that he would get the player he coveted.

headline: Grief and Vigilance After 4 Are Killed on Long Island
text: MEDFORD, N.Y. — In the parking lot of Haven Drugs, the pharmacy where two employees and two customers were fatally shot on Sunday morning, the signs of grief were still fresh and painfully evident on Tuesday.

headline: Wednesday: Often-Misused Possessive
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Never accuse Tim Croce of being disorganized is my new motto. Today is one of those days when I am going to let you discover the gimmick behind this puzzle for yourself. It’s very amusing, and the theme entries give it away anyway. It takes a creative mind to pull something like this off, that’s for sure.

headline: Wal-Mart’s Authoritarian Culture
text: Santa Barbara, Calif.

headline: A $176 Billion Gap for Public Pensions
text: A roundup of how well state pension funds are or are not funded.

headline: Excerpts From Response to Analysis of Public Pension Financing
text: An analysis of funding needs for state pensions, undertaken by two economists, Robert Novy-Marx and Joshua D. Rauh, showed rising costs as commitments come due. The analysis, cited in an article and a chart in The New York Times, has been disputed by many pension funds. Here are excerpts from a response by Keith Brainard, research director at Nasra, the National Association of State Retirement Administrators, after being shown the chart.

headline: Public Unions Take On Boss to Win Big Pensions
text: COSTA MESA, Calif. — City council elections in this Southern California city are usually sedate. Hot-button issues include whether libraries should stay open at night. Campaign budgets often don’t top $10,000.

headline: The Real Reboot Greece Needs
text: Athens

headline: Lottery Numbers
Come Meet the Author, but Open Your Wallet
text: Independent bookstores, squeezed by competition from Internet retailers like Amazon, have long done something their online brethren cannot emulate: author events. And now many bookstores say they have no choice but to capitalize on this grand tradition.

headline: 100 Days
text: There is something crazy about what is going on in our country today. Our fiscal condition continues on an unsustainable path, the European currency is heading for a crackup, the Arab world is in the midst of a crackup, unemployment is creeping upward and basically our two parties are telling us that they will not make the reforms that we know are necessary because it would involve too much pain and could imperil their chances of winning the presidency in 2012.

headline: Sing Out, Hillary
text: WASHINGTON

headline: In African Women’s Soccer, Homophobia Remains an Obstacle
text: Shortly before she was hired in 2009 as the first female coach of Nigeria’s powerful women’s national soccer team, Eucharia Uche said at a seminar that she was troubled by the presence of lesbians on the squad, calling it a “worrisome experience.”

headline: Greece and You
text: The euro-zone bailout of Greece is, in good part, a bailout of European banks. In France and Germany alone, banks hold some $90 billion worth of public and private Greek debt. The European Central Bank also holds Greek government debt, and the fear is that if Greece defaults, cascading losses could threaten all of Europe.

headline: A Start-Up’s Camera Lets You Take Shots First and Focus Later
text: With an innovative camera due out later this year from a company called Lytro, photographers will have one less excuse for having missed that perfect shot.

headline: The Carbon Ruling
text: The Supreme Court’s decision on greenhouse gases on Monday is a disappointment to the states and environmental groups that had hoped to use federal common law to curb carbon dioxide pollution from power plants. It would also appear to be a setback in the fight against global warming. But it is, in fact, a clarifying and positive decision — vindicating the Clean Air Act, which is under siege in the House, and increasing pressure on the Environmental Protection Agency to carry out its authority to regulate greenhouse gases under that act.

headline: Medicare Back on the Hustings
text: Leading Republicans — after proposing to gut Medicare — are still trying to pose as the program’s saviors. How cynical can they get?

headline: Bloomberg Move Exploits Taxi Industry’s Limited Reach
text: For months, New York City’s powerful taxi industry has tried to sway City Council members on proposals that could redefine the traditional roles of the city’s yellow taxis and livery cabs.

headline: A Certainty of Uncertainty at Wimbledon
text: We know a few things for certain about the Wimbledon championships, which began at the All England Lawn Tennis Club in London on Monday. This will be the 125th playing of Wimbledon. The turf on the courts will be 8 millimeters high. The balls will be optic yellow, as they have been since 1986. The weather will be changeable. The players will be wearing mostly white, according to club rules. The number of competitors will decline geometrically until only the winner remains in each category — two winners in doubles, of course.

headline: The Color of Money
Hamptons Hope for an End to the Seasonal Store
text: Summer resort communities have a challenge when it comes to maintaining a vibrant town: how to retain their local character when the population surges with an influx of visitors, then avoid feeling like a ghost town when those part-time residents head home.

headline: Blocks From the President, Developers Plan Big
text: WASHINGTON — Since the late 1990s, the once-desolate section of downtown Washington east of the White House has undergone a striking transformation. About $10.6 billion has been invested in more than 150 real estate projects. Some 56,000 people now live downtown, up from 38,000 in 2000.

headline: House Nearing Completion of Patent Office Overhaul
text: WASHINGTON — A legislative overhaul of the United States Patent and Trademark Office moved toward completion in the House on Tuesday when members of the two important committees agreed to keep the office subject to annual appropriations but to end for the first time the diversion of patent fees to other uses.

headline: To Stretch or Not to Stretch
text: Is it time, once again, to stretch? For decades, many of us stretched before a workout, usually by reaching toward our toes or leaning against a wall to elongate our hamstrings, then holding that pose without moving until it felt uncomfortable, a technique known as static stretching. Most people, including scientists and entire generations of elementary-school P.E. teachers, believed that static stretching lengthened muscles and increased flexibility, making people better able to perform athletically.

headline: Senators Seek Information on Side Effects of Medtronic Bone-Growth Product
text: Two senators on Tuesday expanded an investigation of the medical device maker Medtronic, demanding that the company turn over records involving millions of dollars in payments to researchers and internal correspondence with doctors who had published its research on a controversial bone-growth product.

headline: Word of the Day | miasma
text: miasma •\mi-ˈaz-mə, me-\ • noun

headline: Last Whiff of Bagels, Mixed With Despair
text: H & H Bagels, the Upper West Side’s most celebrated destination for what is quite possibly the Upper West Side’s most iconic food, is closing its store in the neighborhood, employees said Tuesday.

headline: Mexico: Columnist Is Killed
text: A journalist who regularly had written on organized crime, politics and corruption in Veracruz State was shot to death on Monday along with his wife and 21-year-old son, the authorities said. The police said Miguel Angel Lopez Velasco, 55, a columnist for the newspaper Notiver, and his family members were killed by unknown assailants at his home in the city of Veracruz. His son, Misael Lopez, worked as a photographer for the newspaper. Since the beginning of last year, 13 journalists have been killed in Mexico, including at least three in reprisal for their work, according to the Committee to Protect Journalists, a group based in New York.

headline: A Big Day for Mets’ Bay
text: There was not a lot of happy news on Tuesday for the Mets. Jose Reyes made their lives more difficult by announcing he would not negotiate a contract extension during the season, Dillon Gee had his worst outing of the year, and the Mets lost for the third time in four games.

headline: New Name for Football Stadium at Rutgers
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J. — Tim Pernetti became a real-estate agent, of sorts, when he took over as athletic director at Rutgers in 2009, or 140 years after the school hosted the first intercollegiate football game. He saw acres of blank space that could splashed with logos.

text: NYT: Front Page for 06/22/2011

headline: Battle for Libya | June 21, 2011
text: Rockets landed in Misurata, fired by forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

text: FRONT PAGE

headline: News Quiz | June 22, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Chairman of Christie’s Gets Qatar Post
text: Christie’s chairman, Edward Dolman, left, has been named executive director of the Qatar Museums Authority to establish a network of museums in Doha, the capital, and to acquire art as well as to preserve the collections of the state. Mr. Dolman will divide his time among Doha, New York and London and will oversee the authority’s various initiatives to promote culture worldwide. In 2008 it opened the Museum of Islamic Art, a zigguratlike structure of white stone designed by I.M. Pei. Last year it opened the Mathaf: Arab Museum of Modern Art, which houses a collection of more than 6,000 works, spanning the 1840s to the present. Its latest project, scheduled for completion in 2014, is the reopening of the Qatar National Museum in a new building designed by the French architect Jean Nouvel.

headline: The Triumph of Bad Ideas
text: Bill Gross of Pimco calls for more fiscal stimulus and denounces the “anti-Keynesian” consensus. Now he tells us.

headline: Was Albert Pujols’s Injury Avoidable?
text: Rule 6.05 (k) A batter is out when, in running the last half of the distance from home base to first base, while the ball is being fielded to first base, he runs outside (to the right of) the three-foot line, or inside (to the left of) the foul line, and in the umpire’s judgment in so doing interferes with the fielder taking the throw at first base, in which case the ball is dead; except that he may run outside (to the right of) the three-foot line or inside (to the left of) the foul line to avoid a fielder attempting to field a batted ball.

headline: Why Your Comment Was Deleted
text: 1. Gee whillikers, you used an obscenity! It’s clear that many people don’t even realize that they’re using banned words. But that’s by far the biggest reason for rejection.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, June 22, 2011
text: Test your math skills with today’s question, created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the article “A Labor of Wonder: Mapping 19,993 Trees in Central Park.”

headline: Reagan and Revenues
text: The wholesale voodization of the GOP is a sight to behold; apparently the nonsense about the Reagan tax cuts having led to a vast rise in revenue is now something one must claim to believe. Anyway, a quick note about Federal revenue history.

headline: Thomas N. Armstrong III, Museum Chief Who Once Led the Whitney, Dies at 78
text: Thomas N. Armstrong III, who greatly expanded the Whitney Museum of American Art’s holdings when he was its director in the 1970s and ’80s but whose ambitious plans for a museum addition aroused a firestorm of opposition that led to his dismissal, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 78.

headline: A Prankster’s Life Is Cut Short
text: WHO was Ryan Dunn?

headline: World War II Mystery Solved in a Few Hours
text: As Tuesday dawned, what we knew about an anonymous photo album by a Nazi photographer was only what could be inferred from its 214 pictures (all but one uncaptioned). We could see he had amazing access: taking portraits of Russian and Jewish prisoners one month, standing just a few feet from Adolf Hitler the next. We knew he had been to the Eastern Front, we surmised that he worked for the Propagandakompanie and we guessed that the pretty woman in the album’s closing pages was someone special.

headline: Q&A: Finding Other Ways to Record TV Shows
text: Q.

headline: Like All Good Action Heroes, Casio’s Commando Is Tough — but Complex
text: The people who make phone cases are going to be very unhappy with the Casio G’zOne Commando phone. So are people who like simplicity.

headline: Do You Worry About the Lack of Anonymity in the Digital Age?
text: In several incidents recently, regular citizens have found themselves involved in news events – and then publicly identified, thanks to technology. What do you think about cases like this? How do you think it might feel if the world knew who you were after you were caught on camera? Do you ever worry about your ability to remain anonymous, if that is what you want?

headline: Wise-Walker Downsizes the Laptop Bag
text: After years of carrying bags big enough to hold a bull mastiff, I thought that I might be ready to slim down a bit. That’s why I was so refreshed when I saw the Nomadic WR-08 Wise-Walker A4 Shoulder Bag. This bag’s Star Wars-esque name reflects the dimensions (but not the thickness) of an A4 sheet of paper and is a uniquely Japanese take on the traditional laptop bag.

headline: Top 10 Inside Linebackers in N.F.L.
text: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely -– but not strictly -– by film study of all 32 teams from the 2010 season. Stats weren’t acknowledged, but players with poor numbers generally don’t make top 10 lists anyway. Vague enough for you? Criteria for top 10 lists tend to be. That’s why most of you will have no trouble finding some disagreement with what you’re about to read.

headline: Fantasy Focus: Pitching Observations
text: Brandon League blew three consecutive save chances in May (and absorbed four losses in four straight outings) but still has 20 saves on the year, one off the league lead. The Mariners are likely to generate more save situations than the average team because their pitcher-friendly park, strong starting staff, solid defense and terrible offense ensure that many of their wins are by small margins. League doesn’t strike out too many batters (20 in 30 2/3 innings), but he has walked only five, keeps the ball on the ground (2-to-1 ground-ball-to-fly-ball ratio) and averages 96 miles per hour on his fastball. He came out of Tuesday’s loss in Washington after a line drive hit him on the leg and could miss some time.Trevor Cahill went from a seven-walk, zero-strikeout disaster start on June 14 to an eight-inning, one-walk, seven-strikeout gem on Sunday. You can usually predict what stars like Roy Halladay and Justin Verlander will do on one end, and how players like Joe Saunders and Rodrigo Lopez will fare on the other. The 90 percent of pitchers in between can pretty much do anything on a given day. Sometimes it’s best to get the cheapest ones applicable to your league and spend nearly all your resources on hitting.

headline: In Lille, Near Paris, Examining ‘Paranoia’
text: Lille, about an hour by high-speed train from Paris, is an arty place; it was selected as a European Capital of Culture in 2004. And sometimes, culture pops up in unlikely places.

headline: The Early Word: The Price of War
text: Today’s Times

headline: After Child Deaths, KidsAndCars.org Renews Challenge to G.M.
text: KidsAndCars.org, a nonprofit organization that focuses on safety issues relating to children and automobiles, announced on Monday that it renewed demands for General Motors to voluntarily recall all 2000-1 model-year vehicles equipped with trunks to install internal trunk releases.

headline: Across the World, Less Interest in Leaving Home
text: Fewer residents of the world are trying to get out of Dodge, according to Gallup.

headline: What’s Wrong With Colorado Mountain Coffee’s Web Site?
text: Since December, Colorado Mountain Coffee has been selling mountain-roasted Arabica coffee exclusively online. Its owners say that what sets the company’s coffee apart is its roasting process, which is done at high altitude. “With less oxygen and pressure at high elevation, we are able to preserve the beans’ delicate flavor profile,” said Ryan Wagner, who founded the site along with David Richards.

headline: Can Huntsman Be Civil to Obama and Win?
text: Can Jon M. Huntsman Jr. run against President Obama without really running against him?

headline: AstraZeneca Sells Dental Unit for $1.8 Billion
text: The European drug maker AstraZeneca said on Wednesday that it was selling its Astra Tech dental and medical device business to Dentsply for $1.8 billion, in a deal that would create the third-largest dental implant company in the world.

headline: 8 Bahrain Activists Get Life Sentences
text: CAIRO — A special military court in Bahrain convicted 21 mostly Shiite activists on Wednesday on charges of conspiring to overthrow the government during street demonstrations this year, sentencing eight to life in prison and the others to terms of up to 15 years.

headline: Video: Pawlenty Up With First 2012 Ad in Iowa
text: There are plenty of ways to mark the beginning of a real presidential campaign. The first campaign commercial in Iowa is one of them. And here it is. Click over to a post by The Times’s Jeff Zeleny, who wrote on Tuesday about the decision by Tim Pawlenty, the former governor of Minnesota, to broadcast it now.

headline: The Cloud That Ate Your Music
text: I’M ready for the cloud. Soon, I hope, it will be ready for me.

headline: Rare Struggles for the Rookie Gee
text: In his previous outing against the Atlanta Braves, on June 15, the rookie Dillon Gee had perhaps his best stuff of the year. He pitched four scoreless innings that night with only one hit and two walks.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Cholesterol Drugs Can Increase Diabetes Risk
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Recent Rains Bolster Hydroelectric Plants, but China Braces for Summer Power Shortages
text: BEIJING — Heavy rains in central China last week will help China produce extra hydroelectric power in the coming weeks, but not enough to avoid severe electricity shortages this summer, Chinese officials said Wednesday.

headline: Panel Hears Complaints on Pensions at Delphi
text: A Congressional panel heard complaints Wednesday that the Obama administration had created pension winners and pension losers when it led the bankruptcy overhauls of the auto companies in 2009, despite federal rules meant to weave a uniform safety net for retirees.

headline: Local Taxi Issues Take a Ride to Albany
text: There’s an old joke about an Englishman living in New York who was heading home and thought it would be a hoot to pull up to the family house in London in the back of a New York yellow taxi. He talked a cabby into going along with the idea, all expenses paid. They sailed to Southampton, with the taxi as cargo, then drove to London.

headline: My Life as an Undocumented Immigrant
text: One August morning nearly two decades ago, my mother woke me and put me in a cab. She handed me a jacket. “Baka malamig doon” were among the few words she said. (“It might be cold there.”) When I arrived at the Philippines’ Ninoy Aquino International Airport with her, my aunt and a family friend, I was introduced to a man I’d never seen. They told me he was my uncle. He held my hand as I boarded an airplane for the first time. It was 1993, and I was 12.

headline: N.H.L. Tries to Give Back the Water
text: Before the Stanley Cup Finals between the Vancouver Canucks and the Boston Bruins, the National Hockey League said that the finals would be the first “water neutral” series in its history.

headline: Beijing Warns U.S. About South China Sea Disputes
text: BEIJING — The Chinese vice foreign minister warned the United States on Wednesday to stay out of the increasingly tense territorial disputes and maritime conflicts in the South China Sea, which has some of the busiest shipping lanes in the world and is believed to be rich in oil and natural gas reserves.

headline: Shazam Identifies the Sound of Fresh Venture Funds
text: Can Shazam, the mobile application that can identify songs, recognize the sound of cha-ching?

headline: Samurai Shopper | Quicker Picker Uppers
text: As an occasional insomniac, the Samurai Shopper finds that TV shopping networks no longer put me in the zzzzzone; but Antenna, way up north on Channel 166, does. From 5 a.m. till midday, Antenna runs old movies that beg for oblivion but have been unaccountably resurrected. Today’s fare, circa 1950, was “The Last of the Buccaneers,” a down-market swashbuckling adventure of Jean Lafitte, starring Paul Henried. Asleep yet? How about Beau Bridges as “The Fifth Musketeer”?

headline: Michigan Residents Sue Over Law on Emergency Management of Struggling Cities
text: More than two dozen residents of Michigan filed a lawsuit on Wednesday against top officials in the state, contending that a new law broadly expanding the powers of emergency managers in the most financially troubled cities violates Michigan’s Constitution.

headline: China Moves Closer to Libyan Opposition
text: BEIJING — China’s foreign minister met here with the leader of Libya’s rebel opposition on Wednesday and said in a statement afterward that the opposition was “an important dialogue partner,” the latest in a series of Chinese moves to improve ties to the opposition.

headline: Cast Away: Tom Hanks Spends a Morning at Univision’s ‘Despierta America’
text: This is how it goes in Hollywood: One day you’re the two-time Academy Award-winning star of “Philadelphia” and “Forrest Gump”; the next, you’re a backup dancer to a TV weather reporter. Demonstrating that he is America’s sweetheart in any language, Tom Hanks – or, as he is referred to repeatedly in the above clip, Tomasito – turned up on Tuesday morning at Univision, the Spanish-language television network. He was there, presumably, to promote his new movie, “Larry Crowne,” but the result was more like the real-life equivalent of a “Saturday Night Live” skit as Mr. Hanks gamely interacted with the cast of “Despierta America” despite his lack of language skills. (But he is, as you may recall from “Big,” a surprisingly competent dancer.) We were pointed to this scene by The Daily What; you can also see Mr. Hanks eat a hot chile on a cooking segment here.

headline: Following Up, Part 2.  Down the Rabbit Hole: Arms Exports and Qaddafi’s Cluster Bombs
text: Over the next few days, At War will try something different, and allow readers to look over our shoulders on an unusual reporting and verification adventure, and to journey with us on the follow-up on the attacks with cluster munitions in Misurata, Libya. Ready for a tour of some of the ins-and-outs of conflict reporting in the Internet Age? Then come along for a bit of a ride.

text: TOP STORIES

headline: Fire at Popular Capitol Hill Watering Hole
text: Capitol Hill was rocked Wednesday morning by a fire at a favored watering hole, the Tune Inn, located a few blocks down Pennsylvania Avenue from the House.

headline: Huntsman Finishes Opening Day with Big Money Haul
text: Jon M. Huntsman Jr. opened his day on Tuesday by formally declaring his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination. He closed it by accomplishing an equally important task: collecting $1.2 million for his campaign.

headline: Milan Top 5 | Salvatore Ferragamo
text: The fringed wide-brimmed straw hat gave a hint of the inspiration behind Massimiliano Giornetti’s super-elegant Salvatore Ferragamo show: an artist in the south of somewhere. Italy, France, Spain. They all work. Wide-legged linen pants were worn with long, lean double-breasted sport jackets and cotton chore coats. My favorite was a white tunic-style shirt over white pants, with a natural linen double-breasted jacket worn open. The slingback espadrilles were the spot-on shoes from this house that was built on soles.

headline: Financially Troubled Philadelphia Orchestra Finds New Support

Most of the money — $16.3 million – came in the form of challenge grants that must be met by the end of the year. Gifts and promised gifts came from several local foundations and members of the orchestra’s board. The donors include the William Penn Foundation, Wyncote Foundation and Neubauer Family Foundation, the orchestra said.

headline: The Art on His Sleeve
text: All artists have their talismans and rituals. For Balthus the talisman was the tablier he picked up at the American Hospital in Paris during World War II, which he wore religiously. Balthus always painted in the smock, using it like a cloth to wipe his brushes clean. It was never washed and, over 60 odd years, it accumulated layer upon layer of pigment, becoming an artwork in itself. The artist Katerina Jebb, who uses scanners and copy machines in her work, has scanned the front and back of the tablier in 12-by-16-inch fragments to create a life-size copy of it on paper that will be shown at the Balthus Chapel in the village of Rossinière, Switzerland from June 25, 2011 through May, 2012. Jebb’s high-definition scan captures every speck of paint on the sturdy, dark blue cotton — you can almost pick out the colors from Balthus’s surreally erotic “Guitar Lesson.”

headline: Suit Seeks to Win Back Poker Kitty From Tobey Maguire
text: LOS ANGELES — Tobey Maguire, who hit the jackpot with his starring role in the “Spider-Man” films, may have overplayed his hand at the poker table, according to a suit filed in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Central District of California here. The trustee for Ruderman Capital Partners is demanding that Mr. Maguire repay at least $311,200 in winnings from what it describes as unlicensed, high-stakes poker games between 2006 and 2009. Radaronline on Wednesday carried a report of the suit, which was filed here in March. According to the filing, Bradley Ruderman, who managed the fund and in January of last year was sentenced to 10 years in federal prison on various fraud charges, used investor money to pay off losses in the games, in which Mr. Maguire was among the winners.

headline: The Huntsman Candidacy
text: Can a moderate Republican win the G.O.P. nomination? That’s the question everyone’s asking with regard to Jon Huntsman, who formally announced his candidacy yesterday, and the answer is a resounding yes. From George H.W. Bush and Bob Dole through George W. Bush and John McCain, the modern-day Republican Party has a long tradition of picking nominees whose records and positions place them to the left of True Conservatism, at least as defined by movement institutions, talk radio and the like. Even in the age of the Tea Party, there’s reason to imagine this pattern persisting: Many Republican primary voters hold heterodox positions (for instance, on tax increases on the rich) relative to the official conservative line, several of the crucial early primaries allow independents to cross over and vote, and in races against incumbent presidents there’s a high premium on electability. It’s certainly possible for a Republican to be too liberal for the primary electorate, and often a moderate candidate has to flip-flop on a key issue (or six) to appease the party’s interest groups. But the historical record suggests that there’s more room between Rush Limbaugh and the center than many commentators (and politicians) seem to think.

headline: Beauty and the Beach

headline: Eureka! A Roaming Bowhead Whale
text: Balaena mysticetus is her formal name, but you can call her bowhead. She’s about the length of two big yellow school buses parked end to end and a bit on the heavy side, around 100 tons with a two-foot-thick layer of blubber. Bowhead is hardly an accidental nickname, as her head makes up a third of of her total body length and her mouth is the largest of any whale species, big enough for a tongue weighing nearly one ton.

headline: Surveying That Soft Stuff of Wings and of Dreams
text: When the Titanic went down in 1912, with it went not only passengers, but a hold full of international luxury goods: orchids, velvet, Tiffany china — and more than 40 cases of feathers. With the craze for ornate ladies’ hats near its peak, birds from all over the world were being hunted for their plumes, the more colorful and outlandish the better. The feathers that landed at the bottom of the sea that day were worth, in today’s currency, $2.3 million.

headline: American Forces in Afghanistan and Iraq

headline: Nocturnalist: Playing Dead
text: At Brooklyn's Green-Wood Cemetery, a theatrical production, "The Spoon River Project," plays out among the tombstones.

headline: Giving Eccentricities Free Rein
text: SOMEDAY you may find yourself in the basement of the new Jay Kos store in NoLIta. You may stand in front of the three-way mirror, where maybe you will be trying on some phenomenal lavender linen pants. There will be Scotch on offer, maybe a cigar if the mood is right. Mr. Kos — I mean, come on, who are we kidding? — Jay may sit in a chair across from you, his thicket of graying hair pulled back into a loose grab, his wrist choked with bracelets and lanyards and leather straps, his weathered jeans impeccably fit. There will be stories of incredible parties with the well-known, casual barbs about the well-to-do. You could get used to this, you think.

headline: This Porker Has a Beef With the World
text: We are all creatures rooting in the gutter of appetite, but most of us are also looking at the stars. Or so it goes in Jason Grote’s “Civilization (All You Can Eat),” a play whose conventional heart is not particularly well camouflaged by its postmodern bells and whistles.

headline: Asked & Answered | Gabriel Rucker
text: It’s early in the evening on a Tuesday, and Gabriel Rucker is in a winning mood. The chef and restaurateur, who first gained national attention in 2007 for his restaurant Le Pigeon in Portland, Ore., is this year’s recipient of the James Beard Foundation’s Rising Star Chef of the Year award, an honor reserved for chefs under 30. His work at Le Pigeon draws from classic technique, the ample larder of Oregon’s Willamette Valley and the character of Portland itself — equal parts divine and dingy, local and wild. Rucker’s latest venture, Little Bird, opened in late 2010 and is more of a classic bistro in style and setting, with a fascinating cocktail list, cheap beer selections and strokes of clever embedded throughout the menu; think enormous marrow bones with balsamic vinegar onions presented à la Fred Flinstone, or a sorbet and ice cream course served in pastel miniature egg cartons.

headline: Sites Rebuild After F.B.I. Raid on Data Center
text: Curbed Network, a New York blog publisher, and a few other companies were working to restore their operations to normal on Wednesday after an F.B.I. raid on a data center the day before took them offline or slowed their Web sites’ performance.

headline: Nothing but Blue Skies for a Fake Harvard Law Grad
text: “Suits,” a new legal series beginning on Thursday on USA, erupts from a Mount Vesuvius of absurdities, and yet like so much else in the USA stable, it comes in relatively good faith — not merely with a snappy sense of its own fun, but also with a chipper belief in the viability of renewal. The channel seems to have a mandate to uplift the national mood, to appeal to the fantasy of second chances and sexy opportunities. On a USA series there are no dank unemployment offices, no cups of weak coffee, only high floors, soaring views and crisp French roasts.

headline: Brian Lam, Gizmodo Editor, Moves On

headline: Best Way to the Concert? Get Yourself a Rowboat
text: “Swelter” was an apt title for the spatial brass work performed at Central Park Lake on Tuesday afternoon, part of the daylong citywide festival Make Music New York. The performance was as much an urban happening as an outdoor concert, and though the weather was steamy, an eager audience in rowboats did not seem to mind.
