headline: Claire Cain Miller on risky startups; Dean Kamen, Legos and education; news.
text: Silicon Valley is bubbling over with chatter about big investments in startups that are barely off the ground. Bettina Edelstein speaks with Times technology reporter Claire Cain Miller about risky startups and why they're getting so much attention. The inventor Dean Kamen is known for creating the Segway, among other things, and he's also behind a group called FIRST that aims to get young people interested in science, technology and engineering. J.D. Biersdorfer chats with Kamen about that and the winning project for the organization's Global Innovation Award. The news roundup includes a Dropbox security faux pas; Verizon ending unlimited mobile data plans; Facebook's planned Music Dashboard; new web address suffixes. J.D.'s tech tip: Using the Windows 7 System Maintenance troubleshooter.

headline: American Stereotypes Trek Across a Moroccan Desert
text: As forms of American aggression go, sending a few dozen ambassadors of cultural misunderstanding to a foreign country with cameras in tow ranks as minor. But shows like “Expedition Impossible,” which emphasize the traveler over the destination, qualify as invasions just the same.

headline: Big Deal | A Rare Fifth Avenue Mansion Goes on the Market
text: Take a mansion for sale on a singular block of Fifth Avenue, designed by a Gilded Age architect whose work defined an aesthetic that forever changed the landscape of the well-to-do corners of New York, throw in a $49 million price tag, and you have a blockbuster listing that is going on the market this weekend.

headline: Roddick Feels Woods’s Pain
text: WIMBLEDON — It sounded all too familiar to Andy Roddick, hearing that Tiger Woods’s latest comeback from injuries to his left knee and Achilles’ tendon has been further delayed because of “doctor’s orders.”

headline: Note to Self: A Good Pair of Shoes Always Ends Up Paying for Itself
text: James Kudelka manages something fairly remarkable in his version of “Cinderella,” which American Ballet Theater performed on Tuesday in the first of a seven-performance run at the Metropolitan Opera House. He succeeds in creating a fairy-tale ballet entirely devoid of charm, a “Cinderella” that is for neither children nor adults and that somehow misses nearly every theatrical moment in the familiar story.

headline: Scene City: The Shakespeare Gala
text: Even on a perfect summer evening, with golden light filtered through the Central Park trees, a soft breeze and a parade of celebrities in resplendent festive attire, it was hard to focus solely on the evening’s loveliness in celebration of more than 50 years of free Shakespeare in the Park.

headline: Two Men Hang Out on a Couch. But One Appears to Be a Dog.
text: “Wilfred,” beginning Thursday night on FX, is a semi-dark comedy in which Frodo Baggins frequently shares a bong with a large Australian man wearing a dog suit. Some shows aspire to cult status; this one goes straight there, practically bypassing the need to be broadcast at all.

headline: Rootless Rapper Finds His Rhythm
text: Making one of the year’s most important rap albums just doesn’t mean what it used to. For one thing, it can have very little to do with actual rapping. Just ask the Cuban-American Miami rapper Pitbull, now more important than ever, and more popular, thanks to his irrepressible new album, “Planet Pit.”

headline: A Singer in No Rush, Deploying Her Big Gestures Carefully
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Sade Adu emerged from below the Nassau Coliseum stage here on Tuesday night immaculate: her all-black outfit tight and modest, her heels perilously high, her hair pulled back hard. Ms. Adu is 52, and in almost three decades of leading her band, Sade, she has barely aged and has never once appeared hurried. Stasis is her art.

headline: Reality Contests Win
text: NBC’s reality competitions “The Voice” and “America’s Got Talent” dominated the ratings on Tuesday night, while two new shows on ABC got off to modest starts. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the most watched show was “America’s Got Talent,” which attracted 12 million viewers at 8, but “The Voice,” from 9 to 11, led the night in the demographic of viewers 18 to 49 while earning nearly as many total viewers (11.8 million). ABC drew 5.5 million at 9 for the premiere of its new series “101 Ways to Leave a Game Show.” The debut of its drama “Combat Hospital” drew 5.3 million viewers.

headline: Schiele and Picasso Draw Interest at London Auctions
text: LONDON — A colorful cityscape by Egon Schiele being sold by the Leopold Museum in Vienna brought $40.1 million at a sale of Impressionist and modern art at Sotheby’s here on Wednesday night, yet another sign that taste this season is veering toward the 20th century.

headline: Accelerate Android With Tips and Tricks
text: Mobile phones that run Google’s Android operating system come in various shapes, sizes and features, unlike Apple’s iPhones. And Android phones are available on a variety of carriers, including Boost Mobile, where a data plan can cost as little as $35 a month.

headline: Shakespeare’s Been Reading the News
text: GREAT as they are, not all of Shakespeare’s plays are as relevant to life today as others. But then there’s “All’s Well That Ends Well.” It’s about a caddish husband and the good and loving wife who puts up with his nonsense. Sound familiar?

headline: Aye, There’s the Rib
text: On the docket for today: a weekend dinner of glazed lamb ribs, hot and sticky off the grill, accompanied by a cool minted yogurt sauce that flashes with citrus and fire. You could accompany the meat with rice or salad and certainly with beer or cold tea. The dish has the power to transform any porch or garden, roof or chalky concrete side yard into Southampton in high summer.

headline: Overtaking With the Ace, or Overthinking?
text: Play at the fifth European Open Championships in Poznan, Poland, started last Saturday and will continue until July 2. The opening event was the Mixed Teams, won on Wednesday by Pierre Zimmermann, Bénédicte Cronier, Philippe Cronier, Catherine d’Ovidio, Franck Multon and Sylvie Willard. In the 48-board final they defeated Bep Vriend, Anton Maas, Carla Arnolds, Ton Bakkeren, Martine Verbeek and Huub Bertens  by 135 international match points to 41.

headline: Rugs Inspired by the Kimono
text: When Michael Mandapati opened Warp and Weft a decade ago, his intention was to sell 19th- and early 20th-century carpets. But Mr. Mandapati, a New Delhi native, was eventually questioning his mission. “I wasn’t sure if I liked traditional designs anymore,” he said. His epiphany came while browsing at the Strand bookstore, where he discovered books about the quilts made by the women of Gee’s Bend in Alabama. “I was completely in awe,” he said. “Warp and Weft Modern was born, inspired by those quilts.”

headline: Diane Keaton Gets Into the Design Game
text: Diane Keaton still maintains a busy schedule as an actress, but in recent years the Oscar-winner has devoted considerable time to another area of interest: architecture and design. A serial house flipper, Ms. Keaton, 65, has bought several homes in her native Southern California and painstakingly renovated them before getting the itch to move on and repeat the process. The actress is also actively involved in architectural preservation (she is on the board of the Los Angeles Conservancy), and in 2007, she co-wrote “California Romantica” (Rizzoli), a book celebrating the Spanish and Mission-style architecture she loves.

headline: In Queens, Artists Throw a Crafts Fair

text: FROM the roof of a loft building on East 14th Street, you can peer into a deep brick-lined canyon where the sweet tang of lilies mixes with a base note of French fries. There’s a meadow of bright green AstroTurf, a hedgerow of bushy tomato plants and two teenage maples.

headline: Welcome to Chicago, Just Don’t Kill Us
text: AFTER two films and more than $1.5 billion in global box-office sales, it’s no surprise that another installment in the “Transformers” franchise would soon be exploding in a theater near you. The battle between the Autobots (the good robots) and the Decepticons (the evil ones) continues in “Dark of the Moon,” opening Wednesday with more destruction, more robots and one powerful cinematic weapon: 3-D.

headline: Tiny Edens on Urban Rooftops

headline: New Hampshire: Lawmakers Override Veto of Abortion Consent Bill
text: The State Legislature on Wednesday overrode Gov. John Lynch’s veto of a bill that requires abortion providers to notify parents of minors 48 hours before performing the procedure. The House overrode the veto by a 266-102 vote; the Senate vote was 17-7. “Granite Staters believe in more parental involvement, not less,” the House speaker, William O’Brien, said in a statement. New Hampshire will become the 37th state with such a law.

headline: Dieter Zetsche, Matchbox 20 and a 1937 540K Inaugurate Mercedes Showroom
text: On Tuesday night Mercedes-Benz Manhattan celebrated the opening of its sprawling, company-owned showroom on 11th Avenue between 53rd and 54th Streets. The dealership occupies the bottom floors of Mercedes House, a residential development designed by the architect Enrique Norten.

headline: Arkansas: Closing of Wells Is Sought
text: The Arkansas Oil and Gas Commission on Tuesday proposed a permanent moratorium on disposal wells related to natural gas drilling in a 1,150-square-mile area in the center of the state. State scientists have found a highly suggestive link between the operation of these wells and a swarm of more than 1,220 earthquakes since early last fall, including a 4.7-magnitude quake in February. Since two of the wells were shut down in March, the number of earthquakes has dropped by almost 50 percent. The moratorium would shut down two other wells. On July 26, the commission will make a decision about the moratorium after hearing from state scientists, and from oil and gas company representatives, who have said that a direct correlation has not been proved.

headline: Security Professionals Say Network Breaches Are Rampant
text: There has been a flood of news about hacker break-ins at companies. But how bad is the situation really?

headline: Need Overwhelms Makeshift Clinic in Syria Camp
text: KHIRBET AL-JOUZ, Syria — Mohamed Marei awoke to the wails of a sick child arriving at his makeshift medical clinic, where he and half a dozen other men were living, having fled their homes to escape a violent government crackdown in the country’s rural northwest.

The freshening breeze seemed to promise a respite from the 24-hour news cycle as we set off for the Governors Island Alliance’s Summer Gala. But the chirping of birds seemed only to remind guests of tweeting of a different sort.

headline: Fans Adjusting to a New Address and Ambience in Omaha
text: OMAHA — A chain-link fence surrounds the perimeter of Rosenblatt Stadium, the home of the College World Series from 1950 until last year, as it awaits the wrecking ball. The sidewalks along 13th Street, normally teeming at tournament time, were deserted Tuesday morning. Two blocks away, a woman walked a small brown dog past an empty lot that last year housed two recreational vehicles and a party tent.

headline: France: Galliano Blames His Addictions for Slurs
text: The fashion designer John Galliano defended himself Wednesday against hate-crime charges in Paris, saying that because of addictions he could not remember spewing anti-Semitic insults. Mr. Galliano, 50, apologized for the slurs and said he was in treatment for addictions to alcohol, sleeping pills and Valium. His one-day trial before three judges concerned incidents at a bar in October and February. He is accused of the crime of delivering public insults about religion, race or ethnicity. A verdict is to be issued Sept. 8.

headline: Mortgage Debt, a Lasting Burden
text: The government wants to wind down Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. But the task is getting bigger, not smaller. Impaired and hard-to-sell mortgage debt — more than $900 billion of it so far — increasingly dominates the two housing finance giants’ balance sheets.

headline: Post Office to Stop Payments to Retirement Fund
text: WASHINGTON — To stave off insolvency, the Postal Service will discontinue legally required payments to its employees’ retirement fund on Friday, the agency announced Wednesday.

headline: Mr. Marsh’s Italian Job
text: In June 1861, George Perkins Marsh arrived in Turin to begin his appointment as envoy extraordinary to Italy from the United States of America. It was a fitting title. These were extraordinary times: that spring witnessed both the disintegration of the United States and the unification of Italy. The Lincoln administration, eager to buttress the Union’s European position against burgeoning Confederate diplomacy, immediately recognized the new Italian state. Whether Washington could build an actual alliance with Italy that could serve its war aims was a question Marsh had been sent to answer.

headline: Andy Murray Sparks Little Hope Among Britons
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Between bites of a ham and cheese sandwich, Jill Smith, an Englishwoman who attended Wimbledon on Wednesday with her grown daughter, assessed the title chances of Britain’s top player, Andy Murray.

headline: Drawing Down, With a Vigilant Eye on Pakistan
text: WASHINGTON — Hours after the Sept. 11 attacks, Pakistan’s leaders were given an ultimatum by the Bush administration: Because the looming war in Afghanistan could not be won without Pakistan’s help, Islamabad would have to choose between continuing its alliance with the Taliban or joining forces with the United States.

headline: Some Greeks Fear Government Is Selling Nation
text: ATHENS — They are the crown jewels of Greece’s socialist state, and they are now likely to go to the highest bidder: the ports of Piraeus and Thessaloniki; prime Mediterranean real estate; the national lottery; Greek Telecom; the postal bank and the national railway system.

headline: Three States Short of a Secure Community
text: EARLIER this month, New York and Massachusetts joined Illinois in withdrawing from Secure Communities, the promising immigration enforcement program that the Obama administration hopes to extend nationwide by 2013. The effort, begun in 2008 and since expanded to nearly 1,800 jurisdictions in 43 states and territories, links federal, state and local arrest data with the immigration status and fingerprint records of the Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency; the agency then uses that information to decide whether to deport lawbreakers.

text: When the New York start-up Foursquare Labs made its debut in 2009, it quickly began popularizing the idea of “checking in,” or using a cellphone application to tell friends that you are at a particular restaurant, bar or park.

headline: Cuomo Secures Big Givebacks in Union Deal
text: ALBANY — The state’s largest public-employee union, acknowledging the pressures on government workers around the nation, agreed on Wednesday to major wage and benefits concessions in a pact to avoid sweeping layoffs.

headline: As Politics of War Shift, Risks for Obama Ease
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama expanded the Afghanistan war a year after taking office, Republicans fiercely criticized his deadline to bring troops home. But his decision on Wednesday to accelerate their withdrawal came with few reprisals, a sign of a remarkable shift in the politics of war.

headline: Finding the Score Within
text: A few years ago, when I was composing a concerto for myself as vocalist, I rediscovered some tapes I had made when I was 6 years old. Back then one of my favorite things was a portable Aiwa cassette recorder and I used it to make non-linear musique concrète — that is a fancy way of saying I recorded weird sounds around the house, rubbing my toy cars against the microphone, alternately growling and counting off numbers in Japanese like some spastic MC.

headline: Recluse Left Bulk of Wealth for Art Charity and to Her Nurse
text: For the past several decades, Huguette Clark, a wealthy copper heiress, had largely been a mystery to the public. She cloistered herself in hospitals in New York, and saw only a small number of visitors. She had no children and no close relatives.

headline: Kristof on Malnutrition, and Its Cure
text: Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof reports from Niger on the need for proper breastfeeding in impoverished countries.

headline: For SUNY and CUNY, Top Lawmakers Support Plan to Raise Tuition $300 a Year
text: For decades, leaders of the City University of New York and the State University of New York have chafed under the whims of state lawmakers who approved double-digit tuition increases in some years and none in others, leaving administrators struggling to make ends meet with little ability to plan ahead.

headline: Britain: New Smoking Ban Is Pressed
text: On a vote of 78 to 66, the British House of Commons agreed Wednesday to consider outlawing smoking in private vehicles carrying children in an effort to reduce exposure to secondhand smoke. The vote ordered the government to draft a ban.

headline: A Life in Libraries, Thanks to Gutenberg
text: Before he became the first name of a bank, J. P. Morgan was a Wall Street mogul who, a century ago, bequeathed his collection of 14,000 or so rare books to what his son would transform into the Morgan Library and Museum on Madison Avenue. Since then, the collection has grown to about 80,000 printed books, supervised since 1999 by John Bidwell, 63, the Astor Curator of Printed Books and Bindings. He majored in history at Columbia University, and received his master’s at Columbia’s School of Library Service and his doctorate in English from Oxford. Dr. Bidwell commutes from Princeton, N.J., where he lives with his wife, Andrea Immel, a curator at Princeton University Library.

headline: The Way Out?
text: Americans are impatient — and increasingly despairing — about the war in Afghanistan. After 10 years of fighting, more than 1,500 American lives lost and $450 billion spent, they need to know there is a clear way out.

headline: South Africa Embraces Mrs. Obama With Fervor
text: SOWETO, South Africa — Graça Machel, the wife of South Africa’s first black president, Nelson Mandela, took the pulpit of the Regina Mundi church here on Wednesday to introduce Michelle Obama, the wife of America’s first black president.

headline: Guatemala: Clinton Pledges Aid to Fight Drug Cartels
text: The United States on Wednesday promised $300 million this year, 10 percent more than in 2010, to battle drugs and organized crime in Central America, one of the most violent regions in the world. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton made the announcement at a security meeting in Guatemala City at which a range of international donors pledged nearly $1 billion to the region.

headline: Thursday: Nutty Confection
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Watch your STEP on the way in here. We’re mopping up. Ian Livengood came through here and spilled some of his puzzle in the process. It’s not surprising; if you carry something full of OIL around long enough, some of it’s bound to spill. He says he’ll make it up to us, though, and he does just that at 70 Across.

headline: 2012 Republicans Respond to Obama Speech
text: Some of the leading Republican presidential candidates offered dramatically different reactions to President Obama‘s announcement of troop reductions in Afghanistan, a reflection of the schism in the Republican Party over the future of the war.

headline: That Worst Nightmare, This Time Even Worse
text: Prenuptial jitters and the paranormal, two staples of pop culture narratives, are coupled uneasily in “Sex Lives of Our Parents,” a new comedy by Michael Mitnick at the McGinn Cazale Theater as part of the Second Stage Theater’s uptown series.

headline: The Haunting of Rick Perry
text: Should Gov. Rick Perry of Texas enter the 2012 presidential race, he would enjoy a strange and remarkable escort — the irrepressible ghost of Cameron Todd Willingham.

headline: Britain: New Smoking Ban Is Pressed
text: British lawmakers agreed on Wednesday to consider outlawing smoking in private vehicles carrying children, to reduce exposure to second-hand smoke. Members of the House of Commons voted 78 to 66 for a bill to be drafted that would “require the secretary of state” to introduce a ban.

headline: A Deeper Look at the Presidency, Climate Policy and Politics

headline: Deal Will Make It Harder to Use Renovation to Free Apartments From Rent Regulation
text: For years, the quickest way for landlords to unshackle their apartments from rent regulation has been to renovate units as soon as the tenants moved out, allowing them to significantly raise rents, to free-market rates.

headline: Budget Cutters v. the Law
text: The last three years have been the hardest for state budgets since the depression, and virtually every state has cut services. Most often, it is the poor, the young, and the elderly who are most hurt, as 34 states cut K-12 education, 31 health care, and 29 elderly and disabled services.

headline: Albany Mulls Altering Way State Permits Power Plants
text: Utility customers would be able to pay off the cost of making their homes more energy efficient through charges on their monthly electric bills and the process of getting permits for new power plants would be streamlined under a bill that state lawmakers in Albany were expected to pass on Wednesday night.

headline: A Reasonable Public Union Deal
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York and leaders of the state’s biggest public employee union announced a responsible agreement on Wednesday that would create significant budget savings while helping to reduce potential layoffs. The five-year deal with the Civil Service Employees Association freezes wages for three years and raises employee contributions to health benefits. Other unions in the state should quickly adopt similar packages.

text: The Supreme Court is not bound by the code of conduct for federal judges, but justices have said they follow it voluntarily. Justice Clarence Thomas, however, does not appear to believe that he needs to adhere to those rules.

headline: David Rayfiel, Screenwriter With Sydney Pollack, Dies at 87

And surely poor, neglected Robin is at this moment lolling around somewhere in the Bat Cave sketching lobby posters for “The Boy Wonder,” which will never make it to a theater near you. headline: Seeing Things | Studio Visit: Lisa Anne Auerbach
text: The artist Lisa Anne Auerbach likes to make statements, which are most often knitted. She is best known for her sweater-and-skirt works that feature clever, assertive slogans offering commentary and critique on issues that are important to her, whether political or personal. After receiving an M.F.A. in photography from the Art Center College of Design in Pasadena, Calif., she no longer had access to the school’s darkroom and taught herself to knit instead. “Knitting was a way I could continue to make art,” she says. “It’s portable and I can do it anywhere. Now that I’m teaching photography at Pomona College, I knit on the train during my commute, and it’s a great way to pass the time in faculty meetings.” Auerbach, who lives and works in a space in downtown Los Angeles (which she shares with several other artists), still knits the old-fashioned way, with needles, but her studio also houses two computer-controlled knitting machines.

headline: Following Up, Part III.  Down the Rabbit Hole:  Qaddafi’s Cluster Munitions and the Age of Internet Claims
text: This month At War has revisited in detail the attacks this spring by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces on Misurata, Libya with cluster munitions. The blog has retraced the steps that led to the identification of the Spanish-made MAT-120 munitions, and documented the sale and transfer of these munitions from Spain to Libya from 2006 through early 2008, addressing, in the process, the Qaddafi government’s claims of not possessing any of these rounds.

headline: Long Elusive, Mob Legend Ended Up a Recluse

headline: Our Favorite Reader Mail, Ever
text: We get letters of all kinds addressed to the sixth floor: complaints, fan mail, unsolicited manuscripts and story ideas. But rare indeed is the retro-looking postcard featuring drug paraphernalia. This postcard was sent to us by the artist A. Bitterman, who kindly permitted us to scan and post it here. It refers to a story we ran in our Voyages issue on a substance-fueled tour through Disney World. Enclosed with the postcard, A. Bitterman also sent us a packet of information about his installation, Point of Interest, in Kansas City, Mo. If you are ever there on a voyage of your own, check it out.

The N.H.L.’s starts Friday and rolls into Saturday for those who really love obscure young hockey players unearthed from somewhere ridiculously close to the North Pole.

headline: Loopt Flips Daily Deal Model Upside Down With U-Deal

They tend to flood their subscribers’ inboxes with dozens of discounted services from a wide range of places — from tequila tastings at a Mexican restaurant to private instruction at a yoga studio to upscale lawn care services — regardless of whether or not users are interested.

headline: Theater Talkback: Storytelling, More or Less
text: Engrossing storytelling is certainly among the pleasures the theater can provide. But how much story is too much story onstage, where time constraints make it harder to maintain a balance between narrative, character development and the exploration of theme? The question arose for me last week when I headed to San Francisco to review the new stage adaptation of Armistead Maupin’s “Tales of the City” at the American Conservatory Theater.

headline: Readers’ Summer Cocktails With 3 or Fewer Ingredients
text: This week in The Times, bartenders suggested seasonal drinks with just three main ingredients — loads of refreshment for minimal effort. Seltzer, simple syrup and basic garnishes didn’t count. (Eight of those recipes, with photos, are here; more recipes, along with articles that are useful in the pursuit of summer refreshment, are collected here.) On Tuesday evening, we put out the call for readers to share their favorite summer cocktail recipes with three ingredients or fewer on Twitter, using the (admittedly ungrammatical) hashtag #3orless. Here’s a sampling of some that the editors found appealing, cocktails as easy to assemble as they are to drink. Tweet yours, or post it in the comments section below.

headline: Is Fukushima a Roadblock, or Just a Speed Bump?

Three experts from Platts, the energy newsletter publishing company, suggested on Thursday that it might be minimal. The three spoke in a webinar sponsored by Westinghouse, the reactor manufacturer.

headline: Harvard-Educated Technocrat Chosen as Somalia Premier

headline: Now Free, a Chinese Dissident Muzzles Himself
text: BEIJING — After 80 days held without charge, China’s most voluble government critic, the artist Ai Weiwei, emerged from detention late on Wednesday night, thanked reporters for their concern and then did something almost unimaginable — he refused to say anything more.

headline: What? You Store Your Clothes in Plastic?
text: Dry cleaning bags are not your friends. They may appear to be helpful, caring sheaths of plastic, but in the end, they do not act like friends would. In fact, they will yellow your designer clothing and linen tablecloths and, eventually, trap moisture, which leads to mold. Would a friend lead to mold? And those garment bags — the really thick ones from nice stores? They are just as bad, perhaps worse for appearing to be extra protective. Barbara Harman knows this, and it is part of the reason she founded the Butler’s Closet, a new Web-based business that specializes in covers for clothing, furniture, linens and other precious things. The covers, made from fabric that is free of chemicals, bleaches, sizing and dyes, meet the same textile conservation standards used by museum curators. They retail from $16 to $135.

headline: A Journalism Teacher’s Quest for Accuracy in Southern Niger
text: I teach my journalism students to ask good questions. Stay away from ones that elicit yes or no answers. Go for the follow-up. Ask for clarification. Listen. Here in southern Niger, I’m learning that asking good questions is no guarantee of getting accurate information, and that not even patience and skepticism can get to the truth sometimes.

headline: Two 20-Somethings Compare Their Days
text: Saumya Dave, a student, and Noreen Connolly, a teacher, are the 2011 “Win A Trip” winners and are currently traveling with Nick through parts of North and West Africa. Saumya’s third post is from Niger.

headline: Debating Whether Businesses Will Continue to Offer Health Insurance
text: Two weeks ago, the international consulting firm McKinsey & Company threw itself into the rancorous partisan debate over the 2010 health care overhaul by publishing research that appeared to predict that many employers would dump their health insurance plans when the new law fully took effect in 2014. The new law offers subsidies to help low-income people purchase health insurance from state-run exchanges, and it also penalizes companies with more than 50 employees when they fail to offer those employees affordable coverage. As McKinsey notes, paying the penalty will cost less than providing the insurance, so companies could profit by socializing that cost.

headline: The Lowdown | Jimmy ‘Cobra’ Carbonetti
text: Jimmy “Cobra” Carbonetti is something of a downtown urban legend. A scruffy, smart-mouthed kid with a sharp wit — and memorable mutton chops — Cobra is yet another one of those natives seemingly too young to be as accomplished as he is. He is the proprietor of Cobra Guitars, a custom guitar shop in the East Village, and he strums his own creations in the acclaimed rock band Caveman. Rumor has it that the entire music industry is chasing after Caveman, waving record contracts, but the gaggle of mischievous man-boys, led by a singer with an I.Q. purported to be off the charts, refuses to sign anything. Obscenely talented, and airtight in performance delivery, Caveman is finally getting over its commitment phobia, releasing its first album, “CoCo Beware,” this fall. Should you cross paths with Cobra Carbonetti, in his uniform of shirt sleeves, vests and cowboy boots, beware of his back-snapping bear hug.

headline: 36 Hours in St.-Tropez
text: FRANCE’S most famous summer playground can be captured in one word: indulgence. Once the June sun starts to heat its bougainvillea-draped lanes and Mediterranean beaches, mega-yachts pack into the harbor, Maseratis and Bentleys prowl the cobbled streets, gazillionaires arrive by helicopter at music-pounding beach clubs, and Middle East royals and Asian industrialists shell out tens of thousands of dollars on Champagne in celebrity-packed nightclubs. Recent years have been fertile for new indulgences — not all of them reserved for the seven-figure set — thanks to new hotels, party spots and restaurants. Whatever your income bracket, there’s a place to play in St.-Tropez.

Today, Lisicki wept again, but this time she was overcome with the emotion of upsetting Li Na in a stirring match under the translucent roof at Center Court.

headline: Don’t Forget Resort Jewels | Lizzie Fortunato
text: “I am a magpie collecting things everywhere I go,” says Lizzie Fortunato, the designer behind her namesake Lizzie Fortunato Jewels line. Her finds have included antique whalebone poker chips in Montevideo, Uruguay, textiles from a Guatemalan village and vintage arrows at a flea market in rural Texas. This inspiration from travel is delightfully apparent in her resort collection, “Paradise Is an Island.” The assortment is a tropical concoction of polychromatic glass beads, winsome brass arrowheads and carnelian tusks, all strung together on gold chains and rope — the perfect colorful addition to an urbanite’s summer wardrobe. Despite each piece having names of exotic vacation hot spots, like “Easter Island Necklace,” the root of the label could not be more down-to-earth. For Fortunato, jewelry has always been a natural outlet. “By the time I was in college, I was fashioning statement necklaces out of industrial bolts and chains, glass beads that a friend toted back from South Africa and family heirloom pieces — literally anything I could get my hands on,” she explains. The results are a fusion of high and low, with thoughtful handiwork and smart combinations of pearls, colorful rope and shapely gold.

headline: Handicapping the Republican Field: Part I, the Top Tier
text: It is too soon to apply a purely objective approach to forecasting the outcome of the Republican primaries. But I do not think that it is too soon to start getting specific about the chances that we might assign to each candidate. Most of the crucial candidates have kicked off their campaigns. Debates are being held, the Iowa Straw Poll is only about 50 days away, and one candidate has already begun running commercials in Iowa.

headline: Drifting Apart, Struggling Together
text: At one point in “A Better Life,” an emotionally resonant film about how we live now, the director Chris Weitz opens a scene with a pair of adorable, gap-toothed little girls belting into karaoke microphones, giving their charming all to a song with un-self-conscious gusto. He then cuts to three bald men, crammed tattooed arm to tattooed arm on a couch, who are beaming at the girls with barefaced and shared delight, lighted up by the grace of children behaving like children. It’s touching and startling to see these men show such tenderness at this innocent spectacle, especially because all three are gangbangers.

headline: One Ticked-Off Comic, Venting to the Faithful
text: A thin-skinned, hyperkinetic entertainer under stress: that would describe the brash red-headed star, now 48, of Rodman Flender’s tour documentary, “Conan O’Brien Can’t Stop.” As revealed in the film, this high-strung showoff who often behaves like a fourth grader on the verge of a tantrum is a classic example of talent fueled by anger.

headline: No Easy Road
text: Milos Karadaglic is a 28-year-old guitarist from Montenegro who studied at the Royal Academy of Music in London and is getting an enormous push from Deutsche Grammophon, which released his first CD, “Mediterráneo,” this week. The disc is likable but a bit odd. Its mostly Spanish program includes technique-testing barnstormers, like Albéniz’s “Asturias” and Tárrega’s “Recuerdos de la Alhambra,” alongside simple pieces (Tárrega’s “Lágrima” and “Adelita,” and the anonymous Romance that Narciso Yepes transformed into a theme for “Jeux Inderdits”) that guitar students typically master in their first year on the instrument.

headline: Christie Crows About Changes to Pension System
text: “It’s an extraordinary day for New Jersey,” Chris Christie boomed proudly when we talked Thursday afternoon. It’s a pretty extraordinary day for New Jersey’s Republican governor, too.

headline: Sales Are Smokin’ for Evanovich Book
text: Janet Evanovich sold an eye-popping 218,000 copies of her new novel, “Smokin’ Seventeen,” in the first day it went on sale this week, her publisher, Random House, said on Thursday. About 100,000 hardcovers, 100,000 e-books and 18,000 audio books were sold on Tuesday, the largest first-day sale for Random House this year. Commercial fiction is a strong seller in e-book format, particularly with well-known authors like Ms. Evanovich. She jumped to Bantam Books, part of Random House, last July after contract negotiations fell through with her former publisher, St. Martin’s Press.

headline: Reality Shows Lift NBC in Ratings
text: A second consecutive night of “The Voice” and “America’s Got Talent” made NBC No. 1 in the ratings on Wednesday night. While prime-time schedules on most of the networks were interrupted from 8 to 8:15 p.m. in the Eastern time zone for President Obama’s address on Afghanistan, Nielsen’s estimates show NBC’s two reality shows far ahead of their competitors. NBC’s elimination episode of “The Voice” attracted approximately 10 million viewers after the speech, while “America’s Got Talent” garnered close to 13 million during the 9 p.m. hour. CBS and Fox tied for second place, with Fox averaging 5.7 million viewers for “So You Think You Can Dance” opposite reruns on CBS. Sitcom repeats couldn’t lift ABC out of fourth place, nor could a 10 p.m. “Primetime Nightline” special on the Casey Anthony murder case (4.8 million).

headline: Living on a Tugboat, and Part of a Dwindling Breed
A Few Friendly Ghosts Help Out a Master of Tap
text: The first time I met Savion Glover was during a rehearsal for an event that Bill Cosby was hosting at Lincoln Center in 2000. The scene onstage was making him tense — meaning that Mr. Glover had no desire to perform a mugging number in the manner of a “Cosby Show” episode — so eventually, without a word, we left. (I interviewed him in his car as we headed downtown.) Mr. Glover’s struggle was obvious: how to present tap, the art form, in a serious way?

text: Americans who have wondered whether Illinois, California and other troubled states are slouching toward the fate of Greece may get their answer in the coming months.

headline: In Germany’s Capitals, Cold War Memories and Imperial Ghosts
text: BERLIN — Just 20 years ago, German lawmakers hunkered down for a passionate 10-hour debate to make a decision that seemed as momentous as it was a no-brainer: Should the capital of the newly reunified country remain where it was — in Bonn on the Rhine — or move back to its historic, eastern location on the Spree, amid the monuments and mixed memories of Berlin?

headline: The Call of the Wild, Heeded With Tenacity
text: The trailer for “Turtle: The Incredible Journey” promises more excitement than you might suspect could be packed into a story about loggerhead turtles, a plucky seafarer with high mileage. Since it played at the 2009 Toronto International Film Festival, where it was in the documentary lineup, the movie has picked up plenty of goodwill and awards. Last year its director of photography, Rory McGuinness, won a wildlife/nature award from the Australian Cinematographers Society. Given the quality of their work, the special-effects wizards who whipped up some visual wow for the movie, including computer-generated imagery, deserve a share of the applause too.

headline: Death of Broadway Stagehand at ‘How to Succeed in Business’ Is Being Investigated
text: New York City’s Office of Chief Medical Examiner said on Thursday that it was conducting an investigation into the death of a stagehand at the Broadway musical “How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying.”

headline: Why 1970 Deserves Its 15 Minutes of Fame
text: The Beatles broke up, the Weathermen accidentally torched a Greenwich Village brownstone, and pop music went really soft. (Except when it didn’t.) That’s the tale, in a nutshell, told by “Fire and Rain: The Beatles, Simon & Garfunkel, James Taylor, CSNY, and the Lost Story of 1970,” which proposes to wrap together a year in the life of several loosely connected artists.

headline: Final Cut Pro Gets Easier
text: Final Cut Pro X is easier for beginners, but there is a catch for those who are already used to the program.

headline: Spare Times: For Children, for June 24-30
text: ‘THE OHMIES’

headline: And Then There Were Eight (on the F.B.I.’s List of the Most Wanted Fugitives)
text: Two down.

headline: A Classicist Who Enjoys Wild Flights of Imagination
text: “The Two Mrs. Carrolls” is the title of a well-regarded 1947 film noir starring Humphrey Bogart and Barbara Stanwyck. But it might as well describe the dual aspects of the great jazz pianist Barbara Carroll, who began an engagement at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola on Tuesday evening.

headline: Clinton Warns House Democrats Against Defunding Libya Operations
text: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton met with scores of House Democrats on Thursday and urged them to vote against an impending measure to block funding for American operations in Libya.

headline: Glimpsing Africa Anew in Its Art
text: PURCHASE, N.Y. — To fit African art into Western art history, we had to contain it, tame it. One way was by sorting the art into so-called tribal styles, in much the way we split up the continent into countries. Sure, the divisions were fake, but they gave us a feeling of control.

headline: Doomed in April, Dominant in June
text: It was only April, but the Boston Red Sox were in trouble. Despite glowing preseason predictions, they started the season with six consecutive losses, and by April 15 their record was a dismal 2-10. Their vaunted lineup was hitting .224, and the pitching staff was allowing 6.6 runs a game.

headline: A Side Order of Romance, Please
text: EAGER to leave town for the Fourth of July weekend, I was determined to finish a project at work that involved entering reams of data into a spreadsheet. But late in the day I pushed a wrong key, and everything vanished. I spent the next anguish-filled hour watching a technical support person try to retrieve the file. At last he did, and I hurried to my sister’s.

headline: Spare Times for June 24-30
text: Museums and Sites

headline: Providence Is Said to Be Near a Deal for Blackboard
text: The buyout firm Providence Equity Partners is near a deal to buy Blackboard, a provider of educational software, and a deal could be struck as soon as next week, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Thursday afternoon.

headline: The Fate of Prospect Park’s Five Arches
text: HOT enough for you? Head for Prospect Park in Brooklyn. Not the rich, intoxicating greenery of its 585 acres, but the shady coolness of any of Olmsted & Vaux’s five unique arches designed not as passageways, but as rooms. Taken together they show the sensitive, humanistic possibilities of the city — which its citizens have betrayed.

headline: Cooper-Hewitt’s Exhibition Galleries to Close for Two-Year Renovation
text: The exhibition galleries at the Smithsonian’s Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum will close on July 4 for a two-year renovation and expansion. The project, which starts this fall, is part of a $64 million capital campaign that includes a 60 percent increase in exhibition space, improvements to the National Design Library and an increased endowment. During the renovation of the Carnegie Mansion, scheduled to be completed in 2013, Cooper-Hewitt’s exhibitions, events and education programs will be staged at various off-site locations. The show “Design with the Other 90%: Cities,” for example, opens Oct. 15 at the United Nations and runs through Jan. 9, 2012. Admission to the museum will be free from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. on July 4 to mark the closing of the final exhibition, “Set in Style: The Jewelry of Van Cleef & Arpels.” The museum’s terrace, garden and shop will remain open this summer without an admission fee.

headline: Like Living, Only More So
text: “Am I overexisting or am I over existing? That's my inside joke.” These words — evoking a doubt-free Hamlet unfazed about whether or not to be — bounce forth from the tumult of video, furniture, music, extreme makeup and insistent jabberwocky that form “Any Ever,” Ryan Trecartin’s game-changing exhibition at MoMA PS1 in Long Island City, Queens.

headline: Where Lone Stars Don’t Feel So Alone
text: “TEXANS make the best New Yorkers,” Robert Leleux says loudly. “It’s because we’re bred for size. New Yorkers appreciate that — our extravagance. We wouldn’t play so well in Indiana.”

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for June 24-30
text: Art

headline: Plaza’s Developer Tackles TriBeCa Project
text: THE El Ad Group, which was behind one of the real estate boom’s splashiest but also embattled projects, the conversion of the Plaza Hotel, has unveiled its first new condominium in New York since sales at the Plaza started in 2006. The condo, called 250 West Street, will have 111 units in a renovated 11-story warehouse on a lot that stretches a full block from West to Washington Street in TriBeCa.

headline: You’re a Fascist? Let’s Hop in Bed!
text: How many years has it been since you encountered someone waving a placard or wearing a T-shirt with the slogan, “Make love, not war”? Resurrected in the French satirical farce “The Names of Love,” that hippie free-loving attitude is personified by Baya Benmahmoud (Sara Forestier), a charming, insouciant whack job in her 20s who boasts that she always sleeps with a man on their first date.

headline: Dance Listings for June 24-30
text: Dance

text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#526", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

headline: Romney to Get Some Welcome Help
text: Mitt Romney is about to get some outsized help from an outside group that is being started by former political aides and will be dedicated to helping his candidacy with unlimited donations.

headline: The Cream of This Year’s Crop
text: Here is a look at some of the players expected to be selected early in the N.H.L. entry draft, which will be held Friday and Saturday in St. Paul:

headline: Start of Countdown on Wright’s Return Is Part of a Good Day for the Mets
text: General Manager Sandy Alderson strode into a conference room at Citi Field after the Mets’ 4-1 victory over the Oakland Athletics on Thursday. He took a seat and delivered not just one good piece of injury-related news, but two — practically a gusher for a team that had been crumbling, limb by limb.

headline: Room for 1.) a Dog, and 2.) Wedding Gifts
text: NEARLY four years ago, James Marotta bought what he intended to be a bachelor pad. An alcove studio in a Midtown East co-op building, it cost him $372,000, but he never had a chance to be a bachelor there.

headline: Romney to Hold Fund-Raiser in London
text: Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, will travel to London next month for a high-dollar fund-raiser as he seeks to tap the pocketbooks of wealthy Americans living overseas.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings for June 24-30
text: Classical

headline: When the Teacher Gets High Marks in the Raunchy and the Profane
text: In “Bad Teacher,” a breezily crude comedy about unladylike pleasures like guzzling booze, swearing at children and being mean because, well, you can be, Cameron Diaz taps into her inner thug. It’s a beautiful thing. A performer with a gift for light comedy and a comically ductile face that can work in fascinating counterpart to her rocking hot body (as her character would say), Ms. Diaz has found her down-and-dirty element in the kind of broad comedy that threatens to get ugly and more or less succeeds on that threat.

headline: Finding the Offbeat Off the Beaten Path
text: The urge to go where no one else will is a respectable one, as seen in a pair of series that begin Friday night on IFC, in which eager, guileless travelers — subcultural scavengers — take an interest in the sorts of people and places most would overlook. But what these explorers want from their adventures differs greatly: sometimes the spotlight isn’t its own reward.

headline: ‘Untold Story’
text: Chapter One

headline: An Impish Creature That Won’t Be Fenced In
text: The New York Philharmonic might want to keep some of the tall sunflowers that loom from the back of the stage at Avery Fisher Hall in its enchanting production of Janacek’s anthropomorphic opera, “The Cunning Little Vixen,” which opened on Wednesday night. The hall is rather drab, and the fairy-tale flowers would dress up the place. Also, on nights when Philharmonic concerts are less than inspired, a remnant of Doug Fitch’s lovely Janacek production would remind listeners of one of Alan Gilbert’s boldest artistic ideas.

headline: An Alternative Life for Princess Diana
text: Like many women of my generation, I count the 1981 wedding of Diana and Charles as one of my most vivid early memories. I was 5 when it occurred, and I rose at dawn to watch it on a black-and-white television with my family. I was so captivated by the grandeur — the billowing dress with its 25-foot train, the horse-drawn carriage, the kiss on the balcony of Buckingham Palace — that I asked my parents what steps I myself might take in order to marry a prince. It wouldn’t be possible, they informed me, because we weren’t Episcopalians. It seems, in retrospect, strangely evasive of my mother and father to imply that religion was all that stood between me and the British throne, but maybe I was lucky to have my dreams quashed so early. Apparently, the experience of watching that royal wedding at a formative age is now routinely blamed for turning countless little girls into adult Bridezillas.

headline: Revaluation Rattles Age-Restricted Community
text: WOODLAND PARK

headline: Jazz Listings for June 24-30
text: Jazz

headline: No Jeter? No Problem
text: No team in the American League has won more games than the Yankees since June 14, when a certain milestone-chasing shortstop landed on the disabled list. Is there a correlation between Derek Jeter’s injury and the Yankees’ surge? Good question, and a complicated one.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings for June 24-30
text: Pop

headline: 6 Candidates Bid for G.O.P. Iowa Straw Poll
text: The lineup for the Iowa Straw Poll appears to be set.

headline: Over Time, Traffic Cars Are Looking Like Police Cars
text: The cars driven by the Police Department’s army of civilian traffic enforcement agents have long stood out from the standard patrol cars driven by officers. The traffic agents’ cars were black with white lettering while the patrol cars are all white and affixed with royal-blue decals.

headline: Paris Men’s: Dude Surfers
text: With the exception of Karl Lagerfeld, who treats the Grand Palais like a Hollywood back lot, designers don’t have the will, or the budgets, for big entertainment anymore. The Paris men’s shows could always surprise with a great venue, or staging, or casting that conveyed the spirit of the designs. But Thursday’s shows put out so little energy that they made a case for seeing the clothes in the showroom. Or catching them later online.

headline: Movie Listings for June 24-30
text: Movies

headline: Q & A
text: When Shareholders Seek Amendments

headline: Was Huntsman ‘Self-Financing’ or ‘Priming the Pump’?
text: There will be several intriguing things to keep an eye on when Republican presidential candidates file their financial disclosure reports in July. Among them: How much of his own money did Jon M. Huntsman Jr. invest in jump-starting his campaign?

headline: A Clubhouse for Anglers, Banjo Included
text: Something is clearly going on behind that modest blue door near the East River waterfront in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Burlap sacks cover the windows, but music and laughter spill out. Strolling by, you might mistake it for a cozy house party.

headline: The Lock, Stock and Barrel Listing
text: BEFORE listing her house on Martha’s Vineyard three years ago, Candia Fisher brought in the Manhattan design team of Aman & Carson to redo the timeworn interior.

headline: Life Lessons in ‘Normal Heart’
text: IAN SMITH was born and raised in the 1980s in Bangor, Me., a world away from the young gay men of New York City of that era who were among the first to die of complications from AIDS. Mr. Smith, 29, is gay himself, and in Manhattan he has heard stories about some of those men from their friends and lovers who survived. But nothing prepared him for the shock he felt recently seeing “The Normal Heart,” the Broadway drama about the early years of AIDS, which won the Tony Award for best play revival this month.

headline: Time Out
text: Could McKinsey, the consulting firm that became synonymous with “restructuring,” finally have stumbled on a truth we all agree on? According to Mother Jones, as quoted in The Awl, McKinsey has come to the conclusion that: “Always-on, multitasking work environments are killing productivity, dampening creativity and making us unhappy.”

headline: Netflix Chief Joins Facebook’s Board
text: Reed Hastings is adding Facebook’s board to his lineup of directorships.

headline: A Fine Line: Style or Philosophy?
text: For the hot, tired and frazzled masses, the Guggenheim Museum offers an oasis of cool serenity this summer. “Marking Infinity,” a five-decade retrospective of the art of Lee Ufan, fills the museum rotunda and two side galleries with about 90 works in a Zen-Minimalist, be-here-now vein.

headline: His First Brush With the City of Light
text: If you were an Eastern European artist in early-20th-century Paris, you were part of a close, intensely competitive network. Montparnasse was full of ramshackle studio buildings like La Ruche, or the beehive, a honeycomblike structure where the Russian-Jewish painter Marc Chagall (1887-1985) struggled alongside Modigliani, Soutine and other expats. “In La Ruche, you died or came out famous,” Chagall is said to have remarked.

headline: Condo Plan in Garden City Dismays ‘Mews’ Residents
text: Garden City

headline: John J. Cuticelli Jr.
text: Mr. Cuticelli, 60, is the chief executive of Sheldon Good & Company, one of the country’s oldest real estate auction houses. The company was acquired almost two years go by Racebrook Capital, a private equity firm that he controls.

headline: D.I.Y. Darling of the Paint Store
text: THE North Richmond Hill section of Queens is dotted with handsome single-family houses, many of them Victorian grandes dames featuring fat columns and broad, welcoming porches. Sharlene Gumbs, a clinical embryologist who lives in a neighborhood apartment building, sometimes looks at them longingly. She would love to live in one someday.

headline: Obama Visits Army Base in Upstate N.Y.
text: FORT DRUM, N.Y. – President Obama learned the limits of his power as commander in chief on Thursday.

headline: A Couple United in Self-Absorption
text: Endlessly fascinated by the idea that some people are endlessly fascinated with themselves? David Guy Levy has made a movie perfectly suited to you. Other viewers, though, may find themselves measuring whether the irritation level here is higher than the entertainment level.

headline: The Post-Foreclosure Wait
text: MORTGAGE troubles won’t necessarily shut you out of the housing market forever.

headline: Drug Makers Win Two Supreme Court Decisions
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday handed drug companies two significant victories, one limiting suits from people injured by generic drugs and the other striking down a law that banned some commercial uses of prescription data.

headline: A Saturday in ‘Spain’
text: Can’t get to Spain on Saturday night? The New York Botanical Garden is featuring an evening viewing of its exhibition “Spanish Paradise: Gardens of the Alhambra,” with wine, tapas and music, from 6 to 8:30. It is part of the “Nights in the Gardens of Spain” series, which started last Saturday, above, and continues on two Thursdays in July. The Alhambra-themed events include an afternoon of American poets reading Lorca on July 16. New York Botanical Garden, Bronx River Parkway and Fordham Road, Exit 7W, Bedford Park, the Bronx; (718) 817-8700, nybg.org.

headline: ‘Paris Through the Window’
text: Images from the Philadelphia Museum of Art’s new exhibition of works by Marc Chagall.

headline: Of Spirituality and a Quest for Romance
text: The documentary “Raw Faith” features two things seldom seen on a movie screen these days: spirituality that doesn’t sound maniacal, and older adults who are exploring romance.

headline: A Tough Mama Tries to Find Her Inner Diva
text: IT seems serendipitous that while appearing in “Rabbit Hole” on Broadway in 2006, Tyne Daly attended a benefit organized by the mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne, at which Ms. Daly successfully bid on a trip to Italy. The package was “4 Cities, 10 Days, 11 Operas.”

headline: ‘Master Class’
text: Scenes from past productions of the Terrence McNally play.

headline: John Waters, the Artful Dodger
text: “I ALWAYS think of art as animate objects with their own little lives and personalities,” said John Waters, the filmmaker known for ignoring the boundaries of good taste and bad in movies like “Pink Flamingos” and “Hairspray.” “I’m curious about who can live with each other.”

headline: ‘Absentee Landlord’
text: A look at an exhibition curated by John Waters for the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis.

headline: Clothes Call
text: A look at the backstage work of two Broadway dressers.

headline: Reaction to President Obama's latest speech about Afghanistan and a discussion of his evolving position on gay marriage.
text: Reaction to President Obama's latest speech about Afghanistan and a discussion of his evolving position on gay marriage. Chief correspondent for The Caucus at NYTimes.com Michael Shear, Washington correspondents Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Binyamain Applelbaum, plus Deputy news editor for blog development Megan Liberman join Sam Roberts in New York.

headline: Bridging Loneliness in Mexico City
text: Making sadomasochism appear less erotic than stamp collecting, “Leap Year” is a slow flare of emotional agony. The prime sufferer is Laura (Mónica del Carmen), a freelance writer whom we first meet beneath the cold fluorescents of a supermarket in Mexico City. She is watching a man in the checkout line with a look of resigned yearning that will become very familiar.

headline: Hundreds of Geese to Be Killed in Coming Weeks, City Says
text: Between 700 and 800 Canada geese are expected to be rounded up from parks in and around New York City and killed in the next several weeks, the city Department of Environmental Protection said Thursday afternoon.

headline: Weekend Miser
text: While Weekend Miser is off to Los Angeles, and probably not behaving in a very miserly fashion, we are left to our own devices to find cheap entertainment. She left behind a sheaf of papers (O.K., a bunch of e-mails) that is a bit overwhelming, but June is Gay Pride Month, so it’s easy to find plenty of inexpensive things to do around the festivities.

headline: Jobless Claims and Home Sales Reflect Slowdown in Economy
text: More Americans than forecast filed applications for first-time jobless benefits last week and new-home sales fell in May, highlighting the Federal Reserve chairman Ben S. Bernanke’s concern that the slowdown in the economy might persist.

headline: Drafting Is an Art, Not a Science, but Some Teams Could Get Quick Help
text: It is like the other professional drafts, with teams choosing amateur players who break into wide smiles when their names are called, even if — rather than being from U.C.L.A. or Tennessee — they come from the Peterborough Petes, MODO Hockey Ornskoldsvik or the University of North Dakota.

headline: Ford’s High-Tech Control System Hurts Ranking for Quality
text: DETROIT — As sales of Ford Motor vehicles took off in the past year, executives pointed to high-tech options as a major selling point. But now the Detroit automaker is learning that advanced technology like touch screens and high-mileage engines can also cause headaches — and a consumer reaction.

headline: For Many in Britain, Being a Homeowner Is a Fading Dream
text: LONDON — For a large number of young adults in Britain, homeownership has become increasingly difficult to achieve, viewed as a distant goal attainable only later in life, if at all.

headline: Posing as a Poet for the Sake of a Child’s Education
text: A repellent comedy that’s less fun than a parasite infection, “The Best and the Brightest” plays like a television pilot written by sexually frustrated frat boys. Top-heavy with seasoned talent (including Neil Patrick Harris and Christopher McDonald) and bottom-loaded with bile, this skewering of wealthy Manhattanites puts more energy into demeaning women than into sustaining a narrative.

headline: After Protests, Senegal’s President Backs Off Election Change
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Stone-throwing youths took to the streets of this capital on Thursday to protest what they saw as a power grab in one of Africa’s democratic bastions, forcing the president to back down.

headline: F.T.C. Is Said Near a Move on Google
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Trade Commission is preparing to issue subpoenas to Google as part of a wide-ranging civil antitrust investigation into practices in Google’s search engine business, according to two people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Fighting Wildfires With Computers and Intuition
text: PHOENIX — As thousands of firefighters used hand tools and hoses to combat the wildfires torching vast stretches of the Southwest, Drew Smith stared into a computer screen at a command center near one of the fiercest blazes and tried to determine which way the flames would veer next.

headline: Players Show Solidarity With Lockout Looming
text: Eight days before N.B.A. owners could lock them out, 52 players gathered for a show of strength at a Manhattan hotel on Thursday, united in their determination to reach a deal that is not a drastic leap backward.

headline: People vs. Nature in This Look at City and Country
text: “General Orders No. 9” is a tone poem laid over 72 minutes’ worth of images, many of them lovely, and is, as its press material says, “unlike any film you have ever seen.” The concept seems bold on first look, but if you stop and break down the ideas that Robert Persons, the writer and director, seems to be presenting, they’re actually rather retro.

headline: Gritty Tape to Some, Contraband to NASA
text: Solved: the case of the missing moon dust.

headline: Playing It Close in Wireless, With an Eye for Satellite Deals
text: If Charles Ergen has a master plan for his deal-making, the 58-year-old founder and chairman of Dish Network and EchoStar isn’t sharing the strategy publicly.

headline: No Senate Decision Yet on Holding Gay Marriage Vote
text: ALBANY — State senators were poised to decide the fate of same-sex marriage late Thursday night or Friday morning as their legislative session wound down to its final hours.

headline: Republican Challenges Administration on Plans to Override Education Law
text: In a sharp rebuke to the Obama administration, the Republican chairman of the House education committee on Thursday challenged plans by the education secretary to override provisions of the federal No Child Left Behind Law, and he said he would use a House rewrite of it this year to rein in the secretary’s influence on America’s schools.

headline: Court Rules Against Former Lawmaker
text: The Department of Justice won a major victory in its case against former Representative Rick Renzi of Arizona, who had argued that criminal charges against him should be dismissed based on constitutional protections provided to lawmakers as they debate legislation pending before Congress. Mr. Renzi, a Republican, was indicted in early 2008 on charges that he illegally used his office to enrich himself through a complex land-swap scam. He argued that the indictment relied upon illegal government recordings of his telephone calls and ignored a federal “speech or debate clause” of the Constitution, which protects members of Congress from being questioned about their legislative actions. A federal appeals court in California said Thursday that the speech was not protected.

headline: Court Says Ex-Wife May Retain Money From Ponzi Scheme
text: The Ponzi schemes that came to light during the depths of the financial crisis have spawned various lawsuits seeking to claw back money from divorce agreements.

headline: A Player in Control of His Forehand, but Not Always of His Emotions
text: WIMBLEDON, England — After another one of his backhand strokes skidded into the net, Ryan Harrison screamed, “Move!”

headline: Private College Costs Rising 4.6 Percent
text: Tuition and fees at private nonprofit colleges and universities will increase by an average of 4.6 percent — about $1,228 — for the next academic year, according to the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities. The average tuition increase was 4.5 percent last year and 4.3 percent the previous year, down from average annual increases of 6 percent in the decade before the economic downturn. The colleges’ average financial aid will increase by 7 percent. Last year, institutional aid increased by 6.9 percent and the previous year, 9 percent. In 2010-11, the published tuition and fees at private colleges and universities averaged $27,293.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,619 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

headline: Biggest Women’s Serve Is Just Enough to Beat Li
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Centre Court is not in need of towels. It is in need of handkerchiefs.

headline: Soccer Sets Portland Abuzz (a Chain Saw Helps)
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — The scene at the Bitter End Pub one recent Saturday was a sports bar’s dream: With the Colorado Rapids about to face the hometown Timbers in a professional soccer game across the street at Jeld-Wen Field, hundreds of supporters of both teams were shoulder to shoulder, laughing and toasting their team’s success.

headline: Did My Brother Invent E-Mail With Tom Van Vleck? (Part Five)
text: This is part five of a five-part series. Parts 1 | 2 | 3 | 4

headline: A Son Lost to War, Still Making His Presence Felt
text: Bill Brennan of Park Slope, Brooklyn, did not see President Obama’s speech Wednesday night about bringing home troops from Afghanistan. Nor did he watch last month when the president announced the killing of Osama bin Laden. It’s not that Mr. Brennan does not approve or care.

headline: With No Decision on Same-Sex Marriage, Lawmakers Adjourn for Night
text: ALBANY — The New York State Legislature abruptly adjourned for the night late Thursday without voting on any of the highest-profile measures before it, including same-sex marriage.

headline: Arrest Puts Spotlight on Brazen Hacking Group LulzSec
text: LONDON — As suspects go, Ryan Cleary did not look dangerous: a pale 19-year-old who looked five years younger, wearing a white skateboarding T-shirt and track pants, standing nervously in a courtroom here on Thursday.

headline: Oracle’s Profit Rises, but Weak Hardware Sales Are Worrisome
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Oracle, long a shining star in the technology sector, posted disappointing results in its hardware segment on Thursday, leaving investors nervous about its ability to digest its acquisition of Sun Microsystems.

headline: City Rejects Unions’ Offer to Help Close Budget Gap
text: The leader of a group of municipal labor unions accused city officials on Thursday of shutting the door on negotiations over a financial rescue package that could avert thousands of teacher layoffs after the Bloomberg administration rejected an offer of $262 million to help close a budget gap.

headline: New York Tales: The A Line and the H & H Line
text: To the Editor:

headline: New Jersey Lawmakers Approve Benefits Rollback for Work Force
text: TRENTON — New Jersey lawmakers on Thursday approved a broad rollback of benefits for 750,000 government workers and retirees, the deepest cut in state and local costs in memory, in a major victory for Gov. Chris Christie and a once-unthinkable setback for the state’s powerful public employee unions.

headline: In Draft Considered Low Impact, Cavaliers Choose Duke’s Irving First
text: NEWARK — For one night, talk in the N.B.A. turned from the league’s labor woes to its future stars as Duke’s Kyrie Irving led the way as the first pick in what is regarded as a thin 2011 draft class.

headline: Helping the Lame Walk, Without a Miracle
text: They come in on crutches, on homemade wheeled dollies, crude peg legs, even carried on the backs of mothers or brothers.  Even with all their limbs they would have been impoverished, and losing a leg robbed them of the ability to carry out the subsistence labor the poor do all day to stay alive.   They are reduced to begging or burdening their families.

headline: Each Summer, for Some, Brings a Longing to Chase Tennis Balls
text: Laray Fowler has always been around tennis. A Westchester County native, she grew up playing the game and began working as a United States Open ballgirl when she was 13. She has been a mainstay in Flushing, Queens, ever since.

headline: Chile: Vatican Rejects Priest’s Appeal
text: The Vatican has turned down an appeal from the Rev. Fernando Karadima, who had been found guilty of sexually abusing minors and young men while he headed a parish in Santiago. The archbishop of Santiago, Ricardo Ezzati, announced the decision Wednesday, upholding the Vatican’s January ruling ordering the priest to retire “to a life of prayer and penitence.” Father Karadima is facing a criminal investigation in a civilian court in Chile on the same charges.

headline: Bromance With the Big Man
text: There weren’t a lot of blacks in my high school graduation class — two, to be exact — which meant that race was somewhat of an abstraction, happening elsewhere, mostly on a screen or from the grooves of a record.

headline: Ivory Coast: Hague Inquiry Is Sought
text: An international prosecutor said Thursday that he had sought approval of the International Criminal Court in The Hague to investigate reports of war crimes and crimes against humanity in the conflict after last November’s presidential elections in Ivory Coast. President Alassane Ouattara has asked the court to intercede, even though the country is not a signatory to the court. The prosecutor, Luis Moreno-Ocampo, said his office had reason to believe that during the postelection violence at least 3,000 people were killed, more than 70 disappeared and more than 100 were raped.

headline: Eric Swenson, Co-Founder of Skateboarding Magazine, Dies at 64
text: Eric Swenson, a founder of Thrasher, a magazine that re-energized the sport of skateboarding and helped propel it from a suburban teenage activity to an international form of recreation and a competitive sport, died on Monday in San Francisco. He was 64.

headline: Allowing Greece to Fail Like G.M., Not Lehman
text: Investors fixated on the possibility that a Greek default would deliver a shock akin to the Lehman Brothers collapse in 2008 might want to consider another analogy. A restructuring of Greece’s obligations could more closely resemble the orderly wind-down of General Motors. The carmaker’s bankruptcy filing didn’t cause the market or economic Armageddon that followed Lehman’s demise.

headline: Marriage Is a Mixed Blessing
text: WILL the New York State Legislature ultimately put itself on the right side of history by allowing same-sex couples to marry? Many of us in the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender community, amazed at how quickly public opinion has evolved on this issue, are eager for this historic civil rights victory.

headline: In Cellphone Wars, Movie Chain Uses a Violator’s Words
text: BRANDS increasingly monitor the Internet for negative product reviews, and contact reviewers to remedy complaints, persuading some to revise reviews with higher ratings.

headline: Lulz Security Says It Hacked Into Arizona Data
text: Lulz Security, a group of hackers who have claimed responsibility for a number of recent online data attacks, said Thursday that it had successfully breached the Arizona Department of Public Safety’s internal servers, gaining access to hundreds of law enforcement documents, police profiles and e-mails.

headline: Friday: End of a Flick?
text: Administrivial Cryptic Announcement: Some of you may already know this, but if you like to do cryptic crossword puzzles other than the Variety cryptics that appear here in The New York Times, head on over to The Nation and enjoy the mind-benders set by Joshua Kosman, classical music critic for The San Francisco Chronicle, and Henry Picciotto, math teacher at The Urban School of San Francisco. They step into the formidable shoes of Frank W. Lewis, who set The Nation‘s cryptic for over six decades. You can do their debut puzzle here. A warm welcome to Mr. Kosman and Mr. Picciotto from Wordplay!

headline: Seized Phone Offers Clues to Bin Laden’s Pakistani Links
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The cellphone of Osama bin Laden’s trusted courier, which was recovered in the raid that killed both men in Pakistan last month, contained contacts to a militant group that is a longtime asset of Pakistan’s intelligence agency, senior American officials who have been briefed on the findings say.

headline: The Saga of Sister Kiki
text: In 1900, Theodore Dreiser wrote “Sister Carrie,” about a young woman who left the farm and got mauled by the crushing forces of industrial America: the loneliness of urban life, the squalid conditions of the factory, the easy allure of the theater, the materialism of the new consumer culture.

headline: Behind the Closed Doors of Harvard, 91 Years Ago
text: If you were a serious, grade-grubbing Harvard student 91 years ago, you probably wouldn’t want to be living next to Perkins 28, the dorm room that is the setting for much of “Unnatural Acts: Harvard’s Secret Court of 1920.” First of all, the guys who hang out there are really noisy — I mean, screamers, who play the Victrola at full volume.

headline: They Dropped Their Flood Insurance, Then the ‘Mouse’ Roared
text: MINOT, N.D. — Moving from their hillside condominium to a just-built house near the meandering waters of the Souris River, the Rasmussens, like so many of their neighbors, never even contemplated buying federal flood insurance.

headline: Chávez’s Stay in Cuba Stirs a Debate at Home
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — The prolonged seclusion of President Hugo Chávez in Cuba after undergoing emergency surgery has stirred opponents here who were already chafing at Venezuela’s reliance on Cuban advisers for military and intelligence affairs.

headline: How AARP Can Get Its Groove Back
text: Claremont, Calif.

headline: Reservist Charged in ’10 Building Shootings
text: WASHINGTON — The Marine Corps reservist arrested in Arlington National Cemetery last week with suspicious materials in his backpack was charged Thursday with firing shots last year at five military buildings in the Washington area, including the Pentagon.

headline: Drug Marketing and Free Speech
text: Pharmaceutical companies, which spend billions of dollars a year promoting their products to doctors, have found that it is very useful to know what drugs a doctor has prescribed in the past. Many use data collected from prescriptions processed by pharmacies — a doctor’s name, the drugs and the dosage — to refine their marketing practices and increase sales.

headline: Their Temper Tantrum
text: Congressional Republicans, who played a major role in piling up the government’s unsustainable debt in the first place, have thrown a tantrum and walked out of the debt limit talks. This bit of grandstanding has brought the nation closer to the financial crisis that Republicans have been threatening for weeks. But, at least now, their real goals are in sharp focus.

headline: Politicians Who Fear the Public Light
text: As we wrote this editorial on Thursday evening, we were still waiting for the New York State Senate to do what it should have done long ago — end a basic inequality under the law by allowing same-sex couples the full right to marry. The solution is obvious: Pass a clean bill that allows all adult New Yorkers to marry whomever they choose to marry, without unneeded exemptions for religious-affiliated organizations.

text: House Republicans are gearing up to vote, likely Friday, on whether to authorize continued United States support for NATO-led military operations over Libya. There are two main proposals — and a clear choice to be made. We fear they are leaning in a wrongheaded and dangerous direction.

headline: Battle for Libya | June 23, 2011
text: Libyan rebel leaders met to discuss operations in Zintan while Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s supporters rallied in Tripoli.

headline: Ban Complete, Gatlin Keeps Sprinting Ahead
text: EUGENE, Ore. — To look at him Thursday at the starting line for the first heat of the 100-meter dash — eyes on the finish while his competitors looked down — it would be hard to tell that Justin Gatlin, the former Olympic gold medalist, was recovering from strep throat and problems with his hamstring and quadriceps.

text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — By the time the 2011 draft arrived, his last draft, Donnie Walsh had already disassembled and reassembled the Knicks in spectacular fashion, installing true stars where false idols once stood. His final stroke was necessarily more modest.

text: Heather Hurlburt, left, of the National Security Network and Eli Lake of The Washington Times debate the future of intervening in failed states.

headline: Senate Offers Revised Rules for Suspects of Terrorism
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate Armed Services Committee has voted for a sweeping and bipartisan package redefining the rules for detaining terrorism suspects, including giving military judges the power to review the cases of prisoners in Afghanistan and mandating military detention for important Qaeda suspects — even if they are captured on United States soil.

headline: Used Gas Sippers, Keeping That New-Car Value
text: Cars are not supposed to be a good investment. But Spencer Hunter, an Oregon patent lawyer, recently turned a small profit selling his 13-month-old Toyota Prius.

headline: Obama Speech Is Interrupted by Gay Marriage Supporters
text: President Obama said he expected some heckling and he got it. More than 600 gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender people paid $1,250 each to attend a Democratic fund-raising dinner in Manhattan on Thursday and, to the vocal disappointment of some, they did not hear him endorse same-sex marriage generally or the bill that would legalize it in New York State.

headline: Officials Say Two Planned Armed Attack in Seattle
text: SEATTLE — Federal law enforcement officials have arrested two men who they say planned to attack a military processing center here using machine guns and grenades.

headline: General Says Mugabe Rival Is a Threat to Zimbabwe
text: JOHANNESBURG — As regional leaders push for free and fair elections in Zimbabwe, a high-ranking general in the country’s army has vowed that the security services will ensure that President Robert Mugabe, 87, remains in power, calling his chief political opponent a “national security threat” who “can only be dealt with by people in uniform.”

headline: Let’s Make a Deal, Amazon Tells Texas
text: In the middle of a fight with Texas tax collectors over book sales in the state, Amazon offered Thursday to invest $300 million in five or six warehouse and distribution centers in the state, employing 6,000 people, if lawmakers would let the company operate for four-and-a-half years without collecting sales taxes.

headline: Syria’s Ailing Economy Poses a Threat to Assad
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Hotels that catered to sandal-wearing backpackers in the storied Syrian city of Aleppo stand empty. Capital from the Persian Gulf that underpinned Syrian ambitions of modernization has begun to dry up. The Syrian pound has faltered, exports have fallen and the government has promised respite with money it will not have for long.
