text: When Mayor Edwin Lee of San Francisco unveiled his $6.8 billion budget earlier this month to a standing ovation from the city’s supervisors and other officials, it featured something that would make most politicians duck for cover: Tax increases.

headline: Casino Bill’s True Believer Enters the Final Stretch
text: It took 20 years for State Representative Lou Lang, one of Illinois’ most outspoken politicians, to convince his colleagues to support more gambling in Illinois.

headline: A Manager Manages, Though in Fifth Place
text: Those before-and-after photos used to illustrate the effects of stress on a man performing a complicated job would not reveal much about Mike Quade. The 54-year-old baseball “lifer” hasn’t had a hair on his head or anywhere else on his body since a childhood episode of alopecia areata, a condition that can result in total hair loss.

headline: Nets Have Busy Draft Night, but Effect May Be Minimal
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Nets seemed as if they would be in for a quiet draft night Thursday, but General Manager Billy King lived up to his billing as a dealer by trading up for one pick and purchasing another.

headline: News Quiz | June 24, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Supreme Court Ruling Accepts No Substitutes in Crime Lab Testimony
text: WASHINGTON — Two years ago, the Supreme Court ruled that crime laboratory reports may not be used against criminal defendants at trial unless the analysts responsible for creating them give testimony and subject themselves to cross-examination. But it left an important question open: whether the required testimony must come from the analyst who actually did the work or from a colleague or a supervisor.

text: Suzy Menkes, fashion editor of The International Herald Tribune, sits down with the designer Kim Jones to discuss his men’s wear collection for Louis Vuitton, based on his experiences in Africa.

text: For a spell late last year an unnerving sense of stability had settled in England’s Northeast, at least as far as their Premier League teams were concerned.

text: Test your knowledge of history with today’s question about American history.

headline: A Father’s Voice, Through Kodachrome
text: The small, rectangular aluminum cases stored in my mother’s basement had been beckoning me for years. I knew their contents: flood-damaged Kodachrome slides taken by my father, Gordon Heisler. But what I didn’t know, or wasn’t prepared to know until now, 10 years after his death, is that I would find a posthumous lesson in photography and family history.

headline: Do You Read E-Books?
text: J. K. Rowling, the author of the “Harry Potter” series, started a new interactive Web site that will also sell e-books. Do you read e-books? If so, which books have you read digitally, and on what devices? How have you found the e-reading experience?

headline: Workers Remove Device From Damaged Japanese Reactor
text: TOKYO — A 3.3-ton device that bedeviled the troubled Monju prototype fast-breeder reactor for nearly a year was removed on Friday morning, Japan’s Atomic Energy Agency said.

headline: Tip of the Week: Cleaning Out Your Windows PC
text: Windows 7 has a number of tools like Disk Cleanup to help keep your system running smoothly, and it also includes a System Maintenance troubleshooter. Although the program usually runs itself once a week, you can manually fire it up by going to the Start menu, clicking on Control Panel and typing the word “troubleshooter” into the Search box at the top of the window. Click Troubleshooting and in the System and Security area, click on “Run maintenance tasks.”

headline: Driving the Amp Electric Mercedes ML EV
text: Before the showers arrived on Thursday, New York City was the proverbial steam bath, with temperatures in the 70s, the fog ceiling settling at Midtown’s 20th floor and relative humidity at 100 percent. It was a day to crank the A/C in my 2009 Mercedes-Benz M-Class S.U.V. and hope the battery did not die.

headline: London Fair Offers Masterpieces of All Sorts
text: From June 30 to July 5, the annual fair Masterpiece London will bring together 150 top international dealers in the fine and decorative arts. On display at the South Grounds of the Royal Hospital Chelsea (44-20-7499-7470; www.masterpiecefair.com) will be everything from Bugattis and bronze sculptures to Picassos and pink diamonds.

headline: Cars as a Harbinger of an Upturn
text: For those who believe that the economic recovery has merely hit some bumps, and that growth will accelerate during the second half of the year, the automobile industry may offer the most persuasive evidence.

headline: Top 10 Safeties in N.F.L.
text: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely -– but not strictly -– by film study of all 32 teams from the 2010 season. Stats weren’t acknowledged, but players with poor numbers generally don’t make top 10 lists anyway. Vague enough for you? Criteria for top 10 lists tend to be. That’s why most of you will have no trouble finding some disagreement with what you’re about to read.

headline: EQT to Sell Securitas Direct for $3.4 Billion
text: EQT, the Swedish private equity firm, said late Thursday that it had agreed to sell the alarm system company Securitas Direct to Bain Capital and Hellman & Friedman for up to 21.9 billion Swedish kronor, or $3.4 billion.

headline: Want to Be a Ball Boy at the U.S. Open? Get in Line
text: “Just stay low,” I mumbled to myself. An old baseball coach once told me you look faster that way, and looking fast seemed like half the battle in the competition to be a ball boy at the United States Open.

headline: Why Women Have an Advantage in Technology
text: Audrey MacLean describes herself as an accidental technologist, an accidental entrepreneur, and an accidental investor. But at the age of eight, she made at least one plan: She would earn a college scholarship. Ms. MacLean, 59, executed that plan  and went on to help start Network Equipment Technologies, which went public in 1987. Later, she was a founder and chief executive of Adaptive. She has given seed financing to numerous successful start-ups including Pure Software (founded by Netflix’s Reed Hastings), AdForce and Selectica.

headline: On Debt Talks, Now It’s Obama and Boehner
text: The day after President Obama reached a deal on tax cuts with Republicans last December, reporters asked him about the battle that was looming over raising the nation’s debt ceiling.

headline: House Deals Obama Symbolic Blow With Libya Votes
text: 2:32 p.m. | Updated  The House of Representatives dealt a symbolic blow to President Obama on Friday by resoundingly failing to approve a bill authorizing the contentious military operations in Libya. But the House stopped short of a total desertion of a war-time president by also rejecting a measure to limit financing to support the military operations there.

headline: Honduras Creates a Shark Sanctuary
text: In a sign that the global movement to protect sharks is picking up steam, Honduras is declaring its waters to be a permanent sanctuary for the fish.

headline: Stalking the Stalkers
text: On the corner of State and Camp, I came upon a Google Street View car at a stop sign. The driver was a young, husky guy with mirrored shades, a faint goatee and a phone pressed to the side of his head. The car was painted in bright colors with the Google logo, and jutting upward from the roof was a small tower on which sat a bright red ball that contained a camera. It looked like a giant penis with an eye. I was on my Vespa, and I pulled over. The car crossed State Street and headed up Camp, toward Audubon Park. California plates. I took out my iPhone, turned on the camera and pursued.

headline: Life Preserver
text: A few months ago, I signed up to be a living kidney donor to help someone in need who was not related to me. Recently I was told that I was a match for a local 16-year-old. But if I were to enroll in the national kidney registry, my donation could facilitate a donor chain, potentially benefiting 5 or 10 patients. Should I help one person now or several people in the future? It’s hard to say no to a child, yet does the good of the many outweigh the good of the one in this case? BALA AMBATI, SALT LAKE CITY

headline: Order! Order in Judge Judy’s Court!
text: You have five grown children. I shudder to think what would have happened had any arrived home with a tattoo.  Twenty-five-odd years ago, my son Adam got off the bus from college, and he had an earring in his ear. At that time it just wasn’t a thing that young people did, at least in my family. I said you can come home for break, but the earring is going to stay in your pocket. He thought I was kidding, so I left him at the station.

headline: Mario Draghi to Head Europe’s Central Bank
text: BRUSSELS — European leaders appointed Mario Draghi on Friday as the next president of the European Central Bank after resolving a dispute between France and Italy over representation on the bank’s executive board.

headline: How to Succeed in Hollywood Despite Being Really Beautiful
text: After she graduated at the top of her class from Georgetown University and turned down a job at Goldman Sachs, Brit Marling moved to Los Angeles with her two best male friends to make movies. Because she is beautiful — she hazily evokes a “Manhattan”-era Meryl Streep crossed with a California surfer girl — she found she could easily land auditions for small roles in horror movies and action films. Those didn’t interest her. So she decided to create some roles for herself.

headline: Life Sentences in Rwanda Genocide Case
text: PARIS — A United Nations tribunal on Friday handed a former government minister and her son life imprisonment for their roles in Rwanda’s 1994 genocide, finding them guilty of genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity, including multiple rapes. The former minister, who had been in charge of family and women’s affairs, is the first woman to be convicted of genocide by an international tribunal.

headline: Say Goodnight, Grace (and Julia and Emma, too)
text: When the Social Security Administration released its annual database of baby names earlier this year, there were plenty of grabby little details. Isabella and Jacob remained the most popular names for the second straight year — Jacob has been the No. 1 boy’s name since 1999 — while Iker, Crew and Zuri each cracked the top 1,000 for the first time. But a closer look at the database reveals several deeper trends.

headline: The Ninny State
text: In the 1940s and ’50s, kids fell in love with a new technology, and adults freaked out. A psychiatric researcher warned that this latest pastime was “a distinct influencing factor in the case of every single delinquent or disturbed child” he had studied. In 1948, Time magazine said that it would “not only inspire evil but suggest a form for the evil to take.” As David Hajdu relates in his insightful history of the era, “The Ten-Cent Plague,” states and cities introduced more than a hundred laws to ban or limit its sale. Congress held televised hearings to denounce it.

headline: Former Prime Minister Goes on Trial in Ukraine
text: MOSCOW — Scuffles broke out and at least one member of Parliament was doused with water as Yulia V. Tymoshenko, Ukraine’s fiery former prime minister, went on trial in Kiev on Friday on charges of abuse of power.

headline: The 6.12.11 Issue
text: Hey, Mickey!

headline: The Reddest Village in China
text: On the 90th anniversary of the Communist Party of China, Times reporters visit Nanjiecun, China, perhaps the country's last Maoist collective.

headline: In China, a Place Where Maoism Still Reigns
text: Wang Hongbin, a 60-year-old man with deep creases lining his face, took a break from his duties as village chief this month to show me around Nanjiecun, in the wheat-heavy center of the country. It was unlike any place I’d seen in my years in China. No commercial advertisements cluttered the streets, just billboards screaming proletariat platitudes and memorializing Communist icons. “Long Live the Invincible Mao Zedong Thought,” read the inscription on an archway near the main government building. In the town’s three convenience stores, female clerks wore olive uniforms meant to evoke the People’s Liberation Army. And in the village square, surrounding the gigantic statue of Mao, stood four 30-foot portraits — one of Marx, one of Lenin, one of Engels and one of Stalin.

headline: Forecasts for Growth Drop, Some Sharply
text: A drumbeat of disappointing data about consumer behavior, factory sales and weak hiring in recent weeks has prompted economists to ratchet down their 2011 economic forecasts to as little as half what they expected at the beginning of the year.

headline: Brooklyn Museum Names New Chairman
text: The Brooklyn Museum announced Thursday that it had elected a new chairman, John S. Tamagni, an investment banker who has served on the board for more than 30 years. He will succeed Norman M. Feinberg, who has led the museum’s board since 2006.

headline: Rejecting Offer of Dialogue by Syrian President, Protesters Return to the Streets
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Thousands of Syrians turned out Friday for weekly protests in the country’s most restive towns and cities, denouncing as insincere an overture by President Bashar al-Assad for dialogue and testing the ability of the military and the government’s already-stretched security forces to contain the unrest.

headline: Luxury Brands Follow the Money to Asia
text: HONG KONG — Consumers with buying power and expensive tastes are fueling a boom in the luxury goods industry across Asia — shoppers like Chen Zhuhang and Lin Xing, who were out on a spending spree along Canton Road here this week.

headline: Sit Up Straight. Your Back Thanks You.
text: EVERYONE wants to avoid back trouble, but surprisingly few of us manage to escape it. Up to 80 percent of Americans experience back pain at some point in their lives, and each year 15 percent of all adults are treated for such problems as herniated discs, spinal stenosis or lumbar pain.

headline: The Last Ironman
text: Finishing an Ironman triathlon, which consists of a a 2.4-mile swim, a 112-mile bike ride and a marathon, is a remarkable feat for any athlete. But 30-year-old John Carson, who will retire from the sport after this weekend’s Ironman in Coeur d’Alene, Idaho, is no ordinary athlete.

headline: Eager for Celebrity Sightings? Try the Children’s Books Section
text: Blogger, chef, governor — celebrities can become anything! And while writing or collaborating on grown-up books is a perennially popular option (see Nicole Richie, Lauren Conrad, even Albert Brooks), writing children’s books involves a lot fewer words, and illustrators do at least half the work.

headline: A Blog Is Born | The Food Life
text: The fashion industry isn’t necessarily known for its kinship with food. Restaurants, sure, but food — homegrown, cooked or baked — not really. Lauren Levinger and Michael King are trying to change all that with their blog, The Food Life, which will premiere on June 29. With contributors ranging from artists and designers to restaurateurs (including the model and “It” girl Britt Maren and her boyfriend Derek Orell, the chef at the Fat Radish), the site will offer input from New York’s literal and figurative tastemakers. “We want to provide readers with food stories,” Levinger says. “Other blogs have recipes and restaurant reviews, but we wanted to go further.”

headline: Crisis in Sudan: Allegations of Ethnic Cleansing in the Nuba Mountains
text: Rebecca Hamilton is the author of “Fighting for Darfur.” Her Sudan reporting is supported by the Pulitzer Center.

headline: Practice, and a Nice Moment at the FIA Press Conference
text: VALENCIA, Spain – It was business as usual on the track in Valencia on Friday as the cars went out for the two practice sessions. Mark Webber was the fastest driver of the first session, and as I write these words as he is speeding around slightly behind his teammate at Red Bull, Sebastian Vettel, in the second practice session. The Ferrari drivers are third and fourth at the moment, and it’s a little like where we left off in Canada.

headline: Wouldn’t It Be Nice: Brian Wilson Biopic in the Works
text: In a project that will hopefully be completed in less time than it took for Brian Wilson to finish “Smile,” an independent production company is preparing a biographical film about Mr. Wilson, the troubled pop music genius and creative force behind the Beach Boys. River Road Entertainment, which has previously produced features like “The Tree of Life” and “Fair Game,” said that it is developing a film about Mr. Wilson, who with his brothers, Dennis and Carl, and Mike Love and Al Jardine formed the Beach Boys in 1961. That band’s groovy hits include “Surfin’ U.S.A.” and “Good Vibrations,” as well as the album-length mini-masterpiece “Pet Sounds.”

headline: Royal Ballet’s New Chief Must Find His Own Role
text: AT a recent New York City Ballet performance I encountered two senior figures of the Royal Ballet’s management, Jeanetta Laurence, its associate director, and Kevin O’Hare, its administrative director. Since I have known both slightly for years, I greeted them, welcoming them to “my” city.

headline: Beethoven and Haydn, Anew
text: BEETHOVEN: ‘DIABELLI’ VARIATIONS

headline: Eastern Europeans’ Stock Rises in N.B.A. Draft
text: The first round of the N.B.A. draft on Thursday night had an international flavor, with 10 of the players having been born outside the United States. Even Canada got into the mix, producing two first-rounders. But the story of the night was the resurgence of Eastern Europeans, with six players from that region going in the first round.

headline: A Second Chance for Galliano
text: At the women’s fall shows in March, John Galliano’s arrest and dismissal from Dior dominated the week. Now the spring men’s collections are under way, and though Mr. Galliano, looking thin and barely audible, was on trial Thursday, there was virtually no discussion in the front row about him or the racial-insult case.

headline: June 26 — July 2
text: Art

headline: Excerpt: 'Rhett & Link'
text: The IFC series follows commercial directors and their small-town clients.

headline: Car Sales as a Harbinger of an Upturn
text: From our colleagues at Economix:

headline: Larry Ellison Calls Assets Overpriced, Curbs Deal-Making
text: Tony Avelar/Bloomberg News Lawrence J. Ellison, Oracle’s chief executive, speaking last year in Santa Clara, Calif.

headline: California Widens Clean-Fuel Zone for Ships
text: Noting that cargo ships are traveling longer distances to avoid having to switch as quickly to a cleaner-burning fuel off the California coast, the state’s Air Resources Board has changed its fuel regulations.

headline: LeBlanc Backstops Canada at Women’s World Cup
text: It is not hyperbole to say that Karina LeBlanc has seen all the changes in women’s soccer, specifically in Canada’s team, right in front of her.

headline: Euro Zone | The Anti-Amalfi
text: Each summer, the treacherous coastal road in Italy linking picturesque Sorrento with postcardy Positano is jammed with cars and buses bringing tourists through the fragile hill towns of the Amalfi Coast. Long waits for a table and abominable prices on everything from dinky hotel rooms to mediocre pasta are customary. But just south of Amalfi is Cilento National Park, where a dollar goes further and the traffic and tourists are few and far between. The area encompasses dozens of coastal and mountain towns worth stopping for a stroll or an aperitivo. And throughout the summer you’ll find a smattering of cultural events: the London Festival Opera will perform Puccini’s “La Bohème,” “Tosca” and “Madame Butterfly” in Santa Maria di Castellabate, and the nearby temples of Paestum will play host to performances of Medea and the Decameron.

headline: Economic Doldrums Look Persistent, Bloomberg Says
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Friday said the national economy showed “no signs of really improving,” and he criticized federal officials for failing to come together to address it.

headline: The American Jihadis
text: Mention Fort Hood or Times Square, and there’s a fair chance Americans will think not of soldiers in Texas or neon in Manhattan but of terrorism. Since 2009, a flurry of homegrown plots has alarmed counterterrorism officials and prompted a reassessment of the widely accepted notion that American Muslims are especially resistant to the siren call of Al Qaeda.

headline: Jim Riggleman Quits on the Nationals
text: The other night in Milwaukee, I talked to Prince Fielder. He’s not signed for next season. This is really by choice; Fielder and the Brewers have not agreed on a contract extension. But, still, he’s unsigned. So what’s his approach?

headline: Frustration Rising in Albany With No Vote on Marriage
text: Updated, 1:06 p.m. | Frustrations flared in the Capitol on Friday as Democratic lawmakers and gay rights advocates suggested that the Republicans in the State Senate were deliberately delaying a vote on whether to legalize same-sex marriage in New York.

headline: Pictures to Warn the World About Smoking
text: This week, American health officials released nine graphic warning labels for cigarette packs. The move puts the United States in the company of nearly 40 other countries that have already adopted pictorial warnings on cigarettes.

headline: Super PACs Report Strong Early Fund-Raising Numbers
text: Two political action committees formed to raise and spend unlimited amounts independent of candidates reported raising more than $4.6 million since the beginning of the year, according to filings with the Federal Election Commission.

headline: Aiming to Spread Judaism One Book at a Time
text: LONGMEADOW, Mass. — In 2004, Harold Grinspoon, a local real estate mogul, heard a story on National Public Radio about the Imagination Library, founded by the singer Dolly Parton to give free books to children in her native rural Tennessee (and which now gives books around the country, in Canada and in England). Mr. Grinspoon, who has long given millions of dollars to Jewish summer camps and to schools and synagogues here in western Massachusetts, had an idea: do what Dolly does, with a Jewish twist.

headline: Why Nerds Succeed
text: For the modern adult, nothing signifies self-confidence, street credibility and authenticity like one simple confession: “I was such a nerd in high school.” (Emphasize “such” with a dramatic sigh. Then roll your eyes.) It’s pretty easy now to gaze upon the past with rose-colored — and thick-framed — glasses. It’s popular to have been unpopular. A new world order has unfolded, with nerds ascendant.

headline: The President’s Debt-Ceiling Strategy
text: There’s been a lot of discussion on liberal blogs (see Matt Yglesias, Jonathan Chait, Kevin Drum, Greg Sargent, and Chait again) about whether President Obama’s decision to go along with the Republican insistence on tying a deficit reduction package to the debt ceiling vote constitutes a blunder or a deliberate strategy — whether he’s a “bad negotiator” who’s let the Republicans hold him (and the American economy) hostage to their demands for spending cuts, or a “clever moderate” who’s using the debt ceiling to force his own base to live with painful deficit choices.

headline: ‘An Accidental, Experimental Masterpiece’
text: I was walking, recently, with my physical body through a physical bookstore when — somewhere between the giant display of e-readers, the Blu-ray wing, the Wi-Fi cafe and the looming tower of interactive language software — I stumbled across an actual, physical book that stopped me cold.

headline: Showcasing Lower Manhattan as 9/11 Anniversary Nears
text: In advance of the 10th anniversary of 9/11 and the opening of the 9/11 Memorial on Sept. 12, NYC & Company, the official marketing, tourism and partnership organization for New York City, is encouraging tourists to visit, dine, shop and stay in the downtown area.

headline: A Clean Balance Sheet for a Corporate Asset
text: AS Chrysler emerged from bankruptcy in 2009, the reorganized Fiat-controlled automaker reasonably concluded that it needed to improve the minivans that had been corporate mainstays for a quarter-century.

headline: The debut of the 'The Mechanic Muse' column; Andrew Delbarco on "Mightier Than the Sword" by David S. Reynolds; bestseller news
text: This week, Kathryn Schulz and Alex Star on the debut of the Book Review's new column, The Mechanic Muse; Andrew Delbanco discusses "Mightier Than the Sword: Uncle Tom's Cabin and the Battle for America" by David S. Reynolds; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: UBS Hires New Head of Hedge Fund Distribution
text: Fabrice Coffrini/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images A UBS branch in Bern, Switzerland.

headline: The Rules: Version Française
text: In “De la Séduction” (“On Seduction”), the French philosopher Jean Baudrillard defined his subject as “the mastery of the symbolic universe.” His point was that in contrast to political power, which involves “the mastery of the real universe,” seduction is a deft manipulation of rituals and codes, “a never ending game” that seducer and seduced play for its own sake, delighting in its elegant formulas and subtle challenges. Understood in this way, seduction is less a means to sexual conquest than an end in itself, an exquisitely refined form of social interaction. As the celebrity intellectual (and self-styled séducteur) Bernard-Henri Lévy has put it: “Civilization is seduction. What separates man from the animals is seduction.”

headline: A Digital Helping Hand for Scholarly Work
text: Digitally savvy academics have been struggling to reconcile new media with traditional scholarly publishing, which is painfully slow and generally locked behind paywalls or unavailable online. One answer has been offered by the Roy Rosenzweig Center for History and New Media at George Mason University, which on Wednesday unveiled PressForward, a new open access platform for online scholarship.

headline: It’s All About Holding Hands and Stitching Hems
text: When Sutton Foster won the Tony Award for best actress this month for her performance in “Anything Goes,” she began her acceptance speech by thanking the usual suspects: co-stars, teachers, director, boyfriend. It wasn’t until she thanked her dresser, though, that Ms. Foster’s composure broke, and the waterworks started.

headline: Go Daddy Expected to Be Sold to Buyout Firms
text: 6:26 p.m. | Updated

headline: Robert Lipsyte: Skeptic in the Press Box
text: A 19-year-old aspiring novelist and native New Yorker just out of Columbia University, Robert Lipsyte had never bought a copy of The New York Times until he decided to look in the classifieds for a summer job before graduate school. He found one at the paper itself, as a copy boy in the sports department in 1957, though he had little interest or experience in sports. In junior high, he was a self-­described nerd and “became a particular target of the bullies because I compulsively talked back and was too fat to run away afterward.”

headline: Handicapping the Republican Field: Part II, the Wild Cards
text: I mentioned last week that I’d thought we’d seen the emergence of a relatively distinct “top tier” of Republican candidates, consisting of Mitt Romney, Tim Pawlenty, Rick Perry and Michele Bachmann. Having taken a deeper look, I am more confident in that claim — I’d posit that there is a better than an 80 percent chance that the nominee will be one of those four people.

headline: A Primer on Pakistan
text: During the regime of Gen. Pervez Musharraf, it became the policy of the United States to help spread Sufi Islam in Pakistan. A Sufi council was formed and a few seminars and some musical concerts were held; a Sufi University is still being worked on. Meanwhile, Sufi shrines have been attacked all across Pakistan. Many Pakistanis now believe Sufis to be the allies of American intelligence operatives, a belief only strengthened by the recent Raymond Davis affair, in which a Central Intelligence Agency contractor was detained in the killing of two Pakistanis.

headline: Cengage in National Geographic Deal
text: Cengage Learning, a private-equity-backed education company, agreed on Friday to acquire National Geographic’s digital and print school publishing unit.

headline: The Story of the Mole
text: A very nice dermatologist called me about the small growth on my father’s ear, which he had biopsied. He left a phone message asking me to call him at home (over a holiday weekend! I liked this guy already). His message said that “more removal needs to be done.”

headline: Campaigning for Change in Mexico
text: Jorge G. Castañeda was long involved in efforts to end the 70-year dictatorial reign of the Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI) over Mexico. In 1988, he supported the presidential ambitions of Cuauhtémoc Cárdenas, who probably won the election that was officially called for the PRI candidate Carlos Salinas de Gortari. Cárdenas decided to contest local races across Mexico, and in 1989 Castañeda traveled to the town of Tepoztlán as an election observer. As he recounts in “Mañana Forever?” it became obvious that the PRI was tampering with the ballots in this election as well, and Castañeda urged the local cardenistas to put up a fight.

headline: Jets Will Hold Training Camp in New Jersey
text: Citing the uncertainty of the N.F.L. lockout, the Jets said they would hold their training camp this year in Florham Park, N.J., and not at SUNY Cortland, where it has been held the past two years.

headline: Up Front: Introducing The Mechanic Muse
text: The literary critic Hugh Kenner, who died in 2003, is best known for his intimate studies of Ezra Pound, T. S. Eliot, James Joyce and their contemporaries. Unlike many advocates of these authors, Kenner was also a technology enthusiast; he celebrated the Wright brothers’ flight as the first great act of American modernism and even attempted to translate a passage of Samuel Beckett into the Pascal programming language.

headline: What Is Distant Reading?
text: “Ars longa,” the ancient saying goes, “vita brevis.” Art is long, life short, and the problem is intensifying. As the literary ars lurches exponentially more longa — accommodating the printing press, “Gravity’s Rainbow,” Google Books — our collective TBR pile towers ever more vertiginously overhead. Which raises a question: What are we mortal beings supposed to do with all these books?

headline: Chinese History, Straight From the Source
text: “Beginning of the Great Revival” (called “The Founding of the Party” in China) — a companion piece to “The Founding of a Republic” from 2009 — is a lavish, sprawling mosaic, spanning Chinese history from 1911 to 1921 and concluding with the establishment of the Chinese Communist Party. (Filmed for the party’s 90th anniversary, “Revival” had a colossal release at home; the State Film Commission sought at least 30 million viewers.) Its principal focus is the May Fourth Movement, which sprang from failed government efforts to wrest Shandong Province from foreign control at the Paris Peace Conference of 1919, resulting in student riots in Beijing.

headline: Preparing to Be Torn
Overlooked Vancouver Video Shows ‘Kissing Couple’ Was Knocked Down by Riot Police
text: As journalism in the Internet age starts to seem more and more like a remix of the 1966 film “Blow-Up,” reporters have discovered video shot during a riot in Vancouver, British Columbia, last week that shows exactly what happened just before a news photographer snapped a beguiling image of a man kissing a woman in the middle of a street filled with riot police officers.

headline: The Death Camp Pharmacist
text: If memory serves, the great Italian poet and novelist Cesare Pavese once made the Archimedean claim that, given a place to stand and a pivot, he could write about anything. The mediocre German-Romanian poet and novelist Dieter Schlesak (may Pavese’s ghost forgive me for mentioning him in the same paragraph) makes the same point ex negativo. To wit, with nowhere to stand and no pivot, he can make nothing happen. “The Druggist of Auschwitz,” his so-called documentary novel, is neither document nor novel. It is that depressing thing, a very bad book on a very terrible subject.

headline: The Rise and Fall of Pseudonyms
text: When the venerable tradition of the pseudonym is discussed, it is often in reductive terms. The other day, someone said to me, “There are three reasons why authors use pen names, right?” and went on to cite them: Women writing as men. Writers with dirty secrets to hide. Highbrow writers slumming it in trashy genres. It’s true that each of those motives is historically common, but there are many others.

headline: Inside the List
text: HOT WAR: Tom Clancy is back at No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list with his latest thriller, written with Peter Telep. “Against All Enemies” — no relation to the counterterrorism expert Richard Clarke’s 2004 nonfiction best seller of the same name — recounts the exploits of a former Navy Seals member and C.I.A. paramilitary officer named Maxwell Moore, who survives an attack on an American ship off the coast of Pakistan only to find himself doing battle with the Taliban on the United States/Mexican border.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: TEN THOUSAND SAINTS,  by Eleanor Henderson (Ecco/HarperCollins, $26.99.) Henderson’s fierce, elegiac novel follows a group of friends, lovers, parents and children through the straight-edge music scene and the early days of the AIDS epidemic.

headline: Paperback Row
text: YOUR FACE TOMORROW: Volume Three — Poison, Shadow and Farewell,  by Javier Marías. Translated by Margaret Jull Costa (New Directions, $16.95.) In the final volume of Marías’s disquieting novel, his narrator — hired by MI6 in London as an “expert translator or interpreter of people” — peers into the territory of torture as he returns home to Madrid to both spy on and protect his own family.

headline: Testing the Conscience of a Village Under the Nazis
text: All novelists are godlike. Sovereign creators of worlds they populate with beings wrought from something less than dust and rib, they set events in motion and determine their consequences. The situation is less ideal than it sounds: omnipotence can be a dreary limitation. That’s why the best novelists are also childlike. Bent over impalpable dollhouses, moving their lips while they rearrange the furniture and figures, they give themselves over to such deep play that their stories read less like a premeditated imposition than obedience to the whispered suggestions of the universe.

headline: Paris Top 5 | Dries Van Noten
text: Always a Paris highlight, Dries Van Noten delivered a beautiful, carefully considered show. Cabana stripes turned on their side in airy nylon trenches, blousons, pants and wide-legged shorts worn over loose leggings gave an elegance to the athletic inspiration we’ve been seeing this show season. But it was the beautiful proportions of the elongated, trim double-breasted jacket with the loose shorts and leggings that took the prize.

headline: The Impact of ‘Uncle Tom’s Cabin’
text: No less an authority than Leo Tolstoy included “Uncle Tom’s Cabin” on his short list of “examples of the highest art flowing from love of God and man.” Fifty years later, James Baldwin called the same book a “very bad novel” full of “excessive and spurious emotion.” What goes on here? The question belongs in the present tense because it is by no means settled.

headline: A Frontier Schoolhouse Story
text: In the spring of 1916, two society girls from Auburn, N.Y. — Smith graduates who, having already done a European tour, were iffy about charity work but picky about husbands — found by chance the answer to the question of what to do with themselves. A lady who’d come for tea mentioned a friend who had a brother, a Princeton man, who was looking for two college-educated women to teach at a schoolhouse he’d built with his neighbors in the Elkhead Mountains of Colorado. Instantly, both knew they wanted to go. One of them, Dorothy Woodruff, was the grandmother of Dorothy Wickenden. And in “Nothing Daunted,” Wickenden has painstakingly recreated the story of how that earlier Dorothy and her friend Rosamond Underwood embarked on a brief but life-changing adventure, teaching the children of struggling homesteaders. Mining a trove of letters as well as oral histories and period documents, including an autobiography published by their employer, Farrington (Ferry) Carpenter, Wickenden lets their tale of personal transformation open out to reveal the larger changes in the rough-and-tumble society of the West — “a back story,” as she aptly puts it, “to America’s leap into the 20th century.”

headline: Deer Tick as Deervana
text: Melena Ryzik goes to Brooklyn Bowl to catch Deer Tick, an alt-countryesque indie rock band, perform as Deervana, a Nirvana tribute band.

headline: From Lisbon, Visiting the Storied City of Évora
text: MANY day trips and overnight stays — especially to outlying towns and cities in southern Europe where weekend hours for shops and tourist sites can seem almost whimsical — often do little more than whet one’s appetite to return for a proper visit. But, at less than two hours by car from Lisbon, an overnight visit to the storied Portuguese city of Évora and the surrounding area packs a lot into relatively little time.

headline: Exploring Évora
text: An overnight visit to a storied Portuguese city packs a lot into relatively little time.

headline: Hüsker Dü’s Propulsive Liberation
text: It was early 1983, probably, after the “Everything Falls Apart” EP presaged Hüsker Dü’s departure from hard-core punk and before the “Metal Circus” EP made it official. Just a gig at a crummy club near CBGB, and late — after 1. There weren’t a dozen onlookers, but Hüsker Dü’s two early records were knockouts, and that Minneapolis trio never came east, so there we were. From our booth in back the music sounded terrific: headlong and enormous, the guitar unfashionably full, expressive and unending, with two raving vocalists alternating leads on songs whose words were hard to understand and whose tunes weren’t. Another half-dozen curious fans drifted in. And then, halfway through, the guitarist passed into some other dimension. When he stepped yowling off the low stage, most of us gravitated closer, glancing around and shaking our heads.

headline: Steven Tyler’s Warp Speed Memoir
text: Calling Steven Tyler an incoherent loudmouth is like describing James Brown as a guy who moved around a lot. Tyler has devoted his improbably long musical career to testing the limits of incoherence, loudness and his mouth. From his 1970s glory days as the jive-talking lead singer of Aerosmith to his unlikely TV success as a judge on “American Idol,” he’s always delighted in babble for its own sake. In his words, he’s been “61 Highwayed and I did it my wayed; Little-Willie-Johned and been-here-and-goned; million-dollar riffed and Jimmy Cliffed; cotton-picked and Stevie Nick’d.” What he lacks in lucidity, which is just about every­thing, he makes up for with garrulous charm. As Laurence Sterne says of Yorick in “Tristram Shandy,” he has big sails but not an ounce of ballast.

headline: Curing the Pelvic Headache
text: The appeal of conversion stories often depends on descriptions of the darkness before enlightenment: we enjoy learning in detail about the presalvation misery, debauchery or sinfulness. The more detail, the better. The English novelist Tim Parks understands that principle. In his urbane, droll, weird yet far from charmless account of the pain and misery suffered by his body in general, and by his bladder, prostate, penis and related bits in particular, the conversion is from a cerebral, anxious, hunched-over and compulsively verbal kvetch (not his term, but the literal “squeeze” makes the Yiddish word seem appropriate) to something resembling the opposite.

headline: Taking Literary Revenge on Joseph Conrad
text: The best lines in “The Secret History of Costaguana” were written by Joseph Conrad. Harsh, maybe, but such is the treatment that its Colombian author, Juan Gabriel Vásquez (“The Informers”), invites — with crafty masochism — in this postmodern literary revenge story.

headline: The Trouble With Common Sense
text: The popularity of the Mona Lisa is an illusion. As Duncan J. Watts explains: “We claim to be saying that the Mona Lisa is the most famous painting in the world because it has attributes X, Y and Z. But really what we’re saying is that the Mona Lisa is famous because it’s more like the Mona Lisa than anything else.” In other words, we are trapped inside a hall of mirrors of our own devising. We think the Mona Lisa is famous because of its traits, but we think those traits are significant only because they belong to the Mona Lisa, which we know to be famous. Ditto Shakespeare? Yes. When an incredulous English professor asked him whether he believed “Shakespeare might just be a fluke of history,” Watts indicated that he meant exactly that.

headline: Love and Real Estate in South Asia
text: Anuradha Roy’s first novel opens with the image of a house, “a Roman-­looking affair with tapering pillars” that seems to float down a river in flood. First its veranda goes under and then its windows, until the rooms look drowned and the building itself appears to leave its moorings. The imagination of disaster is never far from these pages, and though this house will finally stay on its foundation, it does get swamped by a monsoon-swelled river, and with consequences that are bitter indeed. That waterfront property is only one of the three houses in which Roy’s narrative is played out — each of them bedraggled, each living on after its time, and none of them a proper home.

headline: ‘The Great Gatsby’: The Next Generation
text: When readers met Pamela Buchanan in the pages of “The Great Gatsby,” she was about 2 years old. As “Daisy Buchanan’s Daughter” opens, she is in her 80s, waiting for a birthday call from President George W. Bush, during which she intends to blow her brains out to protest the Iraq war. While waiting, she blogs. Through a suicide note that eventually becomes an autobiography almost perfectly contemporary with “the American Century,” we learn that Pam has been many things: rich mother’s regret, successful author, war correspondent, diplomat’s wife. She was on the beach at Normandy, saw Dachau liberated and knew the Kennedys.

headline: Cambodia After Year Zero
text: In the preface to “Cambodia’s Curse: The Modern History of a Troubled Land,” Joel Brink­ley recalls his first encounter with Cambodia. Brinkley was reporting for The Louisville Courier-Journal from a refugee camp near the Thai border in 1979, in the aftermath of Pol Pot’s reign. “As they tell of years of horror and misery,” Brinkley wrote, “their faces are expressionless and dull . . . as if they’re talking about a dull day of work. Their tales end with a nodding acknowledgment of the death of their nation and culture.” Brinkley, who later worked for The New York Times, finds little has changed in the 32 years since then. As the title suggests, his book is an unabashed plea to refocus international aid and diplomacy on a suffering people. It is also an attempt to hold some of those responsible for that suffering accountable — but not all.Cambodia lost a quarter of its population under the Khmer Rouge. For many, survival meant 14-hour days of backbreaking work, often on little more than a cupful of rice or a smattering of gruel. You could be killed on the least suspicion you sympathized with the Vietnamese. The effects of this period have proven hard to shake.

headline: Does Coaching Win Championships?
text: “What the heck? Why haven’t we been doing this more often in the past?”—Dom Starsia, men’s lacrosse coach, University of Virginia

headline: Ahead of U.N. Vote, Effort to Restart Mideast Talks
text: JERUSALEM — Intensive efforts are under way to stave off a Palestinian bid for United Nations membership in September, with diplomats trying to lure Israeli and Palestinian leaders back to negotiations on the basis of President Obama’s formula of a state based on the 1967 lines with mutually agreed land swaps.

headline: A Prep School Confronts the ’60s
text: In the opening chapter of Carolyn Cooke’s “Daughters of the Revolution,” two young men go kayaking off the coast south of Boston. It is 1963 and both men are graduates of the Goode School, a redoubt of WASP privilege. One of them, Archer, comes from money and the other, Heck, comes from moderate means and continues to struggle. Heck packs sandwiches for them both in hopes that Archer won’t suggest they eat at a restaurant; when the weather turns bad, he notices that Archer has helped himself to the only life jacket in the boat. Issues of entitlement become a matter of life and death.

headline: Inside the Churchill Clan
text: Like his mother, Jennie Jerome, and his cousin-by-marriage Consuelo Vanderbilt, Winston Churchill’s Aunt Lily Hammersley was an American heiress whose fortune, it was hoped, would assist in bailing out the Churchill clan’s ever shaky finances. Hurriedly wed and brought to England as the newest Duchess of Marlborough, Lily arrived at Blenheim, the family’s vast, dilapidated country seat. “The first thing that confronted her,” Mary S. Lovell writes in “The Churchills,” was a life-size nude of Lady Colin Campbell, her husband’s former mistress and divorce co-respondent, painted by Whistler, “which hung in the duke’s dressing room.” The canvas soon thereafter disappeared from art history. It is widely assumed that Lily had it burned.

headline: For a Few Developers, It’s Hammer Time
text: LOUIS FOUNDOS didn’t think he would have a problem selling out his new condominium project last fall. It was a renovated building in East Harlem with everything a first-time buyer might want, including granite countertops, dishwashers and washing machines in every unit. It was just a few blocks from the subway, and plenty of new development was under way in the neighborhood.

headline: Wozniacki Is Waiting for a Major Breakthrough
text: WIMBLEDON, England — The ball dropped from the sky Friday as Caroline Wozniacki was trying for the second time to convert a match point against Virginie Razzano. Was it the plague of Court 2 descending on another top women’s player put in its path?

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: A Bounty of Buffy
text: There’s only one new book on our lists this week and that honor goes to Volume 8 of “Buffy the Vampire Slayer,” which lands at No. 1 on our softcover list this week. The series, published by Dark Horse Comics, was presented as “Season Eight,” a look at the adventures of Buffy and her friends as if the television series had continued. The first issue of the series had orders of more than 110,000 copies. The series also made some news when Buffy had a brief affair with a fellow (female) slayer. “Season Eight” lasted 40 issues. The concluding storyline, issues No. 36 through 40, is collected in Volume 8. All of issue No. 36 is available on the Dark Horse site.

headline: The Italian Potboiler’s Master Chef
text: IN 1949 the cognoscenti of the film world were focused on Vittorio De Sica, Roberto Rossellini, Luchino Visconti and the other Italian directors who had been gathered together under the banner of neo-realism.

headline: Connecticut Budget Is Upended as State Workers Reject Deal
text: HARTFORD — Connecticut’s state workers, in voting results announced on Friday, rejected a deal meant to produce $1.6 billion in labor savings over two years, blowing a gaping hole in the state budget, raising the likelihood of thousands of layoffs and threatening chaos in a state that has largely avoided the rancorous labor issues seen elsewhere.

headline: Leasing a Car? It May Have Hidden Value
text: The common wisdom is that it’s more expensive to lease a car than to buy one. But the recent rise in used-car prices may provide a lucrative opportunity for those with leases to come out ahead of the game.

headline: The Great Unknowns
text: Well, that was fast. The N.B.A. draft decelerated from 60 to zero in what seemed like a few seconds. One minute it was all sweetness and light, hope and change, kids with shiny new jerseys. The next it was devoid of top-level talent, hindered by teams afraid of the future, the last step before labor Armageddon. And while all that might be true, it was also true before the draft started, so it was fascinating to watch the perception pivot on a dime without anything actually changing.

headline: School’s Out, Forever
text: JUST don’t cry. That has been Sister Nora McArt’s mantra. She has been unflappable in her 42 years at St. Martin of Tours Elementary School in the Bronx, braving the gang fights, racial unrest and crack wars that were waged outside the school and convent in the Crotona neighborhood. No matter the mayhem, she had to be calm for the children.

headline: Obama Seeks to Restart Budget Talks
text: President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. will meet separately on Monday with the Democratic and Republican Senate leaders in an opening bid to restart budget talks on addressing long-term debt reduction and clear the way for a necessary vote on raising the nation’s debt limit.

headline: Dwyane Wade in the Front Row

headline: Videophiles | Xeno & Oaklander’s ‘The Staircase’
text: Just when you thought winter was finally over, a cold front suddenly hits. The new video for “The Staircase,” by the synth pop group Xeno & Oaklander, which makes is United States premiere on The Moment today, epitomizes the cool aesthetic of the underground minimal electronics movement. The video has the quality of a Xerox, reproduced over and over, blown out and dark, and induces a sense of something lost. Sean McBride and Miss Liz Wendelbo, the duo behind Xeno & Oaklander, along with other members of the Wierd Records label, have been largely credited with the revival of minimal wave here in New York. Taryn Waldman of Boxmotion, who directed the “The Staircase,” and Patrick Stroub, its cinematographer, make references to Roman Polanski’s film “Repulsion,” as a slip of a woman, Xeno (Wendelbo), climbs the stairs of a claustrophobic 19th-century Brooklyn tenement building, seemingly unaware that the object of her affection and of her voyeurism, Oaklander (McBride), is right next to her. (Xeno’s stark, wintry eyes come courtesy of the master retoucher Pascal Dangin, known in fashion circles for his work for Annie Leibovitz, Patrick Demarchelier, Steven Meisel, Steven Klein, Craig McDean and others.) Alienation, disconnection, damage? Oh, city life!

headline: ‘Big C’ or Small Business, TV Promotions Get Creative

headline: Naturalist Perched Here
text: ONE can imagine how John James Audubon, the renowned naturalist and illustrator of “Birds of America,” might have reacted to the idea: his own name, being used to promote the very development that would transform the rambling woodlands of his beloved Washington Heights estate into a densely populated urban district. But that is precisely what happened, according to Matthew Spady, a longtime resident and magpie collector of historical facts about the area.

headline: Time for a Change
text: We were sitting at a communal table at the Sonoma Farmers Market when the couple next to us laid their baby on the table and changed his diaper. They also gave a loud play-by-play for delighted family members in the vicinity. A week before, a father across the aisle from me on an international flight changed his baby’s diaper on the food tray. I lost my temper on the plane, but said nothing at the farmers market. What should I have said?  — Ricky S., San Francisco

headline: The Hidden Route to Machu Picchu
text: AS we neared the end of a very long climb up a very steep ridge, my guide, John Leivers, shouted at me over his shoulder. “It’s said that the Spaniards never found Machu Picchu, but I disagree,” he said. I caught up to him — for what seemed like the 20th time that day — and he pointed his bamboo trekking pole at the strangely familiar-looking set of ruins ahead. “It’s this place they never found.”

headline: Bribery, but Nobody Was Charged
text: In late June 2004, a plant manager for one of Tyson Foods’ poultry processing plants in Mexico sent a memo to company headquarters in Springdale, Ark.: two women who “most definitely do not work for Tyson Foods in Mexico” each were paid 30,700 pesos, or about $2,700, a month and had been for years. Tyson is one of the world’s largest producers of poultry, pork and beef products, a ubiquitous presence in American supermarkets that has been trying to increase foreign sales. The memo set off an ethics scandal that reached into Tyson’s executive suite and raises questions about who, if anyone, is being held accountable for high-level corporate crime.

headline: Video: Deer Tick Channels the Band’s Inner Grunge to Play Nirvana
text: “Here we are now, entertain us.” It’s been more than two decades since a trio of musicians from the Pacific Northwest announced itself, demanded something from its audience and channeled their disaffection into blockbuster record sales, changing the course of rock history. To celebrate the 20th anniversary of Nirvana’s seminal album “Nevermind,” in September, Universal Music will release a deluxe five-disc edition of the album, with “unreleased recordings, rarities, b-sides, BBC radio appearances, alternative mixes, rare live recordings and an unreleased concert,” according to a press release the label sent out this week. (It goes on sale Sept. 20 in North America and a day earlier overseas.) The collection rides a wave of 1990s nostalgia, from  baby doll dresses and Doc Martens to riot grrrl.

headline: Catch That Reference? There’ll Be a Quiz
text: WHAT did you learn at the movies today? This is surely one of the least frequently asked questions in the world, especially in summertime, when hot weather and idle hours drive young scholars into the multiplexes. It is a frequently unexamined article of faith — among both entertainment-hungry ticket buyers and the scolds and scoffers who belittle their pleasures — that popular commercial movies are, or should be, intellectually undemanding, easily digestible, requiring no special knowledge and offering none in return.

headline: George Hill Moves On, Moves Home
text: The mystique that surrounds the San Antonio Spurs is very real. Of all N.B.A. teams, none has a better record of finding truly unknown players and harnessing their talent. Tony Parker and Manu Ginobili provide notable examples, but they are only the most exceptional in a long line of unearthed gems. Alongside the Spurs’ core has been a never-ending stream of competent role players. Stephen Jackson, Malik Rose, Robert Horry, Hedo Turkoglu, Rasho Nesterovic, Bruce Bowen, Matt Bonner, Roger Mason Jr. and Gary Neal – not to mention the string of ring-seeking veterans on the last legs of their career – were all plucked from obscurity and thrown into the mix of a championship-contending squad to great effect.

text: Alexandra Catherine Neshamkin French and Gabriel Hervé Mugar were married Saturday at the Swedenborg Chapel in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Kevin K. Baxter, a Swedenborgian minister and the chapel’s pastor, led the ceremony.

headline: Meghan Kober, Pip Decker
text: Meghan Elizabeth Kober and Pip Meneghin Decker were married Saturday at the Church of St. Vincent de Paul in Stirling, N.J. The Rev. Charles D. Sullivan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Valerie Kolko, Matthew Glassman
text: Valerie Beth Kolko and Matthew Scot Glassman are to be married Sunday. Rabbi Leah R. Berkowitz is to officiate at Bay 7, an event space, in Durham, N.C.

headline: Hannah Flack, Timothy Cassedy
text: Hannah Forman Flack, a daughter of Frances S. Forman and Robert F. Flack of Watertown, Mass., was married Saturday to Timothy Blum Cassedy, the son of Ellen D. Cassedy and Jeffrey D. Blum of Takoma Park, Md. The ceremony, at the Foundry, an events space in Long Island City, Queens, was led by Roosevelt Montás, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister in order to officiate.

headline: Sangeeta Reddy, John Elliott
text: Sangeeta Reddy, a daughter of Vijaya Reddy and Dr. Rama K. Reddy of Todt Hill, Staten Island, was married Saturday in Manhattan to John Joseph Elliott, a son of Barbara F. Elliott and Dr. J. Jeffrey Elliott of McLean, Va. The Rev. Joseph F. Lorenzo performed the ceremony at the Shrine Church of St. Anthony of Padua, where he is pastor. Later in the day, Pandit Venkatesan B. Moorthy led a Hindu ceremony at Three Sixty, an events space in Manhattan.

headline: Janna Johnson, Clayton O’Toole
text: Janna  Lorraine Johnson and Clayton  David O’Toole were married Saturday at St. Peter’s Episcopal Church in Kansas City, Mo. The Rev. Barry R. Howe, a retired bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of West Missouri, performed the ceremony.

headline: Kerry Galvin and Matthieu Bridier
text: Kerry Ann Galvin and Matthieu Murray Bridier were married Saturday at Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in Westhampton Beach, N.Y. The Rev. George F. Riley performed the ceremony.

headline: Samreen Hasan, Asif Rehman
text: Dr. Samreen Hasan and Asif Rehman were married Saturday evening at Lyndhurst Castle, an event space in Tarrytown, N.Y. Robert D. Coolidge, an imam and a chaplain at Brown University, led a Muslim ceremony.

headline: Katherine Lydecker, William MacPherson
text: Katherine Hudson Lydecker, a daughter of Toni H. Lydecker and Kent Lydecker of St. Petersburg, Fla., was married Saturday to William Robbins MacPherson, a son of Susan E. MacPherson and Russell B. MacPherson of North Marshfield, Mass. The Rev. David R. Harkness, a Presbyterian minister, officiated on Malden Island, a summer community in Five Islands, Me.

headline: Alexandra MacRae, Parker Conrad
text: Alexandra Julia Barclay MacRae, the daughter of Sigrid von Huene MacRae and Desmond A. MacRae of New York, was married Saturday to Parker Rouse Conrad, the son of Ellen Rouse Conrad and Winthrop B. Conrad Jr., also of New York. The Rev. Daniel D. Lennox, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Mooring, a bed and breakfast in Georgetown, Me.

headline: Catherine Burch, Gary Belkin
text: Catherine Carter Winslow Burch and Dr. Gary Stuart Belkin are to be married Sunday on Governors Island in New York. The Rev. Virginia Hill Worden, an interfaith minister, is to officiate with Cantor Tyrone Bauer.

headline: Hasina Outtz and Justin Reed
text: Hasina Hamilton Outtz, the daughter of Janice Hamilton Outtz and James L. Outtz of Upper Marlboro, Md., was married Saturday to Justin Vernon Reed, the son of Patricia C. Reed and Everett V. Reed of Lawrenceville, N.J. Msgr. Eddie E. L. Tolentino III performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic chapel in Aquinas House at Princeton University, with the Rev. Darrell L. Armstrong, a Baptist minister, taking part.

headline: Jessica Lubin, James Hall
text: Jessica Nicole Lubin was married Saturday to Second Lt. James Matthew Hall. The Rev. Mark Giller, an associate pastor of the Sanctuary of the Beloved, officiated at the Overlook Lodge in Bear Mountain, N.Y.

headline: Frances McKay, Robert Jones
text: Frances Remington McKay, the daughter of Elizabeth R. McKay and Thomas A. McKay of Ridgewood, N.J., was married Saturday evening at her parents’ summer house in South Dartmouth, Mass., to Robert Logan Jones, the son of Bettye E. Jones and Donald B. Jones of Midland, Tex. Canon John G. Hartnett, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

headline: Caren Mintz, Joseph Grossman
text: Caren Tracy Mintz and Joseph Michael Grossman are to be married Sunday at the Lighthouse, an event space at Chelsea Piers in New York. Rabbi Azriel C. Fellner is to officiate.

headline: Wendy Doyle, Thomas Mullen
text: Wendy Marie Doyle and Thomas Joseph Mullen were married Saturday at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. Ugo Nacciarone, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Ruthanna Graves, Kevin McQueen
text: Ruthanna Graves and Kevin Paige McQueen were married Saturday in South Orange, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Rick Boyer, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the home of Diane Webster and William Webster, friends of the bride.

headline: Dawn Zimniak and Jibril Jackson
text: Dawn Marie Zimniak and Jibril Hassan Jackson were married Saturday at St. Patrick’s Cathedral in New York. The Rev. John P. Duffell, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Stephanie Martinez, Robert Ruckman
text: Stephanie Lynn Martinez, the daughter of Vicki L. Thompson of Woodstock, Va., and Gary F. Martinez of Severna Park, Md., was married Saturday evening to Robert Elliott Ruckman, a son of Kathleen S. Ruckman and Dr. Roger N. Ruckman, both of Washington. The Rev. Melody Page Sutherland, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Oaks, an event space in Royal Oak, Md.

headline: Liane Young, Xin Gao
text: Liane Lee Young, the daughter of Karen Lee Young and Dr. Michael C. Young of Wellesley Hills, Mass., was married Saturday to Xin Gao, a son of Dr. Pengfei Gao of Venetia, Pa., and the late Zhenzhen Zhuang. The Rev. David G. Schmelzer, a minister of the Vineyard Christian Fellowship, officiated at the Seaport Hotel in Boston.

headline: Alice Childress, Christopher Daniels
text: Alice Payne Childress and Christopher Channing Daniels were married Saturday evening at the Clifton Inn in Charlottesville, Va. Bhavani Metro, a minister with Integral Yoga, officiated.

headline: A Lord of Fright Reclaims His Dark Domain
text: A GREAT romance ended for the director John Carpenter 10 years ago on the set of his movie “Ghosts of Mars.”

headline: Judge Sends Conrad Black Back to Prison
text: After nearly a year of fighting to remain free, Conrad M. Black is going back to prison.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 24
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Scorecard | Louis Vuitton Wins!
text: Ready for some intellectualizing in Paris? Scorecard watched Louis Vuitton’s new men’s- wear studio director, the Botswana-raised British designer Kim Jones, get the positive ions flowing with his exuberant Masai checks-meets-bespoke tailoring exposition on multi-culti dressing Thursday. Meanwhile over at Alexis Mabille, the semiotic conclusion was that it wasn’t quite anchors away.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 24
text: More Photographs

headline: ‘The Rights of the People’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Where Credit Is Due
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Sarkozy Rebuts Gates’s Remarks on Libya Strikes
text: BRUSSELS — President Nicolas Sarkozy of France said on Friday that criticism by the departing United States defense secretary, Robert M. Gates, about European support for operations in Libya had been motivated by personal reasons and was grossly unfair.

headline: Grasping Climate Change at a Garden-Plot Level
text: One of the first places where Americans may notice the impact of climate change is in their own gardens and backyards, their most common point of intersection with the natural world.

headline: Following the Rich
text: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan considers the various surveys and analyses done of and for the rich. He says all the time and money put to looking at the wealthy, particularly when most people are feeling anything but wealthy, raises questions about the value of the information. Could anything from the various reports help others?

headline: New Haydn Recordings by Philharmonia Baroque
text: HAYDN: SYMPHONIES NOS. 88, 101, 104

headline: The Last Days of St. Martin of Tours
text: Forty years ago this month, David Gonzalez walked down the aisle of the Church of St. Martin of Tours in the Crotona neighborhood of the Bronx, clutching his eighth-grade diploma from the parish school. For the past few weeks, Mr. Gonzalez, now a reporter for The New York Times, has been back at St. Martin’s, this time to perform one of the Roman Catholic Church’s works of mercy: Burying the dead.

headline: Syrian City Crushed in 1982 Rises Up Again
text: As protesters rallied again across Syria on Friday, activists reported a large protest in the center of Hama, Syria’s fourth-largest city, where a rebellion was brutally crushed in 1982, during the reign of Hafez al-Assad, the current president’s father.

headline: Talent for Punctuating Classics With Surprises
text: It is heartening to see a young, energetic group like the Knights become, in effect, the resident orchestra for the free summer concerts at the Naumburg Bandshell in Central Park.

headline: 13 Hours of Sounds and Psychedelia
text: Listeners at the Winter Garden of the World Financial Center had to jump out of the way as the Asphalt Orchestra, a brainchild of Bang on a Can, snaked its way through the large crowd at the annual Bang on a Can Marathon on Sunday. The orchestra, an ebullient, avant-garde marching band that blends performance art with inventive new works and funky arrangements, offered a version of Frank Zappa’s “Zomby Woof” by Peter Hess (the group’s tenor saxophonist); an arrangement of Bjork’s “Hyper-Ballad” by Alan Ferber; and Goran Bregovic’s exuberant “Champagne.”

headline: Cold-Blooded Dinosaurs As Warm as Humans
text: By studying the chemical composition of dinosaur teeth, scientists have determined that some sauropods had body temperatures as warm as those of mammals.

headline: Southern Union Says Williams Bid $30 a Share in January
text: Southern Union has not tipped its hand yet on whether it will abandon its $4.2 billion sale to Energy Transfer Equity in favor of a $4.9 billion cash proposal from the Williams Companies.

headline: Trends: Super Whites
text: Bright white evokes field sports and science labs. The look, in monochrome, turns up in the collections of Comme des Garçons, Yves Saint Laurent and Givenchy.

headline: Citizen Kushner
text: ON a recent Monday evening, Jared Kushner, the 30-year-old publisher of The New York Observer, was holding court in the grand ballroom at the Harmonie Club on East 60th Street. The occasion marked the newspaper’s annual “100 Most Powerful People in New York Real Estate” issue, and many in attendance were city fixtures, people whose names appear on donor plaques and ballots, not on movie marquees: the developer Richard LeFrak, New York Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman, the public relations wizard Howard Rubenstein.

headline: Virgins, Pimps and Other Facts of life
text: The dancers in “The White Room,” Jennifer Muller’s new evening-length work, aren’t identified with character names or descriptions, but it’s not too difficult to sort out their agendas. This story of innocence and corruption shifts among characters including a virginal woman in white (Hsing-Hua Wang), a cartoonish kingpin (Pascal Rekoert), an ominous pimp (Gen Hashimoto) and an imposing woman who takes Daphne du Maurier’s Mrs. Danvers out of Manderley (Susanna Bozzetti).

headline: A Hard Rain Begins to Fall on Lives in Gulfport, Miss.
text: With “The Play About My Dad,” Boo Killebrew attempts a daunting juggling act: telling multiple accounts of Hurricane Katrina’s assault on her hometown, Gulfport, Miss., and recounting the dissolution of her parents’ marriage and her rapprochement with her father, a doctor called to action when the storm hits. She largely pulls it off, though detours intermittently threaten the balance.

headline: Everybody Outside With the Deep Fryer
text: RECENTLY, I acquired an electric deep fryer. It worked a little better than a pot of oil on the stove, but it didn’t make deep-frying any less of a messy, smelly affair.

headline: N.Y. Gay Marriage Bill Gains Key Votes
text: ALBANY — Thirty-three state senators have publicly declared they will support legalizing same-sex marriage, all but assuring passage of the measure which will make New York the largest state where gay and lesbian couples can wed.

headline: Growing Up With Two Icons
text: I ORDERED a Greek salad, followed by cheesecake. She went for split-pea soup and a bagel, with a fountain Diet Coke. Jenny Lumet, told she could pick a place for lunch, chose the Metro Diner, on Broadway at 100th Street, near her home. “I’m kind of a diner girl,” she said.

headline: Weekend Fare for June 24 to 26
text: Lincoln Ristorante hosts a negroni workshop Saturday from 3 to 4:30 p.m. The restaurant’s wine director, Aaron von Rock, will talk about the drink’s history and guests can enjoy happy hour with hors d’oeuvres from chef Jonathan Benno’s summer menu. The class is $50 per person. Reservations can be made online through the restaurant’s Web site. Lincoln, 142 West 65th Street (Broadway); (212) 359-6500.

headline: What’s Left in Joplin
text: A little over a month ago, the photographer Andrew Moore was just beginning his next project in Omaha, Neb. But when a tornado hit Joplin, Mo., he called Kathy Ryan, our photo director, and suggested that he make the five-to-six-hour drive to the area to take some pictures of the aftermath for the magazine. One of them was published as last week’s Look feature.

headline: Reviewing the 2011 Chrysler Town & Country
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Cheryl Jensen reviews the 2011 Chrysler Town & Country, which Chrysler historically has positioned as the choice of the luxury-minded minivan buyer. As Ms. Jensen notes, however, the automaker’s upmarket aspirations have not always translated to the final product.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Kris Van Assche
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#915", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

headline: TimesCast | Congress Votes on Libya
text: The House rejects a measure to authorize American operations in Libya but it refuses to cut financing.

headline: A Troubling Mutual Fund Case; Juggling Multiple Jobs; Putting More People to Work; the Oil Market and Bailing Out Greece
text: This week: Jeff Sommer with Gretchen Morgenson on a troubling mutual fund case, Phyllis Korkki and Hannah Seligson on juggling multiple jobs, and Robert Frank on how to put more people to work. Also, Mr. Sommer discusses the oil market and bailing out Greece.

headline: On the Street | Wedding Season
text: The reign of the Cinderella wedding dress continues, although the simplicity of the recent London royal wedding may soon have an effect.

headline: Mothers Cultivate Their Gardens in Burkina Faso
text: Saumya Dave, a student, and Noreen Connolly, a teacher, are the 2011 “Win A Trip” winners and are currently traveling with Nick through parts of North and West Africa. Noreen’s fourth post is from Burkina Faso.

headline: Grilled Shellfish With 'Barbecue' Sauce
text: Mark Bittman cooks fresh clams on the grill, and a sauce to go with them.

headline: The Minimalist: Grilled Shellfish With ‘Barbecue’ Sauce
text: Clams, mussels and oysters offer the lazy summer cook an advantage: they’re enclosed in perfectly sealed pots, Mother Nature’s very own pressure cooker. With a bit of heat from the grill, shellfish literally steam themselves and then pop open, ready for consumption, with virtually no effort required on the part of the griller.

headline: Executive Unbound?
text: Conor Friedersdorf, left, of The Atlantic and Reihan Salam of National Review debate the limits of presidential power.

headline: Scenes from Undead Jazz Festival
text: Images from the music series.

headline: TimesCast | Gay Pride Weekend
text: June 24, 2011 - With a vote looming, organizers prepare for this weekend's Gay Pride parade.

headline: ‘Everything Is Obvious, Once You Know the Answer’
text: Chapter 1: The Myth of Common Sense

headline: Photos of the Moment | Walter Van Beirendonck
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#85", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

headline: Born This Way: On a Farm
text: O.K., I’m a sucker for overalls; have been ever since that great American classic of town-and-country life, “Green Acres.” Junya Watanabe’s free-spirited collection, presented in a garden, featured loose-fitting overalls with Wellies, scrap-patch shirts, plaid shorts and waxed cotton utility jackets. I don’t know if he was appealing to the music festival crowd or the farm-to-table movement or just some dudes in Brooklyn, but his timing couldn’t be better.

headline: Conservative Group Rolls Out Major Ad Campaign
text: Crossroads GPS, the conservative independent group founded by Karl Rove, will spend $20 million on a national television advertising campaign aimed at framing “the national debate on jobs, the economy and the national debt,” a spokesman said.

headline: In Brooklyn, the Rats Move Out Before the Nets Move In
text: Residents living in the shadow of the Atlantic Yards arena project in Brooklyn shared horror stories on Thursday evening about cohabiting with rodents, and in the telling the rats seemed to grow to Godzilla-like proportions.

headline: Lauren & Michael
text: In this homemade video, Michael Camarinos recalls being impressed that Lauren Mavroudis could tee off.

headline: F.D.A. Urges Less Use of Anemia Drugs
text: WASHINGTON — Federal drug regulators said on Friday that three drugs that had been widely used to treat anemia in both kidney and cancer patients were so dangerous to the heart that doctors should consider avoiding the medicines altogether in some patients and using less of them in others.

headline: Wrapped in Paper, Gifts From the Earth
text: IS there anything better than a steaming new potato? I doubt it. Not to be confused with small potatoes or little boiling potatoes (which, don’t get me wrong, are wonderful), real new potatoes are freshly dug, perishable and heavenly. They’re showing up now at farmers’ markets, probably the best place to find them unless you have a gardener friend willing to share.

headline: A Stronger Net Security System Is Deployed
text: A small group of Internet security specialists gathered in Singapore this week to start up a global system to make e-mail and e-commerce more secure, end the proliferation of passwords and raise the bar significantly for Internet scam artists, spies and troublemakers.

headline: Chic in Review | Versace to the People
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Liane & Xin
text: In this homemade video, Dr. Liane Young and Xin Gao recall meeting at a mixer at a Boston nightclub.

headline: The Week in Pictures for June 24
text: A slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

headline: Summer’s Here. Have a Potato.
text: In this week’s City Kitchen, an ode to a seasonal delight, freshly dug new potatoes, coming soon to a farmers’ market near you. Nothing better. Of course you can boil them, but baking them in parchment with garlic and herbs shows off their ethereal sweetness. Count on at least half a pound per person — there won’t be leftovers. By the way, they’re bound to go with whatever you’re having for the Fourth.

headline: Plans for Festivities Move Ahead as Gay Marriage Vote Looms
text: This weekend’s gay pride festivities in New York City are unfolding as the State Legislature lurches toward a vote on same-sex marriage. Organizers are preparing for anything from violence to public outbreaks of euphoria, depending on the outcome.

headline: Meghan & Pip
text: In this homemade video, Pip Decker and Meghan Kober hail a cab and recall how they met at a mutual friend's wedding in Williamsburg, Va.

headline: Creating an Adolescence for the Ages
text: WHEN it comes to the teen movie, as with many well-defined genres, familiarity is often part of the point. But a pair of new American indies — “Terri” (opening Friday) and “The Myth of the American Sleepover” (opening July 22) — show that the conventions of the high-school film provide a useful shorthand even as they present room for nuance and complication. “Terri,” a character study and unlikely buddy movie named for its outsize protagonist, tackles the evergreen subject of adolescent alienation. Drifting from one slumber party to another, “Myth” borrows the night-in-the-life structure associated with two classics of the genre, “American Graffiti” and “Dazed and Confused.”

headline: Interview: Azazel Jacobs
text: The director Azazel Jacobs discusses his offbeat coming-of-age film "Terri."

headline: ‘Expedition’ Leads ABC to Second Place
text: “Expedition Impossible,” a new reality show on ABC from Mark Burnett involving teams of contestants traveling through Morocco and competing for money, got off to a solid if somewhat subdued start on Thursday, attracting seven million viewers at 9 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. The premiere’s audience was down slightly from ABC’s show at 8, “Wipeout” (7.4 million), but higher than the network’s “Rookie Blue” at 10 (5.9 million). For the night, ABC finished runner-up to CBS and its lineup of repeats, including “CSI” (7.7 million) and “The Mentalist” (8 million). Fox was third with an elimination episode of “So You Think You Can Dance” at 8 (6.3 million) and a rerun of “Glee” at 9 (3.2 million). NBC and repeats of its comedy block lagged behind in fourth. In the 10 p.m. hour, NBC’s “Love Bites” attracted just under two million viewers.

headline: A Rapper’s Still Stirring Things Up by Being Laid-Back
text: Very early on Thursday morning at the Blue Note, Rakim told a story about going to the house of the producer Marley Marl in the mid-1980s to record a song. Once there, he took the microphone and promptly sat on the couch. Marley Marl, he remembered, became agitated and suggested that he stand up to give the track more energy. Rakim demurred. That low-energy hum? “That’s how I wanna sound.”

headline: This Sunday: More Memories, Please, Derek Jeter
text: Just as no music will ever sound as meaningful to you as your favorite bands did when you were a teenager, no athletes measure up to the idols of your childhood. For Derek Jeter, however, I claim an exception.

headline: People, You Will See This Film. Right Now.
text: BEIJING — This month China’s great masses are being mobilized by their leaders for an unusual purpose. Employees at state-owned companies and at all levels of government are joining students from grade school to universities as they leave their homes, head out into the heat and do their duty: ensure the financial success of the government’s latest propaganda film, “Beginning of the Great Revival.”

headline: In Hours, Online Readers Identify Nazi Photographer
text: It appeared to be something of a mystery: a little photo album that had fallen into the hands of a New York garment industry executive with debts to pay off. In one snapshot was a bus with German lettering on the side. In another, a kitten on a soldier’s lap.

headline: An Artist Who Disappears, Appearing at Ground Zero
Jazz Bands, Very Loud, Find Smaller Crowd
text: The Undead Jazzfest, in its second year, started on Thursday at half-capacity and double volume.

headline: They Stumble That Run Fast, These Star-Crossed Shakespearean Lovers
