text: BECKET, Mass. — In the 1980s and early 1990s, Joëlle Bouvier, with her partner at the time, Régis Obadia, was part of a vanguard of young choreographers who gave contemporary dance new prominence and glamour in France. Known for their onstage charisma, their eye for visual effect and an intense, often violent physicality, they were part of a certain movement style and aesthetic unmistakable to anyone who spent time watching French contemporary dance in the 1990s.

headline: Podcast: Creating Jobs, and Juggling Them
text: The budget deficit has been grabbing many of the headlines and much of the attention in Washington. But it’s a distraction. There’s a more immediate economic problem.

headline: Building Japan’s Nuclear ‘Safety Myth’
text: As the Japanese continue to search for answers to the disaster at the Fukushima Daiichi plant, some are digging deep into the national psyche and examining a national propensity to embrace a belief now widely seen as irrational.

headline: At the Open Championships, a Slow Start and a Big Finish
text: At the fifth European Open Championships in Poznan, Poland, the Mixed Teams event was won on Wednesday by the French team of Pierre Zimmermann, Bénédicte Cronier, Philippe Cronier (the Croniers are married), Catherine d’Ovidio, Franck Multon and Sylvie Willard (although Zimmermann lives in Switzerland). They beat the Dutch team of Bep Vriend, Anton Maas, Carla Arnolds, Ton Bakkeren, Martine Verbeek and Huub Bertens, who had defeated the American team of Jim Mahaffey, Judi Radin, Sam Lev, Irina Levitina, Jacek Pszczola and Janice Seamon-Molson in the semifinals.

headline: Shakespeare Troupe Starts Building Brooklyn Theater
text: Leaders of the Theater for a New Audience, one of New York’s premier Shakespearean troupes, reached a milestone on Friday in their decades-long dream for a home as they held a groundbreaking ceremony for a $47.5 million theater. The project represents an unusually large financial commitment by the city to move an arts organization — in this case, a critically acclaimed theater company from Manhattan — into Brooklyn.

headline: The Politics of the State’s DNA Database (Who’s In It, Who Can See It)
text: A bill that would let the state take DNA samples from anyone convicted of any crime — including misdemeanors — has stalled in Albany, where the State Senate and the Assembly have butted heads over what the bill should include.

headline: Jets’ Training Camp Moving
text: Citing the uncertainty of the N.F.L. lockout, the Jets said they would hold their training camp this year in Florham Park, N.J., and not at SUNY Cortland, where it has been held the past two years.

headline: Google to End Health Records Service After It Fails to Attract Users
text: Google is giving up on its vision of helping people live healthier lives with online personal health records.

headline: Azerbaijan and Armenia Fail to End Enclave Dispute
text: MOSCOW — Hopes for a breakthrough on a conflict between Azerbaijan and Armenia were deflated Friday when Russia, which convened talks in the city of Kazan, released a statement saying that the leaders of the two countries had not agreed to the framework for a deal.

headline: Florida Suit Says Arrests Are Retaliation for Atheism
text: MIAMI — An atheist in Central Florida filed suit in Federal District Court in Tampa on Friday, accusing the Polk County sheriff, an evangelical Christian, of harassing and unnecessarily arresting her as retaliation for not believing in God and for her efforts to keep prayer out of public meetings.

headline: Play Soccer, Cook Brunch, Call Mom
text: In theory, Sunday is a day away from the grind for the chef-author-entrepreneur Marcus Samuelsson. But instead of indolence, soccer and food rule the agenda. A judge on the Food Network’s “24 Hour Restaurant Battle,” Mr. Samuelsson, 40, is the executive chef and co-owner of Red Rooster Harlem; his restaurant empire also includes the Blue Parrot in East Hampton and Aquavit. His latest venture is Food Republic, a lifestyle Web site-guide to “manning up” in the kitchen. He lives in Harlem with his wife, Maya Haile, a model. ROBIN FINN

headline: Somalia: Foreign Helicopter Attack Kills 15 Rebels
text: At least 15 insurgents were killed in a foreign helicopter attack on a Shabab rebel military base near Kismayo, Somalia, witnesses and officials said Friday. The attack, which occurred on Thursday, killed at least 15 Shabab commanders, including eight foreigners, a local human rights organization said. It was not clear who carried out the attack. American Special Operations forces have attacked Somali militants by helicopter at least once before.

headline: Sounds in the City
text: The City Critic visited several Make Music New York events on Tuesday, June 21.

headline: Charity Goes Mobile to Appeal to Young
text: Nancy Lublin was sitting in her office in Manhattan one evening last December when she noticed her staff outside giving one another high fives, pumping their fists and generally engaged in raucous celebration.

headline: G.O.P. Hopefuls Press Romney on Abortion Rights
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — Seeking to distinguish themselves from Mitt Romney, the presumed Republican front-runner in the 2012 presidential race, challengers exploited a bit of daylight that opened between him and other candidates this week over abortion.

headline: Could You Pipe Down? My Ears Thank You
text: My two friends and I don’t expect a Nobel Prize. We don’t expect to have a bridge or a building named after us. None of the great scientists think in those terms while pursuing their breakthroughs; they think only of the good their research might do for humanity.

headline: Hacked Memos of State Police in Arizona Are Released
text: PHOENIX — A cache of internal documents released online on Thursday by hackers who gained access to the computer system of the Arizona Department of Public Safety revealed the array of potential outlaws on the state police’s radar screen, from international terrorists to Mexican drug smugglers to motorcycle gang members.

headline: Playing Nice Before the Match
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Imagine Yankees pitcher C. C. Sabathia loosening up for a start against the Red Sox by throwing to Boston catcher Jason Varitek. That is a battery that would assault the senses of either team’s fans. It is different in tennis, where rivals warming each other up is a time-honored ritual, so ingrained in the game the players do not give it a second thought.

headline: How Budget Cuts Affect the Mentally Ill
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cutlass Lessons and Tattoos for Aspiring Pirates
text: Sundry maritime marauders will be roaming the grounds of Philipsburg Manor over the July 4 weekend, transforming what was a farming, milling and trading center in 1750 into a swashbucklers’ festival.

headline: A Musical Exploration, Monticello to Mali
text: FOUR years ago, the Caramoor International Music Festival in Katonah, flush with a big new grant, began “Sonidos Latinos,” a comprehensive survey of Latin-American music. By the time the grant expired two years later, the project’s evocative portraits of musical cultures had earned it an enviable reputation — one the festival stands to build on when, in four concerts over the next month, it explores four more cultures.

headline: Deal Will Avert Plan to Lay Off City Teachers
text: The threatened layoffs of 4,100 teachers in New York’s public schools were averted under a deal that the Bloomberg administration, the City Council and the teachers’ union reached on Friday night.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Saving Social Security
text: To the Editor:

headline: As Lockout Approaches, N.B.A. Players Wear Unity on Their Shirts
text: Two dozen men, all taller than average, dressed in matching gray T-shirts, filed out of a Midtown Manhattan hotel and into a waiting bus on Friday afternoon, their message conveyed in their uniformity.

headline: Zimbabwe: Government Minister Arrested
text: One of Prime Minister Morgan Tsvangirai’s closet advisers, Jameson Timba, a minister of state, was arrested in Harare on Thursday. Mr. Tsvangirai’s spokesman, Luke Tamborinyoka, said the police had not specified the charge or admitted they had him in custody. Mr. Timba’s driver saw him being arrested, Mr. Tamborinyoka said. More than a quarter of President Robert Mugabe’s opponents in Parliament have been arrested since their party, the Movement for Democratic Change, agreed to enter a troubled power-sharing government with his party, ZANU-PF.

headline: How to Leave a War
text: President Obama’s speech on Wednesday announcing the gradual withdrawal of troops from Afghanistan was certainly a news story of significance, and it quickly drew more commentary than even the most voracious national security policy hound could possibly absorb. But that’s why we’re here. (The full text of the speech is here.)

headline: My Reliable Dad
text: To the Editor:

headline: When Victims Have Pasts of Their Own
text: A prosecutor later called the attack a “siege of terror,” but even that falls short.

headline: Shakespeare’s Fools for Love, Fighting a ‘Merry War’
text: I couldn’t help it. During the wedding scene in Shakespeare on the Sound’s lively, likable production of “Much Ado About Nothing,” I found myself thinking about Pippa Middleton and Prince Harry.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Discussing Race in City Is Fraught After 10 Killings
text: A serial killer in Rocky Mount, N. C., a city about 50 miles northeast of Charlotte, is believed to have killed 10 people — all of them African-American drug users who worked as prostitutes. The murders have laid bare the area’s fraught history of racism and mistrust. Some of the women had been missing for years. Even with an arrest in the case last year, the relationship between African-Americans and law enforcement here remains unsettled.

headline: New Law in Kansas Seen as a Threat to Abortions
text: OVERLAND PARK, Kan. — One in a series of abortion limits approved in Kansas since Republicans took full control of the state government this year — a new license law — is raising uncertainty about the future of all abortion providers in the state.

headline: A Town Celebration, Fireworks and All
text: TIMOTHY J. HOGAN, chairman of this year’s KaBoomFest in Red Bank, remembers the first one he attended 10 years ago. He and his family had just moved there, he said, “and we weren’t aware” of the popularity of the fireworks that cap the annual townwide celebration, to take place July 1 to 3 this year.

headline: Jazz Historian’s 15-Year Dream: Book on Louis Armstrong
text: TOMS RIVER, N.J.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Julie Taymor’s Reputation
text: To the Editor:

headline: All of His Crops Flourished. Too Bad They Were in a Park.
text: If they squint, neighbors say, the farm tilled by David Abreu begins to look a little like home — his cilantro is as green, his bean supply as tidy. And then there is the man himself: clutching his machete handle, pant legs stained black, surveying the soil like any farmer who takes pride in his land. “He could be my father,” said one neighbor, José Rodríguez, 52, originally from Santiago, Dominican Republic.

headline: Cuomo Likely to Veto Bill on School Borrowing
text: ALBANY — State lawmakers on Friday approved a bill that would allow school districts to borrow as much as $1 billion without voter approval, but a spokesman for Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said the measure would most likely be vetoed.

headline: A Question for the Right
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Scoop of Urban Flavor
text: Local, a new ice cream shop and cafe in Chappaqua, is a slice of hipster Williamsburg that somehow delights in its suburban setting, mixing nourishment (kale salad with pistachios and miso-lemon dressing) with old-fashioned fun (chocolate fudge sundaes and banana splits served in traditional glass tulips and gondolas). The food comes from local producers and growers, there are no preservatives or artificial ingredients, and take-out containers are compostable.

headline: ‘Safety Myth’ Left Japan Ripe for Nuclear Crisis
text: SHIKA, Japan — Near a nuclear power plant facing the Sea of Japan, a series of exhibitions in a large public relations building here extols the virtues of the energy source with some help from “Alice in Wonderland.”

headline: U.S. Faces Questions and a Familiar Foe
text: The United States will face Mexico in the Gold Cup final on Saturday night, which should surprise no one: those teams routinely dominate the event. But that does not mean that the tournament has not been full of surprises:

headline: After Chinese Dance, Some Thoughts on Dating
text: That the New York of “Sex and the City” ended with the advent of high-speed Internet cable was not something we expected to learn at a performance by Shen Yun, the colorful gymnastic Chinese classical dance company, at Lincoln Center on Thursday night. But Candace Bushnell gave us an earful about the demise of Carrie Bradshaw’s New York.

headline: Battle For Libya | June 24, 2011
text: Dozens of detained rebels returned Friday on a Red Cross ship to their eastern stronghold of Benghazi, detailing how they were tortured at the hands of Libyan leader Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi forces.

headline: The U.N. and a Two-State Mideast Solution
text: To the Editor:

headline: Madoff Trustee Seeking Billions More From JPMorgan
text: Irving H. Picard, the trustee liquidating Bernard L. Madoff’s firm, said on Friday that he had filed a revised lawsuit against JPMorgan Chase & Company, demanding a minimum of $19 billion in damages.

headline: There’s No Quitting in Managing
text: Like a lot of major league players, Prince Fielder of the Milwaukee Brewers is not signed for next season. This is by choice, really, because Fielder and the Brewers have not agreed on a contract extension. But, still, he is unsigned. So what’s his approach?

headline: Nationals Name Manager but Stress Interim Label
text: CHICAGO — Mike Rizzo grew up in suburban Park Ridge, Ill., and said he was looking forward to visiting family, friends and “some old haunts” during a weekend visit here.

headline: Nevada: Truck Collides With Train
text: Two people were killed and at least 20 were injured on Friday morning when a tractor-trailer collided with a California-bound Amtrak train in a remote part of western Nevada. The crash occurred at a crossing about 75 miles east of Reno when the driver of the truck apparently drove into the side of the California Zephyr, which was traveling from Chicago to the Bay Area with more than 200 passengers and 14 crew members aboard, Amtrak officials said.

headline: Inexpensive Thai Fare, With a Sunset View
text: WHEN it opened last March, Thai Elephant 2 promised some culinary relief from the many burger variations lining Route 22 in Patterson. And if you order right, it can be a pleasant oasis. The style of Thai food here isn’t high end, with elaborately carved fruits and vegetables (though rice is charmingly presented in the shape of a star). It is workaday Thai, with some delicious dishes and some that need help, from a kitchen that at the moment lacks consistency. But it does offer a lovely view, food that can be satisfying and healthful and, not least, bargain prices, particularly at lunch.

headline: Sympathy for the Devils
text: Miami

headline: Canada: Drunken Passengers May Have Caused Plane Crash
text: The Transportation Safety Board of Canada said in a report that three drunken and argumentative passengers may have caused the crash of a chartered float plane that killed them as well as the pilot. The passengers boarded the brief flight between two islands off the coast of British Columbia in May 2010 after being refused water taxi service because they were carrying a case of beer and several bottles of liquor. In a report issued this week, the board said that it found evidence that one of the passengers, who had been quarreling among themselves, shoved the pilot’s seat from behind, forcing him against the aircraft’s controls and causing a fatal dive into the water.

headline: Berries, Ripe for the Picking
text: Even as Patricia DiVello, 52, watched several children gathering strawberries on a recent afternoon at Patty’s Berries and Bunches, her pick-your-own farm in Mattituck, she was already looking forward to the next crop.

headline: Move by Rangers Surprises Even the Player They Choose With the 15th Pick
text: ST. PAUL — The early hours of the first round of the N.H.L. entry draft proceeded without any major surprises — at least until the Rangers picked at No. 15. The stunned look on the face of center J. T. Miller, a member of the United States under-18 team, showed just how unexpected this was.

headline: South Africa: Governing Party Seeks to Tone Down Secrecy Bill
text: The governing African National Congress, which has been pushing a bill that would have enshrouded much routine government activity in secrecy and punished whistleblowers and journalists with up to 25 years in prison, said Friday that it now favored “drastically” reducing the scope of the bill to apply only the country’s security services. It also said the harsh minimum prisons sentences should be removed from the legislation. In a statement, the party said the bill must ensure that the law would not be abused to hide corruption, the very outcome the bill’s critics had feared.

headline: Parallel Lives from the Eastern Shore
text: Harriet Ross Tubman and Frederick Douglass, two of the best-known African Americans of the Civil War era, were both born into slavery on Maryland’s Eastern Shore, at roughly the same time. Perhaps because of its border-state decision to stay with the Union, Maryland and its slave-owning past are often forgotten today. And yet as the lives and scars of these two attested, slavery in rural Maryland could be as oppressive and isolated as the cotton fields of the Deep South. Swaths of white family-owned farmland were worked by thousands of enslaved people, who also worked on the water to bring back the rich catch of the Chesapeake Bay. And in no part of the state was slavery as brutal as the Eastern Shore — conditions exposed by the oddly parallel lives of these two famous Marylanders.

headline: Them That’s Not Shall Lose
text: “Anyone who has ever struggled with poverty knows how extremely expensive it is to be poor.”

headline: Venezuela: Chávez Breaks Silence; Says Little
text: President Hugo Chávez, recovering in Cuba after emergency surgery there this month, broke an unusual stretch of silence with four brief Twitter messages on Friday.  The messages, laden with references to military glory, Venezuela’s national anthem, the weather and an 1821 battle against Spain, were the first public communications from Mr. Chávez since June 12, when he spoke by telephone to a journalist two days after his surgery in Havana for a pelvic abscess. Mr. Chávez made no reference to his health or location, which have stirred fierce debate in Venezuela over the scant disclosure of such information. Still, he singled out Gen. Euclides Campos Aponte, commander of Venezuela’s army, for praise. “Good morning followers!” he wrote in one message. “Today is the day of my Army and the sun is shining! A gigantic hug to my soldiers and my beloved people!”

headline: Boehner Must Navigate Rocky Road to a Budget
text: WASHINGTON — The morning after Republicans claimed the House on Nov. 2, John A. Boehner, the soon-to-be speaker, was asked how he was ever going to get a multitrillion-dollar increase in the federal debt ceiling through his new Tea Party-infused majority.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Local Wine, but Owners From Chile
text: When the Chilean owners of Laurel Lake Vineyards, in Laurel, bought the winery for $2 million in 1999, it was producing 5,100 cases of wine. By leasing additional acreage and planting more vines in stages, they raised the output at the 13-acre winery to 9,000 cases last year.

headline: Indiana Law to Cut Planned Parenthood Funding Is Blocked
text: WASHINGTON — A federal judge ruled Friday that the State of Indiana could not cut off money for Planned Parenthood clinics providing health care to low-income women on Medicaid.

headline: Rustic Greek Cooking in a Casual Setting
text: MP TAVERNA opened in Roslyn in mid-May and immediately went to the head of the class. It is now on my list of favorite Long Island restaurants, and it is the least expensive of the group.

headline: Giambi Returns to Stadium With a Smile and a New Role
text: Jason Giambi was a popular person as he walked through Yankee Stadium on Friday afternoon. He greeted a clubhouse attendant with a smile, clapped several reporters on the back and even hugged the police officer stationed outside the Colorado Rockies’ dugout during batting practice.

headline: The Dairy Built on Stiletto Heels
text: LITCHFIELD, Conn.

headline: Bread, Cheese, Four Walls
text: After almost 20 years of selling mozzarella and bread under canvas tents at farmers’ markets, Hoboken Farms finally has a real roof over its head. In May, Brad Finkel, who owns the business, added his first brick-and-mortar location — a tiny takeout sandwich shop — on the western edge of Summit.

headline: Tastes of the Sea in a Shore-Like Setting
text: LIKE much of Asbury Park these days, the downtown feels like a work in progress, particularly around Cookman Avenue, where construction sites and window signs heralding the arrival of new businesses signal a fresh, if fragile, future for the neighborhood. And everywhere you look, hipper, more well-heeled aspirations rub up against a grittier, blue-collar past. It all gives the city its essential character, of course, that sense of being perpetually on the verge.

headline: ‘Friday Night Lights’ Watch: The Return of Tim Riggins
text: We are covering the final season of “Friday Night Lights” according to the NBC schedule. We ask readers who have already seen the season on DirecTV or on DVD to please refrain from giving away future plot points in the comments section. For analysis of previous episodes, click here.

headline: Saturday: Gnarly Waves, Dude!
text: Administrivial Solving Tips Alert: The question of how to solve a puzzle that has rebus elements in it when you are solving on computer — whether you are on Mac or PC, solving in Across Lite or the applet — has come up, and I’d like to direct your attention to a new category on the right-hand side of the page in the Blogroll called Solving Tips. In it we will be putting helpful tips for (wait for it) solving. Our own Martin Herbach was kind enough to research and write up a new page about how to enter multiple letters for rebus entries, and there is an interesting article from puzzlemaster Will Shortz. Stay tuned for more additions, and if there is anything else you would like to see there, please contact me at deb.amlen@nytimes.com.

headline: Two Are Accused of Stealing $16 Million Over Eight Years
text: A woman and her son were charged Friday with stealing more than $16 million from two textile companies in SoHo and using the money to support lavish lifestyles and the son’s failed ambulance company.

headline: Pick Raises Questions Knicks Say He Answered
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The Knicks’ selection of Georgia Tech guard Iman Shumpert with the 17th pick drew boos, puzzled television analysts and opened debate about the wisdom of the draft choice, probably the last major move by the team president Donnie Walsh.

headline: With a Bit of Land Restored, Villagers End Campaign
text: BILIN, West Bank — Residents of this tiny Palestinian village, along with Israeli and foreign supporters, on Friday held what organizers billed as the last of their trademark weekly demonstrations against the Bilin section of Israel’s West Bank barrier. It was a milestone that illustrated both the success of the unarmed popular movement that was born here, and its limitations.

headline: President Announces an Initiative in Technology
text: LAWRENCEVILLE, Pa. — President Obama visited a university research center in Pittsburgh on Friday to announce a new partnership between the government, industries and leading universities to speed the movement of technological advances to commercial users. The trip was the latest of his increasingly frequent travels to battleground states to showcase administration efforts to create manufacturing jobs.

headline: German E.Coli Sickens 8 in France
text: PARIS — The deadly German E. coli strain that killed at least 45 people has resurfaced in France, where officials said a cluster of eight people have fallen ill, apparently from eating contaminated sprouts grown in France.

headline: Hitters With Blue Eyes Are Wary About Glare
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — In a 1956 recording, Chuck Berry sang: “Round the third, he was headed for home. It was a brown-eyed handsome man.”

headline: The Great Corn Con
text: FEELING the need for an example of government policy run amok? Look no further than the box of cornflakes on your kitchen shelf. In its myriad corn-related interventions, Washington has managed simultaneously to help drive up food prices and add tens of billions of dollars to the deficit, while arguably increasing energy use and harming the environment.

headline: Battling Over Bike Lanes, Online
text: New York’s bicycle advocates turn to the Internet to make their voices, and message, heard over the city’s car traffic.

headline: When Bikers Clash, the Tape Rolls
text: WHEN Casey Neistat got a ticket on Second Avenue and Seventh Street in the East Village for riding his bicycle outside the designated bike lane in May, he did what many outraged cyclists do. He grabbed his cellphone and shot a video of his encounter with the ticketing officer, who admonished him to ride in the lane at all times.

headline: Public or Private, It’s Work
text: Sutton, Vt.

headline: 2 by 2, or Not, Zoo Animals Escape Flood
text: MINOT, N.D. — As a historic flood threatened to drown this city, the animals from the local zoo were evacuated to a warehouse high above the valley floor. There were two of every sort — donkeys, hedgehogs, bald eagles, reindeer, toucans and many others — packed together in a makeshift sanctuary.

headline: Long Series of Trials Could Prove to Be Mobster’s Death Sentence
text: James (Whitey) Bulger’s long flight back from Los Angeles to Boston on Friday was only the beginning of a much longer journey, a legal odyssey that is likely to keep him in court for years. Unless Mr. Bulger, who is 81, bypasses the long court process with plea deals, the trials themselves could be a death sentence.

headline: An Unfair Burden
text: For all of the economic hardship of the last several years, there was reason to hope that the nation could avoid a crushing increase in the number of Americans living in poverty. That hope is fading fast.

headline: Legislature Approves Bloomberg Plan to Allow Street Hails of Livery Cabs
text: The State Legislature voted on Friday to vastly expand the reach of regulated, metered taxi service in New York City, a move that would create a class of livery cabs that can be hailed legally on the street outside the busiest parts of Manhattan.

headline: Yemen’s Security Forces Clash With Protesters at Funeral Procession for a Popular Activist
text: SANA, Yemen — Security forces fired at a funeral procession in the city of Aden on Friday and gunmen responded by attacking a military tank, the government and local journalists said. A total of five people were killed in the clashes.

headline: Bullying in N.J.; Bargaining in N.Y.
text: New York and New Jersey, like so many other states, are struggling with big budget gaps and high health care expenses for union employees. The Cuomo administration in New York sat at the bargaining table and worked out a fair arrangement for bigger contributions by workers. Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, by contrast, bullied and postured and got the Legislature to strip unions of collective-bargaining rights on health insurance.

headline: Dangerous Imports
text: The Food and Drug Administration has proposed sensible steps to cope with the dangers posed by a flood of imported food, drugs, cosmetics and medical devices. The trouble is, Congressional Republicans are determined to cut the agency’s budget when it ought to be getting an increase to deal with this worsening risk.

headline: New York Allows Same-Sex Marriage, Becoming Largest State to Pass Law
text: ALBANY — Lawmakers voted late Friday to legalize same-sex marriage, making New York the largest state where gay and lesbian couples will be able to wed and giving the national gay-rights movement new momentum from the state where it was born.

headline: How Gay Marriage Will Change Couples’ Financial Lives
text: Updated | June 27, 2011 Couples may marry for love, but the partnership is also an economic one. And now that New York has become the sixth state to perform same-sex marriage, couples who tie the knot here will gain a variety of financial benefits and legal rights.

headline: In Lean Times, Schools Squeeze Out Librarians
text: Budget belt-tightening threatens to send school librarians the way of the card catalog.

headline: Denmark Leads Nationalist Challenge to Europe’s Open Borders
text: COPENHAGEN — Ten years ago, as Denmark joined the European Union’s visa-free open travel zone, the outraged Danish People’s Party bought a decommissioned border guardhouse, vowing that one day it would be in use again.

headline: On the Art of Puttering
text: We are a driven people, New Yorkers. Too much to do, not enough time. We keep lists; we crowd our schedules; we look for more efficient ways to organize ourselves — we get things done when we’re not too busy planning to get things done. Even our leisure time is focused, and there is something proactive about our procrastination. We don’t merely put things off. We put things off by piling other things on top of them. As Robert Benchley once noted, “anyone can do any amount of work, provided it isn’t the work he is supposed to be doing at that moment.”

headline: Burnett Fizzles as Giambi Dazzles
text: A. J. Burnett walked slowly from the pitcher’s mound to the Yankees dugout Friday, head down and shoulders slumped as tepid applause mixed with half-hearted booing in the Yankee Stadium stands. It was as if the fans did not know what to do with Burnett; taken as a whole, their reaction to his departure in the seventh inning might best be described as collective indifference.

headline: Firefighters’ Pride
text: SOME are geographical descriptions: the Brooklyn Bridge Club, the Pride of Williamsburg, Midtown Express. Some use animal names: the River Rats, the Hollis Hogs, the 38th Street Mutts.

headline: The Firehouses of New York
text: The firefighters of New York have been devising clever slogans for their firehouses. Here are a few of them.

headline: Rebels Arm Tripoli Guerrillas and Cut Resources to Capital
text: ROGEBAN, Libya — Having consolidated control over almost all of Libya’s western mountains, rebel leaders here say they are now pursuing a two-pronged strategy to bring down the government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi: starving it of resources while covertly arming a growing guerrilla force within Tripoli itself.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Criminal Case Against James J. Bulger and Catherine Geiger
text: A selection of court documents regarding James (Whitey) Bulger, the legendary Boston crime boss, who was arrested on Wednesday after a 16-year manhunt.

headline: Obama’s Growing Trust in Biden Is Reflected in His Call on Troops
text: WASHINGTON — As President Obama began mulling his next big decision on troop levels in Afghanistan last January, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. quietly flew to Kabul to meet with President Hamid Karzai and tour the battlefield with the top American commander, Gen. David H. Petraeus.

headline: Mets Fall Behind Early, and It Only Gets Worse
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Coming off what may have been his best start of the season, Mike Pelfrey was looking to suppress a potent Rangers lineup long enough so that his team could mount an offensive attack.

headline: Banker Makes Guilty Plea as Sex Charge Is Reduced
text: An Egyptian banker pleaded guilty on Friday to a misdemeanor charge of kissing and touching the breasts of a housekeeper at the Pierre hotel without her consent.

headline: A Sense of Euphoria Settles on the West Village
text: Supporters of the same-sex marriage bill danced in the streets of the West Village after the State Senate approved it on Friday night.

headline: Peter Falk’s Career
text: Peter Falk, who played Columbo, one of the most famous and beloved fictional detectives in television history, has died.

headline: Gene Colan, Prolific Comic-Book Artist, Dies at 84
text: Gene Colan, a towering figure among comic-book artists, whose depictions of some of the best-known characters in the genre were lauded for their realism, expressiveness and painterly qualities, died on Thursday in the Bronx. He was 84 and lived in Brooklyn.

headline: Don Diamond, Character Actor, Is Dead at 90
text: Don Diamond, a character actor on radio, television and film who was best known for playing supporting roles on TV westerns, died on Sunday en route to a hospital in Los Angeles. He was 90.

headline: New York Legalizes Same-Sex Marriage
text: Lawmakers voted late Friday to legalize same-sex marriage, making New York the largest state where gay and lesbian couples will be able to wed.

headline: Celebration at the Stonewall Inn
text: More than 1,000 supporters of same-sex marriage gathered at the Stonewall Inn, a birthplace of the gay rights movement in New York's West Village neighborhood, to celebrate the bill's passage.

headline: Car Bomb Blast at Afghan Hospital Kills at Least 20
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A sport utility vehicle packed with explosives blew up on Saturday outside a small hospital in a remote area of eastern Afghanistan, killing at least 20 people and injuring at least 23 more, government officials said.

headline: The Weekend Word: Rejection
text: Today’s Times

headline: Top 10 Cornerbacks in N.F.L.
text: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely -– but not strictly -– by film study of all 32 teams from the 2010 season. Stats weren’t acknowledged, but players with poor numbers generally don’t make top 10 lists anyway. Vague enough for you? Criteria for top 10 lists tend to be. That’s why most of you will have no trouble finding some disagreement with what you’re about to read.

headline: Two Books Explore Borg and McEnroe Rivalry
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Thirty years ago this summer, John McEnroe and Bjorn Borg stepped onto Centre Court here at the All England Club and staged a rousing final that riveted the tennis world.

headline: A Car Question for Adam Carolla
text: Adam Carolla, the comedian and jack-of-all-trades television personality, stopped by The Times on Friday afternoon to chat about his new Speed Channel program, “The Car Show.” Discussion of the show, which premieres July 13, turned out to be an afterthought, though, as the 30-minute interview was waylaid by a single question.

headline: The Ways of Silencing
text: We might wish politicians and pundits from opposing parties to engage in reasoned debate about the truth, but as we know, this is not the reality of our political discourse.

headline: Urban Forager: An Irresistible Berry (Within Limits)
text: Ever since I discovered mulberries growing in a park in Flushing, Queens, on the day of my grandmother’s death two years ago, the delight of finding summer berries has been bittersweet for me. Last week, I was having another difficult day when my fiancé and I took a walk in Central Park to search for the linden trees, which I thought would be in full bloom and would make a lovely tea. But our most recent heat wave had spurred an early flowering, and when we arrived in the area I call “Linden Hill,” the creamy-colored blossoms were already browning with age.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Givenchy
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#797", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

headline: The Week in Pictures for June 24
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the debate over same-sex marriage legislation, the closing of a landmark bagel shop and an effort to tag horseshoe crabs.

headline: Billionaire Owner of New Jersey Nets Takes Helm of Party in Russia
text: MOSCOW — The billionaire owner of the New Jersey Nets basketball team, Mikhail D. Prokhorov, was elected leader of a Russian political party on Saturday in the first foray of a big businessman into politics here in nearly a decade.

headline: Helping a Starving Family in Niger
text: Saumya Dave, a student, and Noreen Connolly, a teacher, are the 2011 “Win A Trip” winners and are currently traveling with Nick through parts of North and West Africa. Noreen’s fifth post is from Niger.

headline: Photos of the Moment | John Galliano
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#583", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

headline: Fish Reaches Wimbledon’s Fourth Round
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Mardy Fish, the last American man standing at Wimbledon, advanced to the fourth round on Saturday when Robin Haase retired after trailing, 6-3, 6-7 (5), 6-2, 1-1.

headline: Hawk Cam | Pip Starts to Soar — and Climb
text: Since taking her first flight from a 12th-floor nest outside New York University’s Bobst Library, young Pip the hawk spent much of her time Thursday and Friday flitting around a secluded courtyard between buildings on Washington Square East and Greene Street.

headline: Behind N.Y. Gay Marriage, an Unlikely Mix of Forces
text: In the 35th-floor conference room of a Manhattan high-rise, two of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s most trusted advisers held a secret meeting a few weeks ago with a group of super-rich Republican donors.

headline: Palins to Attend Documentary Premiere in Iowa
text: The Sarah Palin film that is making its Iowa debut next week will have two special guests in the audience: Ms. Palin and her husband, Todd.

headline: Returning to Bronx, 3 Losses Forgiven
text: George Frazier had just become the first pitcher in major league history to lose three games in a best-of-seven World Series. Even worse, he had done it for George Steinbrenner’s Yankees.

headline: An All-Star Homecoming for Longoria, but Probably Just to Visit
text: MILWAUKEE — Evan Longoria is the oldest of four siblings — the youngest a 16-year-old brother — and he has established high expectations at the start of his major league career. In each of his first three seasons with the Tampa Bay Rays, Longoria has been an All-Star, voted to start at third base the last two years. At 25, he would seem to be a safe bet to make it every summer.

headline: Women’s World Cup: U.S. Confronts a Crowd of Contenders
text: The days of dominance for the United States women’s national team — when it could count on defeating opponents with sheer athleticism — have passed. The women’s game has evolved, and teams around the world are showing greater skill and tactical sophistication.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: 30 Seconds With Monica Seles
text: Monica Seles, a former No. 1-ranked tennis player, won 9 Grand Slam singles titles, 53 career titles and a bronze medal at the Sydney Olympics in 2000. She officially retired in 2008, five years after her last match. Seles, 37, was in Manhattan last Monday to help kick off Wimbledon by playing against select fans on a grass court at Rockefeller Center, part of a series of activities presented by HSBC Bank.

headline: Murray’s Mother Appreciates the Scenery
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Mothers can sometimes be mortifying. Take Andy Murray’s mother, Judy, who is also his coach. She has a mom crush on the Spaniard Feliciano Lopez, whose pinup looks led her to nickname him Deliciano on Twitter.

headline: Babe Didrikson Zaharias’s Legacy Fades
text: BEAUMONT, Tex. — Mildred Ella Babe Didrikson Zaharias has, in many ways, become America’s all-but-forgotten sports superstar. And nowhere is Didrikson’s faded sporting legacy felt more powerfully than here in her hometown, where she hopped hedges along Doucette Street and learned how to play golf at Beaumont Country Club.

headline: Surviving Heart of the Storm, and Aiming for the Peak
text: COLORADO SPRINGS — For now, Christy Carlson has traded in a storm-chasing partner for a racecourse navigator.

headline: Trouble Behind and Ahead as Serena Williams Wins
text: WIMBLEDON, England — As the matches keep getting easier for Serena Williams at one of her traditional stomping grounds, more details of her recent difficulties continue to emerge.

headline: Distrust of Government Impedes Reform in Greece
text: ATHENS — Demonstrators projected the word across the facade of Parliament last week, and it underscored the hurdle that Prime Minister George Papandreou faces in selling an increasingly resentful electorate on a tough new round of austerity measures: “Thieves.”

headline: In Another Red Bull Day, Vettel Again Crushes all the Competition
text: After again cruising at the top of the time sheets in Saturday’s qualifying session in Valencia, Spain, Sebastian Vettel has now scored seven pole positions this season out of eight races. Mark Webber, his teammate at Red Bull, was second fastest, just a tenth of a second behind — but that did not prevent the Australian from looking a little stunned.

headline: In Another Red Bull Day, Vettel Again Crushes all the Competition
text: After again cruising at the top of the time sheets in Saturday’s qualifying session in Valencia, Spain, Sebastian Vettel has now scored seven pole positions this season out of eight races. Mark Webber, his teammate at Red Bull, was second fastest, just a tenth of a second behind — but that did not prevent the Australian from looking a little stunned.

headline: Variety:  A Sometimes Dyagramless
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Welcome to the Variety Diagramless, where you get to build your own puzzle with the aid of a well-known constructor.

headline: German E.Coli Sickens 8 in France
text: PARIS — The deadly German E. coli strain that killed at least 45 people has resurfaced in France, where officials said a cluster of eight people have fallen ill, apparently from eating contaminated sprouts grown in France.

headline: A Discussion with Three House Speakers
text: Excerpts from a panel discussion on the role of the speaker of the House and the legacy of Henry Clay, moderated by John Harwood, featuring three current and former House Speakers.

headline: Western Libya Earns a Taste of Freedom as Rebels Loosen Qaddafi’s Grip
text: ROGEBAN, Libya —Until a few weeks ago, the rebellious towns in the Nafusah Mountains were struggling to survive on dwindling supplies of barley, water and gas during a long siege by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s soldiers.

headline: Dr. Wakefield and Dr. Dickey, Dentists, Not Pitchers
text: DALLAS — For many players in baseball, the maddening act of trying to hit the knuckleballs thrown by R. A. Dickey and Tim Wakefield is like having teeth pulled. And for many patients in the Dallas area, facing Dickey and Wakefield literally means a tooth extraction.

headline: Q. and A. With Fox Soccer’s Eric Wynalda
text: Eric Wynalda, who scored the first goal of the 1994 World Cup for the United States, is now an analyst and commentator for Fox Soccer during the Concacaf Gold Cup. The tournament concludes Saturday night with the final between the United States and Mexico at the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif. (Fox Soccer, 9 p.m. Eastern) Wynalda, known for his forthright approach to the game and all things national team, spoke with Jack Bell of The New York Times about the United States’ play during the tournament and about the final.

headline: As a Source of Tennis Stars, Africa Runs Dry
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Brian de Villiers was in the player restaurant high above the grass courts here last week, leafing through the pages of a resort brochure from the scenic southern African country of Namibia.

headline: The Nightmare of the Airline Change Fee
text: IN our last episode, the Haggler tried, without success, to avoid the middle seat on two cross-country flights. The tale included a few examples of obnoxious passenger behavior — like tobacco-chewing — that provoked a whole lot of reader e-mail about similar instances of onboard incivility.

headline: For World Cup Host Germany, Diversity Is the Goal
text: Fatmire Bajramaj and her family fled to Germany from Kosovo as Yugoslavia broke apart in conflict in the early 1990s. She began playing soccer as a 6-year-old without her father’s knowledge or permission.

headline: Some Runners Choose Not to Wait for a Family
text: EUGENE, Ore. — After taking second place at the 10,000-meter race at the USA Track and Field Championships on Thursday, Kara Goucher took her 9-month-old son, Colt, from her husband’s arms and ran a victory lap with him around the track. He wore tiny gray Nike sneakers and sucked on his fingers.

headline: Former Yankee Karstens Hitting His Stride in Pittsburgh
text: In his second start for the Pittsburgh Pirates, in August 2008, Jeff Karstens took a perfect game into the eighth inning against Randy Johnson and the Arizona Diamondbacks. As his former Yankees teammates watched on television before their game at Texas, Karstens got two outs before a double ruined his attempt.

headline: Findings That May Get Lost
text: NEWS arrived last week that Morgan Keegan, a big name in what might be called Wall Street South, apparently duped investors in some of its mutual funds.

headline: Job Jugglers, on the Tightrope
text: WHEN someone asks Roger Fierro “What do you do?” — which he knows is shorthand for “Where do you work?” — he laughs. Then he says, “I do everything.”

headline: In Niger With Nicholas D. Kristof
text: Saumya Dave, win-a-trip winner, reflects on how the life of one woman living in Moli, Niger, impacted her.

headline: LVMH Chief Says Galliano Will Not Return
text: Bernard Arnault, the chairman of LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, said Saturday that John Galliano would not be working again for any of the luxury group’s brands, including the Galliano label. Mr. Arnault disputed comments made Friday that there had been informal conversations among LVMH executives about the feasibility of Mr. Galliano’s returning to his label at some point and what the media and public reaction might be.

headline: Higher Reserves Proposed for ‘Too Big to Fail’ Banks
text: After nearly two years of political jousting, a panel of global regulators said on Saturday that banks deemed too big to fail would have to set aside an additional cushion of capital reserves in what is the centerpiece of their efforts to avoid a repeat of the 2008 financial crisis.

headline: Two G.O.P. Hopefuls Divide the Voters in Deep-Pocketed Utah
text: SALT LAKE CITY — Two hugely popular political figures in Utah, Mitt Romney and Jon M. Huntsman Jr., are going fishing in this same small pond of a state, seeking financial support in their bids to become the Republican Party’s nominee for president next year.

headline: The Payroll Tax Needs a Vacation
text: THE federal budget deficit is a distraction.

headline: A Murder Trial as Tourist Draw in Central Florida
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — By the time Casey Anthony stepped into the courtroom here last week, her hair in a loose bun, the line of people outside determined to get a coveted ringside seat, with its close-up view of her, had swelled to 60.

headline: A Sitting Duck Can’t Catch a Moving Turkey
text: This interview with  John W. Rowe, chairman and C.E.O. of the Exelon Corporation, the electric utility, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Beyond Common Ground on Health Care Costs
text: Beyond Common Ground On Health Care Costs

headline: Our Geeks Are Better Than Your Geeks
text: ONE incompetent young salesman in a short-sleeved blue shirt. That’s about all Newegg, an online retailer, needed to create a hilarious parody commercial.

headline: That Family Work Ethic
text: MY dad used to call my siblings and me his “little army.” He relied on my four sisters, two brothers and me to help him with his dry cleaning stores in Louisville, Ky., where we were born and raised.

headline: Taking a Risk With Taliban Negotiations, Even if the Talks Are Real This Time
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s strategy for gradually ending the war in Afghanistan relies heavily on peace talks with the Taliban. But those talks have hardly begun, and even some administration officials acknowledge that the odds of success are slim.

headline: In Medicine, New Isn’t Always Improved
text: IT is an American impulse to covet the new and improved — whether it’s a faster computer, a smarter cellphone or a more fuel-efficient car. And in medicine, too, new drugs, devices and procedures have advanced patient care.

headline: Bitter Feud Between Top Iraqi Leaders Stalls Government
text: BAGHDAD — Fifteen months after an election that was supposed to lay the groundwork for Iraq’s future, the government remains virtually paralyzed by a clash between the country’s two most powerful politicians, who refuse to speak to each other.

headline: Shyness: Evolutionary Tactic?
text: A BEAUTIFUL woman lowers her eyes demurely beneath a hat. In an earlier era, her gaze might have signaled a mysterious allure. But this is a 2003 advertisement for Zoloft, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (S.S.R.I.) approved by the F.D.A. to treat social anxiety disorder. “Is she just shy? Or is it Social Anxiety Disorder?” reads the caption, suggesting that the young woman is not alluring at all. She is sick.

headline: What Would Nixon Do?
text: PRESIDENT OBAMA has made good on his pledge to begin drawing down American forces in Afghanistan, but his stated strategy is unlikely to lead to a successful withdrawal.

headline: Lessons in Communication, for Newspapers Themselves
text: AS journalists, we spend our lives communicating basic facts to the public, yet somehow we’ve done a poor job of communicating the basics of journalism itself. Its values. What news is and isn’t. Why journalism matters to the broader good. Why it’s the quality of journalism, not necessarily the quantity, that matters most — a notion that journalists have had a hard time communicating even to the executives of their own publicly held companies.

headline: Forces Make Arrests Across Syria; 5 Dead
text: ANTAKYA, Turkey — Syrian security forces arrested scores of people across the country on Saturday as mourners took part in the funerals of six protesters killed Friday outside of Damascus, continuing a grim pattern of protest, death, mourning and repression that has been repeated week after week as the uprising in Syria enters its fourth month.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,620 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following American on Friday:

headline: Into the Bustle of China’s Boom
text: I’M an architect in the Seattle office of NBBJ, an international design firm. In the fall of 2007, the partners asked me to transfer to our office in Shanghai for two years. We were designing a research and development building in Beijing for an American technology company. Another employee who had been managing the office and overseeing the project was returning home in 2008.

headline: Foreclosed Home Is a Risky Move for Homeless Family
text: In a giggly voice, a small homeless girl with blue-framed glasses chased her younger brother and sister around the front porch of a long-deserted two-flat on the South Side, chanting, “Fight, fight, fight, ’cause housing is a human right.”

headline: How to Break an Information Bottleneck?
text: ON his first full day in office, President Obama aimed a blowtorch at federal agencies that try to keep information on ice.

headline: After the Storm, a Sense of Neighborhood Reaffirmed
text: Less than 30 minutes from downtown by Metra express train, Mount Prospect is popular with many of its roughly 54,000 residents because it has little of the violent crime, low standardized test scores and official corruption that attract news-media attention.

headline: Cuomo’s Presidential Moment Forms Contrast With Obama
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York had help in securing passage of the bill that will provide for equal treatment of same-sex couples under New York’s marriage law. Public opinion on the issue is shifting rapidly: 58 percent of New Yorkers support same-sex marriage today compared with 37 percent in 2004. Many allies were at work on the cause, from gay rights groups to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to the pop star Lady Gaga, who at a concert in Buffalo urged her fans to lobby the freshman State Senator Mark J. Grisanti, a Republican, to vote for the bill. (Mr. Gristani, initially considered a strong “no” vote, was one of four Republicans to support the measure.)

headline: When a Terrorist Wants to Buy a Gun
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: A Troubled High School Celebrates a Milestone
text: Standing in the hallway of Austin Polytech, Stran’Ja Burge, 18, adjusted her burgundy graduation cap and shifted her weight restlessly from one foot to the other. Her four-year-old high school was about to graduate its first senior class, but for Ms. Burge, the end of high school had still not registered.

headline: The Zen of Shawn Green
text: Shawn Green, a former outfielder, looked trim and fit while standing in the Mets’ dugout before a game a few weeks ago. Green is just 38, but he retired after the 2007 season, when he hit .291.

headline: Scorecard | Givenchy Wins!
text: Shirtdress-length shirts, man boob tops, and OshKosh B’Gosh getups for outer borough gentleman-farmer types: as Cathy Horyn noted, Friday was a good day for men’s fashion in Paris. So who made the most successful gender play? Fashion’s Rottweiler Riccardo Tisci may have traded in the teeth-bared prints from last season, but Scorecard observes his new floral motif at Givenchy still seemed to have bite.

headline: A Solitary Victory for Fish at Wimbledon
text: WIMBLEDON, England — If Mardy Fish were in a band, he would be the drummer. It’s his tennis play, much more than his personality, that demands notice. He assured himself of undivided attention in the United States by becoming the only American man to advance to the second week of Wimbledon.

headline: At Clerks’ Offices, Girding for More Weddings
text: ALBANY — From City Hall in Manhattan to rural hamlets upstate, New York officials began to prepare on Saturday for a surge in gay couples expected to flood clerks’ offices next month seeking to marry.

headline: Exemptions Were Key to Vote on Gay Marriage
text: ALBANY — It was just a few paragraphs, but they proved to be the most microscopically examined and debated — and the most pivotal — in the battle over same-sex marriage.

headline: Putting the Library on Your Smartphone
text: APPS NYPL Mobile, Biblion, Find the Future

headline: Top Ten Fantasy Running Backs
text: Arian Foster tops our list of fantasy football running backs for the 2011 season.

headline: Hispanic Star and New District Threaten Doggett
text: Representative Lloyd Doggett, the nine-term, liberal Austin congressman, foiled Republicans’ efforts to redistrict him out of office in 2003 and intends to do it again in 2012, living “in a Winnebago, if that’s what it takes,” to vie for a newly-drawn district that encompasses San Antonio’s most Democratic and Hispanic neighborhoods and spreads up to southern Travis County.

headline: Shift the Astros, and a Real Rivalry May Be Born
text: Jason Cohen wrote this column for the Texas Report.

headline: Sharapova Travels With Her Net
text: WIMBLEDON, England — The Nets’ failure to make the playoffs for a fifth consecutive season was not all bad. It allowed Maria Sharapova to be reunited with her fiancé, Sasha Vujacic, a New Jersey guard, who traveled with her to the French Open and Wimbledon.

headline: Third-Party Groups Take Up Challenge of How Best to Improve Public Universities
text: For years, Gov. Rick Perry’s efforts to increase efficiency and productivity at public universities — largely by pressuring university system officials to carry out specific changes proposed by the Texas Public Policy Foundation, a conservative research group — were mostly conducted out of the public eye.

headline: In World of Politics, Limits to Aggie Solidarity
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: How Youzhny Defeated Almagro
text: Mikhail Youzhny advanced to a Round of 16 match with Roger Federer by convincingly defeating Nicolas Almagro, 4-6, 6-3, 7-6, 6-3, on Saturday at Wimbledon. On a sunny, breezy day on Court 18, they each competed at a high level, but Youzhny was mentally stronger, playing with unwavering concentration, bearing down especially hard on his service games. Remarkably, he was not broken in the last three sets.

headline: Sabathia’s Dominance Lets the Yankees Focus on Their Offense in a Victory
text: Here came Alex Rodriguez, audaciously rumbling home on a fly ball hit by Nick Swisher that was not all that deep. Rodriguez safely slid headfirst into home plate, gathering dirt on the front of his uniform and robust applause from the big crowd at Yankee Stadium on Saturday.

headline: In Uganda, a Bitter Rivalry Is Played Out on the National Stage
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — Like many war stories, this one began with love.

headline: A Gangster’s Gal Was Loyal to the End of Life on the Run
text: From an early age, Catherine Elizabeth Greig knew the life of a moll. By about 20, she had married a Boston firefighter named Bobby McGonagle, joining a family with close ties to a gang that was part of the Irish mafia in their South Boston neighborhood. Violence and shootouts were not uncommon as gangs warred for control of the rackets.

headline: First a Gold Rush, Then the Lawyers
text: SAN ISIDRO, El Salvador — When a Central American gold rush brought a Canadian mining company here a few years ago, the company promised to stake a claim that would be as green as the lush hills.

headline: Dog Provides Inspiration for Fish
text: WIMBLEDON, England — It was worth the jet lag and the hassle of two transatlantic journeys for Mardy Fish to be able to spend time with his baby on her second birthday. Her name is Charlie and she’s a dachshund that Fish, who is married to the Beverly Hills lawyer Stacey Gardner, described as “kind of like a child for us.”

headline: Randall Adams, 61, Dies; Freed With Help of Film
text: Randall Dale Adams, who spent 12 years in prison before his conviction in the murder of a Dallas police officer was thrown out largely on the basis of evidence uncovered by a filmmaker, died in obscurity in October in Washington Court House, Ohio. He was 61.

headline: More on Our Encounter with Hunger
text: My Sunday column is about the crisis in world food prices — told through our Win-a-Trip journey to a village in southern Niger, where we ran into a woman who was literally starving. As I note in the column, the student winner of the trip, Saumya Dave, was quite properly distressed. Here’s what she wrote down about the encounter:

headline: Documents: Leaked Industry E-Mails and Reports
text: Over the past six months, The Times reviewed thousands of pages of documents related to shale gas, including hundreds of industry e-mails, internal agency documents and analyst reports. A selection is included here.

headline: Mike Waterson, Member of British Folk Troupe, Dies at 70
text: Mike Waterson, a founding member of the Watersons, the self-taught singing group that was long considered the royal family of British folk music, died in England on Wednesday. He was 70.

headline: Spotlight on the Gay Community Today
text: More visible, diverse and complex than ever, the Bay Area’s gay population is evolving. To understand these changes, a number of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender locals shared their thoughts on what unites, divides and defines the gay community today.

headline: Celebration of Gay Pride Masks Community in Transition
text: Scott James writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Guidelines to Manners for Today
text: As gay people and issues have become more visible on the American landscape, social etiquette has been scrambling to catch up.

headline: Sunday: T Mobile
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — I don’t know about you, but I have a distinct preference for the punny. Yes, it’s the lowest form of humor. Yes, we are so much more intellectual than that, with our fancy schmancy “only doing The New York Times crossword in ink on Saturdays in Latin.”

headline: Building Boom in Gaza’s Ruins Belies Misery That Remains
text: GAZA — Two luxury hotels are opening in Gaza this month. Thousands of new cars are plying the roads. A second shopping mall — with escalators imported from Israel — will open next month. Hundreds of homes and two dozen schools are about to go up. A Hamas-run farm where Jewish settlements once stood is producing enough fruit that Israeli imports are tapering off.

headline: There Goes a Piece of the Old Neighborhood, Again
text: WHAT many natives of the West 70s and 80s have long prophesied has come to pass: The neighborhood is finished.

headline: Lisicki Wins With Perspective
text: Sabine Lisicki faced a tough opponent and a dangerous set of circumstances when she took the court Saturday against Misaki Doi of Japan. Coming off of a big win over Li Na on Center Court just two days before, Lisicki now faced Doi, a lefty from Japan who had come through the qualifying at Roehampton.

headline: Avedon, Breaking Through the Artifice of Celebrity
text: Among the anecdotes circulated about the legendary photographer Richard Avedon (1923-2004) is one involving the Duke and Duchess of Windsor — that is, King Edward VIII of England and Wallis Simpson, the American divorcée he married after abdicating the throne.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Grading a High School
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Tax Break on Foreign Profits
text: To the Editor:

headline: Medicaid in Illinois
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sunday Dialogue: The Battle Lines Over Libya
text: As Americans ask pointed questions about our military actions overseas, a letter on Wednesday asked, “What would George W. Bush do?” Not surprisingly, that set off a spirited debate.

headline: On NYTimes.com, Now You See It, Now You Don’t
text: WHEN Jill Abramson  takes over as the new executive editor at the end of the summer, The New York Times that she oversees will be a very different organization than it was when she joined it 14 years ago.

headline: The State of Unemployment
text: Americans are out of work. Who is listening?

headline: Marvel Superheroes and the Fathers of Invention
text: The comic book industry began life in the early 20th century as the province of con men who stripped artists of their creations, then moved on to the next mark. The artists who were paid virtually nothing for work on characters that are now worth billions at the movies are nearly all dead. But their heirs are beginning to speak for them through a federal copyright law that practically invites descendants to sue for ownership interests in characters whose current value could never have been imagined at the moment of creation.

headline: Tapping the Oil Reserve
text: We have never been enthusiastic about quick fixes. But the Obama administration’s decision to release 30 million barrels of oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve — the nation’s emergency stockpiles — makes sense.

headline: Whose Stimulus?
text: Big businesses are telling Washington that they are willing to do their bit for the economy — if the price is right. Multinational companies say they could repatriate hundreds of billions in foreign profits and pump them into domestic investment and hiring, but only if Congress and the White House agree to cut the tax rate on those profits to 5.25 percent from 35 percent. They call their plan “the next stimulus.” Sounds more like extortion.

headline: Wait Wait ... Don’t Tell Me!
text: NPR’s “Wait Wait... Don’t Tell Me!” is heard weekends on public radio stations across the country. (npr.org/programs/wait-wait-dont-tell-me/)

headline: It’s Science, but Not Necessarily Right
text: ONE of the great strengths of science is that it can fix its own mistakes. “There are many hypotheses in science which are wrong,” the astrophysicist Carl Sagan once said. “That’s perfectly all right: it’s the aperture to finding out what’s right. Science is a self-correcting process.”

headline: Before U.S. vs. Mexico, a Salute to Fans
text: PASADENA, Calf. — Hey, everyone, as I’m sure all of you are aware, tonight is the final of the Gold Cup. And it promises to be another epic battle between the United States and Mexico.

headline: Got Twitter? You’ve Been Scored
text: IMAGINE a world in which we are assigned a number that indicates how influential we are. This number would help determine whether you receive a job, a hotel-room upgrade or free samples at the supermarket. If your influence score is low, you don’t get the promotion, the suite or the complimentary cookies.

headline: Even for Cashiers, College Pays Off
text: ALMOST a century ago, the United States decided to make high school nearly universal. Around the same time, much of Europe decided that universal high school was a waste. Not everybody, European intellectuals argued, should go to high school.

headline: The Phony Tough-on-Terror Crowd
text: Republicans and Democrats are championing bills to further militarize the prosecution of terrorists, beyond anything even President George W. Bush proposed.

headline: Face to Face With a Mother’s Pain
text: SAY, Niger

headline: It Has to Start With Them
text: WHEN President Obama announced his decision to surge more troops into Afghanistan in 2009, I argued that it could succeed if three things happened: Pakistan became a different country, President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan became a different man and we succeeded at doing exactly what we claim not to be doing, that is nation-building in Afghanistan. None of that has happened, which is why I still believe our options in Afghanistan are: lose early, lose late, lose big or lose small. I vote for early and small.

headline: To Know Us Is to Let Us Love
text: IN the mid-1980s, when I was in college, what concerned and frustrated my peers and me was how few states had basic statutes forbidding discrimination against gay men and lesbians: laws that merely prevented someone from being denied a job or apartment on the basis of whom he or she loved. At that point only Wisconsin and the District of Columbia provided such protection. The decade would end with just one addition, Massachusetts, to that meager list.

headline: Why Is He Bi? (Sigh)
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Oil Oozes Through Your Life
text: WHEN whales were an important energy source back in the 18th and 19th centuries, whalers made sure to use every last part of each one, given how difficult they were to kill. The blubber was boiled into oil for heat and light; the bones refashioned into women’s corsets; the teeth sold for scrimshaw carvings; the sperm reserved for cosmetics and other uses. “Such a sweetener! Such a softener! Such a delicious molifier!” — as Herman Melville’s narrator puts it in “Moby Dick.”

headline: Is This Our Future?
text: THE moment I realized that driving the new Chevrolet Volt was fundamentally a new experience was not when I first turned it on and went around the block. Yes, it was whisper-quiet, powered by its 16-kilowatt-hour, 400-pound battery, but it still felt like a “normal” automobile. And it wasn’t when I drove the 100 or so miles from Manhattan to Southampton, N.Y., either. Although the battery’s range is only about 40 miles, the car kept going even after the battery was drained; it just switched to its gasoline engine, in a transition so seamless I barely noticed it. It wasn’t even when I arrived in Southampton that evening and plugged a special cord into an electrical outlet in the garage, to recharge the battery overnight.

headline: Fifth Avenue, 5:50 P.M.
text: A photograph of the Dyke Parade on Fifth Avenue.

headline: To Our Readers
text: This is the first issue of the Sunday Review, a new section that replaces the Week in Review. It features news analysis from Times reporters and opinion writing from our columnists, as well as essays and reported opinion pieces from outside contributors. We hope you enjoy the changes, and if you have criticisms, thoughts or suggestions, please get in touch with us at oped@nytimes.com. — The Editors
