headline: Wisconsin Judge Said to Have Attacked Colleague
text: CHICAGO — That the members of the Wisconsin Supreme Court were deeply divided has hardly been a secret of late. When the justices this month decided a law curtailing collective bargaining rights for public workers should come into effect, one of the dissenting justices openly accused the other side of a “partisan slant.”

headline: Why College Brings a Huge Return
text: My column in the Sunday Review section makes the case for going to college and cites two just-released reports, one by two Georgetown University researchers and the other by two Hamilton Project researchers. Each report has some charts worth reproducing.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Hermès
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#961", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

headline: Where Fashion Types Talk of Summer Travel
text: Open less than a year, the Lambs Club in the lobby of the Chatwal Hotel has become a go-to lunch spot for the fashion set and the news media that cover them. Nestled along 44th Street east of Broadway and not far from the Royalton, where the chef Geoffrey Zakarian fed a similar crowd back in the late 1980s, the stylish black-and-red Art Deco room is named for the theatrical club once housed in the building. It draws a chatty, buzzy scene of executives from labels as diverse as American Apparel and Nina Ricci along with a variety of editors and writers. On Wednesday, a designer and an editor discussed plans for a store opening, vacations and what to do on Fashion’s Night Out. DIANE CARDWELL

headline: Ready, Set, Summer! A Guide
text: JESSICA LATHAM and Annabel Linquist, sleeveless and sun-kissed — their cheeks flushed and lightly freckled and their noses peeling just so — sipped rosé by the bar of Eataly’s Birreria, looking like the very picture of summer.

headline: Quickie Rentals
Photos of the Moment | Dior Homme
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#0", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

headline: Mets Trounce Rangers, but Niese Exits Early
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — His team had just scored eight runs in the top of the sixth inning on the way to a breezy victory on a sizzling hot day, so when Jon Niese’s heart began to race and he had difficulty catching his breath on the mound, there was no need to battle his way through it.

headline: Canadian Junior Leagues Still Proving to Be Best Path to the Draft
text: What young prospects do N.H.L. general managers find desirable this summer? In descending order: Canadians, Swedes and Americans.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Atop TV Sets, a Power Drain That Runs Nonstop
text: Those little boxes that usher cable signals and digital recording capacity into televisions have become the single largest electricity drain in many American homes, with some typical home entertainment configurations eating more power than a new refrigerator and even some central air-conditioning systems.

headline: Sudden Inspection at Gay Bar Mars Victory Celebration for Some
text: An unannounced inspection that several agencies carried out at a gay bar in Manhattan on Friday night occurred at nearly the same time that patrons were celebrating the passage of legislation in Albany legalizing same-sex marriage.

headline: New York International Event Gives Local Players a Leg Up
text: In its first three years, the New York International tournament provided local players with opportunities to earn norms for titles, sometimes while beating strong grandmasters.

headline: Thoughts on Gay Marriage in New York
text: People in Central Park react to the passage of the same-sex marriage bill in New York.

headline: Insiders Sound an Alarm Amid a Natural Gas Rush
text: Natural gas companies have been placing enormous bets on the wells they are drilling, saying they will deliver big profits and provide a vast new source of energy for the United States.

headline: Romney Leads in Iowa Poll
text: The first credible snapshot of the state of play in the Republican presidential campaign in Iowa shows that Mitt Romney and Michele Bachmann have the strongest support in the state that will open the nominating contest.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 26
text: This week the Sunday talk shows will briefly address recent developments in the 2012 campaign before delving into the planned troop drawdown in Afghanistan. Guests will also discuss how Congress can address the debt ceiling before it’s too late, while salvaging the weakened economy in the meantime.

headline: Hacking Group Lulz Security Says It Is Ending Spree
text: 10:26 p.m. | Updated Adding background on Ryan Cleary, whom the British police arrested this week and linked to Lulz Security.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Bridge Comes to San Francisco With a Made-in-China Label
text: SHANGHAI — Talk about outsourcing.

headline: Battle for Libya | June 25, 2011
text: Rebels in Zintan celebrated the defection of soccer players on the national team.

headline: Problem: Rock. Solution: Hold On Tight.
text: The Unified Bouldering Championships Pro Rock Climbing Finals came to Central Park, with climbers competing for a $50,000 purse.

headline: Photo Replay: June 25
text: The day in sports included plenty of drama from the conclusion of Wimbledon’s first week, as well as the U.S. Track and Field Championships and M.L.B. action.

headline: In an Early 2-0 Hole, Mexico Storms Back to Win the Gold Cup
text: PASADENA, Calif. — There was no shortage of memorable moments in Mexico’s 4-2 victory over the United States in the final of the Concacaf Gold Cup on Saturday night. None better epitomized the thrilling game — and the Americans’ defensive shortcomings — than Mexico’s fourth goal, which salted away the title and a place in the 2013 Confederations Cup in Brazil.

headline: Prominent Chinese Dissident Hu Jia Is Released From Jail
text: BEIJING — Hu Jia, one of China’s most prominent social activists and a leading political dissident, was released from prison on Sunday after completing a 42-month sentence for state subversion,  his wife, Zeng Jinyan, stated in a post on the American microblog Twitter.

headline: Evils of Access
text: Still on the road, and internet access was just terrible yesterday. Also, traveling all day Monday. Life as we know it should resume Tuesday.

headline: Wrong Wrong Wrong
text: Bruce Bartlett points out something I had forgotten: the 1993 Clinton tax increase wasn’t the first time conservatives predicted doom from any rise in tax rates. They did the same in response to the Reagan tax hike of 1982 — and yes, the sainted Reagan, after cutting taxes at the beginning, raised them repeatedly thereafter.

headline: Monetary Policy in a Balance Sheet Recession (Wonkish)
text: I agree with David Beckworth that Richard Koo is wrong to insist that monetary policy can’t do anything in a balance sheet recession. But I think Beckworth introduces unnecessary complications; also, Koo isn’t entirely wrong.

headline: After Loss to Mexico, U.S. Moves Uncertainly Ahead
text: Surrendering four consecutive goals with a tattered defense, the United States squandered a chance to defeat Mexico in the Gold Cup final on Saturday night and missed out on a crucial dress rehearsal for the 2014 World Cup.

headline: The Mafia Multiplier
text: Attempts to infer the effects of fiscal policy from local variations in spending suffer from the absence of clean experiments: if spending rose more or fell less in one state or metropolitan area than another, how much is due to factors that are correlated with other things determining the effect of recession and recovery.

headline: In Paris, a Festival for Food Lovers
text: On July 1, the French gastronomic group Le Fooding will be celebrating summer with a butcher, a baker and a macaron maker at their annual Bazarette du Fooding, a collection of food and drink purveyors.

headline: Top 10 Guards in N.F.L.
text: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely -– but not strictly -– by film study of all 32 teams from the 2010 season. Stats weren’t acknowledged, but players with poor numbers generally don’t make top 10 lists anyway. Vague enough for you? Criteria for top 10 lists tend to be. That’s why most of you will have no trouble finding some disagreement with what you’re about to read.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S. vs. Mexico
text: Twenty-two minutes into Saturday night’s Gold Cup Final, Bob Bradley looked to be the smartest coach in the hemisphere, and the United States national team seemed ready to stake its claim as the dominant soccer force in the region.

headline: Vettel Walks Over Everyone Again to Win in Valencia
text: VALENCIA, Spain – Sebastian Vettel dominated the European Grand Prix in Valencia the way he has dominated the season: Cruising to his sixth victory in eight races.

headline: Vettel Walks Over Everyone Again to Win in Valencia
text: VALENCIA, Spain – Sebastian Vettel dominated the European Grand Prix in Valencia the way he has dominated the season: Cruising to his sixth victory in eight races.

headline: In Minot, N.D., Flood Waters Stop Rising
text: MINOT, N.D. — The flooded Souris River stopped rising on Sunday after spreading across much of this city’s downtown, submerging homes up to the roofs, and displacing more than a quarter of the population.

headline: English Verities
text: Also, an adorable rehearsal for evensong in the cathedral.

headline: Sometimes Even the Lulls Are Full of Action
text: A quartet under Mark Turner’s name started an early set on Tuesday night at the Village Vanguard with some standards: Thelonious Monk’s “Crepuscule With Nellie” and Bud Powell’s “Dance of the Infidels.” Not long after the beginning, the music started to change from the inside out: known structures, unknown contents. And after that it became even less traceable.

headline: Not-A Does Not Imply B
text: Just a thought suggested by some economic discussions I’ve followed, including the comments on this blog: many people seem to have a hard time accepting that there are intermediate positions, in particular that you can question free-market, hard-money dogma without being a wild man. To say that some inflation can sometimes be a good thing does not mean advocating hyperinflation; to call for deficit spending in slumps does not mean saying that debt and deficits never matter; and so on.

headline: Afghan Girl Tricked Into Carrying Bomb, Officials Say
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Insurgents tricked an 8-year-old girl in a remote area of central Afghanistan into carrying a bomb wrapped in cloth that they detonated remotely when she was close to a police vehicle, the Afghan authorities said Sunday.

headline: 2 Roads Diverged in an Iowa Cornfield …
text: The results from this morning’s Des Moines Register Iowa Poll are being interpreted as bad news for Tim Pawlenty, who has 6 percent of the vote despite his focus on the state. But Mr. Pawlenty’s numbers are not quite as bad as advertised.

headline: At Mass, Archbishop Is Silent on Same-Sex Marriage
text: Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan did not exactly hide his opposition to efforts to legalize same-sex marriage in New York.

headline: Paris Men’s: Peeling Down for Spring
text: Like most creative people, designers have to clear their heads now and then. Raf Simons reduced his collection to the essentials of contemporary men’s dressing. Even so, you would recognize the Raf silhouette anywhere; that’s part of his power. In recent years he has acknowledged a more mature customer by paying close attention to cut, quality fabrics and details.

headline: Murray vs. Gasquet Promises Emotion and Plenty of Strategy
text: Andy Murray faces Richard Gasquet in the first match of the second week of Wimbledon on Monday. The two played an epic five setter three years ago, when Murray came from two sets down to win before a boisterous Centre Court crowd. Gasquet wilted in that match, as Murray’s superior conditioning became evident in the fourth and fifth sets.

headline: This May Be Something Completely Different
text: LOS ANGELES — You can kill him, cremate him and (ostensibly) kick his ashes around the stage at a comedy festival in Aspen.

headline: Reports on the Amtrak Crash in Nevada
text: Updated | 5:05 p.m. Investigators were examining the wreckage Sunday after a tractor-trailer plowed through railroad gates into an Amtrak train at a crossing early Friday in Nevada, killing at least six people and leaving at least 28 people unaccounted for.

headline: Paris Top 5 | Louis Vuitton
text: Kim Jones, in his first men’s collection for Louis Vuitton, drew upon his African upbringing for this travel-minded collection. The classic Damier checked pattern was given a jolt of color inspired by the Masai tribe in bright red and blue shirts, knits and scarves. A waterproof bonded silk drawstring jacket was paired with cashmere jersey shorts and sweatshirt for a medal winning look worthy of this house of luxury goods.

headline: French E. Coli Episode Seems Isolated, Officials Say
text: BRUSSELS — The French authorities said Sunday that the latest outbreak of a deadly strain of E. coli in Europe appeared to be isolated, even as European Union officials discussed wider action to restrict sales of bean sprouts, the suspected cause of the outbreak.

headline: Recalling First Black Appointed to New York Police Dept.
text: His parents were among the last generation born into Southern slavery, and his own birth in 1883 was notable for another benchmark: At 16 pounds, he was the biggest baby ever recorded in North Carolina.

headline: A Demographic Gray (or Graying) Lures TV Industry
text: Last Sunday, the TV show “My Generation,” which runs weekly on PBS, lost the daytime Emmy for outstanding lifestyle programming. Its competition was fierce: “The Nate Berkus Show,” from Oprah’s home design guy; the Style Network’s “How Do I Look?” and “The Martha Stewart Show,” which took home the trophy. But for “My Generation,” a show created by AARP, and aimed at viewers 50 and older, it was truly an honor just to be nominated.

headline: Amid Criticism, a Fast Start for ‘Cars 2’
text: Pixar’s “Cars 2” overcame surprisingly negative critical reviews to overperform at the weekend box office, selling an estimated $68 million at North American theaters. That No. 1 finish extends Pixar’s perfect box-office track record — all 12 of its feature films have opened in first place. How sales hold up, however, will be watched carefully. “Cars 2,” directed by John Lasseter, chief creative officer at Pixar, represents an end to the studio’s perfect critical track record; only about 34 percent of reviews were positive, according to RottenTomatoes.com, by far the worst for any Pixar title.The R-rated comedy “Bad Teacher” (Sony Pictures Entertainment) was a stronger-than-expected second with about $31 million in ticket sales — a result that cements mega-raunchy films as one of Hollywood’s best performers of the moment. “Green Lantern” (Warner Brothers) fell 65 percent in its second weekend to third place, taking in about $18.4 million for a new total of $89 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing statistics. “Super 8” (Paramount Pictures) continued to show strength in its third weekend, selling about $12 million for a new total of $95 million. “Mr. Popper’s Penguins” (20th Century Fox) was fifth with about $10.3 million for a two-week total of $39.4 million.

headline: … And in Other Soccer Action: The Galaxy’s Accidental Goalkeeper
text: … And in other soccer action on Saturday … no one will ever mistake Mike Magee for one of the great goalkeepers of Europe, the United States or anyplace else guys wear grotesquely padded gloves, stand between two posts and try to stop powerful shots launched at their heads.

headline: How Fast Should Your Camera’s Memory Card Be?
text: When you are shopping for a camera memory card, faster is better, right?

headline: U.S. Plans Stealth Survey on Access to Doctors
text: WASHINGTON — Alarmed by a shortage of primary care doctors, Obama administration officials are recruiting a team of “mystery shoppers” to pose as patients, call doctors’ offices and request appointments to see how difficult it is for people to get care when they need it.

headline: The Financiers Who Helped Back N.Y. Gay Marriage Campaign
text: Much of the attention around the legalization of same-sex marriage in New York has revolved around the back-room politicking involved: the deals, the cajoling, the organizing.

headline: Money May Not Buy You Love, but It Might Help You Land a Spouse
text: What should Daisy Goodwin have called her novel about a Gilded Age Newport belle who heads for England to marry her way into a title? It was published in Britain as “My Last Duchess,” since it makes abundant reference to the chilling Robert Browning poem of that name. Now, for American readers, it has been given a forgettably bland name: “The American Heiress.” A hybrid of the two, “The American Duchess,” would have better described what Ms. Goodwin’s sly, glittery period piece is about.

headline: Cheering a Gay Marriage Law, and Its Champions
text: Two days after New York became the sixth and largest state to legalize same-sex marriage, participants in the 42nd annual gay pride parade on Sunday used the occasion to reflect somberly on the gains and losses of the past year.

headline: Left-Handers Have Edge in Slice and Singularity
text: WIMBLEDON, England — At half past noon on Sunday, there was a scene at the All England Club’s Aorangi Park usually seen once every blue moon: four left-handers hitting on three adjacent practice courts.

headline: Fog Blurs Vision, and Lines, Between Performer and Audience
text: It was dark, and the air hummed with something ominous. A thick fog pressed in and the crowd, with a mix of familiar and unknown faces, was all made strange and a little sinister by the impenetrable haze. We were at “Amidst,” a new work by Pavel Zustiak, that is as much about the watchers as the watched.

headline: Google’s War on Nonsense
text: Imagine a sci-fi universe in which every letter, word and sentence is a commodity. Companies make money off chunks of language. Bosses drive writers to make more words faster and for less pay. Readers then pay for exposure to these cheaply made words in the precious currency of their attention.

headline: Sometimes Pop Songs Double as Prayers
text: Milton Nascimento, the singer and songwriter who is one of Brazil’s national treasures, played up his jazzy side on Friday night at the Rose Theater, the home of Jazz at Lincoln Center. That’s the facet of his songwriting that smoothly and stealthily poses and solves musical challenges: how to make odd meters strut like a samba, how to make a chromatic labyrinth sound like a promenade. It’s the kind of craftsmanship that has earned him admiring collaborators like Paul Simon and Wayne Shorter.

headline: Perdue Goes to the Farm With an Earnest Approach
text: ADVERTISING for Perdue Farms is no longer strictly a family affair.

headline: The Textbooks Were Right, Well, at Least This Time
text: When the final day — 58 boards — began in the Mixed Pairs at the fifth European Open Championships in Poznan, Poland, on Thursday, Anna Zack Einarsson and Bengt-Erik Efraimsson from Sweden had a comfortable lead. But they had 24 under-average boards, including three zeros. This allowed Magdalena Ticha and Richard Ritmeijer from the Netherlands and Catherine d’Ovidio and Philippe Cronier from France to move into contention.

headline: Songs of a Doubting Thomas at Bowery Ballroom
text: In the years since the dissolution of the Christian-themed indie rock band Pedro the Lion, its singer David Bazan has been a regular on the house-show circuit, popping up in someone’s living room for a night for audiences of a few dozen.

headline: Companies Are Erecting In-House Social Networks
text: What would Facebook look like without photos of drunken nights out and tales of misbehaving cats? It might look a lot like the internal social network at the offices of Nikon Instruments.

headline: Collaboration at 72 Beats Per Minute
text: “I’m supposed to remind you at this portion of the show that I’m a composer,” John Moran announced just over halfway through “John Moran + Saori (... in Thailand),” the 2010 piece he presented in its New York premiere at the Issue Project Room in Brooklyn on Friday evening, and repeated on Saturday. Anyone new to Mr. Moran’s work probably welcomed an explanation; up to that point, little about his performance with the dancer Saori Tsukada had registered as music by any conventional notion.

text: Morningside Park

text: Abrons Arts Center

headline: Comedian, Chastened, Gets Back to Laughs
text: About halfway through a raucous standup set on Saturday night in which he dispensed much unsolicited romantic advice and hit on several women seated near the stage, Tracy Morgan told the crowd at Carolines, the Times Square comedy club, he knew what it wanted to hear.

headline: Monday: Celebrity Guest Solver Joel Stein
text: Administrivial Disappearing Comments Update: My apologies for the disappearing comments. I’ve found them, and wouldn’t you know, they’re always in the last place you look. A new system had been put in place and it was sending some of the comments on walkabout. After an epic battle, in which I wielded both power tools and my magic bullet-proof bracelets, that system has been shut down, so we should be back to normal. Thank you for your patience.

headline: Sailing a Saucy Ship Into Bel Canto Seas
text: KATONAH, N.Y. — What’s wrong with this picture? Since 1997 the Caramoor International Music Festival has presented an opera series devoted to the bel canto repertory, with an emphasis on Rossini, Donizetti, Bellini and Verdi. Neither its name (Bel Canto at Caramoor) nor its mission has changed, but when the series and the festival opened on Saturday evening, the work at hand was Gilbert and Sullivan’s “H.M.S. Pinafore or The Lass That Loved a Sailor.”

headline: A Decent Proposal
text: Supporters of same-sex marriage say gay people are entitled to be fully equal citizens, including in their yearning to make families. Opponents say the state has no business bestowing the blessings of marriage on those who do not fit the traditional template.

headline: Scorecard | Raf Simons Wins!
text: It’s a truism that in Paris suits are not for Suits, which Scorecard knows was exemplified Saturday by Kris Van Assche’s whiteout of superskinny-lapel jackets and dropped-crotch high-waters accessorized with wide-brimmed toppers on the Dior Homme runway. Too bad, then, that Raf Simons had to make it all look literally old hat with his witty display of that creative industry favorite — plaid — in a former bank headquarters. It might just be hip to be square.

headline: Raves for ‘Superstar’
text: With the musicals “Sister Act” and “The Book of Mormon” now singing to the heavens on Broadway, and a revival of “Godspell” set to join them this fall, is there room in the congregation for a fourth musical with strong spiritual underpinnings? In Ontario, the Stratford Shakespeare Festival’s new revival of “Jesus Christ Superstar,” the 1971 rock opera by Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice about the last week of Jesus’ life, has received rave reviews from local theater critics, prompting New York producers and other critics to book flights to Toronto for a look. Mr. Lloyd Webber, who holds the rights to mount a Broadway revival, saw the production this month and called it “fabulous,” adding that it was “very probably the best acted performance of the show I have ever seen.” Mr. Rice has also seen it, adding to the buzz that the production might have a life beyond Stratford. The director, Des McAnuff, who is also artistic director of the festival, said in a telephone interview that “we’re definitely taking calls from New York and elsewhere about having a future elsewhere, but it’s very much an open question.” Asked about a transfer to Broadway, Mr. McAnuff said, “We would of course love to move this and love an opportunity to take our Stratford company members with us if we go.”

headline: AMC Chief Responds to ‘Killing’ Complaints
text: The president of the cable channel AMC said he didn’t regret the cliffhanger ending of “The Killing” a week ago but admitted there was a lesson to be learned. “We underestimated the passion” viewers have for closure within a season, Charlie Collier  told Entertainment Weekly on Friday. “If I could do anything differently, it would be to manage expectations.” Many fans of “The Killing” (with Mireille Enos, above), which is about an investigation into the death of a teenage girl in Seattle, were left fuming when the first season ended on June 19 without an explanation for the crime. The anger was noticeable on social media Web sites, prompting Mr. Collier’s acknowledgment. “The audience has an important voice, we heard them and don’t take them for granted,” he said. Mr. Collier said he stood by the show’s executive producer, Veena Sud, who told the public radio show “The Business,” last week that the investigation would be resolved in Season 2. Ms. Sud recounted a conversation on one Web site that had a viewer declaring, “I’ll never ever come back for season two.” She said, “On the same thread three more people popped up and said: ‘I haven’t watched this show yet, but now I will because you guys are so emotional about it, it’s gotta be something to watch.’ So that’s a great thing.”

headline: Women’s Project Announces Lineup
text: A new play by Catherine Trieschmann will headline the 2011-12 Women’s Project lineup, the theater company announced. “How the World Began” focuses on a teacher in rural Kansas whose comments about the origins of the universe have unforeseen consequences. Directed by Daniella Topol (“Dead City”), the play is the follow-up to the highly praised “Crooked,” Ms. Trieschmann’s previous collaboration with Women’s Project. The season will begin in October with Rebecca Taichman’s production of “Milk Like Sugar” by Kirsten Greenidge (“Bossa Nova”), followed by “How the World Began,” and “We Play for the Gods,” which features contributions from 16 artists, connecting theater history with the current vision of the Women’s Project Lab.

headline: Shareholders Push Tepco to Abandon Nuclear Power
text: Masafumi Asada bought shares of the Tokyo Electric Power Company almost a decade ago with a single purpose: To vote against the use of nuclear power.

headline: Bollywood Honors
text: “Dabangg,” an action musical about a corrupt police officer, dominated the International Indian Film Academy awards, Bollywood’s version of the Oscars, over the weekend. Directed by Abhinav Kashyap, above left, and starring Salman Khan, the film won six awards, including best picture, The Associated Press reported. The ceremony, part of a three-day event, took place for the first time in North America; more than 22,000 fanspacked the Rogers Center in Toronto.

headline: Talk of President Cuomo? 2016 Is a Long Way Off
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo took the hero’s stroll down Fifth Avenue Sunday, his reception from the Gay Pride masses somewhere between loving and rapturous. And who could argue?

headline: Ballet and New Music Mix, Meet and Mingle
text: The word “enterprising” always applies to New Chamber Ballet. On Saturday night at Studio 4 in New York City Center, in addition to its usual accomplishments of presenting new and recent choreography with live music, it offered a program set entirely to music written in the last 30 years. Let nobody underrate this. Of the dozens of ballets seen in New York in the last two months, how many have been to music more recent than Stravinsky or Britten?

headline: Against Fish, Key for Berdych Is Confidence
text: Tomas Berdych, last year’s surprise Wimbledon finalist, has regained his winning form on grass after a disappointing clay-court season. At 6-foot-4, Berdych has a big first serve and follows it up with a cleanly hit forehand that is fast, heavy and generated with little fuss. His tremendous power comes from his legs, which may be the strongest in tennis. His game is simple: serve big, keep the backhand deep and in play, and wallop his classic-style forehand.

headline: From Scapegoat to Hero, Nunez Helps Yankees Secure Victory
text: The Yankees spent several hours early Sunday honoring the franchise’s storied past, with ceremonies and tributes and all the warm memories that come with Old-Timers’ Day. Then, once the game with the Colorado Rockies began, Eduardo Nunez — the youngest current Yankee — provided a glimpse into the sometimes-grim, sometimes-glorious existence that is a franchise’s future.

headline: Flawed Man Draws a Good Woman
text: Daniel Sullivan plants a hot kiss smack in the middle of his captivating production of the thorny “All’s Well That Ends Well” for Shakespeare in the Park. Acts of osculation have of course been known to sweep people off their feet. But Mr. Sullivan ingeniously uses this one to ground his audience and to stabilize an uneasy play.

headline: Concern at Nebraska Reactors as Floodwaters Rise
text: BROWNVILLE, Neb. — Like inhabitants of a city preparing for a siege, operators of the nuclear reactor here have spent days working to defend it against the swollen Missouri River at its doorstep. On Sunday, eight days after the river rose high enough to require the operators to declare a low-level emergency, a swarm of plant officials got to show off their preparations to the chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

headline: Mets Again Empty in Homers and Overflowing in Hits
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Although the Mets scored a dozen more runs in their last two games than the Texas Rangers did, it would not be correct to say they outslugged their high-powered opponents.

headline: When Fools Rush In
text: It turns out you can kid a kidder, and it’s easy to fool a fool. What about four fools? There’s no safety in numbers, certainly not in “Double Dhamaal,” a mind-contracting Hindi comedy that seems to take its cues from the Three Stooges, the Keystone Kops and every Bollywood cliché it can chew up and spit back as farce.

headline: Chaos in Yemen Creates Opening for Islamist Gangs
text: ADEN, Yemen — The ancient port city of Aden is now virtually surrounded by roving gangs of Islamist militia fighters — some linked to Al Qaeda — who have captured at least two towns, stormed prisons and looted banks and military depots in southern Yemen.

headline: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include personal income and spending for May (Monday); S.& P./Case-Shiller housing price index for April and consumer confidence for June (Tuesday); Pending home sales for May (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims and the Chicago purchasing managers index for June (Thursday); and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for June, automakers report North American sales for June, the I.S.M. manufacturing index for June and construction spending for May (Friday).

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: For the Producer of ‘Survivor’ and ‘The Voice,’ There’s No Sitting Still
text: Mark Burnett, who more or less created the reality programming business in American television, is back in the ratings fast lane.

headline: A Mission to See
text: The title “Vincent Wants to Sea” is a painfully unpunny translation of the original German title “Vincent Will Meer,” a homophone of “Vincent will mehr” or “Vincent wants more.” Both titles boldly underline the metaphorical significance of the film’s literal journey — a road-trip from Munich to the Mediterranean by way of the Swiss Alps. The exact meanings may get lost in translation, but trite is a universal language apparently.

headline: Look, Two Hands: A Twist on a Golf Tradition
text: In a PGA Tour playoff duel between former Clemson teammates this season, the gloves were off. Lucas Glover dispatched Jonathan Byrd on the first extra hole in a shootout that thrilled Tigers fans and no doubt led to sweaty palms in the highly lucrative golf glove industry.

headline: A Newsroom That Doesn’t Need News
text: LOS ANGELES It is 6:30 in the morning, and a stubborn mist is hanging low over the Hollywood Hills.

headline: Rematch Between Wozniacki and Cibulkova Hinges on Aggressive Play
text: Caroline Wozniacki and Dominika Cibulkova, who play for a place in the quarterfinals Monday, met in the third round of the Australian Open. Cibulkova jumped out to an early lead by playing grip-it-and-rip-it tennis, going for winners early and often against the steady Wozniacki. It was impressive for the first few games, but Wozniacki gave Cibulkova one too many balls, and the unforced errors mounted for Cibulkova.

text: The Times reviewed thousands of pages of documents related to shale gas, including hundreds of industry e-mails, internal agency documents and analyst reports. A selection is here.

headline: For San Diego Schools, a Fear That Larger Classes Will Hinder Learning
text: SAN DIEGO — Many in the forefront of what is called the education reform movement — like Bill Gates, the philanthropist, and Arne Duncan, the nation’s education secretary — have attended private schools with small class sizes. Others, like New York’s mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg, and its former schools chancellor Joel I. Klein have sent their children to private schools with small class sizes.

headline: Philip Morris Sues Australia Over Cigarette Packaging
text: Philip Morris International said it had started legal action against the Australian government over the nation’s plans to allow the sale of cigarettes only in plain packages.

headline: A Sampling of Experiments From the Bloomberg Laboratory

headline: ‘Pilot’ Label Lets Mayor’s Projects Skip City Review
text: It has never been easy for a mayor to get things done in New York City, where every government proposal must navigate a thicket of community groups, policy boards, and empowered neighborhood gadflies who can blackball a project in a blink.

headline: Average Price for U.S. Gas Falls to $3.63
text: The average price for regular gasoline at filling stations in the United States fell 11.22 cents to about $3.63 a gallon, according to the Lundberg Survey, a market research company.

headline: Maneuvering to Control Future of Formula One
text: The fortunes of a Formula One race can change in a split second. When Sebastian Vettel, the 23-year-old star of the Red Bull Racing team, slipped up on the last lap of the Canadian Grand Prix this month, he allowed Jenson Button of McLaren to snatch away the victor’s Jeroboam of Champagne.

headline: Peng Needs to Force Mistakes, Not Make Them
text: Peng Shuai has made only 12 unforced errors in reaching the round of 16 at Wimbledon. That’s an average of four mistakes a match, which are numbers we normally associate with Rafael Nadal on clay. Although few are predicting an upset, Peng has the mind and the moxie to give Maria Sharapova a serious test.

headline: Braun and Brewers Arrive Together
text: MILWAUKEE — The savior of the Milwaukee Brewers was born in California in 1983, the first of 28 consecutive years in which the franchise has not won a playoff series. He grew up playing shortstop, following players like Derek Jeter and Alex Rodriguez, whom he met on a recruiting trip to the University of Miami, where he enrolled and starred for three seasons.

headline: A Day for Masters to Share the Track With Youthful Elite
text: EUGENE, Ore. — They may be in their 40s and 50s, and their races may be for the love of running and not to gain entry to the world championships in South Korea, but they still boast six-pack abdominals and four-plus-minute miles.

headline: Beyond New York, Gay Marriage Faces Hurdles
text: ALBANY — After a string of defeats in recent years from California to Maine, the movement to legalize same-sex marriage is hoping its unexpected victory in New York will revive efforts to legalize gay weddings around the nation.

headline: Sidney Radner, Guardian of Houdini Legacy, Dies at 91
text: Sidney H. Radner, an amateur magician and newly minted Yale grad in 1941 when he became the unlikely steward of a trove of Harry Houdini artifacts, building it into one of the world’s largest Houdini collections, died on Sunday in Holyoke, Mass. He was 91.

headline: Bachmann Readies Presidential Campaign
text: WATERLOO, Iowa – On the eve of her presidential announcement, Michele Bachmann returned home to the city of her childhood on Sunday to reconnect with her Iowa roots, which she hopes to parlay into an advantage in her quest to win the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Yankees Legends Attend Their Family Reunion
text: Joe Torre awoke about 5 a.m. Sunday in a mild panic. In a few hours, he would be going to Yankee Stadium for his first Old-Timers’ Day, and it occurred to him that he did not have any cleats.

headline: Avoid Gaza Flotilla, Israel Warns Foreign Journalists
text: JERUSALEM — Israel threatened Sunday to bar for up to a decade any foreign journalist who boards a flotilla seeking to challenge an Israeli naval blockade of Gaza.

headline: Alice Playten, an Actress of Small Frame, Big Voice, Dies at 63
text: Alice Playten, a versatile character actress and musical comedy voice whose piping wail earned her comparisons to a baby Ethel Merman, died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 63 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: Robert Miller, Manhattan Art Dealer, Dies at 72
text: Robert Miller, an art dealer whose Manhattan gallery represented an eclectic list of prominent American painters, sculptors and photographers, notably Robert Mapplethorpe, died on Wednesday in Miami. He was 72 and lived in El Portal, Fla.

headline: Tea Party Plans Its Own Debt Panel

headline: Even Boom States Get the Blues
text: MINOT, N.D. — For a very long time this state was derided as an empty expanse of windswept nothingness where snow stormed in and residents stormed out in predictable abundance. Then, as the rest of the country struggled the last few years, North Dakota started winning consistent praise as an oasis of economic prosperity. The snow kept coming, but suddenly so did new residents.

headline: Dissolution of Hacker Group Might Not End Attacks
text: Facing increasing pressure from law enforcement agencies over its brazen computer attacks, the small group of hackers known as Lulz Security announced over the weekend that it would disband.

headline: U.S. to Provide Guidelines to Bolster Computer Security
text: The Homeland Security Department plans to unveil on Monday a new system of guidance intended to help make the software behind many services — be they Web sites or power grids — less susceptible to hacking.

headline: In Zimbabwe, Mugabe Government Is Not Sharing the Power to Arrest Rivals
text: JOHANNESBURG — Jameson Timba, a senior aide to Prime Minister Morgan Tsvangirai of Zimbabwe, had just returned home on Friday from a conference in Barcelona on the rule of law when plainclothes policemen — answerable to President Robert Mugabe — arrested him in Harare, Zimbabwe’s capital. Mr. Timba was accused of a common crime: insulting Mr. Mugabe.

headline: Canadian Parliament Orders Postal Union Back to Work
text: OTTAWA — Canada’s Parliament passed legislation Sunday evening that ordered the country’s 48,000 postal workers back to work.

headline: No Resolution for Mixed Martial Arts

headline: Genentech to Appeal to F.D.A. for Breast Cancer Drug
text: Genentech this week will step up its efforts to keep the drug Avastin available as a treatment for breast cancer, urging the Food and Drug Administration to give it one more chance to prove the medicine works.

headline: Spike in U.S. Deaths in Iraq Raises Worries
text: BAGHDAD — Two American soldiers were killed Sunday in Iraq, the military command said, making June the worst month in combat-related fatalities for United States forces in Iraq in more than two years. The casualties also reflected the dangers ahead as the United States prepares to withdraw all its troops from Iraq by the end of the year.

headline: Politico Enters E-Book Venture With Random House

headline: Hearst’s Umbrella Ad Campaign
text: On Monday, Hearst Magazines is to begin an elaborate advertising campaign, aimed at advertisers and readers, to burnish its brand image rather than promote individual magazines like Esquire or Good Housekeeping. The campaign, with the “Unbound” theme, comes after significant business developments like the $892 million acquisition of 100 publications from Lagardère, the $325 million purchase of the digital marketing agency iCrossing and the joint venture with Scripps Network Interactive to introduce Food Network Magazine.

headline: For Council Speaker, Enjoying a Run of Good Fortune
text: Whenever Christine C. Quinn became overly excited as a child, her father, Larry, would admonish her to save up her enthusiasm for the moment when she won the lottery. If you allow yourself to express all that happiness now, he told her, “you won’t have what you need for that day.”

headline: 160 Million and Counting
text: In 1990, the economist Amartya Sen published an essay in The New York Review of Books with a bombshell title: “More Than 100 Million Women Are Missing.” His subject was the wildly off-kilter sex ratios in India, China and elsewhere in the developing world. To explain the numbers, Sen invoked the “neglect” of third-world women, citing disparities in health care, nutrition and education. He also noted that under China’s one-child policy, “some evidence exists of female infanticide.”

headline: Byron Burford, Artist of Circus Life, Dies at 90
text: Byron Burford, a figurative artist who attracted a broad following, particularly in the Midwest, with vivid images of athletes, soldiers, factory workers, jazz musicians and a panoply of circus people, died on June 17 at his home in Iowa City. He was 90.

headline: Behind Veneer, Doubt on Future of Natural Gas
text: Energy companies have worked hard to promote the idea that natural gas is the fossil fuel of tomorrow, and they have found reliable allies among policy makers in Washington.

headline: Egyptian Leader Assures McCain and Kerry on Transition
text: CAIRO — After talks with the leader of Egypt’s ruling military council, Senator John McCain on Sunday expressed confidence that the caretaker military rulers wanted to transfer powers to an elected government “as soon as possible.”

headline: Our Untransparent President

headline: Across Europe, Irking Drivers Is Urban Policy
text: ZURICH — While American cities are synchronizing green lights to improve traffic flow and offering apps to help drivers find parking, many European cities are doing the opposite: creating environments openly hostile to cars. The methods vary, but the mission is clear — to make car use expensive and just plain miserable enough to tilt drivers toward more environmentally friendly modes of transportation.

headline: Taking a Spin on the Hudson, and Earning Course Credit, Too
text: The sailboat raced across the murky soup of the Hudson River, piloted by two teenagers new to the water and one who was an old salt.

headline: Old-Timers’ Day in Pictures
text: From Yogi Berra to Joe Torre to Bernie Williams, the Old-Timers returned to Yankee Stadium.

headline: Gay Marriage: A Milestone
text: New York State has made a powerful and principled choice by giving all couples the right to wed and enjoy the legal rights of marriage. It is a proud moment for New Yorkers, thousands of whom took to the streets on Sunday to celebrate this step forward. But this moment does not erase the bigotry against gays and lesbians enshrined in the federal Defense of Marriage Act, which denies federal recognition of same-sex marriages and allows any state to refuse to recognize another state’s unions.

headline: A Monday Full of Action and Answers at Wimbledon
text: The second Monday of Wimbledon is a special day because all 32 remaining singles players are in action. Christopher Clarey laid out many of the story lines for Week 2 at the All England Club. Who is your sentimental favorite — Roger Federer or Andy Murray? Which upstart do you want to see more off — Bernard Tomic or Sabine Lisicki? Which female star is closer to championship form — Maria Sharapova or Serena Williams?

headline: Gay Marriage: Where’s Mr. Obama?
text: On Thursday night, when same-sex marriage in New York State was teetering on a razor’s edge, President Obama had a perfect opportunity to show the results of his supposed evolution on gay marriage.

headline: Where’s the Reconciliation?
text: King Hamad bin Isa al-Khalifa of Bahrain has promised to launch a national dialogue aimed at reconciling his country after a brutal crackdown on antigovernment protesters. It is hard to take this seriously — or see any real chance of success — when many of the people who should be at the negotiating table are still in jail.

headline: Legal Help for Indigent Parents
text: A court in South Carolina jailed Michael Turner for 12 months for civil contempt because he owed $5,728.76 in accumulated child support. He could have avoided jail by proving he was indigent and could not pay. But Mr. Turner could not afford to hire a lawyer to make that argument, and the state did not provide him one.

headline: In Ramadi, Distrust Threatens Iraq’s Gains
text: RAMADI, Iraq — This palm-lined city along the Euphrates, once a deadly stronghold of the insurgency, has been hailed as one of Iraq’s greatest turnaround stories, the first major urban area where militants were driven back and life slowly returned to shattered neighborhoods.

headline: Several States Forbid Abortion After 20 Weeks
text: Dozens of new restrictions passed by states this year have chipped away at the right to abortion by requiring women to view ultrasounds, imposing waiting periods or cutting funds for clinics. But a new kind of law has gone beyond such restrictions, striking at the foundation of the abortion rules set out by the Supreme Court over the last four decades.

headline: Bill on Humane Slaughter Yields New Front for Muslim Tensions
text: AMSTERDAM — It has not been a good year for Ahmet Kilic. Sales are down in the store where for the last two and a half years he has sold groceries and meat, slaughtered according to halal conditions. The store, on the southern edge of this Dutch city, was started 22 years ago by his brother and uncle, natives of Turkey, who took it over from its former Dutch owners.

headline: A River Crests, and a North Dakota City Is Swamped
text: The Souris River upended life in Minot, N.D., after surpassing its 1881 record level of 1,558 feet above sea level.

headline: China and Vietnam Agree to Talks on South China Sea Dispute
text: BEIJING — China announced Sunday that it and Vietnam had agreed to hold talks on how to resolve conflicts arising from a sovereignty dispute over the South China Sea, an issue that has escalated tensions between them and led to angry protests by the Vietnamese.

headline: After Gay Marriage Vote, a Celebration in San Francisco, but Bittersweet
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Among the usual sights at San Francisco’s annual gay pride parade on Sunday — rainbow flags, lesbians on motorcycles, unfortunately naked men — were a few that would probably have seemed out of place in years past: namely, a collection of small, handmade signs reading “We Love NY.”

headline: Atlanta Closer in Distance Than in Philosophy on Gay Marriage
text: ATLANTA — Philip Rafshoon and his partner, Robert Gaul, were taking some good-natured ribbing for their sexual orientation at a comedy show here on Saturday. They were the only openly gay people in the audience.

headline: Different Approaches for Wielding the Gavel
text: LEXINGTON, Ky. — Henry Clay became speaker in 1811 on his first day in the House of Representatives. It took Nancy Pelosi and John A. Boehner 20 years apiece.

headline: Hemophilia Is Target of Therapy on Genome
text: Researchers using a new technique for editing the genome of living cells have shown that they can cure hemophilia in mice, at least in principle, with a couple of injections that carry out the “cut” and “paste” operations needed to insert a corrective gene.

headline: Gold Cup Post-Mortem: Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow
text: The United States national team’s run through the Concacaf Gold Cup felt like one of those rickety rides at Coney Island: occasionally thrilling, but always a sniff of potential catastrophe in the air. At one moment you felt exhilarated and glad you came along for the ride; a few seconds later you threw up in your mouth a little and just wanted to go home.

headline: Are You More Introvert or Extrovert?
text: An article in the new Sunday Review section suggests that as a society we increasingly treat shyness as a disorder rather than seeing the value of that temperament. Do you agree? headline: Auditor Warns of Risks From Local Debt in China
text: SHANGHAI — The head of China’s national audit office warned on Monday that the country was facing growing risks because of a sharp rise in local government debt and poor controls over borrowing by investment companies set up by municipalities, provinces and other bodies.

headline: Charges of War Crimes Brought Against Qaddafi
text: PARIS — The International Criminal Court in The Hague issued arrest warrants on Monday for Libya’s leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, one of his sons and his intelligence chief, accusing them of crimes against humanity during the first two weeks of the uprising in Libya that led to a NATO bombing campaign.

headline: Syria Allows Opposition to Meet in Damascus
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Scores of opposition figures met publicly Monday in Damascus for the first time since Syria’s antigovernment uprising began. The officially sanctioned gathering underlined the changes the rebellion has wrought in Syria as well as the challenges ahead in breaking a cycle of protests and crackdowns that have left hundreds dead.

headline: After Same-Sex Marriage, Same-Sex Divorce
text: It is worth pointing out that the two most prominent politicians in the successful campaign to legalize same-sex marriage in New York want nothing to do with marriage. For themselves, anyway.

headline: VW Delays MAN Board Move Pending Merger Clearance
text: Volkswagen said on Monday that it would postpone appointing its top executives to the supervisory board of the truck maker MAN until it obtained merger clearance.

headline: For BET, ‘Real Housewives’ Adds a Y Chromosome
text: Whether you are a fan of Bravo’s endlessly mutating “Real Housewives” reality-television franchise or would be willing to alter the continuum of time and space to prevent it from existing, you’ll find something to like about this parody from Sunday’s BET Awards: “The Real Husbands of Hollywood,” featuring Anthony Anderson, Bobby Brown, Jermaine Dupri, Nelly and the BET Awards host Kevin Hart (as well as a cameo from a none-too-pleased Nick Cannon).

headline: Now Booking | Beresheet
text: The road to Mitzpe Ramon, a dusty town halfway across Israel’s Negev Desert, is well paved and lonely. Heading south from Tel Aviv, you’ll pass by (and hopefully not drive into) some camels, zip past an ancient Nabatean fortress, spot an Israeli military base or two and even a disconcertingly large prison. All this is set against a rocky, khaki-drenched landscape that seems to close in on itself as you near the town; then, in a strikingly silent swoop, it opens up in the form of Makhtesh Ramon, the biggest erosion crater on the planet. And on its rim, in a crafty juxtaposition of luxury and nothingness, you have the new resort Beresheet.

headline: Monday Reading: For a Good Inflight Meal, Pack a Picnic
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Unseeded Tomic Reaches Wimbledon Quarterfinals
text: WIMBLEDON, England –- Unseeded teenager Bernard Tomic of Australia used a powerful serve and attacking style to upset Xavier Malisse of Belgium, 6-1, 7-5, 6-4, in their fourth-round match Monday at the All England Club.

text: WIMBLEDON, England – Maria Sharapova of Russia returned to the quarterfinals of Wimbledon for the first time since 2006, using her rejuvenated game to dispatch Shuai Peng of China, 6-4, 6-2, in their fourth-round match that was a testament to Sharapova’s growing confidence.

headline: Justices Reject Ban on Violent Video Games for Children
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday struck down on First Amendment grounds a California law that banned the sale of violent video games to children. The 7-to-2 decision was the latest in a series of rulings protecting free speech, joining ones on funeral protests, videos showing cruelty to animals and political speech by corporations.

headline: Philip Roth No Longer Reading Fiction
text: Whether you’re interested in Philip Roth’s critical exegesis of “A Visit From the Goon Squad,” his contrarian take on “Freedom” or just curious to know what he thinks of “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,” his answer is likely to be the same: He probably hasn’t read them because he is no longer reading fiction at all. In an interview with The Financial Times, Mr. Roth, the ornery author more than two dozen novels (the FT credits him with 53 books) including “Portnoy’s Complaint,” “The Human Stain” and “Nemesis,” said that other people’s literary inventions are no longer part of his diet. “I’ve stopped reading fiction,” he said. “I don’t read it at all. I read other things: history, biography. I don’t have the same interest in fiction that I once did.” Asked why he came to this position, Mr. Roth said: “I don’t know. I wised up.”

headline: GSV Capital Joins Facebook Party
text: The GSV Capital Corporation, a publicly traded investment firm, has officially punched its ticket to Facebook’s I.P.O.

headline: Upsets if Not Shocks on Women’s Side
text: WIMBLEDON, England — It was a wild Monday for the women at Wimbledon, with the Williams sisters and No. 1-ranked Caroline Wozniacki losing in the fourth round. But for all the attention-demanding results, it was perhaps not as surprising an afternoon as it seemed at first glance.

headline: Booming Field: Studying the Living Vanished
text: This post is about one of the great, and underappreciated, vanishings under way as the Anthropocene gets into high gear — the loss of a substantial portion of the world’s amphibian diversity in the face of a fungus spread by human activities. The depth of what is happening is summed up in this quote from a recent essay in Herpetological Review by Joseph R. Mendelson III, the curator of herpetology at Zoo Atlanta:

headline: Tobacco Companies Fight Australian Cigarette Bill
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Legislation that would ban logos from appearing on cigarette packages in Australia is drawing the ire of business lobbying groups and even members of the United States Congress, who warn that the Australian government could be in breach of its international trade obligations.

headline: Murray Routs Gasquet to Reach Quarterfinals

headline: Paris Top 5 | Givenchy
text: Riccardo Tisci took the usually benign touristy tropical print and gave it an exciting, aggressive edge in his terrific show for Givenchy. The Bird of Paradise plant with it’s knife-like leaves and sharply pointed flowers was given an acid color wash and placed on almost everything in the collection. Given the wild colors and graphics of surf gear, these far out clothes looked immediately wearable. The pistachio suit with matching printed jacket, shirt, tie, shorts, and even a baseball cap won with flying colors.

headline: ‘Intent’ Comes to an End, Still Tormenting Its Star
text: There are plenty of worthy cop shows, and “The Good Wife” has brought a fresh thrill to the ripped-from-the-headlines procedural. But it was still hard to watch the final episode of “Law & Order: Criminal Intent” without a pang of regret.

headline: Bachmann Is In, Officially
text: UPDATED, 12:45 p.m.: WATERLOO, Iowa – Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota formally opened her candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination on Monday, presenting herself as a forceful conservative who will confront the party’s establishment and not compromise on principles to capture grass-roots enthusiasm that has risen up in opposition to President Obama.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Tajima Breaks 10-Minute Barrier at Pikes Peak
text: Nobuhiro Tajima significantly lowered his own record in the Unlimited class at Pikes Peak on Sunday, bringing the hill-climb mark from 10:01.41 minutes to 9:51.28. Tajima, 60, is known among competitors and fans as Monster Tajima for his dominance on the Colorado mountain — he now has won his class six consecutive years — but he did not say if he planned to retire from the annual climb.

headline: Climate Change in Mongolia
text: Clyde E. Goulden is the director of the Institute of Mongolian Biodiversity and Ecological Studies at the Academy of Natural Sciences in Philadelphia.

headline: Wozniacki Stopped Short in Another Grand Slam
text: WIMBLEDON, England –- For one set, No. 1 seed Caroline Wozniacki of Denmark made it seem like she would easily take care of Dominika Cibulkova of Slovakia in their fourth-round match on Monday, but after Cibulkova turned the match around entirely, Wozniacki finds herself out of another major tournament short of a title.

headline: Dodgers File for Bankruptcy, Increasing Tension With Selig
text: The Los Angeles Dodgers filed for bankruptcy in a Delaware court Monday, a move that is expected to give a quick jolt of cash to the troubled team but also to ratchet up the fight between the owner, Frank McCourt, and Bud Selig, Major League Baseball’s commissioner, who last week rejected a proposed television deal by the team that was worth $2.5 billion to $3 billion.

headline: Long Sentences Send a Message Few May Hear
text: The Justice Department has asked for a sentence of as much as 385 years for Lee B. Farkas, former chief executive of the Taylor, Bean & Whitaker Mortgage Corporation, who was convicted of orchestrating a $2.9 billion fraud that caused the collapse of Colonial Bank.

headline: This Business of F1 After Valencia
text: Things may have settled down on the racetrack, where the same guy wins or comes in second in every race, but behind the scenes there seems to be a battle brewing, the winner of which is far from certain.

headline: This Business of F1 After Valencia
text: Things may have settled down on the racetrack, where the same guy wins or comes in second in every race, but behind the scenes there seems to be a battle brewing, the winner of which is far from certain.

headline: Groups Say Changes to Labor Law Won’t Do Enough for Veterans
text: Even before President Obama said last week that he would speed the pullout of American troops from Afghanistan, the Department of Labor was trying to strengthen a Vietnam-era law designed to make sure returning soldiers get jobs.

headline: From Mob Hangout to Tea Shop With Extras
text: Pinkies up, wiseguys.  Sullivan St. Tea & Spice Company has moved into the former home of Vincent Gigante’s Triangle Social Club in Greenwich Village.  Mark Greenberg, the owner, said that he wanted to offer more products than he could showcase at Grounded, his organic coffee and tea cafe in the West Village.

headline: Justices Strike Down Arizona Campaign Finance Law
text: WASHINGTON — In its first campaign-finance decision since its 5-to-4 ruling in the Citizens United case last year, the Supreme Court on Monday struck down an Arizona law that provided escalating matching funds to candidates who accept public financing.

headline: Ready or Not, Summer Swoon Arrives
text: It seems a bit early to be the dog days of summer, but they seem to have crept up on us. No, the weather hasn’t yet turned beastly hot in most places. Baseball hasn’t yet totally separated into the haves and never-will-haves. There is still free agency drama to come in basketball and hockey. The N.F.L. went to the dogs months ago and it had nothing to do with summer. And yes, maybe the idea crept in because one of the dramas from Wimbledon involves Novak Djokovic trying to get his poodle into England.

headline: In Cycling Race Across America, Sleep Is Shunned
text: ANNAPOLIS, Md. — After cycling 3,000 miles through 12 states on just seven and a half hours of sleep spread out across eight days, with nary a shower, solid food or a real bed in between, Christoph Strasser glided past the Race Across America finish line here and was asked how he felt.

headline: Jury Finds Blagojevich Guilty of Corruption
text: CHICAGO — A jury on Monday convicted Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois, of a broad pattern of corruption, including charges that he tried to personally benefit from his role in selecting a replacement for President Obama in the United States Senate.

headline: Smithsonian American History Museum to Have a New Leader
text: Brent Glass, the director of the Smithsonian’s National Museum of American History, who oversaw a two-year renovation that answered some of the criticisms of the museum, will retire effective July 10. An acting director is to be appointed in July, and Mr. Glass will continue as an adviser to the Smithsonian through the end of the year.

headline: Pironkova Eliminates Venus Williams for Second Year in a Row
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Venus Williams joined her sister Serena in making an early exit at Wimbledon on Monday, losing to Tsvetana Pironkova of Bulgaria, 6-2, 6-3.

headline: 7 Agencies Will Tell You This Cereal Is No. 1
text: The Big G division of General Mills is starting a campaign to promote the fact that Honey Nut Cheerios is “America’s favorite cereal” — that is, the best-selling cereal in the United States, according to Nielsen data. Seven agencies are collaborating on the campaign.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: Hazards: Cocaine Users May Face Danger to Skin
text: Doctors are warning cocaine users they may develop a painful, disfiguring skin reaction after taking the drug, because it often is mixed with levamisole, a veterinary medicine that can set off severe allergic reactions.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Matt Belson joined Arnold Worldwide, Boston, in a new post, as vice president and account director for the Dell brand. He had been global account director for Dell at Y&R, New York, part of the Young & Rubicam Brands unit of WPP. Arnold is part of the Havas Worldwide unit of Havas.

headline: Awareness: H.I.V. Campaign Finds 18,000 New Cases
text: A three-year campaign intended to expand testing for H.I.V. and get people into treatment turned up more than 18,000 adults who were not aware that they were infected, the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported last week.

headline: A SHOW OF FAITH, ANN ARBOR, MICH.
text: When I was little, praying the rosary every night with my family helped me get into the habit of fighting distraction.

headline: Amanda Knox’s Murder Conviction Appeal Begins in Italy
text: PERUGIA, Italy — An appeal by Amanda Knox, an American convicted two years ago in the 2007 murder of a British exchange student, opened Monday with an Ivorian man, also convicted in the killing, testifying that Ms. Knox and her ex-boyfriend had committed the crime.

headline: Patterns: After Heart Attack, Delays in Critical Care
text: When heart attack victims are taken to hospitals that aren’t equipped to perform lifesaving procedures to open blocked arteries, standard medical guidelines recommend they be transferred to another hospital within 30 minutes. Yet only one in 10 patients is transferred in that time, a new study has found.

headline: Concerns About Costs Rise With Hospices’ Use
text: As she surveyed patients’ charts, Nancy Romeo, a medical review auditor at a hospice company, was surprised by the resilience of those supposedly near death.

headline: Djokovic Makes Quick Work of Llodra
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Novak Djokovic seemed to be in a hurry Monday, taking a two-set lead in just 64 minutes against Michael Llodra of France in the fourth round at Wimbledon.

headline: Museum of Fine Arts Reaches Restitution Deal to Keep Painting
text: The Museum of Fine Arts in Boston said it would pay an unspecified amount to the heir of an art dealer who was killed at Auschwitz and will keep a 17th-century Dutch painting in its collection that was once owned by the dealer and likely seized by the Nazis. The Boston Globe reported that after a lengthy investigation into the work, an oil portrait by the Dutch painter Eglon van der Neer, the museum determined that it had belonged to Walter Westfeld, who had run a German gallery shut down by the Nazis in 1936 and who was sent to Auschwitz in 1943. The museum, which purchased the painting in 1941, posted an image of it online in 2000 amid concerns about its provenance; in 2004 it was contacted by Fred Westfield, a nephew of the art dealer. Mr. Westfield, a retired economics professor in Tennessee, learned about the painting from a Google search. The Globe said that the museum had in recent years returned other works stolen during World War II. It also fought a legal battle to keep the Oskar Kokoschka painting “Two Nudes (Lovers)”; a federal appeals court ruled last year that it was the rightful owner of this work.

headline: The New American Money Math
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

headline: Creating a Cake For Jeter
text: Set designer Kevin O'Callaghan puts the icing on the cake for the cover of the June 26th issue of the Sunday Magazine.

headline: Why I Tend to Project a Little High
text: I have a confession to make: I am a chronic over-projector. This fact has even been reported several times by The New York Times. In May 2008 I was quoted predicting that our revenue would be “an estimated $8.5 million this year.” We actually finished the year at $6.6 million. Even as recently as June 2010, I thought we’d hit sales of “$16 million in 2010.” We finished the year at $13.5 million.

headline: App Smart Extra: A Campsite App for the iPhone
text: My current App Smart column, about apps that help camping enthusiasts find places to pitch a tent, applauds Google Maps for its ability to help turn up camping spots.

headline: Israel Rescinds Its Warning to Gaza-Bound Journalists
text: JERUSALEM — Israel on Monday set aside a warning it issued the previous day that foreign journalists aboard a flotilla planning to challenge its naval blockade of Gaza risked being barred from the country for up to a decade and having their equipment impounded.

headline: Officer Who Exposed Russian Spies Is Sentenced in Absentia
text: MOSCOW — A Moscow court sentenced a former Russian intelligence officer in absentia to 25 years in prison on Monday for leaking information that led to the exposure last summer of a Russian spy ring in the United States.

headline: Khmer Rouge Leader Leaves Court, in Sign of Legal Wrangling to Come
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — From behind the lawyers, a hand went up, calling for attention as the trial of the four surviving leaders of the Khmer Rouge got under way Monday on charges of genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity committed more than three decades ago.

headline: Hospice and Its Costs
text: The Times, in collaboration with Kaiser Health News, reports today that the nation’s bill for hospice care is rising at a staggering pace, prompting charges that many providers, particularly commercial companies, are inappropriately enrolling patients.

headline: Tea Party Leaders Look to Bachmann, Paul and Perry

headline: Justices Agree to Consider F.C.C. Rules on Indecency
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to decide whether the Federal Communications Commission’s policies banning nudity, expletives and other indecent content on broadcast television and radio violated the Constitution.

text: For a group of Chinese students spending this summer working in New York City, learning English was challenging enough. But learning Brooklynese?

headline: Lopez Comes From Two Sets Down, Gets Murray Next
text: WIMBLEDON, England – Three days after knocking Andy Roddick out of Wimbledon, Feliciano Lopez of Spain was on the verge of suffering a similar fate, falling behind two sets to none against unseeded Lukasz Kubot of Poland.

headline: Deb Shops Files for Bankruptcy
text: Deb Shops, a young-women’s fashion retailer, said on Monday that it had filed for bankruptcy protection and would be taken over by its senior lenders, nearly four years after the company was purchased by the buyout veteran Thomas H. Lee.

headline: ‘Stick Fly’ Is Broadway-Bound in Production Presented by Alicia Keys
text: New York may be a concrete jungle, but the bright lights of Broadway have inspired Alicia Keys to produce Lydia R. Diamond‘s play “Stick Fly” for the Lyceum Theater at the end of the year. Press representatives for the show said on Monday that Ms. Keys, the “Empire State of Mind” songstress, will present the play, which she is producing with Reuben Cannon and Nelle Nugent, and which will be directed by Kenny Leon, the director of last year’s Tony Award-winning revival of “Fences.”

headline: Same-Sex Marriage and Wall Street
text: The passage of the same-sex marriage bill in New York State relied on money and influence from a small core of libertarians from the hedge fund world. DealBook examines the money behind the bill.

headline: The Economist Behind the Khmer Rouge
text: Updated | 2:59 p.m. As my colleague Seth Mydans reports from Phnom Penh, four senior members of the Khmer Rouge appeared before a war-crimes tribunal in the Cambodian capital on Monday, charged with responsibility for policies that caused the death of as much as one-fourth of the population in the late 1970s.

headline: History of a Virus
text: Rinderpest, a relative of measles that kills cattle, emerged more than 1,000 years ago, probably on the Central Asian steppes. After 300 years of human efforts, it is now the second virus, after smallpox, to be eradicated.

headline: Rinderpest, Scourge of Cattle, Is Vanquished
text: On Tuesday in a ceremony in Rome, the United Nations is officially declaring that for only the second time in history, a disease has been wiped off the face of the earth.

headline: It’s Official: A Timetable for Jamaica Bay’s Cleanup
text: New York State and city officials said Monday that they had reached a formal agreement with environmental groups on a plan to address two major threats to Jamaica Bay: water pollution and vanishing marshlands.

text: On Sunday, Times readers got their first look at Sunday Review, a new section that replaces the Week in Review.

headline: Straight-Set Victory Puts Fish in the Quarterfinals
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Mardy Fish of the United States raced to the net and easily popped a forehand volley into the open court to claim the second set against Tomas Berdych of the Czech Republic. An upset was afoot at the All England Club and Fish moved quickly between points, as if on a mission.

headline: American Ballet Theater Announces November Slate
text: American Ballet Theater plans to take up residence at City Center from Nov. 8 through Nov. 13 to present a combination of new work and revivals. The opening-night gala will kick off with a new ballet choreographed by Demis Volpi, a member of the Stuttgart Ballet. Twyla Tharp’s “In the Upper Room” and Martha Clarke’s “Garden of Villandry” will also be performed that evening. Among the works audience members will get a chance to see later in the week are revivals of Merce Cunningham’s “Duets,” with music by John Cage; Paul Taylor’s “Black Tuesday,” set to Depression-era music; and Ms. Tharp’s “Sinatra Suite,” which includes music sung by Frank Sinatra and costumes by Oscar de la Renta.

headline: Afghan Central Banker, Fearing Reprisals, Quits Post Amid Inquiry Into Scandal
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Citing fear of reprisals and political interference in his investigation of the largest financial scandal in the country, the governor of Afghanistan’s Central Bank announced his resignation Monday while in the United States, saying that he no longer felt safe in Afghanistan.

headline: Look of the Moment | Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge
text: The Look: Haute Officer – a fitted coat-dress with epaulettes and brass buttons commands new life into royal blue.

headline: Ron Meyer to Remain as Chief of Universal
text: 3:37 p.m. | Updated Ending months of speculation in Hollywood over the future of Universal Studios, Comcast, which gained control of NBC Universal in January, will keep the studio’s top manager in place.

text: The passage of the same-sex marriage bill in New York State relied on money and influence from a small core of libertarians from the hedge fund world. DealBook’s Evelyn M. Rusli speaks to Michael Barbaro, reporter for The New York Times, about what he discovered when he examined the money behind the issue.

headline: Wimbledon’s Television Riddle
text: Wimbledon’s second Monday has been a feast for tennis fans, with all of the remaining 32 players in the men’s and women’s draws in action. But it was a disappointing morning, with coverage bouncing between ESPN and NBC, and live streaming on their Web sites.

headline: ‘Poisoned: The True Story of the Deadly E. Coli Outbreak That Changed the Way Americans Eat’
text: It was evening by the time forty-four-year-old Suzanne Kiner pulled into the parking lot at Woodinville Pediatrics, twenty miles from Seattle. Her nine-year-old daughter, Brianne, felt too weak to walk. Topping 250 pounds and with glasses and short wavy hair, Suzanne lifted her sixty-five-pound daughter from the backseat and carried her inside. Brianne had missed the previous day of school with a low-grade fever and stomach ache. Besides liquids, all Suzanne could get in her was raspberry popsicles. Then the diarrhea had started, along with the cramps that reduced Brianne to tears.

headline: A Timely E. Coli Story, Spun as a Legal Thriller
text: If little mental woodpeckers of guilt begin to hammer away every time you reach for a John Grisham novel (shouldn’t you be reading something factual and relevant to current events?), your perfect beach book has arrived. With “Poisoned,” Jeff Benedict manages to deliver the full literary experience of a medico-legal thriller in a work of nonfiction that, fortuitously enough, could not be more relevant to recent headlines.

headline: The Soon-to-Evaporate Help for At-Risk Homeowners in 32 States
text: Homeowners at risk of foreclosure in 32 states can get emergency financial aid from the federal government, but they have to act fast. Deadlines are tight, and homeowners are already flooding the program with inquiries.

headline: CBS Leads a Lackluster Sunday Night
text: On a low-rated Sunday night of network television, CBS’s line-up of “60 Minutes” and reruns delivered the most viewers in prime time, while NBC’s second season premiere of “The Marriage Ref” struggled, garnering just 4.6 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. “60 Minutes” attracted the night’s largest audience with 7 million viewers at 7 p.m.; after that CBS broadcast repeats of “Hawaii Five-0” (4.9 million), “Undercover Boss” (4.8 million) and “CSI: Miami” (5.2 million) until 11 p.m. NBC ranked second for the night despite the modest showing for “The Marriage Ref” at 10. NBC broadcast an encore of last week’s “America’s Got Talent” and it averaged 5.4 million viewers an hour from 8 to 10. ABC was third over all with repeats of “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” (3.9 million), “Castle” (4.2 million), and “Body of Proof” (4 million). Fox ranked a distant fourth with reruns of its regular Sunday night comedies.

headline: Amsterdam’s Van Gogh Museum to Close for Renovations
text: Starting in the fall of 2012, travelers to Amsterdam will have to make do with fewer artistic masterpieces, as the Van Gogh Museum closes for a six-month refurbishment.

headline: Drawing Dance: A Stop in Marseille
text: The Brooklyn-based artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting their two-year Legacy Tour through a series of drawings and paintings. After 58 years, the company is scheduled to disband on New Year’s Day 2012.

headline: Nadal, Who’s Limping and Laboring, Now Encounters Fish, Who’s Peaking
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Rafael Nadal winced in his chair as a trainer taped his left foot, and he still won the first set. Juan Martín del Potro hobbled off court after slipping on the grass, and he still won the second.

headline: A Panhandler’s Experiment: 996,538 People to Go
text: The bearded youngish man with the clipboard in Union Square is not collecting money for Greenpeace or signatures on a petition. He is a panhandler with a rather ambitious plan: to ask a million people for a donation for himself and his family, and to document the results of his requests.

headline: Chevrolet Beat E.V. Hints at G.M.’s Electric Ambitions for India

The Beat would be the likely platform if G.M. were to produce a purely electric car for India.

headline: G4 Will Show Remaining Episodes of Series Featuring Ryan Dunn

headline: Edwards Still Driving, Not So Well
text: Jets wide receiver Braylon Edwards’s driving record is far from pristine. He has been pulled over for speeding at least seven times since 2002 and was arrested for a D.W.I. in Manhattan last September after he blew a .16 breathalyzer.

headline: Paying Homage to Darwin in an Unconventional Format: Rap
text: Don’t sleep with mean people.

headline: Vain Glorious | Sun Spots
text: Trust Dolce & Gabbana to come up with a cat’s meow of a compact. Its new Animalier Bronzer, designed by the makeup artist Pat McGrath in the house’s signature leopard print, is almost too chic to brush away. The limited-edition bronzer ($50 at saks.com) offers spot-on smoldering shades that are surprisingly versatile. Dust a bit below the cheekbones and along the jaw for a fresh, sun-kissed glow, or play with the lighter, more neutral browns to emphasize the brow line. You can even create a smoky eye using the mahogany and umber tones. We’re purring already.

headline: ‘It’s Going to Pass,’ Quinn Tearfully Told Her Partner
text: It was Friday, June 24. In Albany, the State Senate was voting on a bill to legalize same-sex marriage. In New York City, the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, was anxiously awaiting the decision in her Lower Manhattan office, a cellphone glued to her right ear and her longtime partner, Kim Catullo, on the line.

headline: Britain and China Set $2.2 Billion in Deals and a Goal of Doubling Trade by 2015

text: A group of placard-waving Tea Party activists converged on the headquarters of the National Republican Senatorial Committee early Monday afternoon, demanding that its leaders refrain from supporting incumbents facing primary challenges, and serving as a reminder that the intraparty fight over party purity continues.
