headline: Forget About Crunches. Here’s How to Protect Your Back.
text: If you have not suffered a vertebral fracture, adopting an exercise routine that improves posture and strengthens back muscles can go a long way toward preventing one. And if you are already plagued by back pain due to vertebral fractures, the exercises and protective movements described below may bring relief and prevent the problem from getting worse.

headline: A New Yorker With Flair Offers Praise for Another
text: The heyday of the New York taxicab, experts say, was when the Checker roamed the earth. An outsize creature, American-made and Hollywood-approved, the Checker was a taxi as big as the city it served: garish, romantic, entertainingly oversized.

headline: Pâtés, Minus the Geese
text: When I began a career in catering in the ’70s, every mother of a vegetarian, mine included, worried about how her child was going to get enough protein. My response: I developed a soybean pâté that had a downright meaty flavor. For years I made it every week for myself and for friends and clients.

headline: Rethinking Silly Car Trips
text: In an article in Monday’s Times, I write about various strategies that European cities are using to cut down on private car use and inner-city driving. In Zurich, a multipronged approach has left residents less likely to own a car and less likely to use one if they do.

headline: A Telltale Sign of Bone Loss
text: In today’s Science Times, Jane E. Brody, personal health columnist, writes about vertebral fractures, the common compressions in the bones of the spinal column that can lead to chronic back pain, loss of height and hunched posture.

headline: Pictures of the Day: North Dakota and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from North Dakota, Libya and Mexico.

headline: Greatest Threat to Caribou Herd in Canada Isn’t From Wolves
text: Humans are a much bigger problem than wolves for a caribou herd in the oil sands area of Alberta, Canada, scientists reported last week in Frontiers in Ecology.

headline: Sharapova’s Ruthless Style Helps Her Advance
text: Maria Sharapova dominates matches with her big first serve and her fearless return. She excels in the first two shots of each point, putting enormous pressure on her opponent with her unbridled aggression. On Monday she gave Shuai Peng a lesson in power tennis on grass, winning, 6-4, 6-2, to advance to the Wimbledon quarterfinals.

headline: The Bon Iver Review Quiz
text: When Jon Caramanica made his first trip to Eau Claire, Wisc., to interview Justin Vernon for a profile in the magazine, the second Bon Iver record wasn’t even mastered. So it’s a relief that the reviews have proved to be mostly positive. (You don’t want to put all your energy into the Peter Frampton profile to coincide with the release of “I’m in You.” Not that the first Bon Iver record, “For Emma, Forever Ago,” is exactly analogous to “Frampton Comes Alive!” But you get the picture.)

headline: Wear Resort Now | Trench Coats
text: It’s no surprise that trenches are a mainstay of the fall collections, but seeing them at the resort shows reminds us that they’re a fashion staple. This resort season, Bibhu Mohapatra and Mulberry showed classic khaki, while Lanvin and Nina Ricci favored glamour over utility, casting their versions of the iconic topper in neutral silks. At the prefall collections designers like Marni, Céline and Emilio Pucci reinvented the staple with patent leather, shorter hems and tweed. These not-so-basic basics are worth the investment.

headline: The end of a deadly disease, dispelling myths about math and the truth about sunscreen

headline: Drilling Down Series
text: Articles in the Drilling Down series from The New York Times examine the risks of natural-gas drilling and efforts to regulate this rapidly growing industry.

headline: Obama’s Choice on Jobs: Politics or Policy
text: Bill George is a professor of management practice at Harvard Business School and a former chairman and chief executive of Medtronic. He is the author of four best-selling books, including “True North.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: North Dakota and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from North Dakota, Libya and Mexico.

headline: In Yielding to Temptation, Losing a Chance at True Love
text: PRINCETON, N.J. — Though an astonishing opera, Stravinsky’s “Rake’s Progress,” the story of the dissolution of a charming but callow young man in 18th-century England, remains on the margins of the standard repertory. It is hard to say why.

headline: U.S. Guidelines Aim to Bolster Software Security
text: The Homeland Security Department unveiled a new system of guidance on Monday intended to help make the software behind Web sites, power grids and other services less susceptible to hacking.

headline: One Math Museum, Many Variables
text: For everyone who finds mathematics incomprehensible, boring, pointless, or all of the above, Glen Whitney wants to prove you wrong.

headline: CBS Plans Talk Show for ‘Survivor’ Host Jeff Probst
text: The CBS Corporation, the longtime distributor of “The Oprah Winfrey Show,” is conceiving a new daytime talk show starring Jeff Probst, the host of the reality show “Survivor,” the company said Monday.

headline: TimesCast | Khmer Rouge Leaders On Trial
text: June 27, 2011 - In Cambodia, it has taken more than 30 years for four surviving leaders of the Khmer Rouge to be brought to trial.

headline: Nothing Gets Between Fran Lebowitz and Her Checker
text: Fran Lebowitz — writer, wit, automobile enthusiast — owns and drives a pale gray 1979 Checker Marathon, which she keeps in an expensive garage in the East Village. As the Times reported, she took the car for a spin the other day around Manhattan. We took notes.

headline: Scorecard | Lanvin Wins!
text: Only in the City of Light is the question “Men in skirts or men in suits?” an endlessly fruitful topic of discussion. On the final day of the Paris men’s-wear shows, Scorecard knows that at the iconic belle époque watering hole Maxim’s, Thom Browne’s biannual surreally performative undermining of heteronormativity melted a bit under scrutiny. Meanwhile over on the stock exchange, Lanvin’s poetic designers Alber Elbaz and Lucas Ossendrijver told their boys to man up — in a Byronic hero kind of way.

headline: A Summer Beer Worth the Fuss
text: DESPITE what my family might think, I’m not the fussy sort. I do believe there’s a right way to load the dishwasher and a proper place to stow the remotes, among other things. I’m particular, maybe, but certainly not fussy.

headline: Philharmonic Announces Free Concert to Mark 9/11
text: The New York Philharmonic said on Monday that it would give a special memorial concert to mark the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terror attacks: a free performance of Mahler’s Symphony No. 2, the “Resurrection,” at Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: Fashion at the BET Awards
text: Red carpet photos from the 2011 BET Awards.

headline: U.N. Approves Troop Deployment in Sudan
text: The United Nations Security Council on Monday unanimously approved a resolution authorizing the deployment of 4,200 Ethiopian troops to Sudan’s disputed Abyei region, a move diplomats said was aimed at defusing tensions in the run-up to the southern third of the country declaring independence on July 9.

headline: TimesCast | A Disease Eradicated
text: June 27, 2011 - The United Nations will soon declare Rinderpest the second disease ever to be eradicated.

headline: Prospect Park Lake, Sunday Afternoon
text: Four-week-old mute swan cygnets relaxed after snacking on duckweed.

headline: Credit Suisse Chief Penalized $750,000 in Divorce Case
text: Brady W. Dougan might want to start setting automated Outlook reminders.

headline: A Release Valve for Cyclists’ Unrelenting Pressure
text: Before the Tour de France begins this weekend, before the cameras follow all those seemingly virile athletes, let us consider another sort of role model on two wheels.

headline: Outrage Over a Storied Roman Theater’s Future
text: ROME — Real-time drama is taking place at the Teatro Valle, the storied theater here where Pirandello’s “Six Characters in Search of an Author” was first performed 90 years ago.

headline: Former Executives Claim Marsh ‘Colluded’ With Spitzer
text: Two former executives of Marsh & McLennan, who are suing the insurance broker contend in an amended complaint that their former employer colluded with Eliot Spitzer when he was New York attorney general to avert a criminal prosecution of the firm.

headline: Guilty Verdicts in Attack on a Crown Heights Family
text: Two men accused of breaking into a Crown Heights apartment in 2007 and terrorizing a family during a robbery were convicted of sex abuse, robbery, assault and other charges on Monday after a trial that lasted seven weeks in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

headline: Milestones: Blagojevich Scandal
text: A look at the events surrounding Rod Blagojevich’s conviction on corruption charges.

headline: Disabled and the Abled, Inhabiting Close Quarters
text: It’s no surprise that Neil LaBute’s contribution to “Some of Our Parts,” a bill of seven 10-minute plays about disabilities, is the brashest. It’s also the best.

headline: Turning Design on Its Side
text: SHENZHEN, China — For some time now China has been the world’s great incubator of architectural ideas: the place where architects are free to explore some of their most outlandish fantasies. And more and more, that freedom seems to be giving rise to an architectural renaissance, one that is producing legitimate architectural masterpieces.

headline: A Farewell (for Now) to Old Selves
text: On the “American Idol” finale last month, Beyoncé introduced her muscular, arresting ballad “1+1” in the sort of performance that is seared on the brains of 8-year-old girls who aspire to be singers. There she was, bathed in red light, almost swallowed by smoke, pushing the song out as if through a birth canal, a moment too good for that modest stage.

headline: Nation Goes on Its Merry Way to Ruin
text: Although the financial crisis of 2008 has left a long trail of casualties, one group has benefited from the cataclysm: financial journalists. Several have already published books shedding light on the unprecedented events that caused investment banks to fail, global stock markets to plummet and borrowers to lose their homes. “Reckless Endangerment,” by Gretchen Morgenson, assistant business and financial editor and a columnist at The New York Times, and the financial analyst Joshua Rosner, is a worthy addition to the genre.

headline: A Turkish Choreographer Inspired by New York
text: The Turkish choreographer Korhan Basaran isn’t interested in beating around the bush: the title of his evening-length show last Tuesday night at the Ailey Citigroup Theater was “I am Korhan, this is my dance!” He began “On Life,” the final section, which was inspired by New York, chatting with audience members while wearing an “I ♥ NY” T-shirt.

headline: Governors Island Show From Cooper-Hewitt
text: The Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum may be closing its galleries starting Monday for a two-year renovation, but it is hardly going quiet. In addition to a previously announced show to take place at the United Nations this fall, the museum will host an exhibition of contemporary graphic design next summer on Governors Island. “Graphic Design: Now in Production” is organized with the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, where it will run from Oct. 22 to Jan. 22. It is scheduled to open on Governors Island on June 2, 2012. The previously announced show, “Design with the Other 90%: Cities,” opens Oct. 15 and is part of a series on how design can address global issues. Both shows will be free.

headline: Three Bands Turn Up at a Show for Two
text: There were three strong working bands at the Prospect Park Bandshell on Friday night, and what they had in common was a handle on the renewable resource that we call the jazz tradition. Each came with its own history and approach, its own ensemble calculus. They were appearing together as part of the Celebrate Brooklyn! festival: three bands, but filling just two slots, because it was business as usual for only one of them.

headline: Women Break Down Barriers in Mideast Finance
text: Hoda Abou-Jamra still remembers the meeting when potential investors for her private equity fund thought she was the secretary.

headline: New Music
text: DOLLY PARTON

headline: Sometimes, Jazz Lulls Are Full of Action
text: A quartet under Mark Turner’s name started an early set last week at the Village Vanguard with some standards: Thelonious Monk’s “Crepuscule With Nellie” and Bud Powell’s “Dance of the Infidels.” Not long after the beginning, the music started to change from the inside out: known structures, unknown contents. And after that it became even less traceable.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Sweet Smell of Success'
text: A. O. Scott looks at Alexander Mackendrick's 1957 film starring Burt Lancaster as a powerful gossip columnist and Tony Curtis as an ambitious press agent.

headline: A Room of Her Own, for the Right Song
text: The Cole Porter standard “It’s All Right With Me” is a psychological test for any singer, especially a woman. The song’s ambivalent narrator, recovering from a breakup, feels “strangely attracted” to a potential new partner and gives in, despite her guilty sense that it’s the wrong time, the wrong place and the wrong face.

headline: Israeli Video Blog Exposed as a Hoax
text: Last Updated | Wednesday | 3:44 p.m. A YouTube video featuring a man who presented himself as an American gay rights activist disillusioned with the latest Gaza flotilla campaign has been exposed as a hoax.

headline: Bachmann Opens Campaign as Expectations Grow
text: WATERLOO, Iowa — Representative Michele Bachmann’s presidential candidacy, which she formally opened here on Monday, shakes up an already unsettled Republican field and creates one of the biggest tests yet for the breadth of the Tea Party movement’s appeal.

headline: A Biological Ritual, Experienced Through Different Cultures
text: Saumya Dave, a student, and Noreen Connolly, a teacher, are the 2011 “Win A Trip” winners. They recently finished traveling with Nick through parts of North and West Africa. For her fourth post, Saumya wrote about how she saw menstruation being handled in different rural villages.

headline: Supreme Court Decision on California Video Game Sales to Children
text: Justice Antonin Scalia said violent video games are protected by the first amendment.

headline: Beltran’s Knee Is Strong, and So Are His Numbers
text: DETROIT — When Carlos Beltran decided to have surgery on his right knee in January 2010, against the wishes of the Mets, it set off a storm of acrimony. The situation reached the point where the Mets announced their objections and told his agent they reserved the right to void his contract should the surgery go awry.

headline: Announcing the Candidates
text: Word usage in Republican presidential announcement speeches.

headline: Trial of New Orleans Police Begins in the 2005 Killings of Unarmed Civilians
text: NEW ORLEANS — On the sunny morning of Sept 4, 2005, five days after Hurricane Katrina, a team of police officers rushed to Danziger Bridge in the eastern part of this city in response to a report of shots fired.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,622 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Afghans Build Security, and Hope to Avoid Infiltrators
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — For someone who had once joined an insurgent group, and whose family was tied to a top Taliban commander, Akmal had a strikingly easy path into the Afghan National Army.

headline: A Yankees Footnote to Jeter’s Quest for 3,000
text: More than any other team, the Yankees have created many of baseball’s most revered numbers.

headline: Woolsey to Retire From House
text: Representative Lynn Woolsey, a liberal Democrat from Northern California, announced Monday that she would leave Congress at the end of her 10th term next year, one of two veteran House Democrats to reveal a change in political plans this week.

headline: Two Red Bulls Return, Another Exits
text: Tim Ream and Juan Agudelo are back with the Red Bulls after spending the last three weeks with the United States national team for the Concacaf Gold Cup.

headline: New York Opens Door to Gay Weddings
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘The Wal-Mart I Know’: An Executive’s Story
text: To the Editor:

headline: Parts of Georgia Immigration Law Blocked
text: ATLANTA — A federal judge has blocked the most controversial parts of a tough new Georgia immigration law that was to have taken effect Friday, but left most of the law’s provisions intact.

headline: Mark Gerard, Veterinarian at Center of a Horse Race Fraud, Dies at 76
text: Mark J. Gerard, a veterinarian who cared for champion racehorses like Kelso and Secretariat but who perpetrated one of the most notorious racetrack frauds of the postwar era, died June 21 in Miami. He was 76.

headline: Hearing Loss, Misunderstood and Stigmatized
text: To the Editor:

headline: Norma Lyon, the ‘Butter-Cow Lady,’ Dies at 81
text: Norma Lyon, a self-described dairy farmer’s wife and mother of nine who achieved fame well beyond the Midwest as the “butter-cow lady” of the Iowa State Fair, sculpturing tons of U.S. Grade AA salted butter each year into life-size figures of cows, famous people and, once, a diorama of the Last Supper, died on Sunday in Marshalltown, Iowa. She was 81.

headline: In the Teamsters, a Candidate Tries to Break the Mold
text: Sandy Pope acknowledges straightaway that she faces an uphill battle — she is the first woman to run for the presidency of the very macho Teamsters union, and she is running against a three-term incumbent, James P. Hoffa, who has the most famous last name in American labor.

headline: Should Marijuana Be Legalized and Regulated?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Still No. 1, U.S. Is No Longer the Clear Favorite
text: In the arena of international geopolitics, the United States’ relationship with North Korea preserves the chill of the Cold War. On the soccer field, feelings are not much warmer, but at least in the setting of the Women’s World Cup, the teams and players meet on common ground, if for only 90 minutes.

headline: Bloggingheads: “Islamic” Terrorism
text: Faiza Patel, left, of the Brennan Center for Justice and Arun Kundnani of the Open Society Institute discuss the sources of terrorism.

headline: Planned Parenthood Fights Kansas’ Move to Cut Off Funds
text: Planned Parenthood filed a federal lawsuit in Kansas on Monday that said the state budget had violated its free speech and due process rights by preventing it from receiving federal family planning money.

headline: Long-Serving Finance Minister Calls for Reforms to Bolster Russia’s Power
text: MOSCOW — It has been an unusual season for Aleksei L. Kudrin, Russia’s finance minister, one of Moscow’s quietest and most powerful men.

headline: For Many Immigrants, Marriage Vote Resonates
text: Throughout the debate over legalizing same-sex marriage, arguments against it were often articulated most forcefully by the single voice, in a thick Spanish accent, of State Senator Rubén Díaz Sr.

headline: Sinking G.O.P. Poll Numbers May Put Florida in Play
text: MIAMI — In the past few weeks, Gov. Rick Scott has traveled around the state extolling the accomplishments of the recent legislative session and promoting his success in pushing Florida down a more conservative, financially sound path.

headline: Distracted by Online Banner Ads? Here’s an Alternative
text: MANY consumers bypass Madison Avenue with software that filters out online advertising. Adblock Plus, for example, averages about 13 million daily users on one browser, Firefox, alone.

headline: Nuclear Plant’s Vital Equipment Dry, Officials Say
text: FORT CALHOUN, Neb. — When safety regulators arrive for a tour of a nuclear plant, the operators usually give the visitors a helmet, safety glasses and earplugs. When Gregory B. Jaczko, chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, got to the Fort Calhoun plant on Monday morning, the Omaha Public Power District offered him a life jacket.

headline: Behind Cuts, Real Faces and Fortunes
text: They might be seen as the tiniest of cogs in the vast machinery of municipal government: Selina Sharmin, a Queens librarian by way of Bangladesh, and Estena Powell, a Manhattan park worker by way of the South Bronx.

headline: Still Some Horror Stories, but Fewer Stranded Flights
text: SUMMER is here, the airplanes are full, fares are rising, service is falling and flight delays are increasing. Can we also expect to see more planes stranded for long hours on the tarmac, as we did in the summers of 2008 and 2009?

headline: Former Citigroup Accountant Accused of Embezzling $19.2 Million
text: Gary Foster toiled away as a midlevel accountant in Citigroup’s Long Island City back office, collecting around a $100,000 paycheck last year.

headline: Handicapping Huntsman
text: When I ran for the office of secretary of my freshman class at the University of Pennsylvania in 1955, my campaign manager was Jon Huntsman, father of Jon Huntsman, Jr., the former governor of Utah, former Ambassador to China and current candidate for the Republican nomination for the presidency. (I won and found, happily, that the office carried with it almost no responsibilities.)

headline: The Virtual Hotel Concierge
text: Some hotels have begun to expand the definition of concierge to mean more than just a knowledgeable employee. It now can also mean smart digital devices. Software companies are creating programs that offer information like restaurant tips, flight arrivals and departures and driving directions via these devices to guests at midtier hotels that do not provide traditional concierge services.

headline: Microsoft Takes to Cloud to Ward Off Competition
text: People like Tom Conophy are stirring anxiety — and action — in Microsoft’s executive offices these days.

headline: Bond Yields Rise in Europe Despite French Assurances
text: Government bond yields rose across Europe on Monday as investors nervously awaited Greece’s austerity vote this week and greeted skeptically a plan put forward by France for its banks to shoulder part of the cost of a rescue package for Greece.

headline: Police Sergeant to Get Jail Term for Perjury and Illegal Searches
text: A police sergeant pleaded guilty on Monday to performing illegal searches of the cars and an apartment of people he had stopped, and then lying in court about his justification for the searches.

headline: Staying in the Game on Football’s Fringe
text: BETHLEHEM, Pa. — The Lehigh Valley Steelhawks play football in a nearly empty college basketball arena. As players slam opponents onto a playing surface with all the protection of a patio carpet and crash into barely padded plywood walls, the few hundred fans blow plastic trumpets, ring cowbells and thump on seatbacks. The team’s general manager is also its announcer. End-of-quarter entertainment is a family of four playing musical chairs at midfield to a Beastie Boys song.

headline: Elders Offer Help at Japan’s Crippled Reactor
text: TOKYO — By any measure, the thousands of people toiling to cool the crippled nuclear reactors in Fukushima are engaged in jobs that the Japanese consider kitanai, kitsui and kiken, or dirty, difficult and dangerous.

headline: A Reality-Based Cooking Show with a Difference
text: June 28, 11:15 a.m. | Updated There’s no shortage of reality-inspired cooking shows in which participants struggle against long odds.

headline: Tanzania: No Serengeti Highway
text: The Tanzanian government has indicated that it will not build a highway through the Serengeti National Park, a plan that conservation groups worried would ruin one of the world’s greatest migrations of animals. In a letter dated June 22, Ezekiel Maige, Tanzania’s natural resources and tourism minister, said that the roads in the park would remain gravel and that the government is “seriously considering” building a highway south of the Serengeti.

headline: Wall St. Job Cuts Loom if Slump Persists
text: Wall Street is again talking of impending job cuts. With trading revenue falling, the pressure is growing for investment banks to lay off employees. Executives are still debating whether the current slump is a blip. But nobody wants to slash ranks right before a turnaround, so the knives may not come out for a few months.

headline: On Obama, Wall St. Shows a Reluctance to Commit
text: President Obama’s $35,800-a-plate fund-raising dinner was the talk of Wall Street last week.

headline: City Signs to Help Pedestrians (They Aren’t Just for Tourists)
text: It is a badge of urban pride: knowing how to walk around New York City without a map.

headline: Los Alamos Laboratory Is on Alert for a Wildfire
text: DENVER — A wildfire that roared out of nowhere on Sunday in northern New Mexico prompted an evacuation of Los Alamos County on Monday, and by midafternoon had spread to the boundary of the Los Alamos National Laboratory, the highly sensitive headquarters for United States military nuclear research.

headline: Cuomo, Obama and the Realm of the Possible
text: Matt Yglesias, the blogger for Think Progress, and others have been critical of my article from Saturday contrasting the leadership approaches taken by New York Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and President Obama. Here’s Mr. Yglesias:

headline: As Yemen Teeters From Political Unrest, a Humanitarian Crisis May Not Be Far Off
text: SANA, Yemen — While Yemen’s political crisis stagnates — a popular uprising has stalled and a wounded president has not been seen publicly for weeks — its economic crisis has only grown worse.

headline: Q. and A. with Aleksei L. Kudrin
text: Following are excerpts from an interview conducted last week by The Times’s Moscow bureau chief, Ellen Barry, with Aleksei L. Kudrin, the finance minister of Russia. Mr. Kudrin is considered the third most powerful figure in the Kremlin, after Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin and President Dmitri A. Medvedev, and is a close ally of Mr. Putin.

headline: Crime Boss in Hiding Found Time for Travels
text: BOSTON — James (Whitey) Bulger may have been on the lam, as they say, but he did not let it cramp his style.

headline: California Nears Deal on a Budget
text: LOS ANGELES — Gov. Jerry Brown of California and the Democratic-controlled Legislature have reached a tentative deal on the state budget, relying on more optimistic revenue predictions to add $4 billion to next year’s budget. The plan, which the Legislature is expected to begin approving on Tuesday, would also trigger deeper cuts in education and social services if those revenues did not materialize.

headline: The First Amendment, Upside Down
text: The Supreme Court decision striking down public matching funds in Arizona’s campaign finance system is a serious setback for American democracy. The opinion written by Chief Justice John Roberts Jr. in Monday’s 5-to-4 decision shows again the conservative majority’s contempt for campaign finance laws that aim to provide some balance to the unlimited amounts of money flooding the political system.

headline: New Drugs Fight Prostate Cancer, but at High Cost
text: A group of new drugs is promising to prolong the lives and relieve the symptoms of men with advanced prostate cancer, but could also add billions of dollars to the nation’s medical bills.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Timing Is Questioned in Seeking House Vote on U.S. Role in Libya
text: The overwhelming vote in the House on Friday against approving American participation in the NATO action in Libya raised a question in Washington: Why did President Obama not press harder for a vote authorizing the operation months ago when the intervention was more popular?

headline: In Day of Drama, 16 Matches Produce 16 Quarterfinalists
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Petra Cetkovska took a bathroom break after she dropped a first-set tie breaker to Sabine Lisicki on Monday, sending some fans watching their fourth-round match into a tizzy. A few had waited in line in dehydrating heat for their unreserved seats for the first fourth-round match of the day on Court 12. Did they really want to sit idly watching the grass grow, even for a few minutes, when so much was happening at Wimbledon?

headline: After New York, New Look at Defense of Marriage Act
text: New York’s new law allowing same-sex marriage could bring renewed focus to an embattled federal law that says other states do not have to recognize such unions.

headline: Change Comes to Savannah
text: Though the river port of Savannah, Ga., lay hundreds of miles from the burgeoning hostilities in Virginia, by the summer of 1861 it was already registering the effects of the Civil War. Like the rest of the Confederacy, Savannah quickly mobilized for war and, as the conflict wore on, came to reflect the wrenching changes that the Confederacy’s bid for independence impressed upon all of Southern society — and nowhere more so than in its population of slaves and free blacks. Indeed, by starting a war to preserve slavery and to celebrate the ties that bound together all whites, the Confederates inadvertently put forces in motion that would begin to undermine that very project.

headline: Sentencing Delay Likely in Police Rape Case
text: The sentencing of two former New York police officers convicted in May of misdemeanor official misconduct but acquitted of felony rape is likely to be postponed on Tuesday so defense lawyers can file motions and review evidence.

headline: Lots of Talk, Too Little Action
text: The price of agricultural commodities has surged by more than a third over the past year — cereal prices by 70 percent — surpassing even the levels that sparked widespread food riots in 2008. According to the World Bank, the rise in prices pushed 44 million more people into hunger in the second half of 2010.

headline: Iran Unveils Missile Silos as It Begins War Games
text: Iran unveiled underground silos on Monday that would make its missiles less vulnerable to attack, marking the country’s latest show of force in the long standoff with the West over its nuclear program.

headline: A Gravel Road Too Far
text: It would be nice to be able to praise the Tanzanian government and President Jakaya Kikwete for dropping plans to build a road across the northern section of Serengeti National Park. The road, about 32 miles long, would have cut across one of the planet’s major migratory corridors — used by great herds of wildebeest and other animals — and one of the last of its kind on the planet.

headline: Two Veteran Democrats Leaving
text: Representative Lynn Woolsey, a liberal Democrat from Northern California, said Monday that she would leave Congress at the end of her 10th term next year, one of two veteran Democrats to reveal a change in political plans this week. Ms. Woolsey, 73, has been a leader of the Congressional Progressive Caucus and an antiwar advocate. Representative Jay Inslee, a Seattle-area Democrat, on Monday formally began his bid to be governor of Washington after seven House terms.

headline: Promising Treatments for Prostate Cancer Patients
text: Though costly, prostate cancer drugs have helped patients live longer.

headline: John L. Mica: Working the Railroad
text: Annotated documents illustrate Representative John L. Mica’s efforts to secure federal funding for a private commuter rail system in his Florida district.

headline: New Jersey’s Governor, Champion of Inequality
text: New York’s approval of same-sex marriage was a testament to Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s political courage. In the New Jersey governor’s office, it is good sense that is in short supply on this issue.

headline: Cornell Fraternity Sued Over Student’s Drinking Death
text: The mother of a 19-year-old Cornell University sophomore who died after drinking heavily at a fraternity house in February filed a wrongful-death lawsuit against the fraternity on Monday, saying her son was hazed and then left to die.

headline: Debt Divide Remains as President Steps In
text: WASHINGTON — The White House and Congressional Republicans remained deeply divided on Monday over whether a budget-cutting deal tied to a debt limit increase should contain new federal revenues.

headline: The Minor Leagues of Football
text: Practice in a park, long bus trips and sparsely filled arenas are all part of life for the players in indoor leagues.

headline: Even Without Teacher Layoffs, City Schools Will Still Feel Pain
text: New York’s $66 billion budget, which the City Council is set to approve on Tuesday, averted the laying off of thousands of teachers that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had said would be necessary. But the plan does not spare the schools from cuts.

headline: Tuesday: Send Help!
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — The universe has an interesting way of sending messages. Just when I was doing a happy dance because I had finally conquered the Saturday puzzle, I was totally taken down. By a Tuesday. All because I have this Achilles’ tendon when it comes to math.

headline: Teacher Grades: Pass or Be Fired
text: WASHINGTON — Emily Strzelecki, a first-year science teacher here, was about as eager for a classroom visit by one of the city’s roving teacher evaluators as she would be to get a tooth drilled. “It really stressed me out because, oh my gosh, I could lose my job,” Ms. Strzelecki said.

headline: French Socialists See Open Race Without Strauss-Kahn
text: PARIS — Pierre Moscovici, a Socialist legislator, is “in mourning,” he said in an interview, and so are the Socialists. With the shocking fall of Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the party leader who was arrested in New York on charges of sexual assault against a hotel housekeeper, the party is trying to pick up the pieces — and to pick a presidential candidate from an uninspiring set of choices.

headline: A Congressman’s Pet Project; a Railroad’s Boon
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Here in sun-parched Central Florida, workers are ready to break ground this summer for a 61-mile commuter rail project that the federal government ranks as one of the least cost-effective mass transit efforts in the nation.

headline: Threats Prompt Motion to Close Trial in Bronx
text: Responding to concerns that a key witness in the murder trial of a reputed gang member has been beaten and shot, a judge in the Bronx has scheduled a hearing for Tuesday on whether to bar the press and the public from the courtroom while he testifies.

headline: Convener in Chief
text: This is a column about management styles. What sort of leader can get things done in an age of austerity?

headline: TimesCast | First Amendment Ruling
text: The Supreme Court rules on First Amendment rights for children making California's ban on the sale or rental of violent video games to minors unconstitutional.

headline: Board Raises Caps on Rent Increases, to the Usual Jeers
text: When a clutch of owners of small apartment buildings banded together to form an association almost three decades ago, one word was notably absent from the name they gave themselves.

headline: Rescue Measures for Greece Advance as French Offer to Ease Debt
text: European leaders inched closer Monday to an agreement that could avoid a potentially catastrophic default by Greece on billions of dollars in debt, as France proposed a plan that could serve as a model for other European lenders to the teetering nation, where a general strike and widespread demonstrations were planned Tuesday ahead of a crucial austerity vote.

headline: Margaret Tyzack, Award-Winning Actress, Dies at 79
text: Margaret Tyzack, a stalwart British actress who won myriad awards for her stage performances, including a Tony, but who was best known in the United States for her roles in the public television series “The Forsyte Saga” and “I, Claudius,” died on Saturday in London. She was 79.

headline: No Trash, No Crash
text: Washington

headline: It’s Perverse, but It’s Also Pretend
text: Reston, Va.

headline: Los Angeles Dodgers Bankruptcy Filings
text: The Los Angeles Dodgers filed for bankruptcy in a Delaware court Monday, a move that is expected to give a quick jolt of cash to the troubled team.

headline: Battle for Libya | June 27, 2011
text: News of an arrest warrant issued for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi sparked emotions in Benghazi and Tripoli.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Equatorial Guinea: Infant Mortality Dips
text: Infant mortality in Equatorial Guinea appears to have declined since the discovery of oil in the 1990s, according to an assessment by the World Bank and other international agencies. Revising and ironing out contradictions in previous data, some of which found that infant mortality had risen despite an influx of oil money, the World Bank now says there appears to have been a drop, in line with a global fall in infant deaths. Still, the bank cautioned that the data were not complete. “There should be a lot of uncertainty around both estimates,” said Shanta Devarajan, the chief economist for the bank’s Africa region.

headline: Reversing Campaign Finance Restrictions
text: The Supreme Court struck down a campaign finance restriction.

headline: Greek Austerity Plan’s Passage Now Seems Less Certain

headline: Cooper-Hewitt Design Museum Plans Governors Island Show
text: The Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum may be closing its galleries starting Monday for a two-year renovation, but it is hardly going quiet. In addition to a previously announced show to take place at the United Nations this fall, the museum will host an exhibition of contemporary graphic design next summer on Governors Island. The exhibition, “Graphic Design: Now in Production,” is co-organized with the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, where it will run from Oct. 22 to Jan. 22. It is to open on Governors Island, in Building 110, on June 2, 2012, and run through Sept. 30. The previously announced show at the United Nations, “Design With the Other 90%: Cities,” the second of a series on how design can address critical global issues, opens Oct. 15 and runs through Jan. 9. Admission to both exhibitions will be free.

headline: French Company Says It Will File Anticompetitive Suit Against Google, Seeking Damages
text: BRUSSELS — An Internet company in France says it will seek heavy damages from Google in what it says is the largest claim of its kind in Europe against the American giant.

headline: Who Made That Adirondack Chair?
text: “To all whom it may concern: Be it known that I, Harry C. Bunnell, a citizen of the United States, residing at Westport, in the county of Essex and the State of New York, have invented a new and useful Improvement in Chairs. … ” So begins patent number 794,777, dated July 18, 1905, in reference to what we commonly refer to as the Adirondack Chair. With its signature slanted back and wide armrests, the recognizable profile of this outdoor recliner has become a trademark of summer in America. Despite the patent filed over a hundred years ago, though, Harry Bunnell, a carpenter and shop owner, was not actually the one who created the chair’s design.

headline: Sidney Lumet Tribute Planned by Film Society of Lincoln Center
text: He made angry men of Lee J. Cobb and E. G. Marshall, got Peter Finch mad as hell and had Al Pacino screaming “Attica” at the top of his lungs, and next month Sidney Lumet, the director of “12 Angry Men,” “Network,” “Dog Day Afternoon” and many more seminal works of cinema, will be the subject of a tribute by the Film Society of Lincoln Center. The society said that the retrospective, called “Prince of the City: Remembering Sidney Lumet,” will run from July 19 through 25 and will feature screenings of 16 films by that director, who died in April. Movies including “Serpico,” “The Verdict” and “The Wiz” will be shown at the Walter Reade Theater in Manhattan. The retrospective will also feature a Q-and-A with Walter Bernstein, the screenwriter of “Fail Safe,” after a showing of that film on July 20; the actor Treat Williams and the N.Y.P.D. detective Robert Leuci will appear after a screening of “Prince of the City” on July 24; and, of course, Lumet’s film “Q&A” will be followed by a Q-and-A with Luis Guzman, Paul Calderon and Judge Edwin Torres, the author of the novel from which the film was adapted.

headline: Madoff Says Judge Made Him a ‘Human Piñata’

headline: One Small Step for Man, One Giant Leap for Autobots
text: There are filmmakers whose work is characterized by thrift, efficiency and devotion to the subtleties of cinematic expression. And then there is Michael Bay, whose films are symphonies of excess and redundancy, taking place in a universe full of fire and metal and purged of nuance. I’m not judging, just describing, and since today’s theme is bluntness, I might as well come out and say that “Transformers: Dark of the Moon” is among Mr. Bay’s best movies and by far the best 3-D sequel ever made about gigantic toys from outer space.

headline: Black Bean Pâté

headline: British Inflation: A Teachable Moment
text: Adam Posen gave a talk yesterday (pdf) about British monetary policy that drives home a point I’ve been meaning to make; namely, that what’s happening in Britain on the monetary front right now is very much a teachable moment for monetary policy more generally. The Bank of England faces the same kind conflict between what it should be doing and what it’s under pressure to do that faces the Fed, but in starker form. And if the BoE holds its ground, we should soon have a clear demonstration that one side is right and the other is wrong.

headline: Thom Browne at Maxim’s
text: Set in that gaudy relic of cafe society, Maxim’s, Thom Browne aimed for a deviant mood as he played Piaf and his slick-haired models came out in his signature tailoring overlaid with beaded cabaret-lamp fringe. One guy wore a white tulle veil on his black hat, maybe to acknowledge the passing of the marriage-equality bill in New York. Who knows? Jacket shoulders were heavily padded and wide, and the Art Nouveau-inspired evening looks celebrated fashion freaks.

Or to put it in a more contemporary context, it’s “the German equivalent of a 7-Eleven.” Except for one difference: this convenience shop is housed in a 1970s BVG Doppeldecker bus.

headline: Behind the Scenes With Derek Jeter (Well, Kind Of)
text: We recently teamed up with the amazing Kevin O’Callaghan. Kevin is a set designer based in New York; we hired him to design and build the Derek Jeter candle that you saw on Sunday’s cover. He has designed pretty much everything, including the MTV Movie Award. He also manages to find the time to serves as the chairman of the 3-D design program at the School of Visual Arts in New York City. With a swift eye for detail, Kevin took on this assignment with great enthusiasm. So much so that he didn’t even ask how much the job paid! Check out this clip of him in action, behind the scenes at the Manhattan studio of the cover photographer, Tom Schierlitz:

headline: Alan Rickman to Return to Broadway in ‘Seminar’
text: We have every reason to believe that deep down, Alan Rickman is a decent, warm-hearted individual, if his affectionate farewell letter to the “Harry Potter” movies is any indication. But after playing the sinister Severus Snape in the final installment of that boy-wizard franchise this summer, Mr. Rickman will next be portraying another in his long line of memorable creeps in “Seminar,” a new play by Theresa Rebeck that will open on Broadway in the fall.

The article garnered 174 published comments, and others listed their jobs on Twitter with the hashtag #myjobs.

headline: On Noise Standards, Motorcyclists Split
text: 3:12 p.m. | Updated Citizen groups have long agitated for ordinances and laws to curb the noise generated by motorcycles. With the help of some unlikely bedfellows, including the Motorcycle Industry Council and the American Motorcyclist Association, the groups are gaining ground.

headline: Cancer Survivors Appeal to F.D.A. Over Avastin
text: About a dozen women with breast cancer, some tearful, beseeched the Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday to retain the approval of the drug Avastin as a treatment for the disease.

headline: Telluride Film Festival Taps a Singing Movie Lover
text: The Brazilian singer-songwriter Caetano Veloso has agreed to step into an unfamiliar role, that of “guest director” helping to pick and present the films for the 38th Telluride Film Festival, which will be held over the Labor Day weekend. A confessed cinephile, Mr. Veloso has composed soundtracks for movies, performed in his friend Pedro Almodóvar’s “Talk to Her,” written essays about his love for Italian neo-realist films and even recorded a CD tribute to Federico Fellini and Giulietta Masina.

headline: Technology, Free Speech and Children
text: When my column about technology and children was published on Sunday, the Supreme Court had not yet ruled on California’s ban on the sale of violent video games to children under the age of 18. Yesterday as expected, the Supreme Court struck down the ban. It was a 7 to 2 decision, but that suggests greater agreement than there really was, as Adam Liptak maps out. What’s most interesting about the fissures on the court is the different thinking among the justices about the impact of technology on children, and the implications for other important clashes over teenagers’ free-speech rights that are percolating in the lower courts.

headline: Film Festival | Documentaries About History
text: Our summer experiments continue! Last week: Historic Headlines. This week: A collaboration with SnagLearning to bring you “film festivals” of classroom-worthy documentaries, each day on a different theme. Monday’s collection was about technology, and today we’re featuring five films about history. The whole collection is available here.

headline: The Gaga Effect Spreads to Tumblr
text: Is there any technology platform that Lady Gaga, the eccentric and entertaining pop songstress, can’t dominate? She’s already appeared in a commercial for Google Chrome, started her own game on FarmVille, crashed Amazon’s servers and partnered with companies like Gilt and Polaroid to release special-edition products.

headline: Some Charges May Be Dropped in Bulger Case as Prosecutors Focus on Killings
text: BOSTON — The federal government moved on Tuesday to drop a racketeering case against the longtime fugitive James (Whitey) Bulger, saying it wanted to focus on a separate case that charges him with 19 murders, among other crimes.

headline: ‘Bachelorette,’ Seeking Love, Wins Eyes
text: ABC’s reality competition “The Bachelorette” posted its best ratings in three weeks on Monday, delivering the night’s largest audience with eight million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. The solid ratings helped ABC extended its winning streak to 16 weeks as the top-rated network on Monday night. NBC ranked second as “Law & Order: LA” finished in a tie with ABC’s “Extreme Makeover: Weight Loss Edition” at 10 p.m., each attracting 6.4 million viewers. Earlier, NBC’s rerun of “America’s Got Talent,” at 8 p.m., garnered 5.8 million viewers and “Law & Order: Criminal Intent” drew 4.8 million at 9, less than the five million viewers who watched a new episode of Fox’s “MasterChef” in the same time slot. For the night, however, Fox lagged behind CBS, which placed third with reruns of its sitcom line-up followed by a “Hawaii Five-0” repeat at 10 p.m. (5.8 million).

headline: Israeli Advocacy Group Helps Delay Departure of Gaza-Bound Flotilla
text: ATHENS — The departure of a pro-Palestinian flotilla of international ships planning to break Israel’s naval blockade of Gaza has been delayed, largely because of the efforts of an Israeli advocacy group, both sides said Tuesday.

headline: Is the Next Popemobile a Hybrid?
text: POPE BENEDICT XVI will soon go green, if not as green as he may have liked.

headline: Wall Street Cautious on Obama
text: The conventional wisdom is that Wall Street has turned its back on President Obama. But DealBook examines whether financial leaders are simply hedging their bets.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Sweet Smell of Success’
text: A. O. Scott looks back at an earlier era in the media business with the 1957 drama “Sweet Smell of Success,” directed by Alexander Mackendrick with a screenplay by Clifford Odets. Mr. Scott calls the film “a cookie full of arsenic; a delicious and dangerous tour of journalism’s dark underbelly.”

headline: Kvitova, in a Hail of Winners and Errors, Advances to Semifinals
text: WIMBLEDON, England – In a match of lopsided statistics and surprising lapses, Petra Kvitova of the Czech Republic defeated Tsvetana Pironkova of Bulgaria, 6-3, 6-7 (5), 6-2, to reach the Wimbledon semifinals for a second successive year.

headline: Hedging Bets on Obama
text: The conventional wisdom is that Wall Street has turned its back on President Obama. DealBook’s Evelyn M. Rusli and Andrew Ross Sorkin talk about whether financial leaders take issue with the Obama administration, or are simply being cautious.

headline: Despite Star Turn in ‘Cars 2,’ a Zündapp Janus Stays Humble
text: For enthusiasts of obscure midcentury car design, the star of the movie “Cars 2″ may be the villainous Professor Z, based on the Zündapp Janus of 1957 and 1958. The stubby vehicle, built by a traditional motorcycle maker, appears to have two front ends; it’s the automotive equivalent of Dr. Dolittle’s Pushmi-Pullyu.

headline: A Tree Grows in Athens
text: Athens is in trouble. The boutiques on the posh shopping streets of Kolonaki are empty. Constitution Square is a landfill of protest placards. And the normally cheery summer afternoon ritual — an iced Nescafé paired with half a pack of cigarettes — has become an exercise in existential brooding. “It makes me so sad,” Stefania Flenga, an executive for the boutique hotel chain Yes! Hotels, said while surveying the slow simmer of civil unrest on view in front of the Greek parliament. She was no doubt thinking about how all these disturbances are bad for the tourism industry, which accounts for almost 18 percent of the Greek economy. “They’re shooting themselves in the foot,” she said of the picketers.

headline: Sudan Signs Pact With Opposition Forces
text: JUBA, Sudan — Sudan’s government and southern-allied opposition forces in northern Sudan signed a framework agreement on Tuesday that called for the two sides to govern contested border states together and for opposition fighters to be absorbed into Sudan’s national army.

headline: Obama Adviser Defends Libya Policy to Senate
text: WASHINGTON — A resolution authorizing American intervention in Libya was approved on Tuesday by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, hours after members skeptically grilled the administration’s legal adviser over his assertion that airstrikes and other military measures did not amount to hostilities.

headline: A Yankee for a Moment, but a Met Forever
text: City Room was thrilled to receive a news release from the Department of Parks and Recreation on Tuesday afternoon announcing that all 54 outdoor city pools will open to the public on Wednesday. Our excitement, however, turned to something else entirely when we read that “former NY Yankee Lee Mazzilli” would be on hand for opening day at a pool in the Bronx.

headline: By Way of Chicago, David Henry Hwang Comedy ‘Chinglish’ Will Come to Broadway
text: If you had the number three in your office pool of how many new Broadway plays would be announced on Tuesday, prepare to collect your winnings. Adding to today’s embarrassment of Rialto riches, the producers Jeffrey Richards and Jerry Frankel said that they will bring a production of David Henry Hwang’s comedy “Chinglish” to Broadway in the fall, after its run at the Goodman Theater in Chicago ends in July.

headline: Google Says It Activates 500,000 Android Devices Daily
text: Andy Rubin, a vice president for engineering at Google who leads the company’s Google Android platform, said in a Twitter message Tuesday that the company was now activating over 500,000 Android devices each day.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: The Future of Medicare
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Unintended Humor of Google’s New Search Page
text: Today, Google quietly began a Web page called What Do You Love, or WDYL for short. (You have to type in www before wdyl.com to get the page.) It’s an aggregation of all the Google tools and services, centered around a search you enter on a familiar-looking search-box page. If you wanted to see all the things Google can do with, say, the Yankees, you could enter that word into the box and get a page that looks like this:

headline: Longevity Insurance: Buying Down the Risks of Living Too Long
text: Most people buy life insurance to protect against the risks of dying too soon. Now, there are new products offering the same protection if you live too long.

headline: A Live Chat About Shaken Baby Syndrome
text: So many of you were troubled and transfixed by Emily Bazelon’s New York Times Magazine article in February about shaken baby syndrome — and the growing evidence that caregivers might be wrongly accused.

headline: Changes in Madagascar’s Rivers and Lakes
text: Sunday, June 19

headline: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Greece, Libya, Iraq and Germany.

headline: Saudi Forces Withdrawing From Bahrain
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Saudi Arabia will withdraw most of its 1,200 troops from neighboring Bahrain by next week after a three-month mission to quell an uprising against the monarchy there, a Saudi official said on Tuesday.

headline: Raid by Afghan Forces and NATO Ends Attack on Hotel in Kabul
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Several heavily armed attackers stormed one of the capital’s fortified premier hotels on Tuesday night, and sporadic shooting and at least two loud explosions were heard as Afghan security forces battled insurgents for hours afterward.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Greece, Libya, Iraq and Germany.

headline: Champagne Wishes and Condominium Dreams
text: Gary Foster may have been a midlevel accountant in Citigroup’s office in Long Island City, Queens, earning $100,000 a year. But his real estate holdings were more fitting for a high-flying mogul.

headline: Hacker Group Releases Government Files
text: The hacker group Lulz Security appears to be keeping its promise of continued mayhem.

headline: Woods Is Doubtful for British Open
text: NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa. — Tiger Woods did not rule out playing in the British Open. But the bulk of his remarks Tuesday indicated that his ailing left knee and left Achilles’ tendon would not be healed in time for him to make the tournament, the season’s third major championship, at Royal St. George’s in two weeks.

headline: A Gateway to Great Books on Your iPhone
text: Penguin Classics, that more-than-1,500-titles collection of English-language literary classics, has a new free app for iOS devices available on Tuesday.

headline: Ex-Public Housing Official Is Fined
text: A former city public-housing official, who resigned after he was revealed to have used his letterhead to request leniency for a family friend facing pedophilia charges, has been fined $2,000 by the city’s Conflicts of Interest Board.

headline: A Second Try on Immigration Act
text: Senator Richard J. Durbin spoke to a crowd of capped and gowned young people, pumping then up with encouraging words as sustenance for their journey ahead. “When I look around this room, I see America’s future,” he said.

headline: Where There’s Smoke, There Are Inventive Chefs
text: Some of the world’s top chefs are finding sophisticated new ways of cooking on the grill.

headline: Ready, Set, Go | Fall Shopping
text: Believe it or not, cashmere sweaters and coats are about to fill the racks at Bergdorf’s and Barneys. Fall shopping is upon us, and like a well-organized student, preparation is the key to a successful season. Even if you’re part of the über-prepared Moda Operandi posse and have already pre-ordered your must-haves from the runway, we bet you still have some loose ends. Our tip sheet from the shopping experts should help you get a jump on fall.

headline: Youth Is Served in Women’s Semifinals
text: WIMBLEDON, England — So much for the graying of the Grand Slam women’s single champion. No matter who wins the Wimbledon title, the streak of consecutive majors in which each women’s finalist is at least 25 will be snapped.

headline: Could Obama Just Ignore the Debt Ceiling?
text: In the ongoing debate over raising the debt ceiling, one option has not had much prominence: whether the Obama administration could ignore it altogether, and just spend the money it owes anyway. Would that be legal?

headline: Shipwreck Show Postponed
text: The Smithsonian Institution has indefinitely postponed its plans to mount an exhibition of Chinese artifacts salvaged from a shipwreck because of opposition from archeologists who say the objects were collected by a commercial treasure hunter in a manner that violated professional standards. The exhibition, “Shipwrecked: Tang Treasures and Monsoon Winds,” was tentatively scheduled for next spring at the Freer Gallery of Art and Arthur M. Sackler Gallery, the Smithsonian’s Asian art museums. A museum spokeswoman, Deborah Galyan, said that the earliest the museum might mount a “Shipwrecked” exhibit now would be 2013, a delay that she said would give the museums’ director, Julian Raby, who also curated the exhibition, time to address some of the archeologists’ concerns. The exhibition was conceived by the government of Singapore, which bought the artifacts for $32 million from the company that salvaged them from a wreck off the coast of Indonesia. It is currently on view at the ArtScience museum at the Marina Bay Sands resort and casino in Singapore. The salvage company has said it mined the artifacts quickly to avoid looting.

headline: A Fan, a Fiancé, a Fellow Athlete
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Watching Maria Sharapova’s power and precision, the Centre Court crowd at Wimbledon fell into an awed silence Tuesday, one that was broken before or after some points by the clapping of one person. Without a word, Sasha Vujacic was communicating everything his fiancée, Sharapova, needed to hear during her 6-1, 6-1 quarterfinal victory against Dominika Cibulkova.

headline: TimesCast | June 28, 2011
text: The police clash with demonstrators in Athens; a media frenzy surrounds a flotilla headed to Gaza; and President Obama's relationship with Wall Street campaign donors.

headline: Yahoo Creates Company to Profit From Hadoop Software
text: Recent successes at Yahoo are few and far between as it tries to overhaul a slumping business. One notable exception – at least for Silicon Valley’s engineers – is the company’s role in pioneering Hadoop, free software for managing supersized amounts of information.

headline: The Mystery of Lagarde
text: OK, so it’s Christine Lagarde for the IMF. I wish her luck. And I wish we had any idea how well she’ll do the job.

headline: Same Numbers, Two Views of Fernandez
text: On draft night, the Dallas Mavericks traded away a late first-round pick for the opportunity to add veteran Rudy Fernandez to their championship core. For a team on Dallas’s timeline, the immediacy of such a move makes sense; there’s an allure in a proven N.B.A. rotation player over an untested prospect, even if some of the prospects available (Texas’ Jordan Hamilton, who was once viewed as a talent worthy of the late lottery, chief among them) have intriguing long-term potential.

headline: In Bob We Trust?
text: The tubes and wires that are the lifeblood of the Goal blog’s link to its readers have been overheating since Saturday’s Concacaf Gold Cup final, in which Mexico toyed with the United States in its 4-2 victory. Everyone is a critic and no person has come in for more criticism than the coach of the American team, Bob Bradley.

headline: Battle For Libya | June 28, 2011
text: According to AFP, in the latest fighting around the southwestern mountains, the rebels on Tuesday captured a network of bunkers in the desert about 15 miles from the hilltown of Zintan.

headline: A Milestone Goldman Would Rather Forget
text: Here’s a milestone Goldman Sachs won’t be celebrating.

headline: 3.5 Out of 4
text: A moment of self-reflection: to what extent has this slump played out the way I thought it would?

headline: Auto Clubs Prepare Support Systems for E.V. Owners
text: With more electric vehicles taking to the roads, auto clubs that offer roadside assistance are taking notice, with some beginning trial periods for mobile charging services, building charging stations and offering special insurance rates for E.V. owners.

headline: Paris Top 5 | Miharayasuhiro
text: The designer Mihara’s favorite song, Pink Floyd’s existential meditation “Wish You Were Here,” provided the source material for his elegaic Miharayasuhiro collection for spring/summer 2012. Choosing to forgo a runway show in place of a showroom presentation, he donated the saved funds to charities benefiting those affected by the tsunami in Japan. He applied flocked letters from the title of the song onto layers of jersey vests, shirts and jackets, letting the message continue to reveal itself. Paired with fleece shorts constructed from various necklines of T-shirts, the outfit was a moving, romantic take on the athletic wear we’ve seen this season.

headline: Imagine if Street Signs Told You What You Needed to Know
text: This week, the city’s Department of Transportation asked for proposals on new street signage that would help pedestrians navigate the city.

headline: After Two Courts and Two Sets, Azarenka Advances
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Victoria Azarenka of Belarus, the fourth seed, defeated Tamira Paszek of Austria, 6-3, 6-1, on Tuesday to gain the semifinals at Wimbledon. The match, begun late in the afternoon on Court 1, was shifted and completed on the covered Centre Court because of rain.

headline: A Gateway to Great Books on Your iPhone
text: Over on Gadgetwise, The Times’s personal tech blog, Sam Grobart writes about a new mobile app for book lovers:

headline: Speculation Behind High Gas Prices, Report Says
text: Speculative commodities trading on Wall Street is significantly inflating prices at the gas pump, according to a new report by researchers at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline: In an Adoptee’s Words
text: On Sunday, in a story about birth families finding each other on Facebook, I wrote about Jessi Wachtel, who reunited with her biological mother on the social media site. She is the young woman in the “Today” show video below.

headline: MSNBC Fares Well Without Olbermann
text: This week, MSNBC is concluding its first full quarter of the year since Keith Olbermann, its highest-rated host, abruptly left the cable news channel. The quarter’s ratings show just how well MSNBC is faring without him.

headline: Spine Experts Repudiate Medtronic Studies
text: In an extraordinary move, a group of spine specialists are publicly repudiating the research of other experts that has backed the widespread use of a Medtronic bone growth product. In a series of reports published in a medical journal on Tuesday, the specialists called the research misleading and biased.

headline: Video Shows Brazen Bushwick Copper Theft, Police Say
text: From the annals of brazen thievery that brought you the guy stealing the safe in Queens a couple of weeks ago comes the tale of the copper rustlers of Evergreen Avenue in Bushwick, Brooklyn.

headline: Wisconsin Senator Threatens to Protest Inaction on Budget
text: Given the glacial pace of activity in the Senate, it might be hard to tell if it was brought to a standstill.

headline: Hamlet as Eager Korean Prince
text: Melancholy? More like bloodthirsty.

headline: Dodgers and M.L.B. Compromise on Financing
text: The power struggle between the owner of the Los Angeles Dodgers and Major League Baseball ended in a temporary truce Tuesday as the parties agreed to let the team accept interim financing from an outside lender, and removed a key requirement tying the loan to a sale of the Dodgers’ future television rights.

headline: Reviewing Empellón
Empellón
text: ART is risk. So too is business.

headline: ‘Tomi Ungerer: Chronicler of the Absurd’
text: Images from a retrospective of the children’s books illustrator’s work at the Eric Carle Museum of Picture Book Art in Amherst, Mass.

headline: The Question ‘Who Is Herman Cain?’ Soon to Be a Book
text: Every presidential candidate needs a book, and Herman Cain, a Tea Party favorite who is running for the Republican nomination, will have his.

headline: They Might Find Romance if They Avoid the Crocodiles
text: Entering the phrase “reality dating shows” into Google delivers a grim cultural history of the millennium’s first decade. Has anything worthwhile been produced in any medium at all during the last 10 or so years? It is easy to forget when perusing a chronology that more or less begins with “Who Wants to Marry a Multimillionaire?” and takes us through to “Temptation Island,” “Joe Millionaire,” “The Bachelor,” “The Bachelorette,” “For Love or Money,” “Tough Love,” “A Shot at Love With Tila Tequila” and “The Littlest Groom,” a series in which short and average-size women competed for the attentions of a 4-foot-5 single man.

headline: Excerpt: 'Love in the Wild'
text: The new NBC reality dating series is set in the Costa Rican jungle.

headline: White House and Congress Clear Trade Deal Hurdle
text: WASHINGTON — The White House struck a deal with House Republicans Tuesday to reinstate benefits for workers who lose jobs to foreign competition, addressing a major obstacle to consideration of three free trade agreements with South Korea, Colombia and Panama.

headline: Conquering the Big City, With an Auntie Mame on Her Side
text: Early in the first episode of “State of Georgia,” an aspiring actress named Georgia Chamberlain (Raven-Symoné) is told by a Broadway casting director that she’ll never be a star because of her weight. “In ‘Damn Yankees,’ when they talk about the big seduction scene,” he sneers, “they don’t mean the size of the actress.”

headline: German Women Who Lead
text: A range of voices on the value of support at home and work, and on the drive and commitment needed to make a mark on the world.

headline: ‘The Steal’
text: Introduction

headline: Twitter Co-Founders Start (or Restart) a Company
text: Two of Twitter’s co-founders and its former product chief have joined forces to work on a new start-up, the Obvious Corporation, they said on Tuesday.

headline: Sticky Fingers, Used in Service of a Covetous Nature
text: Jack Kerouac said many things better than other writers have said them, and among those things, in “On the Road,” is this: “I suddenly began to realize that everybody in America is a natural born thief.”

headline: Christie’s Contemporary Art Sale Signals Continued Strength in Market
text: LONDON–Even after the May auctions in New York and last month’s Art Basel, the giant contemporary art fair in Switzerland, collectors were still spending big on post-war and contemporary art at Christie’s here on Tuesday night, where examples of blue chip artists topped expectations.

headline: Union Challenges State on Use of Tests in Teacher Evaluations
text: The usually friendly relationship between the state teachers union and the State Department of Education fissured on Tuesday with the union’s announcement that it was taking the state to court over new teacher evaluation rules.

headline: Excerpt: 'Necessary Roughness'
text: The new USA series is about a therapist to a football team.

headline: TimesCast | Athens Protests
text: June 28, 2011 — Days before Greece's Parliament votes to avoid a default, demonstrators took to the streets.

headline: The Enduring Mysteries of a Swan Queen and the Maidens Who Share Her Fate
text: “Swan Lake” is a drama of pathos on an extraordinarily grand scale. The swan-queen heroine, Odette, is intensely vulnerable — unless Prince Siegfried’s love can save her, she is doomed perpetually to return to swan form by day — but her fate is also bound up with that of her corps of swan maidens. When he starts to partner her and demonstrate both love and protectiveness, her own diffidence is extreme; she keeps withdrawing from his arms, one way or another.

headline: TimesCast | Flotilla Heads to Gaza
text: June 28, 2011 - Activists prepare a second flotilla to Gaza, leveraging the media's attention against Israeli policy.

headline: Excerpt: 'State of Georgia'
text: The new ABC Family series stars Raven-Symoné as an aspiring actress in New York.

headline: Supreme Court Has Ruled; Now Games Have a Duty
text: It is now the law of the United States that video games are art. It is now the law of the United States that video games are a creative, intellectual, emotional form of expression and engagement, as fundamentally human as any other.

headline: Being Markus Lupfer
text: With resort still going strong, designers are using art and film to show their collections. Last night at the Mondrian SoHo penthouse, the London-based, German-born designer Markus Lupfer premiered his collection with a mock sci-fi documentary. The director Tabitha Denholm was on hand to provide live commentary along with the actress Margo Stilley (who portrayed Dr. Lupfer). Cory Kennedy spun tracks with the city skyline providing the perfect backdrop. Tennessee Thomas of the Like slipped in and played “It’s My Party and I’ll Cry if I Want To” on the turntables. And all talk centered on the collection featuring bright colors and a clever fit. Here’s our exclusive look behind the scenes of the film, above, directed by Sean Frank.

headline: A Play Date With Champagne and Burgers
text: WHEN André and Rita Jammet closed La Caravelle seven years ago last month, devotees of classic French food in New York were bereft. So were devotees of the Jammets, who ran the dining room with requisite Gallic elegance limned with an almost familial warmth.

headline: No More Silent Summers
text: Of all the milestones in Alan Gilbert’s career, including his first program as music director of the New York Philharmonic in September 2009, no performance made him more visibly excited than the concert he conducted with the Philharmonic in Central Park on a balmy summer night in 2008.

headline: Tea Party Finds Power Leads to Policy Splits
text: HARRISBURG, Pa. — When Tea Party groups celebrated their victories here in November — they had helped take the governor’s office and the legislature — it seemed that one of their priorities, school choice legislation, would have an easy time passing.

headline: She Goes From Kitchen to the Locker Room
text: There is so much sports on television — not just the Super Bowl and ESPN but also the MLB Network, the Tennis Channel, the Golf Channel, NBA TV, the Big Ten Network and all those cable shows hooked on boxing, wrestling, cycling and fishing. What is remarkable is that so little of it has bled into dramas or comedies.

headline: Following in the Shadows of a Very Shadowy Man
text: When the central character in “Aurora” begins eyeballing another person — turning his shiver-inducing gaze on a complaining co-worker, on a salesgirl who anxiously laughs out of turn and even on a child who innocently returns his look — he seems like a man possessed. His eyes lock and the whites catch the light, shining without revelation. You may think you’re in Charles Manson-ville. (It’s only Romania.)

headline: Bloomberg Ad Invokes Al Qaeda in Fighting Illegal Guns
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is back on the air with another political ad, and this time his focus is guns.

headline: A Fictional Killer of Women Who Is All Too Familiar
text: A disturbed young man goes on a rampage in a public place, shooting down innocents and, usually, taking his own life. Such events are not exactly routine, but they are not rare, either, and those not directly affected may have trouble recalling the specific details of a particular massacre once the media frenzy has died down.

headline: Second Avenue and East 15th Street, 3:32 P.M.
text: Hong Mei Lin, left, Sheng Jiang, center, and Yanqing Li prepared for their commencement at Manhattan Comprehensive Day and Night High School.

headline: $8.5 Billion Deal Near in Suit on Bank Mortgage Debt
text: Bank of America is completing an agreement to pay $8.5 billion to settle claims by investors that purchased mortgage securities that soured when the housing bubble burst, according to people briefed on the deal. It represents what is likely to be the single biggest settlement tied to the subprime mortgage boom and the subsequent financial crisis of 2008.

headline: For These Chefs, Even Fire Can Be Improved
text: THE first thing you see on entering Elckerlijc, Peter De Clercq’s restaurant in Maldegem, Belgium, is a massive grill spewing sparks like a blast furnace in the open kitchen. But what you smell is more than just smoldering oak, apple or cherry wood.

headline: E.P.A.’s E15 Pump Labels Raise Ire of Automakers
text: Developed in cooperation with the Federal Trade Commission, the Environmental Protection Agency has unveiled a final label design to be displayed on fuel pumps that dispense the new E15 gasoline blend containing more than 10 percent and up to 15 percent ethanol.

headline: U.S.-India Talks Yield Little for Trade
text: WASHINGTON — Financial policy makers from the United States and India concluded a brief round of meetings Tuesday with talk of friendship but no specific agreements, a result that contrasted with the superficially similar talks between the United States and China last month.

headline: Afghans Report on Kabul Attack via Twitter
text: As my colleague Alissa Rubin reports, attackers stormed the Intercontinental Hotel in the Afghan capital, Kabul, Tuesday night, and witnesses said shooting and a loud explosion were heard as Afghan security forces rushed to the scene.”

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Artists Eat, Too

headline: The Beagle
text: To stand out in New York, a new restaurant needs a fresh concept. Retro? Done. Ditto cocktails and Greenmarket fare. What if you put all three together?

headline: Yuba
text: Kernels of sunny corn lie cradled in an emerald shiso leaf, tempura-ed whole to a featherlight crunch ($10). Diced maitake mushrooms and taro are hidden among the kernels, so the taste is sweet and earthy at once. There are only three leaves to an order. It is not enough.

headline: Caramelized Figs With Honey, Thyme and Crème Fraîche
text: Time: 15 minutes

headline: Food Trucks Shooed From Midtown
text: FOOD trucks, those rolling symbols of New York City’s infatuation with haute casual food, are suddenly being chased from Midtown Manhattan. In the last 10 days, the Treats Truck, which has sold cookies and brownies for four years during lunchtime at West 45th Street near Avenue of the Americas, has been told by police officers that it is no longer welcome there, nor at its late-afternoon 38th Street and Fifth Avenue location. The Rickshaw Dumpling truck, a presence for three years at West 45th Street near the Treats Truck, has been shooed away as well.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: On the Road Again, and Cooking, Too
text: UNGRATEFUL as it sounds, I occasionally tire of the same old backyard standbys churned out by the grill. I love a burger as much as the next person, but during the season for outside cooking and eating, there are so many more possibilities to explore. There is something about leaving the house, getting your hands dirty, and sharing food outdoors that makes everything taste better.

headline: Cantor Picks Up More Chips in Las Vegas
text: Cantor Fitzgerald has notched another win in Las Vegas.

headline: The Minimalist Grills
text: Mark Bittman demonstrates the art of cooking with fire, whether burgers, flatbread or fish.

headline: Tuesday at the Women’s World Cup
text: The United States scored twice in the second half to open its World Cup with a 2-0 victory over a young North Korean team. The North Koreans threatened in the first half, but halftime adjustments by the American team paid off as North Korea tired. Lauren Cheney and Rachel Buehler scored for the United States.Sweden labored to a 1-0 win in 90-degree heat over the long shots Colombia. Jessica Landstrom scored Sweden’s goal in the 57th minute after missing several chances.

headline: Stars Align for Yankees and Red Sox
text: Perhaps a more appropriate site for the All-Star Game on July 12 than Chase Field in Phoenix would be New Britain Stadium in Connecticut, and it just so happens that the Class AA Rock Cats are off that night.

headline: Recipes for Burgers
text: Spanning the entire burger spectrum, recipes for beef, turkey, veggie and other patties for the summer grill.

headline: Fans Fill Moleskine’s Notebooks With Love
text: MOST companies trumpet a new product line with great fanfare, including a big marketing campaign with print and television ads.

headline: Obama to Hold News Conference Wednesday
text: President Obama will hold a news conference on Wednesday morning in the East Room of the White House, the administration said on Tuesday.

headline: One Man’s Vision of the Mets
text: The Mets, sketched in blue and orange (when they win).

headline: Foreman Acquitted in Deadly Deutsche Bank Blaze
text: An asbestos-abatement foreman was acquitted on Tuesday of manslaughter and related charges he faced in the blaze at the former Deutsche Bank building near ground zero that killed two firefighters four years ago.

headline: Nadal Says He’ll Play; Fish Says He’ll Be Ready
text: WIMBLEDON, England — The most scrutinized body part in England outside of Pippa Middleton’s backside is Rafael Nadal’s left foot, which he injured in the first set of his fourth-round victory Monday against Juan Martín del Potro.

headline: Elaine Stewart, Sultry 1950s Actress, Dies at 81
text: Elaine Stewart, a sultry Hollywood actress who was promoted as a “dark-haired Marilyn Monroe” for her roles in 1950s films like “The Bad and the Beautiful” and “The Adventures of Hajji Baba,” died on Monday at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 81.

headline: American Ballet Theater’s ‘Swan Lake’
text: The week of performances at the Metropolitan Opera House is one of the annual climaxes of the city’s balletomania.

headline: Push to Repeal Ohio Law on Public Workers Gains Ground
text: An effort in Ohio to repeal a law reducing the power of public workers to bargain collectively moved forward this week, with the group leading the effort saying it had enough signatures to put it on the ballot and could deliver them to the state on Wednesday.

headline: Block That … Oh, Never Mind
text: That was fast.

headline: Bloggers Report on New Clashes in Cairo
text: Tear gas and rocks once again filled the air in Cairo’s Tahrir Square on Tuesday night following the arrests of protesters, journalists and bloggers reported from the Egyptian capital.

headline: Leaderless in Europe
text: The survival of the common European Union currency, free movement across national borders and trans-Atlantic collective security are all in serious doubt. Europe’s leaders are in denial or paralyzed.

headline: In Turkey, Lawmakers Refuse Oath in Protest
