text: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s newly elected Parliament convened on Tuesday, but 169 deputies refused to take their oaths of office in response to court rulings that barred 8 of their colleagues, currently in jail on terrorism-related charges, from joining the assembly.

headline: Jan van Beveren, Star Dutch Goalkeeper, Dies at 63
text: Jan van Beveren, a goalkeeper who towered over Dutch soccer during the game’s golden period in the Netherlands in the 1970s, died Sunday at his home in Beaumont, Tex. He was 63.

headline: Zynga Reaches Verge of Filing for I.P.O.
text: 8:07 p.m. | Updated

headline: Four Additions to the Hall, and an Intriguing Omission
text: Four former players were selected Tuesday for induction into the Hockey Hall of Fame, but officials and players found themselves answering questions on a teleconference about the gruff coach who did not get in: Pat Burns, who led the Devils to the Stanley Cup in 2003.

headline: Libyan Base Falls to a Rebel Raid in the West
text: EL GA’A, Libya — In darkness on Monday night and Tuesday morning, rebel soldiers from towns throughout the Nafusah Mountain region gathered to put the finishing touches on a bold mission: they planned to capture a sprawling military base controlled by government soldiers that was still stocked, they believed, with the kinds of weapons and ammunition that would help level their fight against the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Lorenzo Charles Dies at 47; Made Winning Dunk in 1983 N.C.A.A. Title Game
text: Lorenzo Charles, whose dunk in the final seconds of the 1983 National Collegiate Athletic Association national championship game propelled North Carolina State University to victory over Houston and himself to the realm of basketball legend, died Monday when the charter bus he was driving crashed in Raleigh, N.C. He was 47.

headline: Greece Demonstrations
text: Protesters hurled rocks and fire bombs at riot police in central Athens on Tuesday as a general strike against new austerity measures brought the country to a standstill.

headline: Egyptian Court Orders Dissolution of Mubarak-Era Local Councils
text: CAIRO — An Egyptian court on Tuesday ordered the dissolution of municipal councils nationwide, taking a major step toward dismantling one of the last political institutions of the former president, Hosni Mubarak.

headline: Iraq Veteran Offered Deal in Passport Violation Case
text: MIAMI — The federal government on Tuesday took the unusual step of offering to drop a passport violation prosecution of a Navy petty officer if he completed a term of probation.

headline: Niese Passes Tests After Rapid Heartbeat
text: DETROIT — Mets starter Jon Niese passed a battery of tests at Henry Ford Hospital on Tuesday that he underwent to help determine the cause and nature of his recurring rapid heartbeat.

headline: Palin, in Iowa, ‘Still Thinking About’ Running
text: PELLA, Iowa — Making a rare visit to early-voting Iowa, Sarah Palin stoked a new round of speculation about whether she would enter the 2012 presidential race — or was continuing a very public flirtation for ends known best to herself.

headline: New York Court Permits Banks to Sue MBIA
text: UBS, Bank of America and about a dozen other banks won reinstatement of a lawsuit against MBIA challenging the 2009 revamping of its insurance unit that guaranteed bad debt.

headline: A Parliament on the Move Grows Costly
text: BRUSSELS — Moving day had arrived. On a recent Friday evening, the color-coded crates were ready, some 2,500 of them stacked outside virtually every office door along the vast halls of the European Parliament complex here.

headline: Cartoons, Commentary and a Mets Community
text: Joe Petruccio has covered the Mets the last two seasons — in watercolors, black markers and ballpoint pens.

headline: Lawyers for 2 Ex-Officers Ask Judge to Bar Accuser From Speaking at Sentencing
text: The lawyers for two former police officers convicted of official misconduct stemming from their repeated visits to a drunken woman’s apartment in the East Village asked a judge on Tuesday to prevent the woman, who had accused their clients of rape, from making a statement before they are sentenced.

headline: Woods Reflects on His Latest Young Challenger
text: Obviously, Tiger Woods is not enjoying life on the shelf, unable to compete, unsure of when he will be ready, all the while having to listen to unflattering comparisons being made about how he measures up against a certain mop-headed golfer from Northern Ireland. But, to hear Woods tell it, he enjoyed watching Rory McIlroy’s dismantling of the field and the Congressional Country Club in his eight-stroke victory at the U.S. Open.

headline: Commercial Lenders Take Step Into Riskier Deals
text: The market for commercial real estate loans is coming back, but already some industry professionals are warning that risky practices that were common in the recent boom are returning.

headline: An Indiana Town Tries to Lure Renters With Ballpark Views
text: FORT WAYNE, Ind. — One of the quirks that endears Wrigley Field in Chicago to baseball fans are the rooftop views from houses on Waveland Avenue beyond left field. Now, developers in this city are hoping to bottle a little of that magic as part of an ambitious downtown renovation plan.

headline: Reflections on the Right to Privacy
text: To the Editor:

headline: For Amateur, It’s All About Fun, Not Turning Pro
text: NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa. — Like a lot of players at the AT&T National who are competing in their third event in three weeks, Patrick Cantlay looked forward to getting back to the hotel Tuesday, drying out and putting his feet up after a rainy practice round at Aronimink Golf Club.

headline: Is the Science Valid?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Debris Gives Space Station Crew Members a 29,000-M.P.H. Close Call
text: One of the hundreds of thousands of pieces of space-age litter orbiting Earth zipped uncomfortably close to the International Space Station on Tuesday.

headline: In Fleeing Security Forces, Syrians Get an Unexpected Taste of Freedom
text: GUVECCI, Turkey — From a rooftop in this dusty border town, Bilal looked out across the rugged valley to an abandoned refugee camp where he had fled advancing Syrian forces, fearing for his life, only to discover something quite unexpected: the feeling of freedom.

headline: Iran’s Nuclear Program: Its U.N. Mission Responds
text: To the Editor:

headline: Revealing Mental Illness
text: To the Editor:

headline: Women and Drug Policy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lawmakers Seek Inquiry of Natural Gas Industry
text: WASHINGTON — Federal lawmakers called Tuesday on several agencies, including the federal Securities and Exchange Commission, the Energy Information Administration and the Government Accountability Office, to investigate whether the natural gas industry has provided an accurate picture to investors of the long-term profitability of their wells and the amount of gas these wells can produce.

headline: Natural Gas Bidding War Puts Spotlight on a Billionaire
text: A multibillion-dollar takeover battle broke out last week over a Houston company that owns 20,000 miles of natural gas pipelines running from the southeastern tip of Florida to the Oklahoma Panhandle.

headline: When Fashion Meets Fishing, the Feathers Fly
text: CAPE NEDDICK, Me. — The most enthusiastic customers at the Eldredge Brothers Fly Shop of late are not looking to buy fly fishing reels or snag stripers. They are here to make a fashion statement.

headline: Teenager Charged in Gang Case Surrenders
text: A Harlem teenager who received the financial and spiritual support of the Abyssinian Baptist Church after she was charged with being involved in a gang surrendered herself to jail on Tuesday as part of a plea deal.

headline: Venezuelan, Like Castro, Has Brother at the Ready
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — To the many comparisons that can been made between Venezuela and Cuba — two close allies, both infused with revolutionary zeal, driven by movements that revere their leaders — consider one more: the presidential brother, stepping in during a time of illness.

headline: Administration Halts Survey of Making Doctor Visits
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Tuesday that it had shelved plans for a survey in which “mystery shoppers” posing as patients would call doctors’ offices to see how difficult it was to get appointments.

headline: In a Greek Default, Higher Risk for Money Market Funds
text: Money market funds have long been a popular haven for conservative investors, but they could become one way that the tremors of the financial crisis in Greece touch the pocketbooks of Americans — about 50 million of them.

headline: Campaign Heats Up in Iowa as Obama and Republicans Call
text: BETTENDORF, Iowa — Republican presidential hopefuls have been thick on the ground in Iowa in recent days, searching for the kind of early voter validation that gave Barack Obama’s long-shot candidacy a propulsive lift in 2008.

headline: A Bountiful Harvest, Rooted in a Former Settlement’s Soil
text: GAZA — Hundreds of acres of watermelons, orange saplings and grapevines stretch in orderly rows out to the horizon. Irrigation hoses run along the sand, dripping quietly. Apple trees are starting to blossom nearby. Avocados and mangoes are on their way.

headline: Eugene H. Kummel, Who Led Major Ad Agency in Expansion, Dies at 88
text: Eugene H. Kummel, a former chairman and chief executive of one of the world’s largest advertising agencies, McCann Erickson Worldwide, died on Saturday in Boston. He was 88.

headline: Judge May Order Reporter to Testify Against Ex-C.I.A. Officer Accused of Leaks
text: WASHINGTON — In a legal opinion unsealed on Tuesday, a federal judge indicated that she might require a New York Times reporter who wrote a book about the Central Intelligence Agency to testify at the trial of a former C.I.A. officer accused of leaking classified information.

headline: Jury to Hear Recordings, Not Witness, on Murder
text: A Bronx judge, faced with a witness who was reluctant to testify in the murder trial of a reputed gang member, said Tuesday that prosecutors could present records of statements the witness had made before being subjected “to threats and outright physical attacks.”

headline: Breast Cancer Patients Plead for Avastin Approval
text: With desperate breast cancer patients imploring the Food and Drug Administration to change its mind, the agency’s staff calmly argued Tuesday that the drug Avastin should lose its approval as a treatment for that disease.

headline: Keeping Artificial Limbs Low-Cost, and High-Quality
text: In response to Friday’s column about the Jaipur Limb, an inexpensive, locally-made artificial leg that has helped millions of impoverished people in poor countries to regain their dignity and livelihood, Laurie C. from Marina,Calif., (5), a reader who uses a wheelchair, made an important point:  “It can be scary to know that you live in a body that is so dependent on inanimate equipment that if you don’t have that equipment, you basically fall off the radar of life itself,” she wrote. “You disappear from society, people avoid you, you become ‘a burden’ … all for the lack of a piece of equipment.”   This is a very persuasive argument for why a low-cost wide-scale product like the Jaipur Limb is necessary.

headline: Bloggingheads: Afghanistan and Terrorism
text: Michael Cohen, left, of the American Security Project and Daniel Serwer of Johns Hopkins University debate withdrawing from Afghanistan.

headline: Debt Limit Dog Days
text: Monday’s meeting between President Obama and the Senate minority leader, Mitch McConnell, was intended to revive the debt-limit talks after Republican negotiators walked out last week, insisting that they won’t agree to raise the limit unless Democrats agree to trillions of dollars in deficit reduction — with no tax increases at all.

headline: The Judge Who Cracked the Bulger Case
text: For anyone trying to fathom James (Whitey) Bulger’s long, pathological career on both sides of the law, a 661-page opinion by Mark Wolf, chief judge of the Federal District Court in Massachusetts, tells the inside story.

headline: For Lee, if Not the Phillies, Everything Is Breaking Right
text: PHILADELPHIA

headline: Mining and the Canyon
text: The Obama administration has extended for six months a 2009 moratorium on new uranium mining claims on one million acres around the Grand Canyon. This is good news; even better is the promise from Ken Salazar, the interior secretary, that he will soon recommend a 20-year ban on new claims in the region. That is the maximum allowed under the 1872 mining law.

headline: Should Justices Keep Their Opinions to Themselves?
text: Washington

headline: Dodd-Frank Rekindles Old Debate
text: One of the most classic American political debates — state versus federal law — is surfacing again in the banking sector, as regulators work to put in place the financial reforms passed a year ago in Washington.

headline: N.B.A. and Union to Meet on Eve of Deadline
text: If the N.B.A. and its players have any hope of striking a deal and avoiding a lockout, it will have to happen Thursday afternoon, with just hours left on the bargaining clock.

headline: Wednesday: You There?
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s midweek, and to help us over the hump we have a very punny puzzle today from Tony Orbach. Not only that, but it has almost a meditative quality, since all of the puns use the “om” sound. I hope you all did the puzzle in lotus pose, as I did. Don’t worry too much if the theme entries were not soundalikes; they’re puns, and it’s O.K. for them to be a bit loose. Besides, too much complaining will harsh my mellow, man.

headline: The Hague: Onus Put on Libyans
text: The prosecutor of the International Criminal Court in The Hague said Tuesday that enforcing the newly issued arrest warrants for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, one of his sons and his intelligence chief was mainly the responsibility of Libya because the war crimes investigation that led to the warrants had been ordered by a resolution of the United Nations Security Council. The prosecutor, Luis Moreno-Ocampo, said at a news conference that two Libyan rebel leaders were in The Hague for talks with his office about their plans, and that arrests could be just months away.

headline: After 26 Years, Shaper of an Influential Radio Station Signs Off
text: Drawers pulled out. Empty boxes, with the flaps winged open. Ralph Jennings was packing up his things after 26 years at WFUV-FM, where he had transformed a chaotic college radio station at Fordham University with a tiny audience into one of the leading public radio outlets in the country and a rare cultural force.

headline: Sony Cuts Howard Stringer’s Pay Package as Chairman by 15%
text: The Sony Corporation, reeling from Japan’s biggest earthquake and a huge data breach, cut the pay of its chairman, Howard Stringer, and his probable successor.

headline: Mayor Elected in Miami-Dade County Runoff
text: MIAMI — Three months after the previous Miami-Dade County mayor was recalled, Carlos Gimenez, a former city manager, fire chief and county commissioner, was elected to replace him on Tuesday in a runoff race that drew meager voter enthusiasm.

headline: Obama’s Position on Gay Marriage Faces New Test
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama’s guests arrive at the White House on Wednesday for a Gay Pride reception — just days after New York became the largest state in the country to make same-sex marriage legal — they will no doubt be in a mood to celebrate.

headline: For New Schools Chief, a Policy Statement in Tones of Harmony
text: Dennis M. Walcott, New York City’s schools chancellor, hates prepared texts for speeches and wears a pedometer to count his daily steps. So it stands to reason that during a 14-stop marathon of graduations over the past week, he frequently abandoned his seat and improvised.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Making the Argument for Greece’s Austerity Plan
text: The Greek Parliament is prepared to vote on austerity measures on Wednesday, and its people have been gathering in demonstrations and strikes to protest the cuts. Here is an open letter explaining why members of Parliament would be crazy to vote no:

headline: Pomp, Diplomas and Words of Inspiration
text: Dennis M. Walcott  spoke about his own experience in Queens public schools. He described skydiving on his 50th birthday. And he told graduates all over New York City, those finishing fifth, eighth or 12th grade or getting a G.E.D., that he hoped one of them would take his job someday. Mr. Walcott, who became schools chancellor in April, has spoken at 14 commencement ceremonies this month (a 15th was planned for Belmont Preparatory High School in the Bronx on Wednesday), far more than his predecessors (Joel I. Klein addressed four in each of the past two years). On Tuesday, Mr. Walcott spoke at the commencement of his alma mater, Francis Lewis High School.

headline: Cuomo Takes Tough Stance on Nuclear Reactors
text: ALBANY — One of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s top advisers met with the operators of the Indian Point nuclear plant last week and told them that the governor was determined to close the plant.

headline: Mets’ Stretch Without a Slam? Gone. Gone.
text: DETROIT — For a franchise that was once credited with a one-run single when Robin Ventura hit a ball over the fence with the bases loaded, the grand slam has been most elusive for the Mets. For more than two seasons, it was as unattainable as a no-hitter.

headline: What Fish Needs to Do Against Nadal
text: Mardy Fish has never beaten Rafael Nadal, and will have to play the match of his life to win on Wednesday. He has to formulate a shrewd game plan, matching his strengths against Nadal’s one or two less than stellar tendencies, then quickly recalibrate when Nadal makes a subtle adjustment.

headline: Yankees Make Quick Work of a Pitcher They Once Coveted
text: The quirks of interleague scheduling yielded two nearly identical matchups Tuesday night, about 100 miles apart, for the American League elite. As a former Cy Young Award winner ushered his division-leading team into Yankee Stadium, the Boston Red Sox drew a similar challenge down the turnpike in Philadelphia. And for that stroke of serendipity, the Yankees are thankful.

headline: In China, Gender Roles Help Eradicate a Stigma
text: Lesbians in China today are remarkably free, the result of profound social changes over three decades of fast economic growth, and of being female in a society that values men far above women.

headline: As California Democrats Agree on Budget, Governor’s Goal Remains Unmet
text: LOS ANGELES — When he took over as governor this year, Jerry Brown set his ambitions high. He wanted to break the partisan gridlock that had handicapped the Legislature for years. With the state facing a staggering deficit, Mr. Brown said over and over that he refused to close the gap with the same sort of smoke-and-mirrors budget tricks that the state had relied on for years.

headline: Red Bulls Advance in Cup
text: The host Red Bulls defeated F.C. New York, 2-1, to advance to the quarterfinals of the U.S. Open Cup. F.C. New York, an expansion team in the U.S.L. Pro league, scored first against their Major League Soccer rivals with a 56th minute goal by Owen Morrison. But the Red Bulls quickly responded with goals by Corey Hertzog and John Rooney. The Red Bulls’ next Cup opponent will be the Chicago Fire in Chicago.

headline: Clip 1: The First Mark
text: Behind the scene sat Peter Nadin's farm, located in the Catskill Mountains of New York State.

headline: Clip 2: The First Mark
text:
Behind the scenes at Peter Nadin's farm, located in the Catskill Mountains of New York State.

Film by Natsuko Uchino and Aimée Toledano. Written by Peter Nadin.

headline: Utopia on the Hudson
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Sponsor Extends Deal
text: Barclays has extended its current sponsorship deal with the PGA Tour to run through 2016, according to a person briefed on the agreement. The 2011 Barclays, which kicks off the four-tournament Playoffs for the FedExCup, will be played Aug. 25 to 28 at Plainfield Country Club in Edison, N.J.

headline: RockMelt Gets Backing From Accel
text: RockMelt, the Web browser for the Facebook set, made a splashy debut in August, in part because of the prominence of its backers. They included Marc Andreessen, the father of the Internet browser, and Bill Campbell, one of Silicon Valley’s most respected executives.

headline: A Union Plan for Financing Construction
text: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. said it would announce on Wednesday that it intends to work with pension fund managers to ensure that at least $10 billion in union pension money is made available in the next five years to finance infrastructure projects.

headline: Lessons From Exercising in the Heat
text: Use your head when exercising in the heat. That is the overt message of a series of recent studies showing that cooling the neck before exercise in hot, humid conditions can improve athletic performance. But the research also raises this provocative issue: Even if you can exercise harder in the heat, is it really a good idea to do so?

headline: Conflict in Gaza: Day 21
text: The three-week-old Gaza war continued to rage as diplomats in Cairo and Washington worked to secure a cease-fire.

headline: Reader-Submitted Photos: Jet in Hudson River
text: Photographs sent to NYTimes.com from readers at the scene.

headline: A Populist’s Legacy
text: Andrew Wyeth, one of the most popular and also most lambasted artists in the history of American art, died at his home in Chadds Ford, Pa. He was 91.

headline: Word of the Day | luxuriate
text: luxuriate •\ˈlək-sh(ə-)re-at, -zh(ə-)re-at\• verb

headline: Against Murray, Lopez Has Nothing to Lose
text: Feliciano Lopez plays Andy Murray in the second match on Center Court today. Lopez has a huge lefty serve, a much improved net game, and a dangerous, difficult to read forehand. In the past his backhand was easy for the top players to attack, and Lopez seemed stuck in the role of talented journeyman.

headline: NYT: Front Page for 06/29/2011
text: NYT: Front Page for 06/29/2011

headline: Schroeder’s (and Schulz’s) Muse
text: “Schulz’s Beethoven: Schroeder’s Muse,” at the Charles M. Schulz Museum in Santa Rosa, Calif., looks at the composer’s role in the “Peanuts” strips.

headline: Star Athlete Killed Hours After High School Graduation
text: A star high school football player was stabbed to death in the Bronx just hours after his graduation on Tuesday, the police said. The stabbing took place during an argument in a parking lot over property missing from his family’s car, they said. The victim, Isayah Muller, 19, was a noted running back at Truman High School in the Bronx, where he earned widespread coverage for his success on the field.

headline: News Quiz | June 29, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Attack at Kabul Hotel Deflates Security Hopes in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Nazir Amini, an Afghan visiting from his home in Germany, had just returned from the buffet with a bowl of ice cream when two men with an AK-47 rifle and a machine gun started shooting guests around the pool at the Intercontinental Hotel, one of the capital’s most fortified buildings.

headline: Bucking Russian Trend, Global Ports Rises 15% in Debut
text: Global Ports, the Russian ports operator, saw its shares soar open 15 percent above their offer price on the company’s debut in London on Wednesday.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, June 29, 2011
text: Test your math skills with today’s question, created by Kari Kokka at Math for America from the article “Small Group Rode LinkedIn to Big Payday.”

headline: What Does Newt Gingrich Know?
text: Let’s consult the literature — all 21 books by the self-proclaimed ideas man of politics. (Gingrich cites 23 books on his Web site. We are not counting the Contract With America or the coffee-table book “Ronald Reagan: Rendezvous With Destiny.”)

headline: Inside a Cambodian Building, a Feeling
text: It’s not that Carlotta Zarattini can’t explain why she wanted so badly to photograph a dilapidated marvel of 1960s architecture in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, known as the White Building. It’s just that she has trouble putting it into words. It’s more of a feeling.

headline: Greece Approves Tough Measures on Economy
text: ATHENS — Greek lawmakers voted on Wednesday to sharply reduce government spending and sell off an array of national assets, staving off default on the country’s debt and easing, for the moment, a crisis among countries that use the euro.

headline: Top 10 Wide Receivers in N.F.L.
text: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely -– but not strictly -– by film study of all 32 teams from the 2010 season. Stats weren’t acknowledged, but players with poor numbers generally don’t make top 10 lists anyway. Vague enough for you? Criteria for top 10 lists tend to be. That’s why most of you will have no trouble finding some disagreement with what you’re about to read.

headline: The Early Word: Halted
text: Today’s Times

headline: Summertime Blues for Teenagers
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: Amsterdam Airport Opens Indoor Park
text: Air travel is no walk in the park these days — unless, of course, you are flying through Amsterdam’s Schiphol Airport. Last month, Schiphol unveiled the world’s first Airport Park, a 20,000-square-foot park within the international airport, beyond security and passport control.

headline: Who’s Driving That Thing? In Nevada, Perhaps Nobody
text: My dad, who at 98 no longer drives, used to complain about women drivers, defensive drivers, slow drivers, cab drivers and, occasionally, fast drivers.

headline: Lawyer for Released Chinese Artist Seeks Review on Taxes
text: BEIJING — Ai Weiwei, the artist and government critic who emerged last week from nearly three months in police custody, is facing nearly $2 million in fines and unpaid taxes, according to his mother and a lawyer retained by his design company.

headline: Farewell to the ‘Butter-Cow Lady’
text: WHO was Norma Lyon?

headline: Do You Know Your Way Around Your City or Town?
text: New York City has announced that it will install new pedestrian-friendly street signs. One option under consideration is the “You Are Here” map, commonly seen at malls and amusement parks. Could you use signs like that to help you navigate the place where you live?

headline: A Cheaper Way to Navigate Abroad, No Costly Data-Roaming Required
text: A few years ago I took a trip to Europe and brought along my new iPhone for a bit of sightseeing. With international roaming charges so high I reduced my e-mail and Web browsing to a mere trickle, thinking I’d save a bit of money. Little did I know that downloading maps would push my bill over the edge, resulting in a nearly $1,000 bill. “Never again,” I swore beneath the Eiffel Tower, “will mapping cost me so much.”

headline: What Some Banks Don’t Want You to Know
text: Several weeks ago, the top small-business bankers at Wells Fargo agreed to take questions from You’re the Boss readers. For reasons that escape me, I’ve found that bankers are often reluctant to tell small-business owners precisely what they expect from borrowers, so I couldn’t resist contributing a few questions.

headline: Republican Voters Lack Enthusiasm for Presidential Contenders, Poll Shows
text: Republican voters are not satisfied with the candidates running for the Republican nomination and wish they had more choices, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. None of the candidates currently hoping to challenge President Obama in 2012 has earned enthusiastic support from more than 7 percent of Republican voters.

headline: U.S. and European Markets Rise on Optimism Over Greek Vote
text: The markets finally exhaled.

headline: The Battle Over Southern Union, Another Round
text: The bidding war for Southern Union has turned into a battle of lawyers.

headline: Male or Female? Good Question!
text: Kay E. Holekamp, a zoologist at Michigan State University, writes from the Masai Mara National Reserve in Kenya, where she is studying the behavior of spotted hyenas.

headline: 2012 Republicans Ignore Each Other, for Now
text: The odd truth about the 2012 Republican presidential primary is that there really isn’t one yet.

headline: Mobile Payments Start-Up Square Raises $100 Million
text: Square, the mobile payments start-up, has raised $100 million in a financing round led by Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers. As part of the deal, Mary Meeker, a partner at Kleiner Perkins, will join Square’s board.

headline: Former Top Lehman Banker Arrested
text: Bradley H. Jack, a former investment banking chief at Lehman Brothers, was recently arrested after he used a forged prescription to obtain Oxycontin and Ritalin pills from a CVS store in Connecticut, a police official said.

headline: More Secrecy in Silicon Valley
text: Last week I took a trip to Silicon Valley, zigzagging around to meet with start-ups, venture capitalists and the big technology companies that inhabit the area. My goal with these meetings was to get a glimpse of new themes and services consumers could soon expect to see.

headline: What’s Loeb Got To Do, Got To Do With It?
text: They like me, they really like me. And congrats to Ron Lieber.

headline: BJ’s Wholesale Agrees to $2.8 Billion Buyout
text: 5:00 p.m. | Updated

headline: Wrestling With Recovery Is No Fairy Tale
text: SOMEWHERE near the middle of “The _______ With the Hat,” Stephen Adly Guirgis’s lacerating portrait of a couple trapped in the self-inflicted prison of addiction, it becomes clear that simply putting the cork in the bottle will not fix everything. Or anything, really.

headline: What Did You Learn From 9/11?
text: August 12, 2011 | Updated  Tomorrow, Saturday, August 13, The Times will be filming for several hours near the Grand Army Plaza Greenmarket at Prospect Park in Brooklyn, starting at 10 a.m. See below for more information about this project. Or, on Twitter, tweet to @LisaIaboni, the journalist leading the project with questions. We hope to see you there.

headline: Join in the Live Chat
text: From 1 to 2 Wednesday afternoon Motherlode will be co-hosting a conversation about “The Child Cases,” a documentary that is the joint effort of “Frontline” (where it aired Tuesday night), ProPublica and NPR. There are links below if you would like to watch the video before you join the chat.

headline: Bank of America Settles Claims Stemming From Mortgage Crisis
text: Just how much will it cost the big banks to atone for the mortgage mess?

headline: Farm to Gallery: Peter Nadin’s Comeback
text: “A carrot is not a work of art. I’m not proposing that anyone think of a carrot as a work of art. But what I am saying is that a carrot and the art I make here are both results of the same process.”

headline: What Constitutes a Just Sentence?
text: Updated, 2:04 p.m. | Kenneth Moreno and Franklin L. Mata dodged a bullet for a while longer.

headline: The Lawyer Behind the Bank of America Settlement
text: 4:40 p.m. | Updated DealBook doesn’t have a lawyer of the day award. But if it did the nod would go to Kathy D. Patrick, a litigator at a small Houston firm who stared down Bank of America and secured an $8.5 billion settlement for her clients — and an $85 million payday for her and her partners.

headline: What to Wear When | Advice From the Terribly Chic
text: Outnet.com, a spinoff from Net-a-Porter, sells designer clothes from past seasons at a considerable discount. Thirty percent off Calvin Klein Collection, not to mention a 50 percent markdown on Marc Jacobs, makes shopping not only a bargain but also just plain fun. We’ve found the hodgepodge of merchandise (and frequent additions) a great way to get what you wanted the first time around but denied yourself because you were being a good girl. Also, the site’s “dress me” tab helps you plug the gaps in your wardrobe rather than spend a fortune on the season’s “It” items. To help you pick and choose among deals — and create stellar ensembles for every day, as well as special occasions — scroll down for looks put together by the terribly chic girls behind Outnet’s success.

headline: Video of Attack on Kabul Hotel
text: As my colleagues Alissa Rubin and Rod Nordland report, after hours of fighting, on Wednesday morning, Afghan and NATO forces finally managed to take control of the Intercontinental Hotel in Afghanistan’s capital, Kabul, after a deadly raid by Taliban militants.

headline: President Obama Sets News Conference This Morning
text: President Obama will take questions from reporters this morning as Greece passed an austerity plan to avert economic turmoil, terrorists struck overnight in the capital of Afghanistan and the deadline neared for a deal to raise America’s debt ceiling.

headline: Clashes Ease in Cairo, but Underline Nation’s Fragile Condition
text: CAIRO — Clashes between the police and protesters that began Tuesday night and carried into Wednesday morning left more than 1,000 people injured in the worst violence to grip the capital since President Hosni Mubarak was forced from power in February.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: TOP STORIES

headline: Wednesday Reading: Feathers-in-Hair Fad Angers Fly Fishermen
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Sony Names New Management for Global PlayStation Unit
text: TOKYO — Sony said on Wednesday that it would shuffle the management of its video game unit, two months after an extensive hacking attack forced the company to shut down its popular PlayStation Network.

headline: Offering Web Buyers a Thrill of Discovery
text: Many consumers would say the Internet has improved shopping, bringing books and fashion, groceries and electronics to our doors with ease.

headline: Trading Firms Await New Derivatives Regulations
text: Wall Street is waiting on Washington.

headline: Group Sues to End N.Y.’s Role in Regional Cap-and-Trade
text: Members of Americans for Prosperity, a group founded and largely financed by oil industry interests, filed a lawsuit this week seeking to end New York State’s participation in the 10-state Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: The Future of Same-Sex Marriage Ballot Measures
text: Last week’s passage of a bill to make New York’s marriage law gender-neutral may accelerate efforts to put the issue before voters in other states.

headline: What If a Food Truck Can’t Park?
text: Is homelessness the looming future for the food trucks of New York?

headline: Can’t Take Brooklyn Out of Blankfein
text: When you visit Bed-Stuy, you don’t necessarily think of Goldman Sachs.

headline: ‘Best Rooney Ever’
text: HARRISON, N.J. — It was probably fitting that John Rooney’s game-winning goal in the Red Bulls’ Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup victory Tuesday night was not a scorching blast into the upper corner, but rather a well-placed shot into the bottom corner that had barely enough speed to beat F.C. New York’s keeper.

headline: Delays at J.F.K.? This Time, Blame Turtles
text: Runway 4 Left at Kennedy International Airport was closed for more than an hour on Wednesday morning.

headline: Rupert Goold’s ‘Decade’ to Tackle Legacy of 9/11
text: Rupert Goold, whose directing credits include “Enron” and “Macbeth” starring Patrick Stewart, is set to create a play about the legacy of 9/11 on its 10th anniversary this year, working with a roster of writers from Britain and this country for a London premiere on Sept. 1. The play, “Decade,” which was conceived and developed by Mr. Goold with Robert Icke, is still in contract negotiations, but John Logan (“Red”) and Alecky Blythe (“London Road”) are reported to be among the writers. Mr. Goold has his own theater company, Headlong.

headline: What’s a Reasonable Home Down Payment?
text: Pretty much everyone agrees it’s a good idea for home buyers to put some of their own money down when borrowing to buy a house. Having a stake in the property, the thinking goes, encourages homeowners to keep making payments on the mortgage.

headline: Making Sickle Cell Disease a Manageable Illness
text: On most days Giovanna Poli acts like a typical 12-year-old. She enjoys riding bikes with her brother, likes learning about the planets in science class and wants to be a pediatrician when she grows up.

headline: What to Ask Your Doctor About Sickle Cell Disease
text: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening and, because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why they’re important.

headline: The Doubts of a Stay-at-Home Dad
text: Our conversation about the June selection for the Motherlode Book Club is winding down (look for the announcement of the July book right after Independence Day…), and Vincent O’Keefe has been watching that conversation closely. As a stay-at-home father to two daughters, he has been “thinking a lot about a surprising issue the book raises indirectly,” he explained in an e-mail, specifically:

headline: When to Back Off?
text: My dad, Murray, is a chatty, gregarious guy — so I told the dining room manager when she stopped by on Day 1 at his new independent living apartment. This facility uses assigned seating at mealtimes, and I wanted his companions to be lively and stimulating.

headline: I.M.F. Offers a Different Take on U.S. Growth
text: We pay a lot of attention to the Federal Reserve’s economic forecasts. It’s worth paying at least a little attention to a second opinion offered Wednesday by the International Monetary Fund, which houses another of the world’s largest herds of economists just three city blocks away.

headline: June 29, 1995 | U.S. Shuttle Docks at Russian Space Station
text: On June 29, 1995, the shuttle Atlantis and the Russian space station Mir docked, forming the largest man-made satellite ever to orbit the Earth.

headline: On the Albanian Riviera, a Frugal Paradise
Face Time | Liv Tyler
text: Tina Turnbow is a professional makeup artist, who is known for lending her celebrity clients editorial polish.

headline: What You Need to Know About Sickle Cell Disease
text: Sickle cell disease is an inherited disorder that causes the red blood cells to be abnormally shaped and get stuck inside the blood vessels, making it hard to deliver oxygen throughout the body. This causes intense pain and can lead to infection and severe complications like organ damage and stroke. Here are five things leading physicians in the field say you should know about the disease.

headline: Selected Studies: Sickle Cell Disease
text: Government agencies, universities and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies developed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

headline: The Fish That Lay the Golden Eggs
text: ABU DHABI — Abu Dhabi is talking caviar on a scale that would make czars blush.

headline: An Expert Talks About Sickle Cell Disease
text: In the Times Health Guide, Carolyn Sayre looks at sickle cell disease, an inherited illness that can cause bouts of crippling pain and debilitation. Here she talks with Dr. George Buchanan, a professor of pediatrics at University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center at Dallas. As director of the Southwest Comprehensive Sickle Cell Center at Children’s Medical Center, he oversees the care of some 650 patients with sickle cell disease.

headline: Credit Suisse to Cut 600 Jobs
text: Credit Suisse plans to cut about 600 jobs across its global investment banking operation because demand for its products and services has dropped, said a person with direct knowledge of the scheduled layoffs.

headline: In Port, Familiar Flavors (Like Blood Stew) Far From Home
text: When the towering cruise ships pull into the dock at Red Hook, Brooklyn, their passengers pile into fleets of taxis and shuttle buses, cameras and sunscreen in tow.

headline: Jill Scott Earns Her First No. 1 Record
text: Two new singers take over the Billboard album chart this week with modest sales.

headline: Sudanese Leader Is Welcomed in Visit to China
text: BEIJING — The president of Sudan, who faces indictment by an international court on war crimes and genocide charges, met President Hu Jintao of China and reviewed an honor guard in Beijing on Wednesday, a ceremonial start to a visit overshadowed by the impending division of Sudan into two nations next month.

headline: Second Acquittal in Deutsche Bank Fire Trial
text: A site safety supervisor was acquitted of all charges on Wednesday in the fire at the former Deutsche Bank building near ground zero that killed two firefighters four years ago.

headline: Tsonga Stuns Federer at Wimbledon
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Pete Sampras, the greatest men’s player of the 1990s, has had to be a good sport as his records, which appeared poised to last for decades, have tumbled like dominoes to the all-surface pressure applied by Roger Federer.

headline: Star Power Rules
text: Women’s tennis has become the classic sports conundrum, the constant pull between a sport’s desire for star power and its need to develop future stars. We know television votes for the established stars every time — NBC hopes the Williams sisters play until they’re in their 50s — so as long as Maria Sharapova lasts at Wimbledon, we will get repeated close-ups of her hair being tucked behind her ear interspersed with shots of her boyfriend, Sasha Vujacic, cheering from the stands.

headline: School Custodians Accused of Stealing $500,000 From City
text: Updated, 2:51 p.m. | Four former New York City school custodial workers were arrested on Wednesday on charges they stole roughly $500,000 from the city through a pair of parallel schemes that included holding jobs they never performed, and doing maintenance work on private properties on the public dime. A fifth employee was still being sought, officials said.

headline: Unprofitable Square Valued at $1.6 Billion
text: Square, the fast-growing mobile payments company, does not suffer from a lack of buzz.

headline: The Prokhorov Effect: Part 2
text: Nets owner and multibillionaire Mikhail Prokhorov was elected this weekend to lead Russia’s Right Cause, an opposition party, of sorts. As The Times noted: “In his speech on Saturday, Mr. Prokhorov clarified that he is opposed to the political party Mr. Putin founded, called United Russia, and that Right Cause will take on his party in the elections. But at a subsequent news conference, he suggested that he may not openly criticize Mr. Putin personally. He said Mr. Putin is not always in full agreement with United Russia.”

headline: S.E.C. Proposes Ethics Rules on Derivatives
text: Securities regulators proposed a series of new ethics standards for the derivatives industry on Wednesday, spelling out a code of conduct for a long unregulated market that played a leading role in the financial crisis.

headline: Q&A: Seeing Your E-Books Clearly
text: Q.

headline: Obama: Republican Leaders Must Bend on Taxes
text: 3:45 p.m. | Updated President Obama said Wednesday that he believed Republicans would concede to tax increases as part of a deficit reduction package in time to avoid a default on the nation’s debt, and voiced exasperation at the lack of progress in negotiations between the administration and Congressional leaders.

headline: ‘On a Clear Day’ Now Has One to Open
text: The team behind the Broadway revival of “On a Clear Day You Can See Forever,”  starring Harry Connick Jr., has announced an opening date and stage: Dec. 11 at the St. James Theater.

headline: ‘Follies’ Returns to Broadway With Kennedy Center Cast
text: Bernadette Peters, Jan Maxwell, Danny Burstein and Ron Raines are set to reprise their starring roles in the Kennedy Center production of “Follies” when it opens Sept. 12 at the Marquis Theater on Broadway for a limited engagement, the show’s producers said on Wednesday.

headline: France Says It Gave Arms to the Rebels in Libya
text: PARIS — France confirmed on Wednesday that it had provided weapons to the Libyan rebels, the first instance of a NATO country giving direct military aid to the forces seeking to oust Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Dealbook: Unprofitable Square Valued at $1.6 Billion
text: Evelyn Rusli at Dealbook writes that early on Wednesday, Square, the fast-growing mobile payments start-up, announced the completion of a $100 million financing round, led by Kleiner Perkins Caulfield & Byers, a leading venture capital firm that has backed Google and Amazon. The round values the company at $1.6 billion, according to two people briefed on the matter.

headline: The Parties of No
text: A few weeks ago, Fareed Zakaria wrote an essay for Time Magazine attacking American conservatism for having “lost touch with reality.” Whereas once the Right tried to grapple with the world as it actually is, he lamented, “conservatives now espouse ideas drawn from abstract principles with little regard to the realities of America’s present or past.”

headline: You Really Can’t Fight Town Hall
text: I cannot be the first person to walk out of Southampton Town Hall and long for a psychiatrist. The place is polite bedlam. Citizens shuffle down the halls muttering to themselves, aflush with high anxiety and low self-esteem, fists full of blueprints they cannot read and will have to change to something else they cannot read.

headline: Toyota Recalls 82,000 Highlander and Lexus RX 400 Hybrids for Stalling Problem
text: An investigation by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has prompted Toyota to recall about 82,000 hybrid S.U.V.’s for a stalling problem.

headline: Working Vacations Recharge Actors
text: A LOT of us surely see summer as a chance for vacation and relaxation, but for actors it can be a busy time as theaters around the country come to life for another short season. Someone’s got to work to provide these entertainments, after all.

headline: London and Toronto Exchanges Call Off Merger
text: 8:00 p.m. | Updated

headline: In a Transition to Coaching, a Broadcaster Keeps Talking
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — The first-round draft pick, carrying the estimable reputation of a young Reggie Miller, was asked what immediately came to mind at the mention of the name Mark Jackson.

headline: How Free Agency Works in New York
text: As free agency fever gets set to overcome the N.H.L. on Friday, what better way to prepare than a Down Goes Brown/Bloge Salming video on one of the story lines waiting to play out: the Rangers heaping a bunch of money on free agent center Brad Richards.

headline: The Stock of Summer Stages
text: Five actors talk about why they’ve chosen to work over the summer.

headline: Ferragamo: The Last Word on Resort
text: Ferragamo wrapped up what has been an especially lengthy resort season on Tuesday afternoon with a grand runway show in a Fifth Avenue mansion that once belonged to James Buchanan Duke and that now is home to New York University’s Institute of Fine Arts. Massimiliano Giornetti, the label’s designer, said he had Duke’s daughter, Doris, and the 1930s in mind when he was making the collection, so it was kind of a fantasy scene when Mariacarla Boscono descended a marble staircase wearing a white double-breasted pantsuit, the jacket cut long so the buttons fell at the waist, with loose flowing trousers. So dramatic.

headline: Round 1 in Appeals of Health Care Overhaul Goes to Obama
text: The Obama administration prevailed Wednesday in the first appellate review of the 2010 health care law as a three-judge panel from the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit held that it was constitutional for Congress to require that Americans buy health insurance.

headline: Design for Athens Cultural Center Unveiled Amid Debt Crisis
text: The final designs for the Stavros Niarchos Foundation Cultural Center, a major hub for the arts planned for Athens, were unveiled on Wednesday. The center, designed by Renzo Piano, includes a 42-acre park, the headquarters for the National Library of Greece and a 1,400-seat opera house for the Greek National Opera. Budgeted at more than $800 million, the project is to be financed by the Stavros Niarchos Foundation. Construction, to begin later this year, is to be completed in 2015.

headline: Samurai Shopper | Weiner World
text: In bygone days, www meant World Wide Web, the gateway to cyberspace, But for the Samurai Shopper and other bereft New Yorkers, www is now a World Without Weiner. Who will provide us with such picaresque distractions from the grim grown-up times that surely lie ahead? Who was a better patsy for our japes and gibes than the half-clad Congressman who took junk mail to a whole ‘nother level? As the fake news pundit Jon Stewart rightly quipped: Weiner’s the gift that keeps on giving. Sticks and stones may have broken Weiner’s bones, but his unfortunate surname turned him into a laughingstock.

headline: Raymond James Settles Auction-Rate Securities Charges
text: Raymond James Financial Services agreed on Wednesday to settle charges that it misled clients about auction-rate securities — investments that were marketed as safe but turned toxic during the credit crisis.

headline: Protesters Return to Cairo’s Tahrir Square
text: Protesters returned to Tahrir Square in Cairo with tents on Wednesday, starting a new sit-in to press their demands for an end to emergency rule and changes to Egypt’s interim government, according to bloggers and activists.

headline: A Network of Plants and Pollinators
text: Daniel Song, a doctoral student at the University of Pennsylvania, writes from Hovsgol National Park, Mongolia, where he is studying how plants and pollinators form interaction networks.Tuesday, June 21

headline: Syria Pulls Its Armed Forces From Some Contested Cities
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian military and the government’s security forces have largely withdrawn from one of the country’s largest cities as well as other areas, residents and activists said Wednesday, leaving territory to protesters whose demonstrations have grown larger and whose chants have taunted a leadership that once inspired deep fear.

headline: Hackers Release More Data From Arizona Police
text: Hackers on Wednesday publicly exposed for the second time information they claimed to have stolen from the computer systems and personnel of the Arizona state police, in a continuation of a nearly two-month hacking spree.

headline: Better Reading for Madoff?
text: How’s Bernard L. Madoff doing in prison? Not so badly, despite his simmering moral anguish, he told Benjamin Weiser in an interview in the Times on Wednesday. He’s working out and, for the first time in his life, devouring books, from junk novels to biographies. “Now, I literally read two books a week,” he said. “I’m reading all the James Michener novels.”

headline: Russia Uses Its Airwaves, and Then Its Power Lines, to Strike at Belarus President
text: MOSCOW — Russia’s irritation with its neighbor Belarus became more apparent on Wednesday when a state-controlled television station here broadcast a documentary damning the Belarussian president for mismanaging the economy, after which a Russian utility cut off about an eighth of that country’s electricity, claiming it had not been paid.

headline: A New Style, Found With a Swipe
text: VIRGINIA MYERS, a software saleswoman from Manhattan, was in a hairstyling rut: She had been using a magazine picture of the actress Lisa Rinna as inspiration for a little too long. Her stylist, Mika Rummo at Salon AKS on Fifth Avenue, knew the drill. “She’s been going with this, or a version of this, for years,” Ms. Rummo said of her client during a recent visit.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: SICILIAN CHIC Inspired by the label’s 2011 runway creations, the cosmetics division of Dolce & Gabbana recently introduced its Italian Summertime Collection. Available at Saks Fifth Avenue, the line includes soft Mediterranean-inspired femininity (Classic Cream Lipstick in Venere, $30; Luminous Cheek Color in Sole, $44; Ultra-Shine Lip Gloss in Acqua, $29) and risk-taking drama (Intense Nail Lacquer in Passione, $20; Smooth Eye Color Quad in Vulcano, $59). Adding some flair for the pale-skinned among us is the limited-edition Animalier Bronzer for $50.

headline: Photo Replay: June 29
text: A view of the day in sports, with tennis on the grass, soccer in the rain and pole-vaulting on a pier.

headline: Dwelling on Dwell Time
text: FORT DRUM, N.Y. — “It must feel great to be back in the States, right?” I get this question all the time from friends who haven’t seen me since I got back from Afghanistan last December.

headline: Murray Beats Lopez to Reach Semifinals
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Fourth-seeded Andy Murray of Britain defeated Feliciano Lopez of Spain, 6-3, 6-4, 6-4, on Wednesday to gain the Wimbledon semifinals.

headline: 3 Men Sentenced to 25 Years in Synagogue Bomb Plot
text: Updated, 4:04 p.m. | Three of the four men convicted in a thwarted plot to bomb synagogues in Riverdale in the Bronx were sentenced to 25 years in prison on Wednesday by a federal judge in Manhattan.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Greece, Egypt and China.

headline: My First Superhero, Sort Of
text: At what point does a parent of young children stop condemning potty talk and simply throw up his or her hands and let the scatological speech spill forth? The lure of toilet-related topics seems as inevitable as potty training itself, as if once out of diapers, children are unable to resist the conversational detritus they might otherwise have left behind.

headline: TimesCast | Austerity Plan Passes
text: June 29, 2011 - Greece's parliament passes the austerity plan, averting an immediate financial crisis, but sparking violent protests for a second day.

headline: American Ballet Theater Partners With the University of North Carolina School of the Arts
text: American Ballet Theater and the School of Dance at the University of North Carolina School of the Arts in Winston-Salem are embarking on a five-year partnership that will teach ABT’s National Training Curriculum throughout three divisions at the school: preparatory, high school and collegiate. The partnership will be announced officially on Thursday by Rachel S. Moore, Ballet Theater’s executive director, and John Mauceri, chancellor of the school of the arts.

headline: News Corporation Sells MySpace for $35 Million
text: 8:14 p.m. | Updated MySpace, the long-suffering Web site that the News Corporation bought six years ago for $580 million, was sold Wednesday to the advertising network Specific Media for roughly $35 million.

headline: Argument, Truth and the Social Side of Reasoning
text: The Stone is featuring occasional posts by Gary Gutting, a professor of philosophy at the University of Notre Dame, that apply critical thinking to information and events that have appeared in the news.Philosophers rightly think of themselves as experts on reasoning.  After all, it was a philosopher, Aristotle, who developed the science of logic.   But psychologists have also had some interesting things to say about the subject. A fascinating paper by Dan Sperber and Hugo Mercier has recently generated a lot of discussion.

headline: Bank of America's Big Settlement
text: Bank of America has agreed to set aside $14 billion to settle claims stemming from sales of mortgage-backed securities. Nelson D. Schwartz explains how the bank will come up with the cash.

headline: Bank of America’s Big Settlement
text: Now that Bank of America has agreed to set aside $14 billion to settle claims stemming from sales of mortgage-backed securities, it has to come up with the cash. The New York Times’s business reporter Nelson D. Schwartz and finance editor Patrick Scott talk about how the settlement will affect the bank’s bottom line.

headline: Egyptian Seeds Are Linked to E. Coli in Germany and France
text: European investigators fitting together the puzzle pieces of devastating E. coli outbreaks in Germany and France cautiously identified a likely source on Wednesday: contaminated fenugreek seeds from Egypt.

headline: Barbie, the Klimt Edition
text: Over the last half-century, Barbie has come in about as many guises and get-ups as Inspector Clouseau: cheerleader, supermodel, ski queen, doctor, astronaut, lawyer. Last year, Mattel, the doll’s maker, released “Mad Men” versions, giving Barbie a pile of fire-red hair and a fetching office-girl dress in her Joan Holloway incarnation.

headline: Tough Week for Meatless Monday
text: Like every day in America, the Fourth of July is a celebration of protein. But the Fourth is a special day for burgers and ribs, not beans and rice, a day with contests to see who can eat the most hot dogs, not the most veggie patties. If you’re anti-meat, the Fourth of July can feel anti-you.

headline: Caucus Click: Dueling News Conferences
text: Senate Republicans offered a counterpoint to President Obama’s news conference.

headline: Nadal Looks Fresh in Victory Over Fish
text: WIMBLEDON, England – Rafael Nadal of Spain, showing no sign of an injury he feared might force his withdrawal, overpowered Mardy Fish Wednesday, racing to a 6-3, 6-3, 5-7, 6-4 victory and a place in the Wimbledon semifinals.

headline: Street Piano Vanishes (and With It, Free Fun in the Bronx)
text: This would make for an unusual police blotter entry: Be on the lookout for a missing piano.

headline: Andy Walking
text: Had one of Andy Warhol’s more entrepreneurial visions come to fruition, the storefront at the northeast corner of 74th and Madison, today a vintage watch dealer, would be the site of the world’s first Andy-Mat, an international chain of fast-food restaurants for people who prefer to eat alone. “I want to start a chain of restaurants for other people like me called Andy-Mats,” Warhol said. “The restaurant for the lonely person. You get your food and then take your tray into a booth and watch television.” According to architectural drawings, customers would have placed their orders with the kitchen directly, through a system of pneumatic tubes. The food, prepared off-site and frozen, would have been delivered to the franchise and then reheated. The project fell through in 1977, but not before $40,000 in rent had been paid, $1 million in capital had been secured, and Maxine de la McKendry, a society hostess and onetime food columnist for Vogue, had prepared the menu: milk over ice, anyone?

headline: A Fresh Take Adds a Jolt to a Standard
text: The modest idea of the New York Philharmonic’s Summertime Classics concerts, which began in 2004, is to provide a few postseason programs of lighter fare, novelties and a staple or two at reduced prices. The British conductor Bramwell Tovey, a lively musician who has charmed Avery Fisher Hall audiences with his avuncular commentaries on music, concert protocols or whatever else strikes him, remains the host of choice for these events. While they are perfectly pleasant, you do not attend to hear extraordinary performances at these concerts.

headline: Film Festival | Documentaries About Science
text: Our summer experiments continue! Last week: Historic Headlines. This week: A collaboration with SnagLearning to bring you “film festivals” of classroom-worthy documentaries, each day on a different theme. Monday’s collection was about technology, Tuesday’s was about history and today’s theme is science. The whole collection is available here.

headline: At German Museum, Cars as a ‘Medium of Mobility’
text: “Car Culture: Media of Mobility,” a new exhibition at the Zentrum für Kunst und Medientechnologie, or the Center of Art and Media, combines the legacy of two local discoveries: the car and the radio wave. The show runs through Jan. 8.

headline: New Investment Strategy: Preparing for End Times
text: Investment professionals have a new pitch: The sky could soon be falling.

headline: From Catfish Row to Times Square: ‘Porgy and Bess’ Returning to Broadway
text: A revamped version of George Gershwin’s “Porgy and Bess,” starring Audra McDonald, Norm Lewis and David Alan Grier, will go to Broadway soon after it completes its run, previously announced, at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass.

headline: LivingSocial Is Said to Talk I.P.O. With Bankers
text: 7:41 p.m. | Updated

headline: ‘The Voice’ Lifts NBC Again
text: The final round of NBC’s singing competition “The Voice” garnered its best ratings in four weeks on Tuesday as the four remaining contestants battled it out to be the last singer standing. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the two-hour episode delivered the night’s largest audience, 12.5 million viewers, building on NBC’s ratings at 8 p.m. for “America’s Got Talent” (12 million). No other network came close on the night. CBS placed second with reruns of “NCIS” (8.2 million) and “NCIS: Los Angeles” (8 million) at 8 and 9. ABC was third, drawing its best ratings at 8 for “Wipeout” (5.5 million) and solid results at 9 for “101 Ways to Leave a Game Show” (5.3 million). At 10, ABC’s “Combat Hospital” (4.6 million) lagged just behind CBS’s repeat of “The Good Wife” (4.8 million). Fox finished in fourth as “MasterChef” attracted 4.2 million viewers at 8 while back-to-back reruns of “Raising Hope” averaged 2.2 million viewers at 9 p.m.

headline: Rhode Island Lawmakers Approve Civil Unions
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — Less than a week after same-sex marriage was legalized in New York, the Rhode Island State Senate on Wednesday evening approved a bill allowing not marriage, but civil unions for gay couples, despite fierce opposition from gay rights advocates who called the legislation discriminatory.

headline: Hostage Taking at Brooklyn Wine Store Ends Without Incident
text: Updated, 6:23 p.m. | A hostage taking that grew out of a foiled armed robbery attempt at a Brooklyn wine shop ended without incident on Wednesday afternoon, the police said, as two suspects surrendered to the authorities.

headline: Latest in Dog Safety: Car Seat Belts
text: Planning to bring the dog along in the car as you head out for your summer road trip? There’s a growing consensus that dogs should be restrained while traveling in automobiles, just like people.

headline: JPMorgan Gives Top North American Banker a Global Role
text: JPMorgan Chase on Wednesday promoted Jeff Urwin, one of its co-heads of North American investment banking, to a global role, according to an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook.

headline: Fed Halves Debit Card Bank Fees
text: WASHINGTON — Fees paid by retailers to banks for debit card purchases, a $20 billion annual expense that has been the subject of a furious political battle over the last year, will be cut in half after the Federal Reserve voted Wednesday to cap the charges.

headline: Weinsteins Place Madonna’s New Film in Oscar Fray
text: The Weinstein Company, which recently acquired the Madonna-directed film “W.E.,” announced Wednesday that it plans to release the film smack in the middle of Oscar season. “W.E.,” which stars Abbie Cornish as a modern-day young woman who finds inspiration in the romance between Britain’s King Edward VIII and the American divorcée Wallis Simpson, will be released on Dec. 9 in New York and Los Angeles. Besides Ms. Cornish, the cast includes Andrea Riseborough (“Never Let Me Go”), James D’Arcy (“Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World”) and Oscar Isaac (“Drive”).

headline: Who Loves Chris Christie?
text: As Atrios notes, there’s a persistent belief among pundits that Christie is somehow the future of the GOP, nay America.

headline: Obama's Message; Zernike Talks Tea Party

headline: In U.S. Monetary Policy, a Boon to Banks
text: The most pronounced development in banking today is that executives have become bolder as their business has gotten worse.

headline: New York Philharmonic’s Music Director Vows to Restore Parks Series
text: There will be no free concerts in the parks for the New York Philharmonic this summer. But Alan Gilbert, the orchestra’s music director, has given his word that situation will change in 2012. “I am making a personal promise that these beloved free concerts will return next summer and continue for many years to come,” he wrote in a letter sent via e-mail to The New York Times on Wednesday, following the publication of a critic’s notebook lamenting the orchestra’s decision to suspend the series, which began in 1965.

text: A condo in a converted 1909 warehouse in Portland, Ore.; a contemporary house in a suburb of Cleveland; and a cottage in Kennebunkport, Me.

headline: Johnson Tends the Nationals’ Future
