text: Portland, Ore.

headline: For the iPad, Books That Respond to a Child’s Touch
text: There may never come a day when book apps, as interactive books for tablet computers are known, are more appealing to children than games. But the apps are getting more engaging.

headline: Principal at Lehman High School Is Said to Be Out
text: The principal of Herbert H. Lehman High School in the Bronx, who has been under investigation for three years by the Department of Education after accusations of grade tampering, will not return to the school in September, a union official was told on Wednesday.

headline: Concerts in the Park
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Kent, a Two-Story Farmhouse in the Garden of England
text: A two-story brick farmhouse on 25 acres of meadowland and gardens in the county of Kent in England is on the market for $1.4 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... Kent
text: A FOUR-BEDROOM FARMHOUSE IN KENT, ENGLAND

headline: Mine Owners Misled Inspectors, Investigators Say
text: Federal investigators said Wednesday that Massey Energy, the owner of the West Virginia mine where 29 men were killed in an explosion last year, misled government inspectors by keeping accounts of hazardous conditions out of official record books where inspectors would see them.

headline: Talking Dance and Art With David LaChapelle and John Byrne
text: John Byrne and David LaChapelle used to be a couple. The romance didn’t last, but the two have continued their relationship through art. Mr. Byrne, a choreographer and former dancer for Paul Taylor, worked on “Rize,” Mr. LaChapelle’s 2005 documentary about krumping, as well as “Elton John: The Red Piano.” Now Mr. LaChapelle has produced Mr. Byrne’s first full-length work of dance, “Transcending Form,” with Fred Torres, at Theater 80 every Wednesday through Aug. 24. In addition, Mr. Byrne has created a structured improvisation piece at Lever House, home to an exhibit of Mr. LaChapelle’s work, “From Darkness To Light.” Pedestrians can happen across this performance every Wednesday from 1 to 2 p.m. We talked to Mr. Byrne and Mr. LaChapelle about their new works, their collaboration and the melding of dance and art. Here are excerpts from the conversation:

headline: Clashes as Greek Government Passes Austerity Measures
text: Greece’s Parliament voted in favor of an austerity plan required by the country’s foreign lenders.

headline: Who Made That Rainbow Flag?
text: Noah considered it a sign from God, Aristotle wrestled with its geometry and Dorothy sang about it as an escape from Kansas. For centuries, the semiotics of the rainbow have evolved through the fields of art, science and beyond, but have only more recently been associated with the lesbian-gay-bisexual-transgender community. Carried in abundance at this past weekend’s New York City Gay Pride Parade, the rainbow flag has become instantly recognizable as a symbol of diversity and acceptance.

headline: Italian Experts Question Evidence in Knox Case
text: ROME — A report by forensic experts filed with an appeals court on Wednesday casts doubt on the DNA evidence used to convict Amanda Knox and her Italian ex-boyfriend for the 2007 murder of a British student. Lawyers for the defendants said the development significantly improved their chances of winning their appeal.

headline: Pretty Tablet, Though Late for the Ball
text: Have you been reading the headlines? There was a big earthquake in Haiti. Some men were rescued from a mine in Chile. Oh, and apparently there was a gigantic oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Video: Obama’s Message; Reader Questions on the Tea Party
text: Richard W. Stevenson, politics editor, dissects the president’s wide-ranging news conference today. Also, Kate Zernike answers reader questions about the Tea Party’s clout in 2012 following her article on the movement’s struggles with governing.

headline: TimesCast | Tahrir Square Clashes
text: June 29, 2011 - overnight in Cairo's Tahrir Square, protesters clashed with police forces in the worst violence since the revolution.

headline: Five Great iPad Apps for Toddlers
text: While experts debate about whether or not tablets and smartphones are appropriate for young children, the fingerprints all over your iPad are an indicator that children — some as young as 12 months of age — have taken the issue into their own hands.

headline: A Rehabilitation That May Prove Fatal
text: EVEN on a clear day, it is easy to miss Seven New York.

headline: Vote Adds to Historic-ness of Crown Heights
text: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission on Tuesday designated a 600-building swath of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, as a historic district. The district, bound by Bergen Street and Eastern Parkway to the north and south, and Nostrand and Brooklyn Avenues to the west and east, adjoins the existing Crown Heights North Historic District, which includes 472 buildings and was designated in 2007.

headline: The Rangers Part Ways With Their Captain
text: The Rangers have bought out the contract of Chris Drury, their 34-year-old captain, the team announced Wednesday. Drury will become an unrestricted free agent when the N.H.L.’s signing period opens Friday at noon.

headline: Paris Top 5 | Lanvin
text: Lanvin’s spring/summer 2012 collection finale in the rotunda of the historic Bourse de Commerce was an unexpectedly moving experience, with a parade of models neutrally and rather simply attired (for Lanvin standards), ascending a staircase from below and walking in a giant circle, melding into one continuous rotating mass until each model in succession retreated back downstairs. Maybe it was the stirring music. Maybe it was the simplicity of a stronger, more utilitarian look that seemed straight out of Claire Denis’s meditation on the military, “Beau Travail.” The gauzy gray mix of a layered double-breasted jacket worn with an airy duster and semisheer trousers tucked into combat boots was heroically beautiful.

headline: Clip: de La Cruz
text: Xavier Cha's film for the de La Cruz Collection.

headline: Fly by Night
text: BY day, Jobee, an unassuming Taiwanese restaurant on Howard Street, just east of the fashion temple Opening Ceremony and north of the fake handbags on Canal Street, serves bland sesame noodles and tasty mock Sichuan chicken to a sleepy lunch crowd. A menu is taped to the door. Kitschy paper lanterns swing from the ceiling.

headline: Saudi Religious Police Detained 5 Women for Driving, Group Reports
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The religious police in Saudi Arabia arrested five women on Tuesday for driving in defiance of a ban on women getting behind the wheel in the conservative kingdom, according to activists and local media reports.

headline: After 2nd Acquittal, Criminal Penalties Over Tower Fire Appear Unlikely
text: About a year after two New York City firefighters were killed while battling a blaze at the former Deutsche Bank building, prosecutors in Manhattan released a report that made clear the deaths could have been avoided if not for a number of failures by various city agencies and private workers in the months before the fire.

headline: Fashion Forward (or Guard)
text: FANS are still chuckling about Charles Barkley bursting out of the garish purple sports jacket he wore to the National Basketball Association draft more than a quarter-century ago. And who could forget Joakim Noah of the Chicago Bulls striding onstage in an oversize tan tuxedo and a giant paisley bow tie that seemed straight out of the Ringling Brothers fall men’s line?

headline: In Paris, Sensuality Saves the Day
text: PARIS — MAYBE it’s too many hours on Twitter that causes people to reduce fashion shows to a check-off list of essentials, but whatever it is, writers at the spring men’s collections here were ticking the appropriate boxes: globalism, gender games, the new sobriety.

headline: This Colorblind Woman Can’t Distinguish Black From White
text: “Yes We Can,” a postmodern, postracial romp by Daniella Shoshan, is a pretty smart play. But you’ll only discover that if you read the script.

headline: S.E.C. Delays Rajat Gupta’s Trial for Six Months
text: 8:17 p.m. | Updated

headline: On Fuel Efficiency, Environmental Groups May Urge California to Go It Alone
text: According to numerous reports, the Obama administration has advanced a federal fuel efficiency fleet-average standard of 56.2 m.p.g. for 2025. But while an official number from the Environmental Protection Agency and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is not expected until September, the reported White House disclosure has sparked intense jockeying among automakers and environmental groups and has retrained focus on California.

headline: Conrad Black, Still in Prison, Finds Publisher for Memoir
text: OTTAWA _ A resentencing hearing last week in Chicago will soon return former newspaper publisher Conrad M. Black to prison. But his legal tribulations have not interfered with Mr. Black’s other occupation — as an author.

headline: Just One Look | Ferragamo Resort Collection
text: If there was any doubt that resort is now a fully fledged season — and not just a smattering of pretty frocks and bikinis to fill the months between fall and spring — Massimiliano Giornetti, may have settled it, presenting his collection for Ferragamo last night to much fanfare at the former Doris Duke mansion on the Upper East Side. A fleet of nautical-inspired looks, evening gowns in a range of blue hues and this crisp, cotton scarf print top and skirt, harked back to the label’s heyday in the 1930s and spoke to Giornetti’s ambition to complement the “stylish lifestyle of a well-traveled heiress.”

headline: A Helsinki Cottage Serves as an Urban Getaway
text: Two architects created an eco-friendly second home in a tiny seafoam-green house in Lauttasaari Recreational Park.

headline: Hand-Held Tools for Digital Scribblers
text: Even after the invention of the typewriter, many great writers stuck with longhand. Hemingway slashed out his words in pen and ink while standing at a specially made desk, and Margaret Mitchell scribbled “Gone With the Wind” in dozens of composition notebooks. But with the rise of the keyboard, and, more recently, the touch screen, it seems as if pen-and-paper lovers are out of luck.

headline: ‘Cripple’ Finally Comes to Inishmaan
text: INISHMAAN, Ireland — As captured by the dark imagination of the playwright Martin McDonagh, life on this storm-battered island near Galway inspired hardness, sarcasm and co-dependency in the characters in his 1996 play “The Cripple of Inishmaan.” It was home to a bachelor who both saved a drowning baby and called his mother a “hairy-lipped fool” and to a young dreamer so desperate to flee that he tricked a grieving friend into helping him escape.

headline: So, Do I Look Like My Father in This Hat?
text: I DIDN’T believe in hats even before every third underslept scruffster on the Lower East Side began abusing them. To me, they seemed to be the worst sort of peacocking, lazy and under thought, a mark of amateurism more than anything else, and almost uniformly detrimental. In winter, too, I leave my head uncovered — falling snow is no excuse to live in a cage.

headline: Choosing a Hat
text: Summer’s here, and with it, relentless sun. Choosing a hat requires careful consideration.

headline: Wainwright Offers Taste of Opera
text: With its plans for next season still a mystery as June winds to an end, New York City Opera raised its flag, briefly, on Tuesday at the Winter Garden of the World Financial Center, offering an evening of arias, ensembles and Rufus Wainwright songs. Mr. Wainwright was on hand to play his music and to explain, more or less, what the operatic excerpts were about.

headline: A Wide-Ranging Festival Savors Some Late-Night Jazz
text: Among the many possible ways of gauging a good time at the second annual Undead Jazzfest, which wound down in the wee hours of Monday morning, there are a few that seem truest to the spirit of the event. If you were there, you might rate your experience by answering the following questions: Did you feel like a part of something vital and collegial? Did you momentarily forget the conventional wisdom about jazz as a withering art? Did you hear something new?

headline: On a Hot Night, Intense Frenzied Punk
text: You can learn a lot about the Coathangers by watching the hands of the keyboard player Candice Jones. Sometimes they strike the keys precisely and carefully, picking out nimble little lines that give this band’s punk some whimsy. And sometimes they appear to have an indifferent, or outright adversarial relationship to the keyboard, slamming on it casually, making the best of what comes out.

headline: In Alliance, Nets Arena to Offer Arts
text: It’s been a springboard for Brooklyn nostalgia, a debate about urban design and the politics of eminent domain and, depending on your perspective or basketball affiliation, a community uniter or divider. Now Atlantic Yards, the development that will bring the New Jersey Nets to Brooklyn, will also be a cultural center.

headline: Strong Sales in London for Some German Artists
text: LONDON — Prices for contemporary German artists — Sigmar Polke, Georg Baselitz and Blinky Palermo, among others — soared to new levels at Sotheby’s here on Wednesday night in an auction that featured 34 works from the collection of Count Christian Duerckheim, a German industrialist who became obsessed with what he calls “the art of his time.” Beginning in the early 1970s Count Duerckheim got to know Mr. Polke and Mr. Baselitz along with Gerhard Richter and lesser-known artists including Jörg Immendorff, Konrad Lueg and Eugen Schönebeck. He often bought their work soon after it was made.

headline: The Harness Has Them Champing at the Bit
text: DURING Lady Gaga’s performance of “Judas” on the season finale of “Saturday Night Live,” her backup dancers were clad in gold harnesses, custom-made by the Brooklyn designer Zana Bayne. They were worn either over a bikini top or bare skin, artfully framing the chest.

headline: G.E. Extends Olympic Sponsorship
text: General Electric extended its global Olympic sponsorship on Wednesday through 2020, matching the decision three weeks ago by NBC Universal to acquire the rights to the four Olympics from 2014 to 2020 for $4.38 billion. G.E., which sold majority control of NBC Universal to Comcast, has sponsored the Olympics since 2008, adding an estimated $200 million sweetener to the $2 billion it paid for NBC to carry the 2008, ’10 and ’12 Games.

headline: Visiting Artists | Xavier Cha
text: The performance artist Xavier Cha thrives on the unknown. Her process is largely improvisational and embraces the random variables many artists work hard to avoid. For “Holiday Cruise!,” her solo show at Taxter and Spengemann Gallery back in 2006, Cha enlisted about a hundred performers to interact with her as she played three different characters. One of the characters was dressed in a bodysuit completely covered with cornrows (and elicited numerous requests to dance). Another character simply lay in and among oversized fruits and vegetables in a massive Horn of Plenty. The third character, Polyhedra, was still as a statue.

headline: Goldman Sachs Prepares to Cut Jobs
text: The ax is about to fall at Goldman Sachs.

headline: Americans Win at Europe Open
text: Three team competitions at the fifth European Open Championships in Poznan, Poland, finished on Wednesday.

headline: Obama Moves Near ‘Greater Equality’ on Gay Marriage
text: WASHINGTON — After months of saying his position on same-sex marriage is “evolving,” President Obama traded that language on Wednesday for comments that stopped just short of endorsing the notion that gay people have the right to marry.

headline: City Council Approves $36.4 Million for Earmarks
text: The City Council voted on Wednesday to approve a budget roughly the size of Kenya’s economy. But for political savants, the most interesting part may be a tiny sliver of it: the $36.4 million set aside in discretionary money.

headline: Shopping Snapshots for June 30
text: Polka dots have become the look for summer.

headline: Scouting Report
text: OPENINGS

headline: An Auld Lang Syne Kicks Off an Artistic Diaspora
text: Artists, festivals, theaters, trends: they come and go with dizzying frequency in this city. It’s dangerous to get too attached to any one idea of New York’s cultural fabric.

headline: 'Zarkana'
text: The Times's Charles Isherwood reviews "Zarkana," a Cirque du Soleil production at Radio City Music Hall.

headline: A Gay Rights Power Player Who Wields a Mighty Phone
text: IF you are Brian Ellner, a tall, handsome, unrelentingly persistent New Yorker with an e-Rolodex that expands at every dinner party, you can always get through to someone impossible to reach.

headline: Your Chair, Mr. Aalto. Yes, It Now Has Eyes.
text: WHAT is that sound coming from a cemetery in Finland? Might it be Alvar Aalto spinning in his grave? A New Yorker has just painted a big red heart on Chair 69, a seriously minimal piece that the architect designed 76 years ago. Do the eyes deceive, or are those ribbons wound around the chair’s stiles and cross rail? And plastic jewels stuck on the seat?

headline: David Hyde Pierce Will Be Your Host
text: In the new thriller “The Perfect Host,” David Hyde Pierce, held at knifepoint, delivers one of the more sublimely ridiculous movie lines in recent memory: “You can’t kill me. I’m having a dinner party.”

headline: Bloomberg Seeks $600 Million Refund From CityTime Company
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg asked on Wednesday that the company that managed the troubled CityTime automated payroll project refund the city $600 million — all the money it has been paid for the project since 2003.

headline: Summers Joins Andreessen Horowitz
text: Looking for an adviser to guide your start-up?

headline: Tanzina Vega on interactive motion-controlled ads; the term "addressable TV;" the Yotel robot; news.
text: Game-style voice and motion controls will let Xbox Kinect users interact with ads. Betting Edelstein chats with Times media reporter Tanzina Vega about how this new mode of advertising works, and its implications. Pedro Rafael Rosado takes a look at the tech term "addressable TV." And J.D. Biersdorfer checks out the Yobot at the Yotel — a giant robot that handles luggage at a new Manhattan hotel. The news roundup includes the Supreme Court's ruling on violent video games; a class-action suit against Dropbox; e-reader ownership booming; new Windows malware that burrows deeply. J.D.'s tech tip: how to save emailed photos in the Mac Mail program directly into iPhoto.

headline: On a Fool’s Mission in a Dying Colonial World
text: Combat experiences are like Tolstoy’s unhappy families: no two are alike, which may be why they often make for great novels, as Tolstoy also knew. The cause need not even be noble, since a hopeless situation and senseless violence can actually fortify a work of fiction. Certainly that is the case with António Lobo Antunes’s “Land at the End of the World,” set in Angola in the early 1970s, as Portugal’s ludicrous effort to preserve its African empire was meandering to an inglorious end.

headline: The Full Results From The New York Times and CBS News Poll
text: Full results from a poll on President Obama’s job performance, the nation’s status, problems facing the country, Congress and more.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted June 24-28 with 979 adults throughout the United States.

headline: Despite Fears, Owning Home Retains Allure, Poll Shows
text: Owning a house remains central to Americans’ sense of well-being, even as many doubt their home is a good investment after a punishing recession.

headline: Obama’s News Conference
text: The following is a transcript of President Obama’s news conference in the East Wing, as provided by the White House.

headline: Wednesday at the Women’s World Cup
text: Brazil, among the Cup favorites, ground out a 1-0 victory over Australia in a scrappy match on Wednesday.

headline: For Consumers, Little to Cheer in New Cap on Debit Fees
text: The Federal Reserve on Wednesday issued its long-awaited rule on the cap on “swipe” fees that banks charge retailers for processing debit card purchases. And it appears that all the banks’ complaints about the proposed cap paid off.

headline: Scene City: Trevor Project Benefit
text: After the city’s annual gay pride parade, the Trevor Project benefit was a time to reflect, if only for a little while.

headline: Walking Proudly Into the Room
text: THE blue police barricades from New York’s annual gay pride parade on Sunday were still out and the shouts of “happy pride,” especially happy this year because of the same-sex marriage law in New York State, had barely faded from the air.

headline: Group Condemns Harassment of Climate Scientists
text: There is a ripple of unease among many scientists who study the warming of the planet these days. Some have faced harassment, legal challenges and even death threats related to their research, the American Association for the Advancement of Science reports.

headline: Nurturing Start-Ups and Small Businesses Around the World, Part 1
text: In almost every developed country, small companies dominate the business landscape. But in many ways America, the great land of entrepreneurship and opportunity, actually has a weaker small-business presence than most.

headline: Americans See Risks and Rewards in Homeownership
text: Results from the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll showing how Americans view home ownership and the housing market.

headline: Randy Falco Named Chief of Univision
text: Randy Falco, the chief operating officer of Univision Communications, was promoted on Wednesday to be the president and chief executive of the fast-growing Spanish language media company.

headline: Misdemeanor Charge for Pole-Sitting Rapper
text: One day after scaling a traffic light in Times Square — and remaining there, rapping, exercising and clogging several blocks of Midtown traffic for nearly two hours — Raymond Velasquez, 34, was arraigned in Manhattan Criminal Court Wednesday afternoon on a misdemeanor charge of reckless endangerment, as well as lesser charges of trespassing and disorderly conduct.

headline: Sales at Alessi, Desiron and Others
text: Grange Furniture is discounting some floor samples up to 70 percent, through July 10 (the Victoria queen sleigh bed, originally $6,545, is $3,142; the Ermitage three-drawer chest, regularly $2,125, is $957); 200 Lexington Avenue (33rd Street); (212) 685-9057 or grangeny.com.

headline: The International Garden Festival in Quebec Nods to New Yorkers
text: New York landscape architects and designers figure prominently at this year’s International Garden Festival, which opened last weekend in Grand-Métis, Quebec. Emmanuelle Vieira, its artistic director, said, “I invited three New York teams, because landscape architecture is changing the face of New York, with the High Line and other amazing projects like Brooklyn Bridge Park and Governors Island.”

headline: Furniture That’s Solid Like Stone, but Much Lighter
text: The Chicago designer Zachary Bitner’s new outdoor furniture looks as if it’s solid concrete or time-worn stone. In fact, it’s made of something considerably lighter, and very durable: a proprietary mix of stone, sand and fiberglass.

headline: Containers Tabbed for Easy Access
text: “They said they needed somebody to solve the lid problem: where is the lid for my container?” said Melissa Easton, a Brooklyn-based industrial designer, of her initial conversations with Tupperware. “It’s like the missing-sock thing.”

headline: Little House on the Baltic
text: HELSINKI, Finland

headline: Creating a Rain Garden at Columbia
text: Moisture-loving plants find a home amid city concrete, saving and filtering rainwater.

headline: In Nantucket, Furnishing a 19th-Century Home the 21st-Century Way
text: A writing professor scoured eBay for vintage items to create what she calls an “instant heirloom house.”

headline: Manhattan’s Newest River
text: EVER wonder what happens to a rain garden when temperatures outside creep toward 100 degrees and it hasn’t rained in weeks?

headline: The Instant Heirloom House
text: NANTUCKET, Mass.

headline: Perches and Yurts
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gratitude for Gardens
text: To the Editor:

headline: From the Archive: Performance Space 122
text: A look back at selected shows at the East Village theater.

headline: Play’s Homecoming
text: The Druid Theater Company traveled to the remote setting of the play “The Cripple of Inishmaan.”

headline: Protests Over Albany’s Role in Roosevelt Island
text: Roosevelt Island had long been run like a colony, with local issues like transportation, real estate development and even trash pickup controlled by a board whose leaders were appointed by Albany.

headline: New Jersey Pushes Primary to June
text: A bill that would move New Jersey’s presidential primary election to June, instead of February, awaits Gov. Chris Christie’s signature. The delay has two benefits: both political parties said they would penalize most states that hold nominating contests before March 2012, and by having the presidential primary on the same day as the races for all the other offices in the state, New Jersey could save as much as $12 million, according to one estimate.

headline: ‘Zarkana’
text: Photos of the new Cirque du Soleil show at Radio City Music Hall.

headline: Shopping for Summer House Furnishings With 2Michaels
text: The interior designers Jayne and Joan Michaels shopped for furniture and accessories for beach-y escapes.

headline: Summer House Furnishings
text: FOR Jayne and Joan Michaels, the twins behind the Manhattan interior design firm 2Michaels, hot summer days mean it’s time for the beach.

headline: New Man in Charge of Knicks
text: When the Knicks were, however tenuously, in the hunt for LeBron James last July, Donnie Walsh sent his top emissary to Cleveland to meet with James’s lead adviser.

headline: Derivatives Industry Awaits Rules, and a Timeline
text: With or without new rules, the derivatives industry is gearing up for big changes.

headline: A Reissued Bauhaus Bookcase
text: While the painter Josef Albers was at the Bauhaus, he designed furniture for the reception room at Walter Gropius’s office in Weimar, Germany. Now the Josef and Anni Albers Foundation hopes to recreate and reissue the furnishings in that room, beginning with the bookcase.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,457 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,631 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Waiting 75 Hours to See Britain’s Big Hope
text: WIMBLEDON, England — The 16-year-old with the “A” amateurishly drawn on his white T-shirt was questioning the ardor of his countryman Andy Murray, who is two victories from claiming Britain’s first Wimbledon men’s singles title since 1936.

headline: Yankees’ Pitching Situation Is Looking Up
text: Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman, who was scrambling two weeks ago to scrounge up a starting pitcher, spent part of Wednesday in Trenton watching Phil Hughes’s latest rehabilitation assignment.

headline: Red Nostalgia Rising
text: The New York Times reporter Edward Wong looks at how Mao-era songs are making a comeback in China, creating new opportunities to propagate Communist ideals.

headline: U.S. Drops Deportation Proceedings Against Immigrant in Same-Sex Marriage
text: In a decision that could have far-reaching effects on immigration cases involving same-sex couples, federal officials have canceled the deportation of a Venezuelan man in New Jersey who is married to an American man, the couple’s lawyer said Wednesday.

headline: Repackaging the Revolutionary Classics of China
text: CHONGQING, China — The kindergarten musical climaxed in a whirlwind of violence: A teacher playing a Japanese soldier sliced down a peasant girl with a curved sword, just as two tykes in Red Army outfits took aim at him with plastic pistols.

headline: Mets’ Grand Slams Still Fascinating
text: DETROIT — Sandy Alderson was so taken by the combination of events that produced two grand slams in the span of seven at-bats Tuesday night — after the Mets had gone almost two years without one — that he provided an eloquent analysis worthy of the event.

headline: The Fear of a Toxic Rerun
text: KUANTAN, Malaysia — A $230 million refinery being built here in an effort to break China’s global chokehold on rare earth metals is plagued by environmentally hazardous construction and design problems, according to internal memos and current and former engineers on the project.

headline: Bill to Aid Farm Workers Union Is Vetoed
text: LOS ANGELES — A generation ago, Jerry Brown, then the governor, helped shape legislation that gave agriculture workers the right to unionize through a secret ballot system. But late Tuesday night, that same Mr. Brown, the governor again, vetoed a bill that would have made it significantly easier for those workers to unionize.

headline: Arrests in Moldova Over Possible Uranium Smuggling
text: MOSCOW — The police in Moldova said Wednesday that they had arrested six people involved with a criminal group that said it was dealing in smuggled nuclear materials and was active in the former Soviet Union and in Arab countries.

headline: Common Sense and Sensibility
text: This month, the Supreme Court ruled that police, when questioning a child suspected of committing a crime, must take the suspect’s age into account and may have to provide Miranda warnings in circumstances that would not require the warnings to be given to an adult suspect.  The vote was 5 to 4, and the author of the majority opinion was Justice Sonia Sotomayor. The premise that children are different from adults and may feel coercive pressure when an adult would not, she said, was simply one of “commonsense reality.”

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Interactive Ads
text: Call it a new twist for an old business — Microsoft is rolling out a mode of advertising that will enable Xbox Kinect users to use game-style voice and motion controls to interact with ads. Betting Edelstein chats with Tanzina Vega, a Times media reporter, about how it works and its potential impact on advertisers, consumers and Microsoft.

headline: Echoes of Isner for Bryans
text: WIMBLEDON, England – In a match suspended by darkness, the combatants came back the next day to play on and on. Sound familiar?

headline: Biography Gives Strauss-Kahn’s Allies a Forum
text: PARIS — Dominique Strauss-Kahn’s wife said she was “very worried” about the sexual-assault charges against her husband in New York, but predicted the couple would emerge from the ordeal “dignified and standing tall,” and with their marriage intact.

headline: Strategic Site Is Captured by Militants in Yemen
text: SANA, Yemen — Islamic militants linked to Al Qaeda gained ground on Wednesday in fierce fighting with security forces just outside the southern port city of Zinjibar.

headline: China: Tibetans Are Arrested After New Protests in Sichuan
text: At least 30 Tibetans have been detained in 15 incidents of protest this month in a restive part of Sichuan Province, in western China, according to a report this week by International Campaign for Tibet, an advocacy group based outside China. Those detained are both monks and laypeople. The protests took place in an area that Tibetans call Kardze, known to the Chinese as Ganzi. The local police headquarters had no comment. The area has been unsettled since April 2008, when at least eight Tibetans were killed by Chinese security forces firing into a crowd of protestors, Tibetan exile groups said at the time. Those protests took place as part of a large uprising that began in Lhasa, Tibet, and unfolded across the Tibetan plateau. The report this week also said two monks from Kardze held a protest in the Barkhor market in Lhasa on June 22, possibly the first there since March 2008. Chinese officials have barred foreigners from going to central Tibet from late June to late July.

headline: Senate Votes to Streamline the Confirmation Process
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate took the rare step of relinquishing power on Wednesday, easily passing a measure that would exempt about 170 executive branch appointees from confirmation in an effort to streamline a process that has increasingly tied up the Senate and become punishing for those tapped for administration jobs.

headline: Senegal: Soldiers Sent Into Streets of Capital After Fiery Riots
text: Senegal has deployed troops around ministry buildings and an important route in the capital, Dakar, a spokesman said Wednesday, in a bid to forestall further rioting after several days of antigovernment violence. Offices of the state power company Senelec were burned in riots on Monday night by protesters angry over power cuts lasting hours. “The situation is back to normal now,” said Serigne Mbacké Ndiaye, a spokesman for President Abdoulaye Wade, adding that Mr. Wade, above, had decided to forgo a trip to the African Union summit meeting in Equatorial Guinea in order to watch over the situation in Senegal. Last week, the capital was rocked by riots over Mr. Wade’s plan, subsequently withdrawn, to change electoral rules in what demonstrators said was an effort to prolong his rule.

headline: Knicks Make Offer to Brown
text: The Knicks extended a qualifying offer to forward Derrick Brown on Wednesday, making him a restricted free agent. The designation means that the Knicks will have the right to match any offer Brown receives, assuming the rules do not change substantially in the N.B.A.’s next labor deal.

headline: 3 Men Draw 25-Year Terms In Synagogue Bomb Plot
text: Three of the four men convicted in a plot to bomb synagogues in Riverdale in the Bronx were sentenced to 25 years in prison on Wednesday by a judge in Manhattan, who rejected the government’s request for life sentences.

headline: Panel Advises F.D.A. to Narrow Its Approval for Avastin
text: A resounding vote by a federal committee of cancer experts on Wednesday makes it more likely the drug Avastin will no longer be readily available as a treatment for breast cancer, dealing a blow to women who think the drug is helping them.

headline: After a Derailed Dream, Working Her Way Up
text: Epilepsy and pregnancy eclipsed Norma M. Inoa’s dream of becoming a New York police detective; until 2010 she was living on Social Security disability payments. Last summer, she completed a training program run by Fedcap, an agency that develops employment opportunities for the disadvantaged and the disabled. In September, at 24, she got her first-ever job in the Fedcap mailroom; two promotions later, she is an accounting clerk. Now 25, she lives on the Grand Concourse, in the Bronx, with her boyfriend, who is a deliveryman for LaserShip, and her 5-year-old son.

headline: Notion of Independence Makes Halting Progress
text: EDINBURGH — Scotland’s grievances against England, its more powerful neighbor to the south, are deep and long, stretching back hundreds of years. But despite the country’s fierce pride in the things that make it different — culture, history, haggis — Scottish independence has always seemed like a quixotic dream, the fantasy of a vocal minority with more passion than power.

headline: Impulse Buying on TV Enters an Even Faster Phase
text: TELEVISION pitchmen for quirky products like Pajama Jeans and lighted slippers once tried to get viewers to place their orders by phone and then shifted to getting products into retail outlets with labels that screamed “As Seen on TV.” Now, they are trying to make impulse buying even easier by experimenting with new technologies.

headline: Exploring the Spectrum of Shyness
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Ups and Downs of Life After Transplants
text: NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa. — Erik Compton’s journey from death’s door to a featured threesome on the PGA Tour has taken three years. His travails resembled an electrocardiogram printout. Ups like his second successful heart transplant. Downs like his failure to get through local United States Open qualifying. Ups like the birth of his and wife Barbara’s first child. Downs like the constant fatigue he battles.

headline: Alec Baldwin: Actor, Charmer, Fish Deboner
text: By the end of the night, Alec Baldwin had followed us to a restaurant miles from the gala at which we’d just met him, squeezed himself onto the banquette at our table for four, and was meticulously deboning our deep-fried whole sea bass.

headline: Commuter Rail in Florida
text: To the Editor:

headline: Illinois: Budget Cuts Blamed for Prison Briefs Shortage
text: A watchdog group is raising concerns over hygiene at a state prison after finding that inmates must wear the same underwear for several days. Prisoners at the Taylorville Correctional Center complained about having to wear dirty underwear and socks for at least half the week, according to a recent report by the John Howard Association, which blamed state budget cuts and overcrowding at prisons. Inmates also said the boxers they received from the prison often had stains and holes, the report said.

headline: Violent Clashes in the Streets of Athens
text: ATHENS — Confrontations between the police and protesters reached a violent climax here on Wednesday as armored riot officers beat back demonstrators and fired volleys of tear gas into the crowds who had gathered outside Parliament. Inside, lawmakers approved a package of austerity measures aimed at helping Greece avoid a default.

headline: When Bookstores Charge for Author Signings
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hearing Aids and the New York Police Department
text: To the Editor:

headline: Three Straights and You’re Out in Gay Softball League
text: The five ballplayers summoned before a protest committee at the Gay Softball World Series stood accused of cheating. Their alleged offense: heterosexuality.

headline: M.L.B. Is Said to Look Into a Plan to Take Control of the Dodgers
text: As the Los Angeles Dodgers’ bankruptcy moves forward, Major League Baseball is planning to ask a judge to let it take control of the team because of a rule in baseball’s constitution, according to two people briefed on the case. The rule allows Commissioner Bud Selig to end the franchise of an owner who files for bankruptcy protection.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Larry Bogdanow, 64, Dies; Crafted Cozy Restaurants
text: Larry Bogdanow, an architect whose love for natural materials and fine craftsmanship brought a sense of warmth and ease to the interiors of dozens of Manhattan’s most popular restaurants, including Union Square Café, Savoy and the Cub Room, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 64.

headline: Larry Bogdanow’s Restaurant Designs
text: The architect’s designs brought a sense of warmth and ease to dozens of Manhattan’s most popular restaurants.

headline: Beneath Connecticut’s Image of Affluence, Deep Fiscal Pain
text: Think of Connecticut, and what comes to mind are the swells of Greenwich, the exurban good life of Litchfield County, the land of New England steady habits. By some measures America’s richest state, it still evokes images of Yankee stability and enterprise relatively immune to the nation’s economic and political tumult.

headline: Clearing the Decks at Bank of America
text: Maybe Brian T. Moynihan, the Bank of America chief executive, can finally carve his own path. The $21 billion of mortgage-related charges just unveiled by the beleaguered bank doesn’t quite clear the decks. But it removes one of the biggest problems left by Mr. Moynihan’s predecessor, Kenneth D. Lewis.

headline: Obama Adviser Outlines Plans to Defeat Al Qaeda
text: WASHINGTON — A week after President Obama announced the initial drawdown of American troops from Afghanistan, his top counterterrorism adviser described plans to rely more heavily on a largely clandestine campaign to destroy Al Qaeda’s network, which he described as already “in its decline.”

headline: In Deficit Plan, Taxes Must Rise, President Warns
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama pressured Republicans on Wednesday to accept higher taxes as part of any plan to pare down the federal deficit, bluntly telling lawmakers that they “need to do their job” and strike a deal before the United States risks defaulting on its debt.

headline: The Pirate Sumter
text: About midday on June 30, 1861, the Sumter, a recently refitted Confederate ship helmed by Capt. Raphael Semmes, slipped over the bar at Pass à l’Outre, the easternmost channel of the Mississippi River south of New Orleans; after a dramatic four-hour chase by the Brooklyn, a Union sloop-of-war, it was on the loose in the Caribbean. The Sumter was just one ship, helmed by an obscure former United States Navy officer — but over the next six months it would have a devastating impact on Union commercial shipping.

headline: Victim Suffered Rapes for Years, Prosecutors Say
text: Four men terrorized a young woman in Brooklyn for nearly a decade, coercing her to have sex with them and others and issuing threats to ensure her silence, prosecutors charged on Wednesday.

headline: Sex Crimes Chief in Office of Prosecutor Is Leaving Post
text: Lisa Friel, the chief of the Manhattan district attorney’s sex crimes unit for nearly a decade, is leaving that post, according to a memorandum circulated in the office on Wednesday.

headline: For Illinois, Blagojevich Is Only the Latest to Fall
text: CHICAGO — After jurors this week convicted Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois, of trying to sell his appointment of a replacement in the United States Senate for President Obama, they were asked what they had come to think of politicians in their home state.

headline: N.H.L. Eyes Are on the Big Free-Agent Prize
text: When the N.H.L. free-agency window opens Friday at noon Eastern, Brad Richards will be the most coveted and expensive prize.

headline: The Cloud Darkens
text: The Internet is getting scary. In recent weeks, hackers known as Lulz Security attacked the Web sites of Sony, the United States Senate, the C.I.A., PBS, among others. They stole names, e-mail addresses and passwords of millions of users and published them online. Then, last weekend, they regrouped under a new name.

headline: They Said They Wanted a Deal
text: Free trade is good for this country. So is helping American workers displaced by foreign competition. Therefore, it was a relief to hear on Tuesday about a bipartisan Congressional deal to pass long-delayed trade agreements with South Korea, Colombia and Panama and salvage some of the expanded benefits for workers under the Trade Adjustment Assistance program.

headline: Reducing Unjust Cocaine Sentences
text: The 1986 federal drug law that punished people caught with crack cocaine far more severely than those caught with powder cocaine was a disaster on many levels. It undermined faith in the justice system by discriminating against poor and mainly minority crack users and favoring affluent white users who preferred the chemically identical powdered form.

headline: Smarter Welfare-to-Work Plans
text: It is a good idea to require able-bodied welfare recipients to work in exchange for benefits. But research has discredited inflexible workfare programs that shunt people into dead-end jobs instead of giving them education and training that could improve their long-term prospects.

headline: Thursday: Surfer’s Handle
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — You say po-TAY-to, I say po-TAH-to. I actually don’t; that’s the kind of thing that would have gotten me keelhauled in the Bronx where I grew up. But I had to warn you somehow, didn’t I, because I’m pretty sure we’re going to have a rousing discussion after you all do this puzzle about the difference between ACRONYMs and initialisms.

headline: Radio City Is Transformed Into a Cirque Tent
text: The hearty-voiced fellow in the cherry-red top hat and matching silk cape obviously has a lot on his mind. Sweeping across the football-field stage of Radio City Music Hall as the ring master of “Zarkana,” the latest Cirque du Soleil spectacular,  he sings incessantly of an absent love, as if she could only be conjured by bombastic synthesizer-rich balladeering, a whole iPod playlist of Celine Dion songs delivered one after another.

headline: Democracy’s Cradle, Rocking the World
text: YESTERDAY, the whole world was watching Greece as its Parliament voted to pass a divisive package of austerity measures that could have critical ramifications for the global financial system. It may come as a surprise that this tiny tip of the Balkan Peninsula could command such attention. We usually think of Greece as the home of Plato and Pericles, its real importance lying deep in antiquity. But this is hardly the first time that to understand Europe’s future, you need to turn away from the big powers at the center of the continent and look closely at what is happening in Athens. For the past 200 years, Greece has been at the forefront of Europe’s evolution.

headline: Fire Up the Grill, Not the Atmosphere
text: FOOD is responsible for 10 to 30 percent of global greenhouse gas emissions. By many estimates, cooking represents more of a meal’s carbon footprint than transport. For certain vegetables, it accounts for more emissions than agriculture, transport and disposal combined.

headline: G.O.P. vs. World
text: AFTER Barack Obama announced new troop withdrawals from Afghanistan last week, it was no surprise to hear rebukes from the mushrooming field of Republican presidential candidates. The surprise came in what they said: although some predictably implied that he was looking to cut and run, several others declared the move too little, too late.

headline: Home Run by Martin Is Big Blow for Yanks
text: Until Milwaukee center fielder Nyjer Morgan slammed into the wall running full-tilt for a fly ball he did not catch anyway, the Brewers right-hander Shaun Marcum had severely tested the Yankees’ patience on Wednesday, taking his sweet time to nibble at the corners with soft-serve pitches.

headline: Yet Again in Sudan
text: The world capital for crimes against humanity this month probably isn’t in Libya or Syria. Instead, it’s arguably the Nuba Mountains of Sudan, where we’re getting accounts of what appears to be a particularly vicious campaign of ethnic cleansing, murder and rape.

text: Rebel fighters demonstrated their skills during their graduation ceremony in Benghazi.

text: Jillian Schwedler of the University of Massachusetts-Amherst and F. Gregory Gause of the University of Vermont debate about the future of the Arab revolutionary movements.

headline: Robert Morris, Pioneer in Computer Security, Dies at 78
text: Robert Morris, a cryptographer who helped develop the Unix computer operating system, which controls an increasing number of the world’s computers and touches almost every aspect of modern life, died on Sunday in Lebanon, N.H. He was 78.

headline: Hits, Runs and Victories Keep Coming
text: DETROIT — The Mets did not hit a grand slam Wednesday night. They could not even manage a home run. But there are other ways to score while keeping the ball in the park. They pounded out 20 hits and 16 runs as their astonishing offensive attack continued its record-breaking pace.

text: A T exclusive film, featuring Angelo Sorrenti. Directed by Jacob Sutton.

text: CHICAGO — If you heard the words “Tempest,” “Turbulence” and “Tornado Watch,” you might head for the basement — fast.

text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: What’s the Most Expensive College? The Least? Education Dept. Puts It All Online
text: Students and families can compare colleges’ tuitions, the pace at which they are rising and the net cost of attending each college on a new Web site the Department of Education made public on Thursday, fulfilling a legislative mandate.

headline: 2 Ex-Officials Held in Kabul Bank Collapse
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghan officials said Thursday that they had arrested two former Kabul Bank executives, the first such arrests since its collapse 10 months ago.

headline: 2 Journalists Freed by Taliban Return to France
text: PARIS — Two journalists who had been held by the Taliban for more than a year arrived in France on Thursday, visibly relaxed and in good health.

headline: What Fan Memorabilia Would You Pay Big Bucks For?
text: “Derek Jeter’s 3,000th hit will be a cause for celebration, marketing and — not least of all — digging up dirt,” begins a recent article about how dirt from the batter’s box will be dug up, sealed, verified, packaged and sold to fans. Is this ridiculous, or is it the kind of thing you’d love to own yourself? What fan memorabilia would you like to have? What would you consider worth paying a significant amount for? Why?

headline: Christine Lagarde and the Demand for Dollars
text: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: A Chinese Dissident Views New York
text: Around the world, Ai Weiwei, 54, is known as an outspoken critic of the Chinese Communist Party and the most prominent of the hundreds of people who have been detained this year by the government (“Dissident Chinese Artist Is Released,” The New York Times, June 22.) But for a time in the 1980s and early ’90s, Mr. Ai was known as something else — a New Yorker.

headline: Greek Parliament Approves Implementation of Austerity Plan
text: ATHENS — Greek lawmakers voted Thursday to speed the enactment of the country’s new austerity measures, clearing the way for foreign lenders to make available the next installment of aid needed to meet the government’s expenses through the summer.

headline: Red Bulls’ Soler Says He’s Not Done Shopping
text: After trading an aging veteran who spent less than three months with the team for a 24-year-old midfielder in the United States national team player pool, the Red Bulls already know what they want next: defense.

headline: Outside of Prague, a Festival Draws Cinephiles
text: Imagine Cannes during its famous film festival, but instead of designer-clad celebrities swigging Champagne, there are backpackers everywhere: camping out in the parks, picnicking on the streets, scrutinizing the lineup of films and workshops. This is the Karlovy Vary International Film Festival, or KVIFF, and this year marks the 46th event to grace its namesake spa town in west Bohemia, two hours from Prague.

headline: How Vulnerable Are the Yankees?
text: Freddy Garcia, a pitcher the Yankees signed in February not knowing if he’d make the team, and Bartolo Colon, who had been absent from the major leagues since July  2009, have certainly been nice stories for the Yankees so far, but their starts to the season go well beyond the realm of pleasant surprises.

headline: Top 10 Running Backs in N.F.L.
text: Friendly Disclaimer: The following list is influenced largely -– but not strictly -– by film study of all 32 teams from the 2010 season. Stats weren’t acknowledged, but players with poor numbers generally don’t make top 10 lists anyway. Vague enough for you? Criteria for top 10 lists tend to be. That’s why most of you will have no trouble finding some disagreement with what you’re about to read.

text: In Today’s Times

headline: June Was Deadliest Month for U.S. in Iraq Since 2008
text: BAGHDAD — Three more American soldiers were killed this week, the United States military announced on Thursday, bringing the combat-related deaths for United States forces in Iraq to a monthly toll not seen since 2008.

text: Q.

headline: Will Google+ Become a Refuge for the Facebook Weary?
text: This week, Google slowly began rolling out invitations to its new social network, called Google+. The service is similar to Facebook but aimed at allowing people to share and discuss photos, links and status updates with small pockets of friends, rather than someone’s entire social network.

headline: Public Workers Strike in Britain Over Pensions
text: LONDON — Joining a growing wave of unrest in Europe over government austerity measures, tens of thousands of British teachers and public-sector workers walked off their jobs on Thursday to protest proposed changes to their pension plans.

headline: Building a Web Business Brick by Brick
text: Someone strolling the Lower East Side of Manhattan is liable to spot a flier plastered with the face of a pugnacious Boston Terrier. That’s Monkey, the nominal guard dog of Any Old Iron, a year-old men’s clothing store that has quickly become a destination for shoppers, as well as a fixture on the local party scene. But what even most fans of the store don’t realize is that Any Old Iron is, in a sense, a gateway to a Web site.

headline: ‘The Voice’ Finds Itself, and Some Stars, Too
text: “The Voice” never explicitly pitched itself as the anti-“American Idol,” but coming as it did on the heels of the first season of “Idol” without Simon Cowell and in advance of the fall arrival of Mr. Cowell’s “X Factor,” it had a narrow window of time to justify its existence, to demonstrate that it could do things that “Idol” could and would not.

headline: Obama Shows Emotion, With Political Consequences
text: The rap on President Obama is that he’s too professorial, too cool, too prone to dissecting a problem logically and then attempting to explain it to the public.

headline: Rural Thais Find an Unaccustomed Power
text: BAAN NONG TUN, THAILAND — Smiling farmers knee deep in emerald rice paddies and shirtless children riding on the backs of mud-caked water buffalo — these are the romantic images of the Thai countryside. There is one problem with it, says Udom Thapsuri, a farmer here and a local sage. It does not exist anymore.

headline: The Team Player Who Blends Into the Comedy
text: “JUSTIN BATEMAN!” Kirstie Alley exclaimed.

headline: Married, With Infidelities
text: Last month, when the New York congressman Anthony Weiner finally admitted that he had lied, that his Twitter account had not been hacked, that he in fact had sent a picture of his thinly clad undercarriage to a stranger in Seattle, I asked my wife of six years, mother of our three children, what she thought. More specifically, I asked which would upset her more: to learn that I was sending racy self-portraits to random women, Weiner-style, or to discover I was having an actual affair. She paused, scrunched up her mouth as if she had just bitten a particularly sour lemon and said: “An affair is at least a normal human thing. But tweeting a picture of your crotch is just weird.”

headline: Malaysia Plan Meets Standards, U.N. Agency Says
text: The International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna said Thursday that the design and planned operations policies of a giant rare earth refinery being built in Malaysia meet international standards.

headline: Kvitova Beats Azarenka to Reach Women’s Final
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Petra Kvitova of the Czech Republic won a tough three-set victory over Victoria Azarenka of Belarus, 6-1, 3-6, 6-2, to advance to the Wimbledon women’s final.

headline: Morgan Stanley’s Next No. 2, the Guessing Game
text: Wall Street has a new guessing game: whom will James P. Gorman choose to be his No. 2?

headline: Athens on the Hudson
text: Baghdad on the Hudson, O. Henry called New York. This week, Athens on the Hudson was more like it.

headline: Thursday Reading: Compare College Costs on a New Web Site
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Vain Glorious | Going to Great Lengths
text: If you’ve been noticing more and more women sporting longer, impossibly perfect locks, it’s not your imagination. Hair extensions are practically de rigueur. The newest are Platinum Seamless Hair Extensions, which are tiny, sticky strips applied to the hair in under two hours (not the seven or eight that other methods require), and are said to be less damaging to hair and more natural looking. Stylists say these last up to three months, which is just as well. Platinum can cost $2,500 — no small chunk of change. At Ricardo Rojas, one of the few salons offering Platinum, that fee includes color match, installation, cut and styling. I tried them out last week and Rojas, whose clients include Eva Longoria and Bar Rafaeli, told it to me straight: “You don’t need these.” But now that I have them, I know why women become addicted. My hair attracted a bizarre amount of attention, so much that I decided it deserved its own diary.

headline: Path Cleared for News Corp.’s BSkyB Bid
text: British regulators confirmed on Thursday that they were ready to pave the way for News Corporation’s takeover of the pay television company BSkyB.

headline: Tribunal Names 4 in ’05 Killing of Lebanese Leader
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A United Nations-backed tribunal investigating the assassination of a former Lebanese prime minister delivered indictments to prosecutors here on Thursday, naming four men, including two suspected members of Hezbollah, in a six-year-old case that remade the country’s politics and unleashed years of discord.

headline: In Washington, a Museum for China’s Labor Camps
text: Dupont Circle is one of Washington’s premier destinations for foodies and revelers. Now activists have a place at the table as a new museum sheds light on China’s labor camp system.

headline: Walking in and Walking Right Back Out of ‘The Tree of Life’
text: You can use all kinds of numbers as barometers of a film’s life: box office receipts, total theaters, days in release. In the case of “The Tree of Life,” Terrence Malick’s epic vision of modern life in America, take those numbers (some 200 theaters, about $6 million domestically since May) and add walkouts — hundreds, going by Tweets, blog posts and other online reports.

headline: Romney Video Attacks Obama on Stimulus and Economy
text: Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, continues his assault on President Obama‘s economic record on Thursday by visiting a shuttered metalworks plant in Allentown, Pa.

headline: Sharapova Is Back in Final After Beating Lisicki
text: Maria Sharapova advanced to the Wimbledon final with a straight-sets victory over Sabine Lisicki. Lisicki’s formidable serve deserted her on Thursday, as she made only 53 percent of her first serves and had no aces. Sharapova leaped all over Lisicki’s second serve, hitting winners or forcing errors to break Lisicki six times. Although Sharapova also had problems serving, committing 13 double-faults, she held serve all but three times to win comfortably.

headline: Dow Gains 153 Points to End the Quarter Higher
text: Stock prices rose sharply on Thursday as easing concerns over European debt troubles and economic growth in the United States helped the Dow Jones industrial average end the second quarter with a modest gain.

headline: German Banks Agree to Roll Over Greek Debt
text: PARIS — The biggest financial institutions in Germany followed the lead of their French counterparts Thursday by agreeing to roll over some of their holdings of Greek debt — a crucial step toward obtaining international agreement on a second bailout for the crippled Greek economy.

headline: Nurturing Start-Ups and Small Businesses Around the World, Part 2
text: 12:21 p.m. | Updated In an earlier post, I looked at some new data from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development that showed the small-business presence in the United States to be somewhat weaker than in peer countries.

headline: Britain Sends Supplies to Libyan Rebels
text: Britain is providing limited assistance to the Libyan rebels fighting the forces of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, including protective clothing for police officers, Foreign Secretary William Hague said on Thursday, a day after France acknowledged providing light weapons to the rebels.

headline: Senate Will Stay in Session Next Week
text: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, said Thursday that the Senate recess scheduled for the Fourth of July week would be scrapped, as the deadline to raise the nation’s debt limit looms.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Layoffs Begin on Wall Street | Let the cuts begin. In what is expected to be the first wave of layoffs, several banks including Goldman Sachs, HSBC, the Lloyds Banking Group and Credit Suisse have made moves this week to reduce their payrolls.

headline: Patriarchy, Liberty and The 160 Million
text: My column on Mara Hvistendahl’s book noted that in many developing countries, “female empowerment often seems to have led to more sex selection, not less.” Adam Serwer thinks that idea is self-evidently ridiculous:

text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: Lawrence Steps Down as Norton’s Editor In Chief
text: Starling Lawrence, the longtime editor in chief of W.W. Norton & Company, will step down from his post next month to focus on acquiring and editing books as editor-at-large of the company.

headline: Giving Medical Receptionists Their Due
text: Not long ago, the receptionist on the hospital floor where I work went on a family leave. Calm and with a wisecracking wit that she attributes to her New Jersey roots, she had worked at the hospital for years and knew better than anyone how to make things happen in the system.

headline: Remembering Larry Bogdanow, a Restaurant Designer with a Craftsman’s Aesthetic
text: The architect Larry Bogdanow, who designed Union Square Cafe, City Hall, Savoy, Telepan and other restaurants, died yesterday at the age of 64. William Grimes, who during his tenure in the restaurant critic’s chair reviewed a number of places with interiors by Mr. Bogdanow, has the obituary. Accompanying it is a slide show featuring a few of Mr. Bogdanow’s rooms which, as the designer David Rockwell told Mr. Grimes, “anticipated the industrial urban aesthetic that’s prevalent right now.”

headline: The Wageless, Profitable Recovery
text: Economists at Northeastern University have found that the current economic recovery in the United States has been unusually skewed in favor of corporate profits and against increased wages for workers.

headline: New Ways to Visit Cuba — Legally
text: ALWAYS wanted to visit Cuba? Well now you can — legally.

headline: A Safety Valve for Inmates, the Arts, Fades in California
text: NORCO, Calif. — Fifteen men darted across the room, their faces slathered in greasepaint, reciting lines from “Tartuffe.” The stage, such as it was, was a low-ceilinged recreation room, and the cast was a troupe of felons who had just stepped in from the dusty yard of the California Rehabilitation Center.

headline: During a Street Battle in Cairo, an Attempt at Dialogue
text: Updated | 5:24 p.m. During a lull in one of the battles that raged on Cairo’s streets on Wednesday, between protesters and the security forces, video posted on YouTube shows that one well-known Egyptian blogger approached the men with truncheons and shields and tried to explain to them what the protests were about.

headline: No Buyer for Chaplin Film at Auction
text: When it comes to motion pictures, Charlie Chaplin is the man, no? Well, an all-but-forgotten short film featuring footage of the comic star failed to sell at a London auction, defying expectations that it might fetch a six-figure sum, Reuters reported. The reserve price on the film at Wednesday’s sale was £100,000 ($160,000) at Bonhams auctioneers, but apparently that was too high. “Charlie Chaplin in ‘Zepped,’ ” is believed to be a propaganda film made in Britain during World War I. A collector discovered the seven-minute short inside an old film reel tin and bought it in 2009 for £3.20 (about $5) on the online auction site eBay. The film shows Chaplin taking on a German Zeppelin aircraft and features some of the earliest animation in film history. Chaplin probably never knew of the movie’s existence, said the film critic and Chaplin biographer David Robinson, according to Reuters. Mr. Robinson said an anonymous filmmaker had put together outtakes from three earlier Chaplin pictures — “His New Profession” (1914), “A Jitney Elopement” (1915) and “The Tramp” (1915) — and included sequences of stop-motion animation and other effects. Chaplin was not involved in the production of “Zepped,” but famously satirized Adolf Hitler in the 1940 movie “The Great Dictator.”

headline: Ballad of the Long Shot
text: Before you announced your campaign, you said that the liberal establishment is scared that “a real black man might run against Barack Obama.” Are you suggesting Obama isn’t really black?  A real black man is not timid about making the right decisions, that’s what I meant. Look, I’m not getting into this whole thing about President Obama. It is documented that his mother was white and his father was from Africa. If he wants to call himself black, fine. If he wants to call himself African-American, fine. I’m not going down this color road.

headline: Do Gen X Women Choose Work Over Kids?

headline: We Want Your Travel Questions

(A tip: be specific, but not too specific. And ask ahead of time — if you are hoping to travel next week, it’s probably too late.)

headline: Folk Art Museum’s Final Week Before Close
text: Lovers of folk art have just a week left to visit the American Folk Art Museum at its home on West 53rd Street before it closes its doors there for good. Struggling under a heavy load of debt, the museum recently sold the building to the Museum of Modern Art. On Thursday it said its last day in the building would be July 8. The museum will remain in operation in its much smaller branch at 2 Lincoln Square, where it currently has a show of quilts from the collection. MoMA has not yet said what it plans to do with the building, which was designed by the architects Tod Williams and Billie Tsien and opened in 2001. A spokeswoman for the folk art museum, Susan Flamm, said the museum would have 90 days to vacate the building after the sale closes, which she said would happen in mid-July.

The paintings to be returned by the German government include oils by the 17th-century painters Jan Steen and Philips Wouwerman.

headline: Hotels Offer Bikes for Local Cruising
text: Staying in shape on your summer vacation just got a little easier: Fairmont Hotels & Resorts is rolling out a free bike loan program at more than 55 of its properties worldwide. It has teamed with BMW Group to provide up to eight cruise bikes, along with helmets and locks, at participating hotels. Locations in North America already have the cycles (Le Manoir Richelieu in Quebec is shown at right); other properties will have them by mid-July. Concierges can help plan bike itineraries: visitors to the Fairmont Le Montreux Palace on Lake Geneva in Switzerland, for example, can cycle around the lake and surrounding countryside.

headline: Brewing Beer With Dancing Strawberries
text: Sam Calagione, the founder and president of Dogfish Head Craft Brewery, clearly enjoys adventurous brewing. But less exotic crafting has its appeal, too, as Kevin Burg and Jamie Beck’s “cinemagraphs” — photographs with movement on a loop — make clear. “My favorite days at Dogfish are the ones in which we are brewing a beer for the first time,” Mr. Calagione writes from Rehoboth Beach, Del. Instead of only describing the process or using “plain ol’ photos,” he invited the cinemagraphers, who are also his friends, to document a day of making strawberry beer: “Their amazing cinemagraphs have a mystical effect of bringing the viewer into the moment.”

headline: Slowly, Alzheimer’s Erases a Poet’s Gifts and Memories
text: The memory of the New York poet Jack Agüeros is capricious nowadays. He remembers the lyrics of certain Puerto Rican folk songs and the name of his petite, growling dog: Nikki. He does not remember collecting the old radios, locks and cast-iron pieces that once decorated his bright Manhattan apartment on West 14th Street.

headline: “C’mon, Nail Me to the Cross in the Darkest Alley”
text: When I walked into Other Music last weekend, the song “Dark Allies” by a two-person Brooklyn band called Light Asylum was playing. I have hardly stopped listening to it since. A Pitchfork review earlier this year praises singer Shannon Funchess for managing to “route her sinewy vocal through the cold-blooded seething of Ian Curtis, the deadpan drawl of Grace Jones and the full-tilt intensity of Henry Rollins circa ‘Damaged.'” I would add Peter Murphy. If you walk through the streets of New York with this on your iPod, every passing pedestrian looks like a lunatic just barely keeping it together — more than usual, I mean. On the band’s MySpace page, the genre is described as “Gospel/Gothic/Melodramatic Popular Song.” My new favorite genre.

headline: ‘Magdalene’ Producers Respond to Accusations of Anti-Semitism
text: The producers of the new Off Broadway musical “The Magdalene” met with representatives of the New York office of the Anti-Defamation League on Wednesday after receiving an e-mail the day before saying that the production contains anti-Semitic elements. The show, inspired by the Gnostic Gospels, offers an alternate version of the traditional story of Mary Magdalene. In the musical the title character, played by Lindsie Van Winkle, is not a prostitute and has a romantic relationship with Jesus, or Yeshua (Shad Olsen), causing infighting among his circle of disciples and further invoking the ire of the Roman government. The story ends as it usually does, with the Jesus character crucified.

headline: 36 Hours in Cape May, N.J.
text: AT the southernmost tip of New Jersey, where the Garden State Parkway’s exit numbers wind down to zero, Cape May, one of the oldest seaside resorts in the nation, has welcomed vacationers for more than 200 years. The images of the Jersey Shore conjured up in the reality TV show bear little resemblance to this family-oriented destination, with its charming Victorian homes and historic lighthouse. While Cape May’s vacation identity is still very much tied to house tours, horse-drawn carriages and dinner theaters, in recent years it has embraced a more stylish persona. Several of its once-faded grande dame hotels and low-slung motels have been updated and transformed into chic escapes, catering to well-to-do families from Philadelphia, northern New Jersey, New York City and beyond. But traditionalists need not fear — Cape May retains its laid-back charm with mini-golf courses, 25-cent Skee-Ball games and families pedaling around on surreys and bicycles built for two.

headline: London Underground | Canal Plus
text: A rather peculiar building has appeared next to a canal in Hackney Wick, London. Just outside the future Olympics site, and shoehorned beneath the underpass of the A12 highway, “Folly for a Flyover” is the work of Assemble, a young collective of designers, artists and architects. The red brick structure — with a roof that peaks out between the eastbound and westbound lanes of highway above — was constructed by volunteers from reclaimed and donated materials. On the weekends the Folly houses a cafe, workshops and performances. Adventurous visitors can rent handmade rowboats from a small dock on the canal. In the evenings, from Friday to Sunday, there is a bar and an adjacent auditorium space underneath the highway, which hosts a series of screenings curated by the Barbican Art Gallery as part of its current exhibition “Watch Me Move: The Animation Show.”

headline: In the Picture: Atlanta, Africa and the Past
text: In 1972, when Radcliffe Bailey was 4 years old, his parents were looking for a change of scene from New Jersey, where most of his extended family had settled. They were considering California, Ontario and Florida, where they were headed on a road trip, when they stopped by chance at a restaurant in Atlanta and met the Rev. Lucius M. Tobin. Mr. Tobin, a onetime teacher of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., at Morehouse College, gave the family members a tour that captivated them with its rich account of the city’s history. Soon after, the minister’s wife was returning with Mrs. Bailey to New Jersey to help her pack up the family home.
