headline: Menacing Working Girls Stuck in Punishing Grind
text: BECKET, Mass. — Almost immediately after Sharon Eyal’s “Love” (2003) began on Wednesday night at the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival here, during the American debut of Carte Blanche, the Norwegian national company of contemporary dance, two audience members hustled out of the theater. Had they reached a verdict that quickly? It’s possible. After all, they had just seen pretty much the same dance before intermission.

headline: City Life Isn’t Always Uplifting
text: By the time the performers of Overground Physical Theater Company gathered onstage for their final bow, it had dawned on me that summer — hands down, the bleakest time for dance in New York — is officially here. In “Urban Tao Evolution,” a convoluted and rambling new work performed at Dance Theater Workshop on Wednesday night, the message had something to do with choosing spirituality over technology. What it really looked like was a New Age musical produced in a high school and performed, to a large extent, by the teachers.

headline: Golf Phenom, Not Tiger Woods. Sure.
text: “The Swinger” is a novel about a very famous golfer who has an amazing career record, a slew of endorsement deals, a gorgeous wife and a squeaky-clean reputation — until his extracurricular kinks become a huge public embarrassment and spoil everything. The authors, Michael Bamberger (“This Golfing Life”) and Alan Shipnuck (“Bud, Sweat and Tees”), call this golfer Herbert X. Tremont, known as Tree, and his wife, Belinda. But they don’t insult the reader’s intelligence by claiming that these characters bear no resemblance to persons living or dead.

headline: Live: Glenn Beck Says Goodbye to Fox News
text: Glenn Beck is like no one else on television.

headline: Theater Listings: July 1 — 7
text: Theater

headline: And, I’m Back
text: Blame Canada — or at least Air Canada. My simple trip home from Toronto turned into an 8-hour ordeal. And today I not only had to get tomorrow’s column done, I had to discuss a (very good) paper on the financing of frozen chicken exports. Honest.

headline: Images of Fossil Birds Show Ancient Pigments
text: Some fossils are not just rock.

headline: Notes From the Underground | Kalup Linzy
text: It was a voyeuristic thrill watching the performance artist and Internet video sensation Kalup Linzy prance around the Boom Boom Room at the Standard Hotel, singing his heart out about his typically provocative subject matter. Clad in a green bathrobe (that had been cut into a dangerously short minidress) and a blond wig, Linzy sauntered barefoot before a relatively stodgy crowd of art-world types, who seemed to clutch their Champagne flutes in confusion. Hosted by Creative Time, the party celebrated the second installment of StandART, the hotel’s video art channel, which this time around includes works by Linzy, Terence Koh, Slater Bradley and Allison Schulnik, among others.

headline: Once Again, Floor Plans Are Making the Sale
text: WHEN the real estate market was booming, buyers routinely signed contracts for apartments in yet-to-be-built buildings, making their decisions based on little more than an artist’s rendering and a miniature model of their new home.

headline: Stymied in Middle Age, Reaching for a New Life
text: “Larry Crowne” is a rom-com fairy tale so tepid and well behaved that watching it feels like being stuck in traffic as giddy joy-riders in the opposite lane break the speed limit. You have little choice but to cool your heels and pretend that the parched crabgrass in the median is a field of flowers.

headline: JESSICA ROHRER: ‘Oakridge Road’
text: P.P.O.W.

headline: The Benefits of a Biweekly Mortgage Plan
text: WITH interest rates low, biweekly mortgage payment plans are looking less attractive than ever.

headline: Verlander Cools the Hot-Hitting Mets
text: DETROIT — For four record-setting games, it seemed as if no team, no park and no pitcher could stop the Mets’ unyielding run-producing machine. They scored 52 runs in that span, the most in franchise history, and were averaging 17.25 hits a game.

headline: Twins, but They Don’t Dress Alike
text: THE unique development of one West Side block produced an unusual pair of near-twin buildings. But no matter how far out the windows they stretch, the residents of the Evanston, at 90th and West End, will never be able to see the facade of its mate, the Admaston, at 89th and Broadway.

headline: DREW HEITZLER
text: Renwick Gallery

headline: ‘PAUL CLAY’
text: Salon 94 Bowery

headline: Wrong To Be Right
text: Atrios is annoyed at David Wessel, and rightly so. I’d summarize Wessel’s column a bit differently: it’s roughly “Some people thought from the beginning that the stimulus should have been much bigger. Hahaha! Also, it turns out that the stimulus was too small, so we need some more.”

headline: JOHN O’REILLY: ‘Recent Montage’
text: Tibor de Nagy Gallery

headline: LORNA SIMPSON: ‘Gathered’
text: Brooklyn Museum

headline: Tom Lebling
text: Mr. Lebling, 47, is a senior vice president of Equity Residential, overseeing the real estate investment trust’s Northeast market. He previously ran its residential operations in South Florida.

headline: Q & A
text: Adding Riders to Stabilized Leases

headline: Showing Two Painters, Three Centuries Apart
text: LONDON — Nicolas Poussin and Cy Twombly may seem to have little in common, but an exhibition that opened on Wednesday at the Dulwich Picture Gallery in London shows that these painters are not such strange bedfellows.

headline: Cinderella Goes to Europe, and Cute Meets Culture
text: The gal-pal comedy “Monte Carlo” comes with a bewildering PG rating for “brief mild language” (so brief I missed the offending words), when it really should have earned a Gee. Cheery, corny and perhaps calculatingly unoriginal, this is packaged entertainment so familiar it feels like a remake and so wholesome you could swear Sandra Dee starred in the 1959 original. Think of it as “No Sex and the City” for tweeners.

headline: The Sounds of Silence
text: MANHATTAN can be too much with us. It can seem like a 23-square-mile rugby pitch, where on any given day nearly three million people are shoving elbows, blowing cigarette smoke, jabbering on cellphones or to themselves, all ready to rumble over the slightest slight. Not long ago a well-educated woman slapped another well-educated woman in a confrontation over a package of vegan pad Thai in the frozen-food section of Trader Joe’s. To which inhabitants of Manhattan might say: “Yeah? So what?”

headline: A Restorative Racket
text: LIKE most commuters, I spend my days in the city but sleep out in the stillness of the suburbs, where at night it’s as quiet as the grave. The only thing you hear is the occasional scrabbling of raccoons trying to knock over the trash cans. But a couple of years ago I happened to spend the night at an Upper East Side hotel, where I was pleasantly startled by two phenomena: the abundant free pornography on cable TV and, around dawn, a whining, grinding, masticating sound that I eventually recognized as a garbage truck partaking of its morning feed. This was followed by some bus rumbling and horn honking and, a few blocks away, an insistent car alarm. The city was already awake and thrumming, going about its business with none of the suburban fussiness that makes it unmannerly, for example, to crank up your lawn mower or your leaf blower before breakfast.

headline: Spare Times: For Children for July 1-7
text: PIRATES OF THE HUDSON

headline: Next Stop, Sacramento
text: Inside Sacramento’s failing levee system.

headline: Dance Listings for July 1-7
text: Dance

headline: In Greenwood Heights, a Place to Stay Put
text: AFTER he graduated from Binghamton University in 2006, Jason Fallon faced a decision. He could rent an apartment in New York City and begin his professional life or he could visit his girlfriend, Rebecca Bear Dallis, who was spending her junior year abroad at the University of Sydney.

headline: Hiroshima and Nagasaki in Black and White
text: The mushroom cloud is one of those images that’s hard to process without resorting to abstractions. In our minds this symbol of nuclear Armageddon has somehow become detached from the weapon’s deadly efficacy.

headline: A Welcome to His World Is Accepted at Your Peril
text: Warwick Wilson, the prim, dapper title character of “The Perfect Host,” played by David Hyde Pierce, seems at first to be a clone of Waldo Lydecker, the snobbish newspaper columnist of Otto Preminger’s film-noir classic “Laura.” As Warwick jousts with John Taylor (Clayne Crawford), a scruffy bank robber on the lam who talks his way into Warwick’s immaculate Los Angeles lair, you expect an insidious tug of war between an aesthete and a roughneck, similar to the power struggle of Clifton Webb’s imperious dandy and Dana Andrews’s earthy detective in “Laura.”

headline: By the Bay, a Berth to Rest and to Mingle
text: Everyone savors those “only in New York” moments: watching the Nathan’s hot-dog-eating contest in Coney Island or spotting a movie star in a restaurant in Manhattan. But another, equal pleasure is often overlooked: the “I can’t believe I’m still in New York” moment.

headline: Lawyers Expected to Seek to Ease Bail Conditions on Strauss-Kahn
text: Prosecutors and defense lawyers in the sexual assault case against Dominique Strauss-Kahn will return to court on Friday, where his lawyers were expected to ask a judge to ease the restrictive bail conditions that were imposed, according to a person briefed on the matter.

headline: Violence Close at Hand Shakes a Bucolic Setting
text: Ed Gass-Donnelly’s rural crime drama, “Small Town Murder Songs,” punctures the veneer of bucolic quiet in a mostly Mennonite farming community in Ontario. Beneath a deceptive calm, it uncovers a core of fear and loathing as ominous as the backwoods world of “Winter’s Bone.”

headline: Horse Farm Prices Take a Tumble
text: A horse farm in Westchester for under $1 million? Unheard of five years ago, brokers say, but not so now.

headline: Playing Make-Believe With Greece
text: If only C. David Ritter had been a central banker, rather than a commercial banker, he could be retiring with praise, rather than facing possible legal liability for following the time-dishonored practice of “extend and pretend,” in which bad loans are treated as if they were just fine.

headline: Sounds of the City — Do You Prefer Cacophony or Quiet?
text: Forty thousand fireworks. Now that’s bound to make some noise. There are New Yorkers who will love every decibel on the Fourth of July, when Macy’s puts on its “biggest fireworks display in America.” Other New Yorkers — well, they’d much rather see the rockets’ red glare than hear the bursting in air. Certainly all city dwellers are used to noise, but there are those who hear a symphony in the cacophony and those who seek out New York’s many pockets of peace and quiet. Here, two views. Which do you prefer, the cacophony of New York or the quiet?

headline: Clip: The First Mark
text:
Behind the scene sat Peter Nadin's farm, located in the Catskill Mountains of New York State.

Film by Natsuko Uchino and Aimée Toledano. Written by Peter Nadin.

headline: Federal Officials Can’t Raise Unlimited Funds, F.E.C. Says
text: The comedian Stephen Colbert’s successful campaign to form a super PAC got plenty of attention on Thursday, but the Federal Election Commission‘s granting of Mr. Colbert’s request might not have been its most significant action of the day.

headline: Another Teenage Misfit Trying to Like Himself
text: In outline the story told in “Terri” could not be more familiar: A misfit high school student, isolated and misunderstood, finds companionship with other oddballs, as well as a measure of self-acceptance. The same description could apply to “Submarine” and “The Art of Getting By,” restricting ourselves only to films currently playing in theaters. All three movies are sincere and thoughtful — necessary but not sufficient conditions for our interest and admiration.

headline: Geithner Staying (for Now)
text: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner said Thursday that he planned to stay in his job “for the foreseeable future.”

headline: An Artist Who Makes Much Out of Very Little
text: The less-is-more tradition in American art is rich and varied. It stretches from the glorious frugalities of Shaker furniture and Amish quilts to the sleek orthodox Minimalism of Donald Judd’s box sculptures and Agnes Martin’s horizontal-stripe paintings. And it also accommodates the modest, plain-spoken sculptures and wall pieces of the artist B. Wurtz.

headline: Romney Says Closed Steel Plant Symbolizes Obama’s Failures
text: ALLENTOWN, Penn. — Standing before the locked gate of a steel plant that President Obama had once visited to promote his economic stimulus plan, Mitt Romney pointed out weeds and boarded-up windows on Friday and called the president’s handling of the economy a failure.

headline: Finding His Inner Child, Cowboy and Housewife
text: A cowboy, a housewife, a retired widower, 1940s movie stars and kids of all ages: these are among the host of characters who people “Cast of Thousands: Gillett Sings Carnelia,” a one-man musical at the Laurie Beechman Theater. Its variety of humanity brings to mind the world of Lily Tomlin.

headline: Tripoli Refugees Stream Into Libya’s Mountains
text: RUJBAN, Libya — The people fleeing Tripoli on Thursday said that several neighborhoods filled with the sound of gunfire every night. At checkpoints throughout the capital, they said, paramilitaries from the dreaded People’s Guard carried long lists of wanted men. The gas lines were five days long.

headline: Emotions Expressed With a Glance
text: NOT all Russian ballerinas are created equal, but Polina Semionova is in a class by herself. There’s something disarmingly different about Ms. Semionova, a willowy, warm dancer who grew up in Moscow, lives in Berlin and, in May, made her long-awaited debut with American Ballet Theater in “Don Quixote.”

headline: Separated at Birth?
text: These two search-and-rescue vehicles were conceived continents apart.  Or were they?

headline: A Rogue Film Festival Earns Respect (Sort Of)
text: The New York Asian Film Festival has an image to uphold, based on a well-honed story of low-rent beginnings and disreputable programming. This familiar narrative starts in 2002 with five young guys and their credit cards, and embraces rowdy, fiercely obsessive audiences jammed into downtown theaters watching movies about young Japanese women whose breasts double as machine guns.

headline: A defiant President pushes back on GOP. Is this “the new” Barack Obama or a political strategy?
text: An apparently frustrated President Obama pushes back on GOP at a press conference this week. Is this “the new” President Obama or strategy as he enters a new political season? Chief correspondent for The Caucus at NYTimes.com Michael Shear, Washington correspondent Mark Landler and Deputy news editor for blog development Megan Liberman join Sam Roberts in New York.

headline: Poor Reception for the Big Game
text: My husband is a sports fanatic. We will be attending a close friend’s wedding in Europe on the evening of (in his view) the “game of the century.” Worse, his favorite team is playing. The reception will be held in a mansion that certainly has a TV in it. How rude would it be for my husband to ask the bridegroom if he could slip in and out of the festivities to watch the game on one of the house’s televisions?Sherri, Washington

headline: The Red Bulls’ McCarty Is Hoping to Make a Name for Himself
text: LITTLE FALLS, N.J. — Like many people, the Red Bulls’ newest player does not hear his given name unless he’s in trouble: “My dad only calls me Michael when he’s really angry with me.”

headline: Caucus Click: Fiscal Scramble
text: Senator Kent Conrad spoke to reporters as he prepared to release the Democrats’ budget proposal.

headline: Jon Caramanica on Beyoncé’s fourth solo album; Eleanor Friedberger on her album, “Last Summer”; and new releases.
text: This week: Jon Caramanica on Beyoncé’s fourth solo album, the fittingly titled “4”; a conversation with Eleanor Friedberger about her first solo album, “Last Summer”; and a look at new releases from Dolly Parton, Gillian Welch and Big Sean. Jeremy Egner is the host.

headline: A Warning on Dodd-Frank From F.D.I.C. Chief in Her Final Senate Hearing
text: Federal lawmakers could harm the financial system by failing to give regulators the money and power to put the Dodd-Frank Act into effect, Sheila C. Bair, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, told lawmakers at a hearing on Thursday in Washington.

headline: Seeking a Path to Justice
text: When the lawyers Nadia Costa and Joshua Safran first encountered Deborah Peagler, she had already served 20 years of a 25-years-to-life sentence for involvement in the 1982 murder of her pathologically abusive boyfriend. Taking advantage of a California law that allows reconsideration of cases involving battered women, the lawyers embarked on a pro bono journey to free her that would last eight years and unearth a reeking trail of perjury,  prosecutorial misconduct and political malfeasance.

headline: Climate Roundup
text: Here are a few notable reports snagged from the nonstop flow on climate science and the policy debate over greenhouse gases:

headline: Medicare Will Pay for Prostate Cancer Drug
text: Medicare confirmed on Thursday that it would pay for Provenge, the prostate cancer drug whose $93,000 price had set off debate about the cost of cancer treatments.

headline: House Tour: Warwick, N.Y.
text: A summer kitchen became a guest house, and a barn is now an art studio.

headline: House Tour: Warwick, N.Y.
text: WHAT Four-bedroom house and a one-bedroom guest house on four acres.

headline: Wire, Buttons and Scraps of Humor
text: Photos of a new exhibition of works by the artist B. Wurtz.

headline: ‘Memory as Medicine’
text: A new exhibition of works by Radcliffe Bailey is on view in Atlanta.

headline: Let’s Build a Stage
text: Photos of preparations for the Royal Shakespeare Company at the Park Avenue Armory.

headline: In Play
text: Photos of the National Pinball Museum in Washington.

headline: Thursday at the Women’s World Cup
text: France and Germany filled the first two slots in the quarterfinals. France routed Canada, 4-0, becoming the first team to score more than two goals in a game so far. Germany eliminated a hard-working Nigeria team, which was unlucky to lose both its games by 1-0 against strong opposition.

headline: Cuomo Clarifies Fracking and Nuclear Plans
text: New York State Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s energy plans for the state are crystallizing. Through administrative moves, he has indicated that he sees the need to responsibly exploit the state’s enormous gas resource while moving toward ending nuclear power generation near New York City and its suburbs.

headline: Weekend Miser
text: Weekend Miser, who we hope returns from Los Angeles relaxed but not Botoxed, will be back on duty next week. In the meantime, we’ve scoured the Internet and rifled through her in-box to drum up a few less traditional ways to celebrate our country this holiday weekend.

headline: Rajaratnam’s Sentencing Is Delayed
text: Raj Rajaratnam will enjoy another two months of freedom.

headline: Obama Is Fund-Raising in Philadelphia
text: PHILADELPHIA — President Obama, speaking at a fund-raiser here on Thursday, did not roll out the aggressively partisan rhetoric he used at a news conference Wednesday to describe Republicans’ approach to budget negotiations.

headline: The Draft Ends in Germany, but Questions of Identity Endure
text: BERLIN — Germany formally discontinued the draft at midnight on Thursday to make way for a smaller, tighter army that will draw people like Johannes Beckert and Steven Stadler, both volunteers signing up for duty at a sprawling, suburban recruitment center that once housed the East German military’s overseas espionage agency.

headline: China Admits Officials Cannot Levitate
text: Despite what appeared to be clear photographic evidence published earlier this month on a Chinese government Web site, China has admitted that, in fact, its officials cannot levitate.

headline: Nicklaus, a Doubles Player, Cheers On the Bryans
text: WIMBLEDON, England — Jack Nicklaus had a seat in the royal box at Centre Court on Thursday, but it was empty during the first women’s semifinal between Victoria Azarenka and Petra Kvitova.

headline: Italy Approves an Austerity Package
text: ROME — The Italian government on Thursday approved a $68 billion austerity package that is intended to reduce the country’s budget deficit and reassure financial markets and Italy’s European Union partners about its commitment to putting its finances in order.

headline: Febreze Commercial
text: In a commercial for Febreze, people were asked to take part in a scent experiment.

headline: Amazon.com Fights California Tax Collectors
text: Californians will have to start paying sales tax on their purchases from Amazon.com starting Friday after Gov. Jerry Brown signed legislation earlier this week requiring online retailers to collect the tax.

headline: Diving Into Reeking Squalor to Test an Air Freshener
text: FOR all the freshening claims made by room deodorizer brands in commercials, the approach of the advertisements themselves can be pretty musty, following a predictable script.

headline: Plan Issued to Save Northern Spotted Owl
text: SEATTLE — It has been two decades since the fate of a bashful bird that most people had never seen came to symbolize the bitter divide over whether to save or saw down the ancient forests of the Pacific Northwest. Yet it was not until Thursday that the federal government offered its final plan to prevent the bird, the northern spotted owl, from going extinct.

headline: Heading Into a Long (Driving) Weekend
text: To the Editor:

headline: Medicare Will Continue to Cover 2 Expensive Cancer Drugs
text: Medicare confirmed on Thursday that it would continue to pay for two expensive cancer drugs that had been at the center of debate — Avastin from Genentech for breast cancer and Provenge from Dendreon for prostate cancer.

headline: Seeking to Avoid Uprising, Kuwait Escalates Budget
text: CAIRO — While many Arab nations have relied on force to try to crush popular aspirations for change, Kuwait, like other oil-rich kingdoms of the Persian Gulf, has instead tried to spend its way to stability.
